title: A prospective, controlled trial of a pharmacy-driven alert system to increase rates of thromboprophylaxis in hospitalized medical patients.
abstract: Although venous thromboembolism is a major cause of in-hospital morbidity and mortality, a significant proportion of hospitalized patients at risk do not receive measures known to reduce the risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. The aim of the present study was to determine whether a pharmacy-driven alert system, compared with usual care, would be associated with a higher rate of adequate venous thromboembolism prevention measures among at-risk hospitalized patients in an internal medicine service. general. The study was a prospective controlled trial conducted at a university teaching hospital. Participants were adults admitted (Monday to Friday) to the general internal medicine inpatient ward from June 19 to September 21, 2006. Their treatment included a pharmaceutical assessment of venous thromboembolism risk and a pharmacist-directed alert to the treating physician. The proportion of patients at risk who received adequate thromboprophylaxis within 36 hours of admission was recorded. Overall, 140 patients were at sufficient risk of venous thromboembolism to be included. In the usual care group, prophylactic measures were ordered for 49 (61%) of the 80 patients at moderate to high risk. In the pharmacist alert group, 44 (73%) of 60 patients at moderate to high risk of venous thromboembolism received adequate thromboprophylaxis (p = 0.15). Although we did not observe a statistically significant difference between groups, our results are consistent with previous reports suggesting that alert systems may increase the proportion of hospitalized patients who receive adequate measures to prevent venous thromboembolism.

title: Effect of a clinical pharmacy service on lipid control in patients with peripheral arterial disease.
abstract: Objective Our group and others have previously established that patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) are significantly undertreated with respect to overall management of cardiovascular risk factors, despite national guidelines to the contrary. In an effort to maximize risk factor control in our PAD patients, we established a physician-controlled, pharmacist-managed algorithmic approach to outpatient lipid management in PAD patients. The purpose of this study was to determine the effect of this service on the detection and control of lipids in patients with PAD. Methods We analyzed the records of patients treated in a large, regional, nonprofit managed care system, group model, serving approximately 405,000 members. An electronic medical record provided complete examination, laboratory, and pharmacy data for all patients. Pharmacy data were analyzed to determine prescriptions for lipid-lowering agents. Lipid control was assessed through fasting lipid data. Patients with validated PAD and no clinical coronary artery disease (CAD) were offered the service between May 2003 and September 2004 and followed up for a minimum of 6 months. Results A total of 5159 active patients diagnosed with PAD were administratively identified. Of these, 1075 could be validated with a non-invasive arterial study. Exclusion of 384 patients diagnosed with CAD resulted in a cohort of 691 patients. Of these, 90 patients were enrolled in the lipid service (study group) and 601 received standard care. The mean follow-up was 17.1 months. Fasting lipid profiles were found in 95.6% (86/90) of study group patients and only 66.9% (402/601) of standard care patients (p < 0.0001 ). Low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) control was improved in the pharmacist-administered group, with 79.1% (68/86) achieving LDL-C less than 100 mg/dL compared with the standard care group (54.8% [219/400]";" p < 0.0001). An LDL-C value of more than 130 mg/dl was observed in 1.2% and 14.0% (56/400) in the treatment and control groups, respectively (p < 0.001). Statin use was present in 51.9% (312/601) of patients in the control group and in 84.4% (76/90) in the pharmacist-administered group (p < 0.001). Conclusions Despite the national consensus of PAD as equivalent to CEA, patients currently do not receive adequate treatment with respect to atherosclerotic risk factor modification. Initiation of a physician-monitored, pharmacist-managed lipid service provides better adherence to national guidelines

title: Using peer feedback to improve handwashing and glove use among Thai health workers.
abstract: Background: Without protective practices such as Universal Precautions, healthcare workers are at considerable risk of blood-borne infections, especially in areas such as Thailand with a high prevalence of HIV infection. The purpose of this study was to assess the effectiveness of a peer feedback program (PFP) on handwashing and glove use (HW/GW) among Thai health care workers. Methods: Subjects (N = 91) were randomized to receive PFP versus no treatment. Using a checklist, peer observers rated their co-workers' HW/GW compliance during patient care. For 1 month, the investigator published a report of compliance behaviors for every 3 days of observations. The investigator also assessed HW/GW by direct observation 1 month before the intervention, during the intervention period, and 1 month after the intervention. Results: The initial HW/GW rates for the PFP and control groups were 49.2% and 61.5%, respectively. The PFP group had a significantly higher adjusted compliance rate than the control group during the intervention period (p = 0.0001). However, there was no significant difference in compliance scores obtained 1 month after the intervention. Conclusions: The PFP was effective during the intervention period, but there was no retention of the effect. Therefore, complementary methods should be sought to promote effect retention. (AJIC Am J Infect Control 2000";"28:365-9)

title: "Caring" for doctors and their families
abstract: Being selected to provide medical care to other physicians or their families represents not only rewarding professional recognition of competence by peers, but also a challenge. Many personal and psychological factors can influence the medical care of doctors. Ill physicians may struggle with role reversal and "VIP syndrome," while treating physicians may have to deal with their own anxiety and issues such as confidentiality, privacy, empathy, and medical relative intrusion into caring for medical family members. . Based on experience with more than 200 physician-patients and many adult family members of physicians, suggestions are offered for the care of these patient groups.

title: "Ethics and clinical research" revisited. A tribute to Henry K. Beecher
abstract: The informed consent doctrine, borrowed from tort law, cannot be easily transplanted into therapeutic settings. The broader, yet unrealized idea of informed consent, which suggests that parties should make decisions jointly, should guide interactions between physicians and patients or investigators and subjects.

title: “First, do no harm”: legal guidelines for health programs that affect adolescents aged 10 to 17 who sell sex or inject drugs
abstract: INTRODUCTION: There is a strong evidence base that stigma, discrimination and criminalization affecting key populations (KP) of adolescents aged 10 to 17 years is intensified due to national and international legal constructions that are based on evidence-based interventions. law enforcement dependent on arrest, detention trial, incarceration, and mandatory "rehabilitation" in institutional placement. While there are evidence-based and rights-based technical guidelines for interventions among older cohorts, these guidelines have not yet been adopted by international public health actors for fear that international law will apply different standards to adolescents aged 10-17. years who engage in behavior such as the sale of sex. or inject drugs. DISCUSSION: As a matter of international human rights, health, juvenile justice, and child protection law, interventions among PC adolescents ages 10-17 should not involve arrest, prosecution, or detention of any kind. It is imperative that interventions are not based on law enforcement, but rather on low-threshold voluntary services, shelter and support, using peer-based outreach as much as possible. These services should be mobile and accessible, and allow alternatives to parental consent for the provision of life support, including HIV testing, treatment and care, needle and syringe programmes, opioid substitution therapy, safe abortions, antiretroviral therapy and gender-affirming care. and hormone treatment for transgender adolescents. To ensure enrollment in services, international guidance indicates that informed consent and confidentiality must be guaranteed, including the waiver of parental consent requirements. To remove the disincentive for health professionals and researchers to engage with adolescent PCs ages 10 to 17, government agencies and ethical review boards are encouraged to waive or waive mandatory reporting. In the event that, in violation of international law and guidance, authorities attempt to involuntarily place KP adolescents in institutions, they are entitled to judicial process. The legal guidelines also state that these adolescents have influence over their location, access to legal advice to challenge the conditions of their detention, and regular visits from peers, friends and family, and that all facilities are subject to frequent and regular reviews by independent bodies, including PC-led community groups. CONCLUSIONS: International control law specifies that protection interventions among 10- to 17-year-old KPs must not only include low-threshold voluntary services, but also "protect" adolescent KPs from the harms that come with evidence-based interventions. application of the law. Going forward, health professionals must respect the right to health by adjusting programs according to the principles of minimal intervention, due process, and proportionality, and duly limit the involvement of juvenile justice and child protection as a measure of last resort. appeal, if applicable.

title: "How much do they pay you if I volunteer?" Suggested Institutional Policy on Reward, Consent, and Research
abstract: Pharmaceutical companies often ask practicing physicians to conduct phase IV or post-market research on new drugs. Companies pay doctors to enroll their patients and report dosage and side effects. Post-marketing research encompasses a multimillion-dollar promotion and awareness effort, but informed consent from subjects typically does not include physician reward. Improving the financial status of investigators while increasing medical risks to phase IV subjects is ethically unsound, especially if the subjects are unaware of the investigators' rewards. We suggest a model policy and guidelines that affirm the need for informed consent from subjects, the need for recognition and support from investigators, and the need for institutions to protect patients from undisclosed risks and relationships.

title: "If it is not broke, do not fix it
"Let Me Get You a Nicotine Patch": Nurses' Perceptions of Implementing Smoking Cessation Guidelines for Hospitalized Veterans
abstract: Many hospitalized smokers do not receive guideline-recommended anti-smoking treatment, but little is known about inpatient nurses' perceptions of anti-smoking treatment. We used a sequential explanatory mixed methods design to help explain the findings of a detailed intervention academic trial in the inpatient medicine units of four Veterans Affairs (VA) hospitals. We surveyed 164 nurses and conducted semi-structured interviews on a purposive sample of 33 nurses with different attitudes towards smoking cessation advice. Content analysis was used to inductively characterize the issues raised by the participants. Emerging themes were categorized using the guideline adherence knowledge-attitudes-behavior framework. Barriers related to knowledge and attitudes included perceived lack of skills in smoking cessation counseling and skepticism about the effectiveness of smoking cessation guidelines in hospitalized veterans. Nurses also reported multiple behavioral and organizational barriers to guideline adherence: patient resistance, insufficient time and resources, the presence of smoking areas in VA facilities, and lack of coordination with primary care. VA hospitals should train inpatient staff on how to negotiate behavior change, integrate smoking cessation counseling into nurses' workflow, develop alternative referral mechanisms for post-discharge cessation counseling and adopt hospital policies to promote abstinence for hospitalized patients.

title: "Rules" of evidence in evaluating the efficacy and effectiveness of treatments
abstract: A brief review of the 'rules' of evidence for evaluating the efficacy and effectiveness of treatments leads to a discussion of what the future might hold in developing randomized clinical trial (RCT) rules to improve impact. of these studies. . The main requirement for improving the impact of studies seems to be discussion and interaction between researchers, clinicians, policymakers, and patient advocates on the one hand, and between basic scientists and clinical researchers on the other.

title: (S)Partners for Heart Health: A school-based program to improve physical activity and nutrition to promote cardiovascular health in fifth graders
abstract: BACKGROUND: The American Heart Association position statement on promoting cardiovascular health in public schools encourages school-based interventions for the primary prevention of cardiovascular disease (CVD) through the prevention or reduction of risk factors in children, with an emphasis on creating an environment that promotes healthy food choices. and physical activity (PA). In an effort to address issues related to CVD risk factors, including obesity, in Michigan children, a multidisciplinary team of Michigan State University (MSU) faculty, physicians, and health professions students was assembled. to "(S)associate" with elementary school physicists. physical education (PE) teachers and MSU Extension staff to develop and implement a cost-effective and sustainable program aimed at preventing and managing CVD risk factors for fifth grade students. This (S)partnership seeks to augment and improve the existing fifth grade physical education, health, and nutrition curriculum by achieving the following goals: 1) improve students' knowledge, attitudes, and confidence about nutrition, physical activity and heart health"; 2) increase the number of students meeting national recommendations for PA and nutrition;" and 3) increase the number of students with desirable CVD risk factor status based on national pediatric guidelines. Secondary goals include promoting school staff and parent support for heart health to help children achieve their goals and providing experiential and service learning for MSU health professions students for academic credit . METHODS/DESIGN: This pilot effectiveness study was approved by the MSU IRB. At the beginning and end of the school year, students undergo a CVD risk factor assessment conducted by MSU medical students and graduate students. Key components of the intervention include eight lesson plans (conducted every other month) designed to promote heart-healthy nutrition and physical activity behaviors conducted by physical education teachers with the assistance of MSU dietetics and kinesiology students (Spartners ). The last 10 minutes of each lesson, MSU Spartners conduct small group discussions/breakdowns with 5th grade students. In addition, each Spartner case manages/counsels two to three fifth grade students using a web-based goal-setting and tracking protocol throughout the school year. DISCUSSION: This document describes the rationale, development, and methods of the Spartners for Heart Health program. This is a multi-tiered intervention designed to promote heart-healthy behaviors and prevent or control CVD risk factors in children. We believe that this will be a viable sustainable intervention that can be disseminated and adopted by other institutions with minimal cost by involving university students as an integral part of the measurement and intervention teams.

title: â€œValue for moneyâ€ : use with care
abstract: In this issue, Owens and colleagues (1) argue that the goal of policy should be "to preserve the delivery of interventions that provide good value." They also acknowledge that assessing costs without considering value is problematic because it could lead to â€œunintended reductions in effective and efficient careâ€ . Cutler and colleagues (2) have argued that an intervention that produces more benefits than costs is socially beneficial regardless of whether it increases spending. The American College of Physicians' Clinical Guidelines Committee makes an important contribution to this policy debate by offering definitions and concepts to guide the pursuit of high-value health care, but the goal of "value for money" raises many questions that warrant careful consideration. further discussion. .

title: 100 apples divided by 15 red herrings: a mid-nineteenth-century warning about comparing hospital mortality rates
abstract: In 1863, Florence Nightingale argued that London hospitals were dangerous, especially compared to provincial facilities. She buttressed this claim with statistics published in the William Fair Registrar General's report, which stated that 24 London hospitals had mortality rates above 90%, while rural hospitals had an average mortality rate of 13%. Farr had calculated mortality rates by dividing the total number of patients who died throughout the year by the number of patients hospitalized in a single day. When calculated as the annual number of deaths divided by the total number of patients hospitalized during the year, the mortality rate for London hospitals was 10%. A raucous debate broke out in the London medical press over the best way to calculate hospital mortality rates. Critics claimed that Farr had not adjusted for differences in disease severity between urban and rural hospitals and that his figures would mislead the public. Farr and Nightingale, in turn, criticized the poor quality of the hospital data. This story reinforces the need to understand the methodological derivation of statistics intended to compare the quality of providers.

title: 1931 German Guidelines on Human Experimentation
2013 ACC/AHA Cholesterol Treatment Guideline: Paradigm Shifts in Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease Risk Management
abstract: The 2013 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Guideline on Blood Cholesterol Management to Reduce Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Risk in Adults represents a major change from previous cholesterol management guidelines. The new guidelines include data from individual randomized trials as well as the most comprehensive meta-analyses, and introduce several important paradigm shifts, including: targeting ASCVD risk reduction rather than targeting LDL-C levels, advocating for the use of evidence-based statin doses as first-line therapy, and using a new risk calculator and risk cutoff to guide initiation of statin therapy. These major changes have created controversy and confusion in the medical community, with some doctors hesitant to accept the change. We review the evidence that forms the basis for these important changes, compare them to other important lipid guidelines, and recommend an integrated approach to managing dyslipidemia to lower the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.

title: 2015 AAHA/AAFP Pain Management Guidelines for Dogs and Cats
abstract: RATIONALE: Strong advances in pain management for companion animals support the decision by the American Association of Animal Hospitals (AAHA) and the American Association of Feline Physicians (AAFP) to expand on the information provided in the Guidelines for Pain Management 2007 AAHA/AAFP Pain Guidelines. The 2015 Guidelines summarize and provide a detailed review of much of this new knowledge. RELEVANCE: Pain management is critical to veterinary practice as it relieves pain, improves patient outcomes, and improves both quality of life and the veterinarian-client-patient relationship. These Guidelines help veterinarians incorporate pain management into practice, improving patient care. APPROACHES: The treatment of pain requires continuous care that includes anticipation, early intervention and evaluation of the response in each patient. A team-oriented approach, including the owner, is essential to maximize recognition, prevention, and treatment of pain in animals. EVIDENCE BASE: The Guidelines include both pharmacological and non-pharmacological modalities to control pain; they are evidence-based to the extent possible and represent a consensus of expert opinion. Behavior changes are currently the main indicator of pain and its course of improvement or progression, and the basis for recently validated pain scores. Post-surgical pain is eminently predictable, but there is strong evidence supporting strategies to mitigate adaptive and maladaptive forms. Chronic pain is dominated by degenerative joint disease (DJD), which is one of the most significant and underdiagnosed diseases of cats and dogs. DJD is ubiquitous, found in pets of all ages, and inevitably progresses over time;" Evidence-based strategies for management are established in dogs and emerge in cats.

title: 5As Team obesity intervention in primary care: development and evaluation of weight control tools for shared decision making
abstract: Despite various clinical practice guidelines, a considerable gap remains in the prevention and management of obesity in primary care. To address the need to change provider behavior, a randomized controlled trial with a convergent mixed-method evaluation, the 5As Team (5AsT) study, was conducted. As part of the 5AsT intervention, the 5AsT Toolkit was developed. This document describes the process of developing and evaluating these tools. The tools were developed jointly by the multidisciplinary research team and the 5AsT, which included registered nurses/nurse practitioners (n = 15), mental health workers (n = 7), and registered dietitians (n = 7), who were previously assigned randomized to the 5AST intervention group in a primary care network in Edmonton, Alberta, Canada. The development of the 5AsT tool occurred through an iterative, need-based, and practice/implementation-oriented process during collaborative 5AsT intervention learning sessions. Feedback during the development of the tool was received through field notes and the final evaluation of the provider was carried out through anonymous questionnaires. Twelve tools were developed in conjunction with 5AsT. All tools were rated as "most useful" or "moderately useful" in primary care practice by the 5AsT. Four key findings during the development of the 5AsT tool were the need for: tools that are adaptable, tools to facilitate interdisciplinary practice, tools to help patients understand realistic expectations for weight loss, and shared decision-making tools for goal setting and relapse prevention. The 5AsT tools are primary care tools that extend the utility of the 5A obesity management framework in clinical practice.

title: 6-PACK program to reduce fall injuries in acute care hospitals: cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the effect of the 6-PACK program on falls and fall injuries in acute care settings. DESIGN Cluster randomized controlled trial. SETTING Six Australian hospitals. PARTICIPANTS All patients admitted to 24 acute wards during the trial period. INTERVENTIONS Participating wards were randomly assigned to receive either the nurse-led 6-PACK program or usual care for 12 months. The 6-PACK program included a falls risk tool and individualized use of one or more of six interventions: "fall alert" signal, monitoring patients in the bathroom, ensuring that patients' walking aids within reach, a regimen for toileting, use of a low-low bed, and use of a bed/chair alarm. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Co-primary outcomes were falls and fall injuries per 1000 occupied bed days. RESULTS During the trial, there were 46,245 admissions to 16 medical and eight surgical wards. As many people were admitted more than once, this represented 31,411 individual patients. Patient characteristics and length of stay were similar for the intervention and control wards. Use of the 6-PACK program components was higher in intervention rooms than in control rooms (incidence rate ratio 3.05, 95% confidence interval 2.14 to 4.34"; P< In total, 1831 falls and 613 fall injuries occurred, and the rates of falls (incidence rate ratio 1.04, 0.78 to 1.37; P = 0.796) and fall injuries (0.96 , 0.72 to 1.27; "P = 0.766) were similar in the intervention and control rooms. CONCLUSIONS Positive changes in fall prevention practice occurred after the introduction of the 6-PACK program. However, no differences in falls or fall injuries were observed between the groups. High-quality evidence showing the effectiveness of falls prevention interventions in acute care settings remains lacking. New solutions to the problem of in-hospital falls are urgently needed. TRIALS REGISTRY Australia and New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry ACTRN12611000332921.

title: before-after study using OncoDoc, a guideline-based decision support system for breast cancer treatment: impact on physician prescribing behavior
abstract: Guideline-based decision support systems have been developed to influence physicians' prescribing behavior, but have not yet been shown to increase physicians' compliance with routine best practice. OncoDoc is a non-automated system that allows flexibility in interpreting guidelines for the best patient-specific recommendations at the point of care. OncoDoc applies to the management of breast cancer. We have piloted the system at the Institut Gustave Roussy with a before-and-after study in which treatment decisions for breast cancer patients were measured before and after using the system to assess its impact on doctors' prescribing behavior. . After 4 months, 127 decisions were recorded. Physician compliance with OncoDoc improved significantly (p < 10(-4) ) to 85.03% after using the system. The comparison of the initial and final decisions showed that the doctors modified their prescription in 31% of the cases. The accrual rate of clinical trials increased by 50%, although not statistically significant because it is estimated in small numbers.

title: vision of poverty from behavioral economics
abstract: Standard poverty theory falls into two camps. Behaviors of the economically disadvantaged are considered by social scientists to be calculated adaptations to prevailing circumstances or to emanate from a unique "culture of poverty" riddled with deviant values. The first field assumes that people are highly rational, that they hold coherent and justified beliefs, and that they pursue their goals effectively, without error, and without needing help. The second camp attributes to the poor a variety of psychological and attitudinal deficiencies that make their views often wrong and their choices fallible, leaving them in need of paternalistic guidance. We propose a third vision. We argue that the behavioral patterns of the poor may not be perfectly calculating or especially deviant. Rather, the poor may exhibit the same basic weaknesses and biases as people in other walks of life, except that in poverty, with its narrow margins of error, the same behaviors are often more pronounced and can lead to to worse results. In what follows, we illustrate the kinds of insights that can be gained from a more behaviorally realistic analysis of the economic conditions of the poor, and propose that alternative policies

title: behaviorally effective model for the training of general health professionals by a rheumatology team
abstract: This project evaluated a model for in-service arthritis education based in part on the principles of applied behavior analysis. Thirty-seven public health nurses (PHNs) from 10 rural Midwestern counties received instruction in the detection and management of patients with arthritis";" a random half of the counties also received medical and public information interventions designed to increase arthritis referrals to community physicians in specific circumstances. In clinical interviews with PHN patients, modest but significant increases in 14 of 16 target behaviors attributable to in-service education were observed. Because the measured impact of arthritis was low in this older adult population, physician referral rates were not affected by either intervention. This model illustrates generalizable behavior modification guidelines that are useful adjuncts to traditional procedures for the development of professional arthritis education.

title: case of osteomalacia, osteoporosis and hypercalcaemia
A case of sarcoidosis with cryptococcal meningitis demonstrated at the Royal Postgraduate Medical School
abstract: A fatal case is described in a 30-year-old army officer who had served abroad.

title: A case report evaluating a large-scale health systems improvement project in an uncontrolled environment: a quality improvement initiative in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa
abstract: Objective New approaches are needed to assess quality improvement (QI) within large-scale public health efforts. This case report details the challenges to large-scale CI evaluation and proposes solutions that are based on an adaptive study design. Study design We used two sequential evaluation methods to study a QI effort to improve the delivery of HIV preventive care in public health facilities in three districts of KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, over a 3-year period. We initially used a cluster randomized controlled trial (RCT) design. Main findings During the study period of the RCT, tensions arose between intervention implementation and evaluation design due to loss of integrity of the randomisation unit over time, pressure to implement changes in the randomisation unit and the use of administrative rather than functional structures for randomisation. In response to this loss of design integrity, we switched to a more flexible intervention design and mixed-methods quasi-experimental evaluation that relies on both qualitative and quantitative interrupted time-series analysis. Conclusions Cluster RCT designs may not be optimal for evaluating complex interventions to improve implementation in uncontrolled 'real world' settings. More flexible and context-sensitive evaluation designs offer a better balance of the need to adjust the intervention during evaluation to meet implementation challenges while providing the data needed to assess effectiveness. Our case study involved HIV care in a resource-limited setting, but these issues are likely to apply to complex improvement interventions in other settings.

title: centralized cardiovascular risk service to improve adherence to guidelines in private primary care practices
abstract: BACKGROUND: Many large health systems now employ clinical pharmacists in care teams to help patients and physicians with the management of cardiovascular (CV) disease. However, small private offices often lack the resources to hire a clinical pharmacist for their office. The purpose of this study is to assess whether a centralized, web-based CV risk service (HRQoL) managed by clinical pharmacists will improve guideline adherence in primary care physician offices in rural and small communities. METHODS: This study is a prospective randomized cluster trial in 12 primary care practices. Physician offices were randomly assigned to the HRQoL intervention or usual care. The intervention will have a duration of 12 months and all subjects will have research visits at the beginning and at 12 months. Primary outcomes will include adherence to treatment guidelines and control of key CV risk factors. Data will also be extracted from the clinical history at 30 months to determine if the effect of the intervention is maintained after stopping it. CONCLUSIONS: This study will recruit subjects through 2015 and results will be available in 2018. This study will provide insight into whether a centralized, remote CV risk service can improve guideline adherence in physician offices that lack the resources to employ clinical pharmacists.

title: clinical decision support system for the prevention of venous thromboembolism: effect on medical behavior
abstract: BACKGROUND: Computerized clinical decision support systems (CDSS) have been promoted for their potential to improve the quality of medical care. However, given the limited range of clinical settings in which they have been tested, such systems need to be rigorously evaluated before their widespread introduction into clinical practice. OBJECTIVE: To determine if the presentation of venous thromboembolism prophylaxis guidelines through a CDSS increases the proportion of appropriate clinical practice decisions. DESIGN: Time-series study conducted between December 1997 and July 1999. SETTING: Department of orthopedic surgery at a university hospital in Paris, France. PARTICIPANTS: A total of 1971 patients who underwent orthopedic surgery. INTERVENTION: A CDSS designed to provide immediate information related to the prevention of venous thromboembolism was integrated into daily medical practice among surgical patients during three 10-week intervention periods, alternated with four 10-week control periods, with a 4-week washout. weeks between each period. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: Proportion of appropriate prescriptions ordered for anticoagulation, according to pre-established clinical guidelines, during intervention versus control periods. RESULTS: Physicians complied with guidelines in 82.8% (95% confidence interval [CI], 77.6%-87.1%) of cases during the control periods and in 94.9% (95% CI, 92.5%-96.6%) of cases during the intervention periods. During each intervention period, prescription adequacy increased significantly (p < 0.001). Each time the CDSS was withdrawn, medical practice returned to that observed before the start of the intervention. The relative risk of inappropriate practice decisions during the control periods versus the intervention periods was 3.8 (95% CI, 2.7-5.4). CONCLUSIONS: In our study, the implementation of clinical guidelines for venous thromboembolism prophylaxis through a CDSS routinely used in an orthopedic surgery department and integrated into the hospital information system changed physician behavior and improved compliance. of the guides. JAMA. 2000";"283:2816-2821

title: clinical trial of a knowledge-based medical registry
abstract: To meet the needs of primary care physicians caring for patients with HIV infection, we developed a knowledge-based medical record to enable the online patient record to play an active role in the care process. These programs integrate online patient registration, rules-based decision support, and full-text information retrieval into a clinical workstation for the practicing physician. To determine whether the use of a knowledge-based medical record was associated with faster and more complete adherence to practice guidelines and better quality of care, we conducted a controlled clinical trial among physicians and nurse practitioners who cared for 349 patients. infected with human immunodeficiency (HIV)";" 191 patients were treated by 65 doctors and nurses assigned to the intervention group, and 158 patients were treated by 61 doctors and nurses assigned to the control group. During the 18-month study period, the computer generated 303 alerts in the intervention group and 388 in the control group. Median physician response time to these alerts was 11 days in the intervention group and 52 days in the control group (PJJ0.0001, log-rank test). During the study, the computer generated 432 primary care reminders for the intervention group and 360 reminders for the control group. The median physician response time to these alerts was 114 days in the intervention group and more than 500 days in the control group (PJJ0.0001, log-rank test). Of the 191 patients in the intervention group, 67 (35%) had one or more hospitalizations, compared to 70 (44%) of the 158 patients in the control group (PJ=J0.04, Wilcoxon stratified for count initial CD4) . There was no difference in survival between the intervention and control groups (P = 0.18, log-rank test). We conclude that our clinical workstation significantly changed the behavior of clinicians in terms of their response to alerts about primary care interventions and that these interventions have led to fewer HIV-infected patients being admitted to hospital.

title: clinically integrated postgraduate training program in evidence-based medicine versus 'no intervention' to improve disability assessments: a cluster randomized clinical trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although several studies have shown that EBM teaching is effective in improving knowledge, there is currently no convincing evidence that EBM teaching also changes professional behavior in practice. Therefore, the primary objective of this study was to assess the effectiveness of a clinically integrated postgraduate training program in EBM in evidence-based disability assessment. METHODS AND RESULTS: In a cluster randomized controlled trial, fifty-four case-based learning groups consisting of 132 physicians and 1680 patients were randomly assigned to intervention or control groups. The intervention group was provided with a 5-day postgraduate clinically integrated training program in evidence-based medicine, consisting of homework (at home), peer teaching, interactive training in database searching, lectures, and brainstorming sessions. The control group received no training. The primary outcome was evidence-based disability assessment, as indicated by frequency of use of evidence of sufficient quality in disability assessment reports. There are no general behavioral outcome measures of EBM available. Therefore, we follow general guidelines to construct performance indicators and define an a priori cut-off point to determine sufficient quality as recommended for evaluating EB training. EBM-trained clinicians performed more evidence-based disability assessments compared with clinicians in the control group (difference in absolute proportion 9.7%, 95% CI 3.5 to 15.9). Differences in primary outcomes between groups remained significant after cluster-adjusted analysis and additional sensitivity analyzes that accounted for subject loss to follow-up. CONCLUSIONS: An EBM program successfully improved the use of evidence in a nonhospital medical specialty. Our findings support general recommendations to use multiple educational methods to change physician behavior. In addition, it seemed important that the professional context of the intervention was very supportive in that database searches, use and application of guidelines and other forms of evidence are considered standard practice and are encouraged by colleagues. and management.

title: clinic-based mammography intervention targeting inner-city women.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The objective was to assess the effect of a clinic-based intervention program on the use of mammography by inner-city women. DESIGN: A randomized controlled trial using firm systems methodology was conducted. SETTING: The study setting was a general internal medicine clinic at a university-affiliated county hospital serving the Seattle metropolitan area. PARTICIPANTS: Women aged 50 to 74 years with at least one routine clinic appointment (when due for mammography) during the study period (n=314) were enrolled in the trial. INTERVENTIONS: The intervention program emphasized nursing involvement and included medical education, provider directions, use of audio-visual and print patient education materials, transportation assistance in the form of bus passes, pre-appointment telephone or postcard reminders and rescheduling assistance. Women in the control company received usual care. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: Completion of mammography within 8 weeks of clinic visits was significantly higher among operated women (49%) than firm control women (22%) (p < 0.001). These effects persisted after adjustment for potential confounders of age, race, health insurance coverage, and previous experience with mammography in the hospital (odds ratio 3.5: 95% confidence interval 1.9, 6.5). The effect of the intervention was modified by the type of insurance coverage, as well as by history of previous mammograms. The process evaluation indicated that bus passes and rescheduling efforts did not contribute to the observed increases in participation in controls. CONCLUSIONS: A clinic-based program that incorporates physician education, provider directions, patient education materials, and appointment reminders and that emphasizes nursing involvement may facilitate breast cancer screening adherence among women. From the center of the city.

title: cluster randomized controlled trial of the clinical and economic efficacy of a 'whole systems' model of self-management support for the management of long-term illness in primary care: trial protocol
abstract: Background Patients with long-term conditions are increasingly the focus of quality improvement activities in health services to reduce the impact of these conditions on quality of life and to reduce the burden on care utilization. . There is significant interest in the potential of self-management support to improve health and reduce utilization in these patient populations, but there is little consensus on the optimal model that would best provide such support. We describe the implementation and evaluation of self-care support through an evidence-based "whole systems" model that includes patient support, training of primary care teams, and service reorganization, all integrated into the routine provision within primary care. Methods The evaluation involves a large-scale, multi-site study of the implementation, effectiveness, and cost-effectiveness of this self-management support model using a cluster randomized controlled trial in patients with three long-term conditions of diabetes, chronic obstructive lung disease (COPD) and irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). Outcome measures include healthcare utilization and quality of life. We describe the methods of the cluster randomized trial. Discussion If the 'whole systems' model proves to be effective and cost-effective, it will provide decision-makers with a model for the delivery of self-management support for populations with long-term conditions that can be widely implemented to maximize 'reach' through of the broader patient population.

title: cluster randomized clinical trial to improve prescription patterns in pediatric outpatients.
abstract: Objectives Having previously shown that an electronic prescription writer and decision support system improved pediatric prescribing behavior for otitis media in an academic clinical setting, we assessed whether point-of-care evidence delivery could demonstrate effects. similar for a wide range of other common pediatric conditions. . Cluster randomized controlled trial design. Setting A teaching clinic/clinical practice site and a primary care pediatric clinic serving a mix of rural and semi-urban patients. Participants A total of 36 providers at the teaching clinic/practice site and eight providers at the private primary pediatric clinic. Intervention An evidence-based messaging system that presented real-time evidence to providers based on prescribing practices for acute otitis media, allergic rhinitis, sinusitis, constipation, pharyngitis, croup, urticaria, and bronchiolitis. Outcome measures The proportion of prescriptions dispensed in accordance with the evidence. Results The proportion of prescriptions dispensed in accordance with the evidence improved four percentage points, from 38% at baseline to 42% after the intervention. The control group improved by one percentage point, from 39% at baseline to 40% at the end of the trial. The adjusted difference between the intervention and control groups was 8% (95% confidence interval, 1%, 15%). The effectiveness of the intervention did not decrease over time. Conclusion For common pediatric outpatient conditions, an evidence-based prescription writer and point-of-care decision support system was associated with significant improvements in prescribing practices.

title: cluster randomized controlled trial aimed at implementing local quality improvement collaborations to improve prescribing and test ordering performance of general practitioners: study protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: The use of guidelines in general practice is not optimal. Although there are evidence-based methods to improve adherence to guidelines, variation in physician adherence to general practice guidelines remains relatively high. The objective of this study is to transfer to the field a quality improvement strategy based on auditing, feedback, educational materials and peer discussion moderated by local opinion leaders. The research questions are: is the large-scale multifaceted strategy implemented as planned?"; what is the effect on the prescribing and test-ordering behavior of general practitioners (GPs)?"; And what are the costs of implementing the strategy? METHODS: In order to assess the effects, costs, and feasibility of this new strategy, we planned a multicenter cluster randomized controlled trial (RCT) with a balanced incomplete block design. Local GP groups in the southern Netherlands who already participate in pharmacotherapeutic audit meeting groups will be recruited by regional health officials. Approximately 50 groups of GPs will be randomly assigned to two arms. These GPs will be offered two different balanced sets of clinical topics. Each GP within a group will receive comparative feedback on test ordering and prescription performance. Feedback will be discussed in the group and working agreements will be created after discussion of guidelines and barriers to change. Data for feedback will be collected from existing and newly formed databases, both at the start and after one year. DISCUSSION: We are not aware of published studies on the successes and failures of attempts to transfer to stakeholders in the field a multifaceted strategy targeting GPs' prescribing and test-ordering behavior. This pragmatic study will focus on compatibility with existing infrastructure, while allowing a degree of adaptation to local needs and routines.

title: Cluster-Randomized Trial of Standard Quality Improvement Versus Patient-Centered Interventions to Improve Depression Care for African Americans in the Primary Care Setting: Study Protocol NCT00243425
abstract: BACKGROUND: Several studies document disparities in access to care and quality of care for depression in African Americans. Research suggests that patients' attitudes and physicians' communication behaviors may contribute to these disparities. Evidence links patient-centered care with improvements in mental health outcomes";" therefore, quality improvement interventions that improve this dimension of care are promising strategies for improving depression treatment and outcomes among African Americans. This article describes the design of the BRIDGE (Blacks Receiver Interventions for Depression and Gaining Empowerment) study. The purpose of the study is to compare the effectiveness of two interventions for African-American patients with depression: a standard quality improvement program and a patient-centered quality improvement program. The main hypothesis is that patients in the patient-centered group will have a greater reduction in their symptoms of depression, higher rates of remission from depression, and greater improvements in mental health functioning at six, twelve, and eighteen months than patients in the standard group. The study also examines patients' assessments of their care and receipt of guideline-based treatment for depression. METHODS/DESIGN: A total of 36 primary care physicians and 132 of their African American patients with major depressive disorder were recruited in a cluster randomized trial. The study uses intention-to-treat analyzes to compare the effectiveness of standard quality improvement interventions (academic details on depression guidelines for clinicians and disease-oriented care management for their patients) and patient-centered quality improvement (training in communication skills to improve participation). decision making for physicians and care management focused on explanatory models, sociocultural barriers, and treatment preferences for their patients) to improve outcomes during 12-month follow-up. DISCUSSION: The BRIDGE study includes African American physicians and patients in low-resource community practices who have not been well represented in clinical trials to improve depression care. The patient-centered, culturally driven approach to depression care is relatively new and has not been tested in most previous studies. The study will provide evidence on whether patient-centered accommodations improve quality of care and outcomes to a greater extent than standard quality improvement strategies for African Americans with depression. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov NCT00243425.

title: Combined location alert and web-based tool change clinician behavior and shorten length of hospital stay in acute pancreatitis
abstract: OBJECTIVES: There are many published clinical guidelines for acute pancreatitis (AP). The implementation of these recommendations is variable. We hypothesized that a clinical decision support (CDS) tool would change physician behavior and shorten length of hospital stay (LOS). METHODS: DESIGN/SETTING: Observational study, titled The AP Early Response (TAPER) Project. Emergency department (ED) and hospital of a tertiary center. PARTICIPANTS: Two consecutive samples of patients with ICD-9 code (577.0) were generated for PC emergency department (ED) or hospital admissions. The diagnosis of PA was based on the conventional Atlanta criteria. The Pre-TAPER-CDS-Tool group (5/30/06-6/22/07) had 110 patients presenting to the ED with AP by 976 ICD-9 (577.0) codes and the Post-TAPER-CDS group -Tool (5/30/06-6/22/07) had 113 by 907 ICD-9 codes (7/14/10-5/5/11). INTERVENTION: The TAPER-CDS tool, developed between 12/2008 and 7/14/2010, is a combined automated early pager alert system that sends text messages to emergency physicians about a patient with PA and an intuitive web-based point of contact. -Instrument of attention, composed of seven recommendations for early management. RESULTS: The groups before and after TAPER-CDS-Tool had similar baseline characteristics. The post-TAPER-CDS-Tool group met two management goals more often than the pre-TAPER-CDS-Tool group: risk stratification (P6L/1st 0-24h (P=0.0003). The mean (sd) of hospital LOS was significantly shorter in the post-TAPER-CDS-Tool group (4.6 (3.1) vs. 6.7 (7.0) days, P = 0.0126). Multivariate analysis identified four independent variables for hospital stay: TAPER-CDS tool associated with shorter stay (P = 0.0049) and three variables associated with longer LOS: Japanese Severity Score (P = 0.0361), persistent organ failure (P = 0.0088) and local pancreatic complications (<0.0001).CONCLUSIONS: The TAPER-CDS tool is associated with changed physician behavior and shortened hospital duration, which has significant financial implications.

title: community capacity-building approach to breast and cervical cancer screening among older women of color
abstract: In the Screening Older Minority Women project, the authors applied a community capacity-building approach to promoting breast and cervical cancer screening among older women of color. Members of informal support networks were recruited for this health promotion intervention to empower Black and Latina women to engage in positive health behaviors. The authors describe the phases of the intervention and the experiences of the community. Guidelines are identified to help researchers and practitioners plan and implement community health promotion interventions with women of color.

title: A community approach to the promotion of breastfeeding in Mexico
abstract: comprehensive education strategy is presented that links training, community education, research, and media efforts to improve breastfeeding practices. Breastfeeding promotion models, an administrative system, and lessons learned during the project are described. The keys to effective breastfeeding promotion have been shown to be accurate information"; appropriate education, training, and follow-up; and a supportive administrative system"; PIP: An operations research project designed to determine which intervention model was most successful in promoting breastfeeding among 585 urban women in Mexico began in 1986. mothers in Chihuahua, and both trained promoters and program supervisors train individuals or groups in Cuauhtémoc. Jalapa served as the control site. The breastfeeding prevalence rate in the 4 communities ranged from 64.5% to 81.3% before the intervention, with a mean in the target group of 74.9%. The mean rose to 88.8% for this group after the intervention. In addition, the breastfeeding prevalence rate in Jalapa fell from 65.9% to 56%. In addition, 70% of the women in the experimental group exclusively breastfed their children during the first month, while only 63.3% in the control group did so. Breastfeeding prevalence rates in subsequent months decreased by 13.7% and 14.7% (5 months) and 9.4% and 3.3% (6 months) in the experimental and control groups , respectively. Informal support groups of breastfeeding mothers unexpectedly formed as a result of the educational and outreach activities. The data showed that the intervention model with promoters was the most successful strategy. They also provided guidelines for researchers and other health professionals interested in promoting community breastfeeding programs. For example, supervisors should not discourage promoters from addressing other community needs, as discouraging them may jeopardize their dedication to breastfeeding promotion. In addition, program planners must collect geographic and sociodemographic data on the area and population prior to planning and intervention.

title: comparison of the effects of computer and manual reminders on adherence to a mental health clinical practice guideline.
abstract: Objective: To evaluate the relative effectiveness of computerized and manual reminder systems in the implementation of a clinical practice guideline. Design: Seventy-eight outpatients in a mental health clinic were randomly assigned within the clinician to one of two recall systems. The computer system, called CaseWalker, reminded physicians when to perform the guideline-recommended screening for mood disorders, ensured fidelity of the diagnosis of major depressive disorder to the criteria of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mood Disorders. Mental Disorders, 4th Edition (DSM-IV), and generated a progress note. The manual system was a checklist inserted into the paper medical record. MEASURES: Rates of screening for mood disorder and completeness of documentation of DSM-IV criteria met by patients said to have major depressive disorder were compared. Results: The CaseWalker, compared to the paper checklist, resulted in a higher detection rate for mood disorders (86.5% vs. 61%, P = 0.008) and a higher detection rate for mood disorders. full documentation of DSM-IV criteria (100 vs. 5.6%, p < 0.001). Conclusions: In a mental health outpatient clinic, computerized reminders were shown to be superior to manual reminders in improving adherence to a clinical practice guideline for depression.

title: computer-based intervention to improve the adequacy of antiepileptic drug level monitoring
abstract: Designed and implemented 2 automated computer screens for use at antiepileptic drug (AED) test order entry to improve appropriateness by reminding clinicians when a potentially redundant test was ordered and provide common prompts for monitoring and pharmacokinetics of the specific AED. All computerized orders for serum AED levels from hospitalized patients during two 3-month periods were included in the study. During the 3-month period after implementation of the automated intervention, 13% of all AED tests ordered were canceled following computerized reminders. For orders that seemed redundant, the cancellation rate was 27%. For non-redundant orders, 4% were canceled when information on pharmacokinetics and AED-specific monitoring was provided. The cancellation rate was maintained after 4 years. There has been a 19.5% decrease in the total volume of AED tests since the implementation of this intervention, despite a 19.3% increase in the overall volume of chemical tests. Inadequacy due to repeated testing before reaching pharmacological steady state decreased from 54% of all AED orders to 14.6%. A simple, automated, activity-based intervention targeting specific test requesting behavior effectively reduced inappropriate laboratory testing. The sustained benefit supports the idea that computerized interventions can lastingly affect physician behavior. Computerized delivery of such evidence-based limit guidelines can help bridge the gap between evidence and practice.

title: portable computerized decision support system to improve the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism: a randomized trial.
abstract: Background: Pulmonary embolism tests often differ from those recommended by evidence-based guidelines. Objective: To evaluate the efficacy of a portable clinical decision support system to improve the diagnosis of suspected pulmonary embolism in emergency department patients. Design: Randomized cluster trial. Allocation was by random number table, providers were not blinded, and outcome assessment was automated. (ClinicalTrials.gov registration number: NCT00188032) Setting: 20 emergency departments in France. Patients: 1103 and 1768 consecutive outpatients with suspected pulmonary embolism. Intervention: After a pre-intervention period involving 20 centers and 1,103 patients, in which providers became accustomed to entering clinical data on handheld devices and investigators evaluated baseline tests, emergency departments were randomly assigned to activation of a decision support system in the devices (10 centers, 753 patients) or posters and pocket cards showing validated diagnostic strategies (10 centers, 1015 patients). Measurements: Appropriateness of diagnostic evaluation, defined as any sequence of tests that yielded a post-test probability of less than 5% or greater than 85% (primary outcome) or strict adherence to guideline recommendations (secondary outcome)" number of tests per patient (secondary outcome).Results: The proportion of patients who received appropriate diagnostic tests was greater during the trial than in the pre-intervention period in both groups, but the increase was greater in the guideline-based group. (increasing adjusted mean difference, 19.3 percentage points in favor of computer-based guidelines [95% CI, 2.9 to 35.6 percentage points]; P = 0.023).Among patients with adequate assessments , those in the computer-based guidelines group received slightly fewer tests than patients in the paper-based guidelines group (mean tests per patient, 1.76 [SD, 0.98] vs. 2.25 [SD, 1, 04] ;" PÃ‚ < 0.001). Limitation: The study was not designed to show a difference in clinical outcomes for patients during follow-up. Conclusion: A portable decision support system improved diagnostic decision making for patients with suspected pulmonary embolism in the emergency department.

title: computerized intervention to decrease the use of calcium channel blockers in hypertension.
abstract: Objective To determine if a computer-assisted reminder would modify the prescription habits for the treatment of hypertension according to current clinical guidelines in a general internal medicine consultation. Design A randomized trial. Setting The Puget Sound Veterans Affairs Health Care System General Internal Medicine Clinic, Seattle Division. Patients/Participants Clinic providers were randomized to a control group (n=35) or intervention group (n=36). We are targeting providers of patients treated for hypertension with calcium channel blockers, a class of medication that is not recommended for initial therapy. Intervention An automated computer query identified eligible patients and their providers. A guideline reminder was placed in intervention providers' patient charts";" patient charts from control providers did not receive any reminders. Measurements and main results During the 5-month study period, 346 patients were seen by the 36 primary care providers (staff physicians, nurse practitioners, residents, and fellows) in the intervention group, and 373 patients were seen by the 35 providers in the intervention group. control group. Intervention providers switched 39 patients (11.3%) to other medications during the study period, compared to 1 patient (<1.0%) from control providers (p < 0.0001). For patients whose therapy did not change, providers noted angina in 23.1%, indications other than hypertension in 9.5%, adverse effects intolerable with first-line therapy in 13.9%, and inadequate control with first-line therapy in 13.9%. Of those patients without provider-indicated contraindications, 23.6% switched from calcium channel blockers to first-line agents during the intervention period. Conclusions The use of a computerized clinical intervention increased adherence to guidelines in the treatment of primary hypertension in general and decreased the use of calcium channel blockers for the treatment of hypertension in particular.

title: computerized reminder for deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis in surgical patients
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To measure the effect of a computerized reminder system on the rate of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) prophylaxis in surgical patients. DESIGN: A prospective trial to measure change in compliance compared to historical controls. MEASUREMENTS: Surgeons at LDS Hospital developed a local consensus on which procedures should have DVT prophylaxis. The historical rate of prophylaxis for procedures was measured through a database search of patient records. A computerized reminder system was then implemented that used an expert knowledge base and a time control mechanism to flag surgical cases for DVT prophylaxis. For eligible patients, a DVT reminder appeared in the operating room schedule";" the surgical staff used this as a guide to apply prophylaxis. During the 3-month trial, the rate of DVT prophylaxis was remeasured and compared with the pre-intervention rate. RESULTS: The pre-intervention rate of DVT prophylaxis over a 3-month period was 85.2% (785 of 921 eligible cases). During the 3 months after the introduction of the computerized reminder, compliance with DVT prophylaxis increased to 99.3% (1,084 of 1,092 eligible cases). The difference between historical controls and study subjects was highly significant (p < 0.001). CONCLUSION: A computerized reminder is an effective method to increase the rate of DVT prophylaxis in surgical patients.

title: computerized reminder system to increase the use of inpatient preventive care
abstract: BACKGROUND Although effective in outpatient settings, computerized reminders have not been shown to increase preventive care in inpatient settings. METHODS We conducted a randomized controlled trial to determine the effects of computerized reminders on the rates at which four inpatient preventive therapies were ordered. During an 18-month study period, a computerized system processed online information from 6,371 patients admitted to a general medicine service (for a total of 10,065 hospitalizations), generating preventive care reminders as appropriate. Physicians in the intervention group saw these reminders when they were using a computerized inpatient order entry system. RESULTS The reminder system identified 3,416 patients (53.6 percent) as eligible for preventive measures that had not been ordered by the admitting physician. For patients with at least one indication, computerized reminders resulted in higher adjusted rates of requesting pneumococcal vaccination (35.8% of patients in the intervention group vs. 0.8% of those in the control group, P<0.001), influenza vaccination (51.4% 1.0%, P<0.001), prophylactic heparin (32.2% vs. 18.9%, P<0.001), and prophylactic aspirin at discharge (36, 4% vs. 27.6%, P<0.001). CONCLUSIONS Most of the hospitalized patients in this study were eligible for preventive measures, and computerized reminders significantly increased the rate of administration of such therapies.

title: concept for the implementation and evaluation of the guideline "Early detection of breast cancer in Germany"
abstract: Systematically developed, evidence-based, and consensus-based guidelines are important tools for improving health care services. The effectiveness of a guideline is not only related to its methodological quality but also to the implementation strategy used. The following article describes the systematic development of a strategy to implement and evaluate the guideline "Early detection of breast cancer in Germany" as part of a national project. A multifaceted systematic implementation strategy has been developed that addresses existing barriers and builds on projects that were recently introduced in Germany to improve early detection and treatment of breast cancer. The goal is to induce behavioral changes in women as health care recipients and in physicians as health care providers, both involved in the medical decision-making process within the scope of the guideline. In addition, it supports organizational changes to ensure compliance with the guideline through quality assurance and quality management. To ensure the evaluation of the implementation process, a set of quality indicators has been identified for the baseline evaluation of the structures, the performance of the providers and the results. Both the effectiveness of the implementation process and the effectiveness of the guideline itself will be measured using the same set of indicators for re-evaluation within a pre-defined time interval of 18 months. The quasi-experimental design of this uncontrolled pre-post implementation study described in this paper allows for the assessment of clinically relevant changes using quality indicators that measure the effectiveness of the guideline at the national level.

title: controlled trial of symptom data inclusion in computer-based care suggestions for the management of patients with chronic heart failure
abstract: Background Heart failure is common and associated with considerable morbidity and cost, but adherence to treatment guidelines by physicians is suboptimal. We conducted a randomized controlled study to determine whether adding information about symptoms to evidence-based, computer-generated suggestions for care would affect treatment decisions among primary care physicians caring for outpatients with heart failure at two medical centers in the United States. Veterans Affairs. Methods Physicians were randomly assigned to receive care suggestions generated using electronic medical record data and symptom data obtained from questionnaires mailed to patients within 2 weeks of scheduled outpatient visits (intervention group) or suggestions generated only with data from electronic medical records (control group). Patients had to have a diagnosis of heart failure and objective evidence of left ventricular systolic dysfunction. We assessed physician adherence to heart failure guidelines, as well as New York Heart Association (NYHA) class, quality of life, satisfaction with care, hospitalizations and outpatient visits, 6 and 12 months after enrollment. Results Patients in the intervention (n = 355) and control (n = 365) groups were similar at baseline. At 12 months, there was no significant difference in adherence to care suggestions between physicians in the intervention and control groups (33% vs. 30%, p=0.4). There were also no significant changes in NYHA class (P = 0.1) and quality of life measures (P > 0.1), as well as no differences in the number of outpatient visits between intervention and control patients ( 6.7 vs. 7.1 visits, P = 0.48). Intervention patients were more satisfied with their physicians (P = 0.02) and primary care visit (P = 0.02), but had more all-cause hospitalizations at 6 months (1.5 vs. 0.7 hospitalizations, P = 0.0002) and at 12 months (2.3 vs. 1.7 hospitalizations, P = 0.05). Conclusion Adding symptom information to computer-generated care suggestions for patients with heart failure did not affect physicians' treatment decisions or improve patient outcomes.

title: controlled trial of web-based diabetes disease control.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To test the effects of a web-based decision support tool, the Diabetic Disease Management Application (DMA), developed to improve evidence-based management of type 2 diabetes. DESIGN AND METHODS FROM THE RESEARCH: We conducted a cluster randomized controlled trial of 12 intervention and 14 control staff providers and 307 intervention and 291 control patients with type 2 diabetes in a hospital internal medicine clinic. Providers were randomly assigned from May 1998 to April 1999 to have access to the DMA (intervention) or no access (control). The DMA displays interactive patient-specific clinical data, treatment tips, and links to other web-based care resources. We compared patients in the intervention and control groups for changes in care processes and outcomes from the year before the study to the year of the study using intention-to-treat analyses. RESULTS: DMA was used in 42% of scheduled patient visits. The number of HbA1c tests obtained per year was significantly increased in the intervention group (+0.3 tests/year) compared with the control group (-0.04 tests/year, P = 0.008), as was the number of LDL cholesterol tests (intervention, +0.2 tests/year"; control, +0.01 tests/year; P = 0.02) and the proportions of patients who underwent at least one foot exam per year (intervention, +9.8%; control, -0.7%; P = .003).HbA1c levels decreased by 0.2 in the intervention group and increased by 0.1 in the control group (P = 0.09);" the proportions of patients with LDL cholesterol levels <130 mg/dL increased by 20.3% in the intervention group and 10.5% in the control group (P = 0.5). CONCLUSIONS—Web-based patient-specific decision support has the potential to improve evidence-based parameters of diabetes care.

title: cross-sectional study of the number and frequency of terms used to refer to knowledge translation in a body of health literature in 2006: a Tower of Babel?
abstract: The study of the implementation of research results in practice is growing rapidly and has acquired many competing names (eg dissemination, acceptance, utilization, translation) and contributing disciplines. The use of multiple terms across disciplines poses barriers to communication and progress in applying research results. We attempted to establish an inventory of terms that describe this field and how often authors use them in a collection of health literature published in 2006. Methods We refer to this field as knowledge translation (KT). Terms describing aspects of KT and their definitions were collected from the literature, the Internet, reports, textbooks, and contact with experts. We compiled a database of KT and other articles by reading 12 health journals representing multiple disciplines. All articles published in these journals in 2006 were categorized as KT or not. KT articles (all KT articles) were further classified, if possible, by describing KT projects or implementations (KT application articles), or presenting the theoretical basis, models, tools, methods, or KT techniques (KT theory articles). Accuracy was checked by duplicate reading. Custom-designed software determined how often KT terms were used in the titles and abstracts of articles categorized as KT. Results A total of 2,603 articles were evaluated and 581 were identified as KT articles. Of these, 201 described KT applications and 153 included KT theory. Of the 100 KT terms collected, 46 were used by the authors in the titles or abstracts of articles categorized as KT. For the 581 KT articles, eight terms or variations of terms used by the authors were highly discriminating in separating KT and non-KT articles (p < 0.001): implementation, adoption, quality improvement, diffusion, complex intervention (with multiple endings) , implementation (within three words of) research and complex intervention. More KT terms were associated with KT application articles (n = 13) and KT theory articles (n = 18). Conclusions We compiled 100 terms that describe KT research. The authors used 46 of them in titles and abstracts of KT articles. Of these, about half discriminated between KT and non-KT items. Therefore, the need for consolidation and consistent use of fewer terms related to KT research is evident.

title: formative study of colon cancer surveillance care: implications for survivor-centered interventions.
abstract: Colon cancer is one of the most commonly diagnosed cancers in the United States, and a growing number of survivors have stressed the need for improved quality of colon cancer surveillance care. Post-treatment surveillance includes follow-up care visits and tests, as well as psychosocial support and lifestyle advice. This formative study explored individual, interpersonal, and organizational factors related to adherence to surveillance care guidelines to identify modifiable factors for potential educational intervention strategies. A convenience sample of 22 survivors (12 women and 10 men) from two cancer centers was recruited to participate in focus group or key informant telephone interviews to explore their experiences with care after completing treatment and to complete a short survey. Content analysis was used to identify themes. Results confirmed that survivors navigated a complex follow-up care schedule and described a strong trust in their health care providers that guided their follow-up care experiences. Participants defined the terms "survival" and "follow-up" in a variety of different ways. Critical individual-level themes for survivors' experiences included having a positive attitude, trusting one's faith, and coping with fears. Interpersonal-level topics focused on interactions and communication with family and health care providers in follow-up care. While organizational-level factors were infrequently highlighted, participants rated office reminder systems and communication between their multiple vendors as valuable. Educational interventions that build on survivors' connections with their doctors and focus on preparing survivors for what to expect in the next phase of their cancer experience could be beneficial at the end of treatment to energize survivors for the transition to the post-treatment period.

title: framework of good practices in inter-institutional interventions with cases of self-neglect
abstract: Self-neglect is probably more common than generally thought and gives rise to a number of difficult conceptual, identification and intervention problems for health and social care workers. These patient management issues are compounded by the lack of an evidence base for practice on which nurses can draw when faced with managing people who neglect themselves. Nurses working with self-neglecting people operate in an interdisciplinary context that includes professional groups, such as environmental health officers, who are not typically part of health and social care teams. In the absence of such an evidence base, a pragmatic solution has been proposed in the form of a framework for inter-institutional practice. This document briefly describes the background behind this framework, including a research study of self-abandoned housing and interagency responses.

title: framework to help healthcare professionals recommend high-quality apps to support chronic disease self-management: an illustrative assessment of apps for type 2 diabetes
abstract: BACKGROUND: This paper presents an approach to help healthcare professionals recommend high-quality apps to support chronic disease self-management. Most app reviews focus on popularity, aesthetics, functionality, usability, and quality of information. There is no doubt that these factors are important in selecting reliable applications that are attractive to users, but behavioral theory can also be useful in tailoring applications to users' needs. OBJECTIVE: The developed framework aims to be methodologically sound, capable of selecting popular apps that include content covered by evidence-based programs, consistent with behavioral theory, as well as a patient-centered approach to matching apps with needs. individual of the patients. METHODS: A single disease, type 2 diabetes, was selected to illustrate how the framework can be applied, as it was thought to represent the types of strategies used in many chronic diseases. A systematic approach based on behavioral theory and best practice guideline recommendations was developed to tailor applications to patient needs. In March 2014, a series of search strategies were used to identify the best health apps for iPhone and Android, representing 29 topics from five categories of type 2 diabetes self-management strategies. Topics were chosen from international guidelines published for the control of diabetes. The lead author (KH) evaluated the most popular apps found addressing these topics using the Behavioral Theory Content Survey (BTS), which is based on traditional behavioral theory. A tool to aid decision making when using applications with healthcare professionals was developed and tested for ease of use and understanding. RESULTS: A total of 14 apps representing the five categories of self-management topics were evaluated. Total theoretical scores (BTS scores) were less than 50 on a 100-point scale for all applications. Each app scored less than 50% of the total possible BTS score for all four behavioral theories and for most of the 20 behavioral strategies";" however, apps scored greater than 50% of the total possible BTS score for specific strategies related to their primary focus. Our findings suggest that the apps studied would be more effective when used in conjunction with therapy than as stand-alone apps. The applications were classified according to the topic and the main intervention strategies. A framework was developed to match apps to identified patient needs based on app categorization and principles of patient-centered care. The approach was well accepted and understood by a convenience sample of health professionals. CONCLUSIONS: The presented framework can be used by health professionals to better tailor applications to clients' needs. Some applications incorporate highly interactive strategies from behavioral theory and, when used as an adjunct, can increase patient engagement and therapy effectiveness.

title: French adaptation of the Overt Behavior Scale (OBS) measuring challenging behaviors after acquired brain injury: The Echelle des comportements observables (ECO)
abstract: PURPOSE: To develop a French version of the Overt Behavior Scale (OBS) and to examine some of its psychometric properties.
