METHODS: The scale was adapted and validated according to the standard guidelines for cross-cultural adaptation of questionnaires (Echelle des comportements observables";" ECO). The reliability and construct validity of the ECO were studied among 29 inpatients and outpatients who sustained an acquired brain injury. The instruments were administered by 12 physicians located at eight rehabilitation centers and the local brain injury association. RESULTS: The ECO provided behavioral profile descriptions very similar to the original scale. It showed excellent reliability and good convergent and divergent validity, as reflected by significant associations with other measures containing similar behavioral items and the absence of significant correlations with broader constructs such as physical and cognitive abilities. CONCLUSION: This study provides evidence that the ECO behaves very similarly to the original OBS, has promising initial findings regarding reliability and validity, and is a valuable research and clinical instrument for assessing the severity and typology of challenging behavior. after acquired brain injury and to monitor the evolution of behaviors after intervention in French and bilingual communities.

title: portable computer-based smoking intervention tool and its effects on medical advice for smoking cessation
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The objective of this study was to evaluate a laptop-based smoking cessation intervention tool designed to assist clinicians in their smoking cessation counseling with patients. METHODS: This study used a pre/post survey design, with a 4-month trial period for the software. Study participants included 22 University of Virginia professors and medical residents. Paired samples t-tests were used to assess mean differences on the 4 main subscales (physician behavior, attitudes, comfort related to counseling patients about smoking cessation, and knowledge). RESULTS: No statistically significant mean differences were found for physician behavior (mean increase = 0.44, P = 0.55) or physician attitude (mean increase = 0.44, P = 0.16). A statistically significant mean increase of 2.29 was observed for the physician comfort subscale (t = 3.87, df = 16, P = 0.001). Physicians reported greater comfort in counseling patients about smoking cessation (p = 0.007) and greater comfort in using the Public Health Service Clinical Practice Guidelines (p = 0.012). CONCLUSION: Physician comfort level in counseling patients on smoking cessation can be improved through handheld software. When used in conjunction with other practice modifications, this tool has the potential to improve clinicians' intervention practices for smoking cessation.

title: hybrid cluster-randomized trial of effectiveness-implementation of group CBT for anxiety in urban schools: rationale, design, and methods.
abstract: Background Schools present a context with great potential for the implementation of evidence-based psychosocial practices. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is an evidence-based practice that has been shown to be highly effective in treating anxiety in various community settings, including schools. Friends for Life (FRIENDS) is an effective group CBT protocol for anxiety. Unfortunately, evidence-based practices for anxiety are rarely employed in under-resourced urban schools, because many treatment protocols are not appropriate for the urban school setting or population, existing behavioral health staff are not trained o Adequate support to enable them to implement treatment with fidelity, o School districts do not have the resources to hire outside consultants. In our previous work, we adapted FRIENDS to create a more culturally sensitive, focused, and feasible CBT protocol for anxiety disorders (CBT for Anxiety Treatment in Schools (CATS)). Methods/Design The objective of this 5-year study is to assess both the effectiveness of CATS for urban public schools compared to the original FRIENDS as well as to compare implementation strategies (train the trainer versus train the trainer?+?continuous consultation) by conducting a hybrid type 2 effectiveness-implementation trial of three parallel groups in 18 urban K-8 public schools. We will also assess profitability and loyalty mediators and moderators. 90 therapists, 18 agency supervisors and 360 children will participate. The Interactive Systems Framework for Dissemination and Implementation guides training and support procedures for therapists and supervisors. Discussion This study has the potential to demonstrate that therapists and agency supervisors who have had little or no prior exposure to evidence-based practices (EBP) can implement EBP for anxiety disorder with fidelity. Comparisons of implementation strategies would provide data to large urban mental health systems to make decisions about EBP adoption.

title: low-fat vegan diet elicits greater macronutrient changes, but is comparable in adherence and acceptability, compared with a more conventional diabetes diet among people with type 2 diabetes
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although therapeutic diets are essential for the control of diabetes, their acceptability to patients has not been extensively studied. OBJECTIVE: To quantify the adherence and acceptability of two types of diets for diabetes. DESIGN: Controlled trial conducted between 2004 and 2006. SUBJECTS/SETTING: Individuals with type 2 diabetes (n=99) in a community-based research center. Participants were randomly assigned to a diet following the 2003 American Diabetes Association guidelines or a low-fat vegan diet for 74 weeks. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Attrition, adherence, dietary behavior, diet acceptability, and cravings. STATISTICAL ANALYSIS: For nutrient intake and questionnaire scores, t-tests determined differences between groups. For measures of diet acceptability, Wilcoxon's paired-samples rank-sum test assessed within-group changes; independent samples Mann-Whitney U test compared diet groups. Changes in reported symptoms between groups were compared using chi(2) for independent samples RESULTS: All participants completed the initial 22 weeks, 90% (45/50) of the American Association of Dietary Association guidelines diet group Diabetes and 86% (42/49) of the vegan diet group completed 74 weeks. carbohydrate and fiber intake increased more in the vegan group At 22 weeks, 44% (22/50) of members of the American Diabetes Association diet group and 67% (33/49) of vegans met the criteria for adherence to the group-specific diet. -group of participants (P = 0.019); the American Diabetes Association guidelines diet group reported a greater increase in dietary restriction;" this difference was not significant at 74 weeks. Both groups reported reduced hunger and reduced disinhibition. Questionnaire responses rated both diets as satisfactory, with no significant difference between the groups, except for ease of preparation, for which the 22-week ratings marginally favored the American Diabetes Association guideline group Cravings for fatty foods decreased more in the group vegan at 22 weeks, with no significant difference at 74 weeks CONCLUSIONS: Despite its greater influence on macronutrient intake, a low-fat vegan diet has similar acceptability to a more conventional diabetic diet. not be a barrier to its use in medical nutrition therapy.

title: meta-analysis of the association between adherence to drug therapy and mortality
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the relationship between adherence to pharmacological treatment, including placebo, and mortality. DESIGN Meta-analysis of observational studies. DATA SOURCES Electronic databases, contact with researchers and adherence textbooks and reviews. Review methods Predefined criteria were used to select studies that reported mortality between participants with good and poor adherence to pharmacological treatment. Data were extracted by disease, pharmacological treatment groups, methods to measure compliance rate, definition of good compliance, and mortality. RESULTS Data were available from 21 studies (46,847 participants), including eight studies with placebo arms (19,633 participants). Compared with poor adherence, good adherence was associated with lower mortality (odds ratio 0.56, 95% confidence interval 0.50 to 0.63). Good adherence to placebo was associated with lower mortality (0.56, 0.43 to 0.74), as was good adherence to beneficial pharmacological treatment (0.55, 0.49 to 0.62). Good adherence to harmful pharmacological treatment was associated with higher mortality (2.90, 1.04 to 8.11). CONCLUSION Good adherence to drug therapy is associated with positive health outcomes. In addition, the observed association between good placebo adherence and mortality supports the existence of the "healthy adherent" effect, thus adherence to drug therapy may be a surrogate marker of overall healthy behavior.

title: midwife-led hospital birthing center within an academic medical center: successes and challenges
abstract: The University of California San Diego Community Women's Health Program (CWHP) has become a successful and sustainable coexistence model of women's health care. The cornerstone of this midwifery practice is California's only hospital birthing center. Located within the medical center, this unique and physically separate birthing center has been the site of more than 4,000 births. With 10% cesarean delivery and 98% breastfeeding rates, it is an exceptional example of low-intervention care. The integration of this previously independent maternity center into an academic center has brought evidence of mistrust and ineffective communication. Education, consistent leadership, and the development of multidisciplinary guidelines helped overcome these challenges. This collaborative model provides a structure in which residents learn to be respectful consultants and appreciate differences in medical practice. The CWHP and its Birthing Center illustrate that through persistence and flexibility, a collaborative model of maternity services can flourish and positively influence not only new families but also future generations of providers.

title: Migraine Management Training Program for Primary Care Providers: An Overview of a Survey and Results of a Pilot Study, Lessons Learned, and Considerations for Future Research
abstract: BACKGROUND: There are five to nine million primary care office visits per year for migraine in the United States. However, migraine care is often suboptimal in the primary care setting. An earlier study indicated that primary care physicians (PCPs) wanted direct contact with headache specialists to improve the migraine care they provide. OBJECTIVE: We attempted to further examine PCPs' knowledge of migraine management and assess the feasibility of a multimodal migraine education program for PCPs. METHODS: We conducted a survey to assess primary care physicians' knowledge of migraine. We then held three live educational sessions and developed an email consultation service for PCPs to submit questions they had about migraine. We present both quantitative and qualitative results. RESULTS: Twenty-one PCPs completed the survey. They were generally familiar with the epidemiology of migraine (mean prevalence of reported migraine was 12.6% +/- 10.1), psychiatric comorbidities (mean prevalence of comorbid depression was 24.5% +/- 16.7, mean prevalence of comorbid anxiety was 24.6% +/- 18.3), and evidence-based behavioral treatments. 56% cited cognitive behavioral therapy, 78% cited biofeedback, and 61% cited relaxation therapy as evidence-based treatments. Although most were aware of the prevalence of psychiatric comorbidities, they did not routinely screen for them (43% did not routinely screen for anxiety, 29% did not routinely screen for depression). PCPs reported frequently referring patients to evidence-based treatments that were not Level A: special diets (60%), acupuncture (50%), physical therapy (30%), and psychoanalysis (20%). Relaxation therapy was a therapy recommended by 40% of PCPs. Only 10% reported referral for cognitive behavioral therapy or biofeedback. Nineteen percent made little or no use of migraine preventative medications. Seventy-two percent were unaware or barely aware of the American Academy of Neurology guidelines for migraine. There was variable attendance at the educational sessions (N=22 in the 1st session, 6 in the 2nd session, 15 in the 3rd session). Very few PCPs used the email consultation service (N=4). CONCLUSIONS: Although PCPs are familiar with many aspects of migraine care, there is a need and opportunity for improvement. The three live sessions were poorly attended and the email consultation service was rarely used. We provide an in-depth discussion of specific areas for educational intervention, challenges in developing a migraine education program for PCPs, and areas for future study.

title: Model for Collaboration on Quality Improvement Projects: Implementation of a Weight-Based Heparin Dosing Nomogram in an Integrated Healthcare Delivery System
abstract: BACKGROUND: At Aurora Health Care, a Milwaukee-based integrated delivery system, a system-level clinical quality improvement department was established in 1995 to facilitate collaboration on clinical quality improvement (QI) initiatives. THE COLLABORATIVE MODEL: A model was developed to utilize expertise within the system to avoid unnecessary duplication of effort, while maintaining acceptance of project interventions at the point of service delivery. It was believed that a single team could design the improvement efforts or guidelines and then work at a more local level with a different group of people to implement the processes. APPLICATION OF THE MODEL TO THE HEPARIN QI PROJECT: Heparin anticoagulation is considered the mainstay of treatment for pulmonary embolism and deep vein thrombosis. However, a large gap was found between current anticoagulation practices and published best practice in achieving a key process measure. To reduce the total time to effective anticoagulation, a system-level team created an intervention consisting primarily of a preprinted order form, including weight-based heparin dosing nomogram, and an educational plan for physicians and others. healthcare professionals. Significant improvement was seen at all pilot sites with overall rates of adequate anticoagulation within the first 24 hours improving from 73% to 95%. DISCUSSION: The system was able to standardize care in four of its five main hospitals and provide better patient outcomes in a larger segment of the community, and then replicate the heparin project in four additional sites over a six-month period. This model has been successfully applied to other quality improvement projects.

title: modeling tool for policy analysis to support the design of efficient and effective policy responses to complex public health problems.
abstract: Background In the design of public health policy, a broader understanding of disease risk factors throughout the life course and a greater awareness of the social determinants of health have led to the development of more comprehensive intersectoral strategies. to tackle complex problems. . However, comprehensive strategies may not represent the most efficient or effective approach to reducing the burden of disease at the population level. Rather, they can act to allocate finite resources less intensively among a larger number of programs and initiatives, diluting the potential impact of the investment. While analytical tools are available that use research evidence to help identify and prioritize disease risk factors for public health action, they are inadequate to support more targeted and effective policy responses to complex public health problems. Discussion This paper discusses the limitations of analytical tools that are commonly used to support evidence-informed policy decisions for complex problems. It proposes a policy alternative analysis tool that can integrate various sources of evidence and provide a platform for virtual testing of policy alternatives to design solutions that are efficient, effective, and equitable. The case of suicide prevention in Australia is presented to demonstrate the limitations of current tools to adequately inform prevention policy and the usefulness of the new policy analysis tool is discussed. Summary Contrary to popular belief, a systems approach takes a step beyond holistic thinking and seeks to identify where public health action and resources are best directed for optimal impact. It is primarily concerned with what can reasonably be left out of prevention strategies and can be used to explore where disinvestment can occur without negatively affecting the health (or equity) of the population. Simulation modeling used for policy analysis offers the promise of being able to better operationalize research evidence to support decision-making for complex problems, improve public health policy guidance, and offers a foundation for strengthening relationships between policymakers, stakeholders and researchers.

title: national cross-sectional study on sociobehavioral factors influencing physicians' decisions to initiate antimicrobial therapy
abstract: PURPOSE: Current efforts to prevent antimicrobial resistance include limiting antimicrobial use, providing education on appropriate use, and developing better point-of-care testing, but what do clinicians really think about rational prescribing and potential interventions? ? We sought to determine what factors might influence a physician's decision to initiate antimicrobial therapy in a patient and their views on measures to promote rational prescribing. METHODS: We conducted a nationwide cross-sectional survey of 10,600 physicians from the medical records of all known board-certified physicians in Germany. RESULTS: Among respondents (n = 3,492"; 33%;" detailed analysis of non-response bias included), 90% indicated that they decide to start antimicrobial therapy in a patient at least once a week, and 66% He informed that he decides it daily. We identify correlates to decide to start antimicrobial therapy in a patient. Predictors were hospital doctor status (odds ratio (OR) 1.29 (95% confidence interval (CI) 1.00-1.68), male doctor (OR 1.81 (95% CI 1, 42-2.31)), age 50-59 (OR 1.56 (95% CI 1.10 to 2.21)), and practitioners in former East German states (OR 1.60 (95% CI 1.10 to 2.21)) %: 1.15 to 2.21)). Each specialist was significantly less likely to decide to start a course of antimicrobial therapy than were otolaryngologists and urologists. Other predictors agreed to prescribe to be safe (OR 1.34 (95% CI 1.03-1.76)), believing that the quality of prescribing practice improves after receiving continuing education from pharmaceutical companies (OR 1.43 (95% CI 1.11-1.84)), and experience with failed therapy for resistant pathogens (OR 2.42 (95% CI 1.83-3.19)). CONCLUSIONS: Physicians in our sample decide to initiate antimicrobial therapy in a patient and value intervention to support prudent use, eg, continuing education, practice guidelines, and implementation of surveillance measures. Sociobehavioral factors, regional variation, gender, and age deserve further investigation to promote rational antimicrobial prescription and explore related influencing factors.

title: new tool to assess the risk of wandering in hospitalized patients
abstract: This article describes the development and implementation of a ambulation detection and intervention program based on the identification of hospitalized patients with cognitive and mobility problems. A wandering screening tool developed by a multidisciplinary team was linked to the appropriate levels of interventions available in the electronic health record. Advanced practice nurses (APNs) confirmed the accuracy of screening and bedside nurse interventions for all patients who tested positive. Of 1,528 patients hospitalized over a 3-week period, 48 (3.1%) tested positive for ambulation. Patients at risk were older (age ≥ 65 years) (66.7%), those admitted to surgical units (41.7%), Caucasian (89.6%), and male (58.3%). Thirteen (27.1%) had dementia and 45 (93.8%) had cognitive problems. Of those patients who tested positive for ambulation, the EPAs coincided with the assessment of the primary care nurses in 79.2% of the cases (38/48) regarding the risk of ambulation and 89.5% (34/38 true positive) for interventions. A two-item wandering screening and intervention tool was feasible for use by bedside nurses. More studies are needed to determine if this tool is effective in preventing wandering.

title: pan-Canadian practice guideline: prevention, detection, evaluation and treatment of sleep disorders in adults with cancer
abstract: PURPOSE: This study aims to provide recommendations on the optimal strategies and interventions for the prevention, detection, evaluation, and treatment of cancer-related sleep disorders (insomnia and sleep syndrome) in adult populations with cancer. METHODS: A systematic search of the published health literature was performed to identify randomized controlled trials, clinical practice guidelines, systematic reviews, and other guidance documents. The Sleep Disorders Expert Panel [composed of nurses, psychologists, primary care physicians, oncologists, sleep physicians, researchers, and guideline methodologists] reviewed, discussed, and approved the final version of the guideline. Healthcare professionals across Canada were asked to provide comments through an external review process. RESULTS: Three clinical practice guidelines and 12 randomized controlled trials were identified as the evidence base. Overall, despite the paucity of evidence, evidence and expert consensus suggest that it is important to screen and screen adult cancer patients for sleep disturbances using standardized screening tools on a routine basis. While prevention of sleep disorders is the desired goal, cognitive behavioral therapies are effective in improving sleep outcomes. As part of the external review with 16 health care providers, 81% indicated that they agreed with the recommendations as written. CONCLUSIONS: Difficulty sleeping is a prevalent problem in cancer populations that needs further recognition by health professionals. Prevention, detection, evaluation and treatment strategies supported by the best available evidence are essential. Recommendations and care route algorithms are offered for practice.

title: patient-initiated system for preventive health care.
abstract: Objective To test the efficacy of a patient-initiated touch-sensitive computer system (TSCS) in improving detection rates for breast, cervical, colon and rectal, and oral cavity cancers. Design One-year randomized controlled trial with primary care practice as the unit of analysis. Setting Sixty primary care practices, randomly recruited from 329 non-teaching practices in a southeastern state. Subjects Random sample of the medical records of 50 male and female adult patients before the intervention and 50 adult patients after the intervention in each practice and a random sample of 507 TSCS users. Interventions Touch sensitive computer system and a registered nurse who acted as liaison with the study practices. The TSCS provided patient-specific preventive service recommendations and facilitated workflow to increase completion of these interventions. Main outcome measure Average change, adjusted for health maintenance examination (HME) and TSCS use, in the proportion of eligible patients who underwent screening mammography, clinical breast examination, digital rectal examination, fecal occult blood, flexible sigmoidoscopy, Pap smear, and oral cavity examination. Results We observed a significant increase in the performance of screening mammography (6.6%"; P <= 0.05) and clinical breast examination (6.1%; P <= 0.01) in women of 50 years of age and older, particularly for those who had an HME during the study year. Conclusions Patients who have HME are more likely to be screened for cancer;" however, a computerized system for preventive services can help improve detection. Among patients who did not have an HME, TSCS users had higher rates of breast cancer detection than nonusers.

title: peer review feedback method to promote compliance with preventive care guidelines in an outpatient clinic for residents
abstract: BACKGROUND: Simply distributing clinical practice guidelines to physicians does not change practice behavior. A low-cost peer-review continuous feedback method was used to promote resident physician compliance with nine preventive care guidelines at the Marshall University School of Medicine ambulatory care clinic (Huntington, West Virginia) . METHODS: Preventive care guidelines were distributed and a peer review feedback program was instituted in the resident physician's primary care practice. The frequency of use by the resident doctor of nine preventive care services was evaluated and compared during three periods: preguide (September 1, 1993 to March 1, 1994"; 148 patients), guideline (September 1, 1994 to March 1995; 148 patients) and one year of follow-up (September 1, 1995 to March 1, 1996; 150 patients).Patients in all three periods were similar in age, sex, and risk of influenza and pneumococcal infection. : During the guideline period, resident physicians offered patients four preventive care services: tetanus toxoid immunization, clinical breast exam, Pap smear, and blood occult testing much more frequently than during the preguidance period. All services were offered significantly more often during the one-year follow-up period compared to the pre-guideline period and as often as in the guideline period . CONCLUSION: A low-cost ongoing peer review feedback program significantly and lastingly improves resident physicians' compliance with clinical practice guidelines on preventive care services. However, the effectiveness of the poor review feedback method may not generalize to private practice or other settings. Research should continue on other methods to promote adherence to clinical practice guidelines and to influence the behavior of physicians in general.

title: pilot study of an evidence-based interprofessional electronic care planning tool for clients with mental health and addiction problems
abstract: BACKGROUND: The health system must develop effective solutions to the growing challenges it faces regarding people suffering from mental health disorders and addictions. The purpose of this study was to assess the usability and potential impact on outcomes of a knowledge translation system intended to improve evidence-based, client-centered care for hospitalized people with schizophrenia. METHODOLOGY: A pre-posttest design was used. The e-Volution-TREAT system was implemented in two inpatient units at a large mental health center. Thirty-seven nurses, health assistants and doctors participated in two units. Data collection involved questionnaires, semi-structured interviews, and observations. Outcome data for thirty-eight consenting clients was collected from the organization's records. RESULTS: Overall, staff participants were very satisfied with the features of the e-Volution-TREAT system. Participants identified barriers to using the system related to work environment, understaffing, equipment issues, discomfort with technology, and a focus on short-term goals rather than long-term ones. There was moderate acceptance of guidelines related to social issues and low acceptance of guidelines related to family support and addictions. There were significant improvements in four client outcomes over time, specifically aggressive behavior, depression, withdrawal, and psychosis. CONCLUSIONS: In conclusion, users were generally satisfied with the e-Volution-TREAT system, although they expressed challenges related to the workload that interfered with the time to use the system. It would be premature to conclude that change in client outcomes was related to the e-Volution-TREAT system without a randomized controlled trial with outcomes compared to a control group. Future research should incorporate strategies to change the context and engage clinicians who are in a position of influence to shape change.

title: population-based cross-sectional study of colorectal cancer screening practices of first-degree relatives of patients with colorectal cancer.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The aim of this study was to determine the proportions and predictors of first-degree relatives (FDRs) of colorectal cancer (CRC) patients (i) who ever received any CRC testing and (ii) received CRC screening of according to CRC screening guidelines. METHODS: Colorectal cancer patients and their FDRs were recruited through the population-based Victorian Cancer Registry, Victoria, Australia. Seven hundred and seven FDRs completed telephone interviews. Of these, 405 FDRs were considered asymptomatic and suitable for analysis. RESULTS: Sixty-nine percent of FDRs had received any CRC testing. Older first-degree relatives, those with private health insurance, siblings, and FDRs who had ever been asked about a family history of CRC by a physician were significantly more likely than their counterparts to have been tested for CRC. Twenty-five percent of FDRs "at or slightly above average risk" adhered to the CRC screening guidelines. For this group, adherence to guideline-recommended screening was significantly more likely for male FDRs and those with a higher level of education. For people at "moderately increased risk" and "potentially high risk," 47% and 49%, respectively, adhered to CRC screening guidelines. For this group, guideline-recommended screening was significantly more likely for FDRs who lived in metropolitan areas, had siblings, were married or in a relationship, and were ever asked about a family history of CRC. CONCLUSIONS: A significant level of noncompliance with screening guidelines was evidenced among FDRs. Better CRC detection according to guidelines and effective systematic interventions are needed to increase detection rates among population groups experiencing inequality. TESTING REGISTRY: Australia and New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry: ACTRN12609000628246.

title: primary care nurse-led walking intervention in older adults: PACE (Pedometer Accelerometer Consultation Assessment) - elevation cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Brisk walking in older people can increase step count and moderate-to-vigorous intensity physical activity (MVPA) in periods of >/= 10 minutes, as recommended in World Health Organization guidelines. Previous interventions reported increases in step count but no changes in objectively measured MVPA in older people. We evaluated whether a complex intervention performed by primary care nurses increased objectively measured step counts and MVPA. METHODS AND FINDINGS: A total of 988 people aged 60 to 75 years, able to walk further and randomly selected from three UK family practices, were invited to participate in a two-arm parallel group randomized trial; random assignment was by household. -ninety-eight people from 250 households were randomized between 2011 and 2012;" 150 individuals to intervention group, 148 to usual care control group. Intervention participants received four regular care nursing physical activity (PA) consultations for 3 months, incorporating behavior change techniques, pedometer step counting and accelerometer PA intensity feedback, and an individual PA diary and plan.Assessors were not blinded to group status, but statistical analyzes were blinded.The primary outcome was change in mean daily step count assessed by accelerometry between baseline and 3 months, with change at 12 months being a secondary outcome.Other secondary outcomes were change from baseline in time in MVPA weekly in episodes of >/= 10 minutes, accelerometer counts and counts/minute at 3 months and 12 months. Reported were adverse events, anthropometric measurements, mood, and pain. Qualitative assessments by intervention participants and practice nurses assessed the acceptability of the intervention. At 3 months, eight participants withdrew or were lost to follow-up, 280 (94%) provided primary outcome data. At 3 months, the changes in both average daily steps and weekly MVPA in sessions of >/= 10 minutes were significantly greater in the intervention group than in the control group: at 1037 (95% CI 513 -1560) steps/day and 63 (95% CI 40-87) minutes/week, respectively. At 12 months, the corresponding differences were 609 (95% CI 104-1115) steps/day and 40 (95% CI 17-63) minutes/week. Counts and counts/minute showed similar effects to steps and MVPA. Adverse events, anthropometry, mood, and pain were similar in the two groups. Participants and practice nurses found the intervention acceptable and enjoyable. CONCLUSIONS: The PACE-Lift trial increased both step count and objectively measured MVPA in episodes of ≥ 10 minutes in people aged 60 to 75 years at 3 and 12 months, with no effect on adverse events. To our knowledge, this is the first trial in this age group to demonstrate objective increases in MVPA and highlights the value of individualized support incorporating objective assessment of PA in a primary care setting. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Controlled-Trials.com ISRCTN42122561.

title: process to develop a community consensus regarding the diagnosis and management of attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder
abstract: Large discrepancies remain between pediatricians' practice patterns and the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) guidelines for the evaluation and treatment of children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Several studies raise additional concerns about access to ADHD treatment for girls, blacks, and poorer people. Barriers can occur at multiple levels, including identification and referral by school personnel, parent help-seeking behavior, medical provider diagnosis, treatment decisions, and acceptance of treatment. Such findings confirm the importance of establishing appropriate mechanisms to ensure that children of both sexes and all socioeconomic, racial, and ethnic groups receive appropriate assessment and treatment. The AAP ADHD Toolkit publication provides resources to help implement ADHD guidelines in clinical practice. These resources address a number of barriers to office implementation, including unfamiliarity with the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders criteria, difficulty identifying comorbidities, and inadequate knowledge of effective coding practices. Also crucial to the success of improved processes within clinical practice is community collaboration in care, particularly collaboration with the educational system. Such collaboration addresses other barriers to good care, such as pressures from parents and schools to prescribe stimulants, cultural biases that may prevent schools from screening children for ADHD or may prevent families from seeking medical care, and inconsistencies in recognition and referral between schools in the same system. Collaboration can also create efficiencies in data collection and communications between the doctor and the school, reducing non-face-to-face (and therefore non-reimbursable) elements of care for doctors. This article describes a process used in Guilford County, North Carolina, to develop a consensus among health care providers, educators, and children's advocates regarding the evaluation and treatment of children with symptoms of ADHD. . The result, a community protocol followed by school personnel and community physicians for more than 10 years, ensures communication and collaboration between educators and physicians in the evaluation and treatment of children with ADHD symptoms. This protocol has the potential to increase the efficiency of practice, improve standards of practice for children with ADHD, and improve identification of children in schools. Perhaps most importantly, the community process through which the protocol was developed and implemented has an educational component that increases school personnel's knowledge of ADHD and its treatment, increasing the likelihood that referrals will be appropriate and likelihood that children will benefit from coordination. of interventions between school personnel, physicians, and parents. The protocol reflects a consensus of school personnel and community health care providers regarding the following: (1) "ideal principles of assessment and management of ADHD"; (2) a common point of entry (a team) into schools for children who need evaluation for inattentiveness and behavior problems, whether the problems are first presented to a medical provider, the behavioral health system, or the school; (3) a protocol followed by the school system , that recognizes the resource limitations of schools but meets the needs of community health care providers for classroom observations, psychoeducational testing, parent-teacher behavior rating scales, and functional assessment; (4) a information packet on each child determined to need a medical evaluation; (5) a contact person or team at each physician's office to receive the information packet e school and direct you to the appropriate physician; (6) an evaluation process that investigates comorbidities and applies appropriate diagnostic criteria; (7) evidence-based interventions; (8) processes for follow-up monitoring of children after the establishment of a treatment plan; (9) roles of core stakeholders (school personnel, physicians, school nurses, and mental health professionals) in the assessment, management, and follow-up of children with attention problems; (10) forms to collect and exchange information at each step; (11) key processes and contacts for the communication flow at each step; and (12) a plan to educate health professionals and schools about the new processes. A replication of the community process, initiated in Forsyth County, North Carolina, in 2001, provides insight into the role of the AAP ADHD Guidelines in facilitating the development of a community consensus protocol. This replication also draws attention to identification and referral barriers at the school level. The following recommendations, drawn from the 2 community processes, describe the role of clinicians in collaborative community care for children with ADHD symptoms. (1) Achieve consensus with the school system regarding the role of school personnel in collecting data for children with learning and behavior problems; components to consider include (a) vision and hearing screenings, (b) school/academic history, (c) classroom observation by a counselor, (d) parent-teacher behavior rating scales ( Vanderbilt, Conner, or Achenbach scales), (e) consideration of speech/language assessment, (f) intelligence screening tests, (g) achievement screening tests, (h) comprehensive intelligence and achievement if discrepancies are apparent on abbreviated tests, and (i) tests of classroom interventions (2) Use pediatric office visits to identify children with academic or behavioral problems and symptoms of inattention (history or questionnaire) (3) Refer identified children to the contact person at each child's school, requesting information according to community consensus (4) Designate a contact person to receive school materials it is for practice tic (5) Review school packet and incorporate school data into clinical assessment. (6) Reinforce with parents and the school the need for multimodal intervention, including academic and study strategies for the classroom and home, in-depth psychological testing of children whose discrepancies between cognitive level and performance suggest disabilities learning or language impairments and the need for an individualized education plan (special education), consideration of “other health issues” designation as an alternative route to an individualized education plan or 504 plan (classroom accommodations), behavior modification techniques for specific behavior problems and medication trials, as indicated . (7) Refer the patient to a mental health professional if evaluation suggests coexisting conditions. (8) Use communication forms to share information about medications and diagnoses, recommended interventions, and follow-up plans with the school and family. (9) Receive follow-up reports requested by teachers and parents and make adjustments in therapy as indicated by the child's functioning in specific areas. (10) Maintain communication with the school and parents, especially at times of transition (e.g., beginning and end of the school year, changing schools, times of family stress, times of change in administration, adolescence, and entering college or the workforce).

title: multicentre prospective study of a pneumonia practice guideline
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To study the effect of a length of stay practice guideline on patient outcomes. DESIGN: A prospective, nonrandomized intervention trial. SETTING: Six hospitals distributed geographically. PATIENTS: Two hundred and forty-two "low risk" patients consecutively hospitalized with pneumonia. MEASUREMENTS AND RESULTS: One hundred and fifty-two patients (63%) completed the post-discharge survey by mail and were included in the analysis. Data were collected prospectively for 85 patients in the initial observation period (B) and 67 patients in the intervention period (I). During I, case managers provided clinicians with information about patient risks based on guideline recommendations. There were no significant changes in guideline compliance (B vs I: 76.5% vs 83.6%";" p=0.32) or length of stay (B vs I: 3.5 days [interval 95% confidence interval, 3.2 to 3.8] vs. 3.6 days [95% confidence interval, 3.3 to 4.0]). Furthermore, there were no statistically significant effects of the intervention on patient outcomes, post-discharge care, and patient satisfaction scores. CONCLUSION: Patients in this study often had shorter stays than recommended by practice guidelines. This suggests that the external environment may have had a greater effect on physician behavior and length of stay than the practice guideline itself. In addition, it demonstrates the importance of continuous evaluation of medical practices immediately before, during and after the application of the clinical practice guideline.

title: protocol for the pharmacological treatment of major depression. A field test of a potential prototype
abstract: BACKGROUND: Much attention is being paid to the development of clinical practice guidelines for the treatment of mental health disorders. The objective of this study was to test in the field a prototype protocol for the pharmacological treatment of Major Depression. METHOD: The protocol consisted of four six-week treatment phases with critical options in therapy defined by MADRS (Montgomery Asberg Depression Rating Scale) scores. Observational data collected on the performance of the protocol in terms of relevance, acceptability, ease of use, and efficacy. RESULTS: The efficacy of the protocol was good for those patients who remained within it, with three quarters of them achieving remission. However, more than half of all patients dropped out of care, and adverse events were the most common reason for this. CONCLUSION: The protocol for the treatment of Major Depression was shown to be relevant, easy to use and potentially effective. LIMITATION: Issues of noncompliance by both clinicians and patients posed significant challenges to protocol design. Such difficulties demonstrate the need to field test any proposed design, as preconceived ideas about the performance of a protocol may be misplaced. CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE: The tested protocol represents progress toward the goal of developing optimal strategies for the use of pharmacotherapeutic agents in the treatment of depression.

title: qualitative assessment of the barriers and facilitators to the implementation of the WHO surgical safety checklist in hospitals in England: lessons from the surgical checklist implementation project
abstract: Objectives: To assess how the World Health Organization (WHO) surgical safety checklist was implemented in hospitals in England; identify barriers and facilitators to implementation; and extract lessons to implement improvement initiatives in surgery/medical care in general. Background: The WHO checklist has been linked to better surgical outcomes and teamwork, but we know little about the factors that affect its successful adoption. Methods: A longitudinal study of interviews with operating theater staff in a representative sample of 10 hospitals in England was conducted between March 2010 and March 2011. Interviews were audio recorded by telephone. Interviewees were asked about their experience of how the checklist was introduced and the factors that hindered or helped this process. The transcripts were subjected to thematic analysis. Results: A total of 119 interviews were completed. Checklist implementation varied widely between and within hospitals, from pre-planned/staged approaches to the checklist simply 'showing up' in operating rooms, or staff felt it had been imposed. Most of the barriers to implementation were specific to the checklist itself (for example, perceived design issues), but also included problematic integration into pre-existing processes. The most common barrier was resistance from experienced clinicians. Facilitators revealed some positive steps that can be taken to prevent/address these barriers, for example modifying the checklist, providing education/training, feeding back local data, fostering strong leadership (particularly at the support level), and instilling accountability. Conclusions: We identified common themes that helped or hindered the introduction of the WHO checklist in England and translated these into recommendations to guide the implementation of improvement initiatives in surgery and wider healthcare systems.

title: qualitative study to understand the inconsistent use of imaging guidelines to stage incident prostate cancer.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Approximately half of veterans with low-risk prostate cancer receive images that are inconsistent with guidelines. Our aim was to identify and describe (1) clinicians' knowledge, attitudes, and practices related to the use of imaging to stage prostate cancer, (2) patient attitudes and behaviors related to the use of imaging, and (3) compare responses at three VA Medical Centers (VAMC). METHODS: A qualitative approach was used to explore patient and provider knowledge and behaviors regarding the use of images. We conducted 39 semi-structured interviews in total, including 22 interviews with newly diagnosed prostate cancer patients and 17 interviews with physicians caring for them, between September 2014 and July 2015 at three VAMCs representing a spectrum of inadequate imaging indices. After identifying the core theoretical concepts, the Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF) was selected to explore the links between the themes within the dataset and the existing domains within the framework. The interviews were audio recorded, transcribed verbatim, and then coded and analyzed using Nvivo software. RESULTS: Patient interview topics were classified into four TDF domains. Patients reported little interest in staging compared to disease management (goals), and many could not remember if they had images (knowledge). Patients tended to trust their doctor to make decisions about appropriate tests (beliefs about abilities). Some patients expressed minor concern about radiation exposure, but anxiety about cancer outcomes outweighed these fears (excitement). Physician interview topics were categorized into five TDF domains. Most clinicians reported knowing and trusting imaging guidelines (knowledge), although some are likely to follow their own intuition, either due to clinical suspicion or years of experience (beliefs about capabilities). In addition, physicians reported that medicolegal concerns, fear of missing associated diagnoses (beliefs about consequences), the influence of colleagues who frequently take images (social influences), and the facility where they practice influence rates of images (environmental context). CONCLUSIONS: Interviews with patients and physicians suggest that physicians are the primary (and in some cases the only) decision makers regarding imaging staging for prostate cancer. This finding suggests that a physician-led intervention may be the most effective strategy for improving guideline-consistent imaging of prostate cancer.

title: quality improvement intervention to address provider behavior related to utilization of the CA-MRSA guidelines
abstract: AIMS AND OBJECTIVES: To assess the impact of a provider-focused quality improvement educational intervention on appropriate prescribing for community-associated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection. BACKGROUND: Patient, provider, and health system factors contribute to the appropriate prescription of antibiotics. Achieving an adequate prescription is essential to reduce the burden of antibiotic resistance. Knowledge of appropriate prescribing for community-associated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection is the first step in shifting prescriber behavior toward evidence-based recommendations. DESIGN: Quality Improvement Project. METHOD: Following a review of best practice guidelines and application of the Stetler Research Utilization model, a brief educational intervention was delivered using PowerPoint speech. Elements of the educational intervention included indications for screening, focusing particularly on the role of watch and wait after culture for simple abscesses. The intervention was delivered in a for-profit, nonacademic urgent care setting and assessed the knowledge and practice of prescribing providers. RESULTS: Of the 48 medical providers, physician assistants, and nurse practitioners, 18 (37.5%) participated";" 12 of the 18 (67%) participants showed an increase in knowledge. Forty-three percent of prescriber charts demonstrated improved practice through use of the guidelines. Of 18 prescribers, 44% submitted a total of 21 abscess cultures. There was no difference in practice behaviors between the professional groups. CONCLUSIONS: Despite the increase in knowledge scores, this improvement in knowledge did not translate into a dramatic change in practice, although trends in a positive direction were observed. RELEVANCE TO CLINICAL PRACTICE: This quality improvement project highlights the complexity of changing prescriber behavior and the need for ongoing interventions.

title: Quantitative Method for Assessing Prescription Patterns Using Electronic Health Records
abstract: BACKGROUND: Most quality indicators available for hospitals are represented by simple ratios or proportions and are limited to specific events. A generalized method that can be applied to various clinical events has not been developed. The aim of this study was to develop a simple method to assess physicians' prescribing patterns for various events and their level of knowledge of clinical practice guidelines. METHODS AND FINDINGS: We developed a quantitative method called Prescribing Pattern Around Clinical Event (PACE), which is applicable to electronic health records (EHRs). Three discrete prescribing patterns (intervention, maintenance, and discontinuation) were determined from the prescription change index (PCI), which was calculated as the increase or decrease in the prescription rate following a clinical event. Hyperkalaemia and Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea (CDAD) were used as example cases. We calculated the PCIs of 10 drugs related to hyperkalemia, classified them into prescribing patterns, and then compared the resulting prescribing patterns with known standards for the treatment of hyperkalemia. Physicians' knowledge of hyperkalaemia was estimated using a questionnaire and compared with the prescription pattern. Prescriptions for CDAD were also determined and compared with clinical knowledge. Clinical data from 1698, 348 and 1288 patients were collected from EHR data. Physicians' prescribing behaviors for hyperkalaemia and CDAD were consistent with standard knowledge. Prescribing patterns correlated well with individual physicians' knowledge of hyperkalemia (kappa = 0.714). Prescribing behaviors according to event severity or clinical condition were plotted as a simple summary graph. CONCLUSION: The algorithm successfully evaluated prescription patterns from the EHR data. Prescribing patterns correlated well with physician knowledge. We hope that this algorithm will allow the quantification of prescribers' adherence to clinical guidelines and be used to facilitate better prescribing practices.

title: randomized clinical trial of a personalized lifestyle intervention for obese, sedentary and primary care patients
abstract: PURPOSE: The aim of the study was to test a personalized lifestyle intervention to help obese primary care patients achieve weight loss and increase physical activity. METHODS: We conducted a 24-month randomized clinical trial in Rhode Island. Primary care physicians identified obese, sedentary patients motivated to lose weight and increase their moderate to vigorous physical activity. These patients were randomized to 1 of 2 experimental groups: enhanced intervention (EI) or standard intervention (SI). Both groups received 3 face-to-face weight loss meetings. The enhanced intervention group also received counseling telephone calls, personalized print materials, and DVDs focused on diet and physical activity. Active intervention occurred at year 1 with a gradual maintenance phase at year 2. RESULTS: 211 obese and sedentary patients were recruited from 24 primary care practices. The participants were 79% women and 16% minorities. They had a mean age of 48.6 years, with a mean body mass index (BMI) of 37.8 kg/m(2) and 21.2 minutes/week of moderate to vigorous physical activity. Significantly more EI participants lost 5% of their initial weight than SI participants (per visit group, P < .001). The difference was significant during active treatment at 6 months (37.2% IS vs. 12.9% SI) and at 12 months (47.8% vs. 11.6%), but ceased to be significant during maintenance phase at 18 months (31.4% vs. 26.7%). or 24 months (33.3% vs 24.6%). The IS group reported significantly more minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity over time than the SI group (per visit group, P = 0.04). The differences in minutes per week at 6 months was 95.7 for the IS group vs. 68.3 minutes for the SI group”; at 12 months it was 126.1 vs 73.7”; at 18 months 103.7 vs 63.7 and at 24 months 101.3 vs 75.4. Similar trends were found for absolute weight loss and the percentage meeting national physical activity guidelines. CONCLUSION: A home-based personalized lifestyle intervention in obese and sedentary primary care patients was effective in promoting weight loss and increasing moderate-to-vigorous physical activity, with effects peaking at 12 months but decrease at 24 months.

title: randomized controlled trial of a drug use review intervention for sedative-hypnotic medications
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Both the public and private sectors use medication use review to influence patients' prescribing behavior and medication use. Previous interventions mailed to prescribers have had mixed results. The objective was to assess the effect of a single mailed intervention on subsequent use of sedative-hypnotic medication. METHODS: An experimental design was used. The intervention contained guidelines for the use of sedative-hypnotics, a prescriber profile detailing the prescription of sedative-hypnotics, and a patient profile. Pooling of patients and their shared prescribers was done to avoid contamination bias and statistical problems associated with lack of independence of observations. Subjects were 189 Washington State Medicaid recipients who had received at least one tablet per day of a sedative-hypnotic medication for 1 year and their prescribing physicians or (when physician information was missing) dispensing pharmacy. RESULTS: A significant reduction in the use of targeted sedative-hypnotic medications was measured in the intervention group (-27.6%) versus the control group (-8.5%). In the intervention group, 9.4% of patients started a new prescription for a benzodiazepine not covered in the drug use review, whereas no control patients had a new use of a benzodiazepine not covered. CONCLUSIONS: The intervention achieved a statistically significant decrease in targeted drug use, and the amount of reduction is likely to have decreased the risk of fractures associated with benzodiazepine use. This study adds to recent evidence that mail-order medication use review interventions can have a desirable impact on patients' medication use.

title: randomized controlled trial of an extensive lifestyle management intervention (ELMI) after cardiac rehabilitation: study design and baseline data
abstract: BACKGROUND: Cardiac rehabilitation programs (CRPs) represent comprehensive interventions that are generally limited to four months. After completing CRP, it appears that risk factors and lifestyle behaviors may deteriorate. The Extensive Lifestyle Management Intervention (ELMI) Post Cardiac Rehabilitation trial will investigate the benefits of a randomized intervention to prevent these adverse changes. METHODS: Patients with ischemic heart disease (IHD) were randomized following standard CRP to ELMI or usual care. The ELMI program is a case management intervention aimed at individualizing risk factor and lifestyle management based on current treatment guidelines. The program consists of cardiac rehabilitation sessions, telephone follow-up, and risk factor and lifestyle counseling sessions. Health professionals work with participants through behavioral counseling and communications with participants' family physicians. Usual care participants return to the care of their family physicians and come to the study clinic only for an annual outcome evaluation. The primary outcome is the change in the global risk of ischemic heart disease after four years. Secondary outcomes include composite cardiovascular events, health care utilization, lifestyle adherence, quality of life, and risk factors. RESULTS: Over 28 months, 302 men and women were randomized. This represented 29% of the total population examined. The average age of study participants is 64 years, 18% are women, 53% have had a prior myocardial infarction, 73% have undergone prior revascularization, and 20% have diabetes mellitus. Ischemic heart disease risk factors for the entire cohort improved significantly after subjects had undergone previous CPAs. Baseline risk factors, lifestyle behaviors, and medications were similar between groups. CONCLUSIONS: This study population is representative of patients who complete a standard PCR. The results of the ELMI trial will provide valuable information for future CRP design.

title: randomized controlled trial of IVR-based brief alcohol intervention to promote patient-provider communication in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Brief interventions for unhealthy alcohol use in primary care settings are effective but underused. Efforts to improve brief intervention rates through provider education and redesign of office systems have had limited impact. Our novel brief intervention uses interactive voice response (IVR) to provide information and advice directly to unhealthy drinkers prior to a doctor's office visit, with the goal of stimulating office dialogue about alcohol use and decreasing alcohol consumption. unhealthy consumption. This automated approach is potentially scalable for wide application. OBJECTIVE: Our objective was to examine the effect of a pre-visit IVR-delivered brief alcohol intervention (IVR-BI) on patient-provider conversations about alcohol during the visit. DESIGN: This was a parallel group randomized controlled trial with two treatment arms: 1) IVR-BI or 2) usual care (no IVR-BI). PARTICIPANTS: In total, 1567 patients were recruited from eight internal medicine and family medicine clinics affiliated with university medical centers. INTERVENTIONS: IVR-BI is a brief alcohol intervention provided by automated telephone. It has four components, based on the intervention steps outlined in the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism guidelines for clinicians: 1) ask about alcohol use, 2) assess for alcohol use disorders, 3) counsel the patient reduce or stop drinking, and 4) follow-up at subsequent visits. MAIN MEASURES: Outcomes were patient-reported: provider-patient discussion about alcohol during visit"; patient initiation of discussion;" and the provider's recommendation regarding the patient's alcohol consumption. KEY FINDINGS: Patients randomized to BI-IVR were more likely to have reported discussing alcohol with their provider (52% vs. 44%, p = 0.003) and mentioned the topic themselves (20% vs. 12% , p < 0.001), and receiving a recommendation (20% vs. 14%, p < 0.001). Other predictors of outcome included baseline consumption, education, age, and diagnosis of alcohol use disorder. CONCLUSIONS: Providing brief automated interventions to patients prior to a primary care visit promotes discussion of unhealthy alcohol use and increases specific professional advice on changing drinking behavior.

title: randomized controlled trial to evaluate the effectiveness of an asthma distance learning program for pediatricians
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To assess the provider acceptability of a distance learning program for pediatric asthma and to test its effects on clinicians' knowledge, attitudes, and treatment practices. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. SETTING: Louisville and surrounding central Kentucky. PARTICIPANTS: Twenty-four pediatricians in clinical practice. Interventions. A distance learning program for pediatric asthma consisting of CD-ROM or Web-based multimedia learning modules and two teleconference calls. OUTCOME MEASURES: Student satisfaction and change in physician's asthma management knowledge, attitudes, and behavior at 1 to 4 months (short-term) and 6 to 8 months (long-term). RESULTS: Pediatricians had graduated from medical school a mean of 11.6 years before baseline (SD +/-8.9)";" 56% were women. For all student satisfaction items, the average score was 4.0 or higher on a 5-point scale, indicating a favorable response from the participants. Participants in the education group reported greater familiarity with the asthma guideline for prescribing daily inhaled corticosteroids compared with control physicians (p = 0.03) at short-term follow-up. Participants also expressed greater confidence in selecting a medication for patients requiring a low-dose inhaled steroid (p = 0.03). However, these differences were not seen at long-term follow-up. Compared to the control group, there was no significant increase in the proportion of patients receiving inhaled steroids for persistent asthma at short-term or long-term follow-up. CONCLUSIONS: Pediatricians using an asthma distance learning program expressed a high degree of student satisfaction. The program was associated with a temporary increase in familiarity and confidence in implementing the components of the asthma guidelines.

title: randomized controlled trial to improve lymph node assessment in stage II colon cancer
abstract: HYPOTHESIS: Physicians appear to learn best from their peers, but the impact of opinion leaders on physician behavior is unclear. Because colon cancer staging has been identified as suboptimal in Ontario, Canada, we sought to assess the influence of local colon cancer experts and opinion leaders in optimizing colon cancer lymph node evaluation. colon. DESIGN, SETTING, PARTICIPANTS: A cluster-randomized trial including all hospitals in Ontario that identified a local opinion leader with intervention between January 5 and June 17, 2004. INTERVENTION: All 42 centers received a standardized conference on colon cancer lymph node evaluation from colon cancer expert opinion leader. The 21 intervention hospitals also received academic details from a local opinion leader by the expert opinion leader and a toolkit. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: The mean number of lymph nodes assessed in patients with stage II colon cancer and the proportion of cases staged with a minimum of 12 lymph nodes before and after a standardized conference were evaluated. RESULTS: Patient demographics and tumor factors were similar in both groups before and after the standardized conference. Lymph node assessment was significantly improved after standardized conference at intervention and control sites (P < 0.001). No additional benefit was shown from the provision of academic tools and details in the intervention. CONCLUSIONS: The provision of information in person by an expert opinion leader in colon cancer can stimulate performance regarding the evaluation of lymph nodes for colon cancer. Academic details from a local opinion leader did not further improve the lymph node assessment.

title: randomized outpatient trial of a decision support information technology tool.
abstract: Background Decision support information technology is often adopted to improve clinical decision making, but is rarely rigorously evaluated. Congress mandated the evaluation of Problem-Knowledge Couplers (PKC Corp, Burlington, Vt), a proposed decision-support tool for the Department of Defense's new health information network. Methods This was a patient-level randomized trial conducted in 2 military practices. A total of 936 patients were assigned to the intervention group and 966 to usual care. The couplers were applied prior to routine outpatient clinic visits. The primary outcome was quality of care, which was assessed based on the total percentage of any of the 24 health care quality process measures (opportunities to provide evidence-based care) that were met. Secondary outcomes included medical resources consumed within 60 days of enrollment and patient and provider satisfaction. Results There were 4,639 medical care opportunities (2,374 in the Coupler group and 2,265 in the usual care group), with no difference in the proportion of opportunities fulfilled (33.9% vs. 30.7%";" P = 0.12 ). Although there was a modest improvement in performance on screening/prevention measures, this was offset by poorer performance on some acute care measures. Coupled patients used more laboratory and pharmacy resources than usual care patients (mean log difference, $71). No difference in patient satisfaction was seen between groups, and provider satisfaction was mixed. Conclusion This study does not provide strong evidence to support the usefulness of this decision support tool, but it does demonstrate the value of a rigorous evaluation of decision support information technology.

title: randomized trial of "corollary orders" to avoid errors of omission.
abstract: Objective: Errors of omission are a common cause of system failure. Doctors often do not order the tests or treatments needed to monitor/improve the effects of other tests or treatments. The authors hypothesized that automated guideline-based reminders for physicians, provided as they wrote orders, might reduce these omissions. Design: The study was conducted in the general medicine hospitalization ward of a public university hospital. Faculty and interns at the Indiana University School of Medicine, who used computer workstations to type orders, were randomly assigned to intervention and control groups. As the intervening physicians wrote orders for 1 of 87 selected tests or treatments, the computer suggested the corollary orders needed to detect or ameliorate adverse reactions to the triggering orders. Physicians could accept or reject these suggestions. Results: During the 6-month trial, corollary order reminders were presented to 48 intervention physicians and withheld from 41 control physicians. Intervention physicians ordered the suggested corollary orders in 46.3% of cases when reminded, compared with 21.9% compliance by control physicians (p < 0.0001). Physicians were discriminating in their acceptance of suggested orders, readily accepting some and rejecting others. There were a third fewer pharmacist-initiated interventions with physicians in the intervention than in the control groups. Conclusion: This study demonstrates that physician workstations, linked to a comprehensive electronic medical record, can be an effective means of reducing errors or omissions and improving adherence to practice guidelines.

title: randomized trial of a computer-based intervention to reduce the use of redundant laboratory tests.
abstract: PURPOSE: To determine the impact of giving clinicians computerized reminders about seemingly redundant clinical laboratory tests. SUBJECTS AND METHODS: We conducted a prospective randomized controlled trial that included all patients hospitalized in a large university hospital over a 15-week period. The intervention consisted of computerized reminders at the time a test that appeared to be redundant was ordered. The main outcome measures were the proportions of clinical laboratory orders that were canceled and the proportion of tests that were actually performed. RESULTS: During the study period, there were 939 apparently redundant laboratory tests among the 77,609 study tests that were ordered between the intervention (n = 5,700 patients) and control (n = 5,886 patients) groups. In the intervention group, 69% (300 of 437) of tests were canceled in response to reminders. Of 137 overrides, 41% appeared to be justified based on chart review. In the control group, 51% of the ordered redundant tests were performed, whereas in the intervention group only 27% of the ordered redundant tests were performed (P < 0.001). However, the estimated annual savings in lab fees was only $35,000. This occurred because only 44% of the redundant tests performed had computer commands, because only half of the computer commands were checked for redundancy, and because nearly one-third of the reminders were overridden. CONCLUSIONS: Reminders about apparently redundant lab test orders were effective when delivered. However, the overall effect was limited because many tests were performed without corresponding computer commands and many commands were not checked for redundancy.

title: randomized trial of computerized reminders and audit and feedback to improve HIV screening in a primary care setting.
abstract: Despite recommendations for voluntary HIV testing, few medical centers have implemented screening programs. The objective of the study was to determine whether a computer-based reminder and feedback intervention would increase HIV screening in a Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) health care system. The study design was a randomized controlled trial at five primary care clinics in the VA Palo Alto Health Care System. All primary care providers were eligible to participate in the study. The study intervention consisted of computer-based reminders to assess HIV risk behaviors or offer HIV testing"; feedback was provided on adherence to the reminders. The main outcome measure was the difference in HIV testing rates. HIV between intervention and control providers Control group providers assessed 1.0% (n = 67) and 1.4% (n = 106) of patients in the preintervention and intervention period , respectively;" intervention providers evaluated 1.8% (n=98) and 1.9% (n=114), respectively (P=0.75). In our random sample of 753 unscreened patients, 204 (27%) had documented risk behaviors. Providers were more likely to adhere to reminders to take the test than reminders to take the risk assessment (11% versus 5%, P < 0.01). Sixty-one percent of providers felt that a lack of time prevented risk assessment. In conclusion, in primary care consultations in our setting, HIV detection rates were low. Providers were unaware of the high rates of risk behaviors in their patient population and perceived significant barriers to testing. Low-intensity clinical reminders and feedback did not increase detection rates.

title: randomized trial of computerized reminders for blood pressure screening in primary care.
abstract: In a randomized controlled trial (N = 8298), the authors compared three ways of encouraging patients in a large family practice to have their blood pressure checked. Working from computerized medical records at a family medicine teaching center, the study included patients aged 18 and older who had not had their blood pressure measured in the previous year. In a normal-care control group, 21.1% of those due for a blood pressure reading got one during the trial year. In one intervention group, a computer-generated message reminded the doctor to check the blood pressure of patients visiting the center for an appointment; 30.7% of the patients assigned to this group were controlled. In the second group, the nurse contacted patients by phone and encouraged 24.1% of those due for a checkup to get one. Sending a letter to patients in the third group yielded a 35.7% compliance rate. Considering the costs of the three interventions, the medical reminder was the most expensive. cash, followed by the letter reminder. Although statistically significant, the impact of reminders was modest. A better approach might involve a combination of routine reminders to the doctor, followed by letters to noncompliant patients.

title: randomized trial of electronic clinical reminders to improve the quality of care for diabetes and coronary artery disease.
abstract: Objective: The objective of this study was to assess the impact of a patient-specific, integrated electronic clinical reminder system on diabetes and coronary artery disease (CAD) care and to assess clinicians' attitudes toward this system. reminder. Design: We enrolled 194 primary care physicians caring for 4,549 patients with diabetes and 2,199 patients with CAD at 20 outpatient clinics. Clinics were randomized so that physicians received evidence-based electronic reminders within their patients' electronic medical record or usual care. There were five reminders for diabetes care and four reminders for DKA care. Measurements: The primary outcome was receiving recommended care for diabetes and CAD. We created a summary outcome to assess the odds of increased adherence to general diabetes care (based on five measures) and general CAD care (based on four measures). We surveyed physicians to assess attitudes toward the reminder system. Results: Adherence rates at baseline for all quality measures were low. Although electronic reminders increased the odds of recommended diabetes care (odds ratio [OR] 1.30, 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.01–1.67) and DKA (OR 1.25, CI 95% 1.01–1.55), the impact of individual reminders was variable. A total of three of nine reminders effectively increased rates of recommended care for diabetes or CAD. The majority of physicians (76%) thought reminders improved quality of care. Conclusion: An integrated electronic reminder system resulted in variable improvement in diabetes and DKA care. These improvements were often limited and quality gaps persist.

title: randomized trial of the efficacy of on-demand versus computer-activated medication decision support in primary care.
abstract: Objectives: Prescription alerts generated by computerized drug decision support (CDDS) can prevent drug-related morbidity. However, the vast majority of alerts are ignored due to clinical irrelevance. The ability to customize commercial alert systems should improve physician acceptance, as the physician can select the circumstances and types of drug alerts that are displayed. We tested the effectiveness of two approaches to personalizing medication alerts to reduce the prevalence of prescribing problems: physician-initiated decision support versus computer-driven decision support. Physicians in each study condition were able to preset levels that triggered alerts. Design: This was a cluster trial with 28 primary care physicians randomized to automated or on-demand CDDS in the MOXXI medication management system for 3,449 of their patients seen over the next 6 months. Measurements: The CDDS generated alerts for prescription problems that could be customized by level of severity. Prescribing problems included dosage errors, drug-drug interactions, age, allergy, and illness. Physicians randomly assigned to the on-demand option turned on medication review when they deemed it clinically relevant, while physicians randomized to computer-enabled decision support viewed all e-prescription alerts according to the level of severity they received. selected for prevalent problems and incidents. Administrative claims and MOXXI data were used to measure the difference in the prevalence of prescribing problems at the end of follow-up. Results: During follow-up, 50% of clinicians receiving computer-triggered alerts changed alert threshold (n = 7), and 21% of clinicians in the alert-on-demand group changed alert level (n = 7). = 3) . In the on-demand group, 4,445 prescription problems were identified, 41 (0.9%) were treated for review of requested medications and in 31 problems (75.6%) the prescription was reviewed. By comparison, 668 (10.3%) of the 6,505 prescription problems in the computer-triggered group were observed, and 81 (12.1%) were reviewed. Most alerts were ignored because the benefit was judged to outweigh the risk, the interaction was known, or the interaction was judged not to be clinically important (computer triggered: 75.8% of 585 alerts ignored; on request: 90% of 10 alerts ignored alerts). At the end of follow-up, there was a significant reduction in therapeutic duplication problems in the computer-activated group (odds ratio 0.55, p = 0.02), but there was no difference in the overall prevalence of prescription problems. Conclusion: Computer customization Triggered alert systems are more helpful in detecting and resolving prescribing problems than on-demand review, but neither approach was effective in reducing prescribing problems. New strategies are needed to maximize the use of drug decision support systems to reduce drug-related morbidity.

title: randomized trial to compare alternative educational interventions to increase colorectal cancer screening in a hard-to-reach urban minority population with health insurance
abstract: This randomized controlled trial evaluated different educational approaches to increase acceptance of colorectal cancer screening in a sample of primarily non-U.S.-born, urban minority individuals over the age of 50, with health insurance, and who are not eligible. detection guidelines. In one group, participants were mailed printed educational materials (n = 180); in a second, participants' primary care physicians received academic details to improve referral practices and screening follow-up (n = 185);" in a third, physicians received academic details and participants received personalized telephone education (n = 185); = 199). Overall, 21.5% of participants (n = 121) received an adequate assessment within one year of randomization. There were no statistically significant pairwise differences between groups in detection rate. However , among those 60 years of age or older, the details plus telephone education group had a higher detection rate than the print group (27.3 vs. 7.7%, p = 0.02). types of interventions to increase colorectal cancer screening among the shrinking segment of the population that remains unscreened ClinicalTrials.gov identifier: NCT02392143.

title: real-world staggered-cluster randomized trial of practice facilitation to improve cardiovascular care
