abstract: BACKGROUND: Practice facilitation has been associated with significant improvements in disease prevention and quality of patient care. Using practice facilitation, the Improving the Delivery of Cardiovascular Care (IDOCC) project aimed to improve evidence-based cardiovascular care delivery in primary care practices in a large health region. Our objective was to evaluate the impact of IDOCC on adherence to care processes. METHODS: A pragmatic stepped wedge-cluster randomized trial recruiting primary care providers in practices located in eastern Ontario, Canada (ClinicalTrials.gov: NCT00574808). Participants were randomly assigned by region to one of three steps. Practice facilitators were intended to visit practices every 3-4 (year 1-intensive) or 6-12 weeks (year 2-sustainability) to support practice behavior changes. The primary outcome was mean adherence to evidence-based care indicators measured at the patient level. Adherence was assessed by chart review of a randomly selected cohort of 66 patients per practice in each year prior to intervention, as well as at year 1 and year 2 post-intervention. RESULTS: 84 practices (182 physicians) participated. On average, facilitators had 6.6 (min: 2, max: 11) face-to-face practice visits in year 1 and 2.5 (min: 0, max: 10) visits in year 2. We collected data of files of 5292 patients. After adjustment for patient and provider characteristics, there was an absolute decrease of 1.9% (95% confidence interval (CI) -2.9 to -0.9%) and 4.2% ( 95% CI: -5.7 to -2.6%) in baseline mean adherence to intensive and sustainability years, respectively. CONCLUSIONS: IDOCC did not improve adherence to best practice guidelines. Our results showed a small statistically significant decrease in mean adherence of questionable clinical significance. Possible reasons for this result include implementation challenges, conflicting priorities in practices, a broad focus on multiple indicators of chronic disease, and the use of an overall adherence index. These results contrast with previously reported facilitation trial findings and highlight the complexities and challenges of translating research findings into clinical practice. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov NCT00574808.

title: research agenda for high-value palliative care
abstract: Palliative care has gone from being misunderstood and viewed with caution by many physicians to being among the most sought after services by health care systems across the country. This is the greatest possible testimony to the potential value of the field. However, with demand rapidly outstripping supply for palliative care specialists (1), the field's ability to deliver high-value care sustainably is paradoxically threatened by its own success. We propose a research agenda organized around 5 key questions about the optimal organization and allocation of limited resources in specialized palliative care to bridge the gap between workforce and patient need. The table provides important considerations and proposed approaches to address each research challenge. Amid a growing body of evidence about the potential value of specialized palliative care (2), we posit that answering these questions is essential to maximizing value and informing much-needed policies to support such care (3).

title: Resolution for Doctors: Time to Focus on the Public Health Threat of Gun Violence
A review of family intervention guidelines for acquired brain injury in pediatrics
abstract: Pediatric Acquired Brain Injury (BI) not only affects the child with the injury, but also has a major impact on their family. Studies suggest that there are higher rates of psychological distress among caregivers and siblings after a child in the family has had an IB. In addition, family functioning after BI affects the child's recovery. In the literature review, we identified seven theoretical clinical guidelines for working with families of children and adolescents with BI. These clinical guidelines are as follows: (1) select developmentally appropriate interventions, (2) match the intervention to the family, (3) provide advocacy, (4) provide injury education, (5) focus on family realignment , (6) appropriately adjust the child's environment, and (7) provide skills training to the family and child. Existing research on family interventions for BI is reviewed in the context of these theoretical guidelines, and then the empirical support for each guideline is assessed using specific criteria for empirically supported treatments. Unfortunately, very few randomized controlled studies exist and continued research is needed to classify all clinical regimens as 'effective'. Additionally, ongoing research will help inform professionals of specific approaches to use when working with a family of a child with BI. Currently, clinicians and researchers can draw on existing clinical guidelines to help address the many barriers to implementation and study of family interventions for pediatric BI.

title: review of quantitative studies on adherence to clinical practice guidelines in mental health
abstract: Mental health clinical practice guidelines have proliferated, but there is little evidence on the degree to which they are actually implemented in clinical practice. The objective of this study was to locate and review all peer-reviewed reports published up to the year 2000 that provide quantitative information on adherence rates to specific mental health guidelines. A literature search returned 41 relevant studies. These studies were of three types: 26 were cross-sectional investigations conducted after guideline publication, six were conducted before and after guideline publication without any specific intervention (pre/post), and nine involved a controlled trial of an intervention. specific. Only 37% were carried out in the mental health specialty sector. Adequate adherence was found in 27% of cross-sectional and pre/post studies, but in 67% of controlled trials. Successful interventions tended to be complex, involving system redesign or additional resources. Only six of 13 investigations (46%) that also measured patient outcome found that better outcome was associated with greater adherence to guidelines. Several studies showed that after cessation of interventions, adherence rates returned to pre-intervention levels. Thus, the evidence indicates that guideline adherence is not high without a specific intervention, but that certain interventions (typically multifaceted and resource-intensive) improve adherence. However, the public health challenge is to design and implement interventions that are sustainable in general clinical practice.

title: review of the evidence for suboptimal compliance of healthcare professionals with standard/universal precautions for infection control.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The review examines from international research: the extent to which professionals comply with infection control precautions; relevant issues that are considered influential on compliance; what strategies have been evaluated to instigate positive behavior change among practitioners and the effect of these interventions. BACKGROUND: Internationally, standard/universal precautions (UP) are considered essential in infection prevention and control, and effective in protecting clinicians and patients. However, adherence has been problematic and the practice of standard/UP precautions is globally suboptimal. METHODS: Literature review where relevant evidence was identified using various electronic databases, from 1994 to 2006, with the number of key terms used. The data was extracted using key headings, which facilitated analysis. RESULTS: Thirty-seven studies were evaluated. Twenty-four related to the measurement of physician compliance and 13 studies that evaluated the t The effect of a research intervention on compliance. In addition, other studies that examined specific reasons for suboptimal compliance or discussed infection control precautions in general were included. CONCLUSIONS: Compliance with infection control precautions is internationally suboptimal. Evidence confirms that adherence to specific aspects of the standards/UP varies, and practitioners are selective in applying recommended practice. Compliance improves after a structured intervention; however, the research does not indicate how long the intervention affects physician compliance, or whether compliance returns to the norm after a period of time. Various reasons for noncompliance are discussed and recommendations for future research are suggested. Relevance for clinical practice. Suboptimal compliance has significant implications for staff safety, patient protection, and the care environment. Infection control teams and investigators need to consider the reasons for noncompliance and provide a supportive environment that is conducive to routine. , long-term application of standard precautions.

title: review of the literature on remote monitoring technology in incentive-based interventions for health-related behavior change.
abstract: The use of technology (eg, the Internet, cell phones) to enable remote implementation of incentive interventions for health-related behavior change is growing. To our knowledge, a systematic review of this literature has not yet been reported. This report provides a systematic review of controlled studies in which technology was used to remotely implement financial incentive interventions targeting substance use and other health behaviors published between 2004 and 2015. For inclusion in the review, studies had to use the technology to remotely achieve 1 of the following 2 goals, alone or in combination: (a) monitor the target behavior, or (b) offer incentives to achieve the target goal. Studies also had to examine financial incentives (eg, cash, vouchers) for health-related behavior change, be published in peer-reviewed journals, and include a research design that would allow the efficacy of the intervention to be assessed. incentives in relation to another condition (eg, non-contingent incentives, usual treatment). Of the 39 reports that met the inclusion criteria, 18 targeted substance use, 10 targeted medication adherence or home health monitoring, and 11 targeted diet, exercise, or home health. weight loss. All 39 studies (100%) used technology to facilitate remote control of target behavior, and 26 (66.7%) studies also incorporated technology into remote delivery of incentives. Statistically significant intervention effects were reported in 71% of the studies reviewed. Overall, the results offer substantial support for the efficacy of remotely implemented incentive interventions for health-related behavior change, which have the potential to increase the cost-effectiveness and reach of this treatment approach. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2016 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: review on the use of laboratory tests: a trigger for cost reduction and quality improvement in health care settings
abstract: BACKGROUND: Considering the role of laboratory tests as a central part of health spending control, this study intends to investigate the overuse of laboratory tests in Iran to pave the way for future interventions. METHODS: Inappropriate laboratory use in a cross-sectional survey was reviewed through retrospective analysis of 384 medical records at a tertiary care center. To pave the way for future interventions, evidence of overuse was classified into two categories, inappropriate and inefficient, and then analyzed. Frequency analysis was used to analyze patient age, gender, hospital wards, length of stay, and diagnosis, as well as inappropriate testing and inefficient testing. RESULTS: A total of 143 (1.50%) of the tests were inefficient and were ordered by laboratory errors such as hemolysis, inefficient sampling or absurd results. 2,522 (26.40%) of the tests were inappropriate and stemmed from noncompliance with medical/clinical suitability criteria. CONCLUSION: Although inappropriate test requesting was more frequent than inefficient testing, the initial improvement strategy should focus on physicians' test requesting behavior by conducting appropriate teaching strategies, continuous auditing and educational feedback, implementing health information technology tools and using laboratory practice guidelines (LPG). ) and testing algorithms. It is recommended to carry out a cycle of continuous improvement of the quality of laboratory services and the training of personnel involved in taking blood samples for inefficient tests.

title: simple intervention to improve hospital prescription of antibiotics
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess changes in prescribing behavior after distribution of antibiotic guidelines printed on a 9 x 6 cm laminated card suitable for clipping to a hospital badge. INTERVENTION: Guidelines for the proper prescription of antibiotics for 20 common and important pediatric infections were printed on a 9 x 6 cm laminated card suitable for affixing to a hospital name tag and distributed to all medical staff. DESIGN: We collected medical record data for three marker conditions (tonsillitis, pneumonia, and orbital/periorbital cellulitis) in patient samples from the six-month periods on either side of the month in which the cards were distributed. The prescribers were unaware of the study and the researchers analyzed the prescriptions without knowing the period in which they were written. The prescriptions were classified according to the appropriate choice of antibiotic and the appropriate dose. Data on the costs of antibiotics were also collected. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Proportion of cases in which the choice of antibiotic was appropriate; proportion of cases in which the dose of the antibiotic was adequate; Annualized costs of third-generation cephalosporins. RESULTS: For tonsillitis there was little change in prescribing practice after the cards were introduced. For pneumonia, appropriate choice cases increased from 77% to 92% (P = 0.028) and appropriate dose cases increased from 48% to 81% (P = 0.001). For orbital/periorbital cellulitis, cases with the appropriate choice increased from 19% to 78% (P < 0.001), and cases with the appropriate dose increased from 30% to 51% (P = 0.11). Annualized costs for third-generation cephalosporins were $193,245 pre-cards and $89,814 post cards. CONCLUSION: The cards appeared to have a beneficial effect on prescription practice for all three marker conditions. This simple intervention is likely to be cost-effective and helpful in reducing inappropriate antibiotic use.

title: simple way to improve compliance with the DVT protocol
abstract: Objective: To assess the impact on deep vein thrombosis (DVT) protocol violations of the introduction of a label affixed to the patient's medication history, which specifically allows the prescription of subcutaneous heparin at low or medium thromboembolic deterrent doses (TEDS), as appropriate. Design: An audit study. Setting: Department of General Surgery at a District General Hospital in the UK. METHOD: All adult hospitalized general surgery patients were studied on a weekday. Staff were not made aware of the studies. Patient details and risk factors for DVT were noted. Details of DVT prophylaxis administered were recorded. In total, four separate studies were performed, namely: with original protocols (I), with refined protocol 1 and 3 years later (II, III), and finally after label introduction (IV). Results: Protocol violations were defined as "acceptable" or "unacceptable". Sensitization between Studies I and II reduced the acceptable violations to zero. There was no statistically significant reduction in unacceptable violations (24 of 80 patients, 1"; 17 of 75, II; 13 of 60, III). In study IV, after the introduction of the tag, there were only 6 violations in 51 patients (p<0.02). Conclusion: Combining increased awareness with medication box labeling reduced unacceptable violations by 63%.

title: snapshot of general practitioners' attitudes, confidence levels, and self-reported pediatric asthma management practice.
abstract: The prevalence of asthma in Australia is high. Previous findings have suggested that asthma management, particularly in primary care, remains suboptimal and recent government initiatives have been implemented to improve asthma management and encourage the use of written asthma action plans (WAAPs) in practice. general. Our aim was to assess the self-reported attitudes, confidence and practices of managing pediatric asthma in a convenience sample of Australian general practitioners (GPs). An initial questionnaire was administered to GPs as part of a randomized controlled trial. General practitioners (GPs) were recruited from two areas in the Sydney, NSW metropolitan area between 2006 and 2008. Invitations were sent to approximately 1200 potentially eligible GPs. Of 150 (12.5%) physicians who enrolled, 122 (10.2%) completed the referral questionnaire. Although 89% were aware of the Australian National Asthma Guidelines, less than 40% were familiar with the guideline recommendations. While 85.2% had positive attitudes toward WAAPs, only 45.1% reported providing them frequently. For children with frequent symptoms, 90% agreed that they should prescribe inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) every day, and 83% reported that they currently prescribe ICS to such patients. These findings indicate gaps between the attitudes and behaviors of GPs and highlight opportunities for interventions to improve pediatric asthma management.

title: statewide controlled trial intervention to reduce the use of unproven or ineffective breast cancer care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Challenged by public opinion, peers, and the Congressional Budget Office, specialty medical societies have begun developing "Top Five" lists of costly procedures that do not provide significant benefit to at least some categories of patients for which they are commonly requested. However, the extent to which these lists have influenced the behavior of physicians or patients is unknown. METHODS: We partnered with a state health systems consortium to examine the effectiveness of two interventions: (i) "basic" public reporting and (ii) an "enhanced" intervention, augmenting public reporting with a smartphone-based application that provides providers with just-in-time information, decision-making tools, and personalized patient education materials to support reductions in the use of eight breast cancer interventions targeted by Choosing Wisely(R) or guidelines of the oncology society. Our objectives are: (1) to examine whether basic public information reduces the use of targeted breast cancer practices among a contemporary cohort of incident breast cancer patients in the intervention state relative to usual care in the intervention states. comparison"; (2) examine the effectiveness of the enhanced intervention relative to the core intervention;" and (3) to simulate the cost savings resulting from the nationwide implementation of both interventions. DISCUSSION: The results will provide rigorous evidence regarding the effectiveness of a single public reporting system for all ages and all payers in influencing provider behavior that can be easily exported to other states and potentially to large systems of care as well. medical. The findings will be even more relevant to the ACO setting, which is expected to provide financial disincentives for ineffective or unproven care. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov number pending.

title: study of factors associated with cost and variation in prescribing among GPs
abstract: BACKGROUND: Inappropriate prescribing has the potential to harm both the individual and society. Previous research identified medical or demographic characteristics that influence prescription variation, but could not be changed. OBJECTIVES: To identify modifiable factors associated with variance and cost of GP prescription. METHOD: Qualitative research methods were used in semi-structured recorded interviews with 17 GPs in Avon, South West NHS Region, UK. RESULTS: GPs were considered cautious and conservative prescribers. Prescribing decisions were often justified by the prescriber, despite conflicting clinical or cost arguments. A personally developed drug formulary was used to reduce dilemmas potentially associated with prescribing uncertainty. Willingness to reflect on and measure prescribing habits against established professional standards varied considerably. The absence of mechanisms for monitoring prescribing decisions, coupled with the underuse of the community pharmacist, led to uncertain prescribing outcomes. Some clinicians found it difficult to stay professionally current due to perceived time constraints. Excessive patient demand was seen as influencing their prescription, but GPs stated that they were not unduly influenced by the drug's representative. CONCLUSIONS: Prescribing has a considerable impact on health and budgets, yet it remains a contentious issue. Better partnerships must be established between the patient, the doctor and the pharmacist. Better monitoring of prescribing decisions and support through policy development and educational intervention are needed to reduce prescribing uncertainty. Newly established Primary Care Groups may need to reflect on the difficulties prescribers face, particularly when prescribing within limited cash budgets, to avoid discord between prescribing behavior and local policy development.

title: successful experiment to reduce unnecessary laboratory use in a community hospital
abstract: series of interventions in a 228-bed general hospital provided physicians with regular information on the amount of laboratory services used to treat their patients. Laboratory test estimates adjusted for case mix allowed each physician to compare laboratory test use with that of their peers in the same department at the same hospital. Physicians with "excessive" practice patterns order hundreds more lab tests than average each year. A multifaceted educational program included the following: 1) "meetings about costs and unnecessary lab tests" were held; 2) physicians were given descriptions of their practice patterns relative to their peers as part of departmental discussions large and small; 3 ) the feedback was repeated a year later; 4) a consensus conference established guidelines for ordering tests;" and 5) a sample of patient records was reviewed to determine the appropriateness of the request for laboratory tests. A total of 37% of a sample of tests ordered during the reference period by physicians with "excessive" practice patterns were classified as inappropriate. The intervention resulted in a reduction of 1.8 tests per patient (P = 0.0005). Eight of the nine tests individually showed reductions in use. The target hospital charge data showed a statistically significant reduction in laboratory charges per patient in the quarter after the start of the program (P = 0.02) and there was no evidence of change in a group of five comparison hospitals. There was no evidence of reductions in the ordering of essential tests. These results demonstrate a cost-effective approach to reducing unnecessary costs that can be implemented in hospitals with integrated data systems.

title: Survey of Primary Care Providers' Tobacco-Related Knowledge, Attitudes, and Behaviors in Mississippi
abstract: RATIONALE: Compared to other regions of the US, Mississippi has a high prevalence of tobacco use and tobacco-related illness. This study evaluated the tobacco-related knowledge, attitudes, and intervention behaviors of family physicians, dentists, and nurse practitioners in the state of Mississippi. METHODS: The Provider Attitude Survey, an 85-item measure of tobacco-related knowledge, attitudes, and intervention behaviors, was mailed to all members of Mississippi family medicine, dentistry, and nurse practitioner professional organizations ( N=2043). RESULTS: More than one-third (n=802, 39.2%) of eligible providers responded. Only 24.3% had received training in smoking cessation and 33.7% knew the clinical practice guide of the Public Health Service. More than 90% indicated that their role was to prevent tobacco use "they felt rewarded when they helped patients quit smoking"; and they were upset and upset about the effects of tobacco on health. Physicians attended more patients than nurses or dentists. Physicians and nurses reported more self-efficacy, motivation, and readiness to treat smoking than dentists. Providers with training performed more interventions and reported more self-efficacy, readiness, and fewer barriers than those without training. Training was associated with greater increases in self-efficacy, preparedness, and intervention behaviors for dentists than for the other groups. CONCLUSIONS: Despite the high prevalence of tobacco use and tobacco-related illness in Mississippi, primary care providers in Mississippi provide smoking cessation interventions at an unacceptably low frequency relative to other regions. Training is likely to increase the frequency of intervention behaviors.

title: sustainable strategy to prevent the misuse of antibiotics for acute respiratory infections
abstract: Background More than 50% of antibiotic prescriptions are for outpatients with acute respiratory infections (ARI). Many of them are not necessary and therefore contribute both to avoidable adverse events and to pressures towards the development of bacterial resistance. Could a clinical decision support system (CDSS), introduced at the time of electronic prescription, adjust the use of antibiotics towards the agreed treatment guidelines for ARIs? Methods This is a retrospective comparison of pre-intervention (2002) and post-intervention (2003-2006) periods in two comprehensive health care systems (intervention and control). The intervention was a CDSS targeting fluoroquinolone and azithromycin"; other antibiotics remained unrestricted. 7000 outpatient visits flagged by an ARI case detection algorithm were reviewed for consistency with guidelines (antibiotic prescribed when warranted). or not prescribed when not warranted) Results 3,831 patients met the case definitions for one or more ARIs: pneumonia (537), bronchitis (2,931), sinusitis (717), and nonspecific AKI (145). received antibiotics. The relative risk (RR) of consistent prescribing was 2.57 (95% CI = ? (1.865 to 3.540) in favor of the intervention site for CDSS target antibiotics;" consistency did not change for other antibiotics ( Adjusted RR=?1.18 (95% CI?=?(0.691 to 2.011)) The proportion of unjustified prescriptions for targeted antibiotics decreased from 22% to 3%, before and after the intervention (p<0.00 01). Conclusions A CDSS was filed at the time of the almost extinguished e-prescription for the unjustified use of specific antibiotics for ARIs for four years. This intervention highlights a path toward sustainable antibiotic stewardship for outpatients with ARI.

title: systematic qualitative review of psychoeducational interventions for depression in cancer patients
abstract: PURPOSE/OBJECTIVES: To determine whether research-based recommendations can be made on the clinical management of depression in cancer patients. DATA SOURCES: Reports of scientific studies, systematic qualitative or quantitative reviews of scientific studies, and practice guidelines published between 1980 and 2000. DATA SYNTHESIS: In total, 36 pieces of evidence supported the conclusion that psychoeducational interventions benefit depressive symptoms . The evidence included two well-conducted meta-analyses and nine well-designed randomized clinical trials with large samples (N > 100). Regarding the content of the intervention, 70% of the behavioral therapy studies and 66% of the counseling studies reached conclusions that supported the hypothesis. Additionally, 58% of studies evaluating behavioral therapy or counseling in combination with cancer education had positive results. CONCLUSIONS: The evidence supports the conclusion that psychoeducational interventions reduce depressive symptoms in cancer patients and that behavioral therapy or counselling, alone or in combination with cancer education, is beneficial. IMPLICATIONS FOR NURSING PRACTICE: Nurses can select from a variety of educational, behavioral, and counseling techniques to prevent or manage depression in their patients.

title: systematic review of clinical decision support systems for antimicrobial stewardship: are we failing to adequately investigate these interventions?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Clinical decision support systems (CDSS) for antimicrobial management can help clinicians optimize antimicrobial therapy. We reviewed all of the original literature (qualitative and quantitative) to understand the current scope of CDSS for antimicrobial stewardship and discuss existing methods used to assess and report such systems. METHOD: PRISMA guidelines were followed. Medline, EMBASE, HMIC Health and Management, and Global Health databases were searched from January 1, 1980 to October 31, 2015. All primary research studies describing CDSS for antimicrobial stewardship in adults in primary or secondary care. For qualitative studies, a thematic synthesis was performed. Quality was assessed using the Integrated Quality Criteria for Review of Multiple Study Designs (ICROMS). The CDSS report was assessed against a reporting framework for the implementation of behavior change interventions. RESULTS: Fifty-eight original articles were included describing 38 independent CDSS. Most systems target antimicrobial prescribing (29/38"; 76%), are platforms integrated with electronic medical records (28/38; 74%), and have a rules-based infrastructure that supports prescription. decision making (29/38; "76%). In the assessment against the intervention reporting framework, the CDSS studies do not report consideration of non-expert end-user workflow. They have a narrow focus, such as antimicrobial selection, and use indirect outcome measures. Commitment to CDSS by physicians was poor. CONCLUSION: Further consideration of factors driving non-expert decision making should be considered when designing CDSS interventions. Future work should aim to expand CDSS beyond simply selecting appropriate antimicrobials with clear and systematic reporting frameworks for CDSS interventions developed to address current gaps identified in evidence reporting.

title: systematic review of computer-based patient record systems and quality of care: more randomized clinical trials or a broader approach?
abstract: PURPOSE: To analyze the impact of computer-based patient record systems (CBPRS) on medical practice, quality of care, and user and patient satisfaction. DATA SOURCES: Manual and electronic search in Medline, Cochrane and Embase databases. STUDY SELECTION: Selected articles were published between 2000 and March 2003. CBPRS was defined as computer software designed to be used by clinicians as a direct aid in clinical decision making. To be included, the systems must have recorded patient characteristics and provided online advice, or specific information or reminders to physicians during consultation. DATA EXTRACTION: Keywords used for the search were: electronic record, computerized record, electronic medical record, electronic patient record, patient order entry, computer-based patient system, clinical decision support systems, and clinical evaluation. . RESULTS: Twenty-six articles were selected. The use of a CBPRS was perceived favorably by physicians, with satisfaction studies being mostly positive. A positive impact of CBPRS on preventive care was seen in all three studies that examined this criterion. The 12 studies that evaluated the impact on medical practice and adherence to guidelines showed that positive experiences were as common as experiences that showed no benefit. None of the six studies looking at the impact of CBPRS on patient outcomes reported any benefit. CONCLUSIONS: CBPRS increased user and patient satisfaction, which could lead to significant improvements in healthcare practices. However, studies on the impact of CBPRS on patient outcomes and quality of care have been inconclusive. Alternative approaches that consider social, cultural, and organizational factors may be needed to assess the usefulness of CBPRS.

title: systematic review of HIV/AIDS prevention education among older adults
abstract: Through a comprehensive literature search, the authors of this systematic review identified 21 articles focused on primary prevention of HIV/AIDS for adults aged 50 years and older. The three main challenges to providing HIV/AIDS education for older adults include age discrimination by health professionals, older adults' reluctance to talk about sexuality, and their misconception of their risk of contracting HIV. Clinical guidelines for social workers, nurses, and physicians identified the importance of sharing information and assessing risk, considering cultural diversity, and designing creative delivery strategies. The three HIV/AIDS education models include group education programs delivered by social workers or other health professionals, peer education models, and one-on-one early intervention models, including HIV/AIDS testing. More outreach and research on HIV/AIDS prevention among older adults is needed.

title: systematic review of faculty development initiatives designed to improve teaching effectiveness in medical education: BEME Guideline No. 8
abstract: BACKGROUND: The preparation of health professionals for teaching is considered essential to improve the effectiveness of teaching. Although many reports describe various teacher development interventions, there is a paucity of research demonstrating their effectiveness. OBJECTIVE: To synthesize the existing evidence that answers the question: "What are the effects of teacher development interventions on the knowledge, attitudes and skills of teachers in medical education and on the institutions in which they work?" METHODS: The search, which covered the period 1980-2002, included three databases (Medline, ERIC, and EMBASE) and used the keywords: "staff development"; in-service training; medical faculty; faculty training/development ;" continuing medical education. Manual searches were also performed. Articles focused on faculty development to improve teaching effectiveness, targeting basic and clinical scientists, were reviewed. All study designs that included outcome data beyond participant satisfaction were accepted. Of the initial 2,777 abstracts, 53 articles met the review criteria. Data were extracted by six coders, using the BEME standardized coding sheet, adapted for our use. Two reviewers coded each study and coding differences were resolved by discussion. Data was synthesized using Kirkpatrick's four levels of educational outcomes. Findings were grouped by type of intervention and described by outcome levels. In addition, 8 high-quality studies were analyzed in a 'focused image'. RESULTS: Most interventions targeted practicing physicians. All reports focused on teaching improvement and interventions included workshops, seminar series, short courses, longitudinal programs and 'other interventions'. Study designs included 6 randomized controlled trials and 47 quasi-experimental studies, of which 31 used a pre-post test design. KEY POINTS: Despite methodological limitations, the teacher development literature tends to support the following results: Overall satisfaction with teacher development programs was high. Participants consistently found the programs acceptable, useful, and relevant to their goals. Participants reported positive changes in attitudes towards teacher development and teaching. Participants reported increased knowledge of educational principles and gains in teaching skills. When formal tests of knowledge were used, significant gains were shown. Changes in teacher behavior were consistently reported by participants and were also detected by students. Changes in organizational practice and student learning were not frequently investigated. However, reported changes included increased educational participation and the establishment of collegial networks. Key characteristics of effective faculty development that contributed to effectiveness included the use of experiential learning, the provision of feedback, effective peer and colleague relationships, well-designed interventions following teaching and learning principles, and the use of a diversity of educational methods within individual interventions. Methodological issues: More rigorous designs and greater use of qualitative and mixed methods are needed to capture the complexity of interventions. Newer methods of performance-based evaluation, using a variety of data sources, should be explored, and reliable and valid outcome measures should be developed. Maintenance of change over time should also be considered, as should process-oriented studies comparing different teacher development strategies. CONCLUSIONS: Teacher development activities seem highly valued by participants, who also report changes in learning and behavior. Despite methodological limitations in the literature, certain program characteristics appear to be consistently associated with effectiveness. More research is required to explore these associations and document the results, at the individual and organizational levels.

title: personalized intervention to implement guideline recommendations for elderly patients with depression in primary care: a pragmatic cluster randomized trial.
abstract: Background Elderly patients with depression are underdiagnosed, undertreated, and at high risk for a chronic course. General practitioners adhere to clinical practice guidelines to a limited degree. In the international research project Tailored Implementation for Chronic Diseases, we test the efficacy of personalized interventions to improve the care of patients with chronic diseases. In Norway, we examined this approach to improve adherence to the six guideline recommendations for older people with depression, targeting health professionals, patients, and administrators. Methods We conducted a cluster randomized trial in 80 Norwegian municipalities. We identified the determinants of practice for six recommendations, and then tailored interventions to address these determinants. Interventions targeted health professionals, administrators, and patients and consisted of outreach visits, a website presenting the recommendations and underlying evidence, tools for managing depression in the elderly, and other web-based resources, including a continuing medical education course for general practitioners. The primary outcome was mean adherence to recommendations. Secondary outcomes were improvement in symptoms of depression as measured by patients and general practitioners. We offered outreach visits to all general practitioners and practice staff in the intervention municipalities. We used electronic software that pulled eligible patients from general practitioner lists. We collected data by interviewing general practitioners or sending them a questionnaire about their practice for four patients on their list and sending a questionnaire to the patients. Results One hundred and twenty-four of the 900 general practitioners (14%) participated in the data collection, 51 in the intervention group and 73 in the control group. We interviewed 77 general practitioners, 47 general practitioners completed the questionnaire and 134 patients responded to the questionnaire. Among general practitioners who provided data, adherence to recommendations was 1.6 percentage points higher in the intervention group than in the control group (95% CI -6 to 9). Conclusions The effectiveness of our personalized intervention to implement recommendations for elderly patients with depression in primary care is uncertain, due to the low response rate in data collection. However, it is unlikely that the effect was large. It remains uncertain how best to improve adherence to evidence-based recommendations and thus improve the quality of care for these patients. ClinicalTrials.gov Trial Registration: NCT01913236.

title: teaching moment communication process for talking about smoking cessation: description of a clinician-focused randomized group intervention
abstract: BACKGROUND: Effective physician-patient communication about health behavior change is one of the most important and most overlooked strategies for health promotion and disease prevention. Existing guidelines for specific behavioral health counseling have been created and promulgated, but have not been successfully adopted in primary care practice. Building on work focused on creating effective clinical strategies to drive health behavior change in the primary care setting, we developed an intervention aimed at improving clinicians' communication skills to create and act on teachable moments for give up smoking. In this manuscript, we describe the development and implementation of the Teachable Moment Communication Process (TMCP) intervention and baseline characteristics of a cluster randomized trial designed to assess its effectiveness. METHODS/DESIGN: This cluster randomized trial includes thirty-one community-based primary care physicians practicing in Northeast Ohio and 840 of their adult patients. Physicians were randomly assigned to receive the Teachable Moments Communication Process (TMCP) intervention for smoking cessation or the delayed intervention. The TMCP intervention consisted of two 3-hour educational training sessions that included didactic presentations, skill demonstration through video examples, skill practice with standardized patients, and feedback from peers and trainers. For each physician enrolled, 12 patients were recruited at two time points. Pre- and post-intervention data were collected from physicians, patients, and audio-recorded physician-patient interactions. At baseline, the two groups of physicians and their patients were similar with respect to all demographic and practice characteristics examined. Physician and patient recruitment goals were met, and retention was 96% and 94%, respectively. DISCUSSION: Findings support the feasibility of training clinicians in the use of the Teachable Moments Communication Process. The next steps are to assess how well clinicians employ these skills within their practices and to assess the effect on patient outcomes. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT01575886.

title: telephone counseling intervention to improve asthma self-management behaviors
abstract: Long recognizing that asthma, one of the most common chronic childhood illnesses, is difficult to manage, the National Asthma Prevention Education Program developed clinical practice guidelines to help health care providers, particularly those in the primary care setting. However, maintenance asthma care still does not meet national standards. Therefore, in an attempt to improve and support asthma self-management behaviors for parents of children aged 5 to 12 years with persistent asthma, a new telephone nurse advice intervention was tested in a randomized controlled trial. A detailed description of the intervention is provided along with parent satisfaction results, an overview of the training used to prepare nurses, and a discussion of challenges experienced and lessons learned.

title: theory of international bioethics: the negotiable and the non-negotiable
abstract: The previous article in this issue of the Kennedy Institute of Ethics Journal makes the case that "moral fundamentalism," the position that international bioethics is based on "basic" or "fundamental" moral principles that are universally accepted in all ages and cultures, collapses under a variety of postmodern and multicultural critiques. This article looks to the contractualist tradition of Hobbes and Locke, reinterpreted by David Gauthier, Robert Nozick, and John Rawls, for an alternative justification for international bioethics. Building on the central themes of this tradition, it is argued that international bioethics can be rationally reconstructed as a negotiated moral order that respects culturally and individually defined areas of non-negotiability. Furthermore, the theory of a negotiated moral order is consistent with traditional ideals about human rights, is flexible enough to absorb the genuine ideas of multiculturalism and postmodernism, and yet is strong enough to justify cross-cultural moral judgments and transtemporal, including the condemnation of the Nazis. doctors in Nuremberg. This theory is also consistent with the history of the ethics of human subject experimentation and provides information on current controversies, such as the controversy over changing the consent rule for experiments in emergency medicine and the controversy over the exemption of certain clinical trials of economic treatments to prevent perinatal. transmission of AIDS from the ethical standards of the sponsoring country.

title: theory-based educational intervention targeting nurses' attitudes and knowledge about cancer-related pain management: a quasi-experimental design study protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: Pain is one of the most common problems among patients diagnosed with cancer. Despite the availability of effective pharmacological treatments, this group of patients often receives less than optimal treatment. Research on nurses' pain management highlights certain factors, such as lack of knowledge and attitudes and inadequate procedures for systematic pain assessment, as common barriers to effective pain management. However, educational interventions directed at pain management by nurses have shown promise. Since cancer-related pain is also known to have a negative effect on vital aspects of a patient's life, as well as being commonly associated with problems such as sleep, fatigue, depression and anxiety, further development is warranted. of knowledge in this area. METHODS/DESIGN: A quasi-experimental study design will be used to investigate whether the implementation of guidelines for routine daily pain assessments after a theory-based educational intervention will result in improved knowledge and attitude among nurses. Another objective is to investigate if the intervention directed at the behavior of nurses will improve the perception of pain in hospital patients. Data on nurses' knowledge and attitudes towards pain (primary outcome), patient perception of pain (secondary outcome), along with sociodemographic variables, will be collected at baseline and at four weeks and 12 weeks later. of the intervention. DISCUSSION: Nursing care is nowadays recognized as an increasingly complicated activity and "the complexity of nursing is such that it can be seen as the complex intervention par excellence". In order to change and improve clinical practice, multiple appropriate points of attack are required to address complex challenges. Consequently, we expect that the theory-based intervention used in our quasi-experimental study will improve care and quality of life for this patient group, and we also anticipate that evidence-based guidelines targeting pain for this patient group will be more widely implemented. widely. TRIAL REGISTRATION NUMBER: ClinicalTrials.gov NCT01313234.

title: tool to assess a community's capacity for substance abuse care
abstract: Evidence-based programs for substance abuse prevention and intervention are on the rise. Community Needs Assessments and Health Classifications provide descriptions of local behavioral health needs, but do not provide public health professionals and policymakers with guidance on the number of programs, health professionals or interventions needed in the local substance abuse care system. This article presents a new framework for measuring and evaluating the substance abuse care system in a community. Assessment can inform resource allocation across the continuum of care to distribute interventions and care more equitably and efficiently. We conducted 2 reviews of the literature and synthesized our findings to create a community assessment methodology and needs calculator, CAST (Calculation for Appropriate System Tool). We reviewed 212 articles to produce an inventory of the community and social correlates of behavioral health, the components of a substance abuse system of care, and the numerical values of the guidelines for estimating community needs. CAST produces community-specific assessments of the capacity of the components of a community substance abuse system of care. CAST generates recommendations by applying social and community determinants of health as risk ratios to each estimate of component needs. CAST can assist public health professionals in evaluating and improving the capacity of community-based substance abuse care systems. By using recommendations for component needs across the continuum of care, community leaders can use CAST to prioritize resource allocation more effectively and efficiently.

title: universal precautions education intervention for health workers in Sardjito and PKU Hospital Indonesia
abstract: nonrandomized control trial was conducted to develop and evaluate a detailed culturally appropriate academic intervention on universal precautions knowledge, attitude, and behavior of health care workers in hospitals. Fifty-five health workers (44 nurses and 11 doctors) participated in the study. They were visited individually to discuss the principles of universal precautions, as well as the effect of autopilot on their work practices. Self-reported measures of knowledge and attitudes were collected from each participant before and after the intervention. Measures of participants' adherence to universal precautions guidelines were collected by a nurse observer according to a predetermined protocol before and after the intervention. There was a significantly different level of knowledge, attitudes and compliance with universal precautions between the control and intervention hospital with p=0.0007, p=0.038 and p=0.03 respectively after the intervention. It is concluded that a detailed academic approach to education used in this study has significantly improved knowledge, attitudes and compliance scores.

title: cluster randomized trial of decision support strategies to reduce antibiotic use in acute bronchitis
abstract: Background National quality indicators show little change in antibiotic overuse for acute uncomplicated bronchitis. We compared the effect of 2 decision support strategies on antibiotic treatment of acute uncomplicated bronchitis. Methods We conducted a 3-arm cluster randomized trial among 33 primary care practices within an integrated health care system in central Pennsylvania. Print decision support intervention sites (11 practices) received decision support for acute cough illness through a print-based strategy, computer aided decision support intervention sites (11 practices) received decision support from decisions through an electronic medical record-based strategy, with control sites (11 practices) serving as the control arm. Both intervention sites also received physician education and feedback on prescribing practices, as well as patient education brochures at registration. Antibiotic prescription rates for acute uncomplicated bronchitis in the winter period (October 1, 2009, to March 31, 2010) after the introduction of the intervention were compared with the previous 3 winter periods in an analysis by intention to treat. Results Compared to the baseline period, the percentage of adolescents and adults who were prescribed antibiotics during the intervention period decreased in the printed decision support intervention sites (from 80.0% to 68.3% ) and at computer-assisted decision support intervention sites (from 74.0% to 68.3%). 60.7%) but increased slightly at control sites (from 72.5% to 74.3%). After controlling for patient and physician characteristics, as well as grouping of observations by physician and practice site, differences for intervention sites were statistically significant from control sites (P = 0.003 for intervention sites). control vs. print decision support intervention sites and P = 0.01 for control sites vs. computer aided decision support intervention sites), but not between them (P = 0, 67 for paper-based decision support intervention sites vs. computer-aided decision support intervention sites). Changes in total visits, 30-day follow-up visit rates, and the proportion diagnosed with uncomplicated acute bronchitis were similar across study sites. Conclusions Implementation of a decision support strategy for acute bronchitis may help reduce overuse of antibiotics in primary care settings. The effect of print versus computer-assisted decision support strategies in providing decision support was equivalent.

title: Adult Personality and Behavior Abnormalities (Section F 6): ICD-10 Field Test Results
abstract: Personality disorders, the most important category in section F6, were studied in the ICD-10 field test. The overall Kappa values for the inter-rater reliability of the F6 section are 0.64, for personality disorders 0.61 and for antisocial personality 0.73. These results are very similar to those of the DSM-III field tests. Subjective assessments of feasibility, suitability, and goodness of fit demonstrate good acceptance of diagnostic guidelines by clinicians. A comparison of ICD-9, DSM-III, and ICD-10 diagnoses yielded broad agreement for personality disorder diagnoses with overlapping Kappa values of 0.91 and 0.94. The acceptance and reliability of the new classification could be increased through a series of improvements and the planned introduction of a multi-axial system.

title: Academic details have no effect on asthma medication prescription in Danish general practice: a 3-year randomized controlled trial with 12-month follow-ups
abstract: BACKGROUND: Educational outreach visits, particularly when combined with social marketing, appear to be a promising approach to modifying the behavior of health professionals, especially prescribing. The results of previous studies have shown a variable effect. OBJECTIVE: The purpose of the study is to examine the effect of academic details as a method of implementing a clinical guideline in general practice. METHODS: A blinded, controlled, cluster-randomized study of the effect of an academic in-depth visit compared with postal distribution of an asthma medication prescribing guide was conducted. Half of the practices in a Danish county with 100 practices were visited once. The outcome measure was routinely collected from data from all Danish pharmacies on asthma drug sales. Data were collected monthly from 2 years before to 1 year after the intervention. RESULTS: There was no effect on asthma medication prescription pattern after the visit, either immediately or in the long term. CONCLUSION: We found no effect of academic details as a single intervention.

title: Access to medical records for medical audit purposes.
Accident prevention
Accuracy of rapid and point-of-care screening tests for hepatitis C
Achieving change in primary care: causes of the evidence-practice gap: systematic reviews of reviews
abstract: Background This study aims to identify, summarize and synthesize the literature on the causes of the gap between evidence and practice for complex interventions in primary care. Design This study is a systematic review of reviews. Methods We searched MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL, the Cochrane Library, and PsychINFO, from inception to December 2013. Eligible reviews addressed the causes of the gap between evidence and practice in primary care in developed countries. Data from included reviews were extracted and synthesized using guidelines for metasynthesis. Results Seventy reviews met the inclusion criteria and covered a wide range of topics, for example guideline implementation, integration of new roles, technology implementation, public health and preventive medicine. None of the included articles used the term 'cause' or stated an intention to investigate causes. A descriptive approach was often used, with the included documents expressing 'causes' in terms of 'barriers and facilitators' to implementation. We developed a four-tier framework that encompasses the external context, the organization, the practitioners, and the intervention. External contextual factors included policies, incentive structures, dominant paradigms, stakeholder engagement, infrastructure, and technological advances. Organizational factors included culture, available resources, integration with existing processes, relationships, skill mix, and staff involvement. At the level of individual professionals, professional role, underlying philosophy of care, and competencies were important. Intervention characteristics that impacted implementation included evidence of benefit, ease of use, and adaptability to local circumstances. We postulate that the "fit" between the intervention and the context is critical in determining the success of implementation. Conclusions This comprehensive review of reviews summarizes current knowledge about the barriers and facilitators to the implementation of various complex interventions in primary care. To maximize the uptake of complex interventions in primary care, health professionals and lead organizations need to consider the range of contextual factors, being aware of the dynamic nature of the context. Future studies should place an emphasis on describing the context and articulating the relationships between the factors identified here.

title: Achieving guidelines for the treatment of depression in primary care: is physician education enough?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The authors examine whether medical education has lasting effects in the treatment of depression. METHODS: Depressed primary care patients initiating antidepressant treatment in primary care clinics of a staff model health maintenance organization were studied. Quasi-experimental and before-and-after comparisons of medical practices, supplemented by patient surveys, were used to compare process of care and depression outcomes. The intervention consisted of extensive medical education spanning a 12-month period. This included case-by-case consultation, didactics, academic details (eg, clearly stating educational and behavioral goals for individual clinicians), and optimal treatment role-playing. The main outcome measures were divided into two groups. Quasi-experimental samples included: (1) antidepressant medication selection and (2) appropriateness (dose and duration) of pharmacotherapy. Survey samples included: (3) intensity of follow-up"; (4) physician delivered educational messages about treating depression; (5) patient satisfaction"; and (6) depression outcomes. RESULTS: No consistent lasting educational effect was observed for any of the outcomes measured. CONCLUSIONS: There was no lasting improvement in the treatment of depression for primary care patients. However, depression treatment guidelines were achieved at the same time for intervention patients enrolled in a multifaceted collaborative care program during the training period. These results suggest that ongoing service delivery programs reorganized to support the role of a primary care physician (eg, on-site mental health staff, close monitoring of patient progress and compliance), in addition to training are essential for the successful implementation of the guideline.

title: Action to stop smoking in case of suspected tuberculosis (ASSIST) in Pakistan
abstract: Background: Tobacco use is responsible for a large proportion of the total burden of tuberculosis disease. Pakistan is one of the 10 countries with a high burden of tuberculosis and tobacco use. Objective: To assess the effectiveness of a behavioral support intervention and bupropion in achieving continuous abstinence for 6 months in adult smokers with suspected pulmonary tuberculosis. Design: Controlled, randomized cluster trial. (Current controlled trials: ISRCTN08829879) Setting: Health centers in Jhang and Sargodha districts in Pakistan. Patients: 1955 adult smokers with suspected tuberculosis. Intervention: Health centers were randomized to provide 2 brief sessions of behavioral support (BSS), BSS plus 7 weeks of bupropion therapy (BSS+), or usual care. Measurements: The primary end point was continued abstinence at 6 months after the quit date and was determined by carbon monoxide levels in the patients. Secondary endpoints were timely abstinence at 1 and 6 months. Results: Both treatments resulted in statistically significant relative risks (RRs) for abstinence compared with usual care (RR for BSS+, 8.2 [95% CI, 3.7 to 18.2]"; "RR for BSS, 7.4 [CI, 3.4 to 16.4]). Equivalence between treatments could not be established. In the BSS+ group, 275 of 606 patients (45.4% [CI, 41.4% to 49.4%]) achieved continuous abstinence compared with 254 of 620 (41.0% [CI, 37.1% to 45.0%]) in the BSS group and 52 of 615 (8.5% [CI, 6.4% to 10.9%]) in the usual care group. There was substantial heterogeneity of program effects between groups. Limitations: Imbalances in urban and rural proportions and smoking habits between treatment groups, and inability to confirm adherence to bupropion treatment and validate long-term abstinence or the effect of smoking cessation on tuberculosis outcomes. . Conclusion: Behavioral support alone or in combination with bupropion is effective in promoting smoking cessation in smokers with suspected tuberculosis. Primary funding source: International Development Research Center.

title: Acute viral hepatitis B becomes fulminant after infection with the hepatitis A virus.
Acute coronary syndromes without elevation of the ST segment. From randomized clinical trials, to consensus guidelines, to clinical practice in Italy: the need to close the circle
abstract: Recent therapeutic advances in the treatment of acute ischemic heart disease have been tested by randomized clinical trials and approved by formal practice guidelines. This rigorous approach has led to a significant reduction in mortality and morbidity across the spectrum of acute coronary syndromes (ACS). However, contemporary non-ST elevation ACS registries established by the cardiology community in Italy, as well as in the rest of Europe and America, have shown only limited compliance with the general indication to treat high-risk patients with a early treatment. invasive approach protected by the use of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor blockers. This partial failure in the process of improving patient care can be attributed to several reasons, including suspicion that practice guidelines may be biased by conflict of interest, concern about the applicability of clinical trial results to real world, unrealistic expectations about treatment, and finally, logistical and financial hurdles, including the availability of cath labs and the high cost of platelet receptor blockers. Although practice guidelines can provide cultural support for translating clinical research results into patient care, and national and local cardiology associations can help raise awareness of the real benefits of an early aggressive approach in high-risk patients. risk, health care managers must remove bureaucratic hurdles and reallocate resources from treatments of unproven benefit to those that have been clearly shown to reduce mortality and reinfarction risk in patients with ACS.

title: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy and computed tomography diagnosis
abstract: 39-year-old woman was admitted to a maternity unit at 34 weeks' gestation with nausea, vomiting, and jaundice. Her condition deteriorated and she was taken to hospital, profoundly unconscious and hypotensive. The diagnosis of acute fatty liver of pregnancy was initially suggested by the typical history of prodromal discomfort and vomiting and the rapid onset of hepatic encephalopathy with profound hypoglycemia and only small increases in transaminase activities. Computed tomography was performed: there was no enlargement of the liver or spleen, but the attenuation value over the liver indicated appreciable fatty infiltration of the liver, establishing the diagnosis of acute fatty liver of pregnancy. Computed tomography has value in the diagnosis of liver disease in late pregnancy, and this technique may become the method of choice for the investigation of acute fatty liver of pregnancy.

title: Adding Evidence-Based Interventions to Assertive Community Treatment: A Feasibility Study
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This 24-month study, conducted in the Netherlands, examined the feasibility of improving the efficacy of Assertive Community Treatment (ACT) by adding evidence-based interventions. METHODS: A total of 159 patients were randomly assigned to two ACT teams, one providing standard ACT (N585) and one ACT Plus team also providing evidence-based interventions (N574): psychoeducation, family interventions, placement, and individual support. , and cognitive attention. behavior therapy. Interventions were delivered by psychologists and nurse practitioners working independently of the ACT team. RESULTS: Although the majority of patients were considered eligible for each of the four interventions (range 65% to 89%), only 12 of 74 patients (16%) successfully completed an intervention. Outcomes, such as use of hospital care, for ACT Plus and ACT Standard patients did not differ significantly. CONCLUSIONS: Guidelines for the treatment of schizophrenia should consider the feasibility of providing evidence-based interventions to difficult-to-engage patients.

title: Adding exercise or subtracting sitting time for glycemic control: where are we?
abstract: While regular structured exercise is a well-established (albeit possibly underused) cornerstone in the prevention and management of type 2 diabetes, population adherence to recommended exercise guidelines remains stubbornly low. In fact, most adults are exposed to environmental settings—at work, in car travel, and in the home environment—that can not only limit their physical activity, but also promote prolonged sitting. However, recent experimental evidence indicates that reducing and dividing the time spent sitting may also be a useful strategy for improving glycemic control. In this issue of Diabetologia, Duvivier and colleagues report findings suggesting that reducing time spent sitting, standing, and low-intensity activities could be a potential alternative to structured exercise for improving glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes. We review and discuss the findings of this study, their potential clinical implications, and a number of knowledge gaps and opportunities that might be considered in the interest of future research. Duvivier and colleagues' findings should encourage health professionals, researchers, and patients with type 2 diabetes to consider the full spectrum of physical activity, from sedentary behavior to structured exercise.

title: Adding motivational interventions to exercise and traditional physiotherapy: review and meta-analysis
abstract: BACKGROUND: Undisputed epidemiological trends indicate that, for the foreseeable future, mortality and morbidity will be dominated by an escalation of lifestyle-related chronic diseases. International guidelines recommend the implementation of evidence-based approaches to achieve changes in health behavior. Motivational interventions to increase adherence and physical activity are not part of traditional physical therapy for any condition. OBJECTIVE: To assess the evidence for the effectiveness of adding motivational interventions to traditional physical therapy to increase physical activity and short- and long-term compliance with exercise prescriptions. DATA SOURCES: A literature search of PubMed, EMBASE, Scopus, CINAHL, PsychINFO, AMED, and the Allied Health Evidence database using keywords and subject titles. STUDY SELECTION: Only randomized controlled trials comparing two or more arms, with one arm focusing on motivational interventions influencing exercise and one control arm, were included. The search identified 493 titles, of which 14 studies (with 1504 participants) were included. DATA EXTRACTION: Data were extracted by the principal investigator and independently reviewed by another author. Two authors independently assessed methodological quality using the Cochrane risk of bias tool and the PEDro scale. Outcomes were measured in level of impairment, activity limitation, and participation restriction. The standardized mean difference between control and intervention groups at follow-up time points was used as the mode of analysis. I2</=50% was used as the cut-off point for acceptable heterogeneity, above which a random effects model was applied. RESULTS: Exercise attendance was measured in six studies (n=378), and the results indicate that there were no significant differences in exercise attendance between groups (random-effects model, standardized mean difference 0.33, interval 95% confidence: -0.03 to 0.68, I2 62%). Perceived self-efficacy results from six studies (n = 722) were combined, finding a significant difference between groups in favor of the interventions (fixed effect model, standardized mean difference 0.71, 95% confidence interval 0.55 to 0.87, I2 41%). The results for levels of activity limitation (n=550) were combined and found a significant difference between groups in favor of the interventions (SMR, standardized mean difference -0.37, 95% confidence interval - 0.65 to -0.08, I(2) 61%). LIMITATIONS: Most of the included studies were of medium quality and four studies were of low quality. Data was pooled from a wide variety of different populations and settings, which increased the range of study characteristics. CONCLUSIONS: Motivational interventions may help exercise adherence, have a positive effect on long-term exercise behavior, improve self-efficacy, and reduce levels of activity limitation. The optimal choice of theory and the most beneficial duration and type of intervention have not been defined, although all interventions showed benefits. There is a need to determine how practicing physiotherapists currently optimize adherence and their current levels of knowledge about motivational interventions. IMPLICATIONS OF KEY FINDINGS: Results indicate that motivational interventions are successful in increasing healthy physical activity behaviour. Physiotherapists are ideally placed to take on this role, and motivational interventions should become part of physiotherapy practice.

title: Addressing nicotine addiction in women. Role of the midwife
abstract: Smoking is the leading preventable cause of cancer, cardiovascular disease, and other premature deaths among women in the United States. Tobacco use accounts for 10% of perinatal mortality and is 100% preventable. Smoking is now more common among teenage girls than boys. Women's health professionals are in an excellent position to intervene in this growing epidemic. This article addresses the health consequences of smoking, as well as the social, economic, and emotional cost of smoking to women and their families. The reasons why women start and continue to smoke despite known risks are examined. The role of the midwife in the treatment of nicotine addiction in women throughout life is examined. A theoretical model based on the stage of change of women is presented as an intervention framework. Behavioral and pharmacological treatment recommendations are included. Professional activity opportunities are presented for community education and advocacy for a tobacco-free society.

title: Compliance with NICE diabetes prevention guidelines in the UK: effect on patient knowledge and perceived risk
abstract: BACKGROUND: NICE guidelines for diabetes prevention include identifying people at risk followed by cost-effective intervention if necessary. Based on risk assessment through a questionnaire and/or blood tests, intervention may comprise a brief discussion of risk factors and preventive counseling or referral for intensive lifestyle intervention. DESIGN AND SETTING: In this cross-sectional study, 59 subjects recruited from local GP practices were invited by letter to attend a screening for a diabetes prevention study. METHOD: After a telephone screening during which subjects were asked if they had been informed if they were at high risk for type 2 diabetes, eligible subjects completed a Risk Perception Survey for Developing Diabetes (RPS-DD), a validated diabetes risk score and underwent an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) at a medical examination. RESULTS: As measured by the Diabetes UK Risk Score, 44.1% were at high risk, 42.4% at moderate risk, and 13.6% at increased risk. 42% of the patients had been informed that they were at high risk by a health professional. Those who had been informed of their risk had significantly higher perceived risk scores (p<0.001), higher knowledge scores (p<0.001), and decreased optimism scores (p=0.004), but were no more aware that diet (p=0.42) and weight control (p=0.57) may play a role in diabetes prevention. CONCLUSIONS: People at high risk of diabetes are not being informed of their risk status as recommended by the NICE guidelines. There is scope for education of health professionals and the public.

title: teen contraception
abstract: PIP: Many adolescent girls in the United States continue to be at risk of unintended pregnancy despite advances in contraceptive technology and the increased availability of contraceptive methods. Physicians caring for adolescents should be familiar with the various contraceptive measures and their appropriateness for adolescents. A health professional should also be prepared to engage in sex education and counsel or refer individual adolescent patients when sexual problems arise. Attention in this discussion of contraception in adolescents is directed to the following: reasons not to use contraception, postcoital contraception, oral contraception (contraindications, side effects, guidelines for use in adolescents and the minipill (progestin only), IUDs, diaphragms, chemical vaginal contraceptives, condoms, abstinence or rhythm, intervention techniques, and appropriate method selection The average adolescent is exposed to unprotected intercourse for a year or more before seeking contraception Available evidence suggests that today's adolescents may be using contraceptives more than ever before, however, a significant number do not use a method for a variety of reasons Most reasons reflect lack of knowledge, some reflect lack of availability Reasons include ignorance of fertile periods, the belief that their age is protective, sexual intercourse recount or not, and strong feelings of guilt evoked by the idea of being prepared for the possibility of sexual intercourse. Many teens are hesitant to seek birth control advice or prescriptions from private doctors because they fear morality lectures and rejection of their requests. There is evidence in at least 1 study that locating the family planning clinic within the school is effective in reducing pregnancy rates and ensuring high continuation rates after 36 months of follow-up. Intervention techniques that might be effective include providing a method immediately after an event (abortion, childbirth, rape) when motivation is highest and tailoring the method to individual lifestyle and preference. If there are no contraindications, the adolescent should be given the preferred method and a method that suits the frequency of intercourse. A backup method should also be provided if the preferred method is not tolerated or never started. To maximize continuation rates, frequent follow-up is essential.

title: Overweight and Obesity in Adolescents: How to Best Manage Them in the General Practice Setting
abstract: BACKGROUND: The prevalence of overweight and obesity continues to increase in adolescents. Community-level management is necessary as specialized services are limited. OBJECTIVE: This article describes a management plan for the overweight adolescent in general practice, using a chronic care approach, and follows the National Medical Research Council clinical practice guidelines for the management of overweight and obesity in children and adolescents. and Health. DISCUSSION: Overweight and obesity will not resolve spontaneously at puberty, and active intervention is required both to improve current health and well-being and to reduce the risks of premature morbidity and mortality in adult life. Modest, cumulative lifestyle changes, along with modest weight loss goals to reduce the risk of weight rebound, are important. Any intervention must take into account the rapid cognitive and behavioral changes of adolescence.

title: Teen Violence Prevention Practices Among California Pediatricians
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To examine the provision of violence prevention services by pediatricians to their adolescent patients and to identify factors associated with the implementation of these services by pediatricians. DESIGN: A cross-sectional sample of California pediatricians completed a self-report questionnaire. The theoretical model "Precede/Proceed" guided the questionnaire in the identification of factors associated with the screening practices and intervention of pediatricians in the prevention of adolescent violence. RESULTS: Two hundred and twenty pediatricians (54% female, 66% white, 24% Asian, 5% Latino, and 5% other) participated in the study. On average, participants screened their patients for violence-related risk factors 31% of the time for fighting, 39% of the time for domestic violence, and 29% of the time for carrying weapons . Participants provided their at-risk patients with violence-related interventions less than 50% of the time (on average) by implementing the following interventions: written materials, follow-up appointments, disciplinary counseling, or referral to a community organization, Child Protective Services, or a clinic specialized in adolescents. Factors associated with violence prevention screening practices included the following: positive attitudes and beliefs regarding violence screening, familiarity with violence prevention guidelines, use of prompts in medical records, perceptions increased skills and positive reinforcement of patients and colleagues for providing violence prevention services. (R(2)=0.44"; P<0.001). Factors associated with violence prevention intervention practices included: positive attitudes and beliefs in detecting violence, availability of resources, and positive reinforcement of patients and colleagues for providing violence prevention services (R(2)=0.37;” p<0.001).CONCLUSIONS: California pediatricians are not extensively screening their adolescent patients for risk factors associated with adolescent violence, nor do they provide interventions to their adolescent patients who may be at risk for violence Factors associated with implementation of violence prevention services by pediatricians can aid in the development of effective interventions designed to improve the provision of these services to their adolescent patients.

title: Adoption, scope, implementation and maintenance of a mental and behavioral health assessment in primary care
abstract: PURPOSE: The guidelines recommend screening patients for harmful behaviors and mental health problems. Health risk assessments can systematically identify patient needs and trigger care. This study seeks to assess whether primary care practices can routinely implement such assessments in routine care.
