METHODS: As part of a pragmatic cluster-randomized trial, 9 diverse primary care practices implemented My Own Health Report (MOHR), a paper-based or electronic health and mental health behavioral assessment and feedback system along with counseling and referral setting. objectives. We looked at how practices integrated MOHR into their workflows, what additional practice staff time was required, and what percentage of patients completed a MOHR (Scope) assessment. RESULTS: Most practices addressed (60%) agreed to adopt MOHR. How they implemented MOHR depended on practice resources, computing capacity, and patient characteristics. Three practices sent invitations to patients to complete MOHRs on the web, 1 called patients and completed MOHRs over the phone, 1 had patients complete paper MOHRs in the office, and 4 had staff help patients complete MOHRs on the web in the office. In total, 3,591 patients were approached and 1,782 completed MOHR (reach = 49.6%). Reach varied by implementation strategy, with greater reach when the MOHR was completed by staff than by patients (71.2% vs. 30.2%, p < 0.001). No practice was able to sustain the full MOHR assessment without accommodations after study completion. Fielding MOHR increased staff and physician time by an average of 28 minutes per visit. CONCLUSIONS: Primary care practices can implement behavioral health and mental health assessments, but counseling patients effectively requires effort. Practices will need more support to implement and sustain assessments.

title: Palliative care adult education program for nursing facility physicians: design and pilot test
abstract: Nursing facilities (NFs) are important sites for the care of dying patients. Curricula that can improve end-of-life care for NF physicians are needed. To this end, a model medical school palliative care curriculum for physicians with experience in NF was modified. Adult learning techniques were emphasized, as well as interactions likely to change clinician behavior. Opinion leader inclusion, feedback auditing, use of consensus guidelines, and other techniques to change physician behavior were included. Written materials were identified to complement the course. This new program was tested and improved. An initial audit of medical practices and a survey of NF staff, a half-day adult education session, and follow-up with the NF medical director are suggested. This intervention should be tested to determine if it improves outcomes of patient end-of-life care in this setting.

title: Adult respiratory distress syndrome
Advancing the literature on the design of audit and feedback interventions: identification of theory-based hypotheses
abstract: Background Audit and feedback (A&F) is a common strategy to help healthcare providers implement evidence into practice. Despite being extensively studied, health care A&F interventions continue to have variable efficacy, with overall effects not improving since 2003. Contributing to this stagnation is the fact that most health care A&F interventions are they have designed largely without being informed by theoretical understanding of behavior. and social sciences. To determine if the trend can be improved, the aim of this study was to develop a list of testable hypotheses based on theory about how to design more effective C&F interventions. Methods Using purposive sampling, 60- to 90-minute semi-structured telephone interviews were conducted with experts in A&F-related theories from a variety of fields (eg, cognitive, health, and organizational psychology, medical decision-making, economics). . Guided by detailed descriptions of A&F interventions from the health care literature, interviewees described how they would approach the problem of designing better A&F interventions. Specific theory-based hypotheses about the conditions for the effective design and implementation of C&F interventions were drawn from the interviews. The resulting hypotheses were assigned by three coders working independently on themes and theme categories, in an iterative process. Results We conducted 28 interviews and identified 313 theory-based hypotheses, which were located in 30 themes. The 30 themes included hypotheses related to the following five categories: A&F recipient (seven themes), A&F content (ten themes), A&F delivery process (six themes), A&F focused behavior (three themes), and others (four topics). Conclusions We have identified a set of testable hypotheses based on theory from a wide range of behavioral and social sciences that suggest conditions for more effective A&F interventions. This work demonstrates the breadth of perspectives on A&F from disciplines not specific to health care in a way that generates testable hypotheses for A&F interventions in health care. These results will serve as the basis for future work seeking to establish research priorities within the A&F research community.

title: Advances in the science of patient safety
abstract: Despite a decade of effort, patient safety has slowly improved, in part due to the limited evidence base for the development and widespread dissemination of successful patient safety practices. The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality sponsored an international group of experts in patient safety and evaluation methods to develop criteria to improve the design, evaluation, and reporting of practical patient safety research. This article reports the findings and recommendations of this group, including increased use of theory and logic models, more detailed descriptions of interventions and their implementation, better explanation of desired and undesired outcomes, and better description and measuring the context and how the context influences. interventions. The use of these measurement and reporting criteria and contexts will improve the science of patient safety.

title: Advantages and challenges of a village doctor-based cognitive behavioral therapy for depression in old age in rural China: a qualitative study
abstract: BACKGROUND: The provision of mental health services in rural China has been severely limited due to a lack of qualified mental health professionals, among other hindering factors. A village doctor-based cognitive behavioral therapy intervention may be one way to improve accessibility. The purpose of this study was to explore the advantages and challenges of implementing this intervention, delivered by trained local clinicians, to treat depression in old age in rural China. METHODS: We conducted a focus group discussion with 10 village doctors, 10 individual interviews with each of the village doctors, and individual interviews with 19 older adults. The thematic guides were advantages and challenges of the intervention program from the perspective of village doctors and older adults. Interviews were audio-recorded, transcribed, coded with NVivo 8, and analyzed with thematic analysis. RESULTS: Village doctors highlighted the importance of role-playing and the use of instruction manuals in training. Adequate supervision was also a key component of the program. The benefits received from the intervention for the village doctors and the elderly were positive, so that both the doctors and the elderly were willing to implement/receive this intervention. Cultural and political factors (requirements and perceived political consideration) facilitated the elderly's access to mental health services. Challenges included the lack of real therapy (in contrast to role play) demonstrated in the training and the lack of a step-by-step manual based on the different types of problems encountered. Other impediments to successful implementation of the intervention included the time constraints of the village doctors and the presence of other people when performing the intervention. CONCLUSIONS: The present study has shown that the intervention program is likely to be an acceptable intervention for geriatric depression in rural China if several challenges are adequately addressed.

title: Counseling patients seeking complementary and alternative medical therapies for cancer
abstract: Many cancer patients use complementary and alternative medical (CAM) therapies. Physicians need reliable information about CAM therapies to responsibly advise patients seeking these interventions. This article summarizes the current evidence on the efficacy and safety of selected CAM therapies that are commonly used by cancer patients. The following main categories of interventions are covered: dietary modification and supplements, herbal products and other biological agents, acupuncture, massage, exercise, and psychological and mind-body therapies. Two categories of evidence on efficacy are considered: potential effects on disease progression and survival, and potential palliative effects. When evaluating the evidence on safety, two types of risk are considered: the risk of direct adverse effects and the risk of interactions with conventional treatments. For each therapy, the current balance of evidence on efficacy and safety points to whether the therapy can be reasonably recommended, accepted (for example, reducing dietary fat in well-nourished patients with breast or prostate cancer), or discouraged (for example, example, high-dose vitamin A supplementation). This strategy enables the development of an approach to providing responsible, evidence-based, patient-centered counseling to people with cancer seeking CAM therapies.

title: Alcohol consumption and dependence in older adults in an urban community
Alcohol: prevention, policies and primary care responses
abstract: BACKGROUND: Alcohol is Australia's most socially acceptable legal drug"; however, alcohol-related harms have increased significantly over time. Encouraging safer levels of alcohol consumption should be a national health priority and key focus for health professionals PURPOSE: The purpose of this document is to look at some of the reasons why alcohol is such a popular and valued product in Australia, as well as some of the common problems caused by alcohol. and the most effective treatment approaches to reduce alcohol use and related harm DISCUSSION: Research evidence suggests that the most effective policies to reduce alcohol use and related harm are those that focus on restricting its availability and accessibility;" however, such strategies are often not implemented or enforced for political and economic reasons. Screening and brief intervention are effective ways of addressing problem drinking in primary care and can be further supported by promoting community-organized abstinence periods.

title: Participation and enjoyment of alcohol- and non-alcohol-related activities among college students: An analysis of behavioral choice theories.
abstract: Alcohol abuse among college students remains a major public health problem, and there is a need for empirical and theory-based models to guide prevention efforts. Behavioral choice theories assume that the decision to consume alcohol is influenced by the relative value of alcohol versus other available activities. In the present study, a sample of drinking college students (N=108";" 56% female, 44% male) who had previously completed a mandatory alcohol intervention completed a measure of participation in and enjoyment of alcohol-related activities and without alcohol. The aims of the study were to examine the influence of drinking quantity and contextual variables on activity enjoyment and to identify non-alcoholic enjoyable activities that take place on nights when students might be drinking. In general, students found alcohol-related activities more enjoyable than non-alcoholic activities, and the amount of drinking was positively related to enjoyment. However, non-alcoholic activities, such as watching movies, going to the theater or museums, going to bars or parties, hanging out with friends, eating in restaurants, and participating in creative activities, were generally just as enjoyable as drinking. Non-alcoholic activities that included partners or dates were more enjoyable than solitary activities. Men were less likely to participate in non-alcoholic activities that included partners and reported less enjoyment related to non-alcoholic activities than women. More research is required to identify procedures for increasing participation in non-alcoholic activities and to determine whether increased participation in non-alcoholic activities results in decreased alcohol consumption. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2016 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: Everything you need to read in the other general magazines
abstract: Between 1998 and 2009, a single surgeon in France reconstructed the genitalia of 2,938 women who had been mutilated or cut as children. The case series, one of the largest to date, suggests that surgery may help at least some women with a history of female genital mutilation achieve an acceptable, pain-free sex life. Most of the women were from French-speaking West Africa, although more than 564 had undergone female genital mutilation while growing up in France. Almost all of them wanted surgery, above all, to recover their feminine identity and autonomy. Four-fifths were also looking for a better sex life. All had undergone female genital mutilation that removed or damaged the clitoris, at a mean age of 6 years. One of the goals of the surgery was to reconstruct a normal clitoris. More than three quarters of women presenting for surgery (78% (2053/2613)) had never had an orgasm. Only 866 women (29%) returned for follow-up one year after surgery. About half (414/840) reported improvements in pain. Slightly fewer reported improvements in sexual pleasure (385/834), and 430 now had orgasms. We don't know how they felt about their bodies after surgery, and future studies should include validated measures of identity, satisfaction with surgery, and global satisfaction with sex, says a linked comment (doi: 10.1016/S0140-6736( 12)60636-9). Lancet2012";"doi:10.1016/S0140-6736(12)60813-7 Citicoline is already licensed in some countries as a neuroprotectant for adults with acute stroke. Animal models suggest that it may protect surviving neurons close to infarction and may even enhance repair. However, results from human trials have been mixed, with the latest and largest recently finding no difference in recovery between people treated with citicoline and controls given a placebo (odds ratio for overall recovery 1.03 , 95% CI: 0.86 to 1.25). Treatment began within Ã¢â‚¬Â¦

title: Non-adherence to the alliance: training strategies to improve outcomes in type 2 diabetes.
abstract: PURPOSE: To explore strategies to improve outcomes for patients with type 2 diabetes. DATA SOURCES: Literature related to type 2 diabetes management, behavior change, communication, diabetes self-management, and training. CONCLUSIONS: Strategies currently suggested to improve patient outcomes, for example, increasing provider adherence to evidence-based management guidelines, simplifying practice systems, and promoting lifestyle changes for patients through through intensive education, have produced mixed results. Of the many complexities involved in managing type 2 diabetes, motivating patients to change their behavior can be the most challenging. One suggestion to improve self-management for patients with type 2 diabetes is to use counseling communication within a behavior change framework in the context of the primary care encounter between nurse practitioners (NPs) and their patients. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: Given the varied results of current strategies, NP training may provide a feasible alternative to improve outcomes for patients with type 2 diabetes. Coaching communication can be implemented during office visits as a free intervention. However, to implement this approach effectively, practicing NPs and NP students need more formal education in this expected but underdeveloped NP role competency. NPs are called upon to contribute to the body of knowledge necessary to validate the merits of coaching for their patients.

title: Alprazolam prescribing in Tasmania: a dual intervention designed to reduce inappropriate prescribing and concomitant opioid prescribing
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The population prescribing rate for alprazolam in Tasmania has been more than twice the national rates. Serious adverse events have been observed through the co-administration of opioid medications with alprazolam. A dual intervention, comprising GP education along with changes in prescribing norms, was designed with the intention of reducing inappropriate alprazolam prescribing and thus reducing adverse outcomes. The aim of this study was to assess the impact of the intervention on prescription rates. METHOD: We measured the number of alprazolam prescriptions in the years before and after the intervention. Data from the Health Insurance Commission were used to allow comparison of subsidized prescribing rates for alprazolam in Tasmania and national data. Participants were Tasmanian registered physicians who were potential prescribers of alprazolam. The interventions were three GP educational meetings during June 2007, one in each of the major regions of Tasmania, regarding evidence-based interventions for panic disorder. In September 2007, changes in regulatory procedures were implemented to minimize the co-prescription of alprazolam with opioids. RESULTS: There was a reduction in alprazolam prescription in Tasmania after the interventions. CONCLUSION: Education can be an effective strategy to influence the prescribing behavior of physicians. It is likely that this effect can be increased by the adoption of more stringent regulatory requirements.

title: Alternative Perspectives on the Biased Foundations of Medical Technology Assessment
abstract: The evaluation of medical technology seeks to improve the care of individual patients (the conventional unit of clinical practice) through evaluation studies carried out in groups of patients (the conventional unit of clinical research). This distinction between individuals and groups has practical relevance for the design, analysis, and clinical applicability of technology assessment studies. We define several biased perspectives on technology evaluation that stem from the distinction between individuals and groups: a misplaced emphasis on efficacy versus effectiveness, on statistical significance versus clinical importance, and on objective versus subjective outcomes. . In each case, we contrast these alternative perspectives and speculate on their implications for health care policy.

title: American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists and the American College of Endocrinology Comprehensive Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Care of Patients with Obesity
abstract: PURPOSE: Development of these guidelines is mandated by the American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists (AACE) Board of Directors and the American College of Endocrinology (ACE) Board of Directors and adheres to AACE published protocols for standardized production of clinical practice guidelines (CPG) . METHODS: Recommendations are based on a diligent review of clinical evidence with transparent incorporation of subjective factors. RESULTS: There are 9 broad clinical questions with 123 recommendation numbers including 160 specific statements (85 [53.1%] strong [Grade A]"; 48 [30.0%] intermediate [Grade B] and 11 [6.9 %] weak [Grade C], with 16 [10.0%] based on expert opinion [Grade D]) constructing a comprehensive health care plan for obesity There were 133 (83.1%) level-based statements strong (best level of evidence [BEL] 1 = 79 [49.4%]) or intermediate (BEL 2 = 54 [33.7%]) evidence-based There were 34 (23.6%) grades of recommendation based on the evidence (Grades AC = 144) that were adjusted based on subjective factors Of the 1,790 reference citations used in this CPG, 524 (29.3%) were based on strong (level of evidence [LE] 1), 605 (33.8%) were based on intermediate (LE 2) and 308 (17.2%) were based on weak scientific studies (EL 3), with 353 (19.7%) based on reviews and opinions (EL 4 CONCLUSION: The final recommendations recognize that the ob esity is a complex chronic adiposity-based disease, in which management targets both weight-related and adiposity-related complications to improve overall health and quality of life. Detailed evidence-based recommendations enable nuanced clinical decision-making that addresses the actual medical care of patients with obesity, including screening, diagnosis, evaluation, therapy selection, treatment goals, and management. individualization of care. The goal is to facilitate high-quality care for patients with obesity and to provide a rational, scientific approach to management that optimizes health outcomes and safety. title: American Cancer Society Colorectal Cancer Survivorship Care Guidelines
abstract: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the third most common cancer and the third leading cause of cancer death in both men and women and the second leading cause of cancer death when men and women are combined in the United States. .). Nearly two-thirds of CRC survivors live 5 years after diagnosis. Considering the recent decline in both incidence and mortality, the prevalence of CRC survivors is likely to increase dramatically in the coming decades with rising CRC detection rates, further advances in detection, and treatment. diseases and the aging and growth of the US population. Survivors are at risk of CRC recurrence, new primary CRC, other cancers, as well as short-term and long-term adverse effects of CRC and the modalities used to treat it. CRC survivors may also have psychological, reproductive, genetic, social, and occupational problems after treatment. Communication and care coordination between the treating oncologist and primary care physician are critical to effectively and efficiently managing the long-term care of CRC survivors. The guidelines in this article are intended to help primary care physicians provide risk-based medical care for CRC survivors who have completed active therapy.

title: Manual of Ethics of the American College of Physicians
abstract: Medicine, law and social values are not static. Reexamining the ethical principles of medicine and their application in new circumstances is a necessary exercise. The sixth edition of the American College of Physicians (ACP) Ethics Manual covers emerging topics in medical ethics and reviews older ones that are still highly relevant. It reflects on many of the ethical tensions in medicine and attempts to shed light on how existing principles extend to emerging concerns. Furthermore, by reiterating ethical principles that have provided guidance in resolving past ethical problems, the Manual can help clinicians avoid future problems. The Manual does not replace the expertise and integrity of individual physicians, but can serve as a reminder of the shared duties of the medical profession.

title: American Medical Society of Sports Medicine Position Statement: Concussion in Sports
abstract: NO LABEL: PURPOSE OF STATEMENT: Black triangle at right To provide an evidence-based summary of best practices to assist clinicians with the evaluation and management of sports concussion. black triangle on the right To establish the level of evidence, knowledge gaps and areas that require further investigation. IMPORTANCE OF AN AMSSM STATEMENT: black triangle on the right Sports medicine physicians are frequently involved in the care of sports concussion patients. black triangle at right Sports medicine physicians are specifically trained to provide care throughout the sports concussion from the acute injury to return to play (RTP) decisions. black triangle on right Care of concussed athletes in sport is ideally performed by healthcare professionals with specific training and experience in concussion assessment and management. Competence should be determined by training and experience, not dictated by specialty. right black triangle While this statement is intended for sports medicine physicians, it may also assist other physicians and health care professionals caring for sports concussion patients. DEFINITION: right black triangle Concussion is defined as a transient traumatically induced disturbance of brain function and involves a complex pathophysiological process. Concussion is a subset of mild traumatic brain injuries (MTBI) that is generally self-limited and is on the less severe end of the brain injury spectrum. PATHOPHYSIOLOGY: black triangle on right Animal and human studies support the concept of post-concussion vulnerability and show that a second shock before the brain has recovered results in worsening metabolic changes within the cell . black triangle at right Experimental evidence suggests that the concussed brain is less responsive to usual neural activation and when premature cognitive or physical activity occurs before full recovery, the brain may be vulnerable to prolonged dysfunction. INCIDENCE: Black triangle at right It is estimated that up to 3.8 million concussions occur in the US each year during competitive sports and recreational activities";" however, up to 50% of concussions may go undetected. black triangle on the right Concussions occur in all sports with the highest incidence in football, hockey, rugby, soccer and basketball. RISK FACTORS FOR SPORTS-RELATED CONCUSSIONS: Black triangle at right A history of concussion is associated with an increased risk of another concussion. black triangle on right Increased number, severity, and duration of symptoms after concussion are predictors of prolonged recovery. black triangle on the right In sports with similar playing rules, the reported incidence of concussions is higher in female athletes than in male athletes. black triangle on the right Certain sports, positions and individual styles of play have a higher risk of concussion. black triangle on the right Young athletes may have a longer recovery time and are more susceptible to a concussion accompanied by a catastrophic injury. black triangle on right Pre-injury mood disorders, learning disabilities, attention deficit disorder (ADD/ADHD), and migraines complicate the diagnosis and treatment of a concussion. DIAGNOSIS OF CONCUSSION: Black triangle to the right Concussion remains a clinical diagnosis ideally made by a health care provider familiar with the athlete and knowledgeable in concussion recognition and evaluation. black triangle on right Graded Symptom Checklists provide an objective tool for evaluating a variety of concussion-related symptoms, while also tracking the severity of those symptoms in serial assessments. black triangle at right Standardized assessment tools provide a useful framework for concussion assessment, although limited validation of these assessment tools is available. SIDELINE ASSESSMENT AND MANAGEMENT: Black triangle to the right Any athlete suspected of having a concussion should be detained and evaluated by a licensed health care provider trained in the assessment and management of concussions. black triangle on right Recognition and initial evaluation of a concussion should be guided by a symptom checklist, cognitive assessment (including orientation, past and immediate memory, new learning, and concentration), balance tests, and a physical examination additional neurological right black triangle While secondary standardized tests are a useful framework for screening, the sensitivity, specificity, validity, and reliability of these tests across different age groups, cultural groups, and settings is largely undefined. Its practical utility with or without an individual reference test is also largely unknown. black triangle on the right Impaired balance is a specific indicator of a concussion, but not a very sensitive one. Sideline balance tests may be substantially different from baseline tests due to differences in shoe/cleat type or surface, use of ankle straps or braces, or the presence of another injury in the lower extremities. black triangle on the right Images are reserved for athletes in whom intracerebral hemorrhage is suspected. black triangle on the right There is no same-day RTP for an athlete diagnosed with a concussion. black triangle on right Athletes suspected or diagnosed with a concussion should be monitored for impaired physical or mental status. NEUROPSYCHOLOGICAL TESTING: black triangle on the right Neuropsychological testing (NP) is an objective measure of brain-behavior relationships and is more sensitive to subtle cognitive impairment than clinical examination. black triangle on the right Most concussions can be adequately managed without the use of NP testing. black triangle on the right Computerized neuropsychological tests (CNP) should be interpreted by trained healthcare professionals familiar with the type of test and the individual limitations of the test, including an informed assessment of reliable rate of change, baseline variability, and false positive and false negative rates. black triangle on the right Paper-and-pencil NP tests can be more comprehensive, test different domains, and test for other conditions that may mask or complicate the assessment of a concussion. The right black triangle NP test should be used only as part of a comprehensive concussion management strategy and should not be used in isolation. black triangle on the right The ideal timing, frequency, and type of PN testing have not been determined. black triangle on the right In some cases, correctly administered and interpreted PN tests provide added value in assessing cognitive function and recovery in the management of sports concussions. black triangle on right It is unknown whether the use of NP testing in sports concussion management helps prevent recurrent concussion, catastrophic injury, or long-term complications. black triangle at right Comprehensive PN evaluation is helpful in the post-concussion management of athletes with persistent symptoms or challenging courses. BACK TO SCHOOL – Black Triangle on the Right Students will require cognitive rest and may require academic accommodations such as a reduced workload and more time for tests while recovering from a concussion. RETURN TO PLAY: black triangle on the right Concussion symptoms must resolve before returning to exercise. black triangle on the right A progression of RTP involves a gradual, gradual increase in physical demands, sport-specific activities, and contact risk. black triangle on the right If symptoms occur with activity, progression should be stopped and restarted at the previous step without symptoms. right black triangle RTP after concussion should occur only with medical clearance from a licensed health care provider trained in the evaluation and management of concussions. SHORT-TERM RISKS OF PREMATURE RTP: black triangle on the right The primary concern with early RTP is decreased reaction time leading to increased risk of repeated concussion or other injury and prolongation of symptoms. LONG-TERM EFFECTS: Black triangle at right There is growing concern that head impact exposure and recurrent concussions contribute to long-term neurological sequelae. black triangle on the right Some studies have suggested an association between previous concussions and chronic cognitive dysfunction. Large-scale epidemiological studies are needed to more clearly define the risk factors and cause of any long-term neurological impairment. DISQUALIFICATION FROM SPORT: black triangle on the right There are no evidence-based guidelines for disqualifying/removing an athlete from a sport after a concussion. Each case must be carefully deliberated and an individualized approach must be taken to determine disqualification. EDUCATION: Right Black Triangle Greater efforts are needed to educate stakeholders, including athletes, parents, coaches, officials, school administrators, and health care providers to improve concussion recognition, management, and prevention. black triangle on the right Physicians should be prepared to advise on the potential long-term consequences of concussion and recurrent concussions. PREVENTION: black triangle to the right Primary prevention of some injuries may be possible with rule modification and enforcement and fair play. black triangle on the right Helmets, both hard (football, lacrosse and hockey) and soft (soccer, rugby) are best suited to prevent impact injuries (fracture, bleeding, laceration, etc.) but have not been shown to reduce the incidence and severity of concussions black triangle to the right There is no current evidence that mouthguards can reduce the severity of concussions or prevent them. black triangle on the right Secondary prevention may be possible through proper management of RTP. LEGISLATION: Right Black Triangle Legislative efforts provide a uniform standard for scholastic and non-scholastic athletic organizations regarding the safety and management of concussions. FUTURE DIRECTIONS: Black triangle on the right Additional research is needed to validate current screening tools, delineate the role of NP testing, and improve identification of those at risk for prolonged postconcussive symptoms or other long-term complications. black triangle on the right Evolving technologies for concussion diagnosis, such as new neuroimaging techniques or biological markers, may provide new insights into the evaluation and management of sports concussion.

title: The Americans want to water down the Declaration of Helsinki
A detailed academic intervention for disseminating physician-provided smoking cessation advice: smoking cessation results from the Physician Smokers' Advice Project
abstract: BACKGROUND: Little is known about the effectiveness of interventions to disseminate smoking cessation interventions among a population of primary care physicians. The aim of this study was to determine the effect of a comprehensive academic community-based intervention on quit rates in a population-based sample of smokers. METHODS: This community-based quasi-experimental study involved representative samples of 259 primary care physicians and 4295 adult smokers. A detailed academic intervention was delivered to clinicians in the intervention areas over a 15-month period. Analyzes of data from the 2346 subjects who reported at least one physician visit over 24 months were performed. Multivariable regression analyzes were performed to determine the impact of the intervention on self-reported smoking cessation rates, reported using adjusted odds ratios. RESULTS: Among smokers who reported a visit to the doctor during the study period, there was a borderline significant effect for those who resided in intervention areas versus control areas (OR = 1.35"; 95% CI .99-1.83; P = 0.057).Among a subgroup of 819 smokers who reported a visit with an enrolled physician, we observed a significant effect for those residing in the intervention areas (OR = 1.80; 95% CI: 1.16-2.75 ; P = 0.008) CONCLUSION: A detailed academic intervention to improve physician-provided smoking cessation counseling is an effective strategy for disseminating smoking cessation interventions to community practices.

title: An administrative intervention to improve the use of laboratory tests within a university hospital
abstract: BACKGROUND: Improving the adequacy of behavioral tests and reducing the number of laboratory tests have been recognized as essential parts of quality improvement. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effectiveness of a short-term administrative educational intervention aimed at reducing the use of the clinical biochemistry laboratory. DESIGN: An analysis comparing the use of laboratory tests performed on hospitalized patients before and after the intervention. SETTING: Computerized database of all laboratory tests performed at Hadassah Ein Kerem Medical Center, Jerusalem, Israel during 1999-2003. INTERVENTION: Administrative intervention included restriction of available emergency laboratory tests and frequency of repeat orders. The educational measures included: discussion of the misuse of laboratory tests and its consequences with the medical staff of the hospital, and presentation of the new restrictive policy. Feedback of the results of the intervention was sent to the wards and reviewed with senior medical staff. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Change in utilization (measured as rates per 100 hospital days) of clinical chemistry tests by hospital division and by selected laboratory tests. RESULTS: An overall reduction of 19% in laboratory tests (95% CI: 18.8-19.2%) was observed one year after the intervention. Utilization decreased significantly in all medical areas of the hospital, ranging from 14.9 to 43.8%. During the intervention period, the use of hematology tests was reduced by 7.6% (P = 0.009). Statistically significant reductions were observed in the ordering of the 12 selected clinical biochemical tests. Although total cholesterol orders decreased by 72.2%, the use of 'high volume' tests, such as glucose and electrolytes, showed only a modest decrease (7.9% and 6.9%, respectively). CONCLUSIONS: The present study included all hospital medical staff and covered all available clinical biochemistry tests. This fairly simple and low-cost intervention resulted in significant reductions in clinical chemistry testing orders, as well as hematology blood tests ordering.

title: An evaluation of user acceptance and satisfaction with the automated clinical practice guideline for tobacco use cessation
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To describe user acceptance and satisfaction with the Automated Clinical Practice Guideline (ACPG) for tobacco cessation (TUC) in the Henry Ford Health System. STUDY DESIGN: Previous research evaluated compliance with the 5 A's (Ask, Advise, Assess, Help, Organize) of the TUC ACPG in 3 study arms. This article describes user satisfaction with the TUC ACPG after implementation. METHODS: In all arms of the study, providers completed a survey before participating in a focus group. RESULTS: All providers in the TUC arm indicated that they "almost always" asked their patients about tobacco use. Providers in the TUC arm were generally satisfied with the features of the TUC ACPG, particularly the ease of electronically referring a patient to the Tobacco Intervention Program. Barriers to use included time constraints, lack of staff, and the desire to "opt out" of the program for patients in specific situations (eg, terminally ill patients). CONCLUSION: As ACPGs are incorporated into electronic medical records, it is important to obtain information from the provider prior to implementation, provide technology that is easy to use and fits into clinic workflow, and give clinicians the autonomy to opt out of the guide. under specific clinical circumstances.

title: An automated minimum retest interval reject rule reduces CRP repeat workload and expense and influences physician ordering behavior.
abstract: Objectives Repeat serum C-reactive protein (CRP) measurements on the same day or on consecutive days are of limited clinical value. Minimum retest intervals are recommended to manage unnecessary retests. As not previously reported, we studied the effect of minimum retest interval test refusal on laboratory workload and expense and on physician requesting behavior. Methods In a prospective study, we evaluated the effect of an automated 48-h PCR minimum retest interval rule on inpatient and outpatient PCR workload and costs. Control data on urea workload and serum electrolytes (UE) were collected from inpatients and outpatients during the study. Results Over 1 year, there was a 7.0% and 12.3% decrease in CRP requests and CRP tests analyzed, respectively, after the introduction of the minimum reassessment interval rule compared to the period 1 year reference. This equated to an estimated annual reduction in revenue costs of £10,500, but a cash saving in consumable costs of £3,000. There were no significant changes in EU requests. Conclusions We report, for the first time, that automated minimum retest interval rejection rules as a stand-alone strategy are a cost-effective and sustainable method of reducing unnecessary repeat PCR testing, leading to small cash savings in the laboratory, more efficient use of laboratory resources and standardization. of patient care pathways. The minimum retest interval reject rule also altered the physician's test request behavior toward a more appropriate request.

title: An educational program influencing healthcare professionals to recommend exercise to their patients with type 2 diabetes: understanding the processes: a case study from Oxfordshire, UK
abstract: BACKGROUND: Increasing physical activity levels decreases the risk of premature mortality associated with chronic diseases, eg, coronary heart disease, type 2 diabetes, stroke. Despite this, most adults in England do not meet the physical activity guidelines. Counseling and signaling of physical activity offered to patients at risk by primary care providers is recommended. However, exercise medicine education is sparse, leading to poor clinicians' knowledge of the evidence and risk-reduction strategies for implementing effective patient behavior change. The intervention 'Generation Games' seeks to increase physical activity in the population over 50 years of Oxfordshire. Offers a Health Professional Education Program (HPEP) that provides exercise medicine education and promotion of Generation Games that health professionals can point patients to. There is a poor evidence base on how such education translates into a change in patient exercise behaviour. METHODS: The research aimed to create a greater understanding of how an educational program can influence health professionals to recommend Generation Games and increase exercise behavior in patients with type 2 diabetes. A case study method facilitated the examination of routines and cultures studied: the diabetes nurses' experience was used as an example of best practice engagement with the HPEP. Observation, interviews and documentation were used to triangulate the data. Data analysis refined and developed themes within key theoretical frameworks. RESULTS: First, there is a lack of knowledge about the risk-reducing benefits of physical activity and a belief that efforts to motivate patients to increase their physical activity are ineffective, creating barriers to engagement. with the HPEP. Second, practice nurses tasked with providing lifestyle advice to patients with diabetes, who also suffer from a deficit in motivational interviewing skills, find entrenched physical activity behaviors extremely challenging and therefore , highly value the HPEP for providing useful tools. Third, patients who hear about generation games from a health professional may have different expectations of how it can change their exercise behavior. CONCLUSIONS: Exercise medicine education has the potential to improve patient care and services. Before initiatives like HPEP can be successful, primary care practice requires a more supportive culture of exercise medicine. Counseling, training, encouragement and follow-up services focused on patient behavior change also need to be adequately resourced.

title: An educational approach to improve outcomes in acute renal failure (ARF): report of a quality improvement project
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the impact of a quality improvement project that used a multifaceted educational intervention on how to improve clinicians' knowledge, confidence, and awareness of acute kidney injury (AKI). SETTING: 2 large acute care university hospitals in England, serving a combined population of over 1.5 million people. PARTICIPANTS: All secondary care physicians working in clinical areas were selected, with a specific focus on physicians working in acute admission areas. INTERVENTIONS: A multifaceted educational intervention consisting of traditional didactic lectures, small group case-based teaching, and an interactive web-based learning resource. OUTCOME MEASURES: We assessed clinicians' knowledge of AKI and their self-reported clinical behavior using an interactive questionnaire before and after the educational intervention. Secondary outcome measures included clinical audit of patients' notes before and after the intervention. RESULTS: Twenty-six percent of clinicians reported knowledge of local AKI patterns in the preintervention questionnaire compared to 64% in the follow-up questionnaire (chi&sup2"=60.2, p<0.001). improvement in the number of physicians reporting satisfactory practice in diagnosing AKI, 50% vs 68% (chi⊃=12.1, p<0.001) and investigating patients with AKI, 48% vs 64% (chi²=9.5, p=0.002). Those responsible for clinical audits showed a trend towards better clinical practice.CONCLUSIONS: This quality improvement project using a multifaceted educational intervention improved awareness of AKI, as evidenced by changes in self-reported management of patients with AKI. Physician LRA Elements of the project have been sustained beyond the project period and demonstrate the power of quality improvement projects to help initiate practice change Our findings are limited by fac confounders and highlight the need for formal randomized studies to determine the impact of educational initiatives in the clinical setting.

title: An educational intervention reduces the rate of inappropriate echocardiograms in a hospitalization medical service
abstract: OBJECTIVES: This study sought to prospectively study the impact of an educational intervention based on appropriate use criteria (AUC) on the request for transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) among house staff in the general internal medicine service for patients hospitalized in a center academic doctor. BACKGROUND: AUCs for TTE were developed in response to concerns about the inappropriate use of TTE. To date, educational interventions based on AUC to reduce inappropriate use of TTE have not been studied prospectively. METHODS: A prospective time series analysis of an educational intervention was performed and then compared with orders for TTE in the same medical service during a control period. The intervention consisted of: 1) a lecture for house staff on the 2011 AUC for TTE"; 2) a pocket card applying the AUC to common clinical scenarios"; and 3) biweekly email feedback regarding ordering behavior. TTE orders were tracked daily during the intervention period, and feedback reports were emailed at 2-week intervals. The primary outcome was the proportion of inappropriate and appropriate TTEs ordered during the intervention period. RESULTS: Of all TTEs ordered in the control and study periods, 99% and 98%, respectively, were classifiable using the 2011 AUC. During the study period, there was a 26% reduction in the number of TTEs requested per day compared to the number requested during the control period (2.9 vs. 3.9 TTE, p < 0.001). During the study period, the proportion of inappropriate ETT was significantly lower (5% vs. 13%, p < 0.001) and the proportion of appropriate ETT was significantly higher (93% vs. 84%, p < 0.001). CONCLUSIONS: A simple educational intervention produced a significant reduction in the proportion of inappropriate ETTs and increased the proportion of appropriate ETTs ordered in an inpatient academic medical service. This study provides a practical approach to using AUC to reduce the number of inappropriate TTEs. Further study in other practice settings is warranted.

title: An Efficacy Trial of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy in a Representative Sample of Outpatients with Psychosis
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The efficacy of cognitive behavioral therapies for psychosis (CBTp) has been sufficiently established for inclusion in some national treatment guidelines. However, treatment efficacy does not guarantee effectiveness in routine practice, where clinician experience and patient mix may be different. Therefore, we assess the applicability, acceptability, and effectiveness of CBT when routinely offered in a public mental health service. DESIGN: A prospectively recruited representative sample (N = 94) of patients with psychotic disorders from a geographic catchment area in Melbourne, Australia, were randomized to CBTp or treatment as usual. METHOD: The CBTp intervention included components of psychoeducation, positive symptoms, and comorbid problems. Therapists collaboratively negotiated goals with patients and used treatment components from a manual. Intention-to-treat analyzes used data at baseline, 9 months, and 18 months. RESULTS: Measures of working alliance and client satisfaction indicated excellent acceptability. Both groups improved to a similar degree on the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale, with no advantage for the CBTp group. The most frequently implemented components of CBTp were comorbid disorders/personal problems and "personalized psychoeducation"; working with persistent symptoms was the main focus in relatively few sessions. CONCLUSIONS: The lack of benefit for the CBTp group may be due to : the infrequent focus on positive symptoms (the most replicated outcome domain for CBTp); the unselected nature of patients (rather than those with distressing symptoms or referred by physicians);" or, to the insufficient experience of the therapist.

title: An electronic health record-based intervention to improve tobacco dependence treatment in primary care: a cluster-randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background To improve documentation and treatment of tobacco dependence in primary care, we developed and implemented an enhanced 3-part electronic medical record: (1) smoking status icons, (2) tobacco dependence treatment reminders, and (3) a smart tobacco form that made it easy to order medication and counseling referrals by fax and email. Methods We conducted a cluster randomized controlled trial of improvement in 26 primary care practices between December 19, 2006, and September 30, 2007. The primary outcome was the proportion of documented smokers who contacted a counselor for give up smoking. Secondary outcomes included documentation of coded smoking status and medication prescription. Results During the 9-month study period, 132,630 patients made 315,962 visits to study practices. Coded documentation of smoking increased from 37% of patients to 54% (+17%) in intervention practices and from 35% of patients to 46% (+11%) in control practices (p < 0.001 for the difference in differences). Among the 9,589 patients who were documented smokers at the start of the study, more patients in the intervention practices were recorded as non-smokers at the end of the study (5.3% vs. 1.9% in the control practices"; P < 0.001 Among 12,207 documented smokers, more patients in intervention practices contacted a smoking cessation counselor (3.9% vs. 0.3% in control practices; P < .001). % in control practices, p = 0.40.) Conclusion This electronic health record-based intervention improved documentation of smoking and increased smoking counseling attendance, but not prescription of smoking cessation medications.

title: An electronic medical record-based intervention to improve quality of care for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and atypical presentations of GERD.
abstract: Background Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is common in primary care, but is often underdiagnosed and untreated. GERD can also present with atypical symptoms such as chronic cough and asthma, and doctors may not be aware of this presentation. Our aim was to implement and evaluate an intervention to improve the diagnosis and treatment of GERD and atypical GERD in primary care. Method This was a randomized controlled trial in primary care office practice using a US national network of practices (Medical Quality Improvement Consortium - MQIC) that share the same electronic medical record (EMR). Thirteen practices with 53 providers were randomly assigned to the EMR-based prompting and education intervention, and 14 practices with 66 providers were randomly assigned to the control group with a total of more than 67,000 patients and examining GERD diagnostic outcomes and the proper treatment. Results Among patients who did not have GERD at baseline, new GERD diagnoses were significantly increased in the intervention group (3.1%) versus the control group (2.3%) (P<0.01). This remained significant after controlling for clustering with a diagnostic probability of 1.33 (95% CI 1.13 to 1.56) for the intervention group. For patients with atypical symptoms, those in the intervention group were more likely to receive a GERD diagnosis (OR 2.02, 95% CI 1.41 to 2.88) and to receive GERD treatment (OR 1 .40, 95% CI: 1.08 to 2.88). 1.83) than those in the control group. Conclusions The diagnosis and treatment of GERD in primary care, particularly among patients with atypical symptoms, can be improved by using an EMR-based tool that incorporates decision support and education. However, there is significant room for improvement in using the right treatment.

title: An evaluation of opioid prescription for chronic non-malignant pain by Australian general practitioners
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Our objective was to evaluate the quality of the prescription of opioid analgesia in chronic non-malignant pain (CNMP) by general practitioners (general practitioners, family physicians). DESIGN: An anonymous questionnaire-based cross-sectional survey. SETTING: The setting was five Australian general practice divisions (geographically based GP associations). METHODS: A questionnaire was sent to all members of the division. Outcome measures were compliance with the individual recommendations of the locally derived CNMP practice guidelines. RESULTS: We received 404 responses (23.3% response rate). In the previous fortnight, clinicians prescribed long-term continuous opioids for CNMP for a median of 4 and a mean of 7.1 (+/-8.7) CNMP patients. Guideline agreement (GLC) was poor, as no GP consistently adhered to all guideline items, and only 31% of GPs typically use most items. The GLC was higher to avoid high dose or fast acting formulations. It was lower for strategies that minimize harm to public and individual health, such as starting opioids in a time-limited trial, using contracts, and excluding or managing aberrant behaviors. GLC was positively associated with relevant training or qualifications, registration with the Australian Prescription Drug Monitoring Programme, being an opioid substitution therapy prescriber, and female gender. CONCLUSIONS: In this study, long-term opioids were frequently started for CNMP without a quality medication use approach. Potential sequelae include inadequate pain management and increased opioid-related harm. These data suggest the need for improved resources and training in the management of opioids in pain and addictions.

title: An Evidence-Based Guide to Writing Clinical Research Grant Proposals
abstract: In 1863, Florence Nightingale argued that London hospitals were dangerous, especially compared to provincial facilities. She buttressed this claim with statistics published in the William Fair Registrar General's report, which stated that 24 London hospitals had mortality rates above 90%, while rural hospitals had an average mortality rate of 13%. Farr had calculated mortality rates by dividing the total number of patients who died throughout the year by the number of patients hospitalized in a single day. When calculated as the annual number of deaths divided by the total number of patients hospitalized during the year, the mortality rate for London hospitals was 10%. A raucous debate broke out in the London medical press over the best way to calculate hospital mortality rates. Critics claimed that Farr had not adjusted for differences in disease severity between urban and rural hospitals and that his figures would mislead the public. Farr and Nightingale, in turn, criticized the poor quality of the hospital data. This story reinforces the need to understand the methodological derivation of statistics intended to compare the quality of providers.

title: An evolving perspective on physical activity counseling by medical professionals
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physical inactivity is a modifiable risk factor for many chronic diseases and a leading cause of premature mortality. An increasing proportion of adults worldwide do not engage in sufficient physical activity to prevent or alleviate these adverse effects. Medical professionals have been identified as potentially powerful sources of influence for those who do not meet minimum physical activity guidelines. Health professionals are respected and expected sources of advice and reach a significant and relevant proportion of the population. Despite this potential, physical activity promotion is not routinely practiced by health professionals. DISCUSSION: Medical professionals face several known barriers to promoting physical activity, including lack of time and lack of perceived efficacy in changing physical activity behavior in patients. Furthermore, the evidence on the effective promotion of physical activity by medical professionals is inconclusive. To address these issues, new approaches to physical activity promotion are being proposed. These include collaborating with community physical activity behavior change interventions, preparing patients for effective brief counseling during a consultation with the medical professional, and the use of interactive behavior change technology. SUMMARY: It is important that we recognize the latent risk of physical inactivity among patients presenting in clinical settings. Preparation to improve the patient's physical activity behaviors should begin before the consultation and may include screening for physical activity. Medical professionals should also identify appropriate community interventions to which they can refer physically inactive patients. Outsourcing most of a comprehensive physical activity intervention to community-based interventions will reduce the clinical consultation time needed to address the problem with each patient. Priorities for future research include investigating ways to promote successful referrals and subsequent participation in comprehensive community support programs to increase physical activity levels of inactive patients. In addition, future clinical trials of physical activity interventions need to be evaluated in the context of a broader results framework to inform a systematic consideration of overall strengths and weaknesses with respect to not only efficacy but also cost-effectiveness and the likelihood of translating successful interventions to clinical settings.

title: An experimental study of the determinants of group judgments in the development of clinical guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical guidelines to improve quality of care are a familiar part of clinical practice. Formal consensus methods, such as the nominal group technique, are often used as part of guideline development, but little is known about the factors that affect the statements produced by nominal groups and their consistency with evidence from the literature. research. METHODS: Cognitive behavioral therapy, behavioral therapy, brief psychodynamic interpersonal therapy, and antidepressants for irritable bowel syndrome, chronic fatigue syndrome, and chronic back pain were selected for the study. 16 nominal groups in a factorial design allowed comparison of GPs alone with mixed groups of GPs and specialists, provision of a literature review without provision, and ratings made in the context of realistic or ideal levels of care resources medical. Participants rated suitability independently and again after a facilitated meeting. Audio tapes of four group discussions were analyzed. FINDINGS: There was agreement with the research evidence for 51% of 192 settings. Agreement was more likely if the group was GP only, if a literature review was provided, or if the evidence was in agreement with clinicians' beliefs. Assumptions about the level of available resources had no impact. Clinical and social cues had mixed effects, regardless of research evidence. Qualitative analysis showed the modifying effect of clinical experience and beliefs on research evidence. INTERPRETATION: Guidelines cannot be based on data alone";" judgment is unavoidable. The nominal group technique is a method for obtaining and aggregating judgments in a transparent and structured way. It can provide important information about levels of agreement among experts. However, the conclusions may be in disagreement with the published literature. If they are, the reasons must be explicit.

title: An experimental study of the determinants of group judgments in the development of clinical guidelines
abstract: Background Clinical guidelines to improve quality of care are a familiar part of clinical practice. Formal consensus methods, such as the nominal group technique, are often used as part of guideline development, but little is known about the factors that affect the statements produced by nominal groups and their consistency with evidence from the literature. research".;" Background Clinical guidelines to improve quality of care are a familiar part of clinical practice. Formal consensus methods, such as the nominal group technique, are often used as part of guideline development, but little is known about the factors that affect the statements produced by nominal groups and their consistency with evidence from the literature. research.

title: An experimental study of the determinants of the degree of disagreement within clinical guideline development groups
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the effect of design features and clinical and social cues on the degree of disagreement among participants in a formal consensus development process. METHODS: Factorial design with 16 groups made up of 135 general practitioners (GPs) and 42 mental health professionals from England. The groups rated the appropriateness of four mental health interventions for three conditions (chronic back pain, irritable bowel syndrome, and chronic fatigue syndrome) in the context of various clinical and social cues. The groups differed in three design features: provision of a systematic review of the literature (versus not provided), group composition (mixed versus general practitioner only), and assumptions about available healthcare resources (realistic versus idealistic). Disagreement was measured using the mean absolute deviation of a group's median rating for a scenario. RESULTS: None of the design features significantly affected the degree of disagreement within groups (all p>0.3). Disagreement differed between treatments (tighter consensus for cognitive behavioral therapy and behavioral therapy than for brief psychodynamic intervention therapy and antidepressants) and signals (tighter consensus for depressed patients and patients willing to try any treatment ). CONCLUSION: In terms of the degree of disagreement in the groups in this study, the development of a formal consensus was a sound technique in that the results did not depend on how it was carried out.

title: An Implementation Research Agenda
abstract: In October 2006, England's chief medical officer (CMO) asked Professor Sir John Tooke to chair a high-level group on clinical efficacy in response to the 'Don't waste, don't want' chapter of the 2005 annual CMO report 'On the state of public health. The High Level Group made recommendations to the CMO to address possible ways to improve clinical effectiveness in the UK National Health Service (NHS) and promote clinical commitment to achieve this. The report contained a short section on research needs that emerged from the report writing process, but to more fully identify the relevant research agenda, Professor Sir John Tooke asked Professor Martin Eccles to convene a group of experts: the Clinical Efficacy Research. Agenda Group (CERAG) – to define the research agenda. CERAG's terms of reference were 'to further develop the research agenda in relation to the pursuit of clinically effective practice within the National Health Service (UK)'. This editorial presents the summary of the CERAG report and the recommendations.

title: An integrated framework for safety, quality and risk management: an incident management and reporting system based on a universal patient safety classification
abstract: More needs to be done to improve safety and quality and manage risks in health care. Existing processes are fragmented and there is no single comprehensive source of information about what is going wrong. An integrated framework is needed for safety, quality and risk management, with an information and incident management system based on a universal patient safety classification. The World Alliance for Patient Safety provides a platform for the development of a consistent approach";" 43 desirable attributes for such an approach are discussed. An example of an incident reporting and management system serving a patient safety classification is presented, with a brief description of how and where it is currently used. Any such system is worthless unless it improves safety and quality. Quadruple-loop learning (personal, local, national and international) is proposed with examples of how an exemplary system has been used successfully at the various levels. The opportunity now exists to "get it right" through international cooperation through the World Health Organization to develop an integrated framework that incorporates systems that can accommodate information from all sources, manage and monitor things that are going wrong, and enable global exchange of information. and the dissemination of tools for the implementation of strategies that have proven to work.

title: An integrative review exploring decision-making factors that influence mental health nurses' use of restraint
abstract: UNLABELED: WHAT IS KNOWN ABOUT THE SUBJECT?: There is emerging evidence that highlights the counter-therapeutic impact of the use of restraint and promotes the minimization of this practice in mental health care. Mental health nurses are often the professional group that uses restraint and understanding the factors that influence their decision making becomes critical. To date, there are no other published articles that have conducted a similar broad search to review this topic. WHAT DOES THIS PAPER ADD TO EXISTING KNOWLEDGE?: Eight emerging themes are identified as factors influencing mental health nurses' decision-making in the use of restraint. The topics are: 'safety for all', 'restraint as a necessary intervention', 'restraint as a last resort', 'role conflict', 'maintaining control', 'staff composition', 'knowledge and perception of behaviors of patients', and the 'psychological impact'. The 'last resort' seems to be the mantra of acceptable use of containment, although, to date, there are no studies that specifically consider what this concept really is. WHAT ARE THE IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE?: These findings should be taken into account in evaluating the use of restraint in mental health settings and appropriate strategies implemented to support the shift towards minimization of restraint. As the concept of 'last resort' is mentioned in many policies and guidelines internationally without a published understanding of what this means, research should prioritize it as the critical next step in restraint minimization efforts. INTRODUCTION: While mechanical and manual restraint as an institutional method of control within mental health settings may seem necessary at times, there is emerging literature that highlights the potential counter-therapeutic impact of this practice for patients and staff. Nurses are the professional group most likely to use mechanical and manual restraint methods in mental health settings. Therefore, in-depth knowledge is warranted to understand what factors influence nurses' decision-making regarding the use of restraint. OBJECTIVE: To explore what influences the decision-making of mental health nurses in the use of restraint. METHOD: An integrative review was conducted using the Cooper framework. RESULTS: Eight emerging themes were identified: 'safety for all', 'restraint as a necessary intervention', 'restraint as a last resort', 'role conflict', 'maintaining control', 'staff composition', 'knowledge and perception of patient behaviors' and the 'psychological impact'. These topics highlight how mental health nurses' decision-making is influenced by ethical and safety responsibilities, as well as interpersonal and staff-related factors. CONCLUSION: Research is needed to better understand "last resort" experience and updating in the use of restraint and to provide strategies to prevent the use of restraint in mental health settings.

title: An Intervention to Change Physician Behavior: Conceptual Framework for the Multicolor Simplified Asthma Guideline Reminder (MSAGR)
abstract: Clinical practice guidelines reduce variation in health care because they standardize the care that health care providers offer. Seventeen years after publication, the National Asthma Education and Prevention Program (NAEPP) guidelines are considered the "gold standard" in asthma care, but remain underutilized despite three revisions , the last one in July 2007. Multiple factors are presented for the lack of compliance with the guidelines. This article discusses the Multi-color Asthma Guidelines Simplified Reminder (MSAGR), an algorithmic graph intervention to help change clinician behavior for better adherence to NAEPP guidelines, and describes the conceptual framework underpinning this intervention as a means of predicting better outcomes for providers and children.

title: An investigative journalist discusses medical ethics
abstract: KIE: Campbell criticizes Britain's medical and research community and the General Medical Council (GMC) for their lack of initiative in investigating the activities of Drs. James Sharp and Jabar Sultan. Sharp and Sultan carried out a series of highly publicized but unethical and potentially harmful experiments on private patients that finally came to public attention thanks to Campbell's report and a BBC television programme. Campbell questions why leading physicians, journal reviewers and others did not speak out against Sharp and Sultan or alert the GMC, and why the GMC did not independently investigate investigators. He warns that with the increasing commercialization of British medicine, legislation is needed to create a national regulatory body to oversee standards in the private sector.

title: An ongoing struggle: a mixed-methods systematic review of interventions, barriers, and facilitators to achieving optimal self-management by children and youth with type 1 diabetes in educational settings.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Type 1 diabetes most commonly occurs in younger children who are often of preschool age and enter the education system with diabetes-related support needs that evolve over time. It is important that children are supported to optimally manage their diet, exercise, blood glucose monitoring, and insulin regimen at school. Young people manage themselves at school/university. METHOD: Theory-based mixed-methods systematic review to determine intervention efficacy and synthesize views of children, parents, and professionals on barriers and facilitators to achieving optimal diabetes self-care and control for children and youth aged 3 to 25 years of age in educational settings. RESULTS: Eleven intervention and 55 view studies were included. Meta-analysis was not possible. The study foci largely coincided with school guidance on diabetes. Intervention studies were limited to specific settings with a high risk of bias for the most part. Opinion studies were mostly of moderate quality with common transferable findings. Health plans and support from school nurses (various types) were effective. Telemedicine at school was effective for individual case management. Most educational interventions to increase the knowledge and confidence of children or school staff had significant short-term effects, but longer follow-up is required. Children, parents, and staff said they struggled with many common structural, organizational, educational, and attitudinal barriers to school. In general, aspects of school guidance (for example, individual health plans) had not been implemented. The children recognized and appreciated the school staff who were trained and trusted to support diabetes management. Research with university students was lacking. Supporting college students on campus significantly improved diabetes knowledge, attitudes, and self-management. Self-management was easier for students who combined diabetes management with the student's lifestyle, such as adopting strategies to control alcohol use. CONCLUSION: This new mixed-method systematic review is the first to integrate intervention effectiveness with child/parent/professional views mapped against school diabetes guidelines. Diabetes management could be improved overall by fully implementing and auditing the impact of the guideline. The evidence is limited in quality and there are gaps in our knowledge of what works. Telemedicine between health care providers and schools, and school nurse support for children is effective in specific contexts, but not all education systems employ on-site nurses. More innovative and sustainable solutions and robust evaluations are required. Comprehensive lifestyle approaches for college students deserve further development and evaluation.

title: An update on the management of patients with non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndromes
abstract: More than 780,000 patients in the United States are diagnosed with acute coronary syndrome (ACS) each year. As physicians, it is our responsibility to provide timely diagnosis, treatment, and management of these patients. After identifying the patient with ACS and confirming that there is no ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction requiring immediate revascularization, clinicians should perform a diagnostic workup for non-ST elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTEACS). It is important to understand the latest best practice guidelines in the treatment and management of NSTEACS patients who have high in-hospital mortality rates. Physicians must integrate the medical history and examination, electrocardiogram, and laboratory findings to correctly diagnose NSTEACS. Early treatment with guideline-directed medical therapy is imperative even in the setting of an early invasive strategy with cardiac catheterization and percutaneous coronary intervention. The focus of this review is to discuss appropriate strategies for the evaluation and management of patients with NSTEACS according to the most recent ACC/AHA practice guidelines.

title: Anesthetics and other shock treatments: World War I and beyond
abstract: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a major health risk factor for military personnel deployed in modern warfare. In World War I this condition (then known as shell shock or 'neurasthenia') was such a problem that French doctors started 'advanced psychiatry' in 1915. Some British doctors tried general anesthesia as a treatment (ether and chloroform ), while others preferred the application of electricity. In 1917 four British 'advanced psychiatric units' were established. Hospitals for shell-shocked soldiers were also established in Britain, including (for officers) the Craiglockhart War Hospital in Edinburgh";" patients diagnosed with more serious psychiatric conditions were transferred to the Royal Edinburgh Asylum. Towards the end of 1918, the anesthetic and electrical treatments of shell shock were gradually displaced by modified Freudian methods of psychodynamic intervention. The efficacy of 'advanced psychiatry' was controversial. In 1922, the War Office produced a report on war shock with recommendations for the prevention of shell shock. However, when World War II broke out in 1939, this seemed to have been ignored. The term "combat fatigue" was introduced when failure rates became alarming, and then the value of preselection was recognized. At Maudsley Hospital in London in 1940, barbiturate abreaction was advocated for rapid relief of severe anxiety and hysteria, using intravenous anesthetics: Somnifaine, paraldehyde, Amytal sodium. 'Pentothal narcosis' and 'narcoanalysis' were adopted by British and American military psychiatrists. However, by 1945, medical thinking gradually settled on the same approaches that seemed effective in 1918. The term PTSD was introduced in 1980. In the UK, the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence guidelines for management (NICE) (2005) recommend Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy and consideration of antidepressants.

title: Analgesia and anesthesia for neonates: study design and ethical issues
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this article is to summarize the clinical, methodological, and ethical considerations for investigators interested in designing future trials in neonatal analgesia and anesthesia, in the hope of stimulating further research in this field. METHODS: MEDLINE, PubMed, EMBASE, and Cochrane registry databases were searched using subject headings related to infant, newborn, neonate, analgesia, anesthesia, ethics, and study design. Cross references and personal files were manually searched. Studies reporting original data or review articles related to these topics were appraised and critically appraised by experts for each topic area. Data on population demographics, study characteristics, and cognitive and behavioral outcomes were systematically abstracted and synthesized and refined by group members. The data synthesis and results were reviewed by a panel of independent experts and presented to a broader audience, including clinicians, scientists, regulatory staff and industry representatives at the Newborn Drug Development Initiative workshop. The recommendations were revised after extensive discussions at the workshop and among committee members. RESULTS: The design of clinical trials to investigate novel or currently available approaches to analgesia and anesthesia in neonates requires consideration of salient study designs and ethical issues. Conditions requiring treatment include pain/stress resulting from invasive procedures, surgical operations, inflammatory conditions, and routine neonatal intensive care. Study design considerations should define inclusion and exclusion criteria, a rationale for stratification, confounding effects of comorbid conditions, and other clinical factors. Significant ethical issues include the limitations of studying infants, obtaining informed consent, conducting benefit-risk assessments, defining compensation or rewards for participation, safety considerations, the use of placebo controls, and variability between meetings. of institutional review in the interpretation of federal guidelines on research involving human subjects. . For optimal study design, investigators must formulate well-defined study questions, choose appropriate trial designs, estimate drug efficacy, calculate sample size, determine study duration, identify pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic parameters, and avoid drug interactions. Specific outcome measures may include scores on pain assessment scales, various biomarkers and their response patterns, process outcomes (eg, length of hospital stay, time to extubation), intermediate or long-term outcomes, and security parameters. CONCLUSIONS: Much more research is needed in this field to formulate a scientifically sound, evidence-based, and clinically useful framework for the management of anesthesia and analgesia in neonates.
