Newer study designs and additional ethical dilemmas may be defined by the accumulation of data in this field.

title: Analysis of information submitted by sponsors of clinical trials regarding the safety of investigational drugs
abstract: During the conduct of clinical trials in medical institutions, trial sponsors submit information on the safety of investigational drugs in accordance with good clinical practice guidelines. In the present study, clinical trial reports conducted at Tokyo University Hospital were examined, focusing on the safety information provided to the Institutional Review Board (IRB). Clinical trial sponsors submitted 202 reports (52 protocols) of safety information to the IRB between April 2000 and March 2001, of which 185 contained a total of 3,021 cases of adverse events. Of these, 194 reports were deemed not associated with any significant problems by clinical/medical investigators and the trials were continued. For 157 of those 194 reports, informing test subjects of report content, including adverse events, was deemed unnecessary. The decision whether or not test subjects should be informed of such content tends to depend on the causal relationship between the adverse events and drug intake, as well as the predictability of the adverse events. For 8 of those 194 reports, the IRB recommended that clinical investigators/physicians provide information to test subjects and/or submit detailed information on the status of these subjects to the IRB. From these results, we suggest that it is necessary to establish a system to unify and evaluate drug safety information to provide safe and efficient clinical trials.

title: Palm Angina: Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial of Palm PDA Software for Referrals for Cardiac Testing.
abstract: OBJECTIVE Personal digital assistants (PDAs) are popular with physicians: in 2003, 33% of Canadian physicians reported using them in their practices. We do not know, however, whether the use of a PDA changes the behavior of practicing physicians. We studied the efficacy of a PDA software application in helping family physicians diagnose angina among patients with chest pain. DESIGN Prospective randomized controlled pilot trial using a cluster design. SETTING Primary care practices in the Toronto area. PARTICIPANTS Eighteen family physicians belonging to the North Toronto Primary Care Research Network (Nortren) or recruited from a local hospital. INTERVENTIONS We randomized clinicians to receive a Palm PDA (which included angina diagnostic software) or continue with conventional care. Physicians prospectively recorded the care process of patients aged 30 to 75 years with suspected angina, for 7 months. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Was the process of caring for patients with suspected angina improved when their doctors had PDAs and software? The primary outcomes we analyzed were the frequency of cardiac stress test requests for suspected angina and the adequacy of referral for cardiac stress testing at presentation and for nuclear cardiology testing after cardiac stress testing. The secondary outcome was referral to cardiologists. RESULTS The software led to greater overall use of cardiac stress tests (81% vs. 50%). The absolute increase was 31% (p = 0.007, 95% confidence interval [CI], 8% to 58%). There was a trend toward more appropriate use of exercise testing (48.6% PDA vs. 28.6% control), an increase of 20% (p=0.284, 95% CI: -11.54% at 51.4%). There was also a trend toward more appropriate use of nuclear cardiology after cardiac stress testing (63.0% vs. 45.5%), an absolute increase of 17.5% (P=0.400, 95% CI : -13.9% to 48.9%). Referrals to cardiologists did not increase (38.2% with PDA vs 40.9%, p = 0.869). CONCLUSION A PDA-based software application can improve the care of patients with suspected angina seen in family practices";" this finding requires confirmation in a larger study.

title: anorexia nervosa
Antibiotic prescription in long-term care facilities: a multidisciplinary qualitative investigation
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To explore the opinions of health professionals on the prescription of antibiotics in long-term care facilities (LTCF). Use the findings to recommend intervention strategies for antimicrobial stewardship in LTCF. DESIGN: Semi-structured qualitative interviews were conducted. Data were analyzed by thematic content analysis. After the interviews, the emerging findings were mapped into the Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF), and the behavior change wheel and behavior change technique (BCT) taxonomy were used to recommend future intervention strategies. PARTICIPANTS: Interviews were conducted with 37 health professionals working in LTCF (10 general practitioners, 4 consultants, 14 nurses, 9 pharmacists) between December 2012 and March 2013. SETTING: Interviews were conducted in the Cork metropolitan region . RESULTS: The main TDF domains that emerged were: 'Knowledge', 'Environmental context and resources', 'Social influences', 'Beliefs about consequences', 'Memory, attention and decision making', and the findings identified a need of 'Behavior regulation'. Many participants believed that antibiotic prescribing was satisfactory in their LTCF, despite a lack of surveillance activities. CONCLUSIONS: This study, using the TDF and BCT taxonomy, found that antibiotic prescription in LTCF is influenced by many social and contextual factors. Patient population and setting challenges, belief in patient consequences, and lack of guideline implementation and knowledge about antibiotic prescribing patterns are important challenges that need to be addressed. Based on the study findings and the application of the TDF and BCT taxonomy, we suggest some practical intervention roles for antimicrobial stewardship in LTCF.

title: antibiotic resistance
abstract: Antibiotic resistance is economically and physiologically costly. Control of antibiotic resistance will require the aggressive implementation of numerous strategies. Ongoing vigilance is needed to monitor the known classes of antibiotics and to be able to identify the development of other potential types. Early intervention is needed to combat the rising rate of resistance. The persistent use of hygiene measures and the controlled use of antibiotics will limit the spread of antibiotic resistance. Health care providers should monitor compliance with control measures. Environmental and hand control measures continue to be a critical component of staff education activities. Active management of infections with non-pharmacological treatments should be promoted. Motivational campaigns will reinforce positive infection control behaviors. Constant monitoring of antibiotic use will help meet CDC guidance to combat antibiotic resistance and keep the population healthy.

title: Antibiotic treatment for 6 weeks versus 12 weeks in patients with pyogenic vertebral osteomyelitis: an open-label, non-inferiority, randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background The duration of treatment for patients with vertebral osteomyelitis is based primarily on expert recommendation rather than evidence. Our aim was to establish whether 6 weeks of antibiotic treatment is not less than 12 weeks in patients with pyogenic vertebral osteomyelitis.";" Background The duration of treatment for patients with vertebral osteomyelitis is based primarily on expert recommendation rather than evidence. Our aim was to establish whether 6 weeks of antibiotic treatment is not less than 12 weeks in patients with pyogenic vertebral osteomyelitis.

title: Prescription patterns of antimalarials in government hospitals and selected parastatal hospitals in Lagos, Nigeria
abstract: BACKGROUND: Malaria is a curable and preventable disease and is a major public health problem in Nigeria. Chloroquine was the first-line drug in its treatment in Nigeria until recently, where artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) are being promoted. Inappropriate prescribing, that is, not prescribing drugs according to evidence-based guidelines to ensure safe, effective, and economical use, is irrational drug use behavior. Greater benefits of chloroquine or a slowing of progression to resistance could be achieved by improving prescribing practice, drug quality, and patient compliance. OBJECTIVE: To determine the pattern of prescription of antimalarials and to evaluate the rational prescription of chloroquine by prescribers in government and parastatal hospitals in the state of Lagos. METHODS: The study was carried out in the ten government general hospitals under the Lagos State Hospital Management Board (now Lagos State Health Service Commission), a parastatal hospital, and an oil company clinic, using patient prescriptions. One hundred prescriptions for adults and children were systematically sampled for each month over a one-year period (January to December 2000). When there were fewer than 100 prescriptions in a month, all available prescriptions were sampled for analysis. RESULTS: The average number of medications per consultation in all hospitals was 4.259 +/- 0.009. The average number of injections per encounter was 1.215 +/- 0.009. About 48.5% of all prescriptions had at least one injection, while 40.9% of prescriptions had dipyrone injection. The average cost of medications per encounter was N 147.40 +/- 0.765. The percentage of encounters with chloroquine was 82.5% followed by sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine 14.2%. The percentage of prescriptions with the correct dose of chloroquine was 47.5%. CONCLUSIONS: Polypharmacy exists in all hospitals. The average number of medications per visit for most hospitals was greater than 4. Less than half of the prescriptions had the correct dose of chloroquine. This study can serve as a baseline for intervention on irrational prescription.

title: Antioxidant vitamin supplements in the prevention of cardiovascular diseases
abstract: Oxidative stress, in particular the oxidative modification of LDL cholesterol, appears to be of great importance in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis. Several observational epidemiological studies have suggested that intake of antioxidant vitamins is associated with reduced cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. Furthermore, experimental animal studies have shown that antioxidant vitamins slow the progression of atherosclerosis. However, prospective controlled clinical trials have failed to demonstrate a benefit of antioxidant vitamin supplementation in the primary or secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease. Therefore, the use of antioxidants and vitamin supplements cannot be recommended as a preventive or therapeutic intervention.

title: Antipruritic therapy in atopic eczema
abstract: In patients with atopic eczema, the quality of life is seriously affected by a tormenting itch. As the pathogenesis of pruritus is not understood, symptomatic measures are the mainstay of treatment along with avoidance of aggravating factors. They include emollients, topical and systemic active ingredients, and physiotherapy (eg, phototherapy) adjusted to the severity of the disease. Behavioral therapy offers additional support. Newer treatment modalities, partly still in the experimental stage, such as immunomodulators, immunosuppressive agents and opiate antagonists, are reserved for patients who do not respond";" they too are checked.

title: Antipsychotic polypharmacy in schizophrenia: benefits and risks
abstract: Antipsychotic polypharmacy refers to the co-prescription of more than one antipsychotic drug for an individual patient. Prescription surveys in psychiatric services internationally have identified relatively frequent and consistent use of combination antipsychotics, usually for people with established schizophrenia, with a prevalence of up to 50% in some clinical settings. A common reason for prescribing more than one antipsychotic is to obtain a greater or more rapid therapeutic response than has been achieved with antipsychotic monotherapy. However, the evidence on the risks and benefits of such a strategy is equivocal and is generally not considered adequate to justify a recommendation for its use in routine clinical practice in psychiatry. Combination antipsychotics make an important contribution to high-dose prescribing, are associated with a greater burden of adverse effects, and are of limited value in helping to establish the optimal maintenance regimen for a patient. The relatively widespread use of antipsychotic polypharmacy identified in cross-sectional surveys reflects not only the addition of a second antipsychotic to increase therapeutic response, but also the use of antipsychotic medication as needed (primarily to treat disturbed behavior), gradual cross-titration while switching from one antipsychotic to another, and clozapine boosting with a second antipsychotic when the disease has not responded adequately to an optimized trial of clozapine. This review addresses clinical trial data and other evidence for each of these pharmacological approaches. Examples of systematic practice-based interventions designed to reduce the prevalence of antipsychotic polypharmacy, most of which have had modest success, are also reviewed. In general, the guidelines agree that if combination antipsychotics are prescribed to treat refractory psychotic illness, this should be done after other evidence-based pharmacological treatments, such as clozapine, have been exhausted. In addition, its prescription for each patient must be in the context of an individual trial, with monitoring of clinical response and adverse effects, and adequate monitoring of physical health.

title: Application of a hospital audit to the use of nebulizers: the Case of the Hotel-Dieu de France-Lebanon
abstract: PROBLEM: The aim of the study was to reduce unwarranted prescriptions for nebulized therapy, to meet international guidelines and reduce healthcare costs. METHODS: DESIGN: We conducted a prospective controlled study to assess the impact of local guidelines aimed at improving physician behavior on the appropriateness and costs of implementation. BACKGROUND AND SETTING: All departments of a university hospital: medical and surgical wards, intensive care units, emergency rooms, and overnight units. KEY MEASURE FOR CHANGE: Reduction in the number of inappropriate prescriptions for nebulized therapy. STRATEGIES FOR CHANGE: Implementation included two educational presentations, posters displayed in all departments, emails sent to all physicians and residents, and prescription re-evaluation one week later. RESULTS: Before the intervention, the rate of inappropriate prescriptions was 11.9% (42/358 of the patients treated with nebulizers had no indication for this treatment and 3/19 of the patients had an indication for nebulization but were not treated) ”; " at post-intervention, the rate of inappropriate prescriptions was 14.6% (15.7% of patients with no indication for treatment, but no patients with an indication for treatment not treated), reflecting a lack of significant impact of the intervention CONCLUSIONS: The simple presentation of clinical guidelines did not lead to a change in medical practices.Another approach is needed to improve this result effectively.

title: Application of the MAT-CHDSP to evaluate adherence to the guideline and achievement of the therapeutic goal in the secondary prevention of coronary heart disease after percutaneous coronary intervention
abstract: PURPOSE: Numerous studies have documented suboptimal adherence to guideline recommendations in the secondary prevention of coronary heart disease (CHD(SP)). Clinical practice guidelines (CPG) are continuously developed to define appropriate patient care, with the aim of reducing the risk of morbidity and death. The Medication Assessment Tool for CHD(SP) (MAT-CHD(SP)) was developed to assess adherence to CPGs on drug therapy and follow-up of patients with CHD(SP). The aim of this study was to explore whether the MAT-CHD(SP) could be applied retrospectively to assess adherence to guidelines and achievement of therapeutic goals in the secondary prevention of CHD. METHODS: We collected data from electronic medical records of all patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention with stent implantation from January to March 2008 (n = 300) and applied the MAT-CHD(SP). We measured the time for data collection and MAT application and tested reproducibility by calculating Cohen's kappa (kappa) value for inter- and intra-observer agreement. RESULTS: A total of 247 MAT applications were analyzed, showing an overall applicability of 66% of the 4446 MAT-CHD(SP) criteria and a high reproducibility of the MAT-CHD(SP) application (kappa values of 0, 93 and 0.95 for intraobserver and interobserver). agreement, respectively). The mean time for data collection and application of MAT-CHD(SP) was 11 min. Adherence to prescription criteria was high (>75%), but compliance with cholesterol and blood pressure therapeutic goals was low (<50%). Documentation of lifestyle advice achieved intermediate (50-75%) or low adherence, as did therapy modifications in patients who did not achieve therapy goals on hospital admission. CONCLUSIONS: The MAT-CHD(SP) offers a means to identify both adherence and non-adherence to CHD(SP)-related CPGs, is applicable in the retrospective evaluation of CHD(SP), and identifies potentials to improve CHD(SP). patient care.

title: Application of theory to improve audit and feedback interventions to increase acceptance of evidence-based transfusion practice: an intervention development protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: Blood transfusion audits show that about 20% of transfusions fall outside national recommendations and guidelines. Audit and feedback is a widely used quality improvement intervention, but effects in clinical practice are variable, suggesting potential for improvement. Behavior theory, behavior change frameworks, and behavior change techniques provide systematic processes for improving intervention. This study is part of a larger program of work to promote acceptance of evidence-based transfusion practice. OBJECTIVES: The objectives of this study are to design two theoretically improved audit and feedback interventions";" one focused on content and one on delivery, and investigate feasibility and acceptability. METHODS: Study A (Content): A coding framework based on current evidence regarding audit and feedback, and behavior change theory and frameworks will be developed and applied as part of a structured content analysis to specify the key components of existing feedback documents. Prototype content-enhanced feedback documents will be developed, as well as a protocol outlining principles for improving feedback content. Study B (Delivery): Individual semi-structured interviews with health professionals and observations of team meetings in four hospitals will be used to specify and identify views on current audit and feedback practice. Interviews will be based on a topic guide developed using the Theoretical Domains Framework and the Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research. Analysis of transcripts based on these frameworks will form the evidence base for developing a protocol describing an enhanced intervention that focuses on feedback delivery. Study C (Feasibility and Acceptability): The improved interventions will be tested in four hospitals. Semi-structured interviews, questionnaires and observations will be used to assess feasibility and acceptability. DISCUSSION: This intervention development paper reflects the UK Medical Research Council's guidance on the development of complex interventions, which emphasizes the importance of a sound theoretical basis for intervention design and recommends a systematic assessment of feasibility and acceptability. before taking the interventions to a large-scale evaluation. randomized study. The work includes specification of current practice so that, in trials later in this programme, there will be a clear distinction between control conditions (usual practice) and interventions to be tested.

title: Applying Choice Architecture Principles to Understanding HIV Testing: Results from Malawi and Zimbabwe
abstract: World Health Organization-led improvements in antenatal HIV counseling in sub-Saharan Africa between 2004 and 2011 have seen a parallel increase in HIV testing. We sought to determine the extent to which the use of choice architecture principles (one that introduces an opt-out as a default option) affects HIV testing uptake, beyond individual-level attitudes and cognitions. We analyzed Demographic and Health Survey data collected between 2004 and 2011 in Zimbabwe (N = 1,330) and Malawi (N = 4,043), countries where more than 10% of adults have HIV. We explored the influence of demographic variables, ways of knowing about HIV, stigma against people living with HIV, attitudes about spousal abuse, and whether or not HIV testing had been offered during antenatal visits. The results demonstrated that, taking into account secular trends in higher testing rates, structural-level support was the strongest predictor of HIV testing above and beyond individual-level attitudes and cognitions. Read more: https://guilfordjournals.com/doi/abs/10.1521/aeap.2015.27.4.362

title: Approaches based on behavioral economics could help push patients and providers towards lower health spending growth
abstract: Policies that change the environment or context in which decisions are made and "push" people toward particular choices have been relatively ignored in health care. This article examines the role that behavioral economics-based approaches could play in "nudgeting" providers and patients in ways that could slow the growth of health care spending. The basic idea of behavioral economics is that behavior is guided by the very fallible human brain and highly influenced by the environment or context in which decisions are made. In policy areas such as pensions and personal savings, approaches based on behavioral economics have provided remarkable results. In health care, such approaches have been used successfully but to a limited extent, such as the use of surgical checklists that have increased patient safety and reduced costs. With health care spending rising at unsustainable rates, we review the role behavioral economics-based approaches could play in offering policymakers a potential set of new tools to curb spending growth.

title: Architectural frameworks: defining the structures to implement learning health systems
abstract: Background The vision of transforming health systems into learning health systems (LHS) that rapidly and continuously transform knowledge into better health outcomes at lower cost is generating increased interest from government agencies, health organizations, and communities of health research. While existing initiatives demonstrate that different approaches can be successful in making the LHS vision a reality, they are too varied in purpose, focus, and scale to be replicated without undue effort. In fact, the necessary structures to effectively design and implement LHS on a larger scale are lacking. In this article, we propose the use of architectural frameworks to develop LHS that adhere to a recognized vision while adapting to your specific organizational context. Architectural frameworks are high-level descriptions of an organization as a system";" they capture the structure of its main components at various levels, the interrelationships between these components, and the principles that guide their evolution. Because these frameworks support the analysis of LHS and allow its outcomes to be simulated, they act as pre-implementation decision support tools that identify potential barriers and enablers to system development. Therefore, the chances of a successful deployment of the LHS are increased. Discussion We present an architectural framework for the LHS that incorporates five dimensional goals, scientific, social, technical, and ethical, commonly found in the LHS literature. The proposed architectural framework is made up of six decision layers that model these dimensions. The performance layer models the goals, the scientific layer models the scientific dimension, the organizational layer models the social dimension, the data layer and information technology layer model the technical dimension, and the ethics and security layer models the ethical dimension. We describe the types of decisions that need to be made within each layer and identify methods to support decision making. Conclusion In this paper, we describe a high-level architectural framework based on the conceptual and empirical LHS literature. Application of this architectural framework can guide the development and implementation of new LHS and the evolution of existing ones, as it enables a clear and critical understanding of the types of decisions that underlie LHS operations. More research is required to evaluate and refine its generalization and methods.

title: Are non-specific practice guidelines potentially harmful? A randomized comparison of the effect of nonspecific versus specific guidelines on medical decision making.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To test the ability of two different formats of clinical practice guidelines to influence the medical order for electrodiagnostic tests in low back pain. DATA SOURCES/STUDY DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial of the effect of practice guidelines on physician self-reported test requesting behavior in response to a series of 12 clinical vignettes. Data came from a national random sample of 900 US neurologists, physical medicine physicians, and general internists. INTERVENTION: US Agency for Health Policy Low Back Panel Medical and Research developed two different versions of a practical guide to the use of electrodiagnostic tests (EDT). The two guidelines were similar in content but varied in the specificity of their recommendations. DATA COLLECTION: The proportion of clinical vignettes for which EDTs were ordered for appropriate and inappropriate clinical indications in each of the three groups of physicians were randomized to receive either vignettes alone, vignettes plus the nonspecific version of the guideline, or vignettes. plus the specific version of the guide. guide. MAIN FINDINGS: The survey response rate was 71 percent. The proportion of appropriate vignettes for which EDTs were ordered averaged 77 percent for the no-guidance group, 71 percent for the nonspecific guidance group, and 79 percent for the specific guidance group (p = 0.002). The corresponding values for the number of EDTs ordered by inappropriate vignettes were 32 percent, 32 percent, and 26 percent, respectively (p = 0.08). Pairwise comparisons showed that physicians who received the nonspecific guidelines requested fewer EDTs for appropriate clinical vignettes than physicians who did not receive the guidelines (p = 0.02). In addition, compared with physicians receiving nonspecific guidelines, physicians receiving specific guidelines ordered significantly more EDT for appropriate vignettes (p = 0.0007) and significantly less EDT for inappropriate vignettes (p = 0.04). CONCLUSIONS: Clarity and clinical applicability of a guideline may be important attributes that contribute to the effects of practice guidelines.

title: Are nurses an answer to the new needs of primary care?
Are the doctors of the psychiatric crisis assessment and treatment team in the first line of psychotherapy?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: There is limited data on the psychological interventions used by Crisis Assessment and Treatment (CAT) team clinicians, despite practice guidelines stating that part of their role is to provide counselling. This study aimed to catalog and categorize the range of psychotherapeutic interventions used by clinicians of a CAT team operating within a metropolitan area. METHODS: Self-report care episode data were collected regarding clinicians' views on the type of psychotherapeutic intervention they employed and details of what they discussed with patients, and the location and duration of interventions. RESULTS: 32 healthcare episodes were catalogued. On average, physicians spent 74% of their total contact time with patients participating in psychological interventions. A wide range of strategies were used, drawn from a broad theoretical base. In addition to general approaches that aid engagement, interventions can be classified into the following categories: meta-strategy ("treatment about treatment"), "critical", "practical", specific psychotherapeutic (cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and others). ), and solidarity. CONCLUSIONS: Physicians found themselves spending most of their patient contact time involved in psychological interventions drawn from a broad theoretical base. Observational studies of what physicians actually do and empirical investigation of its effectiveness may have implications for the training and supervision of physicians.

title: Have the NHS National Results Frameworks passed their expiry date?
Are we adequately preparing the next generation of physicians to prescribe exercise for prevention and treatment? Residents express desire for more training in exercise prescription
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physical activity (PA) is a key intervention for chronic diseases, yet few clinicians provide exercise prescription (PE). EP is an important component in broader strategies to reduce noncommunicable diseases (NCDs). Our goal was to assess the knowledge, competency, and perspectives of PD family medicine residents (FMRs) to help inform future curriculum development. METHODS: A 49-item cross-sectional survey was administered to 396 FMRs from the University of British Columbia. Residents' knowledge, competence, attitudes/beliefs, current practices, personal physical activity levels, and training prospects were assessed primarily using a 7-point Likert scale. RESULTS: The response rate was 80.6% (319/396). After removing 25 that did not meet the inclusion criteria, 294 were included in the final analysis. The majority, 95.6% of FMRs, reported that PE is important in their future practice, despite having low knowledge of Canadian PA guidelines (mean score 1.77/4), low self-reported competence to prescribing exercise as prevention (mean score 13.35/21) and classifying themselves as "somewhat incompetent" prescribing exercise to patients with chronic diseases (mean score 11.26/21). FMR believes that physical activity is an integral part of their patients' health (98.0%), sedentary behavior is detrimental (97.9%), and feels a responsibility to discuss physical activity with patients (99.7 %). Few FMR (14.9%) perceive their PE training as adequate and 91.0% want more. CONCLUSIONS: FMR reporting PE is important, they still do not perceive that they are sufficiently prepared to provide PE. In future curriculum development, medical educators should consider residents' low knowledge, competency, perceived support of the program, and their expressed desire for more training in exercise prescription.

title: ARIA 2016: Care pathways that implement emerging technologies for predictive medicine in rhinitis and asthma throughout the life cycle
abstract: The Allergic Rhinitis and its Impact on Asthma (ARIA) initiative began during a World Health Organization workshop in 1999. The initial goals were (1) to propose a new classification of allergic rhinitis, (2) to promote the concept of multiple morbidity in asthma and rhinitis and (3) develop guidelines with all stakeholders that could be used globally for all countries and populations. ARIA, disseminated and implemented in more than 70 countries worldwide, is now focused on the implementation of emerging technologies for individualized and predictive medicine. MASK [MACVIA (Contre les Maladies Chroniques pour un Vieillissement Actif)-ARIA Sentinel Network] uses mobile technology to develop care pathways for the management of rhinitis and asthma by a multidisciplinary group and by patients themselves. An app (Android and iOS) is available in 20 countries and 15 languages. It uses a visual analog scale to assess symptom control and work productivity, as well as a clinical decision support system. It is associated with an interoperable tablet for doctors and other health professionals. The expansion strategy uses the recommendations of the European Innovation Association on Active and Healthy Ageing. The aim of the novel ARIA approach is to provide an active and healthy life for people suffering from rhinitis, regardless of their age, sex or socioeconomic level, in order to reduce the health and social inequalities generated by the disease.

title: Top: Effects of an educational intervention on prescribing behavior on CVD prevention in general practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: The evidence on the effectiveness of educational interventions on the prescription of behavior modification in the prevention of cardiovascular disease is still insufficient. We evaluated the effects of a brief educational intervention on the prescription of hydroxymethylglutaryl-CoA reductase inhibitors (statins), platelet aggregation inhibitors (IPAs), and antihypertensive agents (HAs). DESIGN: Cluster randomized controlled trial with general practitioner (GP) continuing medical education (CME) groups. METHODS: Prescription of statins, IPA and HA was verified before the start of the study (BL), immediately after the initial consultation (IC) and at follow-up after 6 months (FU). Prescription was considered adequate in high-risk patients (>15% risk of cardiovascular event in 10 years, according to the Framingham equation) and non-prescription in low-risk patients (<= 15%). RESULTS: Only an effect of intervention on prescription for IPA could be found. In general, all changes in prescribing over time were toward higher prescribing rates and persisted to FU, regardless of risk status and group assignment. CONCLUSIONS: Active implementation of a brief evidence-based educational intervention on global CVD risk did not directly lead to risk-adjusted changes in prescribing. Investigations on an extended time scale would capture whether decision support of this type would improve risk-adjusted prescribing in a sustainable way.

title: Diagnostic Test Articles: A New Series and an Invitation to Authors
Assessing the availability of scientific journals, databases, and health library services in Canadian ministries of health: a cross-sectional study
abstract: Background Evidence-informed health policymaking logically depends on timely access to research evidence. To our knowledge, despite considerable political and social pressure to improve the use of the best available research evidence in making decisions about public health policies and programs, there is no study addressing the availability of peer-reviewed research. in Canadian ministries of health. Objectives To assess the availability of (1) a purposive sample of top-ranking scientific journals, (2) bibliographic databases, and (3) health library services in the fourteen Canadian ministries of health. Methods From May to October 2011, we conducted a cross-sectional survey among librarians employed by Canadian ministries of health to collect information regarding the availability of scientific journals, bibliographic databases, and health library services. The availability of scientific journals in each ministry was determined using a sample of 48 journals selected from the 2009 Journal Citation Reports (Science and Social Science Editions). The selection criteria were: relevance to health policy based on information from the scope note on thematic categories and popularity of the journal based on impact factors. Results We found that most Canadian ministries of health did not have subscription access to key journals and relied heavily on interlibrary loans. Overall, based on a sample of high-ranking scientific journals, journal availability through interlibrary loan, online subscription, and print-only was estimated at 63%, 28%, and 3%, respectively. Health Canada had 2.3 times more magazine subscriptions than the average for provincial ministries. Most organizations provided access to numerous multidisciplinary and discipline-specific databases. Many organizations provided access to the library resources described through library associations or consortia. No practitioner-led health library setting was found in four of the fourteen Canadian ministries of health (i.e., Manitoba Health, Northwest Territories Department of Health and Social Services, Nunavut Department of Health and Social Services, and Yukon Department of Health and Human Services). Conclusions There is unevenness in the availability of peer-reviewed research across the fourteen Canadian ministries of health. This inequity could present a problem, since each province and territory is responsible for formulating and implementing evidence-based health policies and services for the benefit of its population.

title: Evaluation of the impact of national guidelines on the treatment of children hospitalized for acute bronchiolitis
abstract: BACKGROUND: Acute bronchiolitis is a common illness accounting for $500 million in hospitalizations annually. Despite the frequency of bronchiolitis, its diagnosis and management is variable. To address this variability, the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) published an evidence-based practice management guideline for bronchiolitis in 2006. OBJECTIVE: To assess changes in physician behavior in the management of bronchiolitis before and after publication of the 2006 AAP bronchiolitis guideline. METHODS: A retrospective chart review was conducted at two academic medical centers of children <24 months of age admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of bronchiolitis at primary or secondary discharge. Pre-guidelines from 2004 to 2005 and post-guidelines from 2007 to 2008 were collected. Evaluation and therapeutic interventions were analyzed before and during hospitalization. Data were analyzed using chi-square analysis for categorical variables, Mann-Whitney test for continuous variables. RESULTS: One thousand two hundred and thirty-three patients met the inclusion criteria. Diagnostic laboratory test rates did not decrease after publication of the guideline. The number of chest radiographs obtained decreased from 72.9% to 66.7% after the guidelines (P = 0.02). Fewer children received a trial of racemic epinephrine (17.8% vs. 12.2%, P = .006) or albuterol (81.6% vs. 72.6%, P < .0001) after the guidelines, and physicians more frequently discontinued albuterol when its ineffectiveness was documented in the publication. -period of the guidelines (28.6% vs. 78.9%, P < 0.0001). Corticosteroid use in children without a history of ADR or asthma decreased after guidelines (26.5% vs. 17.5%, P < 0.0001). CONCLUSIONS: A modest change in the behavior of physicians in the hospital management of bronchiolitis was observed after the guidelines. Additional training and education of health care providers is warranted to reduce unnecessary interventions and use of health care resources.

title: Evaluation of Treatment as Usual Provided to Control Groups in Adherence Trials: Exploring the Use of an Open Questionnaire to Identify Behavior Change Techniques
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Reporting guidelines require descriptions of control group support in the same detail as the interventions. However, it is still unclear how to assess the active content (behaviour change techniques (BCT)) of treatment as usual (TAU) given to control groups in trials. The aim of this study is to pre-test a TAU assessment method in a multicenter cost-effectiveness trial of an HIV treatment adherence intervention. DESIGN: HIV nurses (N = 21) completed an open-ended, semi-structured questionnaire asking about TAU adherence counseling. Two coders independently coded BCT. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Completeness and clarity of nurses' responses, inter-coder reliability, and type of BCTs reported were examined. RESULTS: The clarity and completeness of the nurses' responses were adequate. Twenty-three of the 26 identified BCTs could be reliably coded (mean kappa = 0.79"; mean agreement rate = 96%) and three BCTs scored below kappa = 0.60. The total number of BCTs reported per nurse ranged from 7 to 19 (M = 13.86, SD = 3.35).CONCLUSIONS: This study suggests that the TAU open-ended questionnaire is a feasible and reliable tool for capturing the active content of support provided to control participants in a multicentre adherence intervention trial Considerable variability was observed in the amount of BCT provided to control patients, illustrating the importance of reliably collecting and accurately reporting control group support.

title: Lifestyle assessment and management of patients with obesity: clinical recommendations from systematic reviews
abstract: SIGNIFICANCE: Although one-third of American adults are obese, rates of obesity identification and treatment remain low. Physician engagement is vital in providing overweight or obese patients with guidance and assistance in addressing the underlying cause of many chronic diseases. OBJECTIVES: To describe current best practices for lifestyle assessment and management of obesity and to demonstrate how the Updated Guidelines (2013) for the management of overweight and obesity in adults based on a systematic review of evidence sponsored by the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI) may apply to an individual patient. EVIDENCE REVIEW: The systematic evidence review conducted for the Guidelines (2013) for the management of overweight and obesity in adults supports treatment recommendations in 5 areas (risk assessment, benefits for weight loss, diets for weight loss, comprehensive lifestyle intervention approaches, and bariatric surgery)"; for areas outside this scope, the recommendations are supported by other guidelines (for obesity, the 1998 NHLBI-sponsored obesity guidelines and those of the National Center for Health and Clinical Excellence and Canadian and American professional societies, such as the American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists and the American Society of Bariatric Physicians; for physical activity recommendations, the Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans 2008); a PubMed search identified recent systematic reviews covering depression and obesity , motivational interviewing for weight control, metabolic adaptation to weight loss, and pharmacotherapy for obesity. step in managing obesity ment is to screen all adults for overweight and obesity. A medical history should be obtained that assesses the multiple determinants of obesity, including dietary and physical activity patterns, psychosocial factors, weight-gain medications, and family traits. The emphasis on complications of obesity to identify patients who will benefit most from treatment is more helpful than using body mass index (BMI; calculated as weight in kilograms divided by height in meters squared) alone for treatment decisions. The Guidelines (2013) recommend that clinicians offer patients who would benefit from weight loss (either a BMI of >/=30 with or without comorbidities or >/=25 along with 1 comorbidity or risk factor) a multicomponent intensive behavioral intervention. Some doctors do this within their primary care practices; others refer patients to these services. Weight loss is achieved by creating a negative energy balance through modification of eating and physical activity behaviors. The Guidelines (2013) support comprehensive lifestyle management through intensive intervention. Treatment can be implemented either in a doctor's office or by referral to a registered dietitian or commercial weight loss program. The usual goal is a 5% to 10% weight loss. Patients do not need to achieve a BMI of less than 25 to achieve a health benefit. CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Screening and evaluation of patients for obesity, followed by initiation or referral of treatment, should be incorporated into primary care practice settings. If clinicians can identify appropriate patients for weight loss efforts and provide informed advice and assistance on how to achieve and maintain modest weight loss, they will address the underlying driver of many such as morbidities and can have a great influence on the health status of patients.

title: Assessment of a remote collaborative program for the treatment of depression in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Primary care teams play an important role in the treatment of depression, whose effectiveness improves when they are inserted in a collaborative model of disease management. OBJECTIVE: To report the results of a clinical trial conducted to test the efficacy of a collaborative program between primary care teams and specialists supported by an electronic platform. MATERIAL AND METHODS: Physicians from four community hospitals belonging to the Reloncavi Health Service network recruited 81 patients with depression between the ages of 37 and 43, of whom 84% were women. Participants were divided into an active group, which participated in the collaborative program, and a control group, which received usual care, according to the Ministry of Health Depression Guidelines. The main outcome was the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI-I) score three months after the intervention. RESULTS: Participants had a mean of 29.6 points (95% CI: 27.6-31.6) on the BDI-I and 38% of them were at high risk of suicide. There were no statistically significant baseline differences between the active and control groups. In the intervention group, the BDI-I score changed from 30.0 (95% CI: 27.0 to 32.8) to 15.3 (95% CI: 11.8 to 18.8). In the control group, the score changed from 29.2 (95% CI: 26.4-31.9) points to 20.8 (95% CI: 16.8 to 24.7). The decline was significantly greater in the intervention groups. CONCLUSIONS: Such a program may be useful in helping primary care teams in remote areas of the country improve depression treatment outcomes.

title: Evaluation of a pay-for-performance program in primary care designed by target users.
abstract: Background: Evidence of pay-for-performance (P4P) has been sought over the past decade as financial incentives to influence the behavior of health professionals to improve quality of care have increased. The effectiveness of P4P is inconclusive, although some reviews have reported significant effects. Objective: To assess changes in performance after the introduction of a participatory P4P program. Design: Observational study with pre-post measurement. Scope and topics: Sixty-five general practices in the south of the Netherlands. Intervention: a P4P program designed by target users that contains indicators for chronic care, prevention, practice management and patient experience (general practitioner [GP] functioning and organization of care). Quality indicators were calculated for each practice. A bonus with a maximum of 6890 euros per 1000 patients was determined by comparing the performance of the practice with a reference point. Main outcome measures: Indicators of quality of clinical care (process and outcome) and patient experience. Results: 60 practices were included. After 1 year, significant improvement in process indicators was shown for all chronic conditions, from +7.9% improvement for cardiovascular risk management to +11.5% for asthma. Five outcome indicators improved significantly, as did patients' experiences with the functioning and organization of GP care. No significant improvements were seen in the rate of vaccination against influenza or in the acceptance of cervical cancer screening tests. Clinical process and outcome indicators, as well as patient experience indicators, were affected by the baseline measures. Smaller practices showed more improvements. Conclusions: A participatory P4P program could stimulate quality improvement in clinical care and improve patients' experiences with the functioning of the GP and the organization of care. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2016 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: Evaluation of support for the decision to request blood tests in primary care. a randomized trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Different methods of changing blood test ordering behavior in primary care have been shown to be effective. However, randomized trials comparing these methods are lacking. OBJECTIVE: To compare the effect of two versions of BloodLink, a computerized clinical decision support system, on blood test ordering among general practitioners. DESIGN: Randomized trial. SETTING: 44 general practitioner practices in the Delft region, the Netherlands. PARTICIPANTS: 60 general practitioners in 44 practices who used computer-based patient records in their practices. INTERVENTION: After stratification by individual practices and group practices, practices were randomly assigned to use either BloodLink-Restricted, which initially displays a shortened list of tests, or BloodLink-Guideline, which is based on the Dutch College of General Practitioners guidelines. . MEASUREMENTS: Average number of blood tests ordered per order form per practice. RESULTS: General practitioners using BloodLink-Guideline ordered 20% fewer tests on average than physicians using BloodLink-Restricted (mean [+/-SD], 5.5 +/- 0.9 tests vs. 6, 9 +/- 1.6 tests, respectively) ;" P = 0.003, Mann-Whitney test). CONCLUSIONS: Guideline-based decision support is more effective in changing blood test requesting behavior than decision support. based on initially showing a limited number of tests Guideline-based decision support systems may be effective in reducing the number of laboratory tests ordered by primary care physicians.

title: Evaluation of radiology referral practice and the effect of computer-based guidelines on radiology requests in two emergency departments.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess emergency medical radiology referral practice against a set of French guidelines and measure the efficiency of computer-based guidelines on unnecessary medical imaging. MATERIALS AND METHODS: All radiological requests were computerized in the medical emergency services of two French university hospitals. During the control periods, radiological requests were recorded but no action was taken. During intervention periods, on-screen reminder displays prompted appropriate recommendations. Three control periods and three intervention periods of 1 month each were carried out. The percentage of requests that did not conform to the guidelines and the variation related to the control and intervention periods were measured. RESULTS: The proportion of requests not conforming to guidelines was 33·2% when guidelines were inactive and decreased to 26·9% when recommendations were active (P < 0·0001). The three imaging tests (chest x-rays, plain abdominal x-rays, and brain computed tomography) accounted for more than 80% of all requests; more than 50% of requests for plain abdominal radiographs did not meet the recommendations, while this percentage was respectively 24·9% and 15·8% for chest radiographs and computed tomography (CT) of the brain. Seven situations represented 70% of non-compliant radiological references; in these situations, the knowledge of the young doctors was inadequate. CONCLUSION: Although the computer provided advice that was tailored to the needs of individual patients, along with care, the effect of our intervention was weak. However, our study identified the few situations that were responsible for the most unnecessary radiological requests;" We hope that this result can help clinicians and radiologists to develop more specific actions for these situations. Cartón, M. et al. ( 2002) Clinical Radiology (2002)57, 123–128.

title: Assessing self-harm in an emergency department and accidents: developing a proforma to assess suicidal intent and mental status in those presenting to the emergency department with self-harm
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The United Kingdom has one of the highest rates of self-harm in Europe, around 400 per 100,000 inhabitants (Horrocks et al. 2002). It accounts for 150,000 emergency department visits each year and is one of the top five causes of acute medical admissions in the UK (NICE 2002). OBJECTIVES: Objectives included to explore the method of self-harm and the demographics of those presenting to the emergency department with self-harm. In addition, we wanted to review the ED physician's screening for suicide risk factors and suicidal intent and determine if a psychiatric evaluation with a full mental status examination with referral to psychiatric services had been performed if appropriate. considered necessary. We wanted to explore current practice around self-harm presentations to the emergency department in accordance with NICE guidelines. METHODS: Data were collected retrospectively from February to August 2009. Twenty-five sets of medical notes from patients who had presented with self-harm in the emergency department were randomly collated. Notes were reviewed for evidence of event exploration, psychiatric evaluation, risk factors for suicide, and subsequent referral. RESULTS: 14 of the 25 patients had an overdose. 9 had inflicted some other form of self-harm, namely lacerations on himself. In 2 cases a mixed presentation was found. Previous psychiatric history was documented in 16 cases. 11 had a history of depression or anxiety disorder”; 1 was known to have bipolar affective disorder; 1 was diagnosed in the past with borderline personality disorder; and 3 patients had no prior history. In 9 cases no antecedents were documented. DISCUSSION: Twenty-five sets of medical notes from February to August 2009 from people presenting to the emergency department with self-injury were reviewed. Of these, 12 corresponded to the age group of more than 25. 17 were women and 8 were men. Most of the patients were of white British ethnicity. 14 had taken an overdose; 9 had inflicted some other form of self-harm; and 2 had a mixed presentation. Suicide risk factors and suicidal intent were poorly documented and mental status examination was found to be undocumented in the 25 cases reviewed. 18 were deemed medically fit in the emergency department and were referred for psychiatric review. These unfortunate findings may be a reflection of the time pressures emergency department physicians face, namely four-hour targets, and perhaps a lack of adequate training in psychosocial risk assessment. With such poor documentation by ED physicians, a proforma was developed that incorporates suicide risk factors and assessment of suicidal intent in addition to a brief version of the mental status exam. CONCLUSION: The Royal College of Psychiatrists' recent report on self-harm has raised concerns, that the current level of care provided to service users does not meet the standards set out in policies and guidelines, with poor assessments, unqualified staff and avenues of insufficient care (Royal College of Psychiatrists Report CR 158. 2010). Indeed, evidence suggests that appropriate training and intervention provided to A&E personnel can lead to improvements in the quality of psychosocial assessment of patients with deliberate self-harm (Crawford et al. 1998).

title: Evaluation of the potential impact of a reminder system in reducing diagnostic errors: a quasi-experimental study
abstract: Background Computerized decision support systems (DSS) have primarily focused on improving clinicians' diagnostic accuracy in unusual and challenging cases. However, as errors of omission in diagnosis may predominantly result from incomplete study in routine clinical practice, the provision of appropriate patient- and context-specific reminders may have a greater impact on patient safety. In this experimental study, a combination of easy and difficult simulated cases was used to assess the impact of a novel diagnostic recall system (ISABEL) on the quality of clinical decisions made by various grades of physicians during acute assessment. Methods Subjects of varying grades (consultants, registrars, senior house officials, and medical students) evaluated a balanced set of 24 simulated cases on a test website. The subjects recorded their clinical decisions for the cases (differential diagnosis, request for tests and treatment), before and after consulting the system. A panel of two pediatric consultants independently provided gold standard answers for each case, against which the quality of the subjects' decisions was measured. The primary outcome measure was change in diagnostic errors by omission (OED) count. A more sensitive assessment of the impact of the system was achieved using specific quality scores"; the additional consultation time resulting from the use of DSS was also calculated. Results 76 subjects (18 consultants, 24 registrars, 19 senior house officers and 15 students ) case episodes.The mean OED count decreased from 5.5 to 5.0 in all subjects (repeated measures ANOVA, p < 0.001), with no significant interaction with subject rating. diagnostic quality increased after consultation of the system (0.044; "95% confidence interval 0.032, 0.054). ISABEL reminded subjects to consider at least one clinically important diagnosis in 1 out of 8 case episodes and urged them to request an important test in 1 out of 10 case episodes. The additional median time for the DSS consultation was 1 min (IQR: 30 sec to 2 min). Conclusion The provision of patient- and context-specific reminders has the potential to reduce diagnostic omissions across all subject grades for a variety of cases. This study suggests a promising role for the use of future reminder-based DSS in reducing diagnostic error.

title: Association between the pharmaceutical detail policies of the academic medical center and the medical prescription
abstract: Significance In an effort to regulate physician conflicts of interest, some U.S. academic medical centers (AMCs) have enacted policies restricting visits by pharmaceutical sales representatives to physicians (known as medical details). ) between 2006 and 2012. Little is known about the effect of these policies on medical prescription. . Objective To analyze the association between the detailed policies promulgated in the AMC and the medical prescription of actively detailed and non-detailed drugs. Design, Setting, and Participants The study used difference-in-difference multivariate regression analysis to compare changes in physician prescribing before and after implementation of detailed policies at AMCs in 5 states (California, Illinois, Massachusetts , Pennsylvania, and New York) who made up the prescribing change intervention group by a matched control group of similar physicians not subject to a detail policy. Exhibitions Implementation of the academic medical center of policies that regulate the visits of pharmaceutical vendors to treating physicians. Key Outcomes and Measures The monthly market share within the drug class of prescriptions written by an individual physician for listed and non-listed drugs across 8 drug classes (lipid-lowering drugs, gastroesophageal reflux disease drugs, medications, antihypertensive medications, approved hypnotic medications for the treatment of insomnia [sleep aids], medications for attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, antidepressant medications, and antipsychotic medications) comparing the period of 10 to 36 months before the implementation of detailed policies with the period of 12 to 36 months after implementation, depending on data availability. Results The analysis included 16,121,483 prescriptions written between January 2006 and June 2012 by 2,126 attending physicians in the 19 AMCs in the intervention group and by 24,593 physicians in the matched control group. The average market share of the sample at the doctor-drug-month level for listed and non-listed medications before the enactment of the policies was 19.3% and 14.2%, respectively. Exposure to an AMC itemized policy was associated with a decline in itemized drug market share of 1.67 percentage points (95% CI, ?2.18 to ?1.18 percentage points"; P?<? .001) and an increase in non-detailed drug market share of 0.84 percentage points (95% CI, 0.54 to 1.14 percentage points; P?, antihypertensive drugs, sleeping pills, sleep disorder drugs attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder and antidepressant medications) and for 9 of 19 AMCs that implemented policies Eleven of 19 AMCs regulated vendor gifts to physicians, restricted vendor access to facilities, and incorporated enforcement mechanisms. For 8 of these 11 AMCs, there was a significant change in prescription In contrast, there was a significant change in only 1 of 8 AMCs that did not enact policies in all 3 areas Conclusions and Relevance e Policy implementation in AMCs that restricted n pharmaceutical detailing between 2006 and 2012 was associated with modest but significant reductions in the prescription of detailed drugs in 6 of the 8 main drug classes; however, no change was seen in all AMCs that enacted policies.

title: Association Between Efavirenz as Initial Therapy for HIV-1 Infection and Increased Risk of Suicidal Ideation or Suicide Attempt or Completed Suicide
abstract: Background The relationship between the use of efavirenz and suicidality is not well defined. Objective To compare the time to suicidality with antiretroviral regimens containing efavirenz versus without efavirenz for the initial treatment of HIV. Design Participant-level data were analyzed from four AIDS Clinical Trials Group (ACTG) antiretroviral-naïve studies conducted between 2001 and 2010. Within each study, participants were randomly assigned to an efavirenz-containing medication (n =3241) or without efavirenz. regimen (n=2091). Establishment of ACTG" sites; 74% enrolled in the United States. Patients Participating antiretroviral-naïve patients. Intervention Efavirenz versus regimens without efavirenz. Measurements Suicidality was defined as suicidal ideation, suicide attempt, or completed suicide. Groups were compared. with a hazard ratio (HR) and 95% confidence interval (CI) estimated from a Cox model stratified by study.Results73% were men, median age was 37 years; % had a documented psychiatric history or received psychoactive medication within 30 days prior to study entry Median follow-up was 96 weeks Incidence of suicide per 1000 person-years was 8.08 (47 events) in the group of efavirenz and 3.66 (15 events) in the group without efavirenz, HR: 2.28 (95% CI: 1.27 to 4.10, p=0.006).The incidence of suicide attempt or completed suicide it was 2.90 (17 events) and 1.22 (5 events) in the efavirenz and no efavirenz groups, respectively, HR: 2.58 (95% CI: 0.94 to 7.06, p=0.065). Eight suicide deaths were reported in the efavirenz group and one in the no-efavirenz group. Limitations There was no standardized questionnaire on suicidal ideation or attempt. Efavirenz was open-label in three of four studies. Conclusions Initial treatment with an efavirenz-containing antiretroviral regimen was associated with a two-fold increased risk of suicidality compared with a regimen without efavirenz. Keywords: efavirenz, suicide, suicidal ideation, suicidal behavior, HIV, adverse event, psychiatry

title: Association of a low-frequency variant in HNF1A with type 2 diabetes in a Latino population
abstract: Importance Latino populations have one of the highest prevalences of type 2 diabetes worldwide. Objectives To investigate the association between rare protein-coding genetic variants and the prevalence of type 2 diabetes in a large Latino population and to explore possible molecular and physiological mechanisms for the observed relationships. Design, Setting, and Participants Whole exome sequencing was performed on DNA samples from 3756 Mexican and US Latino individuals (1794 with type 2 diabetes and 1962 without diabetes) recruited between 1993 and 2013. One variant was further tested to determine allele frequency and association with type 2 diabetes in large multiethnic data sets of 14 to 276 participants and characterized in experimental trials. Main outcome and measures Prevalence of type 2 diabetes. Secondary outcomes included age at onset, body mass index, and effect on protein function. Results A single rare missense variant (c.1522G>A [p.E508K]) was associated with the prevalence of type 2 diabetes (odds ratio [OR], 5.48"; 95% CI, 2.83-10; 61; P = 4.4?¡Ã ?10?7) in hepatocyte nuclear factor 1-Â¦Ã (HNF1A), the gene responsible for maturity-onset diabetes of the young type 3 (MODY3). This variant was seen in 0.36% of participants without type 2 diabetes and 2.1% of participants with type 2 diabetes. 2 and 1673 without) and was associated with type 2 diabetes (OR, 4.16; 95% CI, 1.75-9.92; P?=?.0013).In experimental trials, the HNF-1A protein encoding the p.E508K mutant demonstrated reduced transactivation activity of its target promoter compared to a wild-type protein.In our data, carriers and non-carriers of the p.E508K mutation with type 2 diabetes had no significant differences in clinical characteristics compared, including age of onset. The mean age (SD) of the carriers was 45.3 years (11.2) compared to 47.5 years (11.5) of the non-carriers (P?=?0.49) and the mean BMI (SD ) of carriers was 28.2 (5.5) versus 29.3 (5.3) of carriers. non-carriers (P?=?.19). Conclusions and Relevance Using whole exome sequencing, we identified a single low-frequency variant in the HNF1A gene causing MODY3 that is associated with type 2 diabetes in Latino populations and may affect protein function. This finding may have implications for screening and therapeutic modification in this population, but further study is required.

title: Association of combatant status and sexual violence with health and mental health outcomes in post-conflict Liberia
abstract: Context Liberia's wars since 1989 have cost tens of thousands of lives and left many people mentally and physically traumatized. Objectives To assess the prevalence and impact of war-related psychosocial trauma, including information on involvement in Liberia's civil wars, exposure to sexual violence, social functioning and mental health. Design, Setting, and Participants A cross-sectional, population-based, multistage random cluster survey of 1,666 adults aged 18 years and older using structured interviews and questionnaires, conducted over a 3-week period in May 2008 in Liberia. Main outcome measures Major depressive disorder (MDD) and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms, social functioning, exposure to sexual violence, and health and mental health needs among Liberian adults who witnessed or participated in conflict during the last 2 decades. Results In the Liberian adult household C-based population, 40% (95% confidence interval [CI], 36%-45%"; n = 672/1659) met symptom criteria for MDD, 44% (95% CI, 38%-49%; n=718/1661) met criteria for PTSD symptoms, and 8% (95% CI, 5%-10%; n=133/1666) met criteria of social dysfunction 33% of respondents (549/1,666) reported serving time in the fighting forces, and 33.2% of surveyed veterans (182/549) were women Veterans experienced higher rates of exposure to sexual violence than noncombatants: among women, 42.3% (95% CI, 35.4%-49.1% vs. 9.2% (95% CI, 6.7%-11.7 %), respectively, among men, 32.6% (95% CI, 27.6%-37.6%) vs. 7.4% (95% CI, 4.5%-10.4%). of PTSD, MDD, and suicidal ideation symptoms were higher among veterans than among noncombatants and among those who experienced violence. sexual ia versus those who do not. The prevalence of PTSD symptoms among female veterans who experienced sexual violence (74%) 95% CI, 63%-84%) was higher than among those who did not experience sexual violence (44%; 95% CI, 33%-53% ). The prevalence of PTSD symptoms among male veterans who experienced sexual violence was higher (81%; 95% CI, 74%-87%) than among male veterans who did not experience sexual violence (46%; 95% CI, 39%-52 %). Male ex-combatants who experienced sexual violence also reported higher rates of symptoms of depression and suicidal ideation. Both veterans and noncombatants experienced inadequate access to health care (33.0% [95% CI, 22.6%-43.4%] and 30.1% [95% CI, 18.7%- 41.6%], respectively). Conclusions Ex-combatants in Liberia were not exclusively men. Both female and male ex-combatants who experienced sexual violence had worse mental health outcomes than non-combatants and other ex-combatants who experienced sexual violence. did not experience exposure to sexual violence.

title: Association of Socioeconomic Position with Health Behaviors and Mortality
abstract: Context Previous studies may have underestimated the contribution of health behaviors to social inequalities in mortality because health behaviors were assessed only at study baseline. Objective To examine the role of health behaviors in the association between socioeconomic position and mortality and to compare whether their contribution differs when assessed at a single point in time with longitudinal assessment over the follow-up period. Design, Setting, and Participants Established in 1985, the British Whitehall II Longitudinal Cohort Study includes 10,308 civil servants, aged 35 to 55, living in London, England. Analyzes are based on 9,590 men and women followed for mortality through April 30, 2009. Socioeconomic position was derived from the degree of civil service employment (high, intermediate, and low) at baseline. Smoking, alcohol consumption, diet, and physical activity were assessed 4 times during the follow-up period. Main outcome measures Mortality from all causes and from specific causes. Results A total of 654 participants died during the follow-up period. In analyzes adjusted for sex and year of birth, those with the lowest socioeconomic status had a 1.60 times greater risk of death from all causes than those with the highest socioeconomic status (a rate difference of 1.94/1000). person-years). This association was attenuated by 42% (95% confidence interval [CI], 21%-94%) when baseline-assessed health behaviors were entered into the model and by 72% (95% CI, 42% %-154%) when entered as time-dependent covariates. The corresponding attenuations were 29% (95% CI, 11%-54%) and 45% (95% CI, 24%-79%) for cardiovascular mortality and 61% (95% CI, 16%-425%) and 94 % (95% CI, 35%-595%) for mortality not related to cancer and cardiovascular disease. The difference between baseline only and repeated assessments of health behaviors was primarily due to higher explanatory power of diet (7% to 17% for all-cause mortality, respectively), physical activity ( 5% to 21% for all causes). cause-related mortality) and alcohol use (3% to 12% for all-cause mortality). The role of smoking, the strongest mediator in these analyses, did not change when baseline or repeat assessments were used (32% to 35% for all-cause mortality). Conclusion In a civil service population in London, England, there was an association between socioeconomic position and mortality that was substantially explained by adjustment of health behaviors, particularly when behaviors were repeatedly assessed.

title: Asthma education program in Russia: educating patients
abstract: To address the recent increase in asthma morbidity and mortality in Russia, an intervention study was conducted to improve the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of asthma. The American recommendations for asthma management have been adapted for use in the education of Moscow families with children with asthma. Two hundred and fifty-two children with asthma aged 4 to 14 years receiving medical care at eight Moscow public health clinics along with their parents were enrolled in the study to see if American teaching manuals for asthma control would be acceptable and effective. in Russia. Children from four of the clinics with recent asthma attacks were randomly assigned to the education or control group to assess whether patient education and guided asthma care would improve outcomes for patients. Modern drugs were made available to both groups to see if training in US guidelines was needed to get doctors to use the drugs. Children with recent asthma attacks at the other four clinics were defined as comparison group 1 to control for the possible effect of medication availability. All children from the eight clinics who did not have asthma attacks formed comparison group 2 to see if these children's results would change over time. One-year follow-up results showed significant improvement in children's and parents' asthma self-management skills, in terms of asthma treatment, only among those in the education group. Significant increases were seen in the subgroup of children in the education group using anti-inflammatory medications for asthma control. Children in the education group had markedly increased peak flow rates and reduced daily peak flow variability compared to control and comparison groups. There was a significantly greater reduction in doctor visits by the educational group of children compared to the control. Presumably, changes in the behavior of parents and children in terms of asthma treatment and prevention skills, adequate treatment of the disease and access to medications could be responsible for reducing the morbidity of asthma in children .

title: Attitudes towards reproduction in Latin America. Lessons from the use of modern reproductive technologies.
abstract: The use of modern reproductive technology, such as in vitro fertilization and its related procedures, has opened up new areas of legal, religious, and public interest. Thirty years ago, the development of effective methods to control procreation sparked a debate about whether couples had a right to enjoy sex in the absence of its procreative effect. Today, assisted reproductive technology (ART) allows couples to have their own children in the absence of direct intermediation of sex. The Catholic Church has reacted against contraception and ART, and specific instructions have been directed to the public, the medical profession and legislators. In a recent survey, 88.4% of the population in Latin America say they are Catholic";" therefore, bioethical considerations and legal implications regarding reproductive intervention are strongly permeated by the moral teachings of Catholicism. In 1996, 83 physicians and scientists, participating in the Latin American Network for Assisted Reproduction, produced a consensus document on ethical aspects and legal implications of ART. The document contains minimum ethical guidelines to which Latin American professionals have decided to adhere, even in the absence of legal regulations. This article examines how the medical profession, policymakers, and the public react to religious influence when faced with difficult bioethical decisions such as the right to procreate.

title: Audit and feedback as a clinical practice guideline implementation strategy: a model for acute care nursing professionals
abstract: BACKGROUND: Transferring research evidence to practice and changing provider behavior is challenging, even when the benefits are significant. Despite the availability of supportive care clinical practice guidelines (CPGs), consistent integration of these principles into practice has not been achieved. The failure of dissemination strategies has been identified as a key barrier to successful implementation. A potentially effective approach to facilitating the transfer of evidence from research to practice is audit and feedback. The audit and feedback is a summary of the provider's performance over a specified period of time, with or without recommendations to improve practice. RATIONALE: Cancer pain is an optimal symptom to examine when studying the effect of an audit and feedback intervention. It is a common condition with important consequences, there are established CPGs, measurable results are defined and there is potential for improvement in current practice. Intensive care (NP) nurse practitioners are often responsible for directly monitoring and managing symptoms such as pain and are well positioned to implement CPGs and study the effects of guideline adherence on patient pain outcomes. METHODOLOGY: A systematic review of published articles, MEDLINE, the Cumulative Index to Nursing and Related Health Literature, and Cochrane Library computerized databases was conducted to assess the state of the science on audit and feedback as a change strategy. professional practice. A behavior change model is proposed for application to advanced practice nursing. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: Recognized in medicine as a valuable intervention to improve the quality of medical care, audit and feedback is a strategy that has not been widely studied in nursing. Although cancer pain cannot always be completely eliminated, appropriate use of available therapies can effectively relieve pain in most patients. This article is a review of the literature on audit and feedback as a professional practice change strategy and indicates a model to operationalize the intervention.

title: Audit and Feedback: Effects on Professional Practice and Health Care Outcomes
abstract: BACKGROUND: Audit and feedback continue to be widely used as a strategy to improve professional practice. It seems logical that health professionals are forced to modify their practice if they receive feedback that their clinical practice is not consistent with that of their peers or with accepted guidelines. However, audit and feedback have not been found to be consistently effective. OBJECTIVES: To assess the effects of audit and feedback on health professional practice and patient outcomes. SEARCH STRATEGY: The Cochrane Group for Effective Practice and Organization of Care Register and Pending Archive were searched up to January 2004. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized audit and feedback trials (defined as any summary of clinical performance during a specified time period) that objectively reported professional practice measured in a healthcare setting or healthcare outcomes. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two reviewers independently extracted data and assessed study quality. Quantitative (meta-regression), visual and qualitative analyzes were performed. For each comparison, we calculated the risk difference (RD) and risk ratio (RR), adjusted for baseline compliance where possible, for dichotomous outcomes and the percentage and percentage change relative to the treatment group mean. post-intervention control, adjusted for baseline performance where possible, for continuous outcomes. We investigated the following factors as possible explanations for the variation in the effectiveness of interventions across comparisons: type of intervention (audit and feedback alone, audit and feedback with educational meetings, or multifaceted interventions that included audit and feedback), intensity of audit and feedback, the complexity of the target behavior, the seriousness of the result, the baseline compliance, and the quality of the study. MAIN RESULTS: 30 new studies have been added to this update and a total of 118 studies are included. In the primary analysis we included 88 comparisons from 72 studies comparing any intervention in which audit and feedback was a component compared to no intervention. For dichotomous outcomes, the adjusted risk difference for adherence to desired practice ranged from -0.16 (a 16% absolute decrease in adherence) to 0.70 (a 70% increase in adherence) (median=0. 05, interquartile range = 0.03 to 0.11) and the adjusted hazard ratio ranged from 0.71 to 18.3 (median = 1.08, interquartile range = 0.99 to 1.30). For continuous outcomes, the adjusted percentage change relative to control ranged from -0.10 (a 10% absolute decrease in compliance) to 0.68 (a 68% increase in compliance) (median = 0, 16, interquartile range = 0.05 to 0.37).
