Low baseline compliance with recommended practice and higher audit and feedback intensity were associated with larger adjusted hazard ratios (higher effectiveness) across studies. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: Audit and feedback can be effective in improving professional practice. When effective, the effects are generally small to moderate. The relative effectiveness of audit and feedback is likely to be higher when initial adherence to recommended practice is low and when feedback is delivered more intensively.

title: Audit of a tuberculosis contact tracing clinic
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the efficiency of tuberculosis contact tracing in South Glamorgan 1987-9. DESIGN Review of contact tracing clinic records and Mycobacterium Reference Unit data. Clinic practice was compared with the 1983 British Thoracic Society recommendations. SETTING Health Authority Tuberculosis Control Programme. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Proportion of contacts screened, follow-up rates, number of secondary cases detected, and quality of record keeping. RESULTS One hundred and one index patients and 611 contacts were identified. 596 (97.5%) contacts were screened, of which 139 should not have been. Of 356 contacts who required a Heaf test, 237 were evaluated, seven refused testing, and 112 had a chest radiograph without a Heaf test. 95 contacts were unnecessarily tested. Eighty-seven contacts had chest radiography unnecessarily, and seven should have had it but did not. Thirty-four contacts were inappropriately given follow-up appointments and seven were missed for follow-up. Tuberculosis was diagnosed in five asymptomatic contacts, all at initial screening and all close contacts of index patients with lung disease. CONCLUSION Inadequate data, lack of adherence to contact tracing guidelines, and lack of definition of the term highly infectious index case resulted in many contacts being unnecessarily tested or followed up. IMPLICATIONS The efficiency of contact tracing would be improved by specifying the smear results and ethnicity of the index case on the reporting form, clearly classifying contacts as close or causal, and clearly defining the term highly infectious.

title: Australian and New Zealand clinical practice guidelines for the treatment of depression
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists (RANZCP) is coordinating the development of clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) in psychiatry, funded by the National Mental Health Strategy (Australia) and the New Zealand Ministry of Health. METHOD: The CPG team reviewed the literature on treatment outcomes, consulted with clinicians and patients, and performed meta-analyses of outcome research. TREATMENT RECOMMENDATIONS: Establish an effective therapeutic relationship"; provide the patient with information about the condition, the rationale for treatment, the likelihood of a positive response, and the expected time frame; consider the patient's strengths, life stresses, and supports. The choice of treatment depends on the skills of the clinician and the circumstances and preferences of the patient, and should be guided but not determined by these guidelines.In moderately severe depression, all recognized antidepressants, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), and interpersonal psychotherapy (IPT) are equally effective;" clinicians must consider the burdens of treatment as well as the benefits, including side effects and toxicity. In severe depression, antidepressant treatment should precede psychological therapy. For depression with psychosis, electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) or a tricyclic combined with an antipsychotic are equally helpful. Treatments for other subtypes are discussed. Caution is necessary in people with other medications or with medical conditions. If the response to an adequate trial of a first-line treatment is poor, another evidence-based treatment should be used. Second opinions are helpful. Depression has a high rate of recurrence and efforts to reduce it are crucial.

title: Author's Disclosure of Conflict of Interest in Vascular Surgery Journals
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Advances in vascular surgery are increasingly technology-driven, and relationships between surgeons and the medical device industry can be complex. This study reviewed conflict of interest (COI) disclosure in vascular surgery journals regarding several selected technology-driven topics, including endovascular stent grafting (EVS), carotid artery stenting (CAS) and peripheral arterial interventions (PI), to suggest new directions. . METHODS: The authors' COI disclosures were reviewed from all clinical articles published in 2008 and 2009 in each of the six vascular surgery journals, and pertaining to three selected topics (EV, CAS, and PI). COI disclosure rate was assessed based on journal, subject, article type (randomized trial, case series, case report, review, or meta-analysis), and authors' region of origin. Second, consistency of author disclosure was assessed by reviewing articles by the same author and on the same topic. RESULTS: Six hundred thirty-five articles from the six journals were reviewed. COI was declared in 125 (19.7%) of these documents. This rate differed between journals (range, 3.2%-34.1%"; P < .0001). Disclosure rate did not differ between topics (range, 12.8%-21.2%; P = .12), article type (range, 14.7%-30%; p = 0.28), or region of origin (range, 0%-33.3%; "p = 0.09). There were 116 cases where the same author wrote articles describing the same general topic. COI disclosure was consistent in most of these cases (72.4%), but inconsistent in 32 cases (27.6%). The most common inconsistencies (p = 0.006) involved the same type of article in different journals (46.9%) or in the same journal (25%). CONCLUSIONS: COI disclosure rates and disclosure inconsistencies in the vascular surgery literature are due, at least partially, to differences in journal reporting policies, whereas a smaller proportion of these inconsistencies are due to individual behavior of the author. Journals should adopt a consistent requirement for a separate COI statement disclosing all relevant financial arrangements.

title: Authors' response: handwashing is a matter of respect for patients
Automated hand hygiene audit with and without intervention
abstract: BACKGROUND: Continuous automated audit daily feedback with a peer reminder intervention was used to improve compliance. Compliance rates for the automated overt and covert audit phases with and without intervention were compared to mandatory human audits. METHODS: An automated system was installed to covertly detect hand hygiene events with each press of the alcohol-based hand sanitizer dispenser for 5 months. The open phase included key physicians trained to share daily rates with physicians, set compliance goals, and encourage each other to comply for 6 months. For another 6 months, the intervention continued without cooling. Hand Hygiene Australia (HHA) human audits were performed quarterly during the intervention in accordance with World Health Organization guidelines. Percentage point (PP) differences between compliance rates were used to determine change. RESULTS: The HHA rates for June 2014 were 85% and 87% in the medical and surgical wards, respectively. These rates were 55 PPs and 38 PPs higher than the covert automation rates for June 2014 in the medical and surgical suite at 30% and 49%, respectively. During the intervention phase, mean compliance in the medical room did not change from its covert rate, while the surgical room improved compared to the covert phase by 11 PPs at 60%. On average, compliance during the intervention without cooling did not change in the medical room, while the average rate in the surgical room decreased by 9 PP. CONCLUSIONS: Automation provided a unique opportunity to respond to daily rates, but compliance will return to pre-intervention levels once active intervention ceases or human auditors leave the room, unless clinicians commit to change .

title: Automated identification of postoperative complications within an electronic medical record using natural language processing
abstract: Context Currently, most automated methods for identifying patient safety incidents are based on administrative data codes";" however, free text searches of electronic medical records could represent an additional surveillance approach. Objective To evaluate a natural language processing search approach to identify postoperative surgical complications within a comprehensive electronic medical record. Design, setting, and patients Cross-sectional study involving 2974 patients who underwent inpatient surgical procedures at 6 Veterans Health Administration (VHA) medical centers from 1999 to 2006. Main outcome measures Postoperative occurrences of acute renal failure requiring dialysis, deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, sepsis, pneumonia, or myocardial infarction identified through review of medical records as part of the VA Surgical Quality Improvement Program. We determined the sensitivity and specificity of the natural language processing approach to identify these complications and compared its performance with patient safety indicators using discharge coding information. Results The proportion of postoperative events for each sample was 2% (39 of 1,924) for acute renal failure requiring dialysis, 0.7% (18 of 2,327) for pulmonary embolism, 1% (29 of 2,327) for deep vein thrombosis, 7% (61 of 866) for sepsis, 16% (222 of 1405) for pneumonia, and 2% (35 of 1822) for myocardial infarction. Natural language processing correctly identified 82% (95% confidence interval [CI], 67%-91%) of acute kidney injury cases compared with 38% (95% CI, 25%-54 %) for patient safety indicators. Similar results were obtained for venous thromboembolism (59%, 95% CI, 44%-72% vs 46%, 95% CI, 32%-60%), pneumonia (64%, 95% CI, 58%-70% vs 5%, 95% CI, 3%-9%), sepsis (89%, 95% CI, 78%-94% vs. 34%, 95% CI, 24%-47%), and myocardial infarction postoperative (91%, 95% CI, 78%-97%) vs 89%, 95% CI, 74%-96%). Both natural language processing and patient safety indicators were highly specific to these diagnoses. Conclusion Among patients who underwent inpatient surgical procedures at VA medical centers, natural language processing analysis of electronic medical records to identify postoperative complications had higher sensitivity and lower specificity compared to safety indicators. of the patient based on discharge coding.

title: Availability and prescribing practice of malaria drugs in the private health sector in Yemen
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Although the Yemeni government changed the national policy for malaria treatment in November 2005 from chloroquine to a drug combination in the form of artesunate + sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (SP) as first-line treatment and lumefantrine + artemether as treatment treatment for uncomplicated malaria, doctors in public and private health facilities continued to prescribe chloroquine because their knowledge of the new treatment policy was poor. METHODOLOGY: A non-randomized pre-post evaluation trial of training and reporting interventions on prescribing behaviors and antimalarial drug availability among private sector physicians and pharmacists was conducted in three governorates of Yemen. RESULTS: Adherence of private sector physicians to new national guidelines for antimalarial drugs improved from 21% pre-intervention to 38% post-intervention to prescribe artesunate + SP as first-line treatment. The prescription of lumefantrine + artemether as second-line antimalarial treatment also improved from 18% before the intervention to 22% after the intervention. Unfortunately, the combination of halofantrine + SP continued to be frequently prescribed by doctors in the city of Sana'a (18%). Artesunate + SP and quinine are increasing their commercialization significantly from 8% in the pre-intervention period to 22% post-intervention (P value 0.001). CONCLUSIONS: The study provides evidence of the usefulness of the training intervention on national guidelines for the treatment of malaria. In addition, the involvement of private health care providers in notification procedures will promote the rational prescription and availability of antimalarial drugs.

title: Available screening tools for adults with bipolar affective disorder in primary care: an integrative review of the literature.
abstract: PURPOSE: To assess the efficacy of six tools used in primary care for the detection of bipolar affective disorder (BPAD). Historically, BPAD has been underdiagnosed or misdiagnosed, followed by inadequate treatment leading to harmful relapses, suicide, and increased risks of comorbidities. DATA SOURCES: An electronic search was performed to identify articles in the following databases: MEDLINE, CINAHL, Cochrane Library, ERIC, National Guideline Clearinghouse, PsycINFO, Psychology and Behavioral Sciences collection, and PsycARTICLES. Other information was also collected from NIH, CDC, Healthy People 2020, the Black Dog Institute, and the Center for Quality Assessment and Improvement for Mental Health. CONCLUSION: Evidence indicates that primary care providers are often the first and sometimes the only providers, signifying the importance of early detection and screening for BPAD in primary care. By implementing the use of proper screening tools and following recommended treatment and intervention guidelines, relapse prevention is increased and comorbidities are diagnosed more frequently, leading to an overall better quality of life. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: Primary care physicians play a vital role in properly screening for BPAD and implementing recommended treatments to increase relapse prevention and promote a healthier and more socially successful quality of life.

title: Barriers and facilitators to implementation of multiple stroke guideline recommendations: a qualitative study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Translating evidence into practice is an important final step in the evidence-based practice process. Medical record audits can be used to examine how well practice compares to published evidence and identify gaps between evidence and practice. After providing audit feedback to practitioners, local barriers to practice change can be identified and addressed with targeted behavior change interventions. This study aimed to identify the barriers and factors that facilitate the implementation of multiple stroke guideline recommendations in an Australian stroke unit. METHODS: A qualitative methodology was used. A sample of 28 health, nursing and medicine professionals participated in a group or individual interview. These interviews occurred after staff received audit feedback and identified areas for practice change. Questions focused on barriers and facilitators to implementing guideline recommendations on the management of: upper extremity sensory impairments, mobility, including sitting balance; view; anxiety and depression; negligence; swallowing; communication; education for stroke survivors and caregivers; return-to-work advice and Qualitative data were analyzed by topic using theoretical domains described by Michie and colleagues (2005). RESULTS: Six group and two individual interviews were conducted, involving six disciplines. The barriers were different between disciplines. The six key barriers identified were: (1) Beliefs about the capabilities of individual professionals and their discipline, and about the capabilities of patients (2) Beliefs about the consequences, positive and negative, of implementing the recommendations (3) Memory and attention to best practices (4) Knowledge and skills required to implement best practices;" (5) Intention and motivation to implement best practices, and (6) Resources. Some barriers were also facilitators for change. For example, therapists Occupational therapists required new knowledge and skills (a barrier), to better manage sensation impairments and neglect, while physical therapists generally knew how to implement best practice mobility rehabilitation (an enabler).CONCLUSIONS: Findings add to current knowledge on the barriers to change and the implementation of multiple recommendations of the g uies. Major challenges included sex education and screening for depression. Limited knowledge and skills were a common barrier. Knowledge about specific interventions was needed before implementation could begin and to maintain treatment fidelity. The provision of detailed online intervention manuals and protocols can help clinicians overcome the knowledge barrier.

title: Barriers and facilitators associated with the use of non-surgical treatments for patients with osteoarthritis in orthopedic practice.
abstract: INTRODUCTION: International evidence-based guidelines for the management of patients with osteoarthritis (OA) of the hip and knee recommend starting with (a combination of) non-surgical treatments, and using surgical intervention only if a patient does not respond sufficiently to treatment. non-surgical treatments. Treatment options. Despite these recommendations, there is strong evidence that non-surgical treatments are not optimally used in orthopedic practice. To improve the uptake of non-surgical treatments, more information is needed on the barriers and facilitators of these treatments. Therefore, this study evaluated what barriers and facilitators are associated with the use and prescription of different non-surgical treatments prior to hip and knee OA in orthopedic practice among patients and orthopedic surgeons in the Netherlands. MATERIALS AND METHODS: We conducted two Internet-based surveys among 172 orthopedic surgeons and 174 OA patients. Univariate association and multivariate regression techniques are used to identify barriers and facilitators associated with the use of nonsurgical treatments. RESULTS: Most barriers and facilitators among patients were associated with the use of physical therapy, lifestyle advice, and dietary therapy. Among orthopedic surgeons, the majority was associated with the prescription of paracetamol, dietary therapy and physical therapy. Examples of barriers and facilitators between patients included "People close to me had positive experiences with surgery" (OA education facilitator), and "Advice from people close to me to keep moving" (lifestyle advice facilitator and dietary). For orthopedic surgeons, examples were 'Lack of guideline knowledge' (barrier to lifestyle advice), 'Agreements/deliberations with primary care' and 'Easy communication with a dietician' (facilitators for dietary therapy) . Also the belief in the efficacy of these treatments was associated with a higher prescription. CONCLUSIONS: Strategies to improve the use of nonsurgical treatment in orthopedic practice should be directed at changing orthopedic surgeons' beliefs, communication with other OA care providers, and involvement of the patient's environment in the treatment of OA. OA.

title: Barriers and facilitators to the implementation of VA home-based primary care on American Indian reservations: a qualitative multiple-case study.
abstract: Background Veterans Health Affairs (VA) home-based primary care (HBPC) is an evidence-based, interdisciplinary approach to non-institutional long-term care that was developed in urban settings to provide longitudinal care for vulnerable older patients. Under the authority of a Memorandum of Understanding between the VA and the Indian Health Service (IHS) to improve access to health care, 14 VA Medical Centers (VAMCs) independently initiated plans to expand HBPC programs to rural Indian reservations. Americans and 12 VAMCs successfully implemented programs. The purpose of this study is to describe the barriers and facilitators to implementation in rural Native communities with the goal of informing planners and policymakers for future program expansions. Methods A qualitative comparative case study approach was used, treating each of the 14 VAMCs as a case. Using the Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research (CFIR) to inform an open-ended interview guide, telephone interviews (n = 37) were conducted with HBPC staff and clinicians, and local/regional managers, who participated in or supervised implementation . Interviews were transcribed, coded, and then analyzed using domains and CFIR constructs to describe and compare experiences and identify facilitators, barriers, and accommodations that emerged in common across the VAMC and HBPC programs. Results There was considerable variation in local contexts across VAMC. However, implementation was generally facilitated by key individuals who were able to build trust and faith in VA health care among Native American communities. The policy promoted clinical collaboration, but collaborations generally occurred on an ad hoc basis between VA and IHS physicians to optimize patient resources. All programs required some adaptations to address barriers in rural areas, such as distances, caseloads, or delays in hiring additional physicians. VA funding opportunities facilitated the expansion and maintenance of these programs. Conclusions Since program expansion is a responsibility of the HBPC program director, there is little sharing of lessons learned between VA facilities. Shared learning opportunities would benefit Federal health care organizations to expand other medical services to other American Indian and other rural and underserved communities, as well as to coordinate with other health care organizations. The CFIR framework was an effective analytical tool for comparing programs that address multiple internal and external environments.

title: Obstacles and facilitators of evidence-based practice in perinatal care in the SEA-ORCHID project
abstract: RATIONALE, GOALS, AND OBJECTIVES: The Southeast Asia Optimizing Reproductive and Child Health in Developing Countries (SEA-ORCHID) project aimed to improve maternal and infant health outcomes in nine hospitals in Southeast Asia by supporting evidence-based perinatal health care. . In this investigation, our objective was to identify and explore the factors that may have acted as barriers or facilitators of change in evidence-based practice in each of the hospitals. METHODS: During the last 6 months of the intervention phase of the project, semi-structured face-to-face interviews were conducted with 179 nurses, midwives, and physicians from the maternity and neonatal departments at each of the nine participating centers in Southeast Asia. hospitals RESULTS: Interviews identified several factors that participants believed had a substantial impact on the effectiveness of the SEA-ORCHID intervention. These included knowledge, skills, hierarchy, multidisciplinarity and leadership, beliefs about consequences, resources, and the nature of behaviors. The success of the SEA-ORCHID intervention in improving practice may reflect the extent to which the tailored strategies were effective in overcoming these barriers. CONCLUSION: Effective interventions to align practice with evidence are based on identifying and addressing barriers to practice change. The barriers identified in this study may be useful to those designing similar clinical practice improvement projects, as well as for ongoing practice improvement efforts at SEA-ORCHID hospitals.

title: Barriers to breast and cervical cancer screening in underserved women in the District of Columbia
abstract: PURPOSE/OBJECTIVES: To identify barriers to breast and cervical cancer screening from the perspective of medically underserved women in the District of Columbia (DC) that may influence breast cancer screening intentions and cervix"; determine any relationship between attitudes and the influence of significant others on anticipated behaviors;" and identify a relationship between the location where services are provided and the intentions of underserved women to engage in screening behaviors. DESIGN: Cross-sectional, correlational. SETTING: Breast and cervical cancer screening clinics in DC. SAMPLE: 339 medically underserved adult women. METHODS: Face-to-face interviews conducted by researchers. MAIN RESEARCH VARIABLES: Demographic and contextual variables, as well as attitudes and influence of significant others. Intention to have a monthly mammogram or Pap smear or perform a breast self-examination (BSE). FINDINGS: The intention to have a mammogram was positively related to the influence of significant others and negatively related to the lack of attention from health professionals. Intention to have a Pap test was positively related to attitude toward the test and to the influence of significant others. Intention to perform BSE was positively related to attitude toward prior BSE performance and the influence of significant others. No significant relationships were observed between the intention to carry out screening behaviors and demographic variables. CONCLUSIONS: Factors influencing women's attitudes toward screening and intention to engage in these behaviors include prior screening behaviors, influence of significant others, and relationships with health professionals. IMPLICATIONS FOR NURSING PRACTICE: Oncology nurses are well positioned to develop and test intervention strategies designed to increase access to and adherence to recommended screening guidelines among the medically underserved. The findings of this study could potentially guide the development and evaluation of such strategies that are sensitive to this special population.

title: Barriers to the implementation of preconception care guidelines according to the perception of general practitioners: a qualitative study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite strong evidence for the benefits of preconception interventions in improving pregnancy outcomes, delivery and uptake of preconception care and periconceptional folate supplementation remain low. General practitioners play a central role in providing preconception care. Understanding GPs' perceptions of barriers and facilitators to implementing preconception care allows for more appropriate targeting of quality improvement interventions. Consequently, the aim of this study was to examine the barriers and facilitators to the delivery and acceptance of preconception care guidelines from the perspective of general practitioners using theoretical domains related to behavior change. METHODS: We conducted a qualitative study using focus groups consisting of 22 general practitioners who were recruited from three regional general practice support organizations. The questions were based on the theoretical domain framework, which describes 12 domains related to behavior change. The responses of the general practitioners were classified into predefined themes using a deductive process of thematic analysis. RESULTS: Beliefs about abilities, motivations and goals, environmental context and resources, and memory, attention and decision making were the key domains identified in the barrier analysis. Some of the perceived barriers identified by general practitioners were time constraints, lack of women presenting preconception, numerous competing preventive priorities within the general practice setting, issues related to cost and access to preconception care, and lack of resources to assist in the delivery of preconception care guidelines. Perceived enablers identified by general practitioners included the availability of preconception care checklists and patient brochures, brochures, and waiting room posters describing the benefits and availability of preconception care consultations. CONCLUSIONS: Our study has identified some of the barriers and facilitators to the delivery and acceptance of preconception care guidelines, as perceived by general practitioners. Relating these barriers to a domain theoretical framework provides a clearer understanding of some of the psychological aspects that are involved in the behavior of general practitioners towards the provision and acceptance of preconception care. Further research prioritizing these barriers and the theoretical domains to which they relate is needed before a methodologically rigorous intervention can be designed, implemented, and evaluated.

title: Barriers to the use of breast cancer risk reduction therapies
abstract: Evidence from randomized clinical trials supports the use of tamoxifen, raloxifene, exemestane, and anastrozole for risk reduction of invasive breast cancer, predominantly estrogen receptor-positive tumors. Revised clinical guidelines now strongly recommend that doctors offer high-risk women drugs to reduce the risk of breast cancer. Although only a small portion of eligible women receive risk-reducing medications, evidence suggests greater uptake among women with atypical hyperplasia or lobular carcinoma in situ. Among clinicians, barriers to prescribing risk-reduction medications include inadequate training in risk assessment, lack of reimbursement for preventive advice, and lack of availability of easily accessible and easy-to-use predictive tools to estimate profiles. risk/benefit. Strategies to improve acceptance among women have focused on providing breast cancer risk education and information that accurately conveys the risks and benefits of risk-reducing medications. The priority areas of research that have been identified to improve the use of medications for risk reduction are (1) the development of risk assessment tools that more accurately identify women most likely to benefit, (2) the identification of circulating or tissue biomarkers that can predict and monitor treatment responsiveness, and (3) a better understanding of patient-related barriers, including patients' subjective beliefs and experiences.

title: Baseline Depression Severity as a Moderator of Depression Outcomes Between Cognitive Behavioral Therapy and Pharmacotherapy: An Individual Patient Data Meta-analysis
abstract: IMPORTANCE: Current guidelines recommend treating severe depression with pharmacotherapy. Randomized clinical trials, as well as traditional meta-analyses, have considerable limitations in testing for moderators of treatment outcomes. OBJECTIVES: To conduct a systematic literature search, collect primary trial data, and analyze baseline depression severity as a moderator of treatment outcomes between cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and antidepressant medication (ADM). DATA SOURCES: A total of 14,902 abstracts from a comprehensive literature search of PubMed, PsycINFO, EMBASE, and the Cochrane Register of Controlled Trials from 1966 to January 1, 2014 were reviewed. STUDY SELECTION: Randomized clinical trials in which compared CBT and WMD in Patients with a DSM-defined depressive disorder were included. DATA EXTRACTION AND SYNTHESIS: Study authors were asked to provide primary data from their trial. Primary data from 16 of 24 identified trials (67%) with 1700 outpatients (794 in the CBT condition and 906 in the ADM condition) were included. Missing data were imputed using multiple imputation methods. Mixed-effects models adjusting for study-level differences were used to examine severity of baseline depression as a moderator of treatment outcomes. MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES: Seventeen-item Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D) and Beck Depression Inventory (BDI). RESULTS: There was a main effect of ADM over CBT in HAM-D (beta = -0.88"; P = .03) and a non-significant trend in BDI (beta = -1.14; P = .08, statistical test for trend), but there was no significant difference in response (odds ratio [OR], 1.24; P = .12) or remission (OR, 1.18; P = .22).Mixed-effects models using the HAM -D indicated that baseline depression severity did not show moderate reductions in depressive symptoms between CBT and ADM on outcome (beta = 0.00; P = .96).Similar results were seen using the BDI.Baseline depression severity it also did not moderate the likelihood of response (OR, 0.99; P = .77) or remission (OR, 1.00; "P = .93) between CBT and ADM. CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Baseline depression severity did not moderate differences between CBT and ADM in HAM-D or BDI or in response or remission. This finding cannot be extrapolated to other psychotherapies, to individual ADMs, or to hospitalized patients. However, it offers new and substantial evidence that is relevant to researchers, clinicians, therapists, and patients.

title: Baseline characteristic of a randomized trial evaluating the effects of disease management programs for the prevention of recurrent ischemic stroke.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Long-term, comprehensive patient education programs designed to improve self-management can help patients better manage their medical condition. We evaluated its influence on the prevention of stroke recurrence through disease management programs (DMP) created for each of the risk factors in accordance with clinical practice guidelines. METHODS: This is a randomized study conducted with patients with ischemic stroke within 1 year of its onset. Subjects in the intervention group received a 6-month WMD that included self-management education provided by a nurse along with support in collaboration with the primary care physician. Those in the usual care group received routine outpatient care. The primary endpoints are stroke recurrence and stroke death. Patients were enrolled for 2 years with plans for a 2-year follow-up after the 6-month education period (a total of 30 months). RESULTS: A total of 321 eligible subjects (mean age, 67.3 years; female, 96 [29.9%]), including 21 subjects (6.5%) with transient ischemic attack, were enrolled in this study. Regarding risk factors for stroke, 260 subjects (81.0%) had hypertension, 249 subjects (77.6%) had dyslipidemia, 102 subjects (31.8%) had diabetes mellitus, 47 subjects (14.6% ) had atrial fibrillation and 98 subjects (30.5%) had chronic kidney disease.There were no significant differences between the 2 groups with respect to subject characteristics.CONCLUSIONS: This article describes the rationale, design, and baseline characteristics of a randomized controlled trial that aimed to assess the effects of DMPs for secondary prevention of stroke.Follow-up on the subject is ongoing and will end in 2015.

title: Befriending caregivers of people with dementia: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the effectiveness of a voluntary sector-based friendship scheme in improving the psychological well-being and quality of life of family caregivers of people with dementia. DESIGN Single-blind randomized controlled trial. SETTING Community settings in East Anglia and London. PARTICIPANTS 236 family caregivers of people with primary progressive dementia. INTERVENTION Contact with a befriender facilitator and offer of a match with a trained volunteer lay befriender compared to no befriender facilitator contact";" all participants continued to receive 'usual care'. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Carers' mood (hospital anxiety and depression scale-depression) and health-related quality of life (EuroQoL) at 15 months post randomisation. RESULTS The intention-to-treat analysis showed no benefit for the intervention 'access to a facilitator befriender' on the primary outcome measure or on any of the secondary outcomes. CONCLUSIONS Like many caregiver services, friendship schemes are not adopted by all caregivers, and providing access to a friendship scheme is not effective in improving well-being. Current CONTROLLED TRIALS test record: ISRCTN08130075.

title: Behavior change without behavior change communication: promoting handwashing among primary school students in Bangladesh.
abstract: Behavior change communication to improve handwashing with soap can be labor intensive and resource intensive, but quality results are difficult to achieve. Nudges are environmental cues that involve unconscious decision-making processes to drive behavior change. In this proof-of-concept study, we developed an inexpensive set of incentives to encourage handwashing with soap after using the toilet in two primary schools in rural Bangladesh. We completed direct observation of behaviors at baseline, after providing traditional handwashing infrastructure, and at various time periods after specific handwashing pushes (1 day, 2 weeks, and 6 weeks). No additional handwashing education or motivational messages were completed. Handwashing with soap among school-age children was low at baseline (4%), increasing to 68% the day after pushovers were completed and to 74% at both 2 weeks and 6 weeks after the intervention. The results indicate that shove-based interventions have the potential to improve handwashing with soap among schoolchildren in Bangladesh and specific areas for further research are discussed.

title: Behavioral counseling after screening for alcohol misuse in primary care: a systematic review and meta-analysis for the US Preventive Services Task Force.
abstract: Background: Alcohol misuse, which includes the entire spectrum from hazardous drinking to alcohol dependence, is a leading cause of preventable death in the United States. Purpose: To assess the benefits and harms of behavioral counseling interventions for adolescent and adult alcohol abusers. Data Sources: MEDLINE, EMBASE, Cochrane Library, CINAHL, PsycINFO, International Pharmaceutical Abstracts, and reference lists of published literature (January 1985 to January 2012, limited to articles in English). Study Selection: Controlled trials of at least 6 months' duration that enrolled screen-identified alcohol abusers in primary care settings and evaluated behavioral counseling interventions. Data extraction: one reviewer extracted data and a second checked for accuracy. Two independent reviewers assigned quality ratings and rated the strength of the evidence. Data synthesis: The 23 included trials generally excluded people with alcohol dependence. The best evidence was for brief multi-contact interventions (10 to 15 minutes). Among adults who received behavioral interventions, consumption decreased by 3.6 drinks per week from baseline (weighted mean difference, 3.6 drinks/week [95% CI, 2.4 to 4.8 drinks/week] "; 10 trials; 4,332 participants), 12% fewer adults reported episodes of heavy drinking (risk difference, 0.12 [CI, 0.07 to 0.16]; 7 trials; 2,737 participants), and a 11% more adults reported drinking less than the recommended limits (risk difference, 0.11 [CI, 0.08 to 0.13]; 9 trials;" 5,973 participants) over 12 months compared with control participants ( moderate evidence). The evidence was insufficient to draw conclusions about alcohol-related accidents, injuries, or liver problems. Trials involving young adults or college students showed reduced drinking and fewer binge drinking episodes (moderate strength of evidence). Little or no evidence of damage was found. Limitations: The results may be biased to zero because the behavior of the control participants could have been affected by the alcohol misuse assessments. Furthermore, the evidence may not be applicable to people with alcohol dependence and selective reporting may have occurred. Conclusion: Behavioral counseling interventions improve behavioral outcomes for adults with risky drinking. Primary Funding Source: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality.

title: Behavioral Counseling Interventions to Prevent Sexually Transmitted Infections: US Preventive Services Task Force Recommendation Statement.
abstract: DESCRIPTION: New recommendations from the US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) on behavioral counseling for adolescents and adults to prevent sexually transmitted infections (STIs). METHODS: The USPSTF reviewed the evidence on the benefits and harms of counseling. The review included studies that evaluated behavioral counseling interventions delivered in primary settings, those considered feasible in primary care, and those to which patients could be referred from primary care. RECOMMENDATIONS: The USPSTF recommends high-intensity behavioral counseling for all sexually active adolescents and adults. at increased risk of STIs. (Recommendation B) Current evidence is insufficient to assess the balance of benefits and harms of behavioral counseling to prevent STIs in nonsexually active adolescents and in adults who are not at increased risk for STIs. (I statement).

title: Behavioral counseling to promote physical activity and a healthy diet to prevent cardiovascular disease in adults: a systematic review for the US Preventive Services Task Force.
abstract: Background: Poor diet and lack of physical activity can worsen cardiovascular health; however, most Americans do not meet the recommendations for diet and physical activity. Purpose: To assist the US Preventive Services Task Force with advice on preventing cardiovascular disease. Data sources: MEDLINE, PsycINFO, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (2001 to January 2010), experts, and existing systematic reviews. a priori inclusion criteria and critically appraised each study using design-specific quality criteria. Data extraction and analysis: Data from 73 studies (109 articles) were abstracted by one reviewer and checked by a second reviewer. Random-effects meta-analyses were performed for multiple intermediate health and behavior outcomes. Data Synthesis: Long-term observational follow-up of intensive sodium reduction counseling showed a decrease in the incidence of cardiovascular disease";" however, other direct evidence of reduced morbidity from the disease is lacking. High-intensity dietary advice, with or without physical activity advice, resulted in changes of 0.3 to 0.7 kg/m2 in body mass index (adiposity), 1.5 mm Hg (95% CI, 0.9 to 2.1 mm Hg) in systolic blood pressure, ?0.7 mm Hg (CI, ?0.6 to ?0.9 mm Hg) in diastolic pressure, ?0.17 mmol/L ( CI, ?0.09 to ?0.25 mmol/L) (?6.56 mg/dL [CI, ?3.47 to ?9.65 mg/dL]) in total cholesterol level, and ?0 .13 mmol/L (CI, ?0.06 to ?0.21 mmol/L) (?5.02 mg/dL [CI, ?2.32 to ?8.11 mg/dL ]) at the level of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol. Medium and high intensity counseling resulted in moderate to large changes in self-reported dietary and physical activity behaviors. Limitations: Meta-analyses for some outcomes had high statistical heterogeneity or evidence of publication bias. Only 11 trials followed up on outcomes beyond 12 months. Conclusion: Advice to improve diet or increase physical activity changed health behaviors and was associated with small improvements in adiposity, blood pressure, and lipid levels. Primary Funding Source: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality.

title: Behavioral economics and medical compensation: promises and challenges.
Behavioral programs for type 2 diabetes mellitus: a systematic review and network meta-analysis.
abstract: Background: Behavioral programs can improve outcomes for people with type 2 diabetes mellitus, but there is a wide diversity of behavioral interventions and uncertainty about how to optimize the effectiveness of these programs. Purpose: To identify factors that moderate the effectiveness of behavioral programs for adults with type 2 diabetes. Data sources: 6 databases (1993 to January 2015), conference proceedings (2011 to 2014), and reference lists. Study selection: Duplicate screening and selection of 132 randomized controlled trials evaluating behavioral programs compared with usual care, active controls, or other behavioral programs. Data extraction: one reviewer extracted and another checked the data. Two reviewers independently assessed risk of bias. Data Synthesis: Behavioral programs were grouped on the basis of program content and delivery methods. A Bayesian network meta-analysis showed that most diabetes self-management and lifestyle education and support programs (typically offering 11 contact hours) led to clinically important improvements in glycemic control (reduced 0.4% in hemoglobin A1c [HbA1c] ), while most diabetes self-management education programs without additional support, especially those offering 10 or fewer contact hours, provided little benefit. Programs with higher effect sizes were more often delivered in person than through technology. Lifestyle programs led to the largest reductions in body mass index. Reductions in HbA1c appeared to be greater for participants with a baseline HbA1c level of 7.0% or higher, adults younger than 65 years, and people of color (subgroups with 75% nonwhite participants). Limitations: All trials were at medium or high risk of bias. Subgroup analyzes were indirect and therefore exploratory. Most outcomes were reported immediately after the interventions. Conclusion: Diabetes self-management education offering 10 or fewer hours of contact with the delivery staff provided little benefit. Behavioral programs seem to benefit people with poor or suboptimal glycemic control more than those with good control. Primary Funding Source: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality. (PROSPERO registration number: CRD42014010515)

title: Behavioral sexual risk reduction counseling in primary care to prevent sexually transmitted infections: a systematic review for the US Preventive Services Task Force.
abstract: Background: Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) are common and preventable. Purpose: To update a previous systematic review on the benefits and harms of sexual risk reduction counseling for STI prevention for the US Preventive Services Task Force. Data sources: Selected databases from January 2007 to October 2013, handsearching reference lists and gray literature, and studies from the previous review. Study selection: English-language trials of fair or good quality conducted in adolescents or adults. Data extraction: one researcher extracted the data and a second verified the extraction. Study quality was double checked. Data synthesis: 31 trials were included: 16 (n = 56,110) were recently published and 15 (n = 14,214) were from the previous review. Most trials targeted people at increased risk of STIs based on sociodemographic characteristics, risky sexual behaviour, or history of an STI. High-intensity interventions (>2 hours) reduced the incidence of STIs in adolescents (odds ratio, 0.38 [95% CI, 0.24 to 0.60]) and adults (odds ratio, 0.70 [CI, 0.56 to 0.87]). Lower intensity interventions were generally not effective in adults, but some approaches showed promise. Although moderate intensity interventions may be effective in adolescents, data were very sparse. Reported behavioral outcomes were heterogeneous and most likely show benefit with high-intensity interventions at 6 months or less. We found no consistent evidence that sexual risk reduction counseling was harmful. Limitations: Low-risk populations and adolescent boys were underrepresented. The reliability of self-reported behavioral outcomes was unknown. Conclusion: High-intensity sexual risk reduction counseling can reduce STIs in primary care and related settings, especially in sexually active adolescents and adults at increased risk of STIs. Primary Funding Source: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality.

title: Behavioral therapy with or without biofeedback and pelvic floor electrical stimulation for persistent postprostatectomy incontinence
abstract: Context Although behavioral therapy has been shown to improve postoperative recovery of continence, there have been no controlled trials of behavioral therapy for postprostatectomy incontinence persisting for more than 1 year. Objective To assess the efficacy of behavioral therapy in reducing persistent postprostatectomy incontinence and to determine whether pelvic floor electrical stimulation and biofeedback technologies improve the efficacy of behavioral therapy. Design, Setting, and Participants A prospective randomized controlled trial involving 208 community-dwelling men aged 51 to 84 years with persistent incontinence 1 to 17 years after radical prostatectomy was conducted at a university and 2 Continence Affairs clinics. Veterans Administration (2003-2008) and included a 1-year follow-up after active treatment. Twenty-four percent of the men were African American; 75% white. Interventions After stratification by type and frequency of incontinence, participants were randomized to 1 of 3 groups: 8 weeks of behavioral therapy (pelvic floor muscle training and bladder control strategies); behavioral therapy plus dual-channel electromyograph biofeedback in office and daily pelvic floor electrical stimulation at home at 20 Hz, current up to 100 mA (additional behavior); or deferred treatment, which served as a control group. reduction in mean number of incontinence episodes after 8 weeks of treatment as documented in 7-day bladder diaries Results Mean number of incontinence episodes decreased from 28 to 13 per week (55% reduction; confidence interval [ 95% CI, 44%-66%) after behavioral therapy and 26 to 12 (51% reduction; 95% CI, 37%-65%) after behavioral therapy plus. Both reductions were significantly greater than the reduction from 25 to 21 (24% reduction; 95% CI, 10%-39%) or observed among controls (P = .001 for both treatment groups). However, there was no significant difference in incontinence reduction between the treatment groups (p = 0.69). Improvements were durable at 12 months in the active treatment groups: 50% reduction (95% CI, 39.8%-61.1%; 13.5 episodes per week) in the behavioral group and 59% reduction % (95% CI, 45.0%-73.1%; "9.1 episodes per week) in the behavioral plus group (P = .32). Conclusions Among patients with postprostatectomy incontinence for at least 1 year , 8 weeks of behavioral therapy, compared with a late treatment control, resulted in fewer episodes of incontinence.The addition of biofeedback and pelvic floor electrical stimulation did not result in greater effectiveness.

title: Behavioral treatment of obesity in patients cared for in primary care settings: a systematic review
abstract: SIGNIFICANCE: In 2011, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) approved intensive behavioral weight loss counseling for approximately 14 face-to-face 10-15 minute sessions over 6 months for obese beneficiaries in primary care settings, when provided by physicians and other primary care professionals as defined by CMS. OBJECTIVE: To conduct a systematic review of behavioral counseling for overweight and obese patients recruited from primary care, provided by primary care physicians working alone or with trained interventionists (eg, physician assistants, registered dietitians), or by trained interventionists who work independently. EVIDENCE REVIEW: We searched PubMed, CINAHL, and EMBASE for randomized controlled trials published between January 1980 and June 2014 that recruited overweight and obese primary care patients"; provided behavioral counseling (i.e., diet, exercise, and behavioral therapy ) for at least 3 months, with at least 6 months of follow-up after randomization; included at least 15 participants per treatment group and objectively measured weights;" and had a comparator, an intention-to-treat analysis, and an attrition of less than 30% at one year or less than 40% at longer follow-up. FINDINGS: The review of 3304 abstracts yielded 12 trials, with 3893 participants, that met the inclusion and exclusion criteria and pre-specified quality ratings. No studies were found in which primary care physicians provided advice that followed CMS guidelines. Mean weight changes at 6 months from baseline in the intervention groups ranged from a loss of 0.3 kg to 6.6 kg. In the control group, the mean change ranged from a gain of 0.9 kg to a loss of 2.0 kg. Weight loss in both groups generally decreased with longer follow-up (12 to 24 months). Interventions that prescribed both reduced energy intake (eg, >/= 500 kcal/d) and increased physical activity (eg, >/= 150 minutes per week of walking), with therapy traditional behavioral interventions generally produced greater weight loss than interventions without all 3 specific components. In earlier trials, more treatment sessions, conducted in person or over the phone by trained interventionists, were associated with greater average weight loss and the likelihood of patients losing 5% or more of their baseline weight. CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Intensive behavioral counseling can induce clinically significant weight loss, but there is little research on primary care physicians providing such care. The present findings suggest that a range of trained interventionists, providing advice in person or by telephone, could be considered to treat overweight or obesity in patients in primary care settings.

title: Behavior change strategies to reduce the burden of blood pressure-related illness: findings from a global implementation research program.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Global Alliance for Chronic Diseases comprises most of the world's public research funding agencies. It focuses on implementation research to address the burden of chronic disease in low- and middle-income countries and among vulnerable populations in high-income countries. In its inaugural research call, 15 projects were funded, focused on reducing the burden of blood pressure-related disease. In this study, we describe a reflective mapping exercise to identify the behavior change strategies undertaken in each of these projects. METHODS: Using the Behavior Change Wheel framework, each team rated the capacity, timeliness, and motivation of the various actors that were integral to each project (eg, community members, non-medical health workers, and physicians). in projects focused on the provision of services). The teams then mapped the interventions they were implementing and determined the main policy categories in which those interventions operated. Guidance was provided on the use of the behavior change wheel to support consistency in responses across teams. The ratings were iteratively discussed and refined in several group meetings. RESULTS: There was a marked variation in the perceived capabilities, opportunities, and motivation of the various actors who were being targeted by behavior change strategies. Despite this variation, there was a high degree of synergy in intervention roles with most teams using complex interventions involving education, training, empowerment, environmental restructuring, and persuasion-oriented strategies. Similar policy categories also focused on all teams, particularly in the areas of guidelines, communication/marketing, and service provision, with few teams focusing on fiscal measures, regulation, and legislation. CONCLUSIONS: The wide variation in readiness to change behavior among the main actors in these projects suggests that the interventions themselves will be variably adopted, despite the similarity in the approaches taken. The findings highlight the importance of contextual factors in driving the success and failure of research programs. Upcoming outcome and process evaluations of each project will build on this exploratory work and provide further insight into factors that could influence scaling up intervention strategies.

title: Behavioral perceptions in health care
Beliefs and attitudes about breast cancer and screening practices among Arab women living in Qatar: a cross-sectional study.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite rising breast cancer incidence and mortality rates, breast cancer screening (BCS) rates among women in Qatar remain low. Previous studies indicate a need to better understand the many complex beliefs, values, and attitudes that influence health-seeking behavior of Arab women for the development of culturally appropriate and effective intervention strategies to address breast cancer in the Middle East. . This study investigates BCS beliefs, attitudes, and practices of Arabic-speaking women in Qatar. METHODS: Between March 2011 and July 2011, a multicentre cross-sectional quantitative survey of 1,063 (response rate 87.5%) Qatari citizens and non-residents of Qatar who spoke Arabic, aged 35 years or older, was conducted in Qatar. plus. Associations between BCS beliefs and practice were estimated using chi-square tests and multivariate logistic regression analyses. Participants who adhered to the BCS guidelines (BCS practice = Yes) were compared with those who did not (BCS practice = No). RESULTS: In addition to low levels of awareness and low rates of participation in BCS, a quarter of the participants said that their doctors told them about breast cancer and less than half of the women interviewed believed that breast cancer it can be prevented. Women who participated in BCS practice were more likely to have had a doctor talk to them about breast cancer, to believe they were in good or excellent health, that cancer was preventable, or that cancer might run in families. Most wanted to know if they had cancer and felt their health care needs were being met. The main reasons given for not planning BCS were lack of medical advice, fear and shame. CONCLUSIONS: These findings indicate that a variety of channels (health care providers, media, breast cancer survivors, community leaders) should be used to create culturally appropriate breast cancer intervention programs and increased cancer awareness. breast cancer, BCS and the benefits of early detection. of breast cancer. Employing these measures will reduce breast cancer mortality rates among Arabic-speaking women living in the State of Qatar.

title: Beliefs about mammography among women presenting to the emergency department for non-urgent care
abstract: INTRODUCTION: One in 8 American women will develop invasive breast cancer in her lifetime. Despite evidence that mammography is an effective method of early detection, certain vulnerable groups, such as those who use the emergency department as a medical home, do not adhere to mammography screening guidelines and experience disparate cancer mortality from mom The purpose of this study was to investigate differences in beliefs regarding mammography among women attending the emergency department for non-urgent care and ultimately develop interventions that promote mammography for this vulnerable population. METHODS: We explored the relationship between readiness to adopt mammography behavior and perceived barriers, benefits, and susceptibility by administering risk, benefit, and barrier scales to a sample of 110 women presenting to the emergency department. from a public hospital for non-urgent complaints or were sitting in the ED waiting room. We also collect sociodemographic information and preparation stage. RESULTS: Adherence to mammography was around 60%. Most of the women who did not meet the current guidelines were contemplators. Those who were not contemplating getting tested were significantly less likely to perceive themselves to be at risk for breast cancer. Women who had more barriers to mammography perceived less benefit from having a mammogram. African-American women perceived less benefit from having a mammogram. DISCUSSION: The promotion of mammography is appropriately placed in the emergency department waiting room given the suboptimal rate at which screening is performed in this population. Beliefs regarding mammography differ for women at various stages of mammography adoption and for minority women. Understanding these differences will allow intervention in this setting to be tailored to the population. ER nurses are an important and sometimes the only healthcare point of contact for patients who routinely visit the emergency department. As such, they have a valuable opportunity to provide cancer screening advocacy messages. It is critical that nurses in this setting understand the complexities of providing this information and the need to do so.

title: Beneficial and detrimental effects of augmented feedback on the clinical-teaching performance of physicians
abstract: PURPOSE: To assess whether clinical teaching skills could be improved by providing teachers with augmented feedback from students. METHOD: A 1994 randomized controlled trial included 42 attending physicians and 39 residents in the Department of Medicine at the Indiana University School of Medicine who taught 110 students on medical ward rotations for one-month periods. Prior to teacher rotations, teachers in the intervention group received graphical, norm-referenced summaries of their teaching performance as rated by students. Midway through the month, teachers in the intervention group received student ratings augmented by individualized teaching effectiveness guidelines based on the Stanford Teacher Development Program framework. Linear models were used to analyze students' mean ratings on teaching behaviors at the middle and end of the month. Independent variables included performance ratings, intervention status, teacher status, teaching experience, and interactions with baseline ratings. RESULTS: Complex interactions with baseline performance were found for most teaching categories at mid-month and end-of-month. Teachers in the intervention group who had high baseline performance scores had higher student ratings than teachers in the control group with similar baseline scores; teachers in the intervention group who had low baseline performance scores were rated lower than teachers in the control group with comparable baseline scores. Residents who had medium or high baseline scores received a higher rating than treating physicians with comparable baseline scores;" the performance of residents with low baseline scores was similar to that of treating physicians with comparable baseline scores. CONCLUSION: Benchmark performance is important to identify teachers most likely to benefit from increased student feedback Potential deterioration in teacher performance warrants a reconsideration of the distribution of student scores to teachers with performance scores low reference.

title: Benefits and harms of pharmacological treatment for urinary incontinence in women
abstract: Background: Urinary incontinence (UI) in women negatively affects quality of life. Purpose: To conduct a systematic review of the literature on medications for urge UI in women. DATA SOURCES: We searched for articles published from 1966 to November 2011 in MEDLINE, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, SCIRUS, and Google Scholar. Study selection: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) reported in English. Data Extraction: Outcome rates and risk of bias were extracted using a standardized form to pool absolute risk differences and calculate the number of attributable events per 1000 patients treated, with 95% CI. Data synthesis: 94 RCTs were eligible. Pooled analyzes showed that among drugs for emergency UI, per 1,000 women treated, continence was restored in 130 with fesoterodine (CI, 58 to 202), 85 with tolterodine (CI, 40 to 129), 114 with oxybutynin (CI, 64 to 163), 107 with solifenacin (CI, 58 to 156), and 114 with trospium (CI, 83 to 144). Rates of treatment discontinuation due to adverse effects were 31 per 1000 treated with fesoterodine (CI, 10 to 56), 63 with oxybutynin (CI, 12 to 127), 18 with trospium (CI, 4 to 33), and 13 with solifenacin. (IQ, 1 to 26). Inconsistent study definitions of UI reduction and quality of life hampered evidence synthesis. Limitation: Evidence for improvements in quality of life and comparative effectiveness with medications was limited, and evidence for the effects of race, baseline severity of UI, and comorbid conditions on treatment success was insufficient. Conclusion: Overall, medications for urge UI showed a similar small benefit. Therapeutic options should consider the damage profile. Evidence on long-term adherence and safety of treatments is lacking. Primary Funding Source: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality.

title: Benzodiazepines, Opioids, and Driving: An Overview of Experimental Research
abstract: PROBLEMS: Road accidents contribute significantly to the total injury burden in Australia, and the risk of injury is associated with the presence of drugs and/or alcohol in the driver's blood. Increasingly, some of the most frequently detected drugs include prescription medications, the most notable being benzodiazepines and opioids. However, there is a paucity of experimental research on the effects of prescription psychoactive drugs on driving behaviour. FOCUS: This document provides an overview of experimental studies investigating the effects of prescribed doses of benzodiazepines and opioids on driving ability, and points to future directions for research. KEY FINDINGS: There is a growing body of epidemiological evidence linking the therapeutic use of benzodiazepines and opioids with an increased risk of accident. However, the current experimental literature remains unclear. Limitations of study methodologies have resulted in inconsistent findings. IMPLICATIONS: There is limited experimental evidence to inform policy and guidelines regarding fitness to drive for patients taking prescription benzodiazepines and opioids. CONCLUSION: More experimental research is required to elucidate the effects of these medications on driving, under various conditions and in different medical settings. This will ensure that physicians who prescribe benzodiazepines and opioids are well informed and can properly advise patients on the risks associated with driving while taking these medications.

title: Grief Interventions for Adults with Intellectual Disabilities: What Works?
abstract: Currently examining the theoretical basis for grief and loss for adults with intellectual disabilities (ID). However, as the lifespan of people with ID increases, these adults experience more and more events of loss and bereavement. Practitioners, especially grief counselors, find it increasingly important to understand best practice principles for working with grieving adults with ID in their daily work. Professionals are also asked to guide families and care providers in bereavement and death education. This article provides counselors and other professionals with a review of existing research on grief interventions for adults with ID. Practical recommendations are made at three levels: "informal support"; "formal intervention"; and community education.

title: Best practices in the management of primary nocturnal enuresis in children: a systematic review.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Nocturnal enuresis is the involuntary loss of urine at night in a child of an age and physical health where dryness would be expected. The prevalence of this condition in Australia has been estimated at 18.9% in children aged 5 to 12 years, with up to 19% of boys and 16% of girls aged 5 years wetting the bed at least once a month. Until the age of 13, bedwetting is more common in boys and more common in girls after this age. Nocturnal enuresis has a spontaneous cure rate of approximately 14%; however, up to 3% of children remain enuretic into adulthood. Although this condition is pathologically benign, it can have serious social and psychological repercussions for the sufferer, including effects on self-esteem, school success, parental disapproval, and even sexual activity in adulthood. Despite the volume of information available for the management of bedwetting, most of the research has been conducted outside of Australia. Therefore, the purpose of this paper was to produce management guidelines for nocturnal enuresis in children specific to Australian clinical practice. INCLUSION CRITERIA: This review considered systematic reviews or concurrent controlled trials (randomized controlled trials [RCTs], pseudorandomized controlled trials, controlled clinical trials [CCTs], interrupted time series [ITS], and controlled before-and-after trials [CBA]), to examine the effectiveness of interventions to control nocturnal enuresis in children aged up to 16 years. SEARCH STRATEGY: A systematic search of the literature was performed to identify all available evidence. We searched Cochrane and other health technology assessment websites for existing systematic reviews. Pubmed, Embase and CINAHL databases were searched for recent randomized controlled trials and controlled trials (1990 to 2007). Reference lists of all retrieved articles were searched for relevant trials. These reviews and guidelines were summarized and presented to an advisory panel of continence advisory nurses and clinicians to ensure relevance to Australian clinical practice. METHODOLOGICAL QUALITY: Two reviewers assessed the methodological quality of all studies using the JBI critical appraisal forms for experimental studies located within the JBI-MAStARI software. This tool was used to identify all sources of bias. Where there was disagreement between the two reviewers, a third reviewer resolved. RESULTS: Seven systematic reviews, eight new trials, and two guidelines were used in the development of these guidelines. Briefly, management recommendations include: CONCLUSIONS: Despite the high prevalence of nocturnal enuresis and the negative psychosocial sequelae that can arise from this condition, management is both available and effective. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: The practice of managing nocturnal enuresis in children should begin by addressing both daytime enuresis and any evidence of constipation. After this, less invasive behavioral therapies should be tried. If these measures fail, the use of alarms with or without short-term administration of desmopressin could be tried. Other interventions have not yet been shown to be definitively effective and should be considered with caution. However, it must be emphasized that the vast majority of children will become continent at some point in the future, with or without the benefit of interventions. IMPLICATIONS FOR RESEARCH: While it is clear that some behavioral approaches, alarms, and desmopressin may be effective interventions, the evidence for other treatments is less conclusive. However, the observation that even alarms and/or desmopressin do not work for all children suggests that research to establish the effectiveness of other interventions (especially behavioral and adjunctive treatments) should be conducted in the form of large, carefully designed RCTs. .

title: Best strategies for implementing clinical pathways in an emergency department: study protocol for a cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background The clinical pathway is a tool that operationalizes best evidence recommendations and clinical practice guidelines in an accessible format for point-of-care management by multidisciplinary health teams in hospital settings. While high-quality, expertly developed clinical pathways have many potential benefits, their impact has been limited by variable implementation strategies and suboptimal research designs. The best strategies for implementing pathways in hospital settings are still unknown. This study will seek to comprehensively develop and evaluate the best strategies for effective local implementation of externally developed expert clinical pathways. Design/Methods We will develop a theory-based, user-informed intervention strategy to implement two pediatric clinical pathways: asthma and gastroenteritis. Using a balanced incomplete block design, we will randomize 16 community emergency departments to receive the intervention for one clinical pathway and serve as a control for the alternative clinical pathway, thus conducting two cluster-randomized controlled trials to evaluate this implementation intervention. A minimization procedure will be used to randomize the sites. Intervention sites will receive a tailored strategy to support full implementation of the clinical pathway. We will assess the effectiveness of the implementation strategy through measurement of relevant process and clinical outcomes. The main result of the process will be the presence of a properly completed clinical pathway in the file for the relevant patients. The primary clinical outcomes for each clinical pathway include the following: Asthma, the proportion of patients with asthma adequately treated with corticosteroids in the emergency department and at discharge";" and GastroenteritisÂ¡Âªthe proportion of relevant patients treated appropriately with oral rehydration therapy. Data sources include chart audits, administrative databases, environmental scans, and qualitative interviews. We will also conduct an overall process assessment to assess the implementation strategy and an economic analysis to assess the costs and benefits of implementation. Discussion This study will contribute to the body of evidence supporting effective strategies for implementation of clinical pathways and ultimately narrowing research to practice gaps in putting best evidence care recommendations into practice through effective use of pathways. clinics.

title: Intervention of best practices for the care of clients who self-mutilate
abstract: PURPOSE: To describe the development of a best practice intervention to guide nurse practitioners (NPs) caring for people who self-mutilate. DATA SOURCES: The evidence on which the guideline was based includes six descriptive studies and expert clinical opinion articles. The framework for guideline development is a systematic process for obtaining and analyzing the best available evidence, developing a theory-based intervention, and proposing a system for ongoing evaluation of intervention effectiveness. CONCLUSIONS: The guide is an information sheet, which contains the definition of self-mutilation, background of the problem, affected target population and intervention. The three components of the intervention are (a) the NP's self-assessment of values, beliefs, and assumptions about people who self-harm"; (b) a focused and in-depth client assessment"; and (c) therapeutic strategies to address the emotional, social, and biological dimensions of self-mutilation. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: This Best Practices Intervention for the Care of Self-Harming Clients guide provides guidance for NPs to effectively address preventable self-harm behavior. Further studies are needed to examine the effectiveness of guideline use and intervention.

title: Best medicine by default
abstract: Bottom. American health care is transitioning to electronic medical ordering. These computerized systems are unique in that they allow for custom ordering interfaces. While these systems provide great benefits, there are also potential drawbacks, as behavioral science has shown that the very format of electronic interfaces can influence decision making. Current research specifically examines how default values in electronic ordering templates affect physician treatment decisions and medical errors. Methods. Forty-five resident physicians completed order sets for 3 medical case studies. Participants were randomly assigned to receive sets of orders with 'opt-in' defaults (options visible but not selected) or 'opt-out' defaults (options visible and pre-selected). The results compare error rates across conditions and examine the type and severity of errors that are most often made with the default include and exclude values. Results. The exclusion defaults resulted in a higher number of ordered items and specifically an increase in commission errors (overorders) compared to the participation defaults. However, while subscription defaults resulted in fewer orders, errors of omission also increased. When the severity of the bugs is taken into account, the default effects appear to be limited to less severe bugs. Conclusion. Defaults used in electronic order sets influence medical treatment decisions when the consequences to a patient's health are low. This pattern suggests that clinicians cognitively override incorrect defaults, but only up to a point, and involves trade-offs that maximize accuracy and minimize cognitive effort. The results indicate that the default values for low-impact items in electronic templates deserve careful attention because they are unlikely to be overridden by clinicians.

title: Best practices in collaborative mental health care: an analysis of the evidence base
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To conduct a systematic review of the experimental literature to identify best practices in collaborative mental health care in the primary care setting. METHODS: A review of the Canadian and international literature using Medline, PsycInfo, Embase, the Cochrane Library, and other databases produced more than 900 related reports, of which 38 studies met the inclusion criteria. A systematic review and descriptive analysis is presented, with key conclusions and best practices. RESULTS: Successful collaboration requires preparation, time, and support structures, building on pre-existing clinical relationships. Collaborative practice is likely to develop more when clinicians are co-located and is more effective when the location is familiar and non-stigmatizing to patients. The degree of collaboration does not seem to predict clinical outcome. Enhanced collaboration combined with treatment guidelines or protocols offers important benefits over either intervention alone in major depression. Systematic follow-up was a powerful predictor of a positive outcome in collaborative care for depression. A clear relationship between collaborative efforts to increase medication adherence and clinical outcomes was not evident. Collaboration alone has not been shown to result in skill transfer in PCP knowledge or behaviors in the treatment of depression. A service restructuring designed to support changes in practice patterns of primary health care providers is also required. Improved patient education was part of many successful studies. The education was usually provided by someone other than the PCP. Collaborative interventions that are part of a research protocol can be difficult to sustain in the long term without ongoing funding. Consumer choice of treatment modality may be important in treatment participation in collaborative care (for example, having the option to choose psychotherapy versus medication). CONCLUSIONS: There is now a body of experimental literature evaluating the impact of increased collaboration on patient outcomes, primarily in depressive disorders. Best practices in collaborative mental health care are beginning to emerge.

title: Between collegiate conversation and controlled trials: hospital neurologists' sources of information and their practical knowledge in treating stroke patients
abstract: The application of standardized and evidence-based knowledge is an important foundation for coordinated and effective clinical work. A multicentre study, conducted in 30 clinical neurology departments and including 99 junior and senior registrars, addressed aspects of stroke management practice knowledge using open-ended structured oral interviews that were analyzed with respect to inter-physician agreement and with the guides. In addition, participants were asked to rate the usefulness of various information sources and to describe the information sources used according to the aspects of practical knowledge addressed. The respective departmental directors were questioned about the sources of medical knowledge accessible in their clinic. In almost all hospitals, doctors had access to a library and the Internet. However, the departments differed with respect to their information management (frequency and type of medical education, quality management, participation in research activities). Consistent with other studies, the most frequently reported sources of knowledge were textbooks, journals, and clinical studies. For most sources, usefulness ratings largely corresponded to user behavior ratings. Both were only weak predictors for guideline and interpractice compliance. They are more closely related to the homogeneity of practical knowledge within the department than to interdepartmental conformity and guidelines.
