Homogeneity within the department is enhanced by the use of recent, published, evidence-based sources and topical interaction with clinical colleagues. Compliance with the guideline was related to the use of databases and professional journals. Preference for outpatient practice colleagues decreased both inter-physician and guideline compliance. It appears that there is still untapped potential for knowledge management within the department, such as medical education, implementation and use of guidelines, and thematic discussions, which can improve homogeneity and conformance to practice knowledge guidelines applied by physicians. doctors.

title: Between control and therapy: an analysis of the evolutionary concept of special observation in acute psychiatric wards
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Special observation is a seriously invasive and resource-intensive intervention. It is necessary to scientifically conceptualize this measure for future research and practice. METHODS: Evolutionary concept analysis. RESULTS: The identified antecedents, attributes and consequences of the special observation oscillate between control and therapy as well as patient safety and professional coverage. The antecedents are made up of legitimation (indication, evaluation, prescription), resources (internal guidelines, architectural structures, information) as well as contextual factors (security needs, personal attitudes). The attitudes identified are the organization (qualification, change of caregivers, duration, place), the intervention (relationship, reassessment, transparency) as well as the field of tension between control and therapy. Consequences consist of side effects (patients, nurses, resources) and conflicts (ethical dilemmas, role conflicts). CONCLUSION: Society and discipline have influenced the concept over time and a distinction between the custody and control pattern versus a therapeutic approach is recommended.

title: Between scientific application and therapy: ethical consideration
abstract: The development of bioscience and biotechnology during the last thirty years exerted a tremendous influence on medicine. New techniques have emerged and new types of treatment have been and continue to be introduced. Theories about the pathogenesis and causes of the disease change, while new therapeutic drugs are constantly available on the market. The way new technologies and drugs are introduced increasingly contains an experimental phase in which animals and humans are used to test the results of the research. As a rule, these experiments are performed in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki (WMA, Helsinki 1964, Tokyo, 1975). The guidelines in this Statement address the ethical aspects of experiments involving human subjects. Although the guidelines are intended to be of global importance, it remains a fact that some of them are the subject of debate in various regions of the world. They seem to have a cultural background (eg respect for the individual) and bioscientists sometimes argue that for this reason they should be considered unscientific constraints. Based on a general philosophical and ethical consideration, it will be argued in this article that ethical guidelines belong to the very heart of biomedicine and biology. It is in the common interest of researchers, clinicians, patients, and scientists to consider the ethical implications of research results before any valuable knowledge can be claimed to have been obtained. The implementation of monoclonal antibodies in clinical practice can be seen as an example of this argument.

title: Beyond Domestic Violence Screening: A Systems Model Approach in a Managed Care Setting
abstract: BACKGROUND: Implementation of domestic violence screening guidelines has been challenging. The multifaceted "systems model" can provide an effective means of improving the detection, identification, and intervention of domestic violence in the health care setting. METHODS: We developed: (1) a systems model approach using tools for effective "domestic violence referral, assessment, and reporting"; (2) materials to distribute to female patients; (3) training for social and medical health services to provide domestic violence screening and (4) strong community ties SETTING: A nonprofit managed care facility in Richmond, California PARTICIPANTS: Managed care plan staff and members KEY OUTCOME MEASURES: (1) Increased of domestic violence screening by physicians; (2) increased awareness of the health care facility as a resource for domestic violence assistance;" and (3) increased member satisfaction with the health plan's efforts to address domestic violence. RESULTS: The number of physician referrals and patient self-referrals to an on-site domestic violence evaluator more than doubled. A pre- and post-intervention telephone survey of members seen for a routine checkup showed an increase in member recall of being asked about domestic violence. After the intervention, statistically significant increases were observed in members' perception that the health plan was concerned about the effects of domestic violence on health (p<0.0001) and in members' satisfaction with health plans. health plan efforts to address this problem (p<0.0001). CONCLUSIONS: A systems model approach improved domestic violence services in a managed care health setting within 1 year and affected physician behavior as well as health plan member experience. This successful implementation makes it possible to address critical research questions about the impact of a health care intervention for victims of domestic violence in a managed care setting.

title: Big pharmaceuticals and health: insoluble conflict of interest between private companies and public health
abstract: landmark article on game theory showed that individual profit maximization necessarily endangers the public good, and since the problem has no technical solution, "it requires a fundamental extension in morality" (1). We propose here that public health, as a public good, now emerges as a serious example of this problem. Recent events and reports increasingly suggest a misalignment between the interests of the pharmaceutical industry and those of public health. Johnson & Johnson illegally and effectively promoted off-label Propulsid for children despite internal company documents raising safety concerns. Death in a drug trial has been described as a "trade secret". Of Vioxx, Topol wrote: "Unfortunately, it is clear that Merck's commercial interest outweighed their concerns about the drug's toxicity" (2). Academics and leading journal publishers are increasingly raising concerns about the type and quality of published evidence, often biased towards the efficacy of new products. The industry, which funds more than 80% of trials, sets a research agenda driven more by marketing than clinical considerations. Smart statistical and epidemiological tactics help to get the desired results. The budget for marketing is much higher than for research. Mass advertising directed at doctors and the public is becoming increasingly sophisticated: ghost writing, professional guidelines, targeting consumer groups, and manipulating the media to promote disease. Widespread lobbying and political ties limit the independence of regulators. The obligation to shareholders above public health considerations is not exclusive to the pharmaceutical industry. The chemical, tobacco, and food industries share similar tactics: proclaiming doubts about safety issues, buying researchers, infiltrating universities, boards, the media, and legislative agencies. By contrast, powerful and cheap health promotion activities, which are not supported by industry because they are too cheap and unpatented, are markedly underused: technologies to change behavior (for example, cardiac rehabilitation), palliative care and use of old, effective and safe medicines. everyone could benefit from the quality and marketing tools of the industry. Since the sick, the poor and the least educated are the most affected, the successes of the free market seem to pose intractable challenges to social justice in public health.

title: Binge eating disorder in adults: systematic review and meta-analysis
abstract: BACKGROUND: The best treatment options for binge eating disorder are unclear. PURPOSE: To summarize the evidence on the benefits and harms of psychological and pharmacological therapies for adults with binge eating disorder. DATA SOURCES: English-language publications in EMBASE, the Cochrane Library, Academic OneFile, CINAHL, and ClinicalTrials.gov through November 18, 2015, and in MEDLINE through May 12, 2016. STUDY SELECTION: 9 controlled psychological trials in waiting list and 25 placebo-controlled trials that evaluated pharmacological (n = 19) or combined (n = 6) treatment. All were randomized trials with low or medium risk of bias. DATA EXTRACTION: Two reviewers independently extracted trial data, assessed risk of bias, and rated strength of evidence. DATA SYNTHESIS: Therapist-directed cognitive behavioral therapy, lisdexamfetamine, and second-generation antidepressants (SGAs) decreased binge-eating frequency and increased binge-eating abstinence (relative risk, 4.95 [95% CI, 3.06 to 8.00 ], 2.61 [CI, 2.04 to 3.33], and 1.67 [CI, 1.24 to 2.26], respectively). Lisdexamfetamine (mean difference [MD], -6.50 [CI, -8.82 to -4.18]) and SGA (MD, -3.84 [CI, -6.55 to -1.13] ]) reduced binge-eating obsessions and compulsions, and SGAs reduced symptoms of depression (MD, -1.97 [CI, -3.67 to -0.28]). Headache, gastrointestinal upset, sleep disturbance, and sympathetic nervous system arousal occurred more frequently with lisdexamfetamine than with placebo (relative risk range, 1.63 to 4.28). Other forms of cognitive behavioral therapy and topiramate also increased abstinence and reduced binge frequency and related psychopathology. Topiramate reduced weight and increased sympathetic nervous system arousal, and lisdexamfetamine reduced weight and appetite. LIMITATIONS: The majority of study participants were overweight or obese white women between the ages of 20 and 40 years. Many treatments were examined only in single studies. Outcomes were inconsistently measured across trials and were rarely assessed beyond the end of treatment. CONCLUSION: Cognitive behavioral therapy, lisdexamfetamine, SGA, and topiramate reduced binge eating and related psychopathology, and lisdexamfetamine and topiramate reduced weight in adults with binge eating disorder.

title: Biomedical and behavioral research in nursing homes: guidelines for ethical research
abstract: As nursing homes become increasingly important sites for biomedical and behavioral research, researchers must address the ethical issues of increased vulnerability and the high prevalence of mental and physical disorders in the nursing home population. Obtaining valid informed consent is only one of many difficult problems facing the nursing home investigator. Efforts should be made to involve nursing home residents, as well as family and staff members, in reviewing the research. The benefits and burdens of research protocols must be equitably distributed, and potential conflicts of interest for staff members and clinicians must be minimized or their potential adverse impact enhanced. Proper attention to these ethical concerns can facilitate nursing home research while protecting vulnerable residents. We offer proposed guidelines for the ethical conduct of nursing home research in an effort to stimulate discussion among researchers, nursing home staff and residents, families of residents, and ethicists.

title: Pennsylvania Resident Bipolar Disorder Center: Implementing an Efficacy Trial to Improve Treatment of At-Risk Patients
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Adolescents, older adults, African Americans, and rural residents with bipolar disorder are less likely than their middle-aged, white, urban counterparts to be diagnosed, receive appropriate treatment, remain in treatment once identified, and have positive outcomes . The Bipolar Disorder Center for Pennsylvania Residents (BDCP) study was designed to address these disparities. This report highlights the methods used to recruit, test, and enroll a difficult-to-recruit cohort of people with bipolar disorder. METHODS: Study sites included three specialized clinics for bipolar disorder in a university setting and one rural behavioral health clinic. Study operations were standardized and all study personnel received training in study procedures. Various strategies were used for recruitment. RESULTS: It was possible to introduce the identical assessment and screening protocol in settings regardless of whether they had a history of implementing research protocols. This protocol could also be used across the age spectrum, in urban and rural areas, and in a racially diverse cohort of participants. Across the four sites, 515 people with bipolar disorder were enrolled as a result of these methods (69 African Americans and 446 non-African Americans). Although clinical characteristics at study entry did not differ appreciably between African Americans and non-African Americans, treatment pathways differed significantly. CONCLUSIONS: Rigorous recruitment and screening procedures can be successfully introduced in different settings and with different patient cohorts, facilitating access to high-quality treatment for people who frequently do not receive adequate care for bipolar disorder.

title: Books and Reading: An Evidence-Based Standard of Care Whose Time Has Come
abstract: Reach Out and Read (ROR) is the only systematically evaluated clinical activity to promote child development in primary care used in the United States. The ROR intervention is simple: clinicians provide counseling on the benefits of reading aloud, as well as deliver books directly to high-risk children and parents to take home at each pediatric visit for children 6 months to 5 years. ROR is based on a significant evidence base for the value of reading aloud to young children. Studies evaluating ROR from different sites of subjects from different racial backgrounds and numerous outcome measures are consistently positive. From its initial single site at Boston City Hospital in 1989, to more than 4,600 clinical sites in 2010, more than 30,000 physicians distributed more than 6.2 million books a year to 3.9 million children across the United States. Future efforts for ROR include integrating mental health competencies found in the American Academy of Pediatrics guidelines as part of residency and clinical training in the ROR paradigm, quality improvement to ensure fidelity to intervention and expanded participation of pediatric physicians in local early childhood and school readiness. community efforts. Finally, the most important future goal is the adoption of advice on reading aloud and delivery of developmentally appropriate books to high-risk families as best practices by official bodies.

title: Borderline personality disorder in adolescence
abstract: Borderline personality disorder (BPD) is a common and serious mental disorder that is associated with severe functional impairment and a high rate of suicide. BPD is generally associated with other psychiatric and personality disorders, a high burden on families and caregivers, ongoing resource utilization, and high treatment costs. BPD has been a controversial diagnosis in adolescents, but it is no longer warranted. Recent evidence demonstrates that BPD is as reliable and valid among adolescents as it is in adults, and that adolescents with BPD may benefit from early intervention. Consequently, adolescent BPD is now recognized in psychiatric classification systems and national treatment guidelines. This review aims to inform professionals in the field of adolescent health about the nature of BPD in adolescence and the benefits of early detection and intervention. The diagnosis and treatment of BPD should be considered part of routine practice in adolescent mental health to improve the well-being and long-term prognosis of these individuals.

title: Brave new EMR
Breaking new ground: challenging existing asthma guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although we have international and several national guidelines for the diagnosis and management of asthma, asthma remains poorly controlled in many children and adults. In this article, we review the limitations of current asthma guidelines and describe important issues and outstanding questions regarding the use of asthma guidelines, particularly in primary care. DISCUSSION: Clinical practice guidelines based on evidence from randomized controlled trials are considered the most rigorous and precise. However, current evidence-based guidelines are predominantly written from the perspective of the patient with a clear diagnosis of asthma and tend not to consider the heterogeneity of asthma or accommodate individual patient variations in response to treatment or needs, differences in practice settings; or local differences in the availability and cost of therapies. The results of randomized controlled trials, which are designed to establish the efficacy of treatment under ideal conditions, may not apply to "real world" clinical practice, where patients are not selected, follow-up is less frequent, and effectiveness, the benefit of the treatment in routine clinical practice--is the most relevant result. Furthermore, most guidelines view asthma in isolation rather than consider other factors that may affect asthma and response to asthma treatment, particularly age, allergic rhinitis, smoking, adherence, and genetic factors. . When these links are recognized, guidelines rarely provide practical recommendations for treatment in these settings. Finally, there is some evidence that GPs are not convinced about the applicability of asthma guidelines in their practice settings, especially when guideline writers work primarily in specialist practice. CONCLUSION: The development of country-specific guidelines or, ideally, local guidelines could provide more practical solutions for asthma care and could take into account regional factors that influence patient choice and adherence to therapy. Pragmatic clinical trials and well-designed observational trials, in addition to randomized controlled trials, are needed to assess the real-world effectiveness of therapies, and guideline writers should also consider such evidence. Ultimately, practical tools are needed to facilitate the diagnosis and assessment of asthma and factors responsible for poor control, such as associated allergic rhinitis, poor adherence, and smoking, to complement treatment information provided in clinical practice guidelines. for asthma.

title: Breast Cancer Screening Knowledge, Attitudes, and Behaviors Among African American Women: The Black Female Cosmetologists' Health Promotion Program
abstract: BACKGROUND: African-American women have higher rates of breast cancer mortality than their white counterparts. Studies have suggested that this is due in part to the discovery of cancer at a later stage, highlighting the importance of encouraging early detection of breast cancer in this population. To guide the development of a breast cancer education intervention and help focus the health promotion efforts of other health educators and clinicians, this study explored whether a cohort of African American women living in San Diego would demonstrate possession adequate basic knowledge about breast cancer screening. and adherence to widely recommended screening guidelines. METHODS: African-American women (N = 1055) from San Diego, California, participated in a beauty salon survey of breast cancer screening knowledge, attitudes, and practices. The women's ages ranged from 20 to 94 years, with a mean age of 42.20 (SD = 13.53) years. Thirty-four percent reported completing college and/or some graduate training, and 52% reported having some formal college or post-secondary training. Seventy-five percent of the sample reported working outside of their home. Participating cosmetologists and their salons were recruited for the study through word of mouth recommendations from highly respected African-American community leaders. RESULTS: Salon clients reported low rates of compliance with recommended guidelines for breast cancer screening. Of the 1,055 participants, 31% reported performing a breast self-exam every month. Of participants age 40 and older, 57% reported having had a clinical breast exam and 43% reported having had a mammogram in the past year. Knowledge of breast cancer was associated with adherence to screening guidelines. While women recognized the serious health threat posed by breast cancer and that early detection of breast cancer is important, only 30% of women reported feeling well informed about the disease. Many participants demonstrated a lack of basic knowledge about breast cancer. The health belief model posits that access to such information is an essential element in the progression toward engaging in screening behaviors. CONCLUSION: The data from this study reflect a continuing need for increased breast cancer education for African-American women. In light of the considerable general information available related to breast cancer, these data reinforce the need for more breast cancer education programs that are clearly intended to attract the attention of African-American women.

title: Bridging the Gap Between Pragmatic Intervention Design and Theory: Using Behavioral Science Tools to Modify an Existing Quality Improvement Program to Implement "Sepsis Six"
abstract: BACKGROUND: Sepsis has a mortality rate of 40%, which can be halved by implementing the evidence-based "Sepsis Six" care package within 1 hour. The UK audit shows low implementation rates. Interventions to improve this have had minimal effects. Quality improvement programs could be further developed by using theoretical frameworks (Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF)) to modify existing interventions by identifying influences on clinical behavior and selecting appropriate content. The objective of this study was to illustrate the use of this process to modify an intervention designed with plan-do-study-act (PDSA) cycles that had achieved partial success in improving the implementation of Sepsis Six in a hospital. METHODS: Factors influencing implementation were investigated using the TDF to analyze interviews with 34 health professionals. The nursing team that developed and facilitated the intervention used the data to select modifications using the Behavior Change Technique (BCT) Taxonomy (v1) and the APEASE criteria: affordability, feasibility, effectiveness, acceptability, safety, and equity. RESULTS: Five themes were identified that influence the implementation and modification of the guided intervention. These were: (1) "knowing what to do and why" (knowledge, social/professional role and identity TDF domains)";" (2) "risks and benefits" (beliefs about consequences), for example, fear of harming patients through fluid overload acting as a barrier to implementation versus belief in the efficacy of the package that acts as a lever for implementation";" (3) "working together" (social influences, social/professional role and identity), for example, team collaboration that acts as a lever against the doctor/nurse conflict that acts as a barrier";" (4) "empowerment and support" (beliefs about abilities, role and social/professional identity, behavior regulation, social influences), for example, involving staff in the development of the intervention acting as a lever against the lack of trust to challenge colleagues' decisions not to implement acting as a barrier";" (5) "staffing levels" (environmental context and resources), eg shortage of doctors at night impedes implementation. The modified intervention included six new BCTs and consisted of two additional components (Sepsis Six training for the night hospital coordinator"; a partnership agreement that supports the participation of all clinical staff and enables collegial challenge) and modifications to two existing components. (staff education sessions;" documents and materials). CONCLUSIONS: This work demonstrates the feasibility of the TDF and BCT taxonomy (v1) to develop an existing quality improvement intervention. The tools are compatible with the pragmatic approach of the PDSA cycle generally used in quality improvement work.

title: Bridging the science-service gap in schizophrenia care in the Netherlands: the Schizophrenia Quality Improvement Collaborative
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Many patients with schizophrenia are not treated according to evidence-based guidelines. This study examines the large-scale implementation of the National Multidisciplinary Guideline for Schizophrenia in the Netherlands. DESIGN: /st> Observational, prospective, repeated measurement study. SETTING: Thirty mental health teams in different regions of the Netherlands. PARTICIPANTS: Three hundred and fifty-nine physicians with different professional backgrounds and 1489 patients with schizophrenia. INTERVENTION(S): Six evidence-based interventions for schizophrenia were implemented in the context of a quality improvement collaboration: assertive community treatment (ACT) or its adapted version functional assertive community treatment (FACT), cognitive behavioral therapy, psychoeducation, family interventions, support for individual placement and pharmacotherapy. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Professional performance, social functioning, and relapse rates. RESULTS: Improvement of professional performance, in line with the guidelines. The availability of (F)ACT improved from 23% to 60%. Individual placement support improved from 20% to 53%. Comprehensive care plans were developed for 38% of patients, and routine outcome monitoring was introduced to most teams. Social functioning improved slightly (mean HoNOS: 6.2 to 5.6). Relapse rates did not improve during the course of the study. CONCLUSIONS: An intensive implementation program may result in better evidence-based care delivery, greater continuity of care, and slightly better outcomes for people with schizophrenia. More rigorous research designs need to confirm these findings.

title: Brief physician-initiated smoking cessation strategies for clinical oncology settings: a trial coordinated by the Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group
abstract: PURPOSE: Although tobacco use by cancer patients increases the risk of relapse, decreases the effectiveness of treatment, and worsens quality of life, about one-third of patients who smoked before their diagnosis continue to smoke. Because patients have regular contact with oncologists, the efficacy of a physician-based smoking cessation treatment was evaluated. METHODS: Cancer patients (n = 432) were randomly assigned to usual care or a National Institutes of Health (NIH) physician-based smoking intervention. The primary outcome was 7-day point prevalence abstinence at 6 and 12 months after study entry. RESULTS: At 6-month follow-up, there were no significant differences in dropout rates between the usual care (11.9%) and intervention (14.4%) groups, and there were no significant differences between the care groups. usual (13.6%) and intervention groups (13.3%) at the 12-month follow-up. Patients were more likely to have quit smoking at 6 months if they had head and neck or lung cancer, started smoking after age 16 years, reported at baseline using a self-help quit guide or treatment in the last 6 months, and showed a greater basic desire to quit smoking. Patients were more likely to have quit smoking at 12 months if they smoked 15 or fewer cigarettes per day, had head and neck or lung cancer, tried a group quit program, and had a greater initial desire to quit to smoke. Finally, there was greater adherence among clinicians to the NIH model for medical treatment of smoking cessation for patients in the intervention group versus the usual care group. CONCLUSION: Although training physicians to provide smoking cessation treatment to cancer patients may improve physician adherence to clinical practice guidelines, medical smoking cessation interventions do not achieve significant gains in smoking cessation rates. long-term smoking cessation among cancer patients.

title: British Psychopharmacological Association Consensus Guideline on the use of psychotropic medications before conception, during pregnancy and postpartum 2017
abstract: Decisions about the use of psychotropic medications during pregnancy are an ongoing challenge for clinicians and women with mental health problems, due to uncertainties about the risks of the illness itself to the mother and fetus/infant, the effectiveness of medications during pregnancy and risks to the fetus/infant from exposure in the womb or through breast milk. These consensus guidelines are intended to provide pragmatic advice regarding these issues. They are divided into sections on risks of untreated diseases during pregnancy"; general principles of drug use in the perinatal period; benefits and harms associated with individual drugs"; and recommendations for the management of specific disorders.

title: Capacity building for antiretroviral administration in South Africa: a qualitative evaluation of the PALSA PLUS nurse education programme.
abstract: BACKGROUND: South Africa recently launched a national antiretroviral treatment programme. This has created an urgent need for training of nurses in the administration of antiretroviral treatment (ART). The PALSA PLUS program provides guidance and training for primary health care (PHC) nurses in the management of adult lung disease and HIV/AIDS, including ART. A process evaluation was conducted to document the training, explore perceptions of the value of the training, and compare the PALSA PLUS training approach (used at intervention sites) with the provincial training model. The evaluation was conducted in conjunction with a randomized controlled trial measuring the effects of PALSA PLUS nurse education (Trial Reference Number ISRCTN24820584). METHODS: Qualitative methods were used, including participant observation of training sessions, focus group discussions, and interviews. Data were analyzed thematically. RESULTS: Nurse participation in PALSA PLUS training, regarding not only the specific components of ART but also lung health, was high. On-site ongoing training for all APS nurses, as opposed to the one-time centralized training provided to ART nurses only at non-intervention clinics, enhanced the support nurses' experience of their work by enabling, not only continuous experiential learning, supervision and emotional support, but also for continuous managerial review of all those changes at the system and infrastructure level necessary to facilitate the change of behavior of the health provider and the implementation of the guidelines. Training of all primary care nurses in the use of the PALSA PLUS guideline, as opposed to ART nurses only, was also perceived to better facilitate the integration of AIDS care within the clinical context. CONCLUSION: The PALSA PLUS training successfully engaged all PHC nurses in a comprehensive approach to a variety of illnesses affecting both HIV positive and negative patients. Training primary health care nurses for integrated systems-based interventions should be high on the ART funding agenda. However, behavior change training for individual providers is only one aspect of ongoing system-wide interventions needed to achieve lasting improvements in patient care in the context of an overburdened and underresourced PHC system. .

title: Clinical Networking: A Developmental Assessment Framework
abstract: Background Clinical networks have been designed as an interinstitutional mechanism for planning and delivering health services. With recent concerns about the effectiveness of these structures, it is timely to consider an evidence-based approach to how they can be developed and evaluated. Objective To document an evaluation framework for clinical networks based on the network evaluation literature and a 5-year study of clinical networks. Method We searched the literature in three domains: network evaluation, factors that help or inhibit network development, and robust methods for measuring network characteristics. This material was used to build a framework required for effective developmental assessment. Results The architecture of the framework identifies three stages of clinical network development";" partner selection, network design and network management. Within each stage there is evidence on the factors that act as facilitators and barriers to network growth. These factors can be used to measure progress through appropriate methods and tools. The framework can enable network growth and support informed decisions about progress. Conclusions For the first time in one place, a framework that incorporates rigorous methods and tools can identify factors that affect the development of clinical networks. The target user group is internal stakeholders who need to conduct a development assessment to inform key decisions along their network development journey.

title: Construction of state infrastructure for the academic support of students with mild traumatic brain injury
abstract: GOALS: Focus attention on building state capacity to support students with mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI)/concussion. METHOD: Consensus-building process with a multidisciplinary group of clinicians, researchers, policymakers, and staff from the state Department of Education. RESULTS: The white paper presents the group's consensus on the essential components of a state educational infrastructure to support the management of students with mTBI. The nature and recovery process of mTBI is briefly described specifically with respect to its effects on learning and school performance. State and local policy considerations are then emphasized to promote the implementation of a consistent process. Five key components to building a statewide infrastructure for students with mTBI are outlined, including (1) definition and training of the school interdisciplinary team, (2) professional development of the school and medical communities, (3) protocols for identification, assessment, and monitoring of progress, (4) a flexible set of intervention strategies to adapt to the recovery needs of students and (5) systematized protocols for active communication between members of the medical, school and family team. The need for research to guide effective program implementation is emphasized. CONCLUSION: This guidance framework strives to assist in the development of support structures for recovering students with mTBI to optimize academic outcomes. Until more evidence is available on academic accommodations and other school supports, education systems should follow current best practice guidelines.

title: Building Trust: The History and Ongoing Relationships Between DSD Clinicians, Researchers, and Patient Advocacy Groups
abstract: People born with differences or disorders of sexual development (DSD) have been marginalized by society and the health system. Standards of care in the mid-20th century were based on "fixing the child with a DSD, using hormonal and surgical interventions"; these treatments and diagnoses were almost never revealed to the child, and sometimes were not revealed to the child's parents. This led to secrecy, shame and stigma.When these children became adults and demanded access to their medical records, the realization of the depth of the secrecy led to the formation of activism groups that shook the medical community. From poor beginnings, advocates, health professionals, and researchers were able to bring about changes in the standard of care.The 2006 Consensus Statement on the Management of Intersex Disorders called for a multidisciplinary approach to care and questioned the evidence of many of the standard procedures The standard of care moved from a hide-and-seek model to a patient-centered paradigm, and agencies Funding Plans allocate resources to determine future directions for DSD research. the need to address patient priorities led to changes in international standards to include patients in research design. Some challenges that remain include: the Institute of Medicine's findings that sexual and gender minorities experience poor health outcomes; establish trust between all parties"; develop a common language and create places where people can engage in dialogue that addresses personal experiences, research design, clinical practices and intervention strategies.

title: Cesarean birth. Summary of an NIH consensus statement
Can a court order participation in an investigation?
Can a rural community-based work-related activities program make a difference for injured workers disabled by chronic pain?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the effectiveness of a guideline-informed multidisciplinary program of work-related activities in improving the physical, psychological, and occupational functioning of injured workers with chronic pain disability. DESIGN: An uncontrolled pilot study of repeated measures was conducted. SETTING: The intervention was delivered in a community setting in the New South Wales region. PARTICIPANTS: Participants (n = 30), mean age 41 years, had a compensable musculoskeletal injury: 60% were men, 63% had back injuries; the average time off work was 13 months. INTERVENTION: An interdisciplinary cognitive-behavioral study, the intervention was delivered using a multi-partner provider model (a clinical psychologist and a physical therapist from separate offices, working in conjunction with the participant's occupational rehabilitation provider and treating physician). Groups of six participants attended half a day per week for six weeks. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Outcome measures included: physical functioning, pain intensity, and psychological variables, which were assessed before and after the program; and medical certification and job participation, which were recorded before the program and at six-month follow-up. RESULTS: Significant gains were made in pain intensity, physical and psychological functioning, and medical certification.Mean effect size of the intervention was medium to large (d = 0.70).There were no significant changes in employment status at six-month follow-up CONCLUSIONS: The results of this pilot study suggest that rural or community-based independent professionals working collaboratively using an integrated treatment program can produce positive outcomes for workers injured by pain and achieve outcomes similar to those reported for pain based on metropolitan areas.c lines

title: Can computer-generated evidence-based care suggestions improve evidence-based management of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease? A randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Goal. Translation of evidence-based guidelines into clinical practice has been inconsistent. We conducted a randomized, controlled trial of guideline-based care suggestions delivered to physicians by typing orders on computer workstations. study environment. Downtown academic general internal medicine practice. Study design. Randomized controlled trial of 246 physicians (25 percent faculty general internists, 75 percent internal medicine residents) and 20 outpatient pharmacists. We enrolled 706 of their primary care patients with asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Medication care and monitoring tips were delivered to a random half of physicians and pharmacists when writing orders or filling prescriptions using computer workstations. A 2 × 2 factorial randomization of practice sessions and pharmacists resulted in four groups of patients: physician intervention, pharmacist intervention, both interventions, and controls. Data extraction/collection methods. Adherence to the guidelines and clinical activity was evaluated using the electronic medical record of the patients. Health-related quality of life, medication adherence, and satisfaction with care were assessed using telephone questionnaires. Main findings. During their year in the study, patients made an average of five scheduled primary care visits. There were no differences between groups in adherence to care suggestions, generic or condition-specific quality of life, satisfaction with physicians or pharmacists, medication adherence, emergency department visits, or hospitalizations. Physicians who received the intervention had significantly higher total health care costs. Physicians' attitudes toward the guidelines were mixed. Conclusions. Care suggestions displayed to physicians and pharmacists on computer workstations had no effect on the delivery or outcomes of care for patients with reactive airway disease.

title: Can handheld computers improve guideline compliance? A Pilot Study (Palm) of Family Physicians in British Columbia
abstract: OBJECTIVE To examine whether Palm Prevention, a free software tool for Palm OS personal digital assistants (PDAs) that provides quick access to preventive guidelines in a patient-specific manner at the point of care, improved adherence to five preventive measures in care primary. DESIGN Prospective intervention pilot study. SETTING Vancouver, BC and surrounding areas. PARTICIPANTS Eight general practitioners. INTERVENTIONS Each physician used Palm Prevention for five preventive measures during routine preventive health visits with 10 patients (n = 80). Charts of consenting patients were reviewed for documentation of recommended maneuvers. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Compliance rates for five evidence-based guidelines selected from the Canadian and US Task Forces on Preventive Care and incorporated into Palm Prevention. RESULTS Intervention and control physicians were similar in their familiarity with and use of PDAs, and recruited similar patients for the study. The intervention and control groups had similar rates of hypertension detection. The intervention improved adherence to the remaining four guidelines: cervical cancer screening increased by 22% (only absolute increases are reported)"; hyperlipidemia screening increased by 30%; colorectal cancer screening increased by 27% ; and aspirin prophylaxis in high-risk patients increased by 38% Participants were surveyed after the study;" all reported that they found the software useful and would continue to use Palm Prevention. Usage statistics showed that study participants used the tool outside of the trial: users entered between 28 and 68 unique patients into the program during the 2-month intervention. CONCLUSION This pilot study suggests that PDAs are useful for improving preventive care and facilitating the translation of knowledge into practice. This was particularly evident with the most recent guidelines.

title: Can line doctors master the conceptual complexities of dialectical behavior therapy? An evaluation of a State Department of Mental Health training program
abstract: Dialectical behavior therapy for borderline personality disorder has rapidly achieved widespread popularity, one indication being the development of training initiatives by the Department of Mental Health in at least two US states. Efficacy data published by the creator of the treatment, Marsha Linehan, and her colleagues probably explain, at least in part, this popularity. However, the complexity of DBT raises a fundamental question regarding these broader applications: can clinicians from diverse backgrounds acquire a shared and sophisticated understanding of treatment theory? The clinical utility of a treatment is largely based on ease of dissemination (APA, Template for Developing Guidelines: Interventions for Mental Disorders and Psychosocial Aspects of Physical Disorders. Washington, DC: Author, 1995), and in that sense, DBT : a complicated, multifaceted approach--might seem vulnerable. This vulnerability is accentuated when institutional adoption involves the collaboration of numerous clinicians, who, despite occupying diverse roles, must develop a shared understanding of the treatment. Using a detailed examination of DBT knowledge, we assessed the conceptual mastery of 109 clinicians trained through a State Department of Mental Health initiative. Test performance was specifically correlated with DBT training. Previous education or experience in behavioral therapy accounted for little variation, indicating that clinicians in a variety of roles acquired reasonable intellectual mastery of this complex model.

title: 'Can patient practice be increased simply by implementing agreed national guidelines?' An observational study
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To increase the time of autonomous practice of patients in the stroke unit of a nursing home. INTERVENTION: Nurses stimulated and trained patients with the help of four interventions (strengthening muscles, balance and reach when sitting, rising from a chair, walking) from the Evidence-Based Clinical Nursing Rehabilitation Stroke Guidelines . DESIGN: Observational study. The practice time of elderly stroke patients in this study was compared with the time observed in our previous study in the same setting. SETTING: Nursing home rehabilitation units in the Netherlands. SUBJECTS: Seventeen frail stroke patients, including 8 men, 9 women, with a mean age of 75.8 (SD +/- 9), and 17 subjects with the same characteristics who participated in a previous observational study. MAIN MEASURES: Time spent on therapeutic activities was measured using the Behavior Mapping method. RESULTS: Time spent in therapeutic activities increased significantly from 103.5 minutes measured in our previous study to 156.5 minutes in this study (Z = 2.86"; P < 0.005; "d' = 1.09). Mean Barthel index was 8.8 (SD +/- 4.1). Patients with more possibilities were more active, resulting in a significantly positive Barthel Index-therapy time relationship (r = 0.73, P </= 0.001). CONCLUSIONS: The autonomous practice time of elderly frail comorbid stroke patients increased during weekdays. The patients, stimulated and challenged by the nurses, exercise more and more according to their possibilities. Since this guideline was developed especially for nurses, nurses can encourage stroke patients to contribute more to autonomous practice and thus help their recovery.

title: Can psychological models bridge the gap between clinical guidelines and physician behavior? A randomized controlled trial of an intervention to influence dentists' intention to implement evidence-based practice.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The lag between publication of evidence for clinical practice and implementation by clinicians can be decades. Research using psychological models shows that changing intention is very important in changing behavior. This study examined an intervention (trial of alternative actions) to change dentists' intention to implement evidence-based practice (EBP) for third molar (MT) management. DESIGN: Randomized/postal controlled trial. SETTING: Primary care. SUBJECTS AND METHODS: Dentists were randomly selected from the Scottish Board of Dental Practice Register, then randomly assigned to intervention or control groups, and sent a questionnaire. The intervention group listed management alternatives to TM removal prior to their intention to remove TM, and the control group did not. Based on psychological models to reduce the frequency of a behavior (EBP is weighted against TM extraction), the previous list of alternatives should decrease the extraction intention. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Intention to extract MT. RESULTS: A total of 99 dentists - 70 men, 29 women"; mean age = 41.42 years (SD = 8.62) participated in the study. The intervention significantly influenced the intention to extract TM, as desired. Despite similar backgrounds and knowledge of management alternatives, participants in the intervention group had significantly lower withdrawal intention: control group mean (SD) = 0.39 (1.99); intervention group mean ( SD) = -0.78 (1.89); mean difference (SE) = 1.17 (0.42);" 95% confidence interval for the difference = 0.34 to 1.99. CONCLUSION: The results suggest that this intervention, which successfully influenced a proximal predictor of behavior relevant to dental EBP, may result in EBP improvement in a service level trial. Basing implementation interventions and trial methodology on psychological models can effectively bridge the gap between clinical guidelines and practice.

title: Can we address depression in vision rehabilitation settings? Professional Perspectives on Barriers to Integrating Problem-Solving Treatment
abstract: PURPOSE: Low vision rehabilitation (LVR) is a relevant context to integrate evidence-based early psychological interventions given the high prevalence of untreated depression in visually impaired adults. This study aims to identify perceived barriers and facilitators to staff-provided telephone-based problem-solving treatment for primary care (PST-PC) offered as an integrated component of LVR. METHODS: Semi-structured qualitative interviews, developed using the theoretical domain framework (TDF) and the Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research (CFIR), were conducted with 21 LVR professionals and a clinical psychologist involved in PST-PC delivery. Barriers and facilitators at practitioner, client, intervention and organization levels were identified with a thematic analysis using a 'theoretical' approach. RESULTS: Prominent barriers were lack of recognition of the role of PST-PC professionals (n = 32), unmet client expectation with PST-PC (n = 28), dissatisfaction with telephone delivery (n = 27) and the limited organizational awareness of PST. -PC (n = 39). Facilitating factors included a recognized need for evidence-based psychological services (n = 28), clients experiencing benefits in early sessions (n = 38), PST-PC promoting practical skills (n = 26), and comprehensive PST training -PC (n = 36). CONCLUSIONS: PST-PC can provide accessible early intervention for LVR clients with depressive symptoms. Ongoing professional training, clinical support, and assessment of potential LVR clients to determine appropriateness of treatment are likely to improve delivery in this setting. Implications for rehabilitation Depression is very common in adults participating in low vision rehabilitation (LVR) programmes, yet few receive support. Clinical guidelines recommend that integrated models of care be offered within rehabilitation settings as early intervention for mild to moderate levels of depressive symptoms. Integrated Telephone Problem-Solving Treatment for Primary Care (PST-PC) delivered by trained LVR professionals is a hands-on, skills-based model that has the potential to increase access to early psychological intervention for LVR clients with depressive symptoms . LVR clients are often older, have multiple comorbid health conditions, and a significant level of functional disability, requiring flexibility in the delivery of PST-PC and specialized staff training, and support in working with older and more complex clients. .

title: Can we improve adherence to guidelines for the treatment of lower urinary tract infection? A simple and multifaceted intervention in out-of-hours services
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To improve the antimicrobial prescribing behavior of general practitioners in large-scale out-of-hours services for uncomplicated lower urinary tract infection (UTI) in women aged 20 to 80 years, which is considered one of the most common bacterial infections. prevalent in primary care. watch out. METHODS: A quasi-experimental design was used in two large-scale regional after-hours services. A single, multifaceted intervention was offered over a 16-week period in one region (the intervention region). During the two washout periods, at 5 and 17 months, we observed diagnoses and prescriptions. The main outcome measure was the proportion of appropriate and inappropriate prescriptions. RESULTS: The proportion of patients with UIUI ranged from 1.0% to 2.1%. The relative proportion of appropriate prescriptions in the intervention region increased from 26.9% to 69.4%, but then decreased to 40.8%. CONCLUSIONS: A simple, multifaceted intervention for the treatment of LUTIs during after-hours care may improve the quality of antimicrobial prescribing, although the improvement may not be sustained in the long term.

title: Canadian Consensus on Contraception (Part 1 of 4)
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To provide guidelines for health care providers on the use of contraceptive methods to prevent pregnancy and on the promotion of healthy sexuality. RESULTS: Guidance for Canadian professionals on the overall efficacy, mechanism of action, indications, contraindications, non-contraceptive benefits, side effects and risks, and initiation of the cited contraceptive methods"; family planning in the context of sexual health and general well-being, contraceptive counseling methods, and access and availability of contraceptive methods cited in Canada EVIDENCE: Published literature was retrieved through searches of Medline and the Cochrane database from January 1994 to January 2015 using appropriate controlled vocabulary (eg, contraception, sexuality, health) and keywords (eg, contraception, family planning, hormonal contraception, emergency contraception).Results were limited to systematic reviews, controlled trials randomized/controlled clinical trials and observational studies published in English since e January 1994 through January 2015. Searches were periodically updated and incorporated into the guideline as of June 2015. G rey (unpublished) was identified through searches of health technology assessment websites and related agencies. health technology, clinical practice guideline collections, clinical trial registries, and national and international medical specialty societies. VALUES: The quality of the evidence in this paper was graded using the criteria described in the Report of the Canadian Task Force on Preventive Health Care (Table). Chapter 1: Contraception in Canada Summary Statements 1. Canadian women spend a significant portion of their lives at risk of unintended pregnancy. (II-2) 2. Effective contraceptive methods are underutilized in Canada, particularly among vulnerable populations. (II-2) 3. Long-acting reversible contraceptive methods, including contraceptive implants and intrauterine contraception (copper- and levonorgestrel-releasing devices/systems), are the most effective reversible contraceptive methods and have the highest continuation rates. (II-1) 4. Canada does not currently collect reliable data to determine contraceptive use, abortion rates, and the prevalence of unintended pregnancy among women of reproductive age. (II-2) 5. A universal contraceptive subsidy provided by many of Canada's peer nations and some Canadian provinces can produce savings in health system costs. (II-2) 6. Health Canada's contraceptive approval processes have been less efficient than those of other drug approval agencies and Health Canada's processes for other classes of pharmaceuticals. (II-2) 7. It is feasible and safe for contraceptive and family planning services to be provided by appropriately trained allied health professionals, such as midwives, registered nurses, nurse practitioners, and pharmacists. (II-2) Recommendations 1. Contraceptive counseling should include a discussion of typical failure rates and the importance of using the contraceptive method consistently and correctly to prevent pregnancy. (II-2A) 2. Women seeking contraception should be counseled about the wide range of effective contraceptive methods available, including long-acting reversible contraception (LARC). LARCs are the most effective reversible contraceptive methods, have high continuation rates, and should be considered when introducing contraceptive options to any woman of reproductive age. (II-2A) 3. Family planning counseling should include counseling about the decline in fertility associated with increasing age of the woman. (III-A) 4. Canadian health decision-makers should consider health policy that supports a universal contraceptive subsidy and strategies to promote the adoption of highly effective methods as cost-saving measures that improve health and equity in health. (III-B) 5. Canadian health jurisdictions should consider expanding the scope of practice of other trained professionals, such as nurses, nurse practitioners, midwives, and pharmacists, and promote family planning task sharing. (II-2B) 6. The Canadian Community Health Survey should include appropriate reproductive health indicators for health care providers and policymakers to make appropriate decisions regarding reproductive health policies and services in Canada . (III-B) 7. Health Canada's processes and policies should be reviewed to ensure that a wide range of modern contraceptive methods are available to Canadian women. (III-B) Chapter 2: Contraceptive Access and Care Summary Statements 8. Although there are many contraceptive options in Canada, only a limited range of contraceptive methods are commonly used by people of reproductive age. (II-3) 9. Condom use decreases with longer intercourse and when the sexual partner is considered to be the main partner, probably due to a lower perceived risk of sexually transmitted infections in that relationship. Condom use may also decrease markedly as an unintended consequence when an effective nonbarrier method, such as hormonal contraception or intrauterine contraception, is initiated. (II-3) 10. Family planning counseling provides a natural transition to screening for concerns about sexual function or intimate partner violence. (III) 11. Well-informed and motivated people who have developed the skills to practice safer sex are more likely to use contraception and safer sex effectively and consistently. (II-2) Recommendations 8. Comprehensive family planning services, including abortion services, should be accessible to all Canadians, regardless of geographic location. These services must be confidential, free from prejudice, and respectful of people's privacy and cultural contexts. (III-A) 9. A contraceptive visit should include taking a history, screening for contraindications, dispensing or prescribing a contraceptive method, and exploring contraceptive choice and adherence in the broader behavioral context individual's sexual orientation, reproductive health risk, social circumstances, and relevant belief systems. (III-B) 10. Health care providers should provide practical information about the wide range of contraceptive options and their potential non-contraceptive benefits and help women and their partners determine which method is best for the user. (III-B) 11. Health care providers should help women and men develop the skills necessary to negotiate contraceptive use and correct and consistent use of a chosen method. (III-B) 12. Contraceptive care should include discussion and management of sexually transmitted infection risk, including appropriate recommendations for condom use and dual protection, STI screening, post-exposure prophylaxis, and vaccination against hepatitis B and human papillomavirus. (III-B) 13. Health care providers should emphasize the use of condoms not only for protection against sexually transmitted infections, but also as a backup method when adherence to hormonal contraception may be suboptimal. (IA) 14. Health care providers should be aware of current media controversies in reproductive health and acquire relevant evidence-based information that can be communicated briefly and directly to their patients. (III-B) 15. Referral resources for intimate partner violence, sexually transmitted infections, sexual dysfunction, induced abortion services, and child protective services should be available to assist clinicians in providing contraceptive care in the most appropriate setting. comprehensive women's health. (III-B) Chapter 3: Emergency Contraception Summary of Statements 12. The copper-bearing intrauterine device is the most effective method of emergency contraception. (II-2) 13. A copper-bearing intrauterine device can be used for emergency contraception up to 7 days after unprotected intercourse, provided pregnancy has been ruled out and there are no other contraindications to its placement. (II-2) 14. Levonorgestrel emergency contraception is effective up to 5 days (120 hours) after intercourse; its effectiveness decreases as the time between unprotected intercourse and ingestion increases. (II-2) 15. Ulipristal acetate for emergency contraception is more effective than levonorgestrel emergency contraception up to 5 days after unprotected intercourse. This difference in efficacy is more pronounced as time since unprotected intercourse increases, especially after 72 hours. (I) 16. Hormonal emergency contraception (emergency contraception with levonorgestrel and ulipristal acetate for emergency contraception) is not effective if taken on the day of ovulation or after ovulation (II-2) 17. Hormonal contraception Levonorgestrel emergency contraception may be less effective in women with a body mass index > 25 kg/m2 and ulipristal acetate for emergency contraception may be less effective in women with a body mass index > 35 kg/m2 However, hormonal emergency contraception may still retain some effectiveness regardless of a woman's body weight or body mass index. (II-2) 18. Hormonal emergency contraception is associated with higher failure rates when women continue to have unprotected sex. (II-2) 19. Hormonal contraception can be started the day of or the day after use of levonorgestrel emergency contraception, with backup contraception used for the first 7 days. (III) 20. Hormonal contraception can be started 5 days after use of ulipristal acetate for emergency contraception, with backup contraception for the first 14 days. (III) Recommendations 16. All emergency contraception should be started as soon as possible after unprotected intercourse. (II-2A) 17. Women should be informed that the copper-bearing intrauterine device (IUD) is the most effective method of emergency contraception and can be used by any woman without contraindications to IUD use. (II-3A) 18.

title: Canadian Guidelines for the Evidence-Based Treatment of Tic Disorders: Behavioral Therapy, Deep Brain Stimulation, and Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation
abstract: This clinical guideline provides recommendations for nonpharmacologic treatments for tic disorders. We conducted a systematic literature search for clinical trials on the treatment of tics. An evidence-based review (including 30 studies) and 3 studies on behavioral interventions, 3 studies on deep brain stimulation (DBS), and 3 studies on transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) met the inclusion criteria. On the basis of this evidence, we have made strong recommendations for the use of behavior reversal therapy and exposure and response prevention, preferably integrated within a supportive psychoeducational programme, and with the option of combining any of these. pharmacotherapy approaches. Although there is evidence for the efficacy of DBS, the quality of this evidence is poor and the risks and burdens of the procedure are finely balanced against the perceived benefits. Our recommendation is that this intervention continue to be considered an experimental treatment for severe tics refractory to medical treatment that have severely limited quality of life. We recommend that the procedure only be performed in the context of research studies and by physicians experienced in DBS programming and tic management. There is no evidence to support the use of TMS in the treatment of tics. However, the procedure is associated with a low rate of known complications and could continue to be evaluated within research protocols. The recommendations we provide are based on current knowledge, and additional studies may result in their revision in the future.

title: Canadian survey of clinical status at the start of dialysis 1998-1999: a prospective multicentre survey
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The current growth in end-stage renal disease populations has led to increased efforts to understand the impact of status at the start of dialysis on long-term outcomes. Our primary objective was to improve understanding of current Canadian nephrology practice between October 1998 and December 1999. METHODS: Fifteen nephrology centers in 7 provinces participated in a prospective data collection survey. The main outcome of interest was clinical status at the start of dialysis determined by: residual renal function, readiness for chronic dialysis measured by the presence or absence of peritoneal access or permanent hemodialysis, hemoglobin and serum albumin. Uremic symptoms at the start of dialysis were also recorded; however, in some cases, these symptom data were obtained retrospectively. RESULTS: Data from 251 patients were collected during periods of 1 month. Patients began dialysis with calculated mean creatinine clearance levels of approximately 10 mL/min, with an average of 3 symptoms. 35% of patients starting dialysis had been known to nephrologists for less than 3 months. These patients are more likely to start without permanent access and with lower hemoglobin and albumin levels. Even of those known to nephrologists, only 66% had permanent access. CONCLUSIONS: Patients starting dialysis in Canada appear to do so in relative concordance with published guidelines regarding timing of start. Despite increased awareness of kidney disease, a considerable number of patients continue to start dialysis without the prior care of a nephrologist. Of those that are seen by nephrologists, clinical and laboratory parameters are suboptimal according to current guidelines. This survey serves as an important baseline for future comparisons after the implementation of educational strategies for referring physicians and nephrologists.

title: Adolescent path of cancer in France between 1988 and 1997
abstract: We report an adolescent cancer pathway from referral, through diagnosis and treatment, to follow-up in France. All cancer cases between 15 and 19 years of age, diagnosed between 1988 and 1997, registered by nine French population-based cancer registries (10% of the French population) were included. Management of adolescent cancer by pediatricians was rare. An adolescent's journey through cancer care can be summarized as the first visit to the general practitioner, referral to the adult oncologist for hematologic malignancies and medical or surgical specialists for solid tumors, treatment in the adult unit, and follow-up by an adult medical or surgical oncologist. specialist or general practitioner. Only 9% of 15-19 year olds enter a clinical trial (respectively 6% and 3% in adult and pediatric clinical trials). The inclusion rate changes by diagnosis, highest for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (39%), non-Hodgkin's lymphomas (NHL) (27%), and acute non-lymphoblastic leukemia (20%). Only 4% of adolescent cancers were managed in shared adult-pediatric departments, especially for soft tissue sarcomas (14.9%), malignant bone tumors (13.4%), central nervous system tumors (6, 2%) and NHL (4.4%). Whatever the reasons for non-participation in clinical trials, an ideal model that requires communication and cooperation among all pediatric and adult specialists involved in adolescent cancer care should reduce the large gap in access to cooperative groups. .

title: Cancer education among primary care physicians in an underserved community
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Urban minority groups, such as those living in northern Manhattan, are generally underserved with regard to cancer screening and prevention practices. Primary care physicians are in a critical position to counsel their patients on these issues and to order screening tests for their patients. METHODS: Eighty-four primary care physicians in two intervention communities who received cancer screening and prevention education visits were compared with 38 physicians in a nearby community who received no intervention. Using pre- and post-test interviews over an 18-month period, physicians were asked about their attitudes, knowledge (relative to American Cancer Society guidelines), and likelihood of breast cancer screening and counseling , cervical, colorectal and prostate. cancers RESULTS: Comparison of the two physician surveys indicated no statistically significant differences in knowledge of cancer prevention or detection. However, on post-test, intervention group physicians identified significantly fewer barriers to practice than control physicians (p<0.05). Although, in general, educational visits to inner-city primary care physicians did not appear to significantly alter cancer prevention practices, there was a positive dose-response relationship between the subgroup of participants who received three or more contacts of the draft. CONCLUSIONS: We found significant changes in attitude due to academic details among urban primary care physicians practicing in northern Manhattan. A significant pre-test sensitization effect and small numbers may have masked overall changes in cancer prevention and screening behaviors among clinicians due to the intervention.

title: Fatigue related to cancer and treatment
abstract: Fatigue is a distressing and persistent symptom for gynecologic cancer patients and survivors. Cancer-related debilitating fatigue (CRF) is caused by both the disease and its treatment. Although awareness and study of CRF have increased in recent years, constant evaluation has not been a priority in routine medical practice. The pathophysiological mechanisms that induce CRF remain unclear and effective pharmacological interventions have not yet been established. Based on the literature and the results of our own research, this review focuses on recent progress toward understanding the nature and causes of CRF and on several promising treatment modalities. Given the prevalence and severity of CKD in the gynecologic cancer patient population, it is of paramount importance to establish standardized methods of fatigue measurement and management in routine clinical oncology care. However, it remains hypothetical whether CRF has an underlying inflammatory cause, and no mechanism-driven symptom intervention is currently used clinically, although the development of such interventions would provide patients with greater symptom control. Advancing translational and clinical fatigue research will require well-designed anatomical pathway studies and clinical investigations that focus on the development of mechanism-driven interventions based on physiological-behavioral fatigue research, the implementation of guidelines for experimental designs, and the discovery of biomarkers that identify individuals at high levels. CRI risk. Validated patient-reported outcome measures are an essential component of such clinical trials. Because there are numerous subscales, unidimensional measures, and multidimensional measures, clinicians and researchers should consider individual circumstances, good clinical practice, and research objectives as guides in choosing the most appropriate fatigue measurement tool. In addition, education about CRF should be made available to all patients and their caregivers, as accurate, age-appropriate information about conditions like CRF can alleviate much of the stress and anxiety that comes from miscommunication about this distressing condition. condition.

title: Interactions of cardiac drugs and psychoactive drugs: meaning and recommendations
abstract: Understanding cardiac drug interactions with concurrent psychotropic prescriptions is essential for the practicing cardiologist and primary care physician, as well as the psychiatrist. There has been an explosive use of new drugs in both psychiatry and cardiology without widespread knowledge of their possible interactions. The increasing trend toward polypharmacy, the use of psychotropic medications by cardiologists and primary care physicians caring for cardiac patients, and the growth of the aging population present great challenges to the physician. Finally, there is a need to have models/paradigms to predict possible drug interactions, for example, the cytochrome p450 scheme. This article describes a method for identifying, understanding, and coding cardiac and psychotropic drug interactions, a systematic approach to updating this key database, and specific cardiac and psychotropic drug interactions. Specifically, this document 1) details the interactions, 2) addresses the level of their clinical importance, 3) describes the potential mechanisms of the interactions, and 4) provides recommendations to the clinician. Since most of the original clinical trials, whether for cardiac or psychotropic drugs, do not include studies comparing these two drug domains at the same time, their interactions are often known only with their combined use in the clinical setting, using at patient as "guinea pig". , and through subsequent reports.

title: Cardiac rehabilitation and risk factor management after myocardial infarction. Clinical and economic evaluation
abstract: The increasing scarcity of available and finite healthcare resources and the increasing demand for healthcare have made consideration of the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of healthcare services, such as secondary prevention of heart disease, imperative. There is considerable evidence that modifying smoking, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and physical inactivity, either alone or in combination, are effective in reducing the number of clinical events in the secondary prevention of heart disease. Economic evaluation is the comparative analysis of alternative courses of action in terms of costs and consequences. The data generated in the economic evaluations of health services, such as the modification of risk factors in the secondary prevention of heart disease, are useful for developing clinical practice guidelines and health policies. Smoking cessation is the most cost-effective intervention for people with documented heart disease, whereas treatment of hyperlipidemia and referral to cardiac rehabilitation are highly cost-effective per quality-adjusted life year and relatively cost-effective per life year saved. Risk factor management, provided by a team that includes cardiovascular specialists and other physicians along with appropriately trained allied health professionals, is the cornerstone of optimal care in the primary and secondary prevention of heart disease.

title: Cardiac Rehabilitation: Unraveling the Complexity of Bypass and Current Delivery Models
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence-based guidelines recommend risk factor reduction strategies for secondary prevention of acute coronary syndromes, but referral and completion programs to provide this advice are poor. PURPOSE: In this article, we describe the complexity of factors influencing the referral and delivery of evidence-based cardiac rehabilitation (CR) programs across an Australian context and provide guidance for clinicians and policymakers to consider solutions. The Ecological Approach is used as a framework to synthesize the evidence. The approach has 5 categories, whose characteristics can act as barriers and facilitators for the promotion and adoption of healthy behaviors and includes (a) interpersonal factors, (b) interpersonal factors, (c) institutional factors, (d) community networks, and e) Public politics. CONCLUSIONS: Despite the context of strong evidence of efficacy, this review highlights systematic failures in the implementation of CR, an important intervention that has been shown to improve patient outcomes and prevent cardiac events. Recommendations from this review include standardizing program delivery, improving data capture, using technological innovations and social media to facilitate the delivery of information and support, and establishing a cohesive and consistent message across of the interorganizational collaboration involved in CR. CLINICAL IMPLICATIONS: These pathways provide guidance for potential solutions to improve CR acceptance and secondary prevention.

title: Care in specialized medical and mental health units compared with standard care for older people with cognitive impairment admitted to a general hospital: a randomized controlled trial (NIHR TEAM trial)
abstract: OBJECTIVE To develop and evaluate a best practice model of general hospital acute medical care for older people with cognitive impairment. DESIGN Randomized controlled trial, adapted to take into account the limitations imposed by a busy acute medical admission system. SETTING Large acute care general hospital in the UK. PARTICIPANTS 600 patients older than 65 years admitted for acute care, identified as 'confused' on admission. INTERVENTIONS Participants were randomized to a specialized medical and mental health unit designed to provide the best care for people with delirium or dementia, or to standard care (general medical or acute geriatric wards). Features of the specialist unit included "co-staffing of medical and mental health professionals"; enhanced staff training in delirium, dementia, and person-centered dementia care; provision of purposeful organized activity; environmental modification for meeting the needs of people with cognitive impairment, delirium prevention, and a proactive and inclusive approach for family caregivers MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES PRIMARY OUTCOME number of days spent at home during the 90 days after randomization SECONDARY OUTCOMES non-participant observations structured to to determine patients' experiences of family carers' satisfaction with hospital care.When possible, outcome assessment was blinded to allocation.RESULTSThere were no significant differences in days spent at home between the specialized unit and care groups. standard function (median 51 vs 45 days, 95% confidence interval for difference -12 to 24; P = 0.3 Median hospital stay rate was 11 vs. 11 days, mortality 22% vs. 25% (-9% to 4%), readmission 32% vs. 35% (-10% to 5%) and new nursing home admission 20% versus 28% (-16% to 0) for the specialist unit and standard care groups, respectively. Patients who returned home spent a median of 70.5 versus 71.0 days at home (-6.0 to 6.5). Specialist unit patients spent significantly more time in positive mood or engagement (79% vs. 68%, 2% to 20%; P = .03) and experienced more interactions with staff that satisfied emotional needs and psychological (median of 4 vs. 1 per observation; p<0.001). More family caregivers were satisfied with care (overall, 91% vs. 83%, 2% to 15%; P=0.004), and severe dissatisfaction was reduced (5% vs. 10%, -10% to 0%; P=0.05) CONCLUSIONS Specialized care for people with delirium and dementia improved patient experience and caregiver satisfaction, but there were no convincing benefits in health status or service use. caregiver satisfaction might be more appropriate measures of success for frail elderly people nearing the end of life TRIAL REGISTRATION Clinical Trials NCT01136148.

title: Caring for Adults with Developmental Disabilities: Effects of a Continuing Education Course for Primary Care Providers
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the effects of a guideline-based interdisciplinary continuing education course on measures related to the care of adults with developmental disabilities (DD). DESIGN: Before-and-after study with a control group. SETTING: Ontario. PARTICIPANTS: Forty-seven primary care providers (physicians, registered nurses, and nurse practitioners).
