INTERVENTION: Participants received only reference material on primary care of people with DD (control group) or participated in a continuing education course on primary care of people with DD in addition to receiving the reference material (intervention group). MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Participants reported 5 key measures related to the care of adults with DD: frequency of use of guidelines, frequency of periodic health examinations, frequency of evaluation of patients presenting behavior changes, level of comfort when caring for adults with DD, and knowledge of primary care related to adults with DD. RESULTS: Over time, the intervention group showed significant increases in 4 of 5 key measures of care compared with the control group: frequency of guideline use (P < 0.001), frequency of assessment of change in patient behavior (P = 0.001). 03), level of comfort in caring for people with DD (p = 0.01), and knowledge of primary care related to adults with DD (p = 0.01). CONCLUSION: A continuing education course in primary care for adults with DD is a useful interdisciplinary model to train health professionals who provide primary care services to these patients.

title: Caring for the menopausal patient: the view of a nurse practitioner
abstract: PURPOSE: To assess the benefits and risks of hormone therapy (HT) and other treatment options for early postmenopausal women. DATA SOURCES: Published clinical trials, selected peer-reviewed literature, and recent clinical practice guidelines. CONCLUSIONS: The results of the Women's Health Initiative (WHI) studies of HT may not be directly applicable to healthy early postmenopausal women with hot flashes. HT is the most effective treatment for menopausal symptoms. The benefits of HT for relieving menopausal symptoms are likely to outweigh the risks in this population. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: The results of the WHI reinforce the importance of individualized care based on a woman's medical history, medical needs, and desired outcomes. Nurses can help their patients put recent results into perspective. When HT is used, nurse practitioners should consider using lower doses and reassess the need for therapy annually.

title: CD4 cell count and viral load monitoring in patients receiving antiretroviral therapy in Uganda: a cost-effectiveness study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To examine the cost and cost-effectiveness of quarterly monitoring of CD4 cell counts and viral load among patients taking antiretroviral therapy (ART). DESIGN Cost-effectiveness study. SETTING A randomized trial in a home-based ART program in Tororo, Uganda. PARTICIPANTS People with HIV who were members of the AIDS Support Organization and had CD4 cell counts <250 × 10(6) cells/L or World Health Organization stage 3 or 4 disease. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Results calculated for the study period and projected 15 years into the future included costs, disability-adjusted life years (DALYs), and incremental cost-effectiveness ratios (ICERs"; $ per DALY averted). Cost inputs were based on trial and other sources Clinical inputs derived from trial; in the base case, we assumed point estimates reflected true but not significant differences We performed univariate and multivariate sensitivity analyzes INTERVENTIONS Three follow-up strategies : clinical follow-up with quarterly CD4 cell counts and viral load measurement (clinical/CD4/viral load); clinical monitoring and quarterly CD4 count (clinical/CD4);" and clinical follow-up alone. RESULTS Using intention-to-treat (ITT) outcomes per 100 people starting ART, we found that CD4/clinical monitoring compared to clinical monitoring alone increases costs by $20,458 (£12,780, €14,707) and avoids 117.3 DALYs (ICER = $174 per DALY). Clinical monitoring/CD4/viral load compared to clinical monitoring/CD4 adds $142,458 and avoids 27.5 DALYs ($5181 per DALY). The superior ICER for clinical/CD4 monitoring is robust to uncertainties in input values, and that strategy is dominant (less expensive and more effective) compared to clinical/CD4/viral load monitoring in a quarter of simulations . If clinical inputs are based on analysis of treatment starting at 90 days (after laboratory monitoring began), then clinical/CD4/viral load monitoring is dominated by other strategies. CONCLUSIONS Based on this trial, compared to clinical monitoring alone, routine CD4 cell count monitoring is considerably more cost-effective than adding routine viral load testing to the monitoring strategy and is more cost-effective than ART.

title: Adolescent Cervical Cancer Screening: An Evidence-Based Internet Education Program to Improve Practice Among Advanced Practice Nurses
abstract: BACKGROUND: The literature reports wide variation in levels of awareness and application of recent changes in cervical cancer screening guidelines in clinical practice. Evidence-based screening guidelines for cervical cancer prevention and early detection offer health care providers an opportunity to improve practice patterns among adolescents by decreasing psychological distress and reducing health care costs and burdens. morbidities associated with overscreening. PURPOSE: The purpose of this pilot intervention study was to determine the effects of a web-based continuing education unit (CEU) program on advanced practice nurses' (APN) knowledge of current evidence-based recommendations for screening for cervical cancer and its application in practice. This paper presents a process improvement project as an example of a way to disseminate up-to-date, evidence-based practice guidelines to busy health care providers. METHODS: This web-based CEU program was developed, tested, and evaluated specifically for APN. The program addressed her level of knowledge about cervical cancer and its relationship to high-risk human papillomavirus. He also discussed new cervical cancer screening guidelines and the application of those guidelines in clinical practice. FINDINGS: The results of the study indicated that there are gaps in knowledge among NPCs about cervical cancer screening in adolescents. However, when provided with a CEU educational intervention, APNs' knowledge levels increased and their self-reported clinical practice behaviors changed in accordance with new cervical cancer screening guidelines. LINKING EVIDENCE TO PRACTICE: Providing convenient and easily accessible up-to-date e-content provided by CEUs improves adoption of clinical practice guidelines, which decreases the potential for morbidities associated with overscreening for cervical cancer in adolescents and young women.

title: Challenges and opportunities associated with the introduction of next-generation long-lasting insecticidal nets for malaria control: a case study from Burkina Faso
abstract: Background Reductions in malaria incidence in Africa can be largely attributed to increases in malaria vector control activities, predominantly the use of long-lasting insecticidal bed nets (LLINs). . With insecticide resistance affecting an increasing number of malaria-endemic countries and threatening the efficacy of conventional LLINs, there is a growing urgency to implement alternative tools to control these resistant populations. study was to identify potential challenges and opportunities for accelerating access to next-generation LLINs in Burkina Faso, a country with areas of high levels of insecticide resistance Methods An analytical framework was used to guide the selection of interviewees, the collection and the data analysis Semi-structured key informant interviews were conducted in April 2014 in Burkina Faso. Interviews were conducted in French and English, audio recorded, transcribed, and entered into NVivo 10 for data management and analysis. They were coded according to the framework themes and then analyzed to provide a description of key points and to explain patterns in the data. Results Interviewees reported that the policy architecture in Burkina Faso is characterized by a strong framework of actors contributing to policymaking and a strong national research capacity that indirectly contributes to national policy change through collaboration with targeted research. internationally. The funding has a significant impact on the potential adoption, availability, and affordability of next-generation LLINs. This confers significant power on international donors who fund vector control. National decisions about which LLIN to purchase were restricted to quantity and delivery dates; the potential to address insecticide resistance was not part of the decision-making process. Additionally, at the time of the study, there was no World Health Organization (WHO) guidance on where and when next-generation MILDs could have a positive impact on malaria transmission, severely limiting their adoption, availability, and availability. affordability. Conclusions This study shows that access to next-generation MILDs was seriously compromised by a lack of global guidance. Burkina Faso, where WHO recommendations are adopted relatively quickly, a clear WHO recommendation and adequate funding will be key to accelerating access to next-generation LILDCs.

title: Changeability, Trust, Common Sense, and Corroboration: Comprehensive Suicide Risk Assessment
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The authors, in collaboration with NSW Health, recently developed a comprehensive suicide risk assessment framework. This article describes key concepts in the assessment of suicide risk by mental health professionals. METHODS: A framework for conducting a comprehensive suicide risk assessment was derived from the literature, incident analysis, and clinical experience. The framework underwent a consultation process involving clinicians from NSW area mental health services. The goal was to provide clinicians with a standardized concept map for suicide risk assessment. A MEDLINE search was performed for publications related to 'suicide' and 'suicide risk assessment' between 1980 and 2002. Recommendations from sentinel event reviews conducted in a NSW area mental health service were reviewed in the period 1999-2002. Lessons from a visit to a coroner's family support group for people who had experienced suicide also informed the development of the guidelines. RESULTS: A framework for suicide risk assessment is proposed. The framework promotes a reflective style of practice, encouraging clinicians to assess their assessment and its limitations. Risk assessment is always carried out as part of a full clinical evaluation and an assessment of the person's current situation and psychosociocultural context. The concepts of changeability, confidence in evaluation, common sense, and the importance of corroboration are incorporated into the framework. CONCLUSIONS: Mental health clinicians can be guided by a framework in assessing and documenting suicide risk. Suicide risk assessment may generate a suicide risk score for which minimum standards of care may be required.

title: Changes and challenges: managing ADHD in a fast-paced world
abstract: BACKGROUND: Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) affects the lives of children and adults. If left undiagnosed and untreated, ADHD can have serious lifelong consequences. Research has identified diagnostic clues, neurotransmitter pathways, and psychiatric comorbidities related to ADHD, as well as effective pharmacological, behavioral, and psychosocial interventions. Stimulant agents have been the mainstay of ADHD therapy for more than 50 years. The availability of new extended-release (XR or ER) and longer-acting (LA) formulations and new agents allows for broader and more individualized treatment options. Side effects of stimulants are generally mild, short-lived, and respond to adjustments in dosage or timing. Outcomes in ADHD treatment can be improved with the use of clear treatment guidelines and tools to help clinicians implement them efficiently and effectively. The Texas Children's Medication Algorithm Project (CMAP) provides an algorithm-based treatment decision system that is evidence-based and easy to implement. OBJECTIVE: (1) to review the psychological components of mindfulness, the neurotransmitter pathways associated with ADHD, and the variety of therapeutic options for ADHD, with an emphasis on the most recent introductions to the therapeutic armamentarium"; (2) to discuss the rare psychiatric problems and cardiovascular side effects associated with stimulants; (3) review abuse liability, comorbidities, and suggested approaches to these problems;" and (4) review the development and use of CMAP and provide resources for its implementation in clinical practice. CONCLUSION: The pathophysiology of ADHD is related to dysfunction of fronto-subcortical networks and dysregulation of dopaminergic, noradrenergic, and nicotinic neurotransmitter systems. An additive effect of multiple genes, as well as environmental influences, contributes to the clinical picture. Stimulant and non-stimulant treatment has been shown to be effective in different subgroups, with the effectiveness of specific agents most likely related to the primary neurotransmitter involved. The availability of transdermal stimulant formulations, XR, ER, and LA, as well as alternative non-stimulant agents, offers new options for pharmacotherapy of ADHD. Major concerns associated with the potential for stimulant abuse have been allayed by the availability of ER formulations, which have reduced the boosting effects associated with short-acting preparations. Medication outcomes in ADHD can be improved through the use of evidence-based algorithms such as CMAP. The keys to success are proper initial assessment and diagnosis, the use of sustained-release products, sufficient dose titration, and the use of clinical rating scales with feedback from caregivers and teachers. Optimal treatment outcomes can be achieved by appropriate pharmacotherapy combined with psychosocial interventions.

title: Changes in insurance physicians' attitudes, self-efficacy, intention, and knowledge and skills about depression guidelines following an implementation strategy
abstract: INTRODUCTION: To improve guideline compliance by insurance physicians (IPs), an implementation strategy was developed and investigated in a randomized controlled trial. This implementation strategy involved a multifaceted training program for a group of IPs in the application of the depression guidelines. In this study we report the impact of implementation strategy on clinicians' attitude, intention, self-efficacy, and knowledge and skills as behavioral determinants of guideline adherence. Links between these self-reported behavioral determinants and levels of guideline adherence were also determined. METHODS: Just before and 3 months after the implementation of the multifaceted training, a questionnaire designed to measure behavioral determinants based on the ASE model (attitude, social norm, self-efficacy) was completed by the intervention (n = 21) and the control group (n = 19). Questionnaire items were grouped to form ASE determinant scales. The internal consistency of the scales was calculated using Cronbach's alphas. Between-group differences in changes in ASE determinants and the association of these changes with improvements in adherence to guidelines were analyzed using analysis of covariance. RESULTS: The internal consistency of the ASE determinants scales was shown to be sufficiently reliable, with Cronbach's alphas of at least 0.70. At follow-up after 3 months, PIs receiving the implementation strategy showed significant improvement over PIs in the control group for all investigated ASE determinants. Changes in knowledge and skills were only weakly associated with improvements in adherence to guidelines. CONCLUSIONS: The implementation strategy developed for insurance physicians can increase their attitude, intention, self-efficacy, and knowledge and skills in applying the depression guidelines. These changes in behavioral determinants could indicate positive changes in IP behavior toward the use of depression guidelines. However, only changes in knowledge and skills related to guideline use were associated with improvements in IPs' actual performance when applying the guidelines.

title: Changes in lifestyle habits after advice from nurse practitioners: 1-year results from the Groningen Overweight and Lifestyle study.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The Groningen Overweight and Lifestyle (GOAL) study has as its primary objective the prevention of weight gain by nurse practitioners (NPs) guided by a standardized computerized software program. Since favorable changes in physical activity (PA) and diet can improve health independent of weight (loss), it is essential to understand the effects on lifestyle habits. We examined the 1-year effects of NP lifestyle advice on PA and diet, compared with usual general practitioner care (GP-UC). DESIGN: A randomized controlled trial. SETTING: Eleven general practice locations in the Netherlands. SUBJECTS: A total of 341 GOAL participants with overweight or obesity and hypertension or dyslipidemia, or both, who completed an FFQ and a short questionnaire to assess physical activity that improves health (SQUASH) at baseline and after 1 year. RESULTS: After 1 year, the NP group spent 33 min/week more walking compared to the GP-UC group who spent -5 min/week walking (P = 0.05). No significant differences were found between the NP and GP-UC groups in the percentage of people who met the PA guidelines. In both groups, nutrient intake changed in a favorable direction and participants more often met dietary guidelines, but with no overall difference between the NP and GP-UC groups. CONCLUSIONS: With the exception of an increase in walking (based on self-reported data) in the NP group, there were no intervention effects on physical activity and diet. Positive changes in nutrient intake were observed in both groups.

title: Changes in the knowledge and behaviors of nursing professionals after a brief training on the guidelines of healthy eating and joint activities (HEAT)
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Primary care providers, particularly pediatric nurses, are an integral force involved in addressing the obesity epidemic among youth. However, most nurse practitioners report a low level of competence in their ability to adequately prevent and treat pediatric overweight. In response, the National Association of Pediatric Nurse Practitioners (NAPNAP) developed the Evidence-Based Clinical Practice Guideline (CPG) on Healthy Eating and Joint Activity (HEAT) to Improve Behavior and the effectiveness of providers. METHOD: Thirty-five nurse practitioners who attended the NAPNAP Annual Conference participated in an intensive 4-hour HEAT CPG training session. Pre- and post-training data were collected on providers' knowledge, practical behaviors, and barriers in relation to preventing overweight among youth. RESULTS: Post-training results revealed significant improvements in (a) practitioners' knowledge (assessment of patient growth, family history, psychosocial functioning, nutrition, and physical activity)"; (b) practitioners' intention to improve behavioral (i.e., increased intention to use behavior modification and counseling aimed at patient and family behavior change);" and (c) practitioners' report of increased confidence in the ability to address barriers. DISCUSSION: The study findings demonstrate preliminary support for CPG HEAT as an effective tool to help providers improve their ability to maintain patients' healthy weight. Future research is needed to verify the effects of HEAT CPG on long-term improvements in care.

title: Changes in nursing home residents during an innovation based on gerotranscendence theory
abstract: AIMS AND OBJECTIVES: The aim of the present study was to investigate how residents were affected when an intervention based on gerotranscendence theory and guidelines derived from the theory was introduced in a nursing home. BACKGROUND: The notion that communication is essential to staff-resident interaction is widely accepted in both theory and practice, as is the notion that communicative behavior influences patient outcomes. No study to date has focused on whether residents are influenced by staff's use of guidelines derived from gerotranscendence theory. DESIGN: The study was exploratory in nature and used a qualitative approach. METHODS: Data were collected through interviews with residents and participant observations; a qualitative content analysis was performed. SAMPLE SIZE: six residents. RESULTS: The study shows that many residents reviewed and reflected on their lives, and that this aspect changed during the study period. Some residents' descriptions of their situation revealed that certain changes had occurred in the social life of the ward, these changes could be an effect of the intervention. know and provide the best nursing care and individualized treatment to each resident;" this implies a holistic vision that helps residents in their aging process. The use of guidelines derived from the theory of gerotranscendence could help nurses to promote positive aging and constitute a way of treating residents in a more individualized way.

title: Changing acute pain management to improve patient outcomes: an educational approach
abstract: The United States Agency for Health Care Policy and Research (AHCPR) Guidelines for the Management of Acute Pain were written to provide a scientific basis for practice. Educational programs designed to promote the use of the guidelines can change practice in community hospitals. This article describes the development and implementation of an education program for nurses, physicians, and pharmacists at six community hospitals. The content of the program is described, which addresses the use of continuous quality improvement (CQI) teams, detailed pain histories, application of algorithms and dose calculation";" direct and indirect outcome measures are reviewed. Six months after the program, all three experimental sites reported use of the AHCPR Guidelines in practice. Nurses reported that assessing and documenting the duration of patients' pain were perceived as the most important caregiver behaviors that provide benefits to patients: Across all respondents' reports of activities performed regularly, activity performed by the largest proportion was assessing and documenting pain using a 0-10 rating scale.

title: Change clinical behavior by making specific guidelines
abstract: The problems of getting people to act according to evidence-based guidelines are widely recognized.1 A summary of 41 systematic reviews found that the most promising approach was to use a variety of interventions including audit and feedback, reminders, and educational outreach. .1 Effective interventions often involved complicated procedures and were always an addition to the provision of guidelines. None of the studies used the simplest intervention, that is, changing the wording of the guidelines. We examine the importance of accurate behavioral recommendations and suggest how some current guidelines could be improved.

title: Changing Physician Behaviors: An Educational Program to Disseminate a New Clinical Pathway for Hospital Management of Hip Fractures in Elderly Patients in the Lazio Region, Italy
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES: Concerns with patient safety have increased interest in approaches to improve physician performance, but clinical guideline dissemination and conventional continuing medical education have often failed. This study investigated the effects of an educational program based on reflection on experience on the quality of care for patients with hip fracture in Lazio, Italy. METHODS: Five hospitals participated. The study consisted of the development of a clinical pathway, a preparatory phase and the educational intervention itself, which included a course followed by monthly audits with reflection on the practice, guided by the analysis of the patients' medical records. Data on the quality of care for hip fracture patients were collected from the routine information system for the period before and after the intervention. RESULTS: There was a significant increase in the proportion of patients who underwent surgery within 48 hours of admission (from 7% in 2006 to 26.4% in 2007) and a significant reduction in the mean length of hospital stay. (from 18.8 to 16.4 days). Some process indicators of quality of care were high after the intervention, although non-recommended practices are still used routinely (eg, urinary catheterization in 72.2% of patients). There were differences in changes when comparing hospitals. CONCLUSION: An educational intervention that combined the dissemination of a clinical pathway with an external audit oriented to reflection on practice was effective in promoting changes in the behaviors of physicians. The persistence of non-recommended practices and variation between hospitals indicate that multiple factors influence performance and affect the effectiveness of interventions.

title: Changing human behavior to prevent disease: the importance of focusing on automatic processes.
abstract: Much of the global burden of disease is associated with behaviors (overeating, smoking, excessive alcohol consumption, and physical inactivity) that people recognize as harmful to health and yet continue to engage in, even when unintended consequences arise. . To date, interventions aimed at changing such behaviors have largely encouraged people to reflect on their behaviors. These approaches are often ineffective, consistent with the observation that much human behavior is automatic, guided by environmental stimuli, resulting in actions that are largely unaccompanied by conscious thought. We propose that interventions targeting these automatic bases of behaviors may be more effective. We discuss specific interventions and suggest ways to determine if and how interventions that focus on automatic processes can improve global efforts to prevent disease.

title: Changing Minds: Bounded Rationality and Heuristic Processes in Exercise-Related Judgments and Choices.
abstract: Theories currently used to understand, predict, and promote physical activity and exercise represent information-processing models of the mind. A fundamental assumption underlying these theories is that human judgment and decision-making processes are rational. Therefore, interventions derived from these models aim to improve "data entry" (eg, providing complete, accurate, and convincing information about health benefits) with the expectation that rational evaluation of these data results in the desired behavioral "outcome." Given the modest effectiveness of interventions based on these models, we designed 2 experiments to test the validity of the rationality assumption, focusing specifically on exercise-related judgments and decisions. In Experiment 1, exercise judgments were altered by changing an arbitrary anchor, the presence of which should not have influenced these judgments. In Experiment 2, preference between a target and an alternative exercise session increased with the mere addition of a third "decoy" exercise option. Together, these experiments demonstrate that important motivational variables, including perceived exercise desirability, affective attitude, intention, affective forecasts, and exercise choices can be manipulated in a predictable direction without providing any relevant new information, but simply by pointing to specific and well-informed objectives. characterized heuristics. Therefore, these data provide evidence that the "limited" character of human rationality is also manifested in the exercise of judgments and decisions. Exercise researchers and practitioners should consider incorporating process heuristics within dual-process theoretical models of physical activity and exercise behavior. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2016 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: Changing physician behavior to improve disease prevention
abstract: Physicians often fail to provide their patients with nationally recommended preventive services. Addressing this, we have reviewed selected literature on how to change medical behavior using the organizational construction of the transtheoretical model of 'readiness for change'. This model suggests that behavior evolves through stages from precontemplation to contemplation, preparation, initiation, and maintenance of change. Traditional continuing medical education can affect knowledge and beliefs, but rarely results in behavioral change. However, motivational strategies such as practice feedback reports and influential peers can encourage stage change. Successful interventions targeting clinicians preparing for change often use a practice system approach that targets not only clinicians, but also practice staff and patients. Illustrating how the readiness-for-change model can guide the design and implementation of interventions, we describe strategies being used in a statewide randomized controlled trial to improve cancer prevention counseling and early detection by of primary care physicians. Partners for Prevention's multi-stage interventions include support from a medical liability insurer, a motivational videotape, a task-outlined office manual, graphic flowcharts, patient activation forms, practice, a designated prevention coordinator within each practice, and regular phone calls and visits from project staff.

title: Changing Physician Behavior: What Works?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: There are several interventions for guideline implementation in clinical practice, but the effects of these interventions are generally unclear. We conducted a systematic review to identify effective methods for implementing clinical research findings and clinical guidelines to change medical practice patterns, in surgical and general practice. STUDY DESIGN: Systematic review of reviews. METHODS: Electronic databases (MEDLINE, EMBASE, and PubMed) were searched for systematic reviews published in English that evaluated the effectiveness of different implementation methods. Two reviewers independently assessed eligibility for inclusion and methodological quality and extracted relevant data. RESULTS: Fourteen reviews covering a wide range of interventions were identified. Intervention methods used include: audit and feedback, computerized decision support systems, continuing medical education, financial incentives, local opinion leaders, marketing, passive dissemination of information, patient-mediated interventions, reminders, and multifaceted interventions. Active approaches, such as academic details, produced greater effects than traditional passive approaches. Based on the findings of 3 reviews, 71% of the studies included in these reviews showed a positive change in physician behavior when exposed to active educational methods and multifaceted interventions. CONCLUSIONS: Active forms of continuing medical education and multifaceted interventions were found to be the most effective methods for implementing the guidelines in general practice. In addition, active approaches to changing physician performance have been shown to improve practice to a greater extent than traditional passive methods. More primary research is needed to assess the effectiveness of these methods in a surgical setting.

title: Changing the behavior of medical practice to measure and improve clinical outcomes
abstract: Medical practice behavior often results in poor clinical outcomes in managing cardiovascular disease risk factors despite effective treatments and guidelines. The behavior of 165 physicians in 2 settings (suburban and urban) was studied. After collecting baseline clinical data, including systolic blood pressure and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, a series of interventions, including academic details, were carried out. Low-density lipoprotein cholesterol decreased by 10.4% in suburban patients with cardiovascular disease in the intervention group (P = 0.001) and by 10.5% in the enhanced intervention group (P = 0.001). Systolic blood pressure decreased by 1.11% (P = 0.357) in the intervention group and by 5.13% in the enhanced intervention group (P < 0.001). In urban hypertensives, systolic blood pressure decreased by 5.03% (p = 0.001) and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol decreased by 7.01% (p < 0.001). Combining urban and suburban data, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol decreased by 9.32% (p < 0.001) and systolic blood pressure decreased by 4.00% (p < 0.001). Providing clinicians with their clinical results, revising national guidelines, and setting expectations, associated with modest innovations in practice systems, can produce significant and measurable clinical improvements.

title: change social relationships
Chapter: A review of self-management support for musculoskeletal (work-related) pain disorders.
abstract: The form of the review of self-management interventions for chronic diseases and musculoskeletal disorders (MSDs) within this chapter is narrative. Individual qualitative and quantitative research studies, as well as systematic reviews and other reviews of relevance, were considered. We searched four major databases for relevant peer-reviewed literature published in the last 10 years. Publications prior to this period were included in the review if the work was considered seminal in terms of its contribution to the self-management knowledge base within the context of interest. The following terms were used as keywords and linked using Boolean operators: self-care, self-management, chronic illness, chronic illness, topical patient education, patient-centered care, health behavior, low back pain, and musculoskeletal disorders. Since the review focused on people of working age, the limits applied included English language and adults aged 15 to 64 years. Relevant gray literature and references from key authors in the field were also consulted. We did not formally assess the methodological quality of the included studies. Identified peer-reviewed studies were then screened for intervention components that are conceptually closely linked to self-management and the involvement of chronic conditions, especially MSD, and excluded otherwise. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2016 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: Chapter: Behavioral economics and commitment to treatment.
abstract: Behavioral economics is a field that integrates concepts from psychology and economics to explain individuals' decision-making. In recent years, this field has been increasingly incorporated into healthcare settings to promote healthier lifestyles. Participants typically receive monetary incentives when an objective or target behavior is objectively verified. In this chapter, we describe this evidence-based treatment, often referred to as contingency management. This chapter is structured in four parts. The "Background" section reviews the historical background of incentive-based interventions applied to substance abuse treatment. The "Application of Incentive-Based Interventions to Medication Goals" section describes the application of these interventions to other medication goals, such as immunizations, medical screening, diabetes control, physical activity, and weight loss programs. The section "Key Elements and Concepts Embedded in Incentive-Based Interventions" explains the key concepts and elements embedded in effective incentive-based interventions, and the final section discusses issues related to the implementation and spread of incentive programs. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2017 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: Chapter: Escape from cognitivism: Exercise as a hedonic experience.
abstract: Establishing its social relevance should be a strategic goal for exercise psychology. Progress toward this goal, however, has been slower than anyone in the field would have liked. In this chapter, we argue that, in part, the lack of intervention methods that can reliably and significantly increase physical activity level may be due to too narrow a metatheoretical perspective. We illustrate that all the main theories in vogue within exercise psychology in the last decades are derivatives of the same (cognitivist) metatheoretical framework. As such, they all exhibit a crucial limitation, namely the relative disregard for the motivational properties of affective constructs, such as central affect, moods, and emotions. Research over the past 15 years has shown that the old adage that "exercise makes people feel better" is wrong. Therefore, the central goal of this chapter was to underscore the urgent need for the field of exercise psychology to transition into the postcognitive era. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2017 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: Characteristics of patients with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes in Swiss primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although a variety of treatment regimens are available for patients with type 2 diabetes, most patients do not achieve recommended goals. Our aim was to characterize Swiss primary care patients with type 2 diabetes who do not meet HbA1c treatment targets and reveal factors associated with poorly controlled HbA1c level. METHODS: Cross-sectional study nested within the Chronic Care for Diabetes randomized controlled trial. Patients with type 2 diabetes with at least one HbA1c measurement >/= 7.0% during the past year were recruited from Swiss primary care. Data evaluation included general and diabetes-specific clinical measures, treatment factors, and patient-reported outcomes. RESULTS: 326 patients with type 2 diabetes from 30 primary care clinics with a mean age of 67.1 +/- 10.6 years participated in the study. Patient results for HbA1c were 7.7 +/- 1.3%, for systolic blood pressure 139.1 +/- 17.6 mmHg, for diastolic blood pressure 80.9 +/- 10.5 mmHg, and for low-density lipoproteins 2.7 +/- 1.1. 93.3% of the patients suffered from at least one comorbidity and were treated with 4.8 +/- 2.1 different drugs. No determining factor was significantly related to HbA1c in multiple analysis, but a significant pooling effect of GPs on HbA1c could be found. CONCLUSIONS: Within our sample of patients with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes, no "hot spots" can be pinpointed that can be easily addressed by any type of intervention. Especially within this subgroup of patients with diabetes who would benefit most from appropriate interventions to improve diabetes control, there appears to be a complex interplay between diabetes control, comorbidities, GP treatment, and behavior. of patients' health. Until now, this interaction has only been poorly described and understood.

title: Characteristics of successfully implemented telemedical applications
abstract: Background There has been an increased interest in the use of telemedicine applications in clinical practice in recent years. Considerable effort has been invested in testing and experimental services. However, surprisingly few applications have continued beyond the research and development phase. The objective of this study is to explore the characteristics of successfully implemented telemedical applications. Methods A comprehensive search of the telemedicine literature was performed to identify relevant articles. Following a defined selection process, a small number of articles describing features of successfully implemented telemedical applications were identified. These articles were analyzed qualitatively, based on the core procedures of the Grounded Theory (GT), including condensation and categorization. The analysis resulted in a description of the characteristics that were considered important for a successful implementation of telemedicine. Subsequently, these characteristics were discussed in the light of Science and Technology Studies (STS) and the concept of 'social negotiation'. Results Telemedicine applications introduced into routine practice are typically characterized by the following six features: 1) local service delivery issues have been clearly established, 2) telemedicine has been seen as a benefit, 3) telemedicine has been seen as a solution to political and medical problems. 4) there was collaboration between promoters and users, 5) organizational issues and technological arrangements have been addressed, and 6) the future operation of the service has been considered. Conclusion Our findings support research that argues that technologies are not fixed entities that pass from invention to diffusion and routine use. Rather, it is the interaction between technical and social factors that produces a particular result. The success of a technology depends on how this interaction is managed during the implementation process.

title: Child survival in the Third World: a functional analysis of oral rehydration therapy dissemination campaigns
abstract: PIP: Behavior analysts conducted a functional analysis of different intervention strategies employed in 14 oral rehydration therapy (ORT) campaigns in 10 developing countries. Intervention investigators manipulated antecedents, behaviors, and/or consequences to improve diarrhea management. The strategies used radio ads, posters, and brochures to promote behavior change. Only 2 campaigns (Thailand and Egypt) limited their intervention to this background. Only 3 programs manipulated antecedents, behaviors and consequences. The 1983 campaign in Bangladesh incorporated school instruction for siblings and home visits as part of the training and provided incentives to trainers ($30) as a result. The 1985 project in The Gambia used health workers to teach mothers at home about ORT and awarded lottery prizes for happy babies (rice, sugar and soap). The skills training component of the 1984 campaign in Honduras involved 1-on-1 instruction. A radio course on breastfeeding, sibling school instruction, and an illustrated health care manual. Its consequences were games and prizes in calls to radio programs, free calendars, key chains, t-shirts and a trip to Tegucigalpa. The only program limited to a skills training component was the campaign in South India in 1976. The training involved training nurses to instruct mothers on diarrhea management. A stumbling block in all campaigns was that ORT does not appear to improve diarrhea and vomiting immediately. Those campaigns that had a skills training component were more effective than those that did not. Behavior analysts could contribute to ORT campaigns by developing simple and effective training programs and developing inexpensive and effective mechanisms to assess the effectiveness of such campaigns.

title: Childhood autism and related conditions
Childhood Obesity Screening and Treatment Practices of Pediatric Health Care Providers
abstract: This study evaluated clinicians' childhood obesity screening and treatment practices. A 26-question survey was delivered to pediatric providers in person or by mail, email, or fax throughout Louisiana. Fifty-seven providers completed the survey, the majority in primary care clinics. Five providers met at least four of the seven clinical guidelines, but no provider met all guidelines. While 88% of providers screened for obesity, 7% met guidelines for referring obese patients to weight management services. Six providers offered interventions that included all recommended components (ie, diet, physical activity, and behavioral counseling). One intervention met intensity guidelines (ie, >25 hours delivered over at least six months). Barriers to offering services included lack of reimbursement and poor compliance by families. Solutions to overcome treatment barriers must be identified to increase the provision of health care services for children with obesity.

title: Childhood tonsillectomy: who is referred and what treatment options are taken? Baseline findings from the Northern England and Scotland Study of Tonsillectomy and Adenotonsillectomy in Children (NESSTAC)
abstract: BACKGROUND: Tonsillectomies are performed frequently, but there are variations in tonsillectomy rates. Clinicians use guidelines, but the complex psychosocial influences on childhood tonsillectomy include anecdotal evidence of parental enthusiasm. Studies indicate that undergoing the preferred treatment improves outcome. Despite the enthusiasm with which tonsillectomy is offered and requested, there is little evidence of its effectiveness. This resulted in a randomized controlled trial to assess the cost-effectiveness of (adeno)tonsillectomy in children with recurrent sore throats. OBJECTIVE: To compare the characteristics of children entering the randomized trial with those enrolled in a parallel, nonrandomized study to establish trends in patient referral and treatment preferences. DESIGN: Baseline data from a randomized controlled trial with a preferably nonrandomized parallel study comparing surgical intervention with medical treatment in children aged 4 to 15 years with recurrent sore throats referred to five secondary care otolaryngology departments located in the north of England or in the central west. Scotland. RESULTS: The centers evaluated 1546 children";" 21% were not eligible for tonsillectomy. Among older children (8-15 years), girls were significantly more likely to be referred to secondary care. Of 1,015 eligible children, 268 (28.2%) agreed to be randomized, while 461 (45.4%) agreed to the nonrandomized, parallel preference study, with a strong preference for tonsillectomy. Participants who reported that progress in school had been hampered or with more experience of persistent sore throat were more likely to seek tonsillectomy. Referred boys were more likely than girls to opt for medical treatment. Socioeconomic data showed no effect. CONCLUSION: Preference for tonsillectomy reflects educational impact and recent experience, rather than age or socioeconomic status.

title: Children in taxis: an opportunity for pediatricians and emergency physicians to save lives?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Child safety devices (infant seats, booster seats, and seat belts) are effective in reducing the risk of injury";" however, there is still a pattern of non-use or misuse of car seats by parents. The objective of this study was to assess the level of awareness and compliance with safety seat guidelines in cars and private taxis by parents with children presenting for emergency care. METHODS: Two hundred and forty-two caregivers of children (age range, 2 weeks to 19 years) presenting for care at the pediatric emergency department of an urban teaching hospital were contacted to complete an interviewer-administered questionnaire, and 225 participated. The questionnaire included knowledge, attitude, and behavior questions about protective equipment for children of various ages. RESULTS: Eleven (47.8%) of 23 children 1 year of age and younger were reported to use infant seats frequently or always while traveling in private cars, compared to 8 (22.2%) of 36 children 1 year of age or less than were reported to use them while traveling in private cars. taxis (P < 0.05). Seventeen (85%) of 20 children over 8 years of age were reported to have used seat belts frequently or always in private cars versus 10 (41.7%) of 24 in taxis (P < 0.01). One hundred fifty-four (99.3%) of 155 subjects were aware of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration recommended position for their child's car seat. Most parents believed in the effectiveness of child safety seats in preventing vehicle injuries and reported that they would be more likely to use safety devices if they received information about their use in the emergency department. CONCLUSIONS: The data from this survey show that the use of car seats is lower in taxis than in private cars and that this is attributable to the inconvenience of taking these seats to and from the taxi rather than to financial considerations or lack of knowledge about its effectiveness. Strategies should be sought to increase the availability of child safety devices in taxis. The emergency department, as well as the pediatrician's office or clinic, can be a place for an educational intervention for parents and caregivers about the safety of children as passengers.

title: Children with head injuries
Cognitive performance and selective attention of children after recent community violence
abstract: Research has shown strong relationships between community violence and psychopathology, but relatively little is known about the ways in which community violence can affect cognitive performance and attention. The present study estimates the effects of police-reported community violence on the performance of 359 urban children on a computerized neuropsychological task using a fixed-effects quasi-experimental design. Living in close proximity to a recent violent crime predicted faster but marginally less accurate task performance for the full sample, evolutionarily adaptive patterns of "vigilant" attention (i.e., less attention toward positive stimuli, more attention toward negative stimuli) for children who reported low trait anxiety and potentially maladaptive patterns of "avoidant" attention for highly anxious children. These results suggest that community violence may directly affect children's cognitive performance and, at the same time, have different (and potentially orthogonal) impacts on care delivery depending on children's levels of biobehavioral risk. Implications for mental health and sociological research are discussed.

title: Chiropractic care for pediatric and adolescent attention deficit hyperactivity disorder: a systematic review.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Psychostimulants are the first line of treatment for pediatric and adolescent AD/HD. Evidence suggests that up to 30% of prescription stimulant medications fail to show clinically significant results. Also, many children and teens experience side effects from these medications. As a result, parents seek alternative interventions for their children. Complementary and alternative medicine therapies for behavioral disorders such as AD/HD are on the rise and as many as 68% of parents have sought help from alternative practitioners, including chiropractors. OBJECTIVE: The review seeks to answer the question of whether chiropractic care can reduce symptoms of inattention, impulsivity, and hyperactivity for pediatric and adolescent AD/HD. METHODS: Electronic databases (Cochrane CENTRAL Register of Controlled Trials, Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, MEDLINE, PsycINFO, CINAHL, Scopus, ISI Web of Science, Index to Chiropractic Literature) were searched from inception to July 2009 looking for studies in English for chiropractic care. and AD/HD. Inclusion and exclusion criteria were applied to the selected studies. All randomized controlled trials were assessed using the Jadad score and a checklist developed from the CONSORT (Consolidated Standards of Trial Reporting) guidelines. RESULTS: The search returned 58 citations of which 22 were intervention studies. Of these, only three studies were identified for pediatric and adolescent cohorts with AD/HD. The methodological quality was poor and none of the studies qualified according to the inclusion criteria. CONCLUSIONS: To date there is insufficient evidence to assess the efficacy of chiropractic care for pediatric and adolescent AD/HD. The claim that chiropractic care improves pediatric and adolescent AD/HD is supported by only low levels of scientific evidence. In the interest of pediatric and adolescent health, if chiropractic care for AD/HD is to continue, more rigorous scientific research must be conducted to examine the efficacy and effectiveness of chiropractic treatment. RCTs of adequate size using clinically relevant outcomes and standardized measures are needed to examine the effectiveness of chiropractic care versus no treatment/placebo control or standard care (pharmacological and psychosocial care) to determine whether chiropractic care is an effective alternative intervention. for pediatric and adolescent patients. AD/HD

title: Choosing Wisely in Headache Medicine: The American Headache Society's List of Five Things Physicians and Patients Should Question
abstract: In an effort to bring attention to tests and procedures associated with low-value care in headache medicine, the American Headache Society (AHS) has joined the American Board of Internal Medicine Foundation's Choosing Wisely initiative. . The AHS President appointed an ad hoc AHS Choosing Wisely Task Force. The committee surveyed AHS members to develop a list of candidate items for the AHS "Top 5" list of low-value headache medication care. Through a process of literature review and consensus, the final list of five items was chosen. The preliminary recommendations went through several rounds of review and an external review process. The AHS Board of Directors approved the final "Five Things" list. The five recommendations approved by the AHS Board of Directors are: (1) do not perform neuroimaging studies in patients with stable headaches who meet criteria for migraine"; (2) do not perform CT scans for headache when MRI is available except in emergency settings; (3) do not recommend surgical deactivation of migraine trigger points outside of a clinical trial; (4) do not prescribe opioid-containing medications or butalbital as first-line treatment for recurrent headache disorders ;" and (5) do not recommend long-term or frequent use of over-the-counter pain relievers for headaches. We recommend that headache medicine specialists and other physicians who evaluate and treat headache disorders use this checklist when discussing patient care.

title: Choosing Wisely: The American College of Rheumatology's Top 5 List That Doctors and Patients Should Question
abstract: OBJECTIVE: We seek to develop a list of 5 tests, treatments or services commonly used in the practice of rheumatology whose need or value should be questioned and discussed by doctors and patients. METHODS: We used a multi-stage process combining consensus methodology and literature reviews to arrive at the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) Top 5 list. Rheumatologists from various practice settings generated items using the Delphi method. Items with high content agreement and high perceived prevalence advanced to a survey of ACR members, comprising >90% of the US rheumatology workforce. To increase response rate, a nested random sample of 390 rheumatologists received a more intensive survey follow-up. Samples were pooled and weighting procedures applied to ensure generalizability. Items with high ratings underwent a literature review. The working group then selected and formulated the final elements. RESULTS: One hundred and five unique items were proposed and reduced to 22 items during Delphi rounds. A total of 1,052 rheumatologists (17% of those contacted) participated in the member survey, while 33% of those in the nested random sample participated";" The characteristics of the respondents were similar in both samples. Based on the survey results and available scientific evidence, 5 items (related to antinuclear antibodies, Lyme disease, MRI, bone absorptiometry, and biological therapy for rheumatoid arthritis) were selected for inclusion. CONCLUSION: The ACR Top 5 list is intended to promote discussions between physicians and patients about health care practices in rheumatology whose use should be questioned and to help rheumatologists deliver high-value care.

title: Choose Wisely: The American Society of Radiation Oncology Top 5 List
abstract: PURPOSE: To highlight 5 interventions that patients should question, as part of the Choosing Wisely campaign. This initiative, led by the American Board of Internal Medicine Foundation, encourages conversations between doctors and patients about treatments and tests that may be abused, unnecessary, or potentially harmful. METHODS AND MATERIALS: Potential items were initially compiled through an online survey. They were then evaluated and refined by a task force representing the American Society for Radiation Oncology (ASTRO) Councils on Clinical Affairs and Quality, Health Policy, and Government Relations. Literature reviews were conducted to support the recommendation and narrative, as well as to provide references for each item. The ASTRO board of directors then selected a final list of 5 items. RESULTS: ASTRO's 5 recommendations for the Choosing Wisely campaign are as follows: (1) Do not initiate whole breast radiation therapy as part of breast conservation therapy in women >/= 50 years of age with invasive breast cancer stage without considering treatment schedules"; (2) do not initiate management of low-risk prostate cancer without discussing active surveillance; (3) do not routinely use extended fractionation schemes (>10 fractions) for palliation of metastases bone; (4) not routinely recommend proton beam therapy for prostate cancer outside of a clinical trial or prospective registry;" and (5) does not routinely use intensity-modulated radiation therapy to deliver radiation therapy to the whole breast as part of breast-conserving therapy. CONCLUSIONS: The ASTRO list for the Choosing Wisely campaign highlights radiation oncology interventions that should be discussed between physicians and patients prior to initiation of treatment. These 5 elements provide opportunities to offer higher quality and less expensive care.

title: Chronic care model and shared care in diabetes: randomized trial of an electronic decision support system.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the effect of a specialized telemedicine intervention to improve diabetes care using the chronic care model (CCM). PARTICIPANTS AND METHODS As part of the CCM, 97 primary care physicians at 6 primary care practices in Rochester, MN, referred 639 patients to an on-site diabetes educator between July 1, 2001, and December 31, 2003. At first referral, clinicians were centrally randomized to receive either a telemedicine intervention (specialized advice and evidence-based messaging on cardiovascular risk medication management) or no intervention, keeping outcome assessors and data analysts blinded. to group assignment. After each subsequent clinical encounter, the endocrinologists reviewed a summary of the patient's electronic medical record and provided management recommendations and supporting evidence to the intervening physicians via email. Control physicians received email with regular generic information on cardiovascular risk reduction in diabetes. Outcome measures included diabetes care processes (diabetes testing), outcomes (metabolic and cardiovascular risk factors, estimated risk of coronary artery disease), and costs to the patient (payer perspective). RESULTS During the intervention, 951 (70%) of the 1361 endocrinology reviews detected performance gaps and resulted in a message; primary care physicians reported using 49% of messages in patient care. With a median follow-up of 21 months, the intervention, compared with control, did not significantly improve metabolic outcomes or reduce the estimated risk of coronary artery disease (adjusted mean difference, -1%; 95% confidence interval , -19%). to 17%). The intervention group incurred lower costs (p = 0.02), but not diabetes-related costs. CONCLUSION Specialized telemedicine did not significantly improve the value of CCM in primary care.

title: Chronic disease health risk behaviors among people with a mental illness
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Among people with a mental illness, modifiable health risk behaviors contribute substantially to increased morbidity and mortality from chronic diseases. This study examined the prevalence of and interest in changing such behaviors among clients of community mental health services in Australia. METHOD: A telephone interview was conducted with Australian community mental health service clients. Participants reported engaging in four health risk behaviors: tobacco smoking, fruit and vegetable consumption, alcohol consumption, and physical activity. Participants were classified as at risk based on Australian national guidelines. At-risk participants were asked if they were considering improving their health risk behavior in the next month. The association between psychiatric diagnosis and risk and interest in improving health risk behaviors was examined. RESULTS: The prevalence of risk was higher for inadequate consumption of vegetables (78.3%), followed by inadequate consumption of fruits (60%), smoking (50.7%), physical inactivity (46.8%), risk of short-term alcohol (40.3%) and chronic alcoholism risk (35.3%). Most of the participants at risk were considering improving their health risk behaviors due to smoking, physical inactivity and inadequate consumption of fruits and vegetables (65.1%, 71.1% and 53.3%, respectively) . After adjusting for demographic factors, no diagnostic category was associated with risk for any behavior. Those with a diagnosis of depression were more likely to be interested in quitting smoking and increasing physical activity. CONCLUSIONS: Regardless of diagnosis, a high prevalence of chronic disease health risk behaviors was identified, and many participants expressed interest in improving these behaviors. Such findings reinforce recommendations that mental health clinicians routinely provide preventive care that addresses clients' chronic disease risks. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australia and New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry (ANZCTR) ACTRN12613000693729. URL: www.anzctr.org.au/.

title: Competence network in chronic inflammatory bowel diseases
abstract: Inflammatory bowel diseases (IBDs) are appearing intermittently, often chronic diseases that mainly affect young people in their 20s and 30s, influencing their quality of life and socioeconomic efficiency. The triggers for the development of IBD are not fully understood: in addition to environmental factors, there is clear evidence of additional genetic factors influencing disease risk and the pattern of intestinal inflammation in Crohn's disease. Pathophysiological discoveries are leading to new therapeutic opportunities being conducted in large clinical trials with the primary involvement of the IBD Competency Network. The network's scattered structure comprising university and non-university hospitals and laboratories, the self-help organization DCCV, and its vertical cooperation with general practitioners nationwide provides the opportunity to describe diseases from the point of view of the scientist and the physician simultaneously. Therefore, the IBD Competence Network provides the basis for the standardized integration of patient information, for the development of guidelines and the establishment of a quality management system thus leading to improved scientific and clinical research.

title: Smoking Prevalence Among HIV-Positive Adults Compared to the General Adult Population in the United States
abstract: Background: The negative health effects of smoking and HIV infection are synergistic. Objective: To compare the current prevalence of smoking and smoking cessation among adults with HIV receiving medical care and adults in the general population. Design: Nationally representative cross-sectional surveys. Setting: United States. Patients: 4,217 adults with HIV who participated in the Medical Monitoring Project and 27,731 U.S. adults who participated in the National Health Interview Survey in 2009. Measurements: Primary exposure was smoking. Outcome measures were weighted smoking prevalence and quit rate (ratio of former smokers to the sum of former and current smokers). Results: Of the estimated 419,945 HIV-positive adults who received medical care, 42.4% (95% CI, 39.7% 45.1%) were current cigarette smokers, 20.3% (CI, 18.6% to 22.1%) were former smokers, and 37.3% (CI, 34.9% to 39.6%) had never smoked. Compared with the US adult population, in which an estimated 20.6% of adults smoked cigarettes in 2009, adults with HIV were almost twice as likely to smoke (adjusted prevalence difference, 17 .0 percentage points [CI, 14.0 to 20.1 percentage points]), but were less likely to quit (quit rate, 32.4% vs. 51.7%). Among adults with HIV, factors independently associated with higher smoking prevalence were older age, non-Hispanic white or non-Hispanic black race, lower educational level, poverty, homelessness, incarceration, use of substances, excessive alcohol consumption, depression and not achieving a suppressed HIV viral load. Limitation: cross-sectional design with some generalization limitations. Conclusion: Adults with HIV were more likely to smoke and less likely to quit than the general adult population. Tobacco screening and cessation strategies are important considerations as part of routine HIV care.

title: The CIOMS Placebo Rule and the Promotion of Malpractice
Civil commitment of the anorexic patient
abstract: Involuntary engagement appears to be an infrequently used intervention with anorexic patients, in part due to clinicians' uncertainty about its applicability to this population. Unlike overtly suicidal patients, anorexic patients do not usually express an intention to harm themselves, although their actions may result in serious harm. Examination of the language of civil commitment statutes, however, suggests that when anorexic patients' behavior endangers their lives, they will generally be subject to severe disability standards. This appears to be consistent with the practices of experts in the treatment of anorexia and also with practices in other countries. Involuntary hospitalization should be used as an approach of last resort, when patients refuse voluntary hospitalization and their physical safety is at risk. In addition, civil hospitalization should probably also be limited to circumstances in which hospitalization is likely to result in therapeutic benefit. Many seriously ill anorexic patients will lack the competence to make treatment decisions for themselves, allowing for involuntary feeding and other procedures, if necessary. Civil commitment is a tool that can be legitimately used in emergent situations with anorexic patients.

title: Classifications in the field of mental health
abstract: For the first time in the Ninth Revision of the International Classification of Diseases (ICD-9), the chapter on mental disorders contained brief glossary definitions for each category. A number of changes in attitudes and policies at the international and national levels, in particular the reorientation of mental health programs to include behavioral and psychosocial problems, came at an opportune time and had a positive influence on the development of proposals for the chapter. about mental and mental health. behavioral disorders in the Tenth Revision (ICD-10). This, in turn, enabled the WHO to undertake an intensive and extensive assessment of the international needs in the classification of mental disorders and, where the situation was not unequivocal, to organize field tests to provide the empirical data necessary for the solution of the problem. issue. The result is a series of compatible classifications of mental and behavioral disorders based on ICD-10. The first, developed primarily as a reference tool for statistical purposes, will be included in ICD-10 with brief definitions in the glossary, as was the case with ICD-9. Further versions for practicing physicians (with improved glossary definitions followed by diagnostic guidelines) will be published for research (with full definitions, diagnostic guidelines, and diagnostic criteria)"; for use in providing services to the mentally ill;" and for use in general (primary) health care. A multiaxial classification of mental disorders in children will also be performed to identify the clinical syndrome, resulting disability, and environmental factors. These versions tailored to the needs of different groups working in the mental health field are expected to result in further improvements in communications between those responsible for service delivery and care.

title: Classroom-based cognitive behavioral therapy for reducing depressive symptoms in high-risk adolescents: a pragmatic cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To compare the effectiveness of classroom-based cognitive behavioral therapy with attention control and usual school provision for adolescents at high risk of depression. DESIGN Three-arm parallel group randomized controlled trial. SETTING Eight UK secondary schools. PARTICIPANTS Adolescents (n=5030) from 12 to 16 years old from the groups of 8 to 11 years old. The year groups were randomly assigned in a 1:1:1 ratio to cognitive behavioral therapy, attention management, or usual school provision. The allocation was balanced by school, year, number of students and classes, frequency of lessons, and schedule. Participants were not blinded to treatment assignment. INTERVENTIONS Cognitive behavioral therapy, attention management, and usual school disposition provided in class to all eligible participants. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Results were collected using a self-completed questionnaire administered by the investigators. The primary outcome was symptoms of depression assessed at 12 months using the short mood and feelings questionnaire among those identified at baseline as being at high risk for depression. Secondary outcomes included negative thoughts, self-esteem, and anxiety. Analyzes were by intention to treat and took into account the pooled nature of the design. RESULTS: 1064 (21.2%) adolescents were identified as being at high risk for depression: 392 in the classroom cognitive behavioral therapy arm, 374 in the attention control arm, and 298 in the usual school provision arm. At 12 months, adjusted mean scores on the Brief Mood and Feelings Questionnaire did not differ for cognitive behavioral therapy versus attention control (-0.63, 95% confidence interval: -1, 85 to 0.58, P = 0.41) or for cognitive behavioral therapy versus usual school provision ( 0.97, -0.20 to 2.15, P = 0.12). CONCLUSION In adolescents with depressive symptoms, results were similar for attention control, usual school offerings, and cognitive behavioral therapy. Classroom-based cognitive behavioral therapy programs may result in increased self-awareness and reporting of depressive symptoms, but should not be undertaken without further evaluation and investigation. TRIAL REGISTRATION Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN19083628.

title: Clinical and economic efficacy of booklet-based vestibular rehabilitation for chronic dizziness in primary care: a pragmatic, single-blind, parallel-group, randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the clinical and economic effectiveness of booklet-based vestibular rehabilitation with and without telephone support for chronic dizziness, compared with usual care. DESIGN Single-blind, parallel group, pragmatic, randomized, controlled trial. SCENARIO 35 general practices in the South of England between October 2008 and January 2011. PARTICIPANTS Patients aged 18 years or older with chronic dizziness (mean duration > five years) not attributable to non-vestibular causes (confirmed by a general practitioner) and who could aggravated by movement of the head (confirmed by the patient). INTERVENTIONS Participants randomized to receive usual medical care, booklet-based vestibular rehabilitation only, or booklet-based vestibular rehabilitation with telephone support. For the booklet approach, participants received self-management booklets that provide comprehensive advice on performing vestibular rehabilitation exercises at home every day for up to 12 weeks and using cognitive behavioral techniques to promote positive beliefs and adherence. to treatment. Participants receiving telephone support were offered up to three short sessions of structured support by a vestibular therapist. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Abbreviated Vertigo Symptom Scale and total health costs related to dizziness per quality-adjusted life year (QALY). RESULTS Of 337 randomized participants, 276 (82%) completed all clinical measures at the primary endpoint, 12 weeks, and 263 (78%) at 1-year follow-up. We analyzed clinical effectiveness on an intention-to-treat basis, using analysis of covariance to compare groups after intervention, controlling for baseline symptom scores. At 12 weeks, Vertigo Symptom Scale scores in the telephone support group did not differ significantly from those in the usual care group (adjusted mean difference -1.79 (95% confidence interval -3, 69 to 0.11), p = 0.064). At one year, both intervention groups improved significantly relative to usual care (telephone support -2.52 (-4.52 to -0.51), P=0.014"; booklet only -2.43 (-4.27 α -0.60), P=0.010).Analysis of cost-effectiveness acceptability curves showed that both interventions were highly cost-effective, with very low QALY values, the booklet-only approach was more likely to be cost-effective, but the approach with additional telephone support was more likely to be profitable at QALY values above £1,200 (£1,488; "$1,932"). Using the telephone assisted booklet approach, five (3 to 12) patients would need to be treated for one patient to report subjective improvement at one year. CONCLUSIONS Booklet-based vestibular rehabilitation for chronic dizziness is a simple and cost-effective means of improving patient-reported outcomes in primary care. ClinicalTrials.gov TRIAL REGISTRY NCT00732797.

title: Clinical evaluation of motherhood during infancy
abstract: The use of reliable and valid measures of maternity can improve the ability of clinicians and researchers to identify problematic patterns that pose health risks to mothers and babies during the first year postpartum. A critical review of observational and self-report instruments to measure the components of motherhood is presented. Positive indicators of motherhood are discussed and implications for intervention and referral of problematic aspects of motherhood are suggested.

title: Clinical biochemistry closer to the patient
Clinical characteristics associated with the prescription of SSRI drugs in adolescents with unipolar major depression
abstract: Unipolar major depressions (MD) emerge markedly during adolescence. The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) in the United Kingdom recommends psychological therapies, accompanied by selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) prescribed only in severe cases. Here, we seek to determine the scope and rationale for prescribing SSRIs in adolescents with MD before entering a randomized clinical trial. SSRI prescription, along with its clinical characteristics, was determined in 465 adolescent MD patients prior to receiving standardized psychological therapy as part of the Improving mood with psychoanalytic and cognitive therapies (IMPACT) clinical trial. In total, 88 (19%) had been prescribed antidepressants before psychological treatment. The clinical correlates varied by gender: respectively, severity of depression in boys and self-injurious behaviors in girls. Prescribing also differed between clinical research centers. Doctors consider the severity of depression in children as an indicator for the prescription of antidepressants. Self-harm in girls appears to be used as a prescription aid which is inconsistent with past and current revised UK NICE guidelines.

title: Clinical effectiveness of a manual-based coping strategy program (START, STrAtegies for Relatives) in promoting the mental health of caregivers of family members with dementia: pragmatic randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess whether a manual coping strategy compared to treatment as usual reduces symptoms of depression and anxiety in caregivers of relatives with dementia. DESIGN Randomized parallel group superiority trial. SETTING Three community mental health services and one neurological dementia outpatient service in London and Essex, UK. PARTICIPANTS 260 caregivers of relatives with dementia. INTERVENTION A manual-based coping intervention consisting of eight sessions delivered by supervised psychology graduates to carers of family members with dementia. The program consisted of psychoeducation about dementia, caregiver stress, and where to get emotional support"; understanding caregiver behaviors and behavior management techniques; changing unhelpful thoughts; promoting acceptance; assertive communication; relaxation; planning for the future increasing pleasurable activities maintaining learned skills Caregivers practiced these techniques at home, using the manual and relaxation CDs MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Affective symptoms (total hospital anxiety and depression score) at 4 and 8 months Secondary outcomes were depression and anxiety, casuistry on the hospital anxiety and depression scale, quality of life of both the caregiver (health status questionnaire, mental health) and the caregiver (quality of life-disease Alzheimer's); and potentially abusive behavior of the caregiver towards the caregiver (modified scale a for conflict tactics) RESULTS 260 caregivers were recruited, 173 were randomized to intervention and 87 to treatment as usual. Mean Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale total scores were lower in the intervention group than in the treatment-as-usual group over the eight-month evaluation period: adjusted difference in means -1.80 points (range 95% confidence: -3.29 to -0.31, P = 0.02) and absolute mean difference -2.0 points. Caregivers in the intervention group were less likely to have depression at the case level (odds ratio 0.24, 95% confidence interval 0.07 to 0.76) and there was a non-significant trend towards a reduced case level anxiety (0.30, 0.08 to 1.05). Caregiver quality of life was higher in the intervention group (mean difference 4.09, 95% confidence interval 0.34 to 7.83). ) but not for the care recipient (mean difference 0.59, -0.72 a Caregivers in the intervention group reported less abusive behavior toward the care recipient compared with those in the treatment-as-usual group ( odds ratio 0.47, 95% confidence interval 0.18 to 1.23), although this was not significant A manual-based coping strategy was effective in reducing affective symptoms and depression at the case level in caregivers of relatives with dementia.The quality of life of caregivers also improved.REGIS TEST TRO Current Controlled Trials ISCTRN70017938.

title: Clinical efficacy of health visitor training in psychologically informed approaches to depression in postpartum women: pragmatic cluster randomized trial in primary care
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the benefits for postpartum women of two psychologically informed interventions by health visitors. DESIGN Prospective randomized group trial by general practice, with 18-month follow-up. SETTING 101 general practice in Trent, England. PARTICIPANTS 2749 women assigned to intervention, 1335 to control. INTERVENTION Health visitors (n=89 63 groups) were trained to identify depressive symptoms six to eight weeks after birth using the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS) and clinical assessment, and were also trained to provide Psychologically informed sessions based on cognitive behavioral or person-centered principles for one hour a week for eight weeks. Health visitors in the control group (n=49 38 groups) provided usual care. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Edinburgh Postpartum Depression Scale score > or = 12 at six months. Secondary outcomes were the Edinburgh Postpartum Depression Scale, clinical outcomes on the Routine Assessment Outcome Measure (CORE-OM), the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI), the SF-12, and scores on the parental stress index (PSI-SF) at six, 12, 18 months.
