RESULTS: 4084 eligible women consented and 595 women had a 6-week EPDS score > or = 12. Of these, 418 had available EPDS scores at 6 weeks and 6 months. At six months, 34% of women (93/271) in the intervention group and 46% (67/147) in the control group had an EPDS score > or = 12. The odds ratio for score > or = 12 at six months was 0.62 (95% confidence interval 0.40 to 0.97, P = 0.036) for women in the intervention group compared with women in the control group . After adjustment for covariates, the odds ratio was 0.60 (0.38 to 0.95, P = 0.028). At six months, 12.4% (234/1880) of all women in the intervention group and 16.7% (166/995) of all women in the control group had scores > or = 12 (0.67, 0.51 to 0.87, P = 0.003). The benefit for women in the intervention group with a six-week EPDS score > or = 12 and for all women was maintained 12 months after birth. There was no differential benefit for either psychological approach over the other. CONCLUSION Training of health visitors to assess women, identify symptoms of postpartum depression, and provide psychologically informed sessions was clinically effective at six and 12 months postnatal compared with usual care. TEST RECORD ISRCTN92195776.

title: Global clinical measures of dementia. Position Paper of the International Task Force on Harmonization of Guidelines on Medicines for Dementia
abstract: Below is the report of the committee working on global clinical measures for dementia drug guidelines. Concepts involved in global scales, distinctions between change and severity scales, advantages and disadvantages of structured interviews and anchoring of change scores are discussed, and selected existing clinical global scales are described. In addition, the committee evaluated the usefulness of global scales in clinical trials of drugs for dementia. There was consensus among the members of the working group on the following: (1) The global clinical scales are based on interviews";" in most cases, they include information obtained from caregivers and directly from patients, but may be based solely on information from the subject. (2) Physicians' global ratings are intended to assess clinically significant change based on a multidimensional clinical assessment and take into account the clinical heterogeneity of dementia by assessing at least cognition, behavior, and functioning. (3) There are two distinct types of clinical global measures: (a) physician interview-based global severity scales, which generally incorporate classification by stage or severity of illness, and (b) physician interview-based global change scales. physicians, which incorporate global assessment ratings of clinical change. The committee was unable to reach a consensus on whether global scales should be required in phase II and phase III clinical trials, or whether other specific assessments, such as well-designed activities of daily living, cognition, and behavioral measures, when used in appropriate combinations. , replace the global as assessments of clinical significance.

title: Clinical governance in the management of induction of labor
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine if the dissemination of explicit guidelines, developed in consensus with stakeholders, for induction of labor (IOL) processes, results in a reduction in variability in clinical practice. DESIGN: A prospective behavior modification intervention study. STUDY LOCATION AND DURATION: The study was conducted at the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Aga Khan University, Karachi, between January 1 and August 31, 2002. SUBJECTS AND METHODS: In a total of 142 conveniently selected women , submitted to IOL, pre-identified quality assessment indicators were measured. After data collection from an initial 71 women (pre-intervention group), mutually agreed guidelines for clinical practice were disseminated, over a period of time, among consultants, residents, and nurses. These indicators were measured again in 71 subsequent women (post-intervention group) to assess the magnitude of residual nonconformities in these processes. RESULTS: After behavior modification interventions, nonconformities in consultants and resident-dependent processes, such as timely review of patients by consultants (72% vs. 1.4%, p-value < 0, 0001), documentation of IOL indication (66.2 vs. 16.9%, p-value <0.0001), method of IOL induction (56.3 vs. 28.2%, p-value 0.0001) and pre-IOL Bishop score calculation (38.0 vs. 4.2%, p-value < 0.0001) were significantly reduced. CONCLUSION: The dissemination of explicit guidelines developed in consensus with stakeholders significantly reduces variability in clinical practice. Our model can be used to improve quality of care in other areas of obstetric health care.

title: Clinical Inertia: A Common Barrier to Changing Provider Prescribing Behavior
abstract: BACKGROUND: A cross-sectional content analysis nested within a randomized controlled trial was conducted to collect information on provider responses to computer alerts regarding guideline recommendations for patients with suboptimal hypertension care. METHODS: Participants were providers who cared for 1017 patients with hypertension uncontrolled with a single antihypertensive agent within Veterans Affairs primary care clinics. All reasons for action or inaction were ordered into a framework to account for variation in guideline adaptation. RESULTS: The 184 providers' negative responses to the computer alerts contained explanations for not changing the patient's treatment";" 76 responses to the alerts were positive, that is, the provider was going to change the antihypertensive regimen. Negative responses were categorized as: practice inertia (66%), lack of agreement with specific guidelines (5%), patient-based factors (17%), environmental factors (10%), and lack of knowledge (2%). ). . Most of the 135 providers classified as having practice inertia stated, "Continue current medications and I'll discuss this at the next visit." The median number of days to the next visit was 45 days (interquartile range, 29 to 78 days). DISCUSSION: Clinical inertia was the main reason why the indicated treatment change was not made in a subgroup of patients. A framework was provided as a taxonomy for the classification of provider barriers.

title: Clinical Judgment Review: The Distraction of Quantitative Models
abstract: More than 25 years ago, in a book called Clinical Judgment, every act of patient care was described as having an experiential structure. specifications of clinical reasoning. Over the last 2 decades, these improvements have not occurred as widely as expected because many researchers working on clinical forms of clinical research have not addressed these basic scientific challenges in data, taxonomy, and reasoning. Instead, researchers have applied quantitative "models," derived from nonclinical domains, that focus on hard data, randomized trials, Bayes' theorem, quantitative decision analysis, and psychometric strategies for clinimetric measurement. Consequently, the main challenges of clinical judgment remain generally available for basic scientific research by clinical investigators.

title: Clinical Practice Guideline Development Manual: A Quality-Based Approach to Translating Evidence into Action
abstract: BACKGROUND: Guidelines translate best evidence into best practice. Well-crafted guidance promotes quality by reducing variations in care, improving diagnostic accuracy, promoting effective therapy, and discouraging ineffective or potentially harmful interventions. Despite the plethora of published guidelines, the methodology is often poorly defined and varies greatly within and between organizations. PURPOSE: This manual describes the principles and practices successfully used by the American Academy of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery to produce evidence-based, quality-based guidelines using an efficient and transparent methodology for action-ready recommendations with multidisciplinary applicability. . From conception to completion in 12 months, the development process emphasizes a logical sequence of key action statements supported by extension text, evidence profiles, and grades of recommendation that link action to evidence. CONCLUSIONS: As clinical practice guidelines become more prominent as a key metric of quality healthcare, organizations must develop efficient production strategies that balance rigor and pragmatism. Equally important, clinicians must learn to understand what guidelines are and are not, and how they are best used to improve care. The information in this manual should help clinicians and organizations achieve these goals.

title: Clinical Practice Guideline: Otitis Media with Discharge (Update)
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This update of a 2004 guideline developed jointly by the American Academy of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery Foundation, the American Academy of Pediatrics, and the American Academy of Family Physicians provides evidence-based recommendations for managing otitis media with effusion (OME), defined as the presence of fluid in the middle ear without signs or symptoms of acute ear infection. Changes from the previous guideline include the addition of consumer advocates to the update group, evidence from 4 new clinical practice guidelines, 20 new systematic reviews and 49 randomized controlled trials, increased emphasis on patient education and shared decision-making, a new algorithm to clarify action statement relationships, and new and expanded recommendations for the diagnosis and management of OME. PURPOSE: The purpose of this multidisciplinary guideline is to identify quality improvement opportunities in the management of OME and to create explicit and actionable recommendations for implementing these opportunities in clinical practice. Specifically, the goals are to improve diagnostic accuracy, identify children who are more susceptible to the sequelae of developing OME, and educate clinicians and patients about the favorable natural history of most OME and the clinical benefits of OME. medical therapy (eg, steroids, antihistamines, decongestants ). Additional goals relate to OME surveillance, hearing and language assessment, and management of OME detected by newborn screening. The target patient of the guideline is a child aged 2 months to 12 years with OME, with or without developmental disabilities or underlying conditions that predispose to OME and its sequelae. The guideline is intended for all clinicians likely to diagnose and manage children with OME, and applies to any setting in which OME is identified, monitored, or managed. This guideline, however, does not apply to patients 12 years of age. ACTION STATEMENTS: The update group made strong recommendations that clinicians (1) should document the presence of middle ear effusion with pneumatic otoscopy when diagnosing OME in a child"; (2) should perform pneumatic otoscopy to assess the OME in a child with ear pain, hearing loss, or both; (3) you should obtain tympanometry in children with suspected OME for whom the diagnosis is uncertain after performing (or attempted) pneumatic otoscopy; (4) you should manage the child with OME not at risk with watchful waiting for 3 months from date of stroke onset (if known) or 3 months from date of diagnosis (if onset unknown); (5) should recommend not use intranasal or systemic steroids to treat OME, (6) should recommend against the use of systemic antibiotic steroids for the treatment of OME, and (7) should recommend against the use of antihistamines, decongestants, or both to treat OME. mothers of infants with OME who have failed newborn screening regarding the importance of follow-up to ensure normal hearing when OME resolves and to exclude underlying sensorineural hearing loss; (2) must determine whether a child with OME is at increased risk for speech, language, or learning problems due to middle ear effusion due to early sensory, physical, cognitive, or behavioral factors; (3) must screen children at risk for OME at the time of diagnosis of an at-risk condition and between 12 and 18 months of age (if diagnosed at risk before this time); (4) should not routinely screen children for OME who are not at risk and do not have symptoms that can be attributed to OME, such as hearing difficulties, balance (vestibular) problems, poor school performance, behavioral problems, or discomfort in the ears; (5) should educate children with OME and their families about the natural history of OME, the need for follow-up, and possible sequelae; (6) must obtain age-appropriate hearing screening if OME persists for 3 months or longer OR for OME of any duration in an at-risk child; (7) should counsel families of children with bilateral OME and documented hearing loss about the potential impact on speech and language development; (8) should reassess, at 3- to 6-month intervals, children with chronic OME until the effusion is no longer present, significant hearing loss is identified, or structural abnormalities of the eardrum or middle ear are suspected; (9) should recommend tympanostomy tubes when performing surgery for OME in a child ≥ 4 years of age;" and (11) should document resolution of OME, hearing improvement, or quality improvement of life when treating a child with OME.

title: Clinical Practice Guideline: Tinnitus
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Tinnitus is the perception of sound without an external source. More than 50 million people in the United States have reported experiencing tinnitus, resulting in an estimated prevalence of 10% to 15% in adults. Despite the high prevalence of tinnitus and its potentially significant effect on quality of life, there are no evidence-based multidisciplinary clinical practice guidelines to help clinicians with management. The focus of this guideline is on tinnitus that is bothersome and persistent (lasting 6 months or more), often negatively affecting a patient's quality of life. The target audience for the guideline is any clinician, including non-physicians, involved in the management of patients with tinnitus. The target patient population is limited to adults (over 18 years of age) with primary tinnitus that is persistent and bothersome. PURPOSE: The purpose of this guideline is to provide evidence-based recommendations for clinicians managing patients with tinnitus. This guide provides clinicians with a logical framework to improve patient care and mitigate the personal and social effects of persistent and bothersome tinnitus. It will discuss the evaluation of patients with tinnitus, including the selection and timing of diagnostic tests and referral to specialists to identify possible underlying treatable pathology. It will then focus on the assessment and treatment of patients with persistent primary tinnitus, with recommendations to guide the assessment and measurement of the effect of tinnitus, and to determine the most appropriate interventions to improve symptoms and quality of life for tinnitus sufferers. ACTION STATEMENTS: The development group made a strong recommendation that clinicians distinguish patients with bothersome tinnitus from patients with non-bothersome tinnitus. The development group made a strong recommendation against head and neck imaging in patients with tinnitus, specifically to assess tinnitus that is not localized to one ear, is not pulsatile, and is not associated with focal neurological abnormalities. or asymmetric hearing loss. The panel made the following recommendations: Clinicians should (a) perform a specific history and physical examination in the initial evaluation of a patient with suspected primary tinnitus to identify conditions that, if promptly identified and managed, may alleviate the tinnitus." ; (b) obtain a prompt, comprehensive audiological examination in patients with unilateral, persistent (>/= 6 months), or associated tinnitus with hearing difficulties; (c) distinguish patients with bothersome tinnitus of recent onset from those with persistent symptoms ( >/= 6 months) to prioritize intervention and facilitate discussions of natural history and follow-up care; (d) educate patients with persistent and bothersome tinnitus about management strategies; (e) recommend hearing aid evaluation for patients who have persistent and bothersome tinnitus associated with documented hearing loss and (f) recommend cognitive behavioral therapy to patients with tinni your persistent and annoying. against (a) antidepressants, anticonvulsants, anxiolytics, or intratympanic medications for the routine treatment of patients with persistent and bothersome tinnitus; (b) Ginkgo biloba, melatonin, zinc, or other dietary supplements for the treatment of patients with persistent and bothersome tinnitus; and (c) transcranial magnetic stimulation for the routine treatment of patients with persistent and bothersome tinnitus. The development group provided the following options: clinicians can (a) obtain an initial comprehensive audiological examination in patients presenting with tinnitus (regardless of laterality, duration, or perceived hearing status)" and (b) recommend sound therapy to patients with persistent tinnitus bothersome tinnitus The development group did not provide any recommendations regarding the effect of acupuncture in patients with persistent and bothersome tinnitus.

title: Clinical Practice Guideline: Tonsillectomy in Children
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Tonsillectomy is one of the most common surgical procedures in the United States, with more than 530,000 procedures performed annually on children younger than 15 years. Tonsillectomy is defined as a surgical procedure performed with or without adenoidectomy that completely removes the tonsil including its capsule by dissecting the peritonsillar space between the tonsil capsule and the muscular wall. Depending on the context in which it is used, it may indicate tonsillectomy with adenoidectomy, especially in relation to sleep-disordered breathing. This guideline provides evidence-based recommendations on the preoperative, intraoperative, and postoperative care and management of children aged 1 to 18 years who are being considered for tonsillectomy. Additionally, this guide is intended for all clinicians in any setting who interact with children ages 1 to 18 who may be candidates for tonsillectomy. PURPOSE: The primary purpose of this guideline is to provide clinicians with an evidence-based guide to identify children who are the best candidates for tonsillectomy. Secondary goals are to optimize the perioperative management of children undergoing tonsillectomy, to emphasize the need for evaluation and intervention in special populations, to improve counseling and education for families of children who are considering tonsillectomy for their child, to highlight treatment options management for patients with modifying factors, and reduce inappropriate or unnecessary variations in care. RESULTS: The panel made a strong recommendation that clinicians should administer a single intraoperative dose of intravenous dexamethasone to children undergoing tonsillectomy. The panel made a strong recommendation against physicians routinely giving or prescribing perioperative antibiotics to children undergoing tonsillectomy. The panel made recommendations for (1) watchful waiting for recurrent strep throat if there have been fewer than 7 episodes in the past year or fewer than 5 episodes per year in the past 2 years or fewer than 3 episodes per year in the past 3 years "; (2) evaluate the child with recurrent strep throat who does not meet the criteria for statement 2 to modify factors that may nevertheless favor tonsillectomy, which may include, but are not limited to, allergy/intolerance to multiple antibiotics , periodic fever, aphthous stomatitis, pharyngitis and adenitis, or a history of peritonsillar abscess; (3) ask caregivers of children with sleep-disordered breathing and tonsil hypertrophy about comorbid conditions that might improve after tonsillectomy, including growth retardation, poor school performance, bed-wetting, and behavioral problems; (4) advise carers about tonsillectomy as a means of improve health in children with abnormal polysomnography who also have enlarged tonsils and disordered breathing; (5) advise caregivers that sleep-disordered breathing may persist or recur after tonsillectomy and may require additional treatment; (6) advocate for post-tonsillectomy pain control and educate caregivers on the importance of pain management and reassessment;" and (7) physicians performing tonsillectomy should determine their rate of primary and secondary post-tonsillectomy hemorrhage. tonsillectomy at least once a year The panel offered options to recommend tonsillectomy for recurrent pharyngeal infection with a frequency of at least 7 episodes in the past year or at least 5 episodes a year for 2 years or at least 3 episodes a year for 3 years with documentation in the medical record for each episode of sore throat and 1 or more of the following: temperature >38.3 degrees C, cervical adenopathy, tonsillar exudate, or positive test for group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus.

title: Clinical Practice Guideline: Tympanostomy Tubes in Children
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Tympanostomy tube insertion is the most common outpatient surgery performed on children in the United States. Tympanostomy tubes are most often inserted due to persistent middle ear fluid, frequent ear infections, or ear infections that persist after antibiotic therapy. Despite the frequency of tympanostomy tube insertion, there are currently no clinical practice guidelines in the United States that address specific indications for surgery. This guideline is intended for any clinician involved in the management of children, aged 6 months to 12 years, with tympanostomy tubes or who are being considered for tympanostomy tubes in any care setting, as an intervention for otitis media of any type. . PURPOSE: The primary purpose of this clinical practice guideline is to provide clinicians with evidence-based recommendations on patient selection and indications for surgery and management of tympanostomy tubes in children. The development group extensively discussed indications for tube placement, perioperative management, care of children with indwelling tubes, and outcomes of tympanostomy tube surgery. Given the lack of current published guidance on surgical indications, the group focused on situations in which tube insertion would be optional, recommended, or not recommended. Additional emphasis was placed on opportunities for quality improvement, particularly regarding shared decision-making and care for children with existing tubes. ACTION STATEMENTS: The development group made a strong recommendation that clinicians should prescribe topical antibiotic ear drops only, without oral antibiotics, for children with uncomplicated acute otorrhea with a tympanostomy tube. The panel made recommendations that (1) clinicians should not perform tympanostomy tube insertion in children with a single episode of otitis media with effusion (OME) of less than 3 months' duration"; (2) clinicians should obtain a age-appropriate hearing screening if OME persists for 3 months or longer (chronic OME) or before surgery when a child becomes a candidate for tympanostomy tube insertion; (3) clinicians should offer insertion of a bilateral tympanostomy tube to children with bilateral OME for 3 months or longer (chronic OME) and documented hearing difficulties; (4) clinicians should reassess, at 3- to 6-month intervals, children with chronic OME who do not received tympanostomy tubes until effusion is no longer present, significant hearing loss is detected, or structural abnormalities of the tympanic membrane or middle ear are suspected; (5) clinicians should not perform tympanostomy tube insertion panostomy in children with recurrent acute otitis media (AOM) who do not have a mid-effusion in either ear at the time of evaluation for tube candidacy; (6) clinicians should offer bilateral tympanostomy tube insertion to children with recurrent AOM who have unilateral or bilateral middle ear effusion at the time of evaluation for tube candidacy; (7) clinicians should determine whether a child with recurrent AOM or OME of any duration is at increased risk for speech, language, or learning problems due to otitis media due to underlying sensory, physical, cognitive, or behavioral factors; (8) perioperatively, clinicians should educate caregivers of children with tympanostomy tubes about the expected duration of tube function, the recommended follow-up schedule, and screening for complications; (9) Physicians should not encourage routine and prophylactic water precautions (use of earplugs, headbands;" avoid swimming or water sports) for children with tympanostomy tubes. The development group provided the following options: (1) Physicians may perform tympanostomy tube insertion in children with unilateral or bilateral OME for 3 months or longer (chronic OME) and symptoms likely to be attributed to OME, including but not limited to vestibular problems, poor school performance, behavior problems, ear discomfort, or reduced quality of life and (2) clinicians may perform tympanostomy tube insertion in at-risk children with unilateral or bilateral OME that is unlikely to resolve rapidly as reflected by a type B (flat) tympanogram or persistence of the effusion for 3 months or more (chronic OME).

title: Clinical practice guidelines for severe Alzheimer's disease
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although severe Alzheimer's disease (AD) represents a prevalent, serious, and costly public health problem, few practical guidelines exist to help clinicians manage this disorder. METHODS: A search of English-language medical databases from 1996 to the present was conducted for articles related to the management of AD. The focus of this review was on studies that included patients with severe disease. Studies were evaluated considering subjects, trial design, analysis and results. Recommendations were based on the best available evidence. RESULTS: Severe AD can be reliably defined and diagnosed using measures of cognition, function, behavior, and global staging. Specific assessments would also include the caregiver's medical status, safety concerns, and health status. Specific management of the disease would include treatment with cholinesterase inhibitors and/or memantine. Treatment of neuropsychiatric symptoms begins with nonpharmacologic behavioral and environmental approaches. Severe agitation, aggression, and psychosis that are potentially dangerous to the patient, caregiver, and others in the environment can be treated with atypical antipsychotics, taking into account their increased risk of cerebrovascular adverse events and mortality. All pharmacological approaches require careful monitoring and regular periodic reassessments to determine if further treatment is necessary. CONCLUSIONS: Evidence-based guidelines for the management of severe AD have the potential to improve the quality of life of the patient and their caregiver. More randomized controlled trials specifically targeting this phase of the disease are still urgently needed.

title: Clinical practice guidelines to improve shared decision making on the use of assistive devices in home care: a pilot intervention study
abstract: This study examines whether clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) for the introduction of assistive devices (ADs) in home care improve shared decision-making about the use of ADs and modify their sociocognitive correlates. Data were collected in an intervention study with a quasi-experimental design. Questionnaires were obtained from 116 home health nurses and home care workers and their 140 clients with disabilities. Significant differences between the intervention and control groups revealed that the implementation of CPGs improved the self-reported practice of home nurses and home care workers: the number of intervention methods they applied increased and the methods were applied with greater intensity. . Nurses' attitudes toward introducing AD into a shared decision-making process decreased in both the intervention and control groups over time. Client reports of caregivers' practice showed less agreement with caregivers' own reports. The complexity of the CPG and a significant time investment were reported as the main barriers to involving clients in shared decision making through the experimental CPG. However, CPGs hold promise for shared decision-making between formal caregivers and people with disabilities living in the community regarding the use of AD. The findings suggest that these CPGs can structure communication between caregiver and client, and can help caregivers facilitate clients' self-determination regarding coping with their disabilities.

title: Clinical Practice Update: Expert Review of Endoscopic Bariatric Therapies
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES: Multiple endoscopic bariatric therapies (EBT) are currently being evaluated or in clinical use in the United States. EBTs are well positioned to fill an important gap in the management of obesity and metabolic diseases. The purpose of this expert review is to update gastroenterologists on these therapies and provide practical advice on how to incorporate them into clinical practice. METHODS: The evidence reviewed in this paper is a distillation of a comprehensive search of several English-language databases and a hands-on review of relevant publications (including systematic reviews and meeting abstracts). Best Practice Tip 1: EBTs should be considered in patients with obesity who have been unsuccessful in losing or maintaining weight loss with lifestyle interventions. Best Practice Tip 2: EBTs can be used in severely obese patients as a bridge to traditional bariatric surgery. They can also be used as a bridge to allow for unrelated procedures that cannot be performed due to weight limits (ie, orthopedic surgery, organ transplant). Best Practice Tip 3: Clinicians should use EBT as part of a structured weight loss program that includes dietary intervention, exercise therapy, and behavior modification, both in the active weight loss phase and in the maintenance phase. long term. Best Practice Tip 4: Physicians should screen all potential EBT candidates with a comprehensive assessment of medical conditions, co-morbidities, and psychosocial or behavioral patterns contributing to their condition before enrolling patients in an EBT program. weight loss that includes EBT. Best Practice Tip 5: Physicians incorporating EBT into their clinical practice should prospectively follow-up patients to capture the impact of the EBT program on weight and weight-related comorbidities, and any related adverse outcomes. Poor responders should be identified and offered detailed evaluation and alternative therapy. Best Practice Tip 6: Physicians embarking on incorporating EBT into their clinical practice should have a comprehensive understanding of the indications, contraindications, risks, benefits, and outcomes of individual EBTs, as well as a working knowledge of the risks and benefits of alternative therapies for obesity. Best Practice Tip 7: Institutions should establish specific guidelines that are applied consistently across disciplines for granting privileges in EBT that reflect the necessary knowledge and technical skill that a physician must achieve before being granted privileges to perform these procedures.

title: Variation of clinical practice in reduced fetal movements
abstract: BACKGROUND: Reduced fetal movements imply a risky pregnancy. This condition is present in a significant proportion of pregnancies, but both the quality of information and clinical care is variable. MATERIAL AND METHODS: All delivery units in Eastern Norway and Bergen have recorded all consultations for reduced fetal movements, as part of the international collaborative project "Fetal Movement Intervention Assessment" (Femina). Of 23,933 deliveries, 1,200 pregnancies were examined. In 1043 pregnancies the mother had spontaneously reported concerns about "reduced fetal movements"; these were included in the analyses. Results are presented with a 95% confidence interval. RESULTS: Asphyxia, death, growth restriction or delivery prematurity occurred in 19.6% (16.6-22.6%) of cases, varying between units from 9.1% to 26.5%. Standard procedures varied widely;" ultrasonography was used in 39.0% to 98.6% and Doppler in 4.5% to 74.6% of cases. There was an association between the results and the procedures used. Women who waited 24 hours with reduced or absent movements before contacting medical care were at higher risk. Among those with absent movements, 47% (42-52%) had this risk behavior. INTERPRETATION: There is a need for improvements in the quality of information to pregnant women, as well as in the clinical management of affected pregnancies. This could have great health benefits. We propose new information and management guidelines.

title: Clinical practice. Subsequent orthodontic complications caused by risk factors observed in the first years of life
abstract: Primary prevention strategies for oral health are an essential public health priority. Pediatricians have frequent contact with families during routine preventive visits in the early years of a child's life and are in an ideal and unique position to advise families on the prevention of oral disease in their children. Primary prevention is always recommended in very young children, to promote positive outcomes during childhood and later adulthood. The knowledge that pediatricians acquire about orofacial growth can improve the implementation and eventual success of a preventive program. In view of the widespread lack of orthodontic knowledge among pediatricians, this article describes the most common and distinctive symptoms that frequently appear in the early stages of a child's development and are easily detectable by clinicians. It is difficult to define preventive strategies to avoid malocclusion due to its multifactorial origin. However, there are some recognized behaviors that should be discouraged to allow for ideal craniofacial development and some that require early orthodontic referral. The following disorders are easy to diagnose by the pediatrician or parents and represent conditions in which early intervention might be appropriate to prevent possible future orofacial dysfunction: different sucking habits that persist beyond 3 years of age, mouth breathing and significant deviations from the established norms for the eruption of teeth. Early referral to a pediatric dentist or orthodontist is suggested when any of these conditions are observed. In general, measures to prevent malocclusion should be based on providing good incentives to promote normal growth and development of the face and the elimination of possible interferences that could damage these processes.

title: Clinical reminders attached to echocardiography reports of patients with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction increase beta-blocker use: a randomized trial.
abstract: Background: Although ß-blockers are known to prolong survival in patients with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction, they are often underutilized. We hypothesized that a reminder attached to the echocardiography report would increase the use of ß-blockers in patients with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction. Methods and Results: We randomized 1,546 consecutive patients with a left ventricular ejection fraction <45% detected on echocardiography in 1 of 3 laboratories to a ß-blocker reminder or no reminder. Patients were excluded from the analysis if they died within 30 days of randomization (n=89), did not receive medications through the Veterans Affairs system after 30 days (n=180), or underwent echocardiography at >1 laboratory (n=6). The primary outcome was prescription of an oral ß-blocker between 1 and 9 months after randomization. The mean age of the 1271 patients included was 69 years; Sixty percent had a history of heart failure and 51% were receiving beta-blocker therapy at the time of echocardiography. More patients randomized to reminder received a subsequent ß-blocker prescription (74%, 458 of 621) compared with those randomized to no reminder (66%, 428 of 650; P = .002). The effect of the reminder was not significantly different for subgroups based on patient location (inpatient versus outpatient) or prior ß-blocker use. Conclusions: A reminder attached to the echocardiography report increased ß-blocker use in patients with systolic function. of the left ventricle depressed.

title: Clinical research in interventional pain management techniques: the clinician's point of view
abstract: Interventional pain management techniques are considered for patients whose pain is refractory to conventional treatment. According to evidence-based medicine (EBM) guidelines, the highest level of evidence about the efficacy and safety of a treatment is generated from high-quality randomized controlled trials and systematic reviews. A randomized controlled trial is defined as an experiment that determines the influence of an intervention on the natural history of the disease, which means that the comparison group must receive a placebo, which is a sham intervention in the case of interventional techniques of pain management. The systematic review summarizes the results of the available information in a structured way. When randomized controlled trials are available, observational studies are often ruled out. As new information about a treatment becomes available, the perceived value may change, thus determining the survival time of clinical evidence. This survival time is no different when based on randomized or nonrandomized studies. Inclusion criteria are an important component of the randomized controlled trial and are designed to test a treatment in a homogeneous population of patients. Since interventional pain management techniques are primarily used for the treatment of spinal pain, it must be emphasized that there is no gold standard for diagnosis. This lack of validated standard diagnostic procedures is at the origin of different patient selection criteria, which makes the interpretation of the different randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses very difficult. Furthermore, extrapolation from randomized controlled trials with carefully selected patient populations to daily practice is a major problem. Randomized controlled trials in interventional pain management techniques are often shown to be underpowered, which can be attributed to the difficulty of motivating patients and referring physicians to participate in a trial in which there is a 50% chances of receiving a placebo or sham treatment for intractable pain. In addition, the validity of the sham intervention as a reflection of the natural course of the disease is questioned. It is stated that any new technique must prove to be at least as effective as the best available treatment option, which offers the possibility of comparing two groups, both receiving active treatment. The gold standard treatment may be pharmacological or a rehabilitation program (cognitive behavioral) in which case blinding becomes a problem. Large observational studies with a cohort or case-control design have been shown not to systematically overestimate the magnitude of associations between exposure and outcome compared with results from randomized controlled trials. There is an urgent need for guidelines on the conduct of prospective cohort trials that should be designed to confirm or refute anecdotal findings from retrospective studies.

title: Clinical risk management in psychiatry
abstract: This work deals with suicide and violence towards others, which are the current issues of greatest concern in risk management in mental health services. The majority of psychiatric claims handled by the Harvard Medical Institutions Risk Management Foundation over a twelve-year period involved suicide, attempted suicide, or violence toward self or others.

title: Prediction of clinical risk of preeclampsia in nulliparous women: development of a model in an international prospective cohort
abstract: OBJECTIVES To develop a predictive model for preeclampsia based on clinical risk factors for nulliparous women and to identify a subgroup at higher risk, in whom specialist referral might be indicated. DESIGN Prospective multicenter cohort. SETTING Five centers in Auckland, New Zealand"; Adelaide, Australia; Manchester and London, UK"; and Cork, Republic of Ireland. PARTICIPANTS 3572 "healthy" nulliparous women with a singleton pregnancy from a large international study";" data on pregnancy outcome were available for 3529 (99%). MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE Pre-eclampsia defined as Ã¢â€°Â¥ 140 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure Ã¢â€°Â¥ 90 mm Hg, or both, on at least two occasions four hours apart after 20 weeks of gestation, but before the onset of labor or postpartum, with either proteinuria or any multisystem complication. Premature preeclampsia was defined as women with preeclampsia who gave birth before 37 (+0) weeks of gestation. In stepwise logistic regression, the comparison group were women without preeclampsia. RESULTS Of the 3,529 women, 186 (5.3%) developed preeclampsia, including 47 (1.3%) with premature preeclampsia. Clinical risk factors at 14-16 weeks' gestation were age, mean blood pressure, body mass index (BMI), family history of preeclampsia, family history of coronary heart disease, maternal birth weight, and vaginal bleeding for at least five days. Factors associated with reduced risk were a previous single miscarriage with the same partner, taking at least 12 months to conceive, high fruit intake, smoking, and alcohol use in the first trimester. The area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC), under internal validation, was 0.71. The addition of uterine artery Doppler indices did not improve performance (internal validation AUC 0.71). A framework for referral to a specialist was developed based on a model-generated probability of preeclampsia of at least 15% or an abnormal uterine artery Doppler waveform in a subset of women with unique risk factors. Nine percent of nulliparous women would be referred for specialist opinion, of whom 21% would develop pre-eclampsia. The relative risk of developing pre-eclampsia and premature pre-eclampsia in women referred to a specialist compared with standard care was 5.5 and 12.2, respectively. CONCLUSIONS The ability to predict preeclampsia in healthy nulliparous women using the clinical phenotype is modest and requires external validation in other populations. If validated, it could provide a personalized clinical risk profile for nulliparous women to which biomarkers could be added. Test record ACTRN12607000551493.

title: Cluster randomized controlled trial of personalized interventions to improve the management of urinary tract infections in women and sore throat.
abstract: Objective: To assess the effectiveness of tailored interventions to implement guidelines for female urinary tract infections and sore throat. Design: Pre-post trial, cluster randomized, unblinded. Setting: 142 general practices in Norway. Participants: 72 practices received interventions to implement urinary tract infection guidelines and 70 practices received interventions to implement sore throat guidelines, serving as controls for each other. 59 practices in the urinary tract infection group and 61 practices in the sore throat group completed the study. Outcomes were measured in 16,939 visits for sore throat and 9,887 visits for urinary tract infection. Interventions: Interventions were developed to overcome identified barriers to implementing the guidelines. The main components of the personalized interventions were patient educational material, computer-based decision support and reminders, an increase in the telephone consultation fee, and interactive courses for general practitioners and practice assistants Main outcome measures: Changes in Rates of antibiotic use, laboratory tests, and telephone consultations Results: Patients in the sore throat group were 3% less likely to receive antibiotics after the intervention. Women with symptoms of urinary tract infection in the intervention group were 5.1% less likely to request a laboratory test. No significant differences were found between groups for the other outcomes. Large variation was found between the included practices in rates of antibiotic prescribing, use of laboratory tests and telephone consultations, and in the degree of change for all three outcomes. change of practice

title: Cluster randomized trial of a multifaceted primary care decision support intervention for hereditary breast cancer risk.
abstract: Bottom. GPs are increasingly expected to meet the needs of patients concerned about their risk of hereditary breast cancer, but may lack the skills or confidence to use complex management guidelines. We developed a multifaceted, evidence-based intervention aimed at promoting confidence and skills in this area. Goal. To assess the effectiveness of intervention in improving GP confidence in managing patients concerned about genetic risk of breast cancer. Methods. Design. Cluster randomized controlled trial. Around. General practice in the Grampian region of Scotland. Subjects. GPs and patients referred for genetic counseling for breast cancer risk. The main measures. Self-reported confidence of GPs in four activities related to genetics"; referral rates of patients with high genetic risk"; and the referred patients' understanding of cancer risk factors. Results. No statistically significant differences were observed between the intervention and control arms in the primary or secondary outcomes. A possible effect of the intervention on the proportion of patients referred who were at high risk could not be ruled out. Only a small proportion of intervention physicians attended the educational session, were aware of the software, or used it in practice. Conclusions. We found no convincing evidence for the effectiveness of the intervention, probably reflecting barriers to its use in routine practice.

title: Cluster Randomized Trial of a Multitiered Evidence-Based Quality Improvement Approach to Tailor VA Patient-Aligned Care Teams to the Needs of Women Veterans
abstract: Background The Veterans Health Administration (VA) has embarked on a major initiative to transform care through the implementation of Patient Aligned Care Teams (PACTs). Based on the concept of the patient-centered medical home (PCMH), PACT aims to improve access, continuity, coordination, and comprehensiveness through the use of team-driven, patient-focused care. the patient. However, the initial implementation guidance did not consider how VA should adapt PACT to meet the needs of special populations, such as female veterans (WVs). The numerical minority of WVs in VA health care settings (approximately 7Â¨C8% of patrons) creates logistical challenges in providing comprehensive gender-sensitive care. The main objective of this study is to test an evidence-based quality improvement (EBQI) approach to tailor PACT to the needs of VMs, incorporating comprehensive primary care services and gender-specific care. in gender-sensitive settings, thereby accelerating the achievement of the PACT principles for women (Women's Health (WH)-PACT). Methods/Design EBQI is a systematic approach to developing a multilevel clinical research partnership that engages senior organizational leaders and local quality improvement (QI) teams in adapting and implementing new models of care in the context of prior evidence and local practical conditions, with researchers providing technical support, formative feedback and internship facilitation. In a 12-site cluster-randomized trial, we will assess the achievement of the WH-PACT model using surveys of patients, providers, staff, and practices, as well as graph-based and secondary administrative data analyses. We will explore the impacts of receiving WH-PACT care on quality of care and chronic disease prevention, health status, patient satisfaction and experience of care, provider experience, utilization, and costs. Using mixed methods, we will assess "before and after" practice settings; we will document EBQI activities conducted at participating facilities and their relationship with provider/staff and team actions/attitudes; we will document WH-PACT implementation;" and examine barriers/enablers to implementation of the EBQI-supported WH-PACT through a combination of semi-structured interviews and monthly narratives of formative progress and administrative data. Discussion The lack of comprehensive gender-sensitive care has demonstrated consequences for the technical quality and qualifications of care among VMs and may contribute to decisions to continue using or seek care elsewhere under the Affordable Care Act We hypothesize that tailoring PACT implementation through EBQI can improve the experience and quality of care on many levels.

title: Cluster randomized trials for pharmacy practice research
abstract: Introduction Cluster randomized trials (CRTs) are now the gold standard in health services research, including pharmacy-based interventions. Studies of behavior, epidemiology, lifestyle modifications, educational programs, and health care models are using the strengths of randomized cluster analysis. Methodology The key property of CRTs is the unit of randomization (groups), which may be different from the unit of analysis (individual). The size of the sample of subjects and, ideally, the number of clusters is determined by the ratio of between-cluster and within-cluster variability. The correlation between participants recruited from the same group is known as the intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC). Generally, having more clusters with smaller ICC values will lead to smaller sample sizes. When selecting groups, stratification before randomization may be helpful in minimizing imbalances between study arms. Participant recruitment methods may differ from other types of randomized trials, as a behavioral intervention cannot always be blinded. When to use CRT can produce results that are relevant to making "real world" decisions. CRTs are often used in nontherapeutic intervention studies (eg, change in practice guidelines). The advantages of CRT design in pharmaceutical research have been to avoid contamination and generalization of results. A large CRT that studied collaborative physician-pharmacist management of hypertension is used as an example of a CRT in this manuscript. The trial, titled Collaboration Between Pharmacists and Physicians to Improve Outcomes Now (CAPTION), was implemented in primary care practices in the United States for hypertensive patients. Limitations Limitations of the CRT design include the need for a large number of clusters, high costs, increased training, increased monitoring, and statistical complexity.

title: Cluster randomized controlled trial of computer-based decision support for selecting long-term antithrombotic therapy after acute ischemic stroke.
abstract: Background: Identifying appropriate long-term antithrombotic therapy after acute ischemic stroke is a challenging area in which computer-based decision support can help. Objective: To assess the influence on prescribing practice of a computer-based decision support system (CDSS) that provided patient-specific estimates of expected rates of vascular ischemic and hemorrhagic events under each potential antithrombotic therapy. Design: cluster randomized controlled trial. Methods: We recruited patients presenting for a first investigation for ischemic stroke or TIA symptoms, excluding those with a poor prognosis or significant contraindication to anticoagulation. After observation of routine prescribing practice (6 months) at each hospital, centers were randomized for 6 months to control (observed routine practice) or intervention (observed practice while CDSS provided patient-specific information). We compared, between control and intervention centers, the risk reduction (estimated by the CDSS) in vascular ischemic and hemorrhagic events achieved by long-term antithrombotic therapy, and the proportions of subjects prescribed the therapy. optimum identified by the CDSS. Results: Sixteen hospitals recruited 1952 subjects. When the CDSS provided information, the mean relative risk reduction achieved by prescribing increased by 2.7 percentage units (95% CI -0.3 to 5.7) and the odds ratio for prescribing the optimal treatment was from 1.32 (0.83 to 1.80). Around 55% (5/9) of physicians believed that the CDSS had influenced their prescribing. Conclusions: Cluster randomized trials provide excellent frameworks for evaluating new methods of clinical management. Our CDSS was feasible to implement and acceptable to clinicians, but did not substantially influence antithrombotic drug prescribing practice after acute ischemic stroke.

title: COACH Trial: A Randomized Controlled Trial of Cardiovascular Disease Risk Reduction of Nurse Practitioners/Community Health Workers in Urban Community Health Centers: Rationale and Design
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite well-publicized guidelines on the appropriate management of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and type 2 diabetes, implementation of risk reduction practices remains poor. This article describes the rationale and design of a randomized controlled clinical trial evaluating the efficacy of a comprehensive CVD risk reduction program delivered by nurse practitioner (NP)/community health worker (CHW) teams versus enhanced usual care for improve the proportion of patients in urban community health centers who reach the target levels recommended by national guidelines for lipids, blood pressure, HbA1c, and prescription of appropriate medications. METHODS: The COACH (Community Outreach and Cardiovascular Health) trial is a randomized controlled trial in which patients at federally qualified community health centers were randomly assigned to one of two groups: comprehensive intensive management of risk factors; CVD risk over one year by a NP/CHW Team or an enhanced usual care control group. RESULTS: A total of 3899 patients were evaluated for eligibility and 525 were randomized. The groups were comparable at baseline for sociodemographic and clinical characteristics, with the exception of statistically significant differences in total cholesterol and hemoglobin A1c. CONCLUSIONS: This study is a novel amalgamation of multilevel, interdisciplinary strategies to translate highly effective therapies into low-income, federally funded health centers serving patients who bear a disproportionate burden of CVD, type 2 diabetes, and CVD risk factors. not controlled. The impact of such a community clinic-based intervention is potentially enormous.

title: Code of good practice for the clinical evaluation of authorized medicinal products in general practice
abstract: KIE: The British Medical Association, the Royal Society of General Practitioners and the British Pharmaceutical Industry Association have jointly developed a code of practice for the clinical evaluation of licensed medicines by general practitioners. The new code, reproduced in full here, outlines the reasons drug evaluations are needed outside of hospitals; defines the roles of pharmaceutical companies, ethics committees and researchers; lists items that should be included in research protocols; and offers guidelines on confidentiality, publication of results and remuneration.

title: Cognitive behavioral therapy for chronic insomnia: systematic review and meta-analysis.
abstract: Background: Because psychological approaches are likely to produce sustained benefits without the risk of tolerance or adverse effects associated with pharmacological approaches, cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-i) is now commonly recommended as a first-line treatment. for chronic insomnia. Purpose: To determine the efficacy of CBT-i on daily measures of nighttime sleep in adults with chronic insomnia. DATA SOURCES: Searches of MEDLINE, EMBASE, PsycINFO, CINAHL, Cochrane Library, and PubMed Clinical Queries from inception to March 31, 2015, supplemented by manual selection. Study selection: Randomized controlled trials evaluating the efficacy of face-to-face multimodal i-CBT compared with inactive comparators on nighttime sleep in adults with chronic insomnia. Studies of insomnia comorbid with medical, sleep, or psychiatric disorders were excluded. Data Extraction: Two reviewers independently assessed study characteristics, quality and data. The main outcome measures were sleep onset latency (SOL), wakefulness after sleep onset (WASO), total sleep time (TST), and sleep efficiency (SE%). Data Synthesis: Among 292 citations and 91 full-text articles reviewed, 20 studies (1162 participants [64% women";" mean age, 56 years]) were included. CBT-i approaches incorporated at least 3 of the following: cognitive therapy, stimulus control, sleep restriction, sleep hygiene, and relaxation. At the post-treatment time point, SOL improved by 19.03 (95% CI, 14.12 to 23.93) minutes, WASO improved by 26.00 (CI, 15.48 to 36.52) minutes, TST improved by 7.61 (CI, ≥0.51 to 15.74) minutes and SE % improved by 9.91% (CI, 8.09% to 11.73%). The changes seemed to hold at later time points. No adverse outcomes were reported. Limitation: Narrow inclusion criteria limited applicability to patients with comorbid insomnia and other sleep problems, and the precision of estimates at later time points was less clear. Conclusion: i-CBT is an effective treatment for adults with chronic insomnia, with clinically significant effect sizes. Main funding source: none. (PROSPERO registration number: CRD42012002863)

title: Cognitive behavioral therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in women
abstract: Context The prevalence of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is high among women who have served in the military, but no previous study has evaluated PTSD treatment in this population. Previous research suggests that cognitive behavioral therapy is a particularly effective treatment for PTSD. Objective To compare prolonged exposure, a type of cognitive behavioral therapy, with present-focused therapy, a supportive intervention, for the treatment of PTSD. Design, Setting, and Participants A randomized controlled trial of female veterans (n=277) and active duty personnel (n=7) with PTSD recruited from 9 VA medical centers, 2 VA readjustment counseling centers, and 1 military hospital since August 2002 through October 2005. Intervention participants were randomly assigned to receive prolonged exposure (n = 141) or present-focused therapy (n = 143), administered according to standard protocols in 10 weekly 90-minute sessions. Main outcome measures Posttraumatic stress disorder symptom severity was the primary outcome. Comorbid symptoms, functioning, and quality of life were secondary outcomes. Blinded assessors collected data before and after treatment and at 3- and 6-month follow-up. Results Women who received prolonged exposure experienced a greater reduction in PTSD symptoms relative to women who received present-focused therapy (effect size, 0.27"; P = .03). was more likely than the present-focused therapy group to no longer meet diagnostic criteria for PTSD (41.0% vs. 27.8%; odds ratio, 1.80; 95% confidence interval, 1.10-2.96; P = .01) and achieving complete remission (15.2% vs. 6.9%; odds ratio, 2.43; 95% confidence interval, 1.10-5.37;" P = .01). The effects were consistent over time in longitudinal analyses, although in cross-sectional analyses, most differences occurred immediately after treatment. Conclusions Prolonged exposure is an effective treatment for PTSD in female veterans and active duty military personnel. Extended exposure is feasible to implement in a variety of clinical settings.

title: Cognitive behavioral therapy versus zopiclone for the treatment of chronic primary insomnia in older adults
abstract: Context Insomnia is a common condition in older adults and is associated with a number of adverse medical, social, and psychological consequences. Previous research has suggested beneficial results of psychological and pharmacological treatments, but blinded placebo-controlled trials comparing the effects of these treatments are lacking. Objective To examine the short- and long-term clinical efficacy of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and pharmacological treatment in older adults experiencing chronic primary insomnia. Design, Setting, and Participants A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of 46 adults (mean age, 60.8 years; 22 women) with chronic primary insomnia conducted between January 2004 and December 2005 in a single outpatient of a norwegian university clinic for adults and elderly patients CBT intervention (sleep hygiene, sleep restriction, stimulus control, cognitive therapy and relaxation; n = 18), sleep medication (7.5 mg zopiclone every night; n = 16) or placebo medication (n = 12). The total duration of treatment was 6 weeks, and the 2 active treatments were followed up for 6 months. Main outcome measures Clinical ambulatory polysomnographic data and sleep diary were used to determine total wake time, total sleep time, sleep efficiency, and slowness. undulating sleep (only assessed by polysomnography) at all 3 assessment points. Results CBT resulted in better short-term and long-term results compared to zopiclone on 3 of 4 outcome measures. For most outcomes, zopiclone did not differ from placebo. Participants receiving CBT improved their sleep efficiency from 81.4% at pretreatment to 90.1% at 6-month follow-up compared to a decrease from 82.3% to 81.9% in the zopiclone group. Participants in the CBT group spent significantly more time in slow-wave sleep (stages 3 and 4) compared to those in other groups, and spent less time awake at night. Total sleep time was similar in the 3 groups; at 6 months, patients who received CBT had better sleep efficiency using polysomnography than those who took zopiclone. Conclusion These results suggest that CBT-based interventions are superior to zopiclone treatment in both the short and long term. Long-term treatment of insomnia in older adults.

title: Cognitive Bias Elimination 2: Impediments and Strategies for Change
abstract: In a companion article, we proposed that cognitive bias reduction is an essential skill for developing sound clinical reasoning to mitigate the incidence of diagnostic failure. We review the origins of cognitive biases and some proposed mechanisms for how debiasing processes might work. In this article, we first outline a general outline of how cognitive change occurs and the constraints that may apply. We review a variety of individual factors, many of them biases themselves, that can be impediments to change. We then examine the main strategies that have been developed in the social sciences and in medicine to achieve the elimination of cognitive and affective bias, including the important concept of forced functions. The abundance and rich variety of approaches that exist in the literature and in individual clinical domains illustrate the difficulties inherent in achieving cognitive change and also the need for such interventions. Continuous cognitive elimination is arguably the most important characteristic of the critical thinker and well-calibrated mind. We describe three groups of suggested future interventions: educational strategies, workplace strategies, and strength functions. We emphasize the importance of environmental and contextual influences on the quality of individual decision-making and the need to address factors known to impair decision-maker calibration. We also emphasize the importance of the introduction of these concepts and the corollary development of training in critical thinking at the undergraduate level in medical education.

title: Elimination of cognitive bias through sparklines in clinical data screens
abstract: Sparklines, embedded contextual information graphics, can help reduce diagnostic errors by highlighting trends in data, simplifying cognitive tasks, and providing context for decision making. Examples applied to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, cardiac catheterization, and pediatric viral disease illustrate the concept. Sparklines are ideal in situations where limited textual data representations obfuscate interpretation, the chart helps interpret the data, and the chart guides decision making.

title: Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia in cancer patients
abstract: Sleep-wake disorders, particularly insomnia, are among the most prevalent and distressing symptoms experienced by cancer patients. As a result of extensive interdisciplinary research conducted since 2000, cognitive behavioral therapy is now considered the standard of care for the treatment of insomnia in the general population and has also been upgraded to "probably effective" in the Oncology Nursing Society Putting Evidence In practice weight of the category of evidence. Cognitive behavioral therapy is a multi-component psychological and behavioral treatment designed to eliminate factors that perpetuate insomnia. The most commonly used strategies are stimulus control, sleep restriction and relaxation therapies, paradoxical intention, sleep hygiene, and cognitive restructuring. Although this recommendation for the treatment of insomnia has been well publicized, the nursing literature has not effectively translated the theories and principles of cognitive behavioral therapy into practical guidelines or considerations for use by oncology nurses. and advanced professionals. This article attempts to demystify cognitive behavioral therapy and provide nurses at different levels of practice with a foundation from which to evaluate and potentially administer this promising intervention for insomnia.

title: Cognitive-behavioral therapy, imipramine, or its combination for panic disorder
abstract: Context Panic disorder (PD) can be treated with medication, psychosocial intervention, or both, but the relative and combined efficacies have not been impartially evaluated. Objective To assess whether pharmacological and psychosocial therapies for PD are each more effective than placebo, whether one treatment is more effective than the other, and whether combination therapy is more effective than either therapy alone. Design and setting A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial conducted in 4 anxiety research clinics from May 1991 to April 1998. Patients A total of 312 PD patients were included in the analysis. Interventions Patients were randomized to receive imipramine, up to 300 mg/d, alone (n=83); cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) alone (n=77); placebo alone (n=24); CBT plus imipramine (n=65); or CBT plus placebo (n = 63). The patients were treated weekly for 3 months (acute phase); then responders were seen monthly for 6 months (maintenance phase) and then followed up for 6 months after treatment discontinuation. Main outcome measures Response to treatment based on Panic Disorder Severity Scale (PDSS) and Clinical Global Impression Scale (CGI) by treatment group Results Both imipramine and CBT were significantly superior to placebo for the treatment phase. acute treatment as assessed by PDSS (response rates for intention-to-treat [ITT] analysis, 45.8%, 48.7%, and 21.7%; P = .05 and P = .03, respectively ), but were not significantly different for CGI (48.2%, 53.9%, and 37.5%, respectively). After 6 months of maintenance, imipramine and CBT were significantly more effective than placebo for r Both the PDSS (response rates, 37.8%, 39.5%, and 13.0%, respectively; P = .02 for both) and the CGI (37.8%, 42.1%, and 13.0%, 0%, respectively). Among responders, imipramine produced a higher quality response. The acute response rate for combination therapy was 60.3% for PDSS and 64.1% for CGI; none were significantly different from the other groups. The 6-month maintenance response rate for combination therapy was 57.1% for PDSS (P=0.04 vs. CBT alone and P=0.03 vs. imipramine alone) and 56.3% for for CGI (P = 0.03 vs. imipramine alone), but not significantly better than CBT plus placebo in any analysis. Six months after treatment discontinuation, in ITT analysis, CGI response rates were 41.0% for CBT plus placebo, 31.9% for CBT alone, 19.7% for imipramine alone , 13% for placebo and 26.3% for CBT combined with imipramine. Conclusions The combination of imipramine and CBT appeared to confer a limited advantage acutely, but a more substantial advantage at the end of maintenance. Each treatment worked well immediately after treatment and during maintenance; CBT appeared durable at follow-up.

title: Collaborative care for depressed patients with chronic medical conditions: a randomized trial in Puerto Rico
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This study examined whether a collaborative care model for depression would improve clinical and functional outcomes for depressed patients with chronic general medical conditions in primary care practices in Puerto Rico. METHODS: A total of 179 primary care patients with major depression and chronic general medical conditions were randomly assigned to receive collaborative care or usual care. The collaborative care intervention involved increased collaboration between clinicians, mental health specialists, and care managers along with depression-specific treatment guidelines, patient education, and follow-up. In usual care, study staff informed the patient and physician of the diagnosis and encouraged patients to discuss treatment options with their physician. Depression severity was assessed with the Hopkins Symptom Checklist";" social functioning was assessed using the short 36-item form. RESULTS: Compared with usual care, collaborative care significantly reduced depressive symptoms and improved social functioning within six months of randomization. Integrating collaborative care into primary care practices greatly increased the use of mental health services by depressed patients. CONCLUSIONS: Collaborative care significantly improved clinical symptoms and functional status of depressed patients with coexisting chronic general medical conditions receiving treatment for depression in primary care practices in Puerto Rico. These findings highlight the promise of the collaborative care model to strengthen the relationship between mental health and primary care services in Puerto Rico.

title: Collaborative management to achieve treatment guidelines. Impact on depression in primary care
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To compare the effectiveness of a multifaceted intervention in patients with depression in primary care with the effectiveness of "usual care" by the primary care physician. DESIGN: A randomized controlled trial among primary care patients with major depression or minor depression. PATIENTS: Over a 12-month period, a total of 217 primary care patients who were recognized as depressed by their primary care physicians and were willing to take antidepressant medication were randomized, with 91 patients meeting criteria for major depression and 126 of minor depression. INTERVENTIONS: Intervention patients received increased intensity and frequency of visits during the first 4 to 6 weeks of treatment (visits 1 and 3 with a primary care physician, visits 2 and 4 with a psychiatrist) and continued monitoring of adherence to medication regimens during the continuation and maintenance phases of treatment. Patient education at these visits was supplemented by videotaped and written material. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Primary outcome measures included short-term (30 days) and long-term (90 days) use of antidepressant medication at guideline dosage levels, satisfaction with general depression care, and medication antidepressant, and reduction of depressive symptoms. RESULTS: In patients with major depression, the intervention group had greater adherence than usual care controls to the appropriate dose of antidepressant medication for 90 days or more (75.5% vs. 50.0%"; P < 0.01), were more likely to rate the quality of care they received for depression as good to excellent (93.0% vs. 75.0%; P < .03), and were more likely to rate antidepressant medications as helping to help a lot (88.1% vs. 63.3%; P < Seventy-four percent of major depressive intervention patients showed an improvement of 50% or more on the symptoms checklist 90 depressive symptoms compared to 43.8% of controls (p < 0.01), and intervention patients also demonstrated significant improvement. over time compared to controls (P < 0.004). In patients with minor depression, the intervention group had significantly greater adherence than controls to the appropriate dose of antidepressant medication for 90 days or more (79.7% vs. 40.0%). 3%; P < 0.001) and more often rated antidepressant medication as very helpful (81.8% vs. 61.4%; P < 0.02). However, no significant differences were found between the intervention and control groups in the percentage of patients who were satisfied with the care they received for depression (94.4% vs 89.3%), in the percentage who experienced a decrease 50% or greater in depressive symptoms, or decrease in depressive symptoms over time CONCLUSION: A multifaceted intervention consisting of collaborative management by the primary care physician and a consultant psychiatrist, intensive patient education, and surveillance of continuous antidepressant medication refills improved adherence to antidepressant regimens in patients with major and minor depression. outcomes in patients with major but not minor depression.

title: Enhancing Collaborative Practice for Childhood Obesity in Rural Clinics: The Healthy Eating and Active Living Telehealth Community of Practice (HEALTH COP)
abstract: This study evaluated the impact of participation in a virtual quality improvement (QI) learning network on adherence to clinical guidelines for childhood obesity prevention in rural clinics. A total of 7 primary care clinics in rural California included in the Healthy Eating and Active Living TeleHealth Community of Practice and 288 children seen at these clinics for well-child care participated in this prospective observational pre-post study. . The clinics participated in a virtual QI learning network for 9 months to implement best practices and exchange strategies for improvement. Post-intervention, documentation of weight assessment and counseling increased significantly. Children who received care from clinicians who led implementation of the intervention at their clinic showed significant improvements in nutrition and physical activity. Virtual QI learning networks in geographically dispersed clinics can significantly increase physician compliance with childhood obesity guidelines and improve access to recommended care for rural and underserved children.

title: Collective Action for Implementation: A Realistic Assessment of Organizational Collaboration in Health Care
abstract: Background Increasingly, it is suggested that translation gaps could be eradicated or reduced by bringing research users and producers closer together, a theory that remains largely unproven. This document reports on a national study to fill a gap in the evidence on the conditions, processes, and outcomes related to collaboration and implementation. Methods A longitudinal realist evaluation using multiple qualitative methods case studies was carried out with three Collaborations for Leadership in Applied Health Research in Care (England). Data was collected in four rounds of theory development, refinement, and testing. More than 200 participants participated in semi-structured interviews, non-participant observations of events and meetings, and stakeholder engagement. A combined process of inductive and deductive data analysis focused on proposal refinement and iterative testing during rounds of data collection. Results The quality of existing relationships between higher education and the local health service, and views about whether the implementation was a collaborative act, created a dependency path. Where the implementation was perceived to be down and there was a lack of organizational connections, this resulted in a focus on knowledge production and transfer, rather than co-production. Collaboration architectures were counterproductive because they did not facilitate connectivity and emphasized professional and epistemic limits. A more distributed leadership was associated with a greater potential for participation. The creation of cross-border roles was the most visible investment in implementation, and credible people in these roles resulted in cross-border work, facilitation and direct impacts. The academic-practical gap played strongly as a context for the motivation to participate, in the sense that "what's in it for me" resulted in varying levels of engagement along a cooperation-collaboration continuum. Learning within and between collaborations was uneven depending on attention to evaluation. Conclusions These collaborations did not come out of nowhere and took time to learn and develop. Its life cycle began with its position of collaboration, knowledge and implementation. The most impactful attempts at collective action in implementation might be determined by the deliberate alignment of a number of characteristics, including critical relationships, vision, values, structures and processes, and views about the nature of collaboration and the implementation.

title: Colonoscopy adoption for high-risk people with a family history of colorectal neoplasia: a multicenter randomized trial of personalized counseling versus standard information.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Colonoscopic screening is recommended for first-degree relatives of patients diagnosed with colorectal cancer (CRC) or colorectal adenomatous polyps (CAP) before the age of 60 years. This has the potential to reduce CRC-related morbidity and mortality, but acceptance is currently inadequate. METHODS: The aim of the study was to compare the effectiveness of standard information versus a personalized nurse-led intervention designed to promote acceptance of colonoscopy screening by siblings of patients with CRC or PDA. A randomized controlled trial was performed. Digestive surgeons and gastroenterologists recruited index patients who developed CRC or CAP before the age of 60 years. All index patients received standard screening information for their siblings, consistent with current guidelines. Centralized computerized randomization of the index patients resulted in all their siblings being assigned to the same group, intervention or control. The personalized intervention focused first on the index patient, to help him pass on information to his siblings. The nurse then provided the siblings with personalized information based on their responses to a self-questionnaire that explored health behaviors derived from psychosocial models of prevention. The brothers were then given a personalized information booklet to take to their regular doctor. The primary endpoint was the rate of documented colonoscopy performed in siblings within 1 year after diagnosis of the index patient. The intention-to-treat analysis included siblings who refused to participate in the study. Statistical analysis was adjusted for intrafamily correlation. RESULTS: A total of 304 siblings of 125 index patients were included: 160 in the intervention group and 144 in the control group. The colonoscopy acceptance rate among siblings was 56.3% in the intervention group and 35.4% in the control group (P = 0.0027).
