The respective rates after exclusion of rejections were 69.2% and 37.0% (P < 0.0001). More lesions were detected in the intervention group (1 invasive cancer and 11 advanced adenomas vs. 5 advanced adenomas";" P = 0.022). CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrates the efficacy of a personalized nurse-led intervention designed to promote colonoscopy screening acceptance by siblings of patients diagnosed with CRC or CAP before the age of 60 years. Such personalized interventions that also involve clinicians should help reduce CRC-related mortality.

title: Combined diet and physical activity promotion programs to prevent type 2 diabetes among people at increased risk: a systematic review for the Community Preventive Services Task Force.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Trials have shown the efficacy of rigorous diet and physical activity promotion programs in reducing the incidence of diabetes and improving glycemic measures in adults at increased risk of type 2 diabetes. diet and physical activity for people at increased risk of type 2 diabetes, primarily to reduce the risk of diabetes and lower body weight and blood glucose. Data sources: MEDLINE, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, CAB Abstracts, Global Health, and Ovid Health-STAR from 1991 to February 27, 2015, without language restriction. Study selection: 8 investigators selected articles for single-arm or comparative studies of combined diet and physical activity promotion programs with at least 2 sessions for at least 3 months in participants at increased risk of type 2 diabetes. Data Extraction: 7 investigators extracted data on study design"; descriptions of participants, interventions, and outcomes"; and outcomes and assessed study quality. Data Synthesis: 53 studies (30 diet and physical activity promotion programs versus usual care, 13 more intensive versus less intensive programs, and 13 individual programs) evaluated 66 programs. Compared with usual care, diet and physical activity promotion programs reduced the incidence of type 2 diabetes (relative risk [RR], 0.59 [95% CI, 0.52 to 0.66]) (16 studies), decreased body weight (net change, -2.2% [CI, -2.9% to -1.4%]) (24 studies), and fasting blood glucose (net change, -0.12 mmol/L [-2.2 mg/dL] [CI, -0.20 to -0.05 mmol/L {-3.6 to -0.9 mg/dL}]) (17 studies), and improved other cardiometabolic risk factors. Evidence of clinical events was limited. The more intensive programs were more effective. Limitations: Wide variation in diet and physical activity promotion programs limited identification of characteristics most relevant to efficacy. Evidence on clinical outcomes and in children was scant. Conclusion: Combined programs to promote diet and physical activity are effective in reducing the incidence of diabetes and improving cardiometabolic risk factors in people at higher risk. More intensive programs are more effective.

title: Combining intensive practice nurse advice or brief general practitioner advice with varenicline for smoking cessation in primary care: study protocol of a pragmatic randomized controlled trial
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The combination of behavioral support and pharmacotherapy is more effective for smoking cessation and is recommended in clinical guidelines. Although general practitioner smoking cessation assistance can be effective, dissemination of clinical practice guidelines and efforts to improve skills have not led to the routine provision of smoking cessation advice among clinicians. generals. Intensive practice nurse counseling could contribute to better smoking cessation rates in primary care. However, the effectiveness of intensive advice from a nurse practitioner versus usual care from a general practitioner in combination with varenicline is still unknown. MATERIALS AND METHODS: A pragmatic randomized controlled trial comparing: (a) intensive individual counseling provided by a nurse practitioner and (b) brief counseling provided by a general practitioner";" both groups received open-label varenicline for 12 weeks. A minimum of 272 daily smoking adult participants were recruited and treated in their routine primary care setting. The primary outcome was defined as prolonged abstinence from week 9 to week 26, validated biochemically by exhaled carbon monoxide. Data were analyzed blinded according to the intention-to-treat principle, and participants with missing data on their smoking status at follow-up were counted as smokers. Secondary outcomes included: one-year prolonged abstinence, short-term incremental cost-effectiveness, medication adherence, and baseline predictors of successful smoking cessation. DISCUSSION: This trial is the first to provide scientific evidence on the effectiveness, cost-effectiveness, and potential mechanisms of action of intensive practice nursing advice combined with varenicline under real-life conditions. This article explains the methodology of the essay and discusses the pragmatic and/or explanatory aspects of the design. TEST REGISTRATION: Dutch test registration NTR3067.

title: Comfort First: an evaluation of a procedural pain management program for children with cancer
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Comfort First Program (CFP) provides children and their caregivers with early procedural pain management intervention to reduce procedural pain and distress. This study assessed whether the CFP was meeting its goals and effectively implementing the Royal Australasian College of Physicians pediatric pain management guidelines. METHODS: The study was conducted as a cross-sectional audit of a single site. One hundred thirty-five patients (mean age 7.7 years) receiving treatment at the Royal Children's Hospital, Melbourne, Children's Cancer Center Day Oncology Unit were observed. Procedural aspects related to the treatment room, caregiver behavior and staff, child distress, and the use of pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions were recorded using an audit tool developed for the study. RESULTS: The procedure room was normally quiet and prepared before the child entered. The median duration of the procedure was 8 min. The median waiting time for the procedure was 54 min. Usually at least one caregiver was present during the procedures. Comfort First (CF) physicians were more likely to be present at procedures with a significantly distressed child. CF caregivers, nurses, and physicians generally exhibited behavior that promotes comfort. Topical anesthesia was used regularly. Non-pharmacological supports, particularly distraction, were frequently used. Patients younger than 8 years were significantly more likely to receive non-pharmacological support and to have a caregiver and CF doctor present. Age was a significant predictor of distress, with higher rates of distress in younger children. CONCLUSIONS: The CFP was found to be effectively implementing procedural pain guidelines. A periodic audit is recommended to ensure compliance with pain management standards.

title: Coping with challenging behaviour: a cluster randomized controlled trial on the effects of a multidisciplinary program of care for challenging behavior in dementia
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The Grip on Challenging Behavior care program was developed using current guidelines and models on managing challenging behavior in dementia in nursing homes. It was hypothesized that the use of the mindfulness program would lead to a decrease in challenging behavior and prescription of psychoactive drugs without increasing the use of restraints. DESIGN: A randomized controlled trial was conducted using a stepwise design to implement the care program and assess effects. An assessment of challenging behavior and psychoactive medication was carried out every 4 months in all participating units, followed by the introduction of the care program in a group of 3 to 4 units. A total of 6 time evaluations were carried out during 20 months. SETTING: Seventeen special care dementia units from different nursing homes. PARTICIPANTS: A total of 659 residents of special care dementia units. All residents with dementia in the unit were included. Units were assigned using random assignment software to 1 of 5 groups with different starting points for implementation of the care program. INTERVENTION: A care program consisting of various procedures and evaluation tools, which ensure a multidisciplinary approach and structure the process of managing challenging behavior in dementia. MEASUREMENTS: Challenging behavior was measured using the Cohen-Mansfield Agitation Inventory (CMAI) and the Neuropsychiatric Inventory. Research assistants (blinded to unit intervention status) interviewed unit nurses about challenging behaviour. Data on psychoactive drugs and restraints were retrieved from residents' medical records. RESULTS: A total of 2,292 assessments involving 659 residents (1,126 control measures, 1,166 intervention measures) were performed. The group of residents who remained in the intervention condition compared to the group in the control condition differed significantly in CMAI change scores between successive assessments [-2.4 CMAI points, 95% confidence interval (CI) : -4.3 to -0.6]. No significant effect was found for the control-to-intervention group compared with the group that remained in the control group (0.0 point CMAI, 95% CI -2.3 to 2.4). Significant effects were found in 5 of the 12 items of the Neuropsychiatric Inventory and in the use of antipsychotics (odds ratio 0.54, 95% CI 0.37-0.80) and antidepressants (odds ratio 0.65, 95% CI 0 .44-0.94). No effect on the use of restraints was observed. CONCLUSIONS: The Grip on Challenging behavior program was able to decrease some forms of challenging behavior and the use of psychoactive drugs.

title: Communicating with paediatricians: developing social work practice in primary care
abstract: While interdisciplinary collaborative social work models suggest that communication is important, the research literature on physician-social worker collaboration rarely considers work with pediatricians or practice outside of the hospital setting. A cross-sectional survey was sent to a stratified random sample of social workers to assess their satisfaction in communicating with pediatricians. The study found that social workers in health settings were more satisfied than those in mental health settings. The implications of this finding for the development of collaborative and co-located care models are discussed.

title: Communication Style and Exercise Compliance in Physiotherapy (CONNECT): A Cluster Randomized Controlled Trial to Test a Theory-Based Intervention for Increasing Chronic Low Back Pain Patients' Adherence to Physiotherapists' Recommendations: Study Rationale, Design, and methods
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physical activity and physiotherapy are among the accepted clinical rehabilitation guidelines and are recommended self-management strategies for chronic low back pain. However, many people with back pain do not follow the recommendations of their physical therapist. Poor patient adherence can decrease the effectiveness of home rehabilitation advice and exercises. According to self-determination theory, support from health professionals can promote patients' autonomous motivation and greater long-term behavioral persistence (eg, adherence to physical therapists' recommendations). The aim of this trial is to assess the effect of an intervention designed to increase physiotherapists' autonomy supportive communication on low back pain patients' adherence to physical activity and exercise therapy recommendations. METHODS/DESIGN: This study will be a single-blind cluster randomized controlled trial. Outpatient physical therapy centers (N = 12) in Dublin, Ireland (population = 1.25 million) will be randomly assigned by a computer-generated algorithm to the experimental or control arm. Physiotherapists from the experimental arm (two hospitals and four primary care clinics) will attend eight hours of communication skills training. The training will include handouts, workbooks, video examples, role plays and discussions designed to teach physical therapists how to communicate in a way that promotes patient self-motivation. Physiotherapists in the control arm of the waiting list (two hospitals and four primary care clinics) will not receive this training. Participants (N = 292) with chronic low back pain will complete assessments at baseline, as well as 1 week, 4 weeks, 12 weeks, and 24 weeks after their first physical therapy appointment. Primary outcomes will include adherence to physical therapy recommendations, as well as low back pain, function, and well-being. Participants will be blinded to treatment assignment as they will not be told whether their physiotherapist has received training in communication skills. Outcome assessors will also be blinded. We will use linear mixed models to test for differences between arms in both mean levels and rates of change of outcome variables. We will use structural equation modeling to examine the process of change, including hypothetical mediating effects. DISCUSSION: This trial will be the first to test the effect of a self-determination theory-based communication skills training program for physical therapists on compliance with rehabilitation recommendations for their low back pain patients.

title: Community occupational therapy for older patients with dementia and their carers: a cost-effectiveness study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the cost-effectiveness of community-based occupational therapy compared to usual care in older people with dementia and their carers from a societal point of view. DESIGN Cost-effectiveness study in conjunction with a single-blind randomized controlled trial. SETTING Memory clinic, day clinic of a geriatric service and participants' home. Patients 135 patients older than 65 years with mild to moderate dementia living in the community and their primary caregivers. INTERVENTION 10 sessions of occupational therapy over five weeks, including cognitive and behavioral interventions, to train patients in the use of aids to compensate for cognitive decline and caregivers in coping behaviors and supervision. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Incremental cost-effectiveness ratio expressed as the difference in mean total costs of care per successful treatment (i.e., a combined patient and caregiver outcome measure of clinically relevant improvement on the process, performance, and outcome scales). competition) three months after randomisation. Bootstrap methods used to determine confidence intervals for these measures. RESULTS The intervention cost €1,183 (£848, $1,738) (95% confidence interval €1,128 (£808, $1,657) to €1,239 (£888, $1,820)) per patient and primary care unit at three months . Visits to general practitioners and hospital doctors cost the same in both groups, but total mean costs were €1,748 (£1,279, $2,621) lower in the intervention group, with the main cost savings in informal care. There was a significant difference in the proportions of successful treatments of 36% at three months. The number needed to treat for successful treatment at three months was 2.8 (2.7 to 2.9). CONCLUSIONS Community occupational therapy intervention for patients with dementia and their carers is successful and cost-effective, especially in terms of informal care.

title: Community Outreach and Cardiovascular Health (COACH) Trial: Randomized Controlled Trial of Nurse Practitioners/Community Health Workers for Cardiovascular Disease Risk Reduction in Urban Community Health Centers
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite well-publicized guidelines on the appropriate management of cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes, implementation of risk reduction practices remains poor. This report describes the results of a randomized, controlled clinical trial evaluating the efficacy of a comprehensive cardiovascular disease risk reduction program delivered by nurse practitioner/community health worker (NP/CHW) teams compared with usual care. (EUC) to improve lipids, arterial blood, glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c), and patient perceptions of the quality of care for their chronic diseases in urban community health center patients. METHODS AND RESULTS: A total of 525 patients with documented cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, hypercholesterolemia or hypertension, and LDL cholesterol, blood pressure, or HbA1c levels exceeding national guideline goals were randomly assigned to NP/CHW (n= 261) or EUC (n=264) groups. The NP/CHW intervention included aggressive pharmacological management and personalized educational and behavioral counseling for lifestyle modification and problem solving to address barriers to adherence and control. Compared with EUC, patients in the NP/CHW group had significantly greater improvement at 12 months in total cholesterol (difference, 19.7 mg/dL), LDL cholesterol (difference, 15.9 mg/dL), triglycerides (difference, 16.3 mg/dL), systolic blood pressure (difference, 6.2 mm Hg), diastolic blood pressure (difference, 3.1 mm Hg), HbA1c (difference, 0.5%), and perceptions of quality of care for their chronic diseases (difference, 1.2 points). CONCLUSIONS: An intervention delivered by a NP/CHW team using individualized treatment regimens based on treat-to-target algorithms may be an effective approach to improve risk factor status and perceptions of chronic disease care. in high-risk patients.

title: Community care for the control of type 2 diabetes: an evidence-based review
abstract: UNLABELED: In June 2008, the Medical Advice Secretariat began work on the Diabetes Strategy Evidence Project, an evidence-based review of the literature on strategies for the successful management and treatment of diabetes. This project arose when the Health System Strategy Division of the Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care subsequently requested the secretariat to provide an evidence platform for the Ministry's recently published Diabetes Strategy. After an initial review of the strategy and consultation with experts, the secretariat identified five key areas where evidence was needed. Evidence-based analyzes have been prepared for each of these five areas: insulin pumps, behavioral interventions, bariatric surgery, home telemonitoring, and community care. For each area, an economic analysis was completed where appropriate and is described in a separate report. To review these titles within the Diabetes Strategy Evidence series, visit the Medical Advice Secretariat website, http://www.health.gov.on .ca/english/providers/program/mas/mas_about.html, PLATFORM EVIDENCE STRATEGY FOR DIABETES STRATEGY: Summary of Evidence-Based Reviews Continuous Subcutaneous Insulin Pumps for Adult Type 1 and Type 2 Diabetics: An Evidence-Based Review Behavioral Interventions for Type 2 Diabetes: An Evidence-Based Review the evidenceBARIATRIC SURGERY FOR PEOPLE WITH DIABETES AND MORBID OBESITY: An Evidence-Based OverviewCommunity Care for Type 2 Diabetes: An Evidence-Based ReviewHome Telemonitoring for Type 2 Diabetes: An Evidence-Based ReviewThe Diabetes App Ontario Economic Model (ODEM) to determine the cost-effectiveness and budget impact of selected interventions for type 2 diabetes in Ont ary OBJECTIVE: The objective of this report is to determine the efficacy of specialized multidisciplinary community care for the management of type 2 diabetes compared to usual care. CLINICAL NEED: TARGET POPULATION AND CONDITION Diabetes (ie, diabetes mellitus) is a highly prevalent chronic metabolic disorder that interferes with the body's ability to produce or effectively use insulin. The majority (90%) of patients with diabetes have type 2 diabetes. (1) According to the UK Prospective Diabetes Study (UKPDS), intensive control of blood glucose and blood pressure significantly reduces the risk of complications microvascular and macrovascular disorders in type 2 diabetics. Although many studies have documented that patients often do not meet glycemic control goals specified by national and international guidelines, factors associated with glycemic control are less well studied, one of the Who is the care provider? Multidisciplinary approaches to care may be particularly important for diabetes management. According to the Canadian Diabetes Association (CDA) guidelines, the diabetes health care team should be multidisciplinary and interdisciplinary. Currently in Ontario, the core diabetes health care team consists of at least one family doctor and/or diabetes specialist, and diabetes educators (registered nurse and registered dietitian). Increasing the role of allied health professionals in diabetes care and their collaboration with physicians may represent a more cost-effective option for diabetes management. Several systematic reviews and meta-analyses have examined multidisciplinary care programs, but these have been limited to a specific component of multidisciplinary care (eg, intensified education programs) or performed as part of a disease management program broader, not all of which were multidisciplinary in nature. Most reviews also do not clearly define the intervention(s) of interest, making the evaluation of such multidisciplinary community programs difficult. EVIDENCE-BASED METHODS OF ANALYSIS: RESEARCH QUESTIONS: What is the evidence for the efficacy of specialized multidisciplinary community care delivered by at least one registered nurse, one registered dietitian, and one physician (primary care and/or specialist) for the control of type 2 diabetes compared to usual care? watch out? [Hereinafter referred to as Model 1] What is the evidence for the efficacy of specialized multidisciplinary community care delivered by at least one pharmacist and one primary care physician for the management of type 2 diabetes compared to usual care? [Hereafter referred to as Model 2] INCLUSION CRITERIA: Full reports in English Published between January 1, 2000 and September 28, 2008 Randomized controlled trials (RCTs), systematic reviews, and meta-analyses Adult population with type 2 diabetes ( >/= 18 years of age )Total sample size >/=30 Describe specialized multidisciplinary community care defined as outpatient care provided by at least two healthcare disciplines (of which at least one must be a diabetes specialist) with communication integrated among care providers. Compared to usual health care (defined as the provision of health care by non-diabetes specialists, such as "primary care providers"; may include referral to other health care professionals/services as needed) >/= 6 months follow-up EXCLUSION CRITERIA: Studies where discrete diabetes outcomes cannot be summarized Predominantly home interventions Hospital interventions OUTCOMES OF INTEREST: The primary outcomes of this review were glycated hemoglobin (rHbA1c) and systolic blood pressure (SBP) levels. ). and the International Agency for Health Technology Assessment (INAHTA) for published studies between January 1, 2000 and September 28, 2008. Abstracts were reviewed by a single reviewer, and for those studies that met the eligibility criteria, full-text articles were obtained. Reference lists were also examined for any additional relevant studies not identified through the search. Articles with unknown eligibility were reviewed with a second clinical epidemiologist, then with a panel of epidemiologists until consensus was established. The quality of the evidence was assessed as high, moderate, low or very low according to the GRADE methodology. Given the high clinical heterogeneity of the articles that met the inclusion criteria, specific models of specialized multidisciplinary community care based on models of care currently supported in Ontario, models of care that were commonly reported in the literature, as well as suggestions from an Expert Advisory Panel meeting held on January 21, 2009. SUMMARY OF FINDINGS: The initial search returned 2116 unique citations, of which 22 RCTs and 9 published systematic reviews were identified that met the eligibility criteria. . Of these, five studies focused on care provided by at least one nurse, dietitian and physician (primary care and/or specialist) care model (Model 1; see Table ES 1), while three studies focused on care delivered by at least one pharmacist and one primary care physician (Model 2; "see Table ES 2). Based on moderate-quality evidence, Model 2 specialized multidisciplinary community care has shown a statistically and clinically significant reduction in HbA1c of 1.0 % compared to usual care The effects of this model on SBP, however, are uncertain compared to usual care, based on very low-quality evidence Model 2 specialized multidisciplinary community care has shown a reduction statistically and clinically significant in both HbA1c of 1.05% (based on high-quality evidence) and SBP of 7.13 mm Hg (based on moderate-quality evidence) da) compared to usual care For both models, the evidence does not suggest a preferred setting of care delivery (ie, primary care versus outpatient hospital care). clinical t vs. community clinic). Table ES1: Summary of results of meta-analyses of the effects of multidisciplinary care Model 1OutcomeEffect estimate (95% CI)Heterogeneity I(2)(p-value)GRADEGHglycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c [%])-1.00 [ -1.27, -0.73]4% (p=0.37) Moderate Quality Subgroup: Moderate to High Quality-0.91 [-1.19, -0.62]0% (p=0, 74) Systolic blood pressure (mm Hg) -2.04 [-13.80, 9.72 ]89% (p=0.002) Very low quality*Mean change from baseline to follow-up between intervention and control groups Heterogeneity I(2)(p-value)GRADEGHglycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c [%])-1.05 [-1.57, -0.52]0% (p=0.75)High-quality systolic blood pressure (mm Hg) -7.13 [-11.78, -2.48]46% (p=0.17) Moderate quality*Mean change from baseline to follow-up between intervention and control groups.

title: Community-based knowledge transfer and sharing: helping community-based organizations link research with action
abstract: Background Community-based organizations (CBOs) are important stakeholders in health systems and are increasingly being asked to use research evidence to inform their advocacy efforts, program planning, and service delivery. CBOs are increasingly turning to community-based research (CBR) given its participatory approach and emphasis on linking research with action. To further facilitate the use of research evidence by CBOs, we have developed a strategy for community-based knowledge transfer and exchange (KTE) that helps CBOs more effectively link research evidence action research. We developed the strategy by: outlining the main characteristics of CBOs and why they are important stakeholders in health systems; describe the concepts and methods for CBR and KTE; compare CBR's efforts to link research evidence to action with those discussed in the KTE literature and use the comparison to develop a community-based framework for KTE that builds on both the strengths of CBR and the existing frameworks. Existing KTEs Discussion We found that CBR is particularly effective in fostering a climate for using research evidence and producing research evidence to community organizations through community engagement. However, community organizations are not always as involved in activities to link research evidence to action on a larger scale or to evaluate these efforts. Therefore, our community-based strategy for KTE focuses on: an expanded 'link and exchange' model (ie, research producers and users engaging in a process of asking and answering questions together); a greater emphasis on producing and disseminating systematic reviews that address topics of interest to community organizations; develop a large-scale evidence service consisting of both “push” and “pull” efforts that highlight actionable messages from community-relevant systematic reviews in a user-friendly manner” and rigorous evaluations of the efforts to link research evidence to action Summary Through this type of strategy, the use of research evidence for CBO advocacy efforts, program planning, and service delivery can be better facilitated and refined continuously through ongoing evaluations of its impact.

title: Community primary care: improvement and evaluation of diabetes control
abstract: The morbidity and mortality associated with diabetes make it a prime target for quality improvement research. Quality gaps and racial/gender disparities persist in this patient population requiring sustainable improvement in clinical diabetes management. The authors of this study sought to (1) provide a population perspective on diabetes management and (2) reinforce evidence-based clinical guidelines through a web-based educational module. The project also aimed to obtain information about remote work with a community. of rural doctors. This longitudinal pre-post intervention study involved 18 internal medicine physicians and included 3 points of data extraction from medical records over 24 months. A web-based educational module was introduced after baseline data extraction. This module contained chapters on clinical education, practical tools, and self-assessment. Results showed sustained improvement in most clinical outcomes and demonstrated the effectiveness of using web-based media to reinforce clinical guidelines and change physician behavior.

title: Community Implemented Trauma Therapy for Former Child Soldiers in Northern Uganda
abstract: Context The psychological rehabilitation of former child soldiers and their successful reintegration into post-conflict society presents challenges. Despite high rates of deterioration, there have been no randomized controlled trials examining the feasibility and efficacy of mental health interventions for former child soldiers. Objective To assess the efficacy of a community-based intervention targeting post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms in formerly abducted persons. Design, Setting, and Participants Randomized controlled trial recruiting 85 former child soldiers with PTSD from a population-based survey of 1,113 Northern Ugandans aged 12 to 25 years, conducted between November 2007 and October 2009 in IDP camps. Participants were randomly assigned to 1 of 3 groups: narrative exposure therapy (n = 29), an academic refresher program with supportive counseling elements (n = 28), or a waiting list (n = 28). PTSD symptoms and trauma-related guilt feelings were measured using the Clinician-Administered PTSD Scale. The respective sections of the Mini International Neuropsychiatric Interview were used to assess depression and suicide risk, and a locally adapted scale was used to measure perceived stigma. PTSD symptoms, depression, and related impairment were assessed before treatment and at 3 months, 6 months, and 12 months post-intervention. Intervention treatments were carried out in 8 sessions by trained local lay therapists, directly in the communities. Main outcome measures Change in PTSD severity, assessed over a 1-year period after treatment. Secondary outcome measures were symptoms of depression, severity of suicidal ideation, feelings of guilt, and perceived stigma. Results PTSD symptom severity (range, 0-148) improved significantly more in the narrative exposure therapy group than in the academic recovery group (mean change difference, ?14.06 [95% confidence interval , ?27.19 to ?0.92]) and expect -list (mean change difference, ?13.04 [95% confidence interval, ?26.79 to 0.72]) groups. Time-treatment interaction contrast analyzes of the mixed-effects model on PTSD symptom change over time revealed a superiority of narrative exposure therapy compared to academic recovery (F1,234.1 = 5.21, P = .02) and wait. striped (F1,228.3 = 5.28, P = .02). Narrative exposure therapy produced a larger within-treatment effect size (Cohen d = 1.80) than academic remediation (d = 0.83) and waiting list (d = 0.81). Conclusion Among former child soldiers in Uganda, short-term trauma-focused treatment compared with an academic remedial program including supportive counseling or with the waiting list resulted in a greater reduction in PTSD symptoms.

title: Community cardiovascular disease prevention programs and health outcomes in a rural county, 1970-2010
abstract: Importance Few comprehensive cardiovascular risk reduction programs, particularly those in low-income rural communities, have sustained community-wide interventions for more than 10 years and have demonstrated the effect of improvements in risk factors on morbidity reduction and mortality. Objective To document the health outcomes associated with a comprehensive, integrated cardiovascular risk reduction program in Franklin County, Maine, a low-income, rural community. Design, Setting, and Participants Forty-year observational study involving residents of Franklin County, Maine, a low-income rural population of 22,444 in 1970, using the previous decade as a reference, and comparing Franklin County to other counties of Maine and state averages. Interventions Community-wide programs that focus on high blood pressure, cholesterol, and smoking, as well as diet and physical activity, sponsored by multiple community organizations, including the local hospital and physicians. Main Outcomes and Measures "Resident engagement"; detection, treatment, and control of hypertension and hyperlipidemia; smoking cessation rates; hospitalization rates from 1994 to 2006, adjusted for median family income; and mortality rates since 1970. through 2010, adjusted for family income and age.ResultsMore than 150,000 individual contacts of county residents occurred over 40 years.Over time, as cardiovascular risk factor programs were added, relevant health indicators improved. Hypertension control had an absolute increase of 24.7% (95% CI, 21.6%-27.7%) from 18.3% to 43.0% from 1975 to 1978, then control of elevated cholesterol had an absolute increase of 28.5% (95% CI, 25.3%-31.6%) from 0.4% to 28.9%, from 1986 to 2010. Smoking cessation rates improved from 48.5% to 69.5%, better than state averages (Observed?-?Expected [O?-?E], 11.3%; 95% CI , 5.5%-17.7%; P?<?.001), 1996-2000; these differences then disappeared when Maine's overall dropout rate increased. Franklin County hospitalizations per capita were lower than expected for the period measured, 1994-2006 (O?-?E, -17 discharges/1000 population; 95% CI -20.1 to -13.9; P ?<?.001). Franklin was the only county in Maine with adjusted mortality consistently lower than predicted during the 1970-1989 and 1990-2010 periods (O?-?E, -60.4 deaths/100,000; 95% CI, -97.9 to -22.8 ; P?<?.001 and -41.6/100?000; 95% CI, -77.3 to -5.8;" P?=?.005, respectively). Maine were associated with reductions in hospitalization and mortality rates over 40 years, compared with the rest of the state.Further studies are needed to assess the generalizability of such programs to other US county populations, especially rural, since other parts of the world.

title: Comparative benefits and harms of second-generation antidepressants for the treatment of major depressive disorder.
abstract: Background: Second-generation antidepressants dominate the treatment of major depressive disorder (MDD), but the evidence on the comparative benefits and harms of these agents is conflicting. Purpose: To compare the benefits and harms of second generation antidepressants for treating MDD in adults. Data sources: PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library, PsycINFO, and International Pharmaceutical Abstracts English studies from 1980 to August 2011 and reference lists of relevant review articles and gray literature. Study Selection: Two independent reviewers identified randomized trials of at least 6 weeks' duration to assess efficacy and observational studies with at least 1000 participants to assess harm. Data Extraction: Reviewers abstracted data on study design and conduct, participants, interventions, and outcomes, and rated study quality. Extracted data and quality ratings were checked and confirmed by a lead reviewer. Data Synthesis: Meta-analyses and mixed treatment comparisons of treatment response and weighted mean differences on specific scales for rating depression were performed. Based on 234 studies, no clinically relevant differences in efficacy or effectiveness were detected for the treatment of acute, continuation, and maintenance phases of MDD. No differences in efficacy were observed in patients with accompanying symptoms or in subgroups based on age, gender, ethnicity, or comorbid conditions. Individual drugs differed in onset of action, adverse events, and some measures of health-related quality of life. Limitations: Most trials were conducted in highly selected populations. Publication bias could affect the estimates for some comparisons. Mixed treatment comparisons cannot conclusively exclude differences in efficacy. Evidence within subgroups was limited. Conclusion: The current evidence does not justify the recommendation of a particular second-generation antidepressant on the basis of differences in efficacy. Differences in onset of action and adverse events can be considered when choosing a drug.

title: Comparative Benefits and Harms of Second-Generation Antidepressants: Background Paper for the American College of Physicians
abstract: Background: Second-generation antidepressants dominate the treatment of major depressive disorder, dysthymia, and subsyndromic depression. Evidence on comparative benefits and harms is still accumulating. Purpose: To compare the benefits and harms of second-generation antidepressants (bupropion, citalopram, duloxetine, escitalopram, fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, mirtazapine, nefazodone, paroxetine, sertraline, trazodone, and venlafaxine) for the treatment of depressive disorders in adults. Data sources: MEDLINE, EMBASE, PsychLit, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, and International Pharmaceutical Abstracts from 1980 to April 2007, limited to articles in English. Reference lists of relevant review articles were handsearched and the Center for Drug Evaluation and Research database searched for unpublished research. We included six previous systematic reviews or meta-analyses of good or fair quality, as well as 155 direct, placebo-controlled, or double-blind randomized controlled trials of good or fair quality of at least 6 weeks' duration. duration. We also included 35 observational studies with at least 100 participants and a follow-up of at least 12 weeks for damage. and the results. Data Synthesis: If data were sufficient, meta-analyses of head-to-head trials were performed to determine the relative benefit of treatment response and weighted mean differences on specific depression rating scales. If insufficient evidence was available, adjusted indirect comparisons were made using meta-regressions and network meta-analyses. Second-generation antidepressants did not differ substantially in efficacy or effectiveness for the treatment of major depressive disorder based on 203 studies";" however, the incidence of specific adverse events and the onset of action differed. Evidence is insufficient to draw conclusions about the comparative efficacy, effectiveness, or harms of these agents for the treatment of dysthymia and subsyndromic depression. Limitation: Adjusted indirect comparisons have methodological limitations and cannot conclusively rule out differences in efficacy. Conclusion: the current evidence does not guarantee the choice of one second-generation antidepressant over another based on the differences in efficacy and effectiveness. Other differences regarding onset of action and adverse events may be relevant to the choice of a drug.

title: Comparative effectiveness of audit feedback versus additional physician communication training in improving cancer detection in patients with limited health literacy
abstract: BACKGROUND: We designed a continuing medical education (CME) program to teach primary care physicians (PCPs) how to engage in cancer risk communication and shared decision making with patients who have limited health literacy (HL). OBJECTIVE: We evaluated whether training PCPs, in addition to audit feedback, improves their communication behaviors and increases cancer detection among patients with limited HL to a greater extent than just providing feedback on clinical performance. DESIGN: Four-year cluster randomized controlled trial. PARTICIPANTS: Eighteen primary care physicians and 168 patients with limited HL who were overdue for colorectal/breast/cervical cancer screening. INTERVENTIONS: Communication intervention PCPs received skills training that included standardized patient feedback (SP) on counseling behaviors. All PCPs underwent semi-annual patient screening status file audits for up to 24 months and received two annual performance feedback reports. MAIN MEASURES: PCPs experienced three unannounced SP encounters during which SPs rated the PCP's communication behaviors. We examined between-group differences in changes in SP scores and patient knowledge of cancer screening guidelines over 12 months"; and changes in patients' cancer screening rates over 24 months. KEY RESULTS: There were no differences between groups in SP ratings of communication with the doctor at baseline At follow-up, communication intervention PCPs scored higher on overall communication about cancer risks and shared decision making related to colorectal cancer screening compared to PCPs who only received performance feedback. Screening rates were increased among PCP patients in both groups;" however, there were no differences between groups in detection rates except for mammography. The communication intervention did not improve patients' knowledge of cancer detection. CONCLUSION: Compared with audit and feedback alone, the inclusion of PCP communication training increases PCP patient-centered counseling behaviors but not cancer detection among patients with limited HL. Larger studies need to be done to determine whether the lack of change in cancer detection was due to clinic/patient sample size versus the ineffectiveness of communication training in changing outcomes.

title: Comparative efficacy and tolerability of 15 antipsychotic drugs in schizophrenia: a meta-analysis of multiple treatments.
abstract: Background The question of which antipsychotic drug should be preferred for the treatment of schizophrenia is controversial, and conventional peer-reviewed meta-analyses cannot provide a hierarchy based on randomized evidence. Our aim was to integrate the available evidence to create hierarchies of the comparative efficacy, risk of all-cause discontinuation, and major side effects of antipsychotic drugs.";" Background The question of which antipsychotic drug should be preferred for the treatment of schizophrenia is controversial, and conventional peer-reviewed meta-analyses cannot provide a hierarchy based on randomized evidence. The aim was to integrate the available evidence to create hierarchies of the comparative efficacy, risk of all-cause discontinuation, and major side effects of antipsychotic drugs.

title: Comparative efficacy of interventions to promote hand hygiene in the hospital: systematic review and network meta-analysis.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the relative effectiveness of the World Health Organization's 2005 campaign (WHO-5) and other interventions to promote hand hygiene among healthcare workers in hospital settings and to summarize associated information on resource use. DESIGN Systematic review and network meta-analysis. DATA SOURCES Medline, Embase, CINAHL, NHS Economic Evaluation Database, NHS Center for Reviews and Dissemination, Cochrane Library, and the EPOC registry (December 2009 to February 2014)"; studies selected by the same search terms in previous systematic reviews (1980- METHODS OF REVIEW) Included studies were randomized controlled trials, non-randomized trials, controlled before-and-after trials, and interrupted time series studies that implemented an intervention to improve hand hygiene compliance among healthcare workers in hospital settings and measured adherence or appropriate surrogate indicators that met predefined quality inclusion criteria When studies had not used appropriate analytic methods, primary data were re-analysed Random-effects and network meta-analyses were performed in studies reporting adherence directly observed with hand hygiene when considered sufficiently homogeneous with respect to interventions and participants Information on resources required for interventions was extracted and classified into three levels. RESULTS Of the 3639 retrieved studies, 41 met the inclusion criteria (six randomized controlled trials, 32 interrupted time series, one nonrandomized trial, and two controlled before-and-after studies). Meta-analysis of two randomized controlled trials showed that the addition of goal setting to WHO-5 was associated with better compliance (pooled odds ratio 1.35, 95% confidence interval 1.04 to 1.76; I( 2)=81%). Of 22 pairwise interrupted time series comparisons, 18 showed step increases in hand hygiene compliance, and all but four showed a trend of increasing compliance after the intervention. The network meta-analysis indicated considerable uncertainty in the relative effectiveness of the interventions, but nonetheless provided evidence that WHO-5 is effective and that compliance can be further improved by adding interventions that include goal setting, incentives for reward and accountability. Nineteen studies reported clinical outcomes; data from these were consistent with clinically important reductions in infection rates resulting from improved hand hygiene for some but not all important hospital-acquired pathogens. Reported costs of interventions ranged from $225 to $4669 (£146-£3035;" Ã¢â€šÂ¬204-Ã¢â€šÂ¬4229) per 1000 bed days. CONCLUSION Hand hygiene promotion with WHO -5 is effective in increasing health worker compliance The addition of goal setting, reward incentives and accountability strategies may lead to further improvements Reporting of resources needed for such interventions remains inadequate .

title: Comparison of the cost effects of two quality strategies to improve test ordering in primary care: a randomized trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the costs and cost reductions of an innovative strategy aimed at improving primary care physicians' test ordering routines, compared to a traditional strategy. DESIGN: Multicentre randomized controlled trial with randomization at local primary care physician group level. SETTING: Primary care: local groups of primary care physicians in five regions of the Netherlands with diagnostic centers. STUDY PARTICIPANTS: Twenty-seven existing local primary care physician groups, including 194 primary care physicians. INTERVENTION: The test ordering strategy was developed systematically and combined feedback, guideline education, and small group quality improvement sessions. In regular quality meetings in local groups, primary care physicians discussed each other's test requesting behavior, related it to guidelines, and made individual and/or group plans for change. Thirteen groups participated in the full strategy (full intervention arm), while 14 groups received only feedback (feedback arm). MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: Operating costs, development costs, and research costs were calculated for the intervention period per primary care physician per 6 months. The mean costs of the tests requested by the primary care physician every 6 months were evaluated at baseline and at follow-up. RESULTS: It was found that the new strategy cost 702.00, while the feedback strategy cost 58.00. Including running costs alone, the intervention was found to cost €554.70, compared to €17.10 per primary care physician per 6 months in the feedback arm. Excluding opportunity costs for time spent by clinicians, the intervention was found to cost 92.70 per physician per 6 months in the full intervention arm. The average cost reduction physicians in that arm achieved by reducing unnecessary testing was 144 times greater per physician per 6 months than physicians in the feedback arm (P = 0.048). CONCLUSION: Based on our findings, including expected non-monetary benefits, we recommend further long-term effects and cost-effect studies on quality strategy implementation.

title: Comparison of the efficacy of staff instruction versus home staff in an intervention to improve the management of hypertension
abstract: PURPOSE: To determine whether a resident physician can be as effective as a faculty opinion leader in changing physician compliance with a hypertension practice guideline. METHOD: At a general internal medicine clinic associated with an internal medicine residency program, sequential charts were reviewed for patients with uncontrolled or new-onset hypertension who were seen routinely over a 2-week period. Subsequently, 23 providers were randomly assigned to an academic intervention to implement a hypertension practice guideline led by a single second-year resident instructor (RI), and 21 providers were assigned to the same intervention led by a single staff internist ( SI) with an interest in hypertension. The intervention involved academic details, audit charts with feedback, and behavioral reinforcement. Six weeks later, the chart audit was repeated to assess change in practice patterns between providers taught by RI compared to those taught by SI. RESULTS: Overall, guideline-consistent management improved from 32% (51/157) to 45% (56/123) (p < 0.01) post-intervention. This change was due to improvement in care provided by SI-led intervention providers: 28% (17/60) to 57% (26/46) (p < 0.003). IR-led intervention providers showed no improvement: 35% (34/97) to 39% (30/77) (p = NS). CONCLUSIONS: This intervention was effective in improving providers' compliance with a hypertension practice guideline, but only when led by a faculty opinion leader. A resident instructor using the same format was unable to change the providers' behavior.

title: Comparison of strategies to reduce rates of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus in surgical patients: a multicenter controlled intervention trial.
abstract: Objective To compare the effect of two strategies (improved hand hygiene versus detection and decolonization of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)) alone and in combination on MRSA rates in operating rooms. Design Prospective, controlled, interventional cohort study, with 6-month baseline phases, 12-month intervention, and 6-month washout phases. Assembly of 33 surgical pavilions of 10 hospitals in nine countries in Europe and Israel. Participants All patients admitted to the registered wards for more than 24 h. Interventions The two strategies compared were (1) enhanced hand hygiene promotion and (2) universal screening for MRSA with contact precautions and decolonization (mupirocin and chlorhexidine intranasal baths) of MRSA carriers. Four hospitals were assigned to each intervention and two hospitals combined both strategies, using MRSA screening. Outcome measures Monthly rates of MRSA clinical cultures per 100 susceptible patients (primary outcome) and MRSA infections per 100 admissions (secondary outcome). A planned subgroup analysis was performed for clean operating rooms. Results After adjusting for clustering and potential confounders, neither strategy, when used alone, was associated with significant changes in MRSA rates. The combination of both strategies was associated with a reduction in the rate of clinical MRSA cultures of 12% per month (adjusted incidence rate (aIRR) 0.88, 95% CI 0.79 to 0.98). In clean operating rooms, Strategy 2 (MRSA screening, contact precautions, and decolonization) was associated with decreased rates of clinical MRSA cultures (15% monthly decrease, aIRR 0.85, 95% CI: 0, 74 to 0.97) and MRSA infections (17% monthly decrease, aIRR 0.83, 95% CI 0.69 to 0.99). Conclusions In operating rooms with relatively low MRSA prevalence, a combination of improved standard and MRSA-specific infection control approaches was required to reduce MRSA rates. Implementation of single interventions was not effective except in clean operating rooms where MRSA screening in conjunction with contact precautions and decolonization was associated with significant reductions in MRSA clinical culture and infection rates.

title: Comparison of the Educational Efficacy of Internet-Based CME with Live Interactive CME Workshops: A Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite evidence that a variety of continuing medical education (CME) techniques can encourage behavior change in physicians, no randomized trials comparing performance outcomes of physicians have been conducted. physicians participating in Internet-based CME with physicians participating in a live CME intervention using documented approaches to be effective. OBJECTIVE: To determine whether Internet-based CME can produce changes comparable to those produced through live, small-group, interactive CME in physicians' knowledge and behaviors that impact patient care. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: Randomized controlled trial conducted between August 2001 and July 2002. Participants were 97 primary care physicians selected from 21 practice sites in Houston, Texas, including 7 community health centers and 14 private group practices. . A control group of 18 physicians from these same sites received no intervention. INTERVENTIONS: Physicians were randomly assigned to either an Internet-based CME intervention that could be completed in multiple sessions over 2 weeks, or to a single, live, interactive CME workshop in small groups. Both incorporated similar multifaceted instructional approaches that have proven effective in real-world settings. Content was based on the National Institutes of Health National Cholesterol Education Program Adult Treatment Panel III guidelines. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Knowledge was assessed immediately before the intervention, immediately after the intervention, and 12 weeks later. The percentage of high-risk patients who underwent adequate lipid profile examination and pharmacotherapeutic treatment according to guidelines was documented with record audits performed during a 5-month period before the intervention and a 5-month period after. of the intervention. RESULTS: Both interventions produced similar and significant immediate and 12-week gains in knowledge, representing large increases in the percentage of items correct (pretest to posttest: 31.0% [95% confidence interval {CI}, 27.0%-35.0%]"; 12-week pretest: 36.4% [95% CI, 32.2%-40.6%]; P = 93%) with no significant change post-test However, the Internet-based intervention was associated with a significant increase in the percentage of high-risk patients treated with guideline pharmacotherapeutics (preintervention, 85.3%; postintervention, 90.3%;" p = 0 .04). CONCLUSIONS: Properly designed, evidence-based online CME can produce objectively measured changes in behavior and sustained gains in knowledge that are comparable or superior to those obtained from effective in vivo activities.

title: Comparison of three methods of reminding patients for influenza vaccination.
abstract: Despite recommendations supporting annual influenza vaccination for people age 65 and older, vaccination rates remain low. Several studies have evaluated the effect of mailing reminders, but few have compared alternative ways of reminding patients to receive the vaccine. In a randomized trial of 939 patients aged 65 years or older in four family practices conducted between October 23 and December 31, 1984, we compared three ways of reminding elderly patients to receive the vaccine: personal reminder by part of the doctor, telephone reminder by the nurse and reminder by letter. The vaccination rates for the three groups were 22.9%, 37%, and 35.1%, respectively. No reminder was sent to a control group and the rate was 9.8%. Some patients could not be reached by phone, and some did not see the doctor for the specified time. Among patients actually contacted by the nurse, the vaccination rate was 43.5%";" the rate of patients actually seen by the doctor was 45.1%. In general, a phone reminder from the nurse was the most effective method, and at an hourly wage of $16 or less, this method would also be the most cost-effective. The reminders used in this study were automatically generated from a computerized medical record system. The study shows how a computerized system can be used to identify patients for preventive procedures.

title: Competence network "community-acquired pneumonia" (CAPNETZ). A first interim report
abstract: Community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) is a disease with high morbidity and mortality in Germany. However, reliable data on pathogen spectrum and resistance, disease course, evidence-based guidelines for treatment, and pathogen-host interactions are not available. The German Ministry of Education and Research recognized these shortfalls and therefore decided to fund CAPNETZ, a competence network for community-acquired pneumonia. CAPNETZ integrates health research components as well as clinical and basic research (horizontal network) on the one hand and supports cooperation between general practitioners, community hospitals and universities (vertical network). Since October 2002, 1,547 patients with CAP have joined the network. The first results indicate that the new observations made in terms of symptoms, spectrum of pathogens involved and treatment modalities will have an impact on the formulation of new guidelines for the management of community-acquired pneumonia.

title: Competency development in new nursing graduates: bridging the gap between education and practice
abstract: The gap between the education for practice of a new RN graduate and the actual practice requirements of new RNs has long been an accepted fact in nursing. This article describes the development of an intervention from the academic side of the gap to improve the competence of nursing students before graduation. The intervention is notable because it was developed collaboratively between academia and practice. The triple intervention included development of learning modules based on the top 10 high-volume, high-risk patient conditions"; development of faculty and staff educators in learning strategies to enhance competency development"; and share products with the 84 nursing schools in Texas.

title: Complementary therapy in allergic rhinitis
abstract: The term complementary/alternative medicine (CAM) refers to those therapeutic and diagnostic approaches that are different from conventional allopathic medicine. CAM can encompass homeopathy, acupuncture, herbal medicine, antioxidant therapy, and numerous holistic or behavioral techniques. Allergists and physicians from all disciplines are faced with patients using CAM treatments, so it is imperative that they become familiar with the scientific literature that surrounds them. Given the high prevalence of allergic diseases and the associated costs of CAM treatments, testing of CAM therapies is needed to establish appropriate guidelines for their use. The efficacy of CAM modalities needs to be established with randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trials that include control for adverse effects. Of all the CAM therapies examined for treating allergic rhinitis, some herbal and antioxidant therapies demonstrate a trend toward some clinical efficacy. Researchers have yet to determine how to integrate these CAM modalities into the overall treatment paradigm for allergic rhinitis.

title: Complex pharmaceutical intervention in pulmonary care: part A. The process and professional satisfaction of the pharmacist
abstract: OBJECTIVE: In the IPMP (Interventions on the Principle of Pulmonary Medication Profiles) study, personalized pharmaceutical care interventions were provided to selected pulmonary patients due to drug use deviating from Dutch guidelines. The goals were to solve drug-related problems and improve drug use by patients. This article describes the pharmaceutical care process tailored to individual patient problems in the intervention arm of a randomized controlled trial and defines the care package. METHODS: After a preliminary selection of patients with the help of the IPMP algorithmic computer tool, trained Dutch community pharmacists conducted structured consultations with patients (aged 13 to 70 years) in the intervention arm to identify behavior and problems. specific to your medication. Based on this identification process, a personalized intervention was constructed that could comprise one or more of the six pharmaceutical care modules. The modules were grouped into sets that described the complete program of care provided to a patient. If necessary, the pharmacists consulted with the patients' physicians to improve the prescribed therapy. After the interventions, medication changes were discussed with the patients. Prescribed medication and refill rate were monitored on the pharmacy computer for 1 year. All activities and results were extensively monitored and documented. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: Process description, ie number of pharmaceutical care modules provided and medication changes. Pharmacist satisfaction. RESULTS: Personalized interventions were provided to 199 patients at risk of suboptimal drug therapy. In total, 813 pharmaceutical care modules were carried out and documented, and they were grouped into four different programs. In addition to education and motivation to comply with the prescribed medication for the 199 patients, a medication change was suggested in 124 cases. Patients and doctors agreed to a change in 94 cases. Device change was agreed in 58 of 64 cases, often simultaneously with medication change. Pharmacists consulted doctors on 100 patients. Pharmacists reported satisfaction with the pharmaceutical care approach. CONCLUSION: Due to the extensive documentation, the interventions could be fully described. Pharmacists noted better medication use after educating patients or resolving their medication-related problems. In collaboration with doctors, pharmacological treatment could be improved.

title: Complex pharmaceutical intervention in pulmonary care: part A. The process and professional satisfaction of the pharmacist.
abstract: In the IPMP (Interventions on the Principle of Pulmonary Medication Profiles) study, personalized pharmaceutical care interventions were provided to selected pulmonary patients due to drug use deviating from Dutch guidelines. The goals were to solve drug-related problems and improve drug use by patients. This article describes the pharmaceutical care process tailored to individual patient problems in the intervention arm of a randomized controlled trial and defines the care package. After a preliminary selection of patients with the help of the IPMP algorithmic computer tool, Dutch community pharmacists were instructed to have structured consultations with patients (13 to 70 years of age) in the intervention arm to identify specific behaviors and problems. with your medication. Based on this identification process, a personalized intervention was constructed that could comprise one or more of the six pharmaceutical care modules. The modules were grouped into sets that described the complete program of care provided to a patient. If necessary, the pharmacists consulted with the patients' physicians to improve the prescribed therapy. After the interventions, medication changes were discussed with the patients. Prescribed medication and refill rate were monitored on the pharmacy computer for 1 year. All activities and results were extensively monitored and documented. Description of the process, that is, number of pharmaceutical care modules provided and medication changes. Pharmacist satisfaction. Personalized interventions were provided to 199 patients at risk of suboptimal pharmacological treatment. In total, 813 pharmaceutical care modules were carried out and documented, and they were grouped into four different programs. In addition to education and motivation to comply with the prescribed medication for the 199 patients, a medication change was suggested in 124 cases. Patients and doctors agreed to a change in 94 cases. Device change was agreed in 58 of 64 cases, often simultaneously with medication change. Pharmacists consulted doctors on 100 patients. Pharmacists reported being satisfied with the pharmaceutical care approach. Due to the extensive documentation, the interventions could be fully described. Pharmacists noted better medication use after educating patients or resolving their medication-related problems. In collaboration with doctors, pharmacological treatment could be improved.

title: Complexities of fall prevention in clinical settings: a comment
abstract: Falls and associated injuries and mortality are a growing concern among aging Americans. The effective management of fall risk is a complicated process that requires the participation of both health professionals and older adults in three related actions: (a) early detection to detect risk factors", (b) prescription of interventions personalized, and (c) implementation of, adherence to, and adherence to the intervention by the older adult. Early detection of fall risk can prevent future falls;" however, adoption of evidence-based screening and evaluation protocols in the clinical setting has been limited. A variety of practice guidelines and financial incentives are available to healthcare professionals to facilitate adoption. However, a gap remains between recommended practices and current clinical activities. This commentary addresses the complexities of falls prevention practices and offers solutions that may facilitate adoption by clinical practices. To this end, this commentary will present two models (ie, a clinical approach and a financial incentive approach) to summarize current clinical recommendations and practice guidelines for fall risk management in clinical settings. The various drivers to encourage the adoption of evidence-based fall risk management strategies will be described. In this context, we will discuss how understanding different system-wide practice improvement initiatives and the factors that drive action across physician groups can facilitate the adoption and implementation of fall risk management behaviors by clinicians. of the doctors. Additional efforts are needed to explore and evaluate similar initiatives to adopt and implement fall risk management practices at different points of entry into the system (eg, community settings, patients, caregivers).

title: Compliance with biopsy recommendations from a prostate cancer risk calculator
abstract: UNLABELED: Type of study - Diagnosis (cohort) Evidence level 2b What is known about the topic? And what does the study add? Until now, few publications have shown that a prediction model influences the behavior of both doctors and patients. To our knowledge, it was unknown whether urologists and patients adhered to the recommendations of a prostate cancer risk calculator and their reasons for noncompliance. In most patients, the recommendations of the European Randomized Study of Screening for Prostate Cancer Risk Calculator (ERSPC RC) on the need for a prostate biopsy were followed. In most of the cases of non-compliance with the 'no biopsy' recommendations, a PSA level >/= 3 ng/mL was decisive for opting for biopsy. Prior to the implementation of the ERSPC RC in large-scale urological practices, it is important to obtain information on the use of guidelines that may counter the adoption of the use of the RC as a result of contrary recommendations. OBJECTIVES: To assess both urologist and patient compliance with a "no biopsy" or "biopsy" recommendation from the European Randomized Study of Screening for Prostate Cancer (ERSPC) Risk Calculator (RC), as well as their reasons for noncompliance. Evaluate the determinants of patient compliance. PATIENTS AND METHODS: The ERSPC RC calculates the probability of a sextant-positive prostate biopsy (P(posb) ) using the serum level of prostate-specific antigen (PSA), the results of digital rectal examination and transrectal ultrasonography, and the volume prostate evaluated ultrasonographically. A biopsy was recommended if P(posb) >/=20%. Between 2008 and 2011, eight urologists from five Dutch hospitals included 443 patients (aged 55 to 75 years) after a PSA test without prior biopsy. Urologists calculated P(posb) using CR in the presence of patients and completed a compliance questionnaire. Patients completed a questionnaire on prostate cancer knowledge, attitude toward prostate biopsy, self-rated health (12-item short-form Health Survey), anxiety (State Trait Anxiety Inventory-6, memorial anxiety for prostate cancer) and decision-making measures (Decisional Conflict Scale). RESULTS: Both urologists and patients complied with the CR recommendation in 368 of 443 (83%) cases. If a biopsy was recommended, almost all patients (96%"; 257/269) complied, although 63 of the 174 (36%) patients were biopsied against the CR recommendation. Those who complied with the 'do not biopsy' had a lower mean P(posb) than non-compliers (9% vs 14%; P /= 3 ng/mL) (78%; 49/63) and patients because they wanted certainty (60%;" 38/63 ). CONCLUSIONS: Most of the patients followed the ERSPC RC recommendations on prostate biopsy. Therefore, CR may be a promising tool to support clinical decision making.

title: Compliance with Adult Treatment Panel III guidelines for hyperlipidemia in a resident-managed outpatient clinic: a retrospective data analysis.
abstract: BACKGROUND: One in six adults (16.3% of the US adult population) have high total cholesterol levels and have twice the risk of heart disease compared to people with optimal levels. OBJECTIVE: To assess internal medicine residents' compliance with the latest National Cholesterol Education Program Adult Treatment Panel III (NCEP-ATP III) guidelines in the treatment of patients with hyperlipidemia. DESIGN: Retrospective observational study. SETTING: Outpatient Clinic, Saint Vincent Hospital, Worcester, Massachusetts. PATIENTS: Patients diagnosed with hyperlipidemia who attended the clinic over a 1-year period, from December 2009 to November 2010. MEASUREMENTS: A chart review was performed to assess residents' compliance with LDL cholesterol guidelines. of the NCEP-ATP III. and management of non-HDL cholesterol. RESULTS: 770 records were reviewed. Only 212 (27.5%) met the inclusion criteria. Data analysis revealed better adherence to pharmacological treatment (44%-77%) and therapeutic lifestyle changes (44%-83%) compared to follow-up recommendations (22%-31%). An increase in compliance was also seen in all intervention areas when patients had an abnormal lipid profile. LIMITATIONS: Compliance was assessed solely on the basis of electronic medical record documentation, and therefore we may be underestimating compliance with therapeutic lifestyle changes and follow-up recommendations. CONCLUSION: Compliance of internal medicine residents in the diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up of patients with hyperlipidemia according to the NCEP-ATP III guidelines was suboptimal and needs improvement.

title: Comprehensive asthma management for underserved children
abstract: In response to the 'asthma epidemic', local organizations in San Francisco formed the Yes We Can Urban Asthma Association, which uses a comprehensive medical/social model for pediatric asthma care. The Yes We Can Urban Asthma Partnership reaches high-risk children in a variety of clinical settings: urgent care, the hospital, a comprehensive asthma specialty clinic, and through an expanded community health worker program. This article highlights the initial development, implementation, and evaluation of the success of this innovative management program to address the problem of pediatric asthma in underserved urban areas.

title: Computerized Criticism Embedded in Daily Clinical Practice Affects Physicians' Behavior: A Randomized Clinical Trial with AsthmaCritic
abstract: OBJECTIVE: We developed AsthmaCritic, a non-inquisitive criticism system integrated with the electronic medical record of general practitioners. The system is based on the guidelines for asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) issued by the Dutch College of General Practitioners. This article evaluates the effect of AsthmaCritic in the monitoring and treatment of asthma and COPD by Dutch general practitioners in daily practice. METHODS: A randomized clinical trial in 32 practices (40 Dutch general practitioners) using electronic patient records. An intervention group was given the use of AsthmaCritic, a control group continued to work as usual. Both groups had the asthma and COPD guidelines commonly distributed by the Dutch College of General Practitioners. We measured the average number of contacts, FEV 1 (forced expiratory volume), and peak flow measurements per asthma/COPD patient per practice";" and, the average number of prescriptions for antihistamines, cromoglycate, deptropin, and oral bronchodilators per asthma/COPD patient per practice. RESULTS: The number of contacts increased in the age group from 12 to 39 years. The number of FEV1, peak flow, and proportion of coded measurements increased, while the number of cromolyn prescriptions decreased in the 12-39 age group. CONCLUSIONS: Our study shows that the AsthmaCritic guideline-based review system changed the way clinicians monitored their patients and, to a lesser extent, their treatment behavior. In addition, the doctors changed their data recording habits.

title: CT scan of the body: when should it be used?
Computer reminders for chlamydia screening in general practice: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background: Chlamydia notifications are increasing in Australia, and the use of a computer alert that prompts general practitioners to screen young women is a potential way to increase opportunistic testing for chlamydia. The aim of this trial was to determine the efficacy of a general practice computer alert on chlamydia screening in young women. Methods: In 2006, clinics (n = 68) in Melbourne, Australia, were cluster randomized into 2 groups: the intervention group received a computerized alert advising the general practitioner to discuss chlamydia testing with his patient, who appeared when the medical history of a 16-year-old patient was completed. - a 24-year-old woman"; the control group received no alert. The outcome was whether or not that patient received a chlamydia test at the level of a single visit with an eligible patient. A mixed-effects logistic regression model adjusting for pooling was used to assess the impact of the alert on the proportion of women tested for chlamydia during the trial period. Results: Testing increased from 8.3% (95% confidence interval [CI]: 6.8, 9 .8) to 12.2% (95% CI: 9.1, 15.3) (P < 0.01) in the intervention group, and 8.8% (95% CI: 6.8, 10 .7) to 10.6% (95% CI: 8.5, 12.7) (P < 0.01) in the control group Overall, the intervention group had 27% (OR = 1.3; 95% CI: 1.1, 1.4) greater increase in testing Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that alerts alone may not be sufficient to increase chlamydia test levels high enough to have a impact on the burden of chlamydia in the population n, but could be included as part of a more complex intervention.

title: Computerized reminders to implement preventive care guidelines for hospitalized patients.
abstract: Background: Hospitalizations are an opportunity to provide preventive care. Objective: To determine if computerized reminders, which we have shown to be effective in our outpatient setting, increase the provision of preventive care for hospitalized patients. Methods: Randomized controlled trial in the general medicine inpatient service of an urban public hospital affiliated with a university. The study subjects were 78 house employees rotating in the 6 general medicine services. The intervention consisted of reminders to physicians printed on daily round reports about preventive care for which their patients were eligible and suggested orders for preventive care delivered through physician workstations. Preventive care guidelines were derived from the recommendations of the US Preventive Care Task Force. Compliance with preventive care guidelines and house staff attitudes toward providing preventive care to hospitalized patients were the main outcome measures. Results: No significant differences were observed between intervention and control physicians in adherence to preventive care guidelines in the aggregate or when individual preventive care actions were analyzed. This was true despite the fact that most doctors supported the provision of most types of inpatient preventive care. Conclusions: Despite previous success in increasing preventive care in the outpatient setting, we were unable, using a moderately intensive intervention, to increase the provision of preventive care during hospitalizations. The attending physicians during hospitalization were not the patients' primary care physicians, which proved to be a significant barrier. More intensive interventions or more direct links between inpatient and outpatient providers may be required to overcome this resistance. Arch Intern Med. 1996";"156:1551-1556

title: Computer screensaver hand hygiene information curbs a negative trend in hand hygiene behavior.
abstract: Background Proper hand hygiene among healthcare workers is the most important infection prevention measure";" however, compliance is generally low. Profit-framed messages (ie, messages that emphasize the benefits of hand hygiene rather than the risks of non-compliance) may be more effective, but have not been tested. Methods The study was conducted in a 27-bed neonatal intensive care unit. We performed an interrupted time series analysis of objectively measured hand sanitizing events. We used electronic devices in hand sanitizer dispensers, which continuously documented the frequency of hand sanitizing events. In addition, hand hygiene compliance was directly observed before and after the intervention period. Results The negative trend in hand hygiene events per patient-day before the intervention (decrease of 2.3 [standard error, 0.5] per week) changed to a significant positive trend (increase of 1.5 [0 .5] per week) after the intervention (P < .001). Direct observations confirmed these results, showing a significant improvement in hand hygiene compliance from 193 of 303 (63.6%) hand hygiene events observed at pretest to 201 of 281 (71.5%) in the post test. Conclusions We conclude that profit-framed hand hygiene messages presented on screen savers can improve hand hygiene compliance.

title: Computer Administered Clinical Rating Scales. A review
abstract: Although clinician-administered symptom rating scales are the most widely used outcome measures in pharmaceutical research, error variance due to poor interrater reliability increases the risk of type II errors in multicenter clinical trials. Such error variation could obscure the true differences between active drug and placebo, or between two comparator compounds. Computer-administered versions of symptom rating scales originally designed to be administered by trained clinicians offer a solution to this problem. This article reviews the empirical data on the reliability, validity, and equivalence of computer-administered rating scales. Computer-administered versions of clinician-administered scales are now available for the assessment of depression, anxiety, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and social phobia. Validation studies support the reliability, validity and equivalence of these scales.
