Patient feedback has been positive, with patients generally more honest and often preferring the computer to assess sensitive areas such as suicide, alcohol or drug abuse, sexual behavior or HIV-related symptoms. Applications that use interactive voice response (IVR) technology facilitate the longitudinal follow-up of patients without the need for office visits to collect data, increase the accessibility of information for the doctor and the quality of patient care through of more informed decision making. When used in accordance with established ethical guidelines, computers offer a reliable, inexpensive, accessible, and time-efficient means of assessing psychiatric symptoms.

title: Computer-based decision support for the management of pediatric asthma: description and feasibility of the Stop Asthma Clinical System
abstract: Clinical guidelines can help in the management of asthma. Decision support systems (DSS) can improve adherence to clinical guidelines, but tend not to provide clinicians with clues for behavior change strategies to promote patient self-management. The Stop Asthma Clinical System (SACS) is a DSS designed for this purpose. To assess feasibility, seven clinicians used SACS to guide follow-up visits with 26 patients with predominantly persistent pediatric asthma. Data were collected through in-depth semi-structured interviews and surveys. SACS improved assessment of asthma severity and control, classification and intervention in environmental trigger and medication management problems, and development of an action plan (all p < 0.05). Doctor-patient communication was improved. The main challenge was that SACS increased the clinic visit time. SACS may improve physician behavior to improve patient self-management of asthma, but further studies are indicated to mitigate temporal limitations and assess the impact on physician and patient communication and behavior, as well as clinical outcomes.

title: Computerized clinical decision support during medication ordering for long-term care residents with kidney failure.
abstract: Objective: To determine whether a computerized clinical decision support system that provides real-time patient-specific recommendations improves prescribing quality for long-term care residents with renal failure. Design: Randomized trial within the long-stay units of a large long-term care facility. Randomization was within blocks by unit type. Alerts related to the prescription of medications for residents with renal insufficiency were shown to prescribers in the intervention units and hidden but tracked in the control units. Measurement: The proportions of final medication orders that were appropriate were compared between intervention and control units within alert categories: (1) recommended medication doses; (2) recommended administration frequencies; (3) recommendations to avoid the drug; (4) warnings Results: The rates of warnings were almost equal in the intervention and control units: 2.5 per 1000 days of residence in the intervention units and 2.4 in the control units. similar between intervention and control units (relative risk 0.95, 95% confidence interval 0.83, 1.1) for the remaining alert categories, significantly higher proportions of final medication orders were appropriate in units intervention: relative risk 2.4 for maximum frequency (1.4, 4.4) ; 2.6 for medications to avoid (1.4, 5.0);" and 1.8 for alerts to acquire missing information (1.1, 3.4). Overall, final medication orders were significantly more appropriate in the intervention units—relative risk 1.2 (1.0 , 1.4) Conclusions: Clinical decision support for physicians prescribing medications for long-term care residents with renal failure may improve the quality of prescribing decisions.

title: Computerized community cholesterol control (4C): meeting the challenge of secondary prevention.
abstract: Background: Dyslipidemia remains underdiagnosed and undertreated in patients with coronary artery disease. The Computer Based Clinical Decision Support System provides an opportunity to bridge these gaps. Objectives: To study the impact of computerized intervention in the secondary prevention of CAD[1]. Methods: The CDSS[2] was programmed to automatically detect CAD patients and assess the availability of an updated lipoprotein profile and lipid-lowering drug treatment. The program produced automatic computer-generated follow-up and treatment recommendations. Adjusted primary clinics were randomized to intervention (n = 56) or standard care (n = 56) arms. Reminders were sent to primary medical teams in the intervention arm every 4 months, updating them with current lipid levels and recommendations for further treatment. Compliance and lipid levels were monitored. The study group consisted of all CAD patients who were alive at least 3 months after hospitalization. Results: Follow-up was available for 7,448 patients with CAD (median 19.8 months, range 6 to 36 months). Overall, 51.7% of patients were adequately assessed and 55.7% of patients complied with recommended lipid-lowering treatment. A significant decrease in low-density lipoprotein levels was observed in both arms, but it was more pronounced in the intervention arm: 121.9 ± 34.2 vs. 124.3 ± 34.6 mg/dl (P < 0.02). A significantly lower rate of cardiac readmissions was documented in patients who received adequate treatment with lipid-lowering medications, 37% vs. 40.9% (p < 0.001). Conclusions: This initial evaluation of our data represents a real-world snapshot in which clinicians and CAD patients often do not adhere to clinical guidelines, presenting a major obstacle to implementing effective secondary prevention. Our automated computerized reminder system makes compliance with the guidelines much easier and supports broad implementation.

title: Computerized decision support based on a clinical practice guideline improves adherence to standards of care
abstract: PURPOSE: Clinical guidelines are designed to assist in the management of specific diseases; however, these guidelines are often neglected in care delivery. The purpose of this study was to determine whether clinicians' use of a clinical practice guideline would increase in response to having, at the patient visit, a decision support system based on a practice guideline that generates a protocol. personalized management for the individual patient using data from the patient's electronic medical record. SUBJECTS AND METHODS: In a 6-month controlled trial in a primary care clinical setting, 58 primary care physicians were randomized to receive a special encounter form with the guide's computer-generated recommendations or a standard encounter form. The effect of computer-generated advice on physician behavior was measured as the rate of adherence to guideline recommendations. Thirty physicians were analyzed; data from 28 physicians were excluded because these physicians did not meet predefined criteria for minimal exposure to diabetic patient care. RESULTS: The availability of patient management recommendations generated by the decisions resulted in a 2-fold increase in physician compliance with diabetes care guidelines (P = 0.01).Mean compliance for the group receiving the recommendations was 32.0% vs. 15% .6% of the control group CONCLUSION: Decision support based on a clinical practice guideline is an effective tool to assist physicians in the management of diabetic patients This decision support system provides a model of how a clinical practice guideline can be integrated into the process of care by computer to help clinicians manage a specific disease by helping them meet standards of attention. The use of decision support systems based on clinical practice guidelines could ultimately improve the quality of medical care.

title: Computerized decision support for drug dosing in renal failure: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Objective of the study Emergency physicians prescribe various discharge medications that require dose adjustment for patients with kidney disease. The hypothesis of this research was that decision support in a computerized physician order entry system would reduce the rate of medication overdosing for patients with kidney failure. Methods This was a randomized, controlled trial in an academic emergency department (ED), in which computerized physician order entry was used to write all prescriptions for patients being discharged from the ED. The sample included 42 physicians who were randomized to the intervention (21 physicians) or control (21 physicians) group. The intervention was a decision support that provided dosing recommendations for specific medications for patients older than 18 years when the patient's estimated creatinine clearance level was below the threshold for dose adjustment. The primary outcome was the proportion of targeted drugs that were overdosed. Results For 2,783 (46%) of the 6,015 patient visits, decision support had sufficient information to estimate the patient's creatinine clearance level. The average age of these patients was 46 years, 1,768 (64%) were women, and 1,523 (55%) were black. Decision support was provided 73 times to physicians in the intervention group, who overdosed 31 (43%) prescriptions. By comparison, control physicians overdosed a significantly higher proportion of medications: 34 of 46, 74% (effect size = 31%; 95% confidence interval 14% to 49%; P = 0.001). doses of medications requiring dose adjustment for renal failure. Computerized physician order entry with decision support significantly reduced overdosing of specific medications.

title: Computerized decision support to reduce potentially inappropriate prescribing to older emergency department patients: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To assess the effectiveness of computer-aided decision support in reducing potentially inappropriate prescribing in older adults. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. SETTING: An academic emergency department (ED) in Indianapolis, Indiana, where computerized physician order entry was used to write all medication prescriptions. PARTICIPANTS: Sixty-three emergency physicians were randomly assigned to the intervention (32 physicians) or control (31 physicians) group. INTERVENTION: Support for the decision that advised against the use of nine potentially inappropriate drugs and recommended safer substitute therapies. MEASUREMENTS: The primary outcome was the proportion of emergency room visits by older people that resulted in one or more prescriptions for an inappropriate medication. The main secondary outcomes were the proportions of medications prescribed that were inappropriate and the intervention clinicians' reasons for refusing decision support. RESULTS: The average age of the patients was 74 years, two-thirds were women, and just over half were African-American. Decision support was provided 114 times to the intervening physicians, who accepted 49 (43%) of the recommendations. Intervention physicians prescribed one or more inappropriate medications during 2.6% of visits to the elderly emergency department, compared with 3.9% of visits managed by control physicians (P = .02; odds ratio = 0.55, 95% confidence interval = 0.34-0.89) The proportion of all medications prescribed that were inappropriate decreased significantly from 5.4% to 3.4%. inappropriate for older people.This approach could be used in other efforts to improve emergency room care.

title: Computerized reminders to encourage cervical screening in family practice.
abstract: In a randomized trial, three ways to increase cervical screening rates were compared in women attending a family medicine center. Using computerized medical records, 1,587 women ages 18 to 35 who were due for a screening test were included in the study. In a control group, no formal method was used to encourage patients to attend screening tests, and 13.7 percent had a test within one year of testing. In one intervention group, a message was issued to the doctor identifying women visiting the center for a routine appointment as due for screening";" 16.1 percent were tested. Sending a letter to patients in a second group yielded a 25.9 percent compliance rate. In a third group, the practice nurse phoned patients to advise them to get tested, and 20.0 percent complied. Physician reminders provide a low-cost, opportunistic approach to reaching women who visit the clinic, but this approach should be supplemented by calling or sending a letter to those women who do not attend regularly.

title: Conducting Research in Community Care Centers: Ethical and Regulatory Implications
abstract: Successful research in community-based care settings requires collaboration between center staff and researchers. The ethical conduct of research implies respect for people, beneficence and justice. The research must comply with federal regulations and specific state laws. Interviews with 15 community care center administrators revealed differences in understanding of how research is regulated and the influence that research might have when a center provides access to researchers. A Facility Bill of Rights outlines principles related to the ethical conduct of research and questions to consider when deciding whether to provide researchers with access to a facility.

title: Confidentiality and investigation
Burden of congenital rubella syndrome in Morocco: a rapid retrospective evaluation
abstract: Background WHO recommends that countries considering the introduction of rubella vaccine in their immunization program assess the burden of congenital rubella syndrome to determine whether vaccination is warranted. However, few guidelines exist for such assessments in developing countries. We retrospectively estimated the burden of congenital rubella syndrome in Morocco and evaluated our rapid case detection methods.";" Background WHO recommends that countries considering the introduction of rubella vaccine in their immunization program assess the burden of congenital rubella syndrome to determine whether vaccination is warranted. However, few guidelines exist for such assessments in developing countries. We retrospectively estimated the burden of congenital rubella syndrome in Morocco and evaluated our rapid case detection methods.

title: Consensus on guidelines for stereotactic neurosurgery for psychiatric disorders.
abstract: BACKGROUND: For patients with psychiatric illnesses that remain refractory to "standard" therapies, neurosurgical procedures may be considered. Several local and regional expert groups have previously independently proposed guidelines for the safe and ethical performance of such procedures. METHODS: To build on these earlier documents, representative members of continental and international psychiatric and neurosurgical societies joined forces to develop and adopt a global pragmatic set of guidelines. These are intended to address a wide range of neuropsychiatric disorders, brain targets, and neurosurgical techniques, taking into account the cultural and social heterogeneities of healthcare settings. FINDINGS: The proposed consensus document highlights that while stereotactic ablative procedures such as cingulotomy and capsulotomy for depression and obsessive-compulsive disorder are considered "established" in some countries, they still lack level I evidence. Furthermore, it is noted that deep brain stimulation in any brain target tested so far, and for any psychiatric or behavioral disorder, still remains in an investigational stage. Investigators are encouraged to design evidence-based, science-based, randomized controlled trials for brain disease and target selection. Experienced multidisciplinary teams are a mandatory requirement for the safe and ethical performance of any psychiatric neurosurgery, ensuring documented patient refractoriness, proper consent procedures that respect patient capacity and autonomy, multifaceted preoperative and postoperative long-term follow-up evaluation and reports. of effects and side effects for all patients. INTERPRETATION: This consensus document on the ethical and scientific conduct of psychiatric surgery worldwide is designed to improve patient safety.

title: Consensus statement on panic disorder from the International Consensus Group on Depression and Anxiety
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To provide primary care physicians with a better understanding of management issues in panic disorder and to guide clinical practice with recommendations for appropriate pharmacotherapy. PARTICIPANTS: The 4 members of the International Consensus Group on Depression and Anxiety were James C. Ballenger (chair), Jonathan RT Davidson, Yves Lecrubier, and David J. Nutt. Four professors invited by the president also participated: David S. Baldwin, Johan A. den Boer, Siegfried Kasper, and M. Katherine Shear. EVIDENCE: The consensus statement is based on the 6 review articles that are published in this supplement and the scientific literature relevant to these topics. CONSENSUS PROCESS: Group meetings were held over a period of 2 days. On Day 1, the group discussed each review document and the chair and commentator (Dr. Kasper) identified key issues for further discussion. On day 2, the group discussed these key issues to reach a consensus opinion. After the group meetings, the consensus statement was drafted by the chair and approved by all attendees. CONCLUSIONS: The consensus statement provides standard definitions for response and remission and identifies the appropriate strategy for managing panic disorder in a primary care setting. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are recommended as drugs of first choice with a treatment period of 12 to 24 months. Drug therapy should be slowly discontinued over a period of 4 to 6 months.

title: Resource conservation theory and use of research in health systems
abstract: Background Health systems face challenges in using research evidence to improve policy and practice. These challenges are particularly evident in small, under-resourced health systems, which are often located in places (in Canada and around the world) with poorer health status. Although organizational resources have been recognized as important for understanding research use, resource theories have not been a focus of knowledge translation (KT) research. What resources, in general terms, are required for KT and how does their presence or absence influence the use of research? In this article, we consider the conservation of resources theory (COR) as a theoretical basis for understanding the ability to use research evidence in health systems. Three components of COR theory are examined in the context of KT. In the first place, resources are required for the acceptance of the research. Second, the threat of resource loss encourages resistance to the use of research. Third, resources can be optimized, even in resource-constrained environments, to build capacity for KT. Methods A scan of the KT literature examined the organizational resources required for research use. A multiple case study approach examined the three components of COR theory described above. The multiple case study consisted of a document review and key informant interviews with members of the research team, including government decision makers and health professionals through a retrospective analysis of four applied health research studies conducted. previously in a region with limited resources. Results The literature scan identified organizational resources that influence the use of research. The multiple case study supported these findings, contributed to the development of a taxonomy of organizational resources, and revealed how fears related to resource loss can affect research use. Some resources were found to make up for other resource shortfalls. Resource needs differed at various stages of the research use process. Conclusions COR theory contributes to understanding the role of resources in research use, resistance to research use, and possible strategies to improve research use. Resources (and lack thereof) may explain the disparities observed in the acceptance of research in health systems. This document offers a theoretical foundation to guide a deeper examination of the COR-KT ideas and supports needed for using the research in resource-limited settings.

title: Nurse education consultation for cardiovascular prevention - a 2-year randomized study
abstract: The objective of this study was to increase the adherence of patients to the treatment of hypertension through in-office training of nurses. Thirty-three nurses were included in the study. In the intervention group (IG), 19 nurses participated in a 3-day residential training course on the Stages of Change model, Motivational Interviewing, and guidelines for cardiovascular prevention, recruiting 153 patients. Sixteen control group (CG) nurses recruited 59 patients. A decrease in systolic and diastolic blood pressure and total cholesterol was noted in both groups over the 2 years. Heart rate (p = 0.027), body mass index (p = 0.019), weight (p = 0.0001), waist (p = 0.041), low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (p = 0.0001), index waist-hip ratio (p = 0.024), and perceived stress (p = 0.001) were greatly decreased only in the IG. At 2 years, 52.6% of the patients in the IG (p = 0.13) reached the goal of </= 140/90 mmHg blood pressure compared to 39.2% in the CG. For self-reported physical activity, there was a significant difference (p = 0.021) between the groups. The beneficial effects of office training on patient weight parameters, physical activity, perceived stress, and the proportion of patients achieving blood pressure control emphasize office training and the use of behavioral models to motivate patients. patients to comply with treatment.

title: Consumer satisfaction among patients and their general practitioners regarding the involvement of specialist nurses in the primary care of patients with urinary incontinence.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Urinary incontinence (UI) is a very common problem, but existing guidelines on UI are not followed. To align care with guidelines, an intervention to engage UI specialist nurses in primary care was planned and evaluated in a randomized controlled trial. Along with this intervention, we evaluated consumer satisfaction among patients and general practitioners (GPs). METHODS: Patients' satisfaction with care provided by specialist nurses (intervention group) or general practitioners (control group), respectively, was measured using a self-completed questionnaire. Physicians' views of nurse specialist involvement were measured in a structured telephone interview. RESULTS: Patient satisfaction score for specialist nurse care was 8.4 (scale 1-10), compared with 6.7 for usual GP care. More than 85% of patients would recommend the care of a specialist nurse to their best friends and 77% of GPs considered the role of the specialist nurse to be beneficial, with a mean score of 7.2. CONCLUSIONS: Although the sample was relatively small and the stability of the results only tentatively established, the substitution of specialist nurse for GP UI care appears to be well received by both patients and GPs. Small changes such as providing additional UI-specific information and devoting more attention to UI (which had received little attention before) would provide a simple tool to encourage patients to change their behavior in the right direction.

title: Contemporary challenges in education for the caring professions: education for nursing, midwifery and health visits
Contemporary Perspectives on Smoking Cessation: What Oncologists Need to Know
abstract: In the past 5 years there has been a tremendous growth in research on smoking cessation, fueled in large part by the publication of the 1996 Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Treatment of Tobacco Use and Dependence. These federal guidelines published by the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research offered comprehensive empirical evidence that smoking cessation interventions are effective and encouraged routine implementation within medical settings. Since then, numerous tobacco cessation studies have increased the state of knowledge about successful tobacco intervention modalities. Unfortunately, approximately one-third of cancer-related deaths continue to be attributed to smoking behavior. It is imperative that health care providers encourage and participate in the smoking cessation efforts of their patients and families. This article provides a review of the current literature on smoking cessation and describes first-line therapies with proven efficacy for smoking cessation. Physicians are encouraged to consistently assess tobacco use and provide brief interventions using behavioral counseling and pharmacotherapies to treat their patients' tobacco dependence.

title: Contingency management to induce exercise in university students.
abstract: Objective: The effects of contingency management to induce physical activity levels in seven physically inactive nonobese college students by providing monetary payments using a multiple baseline shift procedure were examined. Methods: Participants attended an initial phase, a subsequent intervention phase consisting of three exercise sessions per week for 4 weeks, and a follow-up session 2 weeks after the intervention. A total of $145 was available for attendance and exercise contingency payments. Results: The results indicate that all participants significantly increased exercise during the intervention from no activity at baseline to exercising for three 30-minute sessions per week. The participants maintained some gains during follow-up. Limitations: The study used a small and homogeneous sample size and required participants to exercise in a laboratory setting, which limited external validity. Conclusions: These findings suggest that incentive-based interventions are an effective and viable means of inducing exercise. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2016 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: Continued driving habits of patients diagnosed with excessive daytime sleepiness
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Description of driving behavior of patients with excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS) and the influence of diagnosis, therapy, guidelines and legal advice on their driving. DESIGN: Inventory based on questionnaires. SETTING: Center for Sleep and Wake Disorders, The Hague, The Netherlands. METHODS: All patients with EDS who were in a stable condition for at least 6 months after therapy were sent a questionnaire (n = 138). The questions concerned actual driving behavior, EDS, and the effects of diagnosis, therapy, and counseling provided by the Center. RESULTS: The response was 67% (n = 92). Eighteen patients had never driven a car. Eighteen of the other 74 patients stopped driving or drove less. Fifty-six patients did not change their behavior or drove further. There was little effect on driving behavior of diagnosis, therapy and advice to stop driving. CONCLUSION: EDS patients are often involved as drivers in modern traffic. Legal guidelines and medical advice have little influence on this behavior. Since general measures appear to be ineffective, approaches tailored to the individual patient may lead to more acceptable results.

title: Controlled trial of an audit facilitator in the diagnosis and treatment of childhood asthma in general practice.
abstract: Objective: to test whether an audit facilitator could alter the pattern of diagnosis and treatment of childhood asthma. Design: Stratified randomized controlled trial. Location: 12 general practices in Tayside. Subjects: 3,373 children aged 1 to 15 years inclusive who had symptoms suggestive of asthma or suspected asthma drawn from a systematic review of 10,725 general practice case records. Intervention: Children were screened for a clinical review by their general practitioner or practice nurses. Main outcome measures: Asthma-related consultations, prescriptions, hospital attendance, and health service costs 12 months before and after the study. Results: Compared with controls (n=1563), the intervention group (n=1585) had more practice-initiated asthma consultations (relative risk 2.18 (95% confidence interval 1.74 to 2 .73)), new diagnoses of asthma (2.83 (2.26 to 3.54) )), and previous diagnoses were reaffirmed (1.30 (1.08 to 1.58)), and they were prescribed with more frequently inhaled cromoglycate (1.52 (1.02 to 2.25)). Hospital day rates fell from 152 to 122 in the intervention group and increased from 69 to 117 in the control group between the year before and the year after the study. Total primary care costs increased from £30,118 to £37,243 in the intervention group and fell from £29,131 to £27,990 in the control group. The cost of hospital care fell in the intervention group from £25,406 to £20,727 and increased in the control group from £12,699 to £19,650. Conclusion: An audit facilitator may favorably influence diagnostic pattern and treatment of childhood asthma in general practice. This can have an impact on the costs of health services.

title: Controlling conflicts of interest in the doctor-patient relationship: lessons from Moore v. Regents of the University of California
Cooperation between occupational health insurance and physicians practicing occupational dermatology: potential for optimization in quality assurance
abstract: BACKGROUND: Quality assurance is a task of the medical profession, but it is also a duty of occupational health insurance (OHI). Data on the quality of interaction between physicians practicing occupational dermatology and the OHI are limited. MATERIAL AND METHODS: An online survey of 854 German members of the Working Group on Occupational and Environmental Dermatology was conducted in October 2013. Items included demographic data, a judgment on cooperation between dermatologists and OHI companies, an economic rating of the current compensation scheme and prioritization of optimization tasks. RESULTS: 182 members (21.3% of the invited population) participated in the survey. Cooperation with OHI companies was rated as "very good" by 10.8%, "good" by 56.7%, "satisfactory" by 24.2%, "sufficient" by 7, 0% and as "inadequate" by 1.3%. 93.4% of the interviewees mentioned problems and potential for improvement in the cooperation of their practice or clinic with the OHI companies. The main points of criticism were reimbursement (44.7%), followed by compromise of treatment options (36.5%) and delay or length of treatment in the dermatologist's procedure (29.4%). CONCLUSIONS: Although most physicians practicing occupational dermatology give a positive judgment of their cooperation with OHI companies, there are potentials for quality optimization regarding reimbursement of dermatological services, especially regarding counseling intensive in time in the prevention of occupational skin diseases, in the authorization of diagnosis and therapeutic procedures according to current guidelines and in a timely preventive intervention to take advantage of the therapeutic window before the chronification of skin diseases occurs. fur.

title: Core Outcome Measures for Opioid Abuse Liability Laboratory Assessment Studies in Humans: IMMPACT Recommendations
abstract: critical component in the development of opioid analgesics is the evaluation of their risk of abuse (AL). Standardization of approaches and measures used to assess AL has the potential to facilitate comparisons across studies, research laboratories, and medications. The goal of this report is to provide consensus recommendations regarding core outcome measures for evaluating the abuse potential of opioid medications in humans in a controlled laboratory setting. Although many of the recommended measures are appropriate for evaluating the AL of medications from other drug classes, the focus here is on opioid medications because they present unique risks to both physiological health (eg, respiratory depression, physical dependence) and for public health (eg, in pain) perspectives. A brief historical perspective on AL testing is provided, and then those measures that can be considered primary and secondary outcomes and potential additional outcomes in AL assessment are discussed. These outcome measures include the following: subjective effects (some of which comprise the primary outcome measures, including drug liking); physiological responses; drug self-administration behavior; and cognitive and psychomotor performance. Before presenting recommendations for standardized approaches and measures to be used in AL assessments, the appropriateness of using these measures in clinical trials with pain patients is discussed.

title: Reduction of multiple risk factors for coronary heart disease. Vendor Insights
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although primary care physicians understand the importance of preventive services for patients with multiple risk factors (MRFs) for coronary heart disease, medical intervention is limited. This study investigated (1) clinicians' views on the challenges they face in managing patients with MRF; (2) the counseling and management methods they use; and (3) potential strategies to improve MRF intervention in the primary care setting. METHODS: Two Approaches Focus groups with primary care physicians from various settings were conducted to gain insight into these topics listed above. Each group was co-facilitated by a clinician and behavioral scientist using a previously developed semi-structured interview guide. Group discussions were recorded on tape and later transcribed. Transcripts were analyzed using the constant comparative method for analysis. RESULTS: Physicians face knowledge limitations (contribution of individual risk factors to overall risk); limited support (guidelines, materials, and staff);" and logistical difficulties (organizational problems, time constraints). Their approach to managing MRF tends to be highly individualized with an initial preference for lifestyle change interventions over prescribing medications with some qualifying circumstances Clinicians favored a serial rather than parallel approach to MRF intervention, starting with behaviors perceived as a priority by the patient Proposed solutions to current challenges emphasize education of clinicians physicians and the development of innovative approaches that include medical assistance and a team approach CONCLUSIONS: Physicians are aware and sensitive to the complexity of managing MRF for their patients and themselves However, future MRF interventions will require the involvement of non-medical staff and increased systems support.

title: Management of coronary risk factors in primary practice in Shibuya, Tokyo
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Many large-scale clinical trials have confirmed that coronary risk factors such as hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus predict an increased incidence of cardiovascular events and that control of these risk factors reduces the incidence. However, the actual management of such risk factors and the resulting improvement in cardiovascular events in primary practice remains unclear. Heart Care Network Shibuya, a volunteer study group of regional primary care physicians, investigated coronary risk factor management and clinical outcomes. METHODS: Behavioral patterns of coronary risk factor management and resulting risk factor changes were investigated in 209 outpatients (mean age 65.6 +/- 11.2 years) with more than one hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus or previous myocardial infarction for 1 year. RESULTS: Prescriptions for antihypertensives (from 1.3 +/- 0.8 to 1.4 +/- 0.8 drugs per patient) and antihyperlipidemics (from 0.70 +/- 0.4 to 0.73 +/ - 0.4 drugs per patient) did not increase significantly. Patient education on diet (93% to 97%, p = 0.077), exercise (69% to 81%, p < 0.05), and not smoking (66% to 86%, p < 0.05) increased significantly after 1 year. Blood pressure decreased from 142 +/- 16/81 +/- 10 to 138 +/- 78/78 +/- 9 mmHg (p < 0.05), serum total cholesterol level decreased from 215 +/- 39 to 203 +/- 39 mg/dl (p < 0.05). As a result, more patients achieved the recommended treatment goals in the Japanese Society of Hypertension (34.6% to 46.8%) and the Japanese Atherosclerosis Society (40.2% to 49.5%) guidelines, respectively . However, none of the blood hemoglobin A1c levels, body mass index, or smokers changed significantly. CONCLUSIONS: Regional physicians attempted to control all coronary risk factors. Hypertension and hyperlipidemia, which are relatively more dependent on medical management, improved. In contrast, diabetes mellitus, obesity, or smoking, which require lifestyle changes, did not improve. The main issue in managing risk factors is how doctors act rather than specific actions.

title: Economic consequences of implementing an electronic decision support system for ordering laboratory tests in primary care: evidence from a controlled prospective study in the Netherlands
abstract: BACKGROUND: The economic consequences of interventions to promote rational and evidence-based use of laboratory tests by clinicians are not yet fully understood. We evaluated the economic consequences of a computer-based guideline decision support system (CDSS) for ordering blood tests in primary care. METHODS: We installed the CDSS in 118 practices [159 general practitioners (GPs)] in the Netherlands and calculated the costs of the intervention in this group. During a period of 6 months before and 6 months after the installation of the CDSS, the test requesting behavior of 87 (109 general practitioners) of these 118 study practices was studied and the results were compared with those of a control group. non-historical that did not receive the CDSS. In addition, the costs of laboratory requests for both groups were calculated. RESULTS: The total costs of the intervention, including development costs and installation costs, amounted to 79,000 euros (670 euros per visit). While the introduction of the CDSS did not affect the number of order forms sent to laboratories, it did reduce the number of blood tests per order form. As a result, the CDSS yielded an average cost savings for laboratory requests of 847 euros per practice for 6 months. CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrates that providing electronic decision support for ordering blood tests in primary care represents an economically promising concept. Laboratory cost savings are achievable and not offset by disproportionately high intervention costs.

title: Profitability of a clinical decision support system based on the recommendations of the European Society of Cardiology and other societies for the treatment of hypercholesterolemia: report of a cluster randomized trial.
abstract: Introduction and objectives To assess the cost-effectiveness of a clinical decision support system (CDSS) based on the recommendations of the European Society of Cardiology and other societies for the Management of Hypercholesterolemia (ESCHM). Study Design and Perspective A pragmatic, unblinded, cluster-randomized trial was conducted. To assess the impact on effectiveness and costs of a CDSS implementing an adapted version of the ESCHM recommendations, a side-by-side comparison with a usual care group over 1 year was performed. The contract period began in April 2000 and ended 1 year later. Effectiveness was defined as achievement of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) reduction targets in patients with baseline cardiovascular (CVR) risk >20% at 10 years (LDL-C targets <115 mg /dL for patients with coronary heart disease [CHD], or LDL-C <130 mg/dL for patients without CHD), or maintaining CVR <20% at study end in patients with baseline CVR <20%. The costs of treatments, visits and laboratory tests were estimated from the social perspective (costing year 2002). Methods ESCHM guidelines adapted by a steering committee included therapeutic recommendations aimed at achieving LDL-C goals in a cost-effective manner. To promote healthy cardiovascular lifestyles, items such as placemats and refrigerator magnets (with relevant promotional messages) were distributed to intervention practices. All study doctors recorded patient data in a specific application installed on their computer. In the case of interventional physicians, the CDSS was installed as an add-on module to this application and they were prompted to use it, but were otherwise free to adopt or ignore the recommendations. Adherence to the guideline was monitored by the CDSS. Patients with hypercholesterolemia were selected from 44 general consultations in Spain, mainly in the region of Catalonia. Main outcome measures and results 2221 patients were included in the study (1161 in the usual care group and 1060 in the intervention group). The intervention was shown to be as effective as usual care, both in an unadjusted analysis and after adjusting for absolute CVR and previous treatment with lipid-lowering drugs (LLD) [odds ratio (OR) 1.02; 95% CI 0.58, 1.77]. The intervention had no impact on lipid profiles. Intervention patients were prescribed LLD less frequently than usual care patients (OR = 0.37; 95% CI 0.26, 0.52; "p = 0.0001), particularly when CVR was low.This induced significant savings in treatments (p = 0.0001) and total costs (p = 0.001), which were estimated at 24.9% and 20.8%, respectively.The intervention increased the number of laboratory tests. The recommendations issued by the CDSS were accepted in 71.3% of the visits.Discussion and conclusions The CDSS based on the recommendations of the ESCHM did not modify the efficacy of usual care, but it induced considerable savings.

title: Cost-effectiveness of a manual-based coping strategy program for promoting the mental health of family caregivers of people with dementia (the START (STrAtegies for Relatives) study): a pragmatic randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess whether the START intervention (STRATEGIES FOR RELATIVES) added to treatment as usual is cost-effective compared with treatment as usual alone. DESIGN Cost-effectiveness analysis nested within a pragmatic randomized controlled trial. SETTING Three mental health and one neurological dementia outpatient services in London and Essex, UK. PARTICIPANTS Family caregivers of people with dementia. INTERVENTION Eight-session manual-based coping intervention delivered by supervised psychology graduates to family carers of people with dementia added to treatment as usual, compared with treatment as usual alone. PRIMARY OUTCOME MEASURES Costs measured from a health and social care perspective were analyzed along with Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS-T) total score of affective symptoms and quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) in cost-effectiveness analysis for eight months from the start. RESULTS Of the 260 participants recruited for the study, 173 were randomized to the START intervention and 87 to treatment as usual alone. Mean HADS-T scores were lower in the intervention group than in the treatment-as-usual group over the 8-month evaluation period (mean difference -1.79 [95% CI -3.32 to - 0.33]), indicating better outcomes associated with the START intervention. There was a small improvement in health-related quality of life as measured by QALY (0.03 (-0.01 to 0.08)). Costs were not different between the intervention and treatment as usual groups (£252 (-28 to 565) higher for the START group). Profitability calculations suggested that START had a greater than 99% chance of being profitable compared to treatment as usual alone with a willingness-to-pay threshold of £30,000 per QALY earned, and a high probability of profitability on the HADS-measure. T. CONCLUSIONS The START manual coping intervention, when added to treatment as usual, was cost-effective compared with treatment as usual alone for both outcomes (affective symptoms for family caregivers and caregiver-based QALYs). TEST RECORD ISCTRN 70017938.

title: Profitability of strategies to combat neuropsychiatric diseases in sub-Saharan Africa and Southeast Asia: a study of mathematical models
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the comparative costs and effects of interventions for five neuropsychiatric conditions (schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, depression, epilepsy, and excessive alcohol use). DESIGN Cost-effectiveness analysis based on an epidemiological model. CONTEXT Two subregions of the world defined epidemiologically by the World Health Organization: Sub-Saharan African countries with very high infant and adult mortality (AfrE)" and Southeast Asian countries with high infant and adult mortality (SearD). DATA SOURCES Published studies , cost databases MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Cost per capita and cost per disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) averted, expressed in international dollars ($Int) for the year 2005. RESULTS Through 44 intervention strategies evaluated for For the five neuropsychiatric conditions, cost-effectiveness values differed by up to two orders of magnitude (from $Int100-250 to $Int10,000-25,000 for a year of healthy life gained) was the most costly and least cost-effective strategy The strategies most profitable in the Africa subregion were related to population-based alcohol control, while in the Southeast Asia subregion the The most cost-effective intervention was pharmacological treatment of epilepsy in primary care. The cumulative cost per capita of the most cost-effective set of interventions covering all five conditions was estimated to be $Int4.90-5.70. This package comprises interventions for epilepsy (older first-line antiepileptic drugs); depression (new generically produced antidepressants and psychosocial treatment); bipolar disorder (lithium mood stabilizer medication); schizophrenia (neuroleptic antipsychotic drugs and psychosocial treatment);" and binge drinking (increased taxes and enforcement, reduced access and, in the African subregion, advertising bans and brief advice for heavy drinkers in primary care). CONCLUSIONS Reallocating resources to cost-effective intervention strategies would increase health gains, save money, and help implement much-needed expansion of services for neuropsychiatric conditions in low-resource settings.

title: Cost-effectiveness of strategies to combat vision and hearing loss in sub-Saharan Africa and Southeast Asia: a mathematical modeling study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the relative costs, effects, and cost-effectiveness of selected interventions to control cataract, trachoma, refractive error, hearing loss, meningitis, and chronic otitis media. DESIGN Cost-effectiveness analysis or combined strategies for the control of vision and hearing loss using a population model for life. CONTEXT Two World Health Organization subregions of the world where vision and hearing loss are a major burden: Sub-Saharan Africa and Southeast Asia. DATA SOURCES Biological and behavioral parameters from clinical and observational studies and population surveys. Intervention effects and resource inputs based on published reports, expert opinion, and the WHO-CHOICE database. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Cost per disability-adjusted life year (DALY) averted, expressed in international dollars ($Int) for the year 2005. OUTCOMES Chronic otitis media treatment, extracapsular cataract surgery, trichiasis surgery, meningitis treatment and Annual screening of schoolchildren for refractive error are among the most cost-effective interventions to control hearing and visual impairment, with a cost per DALY averted <Int$285 in both regions. Screening for hearing loss in both school-age children (annually) and adults (every five years) costs about $Int1,000 per DALY averted. These interventions can be considered highly cost-effective. Mass treatment with azithromycin to control trachoma can be considered cost-effective in the Africa sub-region, but not in the South-East Asia sub-region. CONCLUSIONS Control interventions for visual and hearing impairment are generally cost-effective. In deciding whether substantial investments in these interventions are warranted, this finding must be considered in relation to the economic attractiveness of other existing or new health interventions.

title: Cost-effectiveness of a nurse-based intervention (AIMS) to improve adherence among HIV-infected patients: design of a multicenter randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Non-adherence to HIV treatment can have a negative impact on treatment success rates, quality of life, infectiousness and life expectancy of patients. Few adherence interventions have shown positive effects on adherence and/or virologic outcomes. The theory- and evidence-based Adherence Improving Self-Management Strategy (AIMS) is an intervention that has been shown to improve adherence and viral suppression rates in a randomized controlled trial. However, evidence of its cost-effectiveness is lacking. Following a recent review suggesting that cost-effectiveness evaluations of adherence interventions for chronic diseases are rare and that the methodology of such evaluations is poorly described in the literature, this manuscript presents the study protocol for a trial multicenter that evaluates the effectiveness and cost. -effectiveness of AIMS among a heterogeneous sample of patients. Methods/Design The study uses a multicentre randomized controlled trial design to compare the AIMS intervention with usual care from a social perspective. Embedded in this RCT is an economic evaluation based on tests and models. A planned number of 230 HIV-infected patients are randomized to AIMS or usual care. Relevant outcomes include changes in adherence, plasma viral load, quality of life, and societal costs. The time horizon for the trial-based economic evaluation is 12 to 15 months. Costs and effects are extrapolated to a lifetime horizon for model-based economic evaluation. Discussion This multicentre RCT is designed to provide robust methodological evidence regarding the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a nurse-based counseling intervention (AIMS) in supporting treatment adherence among a large and heterogeneous sample of HIV-infected patients in the Netherlands. The aim of the current document is to describe the trial protocol in sufficient detail to allow a full assessment of the quality of the study design. It is anticipated that, if shown to be cost-effective, AIMS may contribute to improving evidence-based counseling guidelines for HIV nurses and other health professionals.

title: Cost-effectiveness of alternative strategies for the initial medical management of non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome: systematic review and decision analytic modeling
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To identify and prioritize key areas of clinical uncertainty regarding the medical management of non-ST elevation acute coronary syndrome (ACS) in current UK practice. DATA SOURCES: Electronic databases. Consultations with clinical advisors. Postal survey of cardiologists. REVIEW METHODS: Potential areas of significant uncertainty were identified and "decision problems" were prioritized. A systematic review of the literature was carried out using standard methods. The decision model built consisted of a short-term phase that applied the results of the systematic review and a long-term phase that included relevant information from a UK observational study to extrapolate cost and effect estimates. Sensitivity analyzes were carried out to examine the dependence of the results on the reference parameters, using alternative data sources. Information expected value analysis was performed to estimate the expected value of perfect information associated with the decision problem. This provided an upper limit on the monetary value associated with further research in the area. RESULTS: Seven current areas of clinical uncertainty (decision problems) in the pharmacological treatment of patients with unstable angina were identified. The agents in question were clopidogrel, low molecular weight heparin, hirudin, and intravenous glycoprotein antagonists (GPAs). Twelve published clinical guidelines for unstable angina or non-ST elevation ACS were identified, but few contained recommendations on specified decision problems. The postal survey of physicians showed that there was the greatest disagreement for the use of small-molecule GPA, and the greatest uncertainty for decisions related to the use of abciximab (a large-molecule GPA). In general, decision problems related to the GPA drug class were considered to be of highest priority for further study. The selected articles describing the clinical efficacy of the treatment were divided into three groups, each representing an alternative strategy. The strategy involving the use of GPA as part of the initial medical treatment of all non-ST-segment elevation ACS was the optimal choice, with an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) of £5,738 per quality-adjusted life year (QALY). ) compared with no use of GPA. Stochastic analysis showed that if the health service is willing to pay £10,000 per additional QALY, the probability of this strategy being profitable is around 82%, rising to 95% at a threshold of £50,000 per QALY. A sensitivity analysis that included an additional strategy of using GPA as part of initial medical treatment only in patients at particularly high risk (defined by age, ST depression, or diabetes) showed that this additional strategy was even more cost-effective, with an ICER £3,996 per QALY compared to no treatment with GPA. The value of data analysis suggested that there was considerable merit in additional research to reduce the level of uncertainty in the optimal decision. Using a threshold of £10,000 per QALY, the maximum potential value of such research in the base case was estimated at £12.7 million per year for the UK as a whole. Taking into account the increased uncertainty in sensitivity analyzes involving clopidogrel, this figure was increased to approximately £50 million. CONCLUSIONS: This study suggests the use of GPA in all patients with non-ST-segment elevation ACS as part of their initial medical treatment. Sensitivity analysis showed that virtually all of the benefit could be obtained by treating only high-risk patients. Further clarification of the optimal role of GPAs in the UK NHS is dependent on the availability of more observational data and high-quality trials. The value of the data analysis derived from the model suggests that a relatively large investment in such research may be worthwhile. Further research should focus on identifying the characteristics of patients who benefit most from GPA as part of medical treatment, comparison of GPA with clopidogrel as an adjunct to standard care, cost-monitoring cohort studies and outcomes for high-risk patients. Non-ST elevation ACS over several years, and explore how clinicians' decisions combine an evidence-based normative decision model with their own personal behavioral perspective.

title: Cost-effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy as an adjunct to pharmacotherapy for treatment-resistant depression in primary care: an economic evaluation of the CoBalT trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Depression is expensive to treat, but providing ineffective treatment is more expensive. Such is the case for many patients who do not respond to antidepressant medication. OBJECTIVES: To assess the cost-effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) plus usual care for primary care patients with treatment-resistant depression compared with usual care alone. METHOD: Economic evaluation at 12 months in conjunction with a randomized controlled trial. Cost-effectiveness assessed using a cost-consequence framework that compares the cost to the health and social care provider, patients, and society, with a range of outcomes. Cost-utility analysis comparing health and social care costs to quality-adjusted life years (QALYs). RESULTS: The mean cost of CBT per participant was £910. The difference in QALY gain between groups was 0.057, equivalent to 21 days per year of good health. The incremental cost-effectiveness ratio was £14,911 (representing a 74% chance that the intervention would be cost-effective at the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence threshold of £20,000 per QALY). Lost earnings and productivity costs were considerable, but there was no evidence of a difference between the intervention and control groups. CONCLUSIONS: The addition of CBT to usual care is cost-effective in patients who have not responded to antidepressants. Therefore, primary care physicians should be encouraged to refer these people for CBT.

title: Cost-effectiveness of guideline-approved treatments for low back pain: a systematic review.
abstract: Health care costs for low back pain (LBP) are rising rapidly. Therefore, it is important to provide treatments that are effective and cost-effective. The purpose of this systematic review was to investigate the cost-effectiveness of guideline-approved treatments for low-back pain. Nine clinical and economic electronic databases and the reference list of relevant systematic reviews and included studies were searched for eligible studies. Economic evaluations conducted in conjunction with randomized controlled trials investigating treatments for low back pain supported by the American College of Physicians and the American Pain Society guideline were included. Two reviewers independently reviewed the search results and extracted the data. The extracted data included the type and perspective of the economic evaluation, the comparison treatments, and the relative cost-effectiveness of the comparison treatments. Twenty-six studies were included. Most studies found interdisciplinary rehabilitation, exercise, acupuncture, spinal manipulation, or cognitive behavioral therapy to be cost-effective in patients with subacute or chronic low back pain. Massage alone is unlikely to be profitable. There were inconsistent results on the cost effectiveness of advice, insufficient evidence on spinal manipulation for people with acute low back pain, and no evidence on the cost effectiveness of medication, yoga or relaxation. This review found evidence to support the cost-effectiveness of guideline-approved treatments for interdisciplinary rehabilitation, exercise, acupuncture, spinal manipulation, and cognitive behavioral therapy for subacute or chronic low back pain. There is little or inconsistent evidence for other guideline-supported treatments.

title: Cost-effectiveness of HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis for people who inject drugs in the United States
abstract: Background: The total population health costs and benefits of HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) for people who inject drugs (PWID) in the United States are unclear. Objective: To assess the cost-effectiveness and optimal administration conditions of PrEP for PWID. Design: Empirically calibrated dynamic compartmental model. Data sources: Published literature and expert opinion. Target Population: US PWID Adults. Time Horizon: 20 years and lifetime. improved provision of antiretroviral therapy (ART) for people who become infected (PrEP+screen+ART). All scenarios are considered at 25% coverage. Outcome measures: infections averted, deaths averted, change in HIV prevalence, discounted costs (in 2015 US dollars), discounted quality-adjusted life years (QALYs), and incremental cost-effectiveness ratios. Base case analysis results: PrEP+screen+ART dominates other strategies, preventing 26,700 infections and reducing HIV prevalence among PWID by 14% compared to the status quo. Achieving these benefits costs $253,000 per QALY earned. At current drug prices, total expenditures for PrEP+screen+ART could be as high as $44 billion over 20 years. Sensitivity analysis results: The cost-effectiveness of the intervention is linear in the annual cost of PrEP and depends on the PrEP medication adherence, individual transmission risks, and community HIV prevalence. Limitation: Data on risk stratification and achievable efficacy levels of PrEP for PWID in the US are limited. benefits for the entire US population, but, at current drug prices, it remains an expensive intervention both in absolute terms and in cost per QALY gained.

title: Cost-effectiveness of practice-initiated quality improvement for depression
abstract: Context Depression is one of the leading causes of disability worldwide, but treatment rates in primary care are low. Objective To determine the cost-effectiveness from a societal perspective of 2 quality improvement (QI) interventions to improve the treatment of depression in primary care and their effects on patient employment. Design Cluster-level randomized controlled trial conducted from June 1996 to July 1999. Setting Forty-six primary care clinics in 6 community-based managed care organizations. Participants One hundred eighty-one primary care physicians and 1356 patients with positive screening results for current depression. Interventions Matched practices were randomized to provide usual care (n = 443 patients) or to 1 of 2 QI interventions offering training for practice leaders and nurses, enhanced educational and assessment resources, and medication tracking nurses (QI-meds) ; n = 424 patients) or local trained psychotherapists (QI therapy; n = 489). Practices could flexibly implement interventions, which did not assign treatment type. Main outcome measures Total health care costs, costs per quality-adjusted life year (QALY), burden of depression days, and employment over 24 months, compared between usual care and the 2 interventions Outcomes Relative to usual care, mean health care costs increased $419 (11%) in QI-meds (P = 0.35) and $485 (13%) in QI-therapy (P = 0.28); estimated costs per QALY gained were between $15,331 and $36,467 for QI medications and $9,478 and $21,478 for QI therapy;" and patients had 25 (P = 0.19) and 47 (P = 0.01) fewer days with burden of depression and were employed 17.9 (P = 0.07) and 20.9 (P = 0.03) more days during the study period.The social payoff of quality improvement efforts initiated in the practice for depression is comparable to that of accepted medical interventions.The effects of the intervention on employment may be of particular interest to employers and other stakeholders.

title: Costs associated with implementing a computer-aided clinical decision support system for antenatal and delivery care: a case study from Kassena-Nankana district in northern Ghana
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This study analyzed the cost of implementing computer-assisted Clinical Decision Support System (CDSS) in selected health care facilities in Ghana. METHODS: A descriptive cross-sectional study was conducted in the Kassena-Nankana district (KND). CDSS was implemented in selected health centers in KND as an intervention to manage patients attending antenatal clinics and the delivery room. CDSS users were primarily trained nurses. The activities and associated costs involved in the implementation of CDSS (pre-intervention and intervention) for the period 2009-2013 were collected from the perspective of the provider. The ingredient approach was used for cost analysis. Costs were grouped into personnel, training, overhead (recurring costs), and equipment costs (capital cost). We calculate the cost without annualizing the cost of capital to represent the financial cost and the cost with annualizing the costs of capital to represent the economic cost. RESULTS: Twenty-two trained CDSS users participated in the study (at least 2 users per health center). Between April 2012 and March 2013, users managed 5,595 prenatal clients and 872 work clients using the CDSS. A decrease in the proportion of complications during childbirth (pre-intervention 10.74% versus post-intervention 9.64%) and a reduction in the number of maternal deaths (pre-intervention 4 deaths versus post-intervention 1 death) were observed. The total financial cost of CDSS implementation was US$23,316, approximately US$1,060 per trained CDSS user. Of the total implementation cost, 48% (US$11,272) was pre-intervention cost and intervention cost was 52% (US$12,044). Equipment costs represented the largest proportion of the financial cost: 34% (US$7,917). When the economic cost was considered, the total cost of implementation was US$17,128, less than the financial cost by 26.5%. CONCLUSIONS: The study provides useful information on the implementation of CDSS in health facilities to improve the adherence of health workers to practice guidelines and make accurate decisions to improve maternal health care.

title: Could clinical audit improve the diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis in Cuba, Peru and Bolivia?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To assess the effectiveness of clinical auditing to improve the quality of diagnostic care provided to patients with suspected tuberculosis";" and understand the contextual factors that impede or facilitate their success. METHODS: Twenty-six health centers in Cuba, Peru, and Bolivia were recruited. Clinical audit was introduced to improve diagnostic care for patients presenting with suspected TB. The standards were based on WHO and TB program guidelines related to the appropriate use of microscopy, culture, and radiological investigations. At least two audit cycles were completed in 2 years. Improvement was determined by comparing performance between two six-month periods before and after the intervention. Qualitative methods were used to determine the facilitating and limiting contextual factors influencing the change in clinical behavior of health professionals after the introduction of clinical audit. RESULTS: We found a significant improvement in 11 of 13 criteria in Cuba, in 2 of 6 criteria in Bolivia, and in 2 of 5 criteria in Peru. Twelve of the 24 audit criteria in the three countries met the agreed standards. Barriers to quality improvement included conflicting goals for clinicians and TB programs, poor coordination within the health system, and patients' attitudes toward the disease. CONCLUSIONS: Clinical audit can drive improvements in the quality of clinical care in resource-poor settings. It is likely to be most effective if it is integrated into and supported by local TB programs. We recommend developing and evaluating an integrated quality improvement model that includes a clinical audit.

title: African American Counseling for Hypertension (CAATCH) Trial: A Multitiered Intervention to Improve Blood Pressure Control in Hypertensive Blacks
abstract: Despite strong evidence for effective interventions targeting blood pressure (BP) control, there is little evidence on the translation of these approaches into routine clinical practice in the care of hypertensive blacks. The objective of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a multilevel, multicomponent, evidence-based intervention compared to usual care in improving BP control among black hypertensives receiving care at community health centers. The primary outcomes are BP control rate at 12 months and maintenance of the intervention 1 year after the trial. Secondary outcomes are the patient's BP change from baseline to 12 months and the cost-effectiveness of the intervention. Counseling African Americans to Control Hypertension (CAATCH) is a cluster randomized clinical trial with 2 conditions: intervention condition and usual care. Thirty community health centers were equally randomly assigned to the intervention conditions group (n=15) or the usual care group (n=15). The intervention consists of 3 patient-directed components (interactive computerized hypertension education, home blood pressure monitoring, and monthly behavioral counseling on lifestyle modification) and 2 clinician-directed components (monthly case rounds). based on the National Joint Committee on Prevention, Detection, Evaluation and Treatment). of high blood pressure guidelines, chart auditing, and providing feedback on clinical performance and patients' home BP readings). All outcomes are evaluated at quarterly study visits for 1 year. The review of the graph is carried out at 24 months to assess the maintenance of the effects of the intervention and the sustainability of the intervention. Poor BP control is one of the main reasons for the mortality gap between blacks and whites. The findings of this study, if successful, will provide important information needed for the translation and dissemination of evidence-based interventions aimed at BP control in clinical practice for this high-risk population.

title: Counseling African Americans to control hypertension: main effects of a cluster randomized clinical trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Data are limited on the implementation of evidence-based multilevel interventions aimed at blood pressure (BP) control in hypertensive blacks receiving care in low-resource primary care practices. METHODS AND RESULTS: Counseling African Americans to Control Hypertension is a cluster-randomized clinical trial in which 30 community health centers were randomly assigned to intervention condition (IC) or usual care (UC). Patients at the HF centers received patient education, home BP monitoring, and monthly lifestyle counseling, while physicians attended monthly hypertension case rounds and received feedback on BP readings at home. home and audits of their patients' medical records. Patients and physicians at the UC sites received printed patient education material and hypertension management guidelines, respectively. The primary outcome was BP control, and the secondary outcomes were mean changes in systolic and diastolic BP at 12 months, assessed with an automated BP device. A total of 1,059 patients (mean age, 56 years; 28% men, 59% obese, and 36% with diabetes mellitus) were included. The BP control rate was similar in both groups (CI=49.3% versus CU=44.5%; odds ratio, 1.21 [95% confidence interval, 0.90-1.63]; P=0.21).In prespecified subgroup analyses, the intervention was associated with greater BP control in patients without diabetes mellitus (CI=54.0% vs. UC=44.7%; odds ratio, 1. 45 [confidence interval, 1.02-2.06]) and small community health centers (CI=51.1% versus UC=39.6%; odds ratio, 1.45 [confidence interval, 1 .04-2.45]). CONCLUSIONS: A multicomponent, practice-based intervention was no better than UC for improving BP control among black hypertensives. Future research on implementing behavior modification strategies for hypertension control in low-resource settings should focus on developing more efficient and personalized interventions in this high-risk population. CLINICAL TRIAL REGISTRATION URL: http://www.clinicaltrials.gov. Unique identifier: NCT00233220.

title: Creating a sustainable interprofessional team building program: first results
abstract: PURPOSE/OBJECTIVES: The purpose of evaluating this program was to explore whether incorporating deliberate learning concepts, by using simulated patient scenarios to teach interprofessional collaboration skills to a health care team in a hospital acute care unit , it would improve the resuscitation response in the first 5 minutes in that unit. DESIGN/SETTING: This was a pilot program evaluation using a clinical unit nurse specialist in the delivery of an interprofessional educational program involving simulation on an acute medical floor in a large tertiary care hospital. SAMPLE: Eighty-four staff members participated in 17 drills. The sample included first-year internal medicine residents, registered nurses, respiratory therapists, and patient care technicians. METHODS: This was a program evaluation using the TeamSTEPPS Teamwork Perceptions Questionnaire (T-TPQ) (class slides: TeamSTEPPS Essentials"; http://www.ahrq.gov/professionals/education/ curriculum-tools/teamstepps/instructor/essentials/sessentials.html#s3) during pre-/post-simulation sessions to assess participants' perceptions of teamwork Expected intervention behaviors were collected through observations of participants participants in the simulations and compared to the American Heart Association guidelines (Circulation 2010;122:S685-S670, S235-S337).Participants' common perceptions of the experience were elicited through open-ended evaluation questions. : Fifty-three participants completed the pre- and post-T-TPQ Average scores in the leadership category of the T-TPQ decreased significantly (p = 0.003) from pre- st (median, 2.167) to posttest T-TPQ (median, 2.566), only 35% of groups administered a defibrillation during ventricular fibrillation. simulation scenario, and only 1 group delivered this shock within the American Heart Association's recommended 2-minute time frame (Circulation 2010;"122:S235-S337). CONCLUSION: A single simulated resuscitation was not a sufficient intervention dose for staff to improve the resuscitation process A longitudinal study should be conducted to determine the effectiveness of the program after staff members have repeated the program several times IMPLICATIONS: A quality improvement simulation training program based on on the unit could help improve staff's first 5-minute resuscitation and response skills by increasing the frequency of unit-based training supervised by the unit's clinical nurse specialist.

title: Creating spaces in intensive care for safe communication: a video-reflexive ethnographic study
abstract: Background The built environment in acute care settings is a new focus in patient safety research, with few studies focusing primarily on the design of ward environments and the placement and choice of material objects, such as lighting fixtures and hand sinks. Methods We report on an interventional video-reflective ethnographic (VRE) study that explored how clinicians used the built environment to achieve safe communication in an intensive care unit (ICU) at a Sydney metropolitan hospital. We conducted 40 semi-structured interviews, 5 weeks of observation, and four reflective focus groups with a total of 87 participants (including medical, nursing, health assistant, and administrative staff). Results We found that staff and patient accessibility in ICU open spaces was both a safety feature and a safety risk, allowing safe communication flow but also allowing potentially unsafe interruptions. Staff managed disruptions while allowing for a safe degree of accessibility by creating temporary protected spaces, using physical markers such as curtains, tape, and signs, as well as behavioral cues, movement, and developing policies that restrict activities in certain areas. Additionally, clinicians were able to use the VRE method to better understand their own practices and problems, and develop meaningful solutions for other problem spaces. Conclusions ICU staff enable secure communication on their wards by creating temporary spaces that are 'connected' and 'protected'. The flexibility of these "soft" strategies is especially well suited to the fast-paced clinical setting of critical care.

title: Crisis Intervention: A Person-to-Person Immediate Help Manual., 4th ed.
abstract: It provides a framework for providing immediate problem-solving assistance to people in crisis. As a manual, it presents basic knowledge as well as methods adapted to particular circumstances. The book is intended for caregivers whose job involves regular or occasional crisis intervention efforts. The techniques are held to be applicable in crisis centers, hotlines, Internet-based services, victim assistance programs, university counseling centers, hospitals, schools, correctional facilities, children and youth programs, and other social service agencies. Users of the concepts include counselors, social workers, psychologists, nurses, physicians, clergy, correctional officers, probation and probation officers, and lay volunteers. Each chapter ends with study questions. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2016 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: Indicate the effects of prenatal providers on discussions of intimate partner violence
abstract: BACKGROUND: Intimate partner violence (IPV) during pregnancy poses a significant risk to the health of the mother and the developing fetus. Practice guidelines recommend that antenatal providers assess and counsel their patients about IPV, however many clinicians express reluctance or discomfort with such discussions. Health in Pregnancy (HIP) software was designed to improve counseling of prenatal providers about behavioral risks. METHODS: English-speaking women aged 18 years or older, less than 26 weeks pregnant and receiving prenatal care at one of five participating clinics in the San Francisco area, were randomized into parallel groups in a controlled trial. (June 2006-present) ;", data analyzed June 2007). Participants who reported one or more risks were randomized to intervention or control in stratified blocks. Providers received summary "tip sheets" alerting them to about their patients' risks and suggested advisory statements RESULTS: Thirteen percent (37/286) of the sample reported current IPV Provider prompts resulted in 85% of the IPV intervention group reporting conversations with their provider, compared to 23.5% of the control group (p<0.001).CONCLUSIONS: IPV discussions were strongly influenced by indication providers. Provider advice is an effective and appropriate adjunct to routine risk assessment in prenatal care.

title: Cultivating a culture of learning in general practice: an educational intervention
abstract: BACKGROUND: Increasing challenges are being faced in primary care, including the rise in chronic diseases and their management in the community. This document describes an educational initiative developed to help local general practitioners (GPs) and primary care teams manage chronic conditions and address referral behavior. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the initiative by exploring the experiences of participants and providers. METHODS: A variety of methods were used to collect data for the evaluation. These included participant feedback in the form of workshop evaluation questionnaires, semi-structured interviews of participants and presenters, and focus groups involving participants. RESULTS: Following data analysis, five themes were identified across all methods used. This document focuses on the key issues of 'practice change' and 'benchmark behaviour' in relation to the specific goals and objectives of the initiative. The data indicated that the participants had identified real changes in practice following their participation in the educational initiative, including changes in individual practice and prescribing behaviour, as well as in the provision of health care in the community. Identified changes in referral behavior were evident in feedback from participants and presenters in secondary care. Participants indicated the proposed changes, including an anticipated reduction in referrals to dermatology with increased management of conditions in primary care, as well as increased awareness of indications for early referral. The use of guidelines to assist in referral decisions was identified and the content and information required of referral letters was also a key area. CONCLUSION: Evaluation of this educational initiative has identified changes in practice in primary care and demonstrates how educational interventions can support and enhance future developments in primary care.

title: Culturally Tailored Chronic Illness Interventions Targeting Korean Americans: A Systematic Review
