abstract: OBJECTIVE: Because little is known about promising interventions to prevent and control chronic disease in Korean Americans, we conducted a systematic review of the literature to investigate: (1) the theoretical frameworks and strategies employed by targeted interventions to Korean Americans"; (2) the cultural factors considered by these interventions;" and (3) the extent of its success in engaging Korean participants and improving their health. DESIGN: Following PRISMA guidelines, PubMed, PsycInfo, and Web of Science were searched to identify primary research articles evaluating interventions to prevent or manage chronic disease, tailored to Korean Americans, and published from 1980 to 2011. Of 238 articles identified, 21 articles describing 16 single intervention trials that met the inclusion criteria. These interventions targeted cancer (10), hypertension (2), diabetes (1), mental health (1), smoking cessation (1), and general health (1). RESULTS: All included studies were published since 2000, reflecting the relatively recent establishment of intervention research with Korean-Americans. All 16 programs delivered linguistically appropriate messages and education. The 11 programs that achieved significant intervention effects also provided or coordinated social support from culturally relevant and well-trained health workers, nurses, or lay family members during an intervention and/or follow-up period. CONCLUSIONS: Culturally tailored and linguistically appropriate messages and education may not be sufficient to prevent or control chronic disease among Korean-American immigrants. Culturally sensitive and engaged social support should be provided to catalyze behavior change and maintain the effect of interventions.

title: Current management of transitional feeding problems in preterm infants born in Queensland, Australia.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Many preterm infants show difficulty establishing sucking-feeding competence in the weeks after birth. Ineffective management of transitional feeding problems can cause complications for the patient and may contribute to a longer length of stay. OBJECTIVES: Since many nurseries appear to vary in their neonatal feeding management practices, the aim of this study was to investigate and document the level of routine support and intervention currently provided to preterm infants with feeding problems. transition feeding at various levels II (special). care) nurseries (SCN) in Queensland, Australia. METHODS: A questionnaire was sent to all SCNs in Queensland in 2005 (n=36). The questionnaire contained a series of short-answer, closed-choice questions designed to elicit information from each SCN regarding their current practices for managing transitional feeding problems in preterm infants. The results were confirmed during a follow-up phone call. RESULTS: Responses were obtained from 29 SCNs (80.6%). None of these nurseries reported having formal, written policies regarding the management of transitional feeding problems in preterm infants. Wide variations were reported in relation to breastfeeding assessments and interventions used by staff within the various SNAs. Of the 29 nurseries, 4 (13.8%) reported using checklists or assessments to judge readiness to breastfeed, and 5 (17.2%) reported using pulse oximetry to judge tolerance to breastfeeding attempts. to suckle Eighteen SCNs (62.1%) reported offering some type of active intervention to help newborns with transitional feeding problems, with the most common intervention techniques reported to be non-nutritive sucking during tube feedings, oral pre-feeding stimulation and active feeding stimulation. Twenty-two SCNs (75.4%) reported having access to a lactation consultant to help mothers with breastfeeding problems. CONCLUSIONS: Differences in the routine management of transitional feeding problems in preterm infants were reported across the various SCNs in Queensland. It is suggested that evidence-based guidelines need to be developed and that to do this further research is required to determine current best practice as well as to answer remaining questions.

title: Current patterns and future directions in the treatment of insomnia
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite the high prevalence and burden associated with chronic insomnia, it remains largely unrecognized and often inadequately treated by clinicians. METHODS: A review of the literature on barriers to acute and chronic treatment of insomnia, as well as recent trials of pharmacological and non-pharmacological agents for insomnia, was conducted. RESULTS: Barriers to appropriate treatment of the condition include outdated guidelines for the management of insomnia, which have contributed to US Food and Drug Administration restrictions on long-term prescription of hypnotic agents; and fears of tolerance and withdrawal effects of long-term use of hypnotic agents, as well as the lack of long-term, randomized, controlled, double-blind trials of existing agents used to treat insomnia. CONCLUSIONS: There is evidence that improving sleep can improve outcome in some medical and psychiatric illnesses. Both behavioral and pharmacological therapies have shown efficacy in chronic insomnia. Furthermore, a recent 6-month randomized controlled trial has shown that at least one agent may be safe and effective in long-term use.

title: Reduce lab test ordering in a managed care setting by redesigning a computerized order form
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To increase the appropriate use of folic acid and vitamin B12 blood tests ordered by primary care physicians in a managed care organization in Israel by redesigning a computerized order form. STUDY DESIGN: Pre-post intervention. METHODS: A new version of the computerized order form was released. Usage patterns were calculated for vitamin B12, folic acid, and ferritin tests, which were previously pooled. Concomitant use patterns for hemoglobin and iron tests were evaluated as controls. RESULTS: Ordered tests for all 3 objectives decreased by 31% to 41% relative to the month prior to intervention, with a further decrease from 36% to 53% the following month. Negligible changes in utilization patterns were observed for controls (-2% to 3%) during the post-intervention period. CONCLUSIONS: Simple restructuring of a computerized order form significantly reduced the number of laboratory tests suspected of being unnecessary or redundant. When overuse of laboratory resources is suspected, managers should assess the efficiency of the organization's current ordering procedures before implementing resource-intensive interventions.

title: Cutaneous malignant lymphomas: 2006 update
abstract: Cutaneous lymphomas represent a unique group of lymphomas and are the second most common extranodal lymphomas. As with other neoplasms, the pathogenesis is based primarily on a stepwise accumulation of mutations in suppressor genes and oncogenes caused by genetic, environmental, or infectious factors. Diagnostic work includes clinical, histological, imaging, and hematological investigations and, in many cases, immunohistochemical and molecular biology analyses. The current WHO/EORTC classification of cutaneous lymphomas differentiates between "mature T- and NK-cell lymphomas", "mature B-cell lymphomas" and "immature hematopoietic malignancies", their variants and subgroups. It is compatible with the WHO classification for hematopoietic and lymphoid tissue neoplasms and respects the organ-specific peculiarities of primary cutaneous lymphomas. The assignment of the various types of cutaneous lymphomas into prognostic categories ("abortive" prelymphomatous disorders; definitive malignant low-grade lymphomas; definitive malignant high-grade lymphomas) provides essential information on the biological behavior and allows adequate planning of treatment. the therapeutic strategy, which can be topical or systemic and aggressive or non-aggressive. In addition to the classic therapy options, there are new and "experimental" strategies, the efficacy of which must be studied in clinical trials.

title: Daily co-trimoxazole prophylaxis in severely immunosuppressed HIV-infected adults in Africa who were started on combination antiretroviral therapy: an observational analysis of the DART cohort.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Co-trimoxazole prophylaxis may reduce mortality from untreated HIV infection in Africa"; it is unclear whether benefits occur in conjunction with combination antiretroviral therapy (ART). We estimated the effect of prophylaxis after initiation of ART in adults. ; BackgroundCo-trimoxazole prophylaxis may reduce mortality from HIV infection in Africa;" it is unclear whether there is any benefit in conjunction with combination antiretroviral therapy (ART). We estimated the effect of prophylaxis after initiation of ART in adults.

title: Decision aid for patients considering total knee arthroplasty with surgeon preference reporting: a randomized controlled pilot trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: To assess the feasibility and potential efficacy of a patient decision aid (PtDA) for patients and a preference report for surgeons to reduce waiting times and improve decision quality in patients with osteoarthritis considering total knee replacement. METHODS: A prospective two-arm pilot randomized controlled trial. Patients with osteoarthritis were eligible if they understood English and were referred for an initial total knee arthroplasty surgical consultation at a Canadian orthopedic joint evaluation clinic. Patients were randomized to the PtDA intervention or to usual education. The intervention was an osteoarthritis PtDA for the patients and a one-page preferences report that summarized the patients' clinical and decision data for their surgeon. The main feasibility outcomes were recruitment rates and questionnaire completion; preliminary effectiveness outcomes were waiting times and decision quality. RESULTS: Of 180 patients eligible for surgical consultation, 142 (79%) were recruited and randomized to the intervention of PTDA (n = 71) or usual education (n = 71). Data collection yielded a questionnaire completion rate of 93% with less than 1% missing items. After one year, 13% of patients remained on the surgical waiting list. off the waiting list (censored using survival analysis techniques) was 33.4 weeks for the PtDA group (n = 69, 95% CI: 26.0, 41.4) and 33.0 weeks for usual education (n=71, 95% CI: 26.1, 39.9) Patients exposed to PtDA had higher knowledge-based decision quality (71% vs. 47%; p<0.0001 ) and the quality decision was an informed choice that is consistent with their values for the option outcomes (56.4% vs. 25.0%; p < 0.001). CONCLUSIONS: Recruitment of patients with osteoarthritis considering surgery and data collection were feasible. Since some patients remained on the surgical waiting list after one year, follow-up should be extended to two years. Patients exposed to PtDA achieved higher decision quality compared to those receiving usual education, but there was no difference in waiting for surgery. TRIALS REGISTRY: ClinicalTrials.Gov NCT00743951.

title: Decision making in the surgical treatment of chronic low back pain: performing prognostic tests to select patients for lumbar spinal fusion
abstract: Chronic low back pain (CLBP) is one of the leading causes of disability in the Western world with an enormous economic burden on society. To date, no specific underlying anatomic cause for CLBP has been identified. Imaging often reveals degenerative findings of the disc or facet joints of one or more lumbar motion segments. These findings, however, can also be seen in asymptomatic people. It has been suggested that pain in degenerated discs may be caused by nerve fiber ingrowth into tears or crevices of the annulus fibrosus or nucleus pulposus, and by reported high levels of proinflammatory mediators. As this so-called discogenic pain is often exacerbated by mechanical loading, the concept of pain relief by spinal fusion has been developed to stabilize a painful spinal segment. For some patients, lumbar spinal fusion is indeed beneficial, but its results are highly variable and difficult to predict for the individual patient. To identify CLBP patients who will benefit from fusion, many surgeons rely on tests that are supposed to predict the outcome of spinal fusion. The three most commonly used prognostic tests in daily practice are immobilization in a lumbosacral orthosis, provocative discography, and trial immobilization by temporary external transpedicular fixation. In order to reach a consensus on the indications for lumbar fusion and improve its results through better patient selection, it is essential to understand the role and value of these prognostic tests for patients with CLBP in clinical practice. The general objectives of this thesis were: 1) to evaluate if there is a consensus among spine surgeons regarding the use and appreciation of prognostic tests for lumbar spinal fusion"; 2) to verify if a thoracolumbosacral orthosis (TLSO) really minimizes lumbosacral motion; 3) to verify whether a TLSO can predict the clinical outcome of fusion for CLBP; 4) to assess whether provocative discography of adjacent segments actually predicts the long-term clinical outcome of fusion; 5) to determine the incidence of postdiscography discitis and whether there is a need for routine antibiotic prophylaxis; 6) to assess whether transpedicular temporary external fixation (TETF) can help predict the outcome of spinal fusion;" 7) to determine the prognostic accuracy of the most commonly used tests in clinical practice to predict fusion outcome for CLBP. The results of a national survey among spine surgeons in the Netherlands were presented in Study I. Surgeons were asked about their opinion on prognostic factors and on the use of predictive tests for lumbar fusion in patients with CLBP. The comments were compared with the findings of the prevailing literature. The survey revealed a considerable lack of uniformity in the use and appreciation of predictive tests. Known prognostic factors from the literature were also not consistently incorporated into the surgeons' decision-making process. This heterogeneity in strategy is probably due to the lack of strong scientific evidence for current predictive tests and it was concluded that there is currently not enough consensus among spine surgeons in the Netherlands to create national guidelines for surgical decision making in CLBP. . In Study II, the hypothetical working mechanism of a trouser cast (ie, minimization of lumbosacral joint mobility) was studied. In patients admitted for a transpedicular temporary external fixation (TETF) trial, infrared light markers were rigidly affixed to the protruding ends of Steinman pins that were fixed at two spinal levels. In this way, the three-dimensional movement between these levels could be analyzed optoelectronically. During dynamic test conditions, such as walking, a cast, with or without unilateral hip fixation, did not significantly decrease lumbosacral joint motion. Although not supported by strong scientific support, lumbosacral orthoses or trouser casts are often used in daily practice as predictors of fusion outcome. A systematic review of the literature supplemented with a prospective cohort study (Study III) was conducted to assess the value of a trouser cast in surgical decision making. It appeared that only in CLBP patients without previous spinal surgery, a pantaloon cast trial with substantial pain relief suggests a favorable outcome of lumbar fusion compared with conservative treatment. In patients with prior spinal surgery, the test has no value. Many spine surgeons believe that provocative discography, unlike plain radiographs or MRI, is a physiological test that can actually determine if a disc is painful and relevant to a patient's pain syndrome, regardless of morphology. of the disk. It has been suggested that for a successful clinical outcome of lumbar fusion, suspect discs should be tender and adjacent control discs should be painless on provocative discography. For this reason, Study IV retrospectively analyzed a cohort of patients in whom the decision to perform lumbar fusion was based on a trial of external fixation (ETFT). Preoperative discography results of only the levels adjacent to fusion were compared with clinical results after spinal fusion. It appeared that in this select group of patients, the discographic status of the discs adjacent to a lumbar fusion had no effect on clinical outcome. The most feared complication of lumbar discography is discitis. Although of low incidence, this is a serious complication for a diagnostic procedure and prevention through the use of prophylactic antibiotics has been recommended. In search of clinical guidelines, the risk of postdiscography discitis was evaluated in Study V using a systematic review of the literature and a cohort of 200 consecutive patients. Without the use of prophylactic antibiotics, an overall incidence of postdiscography discitis of 0.25% was found. To show that antibiotics actually prevent discitis, a randomized trial of 9000 patients would be needed to reach significance. Given the possible adverse effects of antibiotics, it is concluded that the routine use of prophylactic antibiotics in lumbar discography is not indicated. In Study VI, the medium- and long-term results of external fixation (TETF) were studied as a test to predict the clinical outcome of lumbar fusion in a group of patients with back pain in whom there were doubts about the indication for lumbar fusion. Surgery. The trial included a placebo trial, in which patients were unaware whether lumbar segmental levels were fixed or dynamized. Using strict and objective criteria of pain reduction on a visual analog scale, the FTET test was unable to predict the clinical outcome of fusion in this select group of patients. Pin track infection and nerve root irritation were recorded as complications of this invasive test. It was concluded that in patients with chronic low back pain with a doubtful indication for arthrodesis, FTET is not recommended as a complementary tool for surgical decision-making. In Study VII, a systematic review of the literature was performed on the prognostic accuracy of tests currently used in clinical practice that are supposed to predict the outcome of lumbar spinal fusion for CLBP. The tests of interest were magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), TLSO immobilization, FTET, provocative discography, and facet joint infiltration. We were only able to select 10 studies that reported three different index tests (discography, TLSO immobilization, and FTET) that actually reported test qualifiers such as sensitivity, specificity, and likelihood ratios. The accuracy of all prognostic tests appeared to be low, confirming that in many clinical practices fusion is scheduled for patients on the basis of tests of insufficient or, at best, unknown accuracy. As the overall methodological quality of the included studies was poor, higher quality trials including fusion-negative and fusion-positive patients will be needed. We concluded that the best evidence does not currently support the use of any prognostic test in clinical practice. A subgroup of patients with low back pain for whom spinal fusion is a reliable and effective treatment could not be identified. In the literature, several studies have reported that cognitive behavioral therapy or intensive exercise programs have treatment outcomes similar to those of spinal fusion, but with considerably lower complications, morbidity, and costs. Since the findings of this thesis show that currently used tests do not improve fusion outcomes through better patient selection, these tests should not be recommended for surgical decision making in standard care. Furthermore, spinal fusion should not be proposed as a standard treatment for chronic low back pain. The causality of nonspecific spinal pain is complex and CLBP should not be considered as a diagnosis, but as a symptom in patients with different stages of impairment and disability. Patients should be evaluated in a multidisciplinary setting or Spine Center according to the so-called biopsychosocial model, which aims to identify underlying psychosocial factors as well as biological factors. Treatment should occur in a staggered manner beginning with the least invasive treatment. The current CLBP approach, which emphasizes self-management and empowerment of patients to take an active course of treatment, is recommended in order to prevent long-term disability and chronicity.

title: Declaration of Helsinki
abstract: Recommendations that guide physicians in biomedical research involving human beings.

title: Decree No. 93-1155 of May 17, 1993, promulgating the Code of Medical Ethics.
Default options in the ICU: widely used but insufficiently understood
abstract: Purpose of the review Default options dramatically influence the behavior of decision makers and can serve as effective decision support tools in the ICU. Its use in medicine has increased in an effort to improve efficiency, reduce errors and harness the potential of health technology. Recent Findings Default values often fall short of their intended influence when used in critical care settings as quality improvement interventions. Research reporting the use of default values is often limited by variations in relative effect between sites. Pre-implementation experiments and long-term follow-up studies are lacking. Summary Defaults in the ICU can help or hurt patients and clinical efficiency depending on their format and use. When building and finding noncompliance, providers must be aware of their powerful and complex influences on decision making. Additional evaluations of the appropriate creation of healthcare breaches and their resulting intended and unintended consequences are needed. Keywords: behavioral economics, choice behavior, communication, critical care, decision making.

title: The default configuration of computerized physician order entry system order sets drives ordering habits.
abstract: Background: Computerized physician order entry (CPOE) systems are rapidly becoming ubiquitous, and order groups ("order sets") to allow easy order entry are a common feature. This provides a simplified mechanism for viewing, modifying, and placing groups of related orders. This often serves as an electronic equivalent of a specialty application. One feature of these order sets is that specific orders can be predetermined to be "pre-selected" or "default on" whenever the order set is used, while others are "optional" or "default off" (although usually the option is to "deselect" the default tests in a given situation). While it seems intuitive that defaults in an order set are often accepted, further study is required to understand the impact of these "default" settings in an order set on ordering habits. This study set out to quantify the effect of changing the default configuration of a set of orders. Methods: In order to improve quality, transfusion-related order sets were recently reviewed and modified to improve outcome tracking. Initially, the default settings for post-transfusion hematocrit and platelet count changed from "optional" to "preselected." study the effect of predetermined selections from an ordering set on physicians' ordering habits. Results: Post-transfusion hematocrit values were ordered for 8.3% of RBC transfusions when the default order set selection was "off" and for 57.4% of transfusions when the default selection was "preselected." " (P < 0.0001). Post-transfusion platelet counts were ordered for 7.0% of platelet transfusions when the initial default order set selection was "optional", increased to 59.4% when the default was changed to "pre-selected" (P < 0.0001) and then decreased to 7.5% when the default selection was returned to 'optional'. Post-transfusion platelet count rates during the two "optional" periods, 7.0% vs. 7.5%, were not statistically different (P = .620). Discussion: Default settings in CPOE order sets can significantly influence physician selection of laboratory tests. Careful consideration should be obtained from all stakeholders, including physicians and pathologists, when setting default settings in order sets.

title: Defensive medicine among high-risk specialist physicians in a volatile malpractice environment
abstract: Context How often physicians alter their clinical behavior due to the threat of medical malpractice liability, called defensive medicine, and the consequences of those changes, are central questions in the current debate over medical malpractice reform. Objective To study the prevalence and characteristics of defensive medicine among physicians practicing in highly responsible specialties during a period of great instability in the malpractice environment. Design, Setting, and Participants Mail survey of physicians in 6 high-risk litigation specialties (emergency medicine, general surgery, orthopedic surgery, neurosurgery, obstetrics/gynecology, and radiology) in Pennsylvania in May 2003. Main outcome measures Number of physicians in each specialty reporting defensive medicine or changes in scope of practice and characteristics of defensive medicine (safety and avoidance behavior). Results A total of 824 physicians (65%) completed the survey. Nearly all (93%) reported practicing defensive medicine. "Safety behavior" such as ordering tests, performing diagnostic procedures, and referring patients for consultation was very common (92%). Among defensive medicine professionals who detailed their most recent defensive act, 43% reported using imaging technology in clinically unnecessary circumstances. Avoidance of procedures and patients that were perceived to increase the likelihood of litigation was also widespread. Forty-two percent of respondents reported taking steps to restrict their practice in the previous 3 years, including eliminating complication-prone procedures such as trauma surgery and avoiding patients who had complex medical problems or who were perceived to be as litigation. Defensive practice was strongly correlated with respondents' lack of confidence in their liability insurance and the perceived burden of insurance premiums. Conclusion Defensive medicine is very prevalent among Pennsylvania physicians who pay the most for liability insurance, with potentially serious implications for cost, access, and the technical and interpersonal quality of care.

title: Definition of optimal treatment with cholinesterase inhibitors in Alzheimer's disease
abstract: Despite the growing recognition that Alzheimer's disease (AD) represents a global public health and social care crisis, diagnosis is often slow and many patients still do not receive any treatment. Of those who do receive treatment, many remain on lower-than-recommended doses. The International World Charter for Alzheimer's Disease promotes awareness and understanding of AD, highlighting the importance of optimal treatment. However, the definition of "optimal treatment" is not clear. Since cholinesterase inhibitors became available nearly 20 years ago, clinicians have developed a variety of protocols based on clinical experience. This review considers what is optimal for various aspects of cholinesterase inhibitor therapy, taking into account initiation strategies, doses, modes of drug administration (eg, oral versus transdermal), and duration of treatment. treatment. Regardless of the management approach, people with AD, their families and carers have the right to timely diagnosis and access to the best available treatment.

title: Well Child Care Service Delivery: A Look Through the Door
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To describe the provision of well-child care and its components; compare that benefit to Bright Futures recommendations; and compare the provision of well-child care for children with special health care needs with that for children without special needs. METHODS: Over a 10-week period, 2 medical students observed and documented the characteristics of well-child visits performed by general pediatricians and mid-level pediatric providers. Parents completed a demographic questionnaire and an assessment for children with special health care needs. RESULTS: A total of 483 visits from 43 pediatricians and 9 mid-level providers with patients 0 to 19 years of age. The adjusted mean length of visit was 20.3 minutes; 38.9% of visits began with an open question about parent/child concerns. 7.2 Health Monitoring/Advance Counseling Topics Addressed Per Visit Physicians addressed an average of 42% of Bright Futures recommended age-specific health monitoring participatory counseling topics. Topics addressed less frequently than recommended included family support, parental well-being, behavior/discipline, physical activity, media screen time, risk reduction/substance use, puberty /sex, social interactions with peers and violence. Shorter visits were associated with questions about parent/child concerns and with addressing a higher proportion of recommended health supervision/advance guidance topics. Child wellness visits with children with special health care needs were 36% longer than those with children without special needs and addressed a similar number of age-specific anticipatory guidance/health supervision topics. More time was devoted to children with special health care needs, covering health supervision/advance guidance, other conditions (usually their chronic condition), and tests, prescriptions, and referrals. CONCLUSIONS: Using direct observation of visits with pediatric physicians, we found that parent/child solicitation of concerns occurred less frequently than recommended. Fewer than half of the recommended visit-specific health monitoring/preventive counseling topics were addressed, and there was little consistency with some Bright Futures age group-specific recommendations. Notably, both patient/parent request for concerns and greater adherence to health supervision recommendations/anticipatory guidance were associated with shorter visits. Well child follow-up visits with children with special health care needs were longer than those with children without special needs; more time was spent addressing a similar number of health monitoring/advance guidance topics, as well as their chronic conditions.

title: Demand management for planned care: a realistic synthesis.
abstract: Â Matching fluctuating demand with available capacity is one of the basic challenges in all large-scale service industries. It is a particularly pressing concern in modern health systems, as increasing demand (population aging, availability of new treatments, increased patient knowledge, etc.) meets supply stagnation (capacity and funding constraints). in staff and services, etc.). As a consequence, a very large portfolio of demand management strategies has been developed based on quite different assumptions about the origin of the problem and about the means of its resolution. This report presents a substantial review of the effectiveness of major strategies designed to alleviate demand pressures in the area of planned care. The study begins with an overview of the key insights into the genesis of health service demand and capacity problems. Many different diagnoses were discovered: fluctuating demand meeting "stationary capacity"; territorial protection between different providers; social rather than clinical pressures on referral decisions; self-propelling diagnostic cascades; provider-induced demand; demographic pressures on treatment; and the informed patient and demand inflation. We then conducted a review of the key ideas (program theories) underlying interventions designed to address demand imbalance. We found that there was not a close alignment between the alleged problems and the advocated solutions Demand management interventions have their starting point in seeking reforms at the levels of strategic decision-making, organizational reengineering, procedural modifications, and behavioral changes Mapping ideas for reform, we also noted a trend because the theories of program become "whole system" models; need for concerted action on all these fronts. The remainder and core of the report contains a realistic synthesis of the empirical evidence on effectiveness across a broad subset of four main demand management interventions: referral management centers (RMCs); use General Practitioners with Special Interests (GPwSI) at the interface between primary and secondary care; general practitioner (GP) direct access to clinical trials; and referral guidelines. In all cases we find a checkered pattern of success and failure. The primary literature is replete with accounts of unforeseen problems and unintended effects. These programs 'work' only under very limited conditions. To give brief examples, we find that the success of RMCs crucially depends on the balance of control in their governance structures; The GPwSIs influence the lawsuit only after close negotiations on an intermediate and agreed mix of cases; significant efficiencies are created by direct GP access to testing, particularly where there is low diagnostic throughput and high 'discard' rates;" and referral guidelines are more likely to work when implemented by staff responsible for their care. creation. The report concludes that there is no "preferred intervention" that has the ability to outperform all others. Instead, the review found many hard-won, local, and diverse adaptive solutions. Whatever the point of Starting off, success in demand management depends on the synchronization of a complex series of strategies, organisational, procedural and motivational changes.The last chapter offers practitioners a guide on how they might 'think through' all the interdependencies that balance demand and capacity A detailed analysis of the implementation of different configurations of interventions of demand management in different local contexts using mixed methods would be valuable to understand the processes through which such intervention actions are adapted to local circumstances. There is also scope for further synthesis of the evidence. Substitution theory is ubiquitous in health and social care and a realistic synthesis for comparing the fortunes of different professionals located at different professional boundaries (for example, nurses/physicians, dentists/dental care professionals, radiologists/radiographers, etc.) would be valuable in identifying the contexts and mechanisms through which substitution, support, or short-circuiting occurs. The National Institute for Health Research Health Services and Delivery Research Program.

title: Dementia care management: breaking new ground in ambulatory dementia care within a GP-based randomized controlled intervention trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: The increasing prevalence of dementia is a major challenge for the German healthcare system. The DelpHi-MV ("Dementia: Life- and Person-Centered Support in Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania") study aims to implement and evaluate an innovative subsidiary support system for people with dementia (PwD) living at home and their carers . METHODS: DelpHi-MV is a GP-based cluster-randomized controlled intervention trial. DelpHi-Intervention aims to provide "optimal care" by integrating multiprofessional and multimodal strategies to individualize and optimize dementia treatment within the framework of the established health care and social services system. The intervention is delivered by Dementia Care Managers (DCMs), nurses with specific training in dementia, in people's homes. Based on the German guidelines for evidence-based diagnosis and treatment of dementia, a comprehensive set of 95 intervention modules, the "DelpHi-Standard", was defined. Each module consists of predefined trigger conditions, a post-intervention task, as well as at least one criteria for its completion. The intervention begins with a comprehensive assessment of the care situation, needs and resources. The DCM develops and implements an intervention plan tailored to individual conditions in close collaboration with the GP. EXPECTED RESULTS AND CONCLUSIONS: We expect statistically significant differences between the control and intervention groups in the primary outcomes (quality of life, behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia, pharmacotherapy, caregiver burden). The results may provide evidence of the effectiveness and efficacy of dementia care management according to the "Delphi-Standard", prerequisites for implementing this concept in routine medical care.

title: Depression
Design and diffusion of the MOVE! Veterans Weight Management Program
abstract: BACKGROUND: Veterans Health Administration (VHA) professionals identified comprehensive weight management as a high priority in early 2001. PROGRAM DESIGN: The MOVE! The Veterans Weight Management Program was developed based on guidelines published by the National Institutes of Health and other organizations. Feasibility testing of the program was conducted at 17 VHA sites, and the program was refined during initial implementation throughout 2005. SPREAD: MOVE! it was released nationally in January 2006. Local program coordinators and champion physicians were appointed, and tools, online training, marketing materials, and ongoing field support were provided. EVALUATION: MOVE! it has been implemented in almost all VHA medical centers. As of June 2008, more than 100,000 patients had participated in MOVE! for more than 500,000 visits. An assessment based on an established framework is underway. CONCLUSION: MOVE! it is an example of large-scale translation of research into practice. It has the potential to reduce the disease burden of obesity and related conditions.

title: Design and evaluation of a computer reminder system to improve the prescription behavior of general practitioners
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the implementation of a decision support system with reactive computer reminders to improve medication prescription behavior. METHODS: A clustered RCT with incomplete block design was conducted in the south of the Netherlands: 25 physicians received antibiotic and asthma/COPD prescription reminders, 28 physicians received cholesterol prescription reminders. The prescription guidelines were integrated into the GP information system, which was installed in the GP practices of the intervention group. When the computer program was in use, a reminder would appear if the GP deviated from the guidelines during prescribing. PRIMARY OUTCOME: guideline prescription as a percentage of total prescriptions for a specific drug. In addition, an evaluation of the ease of use of the CRS in GP practice was carried out through questionnaires and interviews. RESULTS: Analyzes are currently underway. Preliminary results indicate that the CRS study supported our expectations. In general, there seems to be a reduction in the number of prescriptions according to the advice of the computerized guidelines not to prescribe certain drugs. The final analysis will be done shortly. In general, the Computer Reminder System was perceived as stable and easy to use. CONCLUSION: We created a stable and easy-to-use Computerized Reminder System that was adjusted to the needs and demands of GPs. Preliminary results on the effectiveness of the system seem to indicate that the implementation of a Computer Reminder System with reactive reminders improves medication prescription behavior.

title: Design and implementation of training to improve the management of pediatric overweight
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Physicians report low competence in the treatment of overweight children and the use of behavior management strategies. This document documents the design and implementation of a training program to improve clinicians' skills in the assessment and behavioral management of pediatric overweight. METHODS: Two one-hour CME trainings were designed using published guidelines, research results, and expert committee recommendations. The trainings were delivered to physicians in a pediatric managed care department, using innovative assessment and counseling tools and interactive exercises. Surveys and focus groups were conducted 3 and 6 months after the intervention to examine clinicians' attitudes and practices regarding screening and counseling tools. RESULTS: Post-intervention, most clinicians agreed that the Pediatric Obesity Practice Resource and BMI-for-age percentile provided useful information for clinical practice. Physicians reported increased use of recommended screening tools and changes in office practices to implement these tools. They offered suggestions to improve the ease of use of the tools and to overcome the barriers perceived by the doctor and/or the patient. DISCUSSION: Brief, cost-effective, multifaceted training and provision of counseling tools was perceived as useful for clinical practice. Useful lessons were learned about the design of tools and ways to adapt them to practice. Training the entire health team is advantageous for the adoption of new tools and practices.

title: Design and Methods of the Echo WISELY (Will Inappropriate Scenarios for Echocardiography Will Significantly Decrease) Study: An Investigator-Blinded Randomized Controlled Trial of Education and Feedback Intervention to Reduce Inappropriate Echocardiograms
abstract: BACKGROUND: The appropriate use criteria (AUC) for transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) were developed to address concerns about the inappropriate use of TTE. An earlier pilot study suggests that an educational and feedback intervention can reduce inappropriate TTEs ordered by trainees. Whether this type of intervention will be effective when targeted at attending-level clinicians in a variety of clinical settings is unknown. OBJECTIVES: The objective of this international multicenter study is to test the hypothesis that an educational and feedback intervention based on AUC will reduce the proportion of inappropriate echocardiograms requested by treating physicians in the outpatient setting. METHODS: An ongoing multicenter, investigator-blinded, randomized controlled trial in Canada and the United States will enroll cardiologists and primary care physicians practicing in the outpatient setting. The intervention arm will receive (1) a lecture describing AUC and the latest available evidence highlighting the appropriate use of TTE, (2) access to the American Society of Echocardiography mobile phone app, and (3) reports from individualized feedback emailed monthly summarizing TTE ordering behavior, including information about inappropriate TTEs and brief explanations of inappropriate designation. The control group will receive no education on the appropriate use of TTE and will request TTE as standard practice. CONCLUSIONS: The Echo WISELY (Will Inappropriate Scenarios for Echocardiography Lessen Significantly in an education RCT) study is the first multicenter randomized trial of an educational intervention based on AUC. The study will examine whether an education and feedback intervention will reduce the rate of inappropriate outpatient TTEs ordered by level-of-care cardiologists and primary care physicians (www.clinicaltrials.gov identifier NCT02038101).

title: Design factors for the success or failure of guideline-based decision support systems: a hypothesis involving the complexity of the case
abstract: Computer-based decision support systems (CDSS) today are mostly reminder systems. However, the effectiveness of such systems in modifying physician behavior is not always observed. We assume that this approach is appropriate when doctors believe they know how to prescribe and do not need help, that is, for simple clinical cases. In contrast, on-demand approaches that allow flexibility in interpreting patient conditions are more appropriate for more complex cases, for example, in the management of chronic diseases. ASTI is a CDSS that operates in two modes, a critique mode that works as a reminder-based system, and a user-initiated guidance mode. Using a clinical case complexity score, a pre/post-intervention experiment was conducted with 10 GPs and 15 hypertensive patient cases. Preliminary results tend to indicate that reminder-based interaction is appropriate for simple cases and that clinicians are willing to use on-demand systems as clinical situations become complex, making both modes complementary.

title: Design of high reliability organizations in health care
abstract: To improve safety performance, many healthcare organizations have sought to emulate high-reliability organizations from industries such as nuclear power, chemical processing, and military operations. We describe high reliability design principles for healthcare organizations, including formal structures and the informal practices that complement those structures. A staged model of organizational structures and practices is used, ranging from local autonomy to formal controls to open inquiry and deepen self-understanding, to illustrate typical challenges and design possibilities at each stage. We suggest how organizations can use the concepts and examples presented to increase their ability to self-design for security and reliability.

title: Design of the Balance@Work project: development, evaluation and systematic implementation of an occupational health guide aimed at the prevention of weight gain among employees
abstract: BACKGROUND: Occupational health professionals can play an important role in preventive health promotion activities for employees. However, due to a lack of knowledge and evidence- and practice-based methods and strategies, interventions are hardly being implemented by occupational physicians to date. The objective of the Balance@Work project is to develop, evaluate and implement an occupational health guideline aimed at preventing weight gain among employees. METHODS: Following the Dutch Society for Occupational Medicine guideline development protocol and the Intervention Mapping protocol, the guideline was developed based on the literature, interviews with relevant stakeholders, and consensus among a group of experts. The guideline consists of an individual and an environmental component. The individual component includes recommendations for occupational physicians on how to promote physical activity and healthy eating behavior based on motivational interviewing principles. The environmental component contains an obesogenic environment assessment tool. The guideline is evaluated in a randomized controlled trial among 20 occupational physicians. Occupational physicians in the intervention group apply the guideline to eligible workers for 6 months. Occupational physicians in the control group provide care as usual. Measurements are made at baseline and 6, 12, and 18 months later. Primary outcome measures include waist circumference, daily physical activity, and dietary behavior. Secondary outcome measures include sedentary behaviour, determinants of behavior change, body weight and body mass index, cardiovascular disease risk profile and quality of life. In addition, productivity, absenteeism and profitability are evaluated. DISCUSSION: Improving workers' daily physical activity and dietary behavior can prevent weight gain and subsequently improve workers' health, increase productivity, and reduce absenteeism. After an evaluation of the effect and the process, the guideline will be adjusted and, after authorization, published. Along with various implementation aids, the published guideline will be widely disseminated by the Dutch Society for Occupational Medicine. TEST REGISTRATION: ISRCTN73545254/NTR1190.

title: Design, implementation and evaluation of a knowledge translation intervention to increase organ donation after cardiocirculatory death in Canada: a study protocol
abstract: Background The shortage of transplantable organs is a worldwide problem. There are two types of organ donation: living and deceased. Deceased organ donation can occur after neurological determination of death (NDD) or cardiocirculatory death. Cardiocirculatory donation after death (DCD) represents the largest increases in deceased organ donations worldwide. However, there are variations in the use of DCDs within Canada and around the world. The reasons for these discrepancies are largely unknown. The purpose of this study is to develop, implement, and evaluate a theory-based knowledge translation intervention to provide practical guidance on how to increase the number of DCD organ donors without reducing the number of standard NDD donors. Methods We will use a three-step mixed method. In step one, we will conduct semi-structured interviews, informed by the Theoretical Domains Framework, to identify and describe stakeholders' beliefs and attitudes about DCD and their perceptions of multilevel factors influencing DCD. We will identify: determinants of the evidence-practice gap"; specific behavior changes and/or process changes needed to increase DCD; specific group(s) of clinicians or organizations (e.g. donor organizations provinces) who need a change in behavior;" and specific goals for interventions. In step two, using the principles of intervention mapping, we will develop a theory-based knowledge translation intervention encompassing behavior change techniques to overcome identified barriers and enhance DCD enablers. In step three, we will implement the intervention in hospitals across all 10 Canadian provinces and assess its efficacy using a multiple interrupted time series design. Discussion We will take a behavioral approach to defining and testing novel, theory-based and ethically acceptable knowledge translation strategies to increase the number of available DCD organ donors in Canada. If successful, this study will ultimately lead to more transplants, reducing patient morbidity and mortality at the population level.

title: Designing a patient-centered personal health record to promote preventive care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence-based preventive services offer important health benefits, but Americans receive only half of the indicated care. A variety of government and specialist society policy initiatives are promoting the adoption of information technology to engage patients in their care, such as personal health records, but current systems may not utilize the technology's full potential. . METHODS: Using a model described above to make information technology more patient-centric, we developed an interactive preventive health record (IPHR) designed to more deeply engage patients in preventive care and health promotion. . We recruited 14 primary care practices to promote the IPHR to all adult patients and sought practice and patient input in the design of the IPHR to ensure its usability, prominence, and generalizability. Input involved patient usability testing, practice workflow observations, learning collaborations, and patient feedback. Use of the IPHR was measured using practice citations and IPHR databases. RESULTS: The IPHR that emerged from this process generates personalized recommendations for patients based on guidelines from the US Preventive Services Task Force and other organizations. It extracts clinical data from the electronic medical record of the consultations and obtains information on risk assessment for the health of patients. The clinical content is translated and explained in common language. The recommendations review the benefits and uncertainties of services and possible actions for patients and physicians. Recommendations include self-management tools, risk calculators, decision aids, and community resources, selected to fit the patient's clinical circumstances. At six months, the practices had encouraged 14.4% of patients to use the IPHR (ranging from 1.5% to 28.3% across the 14 practices). Practices successfully incorporated the IPHR into the workflow, using it to prepare patients for visits, augment behavioral health counseling, explain test results, automatically issue reminders to patients about overdue services , inform doctors about the necessary services and formulate personalized prevention plans. CONCLUSIONS: The IPHR demonstrates that a patient-centered personal health record that interfaces with the electronic medical record can provide patients with a high level of individualized guidance and be successfully adopted by busy primary care practices. Further studies and improvements are needed to make information systems even more patient-centric and to demonstrate their impact on care. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Clinicaltrials.gov Identifier: NCT00589173.

title: Design of a valid randomized pragmatic primary care implementation trial: the my own health report (MOHR) project
abstract: Background There is a pressing need for increased attention to patient-centred health behavior and psychosocial problems in primary care, and for practical tools, study designs, and outcomes of clinical and policy relevance. Our goal is to design a scientifically rigorous and valid pragmatic trial to assess whether primary care practices can systematically implement patient-reported information collection and provide patients with the necessary counselling, goal-setting, and counseling in response. Methods This manuscript reports the iterative design of the My Own Health Report (MOHR) study, a cluster-randomized delayed intervention trial. Nine pairs from various primary care practices will be randomly assigned to early or late intervention four months later. The intervention consists of presenting the MOHR assessment ¨C addresses 10 domains of health behaviors and psychosocial problems ¨C and the subsequent provision of the necessary counseling and support for patients presenting for wellness or chronic care. As a pragmatic participatory trial, stakeholder groups, including practice partners and patients, were engaged throughout the study design to take into account local resources and characteristics. Participatory tasks include identifying the content of the MOHR assessment, refining the study design, providing information on outcome measures, and designing the implementation workflow. Study outcomes include scope of intervention (percentage of patients offered and completing MOHR assessment), effectiveness (patients reporting being asked about issues, setting goals for change, and receiving assistance in early versus late intervention practices) , contextual factors that influence the results and intervention costs . Discussion The MOHR study shows how a participatory design can be used to promote the consistent collection and use of patient-reported psychosocial and behavioral health assessments in a wide range of primary care settings. While pragmatic in nature, the study design will allow valid comparisons to answer the stated research question, and the findings will be broadly generalizable to a variety of primary care settings. According to the Pragmatic Explanatory Continuous Indicators Summary (PRECIS) framework, the study design is substantially more pragmatic than other published trials. The methods and findings should be of interest to researchers, practitioners, and policymakers trying to make health care more patient-centered and relevant.

title: Detection and management of alcohol use disorders in German primary care influenced by non-clinical factors.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The main objective was to assess the proportion of patients correctly detected and referred in German primary care. The secondary objective was to identify patient and provider characteristics that predict detection and correct referral. METHODS: In this pooled cross-sectional survey in German primary care, 3003 patients were consecutively invited to participate and asked to complete a standardized health questionnaire. They were then assessed for problematic alcohol use using the Alcohol Use Disorder Identification Test. Physicians recorded their assessment of the presence of any alcohol use disorder and documented the course of treatment for all identified patients for 3 months. RESULTS: Correctly identified problem drinkers were 38.6% in a per protocol analysis and 33.6% using the worst case scenario. Physicians' referral behavior was in accordance with current practice guidelines in 64.6% of documented cases and in 27.0% in the worst case. Various patient (eg, gender, age) and physician (eg, age) characteristics could be identified, influencing the diagnosis and referral of patients. CONCLUSIONS: There is a clear need to increase the special diagnostic and therapeutic skills of general practitioners so that they can indicate and perform secondary prevention. Further research should focus on the likely effects of implementing these diagnostic and management tools.

title: Detection of lymphocytotoxic antibodies in relatives of patients with type I diabetes
abstract: Lymphocytotoxic antibody concentrations were measured in serum samples from 19 patients with newly diagnosed type I diabetes and 43 healthy relatives (33 consanguineous and 10 non-consanguineous). The specificity of the reaction was tested at 15 degrees C and 37 degrees C against T cells and purified helper/inducer and cytotoxic/suppressor subsets. Lymphocytotoxic antibody concentrations in each of the three test groups were significantly higher than those in controls (type I patients, p less than 0.005"; blood relatives, p less than 0.001; and non-consanguineous relatives, p less than 0.002) The frequency of antibody detection was also higher in each of the study groups (p less than 0.01, p less than 0.01 and p less than 0.05, respectively). subgroups at 15°C, but only to cytotoxic/suppressor cells at 37°C Findings of lymphocytotoxic antibodies in healthy relatives of type I diabetics, regardless of consanguinity, suggest that an environmental agent such as a virus is at least partially responsible due to this lymphocytotoxic effect In addition, residual cytotoxic/suppressor cell death at 37 degrees C could explain the suppressor cell defect observed in these patients.

title: Determinants of health-promoting lifestyles in university students
abstract: This descriptive study of 151 college students in Boston, Massachusetts, was conducted to determine the relationships of their perceived health status, gender, grade point average, and health and non-health careers with their lifestyles that promote health. health, using the Health-Promoting Lifestyle Profile (HPLP). ) II, based on the Pender model. Students' perceived health status significantly predicted total HPLP II, exercise, stress management, and spiritual growth. College women practiced nutrition, interpersonal relationships, health responsibility, and total HPLP II significantly better than men. The entire sample scored lower on stress management than any previous group studied. Male students, those reporting health problems, and all students are targeted for intervention and research in their areas of weakness. Nursing practice guidelines are derived from the HPLP II questionnaire. These clinically significant findings may guide nurse practitioners to intervene in college students' health awareness and practices.

title: Determinants of successful clinical networks: conceptual framework and study protocol
abstract: Background Clinical networks are increasingly seen as an important strategy to increase evidence-based practice and improve care models, but success is variable and the characteristics of high-impact networks are uncertain. This study leverages the variability in performance and outcomes of networks supported by the Australian Clinical Innovation Agency New South Wales (NSW) non-mandatory model of clinical networks to investigate factors that contribute to the success of clinical networks. . Methods/Design The objective of this retrospective study is to examine the association between external support, organizational and program factors, and indicators of success among 19 clinical networks over a three-year period (2006-2008). Results (health impact, system impact, implemented programs, engagement, user perception, and financial leverage) and explanatory factors will be collected through an online survey, interviews, and record review. A panel of independent experts will make judgments about the impact or scope of each network's initiatives on health and system impacts. The scores of the expert panel will be the result used in the multivariate analyses. Following the rating of network success, a qualitative study will be conducted to provide a deeper examination of the most successful networks. Discussion This is the first study to combine quantitative and qualitative methods to examine the factors that contribute to the success of clinical networks and, more generally, it is the largest study of clinical networks conducted. The adaptation of expert panel methods to qualify the impacts of networks is the methodological innovation of this study. The proposed project will identify the conditions that should be established or fostered by agencies that develop clinical networks and will be of immediate use in shaping strategies and programs to maximize the effectiveness of such networks.

title: Development of a managed clinical network in palliative care: a realistic assessment
abstract: BACKGROUND: Achieving evidence-based practice is at the forefront of the international practice development agenda. Therefore, it is imperative that robust evaluation methodologies are in place to explore new approaches to service development. OBJECTIVES: This paper reflects on the merits and challenges of realistic evaluation design in establishing a new managed clinical network (MCN) approach to implement guidance related to the care of people with cancer-related pain. DESIGN AND METHODS: There were three evaluation points that examined three versions of the MCN approach to care. At each stage, steps were taken to identify the context, mechanisms, and outcomes associated with the version of the model under scrutiny. Findings from the patient-centered case studies were incorporated into realistic appraisal interviews with the management group. SETTING: A rural primary care setting in Scotland. PARTICIPANTS: Three older men, their families, physicians and nurses providing direct care participated, along with 13 members of the network management group. RESULTS: The research highlighted the level of effort required by professionals to introduce the MCN care approach. Progress was much slower than anticipated, sometimes frustrated by inexperience in change management and lack of familiarity with leading practice development projects and practitioner learning support. Issues related to the age-appropriateness of the evidence base in relation to the care of frail older people were also apparent. The professional group that experienced the most role change was district nurses and community pharmacists. CONCLUSION: The collaborative approach fostered by the realist evaluation framework was found particularly useful and there was consensus that evaluation had become an integral part of the intervention itself. There were a number of methodological challenges and the need to limit the depth of 'realistic unraveling'. However, as a formative approach, in the messy world of interdisciplinary practice development, realistic assessment proved to be a valuable design.

title: Development of a pain assessment tool for use by nurses in an adult intensive care unit
abstract: Critically ill patients are particularly vulnerable to pain, with patients citing it as their second biggest stressor in the ICU. Pain has also been identified as a complicating factor in critical illness. Despite this, pain management is often not considered a priority by the ICU team. Effective management can only be achieved with accurate pain assessment. However, this is difficult in critically ill patients, as patients are often unable to communicate verbally due to the presence of endotracheal/tracheostomy tubes, sedation, and paralytic agents. Therefore, nurses rely on behavioral and physiological indicators to establish the presence of pain. However, since these also occur in situations and conditions not associated with pain, there is a need for a systematic and objective assessment tool. Consisting of a numerical and verbal rating scale to facilitate documentation and auditing, the tool was developed as a result of ongoing refinement and evaluation. The tool scores a patient's pain by incorporating physiological and behavioral indicators and is used in conjunction with the Glasgow Coma Score and the Modified Sheffield Sedation Scale for a comprehensive neurological assessment. Because movement and surgery can exacerbate pain, evaluation is done at rest and during procedures such as suctioning and manual manipulation. As an aid to pain assessment and management, a flowchart and clinical guide have also been introduced. Although preliminary evaluation established the effectiveness of the tool as a means of estimating and recording pain levels in individual patients, it was apparent that there has been no change in the way pain is managed. To address this problem, the level of understanding of the nurses on pain management was verified and teaching sessions were given to increase the profile of pain management in the unit.

title: Development of a science of clinical utility in field study strategies of diagnostic classification systems for mental and behavioral disorders according to ICD-11
abstract: The Department of Mental Health and Substance Abuse of the World Health Organization (WHO) has developed a systematic program of field studies to evaluate and improve the clinical utility of proposed diagnostic guidelines for mental and behavioral disorders in Eleventh Revision of the International Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems (ICD-11). The clinical utility of a diagnostic classification is critical to its role as the interface between health encounters and health information, and to making ICD-11 a more effective tool to help the 194 WHO member countries, including United States, to reduce the burden of disease of mental disorders. This article describes the efforts of the WHO to develop clinically useful science regarding one of the two main classification systems for mental disorders. We present the rationale and methodologies for an integrated and complementary set of field study strategies, including large international surveys, formative field studies of the structure of clinicians' conceptualization of mental disorders, case-controlled field studies using experimental methodologies to assess the impact of changes in diagnostic guidelines on clinicians' diagnostic decision-making and ecological implementation field studies of clinical utility in the global settings in which the guidelines will ultimately be implemented. The results of these studies have already been used to make decisions about the structure and content of ICD-11. If clinical utility is indeed one of the most important goals of diagnostic systems for mental disorders, as their developers routinely claim, future revision efforts should continue to build on these efforts. (PsycINFO database record

title: Development of an intervention to promote the participation of young people in asthma check-up consultations with practicing nurses
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Article is a report of a study to develop an evidence-based pre-consultation guide for use by young people prior to an asthma review with a nurse practitioner. BACKGROUND: The participation of young people aged 13 to 19 years in consultations with health professionals may be limited by the lack of opportunities to learn the appropriate skills in triadic consultations. Evidence-based interventions have been developed to promote adult participation in consultations, but the needs of young people have not been specifically addressed. DESIGN: Guideline-informed multi-method design for the development of complex interventions. METHODS: A pre-consultation guide for youth was developed in 2007 by applying a health behavior change model, developing criteria by a panel of experts, and in consultation with youth using a nominal group technique. RESULTS: The concepts of the Health Action Process Approach model were applied to the development of the criteria that support the pre-consultation guide. In the nominal groups, the young people agreed that they had different needs from those of other children and adults. The consensus was that pre-consultation guidance should include disease-specific information, realistic photographs rather than Clip Art, consistent font styles, bullets and colors, short words, and mature language. Sample statements and questions written by young people were included in the evidence-based guide. CONCLUSION: The vision of young people can contribute to the development of interventions aimed at promoting communication in consultations with nurses. There is potential for this approach to be used to develop interventions in primary and secondary care for a variety of long-term conditions.

title: Develop guidelines for community child health staff and examine referral pathways and outcomes of care in supporting children with emotional and behavioral disorders.
abstract: The East Sussex Public Health Commissioners had asked if referral guidelines were needed to ensure children with the greatest concerns got support from Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services (CAMHS). Community child health doctors and nurses recorded all contacts with children with emotional and behavioral difficulties (EBD) over a one-month period. Data on the presentation of difficulties and on the intervention routes were recorded. The same children were seen five months later and the outcome was measured by clinical assessment and support offered. The work showed that child health staff managed cases both through one-off counseling sessions and through ongoing planned support. In addition, the use of the three-tier pathways recommended by the Department of Health was demonstrated. Analysis of recorded data was used to describe referral pathways and provide guidance on the characteristics of children requiring referral to CAMHS.

title: Development of guidelines for smoking cessation interventions for pregnant adolescents
abstract: More than 400,000 deaths a year in the United States are attributed to active and passive exposure to tobacco smoke. The Healthy People 2000 goals call for a reduction in tobacco use by high-risk populations, such as youth and pregnant women. This article describes guidelines for health professionals to address smoking cessation when working with pregnant adolescents and adolescent mothers who smoke.";" PIP: This article examines the essential components of smoking cessation and health promotion interventions for pregnant and parenting adolescents. It also outlines guidelines for health professionals to address smoking cessation when working with pregnant teens and teen parent smokers. Both pregnancy and tobacco use are increasing among teens in the US The evidence clearly indicates that cigarette use among pregnant teens is even higher than the national rate. Such a habit among pregnant adolescents presents an immediate risk to the fetus, in addition to a widespread risk of establishing entrenched patterns of smoking for the adolescent. Quitting smoking during pregnancy can have a profound effect on reducing infant mortality. In this regard, it is suggested that health professionals can have a positive influence on the health of mothers, babies and children by encouraging and supporting smoking cessation efforts in young mothers. The doctor is in a special position to provide this advice during health supervision visits. In general, the guidelines for intervention presented in this article can be used for school clinics with pregnant students and can be easily implemented in private practices or hospital clinics.

title: Developing Internet-Based Health Interventions: A Guide for Researchers and Public Health Professionals
abstract: BACKGROUND: Researchers and practitioners interested in developing health interventions online often rely on print and web-based resources to guide them through the process of developing online interventions. While helpful in understanding many aspects of best practices for website development, these resources lack concrete examples of experiences developing online interventions for health applications from the perspective of those delivering online health interventions. OBJECTIVE: This study is intended to serve as a series of case studies in the development of eHealth interventions to inform researchers and practitioners who are considering technology-based intervention or programmatic approaches. METHODS: A convenience sample of six study coordinators and five principal investigators at a large US-based land-grant university were interviewed about the process of developing online interventions in the areas of alcohol policy, adolescent health, medication adherence, and human immunodeficiency virus prevention. in transgender people and in men who have sex with men. Participants were asked questions that broadly addressed each of the four phases of the User-Centered Design Process Map from the US Department of Health and Human Services Research-Based Web Design and Usability Guidelines. Interviews were audio recorded and transcribed. Qualitative codes were developed using line-by-line open coding for all transcripts, and all transcripts were independently coded by at least 2 authors. Differences between coders were resolved by discussion. RESULTS: We identified the following seven themes: (1) hiring a strong (or at least the right) research team, (2) taking time to plan before beginning the design process, (3) recognizing that vendors and researchers have different values, goals, and language, (4) develop a detailed contract, (5) document all development decisions and activities, (6) use a content management system, and (7) allow additional time for testing and debugging your intervention. Each of these areas is discussed in detail, with supporting quotes from the principal investigators and study coordinators. CONCLUSIONS: The values held by the members of each participating organization involved in the development of the intervention or online program should be considered, as well as the objectives that the website is intended to meet. These defined values and goals should drive an open and explicit discussion about the scope of work, budget, and other needs from the perspectives of each organization. Due to the complexity of developing interventions online, researchers and practitioners need to become familiar with the process and how it may differ from developing and implementing in-person interventions or programs. To help with this, the intervention team should consider expanding the team to include computer science or learning technology experts, as well as tapping into the institutional resources that will be needed to successfully complete the project. Finally, we describe the trade-off between funds available for online intervention or program development and project complexity.

title: Developing Leadership Capacity for Guideline Use: A Cluster Randomized Control Pilot Trial
abstract: IMPORTANCE: The importance of leadership in influencing nurses' use of clinical guidelines has been well documented. However, little is known about how to develop and evaluate leadership interventions for guideline use. PURPOSE: The purpose of this study was to test a leadership intervention designed to influence nurses' use of guideline recommendations when caring for patients with diabetic foot ulcers in home nursing. This article reports on the feasibility of implementing the study protocol, trial findings related to nursing process outcomes, and leadership behaviors. METHODS: A mixed-methods pilot study with a post-only cluster randomized controlled trial and descriptive qualitative interviews was conducted. Four units were randomly assigned to control or experimental groups. Clinical and management leadership teams participated in a 12-week leadership intervention (workshop, teleconferences). Participants received summary chart audit data, identified goals for change, and created a team leadership action. Criteria for evaluating the feasibility of the protocol included: design, intervention, measures, and data collection procedures. For the trial, medical record audits compared differences in nursing process outcomes. PRIMARY OUTCOME: Nursing assessment score of 8 items. Secondary outcome: 5-item nursing care score based on change goals identified by intervention participants. Qualitative interviews described leadership behaviors that influenced guideline use. RESULTS: The completion of this pilot showed that some aspects of the study protocol were feasible, while others required further development. The trial findings noted no significant difference in the primary outcome. A significant increase was observed in the score of the 5 items chosen by the intervention participants (p = 0.02). In the experimental group, more relationship-oriented leadership behaviors, auditing, feedback, and reminders were described as leadership strategies. CONCLUSIONS: Findings suggest that a leadership intervention has the potential to influence nurses' use of guideline recommendations, but more work is required to refine the intervention and outcome measures. A taxonomy of leadership behaviors is proposed to inform future research.

title: Development of quality measures for the emergency service management of pediatric behaviors related to suicide
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Given the public health importance of suicide-related behaviors and the corresponding gap in the performance measurement literature, we sought to identify key candidate process indicators (measures of quality of care) and structural measures (resources and attributes). organizational) important to the emergency department (ED) management of pediatric behaviors related to suicide. METHODS: We reviewed nationally approved guidelines and published research to establish an inventory of measures. Next, we surveyed pediatric emergency physician experts to assess the level of agreement on the relevance (for patient care) and variability (between hospitals) of 42 candidate process indicators and whether 10 hospital and regional structural measures could affect these. processes. RESULTS: Twenty-three physicians from 14 tertiary care pediatric hospitals responded (93% of hospitals contacted). The candidate process indicators identified as the most relevant to patient care (>/= 87% agree or strongly agree) and the most variable across hospitals (>/= 78% agree or strongly agree) were time waiting time for medical evaluation"; referral to crisis intervention worker/program; mental health, psychosocial, or risk evaluation requested; any inpatient admission; psychiatric inpatient admission; post-discharge treatment plan; waiting time for the first follow-up appointment, follow-up obtained, and type of follow-up obtained Key hospital and regional structural measures (>/=87% agree or strongly agree) were the number of specialized personnel and the type of personnel specialized in or available to the ED; regional policies, protocols, or procedures;" and inpatient psychiatric services. CONCLUSIONS: This study highlighted candidate performance measures for managing pediatric suicide-related behaviors in the ED.
