The 9 candidate process indicators (covering triage, assessment, admission, discharge, and follow-up) and 4 hospital and regional structural measures deserve further development.

title: Building Team Leadership to Facilitate Guideline Use: Planning and Evaluating a 3-Month Intervention Strategy
abstract: BACKGROUND: Research describes leadership as important to guideline use. However, interventions to develop current and future leaders for this purpose are not well understood. OBJECTIVE: To describe the planning and evaluation of a leadership intervention to facilitate nurses' use of guideline recommendations for diabetic foot ulcers in home health care. METHOD: Intervention planning involved a synthesis of theory and research (qualitative interviews and chart audits). One workshop and three follow-up teleconferences were delivered at two sites for nurse managers and clinical leaders (n = 15) responsible for 180 staff nurses. The evaluation involved surveys and interviews in workshops. RESULTS: The intervention components best valued (four-point scale) were: identification of objective indicators (mean 3.7) and development of a team leadership action plan (mean 3.5). The pre-workshop barrier assessment scored the lowest (mean 2.9). Three months later, participants indicated that their leadership performance had changed as a result of the intervention, they were more engaged with staff, and they had clear implementation goals. CONCLUSIONS AND IMPLICATIONS FOR NURSING MANAGEMENT: Creating a team leadership action plan to operationalize leadership behaviors can aid in evidence-based care delivery. Access to clinical data and understanding of team knowledge and leadership skills prior to formal training will help nursing management tailor intervention strategies to identify needs and gaps.

title: Development of the protocol for the evaluation of the quality commitment initiative of the health foundation: an emerging approach
abstract: In 2004, a UK charity, The Health Foundation, established the 'Committing to Quality Initiative' to explore and assess the benefits of involving doctors in improving the quality of healthcare. Eight projects run by professional bodies or societies specializing in various areas of critical care were commissioned. An initiative development approach was adopted, accompanied by a two-tier evaluation: eight project self-evaluations and a related external evaluation. This article describes how the protocol for external evaluation was developed. Challenges faced included wide variation between and within projects (in focus, scope and context, and in understanding of quality improvement), the need to support project teams in their self-assessments while maintaining objectivity necessary and the difficulty of assessing the moving target created by the development approach adopted in the initiative. An initial period to develop the evaluation protocol proved invaluable in helping us explore these issues.

title: Development and Implementation of a Medical Oncology Quality Improvement Tool for a Regional Community Oncology Network: The Fox Chase Cancer Center Partners Initiative
abstract: Fox Chase Cancer Center Partners (FCCCP) is a community hospital/academic partnership consisting of 25 hospitals in the Delaware Valley. Originally created in 1986, the FCCCP promotes quality community cancer care through education, quality assurance, and access to clinical trial research. An important aspect of quality assurance is an annual medical oncology audit that compares quality indicators and guidelines and provides a roadmap for quality improvement initiatives in the community oncology clinical office setting. Each year, the FCCCP team and Associate Medical Oncologists construct disease site- and stage-specific indicators based on the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology. The concordance with multiple indicators is evaluated in 20 graphs of each community practice. A report for each FCCCP medical oncology practice summarizes documentation, screening recommendations, use of new drugs, and research trends at a particular disease site. Descriptive statistics reflect milestones met, number of new cases seen per year, number of disease site cases from tumor registry information, and clinical trial backlog total. Education and documentation tools are provided to physicians and nurses in the oncology practice. The FCCCP's clinical operations team, comprised of medical oncologists and certified oncology nurses, has been conducting quality audits of medical oncology practices for 7 years using NCCN-derived indicators. Successful audits involving gastric, colorectal and breast cancer have been the focus of recent evaluations. For the 2005 Stage II/III Breast Cancer Assessment, median compliance per parameter was 88%, with 15 of 16 practices achieving median compliance greater than 80%. A large-scale quality control audit is feasible in a community network of cancer partners. Recent evaluation of localized breast cancer shows high adherence to guidelines and identifies areas for focused education. The partnership between academic and community oncologists produces a quality review process that is broadly applicable and adaptable to changes in medical knowledge.

title: Development and implementation of a program to assess the medical need of patients for venous thromboembolism prophylaxis
abstract: Goal. The development and implementation of a program to assess the medical need of patients for venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis is described. Resume. Hartford Hospital's Departments of Pharmacy, Medicine, and Information Services collaborated to institute a program to improve VTE prophylaxis in medical patients. After assessing initial adherence to VTE prophylaxis, the departments developed an intervention consisting of a message to be displayed to providers through the institution's computerized prescription order entry (CPOE) system as a reminder to assess the patient looking for risk factors for VTE and the need for VTE prophylaxis. The message was displayed when a patient met predefined criteria for VTE risk factors. The message would no longer be displayed once mechanical or pharmacological VTE prophylaxis was an active order in the patient's medication profile. Extensive education about the program was provided to hospital staff, pharmacists, physicians, nurse practitioners, physician assistants, and nurses. The program was implemented in March 2007 on a pilot medical floor. To measure the impact of the program, a retrospective chart review was conducted using the developed risk assessment tool. The VTE prophylaxis compliance rate after implementation was 93%, compared to 49% before program implementation (p < 0.001). Before the program, only 25% of patients with a contraindication to drug therapy received mechanical prophylaxis, compared to 100% after program implementation. Conclusion. The use of message alerts through a CPOE system and an interdisciplinary team approach to assess patients' risk of VTE appeared to improve the use of VTE prophylaxis in medical patients.

title: Development and implementation of non-pharmacological protocols for the management of patients with Alzheimer's disease and their families in a multiracial primary care setting
abstract: PURPOSE: The majority of patients and families with dementia are cared for in primary care clinics. These clinics are rarely designed to provide the comprehensive care needed. The purpose of this article is to describe nonpharmacologic protocols for the management of patients with Alzheimer's disease and their families that are administered as part of a multifaceted care management intervention program in a multiracial primary care clinic. DESIGN AND METHODS: The nonpharmacologic component for the integrated collaborative care program was developed based on a review of the literature and prior clinical experience. Care is coordinated by a geriatric nurse who meets with patients, families, and primary care physicians. The non-pharmacological protocols included general educational guidelines on Alzheimer's disease. Specific protocols were also developed to treat the common behavioral disorders associated with Alzheimer's disease. An important component of the intervention is a monthly psychoeducational support group for caregivers. RESULTS: The intervention has been well accepted by patients, families and physicians. About half of the treatment group have regularly participated in the support group. IMPLICATIONS: The integration of behavioral interventions and team care within the primary care setting has been successful.

title: Development and testing of a care-based intervention for older adults with heart failure
abstract: The clinical and cost burdens of heart failure (HF) continue to increase, creating an immediate need for cost-effective interventions aimed at improving health outcomes. This article describes the development and testing of a care-based nursing intervention for older adults with advanced HF who have recently been discharged from acute care. The development process and the components of the intervention are presented. A methodology for testing the intervention is also presented. Through a phased development process that includes research, this intervention can be refined and used to guide clinicians, administrators, and policymakers in delivering high-quality care to older adults with heart failure.

title: Development of a behavior change intervention: a case study on the practical application of the theory
abstract: BACKGROUND: The use of theory in the implementation of complex interventions is highly recommended. A complex trial intervention, to improve self-management support for people with osteoarthritis (OA) in primary care, needed to be implemented in the Management of Osteoarthritis in Practice (MOSAICS) trial. One component of the trial intervention was the delivery by general practitioners (GPs) of an enhanced consultation for patients with OA. The aim of our case study is to describe the systematic selection and use of theory to develop a behavior change intervention to implement enhanced consultation delivery by the GP. METHODS: The development of the behavior change intervention was guided by four theoretical models/frameworks: i) an implementation of the change model to guide the overall approach, ii) The Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF) to identify the relevant determinants of change, iii) a model for the selection of behavior change techniques to address the identified determinants of behavior change, and iv) principles of adult learning. Methods and measures were identified to assess the impact of the behavior change intervention. RESULTS: The behavior change intervention presented GPs with a "well-defined change proposition"; addressed seven of the TDF domains (eg, knowledge, skills, motivation, and goals); incorporated ten behavior change techniques (eg, provision of information, skills testing, persuasive communication);" and it was taught in workshops that valued the experience and professional values of general practitioners. The workshops used a mix of interactive and didactic sessions, were facilitated by opinion leaders and used 'context-linked communication skills training'. The methods and measures selected to assess the behavior change intervention included: assessment of satisfaction with the workshops, GP report of intention to practice, and an assessment of GP videotaped consultations with OA patients. CONCLUSIONS: A stepwise approach to the development of a behavior change intervention, using theoretical frameworks to identify the determinants of change combined with behavior change techniques, has allowed for a systematic and theory-based development of a designed intervention. to improve GP consultations for OA patients. The success of the behavior change intervention in practice will be assessed in the context of the MOSAICS trial as a whole, and will inform understanding of the level of practice and patient outcomes in the trial.

title: Development of a complex intervention for the secondary prevention of coronary heart disease in primary care using the UK Medical Research Council framework
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To apply the UK Medical Research Council (MRC) framework for the development and evaluation of complex intervention trials to a primary health care intervention to promote secondary prevention of coronary heart disease. STUDY DESIGN: Case report of intervention development. METHODS: First, the literature related to secondary prevention and lifestyle change was reviewed. Second, a preliminary intervention was modeled, based on findings from the literature and focus group interviews with patients (n = 23) and staff (n = 29) from 4 general practices. Participants' experiences and attitudes toward the key components of the intervention were explored. Third, the preliminary intervention was tested in 4 general practices. After delivery of the pilot intervention, training sessions were evaluated by practitioners, and qualitative data related to intervention experiences were collected through semi-structured interviews with staff (n = 10) and patient focus groups (n = 17). RESULTS: The literature review identified 3 intervention components: a structured recall system, professional training, and patient information. Initial qualitative data identified variations in withdrawal system design, training requirements (medication prescription, behavior change facilitation), and information appropriate to potential study participants. The identification of detailed structures within the components of the intervention clarified how the intervention could be tailored to individual practice, clinician, and patient needs, while preserving the theoretical functions of the components. Findings from the pilot phase informed further modeling of the intervention, reducing administrative time, increasing practical training content, and omitting useless patient information. CONCLUSION: The application of the MRC framework helped determine the feasibility and development of a complex intervention for research in primary care.

title: Development of a complex intervention to promote appropriate prescribing and medication intensification in poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus in Irish general practice.
abstract: Background Poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) can be viewed as failure to meet recommended targets for the control of key risk factors, including glycemic, blood pressure, and lipid control. Poor control of risk factors is associated with significant morbidity, mortality, and health care costs. Failure to escalate medications for patients with poor control of T2DM when indicated is called clinical inertia and is a contributing factor to poor control of T2DM. Our aim was to develop a complex theory- and evidence-based intervention to improve appropriate prescribing and medication intensification in poorly controlled T2DM in Irish general practice. Methods The first stage of the Medical Research Council Framework was used to develop and evaluate complex interventions. To identify current evidence, we conducted a systematic review to examine the effectiveness of interventions targeting patients with poorly controlled T2DM in community settings. The behavioral change wheel theoretical approach was used to identify appropriate intervention functions. Workshops, simulation, collaborations with academic partners, and clinician shadowing were used to operationalize the intervention functions and design the elements of the complex intervention. Results Our systematic review highlighted that professional interventions, potentially through clinical decision support systems, could address poorly controlled T2DM. Appropriate intensification of antiglycemic and cardiovascular medications, by general practitioners (GPs), for adults with poorly controlled T2DM was identified as the key behavior to address clinical inertia. Psychological capacity was the key driver of behavior that needed to change, suggesting five key intervention functions (education, training, empowerment, environmental restructuring, and incentivization) and nine key behavior change techniques, which were operationalized in a complex intervention. The intervention has three components: (a) a training program/academic detail of targeted GPs, (b) a remote search tool to help GPs identify patients with poor control of T2DM in your practice and (c) web-based clinical decision support. system. Conclusions This article describes a multifaceted process that includes an exploration of current evidence and a deep theoretical understanding of behavioral predictors, resulting in the design of a complex intervention to promote the implementation of evidence-based guidelines, through of appropriate prescription and intensification of medication in poor patients. controlled DMT2.

title: Development of a minimization instrument for assigning a hospital-level performance improvement intervention to reduce waiting times in Ontario emergency departments
abstract: Background Rigorous evaluation of an intervention requires that its allocation be unbiased with respect to confounding factors; this is especially difficult in complex and system-wide healthcare interventions. We developed a brief survey instrument to identify factors for a minimization algorithm for hospital assignment. at the intervention level to reduce waiting times in the emergency department (ED) in Ontario, Canada. Methods Potential confounders influencing intervention success were identified by literature review and grouped by healthcare setting-specific stages of change. An international multidisciplinary study (clinical, administrative, decision-maker, managerial) evaluated these factors in a two-stage nominal group and modified Delphi process based on four domains: readiness for change, evidence base, face validity, and clarity of definition. . Results An original set of 33 factors was identified from the literature. The panel narrowed the list to 12 in the first round of polling. In the second survey, the experts scored each factor according to the four domains; Summary scores and consensus discussion resulted in the final selection and measurement of four hospital-level factors to be used in the minimization algorithm: improving patient flow as a hospital leadership priority; physicians' receptivity to organizational change; management efficiency" and physician incentives that support the goal of change. Conclusion We developed a simple tool designed to collect data from senior hospital managers on factors likely to affect the success of a hospital patient flow improvement intervention. A minimization algorithm will ensure a balanced allocation of the intervention with respect to these factors in the study hospitals.

title: Development of a tool to measure clinical competence in occupational therapy: a pilot study?
abstract: Clinical competence is generally defined as a combination of knowledge, skills, and professional behavior. It is typically assessed through written tests, direct observation, chart audits, customer satisfaction surveys, and supervisor ratings. This article describes the development and evaluation of a chart-stimulated recovery (CSR) measure that combines chart audit and clinical interview methods to assess the clinical competence of practicing occupational therapists. The CSR tool was developed using the Canadian Guidelines for Client-Centered Practice and leverages the global domains of competency: use of theory, assessment, program planning, intervention, discharge planning, follow-up, program evaluation, clinical reasoning, and professional conducts. This pilot study involved two independent raters/interviewers who evaluated twelve occupational therapists on two occasions using a random sample of client cases/records on each occasion. The results indicate that the CSR tool is not only reliable and valid, but also generic enough to be used. in a variety of practice settings as a global measure of job performance.

title: Developing an exercise program for older adults: pre-exercise testing, exercise prescription, and program maintenance
abstract: Health professionals have the technical skills, frequency of contact, and credibility with older adults to use exercise as a health-promoting and disease-preventing intervention. This article familiarizes the physician with how to develop an exercise program specifically for older adults. The health promotion and disease prevention outcomes of exercise in older adults are also reviewed, including an explanation of the three stages of exercise programming for older adults. Stage one is labeled pre-exercise testing and looks at testing protocols for aerobic capacity, body composition, flexibility, and strength. Guidelines on who should and should not exercise are also explored. The second stage of exercise programming is exercise prescription. An explanation of how to develop an initial level of training and guidelines on how to set goals based on initial pre-exercise testing are presented. Program maintenance is the third stage";" this includes suggestions for designing an exercise program that increases program adherence, reduces burnout, and prevents relapse into non-exercise behaviors.

title: Development of an ICF-based clinical practice guideline for the assessment of function in head and neck cancer
abstract: BACKGROUND: Functional outcome after head and neck cancer is not regularly assessed in a standardized way in clinical practice. Clinical trials evaluating functional outcome apply many different instruments. Therefore, the results are not always comparable and have limited clinical implications. The aim of this study was the identification, interdisciplinary evaluation, and recommendation of functional outcome instruments for use in clinical practice and clinical trials in patients with HNC. MATERIAL: The preparatory studies developed a short list of outcome instruments based on previously determined criteria. An interdisciplinary group of experts evaluated these instruments and decided which ones can be recommended for use in 3 application areas: screening, evaluation/planning of therapies, and clinical trials. Healthcare decision-makers included physicians (ENT and maxillofacial surgeons, radiation therapists, oncologists), medical psychologists, speech and language therapists, physical therapists, and social workers. RESULTS: 98 instruments were presented at the consensus conference. In total, 21 participants recommended for each of the 3 application areas a basic set of measures for the assessment of impairment in 6 functional domains: monitoring of follow-up therapy, pain, ingestion, voice/speech, other organic problems and problems. psychosocial. CONCLUSION: A multiprofessional expert group discussed and adopted recommendations for the use of functional outcome instruments in clinical practice and/or research. The recommended instruments are now available for use in clinical routine.

title: Development of clinical practice guidelines for the nursing care of people undergoing percutaneous coronary interventions: an Australian and New Zealand collaboration
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This article describes the development of nursing practice guidelines for percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). BACKGROUND: Clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) supporting PCI nursing care are limited. METHOD: The National Health and Medical Research Council (NH&MRC) development guidelines for medical and health practices were used for the guideline development process. A panel of experts (physicians and consumers) attended a consensus conference to review the existing evidence. Subsequently, the opinions of the nurses were identified through an online survey. This was followed by a modified Delphi method that was used to refine a draft guideline in two rounds. RESULTS: The consensus conference was attended by 41 participants (39 cardiovascular nurses and 2 consumer representatives). Eight additional members joined the panel for modified Delphi rounds with 27 participants completing the survey online. The final guideline document consisted of 75 recommendations. Endorsement was then sought from the leading cardiovascular bodies in Australia and New Zealand. DISCUSSION/CONCLUSION: Inconclusive evidence precludes definitive recommendations. Therefore, consultation and consensus are important in developing guidelines for standardized nursing care and outcome monitoring. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: Nurses play a crucial role in IPC care, however there are currently limited guidelines to inform practice. This document describes the method of clinical practice guideline development and consensus building.

title: Developing geriatric competencies for emergency medicine residents through an expert consensus process
abstract: BACKGROUND: The rate of emergency department (ED) visits for older patients exceeds that for all age groups except infants. The aging of the population will increase the use of older patients in the emergency department from 35% to 60% of all visits. Older patients can have complex clinical presentations and be resource intensive. Evidence indicates that emergency physicians do not provide consistent high-quality care to older patients with emergencies, resulting in poor clinical outcomes. OBJECTIVES: The objective was to develop a consensus document, "Geriatric Competencies for Emergency Medicine Residents," by identified experts. This is a minimum set of behavior-based performance standards that all residents should be able to demonstrate upon completion of their residency training. METHODS: This consensus-based process used an inductive, qualitative, multiphase approach to determine the minimum geriatric competencies needed by emergency medicine (EM) residents. Face validity and reliability assessments were used throughout the project. RESULTS: In Phase I, participants (n=363) identified 12 domains and 300 potential competencies. In Phase II, a panel of experts (n=24) pooled the responses from Phase I, resulting in eight domains and 72 competencies. In Phase III, the expert panel narrowed the competencies down to 26. In Phase IV, face validity and reliability analysis yielded 100% consensus for eight domains and 26 competencies. Domains identified were "atypical disease presentation"; trauma, including falls; cognitive and behavioral disorders; emergent intervention modifications; medication management; care transitions; pain management and palliative care"; and the effect of comorbid conditions. CONCLUSIONS: The Geriatric Competencies for MS Residents is a consensus document that can form the basis for MS residency curricula and assessment to meet the demands of our aging population.

title: Development, implementation and evaluation of an asthma care model based on a community pharmacy
abstract: BACKGROUND Pharmacists are in a unique position in the health care system to address critical issues in the management of asthma in the community. Several programs have demonstrated the benefits of a pharmacist-led asthma care program; however, none of these programs have been previously evaluated in Australia. OBJECTIVE To measure the impact of a specialized asthma service provided through community pharmacies in terms of clinical, humanistic and clinical objectives for the patient. METHODS A parallel controlled design was used, in which 52 intervention patients and 50 control patients with asthma were recruited at 2 different sites. In the intervention area, pharmacists were trained and an asthma care model was delivered, with 3 follow-ups. visits over 6 months. This model was evaluated based on clinical, humanistic and economic outcomes compared between and within groups. RESULTS There was a significant reduction in asthma severity in the intervention group, 2.6 ± 0.5 to 1.6 ± 0.7 (mean ± SD;" p < 0.001) versus the control group, 2.3 ± 0.7 to 2.4 ± 0.5. In the intervention group, peak flow rates improved from 82.7% ± 8.2% at baseline to 87.4% ± 8.9% (p < 0.001) at the final visit, and there was a significant reduction in the defined daily dose of albuterol used by patients, from 374.8 ± 314.8 µg at baseline to 198.4 ± 196.9 µg at final visit (p < 0.015) There was also a statistically significant improvement in perceived asthma control and asthma-related knowledge scores in the intervention group compared to the control group between baseline and final visit Annual savings of $132.84 (AU) in medication costs were demonstrated $100,801.20 per patient and $100,801.20 for the entire group, based on overall reduction in severity. CONCLUSIONS Based on the results of this study, it appears that a specialized model of asthma care offers community pharmacists the opportunity to contribute to improving asthma control in the Australian community.

title: Diabetes in rural towns: effectiveness of continuing education and feedback for health care providers in altering diabetes outcomes at the population level: protocol for a cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Type 2 diabetes is one of the fastest growing chronic diseases internationally. Health complications associated with type 2 diabetes can be prevented, delayed, or improved through early diagnosis and effective management. This research aims to examine the impact of a primarily web-based educational intervention on diabetes care provided by general practitioners (GPs) in rural areas and subsequent patient outcomes. A population-level approach is used for outcome assessment, through anonymized city-wide pathology registries. METHODS/DESIGN: The study uses a cluster randomized controlled trial with rural communities as the unit of analysis. Towns from four Australian states were selected and matched based on factors including rurality, population size, proportion of the population that were Indigenous Australians, and socio-economic status. Eleven pairs of villages from two states were suitable for the trial, and one village from each pair was randomly assigned to the experimental group. Physicians in cities assigned to the experimental group are offered an intervention package that includes education on best practice in diabetes care through an online active learning module, a moderated discussion forum, access to counseling targeted and specialized through an online application form and city performance feedback on diabetes management and outcomes. The package is offered through repeated direct mail. DISCUSSION: The benefits of the trial results are described along with the challenges and limitations associated with the methodology. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australia and New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry: ACTRN12611000553976.

title: Diabetes mellitus-refractory obesity
Diabetes Nurse Case Management and Motivational Interviewing for Change (DYNAMICS): Study Design and Baseline Characteristics in the Chronic Care Model for Type 2 Diabetes
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite evidence that diabetes is costly and devastating, the health care system is ill-equipped to meet the challenges of chronic disease care. The Penn State Diabetes and Obesity Institute is evaluating a management model for type 2 DM that includes nurse case management (NCM) and motivational interviewing (MI) to encourage behavior change. The primary care intervention is designed to improve patient self-management and reduce clinical inertia through providers' use of standardized clinical guidelines to achieve better outcomes in diabetes. METHODS: This RCT tests the efficacy of an enhanced NCM intervention on outcomes for patients with type 2 DM (n = 549) mediated by changes in self-care behavior and diabetes control. Outcome measures include: (a) effect on clinical parameters such as HbA1c (<7), BP (<130/80) and LDL (<100), weight and depression scores"; (b) process measures such as detection of complications; (c) psychological and behavioral patient outcomes measured by emotional distress (PAID), diabetes-specific quality of life (ADDQoL), patient satisfaction (DTSQ), self-care activities (SDSCA), and (d) physician satisfaction and cost-effectiveness of the intervention. CONCLUSIONS: Baseline includes age (mean) = 58; BMI = 34.4; 57% women;" 47% Caucasian and 39% Hispanic. The patients had elevated HbA1c (8.4), BP (137/77) and LDL (114). In general, the patients were depressed (CES-D=21.6) and had extremely poor quality of life (ADDQoL=-1.58). We believe that improved NCM will improve self-care and reduce emotional distress for patients with diabetes. If proven effective, improved NCM may translate to other chronic diseases.

title: Diabetes translation research: where are we and where do we want to be?
abstract: Translation research transforms currently available knowledge into useful measures for daily clinical and public health practice. We review progress in diabetes translation research and identify future challenges and opportunities in this field. Several promising interventions are available to optimize the implementation of effective diabetes treatments. Many of these interventions, alone or in combination, need to be tested more formally in larger randomized or quasi-experimental clinical trials using outcomes of particular interest to patients (for example, patient satisfaction and quality of life) and policymakers (for example). example, cost). and profitability). The long-term outcomes (such as morbidity, mortality, quality of life, and costs) of strategies aimed at improving diabetes care need to be evaluated. Translation research also needs to incorporate ways of studying complex systems of care. The challenges and opportunities offered by translation research are tremendous.

title: Diagnosis and treatment of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
abstract: PURPOSE: The purpose of this NIH Consensus Statement is to inform the biomedical research and clinical practice communities about the results of the NIH Consensus Development Conference on Diagnosis and Treatment of Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). ). The statement provides cutting-edge information on effective treatments for ADHD and presents the consensus panel's conclusions and recommendations regarding these topics. In addition, the statement identifies those areas of study that deserve further investigation. At the end of this educational activity, the reader should have a clear practical clinical knowledge of the state of the art regarding this topic. The target audience of physicians for this statement includes, but is not limited to, psychiatrists, family physicians, pediatricians, internists, neurologists, psychologists, and behavioral medicine specialists. PARTICIPANTS: Participants were a 13-member, non-federal, non-advocacy panel representing the fields of psychology, psychiatry, neurology, pediatrics, epidemiology, biostatistics, education, and the public. In addition, 31 experts from these same fields presented data to the panel and a conference audience of 1215. EVIDENCE: The literature was searched through Medline and an extensive bibliography of references was provided to the panel and conference audience. The experts prepared summaries with relevant citations from the literature. Scientific evidence was given priority over anecdotal clinical experience. CONSENSUS PROCESS: The panel, answering predefined questions, developed its conclusions based on the scientific evidence presented in the open forum and the scientific literature. The panel drafted a statement that was read in its entirety and distributed to experts and the public for comment. The panel subsequently resolved the conflicting recommendations and issued a revised statement at the end of the conference. The panel finalized the reviews a few weeks after the conference. The draft statement was made available on the World Wide Web immediately after its release at the conference and was updated with the final revisions of the panel. CONCLUSIONS: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder or ADHD is a commonly diagnosed childhood behavior disorder that represents a significant and costly public health problem. Children with ADHD have pronounced deficits and can experience long-term adverse effects on academic performance, vocational success, and social-emotional development that have a profound impact on individuals, families, schools, and society. Despite advances in the assessment, diagnosis, and treatment of ADHD, this disorder and its treatment remain controversial, especially the use of psychostimulants for short- and long-term treatment. Although there is no independent diagnostic test for ADHD, there is evidence to support the validity of the disorder. More research is needed on the dimensional aspects of ADHD, as well as comorbid (co-existing) conditions present in both childhood and adulthood. Studies (mainly short-term, approximately three months) including randomized clinical trials have established the efficacy of stimulants and psychosocial treatments in alleviating ADHD symptoms and associated aggressiveness and have indicated that stimulants are more effective than therapies psychosocial to treat these symptoms. Due to the lack of consistent improvement beyond core symptoms and the paucity of long-term studies (greater than 14 months), there is a need for longer-term studies with drugs and behavioral modalities and their combination. Although trials are underway, no conclusive recommendations on long-term treatment can currently be made. There are wide variations in the use of psychostimulants between communities and clinicians, suggesting that there is no consensus on which patients with ADHD should be treated with psychostimulants. (RESUME

title: Diagnosis of pulmonary embolism
Diagnostic evaluation of low back pain with emphasis on images
abstract: Purpose: To review the evidence on the diagnostic accuracy of clinical information and imaging for patients with low back pain in primary care settings. Data Source: MEDLINE search (January 1966 to September 2001) of relevant articles and reviews for accuracy of clinical and radiographic data. examination of patients with low back pain. Study selection: The authors screened abstracts and selected articles for review based on a pooled judgment. Data on clinical examination were mainly based on recent systematic reviews; data on imaging tests were mainly based on original articles. Data extraction: one or the other author extracted the results of the diagnosis. The quality of the methods was assessed informally. identified, but quantitative data extraction and scoring were not performed. Data synthesis: Formal meta-analysis was not used because diagnostic hardware and software, gold standards, and patient selection methods were heterogeneous and the number of studies was small. higher for magnetic resonance imaging (0.83 to 0.93) and radionuclide scanning (0.74 to 0.98);" specificity was higher for magnetic resonance imaging (0.9 to 0.97) and radiography (0.95 to 0.99) MRI was the most sensitive (0.96) and specific (0.92) test for infection The sensitivity and specificity of MRI for herniated discs were slightly superior to those of computed tomography, but very similar for the diagnosis of spinal stenosis For adults younger than 50 years of age without signs or symptoms of systemic disease, symptomatic therapy without imaging is appropriate For patients aged 50 years or older or more or those whose findings suggest systemic disease, plain radiography and simple laboratory tests can almost completely rule out underlying systemic disease.Advanced imaging should be reserved for patients who are considering surgery or those who are n those with a strong suspicion of systemic disease.

title: Dietary treatment of hypercholesterolemia: do dietitians do it better? A randomized controlled trial
abstract: PURPOSE: Current National Cholesterol Education Program (NCEP) guidelines recommend initial dietary advice by physicians for most patients with hypercholesterolemia";" Referral to a registered dietitian and lipid-lowering medications are recommended only for patients who remain hypercholesterolemic. The incremental value of detailed nutritional advice from dieticians when added to general nutritional advice provided by physicians was assessed. SUBJECTS AND METHODS: Hypercholesterolemic patients detected during a cholesterol screening project were randomly assigned to receive dietary advice by a physician alone (70 patients) or by a physician and a registered dietitian (66 patients). Patients were followed for 1 year to determine compliance with NCEP guidelines. RESULTS: At 3 months, the mean (+/- SD) decrease in serum low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol level was 7% +/- 11% in the medical group and 12% +/- - 10% in the dietician group (P<0.004). A decrease of 10% or more in LDL cholesterol level was observed in 25 patients (36%) in the medical group and 43 patients (65%) in the diet group (P < 0.001). Only 40 (29%) of patients in both groups achieved NCEP goals at 3 months. Most of them were low-risk patients with a target LDL cholesterol of 160 mg/dl. At 12 months, both groups lost about half of the beneficial effects on LDL cholesterol levels, and the difference between the two groups diminished. CONCLUSIONS: The short-term reduction in LDL cholesterol achieved after counseling by dieticians is superior to that achieved by physicians. However, long-term compliance remains inadequate. For high-risk patients, a more aggressive dietary approach and possibly earlier introduction of lipid-lowering medications should be considered.

title: Different indications, warnings and precautions, and contraindications for the same drug: an international comparison of prescribing information for commonly used psychiatric drugs.
abstract: PURPOSE: Our goal is to derive an internationally applicable data set to improve the safety of prescribing psychiatric medications. METHODS: We conducted an in-depth analysis of prescribing information concordance for 10 key psychiatric medications in four major drug markets with respect to indications, warnings and precautions, and contraindications. RESULTS: Individual prescribing information covered on average 71.4 +/- 30.3% of all named indications, 59.5 +/- 17.1% of all potential warnings and precautions, and 70.1 +/- 24.4% of all applicable contraindications. CONCLUSION: This substantial variation in key prescribing information between countries highlights the need for better international cooperation and standardization of prescribing information.

title: Differentiating normal speech dysfluency from stuttering in children
abstract: The concept of stuttering refers to the lack of fluency or hesitation of a speech pattern. The incidence is reported to be 1% worldwide, with a higher incidence of men than women (3:1). Theories of causation are briefly identified, including a genetic predisposition and neurological factors. In the process of acquiring speech skills, preschool children typically go through a transitional stage of speech influency. This fact can prevent the recognition of early stuttering, can be emotionally painful for the child and can interfere with psychological development. The health care provider is in a key position to provide early diagnosis and intervention for the child with early stuttering. To do so, the health care provider must have the knowledge and skill to differentiate between normal developmental fluency and early stuttering. Factors that differentiate these speech patterns are identified along with guidelines for referral. Current treatment modalities employed by speech pathologists are described. Practical interventions to offer parents to promote fluency in the child's speech and decrease speaker anxiety are summarized.

title: Difficulties in implementing a mental health guideline: an exploratory investigation using psychological theory
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evaluations of interventions to improve guideline implementation have failed to produce a clear pattern of results in favor of any particular method. While implementation depends on clinicians and managers changing a variety of behaviors, psychological theories of behavior and behavior change are rarely used to try to understand difficulties in implementation or to develop interventions to overcome them. OBJECTIVES: This study applied psychological theory to examine explanations for implementation difficulties. It used a theoretical framework derived from an interdisciplinary consensus exercise to code interviews into 11 theoretical domains. The focus of the study was the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence schizophrenia guideline recommendation that family intervention should be offered to families of people with schizophrenia. METHODS: Participants were recruited from community mental health teams from three UK National Health Service (NHS) trusts; 20 members participated (social workers, nurses, team managers, psychologists and psychiatrists). The semi-structured interviews were audio-recorded and the interview questions were based on the theoretical domains and addressed the respondents' knowledge, attitudes, and opinions regarding the guideline. Two researchers independently coded the segments of each interview transcript that were related to each theoretical domain. A score of 1 indicated that domain-related transcript segments did not appear to contain a description of difficulties in implementing family therapy guidelines; similarly, a score of 0.5 indicated possible difficulties and a score of . of 0 indicated definite difficulties.RESULTS: Coding of respondents' responses to questions related to the three domains 'beliefs about consequences', 'social/professional role and identity', and 'motivation' yielded the three highest total scores , indicating that factors related to these domains are unlikely to constitute difficulties in implementation."Context and environmental resources" was the domain with the lowest score, and "Emotion" had the second lowest score, suggesting that these are likely to be areas to consider intervention The top two resources identified as problems were the time and training. The emotions that seemed to potentially influence the offer of family therapy were doubt and fear. CONCLUSION: This exploratory study demonstrates an approach to developing a theoretical understanding of implementation difficulties.

title: Digitization of medicines: artifact, architecture and time
Time dimension in disease: an objective view
Disability associated with psychiatric comorbidity and health status in Bosnian refugees living in Croatia
abstract: Context The relationship between psychiatric symptoms and disability in refugee survivors of mass violence is unknown. Objective To determine whether risk factors, such as demographics, trauma, health status, and psychiatric illness, are associated with disability in Bosnian refugees. Design, Setting, and Participants Cross-sectional survey conducted in 1996 among Bosnian refugee adults living in a camp established by the Croatian government near the town of Vara?din. One adult age 18 or older was randomly selected from each of the 573 families in the camp; 534 (93%) agreed to participate (mean age, 50 years; 41% men). Main outcome measures Culturally validated measures for depression and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) included the Hopkins Symptom Checklist 25 and the Harvard Trauma Questionnaire, respectively Disability measures included the Medical Outcomes Study Short-Form 20, a scale of functioning based on World Health Organization criteria and self-reports of socioeconomic activity, physical energy levels, and perceived health status. Results Respondents reported a mean (SD) of 6.5 (4.7) unduplicated traumatic events; 18% (n=95) had experienced 1 or more events of torture. While 55.2% reported no psychiatric symptoms, 39.2% and 26.3% reported symptoms that meet dsm-iv criteria for depression and ptsd, respectively, 20.6% reported comorbid symptoms for both disorders, a total of 25.5% reported having a disability. comorbid symptoms of depression and posttraumatic stress disorder were associated with increased risk of disability compared with asymptomatic refugees (unadjusted odds ratio [OR], 5.02; 95% confidence interval ¦Ã–, 3.05 -8.26; adjusted o, 2.06;" 95% CI, 1.10-3.86). Older age, cumulative trauma, and chronic medical illness were also associated with disability. Conclusions In a population of Bosnian refugees who had recently fled After the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, psychiatric comorbidity was associated with disability regardless of the effects of age, trauma, and health status.

title: Discern patterns of human immunodeficiency virus risk in healthy young adults
abstract: Previous research has questioned the effectiveness of existing methods for identifying people at high risk of contracting and transmitting the human immunodeficiency virus and other sexually transmitted diseases. Therefore, new approaches are needed to provide these individuals with risk reduction strategies. We review our research on young adult sexual decision-making using theories and methods from the social and cognitive sciences. Four patterns of condom use and associated levels of risks and beliefs were identified. These patterns suggest the value of targeting intervention strategies at individuals with different levels of risk. The findings also imply that the monogamous population may be at higher risk of infection than they realise. Primary care physicians are the first line of contact for many people in the health care system and may be in the best position to screen people at risk. Given the time demands and other barriers, easy-to-use, evidence-based guidelines for such screening are needed. We propose such guidelines for use by primary care physicians to identify an individual's risk, from which personalized intervention strategies can be developed.

title: Dismissal of professional employees: protection against dismissal for acts within a code of professional ethics
Cholinesterase inhibitor discontinuation: results from a survey of Canadian dementia experts.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Cholinesterase inhibitors (ChEIs) are being used for increasingly longer periods of time, including in patients with severe Alzheimer's disease. Because there is little data to help clinicians decide when it is safe and appropriate to stop ICEs after long-term use, practices can vary widely. METHODS: An Internet-based survey of Canadian dementia experts (geriatric psychiatrists, neurologists, geriatricians) involved in clinical trial research was conducted. Recommendations for ChEI discontinuation were determined based on responses to questions related to patient/caregiver preference, administrative considerations, efficacy, and adverse events. RESULTS: There was reasonable consensus that ICEs should be discontinued based on patient and caregiver preferences, and in the presence of bothersome and serious adverse events. There was much less consensus on issues related to efficacy, in particular, constituting a larger than expected decline. There was a general reluctance to rely on a single measure of cognition, function, and/or behavior and, in particular, the MMSE was not considered useful for making decisions about discontinuation. CONCLUSION: Recommendations to discontinue ICEs after long-term use are presented from a survey of dementia experts. Ideally, clinical practice guidelines based on controlled discontinuation trials are needed.

title: Discussion of randomized clinical trials of cancer therapy: evaluation of a Cancer Research UK training program
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate a training intervention aimed at improving health professionals' communication with cancer patients about randomized clinical trials. DESIGN: Before and after evaluation of the training program. SETTING: Members of the National Cancer Research Network, the Scottish Trials Network and the Welsh Cancer Trials Network. PARTICIPANTS: 101 health professionals (33 doctors and 68 research nurses). INTERVENTION: Four modules taught by a trained facilitator using videotapes and interactive exercises to cover general questions about discussing randomized clinical trials with patients, specific problems of adjuvant trials, trials with palliation as an objective, and trials in which patients had a strong preference for one treatment. arm. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Before and after the intervention, participants were videotaped discussing a trial with an actor portraying a patient. These consultations were evaluated for the presence of information required by the good clinical practice guidelines. The patient actors gave an evaluation after each interview. Participants reported their self-confidence about key aspects of the essay discussion. RESULTS: Analysis of videotaped consultations showed that, after the intervention, significantly more participants displayed key communication behaviors, such as explaining randomization (69 vs. 81, odds ratio 2.33, P = 0.033), checking understanding of patients (11 vs. 31, odds ratio 3.22). , P = 0.002) and discussing standard treatment (73 versus 88, odds ratio 4.75, P = 0.005) and side effects (69 versus 85, odds ratio 3.29, P = 0.006). Participants' self-confidence increased significantly (P < 0.001) in all areas. Patient actor ratings of participant communication showed significant improvements in 12/15 key items. CONCLUSION: This intensive 8-hour intervention significantly improved participants' confidence and competence in communicating about randomized clinical trials.

title: Discussion of risky sexual behavior in HIV care is rare and appears ineffective: a mixed methods study
abstract: Consensus guidelines in HIV care require clinicians to provide a brief sexual risk behavior intervention at each visit. Studies based on participant reports find that this occurs infrequently, but studies based on direct observation of clinical encounters are lacking. We conducted a mixed-method study using audio recordings of 116 routine outpatient visits of 58 different HIV-positive patients, at five different practice sites. Visit transcripts were coded and analyzed using a quantitative system. In addition, we conducted a qualitative analysis of the dialogue segments in which risky sexual behaviors emerged as a topic. The discussion of risky sexual behavior occurred over 10 visits and was generally quite brief. Two visits included substantial sexual risk reduction counseling";" two others included substantial discussion that was clearly not directed at the patient's changing behavior. Signs suggesting a need or opportunity for such discussion that physicians did not follow up occurred at an additional seven visits. Interactions about sexual risk had less patient involvement than interactions about other health behaviors. Physicians rarely provide advice on sexual risk reduction in HIV care, even when there are specific indications.

title: Diseases of the digestive system. Jaundice
Dissemination of research on efficacy and results
abstract: Effectiveness and outcomes research seeks to improve patients' health outcomes by improving the quality of care they receive. Dissemination of the results of such research is a necessary step in that process. This paper reviews what is known about designing and disseminating effective information packages targeting health care providers (mainly physicians), where effectiveness means promoting behavioral change by professionals leading to better care. to the patient. Practice-relevant research information is delivered to providers through publication of randomized clinical trial results, dissemination of consensus recommendations, development and use of computerized clinical decision aids, and provision of education continuing medical. Each of these areas offers numerous examples of the extremely modest behavioral response that can be expected from the mere provision of information. The literature also offers some principles that can improve the chances of success, including the desirability of techniques that involve face-to-face interaction, promoting the active participation of the student, repeating the message, making explicit and relevant recommendations for clinical practice, and making use of of opinion leaders and peer influence. Little basic research has been done on provider motivations and actual decision-making processes. Research aimed at promoting a behavioral science of providers could also generate new insights into effective outreach strategies.

title: Dissemination of evidence-based antipsychotic prescription guidelines to nursing homes: a cluster randomized trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To assess the effectiveness of efforts to translate and disseminate evidence-based guidelines on the use of atypical antipsychotics in nursing homes (NH). DESIGN: Three-arm cluster randomized trial. SETTING: NH. PARTICIPANTS: NH of the state of Connecticut. MEASUREMENTS: Evidence-based guidelines for prescribing atypical antipsychotics were translated into a toolkit targeting NH stakeholders, and 42 NHs were recruited and randomly assigned to one of three toolkit dissemination strategies. tools: delivery of the toolkit by mail (minimum intensity); toolkit delivery by mail with quarterly audit and feedback reports on antipsychotic prescribing at facility level (moderate intensity);" and in-person toolkit delivery with academic details, on-site behavior management training, and quarterly reports audit and feedback (high intensity) Outcomes were assessed using the Reach, Effectiveness, Adoption, Implementation, and Maintenance (RE-AIM) framework RESULTS: 30% (7/23) of leadership knowledge of the toolkit of low-intensity NH, 54% (19/35) of moderate-intensity NH, and 82% (18/22) of high-intensity NH reflected intervention adoption and implementation. use and knowledge among direct care staff were reported in high-intensity NH Antipsychotic prescription levels decreased over the study period, but there were no differences statistically significant differences between study arms or secular trends. CONCLUSION: The RE-AIM indicators suggest some success in disseminating the toolkit and differences in scope, adoption, and implementation depending on the dissemination strategy, but no measurable effect on antipsychotic prescription trends. Further outreach to external stakeholders, such as psychiatric consultants and hospitals, may be needed to influence antipsychotic prescription for NH residents.

title: Do decision support systems influence prescription variation?
abstract: BACKGROUND: Translating scientific evidence into daily practice is problematic. All kinds of intervention strategies have evolved, using educational and/or directive strategies, aimed at modifying behavior, but they have been found to be only partially successful. In this article, the focus is on (computerized) decision support systems (DSS). DSSs intervene in the daily routine of clinicians, as opposed to interventions that aim to influence knowledge to change behavior. We examine whether general practitioners (GPs) prescribe according to the advice provided by the DSS and whether there is less variation in prescribing when using the DSS. METHODS: Data from the Second Dutch National Survey of General Practice (DNSGP2), collected in 2001, were used. A total of 82 diagnoses, 749,811 contacts, 133 physicians, and 85 practices were included in the analyses. GPs who used the DSS daily were compared with those who did not. Multilevel analyzes were used to analyze the data. Two outcome measures were chosen: whether or not the prescription was in accordance with DSS advice, and a concentration measure, the Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (HHI). RESULTS: Physicians who use the DSS daily prescribe more according to the advice given in the DSS than physicians who do not use the DSS. Contrary to our expectations, there were no significant differences between the HHIs for both groups: the variation in prescription was comparable. CONCLUSION: We studied the use of a DSS for drug prescription in general practice in the Netherlands. The DSS is based on guidelines developed by the Dutch College of General Practitioners and implemented in the Electronic Medical Systems of GPs. GPs using the DSS prescribe more often according to the advice provided in the DSS compared to GPs not using the DSS. This finding, however, does not mean that the variation is less";" the variation is the same for GPs using and GPs not using a DSS. The implications of the study are that DSSs can be used to implement guidelines, but variation should not be expected to be limited.

title: Do health reforms impact the cost consciousness of health professionals? Results of a national survey in the Balkans
abstract: BACKGROUND: Serbia, as the largest market in the Western Balkans, has entered a socio-economic transition with considerable delay compared to most of Eastern Europe. His health care reform efforts have been bold over the past 15 years, but their results have been inconsistent in several areas. The two waves of global recession that hit the Balkan economies were finally reflected in the financial situation of health care. Serious difficulties in providing accessible health care to citizens became a reality. A large part of the excruciating expense actually pertains to over-the-counter prescription pharmaceuticals and various physician-ordered laboratory and imaging procedures. Therefore, a broad national survey was conducted at all levels of the health system hierarchy to discern the ability of cost-containment strategies to reshape physician mindsets and decision-making in practice. OBJECTIVES: To assess health professionals' judgment of the economic consequences of prescribed medical interventions and to assess the responsiveness of health professionals to policy measures aimed at increasing cost awareness. STUDY DESIGN: Cross-sectional study. METHODS: A national cross-sectional survey was conducted through a hierarchy of medical facilities in various geographic regions before and after the political action, from January 2010 to April 2013. In the middle of the observed period, the National Health Insurance Fund Health (RFZO) adopted severe cost containment measures. Independently, pharmacoeconomic guidelines aimed at prescribers were disseminated. The administration of large hospitals and community pharmacies was forced to restrict access to health care with a high budget impact. The Health Professionals Economic Awareness Questionnaire-29 (EAHPQ-29), developed in the Serbian language, was used in face-to-face interviews. The questionnaire documented physicians' attitudes on: Clinical Decision Making Between Alternative Interventions (CDMAI), Quality of Health Care (QHC), and Cost Containment Policy (CCP). The authors randomly and anonymously recruited 2000 health care experts, with a total of 1487 responses; after removing incomplete surveys, 649 participants were considered before and 651 after the policy intervention. RESULTS: Dentists (1.195 +/- 0.560) had a higher mean CDMAI score compared to physicians (1.017 +/- 0.453). The surgical group compared to the internist group had a higher EAHPQ-29 total score, CCP score, and CDMAI score. The policy intervention had a statistically significant negative impact on the QHC score (F = 4.958; df=1; "p=0.027). There was no substantial impact of the policy interventions on behavior and professional judgment regarding CDMAI, CCP, and EAHPQ-29 total scores.CONCLUSION: Although cost savings were forceful in practice, the effects on clinical decision making were modest.Physicians' perceptions of quality of care explained less effectively due to severely limited resources allocated to providers.This pioneering effort in the Balkans exposes the ineffectiveness of current policies in expanding physicians' cost consciousness.

title: Do knowledge agents facilitate the implementation of the stroke guideline in clinical practice?
abstract: BACKGROUND: The implementation of clinical practice guidelines in rehabilitation practice is often problematic and incomplete. An intervention to improve the implementation of the guidelines is the knowledge transfer program built around the activities of a knowledge broker (KB). This study investigates the use of KB to implement guideline recommendations for intensive therapy and physical activity for patients after stroke in 22 strokes. units in hospitals and rehabilitation centers in the Netherlands. METHODS/DESIGN: This study includes a quantitative evaluation with an uncontrolled pre-post intervention design and a mixed methods process evaluation. From each stroke unit, enterprising nurses and therapists will be recruited and trained as KB. The KB will work for a year on the implementation of the recommendations of the guide in his team. To assess the effectiveness of KB, a questionnaire will be administered to patients, health professionals, and KB at baseline (T0) and after one year (T1). In addition, semi-structured interviews will be carried out with 5 KB in T1. The primary outcome of this implementation project will be support from health professionals for patients to exercise and be physically active, as reported by patients and health professionals themselves. The support immediately after the intervention is compared with the support at the beginning of the intervention. In addition, we will explore the influence of the sociodemographic characteristics of health professionals and the determinants identified in the Theory of Planned Behavior (intention, attitude, subjective norm and perceived behavior). behavioral control) on behavior change support from health professionals. Finally, the KBs will complete a questionnaire about their own psychological and sociodemographic characteristics and about the organizational conditions necessary for the improvement of medical care, such as time, workforce, sponsorship, and management support. DISCUSSION: With this study we will get an idea of when and why knowledge brokers seem to be effective. We will also identify determinants that predict which health professionals are likely to change their behavior. This study will provide guidance on how to implement the guidelines and help improve stroke rehabilitation services.

title: Do nurses have a different physical health profile? A systematic review of experimental and observational studies on the physical health of nurses
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To systematically review the evidence on the health of nurses. BACKGROUND: Nurses are one of the most important resources in a health system. They are subject to biological, socioeconomic, cultural and health system factors that determine their health. Although mental and physical health problems seem to be prevalent among nurses, the literature is often contradictory. The literature on health styles, health behaviors and perceived health by nurses is also unclear. DESIGN: Systematic review of experimental and observational studies on nurses' health. METHODS: Forty-three databases searched. 2692 references identified as of potential interest";" 187 studies included. Only the results of studies on physical health are presented. A meta-analysis was not possible. The Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network system was used to rate the evidence. RESULTS: Nurses had a higher risk of musculoskeletal injuries and were more prone to bloodborne pathogen infections than other health care workers. They had a higher risk of breast cancer than other health workers. Nurses in hospitals were at higher risk of tuberculosis. They had no excess risk of cancer overall, Hodgkin's disease, cancer of the stomach, colon, rectum, pancreas, ovary, kidney, brain, or thyroid, or lymphosarcoma. They have a higher prevalence of occupational allergies than white-collar workers. DISCUSSION: Nurses suffer more from musculoskeletal disorders, which is consistent with the nature of nursing work. They are at increased risk of contracting tuberculosis, especially if they work in pulmonary, medical, or human immunodeficiency virus wards, which may be due to repeated contact with infected patients. Nurses are also more prone to bloodborne pathogen infections, which could be explained by exposure while on the job. The propensity for occupational allergies can be explained by exposure to a series of chemical agents. RELEVANCE TO CLINICAL PRACTICE: Without a solid understanding of nurses' health, it is not possible to develop specific occupational health programs.

title: Do pediatricians apply the NASPGHAN-ESPGHAN 2009 guidelines for the diagnosis and management of gastroesophageal reflux after being trained?
abstract: BACKGROUND: According to a recent survey, European primary care pediatricians do not meet the 2009 North American Society for Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology, and Nutrition guidelines for gastroesophageal reflux and the European Society for Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology, and Nutrition. The main issue that emerged from the survey was the prescription of unnecessary acid-suppressing medications, especially in infants. The reasons were not investigated. The main objective of the present study was to assess the applicability of the guidelines in European primary care paediatricians receiving specific training. METHODS: One hundred pediatricians involved in the above survey agreed to participate and were randomly divided into 2 groups: one group was trained on the guidelines through an online podcast and the other group was trained through a synopsis. For the next 3 months, each pediatrician involved was asked to enroll all consecutive infants, children, or adolescents with symptoms suggestive of reflux. For each patient enrolled, pediatricians completed a report on their diagnostic and therapeutic options. RESULTS: A total of 382 patients (boys/girls 186/196, infants/boys/adolescents 194/123/65) were recruited by pediatricians. Infants with unexplained crying and/or distressed behavior prescribed PPIs were 3.7% compared to 45.2% in pretraining survey data (P < 0 .05). Infants with uncomplicated recurrent vomiting and regurgitation who were prescribed proton pump inhibitors were 4.5% vs. 37.1% in baseline survey data (p < 0.05). The overall rate of children managed in full adherence to guidelines was 46.1% after training compared to 1.8% before training (P < 0.05). No significant differences were observed between pediatricians in the podcast and synopsis groups. CONCLUSIONS: The guidelines on gastroesophageal reflux of the North American Society of Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition-European Society of Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition have good applicability, despite the fact that European primary care pediatricians do not currently comply with them. Simple and inexpensive trainings have been shown to be effective in increasing adherence by pediatricians. Increased compliance clearly favors the role of continuing medical education through simple educational tools and subsequent practice evaluation.

title: Do polypills lead to neglect of lifestyle risk factors? Findings from a meta-analysis of individual participant data among 3140 patients at high risk for cardiovascular disease.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The objective of this study was to investigate whether polypill-based care for cardiovascular disease (CVD) prevention is associated with a change in lifestyle risk factors compared with usual care, among patients with CVD or calculated high cardiovascular risk. METHODS: We conducted an individual participant data meta-analysis of three trials involving patients from Australia, England, India, Ireland, the Netherlands, and New Zealand that compared a strategy using a polypill containing aspirin, a statin, and antihypertensive therapy with regular care. common in patients with a prior CVD event or who were at high risk for their first event. Analyzes investigated any differential effects on self-reported anthropometric measures and lifestyle behaviors. RESULTS: Among 3,140 patients (75% men, mean age 62 years, and 76% with a prior CVD event) there was no difference in lifestyle risk factors in those randomized to polypill-based care compared to polypill-based care. usual care for a median of 15 months. either among all participants combined or in a variety of subgroups. Furthermore, the narrow confidence intervals (CIs) excluded any important effect";" for example, the differences between groups in body mass index was -0.1 (95% CI -0.2 to 0.1) kg/m(2), in weekly duration of physical activity moderate intensity was -2 (-26 to 23) minutes and the proportion of smokers was 16% vs 17% (RR 0.98, 0.84 to 1.15) at the end of the trial. DISCUSSION: This review allays concerns that polypill-based care may lead to neglect of lifestyle risk factors, at least among high-risk patients. The most effective preventive approaches should address lifestyle factors in conjunction with pharmaceutical interventions, as recommended by leading international guidelines.

title: Documentation-based clinical decision support to improve antibiotic prescribing for acute respiratory infections in primary care: a cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background and objective Clinical guidelines discourage the prescription of antibiotics for many acute respiratory infections (ARIs), especially for appropriate non-antibiotic diagnoses. Clinical decision support based on electronic health records (EHRs) has the potential to improve antibiotic prescribing for ARIs. Methods We randomly assigned 27 primary care clinics to receive either a documentation-based clinical decision support system integrated with EHR for the care of patients with AKI, the ARI Smart Formulary, or to provide usual care. The primary outcome was the rate of antibiotic prescriptions for ARIs in an intention-to-intervention analysis based on administrative diagnoses. Results During the intervention period, patients made 21,961 ARI visits to study clinics. Intervention clinicians used the ARI Smart form in 6% of 11,954 ARI visits. The antibiotic prescription rate at intervention clinics was 39% vs. 43% at control clinics (odds ratio [OR], 0.8"; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.6_1, 2, adjusted for clinic grouping.) appropriate AKI diagnoses, the antibiotic prescription rate was 54% at intervention clinics and 59% at control clinics (OR, 0.8; 95% CI, 0.5_1.3).% in intervention clinics and 34% in control clinics (OR, 0.9; 95% CI, 0.6_1.4).When the ARI Smart form was used, according to the diagnoses entered on the form, the antibiotic prescription rate was 49% overall, 88% for appropriate diagnoses with antibiotics and 27% for inappropriate diagnoses with antibiotics In a usage analysis, the ARI Smart Form was associated with a lower rate of prescription of antibiotics for acute bronchitis (OR, 0.5; 95% CI, 0.3_0.8).The smart form for ARI did not reduce overall antibiotic prescribing or significantly improve the appropriateness of antibiotic prescribing for ARIs, but it was not widely used. When used, the ARI Smart Form can improve diagnostic accuracy compared to administrative diagnoses and can reduce antibiotic prescribing for certain diagnoses.

title: Does the joint development and dissemination of multidisciplinary guidelines improve prescribing behavior: a pre/post study with a concurrent control group and a randomized trial?
abstract: BACKGROUND: It is difficult to maintain control over prescribing behavior in general practices. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effects of a multidisciplinary guideline dissemination strategy on medication prescription volume. METHODS: The study included two designs, a pre/post quasi-experimental study with a concurrent control group and a random sample of physicians within the intervention group. The intervention area with 53 GPs was compared with a control group of 54 randomly selected GPs in the south and center of the Netherlands. In addition, randomization was run in the intervention group to create two arms with 27 GPs who were more heavily involved in guideline development and 26 GPs in the control group. A multidisciplinary committee developed prescription guidelines. Subsequently, these guidelines were disseminated to all physicians in the intervention region. Additional effects were studied in the subgroup trial in which GPs were invited to participate more fully in the guideline development process. The guidelines contained 14 recommendations on antibiotics, asthma/COPD medications, and cholesterol medications. The main outcome measures were prescription data over a three-year period (one year before and two years after guideline release) and the rate of change according to recommendations. RESULTS: Significant short-term improvements were seen for one recommendation: mupirocin. Long-term changes were found for cholesterol drug prescriptions. No additional changes were seen for the randomized controlled study in the subgroup. GPs did not accept the invitation to participate. CONCLUSION: The dissemination of multidisciplinary guidelines that were developed within a region does not have a clear effect on prescribing behavior despite the fact that general practitioners and specialists participated more intensely in their development. Apparently more effort is needed to bring about change.

title: Does a joint development and dissemination of multidisciplinary guidelines: a pre/post study with a concurrent control group and a randomized trial improve prescribing behavior?
abstract: Background It is difficult to maintain control over prescribing behavior in general practices. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effects of a multidisciplinary guideline dissemination strategy on medication prescription volume. Methods The study included two designs, a pre/post quasi-experimental study with a concurrent control group and a random sample of physicians within the intervention group. The intervention area with 53 GPs was compared with a control group of 54 randomly selected GPs in the south and center of the Netherlands. In addition, randomization was run in the intervention group to create two arms with 27 GPs who were more heavily involved in guideline development and 26 GPs in the control group. A multidisciplinary committee developed prescription guidelines. Subsequently, these guidelines were disseminated to all physicians in the intervention region. Additional effects were studied in the subgroup trial in which GPs were invited to participate more fully in the guideline development process. The guidelines contained 14 recommendations on antibiotics, asthma/COPD medications, and cholesterol medications. The main outcome measures were prescription data over a three-year period (one year before and two years after guideline release) and the rate of change according to recommendations. Results Significant short-term improvements were seen for one recommendation: mupirocin. Long-term changes were found for cholesterol drug prescriptions. No additional changes were seen for the randomized controlled study in the subgroup. GPs did not accept the invitation to participate. Conclusion The dissemination of multidisciplinary guidelines that were developed within a region does not have a clear effect on prescribing behavior despite the fact that GPs and specialists participated more intensively in their development. Apparently more effort is needed to bring about change.
