title: Does methadone maintenance treatment based on new national guidelines work in a primary care setting?
abstract: BACKGROUND: General practitioners (GPs) are encouraged to treat more drug users, but there are few studies demonstrating the effectiveness of primary care treatment. OBJECTIVE: To determine whether patients retained on methadone maintenance treatment for one year in a modern British primary care setting, with prescribing protocols based on new national guidelines, can achieve harm reduction outcomes similar to those demonstrated in other settings. , using objective outcome measures where available. STUDY DESIGN: Longitudinal cohort study. SETTING: The Primary Care Clinic for Drug Dependence, Sheffield. METHOD: The intervention consisted of methadone maintenance treatment provided by GPs with prescribing protocols based on 1999 national guidelines. The first 96 eligible patients who consented to enter treatment were recruited";" 65 completed the study. Outcome measures were current drug use, HIV risk behaviour, social functioning, criminal activity, and mental and physical health, supplemented by urinalysis and criminal history data. RESULTS: Frequency of heroin use was reduced from a mean of 3.02 episodes per day (standard deviation [SD] = 1.73) to a mean of 0.22 episodes per day (SD = 0.54), ( chi 2 = 79.48, degrees of freedom [df ] = 2, P < 0.001), confirmed by urinalysis. The mean number of convictions and warnings was reduced by 62% (z = 3.378, P < 0.001) for all crimes. HIV risk-taking behavior, social functioning, and physical and psychological well-being showed significant improvements. CONCLUSION: Patients retained on methadone maintenance treatment for one year in a primary care setting may achieve improvements in a range of harm reduction outcomes similar to those shown by studies in other, often more structured, programs.

title: Does publication bias inflate the apparent efficacy of psychological treatment for major depressive disorder? A systematic review and meta-analysis of trials funded by the US National Institutes of Health.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The efficacy of antidepressant medication has been shown empirically to be overestimated due to publication bias, but this has only been inferred statistically with respect to psychological treatment for depression. We directly assessed the extent of study publication bias in trials examining the efficacy of psychological treatment for depression. METHODS AND FINDINGS: We identified US National Institutes of Health grants awarded to fund randomized clinical trials comparing psychological treatment with control conditions or other treatments in patients diagnosed with major depressive disorder during the period 1972-2008, and we determine whether those grants led to publications. . For studies that were not published, data were requested from the investigators and included in the meta-analyses. Thirteen (23.6%) of the 55 funded grants that started trials did not result in publications, and another two never started. Among comparisons with control conditions, adding unpublished studies (Hedges' g = 0.20"; 95% CI -0.11~0.51; k = 6) to published studies (g = 0.52 ; 0.37~0.68; k = 20) reduced the psychotherapy effect size point estimate (g = 0.39; "0.08~0.70) by 25%. Furthermore, these findings may overestimate the 'true' effect of psychological treatment for depression, as outcome reporting bias could not be examined quantitatively. CONCLUSION: The efficacy of psychological interventions for depression has been overestimated in the published literature, as it has been for pharmacotherapy. Both are effective, but not to the extent that the published literature would suggest. Funding agencies and journals should archive both original protocols and raw data from treatment trials to allow detection and correction of bias in reporting of results. Clinicians, guideline developers, and decision makers should be aware that the published literature overestimates the effects of prevailing treatments for depression.

title: Does detection and intervention of multiple health-compromising behaviors and mental health disorders among youth attending primary care improve health outcomes? A systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND: Adolescence and early adulthood are important developmental periods. Screening for health-compromising behaviors and mental health disorders during routine primary care visits has the potential to help clinicians identify areas of concern and provide appropriate interventions. The objective of this systematic review is to investigate whether screening and subsequent interventions for multiple health-compromising behaviors and mental health disorders in primary care settings improve youth health outcomes. METHODS: Using the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidelines, literature searches of Medline, PsycINFO, Scopus, and Cochrane Library databases (Prospero registry number CRD42013005828) were performed using search terms representing four thematic concepts: primary care, youth, screening and mental health and behaviors that compromise health. To be eligible for inclusion, studies had to: include a health outcome measure; include at least 75% of participants under the age of 25; use a screening tool that assesses more than one health domain; and take place within a primary care setting. Risk of bias was assessed using the Quality Rating Scale. RESULTS: Of 5051 articles identified, nine studies met the inclusion criteria and were reviewed: two randomized controlled trials (RCTs), one pilot RCT, two pooled RCTs, one randomized study with multiple intervention groups and no control group, one Group RCT with two active arms, a longitudinal study and a pre-post study. Seven studies, including two RCTs and one pooled RCT, found positive changes in substance use, diet, sexual health or risky sexual behaviour, alcohol-related risk behaviour, social stress, stress management , helmet use, sleep, and exercise. Of only two studies reporting harms, one reported a negative health outcome of increased alcohol consumption. CONCLUSIONS: There is some evidence that the use of screening and intervention with youth for mental health disorders or health compromising behaviors in clinical settings improves health outcomes. Along with other evidence that youth value discussions about health risks with their providers, these discussions should be part of routine primary care for youth. More quality studies are needed to strengthen this evidence.

title: Does shared care help in the treatment of depression?
abstract: INTRODUCTION: shared or collaborative care in the treatment of depression is an evidence-based intervention that has been shown to be more effective than ordinary general medical care in the treatment of depression; however, it is not yet a government policy in the UK. Our goal was to bring together in one place all the studies that have been carried out, up to mid-2009, to demonstrate evidence that shared collaborative care has important advantages in terms of depression outcomes and cost benefits, to make the case for favor the adoption of this approach in the UK and Europe. METHODS: We conducted a literature search using PUBMED to identify and describe all trials, systematic reviews, and meta-analyses that have been conducted on shared care up to mid-2009. We also described a shared care service for depression that some of us had experienced. involved in the development and work at Luton in the late 1990s. Articles describing trials that had not yet been conducted were excluded, focusing instead on trials that were reported. RESULTS: It has been shown in numerous recent studies that shared care in the treatment of depression, which includes the training of General Practitioners in the treatment of depression, and the provision in Primary Care of a Specialist Nurse or another professional who will provide psycho - education, ensuring medication concordance, and can provide psychotherapy, leads to both better treatment outcomes and higher physician and patient satisfaction, as well as providing some cost benefits, despite somewhat higher immediate costs. This is so in both adult and adolescent patients, while in the case of diabetic patients depression is improved, despite the lack of improvement in glycemic control. The shared care intervention is still useful in the case of patients with resistant depressive symptoms, although a longer entry will be necessary in these cases. Patients with subthreshold depression will not benefit as much and patients expressed more satisfaction when offered psychological interventions. It is also the case that collaborative or shared care is effective in treating depression in the elderly. This is demonstrated by studies that include older patients who also suffer from multiple health conditions, arthritis, diabetes, anxiety and PTSD, the poorest, those with suicidal ideation, and also in Ethnic Minorities. DISCUSSION: The results described above are mainly based on studies conducted in the US, but similar studies have been reported in the UK and are consistent with the experience of the Luton service we describe. Based on these results, it would seem important that shared, collaborative care, with primary and secondary care physicians (general practitioners and psychiatrists) working as part of a single team, with the help of mental health professionals attached to primary care, but with easy access to secondary care it is a productive way to optimize depression treatment. In the UK, however, it has not yet been possible to develop such a service for the entire population. This is because, in the UK, general practice is run by primary care trusts, while secondary care, including psychiatry, is run by mental health trusts. This has led the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence, and indeed local care commissioners, to focus on a stepped model for depression treatment, with a key issue being access (or referral) to care. secondary care and discharge back to primary care. , with a group of mental health workers who focus on facilitating (or controlling) these processes, rather than focusing on actually optimizing outcomes of care. CONCLUSION: the evidence advocates the development of collaborative care between primary and secondary care for the treatment of Depression. This will require common medication guidelines in Primary and Secondary Care, easy access for general practitioners to receive advice from psychiatrists about patients, and the use of mental health professionals to provide patients with psychoeducation, treatment concordance support and psychotherapy. . It may be that, to achieve this, services need to be restructured to allow easy communication between professionals.

title: Does therapeutic writing help people with long-term conditions? Systematic review, realistic synthesis and economic considerations
abstract: BACKGROUND: Writing therapy to improve physical or mental health can take many forms. The most researched model of therapeutic writing (TW) is unfacilitated individual expressive writing (written emotional disclosure). Facilitated writing activities are less well researched. DATA SOURCES: Databases, including MEDLINE, EMBASE, PsycINFO, Linguistics and Language Behavior Abstracts, Allied and Complementary Medicine Database, and Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature, were searched from inception to March 2013 (updated at January 2015). METHODS OF REVIEW: Four TW professionals provided expert advice. Study procedures were performed by one reviewer and checked by a second. Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and non-randomized comparative studies were included. Quality was assessed using the Cochrane risk of bias tool. TW studies not provided and provided were analyzed separately under the chapter titles of the Tenth Revision of the International Classification of Diseases. Where possible, meta-analyses were performed using RevMan version 5.2.6 (RevMan 2012, The Cochrane Collaboration, The Nordic Cochrane Centre, Copenhagen, Denmark). Costs were estimated from the UK National Health Service perspective and three cost-consequence case studies were prepared. The Realist Synthesis followed the Realist and Metanarrative Evidence Synthesis: Evolving Guidelines. OBJECTIVES: To review the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of TW for patients with long-term illness (LTC) compared to no control or other controls, reporting any relevant clinical outcomes. Conduct a realistic synthesis to understand how TW could work and for whom. RESULTS: Of 14,658 unique citations, 284 full-text articles were reviewed and 64 studies (59 RCTs) were included in the final effectiveness reviews. Five studies examined "facilitated TW"; these were extremely heterogeneous with unclear or high risk of bias, but suggested that facilitated TW interventions may be beneficial in individual LTC. Unfacilitated expressive writing was examined in 59 studies of variable quality or not Overall, there was little or no evidence of any reported benefit in the following conditions (number of studies): human immunodeficiency virus (six), breast cancer (eight), gynecologic and genitourinary cancers (five), general health mental (five), asthma (four), psoriasis (three), and chronic pain (four). In inflammatory arthropathies (six) there was a reduction in disease severity [n = 191, standardized mean difference (SMD) -0 .61, 95% confidence interval (CI) -0.96 to -0.26] short-term in meta-analysis of four studies For all other CTLs there were no or few data with no or inconsistent evidence of benefit . The M et-analyses conducted across all LTCs provided no evidence of t Which unfacilitated emotional writing had any effect on depression in the short term (n=1563, SMD -0.06, 95% CI -0.29 to 0.17, heterogeneity substantial) or long-term (n=778, SMD -0.04, 95% CI -0.18 to 0.10, little heterogeneity) follow-up, or on anxiety, physiological or biomarker-based outcomes. One study reported costs, no studies reported cost-effectiveness, and 12 studies reported resource use; "and meta-analysis suggested a reduction in medication use but no impact on health center visits. The estimated costs of the intervention were low, but there was insufficient evidence to judge cost-effectiveness. The synthesis findings are realistic suggested that facilitated TM is a complex intervention and that group interaction contributes to perceived benefit It was not clear from the available data who might benefit most from facilitated TM LIMITATION: Difficulties in developing the theory of the facilitation program realistic synthesis meant that the mechanisms operating during TW remain obscure.Overall, there is little evidence to support the therapeutic effectiveness or cost-effectiveness of non-facilitated expressive writing interventions in people with LTC.Further research focused on facilitated TW in people with LTC could be informative STUDY REGISTRATION: This study is re Registered as PROSPERO CRD420120033 43. FUNDING: Health Technology Assessment Program of the National Institute for Health Research.

title: Dominant inheritance of intracranial berry aneurysm
Dressings for venous leg ulcers: systematic review and meta-analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVE To review the evidence for the effectiveness of dressings applied to venous leg ulcers. DESIGN Systematic review and meta-analysis. DATA SOURCES Journal handsearches and electronic database searches, conference abstracts, and bibliographies to April 2006; contacts with dressing manufacturers for unpublished studies. STUDIES REVIEWED All randomized controlled trials evaluating dressings applied to venous leg ulcers were eligible for inclusion. Two reviewers independently extracted and abstracted data from eligible studies using a data extraction sheet. Two reviewers independently assessed methodological quality. RESULTS The search strategy identified 254 studies; 42 of them met the inclusion criteria. Hydrocolloids were no more effective than plain ones. low-adherence dressings used under compression (8 trials; relative risk of healing with hydrocolloid 1.02, 95% confidence interval 0.83 to 1.28). For other comparisons, there was insufficient evidence available to allow firm conclusions to be drawn. None of the dressing comparisons showed evidence that a particular class of dressing healed more ulcers. There were some differences between the dressings in terms of subjective outcomes and ulcer healing rates. The results were not affected by the size or quality of the trials or the unit of randomisation. Insufficient data were available to allow conclusions to be drawn about the relative cost-effectiveness of different dressings. CONCLUSIONS The type of dressing applied under compression was not shown to affect ulcer healing. The results of the meta-analysis showed that the application of hydrocolloid dressings under compression did not produce any benefit in terms of ulcer healing compared to the application of simple low adherent dressings. No conclusive recommendations can be made as to which type of bandage is more cost-effective. Decisions about which dressing to apply should be based on local dressing costs and physician or patient preferences.

title: Driving simulators for detection, evaluation and intervention of occupational therapy
abstract: Simulation technology provides safe, objective, and repeatable performance measures related to driver operational (eg, collision avoidance) or tactical (eg, lane keeping) behaviors. Many occupational therapy researchers and others are using driving simulators to test a variety of applications in various populations. A growing body of literature supports associations between simulated driving and actual highway driving. A limitation of malingerer technology is the occurrence of malingerer disease, but there are management strategies to reduce or mitigate its occurrence. Based on a review of the literature and a consensus process, five consensus statements are presented to support the use of driving simulation technology among occupational therapy professionals. Evidence suggests that through the use of driving simulators, occupational therapists can detect underlying deficiencies in driving performance, identify driving errors in drivers at risk; differentiate between the driving performance of healthy and impaired control groups; show driving errors with absolute and relative validity compared to on-road studies and mitigate the appearance of simulator disease. Much progress has been made among occupational therapy researchers and practitioners in the use of driving simulation technology;" however, empirical support is needed to further justify the use of driving simulators in clinical practice settings such as a valid, reliable, clinically useful and cost-effective tool for driving evaluation and intervention.

title: Hospital Drug Forms
Re-exposure to drugs and patients' rights
abstract: Challenging a hypersensitive patient with a potentially harmful drug is very important for the development of medical knowledge. However, it does not always serve the interest of the particular patient. To protect the interest of an individual patient, one should refrain from contesting unless it is vital to the health of the particular patient at the time and there is no substitute for it. The rights of patients demand the establishment of limitations and guidelines for the recusal procedure in all its aspects. An approach is suggested that brings physicians closer to a solution, that protects the patient from uncontrolled decisions and unnecessary risks.

title: The use of medicines and the role of patients and prescribers
abstract: To advance towards the rational use of medicines in any national or local setting, it is necessary to expand research methods. Both the public and private sectors need to be addressed. In the latter, pharmacists could be studied using a tracker, a fictitious client. An important factor influencing prescribing, drug information, has rarely been scientifically evaluated. However, experimental studies using cluster randomization are feasible even in developing countries. The individual human being must be in the focus of drug studies and health care and health in the foreground. Combining qualitative and quantitative methods will help us achieve rational drug use that is culturally acceptable, economically feasible, and pharmacologically sound." PIP: In an effort to improve rational drug use in local or national settings, especially in In developing countries, the behavior of prescribers and users is the subject of least research The efficacy of medicines depends on a complex set of factors that intervene in the situation of prescription and acquisition One aspect that needs to be examined is the information that drug advertisers and retailers provide to prescribers, a gap that is being addressed by an international network of prescribers In many countries, the largest point of sale for drugs is private sector pharmacies, where drugs are often are dispensed without a prescription A simple and inexpensive way to investigate the behavior of The statute of limitations is to use fictitious trackers to pursue the case. management of given conditions, such as childhood diarrhea There are many factors involved in the prescription;" the process must be studied with an epidemiological approach, that is, through description, analysis, intervention and evaluation. Local therapeutic committees must audit treatment programs standard, essential drug lists and targeted intervention with treatment guidelines. Drug information should also be scientifically evaluated according to the same analytical principles. The experimental method of cluster randomization is suggested as a feasible option for developing countries. In this technique, groups of clinicians are observed or interviewed and quantitative outcome data are collected Individual user behavior is best studied by combining anthropological and biomedical approaches, from a case study perspective An example of a problem amenable to this approach is the possible use of more courses s short courses of antibiotics to decrease the risk of development of resistant organisms.

title: The DRUGS system improves the adherence of Chinese surgeons to guidelines for the use of antibiotics during the perioperative period
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The irrational use of antimicrobial agents to prevent postoperative SSIs is a common phenomenon in China, resulting in increased bacterial resistance, higher hospital infection rates, and additional costs of antimicrobial agents. The objective of the study is to evaluate the effect of the Rational Use of Medicines Guidelines System (DRUGS) on the prescription behavior of antimicrobial agents by the surgeon. METHODS: 10 common surgical operations including 1543 cases (where 778 cases used paper guides and 765 cases used MEDICATIONS) were selected and their demographic and clinical data were collected. Selected operations include thyroid resection, breast mass resection, myomectomy, etc. Evaluation criteria were antibiotic administrative categories, time of initial dose, duration of administration, length of stay, antibiotic costs, SSIs, and adverse drug reactions (ADRs). RESULTS: Most of the antimicrobials were administered within 0.5 h to 2 h before the incision, 656 patients (85.75%) underwent surgery with DRUGS and 256 (32.90%) with paper guidelines according to protocol. For clean wound incision, 547 patients (91.62%) were within 24 h of antibiotic withdrawal using paper guides versus 91 (14.79%) using MEDICATION. A total of 19 types of antibiotics were used in the 1543 cases. The top three on the frequency list were piperacillin and sulbactam sodium, cefatiamidine, and cefoperazone. While after the intervention, the frequency list changed to cefazolin, cefatiamidine, cefoperazone. The mean hospital stay was (7.00+/-4.31)d with paper guidelines and (2.54+/-1.57)d with DRUGS, respectively. The average cost of antibiotics was yen (3,481.36+/-2,584.46) with printed guidelines and yen (1,693.39+/-1,478.27) with MEDICATIONS, respectively. However, there were no significant differences in the incidence of SSI and ADR between the two groups. CONCLUSION: In this study, greater availability of antibiotic guidelines at the time of medication order, combined with MEDICATION, was associated with greater surgeon adherence to the guidelines.

title: Lasting improvements in prostate cancer screening from spaced online education: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) screening for prostate cancer is frequently performed, contrary to clinical practice guidelines. BACKGROUND: It was hypothesized that an email-based intervention called 'spaced education' might reduce inappropriate detection of prostate cancer by physicians. DESIGN: The study was conducted as an RCT. SETTING/PARTICIPANTS: The study involved 95 primary care physicians at eight Veterans Affairs medical centers from January 2007 through February 2009. INTERVENTION: Participants were randomized into two cohorts: spaced-education physicians received four cycles nine-email isomorphics over 36 weeks (zero to two emails per week), while control physicians received no intervention. Each email presented a clinical scenario and asked if it was appropriate to obtain a PSA test. Participants received immediate feedback after submitting their answers. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: The primary outcome was the number and percentage of inappropriate PSA screening tests ordered. Inappropriate testing was defined as the use of PSA for prostate cancer screening in patients older than 76 years or younger than 40 years. The adequacy of screening was dichotomized based on the age of the patient at the time of screening. Patients with PSA tests for reasons other than screening were excluded using a validated protocol. Logistic regression was performed with adjustment for patient grouping by physician. Analyzes were performed in 2009. RESULTS: During the intervention period (weeks 1 to 36), physicians who received spaced educational emails ordered significantly fewer inappropriate PSA screenings than control physicians (10.5% vs. 14.2%, p = 0.041). During the 72-week post-intervention period (weeks 37 to 108), spaced-education clinicians continued to request fewer inappropriate tests compared with controls (7.8% vs. 13.1%, respectively, p = 0.011) , representing a 40% relative reduction in inappropriate testing. put on screen CONCLUSIONS: Spaced education durably improves physicians' prostate cancer screening behaviors and represents a promising new methodology for improving patient care in health care systems.

title: Dynamic spread of happiness in a large social network: Longitudinal analysis over 20 years in the Framingham Heart Study.
abstract: OBJECTIVES Assess whether happiness can be spread from person to person and whether happiness niches are formed within social networks. DESIGN Longitudinal analysis of social networks. SCENARIO Framingham Heart Study social network. PARTICIPANTS 4739 individuals followed from 1983 to 2003. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Happiness measured with a validated scale of four items";" wide range of social network attributes and various social ties. RESULTS Groups of happy and unhappy people are visible on the network, and the relationship between people's happiness extends up to three degrees apart (for example, to one's friends' friends' friends). People who are surrounded by many happy people and those who are central to the network are more likely to be happy in the future. Longitudinal statistical models suggest that happiness clusters result from the spread of happiness and not just a tendency for people to associate with similar individuals. A friend who lives within a mile (about 1.6 km) and who becomes happy increases the probability that a person is happy by 25% (95% confidence interval: 1% to 57%). Similar effects are seen for co-resident spouses (8%, 0.2% to 16%), siblings who live within a mile (14%, 1% to 28%), and next-door neighbors (34%, 7% % to 70%). No effects seen between co-workers. The effect decays over time and with geographic separation. CONCLUSIONS People's happiness depends on the happiness of others with whom they interact. This provides additional justification for viewing happiness, like health, as a collective phenomenon.

title: Dyslipidemia in primary care: prevalence, recognition, treatment and control: data from the German Cardiovascular and Metabolic Risk Project (GEMCAS)
abstract: BACKGROUND: Current European Society of Cardiology (ESC) guidelines define low thresholds for the diagnosis of dyslipidemia using total cholesterol (TC) and LDL-cholesterol (LDL-C) to guide treatment. Although it is mainly a prevention tool, its thresholds are difficult to reach in clinical practice, especially in primary care. METHODS: In a nationwide study with 1,511 primary care physicians and 35,869 patients, we determined the prevalence of dyslipidemia, its recognition, treatment, and control rates. The diagnosis of dyslipidemia was based on CT and LDL-C. Basic descriptive statistics and prevalence rate ratios were calculated, as well as 95% confidence intervals. RESULTS: Dyslipidemia was very common in primary care (76% overall). 48.6% of men and 39.9% of women with dyslipidemia were diagnosed by doctors. However, lifestyle intervention controlled dyslipidemia in about 10% of patients only. A higher proportion (34.1% of men and 26.7% of women) were controlled by receiving pharmacotherapy. The possibility of being diagnosed and subsequently controlled by pharmacotherapy was greater in men (PRR 1.15"; 95% CI 1.12-1.17), in patients with concomitant cardiovascular risk factors, in patients with hypertension (PRR 1, 20; 95% CI 1.05-1.37) and cardiovascular disease (PRR 1.46; 95% CI 1.29-1.64), previous myocardial infarction (PRR 1.32; 95% CI 1.19 -1.47), and whether the patients knew they were hypertensive (PRR 1.18; 95% CI 1.04-1.34) or knew about their previous myocardial infarction (PRR 1.17; 95% CI 1.23-1.53). ). CONCLUSION: ESC thresholds appear to be difficult to reach. A simple call for more aggressive treatment or greater patient compliance is apparently not enough to increase the proportion of controlled patients. A shift to multifactorial treatment that considers lifestyle interventions and pharmacotherapy to reduce weight and lipids may be the only path in a population where simply being normal is certainly not ideal.

title: Early administration of aspirin in patients treated with alteplase for acute ischemic stroke: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Thrombolysis with intravenous alteplase is the only approved treatment for acute ischemic stroke. After alteplase-induced recanalization, reocclusion occurs in 14-34% of patients, probably due to platelet activation. Early administration of antiplatelet therapy after alteplase could reduce the risk of reocclusion and improve outcome. We compared the effects of early addition of intravenous aspirin to alteplase with standard non-aspirin alteplase.";" Background Thrombolysis with intravenous alteplase is the only approved treatment for acute ischemic stroke. After alteplase-induced recanalization, reocclusion occurs in 14-34% of patients, probably due to platelet activation. Early administration of antiplatelet therapy after alteplase could reduce the risk of reocclusion and improve outcome. We compared the effects of early addition of intravenous aspirin to alteplase with standard alteplase without aspirin.

title: Early Coverage, Access, Utilization, and Health Effects of Affordable Care Act Medicaid Expansions: A Quasi-Experimental Study
abstract: Background In 2014, only 26 states and DC chose to implement the Affordable Care Act (ACA) Medicaid expansions for low-income adults. Objective To estimate whether state expansions of Medicaid were associated with changes in insurance coverage, health care access and utilization, and self-reported health. Design Comparison of results before and after expansions in states that did and did not expand Medicaid. Establishment of participants US Citizens 19 ¨C64 with family income below 138% of the federal poverty level in the 2010 ¨C2014 National Health Interview Surveys. Measures "Health insurance coverage (private, Medicaid, no insurance)"; health insurance better than last year; visits to general practitioners and specialists; hospitalizations and emergency department visits; missed or delayed medical care; usual source of care; diagnoses of diabetes, high cholesterol, and hypertension, self-reported health, and depression Results In the second half of 2014, low-income adults in expanding states experienced an increase in health insurance (7.4 percentage points; 95% CI %, ?11.3 to ?3.4) and Medicaid (10.5 percentage points; 95% CI, 6.5 to 14.5) coverage and higher quality of insurance coverage compared to a year ago ( 7.1 percentage points; 95% CI, 2.7 to 11.5) compared with adults in states that did not expand Medicaid Medicaid expansions were associated with increased visits to general practice physicians (6.6 percentage points, 95% CI, 1.3 to 12.0), stays ho nocturnal spitalarias (2.4 percentage points, 95% CI, 0.7 to 4.2) and rates of diabetes diagnosis etes (5.2 percentage points; 95% CI, 2.4 to 8.1) and high cholesterol (5.7 percentage points; 95% CI, 2.0 to 9.4); changes in other outcomes were not statistically significant. Limitations The observational study may be susceptible to unmeasured confounding; is based on self-reported data;" the limited time frame post-ACA provides information on short-term changes only. Conclusions ACA Medicaid expansions were associated with higher rates of insurance coverage, better quality of coverage, higher utilization of some types of health care, and higher rates of diagnosis of chronic health conditions for low-income adults.

title: Early detection and intervention evaluation for people at risk of psychosis: a multicentre randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine whether cognitive therapy is effective in preventing the worsening of emergent psychotic symptoms experienced by young people who seek help and are considered to be at risk of serious illness such as schizophrenia. DESIGN Multisite single-blind randomized controlled trial. SETTING Various services at five UK sites. PARTICIPANTS 288 participants aged 14 to 35 years (mean 20.74, SD 4.34 years) at high risk for psychosis: 144 were assigned to cognitive therapy plus mental status monitoring and 144 to mental status monitoring alone. Participants were followed for a minimum of 12 months and a maximum of 24 months. INTERVENTION Cognitive therapy (up to 26 (mean 9.1) sessions over six months) plus mental status monitoring compared with mental status monitoring alone. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was Comprehensive Assessment of At-Risk Mental States (CAARMS) scores, which provides a dichotomous transition to psychosis score and ordinal scores for severity of psychotic symptoms and distress. Secondary outcomes included emotional dysfunction and quality of life. RESULTS Transition to psychosis based on intention to treat was analyzed using discrete-time survival models. Overall, the prevalence of transition was lower than expected (23/288";" 8%), with no significant difference between the two groups (proportional odds ratio 0.73, 95% confidence interval 0.32 to 1.68). Changes in symptom severity and distress, as well as secondary outcomes, were analyzed using random-effects regression (analysis of covariance) adjusted for baseline site and symptoms. Distress of psychotic symptoms did not differ (estimated difference at 12 months -3.00, 95% confidence interval -6.95 to 0.94), but their severity was significantly reduced in the cognitive therapy group (estimated effect size between groups at 12 months -3.67, -6.71 to -0.64, P=0.018). CONCLUSIONS Cognitive therapy plus monitoring did not significantly reduce transition to psychosis or symptom-related distress, but did reduce the severity of psychotic symptoms in high-risk youth. Most of the participants in both groups improved over time. The results have important implications for the concept of mental state at risk. TRIAL REGISTRATION Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN56283883.

title: Early detection of autism spectrum disorders: screening between 12 and 24 months of age
abstract: PURPOSE: The purpose of this article is to introduce nurse practitioners (NPs) to information about screening for autism spectrum disorders (ASDs) in children between 12 and 24 months of age. Recommendations for appropriate referrals and initiation of early intervention (EI) are also provided. DATA SOURCES: Review of the published literature on ASD. CONCLUSIONS: Children with ASD exhibit social interaction problems, verbal and nonverbal communication deficits, and repetitive, restricted, and stereotyped patterns of behavior or interests. Studies show that these children benefit from starting intensive EI as soon as possible. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: Early detection allows children with suspected ASD to be evaluated by specialists and admitted to treatment programs as soon as possible. Due to the importance of early diagnosis of ASD, it is critical that NPs use established screening instruments to maximize time and increase reliability of assessment.

title: Early photography, goiter and James Inglis
Early training to address patient obesity: a systematic review of nursing education
abstract: OBJECTIVES: This systematic review aims to identify studies that have evaluated educational interventions in the training of undergraduate nurses regarding obesity and to investigate the effectiveness of the interventions. BACKGROUND: Obesity is a prominent global problem and nurses have an increasing role in weight management with patients. The literature has identified several theory-based behavior change techniques that successfully help patients control their weight. Therefore, training nurses in obesity-related behavior change techniques is appropriate to prepare them for their future professional role. However, the effectiveness of these educational interventions has not yet been evaluated. METHODS: The Center for Reviews and Dissemination guidelines informed this systematic review. Systematic searches of four databases were performed and articles were assessed against the inclusion criteria. Data extraction and quality assessment forms were developed and completed to identify salient features of the articles. RESULTS: Eight studies met the inclusion criteria. Only two included baseline and outcome measures, one of which was a randomized controlled trial. Furthermore, only one study included an explicitly identified behavior change technique. Interventions were delivered through a variety of methods; however, quality assessment indicated that all studies had poor methodologies and high risks of bias. CONCLUSIONS: Studies in this area of research are scarce and methodologically unsound. Therefore, it is not possible to identify effective educational interventions for nursing students on weight control. IMPLICATIONS: More robust research is needed to investigate how nurses can be trained to facilitate weight management. Greater transparency of descriptions of interventions, particularly around the behavior change techniques that were taught, would allow for replication and proper evaluation. Until then, it is not known whether current teaching adequately equips nurses to manage overweight and obese patients.

title: Early treatment of migraine attacks with triptans: a strategy to improve outcomes and patient satisfaction?
abstract: Early treatment of migraine attacks with triptans may be more effective than delayed administration of triptans. However, in published studies, the definition of 'early' varied (in terms of timing, intensity of pain, or presence of allodynia) or was unclear. Therefore, no clear clinical indications have been established. Properly designed trials to address this issue remain a priority. Early treatment with triptans may also have drawbacks, including inadvertent treatment of tension-type headaches and the danger of medication overuse. Currently, only migraineurs with rapidly worsening pain, a high rate of pain recurrence, and clinical indications of allodynia should be encouraged to take triptans as quickly as possible. This recommendation implies a requirement for patient education and the need to carefully tailor treatment to individual needs.

title: Eating behavior disorders in children and adolescents: pharmacological therapies
abstract: Anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa exist in childhood, often begin in adolescence, and can have serious medical and psychiatric sequelae that impede physical, emotional, and behavioral development. Although we use the same definitions from the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, version 4 [DSM-IV] to diagnose eating disorders in children, adolescents, and adults, these disorders may be expressed somewhat differently in younger populations, requiring evaluation and treatment procedures that are tailored to your developmental needs. Significant advances have been made in recent years in our understanding of treatments for eating disorders in adults and, specifically, pharmacological treatments for these disorders. Multiple double-blind, placebo-controlled studies have documented the short-term efficacy of antidepressant medications in bulimia nervosa. Although the usefulness of pharmacological treatments for the acute treatment of anorexia nervosa is less clear, recent evidence suggests a role for medication in the relapse prevention stage of the disease. Most trials of medications for eating disorders have been conducted with adults, and the literature on the pharmacological treatment of children and adolescents with these disorders is very limited. This review article summarizes the current literature on the role of medication in the treatment of anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa, with special emphasis on studies conducted in populations of children and adolescents.

title: Eating disorders in the context of preconception care: knowledge, attitudes and clinical practices of fertility specialists
abstract: OBJECTIVE(S): To measure the knowledge, clinical practices, and training needs of fertility specialists in relation to eating disorders. DESIGN: Cross-sectional study. SETTINGS: Fertility clinics. PARTICIPANTS: Eighty fertility specialists from Australia and New Zealand who were members of the Fertility Society of Australia. INTERVENTION(S): None. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES(S): Responses to an online questionnaire completed anonymously. RESULT(S): Approximately 54% of clinicians correctly identified the relevant body mass index for anorexia nervosa, and 30% identified menstrual disorders for anorexia, while 63.8% of clinicians incorrectly nominated the relevant BMI for anorexia nervosa. Maladaptive weight control behaviors as a feature of binge eating disorder. While physicians (83.7%) agreed that it was important to screen for eating disorders during preconception screenings, 35% were routinely screened and 8.8% indicated that their clinics had Clinical practice guidelines for the management of eating disorders. A minority of participants (13.8%) felt satisfied with their level of college education in eating disorders, 37.5% of clinicians were confident in their ability to recognize eating disorder symptoms, and 96.2% indicated that he needed more education and clinical guidelines. For most items examined, clinical knowledge and practices regarding eating disorders did not differ by physician sex or years of clinical experience working as a fertility specialist. CONCLUSION(S): Knowledge about eating disorders in the context of fertility treatment is important. This study highlights the uncertainty among fertility specialists in detecting the characteristics of eating disorders. The findings point to the importance of further education and training, including the development of specific clinical guidelines for fertility healthcare providers.

title: Economic Analysis of the Be Fit Be Well Program: A Weight Loss Program for Community Health Centers
abstract: BACKGROUND: The US Preventive Services Task Force has released new guidelines on obesity, urging primary care physicians to provide obese patients with intensive multicomponent behavioral interventions. However, there are few studies of weight loss in real-world nonacademic primary care, and even fewer in low-income racial/ethnic minority samples. OBJECTIVE: To assess the recruitment, intervention, and replication costs of a 2-year moderate-intensity weight loss and blood pressure control intervention. DESIGN: A comprehensive cost analysis was conducted associated with a weight loss and hypertension control program administered at three community health centers as part of a pragmatic randomized trial. PARTICIPANTS: Three hundred and sixty-five high-risk, low-income, inner-city, hypertensive, and obese minority (71% Black/African American and 13% Hispanic) patients. MAIN MEASURES: Measures included total recruitment costs and intervention costs, cost per participant, and incremental costs per unit of weight and blood pressure reduction. KEY FINDINGS: Recruitment and intervention costs were estimated at $2,359 per participant for the 2-year program. Compared to the control intervention, the cost per additional kilogram lost was $2204/kg, and for blood pressure, $621/mmHg. Sensitivity analyzes suggest that if the program were offered to a larger sample and minor modifications were made, the cost per participant could be reduced to the levels of many commercially available products. CONCLUSIONS: Costs associated with the Be Fit Be Well program were found to be significantly more expensive than many commercially available products and much higher than the amount the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid reimburses physicians for obesity counseling. However, given the serious and costly health consequences associated with obesity in high-risk, multimorbid, and socioeconomically disadvantaged patients, the resources required to provide interventions such as those described here may still be cost-effective with respect to producing behavior change over time. long term.

title: Economic evaluation of health implementation strategies
abstract: Economic evaluations can inform decisions about the efficiency and allocation of resources to implementation strategies, strategies explicitly designed to inform care providers and patients about the best available research evidence and improve its use in their practices. These strategies are becoming increasingly popular in health care, especially in light of growing concerns about quality of care and resource limits. But such concerns have hardly motivated health authorities and other decision makers to spend on some form of economic evaluation in their evaluations of implementation strategies. This editorial addresses the importance of economic evaluation in the context of implementation science, in particular, how these analyzes can be more efficiently incorporated into decision-making processes about implementation strategies.

title: Economic implications of evidence-based prescribing for hypertension: can better care cost less?
abstract: Context Deviation from evidence-based guidelines in the treatment of hypertension is common, but its economic impact has not been rigorously studied. Suboptimal prescribing patterns contribute to the high cost of medications for older patients, as well as the difficulty of providing affordable prescription drug benefits for older Americans. Objective To estimate the potential savings from the perspective of health care payers that would result from greater adherence to evidence-based recommendations for the management of hypertension in patients older than 65 years. Design Comparative analysis of prescribed medications vs. potential regimens suggested by evidence-based guidelines adapted to the medical history of each patient, with cost calculations for both actual and evidence-based regimens. Setting and patients A total of 133,624 patients being treated for hypertension during 2001 who were enrolled in a large state pharmaceutical assistance program that provides prescription drug insurance for seniors. Main outcome measure Cost difference between drugs actually prescribed and regimens suggested by evidence-based guidelines. Results The patients studied filled more than 2.05 million prescriptions for antihypertensive medications in 2001, at an annual program cost of $48.5 million ($363 per patient). We identified 815,316 prescriptions (40%) for which an alternative regimen seemed more appropriate based on evidence-based recommendations. Such changes would have reduced costs to payers in 2001 by $11.6 million (nearly a quarter of the program's spending on antihypertensive drugs), as well as being more clinically appropriate overall. Replacement of calcium channel blockers resulted in the greatest potential savings. Using price caps similar to those in the Medicaid program would have resulted in an even greater potential savings of $20.5 million (42% of program costs). Conclusions Compliance with evidence-based prescribing guidelines for hypertension could result in substantial savings in prescription costs for elderly patients with hypertension that would amount to savings of around $1.2 billion nationally. Identifying similar areas where prescribing can be improved will be critical to the affordability of prescription drug benefit programs.

title: Editorial: Paroxysmal Tachycardia in Children
Publisher: Research Guidelines
Educational and organizational interventions to improve the management of depression in primary care: a systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND: Depression is commonly found in primary care settings but is often overlooked or suboptimally managed. Several organizational and educational strategies have been proposed to improve the treatment of depression. The clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of these strategies have not yet been subjected to a systematic review. OBJECTIVE: To systematically assess the efficacy of organizational and educational interventions to improve the treatment of depression in primary care settings. DATA SOURCES: Electronic medical and psychological databases were searched from inception to March 2003 (MEDLINE, PsycLIT, EMBASE, CINAHL, Cochrane Controlled Trials Register, United Kingdom National Health Service Economic Evaluations Database, Cochrane Depression Anxiety and Neurosis Group register and Cochrane and register of specialists of the Organizational Change Group)"; correspondence maintained with the authors;" and lists of references used. Search terms related to depression, primary care, and all organizational and educational guidelines and interventions. STUDY SELECTION: We selected 36 studies, including 29 randomized controlled trials and nonrandomized controlled clinical trials, 5 controlled before-and-after studies, and 2 interrupted time-series studies. Results related to treatment and depression outcome were sought. DATA EXTRACTION: Methodological details and results were extracted and checked by two reviewers. Summary relative risks were calculated, where possible, from the original data and attempts were made to correct for unit of analysis error. DATA SYNTHESIS: A narrative synthesis was performed. We found 21 studies with positive results. Effective strategies to improve overall patient outcome were those with complex interventions that incorporated physician education, an enhanced role for the nurse (nursing case management), and a greater degree of integration between primary and secondary care (medical consultation). -link). Telephone medication counseling by practice nurses or trained counselors was also effective. Simple implementation of guidelines and educational strategies were generally ineffective. CONCLUSIONS: There is substantial potential to improve the management of depression in primary care. Commonly used educational guidelines and strategies are likely to be ineffective. Implementation of the findings of this research will require a substantial investment in primary care services and a major change in the organization and delivery of care.

title: Educational Intervention in the Knowledge and Performance of Vaccination against Hepatitis B in Patients with Diabetes Mellitus of Residents of Primary Care
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Although guidelines recommend hepatitis B virus (HBV) immunization for adults with diabetes mellitus (DM), vaccination rates remain low. Our aim was to assess knowledge and practice regarding HBV and to assess the effectiveness of a multifaceted educational program. METHODS: Primary care residents (n = 244) from three academic institutions were surveyed on various aspects of HBV. Residents in a training program were then randomly assigned to an educational intervention (E) (n = 20) and a control (C) group (n = 19). Group E received a focused didactic lecture and regular email reminders with immediate feedback. We compared knowledge scores before and after the intervention. Chart audits were conducted to assess resident behavior. RESULTS: A total of 103 (42%) residents responded to the survey. The survey indicated that residents lacked the necessary knowledge and risk assessment skills regarding HBV in patients with DM. In the controlled trial of intervention E, both groups had similar baseline knowledge scores. Group E had a significant increase in knowledge scores immediately post-intervention from a mean of 29% at baseline to 70% (P < 0.001) that was maintained 6 months post-intervention (65%; P < 0.001). ). In group C, scores at 6 months post-intervention were not different from baseline (38% vs. 29%). No significant differences were observed in documentation skills. CONCLUSIONS: A combined educational program was effective in improving knowledge about HBV and vaccination in DM, but had limited influence on physician practice. Further studies incorporating system changes along with educational initiatives to improve clinical practice are required.

title: Educational interventions for general practitioners to identify and manage depression as a risk factor for suicide in young people: a systematic review and meta-analysis protocol.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Suicide is a major public health problem and, globally, is the second leading cause of death in young adults. Globally, there are 164,000 suicides per year in young people under 25 years of age. Depression is a strong risk factor for suicide. Evidence shows that 45% of those who commit suicide, including young adults, contact their general practitioner rather than a mental health professional in the month before their death. More evidence indicates that general practitioners do not detect and treat risk factors or early warning signs of suicide in young people. Healthcare-based suicide prevention interventions targeting general practitioners are designed to increase identification of at-risk youth. The rationale for this type of intervention is that early identification and improved clinical management of those at risk will reduce morbidity and mortality. This systematic review will synthesize the evidence on the effectiveness of educational interventions for general practitioners in the identification and management of depression as a risk factor for suicide in young people. METHODS/DESIGN: We will conduct a systematic review and meta-analysis following the guidelines of the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions and adhere to the reporting guidelines of the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement recommendations. . We will systematically search electronic databases for randomized controlled trials and quasi-experimental studies investigating the effectiveness of interventions for general practitioners in identifying and managing depression as a risk factor for suicide in young people compared to any other intervention, no intervention, usual care or waiting. ready. Gray literature will be searched by screening trial registers. Only studies published in English will be included. No date restrictions will apply. Two authors will independently review the titles and abstracts of potential studies. The primary outcome is identification and treatment of depression. Secondary outcomes are suicidal ideation, suicide attempts, deliberate self-harm, knowledge of suicide risk factors and suicide-related behaviours, attitudes towards suicide risk and suicide-related behaviours, confidence to treat suicide risk factors and suicide-related behaviors. DISCUSSION: Our study will inform the development of future educational interventions and provide evidence of feasibility and acceptability, to help general practitioners identify and manage suicidal behavior in young people. SYSTEMATIC REVIEW REGISTRY: PROSPERO registration number: CRD42014009110.

title: Educational interventions to improve the prescription and dispensing of antibiotics: a systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND: Excessive and inappropriate use of antibiotics contributes to the rise of antibiotic resistance, a major public health problem. Strategies should be developed to improve the prescription of antibiotics. Our purpose is to review educational programs aimed at improving antibiotic prescribing by physicians and/or antibiotic dispensing by pharmacists, both in primary care and hospital settings. METHODS: We conducted a critical systematic search and review of the relevant literature on educational programs aimed at improving the practice of prescribing and dispensing antibiotics in hospital and primary care settings, published from January 2001 to December 2011. RESULTS: We identified 78 studies for analysis, 47 in primary care and 31 in a hospital setting. The studies differed widely in design but mostly reported positive results. Outcomes measured in the studies reviewed were adherence to guidelines, total antibiotics prescribed, or both, attitudes and behavior related to antibiotic prescribing, and quality of antibiotic-related pharmacy practice. Twenty-nine studies (62%) in primary care and twenty-four (78%) in hospital settings reported positive results for all outcomes measured"; fourteen studies (30%) in primary care and six (20%) in hospital settings reported positive results for some outcomes and outcomes that were not statistically influenced by the intervention for others;" only four studies in primary care and one study in a hospital setting failed to report significant post-intervention improvements for all outcomes. Improvement in adherence to guidelines and reduction in total antibiotics prescribed, after educational interventions, were observed in 46% and 41% of all studies reviewed, respectively. Changes in behavior related to antibiotic prescribing and improvement in the quality of pharmacy practice, respectively, were observed in four studies and one study, respectively. CONCLUSION: The results show that the use of antibiotics could be improved through educational interventions, being mostly used multifaceted interventions.

title: Educational visits and prescription of sedative-hypnotics in general practice
abstract: Public concern about the prescription of sedative-hypnotics (primarily benzodiazepines) led to a controlled trial of an educational intervention to promote rational prescribing by general practitioners (GPs). This paper describes the educational intervention and its evaluation process. In urban and rural New South Wales, 137 GPs were visited during office hours by a GP or pharmacist who had received training in communication skills. Material offered to GPs included relaxation tapes and a problem-oriented management guideline booklet. The interview had three stages: rapport was established, then educational material was presented, and finally, the visitor sought the physician's consent to review five long-term benzodiazepine patients. The visits were well received. Several measures were written to reflect physicians' motivation and interest in non-pharmacological management";" There was virtually no correlation between any of these process measures and the outcome of the trial: a change in prescribing behavior. Self-assessment of benzodiazepine prescribing greatly underestimated actual self-reported prescribing incidents. We take this as a reminder that we don't always do what we want to do, and we don't always do what we think we do.

title: Effect of a computerized body mass index indicator on the diagnosis and treatment of obesity in adults.
abstract: Background: In obese adults, physicians often fail to identify obesity and recommend treatments for it. We sought to determine whether a computerized body mass index (BMI) chart would increase the likelihood that GP patients would be diagnosed with obesity and referred for obesity treatment. Methods: A total of 846 obese patients from 37 family physicians were randomly assigned to have either a patient BMI chart indicator placed on their electronic medical record (intervention group) or no BMI indicator placed (intervention group). comparison) in the registry. . We then examine the patients' medical records for evidence of an obesity diagnosis and referrals for specific obesity treatments. We also measured whether the presence of comorbidities in obese patients influenced the likelihood of diagnoses and treatment by physicians. Results: Obese patients of physicians who had a BMI chart in their medical records were significantly more likely to receive a diagnosis of obesity than obese patients of physicians who did not have a BMI chart (16.6% versus 10.7% ";" P= .016). Patients of physicians who were provided with a BMI chart were also more likely than patients of physicians who did not receive a chart to receive a referral for dietary management (14.0% vs. 7.3%, p=0.002 ) and exercise (12.1%). versus 7.1%, p = 0.016). Of the obesity comorbidities, only obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) was a predictor of a patient being diagnosed with obesity (OR=0.49, 95% CI=0.281, 0.869, p=0.014). Conclusions: The inclusion of a computerized BMI chart increased the likelihood that physicians would diagnose obesity in obese patients and refer them for treatment.

title: Effect of minimal pharmaceutical intervention in improving adherence to asthma guidelines.
abstract: Objective To study the effectiveness of a minimal intervention strategy to improve adherence to pediatric asthma guidelines. Design and setting A group of pharmacists were encouraged to discuss the essential elements of asthma care with the general practitioners with whom they normally work. Adherence to the guidelines was evaluated through the study of prescriptions for children with asthma. We compared the treatment of children registered in pharmacies that participated in the study (intervention group) with a control group of children registered in other non-participating pharmacies (reference group) and with the results of a previous study. Main outcome measures The number of children who did not receive short-acting betamimetics, inhaled corticosteroids while receiving long-acting betamimetics, and more than one type of inhaler. Results Significantly fewer children did not receive short-acting betamimetics in the intervention group (176/1447 vs. 534/3527"; p<0.01) and fewer children did not receive inhaled corticosteroids but received long-acting betamimetics. (6/219 vs. 41/477; p=0.03) The number of children who had more than one type of inhaler was the same in both groups (5.1%), but was significantly lower compared to the study above (119/2311 vs. 239/3217;" p<0.01). Conclusions Pharmacists' assistance in complying with pediatric asthma guidelines is beneficial. Pharmacists should be actively involved in the care of children with asthma.

title: Effect of a web-based guided self-help intervention for the prevention of major depression in adults with subthreshold depression.
abstract: Importance Evidence-based treatments for major depressive disorder (MDD) are not very successful in improving health and functional outcomes. Attention has increasingly focused on the prevention of MDD. Objective To assess the efficacy of a web-based guided self-help intervention for the prevention of MDD. Design, Setting, and Participants Two-arm randomized clinical trial conducted between March 1, 2013, and March 4, 2015. Participants were recruited in Germany from the general population through a large public health insurance company (es i.e. insurance funded by joint ventures employee contributions). Participants included 406 self-selected adults with subthreshold depression (Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale score 16, without current MDD according to criteria in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders [Fourth Edition, Text Revision] ). Interventions All participants had unrestricted access to usual care (primary care physician visits) and were randomized to a web-based guided self-help intervention (cognitive behavioral and problem-solving therapy supported by an online coach). "; n?=?202) or a web-based psychoeducation program (n?=?204). Main outcomes and measures The primary outcome was time to onset of MDD in the intervention group relative to the group control over a 12-month follow-up period as assessed by blinded diagnostic raters using the telephone-administered Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-IV Axis Disorders at 6- and 12-month follow-up, covering the period up to the previous assessment. Results Among 406 randomized patients (mean age, 45 years; 73.9% women), 335 (82%) completed telephone follow-up at 12 months. participants (27%) in the intervention group experienced MDD compared to 84 participants (41%) in the control group. Cox regression analysis controlling for baseline Depressive symptom severity revealed a hazard ratio of 0.59 (95% CI, 0.42-0.82; P = .002) at 12-month follow-up . The number needed to treat to prevent 1 new case of MDD was 5.9 (95% CI, 3.9-14.6). Conclusions and relevance Among patients with subthreshold depression, the use of a web-based guided self-help intervention compared with enhanced usual care reduced the incidence of MDD over 12 months. More research is needed to understand whether the effects are generalizable for both first-onset depression and recurrence of depression, as well as efficacy without the use of an online coach.

title: Effect of an educational program (PEGASE) on cardiovascular risk in hypercholesterolemic patients
abstract: BACKGROUND: Many studies have shown a gap between guidelines for cardiovascular disease (CVD) prevention and their implementation in clinical practice. OBJECTIVE: The PEGASE education program has been designed with the aim of improving the management of patients at high risk of CVD. METHODS: In a multicenter study conducted between 2001 and 2004 in France, 96 participating physicians were randomized into a "trained" group, which included 398 "educated" patients, and an "untrained" group, which included 242 "uneducated patients." . The educated patients received six educational sessions in the hospital, four collective and two individual. Framingham score, smoking status, lipid levels, blood glucose, blood pressure, dietary intake, and drug compliance, as well as quality of life, were assessed at baseline (M0) and at 6 months ( M6). The primary endpoint of the study was the effectiveness of the PEGASE program in reducing the overall risk of CVD in high-risk patients. RESULTS: The Framingham score was calculated for 473 patients. The Framingham score was significantly improved at M6 versus M0 in the education group (13.0 +/- 8.21 versus 13.6 +/- 8.48, d = -0.658, p = 0.016), but not in the group with no education (12.5 +/- 8.19 vs. 12.4 +/- 7.81, d = +0.064, p = 0.836)";" the mean change between the two groups did not reach significance. Quality of life, LDL-c level, and diet scores improved only in the "educated" group. CONCLUSIONS: The PEGASE education program improved CVD risk factors, although the global assessment using the Framingham score was not significantly different between groups. This program, designed to meet the needs and expectations of patients and doctors, was easily implemented in all hospitals.

title: Effect of an outpatient antimicrobial stewardship intervention on broad-spectrum antibiotic prescribing by primary care pediatricians: a randomized trial.
abstract: Importance Antimicrobial stewardship programs have been effective for hospitalized patients, often through prescription audits and feedback. However, most antimicrobial use occurs in outpatients with acute respiratory tract infections (ARIs). Objective To assess the effect of an antimicrobial stewardship intervention on antibiotic prescribing for pediatric outpatients. Design of a cluster randomized trial of outpatient antimicrobial stewardship comparing prescribing between intervention and control practices using a common electronic health record. After excluding children with chronic medical conditions, antibiotic allergies, and prior antibiotic use, we estimated prescription rates for specific ARTIs standardized by age, sex, race, and insurance from 20 months before the intervention to 12 months after. (October 2008 to June 2011). ). Setting and Participants A network of 25 pediatric primary care practices in Pennsylvania and New Jersey; 18 clinics (162 physicians) participated. Interventions One 1 hour on-site clinician education session (June 2010) followed by 1 year of quarterly personalized audit and prescribing feedback for bacterial and viral ARIs or usual practice Main outcomes and measures Antibiotic prescribing rates broad-spectrum antibiotics (outside of guidelines) for bacterial ARIs and antibiotics for viral ARIs for 1 year after intervention Results Prescription of broad-spectrum antibiotics decreased from 26.8% to 14.3% (absolute difference, 12, 5%) among intervention practices versus 28.4% to 22.6% (absolute difference, 5.8%) in controls (difference-of-differences [DOD], 6.7%; P = .01 for differences Non-guideline prescribing for children with pneumonia decreased from 15.7% to 4.2% among intervention practices compared to 17.1% to 16.3% in controls (DOD, 10.7% ; P < 0.001) and for acute cases inusitis 38.9% a l 18.8% in intervention practices and from 40.0% to 33.9% in controls (DOD, 14.0%; p = 0.12). Non-guideline prescribing was uncommon at baseline and changed little for strep throat (intervention, 4.4% to 3.4%; control, 5.6% to 3.5%; DOD, -1, 1%; P = 0.82) and for viral infections (intervention, 7.9% to 7.7%; control, 6.4% to 4.5%; DOD, -1.7%;" P = 0.93) Conclusions and Relevance In this large pediatric primary care network, physician education coupled with audit and routine practice improved adherence to prescribing guidelines for common bacterial ARTIs and non-intervention. affected the prescription of antibiotics for viral infections administration.

title: Effect of anemia and cardiovascular disease on surgical mortality and morbidity
abstract: Background Guidelines have been offered on hemoglobin thresholds for blood transfusion in surgical patients. However, good evidence is lacking on the hemoglobin concentrations at which the risk of death or serious morbidity begins to increase and at which transfusion is indicated.";" Background Guidelines have been offered on hemoglobin thresholds for blood transfusion in surgical patients. However, good evidence is lacking on the hemoglobin concentrations at which the risk of death or serious morbidity begins to increase and at which transfusion is indicated.

title: Effect of peer-reviewed audit and feedback on prescribing and test ordering performance of general practitioners: a cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Much of the research around the world focuses on cost containment and better compliance with guidelines in health care. Research that focuses on professional behavior is often conducted in a well-controlled research environment. In this study, a large-scale implementation of a peer-review strategy was tested on both evidence-ordering and prescribing behavior in primary care in the normal quality-improvement setting. METHODS: We planned a cluster RCT in existing local quality improvement collaborations (LQICs) in primary care. The study was conducted from January 2008 to January 2011. LQICs were randomly assigned to one of two trial arms, with each arm receiving the same audit and feedback intervention combined with peer review. Both arms were offered five different clinical subjects and acted as blind controls for the other arm. Differences in test request rates and prescription rates between the two arms were analyzed in a pre-post intention-to-treat analysis and in a per-protocol analysis. RESULTS: Twenty-one LQIC groups, including 197 physicians working in 88 practices, entered the trial. Intention-to-treat analysis did not show a difference in changes in test ordering or prescribing performance between the intervention and control groups. Per-protocol analysis showed positive results for half of the clinical subjects. The increase in total tests ordered was 3% in the intervention arm and 15% in the control arm. By prescription, the increase in prescriptions was 20% in the intervention arm and 66% in the control group. It was observed that the groups with the highest test orders and prescription volumes at the start of the study showed the greatest improvements. CONCLUSIONS: Our study shows that the results of the previous work could not be confirmed by our attempt to implement the strategy in the field. We did not see a decrease in volumes of tests ordered or medications prescribed, but we were able to show a minor increase instead. The implementation of peer review with audit and feedback proved to be infeasible in primary care in the Netherlands. TRIAL REGISTRATION: This trial was registered in the Dutch trial registry under number ISRCTN40008171 on August 7, 2007.

title: Effect of audit and feedback, and reminder messages on primary care radiology referrals: a randomized trial.
abstract: Background Radiological tests are often used by general practitioners (GPs). These tests can be overused and contribute little to clinical management. The objective was to evaluate two methods to reduce requests for radiological tests by GPs in accordance with the UK Royal College of Radiologists guidelines on radiographs of the lumbar spine and knee. Methods We evaluated audit and feedback and educational reminder messages in six radiology departments and 244 general practices they served. The study was a pragmatic, before-and-after, cluster randomized controlled trial with a 2·2 factorial design. A randomized subset of GP patient records were reviewed for consistency with guidelines. The main outcome measure was the number of requests for radiographs per 1000 patients per year. Analysis was by intention to treat. Findings The effect of educational reminder messages (i.e. change in request rate after intervention) was an absolute change of -1 53 (95% CI -2 5 to -0 57) for lumbar spine and -1 61 (-2 6 to -0 62) for knee radiographs, both relative reductions of about 20%. The effect of audit and feedback was an absolute change from -0 07 (-1 3 to 0 9) for lumbar spine to 0 04 (-0 95 to 1 03) for requests for radiographs of knee, both relative reductions of about 1%. Agreement between groups did not differ significantly. Interpretation Bi-annual feedback of audit data is not effective, but the attached routine of educational reminder messages to radiographs is effective and does not affect the quality of references. Any radiology department that handles referrals from primary care could perform this intervention with good results.

title: Effect of behavior modification on outcome in early-to-moderate chronic kidney disease: a cluster-randomized trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Due to recent changes in our understanding of the underlying cause of chronic kidney disease (CKD), the importance of lifestyle modification to prevent progression of renal dysfunction and complications has become obvious. Furthermore, effective cooperation between general practitioners (GPs) and nephrologists is essential to ensure a better system of care for the treatment of CKD. In this cluster-randomized study, we studied the effect of behavior modification on outcome in early-to-moderate stage CKD. DESIGN: Stratified open cluster randomized trial. SETTING: A total of 489 physicians belonging to 49 local medical associations (clusters) in Japan. PARTICIPANTS: A total of 2,379 patients (1,195 in group A (standard intervention) and 1,184 in group B (advanced intervention)) aged between 40 and 74 years, who had CKD and were in consultation with GPs. INTERVENTION: All patients were managed according to current CKD guidelines. Group B groups received three additional interventions: patients received an educational intervention for lifestyle modification and a CKD status letter, in an attempt to prevent them from dropping out of treatment, and physicians in group B received of data to facilitate bridging the gap between goal and practice. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: The primary outcome measures were 1) rate of non-compliance to accept continuous medical follow-up of patients, 2) rate of collaboration between GPs and nephrologists, and 3) progression of CKD. . RESULTS: The rate of discontinuous clinic visits was significantly lower in group B (16.2% in group A vs. 11.5% in group B, p = 0.01). In group B, significantly higher rates of referral and co-treatment were observed (p<0.01). The average rate of deterioration of eGFR tended to be lower in group B (group A: 2.6+/-5.8 ml/min/1.73 m2/year, group B: 2.4+/-5 .1 ml/min/1.73 m2/year, p = 0.07). A significant difference was observed in the rate of deterioration of eGFR in subjects with stage 3 CKD (group A: 2.4+/-5.9 ml/min/1.73 m2/year, group B: 1.9 +/-4.4 ml/min/1.73 m2/year, p = 0.03). CONCLUSION: Our system of care achieved behavioral change in CKD patients, i.e., significantly lower discontinuous clinic visits, and behavior change in both GPs and nephrologists, i.e., referral rates and significantly higher co-treatment rates, resulting in delayed CKD progression, especially in patients with stage 3 proteinuric CKD. REGISTER OF TESTS: Register of clinical tests of the Medical Information Network of the University Hospital UMIN000001159.

title: Effect of behavioral interventions on inappropriate antibiotic prescribing among primary care practices: a randomized clinical trial
abstract: IMPORTANCE: Interventions based on behavioral science could reduce inappropriate antibiotic prescribing. OBJECTIVE: To assess the effects of behavioral interventions and rates of inappropriate antibiotic prescribing (not consistent with guidelines) during outpatient visits for acute respiratory tract infections. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: Cluster randomized clinical trial conducted among 47 primary care practices in Boston and Los Angeles. Participants were 248 enrolled physicians randomly assigned to receive 0, 1, 2, or 3 interventions over 18 months. All physicians received education on antibiotic prescribing guidelines at the time of enrollment. Interventions began between November 1, 2011, and October 1, 2012.
