Follow-up for late-onset sites ended on April 1, 2014. Adult patients with comorbidities and concomitant infections were excluded. INTERVENTIONS: Three behavioral interventions, implemented alone or in combination: suggested alternatives presented sets of electronic commands suggesting treatments without antibiotics; responsible justification led physicians to enter free-text justifications for prescribing antibiotics into patients' electronic health records; the peer comparison sent emails to doctors who compared their antibiotic prescribing rates with those of the "best performers" (those with the lowest inappropriate prescribing rates). MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES: Antibiotic prescription rates for visits with inappropriate antibiotic diagnoses (nonspecific upper respiratory tract infections, acute bronchitis, and influenza) from 18 months before the intervention to 18 months after, adjusting for the effects of each intervention for interventions. concurrent and pre-intervention trends, with random effects for practices and clinicians. RESULTS: There were 14,753 visits (mean patient age, 47 years; 69% women) for antibiotic-inappropriate acute respiratory infections during the reference period and 16,959 visits (mean patient age, 48 years; 67% women) during the intervention period Mean antibiotic prescription rates decreased from 24.1% at baseline to 13.1% at intervention month 18 (absolute difference, -11.0%) for control practices , from 22.1% to 6.1% (absolute difference, -16.0%) for the suggested alternatives (difference-in-differences, -5.0% [95% CI, -7.8% to 0.1% ]; P = 0.66 for differences in trajectories); 23.2% to 5.2% (absolute difference, -18.1%) for responsible justification (difference-in-differences, -7.0% [95% CI, -9.1% to -2.9%] ; P < .001) and 19.9% to 3.7% (absolute difference, -16.3%) for pairwise comparison (difference-in-differences, -5.2% [95% CI, -6, 9% to -1.6%];" P < 0.001). There were no statistically significant interactions (neither synergy nor interference) between the interventions. CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Among primary care practices, the use of accountable justification and the peer comparison such as behavioral interventions resulted in lower rates of inappropriate antibiotic prescribing for acute respiratory tract infections TRIAL REGISTRATION: Clinicaltrials.gov Identifier: NCT01454947.

title: Effect of clinical decision support systems: a systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite increasing emphasis on the role of clinical decision support systems (CDSS) in improving care and reducing costs, evidence to support widespread use is lacking. PURPOSE: To assess the effect of CDSS on clinical outcomes, healthcare processes, workload and efficiency, patient satisfaction, cost, and provider usage and implementation. DATA SOURCES: MEDLINE, CINAHL, PsycINFO, and Web of Science as of January 2011. STUDY SELECTION: Investigators independently screened reports to identify English-published randomized trials of electronic CDSS that were implemented in clinical settings"; used by providers to aid in point-of-care decision making, and reported clinical, care process, workload, relationship-focused, financial, or provider usage outcomes DATA EXTRACTION: Researchers extracted data on study design, participant characteristics, interventions, outcomes, and quality.DATA SYNTHESIS: We included 148 randomized controlled trials.28 (86%) evaluated health care process measures, 29 (20%) evaluated clinical outcomes and 22 (15%) measured costs Both commercially and locally developed CDSS improved measures of the process of medical care related to the provision of preventive services (n= 25; odds ratio [OR], 1.42 [95% CI, 1.27 to 1.58]), ranking trials (n=20; OR, 1.72 [CI, 1.47 to 2.00] ) and prescription of therapies (n= 46; OR, 1.57 [CI, 1.35 to 1.82]). Few studies measured possible unintended consequences or adverse effects. LIMITATIONS: Studies were heterogeneous in terms of interventions, populations, publication bias and selective reporting cannot be excluded. CONCLUSION: Locally and commercially developed CDSS are effective in improving health care process measures in various settings, but evidence for clinical, economic, workload, and efficiency outcomes remains sparse. The review furthers knowledge in the field by demonstrating the benefits of CDSS outside of experienced academic centers.

title: Effect of computer-assisted implementation of the European Best Practice Guideline on adherence and goal achievement: ORAMA results.
abstract: Background: The success of guidelines largely depends on their effective implementation and acceptance in clinical practice. The Optimal Assessment of Management of Renal Anemia (ORAMA) study investigated the impact of European best practice guidelines (EBPGs) on patient outcomes. Methods: ORAMA was a prospective, international, multicenter, cluster-randomized study. Fifty-three centers in eight European countries enrolled patients with stage V chronic kidney disease receiving chronic dialysis. Patients were anemic (hemoglobin [Hb] <11 g/dL [110 g/L]) or treated with erythropoiesis-stimulating agents and/or iron supplements. Centers were randomly assigned to two groups, with or without access to a computerized clinical decision support (CDS) system. In a post hoc analysis, patients were subdivided into investigators' adherence or non-adherence to the EBPG, regardless of CDS use. The primary endpoint was the proportion of patients with Hb >11 g/dL (110 g/L), reflecting hematologic targets on the revised EPBG. Results: In this population of 599 dialysis patients, hematologic endpoints did not differ in the presence or absence of a CDS system. There was a general shift towards a better distribution of patients by Hb categories while the width of the distribution curves remained unchanged. The proportion of patients with Hb >11 g/dl (110 g/l) was higher among adherents (79% and 84% with or without CDS use, respectively) than among non-adherents (59% and 57%, respectively). ). Conclusions: ORAMA is the first international study that shows that adherence to the EBPG improves the achievement of anemia rates. The availability of a CDS system did not affect anemia management.

title: Effect of evidence-based computerized guidelines on the management of asthma and angina in adults in primary care: cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Abstract Objective: To evaluate the use of a computerized decision support system for the implementation of evidence-based clinical guidelines for the management of asthma and angina in adults in primary care. Design: A pragmatic before-and-after cluster randomized controlled trial using a two-by-two incomplete block design. Setting: 60 general practices in the North East of England. Participants: General practitioners and practice nurses in the study practices and their patients aged 18 years or older with angina or asthma. Main outcome measures: Compliance with guidelines, based on review of patient-reported case notes and generic and condition-specific outcome measures. Results: The computerized decision support system had no significant effect on consultation rates, measures of the process of care (including prescribing), or patient-reported outcomes for any of the conditions. Software usage levels were low. Conclusions: No effect of evidence-based computerized guidelines on the management of asthma or angina in adults in primary care was found. This was probably due to low levels of software usage, despite the system being optimized as far as technically possible. Even if the technical issues of producing a system that fully supports chronic disease management are resolved, the challenge of integrating the systems into clinical settings where busy clinicians manage patients with multiple and complex conditions remains.

title: Effect of daily aspirin on long-term risk of cancer death: analysis of individual patient data from randomized trials.
abstract: Background Treatment with daily aspirin for 5 years or more reduces the subsequent risk of colorectal cancer. Several lines of evidence suggest that aspirin might also reduce the risk of other cancers, particularly of the gastrointestinal tract, but evidence in men is lacking. We studied cancer deaths during and after randomized trials of daily aspirin versus control originally conducted for the prevention of vascular events.";" Background Treatment with daily aspirin for 5 years or more reduces the subsequent risk of colorectal cancer. Several lines of evidence suggest that aspirin might also reduce the risk of other cancers, particularly of the gastrointestinal tract, but evidence in men is lacking. We studied cancer deaths during and after randomized trials of daily aspirin versus control originally conducted for the prevention of vascular events.

title: Effect of exercise referral schemes in primary care on physical activity and improvement of health outcomes: systematic review and meta-analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the impact of baseline exercise schedules on physical activity and health outcomes. Design Systematic review and meta-analysis. DATA SOURCES Medline, Embase, PsycINFO, Cochrane Library, ISI Web of Science, SPORTDiscus, and registries of ongoing trials up to October 2009. We also checked study references. Study selection Design: Randomized controlled trials or non-randomized controlled studies (group or individual) published in peer-reviewed journals. POPULATION sedentary individuals with or without a medical diagnosis. Exercise referral schemes defined as: clear referrals by primary care professionals to outside service providers to increase physical activity or exercise, individual-tailored physical activity or exercise programs, and initial assessment and follow-up throughout of the programs. Comparators: usual care, no intervention, or alternative exercise referral schemes. RESULTS Eight randomized controlled trials met the inclusion criteria and compared exercise referral schemes with usual care (six trials), alternative physical activity intervention (two), and an exercise referral scheme plus a self-determination theory intervention. (one). Compared with usual care, follow-up data for exercise bypass schemes showed a greater number of participants achieving between 90 and 150 minutes of physical activity of at least moderate intensity per week (pooled relative risk 1.16, 95% confidence intervals 1.03 to 1.30) and a reduced level of depression (pooled standardized mean difference -0.82, -1.28 to -0.35). Evidence of a difference between groups in moderate- or vigorous-intensity physical activity or other health outcomes was inconsistent at follow-up. No differences in outcomes were found between the exercise bypass schemes and the other two comparison groups. None of the included trials separately reported outcomes in individuals with specific medical diagnoses. Significant heterogeneity in the quality and nature of exercise referral schemes between studies could have contributed to inconsistency in results. Conclusions Considerable uncertainty remains as to the effectiveness of baseline exercise schedules in increasing physical activity, fitness, or health indicators, or whether they are an efficient use of resources for sedentary people with or without a medical diagnosis. .

title: Effect of financial incentives for physicians, patients, or both on lipid levels
abstract: Importance Financial incentives for physicians or patients are being used more and more, but their effectiveness is not well established. Objective To determine whether financial incentives for physicians, incentives for patients, or shared incentives between physician and patient are more effective than control in reducing low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) levels in patients with high cardiovascular risk. Design, Setting, and Participants Four-arm, multicenter, cluster-randomized clinical trial with a 12-month intervention conducted between 2011 and 2014 in 3 primary care practices in the northeastern United States. 340 eligible primary care physicians (PCPs) were enrolled from a pool of 421. From 25 to 627 potentially eligible patients of those PCPs, 1,503 were enrolled. Patients 18 to 80 years of age were eligible if they had a 10-year Framingham Risk Score (FRS) of 20% or greater, had coronary artery disease equivalents with LDL-C levels of 120 mg/dL or greater , or had an FRS of 10% to 20% with LDL-C levels of 140 mg/dL or higher. The investigators were blinded to the study group, but not the participants. Interventions Primary care physicians were randomly assigned to control, physician incentives, patient incentives, or shared physician-patient incentives. Physicians in the Physician Incentive Group were eligible to receive up to $1,024 per enrolled patient who met LDL-C goals. Patients in the patient incentive group were eligible for the same amount, distributed through daily lotteries linked to medication adherence. Physicians and patients in the shared incentive group shared these incentives. Physicians and patients in the control group received no performance-related incentives, but all participating patients received up to $355 each for their participation in the trial. Main outcomes and measures Change in LDL-C level at 12 months. Results Patients in the physician-patient shared incentive group achieved a mean reduction in LDL-C of 33.6 mg/dL (95% CI, 30.1-37.1"; baseline, 160.1 mg/dL). dL, 12 months, 126.4 mg/dL); physician incentives achieved a mean reduction of 27.9 mg/dL (95% CI, 24.9-31.0; baseline, 159.9 mg /dL; 12 months, 132.0 mg/dL); those on patient incentives achieved a mean reduction of 25.1 mg/dL (95% CI, 21.6-28.5; baseline, 160.6 mg/dL; 12 months, 135.5 mg/dL); and those in the control group achieved a mean reduction of 25.1 mg/dL (95% CI, 21.7-28.5; baseline, 161 .5 mg/dL; 12 months, 136.4 mg/dL; P?<?.001 for comparison of 4 groups.) Only patients in the doctor-patient shared incentive group achieved reductions in LDL levels -C statistically different from those of the control group (8.5 mg/dl; 95% CI, 3.8-13.3; P?=?0.002) Conclusions and relevance In primary care practices, shared financial incentives for physicians and patients, but not incentives for physicians or patients alone, resulted in a statistically significant difference in LDL-C reduction at 12 months. However, this reduction was modest and more information is needed to understand whether this approach represents good value.

title: Effect of financial incentives for physicians, patients, or both on lipid levels: a randomized clinical trial.
abstract: Importance: Financial incentives for physicians or patients are increasingly used, but their effectiveness is not well established. Objective: To determine whether economic incentives for physicians, incentives for patients, or shared incentives between physician and patient are more effective than control in reducing low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) levels in patients with high cardiovascular risk. . Design, Setting, and Participants: Four-arm, multicenter, cluster-randomized clinical trial with a 12-month intervention conducted between 2011 and 2014 in 3 primary care practices in the northeastern United States. 340 eligible primary care physicians (PCPs) were enrolled from a pool of 421. Of 25,627 potentially eligible patients of those PCPs, 1,503 were enrolled. Patients 18 to 80 years of age were eligible if they had a 10-year Framingham Risk Score (FRS) of 20% or greater, had coronary artery disease equivalents with LDL-C levels of 120 mg/dL or greater , or had an FRS of 10% to 20% with LDL-C levels of 140 mg/dL or higher. The investigators were blinded to the study group, but not the participants. Interventions: Primary care physicians were randomly assigned to control, physician incentives, patient incentives, or shared physician-patient incentives. Physicians in the Physician Incentive Group were eligible to receive up to $1,024 per enrolled patient who met LDL-C goals. Patients in the patient incentive group were eligible for the same amount, distributed through daily lotteries linked to medication adherence. Physicians and patients in the shared incentive group shared these incentives. Physicians and patients in the control group received no performance-related incentives, but all participating patients received up to $355 each for their participation in the trial. Main Outcomes and Measures: Change in LDL-C level at 12 months. Results: Only patients in the doctor-patient shared incentive group achieved statistically different reductions in LDL-C levels than the control group (8.5 mg/dL"; 95% CI, 3.8-13 .3", P = 0.002). For the comparison of the 4 groups, P < 0.001. Conclusions and Relevance: In primary care practices, shared financial incentives for physicians and patients, but not incentives for physicians or patients alone, resulted in a statistically significant difference in the reduction of LDL-C levels at 12 months. However, this reduction was modest and more information is needed to understand whether this approach represents good value. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2016 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: Effect of improving depression care on pain and functional outcomes among older adults with arthritis: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Context Depression and arthritis are common and disabling health problems in old age. Depression is also a risk factor for poor health among arthritis patients. Objective To determine whether improving depression care improves pain and functional outcomes in older adults with depression and arthritis. Design, Setting, and Participants Preplanned Subgroup Analysis of Mood Improving Access to Treatment Collaborative (IMPACT), a randomized controlled trial of 1,801 depressed older adults (¡Ã 60 years), which was conducted in 18 primary care clinics. from 8 primary health care organizations in 5 US states from July 1999 to August 2001. A total of 1,001 (56%) reported coexisting arthritis at baseline. Intervention Antidepressant medication and/or 6 to 8 sessions of psychotherapy (Problem Resolution Treatment in Primary Care). Main outcome measures Depression, pain intensity (0 to 10 scale), interference with daily activities due to arthritis (0 to 10 scale), general health status, and overall quality of life outcomes assessed at baseline, 3 , 6, and 12 months. Results In addition to reduction in depressive symptoms, the intervention group compared to the usual care group at 12 months had lower mean (SE) scores for pain intensity (5.62 [0.16] vs. 6.15 [0.16]"; difference between groups, ? 0.53; 95% confidence interval [CI], ?0.92 to ?0.14; P = .009), interference with daily activities due to to arthritis (0.18 [4.40] vs. 0.17 [4.99]; difference between groups, ?0.59; 95% CI, ?1.00 to ?0.19; P = .004 ) and interference with daily activities due to pain (2.92 [0.07] vs 3.17 [0.07]; difference between groups, ?0.26; 95% CI, ?0.41 to ? 0.10, p = 0.002).General health and quality of life also improved among intervention patients relative to control patients at 12 months.ConclusionsIn a large and diverse population of older adults with arthritis (mainly osteoarthritis) and comorbid depression, the benefits of improved r depression care extended beyond the reduction of depressive symptoms and included a decrease in pain, as well as an improvement in functional status and quality of life.

title: Effect of renin-angiotensin system inhibitors and other antihypertensive drugs on renal outcomes: systematic review and meta-analysis.
abstract: Background A consensus has emerged that angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) have specific renoprotective effects. The guidelines specify that these are the drugs of choice for the treatment of hypertension in patients with kidney disease. We try to determine the extent to which this consensus is supported by the available evidence.";" Background A consensus has emerged that angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) have specific renoprotective effects. The guidelines specify that these are the drugs of choice for the treatment of hypertension in patients with kidney disease. We try to determine to what extent this consensus is supported by the available evidence.

title: Effect of integrated care for sick list patients with chronic low back pain: economic evaluation in conjunction with a randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the cost-effectiveness, cost-utility, and cost-benefit of an integrated care program compared with usual care for sick list patients with chronic low back pain. DESIGN: Economic evaluation in conjunction with a randomized controlled trial with 12-month follow-up. SETTING: Primary care (10 physiotherapy practices, one occupational health service, one occupational therapy practice) and secondary care (five hospitals) in the Netherlands, 2005-9. PARTICIPANTS: 134 adults aged 18 to 65 years registered ill due to chronic low back pain: 66 were randomized to integrated care and 68 to usual care. INTERVENTIONS: Integrated care consisted of a workplace intervention based on participatory ergonomics, with the participation of a supervisor, and a program of graded activities based on cognitive-behavioral principles. Usual care was provided by general practitioners and occupational physicians according to Dutch guidelines. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: The primary outcome was duration to sustainable return to work. The secondary outcome was quality-adjusted life years (QALYs), measured by EuroQol. RESULTS: Total costs in the integrated care group (£13,165, SD pound13,600) were significantly lower than in the usual care group (£18,475, SD pound13,616). Cost-effectiveness plans and acceptability curves showed that integrated care was cost-effective compared to usual care for return to work and QALYs gained. Cost-benefit analyzes showed that each pound1 invested in integrated care would generate an estimated pound26. The net societal benefit of integrated care compared to usual care was £5,744. CONCLUSIONS: Implementation of an integrated care program for ill patients with chronic low back pain has great potential to significantly reduce societal costs, increase care effectiveness, improve quality of life, and improve function on a large scale. Therefore, integrated care has great benefits for patients and society, as well as for employers.

title: Effect of interactive group discussion among physicians to promote rational prescribing
abstract: This study evaluated the effect of an educational intervention (interactive group discussion) on the prescribing behavior of 51 general practitioners from northwestern Tabriz. The prescriptions were analyzed preintervention and postintervention (control and intervention groups) using a proforma with 8 indicators of correct prescription. The mean number of drugs per pre-intervention prescription was 3.82. The percentage of prescriptions with antibiotics, corticosteroids and injectables was 40.8%, 25.9% and 58.0%, respectively. Post-intervention there were slight but non-significant changes in indicators in both intervention and control groups compared to pre-intervention results.

title: Effect of intervention aimed at increasing physical activity, reducing sedentary behavior, and increasing fruit and vegetable intake in children: the Active for Life Year 5 (AFLY5) school-based cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To investigate the effectiveness of a school intervention to increase physical activity, reduce sedentary lifestyle and increase the consumption of fruits and vegetables in children. DESIGN Cluster randomized controlled trial. SETTING 60 primary schools in the South West of England. PARTICIPANTS Primary school children who were in school year 4 (age 8-9 years) at recruitment and baseline assessment, in year 5 during the intervention, and at the end of year 5 (age 9-10) in the follow-up evaluation. INTERVENTION The Active for Life Year 5 (AFLY5) intervention consisted of teacher training, provision of interactive lesson and homework plans for children and parents, all necessary lesson and homework materials, and written materials for school newsletters and parents. The intervention was administered when the children were in school year 5 (age 9-10 years). Schools assigned to the control received standard teaching. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The prespecified primary outcomes were minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity assessed by accelerometer per day, minutes of sedentary behavior assessed by accelerometer per day, and reported daily consumption of servings of fruits and vegetables. RESULTS 60 schools with more than 2221 children were recruited";" valid data were available for fruit and vegetable consumption for 2121 children, for accelerometer-assessed physical activity and sedentary behavior for 1252 children, and for secondary outcomes for between 1825 and 2212 children for the main analyses. None of the three primary outcomes differed between children in schools assigned to the AFLY5 intervention and those assigned to the control group. The mean difference comparing the intervention group with the control group was -1.35 (95% confidence interval -5.29 to 2.59) minutes per day for moderate to vigorous physical activity, -0.11 (-9.71 to 9.49) minutes per day for sedentary behavior, and 0.08 (-0.12 to 0.28) servings per day for fruit and vegetable consumption. The intervention was effective for three of nine of the secondary outcomes after multiple tests were taken into account: self-reported time spent looking at screens at the weekend (-21 (-37 to -4) minutes per day), self-reported servings snacks per day (-0.22 (-0.38 to -0.05)) and energy drink servings per day (-0.26 (-0.43 to -0.10)) were reduced. The results of a series of sensitivity analyzes testing different assumptions about missing data and per-protocol analyzes produced similar results. CONCLUSION The findings suggest that the AFLY5 school-based intervention is not effective in increasing physical activity levels, decreasing sedentary behavior, and increasing fruit and vegetable intake in primary school children. Change in these activities may require more intensive behavioral interventions with children or prior interventions at the family and social level, as well as at the level of the school environment. These findings have relevance to researchers, policymakers, public health professionals, and clinicians involved in health promotion, policy formulation, and service delivery. Trial Registration Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN50133740.

title: Effect of offering different levels of support and free nicotine replacement therapy through an English national quitline: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To compare the effects of free nicotine replacement therapy or proactive telephone advice in addition to standard smoking cessation support offered through a quitline. DESIGN Parallel group, 2 × 2 factorial, randomized controlled trial. SETTING National Quitline, England. PARTICIPANTS 2591 non-pregnant smokers aged 16 years or older residing in England who called the quitline between February 2009 and February 2010 and agreed to a quit date: 648 were randomized to standard support, proactive support or proactive support with nicotine replacement therapy, and 647 were randomized to receive standard support with nicotine replacement therapy. INTERVENTIONS Two interventions were offered in addition to standard support: 6-week nicotine replacement therapy, free and proactive counseling sessions (repeated phone calls and interaction with cessation counsellors). MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was self-reported smoking cessation for six or more months after the quit date. The secondary outcome was cessation validated by exhaled carbon monoxide measured at six or more months. RESULTS At six months, 17.7% (n = 229) of those who received nicotine replacement therapy reported quitting compared to 20.1% (n = 261) who did not receive such therapy (odds ratio 0.85, 95% confidence interval 0.70 to 1.04) and 18.2% (n=236) who offered proactive advice reported quitting compared to 19.6% (n=254 ) that offered standard support (0.91, 0.75 to 1.11). Data validated by carbon monoxide readings changed the findings for nicotine replacement therapy only, with smoking cessation validated in 6.6% (85/1295) of those receiving nicotine replacement therapy compared to 9.4% (122/1296) who did not receive such therapy (0.67, 0.50). to 0.90). CONCLUSIONS Offering free nicotine replacement therapy or additional (proactive) advice to standard helpline support had no additional effect on smoking cessation. ClinicalTrials.gov TRIAL REGISTRY NCT00775944.

title: Effect of patient-specific ratings versus conventional guidelines on investigation decisions in angina: the Appropriateness of Referral and Investigation in Angina (ARIA) trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Conventional guidelines have limited effect in changing clinician ordering of tests. We attempted to determine the effect of patient-specific ratings versus conventional guidelines on the appropriate investigation of angina. METHODS: Randomized controlled trial of 145 physicians who received patient-specific ratings (online message indicating whether the specific vignette was considered appropriate or inappropriate for research, with access to detailed information on how the ratings were derived) and 147 physicians who received conventional guidelines of the American Heart Association and the European Society of Cardiology. Physicians made recommendations on 12 web-based patient vignettes before and 12 vignettes after these interventions. The outcome was the proportion of appropriate research decisions as defined by 2 independent expert panels. RESULTS: Decisions about exercise electrocardiography were more appropriate with patient-specific ratings (819/1491 [55%]) compared with conventional guidelines (648/1488 [44%]) (odds ratio [OR], 1, 57"; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.36-1.82). The effect was stronger for angiography (1274/1595 [80%] with patient-specific scores compared with 1009/1576 [ 64%] with conventional guidelines [OR, 2.24; 95% CI, 1.90-2.62]. Within-group comparisons confirmed that conventional guidelines had no effect, but that patient-specific ratings significantly changed clinicians' decisions toward appropriate recommendations for exercise electrocardiography (55% vs. 42%; OR, 2.62; 95% CI, 2.14-3.22) and for angiography (80% vs. a 65%, OR, 2.10, 95% CI, 1.79-2.47).These effects were robust for medical specialty (cardiologists and general practitioners). general) and for vignette characteristics, including older age, female gender, and nonwhite race/ethnicity. CONCLUSION: Specific patient ratings, unlike conventional guidelines, have changed clinicians' testing behavior and have the potential to reduce variations in practice and increase the appropriate use of research.

title: Effect of physician recommendation and patient adherence on colorectal cancer screening rates.
abstract: This study explored: (1) patient characteristics associated with physician recommendation for colorectal cancer (CRC) screening and patient adherence to recommendation, and (2) the combined effect of recommendation and compliance in CCR tests, in a broad definition. Data were from the 1999 MA BRFSS and a callback survey of 869 BRFSS participants, age 50 and older. Logistic regression was used to identify correlates of recommendation, compliance, and trial. Physician-patient factors were positively associated with recommendation, adherence, and testing. Inadequate health insurance was negatively associated with recommendation (OR = 0.45, 95% CI = 0.27 to 0.78) and evidence (OR = 0.64, 95% CI = 0.38 to 1 ,one). Men were not more likely to be recommended (OR = 1.1, 95% CI = 0.78 to 1.5), but were more likely to adhere (OR = 1.9, 95% CI = 1, 2 to 2.0) and being tested ( OR = 1.4, 95% CI = 1.0-1.9). There were gender differences in the recommendation when considering health measures and risk factors. Research is needed to understand the differences in recommendation and adherence. Greater encouragement and follow-up may be needed for groups least likely to adhere.

title: Effect of self-efficacy and social support on adherence to antihypertensive drugs
abstract: OBJECTIVE OF THE STUDY: To determine the relationship between poor adherence and self-efficacy or social support after a pharmaceutical intervention. DESIGN: Post-hoc analysis of data from two randomized controlled trials of collaborative physician-pharmacist interventions (6 and 9 months, respectively) to improve blood pressure control. SETTING: Eleven university-affiliated primary care clinics. PATIENTS: Five hundred and eighty-four patients (age 21 to 85 years) with uncontrolled primary hypertension; 296 were in the intervention group and 288 in the control group. INTERVENTION: Pharmacists provided intensive management of hypertension and medication adherence counseling to patients in the intervention group MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN OUTCOMES: Self-efficacy and social support questionnaires were administered at baseline and end of study Patient adherence was monitored by use of the adherence questionnaire self-reported Morisky Self-reported adherence scores improved significantly in the intervention group control group (p=0.0053) but not in the intervention group, however baseline adherence in both groups was high There were improvements small, but significant, self-efficacy (p<0.04) and social support (p<0.05) scores in the intervention group but not in the intervention group. the control group at the end of the study Social support and, to a lesser extent, self-efficacy improved as a function of duration of study p participation (9-month vs. 6-month intervention), regardless of whether the patient received the intervention. Blood pressure control in both groups improved significantly at the end of the study; however, mean arterial pressure was significantly lower in the intervention group (129.7/76.6 mm Hg) compared to the control group (140.8/78.9 mm Hg; p<0.0001 for systolic , p=0.032 for diastolic). CONCLUSION: Social support and self-efficacy improved significantly in the intervention group at the end of the pharmacist intervention. Drug adherence was correlated with self-efficacy, although drug adherence was not significantly improved in the intervention group. The fact that social support and self-efficacy improved as a result of a function of duration of study participation suggests that participation in a research study may have had a positive influence on these measures. Although changes in social support, self-efficacy and medication adherence were modest, there was significantly better blood pressure control in participants. intervention group compared to the control group. These findings indicate that changes in medication adherence, self-efficacy, or social support likely played less of a role in blood pressure outcomes in these studies.

title: Effect of telecare management on pain and depression in cancer patients: a randomized trial
abstract: Context Pain and depression are 2 of the most prevalent and treatable cancer-related symptoms, but they often go unrecognized, poorly treated, or both. Objective To determine whether centralized telephone care management coupled with automated symptom monitoring can improve depression and pain in cancer patients. Design, setting, and patients Randomized controlled trial conducted in 16 urban and rural community oncology practices involved in the Indiana Cancer Pain and Depression (INCPAD) trial. Recruitment occurred from March 2006 to August 2008 and follow-up concluded in August 2009. Participating patients had depression (Patient Health Questionnaire-9 score Â¡Ã 10), cancer-related pain (Brief Pain Inventory [BPI] worst pain score Â¡Ã 6), or both. Intervention The 202 patients randomly assigned to receive the intervention and the 203 to receive usual care were stratified by symptom type. Patients in the intervention group received centralized telecare management by a team of specialist nurses and physicians along with automated symptom monitoring at home using interactive voice recording or the Internet. Main outcome measures Blinded assessment at baseline and at months 1, 3, 6, and 12 for depression (20-item Hopkins Symptom Checklist [HSCL-20]) and severity of pain (BPI). Results Of the 405 participants enrolled in the study, 131 had depression alone, 96 had pain alone, and 178 had both depression and pain. Of the 274 patients with pain, 137 patients in the intervention group had greater improvements in BPI pain severity over the 12-month trial, either measured as a continuous severity score or as a categorical response to pain (30% decrease in BPI) than the 137 patients in the usual care group (p < 0.001 for both). Similarly, of the 309 patients with depression, the 154 patients in the intervention group had greater improvements in HSCL-20 depression severity over the 12-month trial, either measured as a continuous severity score or as a response. categorical to depression (¡Ã 50% decrease in HSCL) than the 155 patients in the usual care group (P < 0.001 for both). The standardized effect size for differences between groups at 3 and 12 months was 0.67 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.33-1.02) and 0.39 (95% CI, 0.01-0.77) for pain, and 0.42 (95% CI, 0.16-0.69) and 0.41 (95% CI, 0.08-0.72) for depression . Conclusion Centralized telecare management, coupled with automated symptom monitoring, improved pain and depression outcomes in cancer patients receiving care in geographically dispersed urban and rural oncology clinics.

title: Effect of Telehealth on Quality of Life and Psychological Outcomes Over 12 Months (Whole Systems Demonstrator Telehealth Questionnaire Study): Nested Study of Patient-Reported Outcomes in a Pragmatic Cluster Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the effect of second-generation home telehealth on health-related quality of life, anxiety, and depressive symptoms over 12 months in patients with long-term conditions. DESIGN A study of patient-reported outcomes (the Whole Systems Demonstrator Telehealth Questionnaire Study"; baseline n=1573) was nested within a pragmatic, cluster-randomized trial of telehealth (the Whole Systems Demonstrator Telehealth Questionnaire Study; baseline n=1573). , n=3230).General practice was unit randomization and telehealth was compared with usual care.Data were collected at baseline, four months (short term), and 12 months (long term). primary intent-to-treat assessed treatment efficacy; multilevel models controlled for clustering by general practice. and a variety of covariates. Analyzes were performed for 759 participants who completed questionnaire measures at all three time points (case cohort complete) and 1201 who completed the baseline assessment plus at least one other assessment (case cohort available).Secondary per-protocol tests tested efi treatment and included 633 and 1108 participants in the full case and available case cohorts, respectively. ion of primary and secondary care through general practices, specialist nurses and hospital clinics in three diverse regions of England (Cornwall, Kent and Newham), with established integrated health and social care systems. PARTICIPANTS Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), diabetes, or heart failure recruited between May 2008 and December 2009. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Generic health-related quality of life (assessed by physical and mental health component scores of the SF-12, and the EQ-5D), anxiety (assessed by the Brief State-Trait Anxiety Inventory of six items) and depressive symptoms (assessed by the Depression Scale of the Center for Epidemiological Studies of 10 items). RESULTS In intention-to-treat analyses, differences between treatment groups were small and non-significant for all outcomes in the full case (0.480 Ã¢â€°Â¤ P Ã¢â€°Â¤ 0.904) or case available (0.181 Ã¢â€°Â¤ P Ã¢â€°Â¤ 0.905) cohorts. The magnitude of the differences between trial arms did not reach the trial-defined minimal clinically important difference (standardized mean difference of 0.3) for any outcome in either cohort at four or 12 months. The per-protocol analyzes replicated the primary analyses; the main effect of the trial arm (telehealth versus usual care) was not significant for any outcome (complete case cohort 0.273 Ã¢â€°Â¤ P Ã¢â€°Â¤ 0.761; available case cohort 0.145 Ã¢â € °Â¤ P Ã¢â€°Â¤ 0.696). CONCLUSIONS Second-generation home telehealth, as implemented in the Comprehensive Systems Demonstrator Evaluation, was neither effective nor efficient when compared to usual care alone. Telehealth did not improve quality of life or psychological outcomes. for patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, diabetes, or heart failure for 12 months. The findings suggest that concerns about the potentially harmful effect of telehealth are unfounded for most patients. TEST RECORD ISRCTN43002091.

title: Effect of telephone contact on new suicide attempts in patients discharged from an emergency department: a randomized controlled study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the one-year effects of telephone contact with patients one month or three months after discharge from an emergency department for deliberate self-poisoning compared with treatment as usual. DESIGN Multicenter, randomized, controlled trial. SCENARIO 13 emergency departments in the north of France. PARTICIPANTS 605 people discharged from an emergency department after a suicide attempt due to deliberate self-intoxication. INTERVENTION The intervention consisted of contacting patients by telephone one to three months after discharge from an emergency department for suicide attempt to assess the success of the recommended treatment or to adjust treatment. Control patients received their usual treatment, in most cases being returned to their GP. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome measures were the proportion of participants who re-attempted suicide, the number of deaths by suicide, and loss to follow-up at 13-month follow-up. Secondary outcome measures were types and number of health care contacts. RESULTS By intention-to-treat, the three groups did not differ significantly in additional suicide attempts, suicide deaths, or losses to follow-up: contact at 1 month (intervention 23% (34/147) versus controls 30% (93/312), difference 7%, 95% confidence interval - 2% to 15%), three months (25% (36/146) vs. 30%, difference 5%, -4% to 14%). Participants contacted at 1 month were less likely to report a new suicide attempt at follow-up (12% vs. 22% in the control group, difference 10%, 2% to 18%). CONCLUSION Contacting people by phone one month after being discharged from an emergency department for deliberate poisoning can help reduce the number of suicide attempts for one year.

title: Effect of training on the adoption of nutrition-related activities for cancer prevention by primary care clinics: results of a randomized controlled study
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The National Cancer Institute (NCI) developed a manual to guide primary care practices in structuring their office environment and routine visits to improve nutritional assessment, counseling/referral, and monitoring for cancer prevention. Adoption of the manual's recommendations by primary care practices was assessed by examining two strategies: training clinicians on how to implement the manual's recommendations versus simply mailing the manual. This article reports the results of a randomized controlled trial to assess the effectiveness of these two strategies. DESIGN: A three-arm randomized controlled trial. SETTING: Independent primary care physician practices in Pennsylvania and New Jersey. INTERVENTION: Each study practice was randomly assigned to one of three groups. Training group practices were invited to send a member of their chosen practice to a 3-hour "train the trainer" workshop, manual-only group practices received the nutrition manual, and control received no intervention. For training group practices, training was provided on the four main components of the nutrition manual: how to organize the office environment to support activities related to nutrition for cancer prevention; how to assess patient compliance with NCI dietary guidelines; how to provide dietary advice/referral;" and how to implement a patient tracking system to help patients make changes in their nutrition-related behaviors. MEASUREMENTS: Primary study outcomes were derived from two assessment instruments. The instrument observation documented the tools and procedures recommended by the nutrition manual and adopted in patient charts and in the office environment Structured face-to-face interview assessed physician- and staff-reported nutrition-related activities that reflected the recommendations in the nutrition manual. Data from these two instruments were used to construct four adherence scores corresponding to the areas: practice organization, nutritional assessment, nutritional counseling/referral, and patient follow-up. MAIN RESULTS: Adoption of the recommendations of the manual was higher among practices in the training group, as reflected by their higher adherence scores. They set up their practice (p = 0.005) and rated their patients regarding their eating habits (p = 0.046) significantly closer to the nutrition manual recommendations than the practices in the manual-only group. However, despite being the highest in compliance, the training group practices only 54.9% adhered to the manual's recommendations regarding nutritional counseling/referral, and 28.5% adhered to their recommendations on organization of the office, 23.5% adhered to their recommendations on nutritional evaluation and 14.6% adhered to their recommendations for patient follow-up. CONCLUSIONS: Primary care practices exposed to the nutrition manual in a training session adopted more of the manual's recommendations. Specifically, practices invited to the training were more likely to conduct nutritional screenings and to structure their office environment to be conducive to providing nutrition-related services for cancer prevention. The impact of training was modest and not statistically significant for nutrition advice/referral or patient follow-up, which are important for achieving long-term dietary changes in patients. The low overall adherence scores for nutrition-related activities demonstrate that there is a lot of room for improvement among the practices in the training group.

title: Effect of varying the number and location of alcohol-based hand sanitizer dispensers on use in an inpatient general medical unit.
abstract: We sequentially increased the number of wall-mounted alcohol-based hand sanitizer dispensers in a small medical unit to assess effects on hand hygiene performance. Above a certain point, adding more dispensers did not increase hand hygiene frequency, which appeared to be influenced more by location than the total number of dispensers.

title: Effect of written and computerized decision support aids for depression guidelines from the US Agency for Health Care Policy and Research in the evaluation of hypothetical clinical scenarios.
abstract: Goal. The aim of this study was to compare the effects of written and computerized decision support aids (DSAs) based on the US Agency for Health Care Policy and Research depression guidelines Either a written or computerized DSA after first evaluating the scenarios without a DSA. Paired difference between assisted and unassisted scores for diagnostic accuracy, treatment selection, severity and subtype classification, antipsychotic use, and mental health consultations were determined. DSA decreased from 67% to 64% (P = 0.0065). Residents using the computerized DSA (vs. without DSA) requested fewer consultations (65% vs. 52%, P = .028). On post hoc analysis, the written DSA increased sensitivity (66% to 89%, P < 0.001) and the computerized DSA improved specificity (66% to 86%, P = 0.0020) but reduced sensitivity (67% to 49%, P = 0.011). Conclusions. A written DSA improved diagnostic accuracy, whereas a computerized DSA did not. However, the computerized DSA improved specificity and reduced mental health consultations.

title: Effect on birth outcomes of a formalized approach to care in hospital work assessment units: an international randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine whether a complex nursing and midwifery intervention in hospital labor assessment units would increase the likelihood of spontaneous vaginal delivery and improve other maternal and neonatal outcomes. DESIGN Multicenter, randomized, controlled trial with prognostic stratification by hospital. SET 20 hospitals in North America and the UK. PARTICIPANTS 5002 nulliparous women with contractions but not in active labour"; 2501 were allocated to structured care and 2501 to usual care. INTERVENTIONS Usual nursing or midwifery care or a minimum of one hour of care by a trained nurse or midwife in structured care, consisting of a formalized approach to assessment and interventions for maternal emotional status, pain and fetal position MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was spontaneous vaginal delivery Other outcomes included intrapartum interventions, opinions of women about their care and indicators of maternal and fetal health during hospital stay and 6-8 weeks after discharge RESULTS Outcome data were obtained from 4996 women Spontaneous vaginal delivery rate was 64.0% (n=1597) in the structured care group and 61.3% (n=1,533) in the usual care group (odds ratio 1.12, in 95% confidence interval: 0.96 to 1.27). Fewer women assigned to structured care (n=403, 19.5%) rated staff assistance less than very helpful than those assigned to usual care (n=544, 26.4%); odds ratio 0.67, 98.75% confidence interval 0.50 to 0.85. Fewer women assigned to structured care (n=233, 11.3%) were disappointed with the amount of care they received from staff than those assigned to usual care (n=407, 19.7%); "odds ratio 0.51, 98.75% confidence interval 0.32 to 0.70 None of the other outcomes met pre-specified levels of statistical significance CONCLUSION A structured approach to care in hospital work evaluation units delivery increased satisfaction with care and suggested a modest increase in the likelihood of spontaneous vaginal delivery Further study to strengthen the intervention TRIAL REGISTRATION Current controlled trials ISRCTN16315180.

title: Effect on maternal and child health services in Rwanda of paying primary health care providers for performance: an impact evaluation
abstract: Background Evidence is urgently needed on the best methods for accelerating progress towards achieving the Millennium Development Goals. We evaluated the effect of performance-based payment of health care providers (pay-for-performance"; P4P) on the use and quality of maternal and child care services in health care facilities in Rwanda. Background: evidence on the best methods for accelerating progress toward achieving the Millennium Development Goals is urgently needed We evaluated the effect of performance-based payment of health care providers (pay-for-performance;" P4P) on the use and the quality of maternal and child care services in health care facilities in Rwanda.

title: Effective weight control practice: a review of the evidence for lifestyle intervention
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Despite the existence of guidelines for the management of obesity, uncertainty persists about which interventions constitute an effective practice. This uncertainty could act as a barrier for busy healthcare professionals, who may lack the time and expertise to fully assess the vast amount of literature that is published each year on obesity management. Therefore, the objectives of this review were to synthesize the available evidence, determine the most effective and promising practices for the management of obesity in adults, using an established methodology, and present this information according to its quality. EVIDENCE ACQUISITION: This synthesis review was conducted from January 2009. A detailed search of relevant databases was performed up to September 2010. The most effective and promising practices were defined using the Initiative Methodology Background Paper of Canadian best practices, with systematic reviews (with/without meta-analysis). ) as the most rigorous methodology to develop recommendations that were considered more effective (level 1), and non-systematic reviews to develop recommendations that were considered more promising (level 2). The literature was reviewed and classified into these two levels of rigor, supplemented by primary studies to further refine the recommendations. RESULTS: Evidence from systematic reviews and meta-analyses was categorized into three intervention themes or context areas, into which more specific, more effective, and/or promising practice recommendations could be nested. These intervention themes were (1) multi-component targeted interventions for weight control, (2) dietary manipulation strategies, and (3) delivery of weight control interventions, including the roles of health professionals and the method of delivery. Specific recommendations accompanied each topic. CONCLUSIONS: This review highlights the value of multicomponent interventions that are delivered over the long term and reinforces the role of health professionals. The findings will help inform evidence-based practice for health professionals involved in obesity prevention and control.

title: Efficacy and cost-effectiveness of cardiovascular disease prevention in whole populations: modeling study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To estimate the potential profitability of a risk factor reduction program in the entire population aimed at preventing cardiovascular diseases. DESIGN Analysis of economic models. SETTING England and Wales. Population Entire population. Model Spreadsheet model to quantify the reduction in cardiovascular disease over a decade, assuming benefits apply evenly to men and women of all ages and risk groups. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Cardiovascular events averted, quality-adjusted life years gained, and healthcare cost savings for a given efficacy"; estimates of how much it would be worth spending to achieve a specific outcome. OUTCOMES A population-wide program in England and Wales (around 50 million people) which reduced cardiovascular events by just 1% would save the health service worth at least £30 million (£34 million; $48 million) a year compared to no additional intervention Reducing mean cholesterol concentrations or blood pressure levels in the population by 5% (as has already been achieved with similar interventions in some other countries) would result in annual savings of at least 80 £100 million to £100 million Legislation or other measures to reduce dietary salt intake a at 3 g/day (current average intake approximately 8.5 g/day) would prevent approximately 30,000 cardiovascular events, saving at least £40 million per year. Legislation to reduce intake of industrial trans fatty acids by around 0.5% of total energy content could gain around 570,000 life years and generate NHS savings of at least £230m a year. CONCLUSIONS Any intervention that achieved even a modest population-wide reduction in any major cardiovascular risk factor would result in net cost savings to the NHS, in addition to improving health. Given the conservative assumptions used in this model, the true benefits would likely be higher.

title: Efficacy and cost-effectiveness of an exposure-based return-to-work program for patients on sick leave due to common mental disorders: cluster randomized controlled trial design
abstract: BACKGROUND: To reduce the length of sick leave and productivity loss due to common mental disorders (CMDs), we developed a return-to-work program to be provided by occupational physicians (OPs) based on the principles of in vivo exposure ( RTW). -E program). This study evaluates the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of this program by comparing it with usual care (CAU). The three research questions we have are: 1) Is a RTW-E program more effective in reducing sick leave for employees with common mental disorders, compared to usual care? 2) Is an RTW-E program more effective in reducing sick leave for employees with anxiety disorders compared to employees with other common mental disorders? 3) From a societal perspective, is an RTW-E program cost-effective compared to usual care? METHODS/DESIGN: This study was designed as a pragmatic cluster-randomized controlled trial with one year of follow-up and randomization at the OP level. We are aiming for 60 POs to include 200 patients. Patients in the intervention group received the RTW-E program. Patients in the control group received usual care. Eligible patients had been on sick leave due to common mental disorders for at least two weeks and no more than eight weeks. As primary outcome measures, we calculated time to full return to work and length of sick leave. Secondary outcome measures were time to partial return to work, sick leave prevalence rate at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months follow-up, and symptom scores for distress, anxiety, depression, somatization, and fatigue"; work capacity; perceived working conditions; self-efficacy for return to work; coping behavior; avoidance behavior; patient satisfaction;" and work adaptations. As process measures, we used rates of intervention compliance in the intervention group and employee-supervisor communication in both groups. The economic costs were calculated from a social perspective. Total costs consisted of the costs of consuming medical care, the costs of lost production due to sick leave and reduced productivity, and out-of-pocket expenses for patients to travel to their PO. DISCUSSION: The results will be published in 2009. The strengths and weaknesses of the study protocol are discussed. TEST REGISTRATION: ISRCTN72643128.

title: Efficacy and cost-effectiveness of knowledge transfer and behavior modification interventions in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus: the INDICA study: a cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background Type 2 diabetes mellitus is a chronic disease whose health outcomes are related to the decision-making of patients and health professionals. The Intervention in Diabetes in the Canary Islands study (INDICA study) aims to evaluate the efficacy and profitability of educational interventions supported by new technological decision-making tools for patients with type 2 diabetes and primary care professionals in the Canary Islands. Methods/Design The INDICA study is a multicenter, community-based, open-label, controlled clinical trial with cluster random assignment to one of three interventions or usual care. The setting is primary care where doctors and nurses are invited to participate. Patients diagnosed with diabetes, 18 to 65 years of age and regular mobile phone users were randomly selected. Patients with severe comorbidities were excluded. Clusters are primary health care practices with enough professionals and places available to provide the intervention. The calculated sample size was 2,300 patients. Group 1 patients receive an eight-session educational group program every 3 months led by trained nurses and monitored through records and a web-based platform and personalized semi-automated SMS for ongoing support. Group 2 primary care professionals are receiving a brief educational program to update their diabetes knowledge, including a decision support tool integrated into the electronic medical record and a monthly patient outcome feedback report . Group 3 is receiving a combination of patient and professional interventions. The primary end point is the change in HbA1c over 2 years. Secondary endpoints are cardiovascular risk factors, macrovascular and microvascular complications of diabetes, quality of life, psychological outcomes, knowledge of diabetes, and health care utilization. Data is collected from interviews, questionnaires, clinical examinations, and records. Generalized linear mixed models with repeated time measurements will be used to analyze changes in the results. The cost-effectiveness analysis, from a health services perspective, involves direct medical costs per quality-adjusted life year gained and two periods, an Â¡Â®within trialÂ¡Â¯ period and a Markov model of by lifetime. Deterministic and probabilistic sensitivity analyzes are planned. Discussion This ongoing trial aims to establish the implementation of evidence-based programs in the clinical setting for chronic patients.

title: Effectiveness and efficiency under competition: the Cochrane test
Effectiveness of a Behavioral Intervention to Prevent Excessive Weight Gain During Childhood (The Baby Milk Trial): Study Protocol for a Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Childhood is a period of rapid growth and habit formation and thus could be a critical period for obesity prevention. Excessive weight gain during infancy is associated with later obesity, and formula-fed babies are more likely to gain weight compared to breastfed babies. The primary outcome of the trial is a change in weight standard deviation score from birth to one year. METHODS/DESIGN: We will recruit 650 to 700 parents who introduce formula feeding within 14 weeks of their infant's birth for a single (rater) blind, parallel group, individually randomized controlled trial. The focus of the intervention is the caregiver (usually the mother), and the focus of the primary outcome is the baby. The intervention group will receive the behavioral intervention, which aims to reduce formula intake, promote responsive feeding and healthy weaning, and prevent excess weight gain during infancy. The intervention is based on Social Cognitive Theory and action planning ('implementation intentions'). It consists of three components: (1) a motivation component to strengthen parents' motivation to follow infant formula feeding guidelines, (2) an action planning component to help translate motivation into action, and ( 3) a coping planning component to help parents. cope with difficult situations. It will be delivered by trained facilitators (research nurses) over 6 months through three face-to-face contacts, two telephone contacts, and written materials. The control group will have the same number of contacts with the facilitators and general topics on nutrition will be discussed. Anthropometric outcomes will be measured by trained research personnel, blinded to group assignment, at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months after standard operating procedures. Validated questionnaires will assess milk intake, temperament, appetite, sleep, maternal quality of life, and maternal psychological factors. A 4-day food diary will be completed at 8 months. DISCUSSION: The results of the trial will help inform infant feeding guidelines and understand the links between infant feeding, behavior, appetite, and growth. TEST LOG: ISRTCN20814693 . Registration date January 13, 2011.

title: Efficacy of a combined strategy to improve therapeutic compliance and degree of control in patients with hypercholesterolemia: a randomized clinical trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: In subjects with hypercholesterolemia, cholesterol values remain above reference levels. One of the limiting factors for the achievement of the objectives in these patients is the lack of therapeutic adherence. The objective of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of an intervention designed to improve the control of hypercholesterolemic patients, consisting of a combined strategy that would include the delivery of printed information, treatment compliance control cards and the sending of text messages as complementary measures in support of the intervention in the general practitioner's office. METHODS/DESIGN: A randomized clinical trial of parallel groups will be carried out in family medicine outpatient clinics of eight health centers in three Autonomous Communities of Spain, covering a total of 358 subjects aged 18 years or older with a diagnosis of hypercholesterolemia. Patients in the intervention group will be provided with printed material with information on the disease and its management, text messages to mobile phones with summaries of the guidelines, reminders of upcoming appointments and/or scheduling of new appointments in case of non-attendance, and self-report cards to check compliance with the recommendations. Both groups -intervention and control- will receive routine recommendations from their doctors in accordance with current European clinical practice guidelines for hypercholesterolemia and cardiovascular risk management. Regarding the measurements to be made, the main variable is the proportion of subjects who reach the target low-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels over a 24-month follow-up period. The secondary variables are the following: adherence to lifestyle recommendations and adherence to pharmacological treatment”; variation of lipid profiles and levels of cardiovascular risk; occurrence of cardiovascular events; physical activity; food consumption; smoking; anthropometric measures; blood pressure; health problems ; use of lipid-lowering agents; sociodemographic data; beliefs and expectations about preventive recommendations;" and degree of satisfaction with the combined strategy. DISCUSSION: If this intervention is effective, a recommendation could be issued on the application of this combined strategy to subjects with hypercholesterolemia. It is a simple and relatively inexpensive TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov: NCT02314663.

title: Effectiveness of a prospective physician self-audit transfusion monitoring system.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The purpose of this study was to search for a more effective transfusion monitoring system than the existing retrospective peer review system. STUDY DESIGN AND METHODS: This investigation used a control, preintervention, and postintervention study design to assess the effectiveness of a prospective physician self-audit transfusion monitoring system that functioned without the direct involvement of transfusion service physicians. This research also evaluated the effectiveness of issuing physicians with a memorandum of transfusion guidelines. Three process indicators were used to assess physician behavior at various stages of the blood ordering process: 1) the number of crossmatches ordered per admission, 2) the ratio of transfusion to crossmatch, and 3) the number of units of blood returned to the hospital. laboratory after physician self-audit. The study used two outcome measures to reflect overall blood utilization: 1) the percentage of patients receiving red blood cell transfusions and 2) the number of units of blood transfused per recipient each month. RESULTS: The prospective physician self-audit system implemented at the study hospital did not reverse physicians' transfusion decisions, and the process of issuing physicians with a memorandum of transfusion guidelines at the control hospital failed to reduce transfusion use. of blood. However, a transient reduction in blood utilization was observed at the study hospital. CONCLUSION: The reduction was hypothesized to be due to a Hawthorne effect, in which observed behavior is affected by the subject's awareness of the research study.

title: Efficacy of academic detail to optimize medication prescription behavior of family doctors
abstract: PURPOSE: To synthesize current knowledge on the effectiveness and effect size of Academic Detailing (AD), as a stand-alone intervention, in modifying the medication prescribing behavior of family physicians (FPs) in primary care settings. METHODS: MEDLINE, EMBASE, CENTRAL, and Web of Science databases were searched for all English-language articles between January 1983 and July 2010. Bibliographies of articles retrieved from the electronic search were handsearched. to identify additional studies. The inclusion criteria were: full articles describing original research; randomized controlled trial (RCT) or observational study design with a control group; AD studies delivered to FP; AD as a stand-alone intervention; medication prescription as target behavior Two reviewers independently extracted data. Outcomes assessed were: the difference in relative change in prescription rate between intervention and control groups; the difference in absolute change in prescription rate between intervention and control groups;" and effect size, calculated as the standardized mean difference. RESULTS: Eleven RCTs and 4 observational studies were included. Five RCTs described outcomes that showed effectiveness, while 2 RCTs reported a positive effect on some of the target drugs Two observational studies found DA to be effective, while 2 did not The median difference in relative change between the studies reviewed was 21% (interquartile range 43.75%) for RCTs and 9% (interquartile range 8.5%) for observational studies The median effect size across studies reviewed was -0.09 (interquartile range 2.73 CONCLUSION: This systematic review demonstrates that AD can be effective in optimizing medication prescription by FPs Although variable, the magnitude of the effect is moderate in the most studies. This systematic review also provides evidence supporting the use of AD as a strategy to promote evidence-based drug prescription or guideline incorporation into clinical practice. This article is open for POST-PUBLICATION REVIEW. Registered readers (see "For Readers") can comment by clicking SUMMARY on the issue's content page.

title: Efficacy of an audible reminder on hand hygiene compliance
abstract: Multimodal interventions aim to improve adherence to hand hygiene guidelines by healthcare workers. Visitors are not the main target, but they can spread epidemic infections. Effective interventions that improve visitor adherence to hand hygiene guidelines are needed to prevent transmission of epidemic infections to or from healthcare settings. Methods An audible hand hygiene reminder activated by an electronic motion sensor was installed at hospital ward entrances. An 8-month pre- and post-intervention study was conducted to measure the adherence of visitors and hospital staff to hand hygiene guidelines. Results General adherence to hand hygiene increased from 7.6% to 49.9% (p < 0.001). Visitor and non-clinical staff adherence increased immediately from 10.6% to 63.7% and from 5.3% to 34.8%, respectively (p < 0.001). The adherence of doctors, nurses and physical therapists gradually increased from 4.5% to 38.3%, from 5.4% to 43.4% and from 8.7% to 49.5%, respectively (p < 0.001). Improved adherence was maintained among visitors and clinical staff (P < 0.001), but not among non-clinical staff (P = 0.341). CONCLUSIONS: Electronic motion sensor activated sound reminder improved and maintained immediate and significant adherence of hospital visitors and clinical staff to hand hygiene guidelines. This is an effective addition to multimodal hand hygiene interventions and can help control epidemic infections.

title: Efficacy of a clinical quality alert for electronic medical records prepared by means of off-line data analysis
Efficacy of a computer intervention to improve the prophylactic use of antibacterials in the postoperative period.
abstract: Background A 2005 report from the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services and the Centers for Disease Control's Surgical Infection Prevention program indicated that only 41% of prophylactic antibacterials were successfully discontinued within 24 hours of treatment. end of surgery. Electronic order sets have shown promise as a means of integrating directory information with electronic order entry systems and facilitating safer and more efficient care. Objective The objective was to study the efficacy of a computer-based antibacterial order in increasing the proportion of patients who had antibacterial wound prophylaxis discontinued in the appropriate time frame. Design The authors performed a quasi-experimental analysis of interrupted time series over an 8-month study period with the implementation of a computer-based ordering system designed to prevent excessive duration of antibacterial surgical prophylaxis. Measurement The primary outcome was the proportion of surgeries with antibacterials discontinued in the appropriate time frame. In addition, the percentage of surgeries after implementation of the electronic intervention with graphic documentation of infection among surgeries in which the prescriber indicated that the reason for antibacterial therapy was treatment was evaluated. Results The computerized order intervention significantly improved the proportion of surgeries with timely discontinuation of antibacterials from 38.8% to 55.7% (p<0.001) in the intervention hospital, while the control hospital remained at 56-57 % (p=0.006 for the difference between treated and control hospitals). In surgeries after implementation of the intervention where a prescriber indicated that the reason for antibacterial therapy was treatment, the prevalence of infection documented in the chart was only 14%. Conclusions A computer-based electronic order set intervention increased timely discontinuation of postoperative antibacterials.

title: Efficacy of an intervention to improve adherence to occupational physicians' guidelines on duration of sickness absence in workers with common mental disorders: a cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Purpose Evidence-based guidelines in occupational health care improve the quality of care and can reduce the length of sickness absence. However, adherence to the guidance of occupational physicians (OPs) is limited. Based on the literature on guideline implementation, an intervention was developed that was shown to effectively improve self-reported adherence in POs. The aim of the present study was to assess whether this intervention leads to earlier return to work (RTW) in workers with common mental disorders (CMD). Methods In a two-arm cluster randomized controlled trial, 66 OPs were randomized. The trial included 3,379 workers, with 1,493 in the intervention group and 1,886 in the control group. Outcome measures were: time to full RTW, time to first RTW, and total hours of sickness absence. Cox regression analyzes and generalized linear mixed model analyzes were used for evaluations. Results The median time to RTW was 154 days among the 3228 workers with CMD. There was no significant difference in (time to) full RTW between intervention and control group HR 0.96 (95% CI 0.81 to 1.15) or for first RTW HR 0.96 ( 95% CI: 0.80 to 1.15). The mean total hours of sickness absence was 478 h in the intervention group and 483 h in the control group. Conclusions Intervention to improve adherence to OP guidelines did not lead to earlier RTW in OP-guided CMD workers. Possible explanations are remaining external barriers to guideline use, and that perceived guideline adherence might not represent actual guideline adherence and better care. Tracking record: ISRCTN86605310.

title: Efficacy of brief training in cognitive-behavioral therapy techniques for palliative care professionals
abstract: We describe training in CBT techniques for 20 palliative care professionals delivered as the equivalent of 12 days of teaching plus skill-building supervision over a six-month period. Audiotapes of trainees' interactions with patients during their regular work were scored using a specially designed 'Cognitive First Aid' (CFARS) rating scale. The CFARS was highly internally consistent (Cronbach's Alpha 0.93) and inter-rater reliability was high. Trainees showed a significant increase in CBT skills proficiency over six months (p = 0.001). After initial training, half of the trainees were randomly assigned to discontinue supervision";" their measured CBT skill decreased as did their self-reported confidence when reassessed six months later, while those who continued to be supervised gained more skill and maintained confidence (p = 0.007). Palliative care professionals can be trained in CBT skills through a short, simple training course and supportive supervision for skill development. These skills are consistent with national guidelines on providing psychological support to patients at all stages of cancer. Supervision is necessary to ensure the maintenance of skills and the confidence to use them.

title: Efficacy of cholinesterase inhibitors and memantine for the treatment of dementia: evidence review for a clinical practice guideline
abstract: BACKGROUND: The efficacy of the 5 US Food and Drug Administration-approved drug therapies for dementias in achieving clinically relevant improvements is unclear. Purpose: To review the evidence for the effectiveness of cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine, and tacrine) and the neuropeptide-modifying agent memantine in achieving clinically relevant improvements, primarily in cognition, global function, behavior, and quality of life. of life, for patients with dementia. Data sources: Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, MEDLINE, PREMEDLINE, EMBASE, Allied and Complementary Medicine Database, CINAHL, AgeLine, and PsycINFO from January 1986 to November 2006. Study selection: Randomized controlled trials in English if they evaluated pharmacological agents for adults diagnosed with dementia, did not use a crossover design, and had a quality score of at least 3 on the Jadad scale. Data Extraction: Data on study characteristics and outcomes, including adverse events, were extracted. Effect sizes were calculated and data combined where appropriate. Data synthesis: 96 publications representing 59 unique studies were eligible for this review. Both cholinesterase inhibitors and memantine had consistent effects in the cognition and global assessment domains, but summary estimates showed small effect sizes. Outcomes in the behavior and quality of life domains were assessed less frequently and showed less consistent effects. Most studies were of short duration (6 months), which limited their ability to detect delayed onset or progression of dementia. Three studies directly compared different cholinesterase inhibitors and found no difference in cognition and behaviour. Limitations: Limitations of the available studies included short duration, inclusion of only patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease, poor reporting of adverse events, lack of clear definitions for statistical significance, limited assessment of behavior and study results. quality of life and limited direct outcomes. comparison of different treatments. Conclusions: Treatment of dementia with cholinesterase inhibitors and memantine may result in statistically significant but clinically marginal improvement in measures of cognition and global assessment of dementia.

title: Efficacy of collaborative care for older adults with Alzheimer's disease in primary care: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Most older adults with dementia will be cared for by primary care physicians, but the primary care practice setting presents significant challenges to providing quality care. OBJECTIVE: To test the efficacy of a collaborative care model to improve the quality of care for patients with Alzheimer's disease.
