DESIGN, SETTING, AND PATIENTS: Controlled clinical trial of 153 older adults with Alzheimer's disease and their caregivers who were randomly assigned by a physician to receive collaborative care management (n = 84) or augmented usual care (n = 69) in practices care within 2 US University Affiliated Health Care Systems from January 2002 through August 2004. Eligible patients (identified through screening or medical records) met diagnostic criteria for Alzheimer's disease. Alzheimer's and had a self-identified caregiver. INTERVENTION: Intervention patients received 1 year of care management by an interdisciplinary team led by an advanced practice nurse working with the patient's family caregiver and integrated within primary care. The team used standard protocols to initiate treatment and identify, monitor, and treat behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia, emphasizing non-pharmacological management. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI) administered at baseline and at 6, 12, and 18 months. Secondary outcomes included the Cornell Scale for Depression in Dementia (CSDD), cognition, activities of daily living, resource use, and caregiver depression severity. RESULTS: Initiated by caregiver reports, 89% of intervention patients activated at least 1 protocol for behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia with a mean of 4 per patient out of a total of 8 possible protocols. Intervention patients were more likely to receive cholinesterase inhibitors (79.8% vs. 55.1%"; p=0.002) and antidepressants (45.2% vs. 27.5%; p=0.03 Intervention patients had significantly fewer behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia as measured by NPI total score at 12 months (mean difference, -5.6; P = .01) and at 18 months (mean difference, -5.6). mean, -5.4; P = .01).Intervention caregivers also reported significant improvements in NPI caregiver-measured distress at 12 months;" at 18 months, caregivers showed improvement in depression as measured by the Patient Health Questionnaire-9. No group differences were found in CSDD, cognition, activities of daily living, or rates of hospitalization, nursing home admission, or death. CONCLUSIONS: Collaborative care for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease resulted in significant improvement in quality of care and behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia among primary care patients and their caregivers. These improvements were achieved without significantly increasing the use of antipsychotics or sedative-hypnotics. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Clinicaltrials.gov Identifier: NCT00246896.

title: Effectiveness of computer-assisted instruction in increasing the rate of behaviors related to universal precautions.
abstract: Background: With widespread noncompliance with universal precautions well established, an experimental study was designed to compare the rate of behaviors related to universal precautions among nurses participating in computer-assisted instruction. This study also explored the relationship between rates of behaviors related to universal precautions and subjects' demographic and experiential characteristics and history of occupational bloodborne exposure. Methods: Data were collected through the use of a questionnaire to elicit information on subjects' demographic and experiential characteristics and history of bloodborne occupational exposure. The Universal Precautions Assessment Tool was used to collect data on rates of behaviors related to universal precautions in two groups of registered nurses with 30 subjects per group. Results: Using analysis of variance, the null hypothesis was rejected. The intervention used in this study increased behaviors related to universal precautions. Multiple regression was used to analyze the research question and none of the variables was significant. Forty (67.8%) subjects reported having received a puncture or cut caused by a needle or sharp object that was actually or potentially contaminated with blood or body fluids. Of these exposures, one patient was known to be positive for HIV antibodies. Conclusion: Replication studies using computer-assisted instruction interventions are needed, as well as studies aimed at exploring other potentially effective interventions.

title: Efficacy of diabetes and hypertension control by rural primary health care workers (Behvarz workers) in Iran: a nationally representative observational study
abstract: Background Noncommunicable diseases and their risk factors are the main causes of disease burden in Iran and other middle-income countries. There is little evidence that the primary health care system can effectively manage noncommunicable diseases and risk factors at the population level. Our aim was to examine the efficacy of the Iranian rural primary health care system (the Behvarz system) in controlling diabetes and hypertension, and to assess whether the effects depend on the number of health workers in the community."; " Background Noncommunicable diseases and their risk factors are the main causes of disease burden in Iran and other middle-income countries. There is little evidence that the primary health care system can effectively manage noncommunicable diseases and risk factors at the population level. Our aim was to examine the efficacy of the Iranian rural primary health care system (the Behvarz system) in treating diabetes and hypertension, and to assess whether the effects depend on the number of health workers in the community.

title: Effectiveness of eye protection in the metal industry
Effectiveness of guideline-based care by occupational physicians on the return to work of workers with common mental disorders: a cluster randomized controlled trial design.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Sick absenteeism due to common mental disorders (such as depression, anxiety disorder, adjustment disorder) is a problem in many Western countries. Long-term sickness absenteeism generates substantial social and financial costs. For workers with common mental disorders, the costs of sick leave are much higher than the medical costs. In the Netherlands, a practical guide was developed that promotes an activating approach of the occupational doctor to establish a faster return to work by improving the problem-solving capacity of workers, especially in relation to their work environment. Studies on this guideline indicate a promising association between guideline compliance and shorter duration of sick leave, but also minimal adherence to the guideline by occupational physicians. Therefore, this study assesses the effect of guideline-based care on the full return to work of workers who are on sick list due to common mental disorders. METHODS/DESIGN: This is a two-arm cluster randomized controlled trial randomized at the occupational physician level. For one year, occupational physicians in the intervention group receive innovative training to improve their guideline-based care, while occupational physicians in the control group provide usual care. A total of 232 workers, patients registered for common mental disorders and advised by the participating occupational doctors will be included. Data are collected through the occupational health service registry system and through questionnaires at baseline and at 3, 6, and 12 months. The primary outcome is the time to full return to work. Secondary outcomes are partial return to work, total number of sick days, symptoms, and work ability. Personal and occupational characteristics are the prognostic measures. Additional measures are coping, self-efficacy, remoralization, personal experiences, satisfaction with occupational physician consultations and supervisor contact, supervisor experiences and behavior, and degree of adherence to guidelines . DISCUSSION: If the results show that guideline-based care does indeed lead to a faster and more sustainable return to work, this study will help reduce personal, social, and financial costs. TEST REGISTRATION: ISRCTN86605310.

title: Effectiveness of medical nutrition therapy provided by dieticians in the management of non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus: a randomized controlled clinical trial.
abstract: Objective To assess the effect of medical nutrition therapy (MNT) provided by dietitians on medical and clinical outcomes for adults with non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM), and to compare MNT administered according to the Nutritional Care Practice Guidelines (PGC ) to MNT administered with basic nutrition care (BC). Design A prospective, randomized, controlled bilevel clinical trial of MNT on metabolic control in people newly diagnosed with or currently being treated for NIDDM was conducted at diabetes centers in three states (Minnesota, Florida, and Colorado). BC consisted of a single visit with a dietitian"; PGC involved an initial visit with a dietitian followed by two visits during the first 6 weeks of the study period. Data were collected at study entry and at 3 and 6 months. Subjects Outcomes are reported for 179 men and women aged 38 to 76 years: 85 randomized to BC and 94 to PGC This represents 72% of the 247 subjects enrolled Another 62 adults with NIDDM at one site who had no contact with a dietician were identified as a non-randomized comparison group. Outcomes Medical outcome measures included fasting plasma glucose (FPG), glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c), and serum lipid levels. Clinical outcomes included weight, body mass index, waist-to-body ratio. hip and changes in medical status Statistical analysis The initial analysis of the discrete variables was performed using the ?2 statistic with Yates correction The initial analysis of the conti nuas was performed by analysis of variance. Changes in variables between time periods were analyzed by paired t-test and comparisons between groups were analyzed by t-test for independent groups. Results At 6 months, PGC resulted in significant improvements in blood glucose control as indicated by FPG and HbA1c levels and BC resulted in significant improvements in HbA1c level. Participants assigned to the PGC group had a mean FPG level at 6 months that was 10.5% lower than the level at admission, and those in the BC group had a 5.3% lower value. Among subjects who had diabetes for more than 6 months, those who received PGC had a significantly better HbA1c level at 3 months compared to those who received BC. The comparison group showed no improvement in glycemic control over a comparable 6 months. PGC subjects had significant improvements in cholesterol values at 6 months, and subjects in the PGC and BC groups had significant weight loss. Conclusions MNT provided by dieticians resulted in significant improvements in medical and clinical outcomes in the BC and PGC groups and is beneficial for people with NIDDM. People with a duration of diabetes of more than 6 months tended to improve with PGC than with BC. Due to the upward trend in glucose levels after 3 months, continued MNT by dieticians is important for long-term metabolic control. J Am Diet Association. 1995;" 95:1009-1017.

title: Effectiveness of Motivational Interviewing in improving lipid levels in patients with dyslipidemia attended by general practitioners: Dislip-EM study protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: The non-pharmacological approach to cholesterol control in patients with hyperlipidemia is based on the promotion of a healthy diet and physical activity. Therefore, to help patients change their habits, it is essential to identify the most effective approach. Much effort has been devoted to explaining changes or adherence to specific health behaviors. Such efforts have resulted in the development of theories that have been applied in prevention campaigns and that include brief advice and counseling services. In this context, Motivational Interviewing has been shown to be effective in changing health behaviors in specific cases. However, more robust evidence is needed on the effectiveness of Motivational Interviewing in the treatment of chronic pathologies -such as dyslipidemia- in patients seen by general practitioners. This article describes a protocol to evaluate the effectiveness of MI compared to general practice (brief advice), with the aim of improving control of lipid levels in patients with dyslipidemia attended by a general practitioner. METHODS/DESIGN: An open, parallel, two-arm, multicenter, cluster, controlled, randomized clinical trial will be conducted. A total of 48-50 general practitioners from 35 public primary care centers in Spain will be randomized and will recruit 436 patients with dyslipidemia. They will carry out an intervention based either on the Motivational Interview or on the usual brief advice. After an initial assessment, follow-ups will be carried out at 2, 4, 8 and 12 months. Primary outcomes are lipid levels (total cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, triglycerides) and cardiovascular risk. The study will assess the degree of improvement in diet and physical activity, weight loss in overweight patients, and adherence to treatment guidelines. DISCUSSION: Motivational interviewing skills are the main strategies used by general practitioners to treat their patients. Having cheap, simple, effective and applicable techniques is essential for primary care professionals to help their patients change their lifestyle and improve their health. This study will provide scientific evidence on the effectiveness of Motivational Interviewing, and will be carried out under strict control over the data collected, ensuring the maintenance of therapeutic integrity. TRIALS REGISTRY: ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT01282190).

title: Effectiveness of motivational interviewing in patients with dyslipidemia: a cluster randomized trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Getting people to change their habits is known to be challenging. It is crucial to identify the most effective approach that general practitioners (GPs) should use to help their patients change unhealthy habits. The objective of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a multifactorial intervention based on Motivational Interviewing performed by general practitioners to improve lipid levels in patients with dyslipidemia, compared to standard care. METHODS: Multicentre, controlled, randomized, cluster trial with two parallel arms with a follow-up of 12 months carried out in 25 community health centers in Spain. The trial included 38 general practitioners and 227 primary care patients with uncontrolled dyslipidemia. Physicians performed an intervention based on Motivational Interviewing (MI) or routine practice. Lipid levels were measured and the degree of control was analyzed according to the criteria of the clinical guidelines. RESULTS: 107 were assigned to the Experimental Group (EG) and 120 to the Control Group (CG). An overall improvement was achieved in total cholesterol levels (Mean Difference -MD- = -19.60"; 95% CI: -15.33 to -23.87 mg/dl; p < 0.001), cholesterol levels LDL (MD = -13.78; 95% CI: -9.77 to -17.79 mg/dl; p < 0.001) and triglycerides (MD = -19.14; 95% CI: -11.29 to - 26.99 mg/dl; p < 0.001), no differences were found between both groups.However, when we evaluated the degree of lipid control by combining the parameters cholesterol <200mg/dl and LDL cholesterol <130mg/dl, it was observed that a higher percentage of patients achieved target figures in the EG compared to the CG (13.1% vs. 5.0%; adjusted OR = 5.77, 95% CI: 1.67-19.91) CONCLUSION: A approach based on Motivational Interviewing conducted by Primary Care physicians aimed at patients with dyslipidemia, achieved a significant reduction in all lipid parameters, cardiovascular risk, weight reduction and adherence to the Mediterranean diet, similar to that obtained with the usual intervention and top and n the proportion of pa patients achieving combined targets for lipid control and physical exercise level. TRIAL REGISTRATION: The trial is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT01282190;" Jan 21, 2011).

title: Efficacy of multicomponent interventions in primary health care settings to promote continued smoking cessation in adults: a systematic review
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The objective of this review is to evaluate multicomponent/complex primary care (PC) interventions to determine their effectiveness in continued abstinence from smoking in adult smokers. DESIGN: A systematic review of randomized and nonrandomized controlled trials was conducted. ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA FOR INCLUDED STUDIES: Selected studies met the following criteria: evaluated the effects of a multicomponent/complex intervention (with 2 or more intervention components) in achieving at least 6 months of abstinence in adult smokers visiting a PC , biochemical confirmation of abstinence, Intention-to-treat analysis and results published in English/Spanish. METHODS: We followed the PRISMA statement to report the review. The following data sources were searched: MEDLINE, Web of Science, Scopus (from inception to February 2014), 3 key journals, and a tobacco research newsletter. The Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network checklists were used to assess methodological quality. Selection, evaluation, and data extraction were performed independently, using a peer review approach. Due to the heterogeneity of the interventions in the included studies, a meta-analysis was not performed. RESULTS: Of 1,147 identified references, 9 studies were selected (10,204 participants, up to 48-month follow-up, acceptable methodological quality). The methodologies used were mainly individual or group sessions, telephone conversations, brochures or kits to stop smoking, medications and economic incentives for doctors and free medications for smokers. Complex interventions achieved long-term continuous abstinence ranging from 7% to 40%. Behavioral interventions were effective and had a dose-response effect. Both nicotine replacement therapy and bupropion therapy were safe and effective, with no differences observed. CONCLUSIONS: Multicomponent/complex interventions in PC are effective and safe, and appear to achieve greater long-term continuous smoking cessation than usual care and advice alone. The selected studies were heterogeneous and some had significant losses to follow up. Our results show that smoking interventions should include more than one component and strong patient follow-up to maximize outcomes.

title: Efficacy of nursing interventions in people with personality disorders
abstract: BACKGROUND: Nurses generally provide care for people with personality disorders on a day-to-day basis. Consequently, it is important to establish how effective nursing interventions are for people with personality disorders, both in terms of general management and more specific therapeutic approaches. These are also topics of current political and professional debate. However, the crucial question for service planners, providers and commissioners is: What research evidence is there about effectiveness? There is also a need to determine what additional research is needed to evaluate behavior management or modification programs. OBJECTIVE: The objective of this article is to report a systematic review of the literature on the effectiveness of nursing interventions in people with personality disorders, whether performed by nurses alone or in combination with other health professionals. METHOD: The review was carried out in accordance with the UK Health Service National Center for Review and Dissemination guidelines. Literature was identified from electronic database searches, footnote searches, journal hand searching, and contact with study authors. A narrative synthesis was performed in relation to the study design, the participants and the type of intervention. FINDINGS: Eighteen separate studies were included in the review: four randomized controlled trials, four nonrandomized controlled trials, seven before and after studies, and three case studies. CONCLUSIONS: There is a weak evidence base for what constitutes an effective nursing intervention with people with personality disorders. There is stronger evidence from mixed discipline intervention studies than from nursing-only intervention studies. Studies of interventions based on psychological approaches show greater improvements in outcomes than studies of nursing management.

title: Effectiveness of pharmaceutical care for patients with reactive airway disease: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Context It is not known whether patient outcomes are improved by effective pharmacist-patient interactions. Objective To assess the effectiveness of a pharmaceutical care program for patients with asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Design, Setting, and Participants Randomized controlled trial conducted at 36 community pharmacies in Indianapolis, Indiana. We enrolled 1,113 participants with active COPD or asthma from July 1998 through December 1999. Outcomes were assessed in 947 (85.1%) participants at 6 months and 898 (80.7%) at 12 months. Interventions The pharmacist care program (n = 447) provided pharmacists with recent patient-specific clinical data (peak expiratory flow rates [PEFR], emergency department [ED] visits, hospitalizations, and medication adherence), training, personalized patient education materials and resources to facilitate program implementation. The PEFR monitoring control group (n = 363) received a peak flow meter, instructions on its use, and monthly calls to obtain PEFR. However, PEFR data was not provided to the pharmacist. Patients in the usual care group (n = 303) did not receive peak flow meters or instructions on their use"; PEFR rates were not obtained during monthly telephone interviews. Pharmacists in both control groups had a session training but did not receive medication components MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Peak expiratory flow rates, breathing-related hospital or emergency department visits, health-related quality of life (HRQoL), medication adherence, and patient satisfaction Results At 12 months, patients who received pharmaceutical care had significantly higher peak flow rates than the usual care group (P = 0.02) but not than PEFR monitoring controls (P = 0.28). there were significant differences between groups in medication adherence or HRQoL Patients with asthma who received pharmaceutical care tu they saw significantly more symptoms related to breathing. emergency department or hospital visits than the usual care group (odds ratio, 2.16; 95% confidence interval, 1.76-2.63; P < .001). Patients who received pharmaceutical care were more satisfied with their pharmacist than the usual care group (p = 0.03) and the PEFR control group (p = 0.001) and were more satisfied with their medical care than the regular care group. usual only at 6 months (p = 0.01). Despite ample opportunities to implement the program, pharmacists accessed patient-specific data only about half the time and documented actions about half the time records were accessed. Conclusions This pharmaceutical care program increased patients' PEFR compared with usual care, but provided little benefit compared with peak flow monitoring alone. Pharmaceutical care increased patient satisfaction, but also increased the amount of respiration-related medical care requested.

title: Effectiveness of physical therapy for patients with neck pain: an individualized approach using a clinical decision-making algorithm.
abstract: Objective: The purpose of this study was to determine the effectiveness of an individualized physiotherapy intervention in the treatment of neck pain based on a clinical reasoning algorithm. Treatment efficacy was examined by assessing changes in impairment, physical performance, and disability in response to intervention. Design: A treatment group of 30 patients with neck pain completed physiotherapy treatment. The convenience control group consisted of a cohort of 27 subjects who also had neck pain but did not receive treatment for various reasons. There were no significant differences between groups in demographic data and baseline test scores for outcome measures. A non-equivalent, pretest-posttest, quasi-experimental control group design was used. A physical therapist provided an eclectic intervention to the treatment group based on a clinical decision-making algorithm. Treatment outcome measures included the following five dependent variables: cervical range of motion, numerical pain index, time-weighted overhead resistance, the supine head flexion resistance test, and the patient-specific functionality. Both the treatment and control groups completed baseline and follow-up examinations, with an average duration of 4 weeks between tests. Results: Five mixed analyzes of variance with follow-up tests showed a significant difference for all outcome measures in the treatment group compared to the control group. After an average of 4 weeks of physical therapy intervention, patients in the treatment group demonstrated statistically significant increases in cervical range of motion, decreases in pain, increases in physical performance measures, and decreases in level of disability. The control group showed no difference in the five outcome variables between baseline and follow-up test scores. Conclusions: This study outlined algorithm-based clinical reasoning strategies to assess and treat patients with neck pain. The algorithm can help clinicians classify patients with cervical pain into clinical patterns and provides pattern-specific guidelines for physiotherapy interventions. An organized and specific physiotherapy program was effective in improving the condition of patients with neck pain.

title: Effectiveness of physical therapy exercise after knee arthroplasty for osteoarthritis: systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the effectiveness of physical therapy exercise after elective primary total knee arthroplasty in patients with osteoarthritis. DESIGN Systematic review. DATA SOURCES Database searches: AMED, CINAHL, Embase, King's Fund, Medline, Cochrane Library (Cochrane Reviews, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, DARE), PEDro, Department of Health National Research Register. Manual Searches: Physiotherapy, Physiotherapy, Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery Conference Proceedings (Great Britain). Review methods Randomized controlled trials were reviewed if they included a physical therapy exercise intervention compared to usual or standard physical therapy care, or if they compared two types of exercise physical therapy interventions that met the review criteria, after discharge. inpatient after elective primary total knee arthroplasty for osteoarthritis. OUTCOME MEASURES Functional activities of daily living, walking, quality of life, muscle strength, and range of motion at the knee joint. The quality of the trials was extensively assessed. Narrative synthesis plus meta-analysis with fixed effect models, weighted mean differences, standardized effect sizes, and tests for heterogeneity. RESULTS Six trials were identified, five of which were suitable for inclusion in meta-analyses. There was a small to moderate standardized effect size (0.33, 95% confidence interval 0.07 to 0.58) in favor of functional exercise for function three to four months postoperatively. There were also small to moderate weighted mean differences of 2.9 (0.61 to 5.2) for joint range of motion and 1.66 (-1 to 4.3) for quality of life in favor of functional exercise three four months after the operation. The benefits of the treatment were no longer evident at one year. CONCLUSIONS Interventions including functional physical therapy exercises after discharge result in short-term benefit after elective primary total knee arthroplasty. Effect sizes are small to moderate, with no long-term benefit.

title: Efficacy of provider incentives in reducing anemia in rural China: a cluster randomized trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVES To test the impact of provider performance pay for anemia reduction in rural China. DESIGN A cluster-randomized trial of information, subsidies, and incentives for school principals to reduce anemia among their students. Interviewers and study participants were not informed of study arm assignment. SETTING 72 randomly selected rural primary schools in northwestern China. PARTICIPANTS 3,553 fourth and fifth grade students from 9 to 11 years old. All fourth and fifth grade students from the sample schools participated in the study. INTERVENTIONS The schools in the sample were randomly assigned to a control group, without intervention, or to one of three treatment arms: (a) an information arm, in which principals received information about anemia; (b) a subsidy arm, in which principals received unconditional subsidies and information;" and (c) an incentive arm, in which principals received information, subsidies, and financial incentives to reduce anemia among students. Twenty-seven schools were assigned to the control arm (1816 students at baseline, 1623 at endpoint), 15 were assigned to the information arm (659 students at baseline, 596 at endpoint), 15 to the subsidy (726 students at baseline, 667 at end) and 15 to the incentive group (743 students at start, 667 at end) MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Student hemoglobin concentrations RESULTS Mean hemoglobin concentration of students increased 1.5 g/L (95% CI -1.1 to 4.1) in information schools, 0.8 g/L (-1.8 to 3.3) in charter schools, and 2.4 g/L (0 to 4.9) in incentive schools schools compared to co group control. This increase in hemoglobin corresponded to a reduction in the prevalence of anemia (Hb <115 g/L) of 24% in the incentive schools. Interactions with preexisting incentives for principals to achieve good academic performance led to substantially larger gains in the information and incentive arms: when combined with incentives for good academic performance, the associated effects on student hemoglobin concentration were 9.8 g/L (4.1 to 15.5) higher in information schools and 8.6 g/L (2.1 to 15.1) higher in incentive schools. CONCLUSIONS Financial incentives to improve health were modestly effective. Understanding the interactions with other pre-existing motives and incentives is critical. TEST REGISTRATION NUMBER ISRCTN76158086.

title: Efficacy of Screening and Brief Intervention for Alcohol in Primary Care (SIPS Trial): Pragmatic Cluster Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the effectiveness of different brief intervention strategies to reduce hazardous or harmful drinking in primary care. The hypothesis was that a more intensive intervention would result in a greater reduction in hazardous or harmful drinking. DESIGN Pragmatic cluster randomized controlled trial. SETTING Primary care practices in the North East and South East of England and in London. PARTICIPANTS 3,562 patients aged 18 years or older who regularly attended primary care, of whom 2,991 (84.0%) were eligible to participate in the trial: 900 (30.1%) tested positive for hazardous or harmful use and 756 (84.0%) received a brief intervention. The sample was predominantly male (62%) and white (92%), and 34% were current smokers. INTERVENTIONS Practices were randomized to three interventions, each building on the previous one: a control group with a patient information booklet, five minutes of brief structured advice, and 20 minutes of brief style advice. of life. Handout of the patient insert and brief advice occurred directly after screening and brief lifestyle advice at a later consultation. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was patients' self-reported hazardous or harmful drinking status measured by the Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT) at six months. A negative AUDIT result (score <8) indicated that alcohol use is neither dangerous nor harmful. Secondary outcomes were a negative AUDIT result at 12 months, experience of alcohol-related problems (alcohol problems questionnaire), health utility (EQ-5D), service utilization, and staff motivation. patients to change drinking behavior (readiness to change) as measured by a modified readiness rule. RESULTS Patient follow-up rates were 83% at six months (n=644) and 79% at 12 months (n=617). At both time points, an intention-to-treat analysis found no significant difference in negative AUDIT status between the three interventions. Compared with the patient information booklet group, the odds ratio of having a negative AUDIT result for brief advice was 0.85 (95% confidence interval 0.52 to 1.39) and for brief lifestyle advice was 0.78 (0.48 to 1.25). A per-protocol analysis confirmed these findings. CONCLUSIONS All patients received simple information about the result of their screening. Beyond this input, however, evidence was lacking that brief advice or brief lifestyle advice provided an important additional benefit in reducing risky or harmful drinking compared to the patient information leaflet. TRIAL REGISTRATION Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN06145674.

title: Efficacy of screening and treating depression in indigent outpatients
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the effectiveness of depression screening and treatment among indigent outpatients visiting resident physicians. DESIGN: Two-arm randomized trial (N = 33 intervention, N = 28 usual care) with baseline, 6-month, and 12-month outcome measurements. PLACE: Internal Medicine Residency Clinic. PATIENTS: Clinical patients older than 18 years who tested positive for depression on PRIME-MD during a visit to their resident physician. Patients did not receive treatment or seek care for any emotional problems. All patients were enrolled in Medicaid or had income below the poverty line. INTERVENTION: Resident physicians were educated to follow the AHCPR (AHRQ"; Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality) guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of depression in a primary care setting. For patients residents in the intervention group, a screening nurse counseled residents about positive screening, provided them with a standardized protocol outline, and attempted to organize behavioral care Patients in the usual care group received the results of the screening nurse prior to their visit with the resident, and they were advised to seek care for their symptoms MAIN RESULTS: Results for the primary outcome of depressive symptoms measured with the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) demonstrated that the intervention was successful in reducing symptoms relative to usual care (difference = -4.9 BDI points, P = 0.05, interval 95% confidence interval [CI], -9.8 to -0.005 effect size = -0.41). During the 12-month follow-up, 70% of intervention patients received treatment for depression (of these, 91% with antidepressants), while 15% of usual care patients received antidepressant treatment for depression. Another 18% of the usual care group had depression, but no treatment was identified. The differences in BDI between the intervention and control groups were similar at the 6- and 12-month measures. Quality of life and costs were also measured, but the differences between groups were not significant in this regard. CONCLUSION: Screening for and treatment of depression by resident physicians was successful in reducing symptoms relative to usual care in an indigent population. Nearly twice as many intervention patients as usual care controls demonstrated a substantial reduction (10 BDI points) in depression-related symptoms.

title: Effectiveness of strategies to disseminate and implement clinical guidelines for the management of impacted and unerupted third molars in primary dental care, a cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To investigate the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of different guideline implementation strategies, using the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) guideline 42 "Management of unerupted and impacted third molars" (published in 2000) as a model. . DESIGN: A pragmatic cluster RCT (2x2 factorial design). SUBJECTS: Sixty-three dental practices throughout Scotland. Clinical records of all patients aged 16 to 24 years during two four-month periods in 1999 (before intervention) and 2000 (after intervention) were searched by a clinical investigator blinded to the intervention group. Data on the costs of the interventions were also collected. INTERVENTIONS: Group 1 received a copy of the SIGN 42 Guide and had the opportunity to attend a postgraduate education course (PGEC). In addition to this, group 2 received audit and feedback (A and F). Group 3 received a computer-assisted learning (CAL) package. Group 4 received A and F and CAL. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: The proportion of patients whose treatment complied with the guideline. RESULTS: Weighted t-tests for A and F versus no A and F (P = 0.62) and CAL versus no CAL (P = 0.76) were not statistically significant. Given the efficacy results (no difference), the profitability calculation was converted to a cost minimization calculation. The least cost intervention in the trial was to provide general dentists (GDP) with guidelines and the option to attend PGEC courses. Routine data that subsequently became available showed a Scotland-wide drop in removals prior to data collection. CONCLUSION: In a setting where pre-intervention compliance was unexpectedly high, neither CAL nor A and F increased dentists' compliance with the SIGN guideline compared with mailing the guideline and the opportunity to attend. a postgraduate course. The cost of the CAL arm of the trial was higher than arm A and F. More work is required to understand the behavior of dental professionals in response to guideline implementation strategies.

title: Efficacy of thigh-high graduated compression stockings in reducing the risk of deep vein thrombosis after stroke (CLOTS 1 trial): a multicentre randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism are common after stroke. In small trials of patients undergoing surgery, graduated compression stockings (GCS) reduce the risk of DVT. National stroke guidelines extrapolated from these trials recommend its use in stroke patients despite insufficient evidence. We evaluated the effectiveness of thigh-level GCS in reducing DVT after stroke.";" Background Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism are common after stroke. In small trials of patients undergoing surgery, graduated compression stockings (GCS) reduce the risk of DVT. National stroke guidelines extrapolated from these trials recommend its use in stroke patients despite insufficient evidence. The effectiveness of thigh-high GCS in reducing DVT after stroke was assessed.

title: Efficacy of community pharmacist visits for patients with heart failure: a randomized controlled trial HeartMed
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess whether an intervention of medication review, symptom self-management, and lifestyle advice by community pharmacists could reduce hospital admissions or mortality in patients with heart failure. DESIGN Randomized controlled trial. SCOPE Home intervention in patients with heart failure. PARTICIPANTS 293 patients diagnosed with heart failure (149 intervention, 144 control) after emergency admission were included. INTERVENTION Two home visits by one of 17 community pharmacists within two and eight weeks of discharge. Pharmacists reviewed medications and provided self-management of symptoms and lifestyle advice. Controls received usual care. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was total hospital readmissions at six months. Secondary outcomes included mortality and quality of life (Minnesota Heart Failure Life Questionnaire and EQ-5D). RESULTS Primary outcome data were available for 291 participants (99%). 136 (91%) intervention patients received one or two visits. There were 134 admissions in the intervention group compared to 112 in the control group (rate ratio = 1.15, 95% confidence interval 0.89 to 1.48"; P = 0.28, model 30 patients died from the intervention compared with 24 controls (hazard ratio = 1.18)., 0.69 to 2.03, P = 0.54). Although the EQ-5D scores favored the intervention group, Minnesota Life with Heart Failure Questionnaire scores favored controls;" neither difference was statistically significant. CONCLUSION This community pharmacist intervention did not lead to reductions in hospital admissions in contrast to those found in trials of nurse-led interventions in heart failure. Given that heart failure accounts for 5% of hospital admissions, these results present a problem for policymakers who are faced with a shortage of specialists and hope that trained community pharmacists can deliver the same benefits. TEST REGISTRATION NUMBER ISRCTN59427925.

title: Effects of a behavioral-independent financial incentive on the prescribing behavior of general practitioners
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES: It is difficult to maintain control over prescribing behavior in general practice. The purpose of this study was to assess the baseline effects of a behavioral-independent financial incentive on general practitioner (GP) medication prescription volume. DESIGN: Controlled study before and after 2 years with an intervention region and a concurrent control region. SETTING AND PARTICIPANTS: GPs in two regions of the Netherlands (n = 119 and n = 118). INTERVENTION: A financial incentive to prescribe according to local guidelines on specific drugs or drug categories. The economic incentive consisted of a non-recurring assignment independent of behavior. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: Change in the number of prescriptions for 10 specific drugs or groups of drugs. RESULTS: Significant changes were observed only in three types of antibiotics and in the recommended gastric medications. In almost all cases, the effects were temporary. CONCLUSION: Behavioral-independent financial incentives may be helpful in changing GP prescribing behaviour, but the effects are small-scale and temporary.

title: Effects of an exercise program and physician referral for men who have completed active treatment for prostate cancer: a multicenter cluster randomized controlled trial (ENGAGE)
abstract: BACKGROUND: The purpose of this study was to determine the efficacy of a physician-referred exercise program in improving exercise levels and quality of life in men with prostate cancer. METHODS: This was a multicenter cluster randomized controlled trial in Melbourne, Australia, comprising 15 clinicians: 8 clinicians were randomly assigned to refer eligible participants (n = 54) to a 12-week exercise program comprising 2 sessions of supervised gymnastics and 1 home session per week, and 7 clinicians were randomized to follow usual care (n = 93). The primary outcome was self-reported physical activity; secondary outcomes were quality of life, anxiety, and symptoms of depression. RESULTS: A significant intervention effect was observed for vigorous-intensity exercise (effect size: d for Cohen, 0.46; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.09-0.82; P = .010), but not for combined levels of moderate and vigorous exercise (effect size, d, 0.08; CI 95%, -0.28 to 0.45; P = 0.48).Significant intervention effects were also seen for adherence to exercise guidelines (>/= 150 min/week; odds ratio, 3, 9; 95% CI, 1.9-7.8; P = .002), positive intervention effects were seen in the intervention group for cognitive functioning (effect size: d, 0.34; 95% CI %, -0.02 to 0.70; P = 0.06) and symptoms of depression (effect size: d, -0.35; 95% CI, -0.71 to 0.02; P = 0 .06).Eighty percent of the participants reported that the physician's referral influenced their decision to participate in the exercise program. CONCLUSIONS: Physician referral and the 12-week exercise program significantly improved vigorous exercise levels and had a positive impact on mental health outcomes in men living with prostate cancer. More research is needed to determine the sustainability of the exercise program and its generalizability to other cancer populations.

title: Effects of a fixed combination of perindopril and indapamide on macrovascular and microvascular outcomes in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (ADVANCE trial): a randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background Blood pressure is an important determinant of the risks of macrovascular and microvascular complications of type 2 diabetes, and guidelines recommend aggressive blood pressure lowering in diabetic patients with hypertension. We evaluated the effects of routine administration of an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor and diuretic combination on serious vascular events in patients with diabetes, regardless of baseline blood pressure levels or the use of other blood pressure-lowering medications. arterial".;" Background Blood pressure is an important determinant of the risks of macrovascular and microvascular complications of type 2 diabetes, and guidelines recommend aggressive blood pressure lowering in diabetic patients with hypertension. The effects of routine administration of an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor and diuretic combination on major vascular events in people with diabetes were evaluated, regardless of baseline blood pressure levels or the use of other antihypertensive drugs.

title: Effects of a multifaceted intervention on cardiovascular risk factors in high-risk hypertensive patients: the ESCAPE trial, a pragmatic cluster randomized trial in general practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Several observational studies in hypertensive patients have shown a gap between the therapeutic goals recommended in the guidelines and those achieved in daily practice. The ESCAPE trial aimed to determine whether a multifaceted intervention focused on general practitioners (GPs) could significantly increase the proportion of high-risk hypertensive patients in primary prevention who achieved all recommended therapeutic goals. METHODS: A pragmatic, cluster-randomized trial involving 257 GPs randomized by region. GPs in the intervention group had a one-day training session and received an electronic blood pressure measurement device and a brief recommendation booklet. Along with routine follow-up, they focused on a consultation on hypertension and other cardiovascular risk factors every six months for two years. They also received baseline and 1-year feedback on their patients' clinical and biological parameters. The main outcome measures were the change in the proportion of patients achieving all of their therapeutic goals and each individual therapeutic goal at two years, and quality of life. RESULTS: 1,832 high-risk hypertensive patients were included. After two years, the proportion of patients who achieved all their therapeutic goals increased significantly in both groups, but significantly more in the intervention group: OR (odds ratio) 1.89, (95% confidence interval (CI) 1 .09 to 3.27, P = 0.02). Significantly more patients achieved their blood pressure targets in the intervention group than in the usual care group: OR 2.03 (95% CI 1.44 to 2.88, P < 0.0001). Systolic and diastolic blood pressures decreased significantly more in the intervention group than in the usual care group, by 4.8 mmHg and 1.9 mmHg, respectively (p < 0.0001 for both). There were no significant differences in changes in physical and mental quality of life between the groups. CONCLUSION: A multifaceted, easy-to-perform intervention targeting only GPs significantly increased the proportion of high-risk hypertensive patients in primary prevention who achieved their recommended therapeutic goals. TRIAL REGISTRATION: This trial is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT00348855.

title: Effects of a short course of eszopiclone on adherence to continuous positive airway pressure
abstract: Background: Short-term continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) adherence may predict long-term use. Unfortunately, initial intolerance to CPAP can lead to poor adherence or discontinuation of therapy. Objective: To determine whether a short course of eszopiclone at the start of therapy improves long-term adherence to CPAP more than placebo in adults with obstructive sleep apnea. Design: Parallel randomized, placebo-controlled trial from March 2007 to December 2008. Randomization, centrally maintained and masked by pharmacy staff, was computer generated using fixed blocks of 10. Referring physicians, investigators, and patients they were blinded to treatment assignment until after final data was collected. (ClinicalTrials.gov registration number: NCT00612157) Setting: Academic Center for Sleep Disorders. Patients: 160 adults (mean age, 45.7 years [SD, 7.3]"; mean apnea indexaâ‚¬Â¡Â°, 36.9 events/h [SD, 23]) with newly diagnosed obstructive sleep apnea who started CPAP Intervention: Eszopiclone, 3 mg (n? = 76), or matching placebo (n? = 78) during the first 14 nights of CPAP Measurements: CPAP use was measured weekly for 24 weeks. CPAP adherence (primary outcome) and CPAP discontinuation rate and symptom improvement (secondary outcomes) Follow-up at 1, 3, and 6 months was completed in 150, 136, and 120 patients, respectively. : Patients in the eszopiclone group used CPAP 20.8% more nights (95% CI, 7.2% to 34.4%; P? = 0.003), 1.3 hours more per night for all nights (CI, 0.4 to 2.2 hours; P? = 0.005) and 1.1 more hours per night of CPAP use (CI, 0.2 to 2.1 hours; P? = 0.019). risk for CPAP discontinuation was 1.90 (CI, 1.1 to 3.4; P? = 0.03 3) times ma higher in the placebo group. Side effects were reported in 7.1% of patients and did not differ between groups. Limitations: patients had severe obstructive sleep apnea treated in a specialized sleep center with frequent follow-up; results may not be generalizable to different settings. Patients' tolerance to CPAP and their reasons for discontinuation were not assessed. Conclusion: Compared to placebo, a short course of eszopiclone during the first 2 weeks of CPAP improved adherence and led to fewer patients discontinuing therapy. Main source of financing: Sepracor.

title: Effects of an automated electronic reminder on changing antiplatelet medication prescription behavior among Italian general practitioners in diabetic patients: an intervention trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess whether an electronic reminder integrated into a routine computer system increases the use of antiplatelet drugs for diabetic patients among Italian general practitioners (GPs). RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS: A randomized controlled trial was carried out among 300 general practitioners and their patients selected from the health search database. Among these, 150 general practitioners (intervention group) were instructed to activate an electronic reminder plus a letter summarizing the beneficial effects of antiplatelet drugs in diabetic patients with at least one additional cardiovascular risk factor ("high risk"), while that the other 150 general practitioners (control group) received only the letter. The electronic reminder, integrated into a standard software system for daily clinical practice management, was displayed when each participating GP opened the medical record of diabetic patients aged ≥30 years. Only high-risk diabetic patients were included in the analysis. Patients were considered to be on antiplatelet therapy if they received two or more prescriptions at baseline and during follow-up. RESULTS—15,343 high-risk diabetic patients were selected, 7,313 belonging to general practitioners in the control group and 8,030 belonging to general practitioners in the intervention group. Overall, 1,672 patients (22.9%) in the control group and 1,886 (23.5%) patients in the intervention group received antiplatelet drugs at baseline (P = NS). At the end of follow-up, the number of treated patients was significantly increased in the intervention group (odds ratio 1.99, 95% CI 1.79 to 2.22) compared to the control group. The effect of the electronic reminder was more relevant among those patients with one or more cardiovascular risk factors but without previous cardiovascular diseases (CVD), compared to those with CVD. CONCLUSIONS: These findings provide evidence of the effect of an electronic reminder affecting the prescribing behavior of GPs.

title: Effects of a testing service on the use of research tests by community AIDS service organizations: a protocol for a randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background To support the use of research evidence by community-based organizations (CBOs), we have developed 'Synthesized Research Evidence on HIV/AIDS' (SHARE), which is an evidence service for those working in the sector. of HIV. SHARE consists of several components: an online searchable database of HIV-relevant systematic reviews (retrievable based on a taxonomy of HIV/AIDS-related topics and open text search); regular email updates; access to user-friendly summaries; and peer relevance assessments. Our goal is to assess whether this 'full-service' testing service increases the use of investigative testing by community organizations compared to a 'self-service' testing service. Methods/Design We will conduct a two-arm randomized controlled trial (RCT), along with a follow-up qualitative process study to explore the findings further. All CBOs affiliated with the Canadian AIDS Society (n = 120) will be invited to participate and randomly assigned to receive either the 'full service' version of SHARE or the 'self service' version (a list of relevant systematic reviews with links to PubMed records and worksheets that help community organizations find and use research evidence) using a simple randomized design. All management and staff in each organization will have access to the version of SHARE to which their organization is assigned. The duration of the trial will be 10 months (baseline period of two months, intervention period of six months and crossover period of two months), the main outcome measure will be the mean number of logins/month/organization (averaged between the number of users in each organization) between the baseline and the end of the intervention period. The secondary outcome will be the intention to use research evidence measured by a survey administered to a key decision maker from each organization. For the qualitative study, a purposive sample of a key organizational decision maker will be taken from 15 organizations in each trial arm (n = 30). One-on-one semi-structured interviews will be conducted over the phone about their views and experiences with the testing service they received, how helpful it was in their job, why it was helpful (or not helpful), what aspects were most and least helpful and why, and recommendations for next steps. Discussion To our knowledge, this will be the first RCT to assess the effects of an evidence service designed specifically to help CBOs find and use research evidence.

title: Effects of an evidence service on the use of research evidence by health system policymakers: a protocol for a randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background Health system policymakers need timely access to synthesized research evidence to inform the policymaking process. Efforts to address this need using an experimental quantitative design have not been evaluated. We developed an evidence service that draws information from Health Systems Evidence, which is a database of policy-relevant systematic reviews. The reviews have been (a) classified by topic and type of review; (b) coded by the last year in which studies were searched and by the countries in which the included studies were conducted; (c) rated for quality;" and (d) linked to available user-friendly abstracts, scientific abstracts, and full-text reports. Our goal is to assess whether a "full-service" evidence service increases the use of synthesized research evidence by policy analysts and advisers at the Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care (MOHLTC) compared to a "drive-in" evidence service Service Methods/Design We will conduct a randomized controlled trial (RCT) along with a follow-up qualitative process study to explore the findings further For the RCT, all policy analysts and policy advisors (n = 168) in a single MOHLTC division will be invited to participate Using a stratified randomized design, participants will be randomly assigned to receive "full service" evidence service (database access, monthly alerts by email and availability of full-text articles) or the "self-service" evidence service (database access). only). The duration of the trial will be ten months (baseline period of two months, intervention period of six months and crossover period of two months). The primary outcome will be the mean number of visits to the site/month/user between the beginning and the end of the intervention period. The secondary outcome will be the intention of the participants to use the research evidence. For the qualitative study, 15 participants from each arm of the trial (n = 30) will be intentionally sampled. One-on-one semi-structured interviews will be conducted over the phone about their views and experiences with the testing service they received, how helpful it was in their job, why it was helpful (or not helpful), what aspects were most and least helpful and why, and recommendations for next steps. Discussion To our knowledge, this will be the first RCT to assess the effects of an evidence service designed specifically to help health system policy makers find and use research evidence.

title: Effects of computerized reminders for influenza vaccination on morbidity during influenza epidemics.
abstract: To study the effects of computer-generated reminders for influenza vaccination of patients at high risk for lung disease during the winter, we selected 4,555 such patients from a population of 15,000 adults who participated in a three-year randomized trial of preventive care reminders. Physicians who received the reminders vaccinated eligible patients twice as often as control physicians (P = 0.0001). There was a linear increase in the incidence of influenza in our area over the three winters under study (from 1,000 to 33,451 to 71,075 cases per year), and we modeled the percentage of patients with hospitalizations, emergency room visits with chest x-ray, and blood test. gas determinations as a logistic function of this increase. The difference in linear trends between patients in the intervention group (whose physicians received reminders) and those in the control group was significant for emergency room visits (P less than 0.05), hospitalizations (P less than 0.01) and blood gas determinations (P less than 0.001). The most likely explanation for the difference is the higher use of the influenza vaccine in the intervention group.

title: Effects of computerized reminders on complications of peripheral venous catheters and adherence of nurses to a guideline in pediatric care: a randomized cluster study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Reminder systems in electronic patient records (EPRs) have been shown to affect both healthcare professional behavior and patient outcomes. The objective of this cluster-randomized trial was to investigate the effects of implementing a clinical practice guideline (CPG) for peripheral venous catheters (PVC) in pediatric care in the form of reminders integrated into the EPRs, on PVC-related complications and on registered records. Self-reported adherence of nurses (RN) to the guideline. An additional objective was to study the relationship between contextual factors and intervention outcomes. METHODS: The study involved 12 inpatient units at a pediatric university hospital. Reminders included PVC choice, hygiene, maintenance, and daily inspection of the PVC site. The primary outcome was documentation of signs and symptoms of PVC-related complications at the time of extraction, obtained from the RPE. The secondary outcome was RNs' adherence to a PVC guideline, collected through a questionnaire that also included the RNs' perceived work context, as measured by the Alberta Context Tool. The units were assigned in two strata, depending on the appearance of PVC. A simple blind lottery from each stratum randomized six units to the control and intervention groups, respectively. The units were not blinded. The intervention group included 626 PVCs at baseline and 618 after the intervention, and the control group 724 PVCs at baseline and 674 after the intervention. The newborns included at the beginning of the study were 212 (65.4%) and 208 (71.5%) after the intervention. RESULTS: No significant effect of computer reminders on PVC-related complications or NB compliance with guideline recommendations was found. The complication rate at baseline and postoperatively was 40.6% (95% confidence interval (CI) 36.7-44.5) and 41.9% (95% CI 38.0- 45.8), for the intervention group and 40.3% (95% CI 36.8-44.0) and 46.9% (95% CI 43.1-50.7) for the control. Overall, the RNs' self-assessed work context ranged from moderately low to moderately high, indicating that the conditions for successful implementation were less than optimal. CONCLUSIONS: Reminders could have benefited from being accompanied by a personalized intervention that targeted specific barriers, such as low frequency of recorded reasons for removal, low adherence to daily inspection of PVC sites, and lack of regular feedback. to the RNs. EVIDENCE REGISTER: Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN44819426.

title: Effects of computerized guidelines for the management of heart diseases in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Electronic information systems have been proposed as a means to reduce medical errors of commission (doing something wrong) and omission (not providing the right care). OBJECTIVE: To assess the effects of computer-based cardiac care suggestions. DESIGN: A randomized, controlled trial targeting primary care physicians and pharmacists. SUBJECTS: A total of 706 outpatients with heart failure and/or ischemic heart disease. INTERVENTIONS: Physicians and pharmacists were shown evidence-based cardiac care suggestions, approved by a panel of local cardiologists and general internists, while caring for enrolled patients. MEASURES: Compliance with care suggestions, generic and condition-specific quality of life, acute exacerbations of their heart disease, medication adherence, health care costs, satisfaction with care, and physicians' attitudes toward guidelines. RESULTS: Subjects were followed for 1 year during which they made 3419 primary care visits and were eligible for 2609 separate suggestions for cardiac care. The intervention had no effect on physicians' adherence to care suggestions (23% for intervention patients vs. 22% for controls). There were no differences between intervention and control in quality of life, medication adherence, health care utilization, costs, or satisfaction with care. Physicians found the guidelines to provide useful information but restrict their practice and not help make decisions for individual patients. CONCLUSIONS: Care suggestions generated by a sophisticated electronic medical record system failed to improve adherence to accepted practice guidelines or outcomes for patients with heart disease. Future studies need to weigh the benefits and costs of different (and perhaps more draconian) methods of affecting clinical behavior.

title: Effects of general practitioner training and family support services in the care of patients with home dementia: results of a cluster-randomized controlled study
abstract: BACKGROUND: More than 90% of patients with dementia are cared for by their general practitioners, who are instrumental in diagnosis, treatment, and recommendation of support services. OBJECTIVE: To assess whether the special training of general practitioners alters the care of patients with dementia through their systematic recommendation of support groups and advice to caregivers. METHOD: 129 general practitioners enrolled 390 patients with dementia and their informal caregivers in a two-year prospective three-arm cluster-randomized study. Group A constituted usual care, in Groups B and C support groups and caregiver advice (in Group B one year after baseline, in Group C at baseline) were recommended by general practitioners. General practitioners received arm-specific training. The diagnostic and therapeutic behavior of the physicians was recorded at the beginning of the study. Informal caregivers were asked at the 2-year follow-up about their use of support services. RESULTS: The diagnostic behavior of general practitioners conforms to the relevant guidelines. The procedure in newly diagnosed patients does not differ from previously diagnosed patients with the exception of the rate of referral to a specialist. About a third of newly diagnosed dementia patients receive an anti-dementia drug. The use of support and counseling groups increased five and four times, respectively. Utilization of other support services remained low (<10%), with the exception of home nursing and short-term institutional nursing. CONCLUSION: Trained general practitioners often act in accordance with guidelines regarding the diagnosis of dementia, and partly in accordance with guidelines regarding recommended drug therapy. Recommendations of support services for informal caregivers by the general practitioner are successful. They result in a marked increase in the utilization rate of recommended services compared to offerings that are not recommended by the general practitioner. TEST REGISTRATION: ISRCTN68329593.

title: Effects of interactive voice response self-monitoring on the natural resolution of drinking problems: Utilization and behavioral economics.
abstract: Objective: Most problem drinkers do not seek help and many recover on their own. A randomized controlled trial evaluated whether interactive voice response (IVR) self-monitoring support facilitated such 'natural' resolutions. Based on behavioral economics, it was hypothesized that the effects on drinking outcomes vary with drinkers' reference "time horizons," reflecting preferences between products of different value available at different prices. delays and with their use of IVR. METHOD: Drinkers with recently resolved untreated problems were randomized to a 24-week IVR self-monitoring program (n = 87) or an assessment-only control condition (n = 98). Baseline interviews assessed predictors of outcomes, including behavioral economic measures of reward preferences (delay discount, pre-resolution monetary allowance for alcohol versus savings). Outcomes at six months were classified as resolved abstinence, non-resolved abstinence, unresolved or missing. Complier causal average effect (CACE) models examined the self-monitoring effects of IVR. Results: IVR self-monitoring adherents (>=70% of completed scheduled calls) were older and had greater preresolution alcohol control and fewer discounts than non-compliers (<70%). An interaction of the CACE model showed that observed adherers in the IVR group with shorter time horizons (expressed by higher alcohol expenditure before resolution than savers) were more likely to achieve moderation than abstinent resolutions compared with predicted achievers in the control group with shorter time horizons. and with all the defaulters. Intention-to-treat analytic models revealed no effects related to IVR. A more balanced spending on savings versus alcohol predicted moderation in both approaches. Conclusions: IVR interventions should consider factors that affect IVR utilization and drinking outcomes, including person-specific behavioral economic variables. CACE models provide tools for evaluating interventions that involve extended participation. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2016 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: Treatment effects of depression and low perceived social support on clinical events after myocardial infarction: the Enhancing Recovery in Patients with Coronary Heart Disease (ENRICHD) randomized trial.
abstract: We determined whether mortality and recurrent heart attack are reduced by treating depression and low perceived social support (LPSS) with cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), supplemented with a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) antidepressant when available. indicated, in patients enrolled within 28 days of myocardial infarction. heart attack (MI). A randomized clinical trial was conducted in 2481 patients with myocardial infarction. The LPSS was determined by the ENRICHD Social Support Instrument (ESSI). Random assignment was to usual medical care or CBT-based psychosocial intervention. CBT was started at a median of 17 days after the index MI, plus group therapy when feasible, with SSRIs for patients with a Hamilton Depression Rating Scale score greater than 24 or a reduction of less than 50 % Beck Depression Inventory scores after 5 weeks. Improvement in psychosocial outcomes at 6 months favored treatment: mean change in HRSD score, -10.1 in the depression and psychosocial intervention group vs. -8.4 in the depression and usual care group";" mean change in ESSI score, 5.1 in the LPSS and psychosocial intervention group vs. 3.4 in the LPSS and usual care group. After a median follow-up of 29 months, there was no significant difference in event-free survival between usual care and psychosocial intervention.

title: Efficacy and safety of corticosteroid injections and other injections for the treatment of tendinopathy: a systematic review of randomized controlled trials.
abstract: Background There are few evidence-based treatment guidelines for tendinopathy. We conducted a systematic review of randomized trials to establish the clinical efficacy and risk of adverse events for injection therapy.";" Background There are few evidence-based treatment guidelines for tendinopathy. We conducted a systematic review of randomized trials to establish the clinical efficacy and risk of adverse events for injection therapy.

title: Efficacy and safety of sucrose for procedural pain relief in preterm and term infants
abstract: BACKGROUND: Premature and acutely ill term infants who are hospitalized in a neonatal intensive care unit are subjected to multiple frequent painful and invasive procedures intended to improve their outcome. Although several trials have been developed to determine the efficacy of sucrose for procedural pain management in acutely ill preterm and term infants, these have generally lacked methodological rigor and have not provided clinicians with practice guidelines. clear. OBJECTIVES: To compare the efficacy and safety of three interventions for the relief of pain related to heel sticks in preterm and term infants, and to explore the influence of contextual factors such as gender, disease severity and painful procedures. prior to pain responses. METHODS: In a randomized controlled trial, 190 neonates were stratified by gestational age and then randomized to receive (a) sucrose and nonnutritive suckling (n = 64), (b) sucrose alone (n = 62), or (c) sucrose alone. sterile water and non-nutritive sucking (control) (n = 64) to assess efficacy (pain response as measured by the Preterm Infant Pain Profile) (Stevens, Johnson, Petryshen, & Taddio, 1996) and safety (adverse events) after a scheduled heel lance during the first week of life. Stratification was used to control for the effects of age on pain response. RESULTS: There were significant differences in pain response between the treatment groups (F = 22.49, p < 0.001), with the lowest mean preterm infant pain profile scores in the sucrose and non-nutritive sucking group. The efficacy of sucrose after heel lance was not affected by disease severity, postnatal age, or the number of painful procedures. Intervention group and gender explained 12% of the variation in preterm infant pain profile scores. Few adverse events occurred (n = 6), and none of them required medical or nursing intervention. CONCLUSIONS: The combination of sucrose and non-nutritive suction is the most effective intervention for single heel sticks. Research is required on the effects of gestational age on the efficacy and safety of repeated doses of sucrose.

title: Efficacy and safety of very early mobilization within 24 hours of stroke onset (AVERT): a randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background Early mobilization after stroke is thought to contribute to the effects of stroke unit care; however, the intervention is poorly defined and not supported by strong evidence. Our aim was to compare the effectiveness of frequent, higher dose and very early mobilization with usual care after stroke.; Background Early mobilization after stroke is thought to contribute to the effects of stroke unit care; however, the intervention is poorly defined and not supported by strong evidence. We aimed to compare the effectiveness of Frequent, higher dose, and very early mobilization with usual post-stroke care.

title: Efficacy of cognitive and behavioral psychotherapy applied by primary care psychologists in patients with mixed anxiety-depressive disorder: a research protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: Contrary to the recommendations of the clinical practice guidelines, the most common treatment for anxiety disorders and depression in primary care is pharmacological. The objective of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of a cognitive-behavioral psychological intervention, carried out by primary care psychologists in patients with mixed anxiety-depressive disorder compared to usual care. METHODS/DESIGN: This is an open-label, multicenter, randomized, controlled study with two parallel groups. A random sample of 246 patients with mild-moderate mixed anxiety-depressive disorder will be selected from the target population from the lists of 41 primary care physicians. Patients will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group, which will receive standardized cognitive behavioral therapy delivered by psychologists along with usual care, or a control group, which will receive only usual care. The cognitive-behavioral therapy intervention consists of eight 60-minute individual face-to-face sessions delivered over eight consecutive weeks. A telephone follow-up session will be carried out, for reinforcement or referral in your case, 6 months after the intervention, as required. The main outcome variable will be the change in Short Form-36 General Health Survey scores. We will also measure the change in the frequency and intensity of symptoms of anxiety (State-Trait Anxiety Inventory) and depression (Beck Depression Inventory) at baseline and 3, 6, and 12 months later. In addition, we will collect information about the use of medicines and health care services. DISCUSSION: The objective of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of a cognitive-behavioral psychological intervention based on primary care in patients with mixed anxiety-depressive disorder. International scientific evidence has shown the need for psychologists in primary care. However, given the differences between health policies and health services, it is important to check the effect of these psychological interventions in our geographical environment. TEST LOG: NCT01907035 (July 22, 2013).

title: Efficacy of a nurse-led email reminder program for cardiovascular prevention risk reduction in hypertensive patients: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Many strategies have been evaluated to improve the prevention and control of cardiovascular risk factors (CVD). Individualized lifestyle education programs via telephone and telenurse counseling have been found to improve blood pressure control and adherence to lifestyle recommendations. This study tested the efficacy of a nurse-led reminder program via email (NRP-e) in improving CVD risk factors among hypertensive adults. METHODS: All participants received the usual CVD prevention and guideline-based educational program. Subjects in the NRP-e group also received weekly email alerts and phone calls from a nurse care manager for 6 months. The emails contained a reminder program about the need to follow a healthy lifestyle based on current guidelines. Follow-up visits were scheduled at 1, 3, and 6 months after enrollment; randomization was performed centrally and blood samples were evaluated in a single laboratory. RESULTS: The final sample consisted of 98 (control) and 100 (NRP-e) subjects (mean age 59.0 +/- 14.5 years; "51.0% male). After 6 months, the following factors of CVD risk were significantly improved in both groups: body mass index, alcohol and fruit consumption, smoking, adherence to hours of therapy, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, fasting blood glucose, low-density lipoproteins (LDL) and cholesterol total, triglycerides and physical activity.In the NRP-e group, however, the prevalence of several risk behaviors or conditions decreased significantly more than in the control group: obesity (-16%), low consumption of fruits (-24% ), uncontrolled hypertension (-61%), LDL (-56%), and total cholesterol (-40%). CONCLUSIONS: The e-NRP improved a number of CVD risk factors. The program had low costs, required only an average of <20 min per day in addition to normal practice, and may warrant further evaluation for in inclusion among existing care management approaches.

title: Efficacy of a self-help manual to increase resilience in caregivers of depressed adults in Thailand
abstract: Caring for a person with a mental illness can have adverse effects on caregivers; however, little is known about how best to help such caregivers. The aim of the present study was to examine the efficacy of a guided self-help cognitive behavioral therapy. manual to increase resilience in caregivers of people with depression, compared to caregivers who receive only routine support. A randomized controlled trial was carried out, following the CONSORT guidelines, with 54 caregivers assigned to a parallel intervention (self-help manual) ( n = 27) or control (standard support) (n = 27). Resilience was assessed at baseline, post-test (week 8), and at follow-up (week 12). Intention-to-treat analyzes were performed. Repeated measures ANOVA indicated a significant difference in resilience scores between the three time points, showing a large effect. Pairwise comparisons between intervention and control groups indicated that resilience was significantly different between baseline and endpoint. post-test, and between baseline and follow-up, but not between post-test and follow-up. Overall, the intervention group showed a slightly greater increase in resilience over time than the control group; however, the time group interaction was not significant. Guided self-help is useful for improving carers' resilience and could be used as a supplement to the limited support provided to carers by mental health nurses and other clinicians.

title: Efficacy of evidence-based clinical decision support in primary care practices
abstract: Importance There is consensus that incorporating clinical decision support into electronic health records will improve quality of care, control costs, and reduce overtreatment, but this potential has yet to be demonstrated in clinical trials. Objective To assess the influence of a personalized evidence-based clinical decision support tool on the treatment of respiratory tract infections and on the efficacy of evidence integration at the point of care. Design, Setting, and Participants In a randomized clinical trial, we implemented 2 well-validated integrated clinical prediction rules, namely Walsh's rule for strep throat and Heckerling's rule for pneumonia. Interventions and main outcomes and measures The intervention group had access to the integrated clinical prediction rule tool and chose to complete risk score calculators, order medications, and generate progress notes to help with complex decision making at the point of care. .
