The Declaration of Helsinki, a document prepared by the World Medical Association that was originally written in 1964, substantially revised in 1975, and most recently revised in 1996, provides guidelines for such studies. In addition to complying with ethical requirements, clinical investigators also face a number of complex issues that must be addressed in conducting clinical research studies. One of the most difficult issues is the conflict between a physician's concern for the welfare of his patients and the need for protocol-based trials. No matter how enthusiastic surgeons may be about a new therapeutic approach, they must recognize that they are responsible for scientifically validating their innovative approach with a well-controlled clinical trial using valid functional outcome measures.

title: Ethical review of proposals for the evaluation of health promotion programs
abstract: Some policies state that program evaluation falls within the domain of administrative research that does not require review by an ethics review board. We propose that some evaluations of health promotion programs include at least a research element and can be distinguished from quality assurance. While the American and Canadian evaluation societies provide important guidelines and standards for evaluation professionals, research ethics boards provide processes for accountability to the public. The field of health promotion is, by its nature, fraught with challenges for existing research ethics committees. Given the dearth of published literature on the ethics of health promotion evaluation or practice, the field could benefit from the open debate that proposal reviews would encourage.

title: Ethics committees and achievement of good clinical practices
abstract: Local ethics committees (institutional review boards or similar bodies) have been established over the last few decades at (bio)medical research institutions around the world to serve as review bodies for proposed research projects (inclusive clinical trial protocols ), and also to monitor whether the ethical principles, including the requirements of good practices (clinical, laboratory and scientific) are respected and adhered to during the conduct of research projects. The existing pluralism in the philosophical background on which contemporary bioethical theories are developed is seriously questioning the old traditions of Hippocratic, non-utilitarian medical ethics, trying to promote more utilitarian and secular approaches. Individual clinicians or researchers, as well as the ethics committee itself, today face difficult ethical dilemmas, which often have to be resolved in an environment of considerable social, academic, economic, and time pressures, and sometimes without guidance. useful of the appropriate ones. legislation. An interesting possibility for how to overcome some of the pitfalls of the ethical review process is to express a common ethical responsibility for the research project or trial protocol in a statement by most (or all) of the parties involved (such as the principal investigator, sponsor, ethics committee, the patient, "society"). This approach has proven useful in improving the concrete deliberations of the ethics committees established in Slovakia since 1991 in accordance with the requirements of the national guidelines issued by the Slovak Ministry of Health.

title: Ethics committees and pediatric research: a personal look
abstract: Surveillance of clinical research involving children, or tissues taken from them, continues to become more formalized and sophisticated. It can be expected that many physicians and most pediatricians will be offered the opportunity to serve on pediatric Institutional Ethics Committees (IECs) at some point in their professional lives. Bold and independent ethics committees have considerable influence on both the design and implementation of clinical research and the topics of permissible research in which infants and children will participate. The composition of IECs is generally designed to provide a balance of gender, professional background, and institutional and non-institutional affiliations. In addition to these now well-established compositional guidelines, IECs that award pediatric research have a pragmatic requirement for three additional specific roles: those of in loco parentis, in loco infanti, and the special role of nursing staff. These roles and the ethical basis for them are defined. Furthermore, the role in loco parentis is ethnically complex, and an IEC considering this role must be clear about its implications. Pediatric research projects involve not only specific risks inherent to the project in question, but also more general risks inherent to any clinical research intervention effort itself. Pediatric IECs should act as a mode of encouragement, rather than simply 'medical observers', and should insist ab initio on publication of results as a condition of permission to conduct the research in question. A particularly effective form of ethical audit is the national and international peer review that follows such publication of pediatric research. This report discusses these special issues in the evolving context of increased pediatric research surveillance.

title: Ethics committees in Italy: a survey on a sample of oncologists
abstract: OBJECTIVES AND BACKGROUND: The mission of physicians and the purpose of clinical research can create a conflict between medical ethics and human rights. All recommendations, directives, and laws regarding experimental interventions require a formal protocol, Ethics Committee (EC) approval, and the written informed consent of potential participants. In Italy, in 1998 new guidelines on the handling of EC submissions were published. A year later, people involved in CE activities felt that the immediate impact of the new rules (ie decentralization and emphasis on pharmacological aspects of studies) was negative. A prospective study was launched to assess oncologists' opinions on the performance of the Italian CE. METHODS AND STUDY DESIGN: A questionnaire was administered twice to 110 oncologists involved in two multicenter trials. Nine questions were included on the following aspects: presence of an EC at the hospital level, personal experience with an EC, average time required for the evaluation of the proposals presented, and level of satisfaction with the important functions of the EC. RESULTS: Responses were received from 93 (first survey) and 69 (second survey) physicians. In both surveys, physicians reported that they were satisfied with the scientific and ethical aspects of EC operation, but dissatisfied with educational and training activities, as well as bureaucratic and administrative requirements. In the second survey, the average time required for evaluation after the presentation of a study protocol was approximately 2.4 months and the level of dissatisfaction was still high for some critical aspects such as bureaucracy (44%) and activities educational and training (64%). . The analysis of change over time documented small differences (from -8% to +7%) in all aspects evaluated. CONCLUSIONS: Despite the limitations of the present study, namely the small sample size and the intrinsic characteristics of the Italian environment, the findings add empirical evidence on the functioning of local EC and the opinions of clinical researchers. This experience confirms that empirical studies on medical ethics are feasible and can produce useful information to facilitate the implementation of EC in the medical and lay community.

title: Ethics of innovative surgery: definitions, knowledge, and attitudes of American surgeons.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Innovative surgery is not clearly defined, nor is it formally regulated by governing bodies as is the development of drugs and medical devices. This unclear status and subsequent questionable applicability of existing federal guidelines for human subjects research raise an ethical concern. To clarify their position, we solicit American surgeons' definitions, opinions, and attitudes about innovative surgery. Surgeons were also invited to self-report their knowledge of current federal regulations guiding human subjects research and the rules for informed consent and IRB review of clinical research. STUDY DESIGN: A group of US surgeons were given a 46-item questionnaire addressing the definition of innovative vs. investigational surgery and practice, regulations for research involving human subjects, the need for specific informed consent and the IRB review of surgical innovations. RESULTS: A total of 665 responses were used in the content analysis. Respondents expressed a fairly cautious stance in judging hypothetical innovative scenarios. The hallmarks of experimentation and clinical research as modes of innovation became more clearly defined for the surgical situation. CONCLUSIONS: There are defining criteria that invite further scrutiny and prior review of surgical innovations. Some forms of innovation clearly fall under current regulations for research involving human beings";" others may not fully meet the definition, but may still require additional supervision.

title: Ethics of randomized clinical trials and the 'ALARA' approach
abstract: A balanced discussion on the ethics of randomized clinical trials should not be based on a single ethical aspect such as respect for patient autonomy. Rather, the analysis must consider the four ethical principles--respect for autonomy, non-maleficence, beneficence, and justice--as applicable to all groups of people involved. We present the ethical benefits and costs of the current practice of randomized clinical trials for four groups: patients participating in clinical trials, patients not participating in trials, participating physicians, and society. The ALARA (As Low As Reasonably Achievable) approach is then introduced and practical measures are proposed to strike a positive balance between the ethical benefits and costs of randomized trials.

title: Research ethics in relation to human subjects/patients
Ethics of research with psychiatric patients: principles, problems and main responsibilities of researchers
abstract: This paper outlines some of the general issues surrounding recently published research ethics committee practice guidelines, focusing in particular on the difficulties of research involving psychiatric patients. Research is distinguished from ordinary clinical practice by the intention of advancing knowledge. Thus defined, research with psychiatric patients should be governed by the same four principles as research with any other group: knowledge, need, benefit and consent. However, in applying these principles, particularly the principle of consent, psychiatric patients present many acute difficulties. Several proposals to address these difficulties are discussed. It is suggested that, despite the value of published guidelines and the help that may be available from research ethics committees, the primary responsibility for maintaining high standards of research practice lies with the researchers themselves.

title: EUROASPIRE III: a survey of lifestyle, risk factors and the use of cardioprotective drug therapies in coronary patients from 22 European countries
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The objective of the European Action on Secondary and Primary Prevention by Intervention to Reduce Events III (EUROASPIRE III) survey was to determine whether the Joint European Societies guidelines on cardiovascular prevention are being followed in daily clinical practice and to describe the style of life, risk factor and therapeutic management in patients with coronary artery disease (CHD) in Europe. METHODS: The EUROASPIRE III survey was carried out in 2006-2007 in 76 centers in selected geographical areas in 22 countries in Europe. Consecutive patients, with a clinical diagnosis of CHD, were retrospectively identified and then followed up, interviewed, and examined at least 6 months after their coronary event. RESULTS: Thirteen thousand nine hundred thirty-five medical records (27% women) were reviewed and 8966 patients were interviewed. At interview, 17% of patients smoked cigarettes, 35% were obese and 53% centrally obese, 56% had blood pressure > or = 140/90 mmHg (> or = 130/80 in people with diabetes mellitus), 51% had serum total cholesterol > or = 4.5 mmol/l and 25% reported a history of diabetes of which 10% had fasting plasma glucose less than 6.1 mmol/l and 35% a glycated hemoglobin A1c of less than 6.5%. The use of cardioprotective medication was: antiplatelets 91%"; beta-blockers 80%; angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors/angiotensin receptor blockers 71%"; calcium channel blockers 25% and statins 78%. CONCLUSION: The EUROASPIRE III survey shows that a large proportion of coronary patients do not achieve lifestyle, risk factors and therapeutic objectives for the prevention of cardiovascular diseases. There are wide variations in the prevalence of risk factors and the use of cardioprotective pharmacological treatments between countries. There is still considerable potential across Europe to raise standards of preventive care in order to reduce the risk of recurrent disease and death in patients with CHD.

title: EUROASPIRE IV: A survey of the European Society of Cardiology on lifestyle, risk factors and therapeutic management of coronary patients in 24 European countries
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine if the guidelines of the Joint European Societies on cardiovascular prevention are being followed in daily clinical practice of secondary prevention and to describe the lifestyle, risk factors and therapeutic management of coronary patients throughout Europe. METHODS AND RESULTS: EUROASPIRE IV was a cross-sectional study conducted in 78 centers in 24 European countries. Patients /= 6 months later. A total of 16,426 medical records were reviewed and 7,998 patients (24.4% women) were interviewed. At interview, 16.0% of patients smoked cigarettes and 48.6% of those who smoked at the time of the event were persistent smokers. 59.9% reported little or no physical activity"; 37.6% were obese (BMI >/= 30 kg/m(2)) and 58.2% centrally obese (waist circumference >/= 102 cm in men or >/= 88 cm in women); 42.7% had blood pressure >/= 140/90 mmHg (>/= 140/80 in people with diabetes); 80.5% had lipoprotein cholesterol of low density >/= 1.8 mmol/l and 26.8% declared they had diabetes Cardioprotective medication was: antiplatelets 93.8%, beta-blockers 82.6%, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors/angiotensin receptor blockers 75.1%, and statins 85.7%.50.7% of the patients were advised to participate in a cardiac rehabilitation program and 81.3% of those advised attended at least half of the sessions. : The vast majority of coronary patients do not meet the standards of the guidelines for secondary prevention with a high prevalence of persistent smoking, unhealthy diets, sedentary lifestyle and, in Consequently, most patients are overweight or obese with a high prevalence of diabetes. Control of risk factors is inadequate despite reported high drug use, and there are large variations in secondary prevention practice between centers. Less than half of coronary patients access prevention and cardiac rehabilitation programs. All coronary and vascular patients require a modern preventive cardiology program, adequately adapted to the medical and cultural environment of each country, to achieve healthier lifestyles, better control of risk factors, and adherence to cardioprotective medications.

title: Evaluation of an educational intervention to improve asthma treatment in four European countries. Drug Education Project Group
abstract: In the international Drug Education Project, a new educational program for physician groups to improve the treatment of asthma patients was developed and tested in the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and Slovakia. Individualized feedback on prescribing and underlying decision strategy was presented and discussed within the group of physicians, relative to existing guidelines. In a parallel randomized controlled design, the effect on competition and actual prescribing was tested. The results were related to national guidelines. In general, the program improved physicians' attitudes as well as some of their prescribing behaviors. The proportion of patients treated with inhaled corticosteroids was significantly improved in the Netherlands (effect size 1.27), and the proportion using oral corticosteroids for treatment of exacerbations increased in both the Netherlands and Norway (effect sizes 1.99 and 0.87, respectively). General attitudes of Dutch and Norwegian doctors were also significantly improved (effect size 1.06 and 0.87, respectively), as were knowledge (effect size 1.06) and attitudes (effect size 1.49). ) regarding the treatment of exacerbations in Slovakia. In Sweden no significant improvements could be measured. In conclusion, improvements in asthma management are possible with an educational program based on self-study in small peer groups, although effects in one health care setting may not occur in another health care setting. Possible explanatory factors may be different attitudes and experiences with guidelines, as well as continuing medical education programs, and differences in opportunities for change, including prevailing trends in prescribing behaviour.

title: Evaluation of computer applications: some alternative approaches: theory, social interactionism and call for methodological pluralism
abstract: review of the evaluation literature on CDSS indicates that randomized controlled clinical trials (RCTs) are the 'gold standard' for evaluation. While this approach is excellent for studying clinical or system performance, it is not well suited to answering questions about whether or how the systems will be used. As the lack of use of CDSS has been a concern for some years, other evaluation research designs are needed to address these issues. This paper critiques RCTs and experimental evaluation approaches and presents alternative approaches to evaluation that address questions outside the scope of typical RCTs and experimental designs. A wide range of literature is summarized to illustrate the value of assessments that take into account social, organizational, professional, and contextual considerations. Many of these studies go beyond the usual measures of system performance or physician behavior by focusing on the 'fit' of the system with other aspects of professional and organizational life. Because there is little explicit theory informing many assessments, the paper then reviews CDSS assessments informed by social science theory. Finally, it proposes a theoretical basis for the social sciences of social interactionism. An example of such an approach is given. It is a CDSS in psychiatry and is based on Kaplan's 4Cs, which focus on communication, control, attention and context. Although the example is a CDSS, the evaluation approach is also useful for the implementation of clinical guidelines and other medical informatics applications. Similarly, although the discussion is about social interactionism, the most important point is the need to broaden assessment through a variety of methods and approaches that investigate social, cultural, organizational, cognitive, and contextual concerns. Methodological pluralism and a variety of research questions can increase understanding of many influences related to the development and implementation of computer applications.

title: Assessing the Efficacy of a Clinical Practice Change Intervention to Increase the Provision of Preventive Care by Physicians in a Community-Based Mental Health Services Network: A Study Protocol from an Initial Multiple Nonrandomized Trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: People with a mental illness experience substantial health disparities, including higher rates of morbidity and mortality from potentially preventable chronic conditions. One factor contributing to such a disparity is a higher prevalence of modifiable health risk behaviors, such as smoking, inadequate fruit and vegetable intake, harmful use of alcohol, and inadequate physical activity. Evidence supports the effectiveness of preventive care in reducing these risks, and the guidelines recommend that preventive care that addresses these risks be incorporated into routine clinical care. Although community-based mental health services represent an important potential setting for ensuring that people with mental illness receive such care, research suggests that their provision is currently suboptimal. A study will be conducted to assess the effectiveness of a clinical practice change intervention to increase the routine provision of preventive care by clinicians in community mental health settings. METHODS/DESIGN: A two-group multiple benchmark design will be used to assess the effectiveness of a multistrategic intervention implemented over 12 months to increase physician provision of preventive care. The intervention will be implemented sequentially across the two community mental health service clusters to increase provision of client assessment, brief counseling and referral for four health risk behaviors (smoking, inappropriate fruit and vegetable intake, harmful use of alcohol and inadequate physical activity). The outcome measures of interest will be collected through repeated cross-sectional computer-assisted telephone interviews conducted weekly for 36 months with community mental health clients. DISCUSSION: This study is the first to assess the effectiveness of a multi-strategy clinical practice change intervention to increase clinicians' provision of routine preventive care for behavioral risk factors of chronic disease within a community service network. of mental health. The results will inform future policies and practices regarding the ability of clinicians within mental health settings to improve the provision of preventive care as a result of such interventions. TESTING REGISTRY: Australian New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry (ANZCTR) ACTRN12613000693729.

title: Evaluation of the efficacy of educational interventions to prevent delirium
abstract: The aim of this study was to combine knowledge about how physicians learn with a review of educational interventions to prevent delirium in hospitalized patients. The primary objective was to assess the effectiveness of approaches to delirium education. A detailed search of educational and medical databases was performed. The type of intervention used was classified according to the PRECEED model by Green et al, using factors relevant to behavior change in health promotion. The effectiveness of the intervention was determined by assessing changes in staff performance and patient outcomes. Nineteen studies of variable design and quality were identified. Studies that used predisposing, enabling, and reinforcing strategies together were more effective in producing changes in staff behavior and patient outcomes. Education and guidelines used together or in combination have little effect. When strategies to enable and reinforce changes in clinical practice are used in conjunction with education sessions, outcomes for patients are more positive.

title: Evaluation of the Stage of Change Model for a Cervical Cancer Screening Intervention Among Ohio Appalachian Women
abstract: Cervical cancer incidence and mortality rates are disproportionately high among women living in Appalachia, Ohio. This study used the transtheoretical model to examine screening barriers before and after lay health advisor (LHA) intervention (2005-2009) to increase cervical cancer screening rates. Ohio Appalachian women (n = 90) who required a Pap smear, based on risk-appropriate guidelines, were randomized to a 10-month LHA intervention and received two face-to-face visits, two phone calls, and four mailed postcards addressed to the participant's stage of change. The results revealed that 63% had a forward stage movement 10 months after the intervention. The most frequently reported barriers to screening were time constraints, forgetting to make an appointment, and cost. Women who reported the following barriers: "doctor did not recommend the test"; not being able to pay for the test;" and being embarrassed, nervous or afraid to get a Pap test, were less likely to be in the action stage. Understanding the stages of change related to Pap testing and the reported barriers among this underserved population can help inform researchers and clinicians about preparing this population for change and how to set realistic intervention goals.

title: Assessing the Acceptance and Effects of the NHGDoc Computerized Decision Support System on Primary Care Quality: Protocol for a Large-Scale Cluster Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Computerized decision support systems (CDSS) are increasingly being used to improve quality of care. There is evidence of moderate to large effects from randomized controlled trials (RCTs), but evidence on its effectiveness when implemented nationally is lacking. In the Netherlands, the Dutch College of General Practitioners (NHG) started its successful guideline program 30 years ago. NHGDoc, a CDSS based on these NHG guidelines, which covers multiple disease areas for general practice, was developed in 2006 with the goal of improving the quality of primary care. In this document, a protocol for evaluating the acceptance and effects of NHGDoc is presented. METHODS: A group RCT will be conducted among 120 general practices in the Netherlands. Eligible general practitioners will be randomly assigned to receive NHGDoc's regular decision support modules (control arm) or regular modules plus an additional module on heart failure (intervention arm). The Heart Failure module consists of patient-specific alerts related to the management of heart failure patients. Effect evaluation will focus on performance indicators (eg, prescribing behavior) as well as patient outcomes (eg, hospital admissions) relevant to the heart failure domain. In addition, a process assessment will be conducted to gain insight into the barriers and facilitators that affect the uptake and impact of NHGDoc. DISCUSSION: The results of this study will provide insight into the uptake and impact of a CDSS covering multiple domains for primary care implemented by a national guideline organization to improve the quality of primary care. While the trial focuses on a specific domain of care, heart failure, the findings of this study will shed light on the performance of CDSS covering multiple disease areas for primary care, particularly as this study also explores factors that contribute to the acceptance and effectiveness of the system. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Clinical Trials NCT01773057.

title: Evaluation of training methods to bring contingency management to therapists
abstract: The effects of three increasingly intensive training methods on the therapist's use, knowledge, and implementation of contingency management (CM) with adolescent substance abusers were evaluated. Ten public sector mental health or substance abuse provider organizations were randomly assigned to one of three training conditions: workshop and resources (WS+), WS+ and computer-assisted training (WS+/CAT), or WS+/CAT and supervision support (WS+/CAT/SS). Across all conditions, 161 therapists participated in the training experiences, and measurements were obtained at baseline and at 2-month intervals for 12 months after workshop participation. In all training conditions, therapists reported increased use, knowledge, and adherence to CM implementation throughout the 12-month follow-up. The findings show that community doctors are willing to adopt evidence-based treatments when given access to helpful resources. Furthermore, high-quality workshops in combination with access to resources can increase knowledge of evidence-based treatment and can improve adherence to the intervention to the level necessary to improve youth outcomes.

title: Evaluation of a complex intervention to change professional behavior: the evidence-based trial (EBOR)
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To identify the effect of a complex intervention (educational outreach visits conducted by pharmacists) designed to change general practitioner (GP) prescribing at each step of a hypothetical change pathway leading to the final outcome of the primary trial of change in the prescription. METHOD: The study was carried out in six health authorities in the north of England and six in London. We describe three steps that lead to this result: general practices agree to participate"; physicians from each practice who attended the outreach visit conducted by pharmacists"; and physicians' prescribing practice is influenced by these visits. The results of each step were evaluated using a combination of quantitative and qualitative methods. RESULTS: Of the 102 randomly selected practices, 75 (73.5%) agreed to participate. The odds of all clinicians attending the outreach meeting in small practices (i.e. 1 or 2 partners) was 6.7 (95% CI 4.4 to 23.5) compared to other practices ( i.e. > 3 partners). Although pharmacists reported that they had established a good relationship in 100 (72%) first visits and had agreed management plans for 110 (79%) of these visits, they were confident that the practice would likely alter their prescription in only 41% of these visits. Pharmacists' and general practitioners' satisfaction with outreach visits did not necessarily lead to changes in prescribing after the practice visit, and general practitioners' knowledge of pharmacist-promoted guidelines did not necessarily translate into changes in prescribing. clinical practice. The main barriers to guideline implementation identified by pharmacists at follow-up visits were organizational difficulties, physician skepticism about the evidence presented to them, and physicians' lack of interest in changing their prescribing behavior. CONCLUSIONS: Although our study is limited by a post hoc rather than a pre hoc design, it provides a pragmatic approach to understanding the factors that influence the pathway of change in prescribing behavior in response to academic outreach visits.

title: Evaluation of a decision support system for the prevention and treatment of pressure ulcers: preliminary results
abstract: decision support system for pressure ulcer prevention and management was developed based on AHCPR guidelines and other sources. The system was implemented for 21 weeks in a 20-bed clinical care unit. Fifteen nurses from that unit volunteered as intervention subjects to see if the use of the system would have a positive effect on their knowledge about pressure ulcers and their ability to make decisions related to this topic. A similar care unit was used as a control. In addition, the system was evaluated by experts for its educational suitability and by end users for their satisfaction with the system. Preliminary results show no effect on knowledge about pressure ulcers or clinical decision-making skills. The system was rated positively for instructional adequacy and positively for user satisfaction. User interviews related to satisfaction complemented the quantitative findings. A discussion of the problems of performing experiments like this in today's clinical setting is included.

title: Evaluation of a dental public health program for retirees in Denmark
abstract: High priority is given to improvements in the oral health of the elderly in Scandinavia. In 1987, a Danish municipality established a dental public health program for elderly retirees. All citizens aged 67 years were offered preventive and curative care at school using the guidelines and principles established by the Danish Municipal Dental Service for children. The care was provided free of charge. Citizens who do not wish to obtain care through the public system may do so through private dentists. Reimbursement for care obtained from the private system was provided by the National Health Insurance and the municipality. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the outcome of the program after three years of operation. A follow-up design was used and data collection was done through interviews and clinical records. At baseline and during follow-up, 216 (71%) and 235 (77%) pensioners, respectively, were interviewed about their self-assessments of dental health, dental knowledge, attitudes, and behaviour. Clinical data was collected only for the elderly who participated in the public program and included 194 people at baseline and 187 at follow-up. These data included information on tooth loss, dental caries, periodontal health, and presence and function of removable dentures. At follow-up, 86 percent of all respondents had regular visits to the dentist at least once a year compared to 46 percent at baseline";" 75 percent participated in the public program and 11 percent obtained care from private doctors. At the end of the intervention period, fewer older adults reported symptoms of poor oral health or impaired denture function. (ABSTRACT TRUNCATED IN 250 WORDS)

title: Evaluation of a diabetes treatment program in primary care guided by a diabetes specialist
abstract: PURPOSE: An initial pilot program demonstrated promising results in improvements in glycated hemoglobin (HbA(1c)), low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C), and systolic blood pressure (SBP) and prompted us to test these findings in a controlled trial. The purpose of the diabetes-focused, algorithm-driven, mid-level physician-administered, electronically-led treatment program (DAMET-2) clinical trial was to investigate the benefits of a novel program for disseminating guidance in the treatment of diabetes. diabetes from a specialized clinical center to primary care centers with access to services from mid-level providers. DATA SOURCES: DAMET-2 included standardized treatment algorithms and education delivered through computer-assisted and traditional methods associated with telemedicine. Two primary care practices were selected, and subjects diagnosed with type 2 diabetes > or = 6 months, > or = 18 years of age with one or more cardiovascular risk factors (identified through chart review) were eligible for inclusion. Mid-level professionals of experimental group subjects (N = 34) received training in the American Diabetes Association treatment algorithms, had telephone consultations at 2- to 4-week intervals, and bi-monthly visits with diabetes specialists, and received treatment guidance within 24 hours from remote diabetes. Specialists Weekly diabetes clinics were made available to subjects in the experimental group. After 12 months, the latest available subject data was extracted from the subjects' medical records and compared with 12-month medical record data from a control group (N = 101) receiving no additional study services. . CONCLUSIONS: Mean HbA(1c) values decreased from baseline by 0.46% in the active treatment group versus 0.06% in the control group; however, the reductions in HbA(1c) did not reach statistical significance potentially due to the small sample size of the group. experimental group. Mean SBP values were significantly reduced in both groups; however, LDL-C was only significantly reduced in the control group, where more aggressive use of statins may have had an effect. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: Despite Inconsistencies in risk factor reduction from the pilot program, the DAMET-2 program provided information on the importance of electronic records and provider notifications, patient adherence, prioritization of provider resources by level of risk factor among patients and access to education for self-management.

title: Evaluation of a knowledge transfer scheme to improve the formulation of policies and practices in the framework of health promotion and disease prevention in French regions: a realistic study protocol
abstract: Background Evidence-based decision-making and practice are essential in public health. However, the barriers persist and are related to the properties, organizations and contexts of the evidence. To address these important knowledge transfer (TK) issues, we need to rethink how knowledge is produced and used, to improve our understanding of decision-making processes, logics, and mechanisms, and to examine the capacity of public health services to Integrate research results into your decisions and operations. This article presents a realistic evaluation protocol to evaluate an AT scheme in prevention policy and practice at the local level in France. Methods/design This study is a comparative study of multiple cases, using a realistic approach, to evaluate an RT scheme in regional health agencies (ARS) and non-profit regional organizations for education and health promotion (IREPS) , through the analysis of the configurations contexts/mechanisms/results of the same. The assessed KT scheme is designed for the use of six reviews of systematic reviews on the following topics: nutrition, alcohol, smoking, physical activity, emotional and sexual life, and psychosocial skills. It combines the following activities: supporting the access and adaptation of scientific and usable evidence"; strengthening the skills of professionals to analyze, adopt and use evidence in the course of their practices and their decision-making process"; facilitating the use of evidence in organizations and processes. RAMESE II reporting standards were used for realistic assessments. Discussion The objectives of this study are to experiment with and characterize factors related to the scheme's ability to enable public health stakeholders to address AT challenges and integrate scientific knowledge into policy and practice. We will use the realist approach to document the parameters of successful RT strategies in the specific contexts of preventive health services in France, while seeking to determine the transferability of such strategies.

title: Evaluation of a novel individualized communication skills training intervention to improve clinicians' confidence and skills in communication at the end of life
abstract: BACKGROUND: We developed a novel individualized training program regarding end-of-life communication designed to be time-effective for busy young physicians working in hospital settings. OBJECTIVE: Our aim was to test this brief one-on-one training program with young doctors to explore its acceptability, feasibility, and effect on clinician confidence, communication skills, attitudes toward psychosocial care, and burnout. DESIGN: The content of the training intervention was informed by a systematic review of the literature and evidence-based clinical practice guidelines regarding communication at the end of life. The intervention was based on sound educational principles and involved three one-hour teaching sessions over a three-week period, including two one-on-one sessions with an expert facilitator and a simulated patient/caregiver. In addition, participants received written and audiovisual learning materials to take home. PARTICIPANTS were videotaped consulting with a simulated patient/caregiver before and after the training to assess the impact of the course on their communication behaviors. PARTICIPANTS completed de-identified questionnaires before and after training, including self-assessment of confidence, attitudes towards psychosocial care, and the Maslach Burnout inventory. PARTICIPANTS: PARTICIPANTS included 22 attending physicians from a large teaching hospital in Sydney, Australia. RESULTS: All participants reported that the training was useful, it had been helpful in their communication with patients, and that they would recommend the training to others. Significant improvements were found in the communication skills of the participants (in seven of the 21 specific communication behaviors and in the three global ones evaluated, range P=0.02 to <0.001), confidence in communication on relevant topics (P< 0.001), attitudes towards psychosocial care (P=0.03) and sense of personal fulfillment (P=0.043). There were no overall differences in the participants' levels of exhaustion. CONCLUSION: This intervention shows promise and warrants further formal evaluation.

title: Evaluation of a physician-focused educational intervention in Medicaid children with asthma
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 mandated drug utilization review in response to inappropriate drug use. In the Pennsylvania Medicaid program, pediatric asthma is associated with high health care utilization and cost. OBJECTIVE: To determine the effects of a physician-focused educational intervention on asthma medication use and health care utilization. METHODS: A pre-post intervention comparison design was used for children 5 to 18 years of age who were enrolled in the Pennsylvania Medicaid fee-for-service program from July 1, 1998 through March 31, 1998. 1999 (before the intervention) and July 1, 1999. 1999, to March 31, 2000 (post-intervention). The intervention package included the patients' medication profiles, medical history, a national asthma management guideline monograph, and patient education materials for clinicians. The main outcome measures are changes in asthma medication use among heavy users of short-acting beta (2) agonists (SABs). RESULTS: The intervention focused on 2 criteria of asthma medication use: (1) high use of quick-relief medications and (2) use of salmeterol without the availability of a quick-relief medication. The intervention reduced quick-relief medication use by 26% among patients with the highest use without significant changes in long-term control medications. In addition, 82% of recipients evaluated had a positive change in salmeterol use, either because a SAB inhaler was added post-intervention or salmeterol was discontinued post-intervention. There were no significant changes in emergency department visits or hospitalizations related to asthma. CONCLUSIONS: Although the responding physicians agreed on the usefulness of the educational materials, the results suggest that the intervention had limited success in improving pharmacological management and no effect on health outcomes. We believe that educational materials mailed to physicians can be effective in changing prescribing behavior";" however, a more multifaceted intervention may be needed to improve health outcomes.

title: Evaluation of a personalized intervention to improve the management of overweight and obesity in primary care: study protocol of a cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: In the UK, around 22% of men and 24% of women are obese, with varying but worrying levels in other European countries. Obesity is a chronic condition that carries a significant health risk. The National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE, 2006) has published national guidelines, for use in England, on the treatment of overweight or obese people. The NICE recommendations for primary care teams are: determine the degree of overweight and obesity"; assess lifestyle, comorbidities and willingness to change; offer multicomponent management of overweight and obesity; refer to external services when This study investigates a tailored intervention to improve implementation of these recommendations by primary care teams.METHODS/DESIGN: The study is a cluster randomized controlled trial.Primary care teams will be recruited from the East Midlands of England and will be randomized into two arms of the study: 1) the study arm, in which primary care teams are offered a set of tailored interventions to help implement the NICE guidelines for overweight and obesity;" or 2) the control group in which primary care teams continue to practice usual care. The primary outcome is the proportion of overweight or obese patients for whom the primary care team adheres to the NICE guidelines. Secondary outcomes include the proportion of patients with a lifestyle assessment record, referral to external weight loss services, the proportion of obese patients who lose weight during the intervention period, and the mean weight change during the same period. . DISCUSSION: Although often recommended, methods for tailoring implementation interventions to take into account determinants of practice are not well developed. This study is part of a study program that seeks to develop custom implementation methods. TESTING RECORD: Current Controlled Testing ISRCTN07457585. Registered on 09/08/2013. Randomization began on 08/30/2013.

title: Evaluation of a set of tools to improve the detection and treatment of cardiovascular diseases in people with type 2 diabetes: protocol for a pragmatic cluster-randomized trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: The gap between the level of care recommended by evidence-based clinical practice guidelines and the actual care provided to patients in practice has been well established. The Canadian Diabetes Association (CDA) created an implementation strategy to improve implementation of its 2008 guidelines. This study will assess the impact of the strategy in improving the detection, prevention, and treatment of cardiovascular disease (CVD) for people with diabetes. DESIGN: A pragmatic cluster-randomized trial will be conducted to evaluate CDA's CVD toolkit. All family physicians in Ontario, Canada, were randomly assigned to receive the toolkit, which includes several printed educational materials aimed at CVD detection, prevention and treatment, either in the spring of 2009 (intervention arm) or in spring 2010 (control arm). Randomization occurred at the practice level. Forty GPs from each arm will be recruited to participate, and the medical records of 20 of their diabetic patients at high CVD risk will be retrospectively reviewed. Outcome measures will be assessed for each patient between July 2009 and March 2010. The main outcome will be that the patient is receiving a statin. Secondary outcomes will include 1) receipt of an ACE inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker, 2) various intermediate measures (A1c, blood pressure, LDL cholesterol, total/HDL cholesterol ratio, body mass index and waist circumference), and 3) clinical inertia (the inability to change therapy in response to an abnormal A1c, blood pressure, or cholesterol reading). The analysis will be carried out using multilevel hierarchical logistic regression models to take into account the pooled nature of the data. The assignment of the group will be a variable at the medical level. Additionally, a process evaluation study with six focus groups of family physicians will assess the acceptability of the CDA Toolkit and explore the factors that contribute to any change or lack of change in behavior, from the perspective of family physicians. DISCUSSION: Printed educational materials for physicians have been shown to make small to moderate changes in patient care. CDA's CVD Toolkit is an example of a practice guideline implementation strategy that can be disseminated to a wide audience at relatively low cost, so demonstrating its effectiveness in improving diabetes care could have important implications for guideline developers, policymakers and clinicians.

title: Evaluation of abnormal mammography results and palpable breast abnormalities
abstract: Background: Because approximately 1 in 10 women with a breast lump or abnormal mammogram will have breast cancer, a primary care physician must make a number of decisions to exclude or establish a diagnosis of breast cancer. among these women. Purpose: To determine the most accurate and least invasive means of evaluating an abnormal mammography result and a palpable breast abnormality. Data Source: MEDLINE search (January 1966 to March 2003) for articles and reviews describing the accuracy of clinical examination, biopsy procedures, and radiographic examination of patients with abnormal mammography results or palpable breast abnormalities. Study Selection: The authors reviewed abstracts and selected articles that provided relevant primary data. Studies were included if 1) a mammogram, fine-needle aspiration biopsy, or core needle biopsy was performed before a definitive diagnosis"; 2) the study sample included 100 or more women"; and 3) breast cancer status was determined from histopathologic review of excisional biopsy specimens, linkage to a state cancer registry or Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results program, or 95-year clinical follow-up. % or more of the study sample. Data Extraction: One investigator abstracted the results. Methods were assessed for important potential biases, but methodological scoring was not performed. Data synthesis: odds ratios for first screening mammography were 0.1 for the Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) assessment category negative or benign, 1.2 for probably benign finding, 7 due to the need for additional imaging evaluation, 125 due to suspicious abnormality and 2200 due to high suggestion of malignancy. For fine-needle aspiration biopsy of a palpable lump performed by formally trained clinicians, the odds ratio was infinity for an evaluation of malignant, 2.6 for atypical/suspicious, and 0.02 for benign. When diagnostic mammography was used to evaluate a palpable lump or nonpalpable breast abnormality, the positive odds ratios were 5.6 and 9.4, and the negative odds ratios were 0.15 and 0.19, respectively. suggestive of malignancy are at high risk of breast cancer and should undergo core needle biopsy or needle localization with surgical biopsy. Women whose screening mammography results are interpreted as needing further imaging evaluation are at moderate risk for breast cancer and should undergo a diagnostic mammogram or ultrasound to decide whether to biopsy an unexplained breast lesion. palpable. Women whose screening mammogram results are interpreted as probably benign are at low risk for breast cancer and can have a follow-up mammogram in 6 months. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy or ultrasound is recommended as the first diagnostic test for a palpable breast abnormality to distinguish simple cysts from solid masses. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy also allows characterization of a solid mass. Diagnostic mammography does not help determine whether a palpable breast mass should be biopsied and should not affect the decision to perform a biopsy.

title: Evaluation of an informative brochure on AIDS/HIV infection aimed at primary health care professionals in Catalonia
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the understanding and acceptance of a regular information brochure on HIV/AIDS by primary care professionals. DESIGN: Crossed. Setting: Primary care teams of the Institut Catala de la Salut. PARTICIPANTS: A random sample of 300 physicians, registered nurses, and social workers. INTERVENTION: An anonymous self-administered questionnaire returned by regular mail. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: The questions covered the following thematic areas: clinical care of people infected with HIV/AIDS and requests for diagnostic tests for infection, perception of skills in promoting changes in the sexual behavior of patients and drug use , provide psychological support and guidelines for the integration of HIV-positive children in schools and information on social resources. 60% were aware of the publication. The thematic areas that aroused the most interest were: psychological support for affected people, prevention of HIV infection in the health field, clinical advice and diagnosis. 77% had received requests for diagnostic tests and 88% had treated infected people. CONCLUSIONS: Despite the low response rate (50%) and the relative variability between the professionals and the health regions of origin, this first evaluation made it possible to identify specific educational needs in the care and prevention of HIV/AIDS infection in primary education. framework of care and also to improve the distribution methods we use.

title: Evaluation of an Internet-based decision support system to apply the ATS/CDC guidelines for tuberculosis preventive therapy.
abstract: Preventive therapy for patients infected with tuberculosis (TB) remains an important component of TB control. To guide clinicians in applying preventive therapy, the American Thoracic Society and the Centers for Disease Control (ATS/CDC) developed guidelines based on PPD reactivity and pre-test probability of infection. The guidelines have become complex and many clinicians find their application difficult. The authors developed a computerized decision support system to help clinicians apply the ATS/CDC guidelines. This tool, published on the World Wide Web using hypertext markup language, provides patient-specific recommendations based on patient-specific information provided by the physician. Four local TB experts derived eight TB infection scenarios and validated the web-based tool, whose efficacy was tested with general internal medicine residents randomly divided into two groups. Group A (n = 12) used the web-based tool and Group B (n = 17) used preexisting understanding of guidelines and/or written resources to determine the need for preventive therapy in case scenarios. Group A correctly used the therapy in 92/96 possible cases (95.8%), group B only in 77/136 (56.6%) (p < 0.001). Group A required an average of three mouse clicks and 1.5 minutes per scenario to get to their options, and they rated the web-based tool as intuitive and effective. These data demonstrate that a computer-based decision support system for applying TB treatment guidelines can be delivered over the Internet and provide an efficient and effective resource for clinicians.

title: Evaluation of risk graph and computer-based clinical decision support system for the management of hypertension in primary care: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Objectives: To investigate the effect of a computerized clinical decision support system and a risk chart on absolute cardiovascular risk, blood pressure, and prescription of cardiovascular drugs in hypertensive patients. Design: Cluster randomized controlled trial. Location: 27 general practices in Avon. Participants: 614 patients aged between 60 and 79 years with arterial hypertension. INTERVENTIONS: Patients were randomized to a computer-based clinical decision support system plus cardiovascular risk chart"; cardiovascular risk chart alone;" or usual care. Main outcome measures: Percentage of patients in each group with a 5-year cardiovascular risk = 10%, systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure, cardiovascular drug prescription. Results: Patients in the computer-based clinical decision support system and charts-only groups were no more likely to have cardiovascular risk reduced below 10% than patients receiving usual care. Patients in the computer-based clinical decision support group were more likely to have cardiovascular risk = 10% than patients with graphs alone, odds ratio 2.3 (95% confidence interval 1.1 to 4 ,8). The chart-only group had significantly lower systolic blood pressure compared to the usual care group (mean difference: 4.6 mm Hg (95% confidence interval: 8.4 to -0.8). reduction in diastolic blood pressure did not differ between the three groups The chart-only group was twice as likely to be prescribed two classes of cardiovascular medications and more than three times as likely to be prescribed three or more classes of medications compared to the other groups in absolute risk reduction or blood pressure control and requires further development and evaluation before its use in clinical care can be recommended. potentially important increase in systolic blood pressure.

title: Evaluation of Internet-based clinical decision support systems.
abstract: Background: Evidence-based clinical guidelines are increasingly being used to educate clinicians and improve quality of care. While individual guidelines are potentially helpful, repeated studies have shown guidelines to be ineffective in changing physician behavior. The Internet has evolved as a potentially useful tool for guideline education, dissemination, and implementation due to its open standards and its ability to provide relevant and concise clinical information where and when it is needed. Objective: Our objective was to develop and test guidelines-based decision support systems (DSS) that could be delivered over the Internet for two disease models: preventive therapy for asthma and tuberculosis (TB). Methods: Using open HTML and CGI standards, we developed an acute asthma severity assessment DSS and a tuberculosis preventive treatment DSS based on the content of national guidelines that are recognized as standards of care. Both DSS are published on the Internet and work through a decision algorithm developed from the main guidelines with clinical information provided by the user at the point of clinical care. We tested the effectiveness of each DSS in influencing clinician decisions through clinical scenario testing. Results: We first validated the asthma algorithm by comparing the decisions of asthma experts with the decisions made by non-pulmonary nurses using the computerized DSS. Using the DSS, nurses scored the same as experts (89% vs. 88%"; p = NS). Using the same scenario test instrument, we then compared internal medicine residents using the DSS with residents using a paper version of the National Asthma Education Program Guidelines 2. Residents using the computerized DSS scored significantly better than residents using the paper guidelines (92% vs. 84%; p < 0.002). ; residents who used the computerized DSS scored significantly better (95.8% vs. 56.6% correct;" p<0.001). Conclusions: Previous work has shown that guidelines disseminated through traditional educational interventions have a minimal impact on medical behavior. Although computerized DSSs have been effective in changing physician behavior, many of these systems are not widely available. We have developed two clinical DSS based on national guidelines and published them on the Internet. Both systems improved physician compliance with national guidelines when tested in clinical settings. By providing information that is coupled to relevant activity, we hope that these widely available DSSs will serve as effective educational tools to positively impact medical behavior.

title: Evaluation of studies investigating the effectiveness of pharmacists' clinical services
abstract: quantitative evaluation of randomized trials of advice, education and other clinical services provided by pharmacists was conducted. Data sources were MEDLINE and bibliographies of published articles. Pharmacists' services were categorized as patient counseling, physician counseling, patient and physician counseling, and patient care. The outcomes extracted were measures of patient behavior, illness, symptoms, and patient knowledge. Thirty-two trials met the inclusion criteria. Pharmacists were specified as clinical pharmacists in 24 trials and as community pharmacists in 2. In six unblinded patient counseling trials, results favored counseled patients over control patients in each trial, and effects were statistically significant in five trials (outcome was medication adherence in these five trials). In seven trials counseling both patients and their doctors, patient outcomes were significantly better in the intervention group in six trials, four of which were single-blinded. Two trials in which patients were randomized to medical advice or control groups gave inconsistent results. In a trial in which doctors were randomized to receive advice from pharmacists, the proportion of prescriptions that met the guidelines was higher in the advice group than in the control group. Four trials of patient care by pharmacists were inconclusive. These trials demonstrated that counseling of patients and their doctors by pharmacists can improve patient outcomes. The evidence that patient counseling alone improved patient outcomes was good, although weaker due to suboptimal trial design.

title: Evaluation of Talking Parents, Healthy Teens, a new workplace-based parenting program to promote parent-teen communication about sexual health: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: PURPOSE To evaluate a workplace-based parenting program, Parents Who Talk, Healthy Teens, designed to help parents learn how to address sexual health with their teens. DESIGN Randomized controlled trial (April 2002 to December 2005). SCENARIO 13 job sites in Southern California. PARTICIPANTS 569 parents completed job reference surveys, gave permission for confidential surveys to be published for their teens, and were randomly assigned to intervention or control groups. Parents and teens completed follow-up surveys one week, three months, and nine months after the program. INTERVENTION Talking Parents, Healthy Teens consists of eight weekly one-hour sessions in workplaces for parents of adolescent children in grades 6-10 (approximately 11-16 years of age). MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Parent-adolescent communication on a list of sexual topics; if the parent taught the teen how to use a condom; ability to communicate with parent/adolescent about sex; openness of parent-adolescent communication about sex. RESULTS Differences between intervention and control groups were significant for the mean number of new sexual topics that parents and adolescents reported having discussed between baseline and each follow-up (P < 0.001 for each); intervention parents were less likely than controls not to discuss any new topics (8% vs. 29%, 95% confidence interval for a difference of 16% to 24%) and more likely to discuss seven or more topics new (38% vs. 8%, 19% to 41%) at nine months. Some differences increased after completing the program: at one week after the program, 18% of adolescents in the intervention group and 3% in the control group (6% to 30%) said that their parents had reviewed how using a condom from baseline (P<0.001);" this increased to 29% vs. 5% (13% to 36%) at nine months (P<0.001). Compared to controls at nine months, Parents and adolescents in the intervention group reported greater ability to communicate with each other about sex (P < 0.001) and greater openness in communication about sex (P < 0.001). may have substantial effects on parent-adolescent communication about sexual health TRIAL REGISTRATION Clinical Trials NCT00465010.

title: Evaluation of two school education programs on smoking in normal classroom conditions
abstract: OBJECTIVES To assess the effectiveness of two school tobacco education projects in delaying smoking initiation and improving health knowledge, beliefs, and values. DESIGN Randomized controlled trial by conglomerates of two projects taught under normal classroom conditions. Schools were assigned to one of four groups to receive the Family Tobacco Education (FSE) Project; the Smoking and Me (SAM) Project; Both Projects in Sequence (FSE/SAM);" or no intervention at all. SCENARIO 39 schools in Wales and England match in size and recruitment profile. SUBJECTS All first-year school students were included and assessed on three occasions (4538 before teaching (1988), 3930 immediately after teaching (1989), 3786 at follow-up year (1990)). MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Self-reported smoking behavior (supported by a saliva sample) and change in relevant health knowledge, beliefs, and values. RESULTS No consistent significant differences were found in smoking behavior, health knowledge, beliefs, or values between the four groups. For never smokers at baseline, the rate of never smokers in 1990 was 74% (594/804) in the control group, 65% (455/704) in the FSE group, 70% ( 440/625) in the SAM group, and 69% (549/791) in the FSE/SAM group (chi 2adj = 6.1, df = 3, p = 0.1). Knowledge about the effects of smoking increased in all groups from a mean score of 5.4 in 1988 to 6.4 in 1989 and 6.5 in 1990. CONCLUSIONS More comprehensive interventions than health education will be needed to reduce adolescent smoking school only. Other measures should be considered, including new restrictions on access to cigarettes and the promotion of tobacco products. More research will be needed to develop effective school-based health education projects, which need to be formally tested in the field under normal conditions before widespread dissemination.

title: Evidence-based behavioral medicine: what is it and how do we get it?
abstract: The goal of evidence-based medicine is ultimately to improve patient outcomes and quality of care. Systematic reviews of the available published evidence are required to identify interventions that lead to improvements in behaviour, health and well-being. Authoritative reviews of the literature depend on the quality of published research and research reports. The Consolidated Statement of Standards for Reporting Trials (CONSORT) (www.consort-statement.org) was developed to improve the design and reporting of interventions involving randomized clinical trials (RCTs) in medical journals. We describe the 22 CONSORT guidelines and explain their application to behavioral medicine research and evidence-based practice. Additional guidelines specific to behavioral medicine (eg, adherence to treatment) are also presented. Use of these guidelines by clinicians, educators, policymakers, and researchers designing, reporting, and evaluating or reviewing RCTs will strengthen the research itself and accelerate efforts to apply behavioral medicine research to improve clinical processes and outcomes. behavioral medicine practice.

title: Evidence-based care of older people with suspected cognitive impairment in general practice: protocol for the IRIS cluster randomized trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Dementia is a common and complex condition. There are evidence-based guidelines for the management of people with dementia in general practice";" however, dementia screening, diagnosis, and outreach have been identified as potential gaps between evidence and practice. Interventions to implement the guidelines in practice have had variable success. The use of theory in the design of implementation interventions has been limited, but it is recommended because of its potential to generate more effective interventions and to help understand the factors that modify the magnitude of intervention effects in trials. This protocol describes the methods of a randomized trial testing a theory-based implementation intervention that, if effective, may provide benefits for people with dementia and their carers. OBJECTIVES: This trial aims to estimate the effectiveness of a theory-based intervention to increase adherence of GPs (in Victoria, Australia) to a clinical guideline for the detection, diagnosis and management of dementia in general practice. compared to providing GPs with a hard copy of the guideline. Primary objectives include assessing whether the intervention is effective in increasing the percentage of patients with suspected cognitive impairment who receive care according to two key guideline recommendations: receipt of ai) formal cognitive assessment, and ii) assessment of depression using a validated scale (primary outcomes for the test). METHODS: The design is a parallel cluster randomized trial, with the clusters being general practice. Our goal is to recruit 60 practices per group. Practices will be randomized into intervention and control groups using restricted randomisation. Patients who meet the inclusion criteria, and the screening and diagnostic behaviors of GPs directed at these patients, will be identified and measured through an electronic search of medical records nine months after the start of the intervention. Physicians in the control group will receive a printed copy of the guideline. In addition to receiving the printed guide, professionals from the intervention group will be invited to participate in an interactive face-to-face educational workshop led by opinion leaders. The theory-based intervention aims to address the identified barriers and facilitators to the implementation of the recommendations. The investigators responsible for identifying the cohort of patients with suspected cognitive impairment and their screening and diagnostic results will not know the group assignment. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australia and New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry: ACTRN12611001032943 (registration date 28 September 2011).

title: Evidence-based guidelines for teaching patient-centered interviewing
abstract: In a rare study of the effectiveness of an interview method, we previously reported a randomized controlled trial that demonstrated that training in a patient-centered, step-by-step interview method improved residents' knowledge, attitudes, and skills. and had a consistent positive effect on trained patients. resident patients. For those who wish to use this evidence-based, patient-centered approach as a model for their own teaching, we describe here for the first time our training program and propose that the training can be adapted for students, physicians, nurse practitioners, physician assistants, and other new students as well. The training was skills-oriented and experiential, fostered positive attitudes toward patient-centered interviewing, and used a student-centered approach that paid particular attention to the teacher-resident relationship and resident self-awareness. Skills training was guided by a recently identified patient-centered interview method that described the step-by-step use of specific behaviors.

title: Evidence-based guidelines for the treatment of bipolar disorder: revised recommendations from the third edition of the British Association for Psychopharmacology.
abstract: The British Association for Psychopharmacology guidelines specify the scope and goals of treatment for bipolar disorder. The third version is explicitly based on the available evidence and is presented, like the previous Clinical Practice Guidelines, as recommendations to help professionals make clinical decisions: it can also serve as a source of information for patients and carers, and help in the audit. The recommendations are presented together with a more detailed review of the corresponding evidence. A consensus meeting, involving experts in bipolar disorder and its treatment, reviewed key areas and considered the strength of the evidence and the clinical implications. The guidelines were written after extensive feedback from these participants. The best evidence from randomized controlled trials and, where available, observational studies using quasi-experimental designs were used to assess treatment options. The strength of the recommendations has been described using the GRADE approach. The guidelines cover the diagnosis of bipolar disorder, clinical management, and strategies for the use of medications in short-term treatment of episodes, relapse prevention, and treatment discontinuation. Medication use is integrated with a consistent approach to psychoeducation and behavior change.

title: Evidence-based children's health care: what are we missing?
abstract: With comprehensive health reform enacted, reimbursement for a variety of health care services will likely depend on the evidence supporting that provision. Understanding what constitutes "evidence" will have a profound effect on the range of clinical care provided. Too narrow a definition can have a considerable impact on pediatric care in particular: much of today's child health care requires consideration of a broader body of evidence that is often relied upon when developing clinical guidelines. This is especially true for care that addresses behavioral and developmental issues. The current standard for evaluating the evidence uses study design as an indicator of the quality of the evidence";" therefore, it may inadvertently exclude many important findings and not support further relevant research. The project described here generated a new and broader framework for evaluating clinical practice, which should be of value to clinicians and policymakers alike.

title: Evidence-based medicine and management of headache patients by general practitioners in Italy
abstract: The study explores knowledge of technical terms used in evidence-based medicine (EBM) and how to treat migraine patients among a random sample of 500 general practitioners (GPs). A mailed questionnaire included questions on demographics and practice characteristics of GPs"; knowledge of EBM; sources of information on migraine and EBM"; and the treatment behavior of the patient. Only 27.2% of GPs agreed that clinical trials are needed to assess the efficacy of treatments, and this awareness was higher among those who learned about migraine from scientific journals or continuing education courses and who attended courses about MBE. For two-thirds of GPs, disability is equivalent to a diagnosis of disease, and this behavior was more frequent in those who agreed that clinical trials are needed to evaluate the efficacy of preventive or curative treatments for migraine and that the approach migraine clinician requires evaluation. of clinical effectiveness, in which they treated a smaller number of patients with headache, in those who were older and in those who did not use guidelines. The majority (93.1%) of the doctors indicated that it is important to integrate clinical practice and the best available evidence, and this behavior was significantly more frequent in those who agreed that the clinical approach to migraine required an evaluation of the effectiveness clinic, that clinical trials necessary to evaluate the efficacy of preventive or curative treatments for migraine are being carried out, and in those who attended MBE courses. Training and continuing education programs on EBM and headache treatment guidelines for GPs are much needed.

title: Evidence-based medicine and women: do EBM principles and practice improve women's health?
abstract: Physicians and policymakers around the world are embracing evidence-based medicine (EBM). The promise of EBM is to use summaries of research evidence to determine which health care interventions are effective and which are not, so that patients can benefit from effective interventions and be protected from useless or harmful ones. EBM provides an ostensibly rational, objective means of deciding whether or not an intervention should be provided on the basis of its efficacy, which in theory leads to fair and effective health care for all. In this article, I take a closer look at these claims from the perspective of women's health care, using relevant examples. I argue that current evidence-based medicine processes contain a number of biases against women. These biases occur in the production of research that informs evidence-based medicine, in the methods used to analyze and synthesize evidence, and in the application of EBM through the use of guidelines. Finally, the biomedical model of health that underpins most of the medical research used by EBM ignores the social and political context that contributes so much to women's poor health.

title: Evidence based medicine. Interpretation of studies and establishment of policies
abstract: The rise of EBM has been accompanied by a heightened awareness of its shortcomings. It is becoming increasingly apparent from the cost, length and difficulty of conducting RCTs that studies cannot be initiated to address all questions in medicine. Good evidence is often lacking in medicine. Epistemologists question the very notions of evidence and the adequacy of current study designs and measurement tools to investigate the salient issues of concern to patients and other quality-conscious people. Lack of evidence of efficacy does not prove ineffectiveness; however, in reaction to EBM, insurance companies and the government often make this inference to justify decisions to withhold coverage or support research. The unbridled enthusiasm for evidence-based practice guidance from the early 1990s has been tempered by a more mature understanding of its limitations. Not many practice guidelines are well developed, and implementation of faulty guidelines can cause harm. The seven-step process outlined above is slow, laborious, and expensive (sometimes running into the hundreds of thousands of dollars). Furthermore, there is little evidence that the rigor of the methods or the guidelines themselves have a significant effect on practice behavior or patient outcomes. To the most cynical observer, the only consistent beneficiaries of the guidelines are the payers, who use the guidelines with considerable success in reducing costs, length of stay, and utilization rates. Even staunch guideline advocates acknowledge the evidence that dissemination of reviews and recommendations alone fails to motivate clinicians to increase delivery of effective interventions and abandon ineffective ones. This lack of response has stimulated a closer look at the barriers to behavior change and the design of thoughtful implementation strategies that start with simple guidelines, but go further. Tools such as reminder systems, standing orders, academic details, peer review and auditing, feedback, and health system changes recognize that knowing what to do is just one piece of an increasingly complex puzzle. The competitive market for managed care has added new economic influences on physician behavior, but it is also fueling private sector interest in good research. Patients, doctors, and policymakers will continue to seek better data on what works in medicine and what doesn't.

title: Analytical Quality Review of Behavioral Health Randomized Clinical Trials
abstract: The adoption of an evidence-based practice (EBP) policy has implications for both clinicians and researchers. In fields that have already adopted EBP, evidence-based practice guidelines are derived from systematic reviews of research evidence. Ultimately, such guidelines serve as tools used by professionals. Systematic reviews of treatment efficacy and effectiveness reserve their strongest support for treatments that are backed by high-quality randomized clinical trials (RCTs). It is unknown how well RCTs reported in behavioral science journals compare to established quality standards in fields that pioneered the evidence-based movement. We compared the analytical quality characteristics of all behavioral health RCTs (n = 73) published in three leading behavioral journals and two leading medical journals between January 2000 and July 2003. One behavioral health trial was launched as one that employs a behavioral treatment modality to prevent or treat an acute or chronic disease or physical condition. The findings revealed areas of weakness in the analytical aspects of the behavioral health RCTs reported in both sets of journals. Weaknesses were more pronounced in behavioral journals. The authors offer recommendations for improving the analytical quality of behavioral health RCTs to ensure that evidence on behavioral treatments is given high weight in systematic reviews.

title: Examination of clinical judgment in an adaptive intervention design: the fast track program
abstract: Although clinical judgment is often used in assessment and treatment planning, research has rarely examined its reliability, validity, or impact in practice settings. This study tailored the frequency of home visits in a prevention program for disruptive-aggressive children (n = 410";" 56% minority) based on 2 types of clinical judgment: ratings of parent functioning using a standardized scale multi-item and comprehensive assessments of family need for services. Higher reliability and better concurrent and predictive validity emerged for the first type of clinical judgment than for the second.
