Exploratory analyzes suggested that the use of parent functioning ratings to tailor treatment recommendations improved the impact of the intervention at the end of third grade, but the use of more global assessments of family needs did not.

title: Exceptional Births: Home Births as Ethical Anomalies in American Obstetrics
abstract: Interest in home birth appears to be growing among American women, and most obstetricians can expect to find patients considering home birth. In 2011, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) issued an opinion statement intended to guide obstetricians in responding to such patients. In this article, I examine the ACOG statement in light of the historical and contemporary clinical realities surrounding home birth in the United States, an examination guided in part by my own experiences as an obstetrician with favorable and unfavorable home births. medical means. Comparison with other guidelines indicates that ACOG treats home birth as an ethical exception: comparable evidence leads to strikingly different recommendations in the case of home birth and the case of trial of labor after prior cesarean section";" and ACOG treats other controversial topics involving similar ethical issues quite differently. By presenting the provision of information as not only the primary but the sole ethical responsibility of the obstetrician, the ACOG statement obviates the responsibilities of obstetricians to provide appropriate clinical care and create the safest possible clinical environment for those mothers who choose intrauterine delivery. home and for their newborns. . What, at first glance, appears to be a statement of respect for women's autonomy implicitly authorizes behavior that unethically restricts truly autonomous choices. I argue that obstetricians do not need to attend home births. However, our ethical duties compel us to (1) refer clients to trained physicians who will deliver at home, (2) continue respectful prenatal care for those women who choose home birth, (3) provide appropriate consultation to home midwives, and (4) to ensure that transfers of care are seamless and non-punitive.

title: Reference to exercise: the public health panacea for the promotion of physical activity? A critical perspective of exercise reference schemes";" its development and evaluation
abstract: This review critically explores the development, impact and evaluation of exercise referral schemes (ERS) in the UK. There has been a rapid expansion in the use of such ERS in leisure and primary care settings, but the evidence supporting their implementation has been sparse and predominantly limited to the research design of randomized controlled trials (RCTs). Consequently, understanding of exercise referral as a 'real world' intervention has been limited. Given the increasing importance placed on evidence-based practice and clinical effectiveness, it is no longer enough for exercise referral service providers to ignore the need to evaluate schemes. The assessment guidelines provided by the National Quality Assurance Framework for Exercise Reference are limited, so practitioners are often unsure of the best measures to assess effectiveness. Predominantly, exercise professionals focus on physiological data collection, but tend to ignore relevant psychological and environmental parameters. Furthermore, few studies from the UK have followed participants long-term, to see if physical activity behavior is maintained over time. Here, we describe the evidence from two ongoing large-scale (n = 1600/year) evaluation studies of baseline exercise regimens, based on urban locations in the North West of England. A participatory action research framework was used for the evaluation, and multi-method research approaches were incorporated for the evaluation of both HRA participants and health professionals involved in implementing the intervention. This framework is an appropriate methodology for the evaluation and development of complex interventions, and here incorporates case studies, focus groups, interviews, and survey questionnaires. We included a 12-month follow-up study of a cohort of exercise reference participants (n = 342), which measured physical activity levels at leisure time (Godin's leisure time score), at baseline (entry to exercise baseline) and at 3-month intervals thereafter. Adherence to the ERS was approximately 35% to 45%, and older participants were more likely to complete it. The physiological changes during the ERS, although statistically significant, were not of a magnitude that conveyed any real health benefit to an individual's health status. Although small in scale, the physiological changes were all in a positive direction (eg, reduction in blood pressure) and, if sustained over time, could lead to population-level health benefits. Participants referred by specialist and cardiac nurses had higher levels of adherence than participants referred by general practitioners. Scheme B showed that participants who adhered (n = 103) until the end of the ERS (12 weeks) were able to maintain a small increase in physical activity at the end of 12 months (increase of 21 min moderate activity/week in comparison with base). In conclusion, this research shows that the exercise bypass process benefits certain segments of the population, but not necessarily all.

title: Expanded HIV Screening in the United States: Effect on Clinical Outcomes, HIV Transmission, and Costs
abstract: Background: An extensive literature supports the expansion of HIV screening in the United States. However, the question of whom to test and how often remains controversial. Objective: To inform the design of HIV screening programs by identifying combinations of screening frequency and HIV prevalence and incidence in which screening is cost-effective. Design: Cost-benefit analysis linking HIV screening simulation models to published reports of the risk of HIV transmission, with and without antiretroviral therapy. Data sources: Published randomized trials, observational cohorts, national surveys of service utilization and costs, the Red Book, and results from previous models. Target Population: US communities with low to moderate HIV prevalence (0.05% to 1.0%) and annual incidence (0.0084% to 0.12%). Time horizon: lifetime. Perspective: Social. Interventions: Voluntary once-increasing HIV screening of all adults using a same-day rapid test. Outcome measures: HIV infections detected, secondary transmissions averted, quality-adjusted survival, lifetime medical costs, and societal returns, reported in discounted 2004 dollars per quality-adjusted life year (QALY) gained. Base-case analysis results: Under moderately favorable assumptions regarding the effect of care for HIV patients on secondary transmission, screening for HIV in a population with an HIV prevalence of 1.0% and an annual incidence of 0.12% had an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio of $30,800/QALY (screening once), $32,300/QALY (screening every 5 years), and $55,500/QALY (screening every 3 years). In settings with an HIV prevalence of 0.10% and an annual incidence of 0.014%, single screening produced cost-effectiveness ratios of $60,700/QALY. Sensitivity analysis results: The cost-effectiveness of screening policies varied within a narrow range, as assumptions about the effect of screening on secondary transmission ranged from favorable to unfavourable. Assuming moderately favorable effects of antiretroviral therapy on transmission, cost-effectiveness ratios remained below $50,000/QALY in settings with HIV prevalence as low as 0.20% for one-time HIV screening and with prevalences as low as 0.45% and annual. incidences as low as 0.0075% for screening every 5 years. Limitations: This review does not address the difficulty of determining the prevalence and incidence of undetected HIV infection in a given patient population. Conclusions: Routine rapid HIV testing is recommended for all adults, except in settings where there is evidence that the prevalence of undiagnosed HIV infection is less than 0.2%.

title: Expanding the use of continuous sedation until death: going beyond the last resort for the terminally ill
abstract: As currently practiced, clinicians control the use of continuous sedation until death (CSD) in a way that may deny patients a key option to manage their dying process. Ethical guidelines from the American Medical Association and the American Academy of Pain Medicine describe CSD as a "last resort," and a position statement from the American Academy of Hospice and Palliative Medicine describes it as "an intervention reserved for emergency situations." extreme". Consequently, patients must progress to unremitting pain and suffering and reach a stage of last resort before considering the option of seeking CSD. Alternatively, we present and defend a new guideline in which terminally ill patients with decision-making capacity and a life expectancy of less than six months can apply for CSD before undergoing the refractory suffering of a "last resort" treatment.

title: Experience-based design: from system redesign around the patient to co-design of services with the patient
abstract: Engaging patients in service improvement and listening and responding to what they say has played a key role in redesigning healthcare processes for the last five years and more. Patients and users attended stakeholder events, participated in discovery interviews, completed surveys, mapped healthcare processes, and even designed new hospitals with healthcare staff. However, efforts to date have not necessarily focused on the patient experience, beyond asking what was good and what was not. No questions were asked to find out details of how the experience was or should be (being “experience” different from “attitudes”) and the information was then systematically used to co-design services with patients. The knowledge of experience, which only the patient possesses, is unique and precious. In this article, attention is drawn to the burgeoning discipline of design sciences and experience-based design, in which the traditional view of the user as a passive recipient of a product or service has begun to give way to the new view of users as an integral part of the improvement and innovation process.

title: Expert panel recommendations versus decision analysis for post-discharge coronary angiography after myocardial infarction
abstract: Context Expert panels and decision analysis techniques are increasingly used to determine the appropriateness of medical interventions, but these 2 approaches use different methods to process the evidence. Objective To compare the adequacy ratings of coronary angiography after myocardial infarction (from hospital discharge to 12 weeks post-infarction) by an expert panel with the predicted health benefits and cost-effectiveness. by a decision analytic model. Design Comparison of the degree of importance of the clinical variables considered in the adequacy ratings of the panel of experts against a previously published decision analytic model. Identification of 36 clinical scenarios from the panel of experts that could be simulated by the decision analytic model. Main outcome measures Suitability score and suitability rating (expert panel) versus gain in quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) and incremental cost-effectiveness (decision analytic model). Results The most important clinical variables were similar in the 2 approaches, with the result of the exercise tolerance test exerting the greatest influence on the strength of the recommendation for angiography. Among expert panel clinical scenarios deemed appropriate for coronary angiography that could be simulated in the decision analysis model, the median (interquartile range) health gain and incremental cost-effectiveness ratio were 0.59 ( 0.41-0.76) QALYs and $27,000 ($23,000-$35,000) per QALY earned, respectively. Among clinical scenarios deemed inappropriate by the expert panels, the corresponding medians (interquartile ranges) were 0.24 (0.19-0.34) QALYs and $54,000 ($36,000-$58,000) per QALY gained. Spearman's rank correlation between appropriateness score and QALY gain was 0.58 (p < 0.001) and between appropriateness score and estimated incremental cost-effectiveness ratio was 0.66 (p < 0.001) . Conclusions For the 36 expert panel scenarios that could be simulated using the decision analytic model, there was moderate to good agreement between the adequacy score and both the health gain and incremental cost-effectiveness of coronary angiography. compared with no angiography in convalescent patients. phase of acute myocardial infarction, but several scenarios considered inappropriate by the expert panel approach had comparable cost-effectiveness ratios with many generally recommended medical interventions. Formal synthesis of expert judgment and decision modeling is warranted in future guideline development efforts.

title: Explanation of the effects of two different strategies to promote hand hygiene in hospital nurses: a process evaluation together with a cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is only limited understanding of why hand hygiene improvement strategies succeed or fail. Therefore, it is important to look inside the 'black box' of such strategies, to determine which components of a strategy are working well or not. This study examined which components of two hand hygiene improvement strategies were associated with higher hand hygiene compliance by nurses. METHODS: A process evaluation of a cluster randomized controlled trial was carried out in which part of the nursing wards of three hospitals in the Netherlands received a state-of-the-art strategy, including education, reminders, feedback and optimization of materials and facilities. ;" another party received a team- and leader-led strategy that included all elements of the leading edge strategy, supplemented with activities targeting empowerment and social leadership. This process evaluation used four sets of measures: effects on hygiene compliance of nurses, adherence to improvement strategies, contextual factors, and nurses' experiences with the components of the strategy.Analysis of variance and multiple regression analyzes were used to explore changes in hand hygiene compliance of nurses. nurses and thus better understand the effects of the trial. RESULTS: Both strategies were performed with good protocol adherence. Two contextual factors were associated with changes in hand hygiene compliance: a long-term hospital effect ( p < 0.05) and high baseline hand hygiene scores were associated with smaller effects. dreams (p < 0.01). In the short term, changes in nurses' hand hygiene compliance were positively correlated with experienced feedback on their hand hygiene performance (p < 0.05). In the long term, several items from the components 'social influence' (i.e., talking to each other about undesirable hand hygiene behavior p < 0.01) and 'leadership' (i.e., the room manager holds members responsible team for hand hygiene performance p < 0.01) was positively correlated with changes in nurses' hand hygiene compliance. CONCLUSION: This study illustrates the use of a process evaluation to uncover the mechanisms underlying change in hand hygiene improvement strategies. The results of our study demonstrate the added value of specific aspects of social influence and leadership in hand hygiene improvement strategies, thus offering an interpretation of the effects of the trial. TRIAL REGISTRATION: The study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, file number: NCT00548015.

title: Explanation of the variation in GP referral rates for X-rays for back pain
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite the availability of clinical guidelines for the management of low back pain (LBP), there remains a wide variation in referral rates from general practitioners (GPs) for lumbar spine radiography (LSX). This study aims to explain the variation in LSX referral rates of GPs based on their reports on the management of patients with low back pain. METHODS: Qualitative semi-structured interviews with 29 GPs with high and low referral rates for LSX in the North East of England. The thematic analysis used constant comparative techniques. RESULTS: Common and divergent themes were identified between high and low users of LSX. Topics that were similar in both groups included knowledge of current guidelines for LSX use for LBP patients and patient pressure and institutional factors to order an LSX. Differentiating themes for the high user group included: the belief that LSX provides reassurance to patients that they can overcome the risks, pessimism about management options for LBP, and the belief that withholding LSX would negatively affect doctor-patient relationships . Two specific differentiating issues are considered in more depth: GPs' awareness of the use of lumbar spine radiology relative to others, and the perceived risks associated with LSX radiation. CONCLUSION: Several key factors differentiate accounts of GPs having high and low rates of referral for LSX, despite being aware of guideline recommendations. Intervention studies that aim to increase adherence to guideline recommendations on LSX use by changing the ordering behavior of physicians in primary care should focus on these factors.

title: Explanation of variations in prescription costs in England
abstract: OBJECTIVE To derive a predictive model for national prescribing behavior in terms of baseline morbidity and demographic factors. DESIGN Twenty-four demographic, morbidity, and practice factors were entered into a multiple regression analysis to determine net ingredient cost per patient. SCENARIO All 90 family health services authorities in England for 1989. RESULTS For net cost of ingredients per patient, only two demographic factors (number of pensioners and registered population mobility measured by list inflation) and two factors related to morbidity (standardized mortality ratios and numbers of prepaid certificates issued) contributed significantly to a multiple regression model. This model explained 81% of the variation in the net cost of ingredients per registered patient among the authorities of the family health services. The model also allowed a weighting factor of 4.6 (95% confidence interval 3.2 to 6.7) to be derived for the net cost of ingredients for elderly patients (compared to the unit factor of 3) existing prescription. CONCLUSIONS The model shows that variations in prescription costs essentially reflect demand. It also suggests that the current prescription unit value of 3 for patients 65 years and older underestimates additional prescription costs for elderly patients.

title: Exploratory analysis of patients' motivations to quit smoking and to participate in smoking cessation classes
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES: A major investigation has evaluated the impacts of smoking, the impacts of secondhand smoke exposure, the effectiveness of a variety of social and individual smoking cessation interventions, and the frequency with which clinicians talk about quitting. smoking with his patients. Little research has addressed barriers to physician-initiated discussion and intervention related to smoking cessation, especially in relation to resident physicians treating low-income patients. Existing research indicates that clinicians have low expectations regarding patients' wishes to quit and often wait to discuss smoking cessation with patients until the patient brings up the subject. The purpose of this pilot was to identify trends in smoking, desire to quit, and desire to participate in smoking cessation classes at the family medicine clinic. METHODS: Patients completed a survey to obtain demographic information, smoking behavior, presence of chronic diseases, desire to quit, and reasons for wanting to quit. RESULTS: Higher rates of smoking and lower rates of desired quitting were identified. However, among patients contemplating quitting, a relatively high number wanted smoking cessation classes. A higher number of unsuccessful quit attempts predicted higher odds of both wanting to quit and wanting quit classes. Other predictors of desire to quit and class participation are discussed. CONCLUSIONS: Based on current research, clinicians are encouraged to follow practice guidelines, asking all patients about smoking behavior and assisting them in their efforts to quit smoking, especially those who have been unsuccessful in quitting. last.

title: Exploring nurses' and patients' perspectives on limit setting in a forensic mental health setting
abstract: Limit setting is an intervention frequently used by mental health nurses. However, limit setting is poorly conceptualized, its purpose is unclear, and few evidence-based guidelines exist to help nurses set limits safely and effectively. What is known is that how nurses set limits influences patients' perceptions of interactions and their emotional and behavioral responses. In this qualitative study, 12 nurses and 12 patients participated in personal semi-structured interviews that aimed to explore limit setting and propose principles to guide practice. The findings suggested that: (i) limit setting is important for safety in mental health hospitals"; (ii) patients need to be empathically involved when limits are set (when nurses are empathetically involved , the therapeutic relationship is more likely to be preserved and the risk of aggressive responses is reduced);" and (iii) an authoritarian (fair, respectful, consistent, and knowledgeable) limit-setting style, rather than authoritarian (controlling and indifferent), improves positive outcomes regarding adherence, reduced likelihood of aggression, and preservation of the therapeutic relationship. In conclusion, a limit-setting style characterized by an empathic response and an authoritative style, rather than an authoritarian interpersonal style, is recommended. Elucidating the components of this style is critical to effective training and best practice for mental health nurses, and to reducing aggressive limit-setting responses.

title: Exploring the feasibility of joint analysis as a tool to prioritize innovations for implementation
abstract: Background In an era of few and competing priorities for implementation, choosing what to implement is a key decision point for many behavior change projects. The values and attitudes of the professionals and managers involved inevitably impact the priority given to decision options. Reliable capture of such values is challenging. Methods This article presents an approach to capture and incorporate professional values in the prioritization of healthcare innovations being considered for adoption. Conjoint analysis (CA) was used in a single UK Primary Care Trust to measure the priorities of healthcare professionals working with women with postpartum depression. Rating-based CA data was collected using a questionnaire and then mapped onto 12 interventions that were considered as a means of improving the management of postpartum depression. Results Â¡Â®Impact on patient careÂ¡Â¯ and Â¡Â®Quality of supporting evidenceÂ¡Â¯ associated with potential innovations were the most influential in setting priorities. Practitioners were less influenced by whether an innovation was an existing national or local priority, or whether current practice at the Trust met minimum standards. Ranking the 12 innovations according to potential adopters' preferences revealed that "guided self-help" was the highest priority for implementation and "postpartum depression screening questions" the least important. When other factors (such as the presence of routine data or planned implementation activity elsewhere in the Trust) were considered, the project team chose to combine the eight related treatments and implement them as a single innovation called 'psychological therapies'. A. Conclusions Using conjoint analysis to prioritize possible innovation implementation options is a feasible means of capturing the usefulness of stakeholders and thereby increasing the chances that an innovation will be adopted. There are some practical barriers to overcome, such as increasing response rates to pooled surveys before considering routine, untested use of this technique.

title: Exploring the gap between knowledge and behavior: a qualitative study of clinical action after an educational intervention
abstract: PURPOSE: Many medical education interventions improve physician knowledge but fail to change behavior. The authors exposed this knowledge and behavior gap through standardized clinical interactions, which allowed for an in-depth exploration of contributing factors. METHOD: A typical evidence-based educational intervention in a clinical domain (early signs of autism) was administered to family medicine residents at the University of Toronto in 2001-02, and change in knowledge was assessed through a test of multiple choice. Six to eight weeks later, the participants' relevant knowledge was documented and their clinical behavior observed during four interactions with standardized patients. Factors producing a discrepancy between knowledge and behavior were then explored through semi-structured interviews, which were recorded, transcribed, and analyzed using grounded theory methods. RESULTS: Half of the participants demonstrated varying degrees of knowledge and behavior gap. Eight major rationalizations (relationships, patient agenda, knowledge deficit, clinical style, means to an end, ideals, autism stigma, and systems barriers) were used to justify clinical behavior choices, and the same rationalizations were used to justify opposite behavioral choices. . Two conditions that promote clinical action based on knowledge (level of certainty and sense of urgency) were identified. CONCLUSION: The knowledge-behavior gap was exposed and reported factors influencing clinicians' decisions about whether to implement new knowledge were elicited. That identical rationalizations were used to justify opposing behaviors implies that these factors may not be determinants of behavior. The sense of urgency and the level of certainty favor clinical action based on knowledge";" focusing on these can increase the impact of education in practice.

title: Exploring the Roots of Unwanted Security Threats Associated with the Introduction of Hospital Electronic Prescribing Systems and Candidate Prevention and/or Mitigation Strategies: A Qualitative Study
abstract: Objective Hospital's electronic prescription systems (ePrescribing) offer a wide range of benefits for patient safety. However, like other hospital health information technology interventions, they can also introduce new areas of risk. Despite recent advances in identifying these risks, the development and use of electronic prescription systems continue to have many unintended consequences, which can undermine improvement and threaten patient safety. These negative consequences need to be analyzed in the design, implementation and use of these systems. Therefore, our goal was to understand the roots of these reported threats and identify potential avoidance/mitigation strategies. Methods We analyzed a longitudinal qualitative study of the implementation and adoption of electronic prescription systems in six English hospitals, each of which was conceptualized as a case study. The data included semi-structured interviews, observations of system implementation and use meetings, and a collection of relevant documents. We first analyze the data within and then across the case studies. Results Our data set included 214 interviews, 24 observations, and 18 documents. We developed a taxonomy of factors underlying unwanted security threats in: (1) suboptimal system design, including lack of support for complex drug delivery regimens, lack of effective integration between different systems, and lack of support tools effective automated decision-making"; (2) inappropriate use of systems, in particular, over-reliance on the system and introduction of workarounds;" and (3) suboptimal implementation strategies resulting from partial implementations/dual systems and lack of adequate training. We have identified a number of organizational and systems strategies that could avoid or reduce these risks. Conclusions Imperfections in the design, implementation, and use of electronic prescription systems can lead to unintended consequences, including security threats. Hospitals and providers must implement short-term and long-term strategies in terms of technology and organization to minimize unwanted security risks.

title: External validity of randomized controlled trials: "to whom do the results of this trial apply?"
abstract: When making treatment decisions, clinicians and patients should consider relevant randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and systematic reviews. Relevance depends on external validity (or generalisability), that is, whether the results can be reasonably applied to a definable group of patients in a particular clinical setting in routine practice. There is concern among clinicians that external validity is often poor, particularly for some pharmaceutical industry trials, a perception that has led to the underuse of treatments that are effective. However, researchers, funding agencies, ethics committees, the pharmaceutical industry, medical journals, and government regulators neglect external validity, leaving decisions to physicians. However, reporting of determinants of external validity in trial publications and systematic reviews is often inadequate. This review discusses those determinants, presents a checklist for clinicians, and makes recommendations for further consideration of external validity in the design and reporting of RCTs.

title: Facilitating patient self-management of diabetes: a primary care intervention framework
abstract: A quality primary care framework for diabetes self-management (DSM) is presented based on prevailing changes in the practice environment. Recent DSM literature and research is reviewed in relation to (a) patients' DSM perceptions and experiences of office visits and (b) most effective office-based DSM programs. This quality primary care framework enables clinical nurses to more consistently assess and integrate individual patient factors using typically limited clinical resources at office visits to optimize DSM patient outcomes.

title: Factor surveys: using vignettes to study professional judgment.
abstract: Decision making is becoming an increasingly central feature of social work practice, yet there is limited research on the topic. Experimental methods for investigating decision making tend to be limited by practical and ethical difficulties, while questions of validity and generalizability surround ethnographic and other descriptive methods. It is argued here that the factorial survey addresses these methodological difficulties as a research design to study how professionals make decisions in real life. In this research design, actual vignettes (case scenarios or paper cases) are presented to social workers or other staff to make a judgment about one type of family scenario. Random factors within vignettes, combined with randomization of vignette selection for each decision maker, give the factorial survey a unique ability to investigate the effect of multiple factors on complex decisions, unlike the more common factorial experiment. The method is explained and the perspectives and issues for the development of this research design to study professional judgment within social work are discussed. The factorial survey has potential as a method for the rigorous study of the impact of client, family, and context factors on the decisions of social work and social care personnel. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2016 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: Factors affecting the feasibility and acceptability of a practice-based educational intervention to support evidence-based prescribing: a qualitative study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Inappropriate and costly GP prescribing is a major problem facing primary care trusts. Educational outreach in practices, along with other measures such as audit and feedback, have the potential to enable GP prescribing to be more evidence-based. High GP prescription costs are associated with GPs seeing pharmaceutical company representatives "tend to end consultations with prescriptions"; and 'testing' new drugs 'ad hoc' and using this as evidence of drug effect. An educational intervention called 'reflective practice' was developed to meet these and other educational needs. The intervention design was based on studies that have identified the prerequisites for successful behavior change in general practice. OBJECTIVES: The study investigated the following: (i) Is it feasible for GPs to attend the sessions included in the educational intervention? (ii) Is the intervention acceptable to the participants and session facilitators? (iii) What are the barriers to group educational processes and how can they be overcome? METHODS: Four practices in the south west of England were recruited, all experiencing problems with prescription eligibility and cost. Reflective practice sessions (including a videotaped scenario) were conducted in each of these practices and qualitative methods were used to explore the complex attitudes and behavior of the participants. A researcher observed and recorded audio sessions in each practice. At the end of the program, a sample of doctors and all the facilitators were interviewed about their experiences. Recorded data was transcribed and analyzed using standard qualitative methods. RESULTS: Physicians from the largest associations had the greatest difficulty attending sessions. Elsewhere, physicians were also reluctant to get involved due to previous experience of top-down management initiatives on prescribing quality. The facilitators came from a wide range of professional backgrounds. While knowledge of prescription medication management issues was important, the facilitator's professional experience was less important than group facilitation skills in creating a group process that participating physicians found satisfactory. The videotaped scenario was found to be helpful in setting the stage for the discussion. Preserving the anonymity of the GPs' responses in the early stages of the sessions was important to ensure honesty in the discussion. It was sometimes difficult to reach a consensus on the management of common conditions, partly because the use of the term "best buy" implies economic pressures, rather than benefits for patients, and partly because of the value that GPs give the concept of clinical autonomy. 'Reflective practice' seemed to have the potential to make clinicians aware of the relationship between their clinical management decisions and the evidence provided by the British National Formulary and Clinical Evidence. CONCLUSION: The study indicates the importance of preparing the practice adequately, including providing sheltered time for all general practitioners to attend the educational intervention. The settings and the structure of the sessions should make the links between daily practice and published evidence of effectiveness more explicit. The emphasis on profitability can be counterproductive and the broader benefits need to be emphasized. We have also identified the skills profile of the facilitator role. Our study indicates the need for a clearer understanding of GPs' perceived clinical autonomy and how this conflicts with the goal of agreement on practice guidelines for treatment. The intervention is now ripe for further development, perhaps integrating it with other interventions to change professional behaviour. The improved intervention should then be evaluated in a randomized controlled trial.

title: Factors associated with nursing interventions to reduce incontinence in hospitalized elderly
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The problem of incontinence in hospitalized elderly patients is poorly documented and there is little research to determine why nurses choose to help or not help with this problem. Are hospital critical care nurses' attitudes and beliefs about incontinence associated with the perceived opportunity to help the patient with the problem? What do hospital nurses know about the causes and interventions related to incontinence? METHODS: Two vignettes were created, one describing a patient with stress incontinence and one describing a patient with urge incontinence. Questions that measure variables of a support model were developed and nurses were asked to mark on a Likert-type scale when answering each question. RESULTS: One hundred and fifty respondents returned the completed questionnaires along with three expert nurses. Many hospital nurses believed that incontinence was temporary and part of old age. As a group, they had a more positive attitude towards the urge incontinence intervention and believed that the physician and their nurse manager expected them to help the urge incontinence patient. Respondents tended to believe that the patient was less likely to expect help. Respondents were equally divided about the opportunity to provide assistance for stress or urge incontinence. Less than half of the nurses correctly listed the causes and interventions for stress or urge incontinence. CONCLUSIONS: Other perceived more pressing clinical problems and lack of knowledge about appropriate supportive measures affect nurses' perceptions of the opportunity to intervene when elderly hospitalized patients are incontinent. Assessment and intervention are essential for quality nursing care. Undergraduate nursing education and continuing staff education on continence are crucial for successful assessments and interventions. Patients, as consumers of health care, need to be more informed about incontinence and choose to have the problem addressed during hospitalization. The Clinical Practice Guidelines of the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research are an important recommended reference.

title: Factors associated with poor mental health among Guatemalan refugees living in Mexico 20 years after the civil conflict
abstract: Context From 1981 to 2001, 46,000 refugees who fled Guatemala's 36-year civil conflict for Chiapas, Mexico, came under the protection of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. Objectives To estimate the prevalence of mental illness and factors associated with poor mental health in underserved Guatemalan refugee communities located in Chiapas, Mexico, since 1981 and to assess the need for mental health services. Design, Setting, and Participants Cross-sectional survey of 183 households in 5 Mayan refugee camps in Chiapas representing approximately 1,546 residents (adults and children) conducted from November to December 2000. Main outcome measures Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptom criteria ), anxiety , and depression as measured by the Harvard Trauma Questionnaire and the Hopkins Symptom Checklist-25 (Hopkins-25). Results One adult (age = 16 years) per household (n = 170 respondents) who agreed to participate was included in the analysis, representing approximately 93% of households. All respondents reported experiencing at least 1 traumatic event with a mean of 8.3 traumatic events per person. Of those surveyed, 20 (11.8%) had full criteria for PTSD symptoms. Of the 160 who completed the Hopkins-25 Symptom Checklist, 87 (54.4%) had symptoms of anxiety and 62 (38.8%) had symptoms of depression. Witnessing relatives disappear (adjusted odds ratio [AOR], 4.58"; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.35-15.50), being close to death (AOR, 4.19 , 95% CI, 1.03-17.00) or living with 9 to 15 people in the same household (OR, 3.69; 95% CI, 1.19-11.39) were associated with PTSD symptoms A protective factor was found for lack of sufficient food (OR, 0.08; 95% CI, 0.01- High anxiety symptoms were associated with witnessing a massacre (AOR, 10.63; 95% CI, 4, 31-26.22), being injured (AOR, 3.22; 95% CI, 0.95-10.89), and experiencing 7 to 12 traumatic events (AOR, 2.67; 95% CI, 1.14 -6.27) and 13 to 19 traumatic events (AOR, 2.26; 95% CI, 0.65-7.89).High symptoms of depression were associated with being female (AOR, 3.64; CI 95%, 1.47-9.04), being widowed (AOR, 27.55; 95% CI, 2.54-299.27), being married (AOR, 1.93; 95% CI, 0.59 -6.33), witnessing disappearances (AOR, 2.68; 95% CI, 1.16-6.19), experiencing 7 to 12 traumatic events (AOR, 1.57; CI 95%, 0.64-3.88), or experiencing 13 to 19 traumatic events (AOR, 7.44; 95% CI, 2.18-25.37). Conclusion Psychiatric morbidity related to human rights violations, traumatic events, and refugee status was common among Guatemalan refugees surveyed 20 years after the Guatemalan civil conflict.

title: Failure of computerized treatment suggestions to improve health outcomes for outpatients with uncomplicated hypertension: results of a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: The purpose of the study. To assess the effects of evidence-based treatment suggestions for hypertension made to physicians and pharmacists using a comprehensive electronic medical record system. Design. Randomized controlled trial with a 2 x 2 factorial design of physician and pharmacist interventions, resulting in four groups of patients: physician intervention only, pharmacist intervention only, physician and pharmacist intervention, and intervention with no physician or pharmacist (control). ). Around. Academic practice of primary care internal medicine. Subjects. Seven hundred and twelve patients with uncomplicated hypertension. Measurements and Main Results. The suggestions were shown to physicians at the computer workstations used to write outpatient prescriptions and to pharmacists when filling prescriptions. The primary endpoint was generic health-related quality of life. Secondary endpoints were symptom profile and side effects of antihypertensive medications, number of emergency department visits and hospitalizations, blood pressure measurements, patient satisfaction with physicians and pharmacists, compliance with drug therapy and charges for medical care. In the control group, implementation of changes in care according to treatment suggestions was observed in 26% of patients. In the intervention groups, adherence to suggestions was poor, with treatment suggestions implemented in 25% of patients for whom suggestions were shown only to pharmacists, 29% of those for whom suggestions were shown only to physicians and 35% of the group for whom both physicians and pharmacists received suggestions (p=0.13). Between-group differences were neither statistically significant nor clinically relevant for generic health-related quality of life, symptom and side effect profiles, number of emergency department visits and hospitalizations, blood pressure measurements, charges or compliance with drug therapy. Conclusion. The computerized intervention using a sophisticated electronic physician order entry system failed to improve adherence to treatment suggestions or outcomes for patients with uncomplicated hypertension.

title: Fall prevention in acute care hospitals: a randomized trial.
abstract: Context Falls cause injury and death to people of all ages, but the risk of falling increases markedly with age. Hospitalization further increases risk, but there is no evidence to support short-stay hospital fall prevention strategies to reduce patient falls. Objective To investigate whether a falls prevention toolkit (FPTK) using health information technology (HIT) decreases patient falls in hospitals. Design, Setting, and Patients Randomized cluster study conducted from January 1, 2009, to June 30, 2009, comparing rates of falls for patients in 4 urban US hospitals in units receiving usual care (4 units and 5104 patients) or the intervention (4 units and 5160 patients). Intervention The FPTK integrated existing communication and workflow patterns into the HIT application. Based on a valid fall risk assessment scale completed by a nurse, FPTK software tailored fall prevention interventions to address patients' specific determinants of fall risk. FPTK produced bedside banners comprised of short text with an accompanying icon, patient education brochures, and care plans, all communicating specific patient alerts to key stakeholders. Main outcome measures The primary outcome was patient falls per 1000 patient-days adjusted for site and patient care unit. A secondary outcome was fall-related injuries. Results During the 6-month intervention period, the number of patients with falls differed between control (n = 87) and intervention (n = 67) units (p = 0.02). Site-adjusted fall rates were significantly higher in control units (4.18 [95% confidence interval {CI}, 3.45-5.06] per 1,000 patient-days) than in control units. intervention (3.15 [95% CI, 2.54-3.90] per 1,000 patients). -days"; P = .04). FPTK was found to be particularly effective with patients 65 years of age and older (adjusted rate difference, 2.08 [95% CI, 0.61-3.56] for 1,000 patient-days;" P = 0.000,003). No significant effect on fall-related injuries was observed. Conclusion The use of a falls prevention toolkit in hospital units compared to usual care significantly reduced the rate of falls.

title: Requests from relatives to extend physiological support after the declaration of brain death: analysis of a series of cases and proposal of clinical management guidelines
abstract: We describe and analyze 13 cases attended by our ethics consultation service (ECS) in which families requested the continuation of physiological support for their loved ones after death had been declared by neurological criteria (DNC). These ethics consultations took place between 2005 and 2013. The ages of the patients ranged from 14 to 85 years. Continuous mechanical ventilation was the central intervention sought by all families. The ECS's advice and recommendations generally promoted "reasonable accommodation" of claims, balancing compassion for bereaved families with other ethical and moral concerns, such as stewardship of resources, professional integrity, and moral distress. In the cases we characterize as finite goal adaptation, a "reasonable fit" strategy proved effective in balancing the interests and goals of stakeholders, allowing for steady progress toward resolution. When a family adamantly opposed a DNC declaration and requested an indefinite accommodation, the "reasonable accommodation" approach offered clinicians little practical direction, and resolution required definitive action by the family or clinical team. Based on our analysis and reflections on these 13 cases, we propose practical and ethically justified guidelines to help health professionals, administrators, and CHIs facing similar cases.

title: Family-based interventions to increase physical activity in children: a meta-analysis and realistic synthesis protocol.
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Despite the established relationship between physical activity and health, data suggest that many children are insufficiently active and that levels decline in adolescence. Involving the family in interventions can increase and maintain children's physical activity levels at the critical time before high school. Synthesis of existing evidence will inform future studies, but the heterogeneity in the target populations recruited, the behavior change techniques and intervention strategies employed, and the measurement performed may require a multifaceted review approach. Therefore, the main objective of this paper will be to synthesize the evidence from intervention studies that explicitly engage the family unit to increase children's physical activity using an innovative dual meta-analysis and realistic approach. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: Peer-reviewed studies will be independently assessed by two authors for inclusion on the basis of (1) including 'healthy' participants aged 5 to 12 years";" (2) have a substantive intervention goal of increasing physical activity, involving the family, and (3) reporting physical activity. Duplicate data extraction and quality assessment will be performed using a specially designed form and the Effective Public Health Practice Project Quality Assessment Tool, respectively. STATA software will be used to calculate effect sizes for meta-analyses, and subgroup analyzes will be performed to identify moderating characteristics. Realistic syntheses will be performed in accordance with RAMESES publication and quality guidelines, including the development of a program theory and evidence mapping. DISSEMINATION: This review will be the first to use a traditional review framework to conduct a dual meta-analysis and realist synthesis, examining interventions involving the family to increase physical activity in children. Results will be disseminated through peer-reviewed publications, conferences, formal presentations to policymakers and practitioners, and informal meetings. The evidence generated from this synthesis will also be used to inform the development of evidence-based and theory-based interventions aimed at engaging the family to increase physical activity levels in children. PROTOCOL REGISTRY: International Prospective Registry of Systematic Reviews (PROSPERO): number CRD42013005780.

title: Family DOTS and community DOTS for tuberculosis control in Nepal: cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background A key component of the DOTS strategy for tuberculosis control (short course chemotherapy following WHO guidelines) is direct observation of treatment. WHO technical guidelines recommend that health workers carry out this part of the strategy, but will also accept direct observation of treatment in the community"; WHO does not believe that a family member should take on this role. No evidence is available to support these recommendations The Nepal National TB Program asked us to develop and test a direct observation of treatment strategy for the mountainous districts of Nepal, where direct observation of treatment by workers of health is not feasible.Our objective was to evaluate the success rates of two DOTS strategies developed for such areas.; BackgroundA key component of the DOTS strategy for tuberculosis control (short course chemotherapy following WHO guidelines) is direct observation of treatment WHO technical guidelines recommend that workers in the carry out this part of the strategy, but will also accept direct observation of treatment in the community;" WHO does not believe that a family member should take on this role. There is no evidence to support these recommendations. The Nepal National Tuberculosis Program asked us to develop and test a direct observation of treatment strategy for the mountainous districts of Nepal, where direct observation of treatment by health workers is not feasible. Our objective was to evaluate the success rates of two DOTS strategies developed for these areas.

title: Rapid Tracking of Theory-Based KT Intervention Design Through a Consensus Process
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite available evidence for optimal management of spinal pain, poor adherence to guidelines and wide variations in health care services persist. One of the goals of the Canadian Chiropractic Guideline Initiative is to develop and evaluate targeted interventions based on theory and evidence to improve the management of non-specific neck pain by chiropractors. In order to systematically develop a knowledge translation (KT) intervention supported by the Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF), we explored the perceived factors influencing the use of multimodal care to manage non-specific neck pain, and mapped behavior change techniques to key theorists. domains METHODS: Individual telephone interviews exploring neck pain management beliefs were conducted with a purposive sample of 13 chiropractors. The interview guide was based on the TDF. The interviews were digitally recorded, transcribed word for word, and analyzed by two independent assessors using thematic content analysis. A 15-member expert panel met formally to design a KT intervention. RESULTS: Nine TDF domains were identified as probably relevant. Key beliefs (and relevant TDF domains) included the following: influence of formal training, colleagues, and patients on clinicians (Social Influences); availability of educational material (Context and environmental resources); and better clinical results that reinforce the use of multimodal methods. (Reinforcement). Facilitating factors that were considered important included better communication (Skills); audits of the results related to the treatment of patients (regulation of behavior); awareness and agreement with guidelines (Knowledge);" and adaptation of multimodal care (Memory, Attention and Decision Processes). Physicians expressed conflicting beliefs about perceived threats to professional autonomy (Role and social/professional identity) and the speed of recovery when applying or ignoring practical recommendations (Beliefs about Consequences) The expert panel mapped behavior change techniques to key theoretical domains and identified strategies and KT delivery modes relevant to increasing the use of multimodal care among chiropractors.CONCLUSIONS: A multifaceted KT educational intervention targeting neck pain management by chiropractors was developed.The KT intervention consisted of a series of online education webinars, clinical vignettes, and a video supported by the brief action planning model.The intervention was designed to reflect domains te key theoretical, behavior change techniques, and intervention components. The effectiveness of the proposed intervention remains to be verified.

title: Feasibility and acceptability of two incentive-based implementation strategies for mental health therapists implementing cognitive behavioral therapy: a pilot study to inform a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Informed by our previous work indicating that therapists do not feel recognized or rewarded for implementing evidence-based practices, we tested the feasibility and acceptability of two incentive-based implementation strategies that seek to improve therapist adherence to cognitive therapy. -behavioral for young people, an evidence-based practice. Methods This study took place over 6 weeks in two community mental health agencies with therapists (n = 11) and leaders (n = 4). Therapists were randomly assigned to receive a financial or social incentive if they met a predetermined criterion for adherence to cognitive behavioral therapy. In the first intervention period (block 1"; 2 weeks), therapists received the reward to which they were initially randomized if they met the criteria. In the second intervention period (block 2;" 2 weeks), therapists received both rewards if they met the criteria. Therapists recorded 41 sessions on 15 unique clients during the project period. Primary outcomes included feasibility and acceptability. Viability was quantitatively evaluated. Fifteen semi-structured interviews with therapists and leaders were conducted to assess acceptability. The difference in therapist adherence by condition was examined as an exploratory outcome. Adherence ratings were determined using an established and validated cognitive behavioral therapy observational coding system. Results Both implementation strategies were feasible and acceptable; however, the study design will need to be modified for the larger trial based on participant feedback. Regarding our exploratory analysis, we found a trend suggesting that financial reward may have had a stronger effect on therapist adherence than social reward. Conclusions Incentive-based implementation strategies can be feasibly delivered in community mental health agencies with good acceptability, although iterative pilot work is essential. Larger, fully powered trials are needed to compare the effectiveness of implementation strategies to encourage and improve therapists' adherence to evidence-based practices, such as cognitive behavioral therapy.

title: Feasibility and impact of a computerized clinical decision support system in the investigation and initial management of new-onset chest pain: a mixed-methods study.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical decision support systems (CDSS) can change clinician behavior, but the factors that influence their effect remain poorly understood. This study evaluates the feasibility and acceptability of a CDSS to support diagnostic and treatment decisions for patients with suspected stable angina. METHODS: Intervention The Optimizing Angina Management (OMA) program includes a CDSS that guides research and medication decisions for clinicians managing patients with new-onset stable angina, based on English national guidelines, presented via an educational intervention. Design and participants A mixed methods study i. A study of outcomes among patients presenting with suspected angina at three chest pain clinics in England before and after the introduction of the AOM programme. ii. Clinical process observations, interviews, and a focus group with health professionals at two chest pain clinics after delivery of the OMA program. RESULTS: Medications and cardiovascular imaging investigations performed within six months of presentation, and concordance of these with CDSS recommendations. Thematic analysis of qualitative data to understand how the CDSS was used. RESULTS: Data from 285 patients attending chest pain clinics were analyzed: 106 before and 179 after delivery of the OMA program. 40 consultations were observed, 5 clinicians were interviewed and a focus group was held after the intervention. The proportion of patients suitable for diagnostic investigation who received one was 50% (95% CI 34-66%) before AOM and 59% (95% CI 48-70%) of those after AOM. Despite the high use of the CDSS (84% of queries), observations and interviews revealed difficulties with data entry into the CDSS and structural and practical barriers to its use. In most cases, the CDSS was not used to guide real-time decision making, but was only consulted after the patient had left the room. CONCLUSIONS: The OMA CDSS for the management of chest pain is not feasible in its current form. The CDSS was not used to support decisions about the care of individual patients. A variety of barriers to the use of the CDSS were identified, some are easily removed, such as insufficient capture of cardiovascular risk, while others are more entrenched in current practice, such as the unavailability of some research or lack of viewing privileges. prescription for nurses.

title: Feasibility of conducting a randomized controlled trial of telemental health with children diagnosed with attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder in underserved communities
abstract: PURPOSE: Telemental health (TMH), the use of video teleconferencing to deliver care typically provided in person, is increasingly being used to redress disparities in access to care. However, few studies have been conducted to demonstrate the effectiveness of TMH as a service delivery model. The Childhood Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) Telemental Health Treatment Study (CATTS) is a randomized clinical trial (RCT) of TMH conducted in multiple underserved communities. This article reports on the feasibility of conducting an efficacy trial of MTCT in children. METHODS: The CATTS trial used video conferencing to provide guideline-based care and secure websites to coordinate key aspects of trial implementation, including participant recruitment and retention, intervention fidelity, and completion of assessments. RESULTS: The CATTS trial involved seven communities and 150 primary care providers as study partners, enrolling 223 children ages 5.5 to 12.9 years. The intervention group completed an average of 5.3 of 6.0 planned sessions, and 96% of the controls completed a MTCT consultation. Both groups completed an average of 4.8 on the 5.0 tests. Physicians demonstrated high fidelity to their treatment protocols. Minor technical difficulties did not interfere with care. CONCLUSIONS: The CATTS trial demonstrated the feasibility of conducting an RCT of MTCT with children living in multiple underserved communities. Telecommunications technologies can facilitate the coordination of research activities between sites and clinicians. Future trials should work closely with study partners to ensure that a representative study sample is derived. Further trials are needed to help establish the effectiveness of TMH as a service delivery model. TRIAL REGISTRATION: http://clinicaltrials.gov/show/NCT00830700.

title: Feasibility study of an asthma education and communication intervention for general practitioners in Australia
abstract: The Physician Asthma Care Education (PACE) program significantly improved asthma prescribing and communication behaviors of primary care pediatricians in the US. We tested the feasibility and acceptability of a modified PACE program with Australian general practitioners (GPs) and we measured its impact on self-reported consultation behaviors in a pilot study. Recruitment was carried out through a local division of GPs. Twenty-five GPs completed two PACE Australia workshops, which incorporated pediatric asthma management according to Australian asthma guidelines and focused on effective communication strategies. Program feasibility, usefulness, and perceived benefit were measured by questionnaires before the workshop and 1 month after, and an evaluation questionnaire after each workshop. GP was universally enthusiastic and supportive of the workshops. The most helpful items they reported were communication skills, case studies, device demonstrations, and the provided set of tools. GPs' self-reports of the perceived usefulness of key communication strategies and their confidence in their application and reported frequency of use increased significantly after the workshops. The PACE program promises to improve the way Australian GPs manage asthma consultations, particularly with regard to doctor-patient communication. The impact of the modified PACE Australia program on healthcare processes and outcomes for children with asthma is now being measured in a randomized controlled trial.

title: Feasibility, accuracy, and clinical effect of the Xpert MTB/RIF point-of-care test for tuberculosis in primary care settings in Africa: a multicenter, randomized, controlled trial
abstract: Background The Xpert MTB/RIF test for tuberculosis is being implemented in many countries, but evidence is lacking regarding its implementation outside of laboratories, the ability to inform same-day treatment decisions at the point of care, and the clinical effect on tuberculosis-related morbidity. Our objective was to assess the feasibility, accuracy, and clinical effect of Xpert MTB/RIF point-of-care tests in primary care health care settings in southern Africa.";" Background The Xpert MTB/RIF test for tuberculosis is being implemented in many countries, but evidence is lacking regarding its implementation outside of laboratories, the ability to inform same-day treatment decisions at the point of care, and the clinical effect on tuberculosis-related morbidity. Our objective was to assess the feasibility, accuracy, and clinical effect of point-of-care Xpert MTB/RIF testing in primary care health care settings in southern Africa.

title: Feedback as a strategy to change behavior: the devil is in the details
abstract: BACKGROUND: Performance feedback is one of several strategies used to improve clinical practice among students and physicians. OBJECTIVES: The objectives of this paper were to examine the conceptual underpinnings and essential components for audit and feedback strategies, to assess the extent to which recently published audit and feedback interventions include these components, and to recommend future directions for feedback to improve its impact. educational and behavioral. . METHODS: Based on the actionable feedback model, we examined the presence of four theoretical constructs (opportunity, individualization, lack of punitiveness, and personalization) in studies published during 2009-2010 that included a feedback intervention. RESULTS: There was wide variation in the definition, implementation, and outcomes of 'feedback' interventions, making comparison between studies difficult. None of the studies we reviewed included all components of the actionable feedback model. CONCLUSIONS: Feedback interventions reported to date, even when results are positive, often do not include behavior change concepts. This may partially explain the wide variation in approaches and outcomes of such interventions and presents great challenges in replicating any given intervention. For feedback processes to be successfully widely used, disseminated, and implemented, some standardization is needed, and certainly more clarity on the specific action steps that are taken to apply behavioral theory to practice.

title: Fibromyalgia Treatment Update
abstract: PURPOSE OF REVIEW: Fibromyalgia is a common chronic pain disorder characterized by complex symptomatology and few consistently effective treatments. The purpose of this review is to highlight the recent literature from April 2005 to September 2006 on treatment options. RECENT FINDINGS: Previous evidence suggests that medication and self-management approaches to care can improve symptoms, function, and well-being in this patient population. Recent studies examining the efficacy of two serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (duloxetine and milnacipran) and the anticonvulsant pregabalin are encouraging. Studies evaluating different forms of exercise continue to support the belief that increased physical activity is an essential component of any treatment plan for the fibromyalgia patient. Three studies contributed to the understanding of treatment adherence. Finally, three studies evaluating the efficacy of acupuncture in the treatment of fibromyalgia showed conflicting results, but added to the knowledge needed for clinicians to have substantive conversations with patients. ABSTRACT: Recent studies support the recommendation of a multimodal approach to treatment involving evidence-based individualized pharmacotherapy and self-management. Treatment goals should include improvement of symptoms, primarily pain and sleep, and promotion of positive health behaviors with the goal of improving physical function and emotional well-being.

title: Financial incentives to quit smoking during pregnancy: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the efficacy of a financial incentive added to routine specialist smoking cessation services during pregnancy versus usual care in helping pregnant smokers to quit. DESIGN Single-center therapeutic exploratory phase II randomized individually controlled parallel-group superiority trial. SETTING A large health council area with a materially deprived inner city population in the west of Scotland, UK. PARTICIPANTS 612 self-reported pregnant smokers in the NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde who spoke English, were at least 16 years of age, less than 24 weeks pregnant and had an exhaled carbon monoxide breath test result of 7 ppm or more. 306 women were randomized to incentives and 306 to control. INTERVENTIONS The control group received routine care, which was the offer of a face-to-face appointment to discuss smoking cessation and, for those who attended and set a quit date, the offer of replacement therapy of free nicotine for 10 weeks provided by pharmacy services. and four weekly support phone calls. The intervention group received routine care plus the offer of up to £400 in shopping vouchers: £50 for attending a face-to-face appointment and setting a "quit date"; then a further £50 if four weeks after quit date exhaled carbon monoxide confirmed quit; additional £100 provided for continued validated exhaled carbon monoxide withdrawal after 12 weeks; final £200 voucher provided for validated carbon monoxide withdrawal exhaled at 34-38 weeks' gestation MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE The primary outcome was verified cotinine cessation at 34-38 weeks' gestation via saliva (<14.2 ng/mL) or urine (< 44.7 ng/mL) Secondary outcomes included birth weight, engagement, and self-reported dropout at four weeks. RESULTS Recruitment was extended from 12 to 15 months to achieve the target sample size. Follow-up continued to sta September 2013. Of the 306 randomized women, three controls opted out shortly after recruitment; these women did not want their data used, leaving 306 participants from the intervention group and 303 from the control group in the intention-to-treat analysis. Damages from financial incentives were not documented. Significantly more smokers in the incentive group than in the control group quit smoking: 69 (22.5%) versus 26 (8.6%). The relative risk of not smoking at the end of pregnancy was 2.63 (95% confidence interval 1.73 to 4.01) P<0.001. The absolute risk difference was 14.0% (95% confidence interval: 8.2% to 19.7%). The number needed to treat (where financial incentives should be offered to achieve a further dropout at the end of pregnancy) was 7.2 (95% confidence interval 5.1 to 12.2). Mean birth weight was 3140 g (SD 600 g) in the incentive group and 3120 (SD 590) g in the control group (P=0.67). CONCLUSION This phase II randomized controlled trial provides substantial evidence for the efficacy of incentives to quit smoking during pregnancy;" as this was only a single center trial, incentives now need to be tested in different types of cessation services. of pregnancy and in different parts of the US TRIAL REGISTRATION Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN87508788.

title: FIRE (facilitating the implementation of research evidence): a study protocol
abstract: Background Research evidence supports best practice, but it is not always used in health care. The Promoting Action on Implementation of Research in Health Services (PARIHS) framework suggests that the nature of the evidence, the context in which it is used, and whether it helps (or facilitates) those trying to use evidence affect the use of evidence. Urinary incontinence has an important effect on the quality of life of older people, has a high prevalence and is a key priority within European health and social policy. Improving continence care has the potential to improve the quality of life for older people and reduce the costs associated with providing incontinence aids. Objectives This study aims to advance understanding of the contribution that facilitation can make to implementing research findings in practice by: expanding current knowledge of facilitation as a process for translating research evidence into the practice; assess the feasibility, efficacy, and cost-effectiveness of two different facilitation models in promoting the acceptance of research evidence on continence management; assessment of the impact of contextual factors on implementation processes and outcomes;" and implement a proactive knowledge transfer and dissemination strategy to disseminate the study's findings to a broad community of policy and practice. Setting and sample Four European countries, each with six long-term nursing care facilities (24 facilities total) for people aged 60 years or older with documented urinary incontinence Methods and design Pragmatic randomized controlled trial with three arms (standard diffusion and two different facilitation schedules), with integrated processes and economic evaluation.The primary outcome is adherence to continence recommendations.Secondary outcomes include the proportion of residents with incontinence, the incidence of incontinence-related dermatitis, urinary tract infections, and quality of life. Results are evaluated at baseline, then at 6, 12, 1 8 and 24 months after the start of the facilitation interventions. Detailed contextual and process data is collected throughout, through interviews with staff, residents, and immediate family members, observations, context assessment using the Alberta Context Tool, and documentary evidence. A realist evaluation framework is used to develop an explanatory theory about what works for whom and under what circumstances.

title: First online survey of an international multidisciplinary working group (MightyMedic) on current practice in diagnosis, therapy and monitoring of dyslipidemias
abstract: The MightyMedic working group (International Multidisciplinary Group for Hemapheresis and Contrast Therapy of Metabolic Disorders) was founded in 2013. The main idea was to establish an international network of an interdisciplinary nature intended to work for cross-border research projects, clinical trials, educational initiatives ( meetings, workshops, summer schools) in the field of metabolic diseases, namely hyperlipidemias and diabetes, preventive cardiology and atherosclerosis. Therapeutic apheresis, its indications and techniques, is a parallel field of research. The Group's first online survey was completed in the first half of 2014. The survey included #24 Centers in Italy, Germany, Greece, UK, Sweden, Japan and the USA. Relevant data on current practice has been collected in diagnosis, treatment and follow-up of dyslipidemias. In the survey, 240 subjects with hyperlipidemia and treated with lipoprotein apheresis have been reported, but a large percentage of patients (35%) who could benefit from this therapeutic option continue to be treated with a conventional pharmacological approach. Genetic molecular diagnosis is performed in only 33% of patients, while lipoprotein (a) (Lp(a)) is included in the assessment of cardiovascular disease risk in 71% of participating centers. Further detailed investigations and prospective multicenter studies are needed to assess the impact-induced changes of updated indications and strategies, as well as new treatment options, with the aim of standardizing therapeutic and diagnostic approaches.

title: First Episode Psychosis: A Window of Opportunity for Best Practices
abstract: Patients experiencing a first psychotic episode or the early stages of psychosis present key diagnostic problems for clinicians. At the time of presentation of the first episode of psychosis, it is critical that clinicians select the most effective treatment option, as immediate intervention offers the best chance of containing the illness. During this period, it is also important to select the best treatment option because functional decline occurs more rapidly during this early period, which may alter the patient's future prognosis, the level of treatment needed, and affect morbidity. Although research has shown a decrease in the gray matter of the brain for those who develop psychosis along with signs of functional impairment, many patients with psychosis remain untreated for long periods of time and do not visit a doctor due to denial, fear of stigma , lack of attention. recognize the problem or complexities of your system of care. Previous studies have shown that when psychosis is left untreated, the patient's outcome is worse than that of a patient treated earlier in the course of the illness. There are a variety of treatment options for the treatment of psychosis, including the use of first or second generation antipsychotic medications. Physicians should be aware that both types of drugs are associated with certain side effects, such as tardive dyskinesia and weight gain, respectively. For both types of medications, doses should be lower for patients with a first psychotic episode than for patients with chronic psychosis. Finally, patients may present with various comorbidities, such as substance abuse, which may also affect treatment. This expert roundtable supplement will address diagnosis and treatment selection for first-episode psychosis, as well as comorbidities related to the condition. The use of first or second generation antipsychotics for the treatment of psychosis, dosage schedules, and the side effect profile of antipsychotics will also be addressed.

title: Changing the format of a laboratory test order form affects the behavior of the doctor
abstract: PURPOSE: Our study was designed to find out if a change in the physician's request for laboratory tests could be obtained by the simple strategy of changing the settings of the checkboxed laboratory request form that is embedded in a medical record computerized. METHODS: This prospective intervention study was conducted at Maccabi Healthcare Services, a preferred provider organization that has used a computerized medical record since 1992. We examined data from 865 primary care physicians over 3 years. In May 2005, we changed the order form and reduced the number of tests that can be ordered using a checkbox form from 51 to 26. Twenty-seven tests were removed from the form and two tests were added. The total number of laboratory test orders and the mean rate of test orders per physician visit during each of the study periods were calculated separately for each test. RESULTS: Tests added to the computerized laboratory order form showed a 60.7% increase in the first year and a further 90% increase in the following year. For tests with no changes, the percentage changes over the same periods were +18.4% and -22.4%. For the tests eliminated, the variation was -27% and -19.2% for the respective years. CONCLUSIONS: Changes in the format of laboratory test request forms may change the request for medical tests and may be useful in conjunction with other interventions to improve the appropriateness of laboratory tests. A carefully crafted test order form can reinforce clinical guidelines for some preventive and follow-up tests.

title: Formative evaluation of changes in practice for the management of depression within a Shared Care model in primary care
abstract: Objective To investigate the implementation and initial impact of the mental health indicators of the Integrated Network of Physicians (PIN), which are specific for the detection and follow-up management of depression, in three primary care practices with Shared Mental Health Care. in Manitoba. BACKGROUND: Manitoba Health undertook a primary care renewal initiative in 2006 called PIN, which included the development of specific mental health indicators for the detection and follow-up management of depression. These indicators were implemented at three PIN group practice sites in Manitoba, which are also part of Shared Mental Health Care. METHODS: The design was a non-experimental longitudinal design. A formative evaluation investigated the implementation and initial impact of mental health indicators using mixed methods (document review, survey, and interview). Quantitative data were explored using descriptive and comparative statistics, and a content and topic analysis of qualitative interviews was performed. Responses to the survey were received from 32 of the 36 physicians at the three sites. Interviews were conducted with 15 providers. Findings This evaluation illustrated providers' perceived attitudes, knowledge, skills, and behaviors related to the recognition and treatment of depression and furthered our understanding of primary care processes related to depression management related to implementation. of a new initiative. Depression is considered a major problem in primary care practice that is time consuming to diagnose, manage and treat and requires further research. Implementation of the PIN mental health indicators was variable across sites and providers.
