There was an increase in the use of indicators over time and a general feeling that the benefits of screening outweigh the costs";" however, the benefit of screening for depression remains unclear. Consistent with current guidelines, one question suggested by the findings of this evaluation is whether there are more effective ways to impact depression within primary care than screening.

title: Fostering Implementation of Health Services Research Findings in Practice: An Established Framework for Advancing Implementation Science
abstract: Background Many interventions found effective in health services research studies do not translate into meaningful patient care outcomes in multiple settings. Health services researchers recognize the need to assess not only summative outcomes but also formative outcomes to assess the extent to which implementation is effective in a specific setting, prolongs sustainability, and promotes diffusion in other settings. Many implementation theories have been published to help promote effective implementation. However, there is considerable overlap in the constructs included in individual theories, and a comparison of theories reveals that each is missing important constructs included in other theories. Also, terminology and definitions are not consistent across theories. We describe the Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research (CFIR) which offers a general typology to promote the development of implementation theory and the verification of what works, where, and why in multiple contexts. Methods We used a snowball sampling approach to identify published theories that were evaluated for constructs based on the strength of conceptual or empirical support for influencing implementation, consistency in definitions, alignment with our own findings, and the measurement potential. We combined constructs across published theories that had different labels but were redundant or overlapped in definition, and we analyzed separate constructs that merged underlying concepts. Results The CFIR is made up of five main domains: characteristics of the intervention, external environment, internal environment, characteristics of the people involved, and the implementation process. Eight constructs related to the intervention (eg, strength and quality of evidence), four constructs related to the external environment (eg, patient needs and resources), 12 constructs related to the internal environment (eg, patient needs and resources) were identified. eg, culture, leadership commitment), five constructs related to individual characteristics and eight process-related constructs (eg, planning, evaluating, and reflecting) were identified. We present explicit definitions for each construct. Conclusion CFIR provides a pragmatic framework for addressing complex, interactive, multilevel, and transient states of constructs in the real world by adopting, consolidating, and unifying key constructs from published implementation theories. It can be used to guide formative evaluations and build the implementation knowledge base across multiple studies and settings.

title: Founder and recurrent mutations of CDH1 in families with hereditary diffuse gastric cancer
abstract: Background Hereditary diffuse gastric cancer is caused by germline mutations in the epithelial cadherin gene (CDH1) and is characterized by an increased risk of diffuse gastric cancer and lobular breast cancer. Objective To determine whether recurrent germline CDH1 mutations occurred due to independent mutational events or common ancestry. Design, Setting, and Patients Thirty-eight families clinically diagnosed with hereditary diffuse gastric cancer were pooled between November 2004 and January 2006 and tested for CDH1 mutations as part of an ongoing study at the British Columbia Cancer Agency. Twenty-six families had at least 2 cases of gastric cancer with 1 case of diffuse gastric cancer in a person younger than 50 years";" 12 families had a single case of diffuse gastric cancer diagnosed in a person younger than 35 years or multiple cases of diffuse gastric cancer diagnosed in people older than 50 years. Main outcome measures Classification of family members as carriers or non-carriers of CDH1 mutations. Haplotype analysis was performed to assess recurrent mutations for common ancestry in 7 families from this study and 7 previously reported families with the same mutations. Results Thirteen mutations (6 new) were identified in 15 of the 38 families (40% detection rate). The 1137G>A splice mutation and the 1901C>T (A634V) splice/nonsense mutation occurred on common haplotypes in 2 families but on different haplotypes in a third family. The missense/splice mutation 2195G>A (R732Q) occurred in 2 families on different haplotypes. The 2064-2065delTG mutation occurred in a common haplotype in 2 families. Two families in this study plus 2 additional families carrying the novel 2398delC mutation shared a common haplotype, suggesting a founder effect. All 4 families are originally from the southeastern coast of Newfoundland. Due to concentrations of lobular breast cancer cases, 2 branches of this family had been diagnosed with hereditary breast cancer and were tested for BRCA mutations. Within these 4 families, the cumulative risk at age 75 years in mutation carriers for clinically detected gastric cancer was 40% (95% confidence interval [CI], 12%-91%) for men and 63% (95% CI, 19%-99%) for women, and the risk of breast cancer in women carrying the mutation was 52% (95% CI, 29%-94%). Conclusions Recurrent CDH1 mutations in families with hereditary diffuse gastric cancer are due to both independent mutational events and common ancestry. The presence of a Newfoundland founder mutation is strongly supported.

title: Framework for Direct Observation of Performance and Safety in Health Care
Framework for the improvement of the quality of pharmaceutical services: a bridge to cross the abyss of quality. Part I. The opportunity and the tool
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To review the literature on the subject of quality improvement principles and methods applied to pharmacy services and to describe a framework for current and future efforts in improving the quality of pharmacy services and the effective management of pharmacotherapy. BACKGROUND: The Academy of Managed Care Pharmacy developed the Catalog of Pharmaceutical Quality Indicators in 1997, followed by the Summary of National Measures of Pharmaceutical Quality in February 1999. In April 2002, the AMCP presented the Pharmaceutical Framework for Pharmaceutical Management in the XXI century. The Framework documents include a self-assessment tool that details more than 250 specific "components" that describe tasks, behaviors, skills, roles, duties, and responsibilities that contribute to meeting client expectations for effective medication therapy management. FINDINGS: There are many opportunities to improve quality in clinical, service, and cost outcomes related to the management of medication therapy. These may include "patient safety"; incidence of medical errors; adverse drug events; patient adherence to therapy; achievement of blood pressure, glucose, and lipid goals; risk reduction of adverse events adverse cardiac events and osteoporosis-related fractures; patient satisfaction; risk of hospitalization or mortality;" and cost of care. Healthcare professionals can measure improvements in the quality of medical care in a number of ways, including (a) better patient outcome at the same cost, (b) the same patient outcome at less cost, (c ) better patient outcome at lower cost, or (d) significantly better patient outcome at moderately higher cost. Measurement makes effective management possible. A framework of component factors (eg, tasks) is necessary to facilitate changes in key processes and critical factors that will help individual practitioners and health care systems meet client expectations regarding drug therapy, thus improving these outcomes. CONCLUSIONS: Quality improvement in health care services in the United States will be accomplished through incremental changes that are based on a structure-process-outcome model. The structure is provided by evidence created from randomized controlled trials and other studies of care and system outcomes that are based on the scientific method. The process part is created by applying evidence in the form of clinical practice guidelines, clinical practice models, and self-assessment tools such as the Pharmacy Framework for Medication Therapy Management. Incremental changes in structure and process will result in the desirable outcome of meeting customer needs for more effective drug therapy and disease management.

title: Framing options as choice or opportunity: does the frame influence decisions?
abstract: Goal. Health professionals should enable patients to make informed decisions about health care options through the fair presentation of all options. This study examined whether presenting the decision as "opportunity" rather than "choice" biased individuals' preferences in the context of participating in cancer treatment trials. Methods. Self-selected healthy women (N = 124) were randomly assigned to the following decision frames: opportunity to participate in the trial (opt-in), opportunity to be withdrawn from the trial (opt-out), and choice to have standard treatment or participate in the essay (choice). The computer-based task required women to make a hypothetical choice about a real-world cancer treatment trial. The software presented the framed scenario, recorded initial preference, presented comprehensive and balanced information, tracked participants' use of information during decision making, and recorded the final decision. A post-task paper-based questionnaire assessed perceived risk, attitudes, subjective norm, perceived behavioral control, and satisfaction with the decision. Results. The setting influenced the women's immediate preferences. Opportunity frames, either opt-in or opt-out, introduced bias as they discouraged women from choosing standard treatment. The use of the choice framework avoided this bias. The opportunity frame of opting out also affected the social norm perceived by women";" women felt that others supported the trial option. Framing bias was not present once participants had the opportunity to view detailed information about the options within a patient decision aid format. There were no differences between groups in information acquisition and final decisions. Sixteen percent changed their initial preference after receiving complete information. Conclusions. A "choice" framework, where all treatment options are explicit, is less likely to bias preferences. Presenting the full information in parallel format, option by attribute, is likely to "de-bias" the decision framework. It would not be advisable to adapt the information to the initial preferences, since the preferences may change after the detailed information.

title: Fraud and misconduct in clinical research
Fraud and misconduct in clinical research: does it harm patient safety?
From clinical evidence to daily practice: implementation of the findings of a cost-effectiveness analysis for endoscopic injection therapy for upper gastrointestinal bleeding
abstract: BACKGROUND: An earlier trial on upper gastrointestinal bleeding showed that patients treated with repeated injections of fibrin glue for upper gastrointestinal bleeding had significantly less rebleeding than those treated with polidocanol. OBJECTIVE: To analyze the cost and effectiveness of repeated injection of fibrin glue and to investigate whether these results change the attitude of clinicians. DESIGN: A retrospective random sample of five hospitals from the previous study, collection of cost identification and follow-up data from 320 patients (155 in the polidocanol group, 165 in the fibrin glue group). METHODS: An incremental cost-effectiveness analysis and comparison of results using chi-square tests and Kaplan-Meier survival analysis were performed. A survey was conducted through a questionnaire in the five hospitals on the local guidelines for the management of ulcer bleeding and its results were analyzed qualitatively. The measure of effectiveness is the number of new bleeds prevented. Other variables were length of hospital stay and length of stay in the intensive care unit (ICU). RESULTS: The cost of preventing one additional rebleeding by repeated fibrin glue treatment amounts to 14,316 +/- 4,981 euros (incremental cost-effectiveness ratio). There were no significant differences in the length of stays in the ICU or in the hospital. Physicians did not change their management plans for patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding. In a survey, other factors, such as local guidelines, attitudes toward new treatment options, and ease of managing medications, were found to be more important than the result of a single study for changing physician behavior . CONCLUSIONS: The study was not prospectively designed to address a pharmacoeconomic question. Since the relevant variables (eg, length of ICU stay) could not be reliably determined retrospectively, this may lead to biased estimates of incremental cost-effectiveness.

title: From evidence to experience: agreement in the topical management of psoriasis
abstract: Psoriasis vulgaris is a chronic and intermittent cutaneous-systemic inflammatory disease. Its etiology is not defined and it has a higher risk of comorbidities that affect the quality of life of patients. The objectives of this trial were to establish the concordance between the Clinical Practice Guideline (CPG) for the pharmacological treatment of plaque psoriasis and the clinical practice of a group of Mexican dermatologists, experts in the topical treatment of psoriasis";" as well as weighing the interest and knowledge about quality of life and adherence to treatment. A Delphi questionnaire was applied to 30 experts to explore their therapeutic behavior and attitudes towards the evaluation of quality of life and adherence to treatment. A meeting with a subgroup of 10 dermatologists was held to discuss the results. A second questionnaire was answered to distinguish the decisions made for topical treatment in institutional and private practice, as well as other items not explored in the first questionnaire. After analyzing the results of the questionnaires, it was clear that the data published in the Clinical Practice Guideline and the prescriptive attitude of the experts are consistent with respect to the topical treatment of plaque psoriasis. There is also agreement in the attitude regarding the prescription of medications between private and institutional health care physicians, although in private practice the use of vitamin D analogs and corticosteroids is more common and salicylic acid replaces corticosteroids in institutions .

title: From hypertension control to global cardiovascular risk management: an educational intervention in a cluster-randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Hypertension management guidelines recommend adjusting therapeutic efforts according to global cardiovascular (CVR) risk rather than just blood pressure levels. However, this paradigm shift has not yet reached general German practice. We have evaluated the effect of an educational outreach visit with general practitioners (GPs), encouraging them to consider CVR in treatment decisions for patients with hypertension. METHODS: Prospective cluster-randomized trial comprising 3443 patients with known hypertension treated by 87 general practitioners. Practices were randomly assigned to complex (A) or simple (B) intervention. Both groups received a guide by mail";" group A also received a complex peer intervention that promoted the concept of global CVR. Clinical data were collected at baseline and 6-9 months after the intervention. The primary outcome was improvement in calculated CVR in the predefined subpopulation of patients with high CVR (10-year mortality >/= 5%), but without overt cardiovascular disease. RESULTS: Adjusted to baseline, the follow-up CVR was 13.1% (95% CI 12.6%-13.6%) (A) and 12.6% (95% CI 12.2%-13, 1%) (B) with a group difference (A vs. B) of 0.5% (-0.2%-1.1%), p = 0.179. The group difference was -0.05% in GP patients familiar with global CVR and 1.1% in GP patients unfamiliar with global CVR. However, this effect modification was not significant (p = 0.165). Pooled by groups, the absolute reduction in CVR from baseline was 1.0%, p < 0.001. The ICC was 0.026 (p = 0.002). Control of hypertension (BP <140/90 mmHg) improved in the same subpopulation from 38.1 to 45.9% in the complex intervention group and from 35.6 to 46.5% in the simple intervention group, with adjusted follow-up control rates of 46.7% (95% CI 40.4%-53.1%) (A) and 46.9% (95% CI 40.3%-53.5% (B) and an adjusted odds ratio (A vs B) of 0.99 (95% CI 0.68-1.45), p = 0.966 CONCLUSIONS: Our complex educational intervention, including a clinical outreach visit, did not have a significant effect in CVR of patients with known high-risk hypertension compared with a simple postal intervention.

title: From interdisciplinarity to integrated care for children with autism: the essential role of a code of ethics
abstract: To address the developmental deficits of children with autism, several disciplines have come to the fore within intervention programs. These are speech pathologists, psychologists/counselors, occupational/physical therapists, special education consultants, behavior analysts, and physicians/medical staff. As the field of autism therapy moves toward a more comprehensive, holistic, and interdisciplinary model, the complexity of an interdisciplinary service delivery model could pose significant challenges. The difficulty of carrying out this approach could lead to substandard programs being established. Since integration across disciplines is a necessity, the ethical principles and language common to all contributing disciplines are argued as the appropriate integrating force. A summary of these principles and a draft code of ethics are provided to present high standards and expectations for all who participate in such a program.

title: From protocol to practice: translating clinical data into clinical practice
abstract: Physicians must be prepared to treat individual patients based on evidence-based risk assessments. However, ethnic minorities, the elderly, and women have been underrepresented in large-scale studies, so data to support clinical decisions for patients in these groups may be lacking. A notable example is the Framingham Heart Study, with a study population consisting of a nearly homogeneous population from a small American town. Clearly, future studies need to include more representative samples of these populations. In the meantime, the Adult Treatment Panel III guidelines should apply across the board.

title: From specialized care to self-directed treatment
Functional recovery after myocardial infarction in men: the independent effects of social class.
abstract: Background: Social class has been repeatedly associated with cardiovascular disease-related illness and death, but no study has examined the effect of social class on recovery from myocardial infarction. Furthermore, few studies have simultaneously evaluated a wide range of demographic, clinical, and psychosocial factors that may influence health outcomes after myocardial infarction. Objective: To determine whether social class remains independently associated with functional recovery after myocardial infarction, even after controlling for clinical, demographic, and psychosocial factors known to influence outcomes after myocardial infarction. Design: Prospective data analysis of a multicenter, randomized, double-blind clinical trial. Setting: 25 hospitals or clinical settings in the United States and Canada that participated in the Beta Blocker Heart Attack Trial, including the Health Insurance Plan substudy. PATIENTS: 2145 men aged 29 to 69 years who were hospitalized with acute myocardial infarction and were recruited for the Beta Blocker Heart Attack Trial. Measurements: The primary outcome was change in New York Heart Association functional class between baseline and 12 months later in farction, dichotomized as improved or not improved (ie, no change, decline in at least one category, or death). Results: Social class maintained its independent effect on improved functional status, even after controlling for relevant prognostic factors. People from high social class were significantly more likely than people from low or middle social class to have improved functional status 1 year after their heart attack. Certain clinical, demographic, and psychosocial characteristics were associated with recovery, but the effect of social class could not be explained by these additional characteristics. Conclusions: Social class has a substantial influence on recovery from myocardial infarction and may explain differences in clinical outcomes.

title: Functional Somatic Syndromes
abstract: The term functional somatic syndrome has been applied to several related syndromes that are characterized more by symptoms, distress, and disability than by consistently demonstrable tissue abnormalities. These syndromes include multiple chemical sensitivity, sick building syndrome, repetitive stress injury, side effects of silicone breast implants, Gulf War syndrome, chronic whiplash, chronic fatigue syndrome, irritable bowel syndrome and fibromyalgia. Patients with functional somatic syndromes have explicit and elaborate self-diagnoses, and their symptoms are often refractory to standard symptom reassurance, explanation, and treatment. They share similar phenomenologies, high rates of co-occurrence, similar epidemiological characteristics, and higher-than-expected prevalences of psychiatric comorbidity. Although discrete pathophysiologic causes may ultimately be found in some patients with functional somatic syndromes, the suffering of these patients is exacerbated by a cycle of self-validation and perpetuation in which common endemic somatic symptoms are incorrectly attributed to gross abnormalities, leading to reinforces the patient's belief that he or she has a serious illness. Four psychosocial factors drive this cycle of symptom amplification: "the belief that one has a serious illness"; the expectation that one's condition is likely to worsen; "sick role," including the effects of litigation and compensation"; and the alarming description of the condition as catastrophic and disabling. The climate surrounding functional somatic syndromes includes sensationalist media coverage, a deep mistrust of medical expertise and physicians, the mobilization of parties with a vested interest in the status of functional somatic syndromes, litigation, and a clinical approach that overemphasizes the biomedical and ignores the psychosocial aspects. factors All these influences exacerbate and perpetuate the somatic discomfort of patients with functional somatic syndromes, increase their fears and pessimistic expectations, prolong their disability and reinforce their role as sick. Here is a six-step strategy to help patients with functional somatic syndromes.

title: Gastroesophageal reflux disease
abstract: Heartburn two or more days a week requires medical attention, as patients are likely to have gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Chronic GERD can lead to the development of complications, such as erosive esophagitis, stricture formation, and Barrett's esophagus, which increases the risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma. A proton pump inhibitor (PPI) test is the quickest and most cost-effective way to diagnose GERD, and is at least as sensitive as 24-hour intraesophageal pH monitoring. Because PPIs only bind to actively secreting proton pumps, they should be dosed 30 to 60 minutes before a meal. Despite these recommendations, a recent survey of more than 1,000 US primary care physicians found that 36% instructed their patients to take a PPI with or after a meal or did not specify the timing of dosing . Patients who will have the best response to surgical therapy for GERD are those who have clearly documented acid reflux with typical symptoms and who have responded to PPI therapy. Unfortunately, the same survey found that most physicians recommend antireflux surgery for patients in whom medical therapy has failed.

title: General Practice Fund
Information search strategies of general practice practitioners for clinical queries encountered in daily practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Previous studies have shown that clinical consultations are common among physicians. However, data on the information-seeking behavior of general practitioners (GPs) are sparse and the numbers studied are small. OBJECTIVE: The objective of this study was to determine how often and how physicians-in-training seek answers to clinical queries encountered in daily clinical practice. METHODS: Third-year trainee GPs kept records of all patient contacts for eight consecutive practice days. Information was obtained on patient contacts (description), clinical consultations (frequency, type), search behavior (frequency, timing, reason for non-search, resources used, search duration), and responses (frequency, impact). Descriptive analyzes were performed";" Frequencies and percentages were calculated. We calculated the number of clinical consultations per patient, the number of searches per consultation, and the number of responses per search. RESULTS: Seventy-six students reported 1,533 clinical consultations on 7,300 patients with 7,619 complaints [mean 0.2 consultations per patient, standard deviation (SD) 0.1]. For most queries, students searched for an answer (mean 0.8 per query, SD 0.2), primarily during the query (61% of searches), and responses retrieved frequently (mean 0, 8 per search, SD 0.17) reported that they improved clinical decision making by 26%. The most common resources were colleagues or supervisors (28%) and national GP guidelines (26%). The median duration of a search was 4 minutes (interquartile range 3). CONCLUSION: Physicians in training have one clinical consultation for every five patients. They often tried to find answers and reported success in most searches, mainly by consulting supervisors or colleagues and national GP guidelines.

title: General practitioner views on the determinants of test ordering: a theory-based qualitative approach to developing an intervention to improve immunoglobulin ordering in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Research suggests that variation in laboratory ordering patterns may indicate unnecessary use of the test. Serum immunoglobulin ordering patterns vary significantly among general practitioners (GPs). This study aims to explore GPs' views on testing to identify behavioral determinants and recommend feasible intervention strategies to improve the use of immunoglobulin testing in primary care. METHODS: Qualitative semi-structured interviews were conducted with GPs requesting laboratory tests at Cork University Hospital or Kerry University Hospital in southern Ireland. GPs were identified using a list of laboratory doctors from the Cork-Kerry Region Health Service Executive. From this list, a random sample of GPs (stratified by GP request patterns) was generated. GPs were intentionally sampled according to the criteria of "location (urban/rural)"; qualifying time; and practice size (solo/group). Interviews were conducted between December 2014 and February 2015. Interviews were transcribed verbatim using NVivo 10 software and analyzed using the frame analysis method. Emerging themes were assigned to the Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF), which describes 12 domains that can enable or inhibit behavior change. The behavior change wheel and the behavior change technique (BCT) taxonomy were used to identify potential intervention strategies. RESULTS: Sixteen GPs were interviewed (ten men and six women). The findings suggest that intervention strategies should specifically target the key barriers to effective test ordering, considering the context of primary care practice. Seven domains of TDF were perceived to influence immunoglobulin test requesting behaviors and were identified as "mechanisms for change" (knowledge, context and environmental resources, social/professional role and identity, beliefs about capabilities, beliefs about consequences, memory, attention and decision). -processes of elaboration and regulation of behavior). Using these TDF domains, seven BCTs emerged as a feasible "intervention content" to address the ordering behavior of GPs. These included instructions on how to request the test effectively (how to perform the behavior), information on the use of the test by clinicians (behavioral feedback), information on the consequences for the patient that result from not performing the test test (information about health consequences), consultant-based lab/counseling/education (credible source), alter test order form (restructure physical environment), provide guidance (cues/clues), and add interpretive comments to tests results (add objects to the environment). These BCTs were aligned with four intervention functions: education, persuasion, environmental restructuring, and empowerment. CONCLUSIONS: This study has effectively applied behavior change theory to identify feasible strategies to improve the use of immunoglobulin testing in primary care using TDF taxonomy, 'behavior change wheel' and BCT. The identified BCTs will form the basis of a theory-based intervention to improve the use of immunoglobulin tests among GPs. Future research will involve the development and evaluation of this intervention.

title: General practitioners' reasons for the failure of a randomized controlled trial (the TIGER trial) to implement epilepsy guidelines in primary care
abstract: PURPOSE: To explore the reasons for the failure of a randomized controlled trial to influence the implementation of epilepsy guidelines in primary care and to generate a theory about the likely contexts in which the guidelines would lead to changes in clinical behaviour. METHODS: Qualitative study based on focus groups and a single in-depth interview. Participants included 47 primary health care staff selected from a purposive sample of 13 urban and rural general practices. RESULTS: The key reason for the non-implementation of the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network epilepsy guideline was an established pattern of GP behaviour, supported by practice staff, with little perceived need to change. Secondary to this was a lack of awareness of the existence and/or content of the guideline and perceived difficulties in implementing it in practice stemming from resource limitations and potential patient resistance. Thus, individual physician behavior was embedded in broader service structures and policies. CONCLUSIONS: Guidelines are more likely to be implemented when problems with current service delivery are perceived. Attempts to facilitate guideline implementation could also focus on areas where there is already a perceived need for guidance or a disruption in one of the underlying variables that sustains the role and practice of the health professional. They may also be more likely when initiatives focus more broadly than individual medical behavior and are more broadly directed toward redesigning broader care delivery systems by bringing in other providers to provide care coordination, improve self-management of the patient and use information technology tools.

title: Adoption of clinical practice guidelines by general practitioners: a qualitative study
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To explain the recent rapid audited shift in the adoption of locally implemented evidence-based clinical guidelines for asthma and angina in primary care. METHODS: A case study of primary care in two adjacent matched districts in the North of England, focusing on a stratified random sample of 49 general practitioners (GPs) from eight primary care groups. Data was collected from three cycles of mainly qualitative interviews conducted at six-month intervals, before and after the dissemination of the local guidelines and after the audit data was collected. Interviews examined attitudes, awareness and impact of locally disseminated asthma and angina guidelines and subsequent audit. Audit data on guideline adoption was also available in a parallel study. RESULTS: The rapid increase in guideline acceptance observed in the intervention and control groups was not explained by individual practitioner or practice factors. The findings are attributed to physicians' knowledge of evidence-based medicine policies, new health service institutions, and clinical governance activities of primary care groups. Behavior change reflects clinicians' decisions about what to record in case notes as well as their clinical decisions, so the findings may reflect changing perceptions about responsibility rather than preferred treatment regimens. CONCLUSIONS: Guideline production and dissemination is best viewed in the broader context of policy change. Guideline implementation studies should report before-and-after data and incorporate meaningful qualitative components to identify important contextual factors.

title: Surgeon General Antibiotic Stewardship: Scaling the Rogers Innovation Diffusion Curve: Prospective Cohort Study
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The main objective of this study was to establish the concordance of the practice of prescription of the general surgeon with the local guidelines of oral intravenous antibiotics. The secondary objective was to assess the effect of introducing educational antibiotic measures. The Rogers Diffusion of Innovation Model was used to explore the adoption of antibiotic stewardship practices. METHODS: In this prospective cohort study, data were collected from 100 patients before and 100 after the awareness intervention program. The educational intervention included raising awareness of a) guidelines b) pre-intervention outcomes c) introduction of an information sheet on oral and intravenous antibiotics. Agreement with local guidelines was compared between groups before and after the intervention using Fisher's exact test or Pearson's Chi test (SPSS Statistics V22). RESULTS: General surgery physicians' agreement with local oral and intravenous antibiotic guidelines was poor and did not improve significantly after the awareness intervention program. There was no uptake of the antibiotic indication sheet. There was a trend towards an increase in the number of patients switching from IV to oral antibiotics at 48-72 h and a significant increase (p < 0.05) in the number of patients with a clearly documented intention to review IV antibiotics. CONCLUSION: Antibiotic governance measures failed to inspire even an initial group of innovators to use antibiotic fact sheets. It appears that educational measures are effective in improving behavior and intention to prescribe among a group of early adopters, but this fails to reach critical mass. To improve antibiotic governance and embark on the Rogers Diffusion of Innovation Curve, more must be done to engage surgical general practitioners in the timely and judicious prescription of antibiotics.

title: Genetic evaluation of oocyte donors: recipient couple preferences and test results
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To report the preferences of recipient couples for the genetic study of their oocyte donors. DESIGN: Observation report of the results of a genetic testing options form implemented as part of routine care. SETTING: Private practice. PATIENT(S): Recipients and oocyte donors. INTERVENTION(S): Recipient couples completed a form prior to evaluation of their oocyte donor that described the required evaluation and recommended tests that the couple could accept or decline. The couples received information about the frequency of carriers, the risk to their child if the results were abnormal, and the cost. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE(S): Percentage of couples who accept optional tests. RESULT(S): Of the 63 couples with available data from their first Test Choices Form, 42 (67%) accepted and 21 (33%) rejected the Fragile X test, while 34 (54%) accepted and 29 ( 46%) declined the karyotype. When asked if they would agree to further testing of their donor if recommended by a genetic counselor, 15 (24%) said they would agree to further testing regardless of cost, 35 (56%) refused, and 13 (20%) indicated their decision would depend of the cost. In many cases, the genetic counselor obtained the history or the test results influenced further testing, decisions to proceed, or provided important information for the child. CONCLUSION(S): Recipient couples sometimes chose to decline tests that we recommend but do not require, despite the relatively low cost of these tests compared to the total cost of the oocyte donation cycle.

title: Genetic testing for children and adolescents. Who decides?
abstract: In the future, there is likely to be a wide variety of DNA-based tests to diagnose single-gene disorders and to identify predispositions to genetically influenced disorders. This article focuses on the ethical, legal, and psychological implications of screening healthy children and adolescents for such disorders. Testing may offer medical or psychological benefits, but may harm parent-child bonds or the child's self-concept. Physicians may encounter situations in which they must weigh the wishes of the child or adolescent against the wishes of the parents. We examine the legal history and current status of minors as consumers of health care"; psychosocial research on their maturity to make decisions; impact of evidence on intrafamily relationships; views of national commissions on appropriate ages of consent and full informed consent; ethical and legal requirements for competition in children and adolescents;” and disclosure of genetic information We propose guidelines for predictive genetic testing and counseling of children and discuss the risks and benefits of testing.

title: Genetic support for primary care physicians: a demonstration project
abstract: Primary care physicians need to be supported by specialist genetics services if they are to deal effectively with the growing importance of genetics for their patients. Genetic counselors could be effective in that role. This exploratory project aimed to improve the primary-tertiary interface by pilot testing such a service for general practice for 1 year. A genetic counselor provided personalized genetic educational outreach to ten randomly selected general practices in central England over 12 months. A variety of services were provided to practices, including facilitated genetic update sessions, a responsive counseling service, and referral guidelines. The service was evaluated through pre- and post-intervention questionnaires and through seven semi-structured interviews. This article presents an overview of the development and delivery of this service and also reports on the experiences of a sample of the participants. Participants reported positive attitudes towards the service and said they had gained knowledge and confidence, as well as recognizing limitations and gaps in their current knowledge. The ongoing link to a specialized genetics service provided by a genetic counselor had a positive impact during the project and participants have continued to use the genetic counselor for advice and support with patient genetic issues since the project was completed. This is the first example of this service delivery model. More research, using a larger sample size and other measures of behavior change, is needed to assess whether this model should be adopted more widely.

title: German translation of the Suicidal Patient Observation Chart (SPOC) - an instrument for practice
abstract: The nursing of suicidal patients is a complex and responsible task. Direct and immediate intensive care and therapeutic supervision, also known as special observation, is still recommended in the guidelines (DGPPN, 2012) and is perhaps one of the most used interventions in the care of suicidal patients in hospital settings. It involves many types to develop the relationship between the observer and the patient. The original SPOC was developed in Sweden with the aim of increasing the quality of systematic documentation during the supervision of suicidal patients. It is a tool to ensure systematic documentation of observable behavior or perceptible mood during an acute suicidal crisis, for example feelings such as 'worried, anxious' or other potential influencing factors such as 'sudden mood swing'. In this way, the SPOC can guarantee the process of systematic documentation of special observation and increase its quality, that is, who documented what at what time. In addition, SPOC can facilitate better communication of the observation process to the multidisciplinary team and also to the patient. The SPOC includes all 28 items and covers 24 separate observation periods. The objective of this work is to constitute the translation process from the SPOC version in English to the German version. The translation process followed a five-step model. In the first step, the English version was translated by two native German speakers. In the second step, the first two results of the translation were discussed by the group of experts (authors) and a new version was developed. In the third step, the first German version (two native English speakers) was translated back into English. The fourth step was taken, reviewing the results by the groups of experts (authors) and configuring the so-called "pre-version". The last step includes content validity testing by 52 nurses. The test was able to identify some misunderstandings and helped improve the tool in its final version. With the translation, the German-speaking psychiatric nursing practice has a tool that can be used by psychiatric nurses regarding their complex interventions to be performed on this special group of patients.

title: Gestational diabetes and hypertensive disorders of pregnancy as signs of vascular risk: an overview and ranking of the evidence.
abstract: The occurrence of common medical disorders related to pregnancy identifies women at high risk of developing vascular diseases in the future. Systematic reviews of cohort studies demonstrate that gestational diabetes confers a 7-fold increased risk of type 2 diabetes, and preeclampsia confers a 1.8-fold increased risk of type 2 diabetes and a 3.4-fold increased risk of type 2 diabetes. times the risk of hypertension. Gestational diabetes and hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (HDP) increase the risk of premature vascular disease, but the twofold increased risk associated with preeclampsia is only partially explained by the development of traditional vascular risk factors. Despite convincing evidence for gestational diabetes and HDP as indicators of vascular risk, there are no published Canadian vascular prevention guidelines that recognize these postpartum women. In contrast, the 2011 American Heart Association guidelines on cardiovascular disease in women include gestational diabetes and HDP in their assessment of vascular risk. Studies indicate that the importance of surveillance of vascular risk factors in these women after pregnancy is underestimated by the women themselves and their physicians. Although a prudent diet and physically active lifestyle were shown to reduce diabetes risk in women with a history of gestational diabetes in the American Diabetes Prevention Program trial, adoption of these health behaviors is low";" Qualitative studies confirm the need for personalized strategies that address barriers and provide social support. More research is also needed on approaches to reduce vascular risk in women with a history of gestational diabetes and HDP. Otherwise, an early opportunity for chronic disease prevention in high-risk young women will be missed.

title: How to make the most of financial incentives to lose weight
Global initiatives to improve cancer care in resource-limited areas: what ASCO members are doing and how you can get involved
abstract: Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. In 2008, 7.6 million deaths were attributable to cancer, which represents 13% of all deaths. It is estimated that approximately 30% of cancer deaths are attributable to the top five dietary and behavioral risks. These include a high body mass index, low consumption of fruits and vegetables, lack of physical activity, and use of tobacco and alcohol. Various viral infections, such as hepatitis B and C and HPV, are responsible for about 20% of cancer deaths. Approximately 70% of cancer deaths occurred in low- and middle-income countries. Due to increased numbers of older people and better control of comorbidity, cancer deaths worldwide are projected to continue to rise, with an estimated 13.1 million deaths in 2030. To meet this need, the The American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) has become a truly international organization. More than one-third of ASCO members practice in more than 100 countries, representing the world's largest collection of cancer treatment knowledge and insight. More than half of ASCO's Annual Meeting attendees come from outside the United States. The Journal of Clinical Oncology is read by more than 24,000 subscribers worldwide and is available in several different languages. To fulfill its mission, ASCO has a number of international programs to share knowledge and provide the tools to help physicians around the world treat their patients. These programs include mentoring and knowledge sharing, educational initiatives, and scientific and educational meetings. This provides a broad opportunity for participation in improving cancer care around the world.

title: Global Minimum Essential Requirements: A Path to Competency-Oriented Medical Education
abstract: With the increasing globalization of medicine and the emerging concept of a 'global profession of physicians', the issue of essential competencies that all physicians should possess comes into sharp focus. If defined, these competencies would help indicate what teachers are supposed to teach, what students are expected to learn, and what educational experiences all clinicians should have. The 'minimum essential competencies' that all graduates must have if they wish to be called doctors were identified by the Institute for International Medical Education (IIME), sponsored by the Chinese Medical Board of New York, through expert working groups. in educational and health policies. and representatives of major international medical education organizations. In the first phase of the project, seven domains have been identified that define the knowledge, skills, professional behavior and ethics that every doctor should have, regardless of where they received their general medical training. Appropriate tools have been identified to assess each of the domains. In the second phase of the project, the 'Global Minimum Essential Requirements' (GMER) will be piloted in various Chinese medical schools. The objective of the third phase will be to share the results of this educational experiment, aimed at improving the quality of medical education, with the global educational community.

title: Global, regional, and national life expectancy, all-cause mortality, and cause-specific mortality for 249 causes of death, 1980-2015: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2015
abstract: Background Improving survival and extending the longevity of life for all populations requires robust and timely evidence on local mortality levels and trends. The Global Burden of Disease 2015 (GBD 2015) study provides a comprehensive assessment of all-cause and cause-specific mortality for 249 causes in 195 countries and territories from 1980 to 2015. These results informed an in-depth investigation of observed mortality and expected patterns based on sociodemographic measures.";" Background Improving survival and extending the longevity of life for all populations requires robust and timely evidence on local mortality levels and trends. The Global Burden of Disease 2015 (GBD 2015) study provides a comprehensive assessment of all-cause and cause-specific mortality for 249 causes in 195 countries and territories from 1980 to 2015. These results informed an in-depth investigation of observed mortality and expected patterns based on sociodemographic measures.

title: Go
GRADE Evidence-to-Decision (EtD) Frameworks: A systematic and transparent approach to making well-informed healthcare decisions. 2: Clinical Practice Guidelines
abstract: Summary Points Physicians regularly face situations with two or more alternative actions. Each alternative often has different advantages and disadvantages, including differences in effectiveness, adverse effects, costs, and other factors Ã¢â‚¬Â¦

title: Quitting smoking gradually versus abruptly
Group cognitive behavioral therapy for first episodes of psychosis: who refers, who attends and who completes it?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Most national guidelines recommend psychological therapy for people with a first episode of psychosis (FEP), but interventions that have been shown to be effective in randomized controlled trials (RCTs) conducted in research settings are not always translated. effectively in real-world clinical settings. In a limited health system, it is important to understand system and patient barriers to engaging in effective treatment. We sought to determine which patient characteristics influenced clinicians' decisions to refer or not to group cognitive behavioral therapy for FEP and which characteristics were associated with referrals who attended/did not attend and adhered/did not adhere to the programme. METHODS: Between 2006 and 2008, all confirmed FEP cases from a defined geographic region were examined using the Structured Clinical Interview for Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fourth Edition (DSM-IV) Axis Disorders diagnoses. I of the DSM-IV-TR, the Positive Symptom Rating Scale, the Negative Symptom Rating Scale, the Calgary Depression Scale for Schizophrenia, and the Birchwood Insight Scale. The duration of untreated psychosis was established using the Beiser Scale. RESULTS: Of the 124 people (77 men, 47 women) in the final sample, 88 (72%) were referred for cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), 52 (59%) attended, and 12 (23%) did not complete CBT. Those with higher levels of knowledge about the need for treatment (U = 740.00, z = -2.63, P = 0.008) and higher levels of positive symptoms (t (120) = -3.064, P = 0.003) they were more likely to be referred. to CBT. Those with higher educational level (chi(2) = 9.48, P = 0.03) and fewer negative symptoms, particularly in relation to global attention (t (85) = 2.32, P = 0.03), they were more likely to attend and complete CBT. CONCLUSION: Within an early intervention service for FEP, it appears that people with less education, more negative symptoms, and less insight experienced significant barriers to successfully completing group CBT. More information for referring physicians about the benefits of CBT for FEP could help increase referral rates. Assertive disclosure should also be considered for individuals at risk of disengagement or non-compliance.

title: Group therapy for adolescents with repeated self-injury: a randomized controlled trial with economic evaluation.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To examine the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of group therapy for self-harm in youth. DESIGN Two-arm single-blind (assessor) parallel randomized trial of a group therapy intervention in addition to usual care, compared with usual care alone. Randomisation was performed by controlling for minimization of baseline frequency of self-harm, presence of conduct disorder, depressive disorder, and severity of psychosocial stress. PARTICIPANTS Adolescents aged 12 to 17 years with at least two previous episodes of self-harm in the previous 12 months. Exclusion criteria were: not speaking English, underweight anorexia nervosa, acute psychosis, substantial learning difficulties (defined by need for specialized school), current restraint in secure care. Setting Eight mental health services for children and adolescents in the North West of the UK. INTERVENTIONS A manual-based, developmental group therapy program designed specifically for adolescent self-harmers, with an acute phase of six weekly sessions followed by a booster phase of weekly groups for as long as needed. Details of routine care were obtained from participating centers. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was the frequency of subsequent repeated episodes of self-harm. Secondary outcomes were severity of subsequent self-harm, mood disorder, suicidal ideation, and global functioning. Total costs of health, social care, education, and criminal justice sector services, plus costs related to family and productivity losses, were recorded. RESULTS One hundred and eighty-three adolescents were assigned to each arm (total n = 366). Losses to follow-up were low (<4%). For all outcomes, the trial cohort as a whole showed significant improvement from baseline to follow-up. For the primary outcome of self-harm frequency, the proportional odds ratio for group therapy versus routine care adjusted for relevant baseline variables was 0.99 (95% confidence interval 0.68 to 1.44). , P = 0.95) at 6 months and 0.88 (0.59 to 1.33, P = 0.52) at 1 year. For severity of subsequent self-harm, the equivalent odds ratios were 0.81 (0.54 to 1.20, P = 0.29) at 6 months and 0.94 (0.63 to 1.40, P = 0.75) per year. Total 1-year costs were higher in the group therapy arm (£21,781) than for routine care (£15,372), but the difference was not significant (95% CI -1416 to 10782, P=0.132). CONCLUSIONS The addition of this targeted group therapy program did not improve self-harm outcomes for adolescents who self-harmed repeatedly, nor was there evidence of cost-effectiveness. Results to endpoint for the cohort as a whole were better than current clinical expectations. ISRCTN test record 20496110.

title: Growth and nutritional risk in children with developmental delay
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Nutritional risk impacts the outcome of developmental delay. The main objectives were to identify the incidence and contributing factors of stunting. METHODS: Clinical data review of 500 patients with developmental delay admitted to an Early Intervention service was completed. Data were collected using the standardized parental nutrition assessment checklist before and at the time of the initial dietary assessment. The data was compared to nutritional assessment data, GOSH, and the FSAI Dietary Guidelines. Weight category was determined using RCPCH and BMI growth charts. Statistical analysis was performed using the Statistical Package for the Social Sciences version 20 (IBM Statistics 20.0). RESULTS: Nutritional risk was identified in 48.6%. Weight categories were stunted (13.5%), underweight (7.7%), overweight (8.4%), and obese (4.3%) at baseline. Growth retardation was correlated with age <1 year (p = 0.000) and with gestational age (p = 0.017), with the highest rates identified in those born between 32 and 36 weeks (3.6%) . The weight category was associated with the introduction of solids before the 17-week recommendation (10.1%), showing ANOVA significance (P = 0.013). There was poor recognition by parents of nutritional risk in 22.7% of those evaluated. Nutritional difficulties were common: 4.2% were receiving enteral feeding, 7.7% were taking prescribed nutritional supplements, 29.1% (n = 121) had feeding difficulties, and 13.9% (n = 58) had feeding difficulties. had behavioral feeding difficulties. Iron intake did not meet the recommended intake in 20.9% (n = 87), calcium in 4.5% (n = 19). The prevalence of constipation was 21.6, of which 11.8% required medical management. CONCLUSIONS: Developmental delay predisposes to nutritional deficits that influence outcome. Timely screening, evaluation, and interventions are warranted to prevent poorer developmental outcomes.

title: Compliance with the guideline in the management of stable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
abstract: BACKGROUND: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is the single leading cause of death with increasing morbidity and mortality. Clinical practice guidelines (CPG) to optimize pharmacotherapy for COPD patients have been updated based on the promising results of randomized clinical trials. We examined the frequency of and factors associated with physician adherence to guidelines in clinical practice at an academic medical center. METHODS: Patients with a clinical diagnosis of COPD, confirmed by spirometry, who attended outpatient clinics, were recruited. The primary outcome was provider adherence to the 2007 Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease (GOLD) guidelines. Subjects were classified as either guideline-concordant receiving a rescue inhaler (all patients), or at least one long-acting bronchodilator (stage II), or at least one long-acting bronchodilator plus inhaled corticosteroid (stage III-IV). Demographic data, clinical information, and provider type were recorded. Provider type was classified as primary care physician (PCP), pulmonologist, or co-management of both. RESULTS: Of the 450 subjects who met the study criteria, 246 (54.7%) received guideline-based treatment. Age, gender, race, disease severity, and comorbidities were not associated with guideline adherence. Multivariate analysis showed that patients co-managed by a PCP and a pulmonologist were more likely to receive guideline-concordant treatment than those managed by one or the other (Odds Ratio: 4.59";" 95% Confidence Interval: 2.92 , 7.22, p < 0.001). CONCLUSIONS: Slightly more than half of patients with stable COPD receive guideline-concordant care. Co-management by a PCP and a pulmonologist increases the likelihood of receiving guideline-consistent inhaler therapy.

title: Guideline Implementation in Allied Health Professions: A Systematic Review of the Literature
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical guidelines aim to improve the safety and quality of patient care by providing clinicians with evidence-based, graded recommendations of best practices. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effects of the introduction of clinical guidelines for allied health professionals and to estimate the effectiveness of the strategies for dissemination and implementation of the guidelines used. METHODS: A comprehensive search of six electronic databases up to June 2006 and the Cochrane Effective Practices and Organization of Care database was performed. Randomized controlled trials, controlled clinical trials, controlled before-after studies, and interrupted time series studies were included if the intervention aimed to implement the guidelines in allied health professions. The articles were selected to determine their eligibility and their methodological quality was evaluated";" Two reviewers extracted data independently. RESULTS: Fourteen studies met the inclusion criteria. Methodological quality varied widely, with the proportion of met quality criteria ranging from 0 to 6 out of seven. In most studies, the reported effects for patient and process outcomes were small and favored the intervention group. Of the 14 included studies, 10 focused on educational interventions. Six of the 14 studies used a single intervention strategy and seven used a multifaceted implementation strategy. One study compared single and multifaceted strategies. Multifaceted interventions were not more effective than single intervention strategies and the effects of the same strategy varied between trials. CONCLUSIONS: There is no evidence to support an implementation strategy for established guidelines for allied health professionals. When implementing clinical guidelines, it is important to first identify specific barriers to change using behavior change theoretical frameworks and then develop strategies that address these barriers. When measuring the effectiveness of these strategies, practitioners should consider the use of both patient and process outcomes and choose outcomes that reflect their goals.

title: Guideline Implementation: What the Literature Doesn't Tell Us
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite a large number of studies and reviews of the literature on guideline implementation, it remains unclear if and how clinical guidelines can be used to improve quality of care. This study sought to find out whether these studies and reviews have recognized the importance of systems thinking and organizational change for implementation. METHODS: A literature search for systematic reviews of guideline implementation or practice improvement studies was conducted. Each review was studied to the extent that it identified or discussed the value of systems change, organizational support, practice environmental factors, and the use of a change process. RESULTS: Forty-seven good quality systematic reviews were found. They largely agreed that the use of reminders and perhaps feedback in the course of clinical encounters were the most effective ways of implementing the guidelines. However, these same reviews rarely identified these strategies as systems change, and there was little discussion of any need for organizational support or attention to various environmental variables that might affect implementation. The change process required to introduce a new or modified practice system received even less attention. CONCLUSION: Reviews of guideline implementation trials have focused on how to change the behavior of individual clinicians. Little attention has been paid to the impact of practice systems or organizational support on clinical behavior, the process by which change occurs, or the role of the environmental context of practice within which change is attempted. A new attention to these issues can help us better understand and begin the process of improving health care delivery.

title: 'Overweight' Guideline for Children's Health Care
abstract: The '5th National Growth Study' indicates that the percentage of overweight children in the Netherlands increased from 9 to 12% in 1997 to 13 to 15% in 2009. Child health care is a unique environment for promoting development , growth and behavior of children. children, in whom tailored prevention can be offered. The detection of overweight in children and the intervention from Child Health is developed in a multidisciplinary environment that links general practitioners, paediatricians, dietitians, teachers, physiotherapists, pedagogues and psychologists. For overweight children, a change plan is created based on exercise, playing outside, eating breakfast every day, the least possible amount of sugary drinks and fast food, and less time in front of the television or the computer, with fewer snacks energetic. As recommended in the Dutch CBO guideline 'Obesity', obese children are referred to a general practitioner or pediatrician.

title: Early guideline-based rehabilitation after myocardial infarction. A pragmatic randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To determine the effectiveness of individualized educational behavioral treatment delivered by cardiac nurses in hospital compared with usual care for patients after acute myocardial infarction. METHODS: One hundred fourteen consecutive patients were randomized to receive the intervention or usual care. Outcomes were assessed using a self-report questionnaire (Dartmouth COOP Hospital and Health Status Anxiety and Depression Scale), one month interview, and one self-report at 3 and 12 months. The primary outcome was improvement in Dartmouth COOP total score from baseline to 3 months. RESULTS: Four patients needed to be treated to give an additional patient with improved health status at 3 months (number needed to treat [NNT] 4, 95% confidence intervals [CI] 3 to 12). The intervention group was more confident in returning to activities 1 month after hospital discharge. Treated patients had fewer additional treatment needs. CONCLUSIONS: An individualized educational behavioral treatment delivered by cardiac nurses in the hospital may have substantial benefits. A pragmatic large-scale RCT is needed.

title: Community pharmacist outreach educational guidelines and visits to improve prescribing in general practice: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To assess the effectiveness of guidelines with or without personalized educational visits by community pharmacists to improve the general practice of prescribing nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). METHODS: Randomized cluster trial of 20 general practices in Avon, England. Practices were randomly assigned to three groups: control"; mailed guidelines;" mailed guidelines plus educational outreach visits. General practitioners (GPs) in the latter group received two one-to-one outreach visits from community pharmacists. Changes in prescribing were measured using outcomes derived from prescription cost and analysis data (PACT). The primary outcome measure was the change in prescription volume for ibuprofen, diclofenac, and naproxen as a percentage of the total NSAID prescription. Six secondary outcomes included other measures of prescription volume and quality. A cost-benefit analysis was performed. RESULTS: No significant difference was observed for the primary outcome measure: practices receiving extension visits prescribed only 2.1% [95% confidence interval (CI) -0.8 to 5.0] more than all three recommended NSAIDs than control practices and 1.6% (95% CI -1.4 to 4.7) more than practices receiving guidelines only. After adjustment for multiple comparisons, only one secondary outcome showed a statistically significant difference between groups: the proportion prescribing the five most commonly used medicines was 2.2% (95% CI 0.9 to 3.6) higher in the educational outreach group compared to the control group A net increase in costs was shown with both interventions. CONCLUSIONS: Although good baseline prescribing in participating practices limited the ability for improvement, this trial provides no evidence that guidelines with or without outreach community pharmacist educational visits lead to substantial improvements in prescribing behaviour.

title: Guidelines and psychology of medical decision making in the treatment of depressive disorders
abstract: The guidelines aim to improve medical decision making. Guidelines attempt to influence medical behavior in contrast to textbooks and reviews that seek to improve medical knowledge. Scientific models of medical decision making, such as theory of action and empirical data on the effects of guidelines, suggest that guidelines will not always achieve their goal, but may even deteriorate medical quality. The problem of guidelines in medicine in reference to depressive disorders is discussed. The issues at stake are, however, valid for medicine as a whole. Therefore, it needs to be tested in controlled clinical trials whether physicians exposed to the guidelines have better outcomes with their patients than physicians who do not follow them. Only such guidelines should be called evidence-based for which positive effects have been empirically demonstrated.

title: Guidelines as rationale tools: a qualitative analysis of psychosocial patient selection criteria for cardiac procedures
abstract: BACKGROUND: Cardiac procedure guidelines often include psychosocial criteria for selecting patients that potentially introduce social value judgments into clinical decisions and decisions about the rationing of care. The aim of this study was to investigate the terms, justifications, and meanings of psychosocial patient characteristics used in cardiac procedure guidelines. METHODS: We selected English-language guidelines published since 1990 and textbook chapters published since 1989. These guidelines merged multiple sources of evidence and experience and made recommendations regarding patient selection for specific procedures. A multidisciplinary team of clinicians and social scientists extracted passages on psychosocial criteria and developed categories and conceptual relationships to describe and interpret their content. RESULTS: Sixty-five articles met the inclusion criteria for the study. Forty-five (69%) mentioned psychosocial criteria as indications or contraindications for the procedure. The latter was classified into several categories, including behavioral and psychological problems, relationships with significant others, financial resources, social roles, and environmental circumstances. INTERPRETATION: Psychosocial characteristics are described as having 2 roles in patient selection: as risk factors intrinsic to the candidate or as indicators of the need for special intervention. Guidelines often simply list psychosocial contraindications without clarifying their specific nature or providing any rationale for their use. Psychosocial considerations can help in evaluating patients for cardiac procedures, but become ethically controversial when used to restrict access. The use of psychosocial indications and contraindications could be improved with more precise descriptions of the psychosocial problem in question, explanations as to why the criterion is important, and justification of the feature using a biological rationale or research evidence.

title: Guidelines for Adolescent Preventive Services: GAPS in Practice
abstract: DESIGN: Comparison of pre- and post-Guidelines for Adolescent Preventive Services (GAPS) results collected through chart audit. SETTING: A general pediatric clinic based in a rural hospital. PARTICIPANTS: Adolescents who underwent annual examinations between April 1, 1998 and March 31, 2001. A random sample of 441 medical records was reviewed. INTERVENTION: Training in the GAPS model and use of the questionnaire began in April 1998. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Detection, discussion, and referral of GAPS-related risk behaviors. RESULTS: The medical records of 162 minor adolescents (11-15 years) and 279 older adolescents (16-19 years) were audited. Detection of risk behaviors increased from 19% at baseline to 95% with initial GAPS and 87% with periodic GAPS. The most prevalent risk factor was having a rifle or pistol in the home (younger adolescents, 47% and older adolescents, 39%). The mean number of risk behaviors and documented health problems was higher in the initial GAPS (4.8 and 1.3, respectively) than in the periodic GAPS (3.8 and 0.7) (p = 0.01 and 0.006). GAPS questionnaires detected lower levels of risk behavior compared to a local Youth Risk Behavior Survey. Controlling for gender, age, and physician, discussion of psychosocial issues increased during the study period";" however, there was considerable variation among clinicians regarding the topics addressed. The GAPS-related referral rate did not change significantly. CONCLUSION: The GAPS model increases the detection and discussion of risk behaviors by physicians.

title: Guidelines for assessing postnatal problems: introducing evidence-based guidelines into Australian general practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Postnatal morbidity is high and many GPs lack the confidence and knowledge to treat common postnatal problems. There is a high consultation rate, but few women disclose common health problems. OBJECTIVE: The aim of the present study was to increase the knowledge and skills of general practitioners so that they can identify and manage common health problems experienced by women in the year following childbirth. METHODS: An educational program [Guidelines for the Assessment of Postnatal Problems (GAPP)] integrated into a large randomized community intervention trial [Program for Resources, Information and Support for Mothers (PRISM)] with a before/after evaluation was conducted by clinicians Australians working in four metropolitan and four rural communities. The program comprised audit, interactive workshops, role plays, and evidence-based guidelines, and was assessed at baseline and at 6 months through written questionnaires and a surgery consultation with a trained simulated patient evaluator. RESULTS: A total of 68 (86%) physicians participated in the full GAPP program. The odds of a GP improving on knowledge items ranged from 1.0 to 16, with the greatest change occurring in knowledge about the efficacy of cognitive behavioral therapy for maternal depression. Of the GPs with an incorrect response at baseline, the percentage who demonstrated better knowledge at follow-up ranged from 22% to 100%. About half of the GPs demonstrated excellent communication skills at the start of the study. Of the remaining GPs, more than half showed a great improvement in their abilities to detect common postnatal problems during follow-up. At the initial simulated patient visit, 70% of GPs asked about sexual problems but none asked about the possibility of abuse, while at follow-up 94% asked about sexual problems and 51.5% facilitated disclosure of physical and emotional abuse. Anonymous feedback on the program from participating physicians showed that 89% believed that the program positively influenced their actual practice. Interestingly, the GPs demonstrated greater knowledge and skills in the simulated environment than in the written questionnaire. CONCLUSIONS: This relatively short, multifaceted educational program helped many participants improve their knowledge and skills needed to improve physical and emotional health after birth. Despite being experienced clinicians and actively participating in a program on interviewing skills, half of GPs did not facilitate disclosure of the underlying sensitive issue (abuse) during follow-up consultation and could benefit from more in-depth skills training of effective communication.

title: Guidelines for Family-Centered Care in the Neonatal, Pediatric, and Adult ICU
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To provide physicians with evidence-based strategies to optimize support for the family of critically ill patients in the ICU. METHODS: We used the Council of Medical Specialty Societies principles for clinical guideline development as a framework for guideline development. We assembled a 29-member international multidisciplinary team with expertise in guideline development, evidence analysis, and family-centered care to revise the 2007 Clinical Practice Guidelines for Family Support in the Patient-Centered ICU. We conducted a scoping review of qualitative research that explored family-centered care in the ICU. Thematic analyzes were conducted to support the development of Population, Intervention, Comparison, and Outcome questions. Patients and families validated the importance of the interventions and outcomes. We then carried out a systematic review using the Recommendation Rating, Evaluation, Development and Evaluations methodology to make recommendations for practice. The recommendations were submitted to electronic voting with pre-established voting thresholds. No industry funding was associated with the development of the guideline. RESULTS: The scoping review yielded 683 qualitative studies; 228 were used for thematic analysis and development of Population, Intervention, Comparison, and Outcome questions. The systematic review search returned 4158 reports after deduplication and an additional 76 studies were added from flags and handsearches; 238 studies met the inclusion criteria. We made 23 recommendations with a moderate, low and very low level of evidence on the topics of: communication with family members, family presence, family support, consultations and members of the ICU team, and operational and environmental aspects. We provide recommendations for future research and work tools to support the translation of the recommendations into practice. CONCLUSIONS: These guidelines identify the evidence base for best practices for family-centered care in the ICU. All recommendations were weak, highlighting the relative nascentness of this field of research and the importance of future research to identify the most effective interventions to improve this important aspect of ICU care.

title: Guidelines for improving entry and retention in care and adherence to antiretrovirals for people living with HIV: evidence-based recommendations from a panel of the International Association of Physicians in AIDS Care
abstract: DESCRIPTION: After HIV diagnosis, timely entry into, and retention in, HIV medical care are essential to providing effective antiretroviral therapy (ART). Adherence to ART is one of the key determinants of successful HIV treatment outcome and is essential to minimizing the emergence of drug resistance. The International Association of Physicians in AIDS Care convened a panel to develop evidence-based recommendations to optimize entry and retention in care and adherence to ART for people with HIV. METHODS: A systematic literature search was conducted to produce an evidence base restricted to randomized controlled trials and observational studies with comparators having at least 1 biological or behavioral endpoint measured. A total of 325 studies met the criteria. Two reviewers independently extracted and coded data from each study using a standardized data extraction form. Panel members wrote recommendations based on the body of evidence for each method or intervention and then rated the overall quality of the body of evidence and the strength of each recommendation. RECOMMENDATIONS: Recommendations are provided for monitoring entry and retention in care, interventions to improve entry and retention, and monitoring and interventions to improve adherence to ART. The recommendations cover ART strategies, adherence tools, education and counselling, and health system and service delivery interventions. In addition, they cover specific topics related to pregnant women, people deprived of their liberty, the homeless and people in poverty, children and adolescents, as well as substance use and mental health disorders. Recommendations for future research in all areas are also provided.

title: Guidelines for the interaction of the therapeutic team in the hospital treatment of patients with chronic neurotic disorders
abstract: In the treatment of hospitalized patients with chronic neurotic disorders, we try to reduce the distress in the therapeutic team (doctors, nurses, other therapists) that these patients usually cause and improve the outcome of the treatment. Therefore, the therapeutic team was given three to five guidelines on how to treat the patient, and illustrated with possible verbatim statements to the patient. The guidelines aimed at a general interactional approach with the patient and did not determine specific therapeutic interventions. They were established following the principles of Brief Therapy as developed at the Mental Research Institute in Palo Alto. The results of our intervention in the treatment of ten patients are reported. The therapeutic team rated the patterns as generally positive. The therapeutic result varied a lot. A comparison with a matched-pair control group showed a favorable trend. Initial team ratings of prescriptions predicted eventual patient improvement.

title: Medical Treatment Guidelines for Stroke Prevention
Guidelines for the Management of the Quality of the Apalic Syndrome/Vetative State
