abstract: INTRODUCTION: Epidemiology in Europe shows steadily increasing figures for apallic syndrome (AS)/vegetative state (VS) as a consequence of advanced rescue, emergency services, intensive care treatment after acute brain injury, and activating home nursing from high level to the completely dependent end. -Cases in secondary stage to progressive neurological disease. The management of patients with irreversible permanent AS/VS has been the subject of a sustained scientific and moral-legal debate during the last decade. METHODS: A working group on guidelines for quality management of AS/VS was established under the auspices of the Scientific Panel on Neurotraumatology of the European Federation of Neurological Societies to address key issues related to the prevalence of AS/VS and the management of AS/VS. quality. The collection and analysis of scientific data on class II (III) evidence from the literature and recommendations based on best practices as a result of the experience of the members of the task force are in accordance with the EFNS Guidance regulations. FINDINGS: The overall incidence of new cases of full-stage AS/SV of all etiologies is 0.5-2/100,000 population per year. About a third are traumatic cases and two thirds are non-traumatic. Increasing rates of hypoxic brain damage and progressive neurological disease have been noted. The main conceptual criticism is based on the evaluation and diagnosis of all the different stages of AS/VS based solely on behavioral findings without knowing the exact or uniform pathogenesis or neuropathological findings and the uncertainty of the clinical evaluation due to the different evaluation criteria. inclusion. No special diagnosis, no specific medical management can be recommended for the treatment and rehabilitation of AS class II or III. This is why the sine qua non diagnoses of the clinical features and proper management of AS/VS patients in "complete, remission, defect, and terminal stages" require further professional training and experience for clinicians. and rehabilitation staff. INTERPRETATION: The management of AS aims at the social reintegration of patients or should guarantee active humanistic nursing if the treatment fails. The outcome depends on the cause and duration of AS/VS, as well as the age of the patient. There is no single AS/VS-specific laboratory investigation, no specific regimen, or stimulant intervention that is recommended to improve higher brain function. Quality Management requires at least 3 years of advanced training and continuing education to gain qualification approval for AS/VS treatment and experience. Sine qua non areas covering AS/SV institutions are required for early and long-term rehabilitation on a population basis (prevalence of 2/100,000/year) to accelerate functional restoration and prevent or treat complications. Care homes are needed for a respectful and humane nursing that includes basal sensory-motor stimulation techniques. Passive euthanasia is considered an act of mercy by doctors in terms of denying treatment";" however, ethical and legal issues regarding nutrition and hydration withdrawal and end-of-life discussions raise profound concerns. The aim of the guideline is to provide management guidance (based on the best class II and III medical evidence or work group experience) for neurologists, neurosurgeons, other physicians working with patients with AS/VS, neurorehabilitation staff, patients , relatives, and health authorities.

title: Guidelines for Reporting Health Interventions via Mobile Phones: Checklist for Reporting and Evaluation of Mobile Health (mHealth) Evidence (mERA)
abstract: To improve the integrity of reporting of mHealth interventions, the WHO mHealth Technical Evidence Review Group developed the mHealth Evidence Assessment and Reporting (mERA) Checklist. The mERA development process consisted of convening a group of experts to recommend an appropriate approach, convening a global expert review panel for checklist development, and pilot testing the checklist. The guiding principle for the development of these criteria was to identify a minimum set of information necessary to define what the mHealth intervention is (content), where it is being implemented (context), and how it was implemented (technical characteristics), to support replication of the mHealth intervention. intervention. This document presents the resulting 16-item checklist and a detailed explanation and elaboration of each item, with illustrative reporting examples. Through widespread adoption, we hope that the use of these guidelines will standardize the quality of mHealth evidence reporting and indirectly improve the quality of mHealth evidence. #### Summary Points Mobile technologies have the potential to close the systemic gaps needed to improve access to and use of health services, particularly among underserved populations. mHealthâ€ defined as the use of mobile and wireless technologies for healthâ€ aims to capitalize on the rapid uptake of information and communication technologies (ICTs) to improve health system efficiency and health outcomes. Over the past decade, global enthusiasm and interest in development Ã¢â‚¬Â¦

title: Guidelines for the use and interpretation of autophagy monitoring assays (3rd edition)
Guidelines in professions related to medicine
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical practice guidelines aim to reduce inappropriate variations in practice and promote evidence-based health care delivery. OBJECTIVES: To identify and evaluate the effects of studies on the introduction of clinical practice guidelines in nursing (including health visits), midwifery, and other professions related to medicine. SEARCH STRATEGY: We searched the Cochrane Effective Practice and Organization of Care Group Specialized Register, MEDLINE (1975 to 1996), EMBASE, Cinahl and Sigle to 1996, the NHS Economic Evaluations Database (1994 to 1996), DHSS-Data (1983 to 1996). ), the Effectiveness Review Abstracts Database (1994 to 1996), and article reference lists. We also hand-searched the journal Quality in Health Care, made personal contact with content experts, and contacted libraries identified by a panel of experts. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized trials, controlled before-and-after studies, and interrupted time series analyzes of the introduction of interventions comparing 1. Clinical guidelines plus dissemination and/or implementation strategies versus no guidelines"; 2. Guidelines plus dissemination strategies dissemination and/or implementation versus guidelines plus alternative dissemination and/or implementation strategies, and 3. (post hoc) Guidelines used by allied professions versus standard healthcare Participants were nurses, midwives, and other allied professions. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two reviewers independently extracted data and assessed study quality MAIN RESULTS: Eighteen studies involving more than 467 health professionals were included Reporting of study methods was inadequate for all studies. In all but one study, nurses were the professional target group;" one study was aimed at dieticians only. The various behaviors addressed included the management of hypertension, low back pain, and hyperlipidemia. Nine studies were identified for comparison 1. Three of five studies found improvements in at least some processes of care and six of eight studies found improvements in outcomes of care. Only one study included a formal economic evaluation, with equivocal results. Three studies were identified for comparison 2, but it was difficult to draw firm conclusions due to poor methods. Six studies were identified for comparison 3 (post hoc). In general, these studies supported the hypothesis that there was no difference between nursing care using clinical guidelines and standard medical care. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: There is some evidence that guideline-guided care is effective in changing the process and outcome of care provided by medical-related professions. However, caution is needed in generalizing the findings to other professions and settings.

title: Guidelines on the management of smoking during the perioperative period
abstract: Smoking is a public health problem of particular importance during the perioperative period, since it exposes patients scheduled for surgery to increased risks of 20% in hospital mortality and 40% in major postoperative complications. Furthermore, current smoking increases almost all specific surgical complications. The perioperative period offers a real opportunity to quit smoking. The preoperative smoking cessation rate can be significantly increased by offering behavioral management and prescribing a nicotine replacement before any elective surgery. Preoperative smoking cessation should be routinely recommended regardless of the time of surgery, although the benefits increase in proportion to the duration of cessation. All healthcare professionals (general practitioners, surgeons, anesthesiologists-intensivists, caregivers) must inform smokers of the positive effects of quitting smoking and offer them dedicated management and personalized follow-up. In children, parental smoking cessation or removal of the child from environmental tobacco smoke as much before surgery as possible is essential.

title: Guidelines, Publishers, Pharmaceuticals, and the Biological Paradigm Shift
abstract: Private investment in biomedical research has increased in recent decades. In most places it has been hailed as the next best thing to technology itself. Much of the intellectual talent in academic institutions is being absorbed into lucrative positions in industry. Applied research finds willing collaborators in the venture-funded industry, thus ensuring symbiotic growth for both. There are also significant costs involved. As academia interacts with industry, important areas of conflict of interest especially applicable to biomedical research have emerged. They are related to disputes over patents and royalties, hostile encounters between academia and industry, as well as between public and private companies, legal entanglements, research misconduct of various kinds, antagonistic press and lobbying of patient advocates and a general atmosphere in which commercial interest gets in the way. precedence over the welfare of the patient. The pharmaceutical image sucks due to a series of errors of omission and commission. A recent example is the suppression of negative results on Bayer's Trasylol (Aprotinin) and Eli Lilly's Xigris (rhAPC) marketing ploys. Whenever there is a conflict between patient vulnerability and profit motives, the pharmaceutical industry often tends to lean toward the latter. In addition, there are documents that bring to light how companies frequently cross the line between patient welfare and profit-seeking behavior. A voluntary moratorium on pharmaceutical spending is necessary to pamper drug prescribers. A code of conduct recently adopted by OPPI in India to limit drug companies' spending on travel and trinkets is a welcome step. Clinical practice guidelines (CPG) are considered important as they guide the diagnostic/therapeutic regimen of a large number of medical professionals and hospitals. and provide recommendations on medications, their doses and selection criteria. Along with clinical trials, they are another area of growing influence for the pharmaceutical industry. For example, a relatively recent survey from 2002 found that about 60% of 192 clinical practice guideline authors reported having financial connections to the companies whose drugs were under consideration. There is a strong case for making CPG based not only on effectiveness but also on profitability. The various ramifications of this need to be detailed. The work of bodies such as the Research Assessment and Guidelines Evaluation (AGREE) Collaboration and the Guidelines Advisory Committee (GAC) also deserve a close look. Even the actions of foundations working to improve disease have come under scrutiny. The process of establishing 'Best Practice' Guidelines for interactions between the pharmaceutical industry and physicians has already begun and may have important consequences for patient care. Similarly, Good Publication Practices (GPP) have also been established for pharmaceutical companies with the aim of improving the behavior of pharmaceutical companies when reporting drug trials. The rapidly growing trend towards industry influence and control has become a concern for many. It is of such importance that the Association of American Medical Colleges has issued two relatively new documents: one, in 2001, on how to deal with individual conflicts of interest"; and the other, in 2002, on how to deal with institutional conflicts of interest in the conducting clinical research Academic Medical Centers (AMCs), as well as medical research and education institutions elsewhere, need to adopt means that minimize their conflicts of interest Both medical associations and research journal publishers are becoming concerning institutional conflicts of interest in the conduct of clinical research and available documents addressing these issues fully responsible for the design and implementation of the sayo, have independent access to all trial data and control all editorial and publication decisions. However, the findings of a 2002 study suggest that academic institutions routinely participate in clinical research that does not adhere to ICMJE standards of accountability, data access, and publication control. There is an inevitable tendency to produce not necessarily useful but marketable products that guarantee the profitability of industry and the outflow of research grants to academia. The industry supports new, non-traditional therapies, regardless of how effective they are. Whichever traditional therapy is supported is probably because the company in question has a product with a lot of interest there, that has remained a "gold standard" or that player thinks they still have some "juice" left. . Industry sponsorship is primarily for potential drugs, not for trying to determine if there might be non-drug interventions that might be just as good, if not better. In the paradigm shift to biological psychiatry, the role of industry sponsorship is not obvious, but probably more pervasive than many have realised, or correct thinking may consider good, for the health of the branch in the long run. term. An issue of great concern is protection of the interests of research subjects. Patients agree to become research subjects not only for personal medical benefit but, as an extension, to benefit the rest of the patient population and also to advance medical research. The pharmaceutical industry is huge. However, we must also accept that there is a fundamental difference between marketing strategies for other entities and those for medicines. The last barometer is the well-being of the patient and no drug that compromises it can stand the test of time. So how does it make long-term business sense to market substandard products? The biggest mistake long-term players in the industry can make is trying to adopt the shady techniques of the new upstart entrant. The secret of marketing/sales tactics, of the manufacturing process, of other strategies and business expansion plans, of strategies to face the competition are good business tactics. But it is critical that secrecy as a tactic does not extend to the reporting of research results, especially those that are contrary to one's product. Pharma has no choice but to make a quality product, do full adverse reaction profiles, and market it only if it passes both tests. .Why is the pharmaceutical industry adopting questionable tactics? The reasons are essentially two: with all the limitations, a drug reaches the pharmacy after large investments. There are crippling overhead and infrastructure costs to recover. And there are massive profit margins that need to be maintained. If these were to depend solely on genuine drug discoveries, that would be taking too great a risk. Industry players must strike the right balance between profit generation and credibility. In making a profit, marketing champions play their part. In credibility ratings, researchers and paid spokespersons play their part. Everything is going from strength to strength until marketing is based on credibility. When nothing is available to build credibility, something is projected as one and marketing is done, in the calculated hope that profits can be accrued, as profit making must continue unabated. That is what makes the pharmaceutical industry adopt even questionable means to make a profit. Essentially, there are four types of medications. First, drugs that work and have minimal side effects; second, drugs that work but have serious side effects; third, drugs that don't work and have minimal side effects; and fourth, drugs that work minimally but have serious side effects. It is the second and fourth types that create the biggest problems for the industry. Often the industry may try to cast The Fourth Guy as the second to escape censorship. The main game is to prevent the second type from projecting as the first. The third type is essentially harmless, thus attracting censorship and some mirth from antics to market them. But they escape anything more than a light tap on the knuckles. , except when they are cast as the first type. What is necessary for captains of industry and long-term players is to realize: Your main driving force can only be producing the first type. 2. They accept the second type. just until they can get their hands on the first one. 3. You can occasionally play the third type to shore up profits, but never project them like the first type. 4. The fourth type is the laggards, a real threat to credibility and therefore not worthy of any publicity or market promotion. Finding out why most drug companies indulge in questionable tactics, we found some interesting solutions to avoid such tactics with the least amount. of inconvenience for all involved, even though both profits and credibility remain intact.

title: Guidelines-based indicators for measuring the quality of antenatal care
abstract: RATIONALE, PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVES: There is no comprehensive measurement of the quality of prenatal care. Late booking or low number of checks are often used as proxies for poor quality, leading to uncertainty about the actual content of care received. To fill this gap, we have reviewed two sets of clinical guidelines and developed corresponding quality indicators. METHOD: A group of physicians and methodologists reviewed the National Institute for Clinical Excellence Clinical Guidelines on antenatal care and the list of antenatal care interventions recommended by the Research and Development Group, both based on evidence of the effectiveness of specific interventions . We identify unique aspects in three domains: (1) use of services; (2) detection; and (3) interventions. For each indicator, we define: (1) eligibility, that is, the characteristics of the women to whom the indicator applies. ; (2) standard, which is the situation when the objective is met;" and (3) moderators, that is, all the conditions that legitimately hinder compliance with the norm. RESULTS: We developed four service utilization indicators, 25 screening and intervention 17. For each indicator, the respective eligibility, standard, and moderating criteria were described. While many indicators can be retrospectively assessed from medical records, the quality of communication with the provider, the detection of sensitive problems, and the advice on behaviors to avoid can only be obtained with prospective data collection CONCLUSIONS: Indicators of quality of antenatal care, complemented by measures of social position, social support and ethnic/immigrant status, allow careful description of gaps in the quality of care for specific groups of women.

title: Stopping antipsychotic use in long-term care (HALT): a single-arm longitudinal study aiming to reduce inappropriate antipsychotic use in long-term care residents with behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia
abstract: BACKGROUND: Inappropriate use of antipsychotic medications to manage behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD) continues despite revised guidelines and evidence of associated risks and side effects. The goal of the Stopping Antipsychotics in Long-Term Care (HALT) project is to identify residents of long-term care (LTC) facilities who are taking antipsychotic medications and undertake an intervention to deprescribe (or discontinue) these medications and improve non-pharmacological health. behavior management METHODS: The LTC facility will be contracted in Sydney, Australia. The inclusion criteria for residents will be older than 60 years, with regular antipsychotic medication and without a primary psychotic illness or very severe SCPD, measured by the Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI). The data collection will be carried out one month and one week before the start of the deprescription";" and 3, 6 and 12 months later. During the pre-deprescription period, training will be provided to care staff on how to reduce and manage SCPD using person-centered approaches, and academic information will be provided to participants' GPs. The primary outcome measure will be the reduction of regular antipsychotic medication without the use of substitute psychotropic medications. Secondary outcome measures will be NPI total and domain scores, Cohen-Mansfield Agitation Inventory scores, and adverse events, including falls and hospitalizations. CONCLUSION: While previous studies have outlined strategies to minimize the inappropriate use of antipsychotic medications in people with dementia living in long-term care, sustainability and a prescribing culture of BPSD in elderly care remain challenges. The HALT project aims to assess the feasibility of a multidisciplinary approach to deprescribing antipsychotics in this population.

title: Harnessing the power of default options to improve healthcare
abstract: Decision makers are sometimes faced with a default choice: the option that will be implemented if an alternative is not actively chosen. The quality of medical care can be improved through predetermined options, such as giving vaccinations to eligible hospitalized patients who do not refuse them. The authors argue that these options should be strategically established and used to improve public health.

title: hazards at work
Head Start children's lifestyle behaviors, parents' perceptions of weight and body mass index
abstract: This study examined lifestyle behaviors (food intake, active play, and screen time), parental perceptions of children's weight, and body mass index (BMI) of children enrolled in Head Start. 96 parent-child dyads participated. The prevalence of obesity (15.6%) was higher than the national average (10.4%)";" however, most parents (86.5%) of obese children did not perceive their children as obese. Regardless of BMI, food intake and levels of active play generally did not meet recommended guidelines. Additionally, children who were less active were more likely to snack (chi(2) = 6.24, p < or = 0.04). The role of pediatric nurses in counseling and referral of Head Start families is explored.

title: Heal yourself or your system: can doctors help improve medical care?
Health and nutrition education unit in a children's hospital
Health information, behavior change and decision support for patients with type 2 diabetes: development of a tailored and preference-sensitive health communication application
abstract: PURPOSE: Patient involvement in diabetes management, such as shared decision-making and patient self-management, has significant effects on clinical parameters. As a prerequisite for active participation, patients must be adequately informed and sensitive to their preferences. Interactive Health Communication Applications (IHCA) that combine web-based health information for patients with additional support offer the opportunity to reach large numbers of patients at low cost and provide them with high-quality information and support in the moment, the location and rate of learning. they prefer. Still, web-based interventions often suffer from high attrition. Tailoring the intervention to patients' needs and preferences could reduce attrition and therefore should increase effectiveness. The purpose of this study was to develop a personalized IHCA that offered evidence-based, preference-sensitive content and treatment decision support for patients with type 2 diabetes. The content was developed based on a needs assessment and two guidelines. evidence-based treatment. The delivery format is a dialogue-based tunneled design that tailors the content and tone of the dialogue to relevant patient characteristics (health education, attitudes toward self-care, and psychological barriers to insulin treatment). Both content and adaptation were reviewed by an interdisciplinary advisory committee. CONCLUSION: The World Wide Web has great potential for patient information and self-management interventions. With the development and evaluation of a personalized IHCA, we complement the face-to-face consultations of patients with their health professionals and make them more efficient and satisfactory for both parties. The effects of the app are currently being tested in a randomized controlled trial.

title: Health literacy training for public health nurses in Fukushima: a case study of program adaptation, implementation and evaluation
abstract: Health literacy encompasses not only an individual's ability to access, understand, and use health information, but also the ability of health care providers to make health information accessible and usable. The Fukushima nuclear accident has posed challenges related to the communication of radiation-related health information. Public health nurses are gatekeepers of community health in Japan and have primary responsibility for communicating this complex science and risk information to lay members of the community. A health literacy training program was designed to increase the communication skills of participating nurses with two main goals: to change communication practices and norms among public health nurses and to improve access to information for residents of the public health unit. community. Training content incorporated an overview of health literacy skills (including numeracy), processes for evaluating written materials and visual presentations, and guidelines for improving text. The workshop was spread over two days with two-hour sessions each day. A post-training proximal evaluation survey was conducted, followed by a more distal one-month follow-up evaluation to assess the application of learned skills in practice. Twenty-six nurses from the city of Fukushima attended the first trial. Post-training evaluations were very positive, with 85-100% agreement by participants on the appropriateness and usefulness of the workshop. During a one-month follow-up, the nurses reported applying new knowledge and skills to develop written materials. However, they faced difficulties in sharing their new skills with colleagues and challenges in changing work regulations. Participants also found it difficult to use graphics and explain risks in practice. This document highlights the importance of providing health literacy training opportunities for professionals to strengthen the capacity of the health system to provide accessible information and services. This program also serves as an important reference for future disaster management efforts.

title: Attitudes of health professionals towards the management of acute diarrhea
abstract: BACKGROUND: Traveler's diarrhea is the most common health problem in those involved in international travel, and is responsible for many consultations abroad and on return home. METHODS: A questionnaire to assess attitudes towards the treatment and management of travel-related and non-travel-related diarrhea was administered to 542 GPs, nurses and pharmacists. RESULTS: Health professionals' attitudes toward the management of acute diarrhea are variable, with marked divergence regarding adherence to published "good practice" guidelines and recommendations. There are inconsistencies in stated attitudes towards prescribing antispasmodic and antimotility agents and actual prescribing behaviour. CONCLUSIONS: Current treatment guidelines may be outdated. Inappropriate or late treatment harms the patient. Limiting the use of antidiarrheal agents may deny diarrhea sufferers access to medication that can shorten symptoms and morbidity, and hasten a return to normalcy. Revision of guidelines for the management of diarrhea in adults is overdue, as is standardization of response to treatment. Educational initiatives are required to encourage active intervention and improvement of care delivery.

title: Health Promotion in Adolescent and Young Adult Cancer Survivors: Mobilizing Compliance in a Multifaceted Risk Profile
abstract: With increasing cure rates for childhood cancer, nurses are more likely to encounter a large cohort of survivors in practice. There are a variety of late effect programs";" however, funding is limited for these programs and not accessible to all patients. Primary providers can increasingly act as a medical home for childhood cancer survivors (CCS). Understanding the inherent risks of cytotoxic therapy and the progressive consequences of late effects is vital to limiting morbidity and mortality. Adolescent and young adult (AYA) survivors are particularly apt to make behavioral health decisions that create risks for comorbidities. Developmentally appropriate experimentation with the use of drugs, alcohol, or tobacco and increased exposure to ultraviolet rays increase the risk of secondary malignancies and new diseases. The dearth of evidence-based surveillance guidelines and survivor-specific health promotion programs cumulatively increases the gap in noncompliance and misinformation. This article summarizes the risk profile of CCS. It explores health practices, as well as emerging health promotion techniques, within the AYA survivor population and the role nurse practitioners have in improving health maintenance.

title: Assessment of the orientation of health systems: a critical interpretive synthesis
abstract: Background Health Systems Guidelines (HSGs) are systematically developed statements that assist with decisions about options to address health systems challenges, including related changes in healthcare systems arrangements. Health. However, HSG development, evaluation, and reporting pose unique conceptual and methodological challenges related to the various types of evidence that are relevant, the complexity of health systems, and the pre-eminence of contextual factors. To address this gap, we are conducting a research program that aims to create a tool to support HSG assessment and further improve HSG development and reporting. The focus of this paper was to conduct a knowledge synthesis of the gray and published literature to determine the quality criteria (concepts) relevant to this process. Methods We applied a critical interpretive synthesis (CIS) approach to knowledge synthesis that enabled an iterative, flexible, and dynamic analysis of various bodies of literature to generate a candidate list of concepts that will constitute the fundamental components of the HSG tool. Using our review questions as compasses, we were able to guide the search strategy to find documents based on their potential relevance to HSG assessment, development, and reporting. The search strategy included various databases and electronic sources, journals, conference proceedings, research reports, book chapters, unpublished data, dissertations, and policy documents. Article selection and data extraction were completed independently and in duplicate, and a narrative approach to data synthesis was executed. Results 43 articles were identified that met the eligibility criteria. No existing review on this topic was found and no HSG assessment tool was identified. More than a third of the authors implicitly or explicitly identified the need for a high-quality tool aimed at systematically assessing HSG and contributing to its development/reporting. We identified 30 concepts that may be relevant to HSG assessment and were able to group them into three meaningful domains: process principles, content, and context principles. Conclusions Our study showed the role that quality criteria play in HSG development, evaluation and reporting and demonstrated the link and resonance within and between the various concepts in the three domains.

title: Health technologies for monitoring and control of diabetes: a systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND: The primary objective of this review was to determine the strength of the evidence on the effectiveness of self-management devices and technologies for people with type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) or type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) based on specific outcomes related to with health. measures. Self-monitoring devices included those that help patients manage diabetes and prevent cardiovascular complications (CVC). A secondary objective was to explore issues of feasibility, usability, and compliance among patients and providers. METHODS: Study criteria included people > or = 14 years and youth (7-14 years) with DM1 or DM2, intervention with a self-monitoring device, assessment of clinical outcomes with the device, English literature, and > 10 participants. Relevant published literature from 1985 to 2008 was searched. Randomized controlled trials and observational studies were included. Data were extracted for clinical outcomes, feasibility and compliance methods, and outcomes. Selected studies were independently assessed with a validated instrument to assess methodological quality. RESULTS: Eighteen trials were selected. The predominant types of device interventions included self-monitoring of blood glucose, pedometers, and cell phones or wireless technologies. Feasibility and compliance were measured in most studies. CONCLUSIONS: Self-monitoring of blood glucose remains an effective tool for diabetes control. Wireless technologies can improve diabetes self-management, and pedometers are effective tools for lifestyle changes. The results of this review indicate the need for further investigation of controlled trials on existing and novel technologies for diabetes self-management, on health outcomes associated with diabetes and CVCs, and device feasibility and compliance.

title: Use of the health system by alcohol risk drinkers: an analysis of secondary data
abstract: PURPOSE: To examine the effects of hazardous alcohol use on health care use patterns and health outcomes. DATA SOURCES: Using the National Health Interview Survey and the Medical Expenditure Panel Survey, a total sample of 4,449 adults, mean age 45 (SD 15), was pooled based on responses to the question: "In In the last year, on how many days did you have 5 or more drinks of any alcoholic beverage? CONCLUSIONS: Three categories of respondents were grouped as follows: no risk group = 0 days of 5+ drinks/day (n = 2991, 67%)"; low risk group = 1-11 days of 5+ drinks/day /day (n = 796, 18%) and high-risk group = 12-365 days of 5+ drinks/day (n = 662, 15%) Level of risky alcohol use did not predict health care use or health care outcomes; high-risk alcohol drinkers were less likely to use the health care system than other drinkers When divided by rural versus urban life, rural high-risk alcohol drinkers reported more visits to the health care department and all rural life groups reported worse physical and mental health than their urban counterparts IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: Hazardous alcohol use, defined as drinking above low-risk guidelines, affects 3 of every 10 adults, with risky drinking playing a role in more than 60 c chronic health conditions. in multiple practice settings. It can be difficult to identify the underlying problem. alcohol problems, particularly in those living in rural settings;" however, identification of at-risk drinkers is essential for rapid intervention in the potential progression from hazardous drinking to alcohol use disorder.

title: Hand decontamination practices of healthcare workers: adherence to recommended guidelines
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This article reports on a study of health care workers' handwashing/hand hygiene practices from a behavioral perspective. BACKGROUND: Hospital-acquired infection represents a very real and serious threat to all who are admitted to hospital. Pathogens are easily transmitted on the hands of healthcare workers, and hand hygiene substantially reduces this transmission. There are evidence-based guidelines for hand hygiene practices for healthcare workers, but compliance with these is low internationally. METHODS: A quasi-experimental design with a convenient sample was used. The predisposing, reinforcing, and enabling constructs in diagnostic and educational evaluation Theory of Health Education were used as a theoretical framework, and data were collected in 2001. Handwashing practices of health workers (observation of behavior , n = 314) and their predisposition (attitudes, beliefs and knowledge) towards compliance with hand hygiene guidelines (questionnaire, n = 62). The study involved nurses, doctors, physiotherapists and care assistants involved in direct patient care in the study unit. The hand hygiene intervention program aimed to predispose healthcare workers to adopt hand hygiene behavior (poster campaign and educational brochure), reinforce (feedback on pre-test results), and enable the behavior (Provide alcohol-based hand sanitizer at each patient's bedside.) RESULTS: Implementation of the multifaceted interventional behavioral hand hygiene program resulted in an overall improvement in adherence to hand hygiene guidelines (51-83%, P < 0.001). In addition, the health workers believed that their skin condition had improved (P < 0.001). An increase in knowledge about handwashing guidelines was also found. CONCLUSIONS: To be effective, efforts to improve compliance with handwashing guidelines must be multifaceted. Alcohol-based hand sanitizers (with emollients) need to be provided at each patient's bedside. Problems related to skin irritation in healthcare workers need to be addressed urgently.

title: Health workers' self-reported effect of an intervention program on knowledge and behavior related to infection control
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Adherence to infection control guidelines is low and several efforts have been made to improve the performance of health workers in infection control measures. In this study, the performance and evaluation of a hospital-wide infection control program is described. The most important measure was the distribution of an infection control bulletin. METHODS: In the program evaluation, a random selection of health workers received a questionnaire to investigate the extent to which the health workers were aware of the program and whether they reported behavioral changes and updated knowledge as a result of the program. RESULTS: The intervention made it possible to reach >80% of the staff of a Norwegian university hospital. Among those who actually read the Infection Control Bulletin, 92.9% reported that their knowledge was updated and 60.6% reported a change in behavior. DISCUSSION: The intervention had a significant impact on the reports of nurses and nursing assistants about knowledge and behaviors related to infection control. Our study supports the importance of a long-term, multimodal approach for healthcare workers in infection control work. The time and resources spent producing and distributing the Infection Control Newsletter was an effective way to reach a large number of healthcare workers.

title: Healthy Active Living: Physical Activity Guidelines for Children and Teens
abstract: The childhood obesity epidemic is increasing globally. Although the risk factors for obesity are multifactorial, many are related to lifestyle and may be amenable to intervention. These factors include sedentary time and non-exercise activity thermogenesis, as well as the frequency, intensity, amounts, and types of physical activity. Frontline healthcare professionals are ideally suited to monitor the physical activity levels of children, adolescents, and their families, to assess lifestyle choices, and to offer appropriate advice. This statement presents guidelines to reduce sedentary time and increase the level of physical activity in the pediatric population. Developmentally appropriate physical activity recommendations are provided for infants, toddlers, preschoolers, children, and adolescents. Advocacy strategies to promote active and healthy living are included at the local, municipal, provincial/territorial, and federal levels.

title: Healthy living after cancer: a dissemination and implementation study evaluating a telephone-delivered healthy lifestyle program for cancer survivors
abstract: BACKGROUND: Because evidence shows that physical activity, a healthy diet, and weight control can improve cancer outcomes and reduce the risk of chronic disease, leading cancer organizations and health authorities have endorsed related guidelines for cancer survivors. Despite this, and a growing evidence base for effective lifestyle interventions, there is limited uptake in survival care. METHODS/DESIGN: Healthy Living after Cancer (HLaC) is a national dissemination and implementation study that will evaluate the integration of an evidence-based lifestyle intervention for cancer survivors into a telephone cancer information and support service provided by the Australian State Cancer Councils. . Eligible participants (adults who have completed cancer treatment with curative intent) will receive 12 health coaching calls over 6 months from Cancer Council nurses/allied health professionals on national guidelines for physical activity, healthy eating and weight control. Using the RE-AIM evaluation framework, the primary outcomes are service-level indicators of program outreach, adoption, implementation/costs, and maintenance, with secondary outcomes (effectiveness) of patient-reported anthropometric, behavioral, and psychosocial variables collected beforehand. and after the program. program completion. The total target accumulation of participants in the four participating Cancer Councils is 900 over 3 years. DISCUSSION: The project's national scope and broad inclusion of cancer survivors, along with assessment of service level indicators, associated costs, and patient-reported outcomes, will provide the practice-based evidence needed to inform the future allocation of resources to support healthy living. among cancer survivors. EVIDENCE REGISTRATION: Australian New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry (ANZCTR)--ACTRN12615000882527 (registered 08/24/2015).

title: Height, body mass index and socioeconomic status: Mendelian randomization study at the UK Biobank
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine whether height and body mass index (BMI) play a causal role in five measures of socioeconomic status. DESIGN Mendelian randomization study to test the causal effects of differences in height and BMI on five measures of socioeconomic status. Mendelian randomization exploits the fact that genotypes are randomly assigned at conception and thus are not confounded by non-genetic factors. SET UK Biobank. PARTICIPANTS 119,669 men and women of British descent, aged between 37 and 73 years. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Age completed with full-time education, education level, job class, annual household income, and Townsend index of deprivation. RESULTS In the UK Biobank study, shorter height and higher BMI were observationally associated with several measures of lower socioeconomic status. The associations between shorter height and lower socioeconomic status tended to be stronger in men, and the associations between higher BMI and lower socioeconomic status tended to be stronger in women. For example, a BMI higher than 1 standard deviation (SD) was associated with Ã‚Â£210 (Ã¢â€šÂ¬276"; $300; 95% confidence interval Ã‚Â£84 to Ã‚Â £420; P = 6 × 10(-3)) lower annual household income for men and £1,890 (£1,680 to £2,100; P=6 × 10(-15)) lower annual household income for women. Genetic analysis provided evidence that these associations were partly causal.A genetically determined taller height 1 SD (6.3 cm) caused a 0.06 (0.02 to 0.09) years older age at completing school on time full (P = 0.01), at 1.12 (1.07 to 1.18) times more likely to work in a skilled profession (P = 6 × 10 (-7)), and £1,130 (£680 at £1580) higher annual family income (P=4 × 10(-8)). Associations were stronger in men. A higher genetically determined BMI 1 SD (4.6 kg/m(2)) caused an increase of £2,940 (Ã‚ £1,680 to £4,200;" P = 1 × 10 (-5)) lower annual family income and deprivation level 0.10 (0, 04 to 0.16) SD (P = 0.001) higher only in women. CONCLUSIONS These data support the evidence that height and BMI play an important partial role in determining various aspects of a person's socioeconomic status, especially women's BMI for income and deprivation and men's height for education. income and job class. These findings have important health and social implications, supporting the evidence that overweight people, especially women, are at a disadvantage and that taller people, especially men, are at an advantage.

title: Management of Helicobacter pylori: how to improve therapeutic confusion in practice
abstract: There appears to be a disconnect between current guidelines for Helicobacter pylori testing and treatment and clinical practice, including clinicians' beliefs and actual prescribing patterns. In particular, there are markedly different approaches in primary and secondary care, and country-specific differences in eradication therapy for H. pylori infection. Although most clinicians do not believe that H. pylori causes nonulcer dyspepsia, most seem to prescribe eradication. Less information is available on the treatment of H. pylori infection and gastroesophageal reflux disease, and in this condition there are more marked differences in attitudes and practice. Even in peptic ulcer disease, where most clinicians in both primary and secondary care believe that H. pylori should be eradicated, there is often a breakdown in the translation of this belief into practice. There is also confusion regarding the treatment regimens applied for the eradication of H. pylori. Eradication regimens are less successful in practice than in clinical trials. In addition, a considerable proportion of peptic ulcer patients remain symptomatic despite healing of the ulcer diathesis, which may undermine confidence. Therapeutic confusion about what to prescribe, compliance-limiting side effects, bacterial resistance, and socioeconomic factors may affect therapeutic success with eradication therapy in practice. Unfortunately, it has been well documented that the guidelines alone are likely to have little or no impact in practice. Publication in a journal is unlikely to lead to effective implementation in primary care. Based on the available evidence, clinical behavior is most likely to change when guidelines are developed by the group of clinicians for whom they were intended, disseminated through a specific educational program, and implemented through application, preferably during consultation, specific reminders. .

title: Help doctors and patients understand health statistics
abstract: Many doctors, patients, journalists and politicians do not understand what health statistics mean or inadvertently draw the wrong conclusions. Collective statistical illiteracy refers to the generalized inability to understand the meaning of numbers. For example, many citizens are unaware that higher survival rates with cancer screening do not imply a longer life, or that the claim that mammography reduces the risk of dying from breast cancer by 25% means that 1 woman less than every 1,000 will die from the disease We provide evidence that statistical illiteracy is (a) common to patients, journalists, and doctors"; (b) created by a non-transparent reporting framework that is sometimes an unintended result of lack of understanding, but can also be the result of intentional efforts to manipulate or persuade people, and (c) can have serious health consequences The causes of statistical illiteracy should not be attributed solely to cognitive biases, but to the nature of the doctor-patient relationship and conflicts of interest in the health system The classic doctor-patient relationship is based on paternalism (of the doctor) and trust a (of the patient) in authority, which makes statistical literacy seem unnecessary"; so does the traditional combination of determinism (doctors looking for causes, not chance) and the illusion of certainty (patients looking for certainty when there is none). We show that information brochures, websites, brochures distributed to doctors by the pharmaceutical industry, and even medical journals often report evidence in non-transparent ways that suggest high benefits of the interventions presented and little harm. Without understanding the numbers involved, the public is susceptible to political and commercial manipulation of their anxieties and hopes, undermining the goals of informed consent and shared decision-making. What can be done? We discuss the importance of teaching statistical thinking and transparent representations in primary and secondary education, as well as in medical school. However, this requires familiarizing children early on with the concept of probability and teaching statistical skills as the art of solving real-world problems rather than applying formulas to toy problems about coins and dice. An important precondition for statistical literacy is transparent risk communication. We recommend using frequency statements instead of single-event probabilities, absolute risks instead of relative risks, mortality rates instead of survival rates, and natural frequencies instead of conditional probabilities. Psychological research on transparent visual and numerical forms of risk communication is required, as well as training of clinicians in their use. Statistical literacy is a necessary precondition for an educated citizenry in a technological democracy. Understanding the risks and asking critical questions can also shape the emotional climate in a society so that hopes and anxieties are no longer so easily manipulated from the outside and citizens can develop a more informed and relaxed attitude towards their health.

title: Helping Hands: A Cluster Randomized Trial to Evaluate the Efficacy of Two Different Strategies to Promote Hand Hygiene in Hospital Nurses
abstract: BACKGROUND: Hand hygiene prescriptions are the most important measure in the prevention of hospital-acquired infections. However, compliance rates are generally below 50% of all hand hygiene opportunities. This study aims to evaluate the short-term and long-term effects of two different strategies to promote hand hygiene in hospital nurses. METHODS/DESIGN: This study is a cluster randomized controlled trial with inpatient wards as the unit of randomization. Guidelines for hand hygiene will be implemented in this study. Two strategies will be used to improve adherence to hand hygiene guidelines. State-of-the-art strategy is derived from the literature and includes education, reminders, feedback, and selection of appropriate products and facilities. The expanded strategy also contains activities aimed at influencing social influence in groups and improving leadership. The unique contribution of the extended strategy is based on relevant theories from the behavioral sciences. The extended strategy includes all the elements of the leading edge strategy supplemented by eliciting the active commitment and initiative of the district administration, modeling by informal leaders in the district, and setting norms and goals within the team. Data will be collected at four points in time, with six-month intervals. An average of 3,000 opportunities for hand hygiene will be observed by approximately 900 nurses at any one time. DISCUSSION: Carrying out and evaluating an implementation strategy that also targets the social context of teams can greatly increase the overall body of knowledge in this field. The results of our study will allow us to draw conclusions about the effects of different strategies for the implementation of hand hygiene guidelines and, based on these results, we will be able to define a preferred implementation strategy for hospital nursing. TRIAL REGISTRATION: The study is registered as a Clinical Trial at ClinicalTrials.gov, file number: NCT00548015.

title: Helping someone with a drug use problem: a Delphi consensus study of consumers, caregivers, and clinicians.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Problematic illicit drug use (ie, drug abuse or dependence) is associated with considerable health and social harms, highlighting the need for early intervention and engagement with health services. Family, friends and colleagues play an important role in supporting and helping people with drug use problems to seek professional help; however, there are conflicting views on how and when such support should be offered. This document reports on the development of mental health first aid guidelines for problem drug use in adults, to help inform community members on how to help someone who develops problem drug use or is experiencing a related crisis. with drugs. METHODS: A systematic review of the scientific and non-specialist literature was conducted to develop a 228-item survey containing possible first aid strategies to help someone who develops a drug problem or is experiencing a drug-related crisis. Three expert panels (29 consumers, 31 caregivers, and 27 clinicians) were recruited from Australia, Canada, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, and the United States. Panel members independently rated the items in three rounds, and the strategies reached a consensus on importance written into the guidelines. RESULTS: The overall response rate across all three rounds was 80% (86% consumers, 81% caregivers, 74% physicians). 140 first aid strategies were endorsed as essential or important by 80% or more of panel members. Supported strategies provide information and advice on what problem drug use is and its consequences, how to approach a person about their problem drug use, tips for effective communication, what to do if the person is unwilling to change their drug use, drugs, what to do if the person wants (or doesn't want) professional help, what are drug-affected states and how to manage them, how to deal with adverse reactions that lead to a medical emergency, and what to do if the person is aggressive. CONCLUSIONS: The guidelines provide a consensus-based resource for community members who want to help someone with a drug problem. The guidelines are expected to lead to better support and understanding for people with drug use problems and to facilitate participation with professional help.

title: The review of the Declaration of Helsinki continues
Liver reactions associated with ketoconazole in the UK
abstract: Ketoconazole was introduced in the UK in 1981. By November 1984, the Committee on Safety of Medicines had received 82 reports of possible hepatotoxicity associated with the drug, including five deaths. An analysis of the 75 cases that had received adequate follow-up suggested that 16, including three deaths, were likely related to drug treatment. Of the remainder, 48 were possibly related to treatment, five were unlikely to be related, and six were unclassifiable. The mean age of the patients in the 16 probable cases was 57.9 years, with hepatotoxicity being more frequent in women. The mean duration of treatment before the onset of jaundice was 61 days. None of these well-validated cases occurred within the first 10 days after treatment. Serum liver function test results suggested hepatocellular injury in 10 (63%)";" the rest showed a mixed pattern. In contrast, the results of histological examination of the liver often showed evidence of cholestasis. The characteristics of the 48 patients of the possible cases were similar. Allergic manifestations such as rash and eosinophilia were rare. The hepatitis was generally reversible when treatment was stopped, with liver function test results returning to normal after an average of 3.1 months. In two of the three deaths likely associated with ketoconazole treatment, the drug had been continued after the onset of jaundice and other symptoms of hepatitis. Clinical and biochemical monitoring at regular intervals for evidence of hepatitis is recommended during long-term treatment with ketoconazole to prevent possible serious liver damage.

title: Hepatitis Competence Network (Hep-Net)
abstract: In Germany, almost 1 million people are affected by chronic viral hepatitis. Despite improved therapeutic options for the treatment of hepatitis B and C, several issues related to epidemiology, pathophysiology, and therapy remain unclear. Vaccines against hepatitis C and D viruses are not yet available. In addition, many patients and their families need information about infectiousness, disease course, and treatment options. By integrating medical practices and patient advocacy groups, Hep-Net aims at educating information about the infection and seeks to provide access to qualified therapy strategies for all patients with an indication for therapy. After 18 months, the Hep-Net home page already shows more than 9,000 hits per day. Telephone consultation hours, e-mail services and numerous activities in cooperation with Deutsche Leberhilfe eV are very popular. At the Hep-Net study house, high-level clinical studies with the first successful results are organized centrally. Furthermore, basic questions in the fields of epidemiology, virology and immunology are processed in cooperative research projects within the network.

title: Hepatitis A
Herd: a new phenomenon affecting medical decision-making in multiple sclerosis care? Lessons learned from DISCUSS MS
abstract: PURPOSE: Herding is a phenomenon by which individuals follow the behavior of others rather than decide independently based on their own private information. A herd phenomenon in multiple sclerosis (MS) can occur when a neurologist follows a colleague's therapeutic recommendation, even if it is not supported by best practice clinical guidelines. Limited information is currently available on the role of herding in health care. The objective of this study was to determine the prevalence (and its associated factors) of grazing in the management of MD. METHODS: We conducted a study among neurologists with experience in MS care throughout Spain. Participants answered questions about the management of 20 commonly encountered case scenarios in clinical practice and completed 3 surveys and 4 experimental paradigms based on behavioral economics. The grazing experiment consisted of a case scenario of a 40-year-old woman who has been stable for 3 years on subcutaneous interferon and developed a self-limited neurological event. There were no new magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) lesions. His neurological exam and disability scores did not change. A neurologist specializing in multiple sclerosis advised him to switch from interferon to fingolimod against best practice guidelines. Multivariate logistic regression analysis was performed to assess factors associated with grazing. RESULTS: Of the 161 neurologists who were invited to participate, 96 completed the study (response rate: 60%). The herd was present in 75 (78.1%), with a similar prevalence in MS experts and general neurologists (68.8% vs 82.8%";" P=0.12). In multivariate analyses, the number of MS patients seen per week was positively associated with grazing (odds ratio [OR] 1.08, 95% CI: 1.01-1.14). In contrast, physician age, gender, years of practice, practice setting, or risk preferences were not associated with herding. CONCLUSION: Herding was a common phenomenon affecting nearly 8 out of 10 neurologists caring for MS patients. Grazing can affect medical decisions and lead to worse outcomes in MS treatment.

title: Heterogeneity: we can't live with it, and we can't live without it
Heterogeneous demographic and cultural profiles of nonadherent Chinese-American patients for colorectal cancer screening: a latent class analysis
abstract: BACKGROUND: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is a leading cause of cancer death in Chinese Americans, but its CRC detection rates remain low. OBJECTIVE: We examined subgroups of Chinese American patients who do not meet CRC screening guidelines to better inform clinical practices to effectively promote screening. METHODS: Using latent class analysis of data from 327 participants recruited from 18 primary care clinics, we classified nonadherent patients based on sociodemographics, screening barriers, and clinical and attitudinal factors for CRC detection. . RESULTS: The best-fit latent class analysis model described 3 distinctive classes: Western health care class (36%), Eastern health care class (18%), and Mixed health care class (46%). Patients in the Western health care class were highly educated, with an average US residence of 20 years, a high level of English proficiency, the least Eastern cultural views of care, and the greatest exposure to doctors' recommendations, but reported that they did not have time for screening tests. Patients in the Eastern health care class were highly educated seniors and recent immigrants with the least knowledge of CRC and the most Eastern cultural views. Patients in the mixed health care class had a low level of education, resided in the United States for 20 years, and half had sought the services of their physicians for at least 3 years, but their knowledge and cultural views were similar to those of Eastern health care class patients. CONCLUSIONS: Nonadherent Chinese American patients are heterogeneous. Tailored future intervention programs to address beliefs and screening barriers specific to non-adherent patient subtypes are essential. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: Training primary care physicians to recognize different patient demographics and health care beliefs may facilitate physicians' communication with patients to overcome their barriers and improve management behaviors. detection.

title: Heterogeneous Effect of an Emergency Department Expert Chart System
abstract: STUDY OBJECTIVE: We compared the results of different modules (occupational exposure to blood and body fluids, low back pain and fever in children) of the Emergency Department Expert Registry System. Each module of this electronic health record provides real-time advice based on clinical guidelines embedded in the software. METHODS: We used an intermittent interrupted time series design with an intention-to-treat analysis to implement the Emergency Department Expert Registry System in the emergency department of a university hospital for the treatment of pediatric fever, low back pain, and occupational exposure to blood and body fluids. We measured quality of documentation as percentage of essential elements contained in medical history and discharge instructions, percentage of appropriate tests and treatment decisions, median charges per patient visit, physician satisfaction through pre-questionnaires and after the experiment, and patient satisfaction through a telephone questionnaire. RESULTS: The Emergency Department Expert Registration System improved documentation rates for all modules. The Emergency Department Expert Record System consistently improved the appropriateness of diagnostic testing and treatment decisions for patients with occupational exposure to blood and body fluids while lowering average charges. For the child low back pain and fever modules, improvements in appropriateness of testing and treatment were less consistent and did not result in a decrease in charges. Although physicians generally supported the intervention, use of the Emergency Department Expert Record System and physician satisfaction with the modules were higher with occupational exposure to blood and body fluids and less with fever in children . For each complaint filed, mean patient satisfaction was highest during the emergency department expert registration system phase. CONCLUSION: Guideline delivery via an electronic medical record with history decision support improved documentation, patient care, and patient satisfaction, although effects were heterogeneous across complaints filed. The optimal guideline implementation strategy is likely to vary depending on the nature of the clinical problem and the type of healthcare setting. For selected problems, delivery of guidelines in this format via the Internet holds great promise for changing physician behavior and improving care (see http://www.needlestick.mednet.ucla.edu).

title: High-risk management guidelines for suicidal older patients in primary care settings
abstract: Older adults, especially older white men, are more likely to commit suicide than other age groups. The assessment and management of suicidal ideation and behavior in the elderly is especially relevant to primary care physicians because many patients visit their physician shortly before committing suicide. In 1993, the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research (AHCPR) published clinical practice guidelines for the treatment of depression in primary care settings. The AHCPR guidelines offered some help with regard to detection and treatment of patients with suicidal tendencies. However, these guidelines lacked detailed and specific instructions for the management of high-risk patients within the context of intervention research. The current set of guidelines builds on this previous work by describing (1) a general approach to interacting with suicidal patients"; (2) structured assessments to determine degree of suicide risk; (3) crisis intervention strategies"; and (4) ongoing management procedures for working with suicidal patients in primary care settings.

title: Historical background of changes in FDA policy on the study and evaluation of drugs in women
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has recently made two important changes to its policy for the study and evaluation of drugs in women: (1) analyzes of the safety and efficacy of specific drugs will be required by sex as part of all new drugs. and (2) it will no longer be recommended that women of childbearing age be restricted from participating in early drug trials. These changes have come about as a result of ongoing efforts to individualize therapy, improve drug safety and efficacy, and answer important questions about whether the drug development process produces adequate information about drug effects in women. . In turn, these efforts are the result of a long history in the United States of changes in the clinical care of women, changes in the use of women as research subjects, changes in attitudes about the balance between protection and risks for women in clinical trials, and national women's movements to focus on their health care issues and transform the male-oriented model of clinical research. The new FDA guidelines, published in July 1993, will provide researchers with guidance on how to gather valuable information about how drugs work in women and will help physicians and other caregivers consider the effects of gender on health and development. treatment.

title: History of evidence-based medicine. Oranges, Chloride of Lime, and Leeches: Barriers to Teaching Old Dogs New Tricks
abstract: Knowledge translation is the process of taking research evidence and applying it in clinical practice. In this article I will cite some pivotal moments in the history of medicine to highlight the difficulties and delays associated with putting evidence into practice. These historical examples have much in common with modern medical trials and quality improvement processes. I will also review the reasons why the evidence is not used and consider what factors facilitate the acceptance of the evidence. Understanding these concepts will make it easier for individual clinicians and institutions to change clinical behavior and provide a starting point for those looking to implement 'new' practices, new therapies and clinical guidelines. Finally, I will offer a list of criteria that clinicians might choose to consider when deciding whether or not to adopt a new practice, treatment, or concept.

title: HIV prevention in Mexican schools: prospective randomized evaluation of the intervention
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the effects on condom use and other sexual behaviors of a school-based HIV prevention program that promotes condom use with and without emergency contraception. DESIGN Cluster randomized controlled trial. SCENARIO 40 public secondary schools in the state of Morelos, Mexico. PARTICIPANTS 10,954 high school freshmen. INTERVENTION Schools were randomly assigned to one of three arms: an HIV prevention course that promoted condom use, the same course with emergency contraception as backup, or the existing sex education course. Anonymous self-administered questionnaires were completed at baseline, four months, and 16 months. Students in the intervention schools received a 30-hour course (over 15 weeks) on HIV prevention and life skills, designed in accordance with the guidelines of the Joint United Nations Program on HIV/AIDS. Two additional hours of emergency contraception education were provided to students in condom promotion with the contraceptive arm. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome measure was reported condom use. Other reported outcomes were sexual activity"; knowledge and attitudes about HIV and emergency contraception"; and attitudes and confidence about condom use. RESULTS The intervention did not affect reported condom use. Knowledge of HIV improved in both intervention arms and knowledge of emergency contraception improved in the condom promotion arm with contraception. Reported sexual behavior was similar in the intervention arms and the control group. CONCLUSION A rigorously designed, implemented, and evaluated HIV education course in public high schools did not reduce risky behavior, so such courses need to be redesigned and evaluated. The addition of emergency contraception did not decrease reported condom use or increase risky sexual behavior, but it did increase reported use of emergency contraception.

title: The research group of the network of competences in HIV/AIDS presents the first results
abstract: Germany's HIV clinical research efforts are underrepresented internationally. This shortfall is mainly due to the lack of clinical studies involving patients from all over the country and the fact that there is no national patient cohort system in Germany that could provide a basis for such clinical studies. The HIV/AIDS Competency Network is bridging this gap by serving as a comprehensive research alliance at the national level. The establishment of a patient cohort is linked to 20 projects. The success of this new structure is becoming visible.

title: Home blood pressure management and better blood pressure control: results of a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: To determine which of the 3 interventions was most effective in improving blood pressure (BP) control, we conducted a 4-arm randomized trial with 18-month follow-up in primary care clinics at an American Affairs Medical Center. Veterans. METHODS: Eligible patients were randomly assigned to usual care or 1 of 3 telephone intervention groups: (1) nurse-managed behavioral management, (2) nurse-physician-managed medication management, or (3) a combination from both. Of the 1551 eligible patients, 593 people were randomized";" 48% were African American. Intervention phone calls were triggered based on home BP values transmitted through telemonitoring devices. Behavior management involved the promotion of healthy behaviors. Medication management involved adjustment of medications by a study physician and nurse based on hypertension treatment guidelines. RESULTS: The primary outcome was change in BP control measured at 6-month intervals for 18 months. Both behavioral management and medication management alone showed significant improvements at 12 months: 12.8% (95% confidence interval [CI], 1.6%-24.1%) and 12.5 % (95% CI, 1.3%-23.6%), respectively, but not at 18 months. In subgroup analyses, among those with poor baseline BP control, systolic BP decreased in the combined intervention group by 14.8 mm Hg (95% CI, -21.8 to -7.8 mm Hg) at 12 months and 8.0 mm Hg (95% CI, -15.5 to -0.5 mm Hg) at 18 months, relative to usual care. CONCLUSIONS: The overall effects of the intervention were moderate, but among people with poor BP control at baseline, the effects were larger. This study indicates the importance of identifying people who are most likely to benefit from potentially resource-intensive programs. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Clinicaltrials.gov Identifier: NCT00237692.

title: Home health care nurses as a new channel for smoking cessation treatment: results of the CARES project (Community-nurse Assisted Research and Education on Smoking)
abstract: BACKGROUND: Smoking cessation guidelines may not be sufficient to help some subgroups of smokers to quit. Incorporating tobacco cessation into home health care can proactively reach high-risk smokers who may not have access to (or spontaneously seek) to quit. METHOD: Home health nurses (N = 98) were randomly assigned to provide their patients with Motivational Enhancement (ME"; Motivational Interviewing + Carbon Monoxide Feedback) or Standard Care (AHCPR Smoking Cessation Guidelines). Seventy percent of patients were eligible and willing to participate (N = 273; "54% female, mean age = 57 years, 83% Caucasian, 41% 0.05). ME reported more quit attempts and significantly greater reductions in the number of cigarettes smoked per day at all follow-ups up to 12 months post-treatment (all p values < 0.05). CONCLUSIONS: Using an existing public health channel, such as home health care, to reach smokers who vary in their motivation to quit, could have a large public health impact.

title: Hormonal agents of breast cancer: implications for the primary care physician
abstract: PURPOSE: More than 2 million breast cancer survivors are in the United States, making women with breast cancer the largest group of cancer survivors. The purpose of this article is to review current knowledge about survival issues in women with early-stage estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer, focusing on advances in hormonal therapies to reduce the risk of recurrence. DATA SOURCES: Published research studies, clinical treatment guidelines, and ongoing clinical trials. CONCLUSIONS: Innovations in antiestrogenic and estrogen-modulating therapies are an important aspect of continued care after primary treatment of breast cancer. Primary care providers can play an important role in monitoring potential complications of antiestrogen therapy. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: This article reviews the current state of the science on hormonal agents for breast cancer for breast cancer survivors. With the high incidence and prevalence of breast cancer, primary care providers need to be aware of the potential short- and long-term health risks and benefits of hormonal therapies for breast cancer survivors.

title: Withdrawal of hormone therapy: medical practices after the Women's Health Initiative
abstract: OBJECTIVE: No guidelines or randomized trials address best practices for stopping hormone therapy (HT). METHODS: We conducted a survey study to explore HT discontinuation practices at Group Health and Harvard Vanguard, large integrated health systems in the northwestern and northeastern United States, focusing on differences between specialties and study site. RESULTS: The response rate to the written questionnaire (mailed between December 2005 and May 2006) was 78.5% (736/928)"; this article reports the results of 483 eligible physicians. To discontinue oral HT , the majority of physicians (91%) advised gradual tapering, not immediate cessation (8%), and the majority (60%) suggested lowering both dose and days per week Nearly 60% of physicians reported that had no experience with taper patches Harvard Vanguard physicians were more likely than Group Health physicians to encourage stopping HT and less likely to recommend resuming HT when a woman's symptoms returned after stopping HT Physicians were most influenced by their own experience (48%), peer advice (25%), and the woman's preference (19%) in choosing a discontinuation strategy;" only 2% were based on research evidence. Physicians endorsed various approaches to managing symptoms after HT discontinuation, most commonly behavioral changes (44%) and increased exercise (37%), and these approaches were most frequently endorsed by physicians and obstetricians/ Harvard Vanguard gynecologists than by Group Health physicians or family physicians. internists CONCLUSIONS: Two health plans in the northwestern and northeastern United States do not have a standard protocol for stopping HT. Physicians personalized approaches, influenced by their location, colleagues, and specialty. Research is needed to guide approaches to stopping HT.

title: Hospital building in the NHS. Ideas and Designs II: Harness and Core
Hospital physician responsiveness to trial cost feedback: a prospective blinded controlled intervention study.
Smoking behavior and attitude of hospital doctors towards smoking cessation interventions for patients: a survey in an Italian Comprehensive Cancer Center
abstract: PURPOSE: Tobacco control guidelines recommend that all health professionals ask patients about their smoking status and offer them at least minimal advice to quit smoking. However, few data are available on the daily practice of hospital clinicians who work with smoking cancer patients. This study evaluates, in a comprehensive cancer center, the smoking habits of physicians, their clinical practice in offering a smoking cessation intervention to smoking patients, and the training they received in this field. METHODS: An Internet survey was sent to 285 physicians. RESULTS: The survey response rate was 75%. Of the respondents, 62%, 24%, and 14% had never smoked, had smoked, and smoked, respectively. Six percent of all responding physicians had already participated in smoking cessation training and 43% of them declared their willingness to receive training. Eighty-six percent of all responding physicians inquired about patients' smoking status, 50% routinely advised patients to quit, and 32% assessed their motivation to quit. Smoking cessation guidelines were not followed mainly due to lack of time, fear of increasing patient stress, and lack of smoking cessation training. 94% of the physicians surveyed were aware of the outpatient smoking cessation service and 65% referred at least one patient, 66% of the physicians surveyed were aware of the inpatient service and 36% of them requested at least one plant intervention. CONCLUSIONS: This study noted the partial adherence of physicians working in a major cancer center to smoking cessation guidelines. Practitioners' smoking habits did not influence training and clinical practice in offering patients smoking cessation interventions.

title: Household income directly affects children's development, according to research
