abstract: Children in low-income households have poorer cognitive, socio-behavioral and health outcomes, a new report from the social policy research charity Joseph Rowntree Foundation concludes.1 The report says money makes a direct difference to children's health. kids. And not just because low income is correlated with parental education level, attitudes toward parenting, and other parental factors. Kerris Cooper and Kitty Stewart of the Center for Ã¢â‚¬Â¦

title: How did formative research inform the development of a women's group intervention in rural Nepal?
abstract: The failure to reduce neonatal and maternal mortality in poor countries is sometimes attributed to a lack of contextual knowledge about care practices and care-seeking behaviour. There is a lack of knowledge about how to translate formative research into effective interventions to improve maternal and newborn health. We describe the findings of the formative research and how they were used to inform the development of such an intervention in rural Nepal. The formative research was carried out in four parts. Part 1 involved familiarization with the study area and literature review, and Parts 2, 3, and 4 included community mapping, health services audit, and qualitative and quantitative studies of patient behaviors. perinatal care. Participatory approaches have been successful in reducing neonatal mortality and may be appropriate in our context. Community mapping and profiling helped describe the community context, and we found that community organizations often sought to engage the Women's Community Health Volunteer in community mobilization. He did not routinely hold monthly meetings and found them difficult to maintain without support and supervision. In health facilities, most primary care staff were at their posts, but doctors and nurses were not at referral centers. Mortality estimates reflected underreporting of deaths, and hygiene and infection control strategies had low coverage. Most women give birth at home with their mother-in-law, friends and neighbors. Care during perinatal illness was generally sought from traditional healers. Cultural themes of shyness, fear, and normality restricted women's behavior during pregnancy, childbirth, and the postpartum period, and decisions about their health were generally made after communications with family and community. Formative research indicated the type of intervention that might be successful. It must be community and must not be exclusive to pregnant women. It should address negotiations within families and should tailor the information to the needs of local groups and particular stakeholders, such as mothers-in-law and traditional healers. The intervention must not only accept cultural constructions, but also be a forum in which to discuss ideas of contamination, shame and seclusion. We used these guidelines to develop a community-based women's participatory group intervention facilitated through a community action cycle. The success of our intervention may be due to its acceptability at the community level and its sensitivity to the needs and beliefs of families and communities.

title: How do clinicians prefer cultural competency training? DSM-5 Cultural Formulation Interview Field Test Findings
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The objective of this study is to analyze the training methods that clinicians reported as most and least helpful during the DSM-5 Cultural Formulation Interview field test, the reasons why, and the associations between demographic characteristics. and method preferences. METHOD: The authors used mixed methods to analyze interviews with 75 clinicians on five continents about their training preferences after a standardized training session and the clinicians' first administration of the Cultural Formulation Interview. Content analysis identified the most and least useful educational methods by reason. Logistic and bivariate regression analysis compared clinical characteristics with method preferences. RESULTS: Clinicians most often cited case-based behavioral simulations as the "most helpful" training methods and videos as the "least helpful." Bivariate logistic regression models, first unadjusted and then pooled by country, found that each additional year of a physician's age was associated with a preference for behavioral simulants: OR = 1.05 (95% CI: 1, 01-1.10";" p = 0.025). CONCLUSIONS: Most clinicians preferred active behavioral simulations in cultural competence training, and this effect was more pronounced among older clinicians. Effective training can best be achieved through a combination of review of written guidelines, video demonstration, and behavioral simulations. Future work may examine the impact of satisfaction with physician training on patients' symptoms and quality of life.

title: How is the self-reported clinical management of patients with low back pain related to the attitudes and beliefs of health professionals? A survey of UK general practitioners and physiotherapists
abstract: Guidelines for the treatment of low back pain (LBP) have existed for many years, but adherence to them by healthcare professionals (HCPs) remains suboptimal. The aim of this study was to measure the attitudes, beliefs and reported clinical behavior of UK physiotherapists (PTs) and general practitioners (GPs) about low back pain and to explore the associations between these. A cross-sectional postal survey of general practitioners (n=2000) and physical therapists (n=2000) was conducted, including the Pain Beliefs and Attitudes Scale (PABT.PT) and a vignette of a patient with nonspecific low back pain (NSLBP). ) with questions about recommendations for work, activity, and bed rest. Data from 1022 respondents (442 GPs and 580 physiotherapists) who had recently treated patients with low back pain were analysed. While the majority of health professionals reported providing advice for the patient in the vignette that was broadly in line with guideline recommendations, 28% reported that they would advise this patient to stay off work. Job counseling was significantly related to PABS.PT scores with higher biomedical scores (F(1986)=77.5, p<0.0001) and lower behavioral scores (F(1981)=31.9, p<0.001 ) associated with advice not to work. We have shown that the attitudes and reported practice behavior of UK clinicians and physiotherapists for patients with NSLBP are diverse. Many health professionals believed that low back pain requires some avoidance of activities and work. The attitudes and beliefs of these health professionals were associated with their self-reported clinical behavior regarding work advice. Future studies should investigate whether approaches aimed at modifying these HCP factors can lead to better patient outcomes.

title: How many steps/day are enough? for children and adolescents
abstract: Worldwide, public health physical activity guidelines include a special emphasis on children (typically 6-11 years) and adolescent (typically 12-19 years) populations. Existing patterns are commonly expressed in terms of frequency, timing, and intensity of behavior. However, simple step output from accelerometers and pedometers is gaining greater credibility in research and practice as a reasonable approximation of daily volume of ambulatory physical activity. Therefore, the purpose of this article is to review the existing literature on objectively monitored step-defined physical activity for children and adolescents to provide researchers, professionals, and people who use accelerometers and pedometers with evidence-based translations of these public health guidelines. in terms of steps. /day. In terms of normative data (i.e., expected values), current international literature indicates that we can expect 1) among children, boys average between 12,000 and 16,000 steps/day and girls between 10,000 and 13,000 steps/day. day"; and, 2) adolescents consistently decrease steps/day until approximately 8,000-9,000 steps/day are observed in 18-year-olds. Controlled cadence studies show that MVPA continuous walking produces 3,300-3,500 steps in 30 minutes or 6,600-7,000 steps in 60 minutes in 10- to 15-year-olds Limited evidence suggests that a total daily physical activity volume of 10,000 to 14,000 steps/day is associated with 60 to 100 minutes of MVPA in preschool-age children ( approximately 4 to 6 years of age.) MVPA in elementary/primary school children appears to be achieved, on average, within a total volume of 13,000 to 15,000 steps/day in boys and 11,000 to 12,000 steps/day in girls. adolescents (both boys and girls), 10,000 to 11,700 may be associated with 60 my MVPA notes. Translations of guidelines based on time and intensity may be higher than existing normative data (eg, in adolescents) and thus will be more difficult to achieve (but not impossible or contraindicated). The recommendations are preliminary and more research is needed to confirm and expand the values of measured cadences, associated velocities, and MET values in youth; continue to accumulate normative data (expected values) for both steps/day and MVPA across all ages and populations; and conduct longitudinal and intervention studies in children and adolescents needed to inform the shape of stepwise physical activity dose-response curves associated with various health parameters.

title: How much does the quality of child care vary among health workers with different lengths of training? A multicountry observational study
abstract: Background Countries with high infant mortality rates tend to have a shortage of skilled health workers. Little rigorous evidence has been conducted to assess how much quality of care varies between types of health workers. We compared the performance of different categories of health workers trained in Comprehensive Care for Prevalent Childhood Illnesses (IMCI).";" Background Countries with high infant mortality rates tend to have a shortage of skilled health workers. Little rigorous evidence has been conducted to assess how much quality of care varies between types of health workers. We compared the performance of different categories of health workers trained in Integrated Management of Prevalent Childhood Illnesses (IMCI).

title: How the prevention potential of organizational scaling affects the success of the implementation of innovations: electronic medical records in hospitals
abstract: Background Commitment escalation is the tendency for (innovation) projects to continue, even if it is clear that they will not be successful and/or will become extremely expensive. Escalation prevention potential (EPP), an organization's ability to stop or direct deployment processes that do not meet its expectations, can prevent an organization from wasting time and money on failed projects. EPP consists of a set of checks and balances embedded in management practices that safeguard management against irrational (but very human) decisions and can limit the scaling of implementation projects. We study whether the successful implementation of electronic medical records (EMR) is related to EPP and investigate the organizational factors that explain this relationship. Methods Structural equation modeling (SEM) was applied, using questionnaire data from 427 physicians and 631 nurses who had experience with the implementation and use of EMR in hospitals, to study whether formal governance and organizational culture mediate the relationship between EPP and the perceived added value of EMR. Results Physicians and nurses in hospitals with more PPE report more successful implementation of EMR (in terms of perceived added value of EMR). Formal governance mediates the relationship between EPP and implementation success. We found no evidence that open or innovative culture explains the relationship between EPP and implementation success. Conclusions There is a positive relationship between the level of PPE and the perceived added value of EMRs. This relationship is explained by the formal governance mechanisms of organizations. This means that management has a set of tangible tools to positively influence the success of innovation processes. However, it also means that management must be able to critically reflect on their (previous) actions and decisions and be willing to change plans if elements of the EPP indicate that the implementation process is hampered.

title: How Payment Systems Affect Physicians' Provisioning Behavior: An Experimental Investigation.
abstract: Understanding how physicians respond to payment scheme incentives is a central concern in health economics research. We present a controlled laboratory experiment to analyze the influence of fee-for-service incentives and capitation payments on physicians' supply of medical services. In our experiment, doctors choose quantities of medical services for patients with different health states. We find that physicians provide significantly more services under fee-for-service than under capitation. Patients are underserved under fee-for-service and underserved under capitation. However, payment incentives are not the only motivation for physicians' quantity choices, as the health benefits of patients are also of considerable importance. We found that patients who need a high (low) level of medical services receive higher health benefits under fee-for-service (capitation).

title: How Science Thinks and Acts in Practice: Closing the Gap in Weight Management Interventions for Adolescents
abstract: BACKGROUND: Adolescent obesity demands evidence-based treatment approaches given its long-term physical and psychosocial consequences. However, research shows that there are many problems in translating scientific evidence into practice. OBJECTIVE: The objective of this study was to develop science- and practice-based recommendations for planning future weight control interventions in adolescents. METHODS: We conducted (i) literature reviews on intervention studies targeting obesity treatment in adolescents and Dutch clinical guidelines for obesity, as well as practice-based papers and gray literature on obesity treatment and delivery of adolescent health programs and (ii) semi-structured studies interviews with eight physicians and four non-physicians working in the treatment, management and prevention of obesity to explore perspectives on the treatment of adolescent obesity and the use of evidence in practice . RESULTS: After merging the results of the literature reviews and interviews, four problems emerged: (i) few reports on the theoretical models used in intervention studies, Dutch clinical guidelines and semi-structured interviews"; (ii) the inconsistency in the age-specific considerations for treatment of obesity in adolescents in Dutch intervention studies and clinical guidelines;" (iii) the inconsistency in addressing the social nature of obesity in the Dutch intervention studies and guidelines and (iv) how professional responsibility should be divided is not clear in the Dutch intervention studies, guidelines and interviews semi-structured. CONCLUSIONS: The joint action of science and practice is necessary for future interventions. Future interventions should include topics relevant to the adolescent stage and pay more attention to the complex social nature of obesity. Finally, practitioners can generate more practice-based evidence by starting their own practice-based research.

title: Attributing Causality in Quality Improvement: Lessons from Epidemiology
Improving physician and public acceptance and use of colon cancer screening recommendations
abstract: Carrying out colorectal cancer (CRC) screening tests is a multidisciplinary task, whose objective is to reduce mortality and the incidence of CRC without negatively affecting the health status of the participants. The adoption of a public health perspective implies a commitment to guarantee equity in access and the sustainability of the program over time. We review the available evidence on predictors of CRC screening uptake and the impact of interventions to improve screening adoption using conceptual frameworks that define the role of determinants of preventive behaviors and the scope and target of interventions. . The results of this review indicate that it is necessary to implement policy measures aimed at supporting the performance of screening tests, as well as organizational changes that influence the operational characteristics of preventive services, to allow the motivation of the individual to be realized eventually. To ensure coverage and equity in access and maximize the impact of the intervention, policies should be adopted to implement organized programs, ensuring that participation in screening and any follow-up evaluation is not limited by financial barriers. Participant and provider beliefs may determine response to different screening modalities. To achieve the desired health impact, active monitoring of people with screening abnormalities must be implemented, supported by the introduction of infrastructure changes and multidisciplinary teamwork, which can ensure the sustainability of effective interventions over time. Continuous monitoring, as well as the adoption of plans to evaluate the effectiveness of the program, represent crucial steps in the implementation of a successful program.

title: How to implement clinical practice guidelines in iran
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence-based medicine would arrive at the result through evidence-based implementation. Clinical Practice Guidelines (CPG) as one of the evidence-based knowledge products, require appropriate interventions after being developed to be applied. OBJECTIVES: The objective of this qualitative study was to identify the application strategies of the CPGs produced in Iran. MATERIALS AND METHODS: Intentional snowball sampling was performed and continued until theoretical saturation was reached. Semi-structured in-depth individual interviews and Focus Group Discussion (FGD) were conducted with the aim of triangulation. The thematic framework approach was used for the analysis. RESULTS: Twelve interviews were conducted with three health system policy and decision makers, four with experience in the production or adaptation of clinical practices, and five experts in evidence-based drug development and education. In addition, 11 policy makers, managers and decision makers from the health system participated in the FGD. The proposed interventions were classified into the following themes: Interventions aimed at health professionals, Financial, Organizational, Regulatory and Multifaceted. CONCLUSIONS: Along with the process of adaptation and development of CPGs, their use should also be planned";" otherwise, the time and money spent would be wasted. Certainly, imposing the aforementioned interventions with the ultimate goal of sustainable behavior change on health system service providers is beyond the capacity of specific groups or some academic centers. It requires the participation of all professionals under the monitoring and support of the Ministry of Health and Medical Education. The deployment of the family medical plan and the referral system is an opportunity that should be considered a trophy.

title: How to translate the therapeutic recommendations of the clinical practice guidelines into rules to criticize medical prescriptions? Methods and application to five guides
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical practice guidelines provide recommendations on what to do in various medical situations, including therapeutic recommendations for prescription medications. An effective way to computerize these recommendations is to design critical decision support systems, that is, systems that criticize the doctor's prescription when it does not conform to the guidelines. These systems are commonly based on a list of "if conditions then critical" rules. However, writing these rules from the guidelines is not a trivial task. The aim of this article is to propose methods that (1) simplify the implementation of guideline therapeutic recommendations in critical systems by automatically translating structured therapeutic recommendations into a list of "if conditions then critical" rules, and ( 2) can generate a text label to explain to the doctor why their prescription is not recommended. METHODS: The therapeutic recommendations of five clinical practice guidelines on chronic diseases related to cardiovascular risk management were studied. We evaluated the system using a test base of over 2,000 cases. RESULTS: Algorithms are presented to automatically translate therapeutic recommendations into "if conditions then critical" rules. Eight generic recommendations are also proposed";" they are guideline-independent and can be used as default behavior to handle a variety of situations that are often implied by guidelines, such as lowering the dose of a poorly tolerated drug. Finally, we provide models and methods for generating human-readable textual criticism. The system was successfully evaluated on the test basis. CONCLUSION: We show that it is possible to criticize the prescriptions of the doctors from a structured clinical guide, and to give clear explanations. We are now planning a randomized clinical trial to assess the impact of the system on practices.

title: How well do clinicians follow dementia practice guidelines?
abstract: Although there are numerous clinical guidelines on the management of dementia, there are few studies on their implementation in practice. Physicians at six US Department of Veterans Affairs medical centers (n = 200, 85% response rate) were surveyed on their use of recommended practices in the California Task Force Guidelines for of Alzheimer's disease. Most providers (89% to 73%) reported routinely performing neurological exams, obtaining caregiver history, discussing the diagnosis with the patient's family, discussing durable power of attorney, and completing legally required driving reports. dementia. About two-thirds of providers said they routinely conduct cognitive screening, screen for depression, report elder abuse, and discuss care needs and decision-making issues with patients' families. Only half of all outpatient providers implemented caregiver support practices for at least half of their patients. Physicians' choice of medications for cognition, mood, and behavior problems was largely consistent with current practice guidelines. These results suggest possible priorities for quality improvement efforts. More research is needed to clarify the reasons for the particular gaps between guidelines and practice and to identify specific targets for intervention.

title: Human experimentation and medical ethics
Human experimentation in historical and ethical perspectives
abstract: KIE: Prepared as reference material for a World Health Organization/Council for International Organizations of Medical Sciences document, Proposed International Guidelines for Biomedical Research Involving Human Subjects (1982), this article reviews historical aspects of human experimentation and considers various current issues. References early experiments, including self-experiments by physicians"; traces the history of drug trials through the pharmacotherapeutic revolution and the thalidomide tragedy"; and describes the formulation of ethical requirements during the Weimar Republic in Germany. Contemporary issues discussed are the use of controls and placebos, investigators as subjects, special categories of subjects, and informed and indirect consent. The text of the proposed WHO/CIOMS Guidelines is attached.

title: Human fetal tissue for medical research
Human tissue research: EORTC recommendations on its practical consequences
abstract: Improvement in cancer care is possible through the application of new treatment modalities, which are emerging from the knowledge and discoveries coming from laboratory research. This is possible thanks to international collaboration and the collection of tumor tissues. The creation of a European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC) Tumor Bank is a natural step in this direction, offering the collection of tumor samples from patients admitted to EORTC trials. The goal of such a bank is not only to improve the diagnostic review process, but also to facilitate translational research by enabling clinicians and basic scientists to establish close collaborations. The EORTC Tissue Research Policy is developed to ensure, under the legal framework of the EORTC, an ethical and scientific review of research projects, ensure that adequate information is provided to patients, establish procedures on the use of materials , including legal aspects and publication policies. As part of the EU TubaFrost project, the EORTC will provide a common international platform for the use of tissues for research purposes, finding a balance between different laws and ensuring scientific progress.

title: Hypertension Improvement Project (HIP): study protocol and implementation challenges
abstract: BACKGROUND: Hypertension affects 29% of the US adult population and is a leading cause of heart disease, stroke, and kidney failure. Despite numerous effective treatments, only 53% of people with hypertension have ideal blood pressure. The chronic care model suggests that blood pressure control can be achieved by improving the way patients and clinicians approach patient self-care. METHODS AND DESIGN: This article describes the protocol of a 2 x 2 nested randomized controlled trial to test the separate and combined effects on systolic blood pressure of a behavioral intervention for patients and a quality improvement intervention for clinicians. Primary care practices were randomly assigned to the physician intervention or physician control condition. Physician randomization occurred at the clinic level. Physician intervention included training and performance monitoring. The training comprised 2 web-based modules detailing both the JNC-7 hypertension guidelines and lifestyle modifications for hypertension. Performance data was collected for 18 months and feedback was provided to clinicians every 3 months. Patients participating in the intervention and control clinics were individually randomized to patient intervention or usual care. The patient intervention consisted of a 6-month behavioral intervention delivered by trained interventionists in 20 group sessions, followed by 12 monthly telephone contacts with community health advisors. Follow-up measurements were made at 6 and 18 months. The primary outcome was mean change in systolic blood pressure at 6 months. Secondary outcomes were diastolic blood pressure and the proportion of patients with adequate blood pressure control at 6 and 18 months. DISCUSSION: Overall, 8 practices (4 per treatment group), 32 physicians (4 per practice; 16 per treatment group), and 574 patients (289 control and 285 intervention) were enrolled. Baseline characteristics of patients and providers and the challenges they faced during study implementation HIP interventions can improve blood pressure control and reduce cardiovascular disease risk in a primary care practice setting by addressing key components of the model The study design allows for an assessment of the efficacy and cost of interventions by physicians and patients separately, so that healthcare organizations can make informed decisions about implementing one or both interventions in the context from local resources TRIAL REGISTRY: ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT00201136.

title: Hypertension Improvement Project: Randomized Trial of Quality Improvement for Physicians and Lifestyle Modification for Patients
abstract: Despite widely publicized hypertension treatment guidelines for physicians and lifestyle recommendations for patients, rates of blood pressure control remain low. In community-based primary care clinics, we conducted a 2 x 2 nested, randomized, controlled trial of physician intervention versus control and/or patient intervention versus control. Physician intervention included internet-based training, self-monitoring, and quarterly feedback reports. The patient intervention included 20 weekly group sessions followed by 12 monthly telephone counseling contacts and focused on weight loss, dietary pattern Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension, exercise, and reduced sodium intake. The primary outcome was change in systolic blood pressure at 6 months. Eight primary care practices (32 physicians) were randomized to medical intervention or control groups. Within those practices, 574 patients were randomly assigned to intervention or control groups of patients. The mean age of the patients was 60 years, 61% were women, and 37% were black. Blood pressure data were available for 91% of patients at 6 months. The main effect of physician intervention on systolic blood pressure at 6 months, adjusted for baseline pressure, was 0.3 mm Hg (95% CI 1.5 to 2.2"; P = 0. 72).The main effect of the patient intervention was 2.6 mm Hg (95% CI 4.4 to 0.7, P=0.01).The interaction of the 2 interventions was significant (P= 0.03), the greatest impact was seen with the combined physician-patient intervention (9.7 +/- 12.7 mm Hg).The differences between the treatment groups did not persist at 18 months. combinations of doctor and patient reduce blood pressure;" future research should focus on improving the efficacy and sustainability of these interventions.

title: Hypertension in black patients: an update
abstract: Black people are at high risk for hypertension and increased morbidity from cardiovascular and kidney disease, in particular. Greater understanding of racial disparities in hypertension, in terms of risk factors, patient/physician behaviors, and treatment outcomes, is key to improving racial care for black patients. Recent data suggest that black patients progress more rapidly from prehypertension to hypertension, highlighting the need for early and immediate intervention. Unfortunately, adherence and persistence of antihypertensive therapy is generally poor in black patients and is compounded by the increased need for multidrug therapy in this patient population. Treatment strategies currently under investigation focus on methods to improve self-care behaviors and medication adherence. Because this is a rapidly evolving field of study, this article provides an update on recent findings that should be of relevance and interest to practicing physicians.

title: Identification and evaluation of the main beliefs about physical activity of colorectal cancer survivors
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physical activity (PA) has been associated with a lower risk of disease recurrence and longer survival in colorectal cancer (CRC) survivors";" however, less than one-third of CRC survivors meet physical activity guidelines. Interventions to promote PA in CRC survivors need to understand the most important beliefs influencing PA behavior. OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to examine the strength of associations between CRC survivors' most common PA beliefs and Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) motivational constructs, as well as PA behavior. INTERVENTION/METHODS: Colorectal cancer survivors (n = 600) residing in Alberta, Canada, completed self-report questionnaires assessing medical and demographic variables, PA beliefs, TPB constructs, and PA behavior. RESULTS: Colorectal cancer survivors identified better physical fitness (69.5%), family members (67.3%), and medical/health problems (8.8%) as behavioral, normative, and control beliefs most prevalent, respectively. All PA beliefs were significantly correlated with all TPB and PA constructs. CONCLUSIONS: Physical activity interventions for CRC survivors should target many salient beliefs, including behavioral, normative, and control beliefs. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: Understanding the most salient beliefs about PA in CRC survivors can guide nurses in developing successful strategies to promote PA in this population and likely improve quality of life and possibly outcomes of care. the illness.

title: Identification of perceived barriers to pain management in Iranian children: a qualitative study
abstract: Hospitalized children often receive inadequate treatment for their pain. Pediatric nurses experience these shortcomings more than other members of the health care team. This research was an attempt in the form of a phenomenological study to reveal some of the main barriers in childhood pain management as nurses had perceived them. Sixteen nurses were interviewed in the pediatric medical, surgical, and infectious wards of a hospital in Iran. Data analysis was based on the Colaizzi method that revealed three main themes in different areas, namely: organizational barriers, limitations related to the characteristics of the child, and barriers related to the nature of the disease and its treatments. The results of the study have shown organizational limitations added to the lack of authority to administer any medical intervention, inadequate equipment and services, and the lack of availability of opioids as the main factors of pain control and restriction. Additional factors that relate to the child's specifications, such as age, temperament, behavior, expression, and gender, affect pain assessment and treatment. The results revealed the barriers identified in the real context. It seems that some guidelines are needed to achieve optimal pain management.

title: Identification, evaluation and management of obesity in an academic primary care center
abstract: BACKGROUND: The rapidly increasing prevalence of obesity among children is one of the most challenging dilemmas facing pediatricians today. As the medical community struggles to develop effective strategies to treat this epidemic, early identification of obesity by pediatric health care providers remains the crucial initial step in obesity management. OBJECTIVE: To date, there has been no direct evaluation of pediatric physicians' performance in identifying and managing obesity in clinical practice. The objective of this study was to determine obesity identification rates by pediatric residents, nurse practitioners, and faculty in a primary care academic setting and to describe the actions taken by these providers in their assessment and management of obesity. DESIGN: A retrospective review of medical records of all health supervision visits was conducted for children 3 months to 16 years of age, examined between December 1, 2001, and February 28, 2002. For children, the 120% of the 50th weight-for-height percentile was defined as obese. For children > or = 5 years of age, a body mass index > 95th percentile for age and sex was defined as obese. SETTING: A large primary care practice located in a tertiary care academic pediatric hospital, serving a predominantly urban, minority (70% African American), Medical Assistance insured (90%) population. PARTICIPANTS: Primary care providers, including pediatric residents, nurse practitioners, and medical instructors. RESULTS: Of the 2,515 visits reviewed, a total of 244 patients met the study definition of obesity, yielding an estimated obesity visit prevalence of 9.7% among health supervision visits for children 3 months to 16 years of age. old. This prevalence of visits for obesity cannot be used to estimate the prevalence of obesity in the population, given the skewed distribution of visits towards very young children. For all children who met the study definition of obesity, providers documented obesity in their assessments in only 53% of the visits reviewed (129 visits). Although most charts (69%) contained an adequate dietary history, only 15% included a description of the child's activity level or television viewing. Obesity was noted on physical examination in 39% of cases. For children for whom obesity was identified as a problem by their doctors (129 patients), 81% of the charts contained an adequate dietary history, while 27% contained a description of the child's activity level or television viewing . Obesity was noted on physical examination in 64% of cases. Most children identified as obese by their providers received some specific treatment for their obesity, including education, screening, and referral to specialists. Changes in diet were recommended for 71%, increased activity for 33%, and limitation of television viewing time for only 5%. Eighty-three percent of providers recommended close follow-up monitoring. Other recommendations included referral to a dietitian (22%), screening laboratory studies (13%), a food diary (9%), endocrine referral (5%), or referral to preventive cardiology (3%). Provider identification of obesity was affected by patient age and degree of obesity. The identification of obesity was lowest among preschool children (31%) and highest among adolescent patients (76%). Providers who evaluated older and heavier children were also more likely to obtain an activity history, note obesity on physical exam, recommend changes in activity, refer the patient to a nutritionist, obtain screening lab studies, and recommend close monitoring. Identification of obesity and other outcome variables were not significantly influenced by provider training level or patient gender. CONCLUSIONS: Although the prevalence of childhood obesity has now reached epidemic proportions, it was underrecognized and undertreated by pediatric primary care providers in our study. Providers identified obesity as a problem for only half of obese children screened for health surveillance. The lowest rates of obesity identification occurred among children younger than 5 years and those with milder degrees of obesity. Identification did not improve with additional years of pediatric training. Even for the subset of children identified as obese by their providers, assessment and treatment often did not match current recommendations. For example, more attention has been paid to the role of diet, compared to activity, in assessing obesity. Notably, only a small number of providers (5%) recommended a decrease in TV viewing for their obese patients, despite evidence linking TV viewing to pediatric obesity. This finding is concerning, because obesity is known to be a multifactorial disease that responds only to significant changes in dietary and activity behaviors. Only 13% of providers requested laboratory studies as part of their recommendations. The American Academy of Pediatrics currently recommends obtaining a lipid profile, total cholesterol level, and screening for type 2 diabetes mellitus as part of the evaluation for obesity. Most physicians who ordered laboratory studies included thyroid function tests, which are not recommended by the American Academy of Pediatrics due to the very low probability of hypothyroidism as a cause of obesity. Although the extent of evaluation and management of children who were recognized as obese did not meet current guidelines, it was much better than that of patients who were not identified as obese by their providers. This demonstrates the importance of timely identification as the crucial initial step in obesity management. The results of this study are disappointing, especially as evidence mounts on the importance of early intervention to prevent the medical and psychosocial sequelae of obesity, as well as the persistence of obesity in adulthood. This study highlights the need for increased awareness and identification of obesity in the primary care setting, especially among younger children and those with mild obesity.

title: Identification and reduction of errors with surgical simulation
abstract: The primary determinant of a patient's safety and outcome is the skill and judgment of the surgeon. While the knowledge base and decision processing are tested during the residency, technical skills, which are at the core of the profession, are not tested. Innovative state-of-the-art simulation devices that train both surgical tasks and skills, without risk to patients, should enable error and near miss detection and analysis. Studies have validated the use of a sophisticated endoscopic sinus surgery simulator (ES3) to train residents on the basics of the procedure. Evaluations are underway as to whether integrating a comprehensive ES3 training program into the residency curriculum will have long-term effects on surgical performance and patient outcomes. Using various ENT residencies, subjects are exposed to guided training on the ES3, as well as minimally invasive trainers such as the MIST-VR. Technical errors are identified and quantified in the simulator and intraoperatively. Through a web-based database, individual performance can be compared to a national standard. An enhanced version of ES3 will be developed that will support patient-specific anatomical models. This advance will allow the study of the effects of simulated trial of patient-specific procedures (mission trial) on patient outcomes and surgical errors during the actual procedure. The information gained from these studies will help usher in the next generation of surgical simulators that are anticipated to have a significant impact on patient safety.

title: Identification of the barriers and facilitators for a triage, treatment and transfer clinical intervention for the management of patients with acute stroke in the emergency department: a systematic review using the theoretical domains framework (TDF)
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical guidelines recommend that evaluation and management of stroke patients begin early, including in emergency departments (EDs). To inform the development of an emergency room-targeted implementation intervention, we conducted a systematic review of qualitative and quantitative studies to identify relevant barriers and facilitators for six key clinical behaviors in acute stroke care: appropriate triage, of thrombolysis, monitoring and control of temperature, blood glucose levels and swallowing difficulties and transfer of stroke patients in the emergency department. METHODS: Studies of any design, conducted in the emergency department, where barriers or facilitators were identified based on primary data for one or more of these six clinical behaviors. Major biomedical databases (CINAHL, OVID SP EMBASE, OVID SP MEDLINE) were searched using comprehensive search strategies. Barriers and facilitators were categorized using the Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF). The behavior change technique (BCT) that best aligned with the strategy that each facilitator represented was selected for each of the reported facilitators using a standard taxonomy. RESULTS: Five qualitative studies and four surveys of the 44 studies identified met the selection criteria. Most of the barriers reported fell into the TDF domains of "environment, context, and resources" (such as stressful working conditions or lack of resources) and "knowledge" (such as lack of knowledge or familiarity with guidelines). Most of the enablers fell into the domains of "knowledge" (such as educating clinicians about the estimated risk of bleeding after intravenous thrombolysis [tPA]) and "skills" (such as providing the opportunity to treat accident cases). stroke of varying complexity). The total number of assigned BCTs was 18. The most frequently assigned BCTs to reported enablers were "focus on past success" and "information on health consequences." CONCLUSIONS: The barriers and facilitators to the delivery of key evidence-based protocols in an emergency setting have been identified and interpreted within a relevant theoretical framework. Since then, this new knowledge has been used to select specific BCTs to implement evidence-based care in an emergency setting. It is recommended that the findings of future similar reviews take a similar theoretical approach. In particular, the use of existing matrices to help in the selection of relevant BCTs.

title: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis: prevailing and evolving hypotheses about its pathogenesis and implications for therapy
abstract: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a progressive and usually fatal lung disease characterized by fibroblast proliferation and extracellular matrix remodeling, resulting in irreversible distortion of lung architecture. Although the pathogenic mechanisms remain to be determined, the prevailing hypothesis holds that fibrosis is preceded and caused by a chronic inflammatory process that damages the lung and modulates pulmonary fibrogenesis, giving rise to the terminal fibrotic scar. However, there is little evidence that inflammation is prominent in the early stages of the disease and it is unclear whether inflammation is relevant to the development of the fibrotic process. The evidence suggests that inflammation does not play a fundamental role. Inflammation is not a prominent histopathologic finding, and epithelial injury in the absence of ongoing inflammation is sufficient to stimulate the development of fibrosis. Furthermore, the inflammatory response to fibrogenic lung injury is not necessarily related to the fibrotic response. Clinical measurements of inflammation do not correlate with stage or outcome, and potent anti-inflammatory therapy does not improve outcome. This review presents a growing body of evidence suggesting that idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis involves abnormal wound healing in response to multiple microscopic sites of ongoing alveolar epithelial injury and activation associated with the formation of patchy fibroblast-myofibroblast foci, which evolve to fibrosis. Progress in understanding fibrogenic mechanisms in the lung is likely to lead to more effective therapies.

title: If Only It Were So: Medical Physics, US Human Radiation Experiments, and the Final Report of the Advisory Committee to the President (ACHRE)
Impact of a clinical decision support system on the prescription of antibiotics for acute respiratory infections in primary care: a quasi-experimental trial
abstract: Objective To assess the effect of a clinical decision support system (CDSS) integrated into an electronic health record (EHR) on the prescription of antibiotics for acute respiratory infections (ARI) in primary care. Materials and methods Quasi-experimental design with nine intervention practices and 61 control practices in the Practice Partner Research Network, a network of practices that use the same EHR (Practice Partner). The nine intervention practices were located in nine US states. The design included a 3-month baseline data collection period (October to December 2009) before intervention introduction and 15-month follow-up (January from 2010 to March 2011). The main outcome measures were the prescription of antibiotics in episodes of ARI for which antibiotics are inappropriate and the prescription of broad-spectrum antibiotics in all episodes of ARI. Results In adult patients, the prescription of antibiotics in episodes of ARI in which antibiotics are inappropriate decreased more (-0.6%) among the intervention practices than in the control practices (+4.2%) (p= 0.03). However, among adults, the CDSS intervention improved broad-spectrum antibiotic prescribing, with a 16.6% decrease among intervention practices versus a 1.1% increase in control practices (p<0 .0001). A similar effect was found in the prescription of broad-spectrum antibiotics in pediatric patients with a 19.7% decrease among intervention practices vs. a 0.9% increase in control practices (p<0.0001) . Conclusions A CDSS integrated into an EHR had a modest effect on changing prescribing for adults where antibiotics were inappropriate, but had a substantial impact on changing overall broad-spectrum antibiotic prescribing among pediatric and adult patients.

title: Impact of a computerized clinical decision support system on reducing inappropriate antimicrobial use: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Objective: Many hospitals use antimicrobial management teams (AMTs) to improve patient care. However, most work with minimal IT support. We evaluated the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of a computerized clinical decision support system for antimicrobial utilization management. Design: A randomized controlled trial in adult patients hospitalized between May 10 and August 3, 2004. Antimicrobial utilization was managed by an existing AMT using the system in the intervention arm and without the system in the control arm. . The system was developed to alert the AMT to potentially inappropriate antimicrobial therapy. Measurements: Outcomes assessed were hospital expenditures on antimicrobials, mortality, length of stay, and time spent managing antimicrobial use. Results: AMT intervened in 359 (16%) of 2237 patients in the intervention arm and 180 (8%) of 2270 in the control arm, while spending approximately one hour less each day in the intervention arm. Hospital charges for antimicrobials were $285,812 in the intervention arm and $370,006 in the control arm, a savings of $84,194 (23%) or $37.64 per patient. No significant differences were observed in mortality (3.26% vs. 2.95%, p = 0.55) or length of hospitalization (3.84 vs. 3.99 days, p = 0.38) . Conclusion: Use of the system facilitated antimicrobial utilization management by allowing the AMT to intervene in more patients receiving inadequate antimicrobial therapy and achieving substantial time and cost savings for the hospital. This is the first study to demonstrate in a randomized controlled trial of patients that computerized clinical decision support systems can improve existing antimicrobial stewardship programs.

title: Impact of a computerized decision support system on adherence to guidelines on antibiotics prescribed for urinary tract infections in emergency departments: a multicenter prospective controlled intervention before and after study.
abstract: Objectives Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are one of the main reasons antibiotics are prescribed in emergency departments (EDs), and half of these antibiotics are prescribed inappropriately. Our objective was to assess the impact of a computerized decision support system (CDSS) on adherence to empiric antibiotic prescription guidelines (antibiotic and duration) for UTIs in EDs. Methods: A multicenter prospective controlled before-and-after intervention study was conducted from March 19 to October 28, 2012. All adults diagnosed with community-acquired UTI (cystitis, pyelonephritis, or prostatitis) in three EDs were included. French. Antibiotic therapy was considered guideline compliant if the prescribed antibiotic and duration were in accordance with national guidelines. Data was collected using electronic medical records. Paired tests were used when comparing periods within each ED, and global analyzes used multivariate logistic mixed models. Results Nine hundred and twelve patients were included during the 30-week study period. The CDSS was used in 59% of cases (182/307). The CDSS intervention improved compliance with antibiotic prescriptions in only one ED in a bivariate analysis (absolute increase +20%, P = 0.007). Antibiotic choice improved on multivariate analyses, but only when CDSS was used [OR?=?1.94 (95% CI 1.13 to 3.32)]. The CDSS also changed the initial diagnosis in 23% of cases, in the three EDs. Conclusions The CDSS only partially improved compliance with antibiotic prescription guidelines in UTIs.

title: Impact of a computerized template on the prescription of antibiotics for acute respiratory infections in children and adolescents
abstract: Bottom. Computerized decision support (CDS) can potentially improve patient safety and guideline compliance. The authors developed an interactive acute respiratory illness template (ARI-IT) within an electronic health record (EHR) to manage pediatric ARIs and evaluated the impact on antibiotic prescribing. Methods. They randomly assigned 12 practices to receive the ARI-IT or to the control group. Antibiotic rates among all eligible AKI diagnoses were compared between control and intervention AKI visits, controlling for grouping by physician. Results. There was no difference in total antibiotic prescriptions between control and intervention clinics. The use of the ARI-IT significantly reduced antibiotic prescriptions (31.7% vs. 39.9%"; p = 0.02) and the use of macrolides (6.2% vs. 9.5%;" p = 0.02) between visits compared to those eligible visits where it was not used. Conclusion. The use of CDS reduced the prescription of antibiotics and macrolides in children with AKI. However, low overall use resulted in an ineffective intervention.

title: Impact of a Multifaceted Intervention on Cholesterol Control in Primary Care Practices: Compliance with Guidelines for a Heart Health Randomized Trial
abstract: Background Physician adherence to the National Cholesterol Education Program clinical practice guidelines has been poor. Methods We recruited 68 primary care internal and family medicine consultations; 66 were randomly assigned to a study arm; 5 consultations were withdrawn, resulting in 29 receiving the Adult Treatment Panel Third (ATP III) intervention and 32 receiving an alternative intervention focused on the Seventh Report of the Joint National Committee for Prevention, Screening, Evaluation, and Treatment of High Blood Pressure (JNC-7) ATP III providers received a personal digital assistant that provided Framingham risk scores and ATP III recommended treatment All practices received copies of each clinical practice guideline, an introductory lecture , 1 performance feedback report and 4 visits for specific academic details of the intervention. Data in 61 practices were extracted from random samples of medical records of patients treated from June 1, 2001 through May, from May 31, 2003 (baseline) and from May 1, 2004 through April 30, 2006 (follow-up). n decisions (primary outcome) were calculated. Generalized estimating equations were used to compare results by arm, taking into account patient grouping within practices. Results We reviewed 5,057 baseline and 3,821 follow-up charts. The detection rate of lipid levels increased from 43.6% to 49.0% (ATP III practices) and from 40.1% to 50.8% (control practices) (net difference, -5.3 % [P = 0.22]). Adequate management of lipid levels decreased slightly (73.4% to 72.3%) in ATP III practices and more markedly (79.7% to 68.9%) in control practices. The net change in appropriate management favored intervention (+9.7%; 95% confidence interval [CI], 2.8%-16.6% [P < .01]). Adequate drug prescription within 4 months decreased in both arms (38.8% to 24.8% in ATP III practices and 45.3% to 24.1% in control practices; net change, +7.2 % [P = 0.37]) Overtreatment decreased from 6.6% to 3.9% in ATP III and increased from 4.2% to 6.4% in control practices (net change, -4.9% [P = 0.01]). to the ATP III guidelines.

title: Impact of a multifaceted intervention on attitudes and behaviors of nurses and physicians towards family presence during resuscitation
abstract: Recent studies of health care providers' attitudes toward the presence of patients' family members during CPR and invasive procedures (family presence) have focused on retrospective or cross-sectional surveys of staff. Research reveals that doctors' opinions about the value of this practice are mixed. Although guidelines for the implementation of family presence have been suggested, few reports have been published describing actual programs or effective strategies to change the practice. As staff members advocating for the initiation of a family presence program in our own emergency department, we were interested in assessing the attitudes of staff members before the family presence program was initiated and after it was established. We also wanted to see if attitudes differed between nurses and doctors. In this article, we report our experience with the implementation of a family presence program in the emergency department of a major academic teaching hospital.

title: Impact of a quality improvement program on care and outcomes for children with asthma.
abstract: Objective To test a quality improvement intervention, a learning collaboration based on the Institute for Healthcare Improvement's Breakthrough Series methodology, specifically aimed at improving care and outcomes for patients with childhood asthma. Design Randomized trial in primary care practices. Setting Practices in Boston, Massachusetts and Detroit, Michigan Participants Forty-three practices, with 13,878 pediatric patients with asthma, randomly assigned to intervention and control groups. Intervention Participation in a collaborative learning project based on the Breakthrough Series methodology for continuous quality improvement. Main outcome measures Change from baseline in the proportion of children with persistent asthma who received appropriate pharmacological treatment for their asthma, and in the proportion of children whose parents received a written management plan for their child's asthma, as determined by telephone interviews with the parents of 631 children. Results After adjusting for status, practice size, child age, gender, and within-practice grouping, no overall effect of the intervention was found. Conclusions This methodologically rigorous evaluation of a widely used quality improvement technique did not demonstrate a significant effect on the processes or outcomes of care for children with asthma. Potential shortcomings in program implementation, project duration, sample selection, and data sources preclude the general inference that this type of breeding program is ineffective. Additional rigorous studies in more optimal settings need to be conducted to assess the efficacy of this method in improving care.

title: Impact of a web-based antimicrobial approval system on the use of broad-spectrum cephalosporins in a university hospital.
abstract: Objective: To achieve sustained improvement in the use of cefotaxime and ceftriaxone (CEFX) in a major teaching hospital, as measured against national antibiotic guidelines. Design and setting: Pre- and post-intervention survey of CEFX use at the Royal Melbourne Hospital, a tertiary care hospital in Melbourne, Victoria. Intervention: A web-based antimicrobial approval system linked to national antibiotic guidelines was developed by a multidisciplinary team and implemented in March 2001. Main outcome measures: Change in rate of CEFX use (defined daily doses [DDD ] per 1000 acute occupied bed days) during 8 months before and 15 months after the intervention";" Concordance of the indication of CEFX with the national antibiotic guidelines before and after the intervention. Results: The use of CEFX decreased from a mean of 38.3 DDD/1000 bed days before the intervention to 15.9, 18.7 and 21.2 DDD/1000 bed days at 1, 4 and 15 months after the intervention. the intervention. Agreement with national antibiotic guidelines increased from 25% of preintervention courses to 51% within 5 months postintervention (P < 0.002). Gentamicin use also increased, from a mean of 30.0 to 48.3 DDD/1000 bed days (P = 0.0001). Conclusion: The web-based antimicrobial approval system achieved a sustained reduction in CEFX use over 15 months, as well as better prescription consistency with antibiotic guidelines. It has potential for linking with electronic prescribing and for wider use of other medicines, as well as for research into the epidemiology of antibiotic use.

title: Impact of an educational intervention to improve prescribing by private doctors in Uganda
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Private physicians in urban Uganda treat a large percentage of common adult illnesses. Improving their prescribing would not only encourage more rational drug use, but also lower costs for patients. Interventions to improve drug use tend to be more successful when face-to-face educational methods are included. OBJECTIVES: To determine the effectiveness of a face-to-face educational intervention on the treatment of acute respiratory infections (ARI), malaria, and non-dysenteric diarrhea by private practitioners in three urban areas of Uganda. METHODS: The study used a comparison group intervention design to assess the impact of the educational intervention. A total of 108 private physicians were divided into intervention (n = 30) and control (n = 78) groups. Surrogate patients, trained to simulate the symptoms and signs of the target conditions, were used to collect data on physicians' medical practices and prescribing behaviors. Intervention physicians were invited to a one-day interactive educational seminar facilitated by local opinion leaders that covered the principles of rational drug use and the National Standard Treatment Guidelines for treating the target conditions. Physicians also received data on referral practices. RESULTS: Baseline data indicated high rates of inappropriate treatment practices in both the intervention and control groups. There was near-universal use of antibiotics for ARIs (over 90%), high rates of recommended injections for malaria (over 30%), and high rates of polypharmacy (over three drugs per patient). After the intervention, some significant improvements in key practices were observed in the intervention group. Compared with control physicians, antibiotic prescribing for ARIs decreased by 23% in the intervention group, use of malaria combination products decreased by 28%, there were trends toward better adherence to guidelines for ARIs and malaria, and marginal reductions in drug costs. However, the overall impacts of the intervention were limited, especially on quality indicators related to medical history, proper examination, and patient counseling. CONCLUSION: The face-to-face educational intervention resulted in some small improvements in key prescribing practices of private physicians. However, an intervention involving repeated contacts with prescribers and addressing economic considerations would be necessary to obtain further improvements. Private physicians should be made aware of and encouraged to use the National Standard Treatment Guidelines, and attempts to improve their prescribing should be supported by community education.

title: Impact of clinical practice guidelines on physician behavior: tonsillectomy in children
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This study was conducted to assess the extent to which the development and implementation of clinical practice guidelines to include children for tonsillectomy (with or without adenoidectomy) influenced the behavior of participating ENT surgeons. METHOD: A before-and-after study in which the intervention (the development and dissemination of local practice guidelines) was introduced sequentially in different hospitals and surgical practices. The study was carried out in four ear, nose and throat surgical services in the north of England, with 16 consultant ear, nose and throat surgeons and their junior staff on 1190 children aged 0 to 14 years who were assessed, before consulting a ENT surgeon, for have been referred for throat-related problems for which tonsillectomy was a possible treatment option were included in the study. Decision reached by surgeons and proportion of decisions that complied with the new guidelines. RESULTS: Of clinical decisions to list children for tonsillectomy made before the introduction of locally agreed guidelines, 73% (486/660) met the criteria of the later guidelines, 15% (97/660) did not. did and 12% (77/660), it was impossible to judge. After the intervention, the corresponding figures were 73% (386/530), 14% (73/53), and 13% (71/530), respectively. When decisions were made to violate guidelines, this was more often for tonsillectomy when not indicated (83% (141/170)) than withholding tonsillectomy when indicated (17% (29/170). . of the guidelines that were not followed in the decisions to perform tonsillectomy were: the child's age was younger than that recommended by the guidelines--54% (75/141)"; had presented febrile attacks of tonsillitis than those recommended by the guidelines -- 22% (32/141);" and there were "significant" symptoms not included in the guidelines: 20% (29/141). CONCLUSIONS: Despite strong evidence to the contrary, local guidelines were formulated at a level that most surgeons have already reached Guideline development and implementation, therefore, had very little impact on clinical practice The local guideline development process was not sufficient to achieve the shift to evidence-based practice the evidence";" the clinical preference turned out to be bas so intractable. There is a need to improve clinicians' ability to assess and interpret research evidence. Previous work has emphasized the need to explore the factors that influence clinical behavior towards evidence-based practice. Our study suggests the need for more research into why clinicians continue to follow clinical preferences, even when invited to base agreed local clinical policies on evidence.

title: Impact of Clinical Trial Results on National Trends in ÃŽÂ± Blocker Prescription, 1996-2002
abstract: Context Research on the factors influencing prescribing patterns and the extent of change produced by clinical trial findings is limited. Objective To examine changes in the prescription of alpha-blockers for the treatment of hypertension before and after the April 2000 publication of the unfavorable early termination of the antihypertensive and lipid-lowering to prevent heart attack (ALLHAT) trial involving the study doxazosin mesylate. Prescribing changes were considered in the context of other potential concurrent influences on drug use between 1996 and 2002, including changes in alpha-blocker drug prices, generic conversion, drug promotion, and competition. Design, Setting, and Patients Using 2 national pharmaceutical market research reports published by IMS HEALTH, a-blocker prescription orders reported in the National Prescribing Audit: a random computerized sample of approximately 20,000 of 29,000 retail, independent, and drug pharmacies. mail order and aa-blocker prescribing patterns of physicians in practices reported in the National Disease and Therapeutic Index, a stratified random sample of about 3,500 physician practices, were tracked. Outcome measures Trends in physician-reported use of alpha-blockers and in prescribing and dispensing of alpha-blockers by US pharmacies Outcomes There were consistent increases in new alpha-blocker prescriptions, prescriptions dispensed, and medical drug use from 1996 to 1999. There was a modest reversal in these trends after the early termination of ALLHAT and subsequent releases in early 2000. Between 1999 and 2002, new blocker prescription orders decreased by 26% (from 5.15 million to 3.79 million), prescriptions dispensed by 22% (from 17.2 million to 13.4 million), and physician-reported drug use by 54% (from 2.26 million to 1.03 million). Other potential influences do not appear to have contributed significantly to this decline, although the cessation of alpha-blocker marketing may have accelerated the decline. Conclusions Modest but statistically significant decreases in the use of doxazosin and other alpha-blockers coincided with early termination of the ALLHAT doxazosin group. Although clinicians have responded to this new evidence, strategies to increase the impact of clinical trials in clinical practice are warranted.

title: Impact of computerized decision support on blood pressure management and control: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND We conducted a cluster randomized controlled trial to examine the efficacy of computerized decision support (CDS) designed to improve hypertension care and outcomes in a racially diverse sample of primary care patients. METHODS We randomized 2027 adult patients receiving hypertension care at 14 primary care practices to 18 months after their physicians received CDS for each hypertensive patient or to usual care without computerized support for the control group. We assessed guideline-recommended pharmacological treatment prescription and blood pressure control levels for patients in each group and examined whether intervention effects differed by patient race/ethnicity using interaction terms. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS Blood pressure control rates were 42% at baseline and 46% at the evaluation visit with no significant difference between groups. After adjustment for patient demographics and clinical characteristics, number of previous visits, and levels of baseline blood pressure control, there were no differences between intervention groups in the odds of outcome blood pressure control. Use of CDS for providers significantly improved prescription of medications adherent to Joint National Committee (JNC) guidelines compared with usual care (7% vs. 5%, P < ? 0.001); OR] 1.39 [CI, 1.13-1.72]) and the effects of the intervention did not differ by race and ethnicity of the patients. CONCLUSIONS CDS improved appropriate medication prescription without improving disparities in care and overall blood pressure control. Future Focused work is needed on improving these interventions and exploring other practical interventions to reduce disparities in outcomes related to hypertension.

title: Impact of decision support in electronic medical records on lipid management in primary care.
abstract: Electronic decision support tools can help improve the management of hyperlipidemia and other chronic diseases. This study examined the impact of lipid management tools integrated into an electronic medical record (EMR) in primary care practices. This randomized controlled trial was conducted in a national network of physicians using an outpatient EMR. Adult primary care physicians were randomly assigned by practice to receive an electronic form embedded in the EMR. The form contained indications about suboptimal care according to the Adult Treatment Panel-III (ATP-III) guidelines, as well as reporting tools to identify patients outside of office visits whose lipid management was suboptimal. All active patients, ages 20 to 79, whose physicians participated in the study were classified as having high, moderate, or low cardiovascular risk, and the proportion who underwent testing for hyperlipidemia, at target lipids, and at lipid-lowering medications if not at goal were measured according to ATP-III guidelines. A total of 105 physicians from 25 practices and 64,150 patients were included in the study. Results improved for most measures from before to 1 year after the intervention (November 1, 2005 to October 31, 2006). However, after controlling for confounding and clustering in the multilevel model, only the updated lipid tests for high-risk patients were statistically better in the intervention group compared to the control group (adjusted odds ratio 15, 0, P?<?0.05). This study showed little difference in the quality of lipid management after implementing an EMR-based disease management intervention in primary care settings. Future studies may need to examine more comprehensive interventions that include clinic staff in a team approach to care. (Population Health Management 2009";"12:221–226)

title: Impact of EHR-based clinical decision support on guideline adherence for patients taking NSAIDs: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: PURPOSE: Electronic health records (EHRs) with clinical decision support show promise for improving quality of care, but their impact in managing chronic conditions has been mixed. This study examined the impact of EHR-based clinical decision support on guideline adherence to reduce gastrointestinal complications in primary care patients taking nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). METHODS: This randomized controlled trial was conducted in a national network of primary care practices using an EHR and focused on patients taking traditional NSAIDs who had factors associated with a high risk of gastrointestinal complications (history of peptic ulcer disease) concomitant use of anticoagulants, antiplatelet medications [including aspirin], or corticosteroids, or age 75 years or older.) Practices were randomized to receive EHR-based guidelines and alerts for high-risk patients taking NSAIDs or usual care. The primary outcome was the proportion of patients who received guideline-concordant care during the 1-year study period (June 2007 to June 2008), defined as traditional NSAID discontinuation (including switching to a lower-risk medication). ), the co-prescription of a gastroprotective medication, or both. RESULTS: Participants included 27 practices with 119 physicians and 5,234 high-risk patients. Intervention patients were more likely than usual care patients. to receive guideline-concordant care (25.4% vs. 22.4%, adjusted odds ratio = 1.19; 95% confidence interval, 1.01-1.42). For individual high-risk groups, patients taking low-dose aspirin were more likely to receive guideline-consistent care with the intervention than usual care (25.0% vs. 20.8%, odds ratio adjusted = 1.30, 95% confidence interval, 1.04-1.62). ), but there was no significant difference for patients in other high-risk groups. CONCLUSIONS: This study showed only a small impact of EHR-based clinical decision support for high-risk patients taking NSAIDs in primary care practices. These results add to the growing literature on the complexity of EHR-based clinical decision support to improve quality of care.

title: Impact of environmental olfactory cues on hand hygiene behavior in a simulated hospital setting: a randomized study.
abstract: This study investigated the impact of a fresh scent on the rate of hand hygiene compliance (HHC) among novice healthcare providers. In total, 165 participants examined a standardized patient with one sample exposed to a fresh scent (N = 79) and the other exposed to the standard environment (N = 86). Hand hygiene behaviors were tracked prior to patient contact using video surveillance. The standard environment group had a HHC rate of 51%, while participants in the fresh scent group had a higher HHC rate of 80% (P < 0.001). These data demonstrate that hand hygiene behavior can be unconsciously influenced by cues in the environment.

title: Impact of patient environmental education in preventive medicine practices
abstract: BACKGROUND: Studies show that provider-oriented reminders alone are less effective in increasing physician compliance with prevention guidelines than combinations of patient-oriented and provider-oriented physician reminders. The efficacy of patient environmental education (ie, videos, brochures, and office posters) without individual staff or educator involvement has not been well established. The objective of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of patient environmental education in increasing the amount of preventive services that patients receive. METHODS: A nonrandomized controlled trial using historical controls was conducted in a model family medicine clinic at the University of New Mexico School of Medicine in Albuquerque. The study group (n = 389) included adult women who had been seen at the clinic at a time when educational materials were available in the waiting room. The control group (n = 381) were equally selected patients seen during the same period of the previous year, when such materials were not available. During the intervention, patients in the waiting room were exposed to educational materials that encouraged them to ask their doctors about cholesterol tests, Papanicolaou (Pap) tests, tetanus boosters, and mammograms. For both the control and study groups, physician orders for preventive services were monitored over a 4-month follow-up period by review of medical records. RESULTS: There were no statistically significant changes in the number of cholesterol tests, Pap tests, tetanus boosters, or mammograms ordered after the patient environmental education intervention, despite adequate statistical power. CONCLUSIONS: Patient environmental education materials were not effective in increasing the amount of preventive services performed by physicians in this study. Although such interventions are inexpensive, easy to understand, and well-intentioned, they may be ineffective in increasing the performance of preventive services for patients.

title: Impact of feedback and didactic sessions on the reporting behavior of superior endoscopic findings by doctors and nurses
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES: Guidelines have been developed to report measurements of Barrett's esophagus and hiatal hernia and reflux esophagitis grades to improve consistency, communication, and ultimately patient care. Our goals were to assess the percentage of cases in which findings were reported in accordance with guidelines and to assess the impact of education and feedback on reporting behaviour. METHODS: A prospective cross-sectional study design was used. Chart reviews of all adult patients who underwent esophagogastroduodenoscopy at a tertiary care center were performed during three 2-month periods over a 12-month interval: Time 1 (March 1, 2004-April 30, 2004), Time 2 (July 1, 2004) 2004-August 31, 2004) and Time 3 (March 1, 2005-April 30, 2005). Standardized educational sessions began 2 years before Time 1. No intervention was performed between Time 1 and Time 2";" data were collected to examine secular change. Between Moment 2 and Moment 3, individual and group feedback and feedback sessions were provided. RESULTS: Five thousand six hundred nine eligible esophagogastroduodenoscopies were performed, of which 2675 demonstrated Barrett's esophagus, hiatal hernia and/or reflux esophagitis. At baseline, Barrett's esophagus and hiatal hernia measurements were correctly dictated in a median of 67% and 86% of cases, respectively, improving to 100% (P < 0.05) and 98% (P < 0.01) of the cases, respectively. The Los Angeles classification system was used in a median of 100% of cases at baseline and at follow-up. CONCLUSIONS: Anonymous individual and group feedback, in combination with brief and structured didactic educational sessions, significantly improves adherence to established guidelines for reporting Barrett's esophagus and hiatal hernia. Once successfully incorporated into clinical practice, adherence to the Los Angeles Esophagitis Classification System is easy to maintain.

title: Impact of information brochures on the behavior of patients with gastroenteritis or tonsillitis: a cluster randomized trial in French primary care
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the impact of four patient information brochures on the behavior of patients in primary care. DESIGN: Multicenter cluster-randomized controlled trial between November 2009 and January 2011. PARTICIPANTS: French adults and children who consulted a participating primary care physician and were diagnosed with gastroenteritis or tonsillitis. Patients were randomized to receive patient information leaflets or not, according to their primary care physician's cluster randomization. INTERVENTION: Adult patients or adults accompanying a child diagnosed with gastroenteritis or tonsillitis were informed of the study. Physicians in the intervention group gave patients an information leaflet about their condition. Two weeks after the consultation, the patients (or the accompanying adult) answered a telephone questionnaire about their behavior and knowledge about the condition. MAIN MEASURES: Primary and secondary outcomes, mean behavior and knowledge scores, respectively, were calculated from responses to this questionnaire. RESULTS: Twenty-four physicians enrolled 400 patients. Twelve patients were lost to follow-up (3%). In the group receiving the patient information booklet, patient behavior was closer to guideline recommendations than in the control group (mean behavior score 4.9 vs. 4.2, p < 0.01 ).
