Knowledge was better for adults who received the booklet than in the control group (mean knowledge score 4.2 vs. 3.6, p < 0.01). There were fewer visits for the same symptoms by household members of patients who received brochures (23.4% vs. 56.2%, p < 0.01). CONCLUSION: The patient information brochures given by the doctor during the consultation significantly modify the patient's behavior and knowledge of the disease, compared to patients who do not receive the brochures, for the conditions studied.

title: Impact of the introduction of rapid diagnostic tests for malaria on the prescription of antibiotics: analysis of observational and randomized studies in public and private health settings
abstract: Objectives: To examine the impact of the use of rapid diagnostic tests for malaria on the prescription of antimicrobials, specifically antibiotics, for acute febrile illnesses in Africa and Asia. randomized trials and an observational study). Setting: Public and private health settings, 2007-13, in Afghanistan, Cameroon, Ghana, Nigeria, Tanzania, and Uganda. Participants: 522: 480 children and adults with acute febrile illness. Interventions Rapid diagnostic tests for malaria. Main outcome measures Proportions of patients prescribed an antibiotic in trial groups who had undergone rapid diagnostic tests compared to controls and in patients with negative test results compared to patients with negative test results. positives. A secondary objective compared the classes of antibiotics prescribed in different settings. ‚¬â€°714/283Ã¢â‚¬â€°683 (59%) patients in intervention groups. Antibiotics were prescribed for 40% (35Ã¢â‚¬â€°505/89Ã¢â‚¬â€°719) of malaria-positive patients and 69% (39Ã¢â‚¬â€°400 / 57Ã¢â‚¬â€°080) of those with a negative result. All but one study showed a trend towards higher antibiotic prescriptions in the groups that underwent rapid diagnostic tests. Random-effects meta-analysis of trials showed that the overall risk of antibiotic prescription was 21% higher (95% confidence interval 7% to 36%) in intervention settings. In most intervention settings, patients with negative test results received more antibiotic prescriptions than patients with positive results for all the most commonly used classes: penicillins, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (one exception), tetracyclines, and metronidazole . Conclusions Introduction of rapid diagnostic tests for malaria to reduce the unnecessary use of antimalarials, a beneficial outcome for public health, could drive the untargeted use of antibiotics. That 69% of patients were prescribed antibiotics when their test results were negative likely represents overprescription. This included antibiotics of various classes, including those such as metronidazole, which are rarely appropriate for febrile illnesses, in various clinical, health system, and epidemiological settings. It is often assumed that better disease-specific diagnosis will reduce antimicrobial overuse, but you may simply be switched from one antimicrobial class to another. The current global implementation of malaria testing could increase the non-specific use of antibiotics and should be examined.

title: Impact of education on the Mediterranean diet versus the published brochure on eating habits and serum cholesterol in a population at high risk of cardiovascular disease
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To investigate the impact of intensive group education about the Mediterranean diet on dietary intake and serum total cholesterol after 16 and 52 weeks, compared to a published brochure with the Dutch nutritional guidelines, in the context of primary prevention. of cardiovascular diseases (CVD). . DESIGN: Controlled comparison study of an intervention group receiving intensive group education on the Mediterranean diet and a control group of hypercholesterolemic people receiving usual general practitioner (GP) care. SETTING: A socioeconomically deprived area in the Netherlands with a high mortality rate from coronary heart disease (CHD). SUBJECTS: Two hundred and sixty-six hypercholesterolemic people with at least two other CVD risk factors. RESULTS: After 52 weeks, the intervention group decreased total and saturated fat intake more than the control group (net differences were 1.8% (95%CI 0.2-3.4) and 1. 1 in% (95%CI 0.4-1.9), respectively). According to the Mediterranean diet guidelines, the intake of fish, fruit, poultry and bread increased in the intervention group, more than in the control group. Within the intervention group, intake of fish (+100%), poultry (+28%), and bread (+6%) increased significantly after 1 year (P < 0.05). The intensive dietary education program did not significantly reduce serum cholesterol level more (-3%) than the published brochure (-2%) (net difference 0.06 mmol l-1, 95% CI -0.10 to 0.22). Initially, body mass index (BMI) decreased more in the intervention group, but after 1 year, the intervention and control groups gained weight equally (+1%). CONCLUSIONS: Despite beneficial changes in dietary habits in the intervention group compared to the control group, after 1 year, BMI increased and total fat and saturated fat intake was still too high.

title: Impact of non-interruptible medication laboratory monitoring alerts in ambulatory care.
abstract: Objective: Interrupt alerts within electronic applications can cause "alert fatigue" if they are triggered too frequently or are clinically reasonable only a few times. We evaluate the impact of drug lab alerts in real time and without interruptions in the supplier's order of laboratory tests. Design: We enrolled 22 outpatient clinics in a prospective, randomized, controlled trial. Clinics used the existing system or received on-screen recommendations for reference lab tests when prescribing new medications. Since the warnings did not interrupt, providers did not have to act or acknowledge the notification to complete a drug request. Measurements: Data was collected each time providers performed suggested lab tests within 14 days of a new prescription order. Findings were adjusted for patient and provider characteristics, as well as patient grouping within clinics. Results: Among 12 clinics with 191 providers in the control group and 10 clinics with 175 providers in the intervention group, there were a total of 3673 events in which initial laboratory tests would have been recommended: 1988 events in the control group and 1685 in the intervention group. In the control group, reference laboratories were requested for 771 (39%) of the drugs. In the intervention group, reference laboratories were ordered by physicians in 689 (41%) cases. Overall, there was no significant association between the intervention and the rate of requesting appropriate reference laboratory tests. Conclusion: We found that non-interruptible drug laboratory monitoring alerts were not effective in improving receipt of recommended drug reference laboratory test monitoring. Further work is needed to optimize compliance with non-critical recommendations.

title: Impact of the dual intervention of pharmacists and doctors on the benzodiazepines prescribed in patients deprived of liberty: a retrospective study
abstract: High doses of benzodiazepines (BDZ) represent an important risk factor for dependence, particularly in a prison setting. In Lyon prison, BDZ and/or opioid maintenance treatment are often prescribed to patients with mental disorders. The objective of this retrospective study was to evaluate the impact of the collaboration of psychiatrists and pharmacists in reducing the dose of BDZ prescribed to patients deprived of liberty. Since 2001, doctors and pharmacists have held monthly meetings to develop prescribing guidelines and discuss patients receiving high doses of BDZ. All prescribed psychotropic drugs were noted for each patient included in the control (before guidelines) and intervention groups. The criteria used to define the profile of each patient included age, diagnosis (mental disorder), and concomitant treatment (opioids, antidepressants). To compare each group, the daily dose of BDZ prescribed and expressed in diazepam equivalent was used as a quantitative variable. A total of 473 patients were included, 222 in the control group and 251 in the intervention group. The two groups did not show differences in terms of diagnosis. The daily dose of BDZ was higher in the control group when all patients were considered (mean (CONTROL GROUP) = 46 mg diazepam equivalent vs. mean (INTERVENTION GROUP) = 34 mg) and for each of the the following categories of patients: (48 mg vs. 30 mg), 'no opioid therapy' (44 mg vs. 31 mg), 'buprenorphine therapy' (58 mg vs. 63 mg), 'no antidepressant therapy' (41 mg vs. 29 mg) and "antidepressant treatment" (53 mg vs. 38 mg). The results of this retrospective study show the positive impact of multidisciplinary intervention in reducing the prescribed daily dose of BDZ. This experience confirms the positive impact of pharmacist feedback on prescriptions and the development of treatment guidelines by physician-pharmacist collaboration to improve prescribing practice in a prison setting.

title: Impact of medical education about asthma care on patient outcomes
abstract: OBJECTIVE: We evaluated the effectiveness of a continuing medical education program, Asthma Care Education for Physicians, in improving pediatricians' asthma communication and therapeutic skills and patients' asthma care utilization. METHODS: We conducted a randomized trial in 10 regions of the United States. Primary care providers were recruited and randomly assigned by site to receive the program provided by local faculty. The program included 2 interactive seminar sessions (2.5 hours each) that reviewed national asthma guidelines, communication skills, and key educational messages. The format included short lectures, case discussions, and video modeling communication techniques. We collected information on parents' perceptions of physician communication, child asthma symptoms, and patients' asthma health care utilization. We used multivariate regression models to determine the differences between the control and intervention groups. RESULTS: A total of 101 primary care providers and a random sample of 870 of their asthma patients participated. After 1 year, we completed follow-up telephone interviews with the parents of 731 of the 870 patients. Compared with control subjects, parents reported that physicians in the intervention group were more likely to ask about patients' concerns about asthma, encourage them to be physically active, and set goals for successful treatment. Physician patients who attended the program had a greater decrease in days limited by asthma symptoms (8.5 vs. 15.6 days), as well as a decrease in emergency room visits for asthma (0.30 vs. 0. 55 visits per year). CONCLUSIONS: The Asthma Care Physician Education program was used in a variety of settings and was effective in improving parent-reported communication skills between providers, number of days affected by asthma symptoms, and use of medications. medical care for asthma. Patients with more frequent asthma symptoms and higher healthcare utilization at baseline were more likely to benefit from their doctor's participation in the program.

title: Impact of regular collaboration between infectious disease and critical care physicians on antimicrobial utilization and patient outcome
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Antimicrobial stewardship programs have been shown to help reduce the use of unnecessary antimicrobial agents in the hospital setting. To date, there has been very little data focused on high-use areas, such as the medical ICU. A prospective intervention was conducted to assess guideline adherence, antimicrobial spending, and health care cost when an infectious disease fellow regularly interacts with the ICU medical team. DESIGN: A 3-month retrospective chart review was followed by a 3-month prospective intervention the following year. Two hundred and forty-six charts in total were reviewed for adherence to generally accepted guidelines, demographics, and microbiological results. SETTING: Twenty-four-bed medical ICU in an 861-bed tertiary care university teaching hospital in North Carolina. SUBJECTS: Patients receiving antibiotics in the medical ICU. INTERVENTION: During the intervention period, the infectious disease fellow reviewed charts, including physician notes and microbiology data, and discussed antimicrobial use with the ICU medical team. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN OUTCOMES: Antimicrobial use, duration of treatment, Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Assessment II scores, length of stay, days on mechanical ventilation, and mortality rates were compared during the two periods. . RESULTS: No statistically significant baseline differences were observed in the two groups (ie, age, gender, race, or Acute Physiology and Chronic Care Assessment II scores). Antibiotic indications included healthcare-associated (53%) and community-acquired (17%) pneumonias. Significant reductions in extended-spectrum penicillins (p=0.0080), carbapenems (p=0.0013), vancomycin (p=0.0040), and metronidazole (p=0.0004) were observed after intervention. Antimicrobial modification led to an increase in narrow-spectrum penicillins (p=0.0322). The intervention group had a significantly lower rate of non-guideline treatments (p<0.0001). There was a reduction in days of mechanical ventilation (p=0.0053), length of stay (p=0.0188), and hospital mortality (p=0.0367). The calculated annual health care savings was $89,944 from early antibiotic cessation alone. CONCLUSION: Active communication with an infectious disease professional can significantly reduce antibiotic overuse in the medical ICU by modifying or stopping antibiotics early without increasing mortality. This, in turn, can lower health care costs, foster prodigious education, and strengthen relationships between subspecialties.

title: Impact of the WHO depression guideline on patient care by psychiatrists: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Reviews of the scientific literature aim to summarize the state of knowledge and published empirical evidence. Rather, medical guidelines are intervention tools that aim to improve physician behavior and patient outcome. They can have positive effects, but they can also have negative effects. Its effects need to be proven by research. METHODS: In a randomized controlled trial, 103 psychiatrists in private practice were given the WHO depression guideline alone (information group), or were given the WHO depression guideline and trained for one day. in this guideline (intervention group), or left unreported. (control group). They then treated a total of 497 patients according to individual clinical considerations and patient needs. Observation of routine treatment lasted 12 weeks. Physicians and patients documented the course of illness and treatment, including physician-patient interaction. RESULTS: Psychiatrists in the intervention group saw more psychosocial stressors in their patients, prescribed higher doses of medication, had fewer dropouts, and rated treatment outcome as better. Ratings of doctor-patient interactions indicated more strain on their relationships. CONCLUSIONS: The results show both positive and negative effects of guideline exposure, but only in the training group and not in the information group. Guidelines must be empirically tested before they can be called "evidence-based." Each guideline should also explain how it can or should be implemented to be effective.

title: Impaired self-awareness after moderately severe to severe traumatic brain injury
abstract: Patients with moderately severe to severe traumatic brain injury (TBI) may show alterations in self-awareness several months to years after injury. Patients may underestimate cognitive and behavioral difficulties, which are the true residue of their brain injury. Increasingly, research indicates that the residuals of these alterations in consciousness greatly affect the process and outcome of rehabilitation. A recent model for conceptualizing alterations in self-awareness after various forms of brain injury is reviewed.

title: Implementation and adoption of electronic health records nationwide in secondary care in England: final qualitative results of a prospective national evaluation in "early adopter" hospitals.
abstract: OBJECTIVES To assess the implementation and uptake of the NHS Detailed Care Records service in 'early adopter' hospitals in England. DESIGN Theoretical grounded longitudinal qualitative evaluation based on case studies. SETTING 12 'early adopter' NHS acute care hospitals and specialist care settings studied over two and a half years. DATA SOURCES Data was collected through in-depth interviews, observations, and relevant documents directly related to the case study sites and to broader national developments that were perceived as impacting the implementation strategy. Data was analyzed thematically, initially within cases and then across cases. The dataset consisted of 431 semi-structured interviews with key stakeholders, including hospital staff, developers, and government stakeholders; 590 hours of strategic meeting observations and use of the software in context; 334 sets of observation notes, investigator field notes, and national conference notes; 809 NHS documents; and 58 regional and national documents. RESULTS Implementation has proceeded more slowly, with more limited scope, and substantially less clinical functionality than originally planned. The national strategy had considerable local consequences (summarized in five key themes), and broader national developments strongly impacted implementation and adoption. More specifically, delays related to unrealistic expectations about systems capabilities; the time required to build, configure, and customize the software; the work required to ensure that systems support the provision of care; and the needs of end users for training and support. Other factors hampering progress included the changing policy environment and NHS priorities; repeatedly renegotiated national contracts; different stages of development of various NHS care record service systems;" and a complex communication process between different stakeholders, coupled with contractual arrangements that largely excluded NHS providers. There was early evidence that implementation of systems resulted in significant learning within and between organizations and the development of relevant competencies within NHS hospitals.CONCLUSIONSImplementation of the NHS Care Records Service in 'early adopter' sites proved to be time-consuming and difficult to implement. a challenge, with still limited perceivable benefits for clinicians and no clear advantages for patients.Although our results might not be directly transferable to subsequent site adoption since the functionalities we tested were new and untested in the English context, shed light on the processes involved in the implementation n of major new systems. The move towards more local decision-making that we advocate based on our interim analysis and welcomed by the NHS has been followed, but it is important that policymakers do not lose sight of the overall goal of an integrated interoperable solution.

title: Implementation and success of telephonic nursing counseling in linguistically isolated Korean-American patients with high blood pressure
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Telephone nurse counseling may improve the management of chronic conditions, but the effectiveness of this approach in underserved populations is unclear. This study evaluated the use of bilingual telephone counseling provided by nurses in Korean-Americans (KA) who participated in a community-based intervention trial to improve hypertension management. METHODS: KAs were randomized to receive 12 months of hypertension-related telephone counseling that was either more intensive (every two weeks) or less intensive (monthly). Counseling records were maintained for 360 KAs who completed pre- and post-intervention assessments. RESULTS: The overall success rate of the intervention was 80.3%. The level of success was significantly influenced by counseling dose, employment status, and years of residence in the US. During the 12-month counseling period, both groups showed improvement with regard to medication intake, alcohol consumption and exercise, but did not smoke, with no significant differences between groups. CONCLUSION: Bilingual telephone counseling could reach monolingual KAs and improve their behavior in managing hypertension. PRACTICE IMPLICATIONS: Bilingual telephonic nurse counseling may have wide applicability, serving as an effective means of disseminating evidence-based chronic disease management guidelines to a linguistically isolated community with limited resources and health information.

title: Fidelity trajectories of implementation of a health promotion program in multidisciplinary settings: stress management in rehabilitation care
abstract: Background Although the importance of assessing implementation fidelity is recognized, little is known about the heterogeneity in fidelity over time. This study aims to generate knowledge about the heterogeneity in the implementation fidelity trajectories of a health promotion program in multidisciplinary settings and the relationship with changes in the health behavior of patients. Methods This study used longitudinal data from the nationwide implementation of an evidence-based physical activity promotion program in Dutch rehabilitation care. Fidelity scores were calculated based on annual surveys completed by the professionals involved (n?=?Â¡Ã€?70). Higher fidelity scores indicate more complete implementation of the core components of the program. A hierarchical cluster analysis was performed on the implementation fidelity scores of 17 organizations at three different times. Quantitative and qualitative data were used to explore the organizational and professional differences between the identified trajectories. Regression analyzes were performed to determine differences in patient outcomes. Results Three trajectories were identified as follows: Â¡Â®stable high fidelityÂ¡Â¯ (n?=?9), Â¡Â®moderate and improving fidelityÂ¡Â¯ (n?=?6), and Â¡Â ®unstable fidelity ¡Â¯ (n?=?2). Stable high-fidelity organizations were generally smaller, started earlier, and implemented the program in a more structured way compared to moderate and improving loyalty organizations. At the beginning and end of the implementation period, support from doctors and physical therapists, appreciation from professionals, and compatibility with the program were rated more positively by professionals working in stable, high-fidelity organizations compared to moderate-fidelity organizations and improving (p ?<?.05). Qualitative data showed that stable high-fidelity organizations often had an explicit vision and strategy about program implementation. Interestingly, the trajectories were not associated with patients' self-reported physical activity outcomes (fitted model ¦Ã‚?=???651.6, t(613)?=???1032, p?=?.303). Conclusions Differences in implementation fidelity trajectories at the organizational level did not result in differences in outcomes at the patient level. This suggests that an effective implementation fidelity path depends on the conditions of the local organization. More specifically, achieving stable high fidelity in implementation required stress management: realizing a vision of localized change, while safeguarding the core standardized components of the program and engaging the few clinicians throughout the process. When scaling up evidence-based health promotion programs, we propose tailoring implementation stress management to the starting position, size, and circumstances of local organizations.

title: Implementation of a new policy results in a decrease in the frequency of pressure ulcers
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the effects of a new policy on the efficiency of pressure ulcer care. DESIGN: Series of 1-day pressure ulcer surveys before and after implementation. SETTING: A 900-bed University Medical Center in the Netherlands. PARTICIPANTS: On survey days, 657 patients were included before implementation, 735 patients 4 months after implementation, and 755 patients 11 months after implementation. INTERVENTION: Implementation of a hospital guideline for the care of pressure ulcers combined with the introduction of memory foam mattresses on the efficacy of prevention and treatment of pressure ulcers. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Comparisons were made before versus after implementation regarding nursing behavior and frequency of pressure ulcer patients. RESULTS: Inadequate prevention decreased from 19% to 4% after 4 months and 6% after 11 months (P < 0.001), and inadequate treatment decreased from 60% to 31% (P = 0.005). Excluding mattress use as a positive indicator of care behavior, we found no significant increase in adequate care to prevent pressure ulcers. Furthermore, in the appropriate treatment activities, we found no significant differences. Overall, we found a significant decrease in the frequency of hospital-acquired pressure ulcers from 18% to 13% (P = 0.003) after 4 months and 11% (P < 0.001) after 11 months. CONCLUSION: The number of patients with pressure ulcers in hospital can be successfully reduced. General measures such as the introduction of suitable mattresses and guidelines for prevention and treatment are promising tools in this regard.

title: Implementation of an effective intervention for high-risk women in Mexico: protocol for a multisite randomized trial with a parallel study of organizational factors
abstract: Background Implementation studies of effective human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) prevention interventions are rare, especially in resource-poor settings, but important because they have the potential to increase the impact of interventions by improving uptake and sustainability. . Few studies have focused on organizational and provider factors that may influence acceptance and fidelity to core components of the intervention. Using a hybrid design, we will study the implementation of an effective intervention to reduce sexually transmitted infections (STIs) among female sex workers (FSWs) in 12 cities in Mexico. Our protocol will test a Â¡Â®train-the-trainerÂ¡Â¯ implementation model to transport the Mujer Segura (Mujer Sana) intervention to community-based organizations (CBOs). Methods We have partnered with the Mexican Foundation for Family Planning (Mexfam), a non-governmental organization that has community organizations throughout Mexico. At each CBO, trained ethnographers will survey CBO staff about the characteristics of their organization and about their attitudes toward their CBO and the implementation of evidence-based interventions (EBI). Then, after CBO staff recruit a sample of 80 eligible TRSXs and deliver a standard care educational intervention to 40 randomly selected women from that group, a Mexfam staff member will be trained in the Safe Woman intervention and then will train other counselors to provide Mujer Segura to the remaining 40 participating TRTS. FSW participants will receive a baseline behavioral assessment and be tested for HIV and STIs (syphilis, gonorrhea, and chlamydia)";" they will be reassessed six months after the intervention to measure the possible effects of the intervention. At the same time, qualitative and quantitative data on the implementation process will be collected, including measures of counselor fidelity to the intervention model. Once data collection is complete in each CBO, the relative effectiveness of the Safe Woman intervention will be analyzed and, across CBOs, correlations between individual and organizational provider characteristics and intervention effectiveness will be examined. Discussion This cooperative, binational research study will provide critical insights into the barriers and facilitating factors associated with implementing interventions in CBOs using the Â¡Â®train the trainerÂ¡Â¯ model. Our work builds on similar scaling strategies that have been effective in the United States. This study has the potential to increase our knowledge about the generalization of such strategies across health problems, national contexts, and organizational contexts.

title: Implementation of clinical guidelines through an electronic medical record: use, satisfaction and evaluation of the doctor
abstract: BACKGROUND: We developed and evaluated the Emergency Department Expert Record System (EDECS) to provide real-time guidance on the care of low back pain in adults, fever in children, and occupational exposure to blood and body fluids in emergency room workers. health, by incorporating clinical guidelines within an electronic medical record. OBJECTIVE: To describe the behaviors and attitudes of physicians who used EDECS. DESIGN: Pre-post questionnaires were used to assess physicians' attitudes. Intervention phase timing studies were observational, using clocks built into the software. PARTICIPANTS: One hundred and forty-two residents and interns from the emergency department, pediatrics, internal and family medicine, and patients with the aforementioned ailments. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Physician use of EDECS, time spent using EDECS, physician satisfaction and beliefs. RESULTS: Eighty-four percent of 142 eligible physicians used EDECS at least once. Five hundred and ninety-one of 789 (75%) eligible cases were completed using EDECS. Mean session time decreased from 12 min for session 1 to 5.5 min for sessions 16 and above. Physicians generally agreed that EDECS care was better than standard care, particularly with regard to documentation. However, there was considerable heterogeneity in beliefs across complaints. CONCLUSIONS: These data illuminate both the potential of computer-aided decision making and the need for context-specific approaches when trying to implement the guidelines.

title: Implementation of clinical practice guidelines for the prevention of thromboembolism in spinal cord injury.
abstract: Justification/Objectives: The purpose of this study was to determine if the publication of the clinical practice guideline (CPG) â€œPrevention of thromboembolism in spinal cord injuriesâ€ modified the management of the patient and if the adherence to the recommendations of the CPG improved after a targeted implementation strategy. Methods: Data were extracted from the charts of 1, 34, and 520 acute and chronic spinal cord injury (SCI) patients, respectively, from 6 Veterans Affairs medical centers during 3 time periods: pre-publication (T1) , pre-implementation (T2) and post-implementation (T3) of the CPG. Specific interventions were developed to address providers' perceived barriers to adherence to the guidelines, based on findings from focus groups conducted at each site. Interventions incorporated two implementation strategies: standardized documentation templates/standing orders and social marketing/outreach visits. Results: The use of the specified duration of pharmacological prophylaxis increased from 60% to 65% to 75% of patients with acute SCI at T1, T2, and T3, respectively (P = 0.060 and 0.041 for T1 vs. T2 and T2 vs. to T3, respectively). The rates of use of the individual pharmacological prophylactic agents changed significantly throughout the study, with the use of low molecular weight heparin increasing from 7% at T1 to 42% at T3. Physical assessments of thrombosis on hospital days 1 and 30 improved between T2 and T3. The use of prophylaxis in patients with chronic injuries with new risk factors for thromboembolism increased from 16% to 31% to 34% during T1, T2, and T3 (P = 0.001 and 0.87, respectively). Conclusions: The publication of the CPG had a modest effect in practice. The use of structured implementation further increased adherence to some CPG recommendations for thromboembolism prophylaxis. Similar implementation strategies should be considered for CPG recommendations with low adherence and high potential for morbidity and mortality.

title: Implementation of the diagnosis in asymptomatic patients with aortic stenosis: Registry of Implementation of the diagnosis in asymptomatic patients with aortic stenosis
abstract: Frequently in clinical practice, some physicians refer patients with aortic stenosis for an invasive approach in the asymptomatic phase of the disease. This empirical behavior, which contrasts with the recommendations of current international clinical guidelines, is due to the perception that the prognosis of these patients is truly worse than expected. In reality, the management of asymptomatic patients with aortic stenosis remains controversial and there is no clear agreement on how to reduce the excess clinical events associated with the presence of aortic stenosis, mortality and morbidity demonstrated in these patients by recent randomized clinical trials. . The predominant attention of treating physicians is often limited to assessment of the severity of aortic stenosis and the onset of symptoms, but it has been clearly demonstrated instead that the prognosis of these patients is associated with excessive growth of left ventricular mass and increased atherosclerosis. leading to coronary artery disease, heart failure, stroke, and death. Thus, in addition to the markers of faster progression of aortic stenosis, many other clinical and echocardiographic variables must be considered, collected and used together with the prognostic clinical/echocardiographic scales recently validated by several authors in clinical practice, where the vast majority of these variables are culpably not taken into consideration. The registry on the Implementation of Diagnostics in asymptomatic patients with Aortic Stenosis is a prospective study designed with the aim of improving the diagnostic evaluation and improving the prognostic stratification of patients with asymptomatic aortic stenosis.

title: Evidence-based rehabilitation implementation for non-specific back pain and common mental health problems: a process evaluation of a national initiative.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The nationwide implementation of guaranteed access to evidence-based rehabilitation was established in Sweden in 2009, through a Swedish government law. The primary goal of the rehabilitation guarantee was to increase the rate of return to work, reduce and prevent long-term absenteeism after diagnoses related to back pain and common mental health problems. This study aims to develop knowledge about the factors that influence the large-scale implementation of complex and extensive interventions in healthcare settings. METHODS: Three questionnaires, interviews, and documents from different data sources were used in data collection and analysis. Data were analyzed using iterative thematic analysis. RESULTS: The following main facilitators contributed to the realization of the rehabilitation guarantee: financial incentives, establishment of the project organization, hiring, in-service training, and previous experiences of working on similar projects. The barriers were: the short-term project form of the rehabilitation guarantee, the attitudes and competence of clinicians to work towards return to work, the lack of guidelines describing treatment modalities in multimodal rehabilitation, and the lack of of well-defined criteria for the inclusion of patients. The documents revealed that the goal of returning to work became less pronounced during the implementation process. Instead, care and health were more frequently described in the documents used to disseminate information about the rehabilitation guarantee. Intermediate results found were: patients with rehabilitation needs were given more appropriate priority, better preparation for future implementation efforts, and higher overall competence in psychotherapy and teamwork, which was therefore available to different patient groups. those covered by the rehabilitation guarantee. CONCLUSIONS: To facilitate the implementation of established national policy goals in clinical practice, tools specifically aimed at changing physicians' attitudes and behaviors in relation to those goals are needed. Our results underline the importance of investing sufficient time and resources in the activities and in supporting the implementation process.

title: Implementation of evidence-based treatment protocols to control fever, hyperglycemia, and swallowing dysfunction in acute stroke (ASC): a cluster randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background We evaluated patient outcomes 90 days after hospital admission for stroke following a multidisciplinary intervention aimed at evidence-based management of fever, hyperglycemia, and swallowing dysfunction in acute stroke units (ASU)."; " Background We evaluated patient outcomes 90 days after hospital admission for stroke following a multidisciplinary intervention aimed at evidence-based management of fever, hyperglycemia, and swallowing dysfunction in acute stroke units (ASU).

title: Implementation of the Spanish adaptation of the European guidelines on the prevention of cardiovascular diseases in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Successful implementation of cardiovascular disease (CVD) prevention guidelines is highly dependent on primary care physicians (PCPs) providing risk factor assessment, intervention, and patient education. The objective of this study was to determine the degree of knowledge and implementation of the Spanish adaptation of the European guidelines on CVD prevention in clinical practice (CEIPC guidelines) among primary care physicians. METHODS: A cross-sectional survey of PCPs in Spain was conducted between January and June 2011. A random sample of 1,390 PCPs was obtained and stratified by region. The data was collected through a self-administered questionnaire. RESULTS: More than half (58%) of the physicians were aware of and aware of the recommendations, and 62% of them claimed to use them in clinical practice, with general practitioners (without any specialist accreditation) being less likely to do so than general practitioners. family doctors. The majority of PCPs (60%) did not assess cardiovascular risk, citing the limited time available for surgery as the biggest barrier at 81%. The main reason to be skeptical about the recommendations, reported by 71% of doctors, was that there are too many guidelines. Nearly half of clinicians cited lack of training and skills as the biggest barrier to implementing lifestyle and behavior change recommendations. CONCLUSIONS: Most PCPs were aware of the Spanish adaptation of the European CVD prevention guidelines (CEIPC guidelines) and their content. However, only a third of primary care physicians used the guidelines in clinical practice and less than half of the CVD risk assessment tools.

title: Implementation of the NHLBI Integrated Guidelines for Cardiovascular Health and Risk Reduction in Children and Adolescents: Rationale and Study Design for Young Hearts, Strong Beginnings, a Cluster Randomized Trial Targeting Body Mass Index, Blood Pressure, and Heart Rate. tobacco
abstract: BACKGROUND: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) and underlying atherosclerosis begin in childhood, and its presence and severity are related to known cardiovascular disease risk factors. Attention to risk factor control in childhood has the potential to reduce later CVD risk. OBJECTIVE: The Young Hearts Strong Starts study was designed to test strategies that facilitate adoption of the Integrated Guidelines for Cardiovascular Health and Risk Reduction in Children and Adolescents endorsed by the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute. This study compares guideline-based quality measures for body mass index, blood pressure, and smoking using two strategies: a multifaceted practice-directed intervention versus a standard dissemination. STUDY DESIGN: Two primary care research networks recruited practices and provided support for intervention and outcome assessments. Individual practices were randomly assigned to intervention or control groups using a cluster randomized design based on network affiliation, number of physicians per practice, urban versus non-urban location, and practice type. The observation units are individual children because adherence to the measure is extracted from the medical records of individual patients. Randomization units are medical practices. This results in a multi-level design in which patients are nested within practices. Intervention practices received toolkits and supported implementation of guidelines, including academic details, an ongoing e-learning group. This project is aligned with the American Board of Pediatrics Maintenance of Certification requirements, which include monthly physician self-abstraction, webinars, and other essay elements. IMPORTANCE: This trial will provide an opportunity to demonstrate tools and strategies to improve CV prevention in children through guideline-based interventions.

title: Implementation of the Tobacco Tactics intervention versus usual care in Trinity Health community hospitals
abstract: BACKGROUND: Guided by the Reach, Effectiveness, Adoption, Implementation, and Maintenance (RE-AIM) implementation framework, a study sponsored by the National Institutes of Health compared the nurse-managed Smoking Intervention with usual care. A previous article describes the effectiveness of tobacco intervention tactics. This later document provides data describing the remaining constructs of the RE-AIM framework. METHODS: This pragmatic study used a quasi-experimental mixed-methods design at five Michigan community hospitals, of which three received the Nurse Administered Smoking Intervention and two received usual care. Nurses and patients were surveyed before and after the intervention. Measures included outreach (patient engagement rates, characteristics, and receipt of services), adoption (nurse engagement rates, and characteristics), implementation (pre- and post-training changes in nurses' attitudes, service delivery, barriers for implementation, feedback on training). , documentation of services and number of follow-up phone calls from volunteers), and maintenance (continuation of the intervention after the study has ended). RESULTS: Scope: Patient participation rates were 71.5%. Compared with no change at control sites, there were significant pre- and post-intervention increases in self-reported receipt of printed materials at intervention hospitals (n = 1370, p < 0.001). Adoption: All targeted units and several non-targeted units participated in the intervention hospitals";" 76.0% (n = 1,028) of the screened nurses and 317 additional staff members participated in the training, and 92.4% were extremely or somewhat satisfied with the training. IMPLEMENTATION: Nurses in intervention hospitals reported increases in the provision of smoking cessation advice, counselling, medications, brochures, and DVDs (all p < 0.05) and reported decreases in barriers to implementing smoking cessation services ( p < 0.001). Qualitative comments were very positive ('easy to use', 'simplified' or 'time-saving'), although problems were noted when showing patients the DVD and charts in the electronic medical record. Maintenance: Nurses continued to provide the intervention after the study ended. CONCLUSIONS: Given that nurses represent the largest group of frontline providers, this intervention, which meets the Joint Commission guidelines for the treatment of hospitalized smokers, has the potential to be broad in scope and decrease smoking, morbidity and mortality among hospitalized smokers. As we move toward more population-based interventions, the RE-AIM framework is a valuable guide to implementation. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov, NCT01309217.

title: IMPLEMENTATION of a clinical practice guideline for evidence-based management of acute low back pain in general practice (IMPLEMENT): cluster randomized controlled trial study protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence generated from reliable research is not often implemented in clinical practice. Evidence-based clinical practice guidelines are a potential vehicle to achieve this. A recent systematic review of guideline dissemination implementation strategies concluded that there was a lack of evidence regarding effective strategies for promoting guideline uptake. Recommendations from this review and other studies have suggested the use of interventions that are theoretically based because they may be more effective than those that are not. An evidence-based clinical practice guideline for the management of acute low back pain was recently developed in Australia. This provides the opportunity to develop and test a theory-based implementation intervention for a condition that is common, has a high burden, and for which there is a gap between evidence and practice in the primary care setting. OBJECTIVE: This study aims to test the effectiveness of a theory-based intervention to implement a clinical practice guideline for acute low back pain in general practice in Victoria, Australia. Specifically, our main objectives are to establish whether the intervention is effective in reducing the percentage of patients who are referred for plain radiography and improving the mean level of disability of patients three months after consultation. METHODS/DESIGN: This study protocol describes the details of a cluster randomized controlled trial. Ninety-two general practices (groups), including at least one licensed general practitioner, will be randomized to an intervention or control arm by restricted randomisation. Patients 18 years of age or older visiting a participating physician for acute nonspecific low back pain of less than three months' duration will be eligible for inclusion. An average of twenty-five patients per general practice will be recruited, providing a total of 2,300 participating patients. General practitioners in the control arm will receive access to the guideline using the existing dissemination strategy. Professionals from the intervention arm will be invited to participate in facilitated face-to-face workshops that have been underpinned by behavioral theory. Investigators (not involved in the delivery of the intervention), patients, outcome assessors and the study statistician will be blinded to group assignment.

title: Implementation of a guideline for the treatment of type 2 diabetics: results of a cluster randomized controlled trial (C-RCT)
abstract: BACKGROUND: In Italy, many diabetics still lack adequate care in general practice. We evaluated the effectiveness of different strategies for the implementation of an evidence-based guideline for the management of uncomplicated type 2 diabetes among general practitioners (GPs) in the Lazio region. METHODS: Three-arm cluster randomized controlled trial with general practitioners as randomisation units (groups). 252 GPs were randomized to an active strategy (training module with guideline delivery) or passive dissemination (guideline delivery only) or usual care (control). Data on drug and test prescriptions were collected by existing information systems, while patient data came from GP databases. The results of the process were measured at the group level one year after the intervention. The primary results referred to the measurement of glycosylated hemoglobin and the implementation of evaluation tests for micro and macrovascular complications. In order to assess physicians' medication prescribing behaviour, secondary outcomes were also calculated. RESULTS: Physicians identified 6,395 uncomplicated type 2 patients with a high prevalence of cardiovascular risk factors. Data on the initial performance of GPs show low proportions of glycosylated hemoglobin assessments. The results of the C-RCT analysis indicate that the active implementation strategy was ineffective for all primary outcomes (respectively, OR 1.06 [95% CI: 0.76-1.46]"; OR 1.07 [ 95% CI: 0.80-1.43];" OR 1.4 [95% CI: 0.91-2.16]. Similarly, passive diffusion of the guidewire did not show any effect. CONCLUSION: In In our region, GP adherence to guidelines was not improved by a structured learning program Implementation through organizational measures appears to be essential to induce behavior change TEST REGISTRY: ISRCTN80116232.

title: Implementation of a mixed public-private model for tuberculosis treatment in urban Pakistan: lessons and experiences
abstract: SETTING: Six cities in Karachi, Pakistan. OBJECTIVES: 1) Strengthen the capacity of general practitioners (GPs) to provide tuberculosis (TB) treatment through DOTS"; and 2) improve collaboration between the public and private sectors in TB management and notification DESIGN: A quasi-experimental study The study design was adopted to ensure enrollment of TB patients through trained GPs supported by laboratory networks and to improve case detection rate.RESULTS: The following challenges were faced during the implementation of the model in urban settings: a systematic list of GPs was not available; most GPs were untrained health professionals working in squatter settlements, where more GPs with formal training are needed; the motivation of GPs with a large number of patients is very low;" and access to a laboratory is difficult. Of 35 patients enrolled in the first trimester (Q3 2009), 87% successfully completed their treatment. CONCLUSION: Mixed public-private DOTS (PPM) is feasible in Pakistani cities. However, the cost, time and effort required to set up the program are higher than in many other developing countries.

title: Implementation of academic details for breast cancer screening in underserved communities
abstract: BACKGROUND: African American and Hispanic women, such as those living in the Northern Manhattan and South Bronx neighborhoods of New York City, generally do not receive necessary services for breast cancer prevention and screening practices, although they are more likely to die of breast cancer. than other women. Primary care physicians (PCPs) are instrumental in recommending breast cancer screening for their patients. Academic details are a promising strategy for improving PCP performance in recommending breast cancer screening, yet little is known about the effects of academic details on breast cancer detection among physicians practicing in medically active areas. unattended. We evaluated the effectiveness of a multicomponent enhanced academic detailed intervention to increase recommendations for breast cancer screening within a sample of urban community physicians. METHODS: Two medically underserved communities were matched and randomly assigned to intervention and control arms. Ninety-four community (ie, non-hospital-based) primary care physicians in northern Manhattan were compared with 74 physicians in the South Bronx neighborhoods of the New York City metropolitan area. Intervention participants received physician-led enhanced academic details, using the American Cancer Society guidelines for early detection of breast cancer. Physicians in the control group did not receive any intervention. We conducted interviews to measure primary care physicians' self-reported recommendation for mammography and clinical breast examination (CBE), and whether PCPs taught women how to perform breast self-examination (BSE). RESULTS: Using multivariate analyses, we found a statistically significant intervention effect in recommending EBC to female patients aged 40 years and older";" Reports of mammography and breast self-examination increased in both arms from baseline to follow-up, based on physician self-report. At posttest, physician participation in additional educational programs, increased self-efficacy in prevention counseling, routine use of chart reminders, computer-based rather than paper-based counseling and follow-up approaches, printed education materials for the patient, performance goals for mammography, and greater involvement of nursing and other office staff were associated with greater detection. CONCLUSION: We found some evidence of improvement in breast cancer screening practices due to improved academic detail among primary care physicians practicing in underserved urban communities.

title: Implementation of best evidence in smoking cessation treatment for hospitalized veterans: results of the VA-BEST trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although the US Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) has promoted adherence to smoking cessation guidelines since 1997, hospitalized smokers do not receive consistent cessation assistance . METHODS: In a pre- and post-guideline implementation trial in inpatient medicine units at four VA hospitals, the effectiveness of a multimodal intervention (improved academic details, modified nursing intake template, patient education and helpline referral, practice facilitation, and staff feedback). ) the behavior change of the practice was evaluated. Interviews were conducted before discharge with 824 patients to assess the reception of the 5As (ask, advise, assess, help, organize) by nurses and doctors in hospitalized smokers. RESULTS: Subjects were significantly more likely to have received each of the 5A's from a nurse during the post-implementation period (except for "advise to quit"). More patients were helped to quit smoking (75% vs. 56%, adjusted odds ratio [OR] = 2.3, 95% confidence interval [CI] = 1.6, 3.1) and were arranged for follow-up (23% vs 18%, adjusted OR = 1.5, 95% CI = 1.0, 2.2) by a nurse during the post-implementation period. However, unadjusted results showed no improvement in 7-day point prevalence abstinence at 6-month follow-up (13.5% vs. 13.9%). Nurses' self-efficacy in smoking cessation counseling, measured in a survey of 166 unit nurses, improved after implementation of the guideline. DISCUSSION: A multifaceted intervention that includes enhanced academic details is an effective strategy to improve the delivery of smoking cessation services to hospitalized medical patients. To promote long-term cessation, more intensive interventions are needed to ensure that motivated smokers receive guideline-recommended treatment (including pharmacotherapy and referral for outpatient smoking cessation advice).

title: Implementation of clinical guidelines in the treatment of diabetes mellitus in general practice. Evaluation of effort, process, and patient outcome related to the implementation of a computer-based decision support system
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To assess the implementation of clinical guidelines for diabetes mellitus in general practice with a specific clinical decision support computer system (CDSS) as part of the intervention. METHODS: Randomized study with a health center as unit. General practice in Sor- and Nord-Trondelag counties in Norway, 380,000 inhabitants. Seventeen health centers with 24 doctors and 499 patients with diabetes mellitus were in the intervention group and 12 health centers with 29 doctors and 535 patients were in the control group. The main outcome measures were group differences in fractions of patients without records (process assessment) and group mean differences for the same variables (patient outcome assessment). RESULTS: Statistically significant group differences were experienced for fractions of patients with no smoking record (intervention group, 82.6%; control group, 94.5%), body mass index (78.2% vs. 93, 0%) and sufficient records to calculate the risk score for myocardial infarction (91.1% vs. 98.3%);" all for 18 months. Large variations in the center were shown for all variables. The only statistically significant group difference was -2.3 mm Hg (95% CI, -3.8, -0.8) in diastolic blood pressure in favor of the intervention group. Statistically insignificant differences in favor of the intervention group were HbA1c, -0.1% (95% CI, -0.4, 0.1), systolic blood pressure, -1.2 mm Hg (95% CI, -4.4, 2.0). Statistically insignificant differences in favor of the control group were fractions of smokers, +3.0% (95% CI, -4.0, 10.0), body mass index, +0.3 kg/m2 ( 95% CI, -0.8, 1.4), female risk score +0.1 (95% CI, -5.1, 5.2), and male risk score +2.6 ( 95%, -14.2, 19.5). CONCLUSIONS: The implementation of clinical guidelines for diabetes mellitus in general practice, by means of a CDSS and various procedures for their implementation, did not result in a clinically significant change in physician behavior or patient outcome.

title: Implementation of clinical guidelines in the treatment of hypertension in general practice.
abstract: Discrepancies between clinical guidelines and clinical practice call for practical implementation strategies. This study evaluates the implementation of clinical guidelines for hypertension in general practice with a specific computer-based clinical decision support system (CDSS) as part of the intervention. We conducted a randomized study of general practice health centers in SÃ¸r- and Nord-TrÃ¸ndelag counties in Norway (population 380,000). A total of 17 health centers were included, with 24 physicians and 984 patients in the intervention group. Data from 887 patients were used in the analyses. There were 12 health centers with 29 physicians and 1,255 patients in the control group. Data from 1127 control patients were used in the analyses. The main outcome measures were the behavior of the physician, measured by compliance with the registry of the variables recommended in the Norwegian clinical guidelines for hypertension. The objective of the intervention was to reduce the fractions of patients without records. However, there were no clinically significant differences between the intervention group and the control group for the fractions of patients without blood pressure recording (intervention group 14.3%, control group 14.2%) or serum cholesterol (62.3% vs. 56.8%) for 12 months, nor, for 18 months, for fractions of patients with no smoking record (82.9% vs 87.1%), cardiovascular inheritance (79.5% vs 73.4%) and index body mass (81.5% vs 89.2%). One or more variables required for calculation of the risk score for myocardial infarction were missing in 91.7% of patients in the intervention group and in 91.9% of patients in the control group. Large variations in the center were shown for all variables. The implementation of clinical guidelines in the treatment of hypertensive patients in general practice, by means of a CDSS and various procedures for its implementation, did not result in clinically significant changes in the behavior of physicians. Of importance are both the lack of ease of use of the specific CDSS and the problems in performing time-consuming multidimensional procedures.

title: Implementation of evidence-based guidelines for radiography in acute low back pain: a pilot study in a chiropractic community.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the ability of a systematic educational intervention strategy to change chiropractors' plain radiography ordering behavior towards an evidence-based practice for patients with acute low back pain (LBP). DESIGN: A quasi-experimental method was used to compare results before and after the intervention with those of a control community. SETTING: Two communities in southern Ontario. DATA SOURCE: Mailed survey data on the management of acute low back pain. Outcome measures Rates of use of plain radiographs for acute low back pain based on responses to mail-in surveys. RESULTS: Post-intervention, there was a 42% reduction in self-reported need for plain radiography for acute uncomplicated low back pain (p 0.05). CONCLUSIONS: The educational intervention strategy used in this study appeared to have an effect in reducing the perceived need for plain radiography in acute low back pain.

title: Implementing Evidence-Based Practice: Efficacy of a Structured Multifaceted Mentoring Program
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This paper is a report of the effectiveness of a multifaceted structured mentoring program designed to implement evidence-based practice in an intensive clinical research setting. BACKGROUND: Barriers to implementing evidence-based practice are well documented in the literature. Evidence-based practice is associated with higher quality care and better patient outcomes than tradition-based care. However, the integration of evidence-based practice implementation into daily clinical practice remains inconsistent, and the gap between research and clinical practice remains considerable. METHODS: This quasi-experimental mixed methods study included three focused discussions with nursing leadership and shared governance staff, as well as pre- (N = 159) and post-intervention (N = 99) questionnaires administered between June 2006 and February 2007. Online questionnaires included measures of organizational readiness, evidence-based practice beliefs, evidence-based practice implementation, job satisfaction, group cohesion, and intention to leave nursing and current job. Results. Participants in the evidence-based practice mentoring program had greater increases in perceived organizational culture and evidence-based practice readiness and evidence-based practice belief scores than those who did not participate. Qualitative findings suggested that leadership support for a culture for evidence-based practice and dedication of resources to sustainability of the initiative should be a priority to engage staff at all levels. CONCLUSION: These findings corroborate other studies showing that nurses' beliefs about evidence-based practice are significantly correlated with implementation of evidence-based practice and that having a mentor leads to stronger beliefs and greater implementation by nurses. part of nurses, as well as greater group cohesion, which is a powerful predictor of nursing turnover rates.

title: Implementation of antidepressant prescribing depression guidelines in general practice: a quasi-experimental evaluation
abstract: BACKGROUND: Internationally, depression guidelines recommend a stepped-care approach, which implies that antidepressant medication should not be offered as first-stage treatment to patients with mild or subthreshold depression. In the Netherlands, antidepressant prescription rates in general practice as the first step of treatment are considered high. The objective of this study was to evaluate the implementation of the recommendations of the guidelines on the prescription of antidepressants. METHODS: A quasi-experimental study was conducted with a non-equivalent naturalistic control group and a three-year follow-up in the general practice setting in the Netherlands. General practitioners (GPs) participated in a national Quality Improvement Collaborative (QIC), focusing on the implementation of a guideline-based model for a stepped-care approach to depression. The model consisted of self-help and psychological treatment options for patients with milder symptoms as an alternative to antidepressants in general practice. Changes in GP antidepressant prescription rates were documented over a three-year period and compared with those of a control group of GPs, selected from an ongoing national registry network. RESULTS: A 23.3% (49.4%-26.1%) decrease in antidepressant prescription rates was found for newly diagnosed patients with depressive symptoms within the intervention group, while no difference was observed in the reference group (50.3%-52.6%). The decrease over time was significant, compared to the usual care group (OR 0.44, 95% CI: 0.21-0.92). CONCLUSIONS: An implementation program that used stepped-care principles for intervention allocation for depression resulted in reduced antidepressant prescription rates in general practice. GPs can change prescribing behavior within the context of a QIC.

title: Implementation of guidelines for the prevention of opportunistic infections in inflammatory bowel disease
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Opportunistic infections are a key safety issue in the treatment of patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Despite the existence of international guidelines, many gastroenterologists have not adopted routine screening and vaccination. The aim of this study was to modify clinical behavior by using a simple screening tool. METHODS: Each participating gastroenterologist was provided with a screening and vaccination card for hepatitis B, chickenpox, influenza, pneumococcus, human papillomavirus, tuberculosis, hepatitis C, and HIV. Gastroenterologists were surveyed for vaccine recommendations and current practice before and after the introduction of the proforma. Immunity rates and the proportion of patients receiving recommended screening tests and vaccinations were documented. RESULTS: 30 gastroenterologists from 8 different IBD centers participated in the evaluation. A total of 919 patients (55% women, 65% Crohn's disease, 33% ulcerative colitis, 2% indeterminate IBD) were included. Introduction of the proforma increased self-reported gastroenterologist screening from 47% to 97% before and after the intervention, respectively, p<0.001. After applying the proforma, vaccination against hepatitis B, chickenpox, influenza and pneumococcus was recommended in 67%, 2.5%, 75% and 69% of the patients, respectively. Of these, 42%, 39%, 66% and 49% of the patients followed the recommendations and were vaccinated. Cervical smears were recommended in 31%, and 62% of these obtained the recommended cervical smear. CONCLUSIONS: The implementation of a screening and vaccination form significantly changed the self-reported behavior of the gastroenterologist. Patient compliance with these recommendations was suboptimal and suggests the need for further patient education, in addition to other forms of support.

title: Implementation of international osteoarthritis treatment guidelines in primary health care: study protocol for the SAMBA stepped wedge cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background Previous research indicates that people with osteoarthritis (OA) are not receiving optimal recommended treatment. Based on international treatment recommendations for hip and knee OA and previous research, the SAMBA model for integrated OA care in Norwegian primary health care has been developed. The model includes physical therapist (PT)-led patient OA education sessions and an exercise program that lasts 8-12 weeks. This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness, feasibility and costs of a customized strategy to implement the SAMBA model. Methods/design A cluster randomized controlled trial with a stepped wedge design including an evaluation of effects, processes and costs will be carried out in six municipalities (clusters) in Norway. The municipalities will be randomized by the time of transition from the current usual care to the implementation of the SAMBA model through a personalized strategy. The tailored strategy includes interactive workshops for general practitioners (GPs) and PTs in primary care covering the SAMBA model for integrated OA care, educational material, educational outreach visits, commentary, and reminder material. Outcomes will be measured at the patient, GP, and physiotherapist levels using self-report, semi-structured interviews, and record-based data. The primary outcome measure is patient-reported quality of care (Osteoarthritis Quality Indicator Questionnaire) at 6-month follow-up. Secondary outcomes include referrals to physical therapy, imaging, and orthopedic surgeon referrals, as well as participants' satisfaction with treatment, symptoms, level of physical activity, body weight, and self-reported and measured lower extremity function. Actual exposure to custom deployment strategy and user experiences will be measured in a process assessment. In the economic evaluation, the difference in costs of usual OA care and the SAMBA model for integrated OA care will be compared to the difference in health outcomes and reported using the incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) . Discussion The results of the present study will add to the current knowledge on personalized strategies, which aim to improve the acceptance of evidence-based OA care recommendations and improve the quality of OA care in primary health care. The new knowledge can be used in national and international initiatives designed to improve the quality of OA care. ClinicalTrials.gov Trial Registration NCT02333656

title: Implementation of nutritional guidelines: the effect of systematic training for nutrition nurse practitioners
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Approximately 40% of patients admitted to hospitals are malnourished. The implementation of nutritional guidelines could reduce the incidence of malnutrition and requires education and training for hospital staff. OBJECTIVE: It was hypothesized that a behaviorally focused training program for staff would increase the identification of eating difficulties, improve patients' knowledge of appropriate food choices, and increase the number of snacks eaten between meals, and therefore Therefore, it would reduce the risk of malnutrition. METHODS: A pre-post test design was used to assess the effect of the nurse training program. The training took place in five modules over 1 year and combined nutrition topics with implementation topics and theories of planned change. The program was based on experiential learning theories and the steps of look, think and act. The effect on patients was measured using a patient questionnaire. RESULTS: After implementing the guidelines, more patients discussed their eating difficulties with staff, received relevant assistance during the meal, and were served the type of food they had ordered and could chew. Patients' knowledge of appropriate menu food choices increased, suggesting that patients' nutritional intake had improved. CONCLUSION: Our findings suggest that a strategy based on the principles of experiential learning theory and the phases in the look, think and act model facilitated the implementation of nutritional guidelines in a hospital setting.

title: Implementation of clinical guidelines using a computerized graphics system. Effect on the initial care of health workers exposed to body fluids.
abstract: Context. â€”Although clinical guidelines are considered an important mechanism to improve the quality of medical care, implementation problems can limit their effectiveness. There are few empirical data on the effect of computerized systems for the application of clinical guidelines on the quality of care. Goal. â€”Determine whether real-time submission of clinical guidelines using an electronic medical record can increase guideline compliance. Design. —Intermittent prospective interrupted time series with intention-to-treat analysis. Around. â€œEmergency department of the university hospital. Subjects. —Patients were 280 healthcare workers (50 in the initial control phase, 156 in the intervention phase, and 74 in the post-intervention control phase) who presented for initial treatment of occupational exposures to body fluids, including 89% (248/280) who were needle sticks and 81% (208/257) who were exposed to blood. Physicians included resident physicians and attending physicians who worked in the emergency department during the study. Interventions. â€”Implementation of a computerized graphics system that provides real-time information on history and recommendations for laboratory tests, treatment and disposition based on rules derived from clinical guidelines. The main measures. â€”Quality of care determined by essential elements documented in the medical record and aftercare instructions, adherence to testing and treatment guidelines, and total charges and percentage of charges attributable to activities supported by the guidelines . Results. â€”The mean percentage of documenting 7 essential items related to patient history in the medical record increased from 57% during the baseline period to 98% in the intervention phase (42% increase"; confidence interval [ 95% CI], 34%-49%) and 11 items in the aftercare instruction increased from 31% at baseline to 93% during the intervention phase (62% increase; 95% CI, 51%-74 %), but both decreased at baseline when the computerized system was removed Compliance with 4 laboratory test guidelines increased from 63% at baseline to 83% during the intervention phase (20% increase; 95% CI, 9 %-31%), but decreased to 52% when the computer system was removed guidelines increased from 83% at baseline to 96% during the intervention phase (13% increase; 95% CI, 9%-17%) and decreased to 84% after the intervention The percentage of charges incurred for laboratory tests indicated and treatment increased from 44% at baseline to 81% during the intervention phase (37% increase; "95% CI, 22%-52%) and decreased to 36% after the intervention. The average total charges per patient were $460, $384, and $373 in each phase, respectively. Conclusions. â€”The use of a system Clinical guideline software for the management of patients with occupational exposure to body fluids improved documentation, guideline compliance, and percentage of charges spent on indicated activities, while decreasing overall charges. base when the computer system was removed.

title: Implementation of research results in practice using clinical opinion leaders: barriers and lessons learned
abstract: BACKGROUND: An opinion leader-driven intervention to improve practice guideline-based medication management for patients with schizophrenia was tested in four Department of Veterans Affairs health care facilities. The concept of using opinion leaders as disseminators of research evidence and internal agents of change has been widely publicized. PROJECT OVERVIEW: Each intervention site received an intensive multi-component intervention over the course of one year. Evaluation of the project process included brief ongoing surveys of clinicians' attitudes and behaviors, records of opinion leader conference calls, and interviews with opinion leaders toward the end of the implementation period. BARRIERS OR PROBLEMS AND POTENTIAL SOLUTIONS: Several barriers or problems emerged: (1) clinicians do not always agree on who is an opinion leader; some sites may not have a thought leader; (2) some sites had poorly developed formal and informal social development. networks between doctors; (3) a focus on clinicians only as agents of change;" and (4) how much direction should be given to opinion leaders on how to influence attitudes and behaviors? DISCUSSION: Four main problems encountered during the project offer possible solutions to address them.

title: NHS information technology program implementation: a qualitative study of progress in acute trusts
abstract: OBJECTIVES To describe the progress and perceived challenges in implementing the NHS information and technology (IT) program in England. DESIGN Case studies and in-depth interviews, with themes identified using a framework developed from grounded theory. We interviewed staff who had been interviewed 18 months earlier or new staff in the same positions. SETTING Four NHS acute care hospital trusts in England. PARTICIPANTS Medical and Senior Trust Managers, including CEOs, IT Directors, Medical Directors and Nursing Directors. RESULTS Interviewees strongly supported the goals of the program, but had several serious concerns. As before, implementation is hampered by local funding shortfalls, delays in implementing program-compliant patient management systems, and poor communication between Connecting for Health (the agency responsible for the program) and local administrators. . New problems arose. Local administrators are unable to prioritize program implementation due to competing financial priorities and program uncertainties. They perceive an increasing risk to patient safety associated with delays and loss of integration of program components, and are unhappy with Choose and Book (electronic booking for referrals from primary care). CONCLUSIONS We recommend that the program establish realistic schedules for individual trusts and advise managers on interim IT systems they must purchase due to delays beyond their control. Advice must take into account the need for trusts to ensure long-term compatibility with the program and value for money. Trusts need assistance in prioritizing IT modernization, for example, including program implementation in the performance management framework. Even with Connecting for Health taking a different approach of setting core standards with local implementation, these issues will still need to be addressed. Lessons learned in the NHS are of greater relevance as health systems, such as in France and Australia, seek to harness the potential of large-scale IT modernisation.

title: Implications of stroke prevention trials: managing global risk
abstract: Clinical trials have shown that the risk of cardiovascular events can be reduced in stroke patients by lowering blood pressure (BP) and statin therapy, regardless of the presence of specific risk factors. These results suggest an alternative approach to secondary stroke prevention, focused more on global risk than on detection and modification of individual categorical risk factors, such as hypertension, dyslipidemia, and diabetes mellitus. A risk-based approach is warranted because stroke patients are at high risk for several cardiovascular events, not just stroke, and because physiological risk factors such as BP demonstrate a continuous or log-linear relationship with risk. cardiovascular. Essential to the implementation of such an approach is the development of suitable risk stratification models for stroke patients. However, based on the limited evidence available, it appears that most patients who experience an ischemic stroke or TIA are at high long-term absolute risk of a subsequent cardiovascular event and should be treated with all available strategies for risk reduction. of the risk.

title: Importance of the characteristics and modalities of physical activity and exercise in defining cardiovascular health benefits in the general population: EACPR recommendations (Part I)
abstract: In recent decades, increasing evidence has accumulated that physical activity (PA) and exercise interventions are essential components in the primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease. However, it is less clear if and what type of PA and exercise intervention (aerobic exercise, dynamic resistance exercise, or both) or exercise characteristic (frequency, intensity, time or duration, and volume) would produce more health benefits. cardio . This document, as the first in a series of three, will make specific recommendations about the importance of these characteristics for cardiovascular health in the general population. The guidance provided in this series of documents is intended for physicians, health professionals, physical therapists, physiotherapists and exercise physiologists, politicians, public health policy makers and individual members of the public. Based on past and current literature, recommendations from the European Association for Cardiovascular Prevention and Rehabilitation are formulated regarding the type, volume, and intensity of physical activity and exercise.

title: Better asthma outcomes using a coordinated care approach in a large medical group.
abstract: The objective of this study was to review the development of a multidisciplinary asthma disease management program in a large medical group in an urban area and to assess the impact of the program on care processes and health care utilization for adults and children. with asthma.
