The disease management intervention included development of a patient registry, a systematic approach to assessing asthma control using the Asthma Therapy Assessment Questionnaire (ATAQ), case management, and physician education. An administrative database was used to examine hospital admissions and emergency department (ED) visits. A medical record audit was conducted to examine recorded adherence to asthma documentation guidelines and practices. The study reference population included 3486 adults and children with asthma. The ATAQ suggested that, at the start of the study, control problems were common, with 34% of adults surveyed missing work due to asthma. ATAQ also revealed several areas for improving care. For example, only 20% of adult respondents reported having a written treatment plan. File review and administrative complaint analysis showed that the program had beneficial results in several areas. Medical history documentation improved for asthma diagnosis (83.3% vs. 98.6%"; p < 0.001) and patient education (15.7% vs. 26.1%;" p < 0.001 ). No improvements were seen in documentation of peak flow ownership/use, smoking cessation advice, or influenza vaccination. Asthma-related emergency room visits decreased from 148 per 1,000 to 88 per 1,000 (p < 0.001), and asthma-related hospitalizations decreased from 81 per 1,000 to 37 per 1,000 (p < 0.001). The results suggest that this program was associated with a marked reduction in hospitalization rates and ED use for asthma, as well as significant improvement in several essential care processes.

title: Better clinical performance and teamwork of pediatric interprofessional resuscitation teams with a simulation-based educational intervention
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To measure the effect of a 1-day team training course for pediatric interprofessional resuscitation team members on adherence to pediatric advanced life support guidelines, team efficiency, and teamwork in a simulated clinical setting. DESIGN: Multicenter prospective intervention study. SETTING: Four tertiary care pediatric hospitals in Canada from June 2011 to January 2015. SUBJECTS: Interprofessional pediatric resuscitation teams including resident physicians, ICU nurse practitioners, registered nurses, and registered respiratory therapists (n = 300"; 51 teams INTERVENTIONS: A 1-day simulation-based team training course was provided, including an interactive lecture, group discussions, and four simulated resuscitation scenarios, each followed by a briefing. was conducted prior to any team training.The end-of-day (POST) scenario was the same scenario, with a slightly modified patient history.All scenarios included standardized distractors designed to elicit and challenge specific teamwork behaviors. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN OUTCOMES: The primary outcome measure was change (before and after training). ) in compliance with Pediatric Advanced Life Support guidelines, as measured by the Clinical Performance Tool. The measures were as follows: 1) change in start times of chest compressions and defibrillation and 2) teamwork performance, measured by the Clinical Teamwork Scale. The correlation between Clinical Performance Tool and Clinical Teamwork Scale scores was also analyzed. Teams significantly improved Clinical Performance Tool scores (67.3-79.6%; p < 0.0001), time to start of chest compressions (60.8-27.1 s; p < 0 .0001), time to defibrillation (164.8-122.0 s; p < 0.0001) and Clinical Teamwork Scale scores (56.0-71.8%; p < 0.0001 ). A positive correlation was found between the Clinical Performance Tool and the Clinical Teamwork Scale (R = 0.281, p < 0.0001). CONCLUSIONS: Participation in a simulation-based team-building educational intervention significantly improved surrogate measures of clinical performance, time to start of key clinical activities. tasks and teamwork during simulated pediatric resuscitation A positive correlation between clinical performance and teamwork suggests that effective teamwork improves the clinical performance of resuscitation teams.

title: Improving the delivery of cardiovascular care (IDOCC) through facilitating disclosure: study protocol and implementation details of a cluster randomized controlled trial in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is a need to find innovative approaches to translate best practices for chronic disease care into daily practical routines of primary care. Primary care plays a crucial role in the prevention and treatment of cardiovascular diseases. However, there is a substantive care gap and there are many challenges in implementing evidence-based care. The Improving the Delivery of Cardiovascular Care (IDOCC) project is a pragmatic trial designed to improve the delivery of evidence-based care for the prevention and treatment of cardiovascular disease in primary care practices by facilitating the extension of practice. METHODS: The IDOCC project is a staggered-cluster randomized control trial in which practice extension facilitators work with primary care practices to improve prevention and management of cardiovascular disease for patients at increased risk. Primary care practices in a large health region in eastern Ontario, Canada, were eligible to participate. The intervention consists of regular monthly meetings with the scope of practice facilitator for a period of one to two years. Beginning with audit and feedback, consensus building and goal setting, the practices are supported in changing practice behavior by incorporating elements of the chronic care model. These elements include (a) evidence-based decision support for providers, (b) delivery system redesign for practices, (c) improved self-management support tools provided to practices to help them engage patients, and (d) increased community resource linkages for practices to improve patient referral. The primary outcome is a composite score measured at the patient level to represent each practice's compliance with evidence-based guidelines for cardiovascular care. A qualitative analysis of practice extension facilitators' written narratives about their ongoing practice interactions will be conducted. These textual analyzes will add more information to understand the critical factors affecting project implementation. DISCUSSION: This pragmatic, staggered, randomized controlled trial, with both quantitative and process evaluations, demonstrates innovative methods for implementing large-scale quality improvements and evidence-based approaches to care delivery. This is the first Canadian study to examine the impact of a large-scale, multifaceted cardiovascular quality improvement program in primary care. It is anticipated that through the IDOCC evaluation, we will demonstrate an effective, practical and sustainable means of improving the cardiovascular health of patients across Canada. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov: NCT00574808.

title: Improved use of perioperative antibiotics and reduction of surgical wound infections through the use of computerized decision analysis.
abstract: prospective study was conducted over a two-year period to determine whether computer-generated reminders of perioperative antibiotic use could improve prescribing habits and reduce postoperative wound infections. During the first year, baseline patterns of antibiotic use and postoperative infection rates were established. During the second year, computer-generated reminders of perioperative antibiotic use were placed in the patient's chart prior to surgery, and patterns of antibiotic use and postoperative wound infections were monitored. Hospitalized patients who underwent non-emergency surgery from June to November 1985 (3263 patients) and from June to November 1986 (3568) were monitored for indications for perioperative antibiotic use, timing of antibiotic use and postoperative infectious complications. Perioperative antibiotic use was considered advisable in 1,621 (50%) patients in the 1985 sample and 1,830 (51%) patients in the 1986 sample. Among these patients, antibiotics were administered within two hours before incision surgery in 638 (40%) of the 1985 sample and 1,070 (58%) of the 1986 sample (p<0.001). Overall, postoperative wound infections were detected in 28 (1.8%) of 1621 patients in 1985 compared to 16 (0.9%) of 1830 such patients in 1986 (p<0.03). We conclude that computer-generated reminders of perioperative antibiotic use improved prescribing habits with a concomitant decrease in postoperative wound infections.

title: Improved therapeutic monitoring with various interventions: a randomized trial.
abstract: Background Medication errors are often related to failure to properly select medications or adjust laboratory parameters. Differences between guideline recommendations and the actual frequency of therapeutic laboratory monitoring are substantial. This study evaluated interventions to improve laboratory control at the start of drug therapy. Methods This cluster-randomized trial compared 3 interventions with usual care for 10 medications in 15 primary care clinics in a health maintenance organization with an electronic medical record system. Eligible patients, identified from electronic databases, had not received recommended laboratory monitoring within 5 days of re-dispensing a study drug. The interventions were an electronic medical record reminder for the prescribing health professional, an automated voice message for the patient, and a pharmacy team to communicate with the patient. The primary outcome was completion of all recommended reference laboratory controls. Results A total of 961 patients participated in the study. At 25 days, 95 (48.5%) of 196 patients in the electronic medical record reminder group, 177 (66.3%) of 267 in the automated voice message group, 214 (82.0%) of 261 in the pharmacy team outreach group and 53 (22.4%) of 237 in the usual care group had completed all recommended baseline laboratory checks (p < 0.001). After adjustments, the hazard ratios for completing laboratory monitoring compared with usual care were 2.5 (95% confidence interval, 1.8-3.5) for electronic medical record recall, 4.1 (95% confidence interval, 3.0-5.6) for automated voice message and 6.7 (95% confidence interval, 4.9-9.0) for team reach pharmacy. Conclusions All 3 interventions were effective in increasing laboratory monitoring when starting new medications in primary care. More work is needed to determine whether these interventions improve patient outcomes.

title: Improving antibiotic prescribing in ambulatory care: a cluster randomized intervention study using a sentinel surveillance network of physicians.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To assess the effectiveness of guideline implementation, together with individual feedback, on the antibiotic prescribing behavior of primary care physicians in Switzerland. METHODS: One hundred and forty general practices from a representative Swiss sentinel network of primary care physicians participated in this prospective cluster-randomized intervention study. The intervention consisted of providing guidelines on the treatment of uncomplicated respiratory tract infections (RTIs) and lower urinary tract infections (UTIs), along with regular and sustained feedback on individual antibiotic prescribing behavior over 2 years. The main objectives were: (i) to increase the percentage of penicillin prescriptions for all antibiotic-treated RTIs"; (ii) to increase the percentage of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole prescriptions for all antibiotic-treated minor uncomplicated UTIs; (iii) decrease the percentage of quinolone prescriptions for all cases of exacerbated COPD (eCOPD) treated with antibiotics;" and (iv) decrease the proportion of sinusitis and other upper RTIs treated with antibiotics. The study was registered with ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT01358916). RESULTS: Although the percentage of antibiotics prescribed for sinusitis or other higher RTIs and the percentage of quinolones prescribed for COPD did not differ between the intervention and control groups, there was a significant increase in the percentage of penicillin prescriptions for all ITRs treated. with antibiotics [57% vs. 49%, OR=1.42 (95% CI: 1.08-1.89), P=0.01] and in the percentage of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole prescriptions for all UTIs uncomplicated discharges treated with antibiotics [35% vs. 19%, OR=2.16 (95% CI 1.19-3.91), P=0.01] in the intervention group. CONCLUSIONS: In our setting, implementation of the guidelines, together with sustained individual feedback, was not able to reduce the proportion of sinusitis and other upper RTIs treated with antibiotics, but increased the use of recommended antibiotics for RTIs and UTIs. , as defined by the guidelines.

title: Improving management of hypertension through structured medical education and feedback system: cluster randomized trial
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Our objective was to assess whether hypertension management with a structured medical information program and feedback system leads to better blood pressure (BP) control and cardiovascular outcomes. METHODS: Cluster-randomized (3:1), open-label, monitored, multicenter trial in Germany. Primary care physicians in the information group (IG) received detailed training on hypertension guidelines, feedback on target level achievement, and a reminder to intensify treatment after each patient visit, while the observation/ control (CG) did not receive any information. such measures. A mixed model of three levels was developed. Time-independent level differences between groups, group-independent changes, and non-parallel group-specific changes over time were tested. RESULTS: A total of 15,041 (78.1%) hypertensive patients were in the IG and 4,213 (21.9%) in the CG. At one year of follow-up, 82.9% of the patients in the IG and 81.5% in the CG remained in the study. The guideline-oriented BP goal was achieved by 56.8% in the IG and 52.5% in the CG (+4.3%, P = 0.03), while the individual BP goal was reached by 57.0% in the IG and 51% in the CG (P = NS). BP control in the IG was achieved 2 months earlier on average. Clinical inertia, defined as no medication changes despite lack of BP control, occurred significantly less frequently in the IG group. Cardiovascular outcomes at one year did not differ between groups. CONCLUSION: Systematic information delivery in connection with a feedback system reduces clinical inertia and improves adherence to guidelines. Although compared to previous studies, the rates of hypertension control obtained are higher, there is still considerable room for improvement.

title: Improvement of intraoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in prolonged cardiac surgery through automated alerts in the operating room
abstract: Objective: To evaluate the impact of an automated intraoperative alert to redose prophylactic antibiotics in prolonged cardiac operations. Design: Randomized, controlled, evaluator-blinded trial. Setting: Hospital attached to the University. Patients: Patients undergoing cardiac surgery lasting more than 4 hours after preoperative administration of cefazolin, unless they were receiving therapeutic antibiotics at the time of surgery. Intervention: Randomization to an audible and visual reminder on the operating room computer console at 225 minutes after administration of preoperative antibiotics (reminder group, n = 137) or control (n = 136). After another 30 minutes, the circulating nurse was asked to indicate whether a follow-up dose of antibiotics had been given. Results: Intraoperative redosing was significantly more frequent in the reminder group (93 of 137; 68%) than in the control group (55 of 136; 40%) (adjusted odds ratio, 3.31; 95% confidence interval). %, 1.97 to 5.56, p < 0.0001) The impact of the reminder was even greater compared to the 6 months prior to the study period (129 of 480, 27%, p < 0.001), which suggests some side effect in the control group decreased for 19 of 44 patients in the reminder group without redosing The surgical site infection rate in the reminder group (5 of 137; 4%) was similar to that in the control group ( 8 of 136, 6%, P = 0.42), but significantly less than in the pre-study period (48 of 480, 10%, P = 0.02).Conclusion: The use of an automatic reminder system in the operating room improved compliance with guidelines on perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis.

title: Improving adherence to hypertension medication prescription guidelines: a cluster-randomized controlled trial of general versus patient-specific recommendations.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine whether an intervention that focuses the physician's attention on the choice of drugs for the treatment of hypertension improves concordance between drug regimens and guidelines. STUDY DESIGN: Cluster randomized controlled trial comparing an individualized intervention with implementation of a general guideline in geographically diverse primary care clinics of a university-affiliated Department of Veterans Affairs health system. METHODS: Thirty-six physicians and nurse practitioners participated (16 in the general group and 20 in the individualized group), with findings based on 4500 hypertensive patients. Implementation of general guidance for all physicians, including education on guideline-based medication recommendations and goals for adequate blood pressure control, was compared with the addition of an individualized printed notice sent to physicians. physicians at each patient visit, indicating whether or not the patient's antihypertensive medication is available. the regimen was consistent with the guidelines. We measured the change from baseline to endpoint in the proportion of physicians' patients whose drug therapy was consistent with guidelines. RESULTS: The individualized intervention resulted in an improvement in guideline agreement that was more than double that observed for the overall intervention (10.9% vs. 3.8%, t = 2.796, P = 0.008). Bootstrap analysis showed that being in the individualized group increased the odds of agreement 1.5-fold (P = 0.025). The proportion of patients with adequate blood pressure control increased within each study group";" however, the difference between groups was not significant. CONCLUSION: Individualized advice on drug therapy for hypertension given to the physician at each patient visit was more effective in changing the physician's prescribing behavior than implementation of general guidance.

title: Improving Adherence to Therapy and Clinical Outcomes While Containing Costs: Opportunities from Increased Use of Generic Drugs: Best Practice Advice from the Clinical Guidelines Committee of the American College of Physicians
abstract: Description: The discrepancy between health care spending and outcomes achieved in the United States has fueled efforts to identify and address situations in which unnecessarily expensive therapies are used when less expensive and equally effective options are available. The underuse of generic drugs is an important example. Methods: A literature review was conducted to answer 5 questions about generic drugs: 1) How often are brand name drugs used when a generic version is available? 2) How does the use of generic drugs influence adherence? 3) What is the evidence that brand and generic drugs have similar clinical effects? 4) What are the barriers to increasing the use of generic drugs? 5) What strategies can be used to promote cost savings through increased use of generic drugs? This article was reviewed and approved by the Clinical Guidelines Committee of the American College of Physicians. Best practice advice: Physicians should prescribe generic drugs, if possible, instead of more expensive brand-name drugs.

title: Improving antibiotic prescribing for adults with community-acquired pneumonia: does a computerized decision support system achieve more than just academic details? - A time series analysis
abstract: BACKGROUND: The ideal method for promoting the acceptance of clinical guidelines in hospitals is not known. Various strategies have been suggested. This study evaluates the impact of academic details and a computerized decision support system (CDSS) on physicians' prescribing behavior for patients with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). METHODS: The management of all patients who attended the emergency department during three successive periods of time was evaluated";" the baseline periods, academic detail and CDSS. The rate of empiric antibiotic prescriptions consistent with recommendations was studied over time by comparing pre- and post-periods and using interrupted time series analysis. RESULTS: The odds ratio for concordant therapy at the academic detail period, after adjustment for age, disease severity, and suspected aspiration, compared to the baseline period was OR = 2.79 [1.88, 4.14], p < 0.01, and for the computerized decision support period compared to the academic detail period was OR = 1.99 [1.07, 3.69], p = 0.02. An improvement in appropriateness of antibiotic prescribing was demonstrated during the first few months of the computerized decision support period, which was greater than expected with time and academic details alone, based on predictions from a binary logistic model. CONCLUSION: Implementation of a computerized decision support system was associated with an early improvement in antibiotic prescribing practices that was greater than the changes seen with academic details. The sustainability of this intervention requires further evaluation.

title: Improving the use of antibiotics among hospitalists: a pilot project of academic detail with a public health approach
abstract: BACKGROUND: Inappropriate use of antibiotics is a major clinical problem and public health concern. We developed and implemented a pilot detailed academic hospitalist-delivered intervention to improve inpatient antibiotic prescribing patterns. OBJECTIVE: To improve antibiotic prescription patterns in the hospital service of an academic medical center. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: Hospital physicians were recruited to participate in this pre- and post-intervention pilot study at Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center (JHBMC). Public health principles to create a conceptual framework based on behavior change theory were used in the development of the intervention. METHODS: The antibiotic prescribing patterns of 17 hospital physicians were retrospectively reviewed. Antimicrobial prescriptions were classified as appropriate, effective but inappropriate, or inappropriate. A profile was created for each hospitalist and a detailed academic intervention session was scheduled. The session reviewed inappropriate prescribing practices as well as current practice guidelines. After the detailed meeting, the hospitalists' prescribing patterns were followed prospectively. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: The main outcome measures were the proportions of antibiotics prescribed inappropriately before the intervention, during the detailed period and after the intervention. RESULTS: Seventeen hospitalist physicians who participated in the study. A total of 247 pre-intervention prescriptions and 129 post-intervention prescriptions were reviewed. Before academic details, 43% (95% CI 37-49%) of prescriptions were appropriate and 57% (95% CI 51-63%) were inappropriate. After the intervention, 74% (95% CI 65%-81%) of the prescriptions were appropriate and 26% (95% CI 19%-35%) inappropriate";" p < 0.0001. CONCLUSIONS: A carefully planned and methodically executed intervention can result in behavior change, even among busy hospitalists. The academic detail intervention, which included a practice-based learning component, improved hospitalists' antibiotic prescribing practices at JHBMC.

title: Improving Asthma Care in Emergency Departments: Results of a Multihospital Collaborative Quality Initiative in Rural Western North Carolina
abstract: BACKGROUND: In North Carolina, nearly a quarter of people with asthma visit an emergency department (ED) or urgent care center at least once a year due to an exacerbation of asthma symptoms. The Emergency Department Asthma Program was a quality improvement initiative designed to better understand the patient population using the emergency department for asthma care in rural western North Carolina and to demonstrate whether emergency services in small hospitals could, through the implementation of the National Program for Education and Prevention of Asthma. guidelines, improve asthma care, and reduce subsequent asthma-related emergency department visits. METHODS: Eight hospitals in western North Carolina participated in the project, which lasted from November 2003 to December 2007. The intervention consisted of a series of individual and structured continuing medical education events for physicians and physicians. emergency personnel. In addition, patients presenting to emergency departments for asthma-related problems were selected to receive a brief patient questionnaire to determine their basic understanding of asthma and barriers to asthma care; to undergo asthma staging by the treating physician; to receive focused bedside asthma education by a respiratory therapist and finally, at the discretion of the treating physician, to receive a free package of asthma medications, including beta-agonist rescue therapy and corticosteroid therapy administered through a metered-dose inhaler, prior to discharge. month-long project, a total of 1,739 patients presented to participating EDs for 2,481 asthma-related episodes of care;" in 11% of these visits, patients received the intervention, with nearly 100 emergency physicians referring patients to the program Most patients using the ED for asthma treatment were considered to have milder stages and nearly half were uninsured or covered by Medicaid Only 20% of visits identified a primary care physician or clinic Patient intervention did not appear to decrease the rate of subsequent visits for asthma-related symptoms at 30 and 60 days LIMITATIONS: Selection bias is likely, as patients enrolled in the study were more likely than patients in the target sample to be adults and to be insured.Because we did not measure the attendance of emergency personnel at sessions. education or their knowledge and attitudes about asthma care before and after the educational program, we cannot draw conclusions about the effectiveness of the program in changing their knowledge, attitudes, or behavior. CONCLUSIONS: Many patients who use the emergency department for care seem to have mild and intermittent asthma and do not identify a regular source of primary care. Efforts to improve asthma care throughout the community and to reduce preventable exacerbations should include care provided in emergency departments, as this may be the only source of asthma care for many patients with asthma. The project demonstrated that collaborative regional performance improvement efforts in EDs are possible, but that there are many barriers to this approach.

title: Improving asthma-related health outcomes among low-income, multiethnic, and school-age children: results of a demonstration project that combined continuous quality improvement and community health worker strategies
abstract: OBJECTIVE. The purpose of this paper was to improve asthma-related health outcomes in an ethnically and geographically disparate population of economically disadvantaged school-age children by using a team-based approach utilizing continuous quality improvement and health workers. community. PATIENTS AND METHODS. A demonstration project was carried out with 7 community clinics treating _x0001_3000 children with asthma aged 5-18 years. The general asthma clinic population was assessed for changes in process of care through randomized cross-sectional chart reviews at baseline and 24 months (N 560). A subgroup of patients with moderate or severe persistent asthma or poorly controlled asthma (N 405) was followed longitudinally for specific asthma-related clinical outcomes, satisfaction with care, and confidence in asthma management by family interview at baseline and at 12 months. or 24 months. Patient-centered and process-of-care outcomes included patient/parent assessment of quality of care and confidence in self-management, review of asthma action plan, and documentation of quality of care indicators. guideline-based care. Direct clinical outcomes included daytime and nighttime symptoms, rescue medication use, emergency department and acute care visits, hospitalizations, and missed school days. The degree of adherence to the intervention model of each clinic was evaluated and classified to examine the correlation between adherence to the model and the results.

title: Improve blood pressure control through provider education, provider alerts, and patient education
abstract: Background: Inadequate blood pressure control is a persistent gap in quality of care. Objective: To evaluate provider and patient interventions to improve blood pressure control. Design: Controlled, randomized cluster trial. Setting: 2 hospital clinics and 8 community clinics in the Veterans Affairs Tennessee Valley Health System. PATIENTS: 1,341 veterans with essential hypertension cared for by 182 providers. Eligible patients had 2 or more blood pressure measurements greater than 140/90 mm Hg in a 6-month period and were taking a single antihypertensive agent. Intervention: Providers caring for eligible patients were randomly assigned to receive an email containing a web link to the Seventh Report of the Joint National Committee on the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment of High Blood Pressure (JNC 7) guidelines. ). (provider education)"; provider education and a patient-specific computerized hypertension alert (provider education and alert); o provider education, hypertension alert and patient education, in which patients were sent a letter advocating medication adherence, lifestyle modification, and discussions with providers (patient education) Measurements: Proportion of patients with systolic blood pressure less than 140 mm Hg at 6 months, escalation of antihypertensive medication Outcomes: The Baseline mean arterial pressure was 157/83 mm Hg with no difference between groups (P = 0.105).Six-month follow-up data were available for 975 patients (73%).Provider patients who were randomly assigned to provider education had better blood pressure control (138/75 mm Hg) than those in the provider education and alert or provider education only groups ( 146/76 mm Hg and 145/78 mm Hg, respectively). More patients in the patient education group had a systolic blood pressure of 140 mm Hg or less compared with those in the provider education or provider education and alert groups (adjusted relative risk for the patient education group compared with the provider education group alone, 1.31 [95% CI, 1.06 to 1.62]; P = 0.012). Limitations: Follow-up blood pressure measurements were missing in 27% of study patients. The study was unable to detect a mechanism by which patient education improved blood pressure control. Conclusions: A multifactorial intervention that included patient education improved blood pressure control compared with provider education alone.

title: Improving blood pressure control through provider education, provider alerts, and patient education: a cluster randomized trial.
abstract: Background: Inadequate blood pressure control is a persistent gap in quality of care. Objective: To evaluate provider and patient interventions to improve blood pressure control. Design: Controlled, randomized cluster trial. Setting: 2 hospital clinics and 8 community clinics in the Veterans Affairs Tennessee Valley Health System. PATIENTS: 1,341 veterans with essential hypertension cared for by 182 providers. Eligible patients had 2 or more blood pressure measurements greater than 140/90 mm Hg in a 6-month period and were taking a single antihypertensive agent. Intervention: Providers caring for eligible patients were randomly assigned to receive an email containing a web link to the Seventh Report of the Joint National Committee on the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment of High Blood Pressure (JNC 7) guidelines. ). (provider education)"; provider education and a patient-specific computerized hypertension alert (provider education and alert); o provider education, hypertension alert and patient education, in which patients were sent a letter advocating medication adherence, lifestyle modification, and discussions with providers (patient education) Measurements: Proportion of patients with systolic blood pressure less than 140 mm Hg at 6 months, escalation of antihypertensive medication Outcomes: The Baseline mean arterial pressure was 157/83 mm Hg with no difference between groups (P = 0.105).Six-month follow-up data were available for 975 patients (73%).Provider patients who were randomly assigned to provider education had better blood pressure control (138/75 mm Hg) than those in the provider education and alert or provider education only groups ( 146/76 mm Hg and 145/78 mm Hg, respectively). More patients in the patient education group had a systolic blood pressure of 140 mm Hg or less compared with those in the provider education or provider education and alert groups (adjusted relative risk for the patient education group compared with the provider education group alone, 1.31 [95% CI, 1.06 to 1.62]; P = 0.012). Limitations: Follow-up blood pressure measurements were missing in 27% of study patients. The study was unable to detect a mechanism by which patient education improved blood pressure control. Conclusions: A multifactorial intervention that included patient education improved blood pressure control compared with provider education alone.

title: Improving cardiovascular risk management: a randomized controlled trial on the effect of a decision support tool for patients and physicians
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is suboptimal adherence of general practitioners (GPs) and patients to interventions to reduce cardiovascular risk. General practitioners find it difficult to assimilate multiple risk factors into an accurate assessment of cardiovascular risk. In addition, it has been difficult to communicate cardiovascular risk to patients. OBJECTIVES: To improve the primary prevention of cardiovascular diseases (CVD) in primary care by improving patient participation in the use of a decision support tool. DESIGN: Randomized cluster trial. METHODS: Thirty-four GPs enrolled patients (40-75 years) without CVD. In a 4-hour small group interactive training session, intervention group GPs were trained in the use of the cardiovascular risk guidelines and a decision support tool. The control group received educational materials on the paper guidelines. Physicians' clinical performance and patients' self-reported risk perception and lifestyles were measured at baseline and after 6 months. RESULTS: Thirty-four physicians recorded 490 consultations, 276 in the intervention and 214 in the control group. After 6 months, no significant effect of the intervention on doctors' performance or patients' perception of risk was found. There was only an effect on self-reported lifestyle, as more men in the intervention group than in the control group increased their physical activity (odds ratio 3.8, 95% confidence interval 1.7-8.7). CONCLUSION: Interactive training in small groups of 4 h did not guarantee the correct application of the decision support tool and, as such, did not improve the performance of the doctors or correct the risk perception of the patients. The positive effect on physical activity warrants further research on patient participation.

title: Improving care for minority children with asthma: professional education in public health clinics
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Recent studies have shown that lack of ongoing primary care for asthma is associated with higher levels of morbidity in low-income minority children. Although effective preventive therapy exists, many African American and Latino children receive episodic asthma treatment that does not follow current guidelines of care. To see if access, continuity, and quality of care could be improved at pediatric clinics serving low-income children in New York City, we trained clinic staff from the New York City Office of Children's Health of New York to provide ongoing preventive care for asthma. METHODS: We evaluated the impact of the intervention over a 2-year period in a controlled study of 22 clinics. Training for intervention clinic staff was based on National Asthma Prevention and Education Program guidelines for asthma diagnosis and management, and included screening to identify new cases and health education to improve family management . The intervention included strong administrative support from the Office of Child Health to promote staff behavior change. We hypothesized that after the intervention, clinics receiving the intervention, compared to control clinics, would have a greater number of children with asthma receiving ongoing care at the clinics and greater staff use of new treatment methods. pharmacological and educational. RESULTS: At both the first and second year of follow-up, intervention clinics had greater positive changes than control clinics on measures of access, continuity, and quality of care. For second-year follow-up data, these include: for access, a higher rate of new patients with asthma (40/1,000 vs. 16/1,000"; P < 0.01); for continuation, a higher percentage of patients with asthma than return for treatment 2 years in a row (42% vs 12%; P < 0.001) and higher annual frequency of scheduled asthma visits per patient (1.85 vs 0.88; P < 0.001), and by quality, higher percentage of patients receiving inhaled beta agonists (52% vs. 15%; P < .001) and inhaled anti-inflammatory medications (25% vs. 2%; P < .001), and higher percentages of parents reporting receiving patient education about 12 subjects of the Office of Child Health physicians (71% vs. 58%; p < 0.01) and nurses (61% vs. 44%; p < 0.05).CONCLUSION: We conclude that The intervention substantially increased the ability of Office of Children's Health staff to identify children with asthma, engage them in to ongoing care and provide them with advanced asthma care.

title: Improving Chronic Disease Prevention and Screening in Primary Care: Results from the BETTER Pragmatic Cluster Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Primary care provides most of the evidence-based chronic disease screening and prevention services offered by the health system. However, a gap remains between recommended preventive services and actual practice. This trial (the BETTER trial) aimed to improve preventive care for heart disease, diabetes, colorectal, breast, and cervical cancer, and relevant lifestyle factors through an established practice facilitation intervention in the primary care. METHODS: Two-way pragmatic factorial cluster RCT with the practices of primary care physicians as the unit of allocation and individual patients as the unit of analysis. The setting was the urban practices of the Primary Care Team in two Canadian provinces. Eight Primary Care Team practices were randomly assigned to receive either practice-level intervention or waiting list control";" Four physicians from each team (32 physicians) were randomly assigned to receive either the patient-level intervention or the waiting list control. Patients randomly selected from physician lists were stratified into two groups: 1) general mental illness and 2) moderate mental illness. Interventions included a personalized, evidence-based, multifaceted practice-level intervention with a practice facilitator, and a patient-level intervention involving a one-hour visit with a prevention professional where patients received a "prescription prevention " personalized. The primary outcome was a composite summary quality index of 28 evidence-based chronic disease detection and prevention actions with predefined targets, expressed as the proportion of actions eligible at baseline that were met at follow-up. A cost-effectiveness analysis was performed. RESULTS: 789 of 1260 (63%) eligible patients participated. On average, patients were eligible for 8.96 (SD 3.2) shares at baseline. In adjusted analysis, control patients met 23.1% (95% CI: 19.2% to 27.1%) of target actions, compared to 28.5% (95% CI %: 20.9% to 36.0%) who received the intervention at the practice level, 55.6% (95% CI: 49.0% to 62.1%) who received the intervention at the practice level patient, and 58.9% (95% CI: 54.7% to 63.1%) who received practice- and patient-level interventions (patient-level intervention versus control, P < 0.001). The benefit of the patient-level intervention was seen in both strata. The extra cost of the intervention was $26.43 CAN (95% CI: $16 to $44) per additional action completed. CONCLUSIONS: A Prevention Practitioner can improve the implementation of clinically important prevention and detection of chronic diseases in a cost-effective manner.

title: Improve the clinical transfer between the intensive care unit and the professionals of the general ward upon discharge from the intensive care unit.
abstract: Purpose To systematically review and evaluate the effectiveness of interventions to improve the safety and efficiency of patient handover between intensive care unit (ICU) and general ward healthcare professionals at ICU discharge. Methods We searched PubMed, CINAHL, PsycINFO, EMBASE, Web of Science, and the Cochrane Library for intervention studies aiming to improve clinical handover between ICU and general healthcare professionals that had been published up to June 2013. inclusive. Article inclusion and data analysis were prespecified and aligned with the recommendations outlined in the PRISMA guideline. Two reviewers independently extracted data (study purpose, setting, population, sampling method, sample size, intervention characteristics, outcome, and implementation activities) and assessed the quality of included studies. Results Of the 6591 citations initially extracted from the six databases, 11 studies were included in this review. Of these, six (55%) reported statistically significant effects. Effective interventions included nurse liaisons to improve communication and coordination of care, and forms to facilitate timely, complete, and accurate handover information. Effective interventions resulted in better continuity of care (eg reduced delay in discharge) and reduced adverse events. Inconsistent effects were seen for use of care, namely reduced length of stay versus increased readmissions to higher care. No statistically significant effects were found in reducing mortality. The overall methodological quality of the 11 studies reviewed was relatively low, with a mean score of 4.5 out of 11 points. Conclusions This review shows that liaison nurses and handover forms are promising interventions to improve the quality of patient handover between the ICU and the general ward. Stronger evidence is needed on the effectiveness of interventions aimed at improving ICU handover and supportive implementation strategies.

title: Improving immunization compliance in the elderly: results of a randomized cohort study.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To compare three approaches to improve adherence to influenza and pneumococcal vaccination in elderly patients. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial using three parallel group practices in an urban public university hospital. SETTING: Public university hospital. SUBJECTS: All patients 65 years of age and older (n = 1202) cared for by resident physicians (n = 66) who attended three outpatient medical practices from October 1, 1989, to March 31, 1990. INTERVENTIONS: All three provider groups received intensive education on immunization standards. The control group received no further intervention. Staff in the second group provided patient education at their visits. In the third group, the prevention team, a flowchart was used, patient education was offered, and staff tasks were redefined to facilitate compliance";" for vaccinations, for example, nurses could vaccinate independently of the MD initiative. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: Medical records of 1,202 patients seen, including 756 patients seen during the 1988-89 and 1989-90 influenza seasons, were reviewed to determine documented offering and receipt of vaccines. During the intervention period (1989-1990), influenza vaccines were offered much more frequently to patients in the prevention team (68.3%) than to patients in the patient education groups (50.4 %) or control (47.6%) (P = 0.006). even after adjusting for patients' prior vaccination status, age, gender, race, and high-risk comorbidity, and physician training level. Similarly, pneumococcal vaccination was offered more frequently to previously unvaccinated prevention team patients (28.3%) than to patients in the patient education group (6.5%) or control group (5.4%). (p = 0.001), even after adjusting for factors using multivariate analysis. Compliance rates did not differ between patient education and control subjects for either vaccine. Preintervention physician surveys documented higher perceived than actual compliance for both vaccines, with 89.0% and 52.8% of physicians believing they were compliant with influenza and pneumococcal vaccination guidelines, respectively . CONCLUSIONS: The results of this trial provide strong support for organizational changes involving non-medical personnel to improve vaccination rates among older adults.

title: Improving preventive health care delivery with the Comprehensive Annotated Reminder Tool (CART)
abstract: OBJECTIVES: We evaluated the effect of the Comprehensive Annotated Reminder Tool (CART) on physicians' adherence to preventive service recommendations. STUDY DESIGN: Using a pre-post trial randomized control group design, we assigned physicians to either the CART group or the control group, performed prospective follow-up, and assessed appropriate adherence to guidelines. The 3 age-specific versions of the CART Annotated History and Physical Exam form contained up to 49 preventive service recommendations. POPULATION: All resident physicians in a large family medicine residency program were studied over the course of 1 academic year. MEASURED OUTCOMES: We conducted blind chart reviews to assess the appropriateness of physician-ordered preventive services before CART was introduced, during its use, and after its withdrawal. A multiple choice test completed before and after the use of the CART forms assessed knowledge. RESULTS: When CART was used, the adequacy of physician preventive behavior increased by 21% overall. The adequacy of medical history, physical examination, and laboratory interventions increased by 33%. When CART was withdrawn, physician behavior returned to baseline (P < or = 0.0025 for 16 of 20 interventions). No significant differences were observed in the control group over time. Knowledge increased over the study period for all physicians (P < or = 0.005), but did not differ significantly between treatment and control groups (P = 0.608). CONCLUSIONS: The use of CART significantly improved physicians' performance in providing adequate preventive care.

title: Improving depression care through collaborative online learning
abstract: Depression is one of the leading causes of disability worldwide, and depression is diagnosed and treated by many internists. This study aimed to examine the impact of a practice improvement intervention on the detection and management of patients with depression in primary care. This pre-post study design included a physician practice survey designed to capture what physicians believed they were doing in practice, a chart audit tool to capture what physicians were actually doing in practice, and an intervention that included an evidence-based educational program, online toolkit, and practice improvement coaching conference calls that promoted group learning. After completing the intervention, participants increasingly used the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 to screen, diagnose, and measure treatment success for depression and reported increased use of guidelines and team care. Although there are barriers to improving depression care, this study suggests that evidence-based quality improvement programs can positively affect practice.

title: Improving diabetes care: multicomponent cardiovascular disease risk reduction strategies for people with diabetes in South Asia: the CARRS multicenter translation trial
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in people with diabetes in South Asia. The CARRS translation trial tests the efficacy, cost-effectiveness, and sustainability of a clinic-based, multi-component CVD risk reduction intervention among people with diabetes in India and Pakistan. METHODS: We randomly assigned 1146 adults with diabetes recruited from 10 urban clinics to receive usual care from physicians or to receive an integrated multicomponent CVD risk reduction intervention. The intervention involves electronic health record management, decision support prompts for the health care team, and support from a care coordinator to actively facilitate patient and clinician adherence to evidence-based guidelines. supplier. The primary outcome is a combination of control of multiple CVD risk factors (blood glucose and blood pressure or cholesterol, or all three). Other outcomes include control of individual CVD risk factors, process- and patient-focused measures, cost-effectiveness, and acceptability/feasibility. CONCLUSION: The CARRS translation trial tests a model of low-cost diabetes care in urban South Asia to achieve comprehensive case management of cardiometabolic diseases of high-risk patients (clinicaltrials.gov number: NCT01212328).

title: Improving physicians' prescribing behavior through reflection on guidelines and prescribing feedback: a randomized controlled study.
abstract: BACKGROUND: It is difficult to translate research findings into clinical practice through prescribing guidelines or commentary. OBJECTIVE: To study the effect on prescribing quality by a combined intervention of providing individual feedback and deriving quality criteria using guideline recommendations in peer review groups. METHODS: 199 general practitioners in 32 groups were randomized to participate in peer review meetings related to asthma or urinary tract infections. Dispensing of antiasthmatic drugs and antibiotics by participating physicians during the year prior to the intervention period provided the basis for prescribing feedback. Intervention feedback was designed to describe the treatment given in relation to national guideline recommendations. In each group, the doctors agreed on quality criteria for their own treatment of the corresponding diseases based on these recommendations. Comparing their prescribing feedback to their own quality criteria gave each doctor the ratio of acceptable and unacceptable treatments. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: Difference in prescribing behavior between the year before and the year after the intervention. RESULTS: Before the intervention, the mean proportions of patients with asthma acceptably treated in the asthma group and the urinary tract infection (control) group were 28% and 27%, respectively. The mean proportion of acceptably treated patients in the asthma group increased by 6% relative to the control group";" This difference was statistically significant. The mean proportions of acceptable UTI treatments before intervention in the UTI group and the asthma (control) group were 12% for both groups, which increased by 13% in the UTI group relative to the control group. Relative to pre-intervention mean values, this represented a treatment improvement of 21% in the asthma group and 108% in the urinary tract infection group. CONCLUSIONS: Deriving prescribing quality criteria through discussion of guideline recommendations provided clinicians with a basis for judging the treatment of individual patients as acceptable or unacceptable. Presented with feedback on their own prescription, they learned what they did right and wrong. This provided a basis for improvement and the process thus instigated resulted in physicians providing better quality patient care.

title: Improving Empirical Antibiotic Selection by Supporting Computerized Decision Making.
abstract: Background: Physicians must often initiate antibiotic therapy before the results of bacterial cultures and antibiotic susceptibility tests are available. We developed and tested a computerized antibiotic advisor to assist clinicians in the selection of appropriate empiric antibiotics. Methods: We used a two-stage randomized study to compare antibiotic specialist-suggested antibiotics with 482 associated antibiotic susceptibility scores and physician-ordered concurrent antibiotics. Randomized physician-ordered antibiotics were then compared across periods of antibiotic consultant use. Results: The antibiotic specialist suggested an antibiotic regimen to which all pathogen isolates were found to be susceptible in 453 (94%) of 482 culture results, while the physicians indicated an antibiotic regimen to which all pathogen isolates were susceptible in 369 results. culture (77%) (p < 0.001). Physicians who prescribed antibiotics to which all pathogens were susceptible did so a mean of 21 hours after the culture samples were collected. Physicians ordered the appropriate antibiotics within 12 hours of culture collection significantly more frequently when using the antibiotic consultant than during the period before use (p < 0.035). Additionally, 88% of physicians said they would recommend the program to other physicians, 85% said the program improved their antibiotic selection, and 81% said they felt using the program improved patient care. Conclusions: Information from computerized medical records can be used to help improve clinicians' selection of empiric antibiotics for infections. (Arch Intern Med. 1994";"154:878-884)

title: Improving empiric antibiotic therapy using TREAT, a computerized decision support system: cluster randomized trial.
abstract: Background: Adequate antibiotic treatment decreases mortality, while superfluous treatment is associated with antibiotic resistance. We built a computerized decision support system for antibiotic treatment (TREAT) targeting these outcomes. Methods: Prospective cohort study comparing TREAT advice with physician treatment, followed by a cluster randomized trial comparing wards using TREAT (intervention) versus antibiotic control without TREAT (control). Patients suspected of harboring bacterial infections in three hospitals (Israel, Germany and Italy) were included. The primary outcome, appropriate antibiotic treatment, was evaluated among patients with microbiologically documented infections (MDI). Length of hospital stay, adverse events, mortality (intervention trial), and antibiotic costs (both studies), including costs related to future antibiotic resistance, were compared among all included patients. Results: Among 1,203 patients included in the cohort study (350 with MDI), TREAT prescribed appropriate empiric antibiotic therapy significantly more frequently than did physicians (70% versus 57%, P < 0.001) using fewer broad-spectrum antibiotics at half of doctors' antibiotic costs. The randomized trial included 2,326 patients, 570 with MDI. The rate of appropriate empiric antibiotic treatment was higher in intervention versus control wards [73% versus 64%, odds ratio (OR): 1.48, 95% confidence interval (CI): 0.95–2, 29, intention to treat, adjusted for location and clustering]. For patients treated according to TREAT advice in the intervention rooms, the difference from controls was highly significant (OR: 3.40, 95% CI: 2.25-5.14). Length of hospital stay, costs related to future resistance, and total antibiotic costs were lower in the intervention wards than in the control wards. Conclusions: TREAT improved the rate of appropriate empiric antibiotic therapy while reducing antibiotic costs and the use of broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy.

title: Improving empiric antibiotic therapy using TREAT, a computerized decision support system: cluster randomized trial.
abstract: Background: Adequate antibiotic treatment decreases mortality, while superfluous treatment is associated with antibiotic resistance. We built a computerized decision support system for antibiotic treatment (TREAT) targeting these outcomes. Methods: Prospective cohort study comparing TREAT advice with physician treatment, followed by a cluster randomized trial comparing wards using TREAT (intervention) versus antibiotic control without TREAT (control). Patients suspected of harboring bacterial infections in three hospitals (Israel, Germany and Italy) were included. The primary outcome, appropriate antibiotic treatment, was evaluated among patients with microbiologically documented infections (MDI). Length of hospital stay, adverse events, mortality (intervention trial), and antibiotic costs (both studies), including costs related to future antibiotic resistance, were compared among all included patients. Results: Among 1,203 patients included in the cohort study (350 with MDI), TREAT prescribed appropriate empiric antibiotic therapy significantly more frequently than did physicians (70% versus 57%, P < 0.001) using fewer broad-spectrum antibiotics at half of doctors' antibiotic costs. The randomized trial included 2,326 patients, 570 with MDI. The rate of appropriate empiric antibiotic treatment was higher in intervention versus control wards [73% versus 64%, odds ratio (OR): 1.48, 95% confidence interval (CI): 0.95–2, 29, intention to treat, adjusted for location and clustering]. For patients treated according to TREAT advice in the intervention rooms, the difference from controls was highly significant (OR: 3.40, 95% CI: 2.25-5.14). Length of hospital stay, costs related to future resistance, and total antibiotic costs were lower in the intervention wards than in the control wards. Conclusions: TREAT improved the rate of appropriate empiric antibiotic therapy while reducing antibiotic costs and the use of broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy.

title: Improving feedback on prescribing errors from young physicians: a mixed methods evaluation of a quality improvement project.
abstract: Background Prescription errors occur in up to 15% of inpatient drug orders in the UK. However, young doctors report insufficient feedback on errors. One barrier to feedback is that individual prescribers often cannot be clearly identified in prescription documentation. Objective To reduce prescribing errors in a UK hospital by improving feedback on prescribing errors. Interventions We developed three linked interventions using cycles of plan-do-study-act: (1) name stamps for young doctors who were encouraged to stamp or write their name clearly when prescribing";" (2) effective feedback principles to help pharmacists provide feedback to physicians on individual prescribing errors and (3) bi-weekly prescribing advice emails that addressed a common and/or serious error. Implementation and evaluation Interventions were introduced at one hospital site in August 2013 with a second serving as a control. Process measures included the percentage of inpatient drug orders for which junior physicians indicated their name. Outcome measures were trainee physicians' and pharmacists' perceptions of current feedback provision (assessed using quantitative pre-post questionnaires and qualitative focus groups) and the prevalence of erroneous medication orders written by trainee physicians between August and December 2013. Findings The percentage of drug orders for which young doctors gave their name increased from about 10% to 50%. Responses to the questionnaire revealed a significant improvement in perceptions for pharmacists, but no significant change for physicians. Findings from the focus groups suggested greater involvement of physicians in safe prescribing. Interrupted time series analysis showed no difference in weekly prescription error rates between the baseline and intervention periods, compared to the control site. Conclusion The findings suggest enhanced experiences around feedback. However, attempts to produce a measurable reduction in prescribing errors are likely to require a multifaceted approach of which feedback should be a part.

title: Improving Guideline Compliance: A Randomized Trial Evaluating Strategies to Increase Beta-Blocker Use in Heart Failure
abstract: Background: The dissemination of clinical practice guidelines has often not been accompanied by the desired improvements in guideline compliance. This study evaluated interventions to implement a new practice guideline recommending the use of ß-blockers for patients with heart failure. Methods and results: This was a randomized controlled trial involving heart failure patients (n=169) with ejection fraction ≥45% and no contraindications to ß-blockers. Patients' primary providers were randomized in a stratified design to 1 of 3 interventions: (1) control: provider education"; (2) provider and patient notification: computerized provider reminders and letters to patients recommending ß-blockers"; and (3) nurse facilitator: supervised nurse to initiate and titrate ß-blockers. The primary outcome, the proportion of patients who started or increased titration and remained on ß-blockers, analyzed by intention-to-treat, was achieved by 67% (36 of 54) of patients in the nurse facilitator group compared with 16% (10 of 64) in provider/patient notification and 27% (14 of 51) in the control groups (P<0.001 for comparisons between the nurse facilitator group and the other two groups). The proportion of patients with target doses of ß-blockers at the end of the study (median follow-up, 12 months) was also higher in the nursing facilitator group (43%) compared with the control (10%) and the nursing facilitator groups. provider/patient notification (2%) (P<0.001). There were no differences in adverse events between the groups. Conclusions: The use of a nurse facilitator was a successful approach to implement a ß-blocker regimen in patients with heart failure. The use of provider education, clinical reminders, and patient education was of limited value in this setting.

title: Improving nurses' hand hygiene behavior through action planning: a pilot study in the intensive care unit and operating room
abstract: Compliance with hand hygiene guidelines by hospital doctors and nurses is universally low and there is a need to apply powerful social science intervention methods to improve compliance. One method is the formation of implementation intentions (or action plans) in which concrete "if-then" plans are formulated to link an environmental cue to the performance of an intended behavioral action. This pilot study explored the practicality and effects of action planning on the hand hygiene behavior (HHB) of nurses in an ICU and surgical suite of a university teaching hospital. A pre-post test design was used and 17 nurses were invited to participate. A trained researcher observed HHB of nurses before and three weeks after the intervention in which action plans were formulated. Frequencies were calculated and logistic regression analysis was performed to assess changes in HHB. Of the 17 participants, 10 (seven in the OR, three in the ICU) had complete data and were included in the analyses. In total, 283 potential moments for hand hygiene were identified, 142 in the operating room and 141 in the ICU. HHB increased from 9.3% at baseline to 25.4% after intervention (odds ratio: 3.3"; confidence interval: 1.7-6.5;" P<0.001). Although this was a small-scale study, the results are promising for the use of action planning to improve nurses' HHB in the short term. Action planning has been successful in bridging the gap between intention and behavior in other fields, and its use to improve HHB in health care needs to be further investigated.

title: Improve handover from critical care to ward medical teams with simple paperwork changes
abstract: Medical handover has been highlighted by the General Medical Council[1] as a critical step in patient care, ensuring continuity of care, patient safety, and enabling efficient multidisciplinary operation. Handover between intensive care team physicians and Great Western Hospital ward teams was assessed by reviewing discharge summaries and patient notes, and by following up with discharged patients. Carryover was found to be present in only a minority of patients and was not documented in any. Simple changes were made to offload paperwork in the form of a notice and documentation of who the transfer was made to, as well as creating a space on daily review sheets for pending transfer patients to complete. The initial results of the audit were presented at a local meeting to remind staff of the importance of the handover. These simple modifications raised carryover rates to 100% (n=12). Delivery documentation rates also increased from 0% to 100%. This quality improvement project serves to demonstrate that simple, carefully targeted practice changes in identified critical areas can produce dramatic results, in addition to those legally and ethically required, in a very short space of time.

title: Improving knowledge and changing behavior toward guideline-based decisions in diabetes care: a controlled intervention study of a team-learning approach to continuing professional development for clinicians.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Ideally, Continuing Professional Development (CPD) courses should enhance a physician's knowledge and change their professional behavior in daily practice towards a reference model of best clinical practice and adherence to guidelines. Interactive methods, such as team learning and case-based learning, compared to lectures, can impart sustainable knowledge and generate high satisfaction among the participants. We designed an interactive case-based CPD seminar on diabetes care using a team learning approach to assess whether it leads to short-term knowledge improvement and behavior change toward guideline-based decisions and how participants perceive this approach. Learning. . METHODS: Questionnaires and an electronic voting system were used to assess the motivation, acceptance, and knowledge of volunteer participants. In addition, we analyzed data on index diagnostic tests and referrals of patients with diabetes from participating physicians over a six-month period before and after the course compared with a matched control group in a quasi-experimental design. RESULTS: Participants (n=103) rated interactivity and team discussions as the main reasons for improving learning. They also hoped that the course would change their professional behavior. The participants obtained a mean of 43.9% correct answers before and 62.6% after the course (p<0.001). Referral to diabetes specialists increased by 30.8% (p<0.001). Referral for fundoscopy also increased (8.5%, ns) while it decreased in the control group. In addition, participating physicians screened their patients more frequently for microalbuminuria (7.1%, ns). CONCLUSIONS: Our team-based learning CPD approach was well accepted and resulted in short-term knowledge gains. Referral to diabetes specialists in daily practice increased significantly, while all other key indicators of professional behavior changed, but not significantly.

title: Improving laboratory monitoring at the start of drug therapy in ambulatory care: a randomized trial.
abstract: Background The importance of laboratory monitoring of drugs is reflected in product labeling and published guidelines, but monitoring recommendations are inconsistently followed. There is an opportunity to improve monitoring, with the potential to decrease complications of therapy. Methods The objective of this randomized trial was to determine whether computerized alerts were effective in increasing the percentage of outpatients with laboratory monitoring at the start of drug therapy. Physicians and pharmacists came together to develop organization-specific guidelines for monitoring select medications. In collaboration with physicians, pharmacists were alerted to missing lab test results, ordered missing tests, reminded patients to take tests, evaluated test completion, reviewed test results, and abnormal results were handled. Eligible persons included patients started on therapy for any of the 15 medications among 400,000 health plan members. Results In the intervention group, 79.1% (n = 4,076"; 95% confidence interval [CI], 78.0%-80.2%) of dispensations were controlled compared with 70.2% % (n = 3,522; "95% CI, 68.9%-71.5%) in the usual care group (p < 0.001). For example, 78.6% of amiodarone dispensing (95% CI, 73.1%-83.5%) in the intervention group was controlled versus 51.4% (95% CI, 44.4% -58.4%) in the group that received usual care (p < 0.001). ). Conclusions This study demonstrates the effectiveness of a computerized tool plus collaboration between health professionals to increase the percentage of patients receiving laboratory monitoring at the start of therapy. Combining the data available from information systems with the knowledge and skills of physicians and pharmacists can result in better patient monitoring.

title: Improving mammography recommendation: a nurse-initiated intervention
abstract: We seek to improve our compliance with recommendations for screening mammography, in accordance with the American Cancer Society (ACS) guidelines, for eligible patients seen by family medicine residents by using a multipart intervention designed to eliminate the identified barriers of knowledge and behavior by residents. Copies of the ACS Cancer Screening Guidelines were posted in all exam and conference rooms and given to all residents. The intervention that addressed behavioral barriers had three components: (1) identification by nursing staff of eligible women who were overdue for a mammogram when they presented for care, (2) completion of a checklist by residents indicating whether or not a mammogram was recommended and why, and (3) a nurse-initiated backup reminder system for patients who escaped the main checklist system. An audit of 200 pre-intervention and 270 post-intervention charts showed statistically and clinically significant increases in recommended or performed mammograms. Similar statistically significant increases were found in a cohort of 111 patient records at pre- and post-intervention audits. Results indicate that an intervention designed to remove identified resident-dependent barriers to adherence to screening mammography guidelines may be effective in increasing recommended mammography rates.

title: Improving Medication Management in Multimorbidity: Development of the Multimorbidity COllaborative Medication Review and Decision Making (MY COMRADE) Intervention Using the Behavior Change Wheel
abstract: BACKGROUND: Multimorbidity, the presence of two or more chronic conditions, affects more than 60% of patients in primary care. Due to its association with polypharmacy, the development of interventions to optimize medication management in patients with multimorbidity is a priority. The Behavior Change Wheel is a new approach to applying behavioral theory to the development of interventions. Here, we describe how we have used the results of a review of previous research, our own original research, and the Behavior Change Wheel to develop an intervention to improve medication management in multimorbidity by general practitioners (GPs), within the Council. UK Medical Research. guidance on complex interventions. METHODS: Following the steps of the Behavior Change Wheel, we searched for behaviors associated with medication management in multimorbidity by conducting a systematic review and qualitative study with GPs. Of the modifiable GP behaviors identified, we selected one and conducted a focused behavioral analysis to explain why GPs were or were not engaging in this behaviour. We use behavior analysis to determine the intervention functions, behavior change techniques, and implementation plan most likely to effect behavior change. RESULTS: We identified numerous modifiable GP behaviors in the systematic review and qualitative study, of which active medication review (rather than passive maintenance of the status quo) was chosen as the target behavior. Behavioral analysis revealed the capacities, opportunities and motivations of GPs in relation to active medication review. We combined the three intervention functions that were considered most likely to effect behavior change (enabling, environmental restructuring, and incentive) to form the Multimorbidity COllaborative Medication Review and Decision Making (MY COMRADE) intervention. MY COMRADE mainly involves the technique of social support: two general practitioners together review the medications prescribed to a complex multimorbid patient. Four other behavior change techniques are incorporated: restructuring of the social environment, prompts/signals, action planning, and self-incentives. CONCLUSIONS: This study is the first to use the behavior change wheel to develop an intervention targeting multimorbidity and confirms the ease of use and utility of the approach in a complex area of clinical care. The systematic development of the MY COMRADE intervention will facilitate a comprehensive evaluation of its effectiveness in the next phase of this work.

title: Improving Mental Health Care Transitions for Children and Youth: A Protocol for Implementing and Evaluating an Emergency Department Clinical Pathway
abstract: Background Although the emergency department (ED) is often the first point of entry for children and youth with mental health (MH) problems, there is limited capacity to respond to HM needs in this setting. HM systems for children are often fragmented across various ministries, organizations and providers. Communication between these groups is often poor, creating gaps, particularly in care transitions, for this vulnerable population. The evidence-based Emergency Department Mental Health Clinical Pathway (EDMHCP) was created with two main goals: (1) to guide risk assessment and decision making about the disposition of children and youth presenting to the ED with mental health concerns, and (2) provide a streamlined transition to follow-up services with Community MH Agencies (CMHAs) and other providers. The purpose of this article is to describe our study protocol for implementing and evaluating the EDMHCP. Methods/Design This mixed methods health services research project will involve the implementation and evaluation of the EDMHCP in four exemplary ED-CMHA dyads. The theoretical domains framework will be used to develop a customized intervention strategy to implement the EDMHCP. A multiple benchmark study design and interrupted time series analysis will be used to determine whether the EDMHCP has improved health care utilization, medical management of mental health problems, and health sector coordination. The primary outcome of the process will be the proportion of patients with specific HH recommendations documented in the health record. The primary outcome of the service will be the proportion of patients receiving the EDMHCP-recommended follow-up at 24 hours or 7 days. Data sources will include qualitative interviews, health record audits, administrative databases, and patient surveys. A concurrent process evaluation will be conducted to assess the degree of variability and fidelity in implementation at sites. Discussion This article presents a novel model to measure the effects of the EDMHCP. Our development process will identify how the EDMHCP is best implemented among partner organizations to provide evidence-based risk management for children and youth with mental health concerns. More broadly, it will contribute to the body of evidence supporting the implementation of clinical pathways within novel partnerships.

title: Improving Opioid Safety Practices in Primary Care: Protocol for the Development and Evaluation of a Multifaceted, Theory-Informed Pilot Intervention for Healthcare Providers
abstract: INTRODUCTION: In North America, drug overdose deaths are reaching unprecedented levels, largely driven by the rise in deaths related to prescription opioids. Despite the development of various opioid guidelines, prescribing behaviors still contribute to poor patient outcomes and societal harm. Provider and system-level factors can make it difficult or easy to apply evidence-based guidelines";" Interventions designed to address such factors are needed. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: Using implementation science and behavior change theory, we have planned the development and evaluation of a comprehensive Opioid Self-Assessment Package, designed to increase adherence to the Canadian Opioid Guidelines among family physicians. . The intervention uses practical self-assessment and educational tools to provide clinicians with feedback on their current knowledge and practices, and resources to improve their practice. The evaluation approach uses a pre-post test design and includes both quantitative and qualitative methods at baseline and at 6 months. We will recruit a purposive sample of approximately 10 family physicians in Ontario from various practice settings, who are currently treating patients on long-term opioid therapy for chronic pain. Quantitative data will be analyzed using basic descriptive statistics and qualitative data will be analyzed using the Framework Method. ETHICS AND DISSEMINATION: The Research Ethics Council of the University Health Network approved this study. The dissemination plan includes publications, conference presentations and brief reports from stakeholders. This evidence-based, theory-driven intervention has implications for the national application of opioid quality improvement tools in primary care settings. We are engaging experts and end-users in advisory roles and stakeholders throughout our project to increase its national relevance, application and sustainability. Performance measures could be used as the basis for health system quality improvement indicators to monitor opioid prescribing. In addition, the methods and approach used in this study could be adapted to other opioid guidelines or applied to other areas of preventive health care and clinical guideline implementation processes.

title: Improving pediatric asthma outcomes in primary health care: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the effectiveness of the Practitioner Asthma Communication and Education (PACE) Australia programme, an innovative pediatric asthma communication and management program for general practitioners. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. SETTING: General practices from two regions in the Sydney metropolitan area. PARTICIPANTS: 150 general practitioners, who were recruited between 2006 and 2008, and 221 children with asthma in their care. INTERVENTION: GPs from the intervention group participated in two 3-hour workshops, focusing on communication and education strategies to facilitate quality asthma care. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Patient outcomes included receipt of an asthma action plan (WAAP), appropriate medication use, parental days absent from work, and days absent from work. from the child to school or daycare. GP outcomes included frequency of providing a WAAP and patient education, communication and teaching behavior, and compliance with national asthma guidelines regarding medication use.
