RESULTS: More GP patients in the intervention group reported receiving a WAAP (difference, 15%"; 95% CI, 2% to 28%; adjusted P = .046). In the intervention group, children with infrequent intermittent asthma symptoms had lower use of inhaled corticosteroids (difference, 24%; 95% CI, -43% to -5%; P = .03) and long-acting bronchodilators (difference, 19%; 95% CI). %, -34% to -5%; P = 0.02).GPs in the intervention group were more confident in communicating with patients (difference 22%; 95% CI, 3% to 40%; P = 0.03) A higher proportion of GPs in the intervention group reported providing a WAAP more than 70% of the time (difference, 23%; 95% CI, 11% to 36%; adjusted P = 0.002) and prescription of spacer devices more than 90% of the time (difference, 29%; 95% CI, 16% to 42%; adjusted P=0.02). CONCLUSIONS: The PACE Australia program improved GP asthma management practices and led to improvements in some important patient outcomes. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australia and New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry ACTRN12607000067471.

title: Improving patient care through medical imaging perception research
abstract: The interpretation of medical images in all medical specialties is essential for patient care. As technology changes, so does healthcare, and today's physicians increasingly view medical images in a variety of settings. Although access to such data is helpful, even clinicians experienced in image interpretation make mistakes. These errors may become more frequent as clinicians' work days grow longer and the number of images to interpret increases. To avoid errors in medical image interpretation, we must understand the underlying perceptual and cognitive mechanisms that guide image interpretation. We can then use what we've learned to develop better training methods, automated image analysis, and processing tools. We can devise methods to reduce physician fatigue and stress, and develop practice guidelines, thereby improving patient care and outcomes.

title: Improve patient discharge and reduce hospital readmissions by mapping interventions
abstract: Background There is a growing push to reorganize the hospital discharge process to reduce readmissions and avoidable costs. The goal of this study was to provide insight into hospital discharge issues and underlying causes, and to provide an overview of solutions that guide providers and policymakers to improve hospital discharge. Methods The Intervention Mapping framework was used. In the first place, an analysis of the problem was carried out, studying the magnitude, causes and consequences of ineffective hospital discharge. The analysis was based on primary data from 26 focus group interviews and 321 individual interviews with patients and family members, and involved hospital and community care providers. Second, improvements in terms of intervention outcomes, performance targets, and change targets were specified. Third, 220 experts were consulted and a systematic review of effective discharge interventions was conducted to select the theory-based methods and practical strategies needed to achieve change and better performance. Results Ineffective discharge is related to factors at the level of the individual care provider, the patient, the relationship between providers, and organizational and technical support for care providers. Providers can reduce hospital readmission rates and adverse events by focusing on high-quality discharge information, well-coordinated care, and direct and timely communication with their peer counterparts. Patients, or their caregivers, should be involved in the discharge process and be aware of their health status and treatment. Hospital care providers' assessment of whether discharge information is accurate and understood by patients and their community counterparts are important examples of overcoming identified barriers to effective discharge. Discharge templates, medication reconciliation, a liaison nurse or pharmacist, regular site visits, and post-teaching are identified as effective and promising strategies for achieving desired behavioral and environmental change. Conclusions This study provides a comprehensive guidance framework for providers and policymakers to improve the transfer of patients from hospital to primary care.

title: Improving physician compliance with preventive medicine guidelines
abstract: Similar general practice outpatient clinics with randomized patients were used to assess the efficacy of a program that aimed to increase in-house staff compliance with preventive medicine guidelines. Two clinics were designated experimental and two served as controls. In the experimental clinics, age-specific checklists of all recommended preventive procedures (excerpted from the report of the Canadian Task Force on Periodic Health Examination and the American Cancer Society guidelines) were attached to each patient's chart. . In addition, house officials were presented with a series of weekly seminars that address screening issues as well as the specific recommendations included in the checklist. The internal staff of the four clinics were evaluated for their knowledge and attitudes towards the preventive program before and after the intervention. Counts of immunizations and mammograms performed and the total populations eligible for these procedures were determined for the four clinics. As predicted, test scores as well as mammography and immunization rates increased significantly (from 2 to 40 percent) in intervention clinics compared to controls. We conclude that this intervention was clearly effective in the short term. However, follow-up studies will be necessary to determine if the desired long-term effect has been achieved.

title: Improving population-based cervical cancer screening in general practice: effects of a national strategy
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the effects of a Dutch national prevention programme, targeting general practitioners (GPs), on adherence to organizational guidelines for effective cervical cancer screening in general practice. Identify the characteristics of general practices that determine success. DESIGN: A prospective questionnaire study with pre-post measurement (before and 15 months after the introduction of the national program). SETTING AND STUDY PARTICIPANTS: A random sample of one third of 4,758 Dutch general practices. A GP was asked to participate per practice. INTERVENTION: A national GP prevention program to improve population-based cervical cancer prevention that combines several methods to improve quality in general practice, conducted at national, district, and practice levels. Outreach visitors were a key strategy for generating behavior change. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: The proportion of practices adhering to 10 recommendations (across four guidelines) for organizing effective cervical cancer screening. RESULTS: After 15 months, all Dutch practices showed a significant improvement in compliance with nine of the 10 recommendations. Two recommendations, in particular 'identify women who should be medically excluded from screening' and 'reminder those who do not comply', showed the largest absolute increases of 26% and 33%, respectively. In addition to more intensive support from outreach visitors, practice features such as 'computerization' and 'delegation of many clinical tasks to the practice assistant' were important in improving adherence to guidelines. CONCLUSION: The national programme, with a combination of various quality improvement methods, appeared to be effective in improving the organization of cervical screening in general practice. Computerization and, to a lesser extent, the delegation of many clinical tasks to the practice assistant and more intensive support to practices, positively influenced the effectiveness of the national programme.

title: Improving prescribing patterns for the elderly through an online medication utilization review intervention
abstract: Context.— Pharmacotherapy is among the most powerful interventions to improve health outcomes in the elderly. However, as some medications are less appropriate for older patients, systems approaches to improve pharmaceutical care may be an effective way to reduce inappropriate medication use. Objective.— To determine whether a computerized drug utilization review (DUR) database linked to a telepharmacy intervention can improve suboptimal medication use in the elderly. Design.— Population-based cohort design, April 1, 1996, through March 31, 1997. Setting.— Ambulatory care. Patients.—A total of 23,269 patients age 65 and older in the United States who received prescription drug benefits from a large pharmacy benefit manager during a 12-month period. Intervention.â€”Assessment of provider prescribing through an online computerized DUR database using explicit criteria to identify potentially inappropriate medication use in the elderly. The computer alerts triggered phone calls to physicians by pharmacists with training in geriatrics, in which the principles of geriatric pharmacology along with therapeutic substitution options were discussed. Main outcome measures.— Physician contact rate and rate of change to suggested drug regimen. Results.— A total of 43,007 alerts were activated. Out of a total of 43,007 telepharmacy calls generated by the alerts, we were able to reach 19,368 physicians regarding 24,266 alerts (56%). The rate of switching to a more appropriate therapeutic agent was 24% (5,860), but ranged from 40% for long half-life benzodiazepines to 2% to 7% for drugs that were theoretically contraindicated by history. self-reported by patients. Except for the rate of change of ß-blockers in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, all rates of change were significantly greater than the expected baseline rate of change of 2%. Conclusions.— Using a system that integrates computers, pharmacists, and physicians, our large-scale intervention improved prescribing patterns and quality of care and thus provides a population-based approach to advancing geriatric clinical pharmacology. . Future research should focus on demonstrating better health outcomes as a result of better prescription options for the elderly.

title: Improving quality improvement using achievable benchmarks for clinician feedback: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Context Performance feedback and benchmarking, common tools for improving health care, are rarely studied in randomized trials. Achievable Care Benchmarks (ABCs) are standards of excellence achieved by the best in a peer group and are easily and reproducibly calculated from existing performance data. Objective To assess the effectiveness of using achievable benchmarks to improve typical physician performance feedback and improve care. Design Cluster randomized controlled trial conducted in December 1996, with follow-up to 1998. Setting and participants Seventy community physicians and 2978 fee-for-service Medicare patients with diabetes mellitus who were part of the Ambulatory Care Quality Improvement Project in Alabama. Intervention Physicians were randomly assigned to receive either a multimodal improvement intervention, including chart review and physician-specific feedback (comparison group"; n = 35) or an identical intervention plus achievable baseline feedback (experimental group; n = 35).Main outcome measure Pre-intervention (1994-1995) to post-intervention (1997-1998) changes in the proportion of patients who received influenza vaccination; foot exam;" and each of the 3 blood tests that measure glucose control, cholesterol level, and triglyceride level, compared between the 2 groups. Results The proportion of patients who received the influenza vaccine improved from 40% to 58% in the experimental group (p < 0.001) versus 40% to 46% in the comparison group (p = 0.02). The odds ratios (ORs) for patients of attainable referral physicians versus comparison physicians who received adequate care postintervention, adjusted for preintervention care and nesting of patients within physicians, were 1, 57 (95% confidence interval [CI], 1.26-1.96) for influenza vaccination, 1.33 (95% CI, 1.05-1.69) for foot exam, and 1. 33 (95% CI, 1.04-1.69) for the measurement of long-term glucose control. For cholesterol and serum triglycerides, the achievable baseline effect was statistically significant only after additional adjustment for physician characteristics (OR, 1.40 [95% CI, 1.08-1.82] and OR, 1.40 [95% CI, 1.09-1.79], respectively). Conclusion The use of achievable benchmarks significantly improves the effectiveness of physician performance feedback in the setting of a multimodal quality improvement intervention.

title: Improving the quality of delirium care in a general medical service with established interdisciplinary care: a controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical practice guidelines have been developed to improve the detection, prevention, and treatment of delirium. OBJECTIVES: To implement delirium guidelines in general medical patients to reduce the incidence and duration of delirium and improve outcomes in patients with delirium. METHODS: Implementation was carried out by a multidisciplinary team of physicians and project staff in a medical room. The evaluation was carried out as a controlled trial in patients 65 years of age or older with/at risk of delirium, compared to a medical ward control. Interventions included risk screening, delirium screening, multidisciplinary education, ward modifications including a four-bed delirium bay, behavioral and medication protocols, and the use of nursing assistants and volunteers. Primary outcome measures were incidence and duration of delirium";" secondary outcomes were length of hospital stay, mortality, falls, and discharge destination in the delirium subgroup. Process measures included room changes, use of neuroleptics, allied health check, and use of the delirium bay. RESULTS: Of 206 consenting older medical patients, 22% were delusional on admission and 44% were at risk. No incident cases of delirium were identified. In the subgroup with delirium, significantly fewer intervention participants were discharged with persistent delirium (32% vs. 71%, P = .016), with trends toward reduced hospital mortality (0% vs. 18.5% , P = .07) and falls (11% vs. 22%, P = .16), at the expense of a longer stay in the medical room (16 days vs. 8 days, P = .01). CONCLUSIONS: The low incidence of new delusions may reflect the established interdisciplinary care environment. The improved results in the delirium group are encouraging, although implementation was costly, including a longer length of stay in the acute ward.

title: Improving resident compliance with ambulatory care standards: results from the VA Cooperative Study on Computerized Reminders.
abstract: Context Computerized systems for reminding clinicians to provide appropriate care have not been extensively evaluated in large numbers of patients in multiple clinical settings. Objective To examine whether a computerized reminder system operating in multiple Veterans Affairs (VA) ambulatory care clinics improves resident physician compliance with ambulatory care standards. Design, Setting, and Participants A total of 275 resident physicians at 12 VA medical centers were randomized in company or half-day clinic blocks to a recall group (n = 132) or a control group (n = 143). . During a 17-month study period (January 31, 1995 to June 30, 1996), residents cared for 12,989 unique patients who applied at least 1 of the studied standards of care (SOC). Main outcome measures Compliance with 13 SOCs, tracked using hospital databases and resident-completed encounter forms, compared between residents in the recall group versus those in the control group. Results Measuring adherence as the proportion of patients who adhered to all applicable SOCs at their last visit during the study period, the reminder group had statistically significantly higher adherence rates than the control group for all standards combined (58.8% vs. 53.5%"; odds [OR], 1.24; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.08-1.42; P = .002) and for 5 of 13 standards examined individually.Measuring adherence as the proportion of all visits for which care was indicated in which residents provided adequate care, the reminder group also had statistically significantly higher adherence rates than the recall group. control for all standards combined (17.9% vs. 12.2%; OR, 1.57; 95% CI, 1.45-1.71;" P < .001) and for 9 of 13 standards individually examined. However, the benefit of reminders diminished throughout the study, although reminders remained active. Conclusions Our data indicate that reminder systems installed at multiple sites can improve residents' compliance with multiple SOCs. The benefits of such systems, however, appear to deteriorate over time. Future research should explore methods to better maintain the benefits of reminders.

title: Improving Smoking Cessation Counseling Using a Point-of-Care Health Intervention (IT) Tool: From the Virginia Practice Support and Research Network (VaPSRN)
abstract: PURPOSE: Primary care practices are an ideal setting to reduce national smoking rates because >70% of smokers visit their physician annually, yet cessation counseling is inconsistently provided to patients. We designed and built a novel software program for handheld computers and hypothesized that it would enhance clinicians' ability to provide personalized point-of-care smoking cessation counseling. METHODS: A portable computer program based on the smoking cessation guidelines and an adaptation of widely accepted theories of behavior change was created. The tool was evaluated using a validated before/after survey to measure clinicians' counseling behaviors, knowledge, and comfort/self-efficacy in quitting smoking. RESULTS: Participants included 17 physicians (mean age, 41 years; 71% men; 5 medical residents) from a practice-based research network. After 4 months of use in direct patient care, physicians were more likely to advise patients to quit smoking (P = 0.049) and reported increased use of the "5 A's" (P = 0, 03). Greater self-efficacy was observed when advising patients on smoking cessation (p = 0.006), as well as greater comfort when following up with patients (p = 0.04). CONCLUSIONS: The use of a laptop software tool improved smoking cessation counseling among clinicians and shows promise for translating evidence on smoking cessation counseling into practice and educational settings.

title: Improving test ordering in primary care: the added value of a small group quality improvement strategy compared to classical feedback alone
abstract: PURPOSE: We wanted to assess the added value of small peer group quality improvement meetings compared to simple feedback as a strategy to improve test requesting behaviour. The number of tests ordered by primary care physicians is increasing, and many of these tests appear to be unnecessary according to established evidence-based guidelines. METHODS: We enrolled 194 primary care physicians from 27 local primary care practice groups in 5 health care regions (5 diagnostic centers). The study was a cluster randomized trial with randomization at the local medical group level. We evaluated an innovative, multifaceted approach, combining written comparative feedback, group education on national guidelines, and social peer influence in small-group quality improvement sessions. The strategy targeted 3 specific clinical themes: cardiovascular problems, upper abdominal discomfort, and lower abdominal discomfort. The mean number of tests per physician every 6 months at the start of the study and the region of the physicians were used as independent variables, and the mean number of tests per physician every 6 months was the dependent variable. RESULTS: The new strategy was implemented in 13 primary care groups, while 14 groups only received feedback. For the 3 clinical subjects, the decrease in the mean total number of tests ordered by physicians in the intervention arm was much more substantial (on average, 51 fewer tests per physician every half year) than the decrease in the mean number of tests. ordered by physicians in the intervention group. the feedback arm (P = .005). Five tests deemed inappropriate for the clinical problem of upper abdominal discomfort decreased in the intervention arm, and clinicians in the feedback arm ordered 13 more tests every 6 months (P = 0.002). Physician variation in test ordering decreased more in the intervention arm. CONCLUSION: Compared with disseminating comparative feedback reports to primary care physicians, the new strategy of engaging peer interaction and social influence improved physicians' test requesting behavior. To be effective, feedback must be embedded in an interactive educational environment.

title: Improving implementation of a practice guideline for the assessment and treatment of suicidal behavior by training all staff in departments of psychiatry through an e-learning supported Train-the-Trainer program: study protocol for a trial random controlled
abstract: BACKGROUND: In 2012, a multidisciplinary practice guideline for the assessment and treatment of suicidal behavior was issued in the Netherlands. The publication of guidelines often fails to change professional behavior due to multiple barriers. Structured implementation can improve adherence to guidelines. This article describes the design of a study that measures the effect of a Train-the-Trainer program supported by e-learning that aims to train all staff in departments in the application of the guide. We presume that both professionals and departments will benefit from the program. METHOD: In a multicentre cluster randomized controlled trial, 43 psychiatric departments spread across 10 regional mental health institutions in the Netherlands will be paired with respect to the most prevalent diagnostic category of patients and the average duration of treatment. The members of the pair are randomly assigned to the experimental or control condition. In the experimental condition, all department staff, i.e., all registered nurses, psychologists, physicians, and psychiatrists (n = 532, 21 departments) will be trained in the application of the guideline, in a one-day interactive small group. Train - the Trainer program. The program is supported by a 60-minute e-learning module with video vignettes of suicidal patients and additional instruction. In the control condition (22 departments, 404 professionals), the guideline will be disseminated in the traditional way: through manuals, books, conferences, the Internet, magazines, etc. The effectiveness of the program will be evaluated both at the level of health professionals and departments. DISCUSSION: Our objective is to demonstrate the effect of training all department staff with a Train-the-Trainer program supported by e-learning in the application of a new clinical guideline. The strengths of the study are the natural setting, the training of all staff, the random allocation of conditions, the large scale of the study, and the willingness of both staff and management to participate in the study. TEST REGISTRATION: Dutch test registration: NTR3092.

title: Improve the adequacy of the use of antimicrobials in primary care after the implementation of a local antimicrobial guide at both levels of care
abstract: Objective This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of multiple interventions carried out during the implementation of a guideline on improving the adequacy of antimicrobial prescription in primary care. Design This is a cross-sectional before/after study conducted in the Aljarafe Health Area (Andalusia, Spain), with a population of 368,728 inhabitants treated in 37 health centers. Subjects Subjects include patients with antibiotic prescription during 2009 (pre-intervention phase) or 2012 (post-intervention phase) selected by simple random sampling (confidence level, 95%; precision, 5%), with infections recorded in the electronic medical record. Interventions This study involves training sessions in primary care centers and hospital services, incorporation of the electronic guide of the Health Services Websites and incorporation of the Digital Health History guide as a decision-making support tool. Main outcome Difference in appropriate prescription of antibiotics before and after study interventions. Other variables also include age, gender, type of pharmacy, prescribed antibiotic, number of treatments per year, site of infection, and main comorbidities. Sources In addition, this study uses computerized pharmacy records of reimbursed and dispensed medications and electronic medical records. Results The percentage of adequate prescription of antibiotics is shown, which increased from 36% in 2009 to 57% in 2012 (p?<?0.001). The improvement was seen in patients of all ages and of any sex and was greater among patients of working age and patients with comorbidities. The best results were observed in the beta-lactam group and in the treatment of respiratory and skin infections. Conclusion Carrying out multifactorial interventions involving professionals from both levels of care could be an effective strategy to improve the use of antimicrobials in primary care.

title: Improving care of people with acute low back pain by allied health professionals (ALIGN trial): a cluster randomized trial protocol
abstract: Background There is variability between clinical practice guideline recommendations and actual clinical practice in many areas of health care. A 2004 systematic review examining the effectiveness of guideline implementation interventions concluded that there was a lack of evidence to support decisions about effective interventions to promote guideline uptake. Furthermore, the review recommended the use of theory in the development of implementation interventions. In Australia (2003) a clinical practice guideline for the treatment of acute low back pain has been developed. Acute low back pain is a common condition, carries a high burden, and there is some indication of a gap between evidence and practice in the allied health setting. This provides an opportunity to develop and test a theory-based implementation intervention that, if effective, may be of benefit to patients with this condition. Objectives This study aims to estimate the effectiveness of a theory-based intervention to increase the compliance of allied physicians (physiotherapists and chiropractors in Victoria, Australia) with a clinical practice guideline for acute non-specific low back pain (LBP), compared to providing doctors with a hard copy of the guide. Specifically, our primary objectives are to establish whether the intervention is effective in reducing the percentage of patients with acute nonspecific low back pain who are referred or receive radiography, and to improve the mean level of disability for patients three months after disease onset. . acute low back pain. Methods The study design is a cluster randomized trial. Restricted randomisation was used to randomise 210 practices (groups) to an intervention or control group. Practitioners in the control group received a printed copy of the guideline. Practitioners in the intervention group received a theory-based intervention developed to address prospectively identified barriers to practitioner compliance with the guideline. The intervention consisted mainly of an educational symposium. Patients aged 18 years or older who visit a participating physician for acute nonspecific low back pain of less than three months' duration during a two-week data collection period, three months after the intervention symposia, are eligible for inclusion. . Sample size calculations are based on recruiting between 15 and 40 patients per practice. Outcome assessors will be blinded to group assignment.

title: Improving hypertension management in Kazakhstan: implications for improving clinical practice, patient behaviors, and health outcomes
abstract: This article presents the results of the evaluation of a strategy aimed at improving case detection and treatment of patients with hypertension. Study findings suggest that orienting providers to clinical guidelines, public information about hypertension risks, promotion of annual blood pressure screening, and universal access to an outpatient drug benefit package improve detection and case management. Additionally, provider training at the pilot sites resulted in a substantial and significant difference in patient care and health outcomes. Provider training and tools, especially focused on effective patient counseling, contributed significantly to increased case finding, patient adherence to prescribed medications, salt reduction, and increased regular exercise. However, further improvements are required to achieve the expected adherence of patients to medication and lifestyle advice. In the pilot area, we compared two patient samples before and after the start of the intervention. We found an increase in the proportion of patients with blood pressure ≥ 160/100 mmHg. The strategy involved the joint efforts of the Research Institute of Cardiology and Internal Diseases, the Karaganda Drug Information Center, the Karaganda Oblast Health Department, the Kazakh Association of Family Doctors, the Postgraduate Institute for Almaty and USAID's ZdravPlus Project in Central Asia.

title: Improving outcome of bipolar disorder through non-pharmacological strategies: the role of psychoeducation
abstract: This article addresses the efficacy of psychoeducation and related strategies in bipolar disorders. Recently, several randomized clinical trials have shown the efficacy of psychological interventions, that is, identification of prodromal signs, cognitive-behavioral therapy, psychoeducation, and family-focused interventions, as a prophylactic adjunct to medication. All of these studies are presented here, along with pioneering studies in the field. There are several topics that every psychoeducational program must include to ensure its usefulness, and they are summarized in twelve points. Roughly, psychoeducation should contain general information about bipolar illness, elements of improving adherence, teaching about early recognition of relapse, and regular lifestyle issues. Today, various treatment guidelines include psychoeducation as a fundamental prophylactic tool. Clinicians must be aware of this and begin to carry out psychoeducation in their daily clinical practice.

title: Improving the success of mail letter intervention programs to influence prescribing behaviors: a review.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Educational interventions have long been used as a means of influencing prescribing behaviour. Various techniques including educational mailings, academic details, prescriber feedback with or without disclosure of patient identification data, and supplemental patient information have been used to promote proper prescribing habits, reduce costs, and optimize patient care. While the effects of educational intervention programs are widely reported, little information is available on the effectiveness of various mail intervention techniques. OBJECTIVE: To review the effectiveness of mail-in intervention programs and identify factors that may promote successful outcomes. METHODS: A literature search was conducted through PubMed for mail-in intervention program reports published through May 2012. Specific search terms included "drug utilization review," "drug utilization," "Medicaid," "prescription feedback", "mailed medical intervention" and "mailed medical communications". Identified publications that met the following criteria were selected for inclusion: (a) evaluated print educational materials disseminated by mail, (b) occurred in an outpatient setting, and (c) measured the impact of the intervention on prescribing patterns , health care utilization, or the economy. results. Publications meeting all 3 criteria were summarized for intervention strategy, follow-up period, data source, intervention goal, prescriber acceptance of the intervention, and effect on prescribing patterns. health care utilization and economic outcomes. RESULTS: A total of 40 published reports on 39 single interventions met the inclusion criteria. The majority (34/39 [87.2%]) of the studies were conducted in programs funded by the state or federal government; only 5 programs involved private insurers. All programs used follow-up periods of </=12 months after mailing of the final intervention. of 26 of the 39 single interventions reported a positive impact on at least 1 objective outcome. Programs that included a second recipient such as pharmacists (n = 4) reported greater impact compared to interventions mailed to prescribers only. Programs that provided patient care with identification data had a higher success rate than those that provided prescriber feedback and/or educational materials (21/25 [84.0%] vs. 5/14 [35.7%]); It should be noted that 2 of the 5 successful programs that provided Non-Patient-Identifying Materials also used academic details. Programs that sent educational material and/or prescriber feedback related to multiple drug classes or disease states had minimal impact on prescribing patterns (n = 4). However, targeting 1 specific ic disease or appropriate evidence-supported medication resulted in favorable change in a short period of time. Furthermore, providing recommendations supported by widely accepted clinical guidelines or literature was also associated with a high success rate. A subset of programs that sought to assess health care utilization (n = 5) and economic impact (n = 9) saw little change in measured outcomes. Evaluation of prescriber response forms by 7 programs revealed that changes in therapy occurred in approximately 50% of patients with prescribers who intended to accept intervention recommendations. CONCLUSIONS: Although the degree of heterogeneity between articles prevents the provision of definitive results, it appears that a well-constructed mail intervention program has the potential to evoke significant changes in prescribing patterns. Prescribers appear to be receptive to mailed interventions; however, there are limited data to determine the association between acceptance and actual change in prescription. Future research should focus on identifying barriers that may prevent uptake of recommendations from translating into changes in therapy. projects should include longer evaluation periods to determine the duration of impact after the final intervention is delivered and the potential effect on health care and economic outcomes.

title: Improve use of early follow-up care after emergency department visits. A randomized trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To test the hypothesis that the appropriateness of parental use of early follow-up care after emergency department (ED) visits can be improved with post-visit support from a nurse practitioner. DESIGN: Single-blind, randomized controlled trial. Setting: ED of an urban university hospital linked to the primary care center of the hospital. PARTICIPANTS: Parents of 190 children younger than 8 years who sought emergency department care for acute illnesses and who were treated as outpatients with follow-up in the primary care center at the discretion of emergency department physicians. INTERVENTION: Parents in the experimental group were called by a nurse practitioner who offered individualized guidance on follow-up and access to a nurse practitioner for further help as needed. The control group received "usual" follow-up advice during visits to the emergency department. MEASURES/MAIN RESULTS: In the week following emergency department visits, parents in the experimental group were more compliant with instructions related to follow-up than were parents in the control group (79% vs. 61%) , less likely to miss appointments (15% vs. 31%), and less likely to "shop" elsewhere for care (2% vs. 9%). The adequacy of follow-up was assessed 'blind' using pre-specified guidelines. Inappropriate use of follow-up care was significantly reduced among subjects in the experimental group (10% vs. 20%). CONCLUSION: The nurse practitioner intervention improved parental use of follow-up care in our sample. General care for episodic ED users could be improved with similar interventions.

title: In lukewarm defense of the population's health: doctors and antibiotic resistance
abstract: Antibiotic resistance threatens the population as a serious public health threat and a costly social problem. Recent proposals to combat antibiotic resistance focus largely on supply-side approaches. Suggestions include gaming patent rights to give drug companies greater incentives to discover new antibiotics, as well as to resist overselling their new drugs already on the market. This article argues that an emphasis primarily on the supply side unfortunately diverts attention from the important demand-side influences of physicians. Physicians have a vital and inevitably necessary role to play in ensuring socially optimal access to antibiotics. Unfortunately, doctors' management of the antibiotic supply has been poor and their defense of the health of the population lukewarm at best. Acting as a prudent steward of the antibiotic supply often appears to be at odds with a physician's commonly understood fiduciary duties, ethical obligations, and professional standards, all of which traditionally emphasize the individual health paradigm as opposed to health responsibilities. of the population. Meanwhile, clinicians face limited incentives to conserve antibiotics from other sources, such as malpractice liability, regulatory standards, and reimbursement systems. While multifaceted efforts are needed to combat antibiotic resistance effectively, clinicians' vigilance behavior must become a priority area of attention. This article considers how health law and policy tools could favorably change the incentives physicians face to conserve antibiotics. A clear lesson from the managed care reform battles of the recent past is that interventions, to have the best chance of success, must respect the physician's interest in clinical autonomy and individualized medicine, even if, paradoxically, they vigorously promote the health prospects of the population. Furthermore, the legal and ethical obligations of physicians need to be reconceptualized in the context of antibiotics to better support policing in defense of population health. The main recommendation is greater use of financial incentives to reward physicians for adhering to recommended antibiotic prescribing guidelines. Although not a panacea, further experimentation with financial incentives may provide a much-needed boost to physician interest in antibiotic conservation and likely better address legitimate concerns of physician clinical autonomy.

title: In treatment-resistant depression, adding cognitive behavioral therapy to usual care was cost-effective at 1 year.
abstract: Question In primary care patients with treatment-resistant depression, is it cost-effective to add individual cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) to usual care? Methods Design Cost-utility analysis from the perspective of the UK's National Health Service (NHS) and Personal Social Services (PSS) based on 1-year follow-up of a randomized controlled trial (CoBalT trial). Establishment of primary care practices in Bristol, Exeter and Glasgow, UK. Patients 469 patients aged 18 to 75 years (mean age 50 years, 72% women) who adhered to antidepressant medication for 6 weeks but continued to have depressive symptoms, who were diagnosed with depression using the Revised Schedule of Clinical Interviews and had a Beck Depression Inventory (BDI)-II Score 14. Individual CBT intervention, 12 to 18 one-hour sessions conducted in primary care practices or similar settings, plus usual care (n = 234), or usual care alone (n = 235). Usual care might include antidepressant medications. Results Response to treatment (50% reduction in BDI-II score)"; quality-adjusted life years (QALYs), based on EQ-5D-3L scores and quality of life assessments of the UK general population; costs in 2010 British pounds sterling {UK Âª1 = US $1.56}*;" and the incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER). Costs included NHS and PSS costs obtained from primary care records, CBT therapist records and patient questionnaires. Follow-up was 83% to 84% for clinical outcomes and 78% for health and social costs at one year. Main results Adding CBT to usual care reduced symptoms of depression and increased QALYs (Table). CBT plus usual care costs more than usual care alone (Table), with an ICER of 14,911 (US$23,261) per QALY earned over 12 months. In sensitivity analyzes using the Short Form-6 dimensions algorithm to estimate QALYs, the ICER was 29,626 (US$46,217). Conclusion In primary care patients with treatment-resistant depression in the UK, adding cognitive behavioral therapy to usual care was cost-effective after 1 year.

title: Inclusion and exclusion criteria in randomized controlled trials of psychotherapy for PTSD
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a common and often disabling condition. Fortunately, there are effective psychological treatments for PTSD. However, research indicates that these treatments may be underused in clinical practice. One reason for this underuse may be the unwarranted exclusion of patients from these treatments by clinicians based on their understanding of the exclusion criteria used in clinical trials of psychological treatments for PTSD. There is no comprehensive and up-to-date review of the inclusion and exclusion criteria used in randomized clinical trials (RCTs) of psychological treatments for PTSD. Therefore, we aimed to better understand how patients were excluded from such RCTs in order to provide guidance to clinicians regarding clinical populations likely to benefit from these treatments. METHODS: We conducted a comprehensive literature review of RCTs of psychological treatments for PTSD from January 1, 1980, to April 1, 2012. We classified these clinical trials according to the types of psychotherapy discussed in the main guidelines for the treatment of PTSD. PTSD and we review all treatments. that were studied in at least two RCTs (N = 64 published studies with 75 intervention arms as some studies compared two or more interventions). We summarize and tabulate information on exclusion criteria for each type of PTSD psychotherapy. RESULTS: We identified multiple RCTs of cognitive behavioral therapy (n = 56), eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (n = 11), and group psychotherapy (n = 8) for PTSD. The most common exclusions were psychosis, substance abuse and dependence, bipolar disorder, and suicidal ideation. Clinical trials varied in the severity with which these criteria were applied. It is important to note that no exclusion criteria were used in all studies and there was at least one study of each type of therapy that included patients from each of the commonly excluded groups. There is a paucity of evidence on the treatment of patients with PTSD and four co-morbidities: current alcohol and substance abuse or dependence, current psychosis, current mania, and current suicidal ideation. CONCLUSIONS: Psychological treatments for PTSD have been studied in large and representative clinical populations. It seems that more liberal use of these treatments is warranted regardless of comorbidities.

title: INCOG Recommendations for the Management of Cognition After Traumatic Brain Injury, Part III: Executive Function and Self-Awareness
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) produces complex cognitive (and other) sequelae. Deficits in executive function and self-awareness are among the most characteristic neuropsychological sequelae and can have a profound effect on resumption of previous life roles. An international group of researchers and clinicians (known as INCOG) met to develop recommendations for interventions to improve deficits in executive functioning and self-awareness after TBI. METHODS: The team reviewed the available literature and ensured that the recommendations were up to date. To promote implementation, the team developed decision algorithms that incorporate recommendations based on inclusion and exclusion criteria from published trials. The team then prioritized recommendations for implementation and developed audit criteria to assess compliance with the best practice recommendations. RESULTS: Intervention programs that incorporate instruction in metacognitive strategies for planning, problem solving, and other cognitive-executive deficits have a strong evidence base. New evidence supports the use of strategies to specifically improve reasoning skills. There is substantial support for the use of direct corrective feedback to improve self-awareness. CONCLUSIONS: A growing number of scientifically well-designed studies are available demonstrating the effectiveness of a variety of interventions to remedy deficits in executive function and self-awareness after TBI.

title: Increased compliance with an antibiotic prophylaxis guideline to prevent pediatric surgical site infection: before and after study
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate an intervention to improve compliance with antibiotic prophylaxis (AP) guidelines to prevent surgical site infections in children. BACKGROUND: Although adequate BP reduces surgical site infection and guidelines improve quality of care, changing practice is difficult. To facilitate behavior change, several barriers need to be addressed. METHODS: A multidisciplinary task force at a pediatric hospital developed an evidence-based AP guideline. Subsequently, the guideline was published in the operating rooms and the online form, only recommended antibiotics were available in the operating rooms, new interns received orientation, antibiotic verification was included in the waiting time, computerized alerts for postoperative prophylaxis were established inadequate and the surgeons received email. -mails when the guideline was not followed. The indication and administration of PA for surgical procedures was documented in July 2008 (pre-intervention), September 2011 (post-intervention) and April-May 2013 (follow-up). Compliance was defined as complete: appropriate antibiotic, dose, timing, redosing, and duration when prophylaxis was indicated; partial: appropriate drug and timing when prophylaxis was indicated; and appropriate use: complete compliance when prophylaxis was indicated, no antibiotics. when not indicated Pre-intervention and follow-up compliance was compared using chi-tests (2) RESULTS: PA was indicated in 43.9% (187/426) and 62.0% (124/200) of surgical procedures at pre-intervention and follow-up, respectively. There were significant improvements in appropriate use of antibiotics (51.6%-67.0%; P < 0.001), complete compliance (26.2%-53.2%; P <0.001) and partial (73.3%-88.7%, P = 0.001), correct dose (77.5%-90.7%; P = 0.003), time (83.3%-95.8% ; P = 0.001), redosing (62.5%-95.8%, P = 0.003), and duration (47.1%-65.3%);" p < 0.002). CONCLUSIONS: A multifaceted intervention improved adherence to a pediatric BP guideline.

title: Increased compliance to low tidal volume ventilation in the ICU with two stimulus-based interventions: assessment through intervention time series analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Low tidal volume ventilation (LVT) improves outcomes for ventilated patients, and most clinicians report implementing it. Unfortunately, most patients never receive low VTs. Nudges influence decision making with subtle cognitive mechanisms and are effective in many contexts. There have been few studies examining its impact on clinical decision making. We investigated the impact of 2 interventions designed using behavioral science principles on the deployment of low-eVT ventilation in the intensive care unit (ICU). SETTING: University Hospitals Bristol, a 20-bed mixed tertiary medical and surgical ICU, admitting more than 1,300 patients per year. PARTICIPANTS: Data were collected from 2144 consecutive patients receiving controlled mechanical ventilation for more than 1 hour between October 2010 and September 2014. Patients receiving controlled mechanical ventilation for more than 20 hours were included in the final analysis. INTERVENTIONS: (1) Default ventilator settings were adjusted to meet low TVe targets from the start of ventilation, unless actively changed by a clinician. (2) Implemented a large dashboard displaying TVs in ml/kg ideal body weight (IBW) format with alerts when TVs were excessive. PRIMARY OUTCOME MEASUREMENT: TVe in mL/kg IBW. FINDINGS: TVe was significantly lower in the noncompliance group. In the scorecard intervention, TVe fell more rapidly and to a greater extent after a TVe of 8 mL/kg PCI was breached compared with controls. This effect improved in each subsequent year for 3 years. CONCLUSIONS: This study has shown that adjusting the ventilator default settings and an alert dashboard for excessive VTe can significantly influence clinical decision making. This offers a promising strategy for improving compliance with low TVe ventilation and suggests that the use of behavioral science insights has the potential to improve the translation of evidence into practice.

title: Increasing the quantity and quality of the search for the current best evidence to answer clinical questions: protocol and intervention design of the MacPLUS FS factorial randomized controlled trials
abstract: Background and objectives Finding the current best evidence for clinical decisions remains a challenge. With 3,000 new studies published every day, no evidence-based resource provides all the answers or is sufficiently up-to-date. McMaster Premium LiteratUre Service - Federated Search (MacPLUS FS) solves this problem by searching multiple high-quality resources simultaneously and displaying the results in a one-page pyramid with the most clinically useful at the top. However, additional logistical and educational barriers need to be addressed to improve evidence retrieval at the point of care. This trial seeks to test three innovative interventions, among MacPLUS FS-registered clinicians, to increase the quantity and quality of the search for the best current evidence to answer clinical questions. Methods and design In a user-centered approach, we designed three interventions embedded in MacPLUS FS: (A) a web-based clinical question recorder"; (B) an evidence retrieval trainer comprised of eight short educational videos"; (C) an audit, feedback, and gamification approach to evidence retrieval, based on the assignment of "badges" and "reputation scores." We will conduct a randomized factorial controlled trial among the 904 eligible physicians currently registered with MacPLUS. FS at hospitals affiliated with McMaster University, Canada. Graduate students (n = 429) and faculty/clinical staff (n = 475) will be randomly assigned to each of the following three interventions in a factorial design (A x B x C). Utilization will be continuously recorded through clinician accounts that track logins and usage, down to the level of individual keystrokes. The primary outcome is the rate of searches per month per user during the six months of follow-up. Secondary outcomes, measured through the validated Impact Evaluation Method questionnaire, include: usefulness of the answers found (meeting the information needs of physicians), use (application in practice), and perceived usefulness in patient outcomes. . Discussion Building on effective models for teaching at the point of care, these interventions address evidence retrieval as a clinical skill. If effective, they may offer the opportunity to improve it for a large audience, at low cost, by providing better access to relevant evidence in many of the leading EBM resources in parallel.

title: Cholesterol-Lowering Medication Indications: Comparison of Risk Assessment Methods
abstract: Background Recommendations for the prescription of lipid-lowering drugs emphasize the importance of an assessment of the absolute risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) based on all risk factors, rather than simply serum cholesterol concentration. However, if the recommended methods for risk assessment are inaccurate, the recommended prescription will not be made. We compared various sets of guidelines for such treatment in a series of patients referred to a lipid clinic, to assess the difference in the degree of CHD risk at which lipid-lowering medication is recommended under each set of guidelines.";" Background Recommendations for the prescription of lipid-lowering drugs emphasize the importance of an assessment of the absolute risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) based on all risk factors, rather than simply serum cholesterol concentration. However, if the recommended methods for risk assessment are inaccurate, the recommended prescription will not be made. We compared various sets of guidelines for such treatment in a series of patients referred to a lipid clinic, to assess the difference in the degree of CHD risk at which lipid-lowering medication is recommended under each set of guidelines.

title: Individualized treatment goals for elderly patients with type 2 diabetes using vildagliptin as add-on or sole therapy (INTERVAL): a 24-week randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study
abstract: Background Guidelines suggest setting individualized goals for glycemic control in elderly patients with type 2 diabetes, despite the lack of evidence. Our objective was to assess the feasibility of setting and achieving individualized goals over 24 weeks in conjunction with conventional HbA1c lowering using vildagliptin versus placebo.";" Background Guidelines suggest setting individualized goals for glycemic control in elderly patients with type 2 diabetes, despite the lack of evidence. Our objective was to assess the feasibility of setting and achieving individualized goals over 24 weeks in conjunction with conventional HbA1c lowering using vildagliptin versus placebo.

title: Individuals with low back pain: how do they see physical activity?
abstract: BACKGROUND: Recent guidelines for people with acute low back pain have recommended early resumption of normal activity and increased physical activity. Little is known about the relationship between low back pain and physical activity, and about the impact of that relationship in promoting higher levels of physical activity within a general practice population. OBJECTIVES: Our aim was to explore associations between factors influencing changes in physical activity and how people perceive and behave with their low back pain, and the impact of those perceptions and behavior on physical activity. METHODS: Twenty-seven informants were chosen using a purposive sample from a larger group of people who, because of their low back problem, had been referred by their GPs to a community-based single-blind randomized controlled trial (RCT) at the University of York, which is evaluating the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a progressive exercise program. 54 interviews were conducted with this subgroup of the RCT";" four informants were interviewed once, 19 twice and four of them three times. Interviews were transcribed and analyzed using manual and computer-assisted approaches. RESULTS: Physical activity was perceived as (i) activities of daily living, (ii) dyspnea-causing activities that deviated from doing, and (iii) more competitive-type activity. Avoidance of physical activity and fear of recurrence of pain were the two main factors directly associated with informants' back and changes in physical activity. These two factors hindered the increase in physical activity, although most informants strongly believed that physical activity helped relieve low back pain. CONCLUSIONS: When advocating that people with acute low back pain return to or increase physical activity, it is important for clinicians to identify physical activity avoidance and/or fear of pain at the earliest stage in order to tailor counseling and reassurance. properly. If activity avoidance and fear of pain are identified and clinicians want to encourage patients to engage in and maintain increased physical activity, they should explore issues of fear of pain and avoidance and confidence in doing physical activity, in addition to other factors that influence physical activity.

title: Inequalities among the very poor: health care for children in rural southern Tanzania
abstract: Background Few studies have been conducted to assess socioeconomic inequalities in health in African countries. We seek evidence of inequalities in health care by sex and socioeconomic status for young children living in a poor rural area of southern Tanzania.";" Background Few studies have been conducted to assess socioeconomic inequalities in health in African countries. We seek evidence of inequalities in health care by sex and socioeconomic status for young children living in a poor rural area of southern Tanzania.

title: Infectious diseases in general practice and prescription of antibiotics. Observational study in Sicily
abstract: Medicine utilization studies have shown wide differences, between different countries, in prescribing behavior in general practice. In Italy, for example, the choice of antibiotic prescription seems to show a broader use of the parental antibiotic. The aim of this study was to describe the pattern of antibiotic prescription and therapeutic doses used by Sicilian general practitioners (GPs) and to assess their prescribing attitudes regarding the use of parental ones. Each physician had to complete a questionnaire for each therapeutic intervention completed with antibiotic prescription during a period of 6 months. Diagnoses and drugs were classified according to the International Classification of Diseases (ICD-10) and the Anatomical Therapeutic Chemical Classification (ATC), respectively. On 9,395 prescriptions made by 76 doctors in 25 Sicilian cities, the analysis indicated that acute respiratory symptoms represent the most common indication (31.7%) for a medical consultation, and that macrolides [such as azithromycin (8.8%) and clarithromycin (8.3%)], Penicillin [as amoxicillin (7.1%) and co-amoxiclav (8.4%)], III generation Cephalosporins [as cefixime (5.5%) and ceftriaxone ( 5.1%)] represent the most used therapeutic groups. The choice of route of administration was influenced by the age of the patients and, more significantly, by the symptoms and signs of the disease, rather than by the bacteria suspected of causing the disease. In conclusion, our data clearly indicate the lack of awareness of antibacterial therapy guidelines among Sicilian physicians, as well as the need for independent educational training to improve antibiotic knowledge and decrease the cost of health care.

title: Influence of patient requests for advertised direct-to-consumer antidepressants: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Context Direct-to-consumer (DTC) advertising of prescription drugs in the United States is pervasive and controversial. Critics say it leads to overprescribing, while advocates counter that it helps prevent underuse of effective treatments, especially for underrecognized or stigmatized conditions. Objective To determine the effects of patients' DTC-related requests on clinicians' initial treatment decisions in patients with depressive symptoms. Design Randomized trial with standardized patients (SP). Six SP roles were created by crossing 2 conditions (major depression or adjustment disorder with depressed mood) with 3 request types (brand-specific, general, or none). Setting Primary care physician offices in Sacramento, California; San francisco California; and Rochester, NY, between May 2003 and May 2004. Participants One hundred fifty-two family physicians and general internists recruited from individual and group practices and health maintenance organizations;" cooperation rates ranged from 53% to 61% Interventions HCPs were randomly assigned to 298 unannounced visits, with restricted assignments, whereby clinicians saw 1 HCP with major depression and 1 with adjustment disorder HCPs made a specific brand-name medication request, a general medication request or no request (control condition) in approximately one-third of visits Main outcome measures Data on prescribing, mental health referral, and primary care follow-up obtained from written SP reports, audio recordings of visits , chart review, and analysis of written prescriptions and drug samples The effects of type of request on the Prescriptions were assessed using contingency tables and confirmed in generalized linear mixed models accounting for clustering and adjusting for site, physician, and visit characteristics. Results Standardized patient role fidelity was excellent, and the rate of suspicion that physicians had seen a PS was 13%. In major depression, antidepressant prescription rates were 53%, 76%, and 31% for HCPs making brand-specific, general, and no-requests, respectively (p < 0.001). In adjustment disorder, antidepressant prescription rates were 55%, 39%, and 10%, respectively (p < 0.001). The results were confirmed in multivariate models. Minimally acceptable initial care (any combination of an antidepressant, mental health referral, or follow-up within 2 weeks) was offered to 98% of HCPs in the major depression role presenting a blanket request, 90% of those presenting a specific trademark request, and 56% of those who did not request it (p < 0.001). Conclusions Patient requests have a profound effect on prescribing in major depression and adjustment disorder. Direct-to-consumer advertising can have competitive effects on quality, potentially preventing underuse and promoting overuse.

title: Influence on lifestyle measures and five-year coronary risk by a comprehensive lifestyle intervention program in patients with coronary heart disease
abstract: BACKGROUND: Lifestyle measures for the prevention of coronary heart disease (CHD) have been overshadowed by the efficacy of pharmacological treatments. This is particularly the case in the context of secondary prevention where the benefits of lipid-lowering, antiplatelet, and antihypertensive drugs have been emphasized in numerous trials. Lifestyle measures address several CHD risk factors at once and usually don't have serious side effects. OBJECTIVES: The objective of the present study was to determine whether a comprehensive lifestyle modification program could favorably influence dietary and exercise habits in addition to smoking cessation over two years. In addition, an attempt was made to assess whether this program could favorably influence the risk of CHD at five years in the male population included in the study. DESIGN: A total of 197 patients with proven coronary artery disease were enrolled and randomized to a lifestyle intervention program or usual care. Follow-up was after a period of two years. METHODS: The intervention comprised a low-fat diet, regular exercise, smoking cessation, psychosocial support, and education, delivered by nurses, on the rationale for pharmacological and lifestyle measures. Usual care included routine outpatient follow-up. Both groups received the same comprehensive medication according to recent guidelines. RESULTS: Patients in the lifestyle intervention group reduced their intake of saturated fat, sugar, and cholesterol (P<0.001), increased their level of exercise (P<0.01), and quit smoking (P<0.001). 05) compared to the usual care group. A subanalysis of the influence of the estimated 5-year CHD risk in men resulted in a relative risk reduction of 22% (95% confidence intervals 9-35). Although significant, this result should be interpreted with caution due to the low statistical power and reproducibility of the method. CONCLUSIONS: In the presence of modern pharmacological treatments for the secondary prevention of cardiovascular diseases, it remains possible, through favorable diet, exercise, and smoking cessation, to show a further reduction in the 5-year risk of CHD in men.

title: Influences of educational interventions and adverse news about calcium channel blockers on first-line prescribing of antihypertensive drugs to older people in British Columbia.
abstract: Background There is a need to better understand how the dissemination of evidence changes medical practice. The controversy over calcium channel blockers (CCBs) over the past 3 years has provided a natural experiment, allowing for impact assessment of media stories, a national warning letter, a teleconference, small group workshops and informative bulletins on the prescription of first-line antihypertensives. drugs.";" Background There is a need to better understand how the dissemination of evidence changes medical practice. The controversy over calcium channel blockers (CCBs) over the past 3 years has provided a natural experiment, allowing for impact assessment of media stories, a national warning letter, a teleconference, small group workshops and informative bulletins on the prescription of first-line antihypertensives. drugs

title: Influencing antibiotic prescribing through prescriber feedback and management guidelines: a 5-year follow-up.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The extent of antibiotic use for upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) prompted a previous study of an educational intervention based on prescriber feedback and management guidelines. This study demonstrated a reduction in antibiotic prescription for URTIs and a more appropriate choice of antibiotics for tonsillitis/strep throat. There are few long-term follow-up studies of educational programs of this type. OBJECTIVES: This follow-up study aimed to examine whether the reduction in antibiotic prescribing seen in the original study's intervention group remained present after 5 years, and how the prescribing behavior of GPs involved in follow-up differed. of a large national group. medical prescription survey. METHODS: Attempts were made to contact all 157 GPs involved in the original study. Of these, 121 were located and currently working in general practice. Ninety-six agreed to participate, and of these, 79 completed a morbidity and treatment survey of 100 patient encounters (65.3% response rate). RESULTS: The intervention group (n = 37) maintained their pattern of antibiotic prescription for URTIs and choice of antibiotics for tonsillitis/strep throat, with no significant changes between completion of the original study and 5-year follow-up. The control group (n = 42) showed a downward trend in antibiotic prescription for URTIs, with the effect that no significant differences remained between groups at 5-year follow-up. At 5-year follow-up, both groups prescribed significantly fewer antibiotics for URTIs and showed greater adherence to prescribing guidelines for tonsillitis/strep throat than did participants in a large national survey of GPs (n = 984). CONCLUSION: This study demonstrated maintenance of prescribing behavior in the intervention group over the long term. However, the changes in prescribing seen in the control group and the power limitations of the study make it unclear whether this was the result of a sustained effect of the educational intervention. Differences in both groups from the large national survey of GPs suggest that other prescribing influences (such as participation in professional training for general practice) were also having an important effect.

title: Influencing antibiotic prescribing in general practice: an essay of prescriber feedback and management guidelines.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The extent of antibiotic use to treat upper respiratory tract infections in general practice is an area of concern due to the growing problem of bacterial resistance. Effective educational strategies are needed to promote rational prescribing. OBJECTIVES: Our aim was to examine the effectiveness of prescriber feedback and management guidelines in reducing antibiotic prescribing by trainee GPs for undifferentiated upper respiratory tract infection and in improving antibiotic choice for tonsillitis/strep throat. The research tested a stepwise approach to targeting educational information to the most frequent prescribers. METHOD: General practitioners in New South Wales (n = 157) were randomly assigned to a treatment group (n = 78) that received an educational intervention on antibiotic use, or to a control group (n = 79). ) who received an intervention on the use of antibiotics. an unrelated topic. Trainees completed three practice activity surveys, each of 110 consecutive patient encounters, with 6-month intervals between surveys. Prescriber comments and management guidelines on antibiotic use for URTIs and antibiotic choice for tonsillitis/strep throat were provided in writing between surveys 1 and 2. A visit was conducted between surveys 2 and 3. educational to prescribers. Outcome measures were antibiotic prescription rate for all indications, for URTIs, and prescription of selected antibiotics for tonsillitis/strep throat. RESULTS: Antibiotic prescription by the intervention group decreased three times from 25.0 to 23.3 to 19.7 per 100 URTI problems, while the control group increased from 22.0 to 25.0 at 31.7 per 100 URTI problems (P = 0.002). Prescribing according to accepted guidelines for tonsillitis/strep throat increased over time in the intervention group from 55.6 to 69.8 to 73.0 per 100 problems, but decreased in the control group from 59.6 to 57.5 to 58.5 (P = 0.05). CONCLUSION: Prescriber feedback and management guidelines have been shown to influence antibiotic prescription for URTIs and choice of antibiotics for tonsillitis/strep throat. This study provides a model for targeting educational information to those prescribers who most need to change their behavior.

title: Information technologies for patient safety
abstract: Background Research on patient care has identified substantial variations in the quality and safety of medical care and considerable risks of iatrogenic harm as major problems. These failures contribute to the high rates of potentially avoidable morbidity and mortality and the rising levels of health care spending seen in many health systems. There have been substantial advances in information technology in recent decades and there is now real potential to apply these technological advances to improve the provision of healthcare universally. Of particular international interest is the use of eHealth applications. However, there is a large gap between the theoretical and empirically proven benefits of eHealth applications. While these apps often have the technical ability to assist professionals in the delivery of health care, inadequate attention to the sociotechnical dimensions of their use can lead to new avoidable risks for patients. Results and discussion Given the current lack of evidence on improvements in quality and safety and on the cost-benefits associated with the introduction of eHealth applications, there should be a focus on the implementation of more mature technologies";" It is also important that eHealth applications are assessed against a comprehensive and rigorous set of measures, ideally at all stages of their application lifecycle.

title: Informed consent in clinical research in a general hospital in Mexico: opinions of researchers
abstract: In Mexico, informed consent is a legal requirement that ensures that patients who are invited to participate in clinical trials have all the information necessary to decide whether or not to participate in a research protocol. To improve our understanding of the problems physicians in developing countries face when obtaining informed consent (IC), we examined their opinion on the importance of IC in clinical research, the quantity and quality of information provided to the participant, and the conditions under which the IC is obtained. The researchers felt that the CI was useful to patients, providing information that helped the patient make a decision about participation. However, they felt that for some aspects of the research, such as drug development in general, the use of placebos, and the randomization process, many of the patients were not able to fully understand the information provided, referring to the complexity of the information and illiteracy as the main reason. Many researchers were unaware of some of the guidelines established in the General Health Law of Mexico,(1) 36% of them admitted not having completed their IC letters. Most investigators gave the patient only a few minutes to make a decision, and 20% of the IQs were obtained while the patient was hospitalized. Except for one researcher, all considered that specific training in medical ethics would be useful for daily clinical work.

title: Informed consent in human experimentation before the Nuremberg code
abstract: The question of ethics regarding medical experimentation in Germany during the 1930s and 1940s was crucial in the Nuremberg trials and related trials of physicians and public health officials. Those involved in horrible crimes tried to excuse themselves by arguing that there were no explicit rules governing medical research on human beings in Germany during the period and that research practices in Germany were no different from those in allied countries. In this context, the 1947 Nuremberg code is generally considered to be the first document to establish ethical standards in human experimentation based on informed consent. However, new research indicates that the ethical issues of informed consent in guidelines for human experimentation were recognized as early as the 19th century. These guidelines shed light on the still controversial question of when the concepts of autonomy, informed consent, and therapeutic and non-therapeutic research first emerged. This topic assumes renewed importance in the context of current attempts to assess responsibility for the abuse of persons in various experiments conducted since World War II in the United States, Canada, Russia, and other nations.

title: Informed consent: coronary artery bypass graft
abstract: Coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery is a well-documented procedure. Despite the increased prevalence of percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), surgical revascularization will continue to play an important role in patients with coronary artery disease. As previous clinical studies have shown, clinicians can provide patients with important information about risk-adjusted outcomes. Various databases have been used to develop risk models to predict morbidity and mortality in patients undergoing CABG. Patients must choose between CABG and PCI based on the explanations of the doctors. Major trials have shown a marked survival benefit of CABG among those patients at high risk of death from the disease itself, defined by severity of angina, number of affected vessels, and left ventricular function. However, it is not clear that patients always receive the correct information about whether CABG or PCI is the most appropriate procedure. Initial informed consent must be obtained using relevant guidelines by an independent assessor.

title: Informed shared decision making supported by decision advisors for women with ductal carcinoma in situ: study protocol for a cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Women with breast cancer want to be involved in making treatment decisions. The guidelines have confirmed the right to shared and informed decision-making. However, previous research has shown that the implementation of shared and informed decision making is not optimal due to limited physician resources, power imbalances between patients and physicians, and lack of evidence-based patient information. We developed an informed shared decision-making program for women with primary ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). The program provides decision-making guidance to women by specialist nurses and aims to support participation in informed decision-making and choices. In this trial, the informed shared decision-making program in breast care settings will be evaluated. METHODS/DESIGN: A cluster randomized controlled trial will be conducted to compare the informed shared decision making program with standard care. The program includes evidence-based patient decision support and training for physicians (2 hours) and oncology and breast care nurse practitioners (4 days) in shared and informed decision making. Sixteen certified breast care centers will be included, and 192 women with primary DCIS will be recruited. The primary outcome is the degree of patient participation in shared decision making as assessed by MAPPIN-Odyad (multifocal approach to 'sharing' in shared decision making: observer instrument dyad). Secondary endpoints include MAPPIN inventory submeasures (MAPPIN-Onurse, MAPPIN-Omedical, MAPPIN-Opatient, MAPPIN-Qnurse, MAPPIN-Qpatient, and MAPPIN-Qmedical), informed choice, decisional conflict, and duration of encounters . Preparation for decision making and the provision of evidence-based patient decision aids are expected to increase patients' involvement in decision making with informed choices and reduce decision conflicts and length of stay. meetings with the doctor. In addition, an evaluation of the accompaniment process will be carried out. DISCUSSION: To our knowledge, this is the first study investigating the implementation of decision coaches in German breast care centers. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN46305518, registration date: June 5, 2015.

title: Infrastructure for Quality Transformation: Measurement and Reporting in Veterans Administration Intensive Care Units
abstract: Background The Veterans Health Administration (VA) intensive care units (ICUs) develop an infrastructure for quality improvement using information technology and leadership in recruitment. Methods Setting The participation of the 183 ICUs in the quality improvement program is required. The infrastructure includes measurement (electronic data mining, analytics), quarterly web-based reporting, and support for implementing evidence-based practices. Leaders prioritize actions based on quality improvement goals. The electronic extraction is manually validated against the medical record, selecting hospitals whose data elements and measures fall at the extremes (10th, 90th percentile). The results are represented in graphic, narrative and tabular reports compared by type and complexity of the ICU. Results The VA admits 103?689±1156 patients in the ICU/year. Variation in electronic business practices, data location, and the normal range of some laboratory tests affect data quality. A data management website captures data elements important to UCI performance that are not available electronically. A dashboard manages data overload (quarterly reports range from 106 to 299 pages). More than 85% of ICU directors and nursing managers review their reports. Leadership interest is maintained by including UCI goals in executive performance contracts, identifying local improvement opportunities with analytics software, and focused reviews. Conclusion Relevant lessons for non-VA institutions include: (1) the need for ongoing data validation, (2) the essential involvement of leadership at multiple levels, (3) the supplementation of electronic data when key elements are absent, (4) the usefulness of a good but not perfect electronic gauge to move practice while improving data elements, and (5) the value of a dashboard.

title: Start of quality improvement activities in mental health services
