abstract: In the realm of public sector mental health services, responsibility for quality has often been viewed as the responsibility of the individual physician. This presents a particular challenge in introducing an organization-wide quality improvement culture in this environment. The introduction of a systemic view of quality may be resisted by individual physicians reluctant to accept that some clinical autonomy must be subsumed within more standardized patterns of intervention and evaluation. Services must first address the issue of preparing physicians to adopt such a culture, which requires strong direction from the executive level. The area of newly diagnosed psychosis in a public sector mental health service was selected as a starting point to initiate the culture of quality improvement. The end result for the organization has been a positive commitment to improvement, but the journey was long and difficult. This document describes the beginning of this ultimately rewarding journey.

title: Innovative strategy to implement chronic heart failure guidelines among family physicians in different healthcare settings in Berlin
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The aim of this study was to improve drug therapy for patients with chronic heart failure (CHF). METHODS AND RESULTS: This prospective pilot intervention study was conducted with a comparative cross-sectional analysis before and after the intervention. Usual pharmacotherapy was observed for 8 months in two different outpatient healthcare settings in Berlin [11 family physicians from individual GP practices (IGP) and 12 working in a medical care center (MCC)]. Health care centers provide a novel structure for outpatient care and have recently been introduced in Germany. The subsequent intervention involved implementation of heart failure guidelines via a computer-based reminder system, followed by a renewed cross-sectional observation of prescribing behavior over 1 year. Family physicians recruited patients, assessed the severity of congestive heart failure according to NYHA class, and referred patients for echocardiography. The study included 190 patients in the baseline phase and 209 in the intervention phase. Longitudinal follow-up was performed in 172 cases. Echocardiography was requested by 94.6% of the MCC physicians and 79.9% of the IGP. Undermedication was observed in both settings. Guideline-based beta-blocker therapy was prescribed for 46.3% of patients (44.8% of IGPs and 48.5% of MCC-GPs). The prescription improved by 12.3% after the intervention. There were marked deficiencies in the prescription of aldosterone antagonists (35%) for severe heart failure, which improved to 44.2% after the intervention. CONCLUSION: The problem of inadequate implementation of evidence-based therapy for congestive heart failure was partially overcome by the use of the reminder system, which provided participating physicians with brief guideline recommendations during the intervention phase.

title: Computerized inpatient standing orders versus physician reminders to increase influenza and pneumococcal vaccination rates: a randomized trial.
abstract: Context Computerized reminder systems increase influenza and pneumococcal vaccination rates, but computerized standing order systems have not been previously described or evaluated. Objective To determine the effects of computerized physician orders compared with physician reminders on vaccination rates in hospitalized patients. Design, Setting, and Patients Randomized trial of 3777 general practice patients discharged from 1 of 6 study wards over a 14-month period (November 1, 1998 to December 31, 1999) comprised of 2 overlapping influenza seasons in an urban public university hospital. Interventions The hospital's computerized physician order entry system identified hospitalized patients eligible for influenza and pneumococcal vaccination. For patients with standing orders, the system automatically produced vaccine orders addressed to nurses at the time of patient discharge. For patients with reminders, the computer system provided physicians with reminders that included vaccine orders during routine order entry sessions. Main outcome measure Vaccine administration. Results During the approximately 6-month influenza season, 50% of all hospitalized patients were identified as eligible for influenza vaccination. Twenty-two percent of patients hospitalized during the entire 14-month study period were eligible for pneumococcal vaccination. Patients with standing orders received an influenza vaccine much more often (42%) than those with reminders (30%) (p < 0.001). Patients with standing orders received a pneumococcal vaccine significantly more often (51%) than those with reminders (31%) (p < 0.001). Conclusions Computerized standing orders were more effective than computerized reminders in increasing administration of influenza and pneumococcal vaccines. Our findings suggest that computerized standing orders should be used more widely for this purpose.

title: Insomnia
Integrated guide on the care of familial hypercholesterolemia from the FH International Foundation
abstract: Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is a predominantly inherited disorder present from birth that markedly elevates plasma low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol and causes premature coronary heart disease. There are at least 20 million people with HF worldwide, but most go undetected and current treatment is often suboptimal. To address this important gap in coronary prevention, we present, from an international perspective, a consensus-based guideline on HF care. The guide was generated from seminars and workshops held at an international symposium. The recommendations focus on the detection, diagnosis, evaluation, and treatment of HF in adults and children, and establish guidelines for clinical purposes. They also address best practices for cascading screening and risk notification and testing of families for FH, including the use of genetic testing. Treatment guidance is based on risk stratification, management of noncholesterol risk factors, and the safe and effective use of LDL cholesterol-lowering therapies. Recommendations on lipoprotein apheresis are given. The use of emerging therapies for HF is also heralded. This international guideline acknowledges gaps in evidence, but aims to make the best use of contemporary practice and technology to achieve the best outcomes for HF care. Consequently, it should be used to inform clinical judgment and be tailored to local and country-specific health care needs and resources.

title: Integrated motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy for people with comorbid psychosis and substance abuse: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVES To assess the effectiveness of integrated motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy in addition to standard care for people with psychosis and a comorbid substance use problem. DESIGN Two-centre, evaluator-blind, open-label, randomized controlled trial. SCOPE Secondary care in the UK. PARTICIPANTS 327 patients with a clinical diagnosis of schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, or schizoaffective disorder and a diagnosis of drug or alcohol dependence or abuse, or both, according to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, fourth edition. INTERVENTION The intervention consisted of integrated motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy plus standard care, which was compared with standard care alone. Phase one of the therapy, "building motivation," is concerned with engaging the patient, then exploring and resolving ambivalence for change in substance use. Phase two, "Action," supports and facilitates change using cognitive-behavioral approaches. Up to 26 therapy sessions were delivered over a year. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was death from any cause or hospital admission within 12 months of completion of treatment. Secondary outcomes were frequency and amount of substance use (assessed using the timeline tracking method), readiness to change, perceived negative consequences of use, ratings of psychotic symptoms, number and relapse duration and global assessment of functioning and deliberate self-harm at 12 and 12 years. 24 months, with additional follow-up evaluations at 6 and 18 months. Analysis was by intention to treat and produced robust estimates of treatment effect. RESULTS 327 participants were randomly assigned to the intervention (n=164) or treatment as usual (n=163). At 24 months, 326 (99.7%) were evaluated for the primary endpoint and 246 (75.2%) for the main secondary endpoints. Treatment had no beneficial effect on hospital admissions or death during follow-up, with 23.3% (38/163) of the therapy group and 20.2% (33/163) of controls dying or admitted (adjusted odds ratio 1.16, 95% confidence interval). 0.68 to 1.99"; P = 0.579). Therapy had no effect on frequency of substance use or perceived negative consequences of misuse, but did have a statistically significant effect on amount of substance consumed per day. substance use (adjusted OR for primary substance 1.50, 95% CI 1.08 to 2.09; P = 0.016; and all substances 1.48, 95% CI 1.07 to 2 .05, P=0.017) Treatment had a statistically significant effect on willingness to switch use at 12 months (adjusted OR 2.05, 95% CI 1.26 to 3.31, P=0.004) which was not maintained at 24 months (0.78, 95% CI 0.48 to 1.28, P=0.320).There was no effect of treatment on clinical outcomes such as relapses, psychotic symptoms, functioning and CONCLUSIONS Integrated motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy for people with psychosis and substance abuse do not improve outcome in terms of hospitalization, results symptoms or functioning. This approach reduces the amount of substance used for at least a year after completion of therapy. TRIAL REGISTRATION Current controlled trials: ISRCTN14404480.

title: Integration of "Back to Sleep" recommendations in neonatal ICU practice
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES: The American Academy of Pediatrics emphasizes that NICUs should support and model recommendations for reducing the risk of sudden infant death syndrome significantly before early infant discharge. Medical staff are critical role models for parents, and how they position babies in the hospital strongly influences parenting practices at home. The goals of this project were to increase the percentage of infants following safe sleep practices in the NICU prior to discharge and to determine whether improving adherence to these practices would influence parental behavior at home. METHODS: An algorithm detailing when to initiate safe sleep practices, a "Back to Sleep" crib card, educational programs for nurses and parents, a crib audit tool, and post-discharge telephone reminders were developed as improvement intervention strategies. of quality. RESULTS: NICU compliance with the supine position increased from 39% to 83% (P < 0.001), provision of a firm sleeping surface increased from 5% to 96% (P < 0.001), and removal of soft objects of bed improved from 45% to 75% (P = 0.001). Using a post-discharge telephone survey, parental compliance with safe sleep practices was found to improve from 23% to 82% (p < 0.001). CONCLUSIONS: Multifactorial interventions improved adherence to safe sleep practices in the NICU and at home.

title: Integration of addiction treatment in primary care using mobile health technology: protocol for an implementation research study
abstract: Background Health care reform in the United States is encouraging Federally Qualified Health Centers and other primary care practices to integrate treatment for addiction and other behavioral health conditions into their practices. The potential of mobile health technologies to manage addiction and co-morbidities such as HIV in these settings is substantial but largely unproven. This document describes a protocol to evaluate the implementation of an integrated E-Health communication technology delivered via mobile phones, called Seva, in primary care settings. Seva is an evidence-based addiction treatment and recovery support system for patients and real-time case monitoring for clinicians. Methods/Design Our implementation strategy uses three models of organizational change: the program planning model to promote acceptance and sustainability, the NIATx quality improvement model to create a welcoming environment for change and research dissemination of Rogers Innovations, which makes it easy to adapt innovations to maximize their potential for adoption. We will implement Seva and conduct an intensive mixed-methods evaluation at three Federally Qualified Health Care Centers in the United States. Our non-concurrent multi-baseline design includes three periods Â¡Âª pre-test (ending in four months of preparation for deployment), active Seva deployment, and maintenance Â¡Âª with staggered deployment at six-month intervals across sites . The first site will serve as a pilot clinic. We will track the timing of intervention elements and assess study results within each dimension of the Reach, Efficacy, Adoption, Implementation, and Sustainability framework, including effects on clinicians, patients, and practices. Our mixed-methods approach will include both quantitative (eg, interrupted time-series analysis of treatment attendance, with clinics as the unit of analysis) and qualitative methods (eg, interviewing staff regarding adaptations to treatment). implementation protocol), and evaluation of implementation costs. Discussion If the implementation is successful, the field will have proven technology to help Federally Qualified Health Centers and affiliated organizations provide addiction treatment and recovery support, as well as a proven strategy for implementing the technology. Seva also has the potential to improve core elements of addiction treatment, such as the referral and treatment processes. A mobile addiction treatment technology and accompanying deployment model could provide a cost-effective means of improving the lives of patients with drug and alcohol problems.

title: Integration of evidence on patient preferences in health policy decisions: patient-VIP study protocol
abstract: Background Despite a strong move towards active patient participation in health policy decisions, systematic and explicit consideration of this research evidence on patient preferences appears limited. In addition, little is known about the views of various stakeholders regarding the consideration of research evidence on patient preferences in health care policy decisions. This article describes the protocol for an exploratory study on integrating research on patient preferences into health policy decisions. The study questions: the extent to which research evidence on patient preferences is considered in current procedures for health policy decisions; stakeholder views on integrating this type of evidence into health policy decisions; and what could be a decision framework for integrating such research evidence into health care policy decisions. Methods/Design The study is divided into three sub-studies, predominantly using qualitative methods. The first sub-study is a scoping review in five European countries to investigate whether and how research findings on patient preferences are considered in current procedures for coverage decisions and clinical practice guideline development The second sub-study is a qualitative study to explore the views of stakeholders regarding the possibilities of integrating evidence on patient preferences into the healthcare decision-making process in the Netherlands The third sub-study is the development of a framework decision for research on patient preferences. The framework will consist of: a process description regarding the place of evidence on patient preferences in the decision-making process;" and a taxonomy describing different terminologies and conceptualizations of Â¡Â®preferencesÂ¡Â¯ and a overview of existing methodologies for researching preferences The conceptual framework will be presented and discussed with experts Discussion This study will raise awareness of the existence and potential value of research evidence on patient preferences for policy decision making and provides information on methods for researching patient preferences and the barriers and facilitators to integrating such research into health care policy decisions The results of the study will be useful to researchers, guideline developers clinical practice, those responsible for health care policy medical tion and patient representatives.

title: Integrative medicine in residency education: skills development through online curriculum training
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The Integrative Medicine in Residency (IMR) program, a 200-hour Internet-based collaborative educational initiative, has been implemented in 8 family medicine residency programs and has shown potential to serve as a national model for incorporating training in medicine Integrative/complementary/alternative medicine in postgraduate medical education. INTERVENTION: Curriculum content was designed based on a needs assessment and a set of competencies for postgraduate medical education developed following the Accreditation Council for Postgraduate Medical Education outcome project guidelines. Content was delivered through distributed online learning and included on-site activities. A modular format allowed for flexible implementation in different residence settings. EVALUATION: TO ASSESS THE FEASIBILITY OF IMPLEMENTING THE CURRICULUM, A MULTIMODAL EVALUATION WAS USED, INCLUDING: (1) resident evaluation of the curriculum; (2) assessment of residents' competencies through medical knowledge tests, self-assessment, direct observations, and reflections;" and (3) residents' well-being and well-being through behavioral assessments. RESULTS: The Class of 2011 ( n = 61) had a high rate of completion of the curriculum in the first and second year (98.7% and 84.2%) and the course evaluations on the achievement of the objectives, the clinical utility and the functioning of technology were highly rated There was a statistically significant improvement in medical knowledge test scores for questions aligned with PGY-1 and PGY-2 course content CONCLUSIONS: The IMR program is a step forward in the national effort to make integrative medicine training available to clinicians on a large scale and is a success in terms of online education Evaluation suggests that this program is feasible to implement and ace ptable for residents despite the many pressures of residence.

title: Intensive research in the management of Hodgkin's disease
abstract: Ninety-eight patients with clinically localized Hodgkin's disease underwent laparotomy and splenectomy to determine the extent of microscopic spread. In 68 patients, the procedure was performed for untreated disease apparently confined above the diaphragm. Abdominal disease cannot be confidently excluded on the basis of a noninvasive investigation at presentation. Clinical evaluation of splenic disease was unreliable unless gross splenomegaly was present. Foot lymphography was accurate in evaluating para-aortic and iliac disease but was of no value in evaluating other intra-abdominal lymph node involvement, including mesenteric lymph node involvement. Trephine bone marrow biopsy findings were normal in all patients before surgery, and only one patient was found to have diseased bone marrow by Stryker saw biopsy at operation. Liver disease was identified at operation in nine patients, some of whom were asymptomatic with clinically undetectable splenic and nodal disease. Detailed clinical staging failed to detect disease in a third of patients who underwent laparotomy. These studies show that if radiation therapy remains the treatment of choice for truly localized lymph node disease, a detailed staging procedure, including laparotomy and splenectomy, remains essential. The value of this potentially curative treatment is greatly diminished in the patient who has not been adequately staged.

title: Intensive speech and language therapy in patients with chronic aphasia after stroke: a randomized, open-label, endpoint-blinded, controlled trial in a health care setting.
abstract: Background Aphasia treatment guidelines recommend intensive speech and language therapy for chronic aphasia (Ã¢â€°Â¥6 months) after stroke, but large-scale class 1 randomized controlled trials of treatment efficacy are poor. Our aim was to examine whether 3 weeks of intensive speech and language therapy under routine clinical conditions improved verbal communication in daily life situations in people with chronic aphasia after stroke.";" Background Aphasia treatment guidelines recommend intensive speech and language therapy for chronic aphasia (Ã¢â€°Â¥6 months) after stroke, but large-scale class 1 randomized controlled trials of treatment efficacy are poor. Our aim was to examine whether 3 weeks of intensive speech and language therapy under routine clinical conditions improved verbal communication in daily life situations in people with chronic aphasia after stroke.

title: Intentions and prescription of statins: can the theory of planned behavior explain the behavior of the doctor in following the recommendations of the guidelines?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Few studies have evaluated the usefulness of the Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) to explain the behavior of physicians. This study uses TPB to explain clinicians' implementation of guideline prescribing recommendations. METHODS: We developed the questionnaire by conducting qualitative interviews and a pilot study. A random sample of 155 general practitioners (GPs) in England participated in the study. Prescription and practice data were collected from routine sources. We analyze the data using regression methods. RESULTS: TPB explained 48% of the variation in reported intentions to follow guideline prescription recommendations. Perceived attitude and controls, but not subjective norms, were predictors of variation in intentions. The TPB belief variables significantly explained the variation in the effective and efficient prescription indicators (14% and 12%, respectively). Normative, control, and behavioral beliefs contributed to the models. Only for efficient prescription, the TPB items maintained their meaning in the presence of demographic variables. We did not find a significant relationship between intention and prescription. CONCLUSIONS: TPB helped to understand the prescribing behavior of GPs and their intentions to implement a clinical guideline. Beliefs (eg, normative beliefs) were better predictors of behavior than composite scores for their corresponding higher-level construct (eg, indirect subjective norm). TPB models need to be tested in conjunction with randomized trials to test the causality assumption that change in beliefs ultimately results in change in behavior.

title: Interactions between pharmaceutical representatives and doctors in training. A thematic review
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Medical school and residency are formative years in establishing prescribing patterns. Our aim was to review the literature on the degree of pharmaceutical industry contact with trainees, attitudes about these interactions, and the effects on trainees' prescribing behavior, with an emphasis on points of possible intervention and policy formation. DESIGN: MEDLINE was searched from 1966 to May 2004 for articles in English. All original articles were included if the abstract reported content relevant to medical education and the pharmaceutical industry. Editorials, guidelines, and policy recommendations were excluded. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: Contact with pharmaceutical representatives was common among residents. Most of the participants felt that the interactions were appropriate. A minority felt that their own prescription might be influenced by contact or gifts, but were more likely to believe that others' prescription might be influenced. Resident prescribing was associated with pharmacist representative visits and sample availability. A variety of educational policies and interventions appear to influence residents' attitudes toward interactions with industry, although data on the long-term effects of these interventions are limited. In general, residents reported insufficient training in this area. CONCLUSIONS: The pharmaceutical industry has a significant presence during residency training, has gained general acceptance from students, and appears to influence prescribing behavior. Training programs can benefit from policies and curricula that teach residents about the influence of industry and ways to critically evaluate the information provided to them. Recommendations for local and national approaches are discussed.

title: Interactions between doctors and the pharmaceutical industry: what does the literature say?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the effect of three types of interaction between physicians and the pharmaceutical industry (company-sponsored clinical trials, company-sponsored continuing medical education (CME), and information for physicians provided by pharmaceutical retailers) on the orientation and quality of clinical care. essays, the content of CME courses and the prescribing behavior of physicians. DATA SOURCES: MEDLINE and HEALTH search for articles in English published between 1978 and 1993, supplemented by material from the author's personal collection. STUDY SELECTION: A total of 227 articles from the MEDLINE and HEALTH searches and over 2000 articles from the author's library were initially reviewed. The following selection criteria were used: studies conducted in Australia, Canada, New Zealand, Great Britain and the United States"; studies conducted after 1977; quantitative surveys containing details of survey methods; studies on orientation and quality of clinical trials financed by companies and on the content of CME courses giving explicit criteria used in the evaluation;" and reports on the outcome of the interactions indicating how the results were evaluated. Thirty-six studies met these criteria. DATA EXTRACTION: Information was extracted on five topics: Physicians' attitudes toward pharmaceutical industry interactions, Frequency with which physicians participate in interactions, Guidance and quality of company-funded clinical trials, Course content company-sponsored CMEs and physician prescribing changes. behavior as a result of an interaction. DATA SYNTHESIS: Although most physicians participate only occasionally in company-sponsored clinical trials, most see retailers and attend company-sponsored CME courses. However, physicians do not have a very high opinion of information from retailers or company-sponsored CME events. Many doctors consider pharmaceutical companies to be an important source of funding for clinical trials, but are also concerned about accepting money from this source. Corporate funding of clinical trials can affect the quality of trials and the types of research that doctors do. Company-sponsored CME courses can have a commercial bias, even if they are conducted under guidelines designed to ensure the independence of the event. All three types of interactions affect physicians' prescribing behavior and, in the case of obtaining information from retailers, physicians' prescribing practices are less appropriate as a result of the interaction. CONCLUSIONS: Physicians are affected by their interactions with the pharmaceutical industry. More research is needed in most cases to determine whether such interactions lead to more or less appropriate prescribing practices. The CMA guidelines on this topic need to be evaluated to see if they are effective in controlling medical-industry interactions. Additional measures may be necessary if the guidelines fail to prevent negative effects on prescribing practices.

title: Interdisciplinary Perspectives on Managing the Fussy Baby: Key Strategies to Improve Outcomes
abstract: The objectives of this study were to analyze the perspectives of key informants with clinical experience caring for unstable infants in the first months of life and their families, on the changes needed to improve outcomes. The research used an intentional selection strategy and thematic analysis of key informant interviews with 24 health professionals from 11 disciplines. Informants were selected for their extensive experience in managing fussy infants and their families. Participants corroborated existing evidence that postpartum care in Australia is fragmented. All held the view that first, early primary care intervention for fussy babies and their families, and second, improved interprofessional communication are vital if the burden of this problem on the baby is to be minimized. , the family and the health system. Third, there was consensus that there are significant gaps in the knowledge base and management behaviors of health professionals. The development of educational resources, best practice guidelines, shared assessment frameworks for primary care physicians, and strategies to improve communication between professionals are necessary to improve health outcomes and decrease the burden of this common but complex postpartum problem.

title: Internal and external validity of cluster randomized trials: systematic review of recent trials
abstract: OBJECTIVES To assess aspects of the internal validity of recently published cluster randomized trials and to explore the reporting of information useful in assessing the external validity of these trials. DESIGN Review of 34 cluster randomized trials in primary care published in 2004 and 2005 in seven journals (British Medical Journal, British Journal of General Practice, Family Practice, Preventive Medicine, Annals of Internal Medicine, Journal of General Internal Medicine, Pediatrics). DATA SOURCES National Library of Medicine (Medline) via PubMed. DATA EXTRACTION To assess aspects of internal validity, we extracted data on the adequacy of sample size calculations and analyses, methods of identifying and recruiting individual participants, and blinding. To explore the reporting of useful information to assess external validity, we extracted data on group eligibility, group inclusion and retention, group generalizability, and the feasibility and acceptability of the intervention to health providers in the groups. RESULTS Twenty-one (62%) trials accounted for pooling in sample size calculations and 30 (88%) in analysis "approximately a quarter were potentially biased due to procedures related to patient recruitment and identification" ; individual participants were blinded to allocation status in 19 (56%) and outcome assessors were blinded in 15 (44%). In almost half of the reports, information related to the generalisability of the groups was poorly reported, and in two-fifths there was no information on the feasibility and acceptability of the intervention. CONCLUSIONS Cluster randomized trials are essential for evaluating certain types of interventions. Issues affecting its internal validity, such as appropriate sample size calculations and analyses, have become widely publicized and are now better addressed by researchers. Blinding of those identifying and recruiting patients to allocation status is recommended but not always carried out. There may be fewer barriers to internal validity in trials where individual participants are not recruited. External validity seems poorly addressed in many trials, but is arguably as important as internal validity in judging quality as a basis for health care intervention.

title: Recommendations of the International Collegium of Rehabilitative Audiology (ICRA) for the construction of multilingual speech tests. ICRA Task Force on Multilingual Speech Testing
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To provide guidelines for the development of two types of closed-set speech perception tests that can be applied and interpreted in the same way in all languages. The guidelines cover the digit triplet and matrix sentence tests that are most commonly used to assess speech recognition in noise. They were developed by a working group on Multilingual Speech Testing of the International College of Rehabilitation Audiology (ICRA). DESIGN: Recommendations are based on reviews of existing evaluations of the digit matrix and triplet tests, as well as the research experience of members of the ICRA Task Force. They represent the results of a consensus process. RESULTS: The resulting recommendations deal with: Test design and word selection"; Speaker characteristics; Audio recording and stimulus preparation; Masking noise; Test administration"; and test validation. CONCLUSIONS: By following these guidelines for the development of any new such tests, clinicians and researchers working in any language will be able to perform tests whose results can be compared and combined in cross-language studies.

title: Intervening in childhood: implications for autism spectrum disorders
abstract: There is a dearth of empirically validated treatments for infants and toddlers under 3 years of age with autism spectrum disorders (ASD), as well as a dearth of empirical research on successful intervention features for this population. However, early detection efforts are focused on identifying the risk of autism in children under 3 years of age. In order to build ASD interventions for infants and toddlers on a foundation of evidence-based features, the current article presents the results of a systematic literature search and effect size analysis of effective interventions for infants and toddlers with Other Developmental Disorders: Those who were born prematurely, have developmental disabilities, or are at high risk for developmental disabilities due to the presence of a biological or familial condition associated with developmental disabilities. A review of 32 high-quality, controlled experimental studies found that the most effective interventions routinely used a combination of four specific intervention procedures, including (1) parent involvement in the intervention, including ongoing parent training parenting that focused on both parent responsiveness and sensitivity to the key child and teaching families to deliver interventions to infants, (2) individualization based on each infant's developmental profile, (3) focus on a wide range of learning goals rather than a narrow one, and (4) temporal features that involve starting as soon as risk is detected and providing greater intensity and duration of intervention. These four characteristics of effective interventions for infants and toddlers with other developmental challenges likely represent a strong foundation from which researchers and clinicians can build effective interventions for infants and toddlers at risk for or affected by ASD.

title: Development of interventions for the integration of conventional smoking cessation interventions in the routine practice of CAM
abstract: BACKGROUND: Complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) practitioners are a significant and growing presence in health care systems around the world. A central question is whether evidence-based behavior change interventions routinely employed in conventional medical care could also be integrated into CAM practice to address public health priorities. Essential to successful integration are intervention approaches that are considered acceptable and consistent with the practice patterns and treatment approaches of different types of CAM practitioners, that is, that have context validity. The development of interventions to ensure context validity was an integral part of the CAM Reach Project (CAMR), a project examining the public health potential of smoking cessation training for chiropractors, acupuncturists, and massage therapists (CAM practitioners). This article describes the formative research conducted to achieve this goal. METHODS: The development of the intervention, carried out in three CAM disciplines (chiropractic, acupuncture, massage therapy), consisted of six iterative steps: 1) exploratory interviews with key informants; 2) survey of the local community of CAM practitioners; 3) Demonstration of existing CAM cessation curriculum 4) Adaptation/adaptation of existing curriculum; 5) external review of adaptations; 6) delivery of a personalized curriculum to CAM professionals with follow-up evaluation of the curriculum. RESULTS: CAM professionals identified barriers and facilitators to address tobacco use with patients/clients and saw the relevance and acceptability of the content of the intervention . The intervention development process was attentive to your real-world intervention concerns. An extensive intervention tailored to the context of each CAM discipline was considered unnecessary. Participants and advisors from all CAM disciplines embraced the training content, considering it to have broad relevance and application across the three CAM disciplines. All findings informed the final intervention. CONCLUSIONS: The participatory and iterative formative research process yielded a context-valid intervention in real-world CAM practices as it: 1) is patient/client-centered, emphasizing the physician's role in a healing relationship; 2) responds to the different work contexts of CAM physicians and patient/client relationships; 3) integrates relevant best practices from the US Public Health Service Clinical Practice Guidelines on the Treatment of Tobacco Dependence; and 4) accommodates the variety of healing philosophies, scopes of practice, and practice patterns found in participating CAM practitioners. The full CAMR study to assess the impact of the CAMR intervention on the clinical behavior of CAM practitioners is underway.

title: Intervention for autism spectrum disorders
abstract: comprehensive approach to the evaluation of any child with autism must be specifically tailored to each individual child and family. This premise is valid for medical therapies and special education services, as well as for psychopharmacological interventions. Behavioral, as opposed to pharmacological, treatment is the hallmark of an effective intervention for autism. Physicians involved in the care of children with autism should be familiar with educational law and intervention recommendations. Goals should include improved verbal and nonverbal functional communication and social skills, increased participation in developmentally appropriate activities, improved gross and fine motor skills, and the development of independent academic and organizational skills, as well as replacement of problem behaviors. with developmentally appropriate behaviors. Medicating children with autism is difficult, but is often necessary for chronic behavioral difficulties. In the absence of clear and current guidelines, we have tried to use the evidence and clinical experience to suggest an algorithm based on groups of symptoms. Although children with autism may respond to lower-dose medications and be more susceptible to side effects than other children, medical intervention can produce a significant improvement in quality of life for the child and family. Careful thought leading to the correct identification of target behaviors can appropriately direct better alternatives to medication. Although these approaches are costly and time-consuming endeavors, the expenditure of such efforts is the only path available to improve potential outcomes for people with autism, as well as lower the lifetime societal costs for each individual.

title: Mapping of interventions for the development of a strategy to implement insurance medication guidelines for depression
abstract: BACKGROUND: This article describes the development of a strategy to implement insurance medication guidelines for depression. The use of the guidelines is intended to result in a more transparent and consistent assessment of applicants with depressive symptoms. METHODS: The implementation strategy was developed using the Intervention Mapping (IM) method for alignment with insurance medical practice. The ASE behavioral explanation model (Attitude, Social Influence and Self-Efficacy) was used as a theoretical basis for the development of the work. A literature review of implementation strategies and interviews with insurance physicians were conducted to develop instruments for use with the guideline. These instruments were designed to meet the needs and working circumstances of insurance physicians. Performance indicators were defined to measure the quality of the assessment and adherence to guidelines with input from insurance physicians. RESULTS: This study resulted in the development of a training course to teach insurance physicians how to apply the guidelines for depression, using the aforementioned instruments. The effectiveness of this training course will be evaluated in a randomized controlled trial. CONCLUSIONS: The use of IM allowed the development of guideline support instruments adapted to insurance medical practice.

title: Interventions delivered by health professionals providing routine child health care to reduce tobacco smoke exposure in children: a review and meta-analysis
abstract: IMPORTANCE: Reducing children's exposure to tobacco smoke is a public health priority. The guidelines recommend that health professionals in child health settings should address tobacco smoke exposure (TSE) in children. OBJECTIVE: To determine the effectiveness of interventions delivered by health professionals providing routine child health care in reducing TSEs in children. DATA SOURCES: A secondary analysis of 57 trials included in a 2014 Cochrane review and a subsequent extended search was performed. Controlled trials (published up to June 2015) of interventions that focused on reducing childhood TSE were identified, with no restrictions on who delivered the interventions. Secondary data extraction was performed in August 2015. STUDY SELECTION: Controlled trials of routine child health care provided by health professionals (physicians, nurses, physician assistants, health educators, and dieticians) that addressed the outcomes of interest. (reducing ERT in children and parental smoking behaviors) were eligible for inclusion in this review and meta-analysis. DATA EXTRACTION AND SYNTHESIS: Two authors independently extracted study details and quality characteristics. If the outcome measures were sufficiently similar, a meta-analysis was performed using the DerSimonian and Laird random effects model. Otherwise, the results were described narratively. MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES: The primary outcome measure was the reduction of TSEs in children. Secondary outcomes of interest were parental smoking cessation, reduction in parental smoking, and prevention of postpartum maternal smoking relapse. RESULTS: Sixteen studies met the selection criteria. Narrative analysis of the 6 trials that measured TSEs in children indicated no intervention effects relative to comparison groups. Similarly, meta-analysis of 9 trials measuring parental smoking cessation demonstrated no overall effect of the intervention (n = 6,399) (relative risk, 1.05"; 95% CI, 0.74- 1.50, P = 0.78).Meta-analysis of the 3 trials that measured maternal postpartum smoking relapse prevention demonstrated a significant overall effect of the intervention (n = 1293) (hazard ratio 1.53, CI 95%, 1.10-2.14, P = 0.01) High levels of study heterogeneity were likely due to variability in outcome measures, duration of follow-up, intervention strategies, and unknown fidelity CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Interventions delivered by health professionals providing routine child health care may be effective in preventing maternal relapse to smoking.Further research is required to improve the effectiveness of such interventions in reducing go TSEs in children and increase smoking cessation by parents. The findings of this meta-analysis have policy and practice implications related to routine pediatric health professional interventions that aim to reduce children's exposure to tobacco smoke.

title: Interventions for adolescent depression in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Depression in adolescents is underrecognized and undertreated despite its poor long-term outcomes, including suicide risk. Primary care settings may be critical places for depression identification, but there is little information on the usefulness of primary care interventions. OBJECTIVE: We attempted to review the evidence for the treatment of depression in primary care settings, focusing on evidence related to psychosocial, educational, and/or supportive intervention strategies. METHODS: Available data on brief psychosocial treatments for adolescent depression in primary settings were reviewed. Given the paucity of direct studies, we also drew on the related literature to summarize the available evidence on whether brief psychosocial support from a member of the primary care team, with or without medication, could improve depression outcomes. RESULTS: We identified 37 studies relevant to the treatment of adolescent depression in primary care settings. Only 4 studies directly examined the impact of psychosocial interventions provided by primary care for adolescent depression, but they suggest that such interventions may be effective. Indirect evidence from other psychosocial/behavioral interventions, including anticipatory counseling and efforts to improve adherence to treatment, and studies of depression in adults also show benefits of interventions delivered by primary care, as well as the impact of Provider training to improve psychosocial skills. CONCLUSIONS: Potential exists for successful treatment of adolescent depression in primary care, in view of evidence that brief psychosocial support, with or without medication, has been shown to improve a range of outcomes, including adolescent depression itself. . Given the great public health problem posed by adolescent depression, the likelihood that most depressed adolescents do not receive specialized services, and new guidelines for the management of adolescent depression in primary care, clinicians may find it useful to initiate of supportive interventions in their primary care practices.

title: Interventions for implementing thromboprophylaxis in hospitalized medical and surgical patients at risk of venous thromboembolism
abstract: BACKGROUND: Venous thromboembolism (VTE) is one of the leading causes of morbidity and mortality in hospitalized patients. Numerous randomized controlled trials (RCTs) show that the use of thromboprophylaxis in hospitalized patients at risk of VTE is safe, effective and cost-effective. Despite this, prophylactic therapies for VTE are underused. System-wide interventions may be more effective in improving VTE prophylaxis use than relying on the prescribing behaviors of individual providers. OBJECTIVES: To assess the effects of interventions designed to increase the implementation of thromboprophylaxis in hospitalized adult medical and surgical patients at risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE), assessed in terms of: 1. Increased proportion of patients receiving prophylaxis and prophylaxis adequate 2. Reduced risk of symptomatic VTE3. Reduced risk of asymptomatic VTE4. Safety of the intervention. SEARCH METHODS: The Trials Search Coordinator of the Cochrane Peripheral Vascular Diseases Group searched the Group's Specialized Register (last searched July 2010) and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL , The Cochrane Library) 2010, Issue 3. We searched the PubMed, EMBASE, and SCOPUS databases (April 19, 2010), as well as the reference lists of relevant review articles. SELECTION CRITERIA: All studies whose interventions aimed to increase the use of prophylaxis or adequate prophylaxis, decrease the proportion of symptomatic VTE, or decrease the proportion of asymptomatic VTE in hospitalized adult patients were included. Studies that simply distributed published guidelines and studies whose interventions were not clearly described were excluded. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: We collected the following outcomes: the proportion of patients receiving prophylaxis (PR), the proportion of patients receiving adequate prophylaxis (PAR) (primary outcomes), and the occurrence of symptomatic VTE, asymptomatic VTE, and safety outcomes as bleeding. We classify interventions into education, alerts, and multifaceted interventions. We meta-analysed RCTs and nonrandomized studies (NRS) separately using random-effects meta-analysis and assessed heterogeneity using the I(2) statistic and subgroup analyses. Before analysis, we decided that results would be pooled if three or more studies were available for a particular intervention. We assessed publication bias using funnel plots and a cumulative meta-analysis. MAIN RESULTS: A total of 55 studies were included. One of these reported data in patient-days and could not be quantitatively analyzed with the others. The remaining 54 studies (8 RCTs and 46 NRS) eligible for inclusion in our quantitative synthesis recruited a total of 78,343 participants. Among the RCTs, there were insufficient data to pool the results for one primary outcome (prophylaxis received) for the 'alertness' intervention. Alerts, such as computerized reminders or stickers on patient charts, were associated with a risk difference (RD) of 13%, meaning an increase in the proportion of patients receiving prophylaxis (95% confidence interval (CI ) 1% to 25% ). Among the NRS, there were insufficient data to pool both primary outcomes for each type of intervention. The pooled risk differences for received prophylaxis ranged from 8% to 17%, and for received adequate prophylaxis ranged from 11% to 19%. Education and alerts were associated with statistically significant increases in prescribing adequate prophylaxis, and multifaceted interventions were associated with statistically significant increases in prescribing any prophylaxis and adequate prophylaxis. Multifaceted interventions had the largest pooled effects. The I(2) results showed substantial statistical heterogeneity that is explained in part by the types of patients and the type of hospital. A subgroup analysis showed that multifaceted interventions that included an alert may be more effective in improving rates of prophylaxis and adequate prophylaxis than those without an alert. The VTE and safety results did not show significant benefit or harm, although most studies were underpowered to assess these results. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: A large number of studies were reviewed that implemented a variety of system-wide strategies aimed at improving rates of thromboprophylaxis in many settings and patient populations. Statistically significant improvements were found in prescribing prophylaxis associated with alerts (RCTs) and multifaceted interventions (RCTs and NRS), and improvements in prescribing appropriate prophylaxis in NRS with the use of education, alerts, and multifaceted interventions. Multifaceted interventions with an alert component may be the most effective. Demonstrated sources of heterogeneity included patient types and hospital type. The results of our review will help doctors, nurses, pharmacists, hospital administrators, and policymakers make practical decisions about adopting specific local, system-wide measures to improve prevention of VTE, a major public health issue. We found no significant benefit for VTE outcomes";" however, previous RCTs evaluating the efficacy of thromboprophylaxis that were powered to address these outcomes demonstrated the benefit of prophylactic therapies and a favorable balance of benefit against increased risk of bleeding events.

title: Interventions to improve patients' trust in physicians and physician groups
abstract: BACKGROUND: Trust is a critical component of the doctor-patient relationship and is associated with increased satisfaction, treatment adherence, and continuity of care. It is unclear whether there are interventions known to be effective in improving patients' trust in doctors. OBJECTIVES: To assess the effects of interventions aimed at improving a patient's trust in the doctor or in a group of doctors. SEARCH STRATEGY: We searched the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (The Cochrane Library Issue 1 2003), MEDLINE (1966 to week 4 2003), EMBASE (1985 to July 2003), Health Star (1975 to July 2004) , PsycINFO (1967 to July 2004), CINAHL (1982 to June 2003), LILACS (1982 to April 2003), African Trials Register (1948 to April 2003), African Health Anthology (1924 to April 2003), Dissertation Abstracts International (1861 to April 2003) and bibliographies of studies assessed for inclusion. Bibliographies of studies assessed for inclusion were also searched and investigators active in the field contacted. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs), controlled clinical trials, controlled before-and-after studies, and interrupted time series studies of interventions (informational, educational, behavioral, organizational) directed at clinicians or patients (or caregivers) where the confidence was assessed as a primary or secondary outcome. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two review authors independently assessed trial quality and extracted data. MAIN RESULTS: Three RCTs, all published in English and set in North American primary care, involving 1916 participants, were included. There was considerable heterogeneity in terms of the objectives, format and content of the interventions. A trial of a training intervention for family doctors to improve communication behaviors (20 doctors assessed by 414 patients) showed no effect on trust. The other two interventions focused on the patient. One explored the impact on trust of disclosing medical incentives to patients (n=918) in a Health Maintenance Organization (HMO) and showed no decrease in trust. Another investigated the effect of induction visits on the confidence of new HMO members (n=564) in their HMO physicians. Confidence in physicians increased compared to control after visit for one type of induction visit, group visit (Confidence of 10 (SD)) was 8.8 (1.5) and 7.1 (2.2), difference 1.7, (95% confidence interval 1.22 to 2.18)). However, there were many dropouts and the analysis was not based on intention to treat. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: Overall, there is still insufficient evidence to conclude that any intervention can increase or decrease trust in doctors. Further trials are required to explore the impact of policy changes, guidelines and specific training of clinicians on patient trust.

title: Interventions for migraine prophylaxis: protocol of an overview systematic review and network meta-analysis.
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Multiple interventions are effective for migraine prophylaxis. However, the comparative effectiveness of these interventions is still unclear. Therefore, the aim of this study is to summarize the direct and indirect evidence for pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions to prevent migraine attack. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: We will conduct an overview systematic review to identify eligible randomized controlled trials (RCTs) for guideline-recommended interventions for migraine prophylaxis. A comprehensive literature search of MEDLINE, EMBASE and the Cochrane library for systematic reviews will be performed, which will be screened for RCTs. We will describe the general information of the RCTs for participants, interventions, outcome measures, comparisons and primary outcomes. In addition, a network meta-analysis will be performed to determine the comparative effectiveness of treatments using a random effects model. The absolute and relative efficacy of the treatments will be provided. Heterogeneity and inconsistency between trials will be assessed using the I(2) test statistic and Cochrane's Q test. Risk of bias will be assessed and the overall strength of evidence will be summarized. DISCUSSION: The result of this network meta-analysis will provide direct and indirect evidence of treatments for migraine prophylaxis and may provide a treatment ranking for patients and clinicians to help them select the best option. TEST REGISTRATION NUMBER: PROSPERO CRD42015015297.

title: Interventions that change clinical behaviour: mapping the literature
Interventions to change the behaviors of maternity health professionals to promote weight-related support for obese pregnant women: a systematic review.
abstract: BACKGROUND: There has been a rapid increase in the publication of guidelines for managing obesity and weight gain during pregnancy over the last five years. Health professionals have identified multiple barriers to this area of practice, including the need to improve their communication skills, the belief that pregnant women will have negative reactions to weight-related discussions, and a lack of knowledge about weight management. Of weight. This systematic review aimed to identify: the effectiveness of interventions to change the practice of health professionals in relation to maternal obesity or weight control during pregnancy";" and what behavior change techniques and intervention delivery modes have been used in interventions to date. FINDINGS: The search strategy included searching electronic databases, trial registries, and citation searching. Inclusion criteria were intervention studies aimed at changing the practice of health professionals in relation to maternal obesity or weight control. The searches identified 3608 studies. However, no eligible completed studies were identified. One registered Canadian randomized controlled trial was identified. The trial includes a training intervention for family doctors with the aim of supporting adherence to weight gain guidelines during pregnancy. The trial had not yet started, so no effectiveness data were available. CONCLUSIONS: The current focus of research on maternal obesity and weight control is directed at changing the behaviors of pregnant women. These interventions do not address the multiple barriers of health professionals to the practice of maternal obesity and weight control. Further research is required to identify the most effective approaches to help health professionals implement maternal obesity and weight management guidelines in practice.

title: Interventions to improve follow-up of abnormal findings in cancer detection
abstract: The potential reduction in morbidity and mortality through cancer screening cannot be achieved without receiving adequate follow-up care for abnormalities identified through screening. In this article, the authors critically review the existing literature on the correlates of receiving adequate follow-up care for abnormalities detected by screening, as well as the literature on interventions designed to increase rates of receiving follow-up care. Lessons learned describe what is known and not known about factors that are related to or predict receipt of follow-up care. Similarly, effective interventions to increase follow-up are described and gaps identified. A conceptual model is developed that categorizes the health care system in the United States into four levels: policy, practice, provider, and patient. Some patient-level factors influencing receipt of follow-up are identified, but lack of data severely limits understanding of provider-, practice-, and policy-level correlates. Most intervention studies to increase uptake of follow-up have focused on patient-level factors and focused on follow-up of abnormal Pap smears. Insufficient information is available on the effectiveness of interventions at the provider, practice, or policy level. Standard definitions of what constitutes appropriate follow-up are lacking, severely limiting the comparability of findings across studies. The validity of various methods for obtaining outcome data has not been clearly established. More research is needed on interventions targeting factors at the provider, system, and policy levels, particularly interventions that focus on monitoring breast and colorectal abnormalities. Standardization of definitions and measures is needed to facilitate comparisons between studies. Cancer 2004. Published in 2004 by the American Cancer Society.

title: Interventions to improve hospital patient satisfaction with health care providers and systems: a systematic review
abstract: Background Many hospital systems seek to improve patient satisfaction as assessed by the Hospital Consumer Health Care Systems and Provider Assessment (HCAHPS) surveys. A systematic review of current experimental evidence could inform these efforts and does not yet exist. Methods We conducted a systematic review of the literature by searching electronic databases, including MEDLINE and EMBASE, the six Cochrane Library databases, and gray literature databases. We included studies that included hospital patients with interventions targeting at least 1 of the 11 HCAHPS domains, and that met our quality filter score on the 27-item Downs and Black coding scale. Post hoc power was calculated where appropriate. Results A total of 59 studies met the inclusion criteria, of these 44 did not meet the 50% quality filter (mean quality rating 27.8% ± 10.9%). Of the 15 studies that met the quality filter (mean quality rating 67.3% ± 10.7%), 8 focused on the HCAHPS Communication with Physicians domain, 6 focused on overall hospital rating, 5 focused on communication with nurses, 5 focused on pain management, 5 focused on communication about Medications, 5 aimed at Recommending the Hospital, 3 aimed at Calmness of the Hospital Environment, 3 aimed at Cleanliness of the Hospital Environment and 3 addressed to Registration Information. Eight interventions reported significant improvements from the HCAHPS, but their generalizability may be limited by narrowly focused patient populations, heterogeneity of approach, and other methodological concerns. Conclusions Although there are a few studies showing some improvement in the HCAHPS score across various interventions, we conclude that more rigorous research is needed to identify effective and generalizable interventions to improve patient satisfaction.

title: Interventions to increase the use of electronic health information by health professionals to improve clinical practice and patient outcomes
abstract: BACKGROUND: A large volume of health information is available and, if applied in clinical practice, can contribute to effective patient care. Despite the abundance of information, suboptimal care is common. Many factors influence the use of health information by professionals, and the format (electronic or other) may be one of those factors. OBJECTIVES: To assess the effects of interventions aimed at improving or increasing the use of electronic health information (EHI) by healthcare professionals on professional practice and patient outcomes. SEARCH METHODS: We searched The Cochrane Library (Wiley), MEDLINE (Ovid), EMBASE (Ovid), CINAHL (EBSCO), and LISA (EBSCO) up to November 2013. We contacted researchers in the field and scanned reference lists. of relevant articles. . SELECTION CRITERIA: Studies that evaluated the effects of interventions to improve or increase the use of HIE by health professionals on professional practice and patient outcomes were included. We define EHI as information accessed on a computer. We define 'use' as logging into EHI. Any health professional involved in patient care was considered. Randomized, non-randomized, and cluster-randomized controlled trials (RCTs, NRCTs, CRCTs), controlled clinical trials (CCTs), interrupted time series (ITS), and controlled before-after studies (CBAs) were included. Comparisons were: "electronic versus paper health information"; EHI on different electronic devices (e.g. desktop, laptop, or tablet computers, etc.; cell/mobile phones); EHI through different user interfaces; EHI provided with or without an educational or training component;" and EHI compared to any other type or source of information. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two reviewers independently extracted data and assessed risk of bias for each study. GRADE was used to assess the quality of included studies. We reassessed previously excluded studies following our decision to define EHI logins as a measure of professional behavior. We report the results in natural units. Where possible, we calculated and reported the median effect size (odds ratio [OR], interquartile ranges [IQR]). Due to the large heterogeneity between studies, meta-analysis was not feasible. MAIN RESULTS: Two RCTs and four CRCTs involving 352 physicians, 48 residents and 135 allied health professionals were included. The overall risk of bias was low, as was the quality of the evidence. One comparison was supported by three studies and three comparisons were supported by single studies, but the results between the three studies were very heterogeneous. No studies were found to support HIE versus no alternative. Given these factors, it was not possible to determine the relative effectiveness of the interventions. All studies reported practitioner use of HIE, two reported adherence to electronic practice guidelines, and none reported patient outcomes. One trial (139 participants) measured guideline compliance for an electronic versus printed guideline, but reported no difference between groups (median OR 0.85). , IQR 0.74 to 1.08). One small crossover trial (10 participants) reported greater use of clinical guidelines when provided with a mobile versus stationary desktop computer (mean use per shift: intervention group (IG) 3.6, standard deviation (SD) 1, 7 versus control group (CG) 2.0 (SD 1.9), p value = 0.033). One crossover trial (203 participants) reported that use of a custom versus generic interface had little impact on practitioner use of EHI (adjusted mean difference in rate at endpoint: 0.77 logins /month/user, 95% confidence interval). (CI) CI 0.43 to 1.11). Three trials included education or training and reported increased use of HIE by professionals after training. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: This review provided no evidence that the use of EHI translates into better clinical practice or patient outcomes, although it suggests that when professionals receive EHI and education or training, the use of EHI increases. We have defined usage as the activity of logging into an EHI resource, but based on our findings, usage does not automatically translate to the application of EHI in practice. While the use of EHI can be an important component of evidence-based medicine, it alone is insufficient to improve patient care or clinical practices. For EHI to be applied in patient care, it will be necessary to understand why professionals are reluctant to apply EHI when treating people and determine the most effective way(s) to reduce this reluctance.

title: Interventions to modify health professionals' adherence to asthma guidelines: a systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVE: Compliance with asthma guidelines by health professionals is poor. The objective of this study was to assess the effect of interventions to improve healthcare providers' adherence to asthma guidelines on the healthcare process and clinical outcomes. METHODS: Data sources included Medline, Embase, the Cochrane CENTRAL Register of Controlled Trials, the Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature, the Educational Resources Information Center, PsycINFO, and the Education Research and Development Resource Base. Medical Continuing through July 2012. Independently matched investigators assessed study eligibility. The investigators abstracted the data sequentially and graded the evidence independently. RESULTS: Sixty-eight eligible studies were categorized by intervention: decision support, organizational change, feedback and audit, clinical pharmacy support, education only, quality improvement/pay for performance, multicomponent, and information only. Half were randomized trials (n = 35). There was moderate evidence of an increase in controller medication prescriptions for decision support, feedback and audit, and clinical pharmacy support, and low-grade evidence for organizational change and multicomponent interventions. Moderate evidence supports the use of decision support and clinical pharmacy interventions to increase the provision of asthma action plans/patient self-education. Moderate evidence supports the use of decision support tools to reduce emergency department visits, with low-grade evidence suggesting no benefit to this outcome from organizational change, education alone, and improved practice. quality/pay for performance. CONCLUSIONS: Decision support tools, feedback and audit, and clinical pharmacy support were more likely to improve provider adherence to asthma guidelines, as measured through outcomes of the medical care process. There is a need to evaluate interventions targeted at health care providers with standardized outcomes.

title: Interventions to promote evidence-based care for children with ADHD in primary care settings
abstract: Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a common behavior disorder among children. Community doctors are often the main providers of services for children with ADHD. The American Academy of Pediatrics has published a set of consensus guidelines that provides best practice diagnostic procedures for primary care physicians. These recommendations emphasize the importance of using the criteria in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fourth Edition, as a basis for making an ADHD diagnosis and conducting systematic follow-up, including the collection of parent and teacher rating scales to quantitatively assess the response to treatment. Although these recommendations have been widely disseminated and their adoption actively promoted, compliance with the guidelines is generally known to be poor. Two types of intervention models, ancillary service and office systems modification, have been proposed to promote the adoption of evidence-based ADHD practice in primary care settings. This article reviews the effectiveness of these intervention models and analyzes the cost and sustainability of each model in relation to the feasibility of spreading the intervention.

title: Intrinsic conflicts of interest in clinical research: a need for disclosure
abstract: Protecting human subjects from investigators' conflicts of interest is critical to the integrity of clinical research. Personal financial conflicts of interest are addressed in university policies, professional society guidelines, public standards, and government regulation, but "intrinsic conflicts of interest" (conflicts of interest inherent in all clinical research) have received relatively less attention . Such conflicts arise in all clinical research efforts as a result of the tension between the responsibilities of professionals to their research and to their patients and academic and financial incentives. These conflicts must be disclosed to research subjects and handled as diligently as financial conflicts of interest.

title: Introduction: Understanding and Influencing Multilevel Factors Across the Continuum of Cancer Care
abstract: Health care in the United States is notoriously expensive and often does not provide the care recommended in published guidelines. Therefore, there is a need to consider our approach to health service delivery. Cancer care is a good example to consider because it spans the continuum of health care issues from primary prevention to long-term survival and end-of-life care. In this monograph, we emphasize that health service delivery occurs in a multilevel system that includes organizations, teams, and individuals. To achieve health care delivery consistent with the Institute of Medicine's six quality goals (safety, effectiveness, timeliness, efficiency, patient-centeredness, and equity), we must influence multiple levels of that multilevel system. The notion that multiple levels of contextual influence affect behaviors through interdependent interactions is a well-established ecological view. This viewpoint has been used to analyze health service delivery and health disparities. However, the experience in considering multilevel interventions in health care is much less robust. This monograph includes 13 chapters relevant to expanding the research base for multilevel interventions in health care delivery. Topics include case studies of multilevel thinking in health care delivery, the state of knowledge on multilevel interventions, study design and measurement considerations, methods for combining interventions, time as a consideration in evaluating effects, measuring effects, simulations , application of multilevel thinking to health care systems and disparities, and implementation of the Affordable Care Act of 2010. Our goal is to outline an agenda for proceeding with multilevel intervention research, not because it guarantees a improvement in our current approach to health care, but because ignoring the complexity of the multilevel environment in which care occurs has not achieved the desired improvements in quality of care described by the Institute of Medicine at the turn of the millennium.

title: Investigation of breast symptoms in primary care: improving agreement with current best advice
abstract: The purpose of this study was to determine whether a targeted intervention could improve primary care physicians' agreement with guidelines related to the management of women with breast symptoms. One hundred and twelve professionals from randomly selected areas of Australia prospectively audited their investigations for each woman with a new breast symptom during two 12-week periods, before and five months after the publication of the national guidelines. Between the two audits, the clinicians received practice feedback relative to their peers and attended a seminar in their local areas led by specialists from the Royal Australasian College of Physicians and the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons. For five recommendations, there were statistically significant improvements at the second audit in line with the standard Investigation of a New Breast Symptom (INBS) guidelines. All of these were for breast lumps investigations. In the first audit, there were seven recommendations in which professionals already managed more than 80% of women according to the INBS, and in which there were no statistically significant increases in agreement in the second audit. Another six recommendations were less in agreement with recommendations prior to publication of the guidelines and did not improve significantly in the second audit. These tended to be for less common presentations and where the clinical findings were not consistent with the results of other tests. We conclude that a targeted intervention improved clinicians' agreement with current best advice for screening women presenting with new breast symptoms in a primary care setting. More educational programs are needed to improve investigations of rarer symptoms and increase physicians' confidence in the results of their clinical examinations.

title: Is it possible to predict better diabetes outcomes after diabetes self-management education: a mixed-methods longitudinal design?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To predict diabetes-related outcomes of people undertaking a type 2 diabetes self-management education (DSME) program from their baseline data. DESIGN: Longitudinal mixed methods experimental study. Blinded assessments of all baseline and process data were conducted by 6 practice nurses and 2 clinical scholars to predict clinical, behavioral, and psychological outcomes at 6 months post-DSME. SETTING: Primary care. PARTICIPANTS: -31 people with type 2 diabetes who had not previously undergone DSME. INTERVENTION: All participants completed the 12-week DSME 1:1 self-directed learning program of the Diabetes Manual with the support of practice nurses trained as Diabetes Manual facilitators. OUTCOME VARIABLES: Glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c), knowledge of diabetes, physical activity, waist circumference, self-efficacy, diabetes distress, anxiety, depression, demographics, discussion of change, and satisfaction with treatment. These variables were chosen because they are known to influence self-care behavior or have been influenced by a DSME program in the empirical evidence. RESULTS: Baseline and 6-month follow-up data were available for 27 participants, of whom 13 (48%) were male, 22 (82%) British White, with a mean age of 59 years and a mean duration of type 2 diabetes for 9.1 years. Significant reductions were found in HbA1c t(26)=2.35, p=0.03 and diabetes distress t(26)=2.30, p=0.03, and a significant increase in knowledge t(26) =-2.06, p=0.05 between baseline and 6 months. No significant changes were found in waist circumference, physical activity, anxiety, depression, or self-efficacy. Accuracy of predictions varied little between academic clinicians and practice nurses, but a great deal between outcomes (0-100%). The precision of the median and mode of the predicted result was 66.67%. The prediction accuracy for the key outcome of HbA1c was 44.44%. Diabetes distress had the highest prediction accuracy (81.48%). CONCLUSIONS: Physicians in this small study were unable to identify people who were likely to achieve an improvement in DSME outcomes. DSME should be promoted to all patients with diabetes according to the guidelines.

title: Is the type of provider associated with cancer screening and prevention: Advanced Practice Registered Nurses, Physician Assistants, and Physicians?
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physician recommendations for cancer detection and prevention are associated with patient compliance. However, time constraints may limit physicians' ability to provide all recommended preventive services, especially with the growing demand of the Affordable Care Act in the United States. Team-based practice that includes Advanced Practice Registered Nurses and Physician Assistants (APRN/PA) can help meet this demand. This study investigates the relationship between an APRN/PA visit and receipt of guideline-consistent cancer screening and prevention recommendations. METHODS: Data from the 2010 National Health Interview Survey were analyzed with multivariate logistic regression to assess the type of provider seen and receipt of guideline-consistent cancer screening and prevention recommendations (n = 26,716). RESULTS: In adjusted analyses, women who saw a primary care physician (PCP) and an APRN/PA or a PCP without an APRN/PA in the past 12 months were more likely to meet breast cancer screening guidelines. cervix and breast than women who did not see a PCP or APRN/PA (all p < 0.0001 for provider type). Women and men who saw a PCP and an APRN/PA or a PCP without an APRN/PA were also more likely to receive colorectal cancer screening consistent with guidelines and advice to quit smoking and participate in active activities. than women and men who did not see a PCP or APRN/PA (all p < 0.01 for provider type). CONCLUSIONS: Seeing a PCP alone, or in conjunction with an APRN/PA is associated with patient receipt of guideline-consistent cancer screening and prevention recommendations. Integrating APRN/PA into primary care can help with the delivery of cancer screening and prevention services. Further intervention research efforts are needed to explore how APRN/PA will best increase cancer screening, HPV vaccination, and receipt of behavioral counseling, especially during this era of health care reform.
