title: Is there a gap between recommended and 'real world' practice in managing depression in youth? An audit of the practice's medical record.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The literature has shown that guideline dissemination alone is insufficient to ensure that guideline recommendations are incorporated into daily clinical practice. METHODS: Our objective was to investigate the gaps between guideline recommendations and clinical practice in the management of youth with depression by conducting an audit of medical records in a catchment area public mental health service for youth aged 15 to 25 years in Melbourne, Australia. RESULTS: The results showed that the assessment and recording of depression severity to ensure proper treatment planning was not systematic or consistent";" that most youth (74.5%) were prescribed an antidepressant before undergoing an adequate trial of psychotherapy and that less than 50% were monitored for improvement in depressive symptoms and suicide-related behaviors emerging from antidepressant treatment (35% and 30% respectively). Encouragingly, 92% of first-line prescriptions for people age 18 and younger who had never taken antidepressants before were for fluoxetine as recommended. CONCLUSIONS: This research has highlighted the need for specific strategies to ensure effective implementation. These strategies could include practice systems tools that allow systematic monitoring of depressive symptoms and adverse side effects, particularly suicidal behaviours. Furthermore, youth-specific psychotherapy that incorporates the most effective components for this age group, delivered in a youth-friendly manner, would likely aid effective implementation of guideline recommendations to engage in adequate trial of psychotherapy before start medication.

title: Are non-directed outreach visits effective in primary care? A pragmatic randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is increasing evidence that clinical guidelines can lead to improvements in clinical care. However, they are not autorun. Extension visits can improve prescription behavior. METHODS: Within a pragmatic randomized controlled before-and-after trial, involving all general practices in a health district, routine methods were used to distribute guidelines for the management of Helicobacter pylori eradication. A visit to intervention practices and an audit by a pharmacist trained in outreach visit techniques were offered. The intervention was assessed using level three Prescribing and Cost Analysis (PACT) data for metronidazole and omeprazole during the two 12-month periods around guideline introduction. RESULTS: Of the 38 intervention practices, 19 accepted an extension visit and three accepted the offer of an audit. There was a significant increase in omeprazole use during the study of 0.24 [95% confidence interval (CI) +0.19 to +0.29] dose units per year, but the offer had no effect [ -0.02 (95% CI -0.12 to +0.08) dose units] or acceptance of a visit [-0.03 (95% CI -0.15 to +0.08) units of dose]. The results for metronidazole were similar, with an increase in use of 0.028 (95% CI +0.018 to +0.038) dose units per year. The intervention effect was a non-significant change in prescription of -0.005 (95% CI -0.025 to +0.015) dose units. Accepting a visit had little effect on prescribing: a change of 0.003 (95% CI -0.021 to +0.027) dose units. CONCLUSIONS: The routine use of untargeted outreach visits is probably not a worthwhile strategy.

title: Issues Related to the Protection of Human Research Participants
abstract: Making ethical decisions related to the protection of human research participants is often complex and fraught with uncertainty and conflict. Knowledge of the basic principles outlined in the Belmont Report, as well as in federal regulations and guidelines, can provide a useful framework for such decisions, although the ultimate responsibility for ensuring ethical research practices rests with the individual researcher. Ongoing dialogue and discussion about these ethical issues will provide a foundation for strengthening nursing research and practice while ensuring maximum protection for research participants who advance nursing science.

title: It's not just that I encourage hand hygiene among health professionals by focusing on patients.
abstract: Diseases often spread in hospitals because healthcare professionals don't wash their hands. Research suggests that to increase health and safety behaviors, it is important to highlight the personal consequences for the actor. However, because people (and health professionals in particular) tend to rely too heavily on personal immunity, the most effective messages about hand hygiene may be those that highlight its consequences for other people. In two hospital field experiments, we compared the effectiveness of hand hygiene signs that emphasized personal safety ("Hand hygiene keeps you from getting sick") or patient safety ("Hand hygiene keeps you from getting sick"). patients get diseases"). We assessed hand hygiene by measuring the amount of soap and hand sanitizer gel used in dispensers (Experiment 1) and by conducting covert, independent observations of healthcare professionals' hand hygiene behaviors (Experiment 2). The results showed that changing a single word in the messages led to significant changes in behavior: health professionals' hand hygiene increased significantly when they were reminded of the implications for patients, but not when they were reminded of the implications for them. themselves.

title: Jarvis vs. Levine
abstract: KIE: The Minnesota Court of Appeals ruled that an involuntarily mentally hospitalized patient has a qualified constitutional right to refuse neuroleptic treatment in a non-emergency situation, subject to the exercise of professional judgment by state hospital physicians in accordance with the required guidelines. Affirmed the trial court's ruling that patient Jarvis was not entitled to a post-medication review on the grounds that due process requirements for the administration of neuroleptic medications were met by compliance with the involuntary medication policy established by the Minnesota Department of Public Welfare.

title: JNC-7 Guidelines: Are They Still Relevant?
abstract: The recommendations of the Seventh Report of the Joint National Committee for the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation and Treatment of High Blood Pressure (JNC 7), published in 2003, are very relevant today. Reducing blood pressure (BP) to target in hypertensive patients is of paramount importance in reducing cardiovascular risk. Antihypertensive drugs vary in their efficacy in lowering BP and may have BP-independent effects on cardiovascular events, as seen especially with respect to prevention of heart failure and stroke. Thiazide-type diuretics have been recommended as the preferred initial drugs for the treatment of hypertension in most patients, and this remains an appropriate recommendation. Several other classes were recommended as follows in priority, but beta-blockers should now have a minor role in the treatment of uncomplicated hypertension. Although a new JNC report would be reassuring to practitioners and should include some changes from JNC 7, I believe that most of the recommendations are still relevant today.

title: MAGAZINE CLUB: Predictors of Provider Response to Clinical Decision Support: Lessons Learned from the Medicare Imaging Demonstration
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The effectiveness of imaging clinical decision support (CDS) varies. Our goal was to identify CDS factors that contribute to the cancellation or modification of imaging orders. SUBJECTS AND METHODS: This pre-post study was conducted at four institutions that participated in the Medicare Imaging Demonstration. The intervention was CDS at order entry for selected outpatient imaging procedures. Based on the information entered, computerized alerts indicated to providers whether orders were not covered by guidelines, appropriate, of uncertain suitability, or inappropriate according to professional society guidelines. Order providers may override or accept CDS. We consider actionable alerts to be those that could lead to immediate order behavior change in the ordering physician (ie, cancellation of inappropriate orders or modification of orders of uncertain suitability that had a recommended alternative). Chi-square and logistic regression identified predictors of order cancellation or modification after an alert. RESULTS: A total of 98,894 radiology orders were entered (83,114 after the intervention). Vendors ignored 98.9%, modified 1.1%, and canceled 0.03% of orders in response to alerts. Actionable alerts had a 10-fold higher rate of modification (8.1% vs. 0.7%"; p < 0.0001) or cancellation (0.2% vs. 0.02%; p < 0.0001) compared to non-actionable alerts Orders from institutions with pre-existing image CDS had a seven times lower rate of cancellation or modification than sites with recently implemented CDS (1.4% vs. 0.2%; p < 0.0001) On multivariate analysis, actionable alerts were 12 times more likely to result in order cancellation or modification Orders on sites with pre-existing CDS were 7.7 times less likely to be canceled or modified ( p < 0.0001) CONCLUSION: Using the results of the Medicare Imaging Demonstration Project, we identified potential factors that were associated with the effect of CDS on provider ordering of images;" these findings may have implications for the future design of such computerized systems.

title: Judgments about the normative behavior of health professionals: an experimental study
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To explore judgments of rule-related behavior by health professionals and the general public in the UK, in a context of proliferating clinical guidelines and protocols. DESIGN: A questionnaire survey was used in which brief scenarios describing medical practice were presented to a sample of health professionals and members of the general public. METHODS: The health care sample consisted of 315 nurses, doctors and midwives from three English National Health Service (NHS) trusts who volunteered to participate in the study. A stratified sample of members of the general public (N = 350) was recruited through a market research organization. Three types of behavior (adherence to a protocol, violation of a protocol, and improvisation, where no protocol exists) and three types of patient outcomes (good, bad, poor) were manipulated within nine scenarios. Respondents were asked to make judgments about (1) the inappropriateness of the behavior (2) the likelihood that they would take further action, and (3) responsibility for the outcome. RESULTS: The findings suggest that the process of care has a greater effect on judgments about the behavior of health professionals than the result of that behavior. This was equally true for professional and public displays. CONCLUSIONS: The study has both theoretical and practical implications. First, information about the relationship of a behavior to existing rules has a stronger influence than the consequence of the behavior on attributions of responsibility. Second, the use of clinical protocols as a way to manage risk in the NHS may be counterproductive unless full compliance is achieved.

title: Council of the Judiciary offers new guidelines for investigation
Judicious use of antibiotics for common pediatric respiratory infections
abstract: BACKGROUND: Antibiotic resistance among bacteria that cause common respiratory infections, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis, has become a major global public health problem. The use of antibiotics, whether medically justified or not for a particular disease, contributes to the development of resistant bacteria. To help contain the spread of drug-resistant bacteria, members of the CDC and the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recently published principles for the judicious use of antibiotics in common pediatric respiratory infections, including the common cold, otitis media , sinusitis and pharyngotonsillitis. . This article reviews the CDC/AAP principles for the management of these diseases and describes the results of clinical practice studies in which efforts have been made to improve the judicious use of antibiotics. CONCLUSIONS: The success of the CDC/AAP principles in containing the rise of antimicrobial resistance depends on your practice. Results from clinical practice studies indicate that judicious use of antimicrobial therapy in pediatric respiratory infections can be achieved through education and persistence. More widespread educational and behavior modification efforts are needed to reduce unnecessary antibiotic prescribing and reduce the still burgeoning problem of bacterial resistance.

title: Youth working hours
Evidence-based just-in-time email “reminders” in home health care: impact on patient outcomes
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the impact and cost-effectiveness of two information-based provider reminder interventions designed to improve self-care management and outcomes for patients with heart failure (HF). DATA SOURCES/STUDY LOCATION: Interview and agency administrative data on 628 home care patients with a primary diagnosis of HF. STUDY DESIGN: Patients were managed by nurses randomly assigned to usual care or to one of two intervention groups. The basic intervention was an email to the patient's nurse outlining six HF-specific clinical recommendations. The augmented intervention supplemented the initial nursing reminder with additional resources for clinicians and patients. DATA COLLECTION: Patients were interviewed 45 days after admission to measure self-management behaviors, HF-specific outcomes (Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire-KCCQ), health-related quality of life (EuroQoL ) and the use of the service. MAIN FINDINGS: Both interventions improved the mean KCCQ total score (15.3 and 12.9 percent, respectively) relative to usual care (p< or = 0.05). The core intervention also produced a higher EuroQoL score relative to usual care (p < or = 0.05). In addition, the interventions had a positive impact on knowledge of medication, diet, and weight control. The basic intervention was more cost-effective than the augmented intervention in improving clinical outcomes. CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrates the positive impact of directing evidence-based computerized reminders to homecare nurses for improving patient self-care behaviors, knowledge, and clinical outcomes. It also advances the field's limited understanding of the profitability of selected strategies to put research into practice.

title: Evidence-based just-in-time email "reminders" in home health care: impact on patient outcomes.
abstract: Goal. To assess the impact and cost-effectiveness of two information-based provider reminder interventions designed to improve self-management management and outcomes for patients with heart failure (HF). Data sources/Study setup. Interview and agency administrative data on 628 home care patients with a primary diagnosis of HF. Study design. Patients were managed by nurses randomly assigned to usual care or to one of two intervention groups. The basic intervention was an email to the patient's nurse outlining six HF-specific clinical recommendations. The augmented intervention supplemented the initial nursing reminder with additional resources for clinicians and patients. Data collection. Patients were interviewed 45 days after admission to measure self-management behaviors, HF-specific outcomes (Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire-KCCQ), health-related quality of life (EuroQoL), and service use. . Main findings. Both interventions improved the mean KCCQ total score (15.3 and 12.9 percent, respectively) relative to usual care (p = 0.05). The basic intervention also produced a higher EuroQoL score relative to usual care (p = 0.05). In addition, the interventions had a positive impact on knowledge of medication, diet, and weight control. The basic intervention was more cost-effective than the augmented intervention in improving clinical outcomes. Conclusions. This study demonstrates the positive impact of targeting evidence-based computerized reminders to home care nurses in improving patient self-care behaviors, knowledge, and clinical outcomes. It also advances the field's limited understanding of the profitability of selected strategies to put research into practice.

title: Just-in-time evidence-based email "reminders" in home health care: impact on nursing practices.
abstract: Goal. To test the effectiveness of two interventions designed to improve the adoption of evidence-based practices by home care nurses caring for patients with heart failure (HF). Data sources/Study setup. Information on nursing practices was extracted from the medical records of patients admitted between June 2000 and November 2001 for the care of 354 study nurses in a large urban nonprofit home care agency. Study design. The study used a randomized design with nurses assigned to usual care or one of two intervention groups after identification of an eligible patient. The core intervention was a single email reminder highlighting six HF-specific clinical recommendations. The augmented intervention consisted of the initial email reminder supplemented by provider instructions, patient education material, and clinical nurse specialist outreach. Data collection. At each home health visit provided by a study nurse to an eligible HF patient during the 45-day follow-up period, a structured graph abstraction tool was used to collect information on whether the nurse provided the care practices highlighted in the study. email reminder. . Main findings. Both the basic and augmented interventions significantly increased the practice of evidence-based care, based on patient records, in the areas of patient assessment and HF disease management instruction. Although not all results were statistically significant at conventional levels, intervention effects were positive in virtually all cases and effect sizes were often large. Conclusions. The results of this randomized trial strongly support the efficacy of evidence-based just-in-time reminders as a means of changing clinical practice among home care nurses who are geographically dispersed and spend much of their time in the field.

title: Kids Safe and Smokefree (KiSS): a randomized controlled trial of a multilevel intervention to reduce secondhand smoke exposure in children
abstract: BACKGROUND: Secondhand smoke exposure (SeHS) harms children's health, but effective interventions to reduce childhood SEHS in the home and car have proven difficult to implement in pediatric practice. A multilevel intervention that combines counseling from pediatric health care providers with behavioral counseling and navigation to pharmacological smoking cessation aids may improve control of eSH in pediatric populations. METHODS/DESIGN: This trial uses a two-group randomized design with three measurement periods: pre-intervention, end of treatment, and 12-month follow-up. Smoking parents of children under 11 years of age are recruited from pediatric clinics. Clinical-level intervention includes integration of smoking intervention guidelines into electronic health record screens. The prompts guide providers to ask all parents about childhood SEHS, counsel on the harms of SEHS, and refer smokers to smoking cessation resources. After receiving the clinical intervention, eligible parents are randomized to receive: (a) a 3-month telephone behavioral counseling intervention designed to promote reduction of childhood SHSe, parental smoking cessation, and navigation to accessing nicotine replacement therapy or smoking cessation medications or (b) a nutrition education intervention for attention management. Healthcare providers and evaluators are blind to group assignment. Cotinine is used to bioassess the child's SHSe (primary outcome) and parental neglect status. DISCUSSION: This study tests an innovative multilevel approach to reduce childhood SeHS. The approach is sustainable, because clinics can easily integrate smoking intervention indications related to "ask, advise and refer" guidelines into electronic health records and refer smokers to free evidence-based behavioral counseling interventions , such as state quitlines. TRIAL REGISTRATION: NCT01745393 (clinicaltrials.gov).

title: Kindergarten Readiness After Prematurity: Integrating Health, Development, and Behavioral Functioning to Optimize Educational Outcomes for Vulnerable Children
abstract: In the last 20 years, many advances (eg, maternal steroids and surfactant) have changed the course of neonatal medicine. As a result, extremely premature babies survive medical complications that were once fatal. Once discharged from the neonatal intensive care unit, premature babies can continue to experience a spectrum of medical and developmental challenges, and their families face the potentially daunting task of raising a vulnerable child. Families may be referred to multiple systems of care, including primary care physicians, pediatric subspecialists, and early intervention services. The ultimate goal for premature babies is to optimize their motor, communication, social-emotional, and adaptive development, as well as to promote their learning at home, school, and in the community. As children transition to school, key indicators of their functional status include the amount of developmental, educational, habilitative, and behavioral supports they need to participate in learning activities with their peers. Success can be measured by whether preemies are ready for learning in large groups with their peers and the degree of support needed to make this important transition. The purpose of this review is to describe what is known about certain indicators of school readiness in preterm infants, including neurodevelopmental disorders, socioemotional skills, and social factors. We conclude with guidelines for using this transition as an important indicator of developmental trajectories that can help us better understand risk and resilience in this vulnerable population of children.

title: Knowledge, attitudes, and use of low-dose computed tomography for lung cancer screening among family physicians.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Results from the National Lung Screening Trial showed a 20% reduction in lung cancer mortality and a 6.7% reduction in all-cause mortality when high-risk patients were screened with low-dose computed tomography. low (LDCT) versus chest radiography (CXR). The US Preventive Services Task Force has issued a grade B recommendation for LDCT screening, and the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services and private insurers now cover the cost of screening under certain conditions. The purpose of this study was to assess knowledge, attitudes, and use of LDCT screening for lung cancer among family physicians. METHODS: A 32-item questionnaire was distributed to members of the South Carolina Academy of Family Physicians in 2015. Descriptive statistics were calculated. RESULTS: There were 101 respondents, and most had incorrect knowledge about which organizations recommended screening. Many doctors continued to recommend CXR for lung cancer screening. Most felt that LDCT screening increased the odds of detecting disease earlier (98%) and that the benefits outweighed the harms (75%). Concerns included unnecessary procedures (88%), stress/anxiety (52%), and radiation exposure (50%). Most physicians discussed the risks/benefits of screening with their patients to some extent (76%); however, more than 50% reported having made 1 or no screening recommendation in the past year. CONCLUSIONS: Most family physicians report discussing LDCT with patients at high risk for lung cancer; however, referrals remain low. There are gaps in clinicians' knowledge of screening guidelines and reimbursement, and this indicates a need for further educational outreach. The development of decision aids can facilitate shared discussions for decision making about screening, and targeted interventions can fill knowledge gaps. Cancer 2016;"122:2324-2331. (c) 2016 American Cancer Society.

title: Translation of knowledge of research results.
abstract: Background One of the most consistent findings of clinical and health services research is the failure to translate research into practice and policy. As a result of these gaps between evidence and practice and policy, patients do not benefit optimally from advances in medical care and are exposed to unnecessary risks of iatrogenic harm, and health care systems are exposed to high costs. unnecessary costs that generate significant opportunity costs. Over the past decade, there has been increasing international research and policy attention on how to bridge the gap between evidence and practice and policy. In this paper, we summarize current concepts and evidence to guide knowledge translation activities, defined as T2 research (the translation of new clinical knowledge into better health). We structured the article around five key questions: what should be transferred"; to whom should research knowledge be transferred; by whom should research knowledge be transferred; how should research knowledge be transferred"; And, with what effect should research knowledge be transferred? Discussion We suggest that the basic unit of knowledge translation should generally be up-to-date systematic reviews or other syntheses of research findings. Knowledge translators need to identify the key messages for different target audiences and convert them into language and knowledge translation products that are easily assimilated by different audiences. The relative importance of knowledge translation for different target audiences will vary depending on the type of research, and the appropriate endpoints of knowledge translation may vary between different stakeholder groups. There are a large number of planned knowledge translation models, derived from different disciplinary, contextual (i.e. scenarios) and target audience viewpoints. Most of these suggest that planned knowledge translation for healthcare professionals and consumers is more likely to be successful if the choice of knowledge translation strategy is based on an assessment of potential barriers and facilitators. Although our evidence on the possible effectiveness of different strategies to overcome specific barriers remains incomplete, there are a variety of informative systematic reviews of interventions directed at health professionals and consumers (ie, patients, family members, and informal carers) and of important factors. for research use by policymakers. Summary There is a substantial (albeit incomplete) evidence base to guide the choice of knowledge translation activities aimed at health professionals and consumers. The evidence base on the effects of different knowledge translation approaches targeting health care policy makers and senior managers is much weaker, but there are a large number of innovative approaches that warrant further evaluation.

title: Translation of knowledge from the American College of Emergency Physicians clinical policy on syncope using computerized clinical decision support
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To influence medical practice behavior after implementation of a computerized clinical decision support system (CDSS) based on the 2007 ACEP Clinical Policy on Syncope recommendations. METHODS: This was a pre-post intervention. with a prospective cohort and retrospective controls. We performed a review of the medical records of consecutive adult patients with syncope. A computerized CDSS was incorporated into the emergency department information system (EDIS) that prompted clinicians to explain their decision-making regarding imaging and admission in patients with syncope based on ACEP clinical policy recommendations. Medical records of 410 consecutive adult patients presenting with syncope prior to implementation were reviewed, and 301 records were reviewed after implementation. Primary outcomes were medical practice performance as demonstrated by admission rate and head computed tomography (CT) imaging rate before and after implementation. RESULTS: There was a significant difference in the admission rate before and after the intervention (68.1% vs. 60.5%, respectively, p = 0.036). There was no significant difference in the rate of head CT imaging before and after the intervention (39.8% vs. 43.2%, p = 0.358). There were seven physicians who saw ten or more patients pre- and post-intervention. Subset analysis of the practice behavior of these seven physicians revealed a slightly significant difference in admission rate before and after the intervention (74.3% vs. 63.9%, p = 0.0495) and no difference significant in the rate of computed tomography of the head before and after the intervention. -intervention (42.9% vs 45.4%, p = 0.660). CONCLUSIONS: The introduction of an evidence-based CDSS based on the ACEP clinical policy recommendations on syncope was correlated with a change in medical practice behavior in an urban academic emergency department. This change suggests that the recommendations of the emergency medicine clinical practice guidelines can be incorporated into the medical workflow of an EDIS to improve the quality of practice.

title: Knowledge versus practice: the need for education for successful guideline implementation
abstract: This study assessed clinicians' familiarity with a bronchiolitis practice guideline, assessed attitudes toward the guidelines, determined preference of educational materials for guideline accessibility, and examined the relationship between familiarity with the guideline and attitudes with behaviors in clinical practice. Six months after guideline implementation, surveys were distributed to eligible clinicians. The response rate was 68%. Retrospective analyzes of inhalation therapies in three study cohorts were also performed. Most clinicians surveyed in this study were aware of and used a recently introduced guideline, although use of unproven inhalation therapies continued. Despite the demonstrated efficiency of care, continuous educational intervention is necessary to maintain these achievements.

title: Knowledge, attitudes, and practices around breast cancer screening in educated Appalachian women.
abstract: PURPOSE/OBJECTIVES: To determine how and what women learn about breast cancer and screening practices and what factors influence women's breast cancer screening practices. DESIGN: Descriptive analysis of questionnaire data collected at the time of enrollment in a clinical trial. SETTING: Breast care center of a mid-Atlantic academic health sciences center. SAMPLE: 185 women in a predominantly Appalachian, entirely rural state. METHODS: Participants completed the Modified Toronto Breast Self-Examination Inventory and questions related to personal mammography practices at enrollment prior to randomization in a longitudinal clinical intervention study. KEY RESEARCH VARIABLES: women's demographics, knowledge of breast cancer screening practices, adherence to breast cancer screening guidelines, and motivation, knowledge, and practical competence around breast cancer screening. FINDINGS: These educated women had knowledge deficits about breast cancer, breast cancer risk factors, and screening guidelines, particularly timing and practice behaviors for breast self-examination. Women who had received education about health care and cancer screening from health care providers, including advanced practice nurses, were more knowledgeable about breast cancer and screening practices. CONCLUSIONS: Women still have knowledge deficits about breast cancer, breast cancer screening, and personal risk factors. Also, some educated women in this study did not get breast cancer screening according to current guidelines. IMPLICATIONS FOR NURSING: Physicians should continue to remind and update women about breast disease, and cancer screening practices in women should be strengthened. All levels of providers must improve their rates of performing clinical breast exams with physical exams. Nurses, who have a great influence on women's health care, must keep up-to-date in their knowledge of breast disease, detection and treatment.

title: KRAS and colorectal cancer: ethical and pragmatic issues for effecting real-time change in clinical trials and oncology practice
abstract: Systemic therapy has led to a median survival time for patients with advanced colorectal cancer (CRC) nearly four times longer than expected with the best supportive care, a result achieved by combining targeted chemotherapeutic and biologic agents. Although the latter may include anti-epidermal growth factor receptor antibodies, such as cetuximab and panitumumab, we now have strong evidence that patients whose tumors harbor mutated KRAS will not benefit from this class of agent. However, acceptance of the reliability and importance of the KRAS data took several years to evolve for a variety of reasons. The timeline from the presentation and publication of small retrospective phase II studies to the widespread acceptance of the predictive value of KRAS and behavioral changes, specifically, modifications of ongoing national trials in advanced/metastatic CRC, changes in national guidelines, and practice patterns, and adjustments to labeled indications for monoclonal antibodies - was long. In this commentary, we discuss whether the process of disclosing data on the status of KRAS and the treatment of patients with advanced CRC was effective in allowing timely decisions regarding ongoing publicly funded clinical trials and whether or not such decisions were rational and ethical. The general objectives are to highlight the lessons learned regarding the early disclosure of clinical trial results, as well as the investigation and adoption of new scientific data, and to propose modifications to handle similar situations in the future.

title: The design of the laboratory test form influences the ordering of tests by general practitioners in the Netherlands
abstract: The effect of listing fewer laboratory tests on the test request form on the test requesting behavior of a group of 47 Dutch general practitioners was studied. The number of laboratory tests ordered by this experimental group over a 12-month period was recorded. The old usual standard form was used by a control group of 28 general practitioners in a different region. After having used the old standard form with 178 tests for 5 months, the experimental group received forms listing only 15 hematology and chemistry tests plus several urine and stool tests, with space left for 'others'. A comparison of the experimental and control periods showed that the number of tests requested per month in the experimental group was reduced by 18. When the usual standard form was reintroduced, GPs rapidly returned to their previous pattern. The results revealed that the fixed and often unsound routine influences the use of additional diagnostic procedures. Also, limiting and restructuring the evidence request forms may break the routine, but does not essentially change the logic of the evidence request behavior.

title: Lack of Effectiveness of Reminder Charts on JNC-VI and NCEP III Family Medicine Residents' Guideline Knowledge and Attitudes
abstract: BACKGROUND: The literature demonstrates that resident physicians and practicing physicians have an attitudinal-behavioral mismatch in their positive attitudes toward clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) and the implementation of these guidelines in clinical practice patterns. METHODS: A pilot study was conducted to determine whether changing a previously identified CPG adherence factor (accessibility) would produce a significant increase in family medicine residents' knowledge and attitude toward the guidelines. The primary study intervention involved posting a summary of the Sixth Report of the Joint National Committee on Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment of High Blood Pressure (JNC VI) and the National Cholesterol Education Program Expert Panel on Screening, Evaluation, and and Treatment of High Blood Cholesterol in Adults (NCEP III) CPG in all patient registries (>18 years) for a period of three months. The JNC VI and NCEP III CPGs were also distributed to each Wayne State family medicine resident, and a copy of each CPG was posted in the preceptor's area of the involved clinics. All residents were administered identical pre- and post-intervention questionnaires on knowledge and attitudes about CPGs. RESULTS: Post-intervention analysis failed to demonstrate a significant difference in CPG knowledge. A statistically significant difference was found after the intervention only in the attitude question. Barriers to compliance with the CPGs were identified as 1) lack of CPG instruction"; 2) lack of critical appraisal capacity; 3) insufficient time; 4) lack of accessibility to the CPGs"; and 5) lack of teaching modeling. CONCLUSION: This study did not demonstrate significant post-intervention changes in CPG knowledge, and only one question reflected a change in attitude. Increased resident access to clinic time, increased faculty modeling, and implementation of an electronic check-in/reminder system that uses a team-based approach are adherence factors to consider for further investigation. The interpretation of non-compliance with the CPG will benefit from a causal matrix focused on the knowledge, attitudes and behavior of the doctor. Recent findings on resident knowledge-behavior discordance may steer future research into physician CPG noncompliance from generalized barrier research and toward developing information that maximizes the sense of urgency and certainty of clinical practice. single doctor.

title: Depression in old age in primary care. How well are we doing?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To know the attitudes of primary care physicians towards their abilities to detect and treat depression in the elderly. DESIGN: A self-administered questionnaire sent to 1,000 primary care physicians in the state of Michigan. SETTING: The survey was sent to physicians practicing general internal medicine or family practice. PARTICIPANTS: The questionnaire was sent to 500 MD and 500 DO physicians; general internal medicine and family medicine were given equal representation. Of all 1,000 physicians, 60% (n = 604) responded, 51% (n = 309 ) were MD's, 48% (n = 295) were DO's, 41% (n = 245) were general internists, and 59% (n = 359) were family physicians MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: Despite positive attitudes about their abilities to screen for and treat depression in the elderly, only a quarter of respondents routinely used a screening tool in practice Forty-one percent of all clinicians were unaware of depression practice guidelines. Family physicians were more confident in their treatment skills than general internists (85% vs 50%; chi 2 = 11.42, p < or = .003). Male physicians more frequently endorsed pharmacological treatment, while female physicians more frequently used counseling and exercise techniques to treat older depressed patients. Half of all physicians felt informed about community resources for treating older patients with depression. CONCLUSIONS: This survey identified several perceived needs for future targeted interventions: (1) additional exposure to the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research guidelines for all primary care physicians, (2) physician-specific counseling skills intervention male physicians and medication management for female physicians, and (3) additional continuing medical education intervention for practicing general internists. More research is needed to correlate clinicians' attitudes with subsequent behaviors to fully appreciate the nature of treating depression in old age within the primary care setting.

title: Learning and behavior., 5th ed.
abstract: This book examines how people and animals learn and how their behaviors are subsequently modified. This text is designed for introductory or intermediate level courses in behavioral learning, conditioning, or experimental analysis. Chapter 1 discusses the nature of scientific experiments and theories, and contrasts behavioral and cognitive approaches to learning. Chapter 2 describes theories about the learning process. Chapters 3 and 4 discuss innate behaviors and habituation and examine the basic principles of classical conditioning. Chapter 5 describes more recent theoretical developments and experimental findings in this area. Chapters 6, 7, and 8 deal with operant conditioning and examine positive reinforcement"; schedules of reinforcement"; and negative reinforcement and punishment, respectively. Chapter 9 presents different views on such questions as what constitutes a reinforcer and what conditions are necessary for learning to occur. Chapter 10 looks further into generalization and discrimination and reviews research on concept formation. Chapter 11 reviews a wide range of findings in the area of comparative cognition. Chapters 12 and 13 discuss observational learning and motor skills. Finally, Chapter 14 presents an overview of behavioral research on choice. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2016 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: Learning Assessment: Combining Implementation and Quality Improvement Research Methods to Study Innovations in Health Care
abstract: Background In healthcare change interventions, on-the-ground learning about the implementation process is often lost due to a primary focus on improving outcomes. This article describes learning assessment, a methodological approach that combines quality improvement and implementation research methods to study innovations in health care. Methods Learning assessment is an approach to assessing multiple organizations. Qualitative and quantitative data is collected to perform real-time assessment of implementation processes while assessing changes in context, facilitating quality improvement through execution charts and audit and feedback, and generating lessons transportable. Five principles underlie this approach: (1) collect data to describe the changes made by healthcare organizations and how the changes are implemented"; (2) collect process and outcome data relevant to healthcare organizations and for the research team; (3) Assess multi-level contextual factors that affect implementation, process, outcome, and portability; (4) Help healthcare organizations use data for continuous quality improvement; and (5) implement common measurement strategies to generate transportable results organizations by: (1) establishing a detailed understanding of the baseline implementation plan (2) identifying target populations and tracking actions relevant process data (3) collect and analyze real-time quantitative and qualitative data on important contextual factors (4) ) s synthesize emerging data and findings and share them with stakeholders on an ongoing basis;" and (5) harmonize and foster learning from process and outcome data. Application to a multisite program focused on primary care and behavioral health integration shows the feasibility and utility of learning assessment to generate real-time insights into evolving implementation processes. Conclusions Learning assessment generates systematic and rigorous cross-organizational findings on the implementation of health care innovations, while improving organizational capacity and accelerating translation of findings by facilitating continuous learning within individual sites. Researchers evaluating change initiatives and healthcare organizations implementing improvement initiatives can benefit from a learning evaluation approach.

title: Learning with computerized guides in general practice? A randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Bottom. Evidence-based guidelines are considered an important instrument to transfer scientifically generated knowledge to daily clinical practice and guarantee high standards of clinical care. Despite their wide promulgation, clinical guidelines have so far had limited impact on individual professional learning and changing daily medical practice. Goals. Our objectives were (i) to study a potential increase in knowledge among German general practitioners after the implementation of evidence-based and web-based guidelines and (ii) to identify and analyze potential barriers to individual professional learning with computerized guidelines. Methods. A prospective, randomized, controlled trial involving 72 GPs (21% women, 79% men) was conducted. The intervention group (n = 38) had access to the clinical guidelines via the Internet or CD-ROM, the control group did not (n = 34). Both groups received a standardized two-part questionnaire. An increase in knowledge was measured with 25 multiple-choice questions related to four different medical topics. In addition, the reasons for using or not using computerized guidelines after access to the guidelines was open to all participating physicians were analyzed. Results. There was no significant increase in knowledge in the intervention group (P = 0.69). Twenty-two (58%) GPs in the intervention group had used the guidelines. Unspecified curiosity (76%) and a specific medical question (38%) were the predominant reasons for use among clinicians who had used the guidelines. Among 'non-users', 78% indicated that 'lack of time' was the main reason for not using the guides. Conclusion. Efficient knowledge transfer was not achieved through computerized guides. Usage, individual learning and potential implementation depend on proper incentives and pragmatic aspects of clinical practice: easy and fast access.

title: left handed
Legal responsibility of physicians in medical research
abstract: The intent of this document is to provide a general description, in plain language, of legal concepts that may be applicable to a physician conducting research. The document is divided into 2 parts. Part I deals with liability issues and standards of care. It is intended to allow the clinician/investigator to recognize a potential liability situation. Part II examines insurance and related topics, such as the role of the Canadian Medical Protection Association (CMPA). The document begins with a review of 2 possible categories of liability: civil and criminal liability. The legal issues surrounding the consent process, which make up the majority of malpractice claims, are discussed below. The research process is then discussed with an emphasis on the Canadian Medical Research Council Guidelines on Human Experimentation. Part II covers how research projects are funded and identifies the parties from whom insurance coverage may be sought. Information is provided from the various sources that offer insurance and quasi-insurance protection with a focus on the CMPA. Each source details the circumstances necessary for their particular coverage to be activated. Other topics covered include those that arise when research takes place outside of Canada and multiple coverage.

title: Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Health Disparities: Executive Summary of an American College of Physicians Policy Position Paper
abstract: In this position paper, the American College of Physicians examines the health disparities experienced by the lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) community and makes a series of recommendations to achieve equity for LGBT people in the health care system. . These recommendations include improving clinicians' understanding of how to provide culturally and clinically competent care to LGBT people, addressing environmental and social factors that can affect their mental and physical well-being, and supporting more research to understand their unique health needs.

title: Lessons from a randomized controlled trial designed to evaluate computer decision support software to improve asthma management
abstract: Primary objective: To investigate whether computerized decision support software used in the treatment of patients with asthma improves clinical outcomes. Research Design: Randomized controlled trial with practices, each reporting on 30 patients with asthma over a 6-month period. Methods and procedures: 447 patients were randomly selected from asthma practice registries run by 17 general practices across the UK. Intervention practices used the software during consultations with these patients throughout the study, while control practices did not. Main outcomes and results: practice visits, acute exacerbations of asthma, hospital contacts, symptoms in the evaluation and use of medications. A smaller proportion of patients in the intervention group initiated practice visits for their asthma: 34 (22%) vs 111 (34%), odds ratio (OR) = 0.59, 95% confidence interval (CI) (0.37-0.95)"; " and experienced acute asthma exacerbations: 12 (8%) vs 57 (17%), OR = 0.43, 95% CI = 0.21-0.85 six months after the introduction of decision support computer software. There were no discernible differences in reported symptoms, maintenance prescription, or use of hospital services between the two groups. Conclusion: The use of decision support software that implements guidelines during patient consultations can improve clinical outcomes for patients with asthma.

title: Lessons from the evaluation of the UK NHS R&D Implementation Methods Program
abstract: Background Concern for the effective use of research was a major factor behind the creation of the NHS R&D Program in 1991. In 1994, an advisory group was established to identify research priorities in the implementation of research. The Implementation Methods Program (IMP) grew out of this, and its start-up group funded 36 projects. In 2000, responsibility for the program passed to the National Coordinating Center for NHS Organization and Service Delivery R&D, which asked the Health Economics Research Group (HERG), Brunel University, to carry out an assessment in 2002. By then, most of the projects had been completed. . This evaluation was intended to cover: the quality of the products, the lessons learned about the communication strategy and the start-up process, and the benefits of the projects. Methods We adopt a wide range of quantitative and qualitative methods. They included: desk review, stakeholder interviews, questionnaires for funded principal investigators, questionnaires for potential users, and desk analysis. Results Quantitative evaluation of outputs and dissemination revealed that the IMP funded useful research projects, some of which had considerable impact on the various categories of the HERG recovery model, such as publications, additional research, research training, impact on health policy and clinical practice. . Qualitative results from interviews with commissioning and advisory group members indicated that when the IMP was established, implementation research was a relatively unexplored field. This was reflected in advisory and commissioning group members' understanding of their roles, in how priorities for research were chosen and developed, and in how research projects were commissioned. The ideological and methodological debates associated with these decisions have continued among those who work in this field. The need for an effective communication strategy for the program as a whole was particularly important. However, such a strategy was never developed, making it difficult to establish the overall influence of the IMP as a program. Conclusion Our findings about the impact of funded work and the difficulties faced by IMP developers have implications for the development of strategic research programs in general, as well as for the development of more effective research in this field.

title: Letter: Mucosal ulceration in celiac disease
Harnessing insights from behavioral economics to increase the value of health care delivery
abstract: US health spending continues to rise at unsustainable rates. A recent move around increased pricing transparency has been suggested as a way to slow the rate of spending growth, with legislative efforts at both the state and federal levels. While this seems like a good idea at first glance, simply providing pricing information to physicians, particularly interns, may not achieve the kind of big changes in practice patterns that proponents hope for. How price transparency is implemented will likely play a significant role in its effectiveness as an intervention. In this article, the authors review transparency efforts and defaults from other contexts and draw on insights from behavioral economics to provide recommendations for increasing the likelihood that price transparency will lead clinicians to weigh the relative value of prices. the interventions.

title: LGB Affirmative Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Young Adult Gay and Bisexual Men: A Randomized Controlled Trial of a Transdiagnostic Minority Stress Approach
abstract: OBJECTIVES: We tested the preliminary efficacy of a tailored transdiagnostic cognitive-behavioral treatment for improving depression, anxiety, and co-occurring health risks (ie, alcohol use, sexual compulsivity, condomless sex) among gay and bisexual young adult men. Treatment accommodations focused on reducing minority stress processes that underlie mental health disparities related to sexual orientation. METHOD: Young homosexual and bisexual men (n = 63"; M age = 25.94) were randomized to receive immediate treatment or a 3-month waiting list. At baseline assessments, at 3 months and 6 months, participants completed minority mental health and stress self-reports and an interview about risk behavior from the past 90 days. RESULTS: Compared to waiting list, treatment significantly reduced depressive symptoms (b = -2.43, 95% CI: -4.90, 0.35, p < 0.001), alcohol use problems (b = -3.79, 95% CI: -5.94, -1.64). , p < 0.001), sexual compulsiveness (b = -5.09, 95% CI: -8.78, -1.40, p < 0.001), and sex without a condom during the last 90 days with casual partners (b = -1.09, 95% CI: -1.80, -0.37, p < .001), and improved self-efficacy in condom use (b = 10.08, 95% CI: 3.86, 16.30, p < .001). Treatment produced moderately and marginally significant improvements greater than waiting list in anxiety symptoms (b = -2.14, 95% CI: -4.61, 0.34, p = 0.09) and consumption binge drinking in the last 90 days (b = -0.32, 95% CI: -0.71, 0.07, p = 0.09). In general, the effects were maintained during follow-up. Minor stress processes showed small improvements in the expected direction. CONCLUSION: This study demonstrated preliminary support for the first tailored intervention to address the co-occurring health problems of gay and bisexual men originating from minority stress. If found to be effective compared to standard evidence-based treatments, the treatment will have substantial potential to help clinicians translate affirmative LGB treatment guidelines into evidence-based practice. (PsycINFO database record

title: Lifestyle advice provided by primary health care to prevent cardiovascular diseases
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Working Group on Hypertension of the Norwegian College of General Practitioners reports in this document on the documentation on behavioral advice in the prevention of cardiovascular diseases. Hypertension is emphasized. MATERIAL AND METHODS: Recommendations are based primarily on updated meta-analyses and randomized controlled trials. Hypertension is treated to prevent cardiovascular diseases";" that's why we put an emphasis on documentation with meaningful endpoints. The validity of the documentation for general practice is assessed. We also look at whether certain methods or theories for behavior change might be useful to the general practitioner. RESULTS: The value of anti-smoking advice, dietary advice (increasing intake of grains, vegetables, fruit, poultry, and fish), and exercise advice is well documented and applicable in general practice. Respect for patient autonomy and concern for the patient and their health-related habits appear to be important factors in improving the physician's ability to influence patient behavior. INTERPRETATION: The value of lifestyle advice is well documented and should play an important role in clinical strategies to prevent cardiovascular disease in high-risk patients.

title: Life support technologies and the elderly
Lifestyle counseling in primary care: long-term effects on cholesterol level
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the long-term effectiveness of lifestyle advice for subjects at low to moderate cardiovascular (CV) risk in primary care. METHODS: DESIGN: Prospective comparison of baseline versus postintervention, and comparison of enrolled patients versus control subjects drawn from a large primary care database. SETTING: 94 general practices in Italy. PARTICIPANTS: All hypercholesterolemic subjects aged 20-70 years who did not qualify for statin treatment according to the guidelines and who were seen in 12 predetermined business days"; 713 patients; 94 general practitioners. INTERVENTION: Short (5-10 min) intervention educational (qualitative dietary advice, promotion of walking or other aerobic physical activities);" distributing simple dietary advice at the doctor's discretion. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Total cholesterol level and global CV risk calculated according to the Framingham equation. RESULTS: Total cholesterol and global CV risk (10 years) decreased by 0.31 mmol/l (p < 0.0001, 95% CI 0.23-0.40) and 1.35% (p < 0.01). , 95% CI -1.73 to -0.97), respectively. after a 54-month follow-up. The included patients showed a greater decrease in total cholesterol than the control patients: 2.24% (p < 0.05, 95% CI: 0.58-3.91%). CONCLUSIONS: A simple long-term in-office lifestyle counseling program produces a small but clinically significant reduction in total cholesterol and overall CV risk. This finding should encourage GPs to routinely offer simple, unstructured lifestyle advice to all their patients.

title: Lifestyle interventions in primary health care: professional and organizational challenges
abstract: BACKGROUND: Interventions that support patients' efforts at lifestyle changes that reduce tobacco use, hazardous alcohol use, unhealthy eating habits, and insufficient physical activity represent important areas of development for care. health. Current research shows that it is a challenge to reorient health care towards health promotion. The aim of this study was to explore the scope of health professionals' work with lifestyle interventions in Swedish primary health care, and to describe professional knowledge, attitudes and perceived organizational support for lifestyle interventions. Lifestyle. METHODS: The study is based on a web-based cross-sectional survey of general practitioners, other physicians, residents, public health nurses, and registered nurses (n = 315) in primary health care. RESULTS: Fifty-nine percent of participants indicated that lifestyle interventions were a substantial part of their duties. Most (77%) would like to work more with patients' lifestyles. Health professionals generally reported in-depth knowledge of lifestyle intervention methods for disease prevention. Significant differences were found between professional groups regarding specific knowledge and degree of work with lifestyle interventions. Alcohol was the least addressed lifestyle habit. Management was supportive, but structures to support work with lifestyle interventions were poor and the need for national guidelines was identified. CONCLUSIONS: Health professionals reported in-depth knowledge and positive attitudes towards lifestyle interventions. When planning further implementation of lifestyle interventions in primary health care, differences between professional groups in knowledge, scope of work with promoting healthy lifestyles, and related issues should be considered. with lifestyle and the provision of organizational support, such as national guidelines.

title: Lifestyle or life-saving drugs? A survey of consumer and primary health care professional opinion on over-the-counter statins
abstract: BACKGROUND: Over-the-counter (OTC) simvastatin 10 mg became available in the UK in July 2004 with the aim of improving the primary prevention of ischemic heart disease. OBJECTIVE: To document the views of key stakeholders (general practitioners [GPs], community pharmacists, and consumers) on issues related to the reclassification of simvastatin to OTC availability, highlight differences between stakeholder groups, and identify factors likely to influence consumer behavior. METHODS: Eight months after the UK launch of OTC simvastatin, a self-administered questionnaire survey of GPs, community pharmacists, and potentially eligible consumers was conducted. Participants were asked about their knowledge of the drug, their willingness to use such drugs, and their views on relevant management practices. RESULTS: Awareness of OTC simvastatin was high among GPs but low among consumers. Although pharmacists favored OTC availability, consumers and physicians generally thought it was not a good idea. GPs and pharmacists cited increased consumer choice as the most important likely benefit";" consumers thought that the potential savings for the NHS were equally important. Medication misuse and neglect of lifestyle risk factors were unanimously considered the most important likely risks. Unlike most pharmacists, most GPs thought current dosing schedules were inappropriate, but there was consensus that long-term non-adherence would likely reduce any benefit of treatment. Most respondents agreed that GPs should be informed if their patients were using OTC statins, but disagreed on the best way to communicate this information. CONCLUSIONS: The availability of OTC statins did not appear to be considered a popular public health intervention by consumers and GPs, as the drugs were widely perceived to be prone to misuse. However, OTC availability was favored by pharmacists, who saw this as empowering for both consumers and themselves. Key issues remain in the delivery, management, and evaluation of the public health impact of this intervention.

title: Lifetime prevalence of gender-based violence in women and the relationship with mental disorders and psychosocial function
abstract: Context Physical violence, rape, sexual assault and stalking by an intimate partner are pervasive and concurrent forms of gender-based violence (GBV). An association between these forms of abuse and lifelong mental illness and psychosocial disability among women needs to be examined. Objectives To assess the association of GV and mental disorder, its severity and comorbidity, and psychosocial functioning among women. Design, Setting, and Participants A cross-sectional study based on the 2007 Australian National Mental Health and Wellbeing Survey of 4451 women (65% response rate) aged 16 to 85 years. Main outcome measures The Composite International Diagnostic Interview version 3.0 of the World Health Organization's World Mental Health Survey Initiative was used to assess the lifetime prevalence of any mental disorder, anxiety, mood disorder, substance use disorder and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Also included were indices of lifetime exposure to trauma, including gender-based violence, sociodemographic characteristics, economic status, family history of mental disorders, social support, general mental and physical functioning, quality of life and general disability. Results A total of 1,218 women (27.4%) reported experiencing at least 1 type of GBV. For women exposed to 3 or 4 types of gender-based violence (n = 139), the rates of mental disorders were 77.3% (odds ratio [OR], 10.06"; confidence interval [CI] of 95%, 5.85-17.30) for anxiety disorders, 52.5% (OR, 3.59; 95% CI, 2.31-5.60) for mood disorder, 47.1 % (OR, 5.61; 95% CI, 3.46-9.10) for substance use disorder, 56.2% (OR, 15.90; 95% CI, 8.32-30.20) for PTSD, 89.4% (OR, 11.00; 95% CI, 5.46-22.17) for any mental disorder and 34.7% (OR, 14.80; 95% CI, 6.89- 31.60) for suicide attempts violence was associated with a more severe current mental disorder (OR, 4.60; 95% CI, 2.93-7.22), higher rates of 3 or more disorders over the lifetime (OR, 7.79; 95% CI, 6.10-9.95), physical disability (OR, 4.00; 95% CI, 1.82-8.82), mental disability (OR , 7.14; 95% CI, 2.87-17.75), impaired quality of life (OR, 2.96; 95% CI, 1.60-5.47), increased days of sick leave (OR, 3.14; 95% CI, 2.43 -4.05) and general disability (OR, 2.73; 95% CI, 1.99-3.75). Conclusion Among a nationally representative sample of Australian women, gender-based violence was significantly associated with mental health disorders, dysfunction, and disability.

title: 'Like sugar and honey': the entrenched ethics of a larval control project in The Gambia
abstract: This article describes a malaria research project in The Gambia to provoke reflection on the social value of transnational research. The Larval Control Project (LCP) investigated the efficacy of a microbial insecticide in reducing vector density and ultimately clinical malaria in Gambian children. The LCP protocol outlined a clinical surveillance scheme involving Village Health Workers (VHWs) supported by project nurses. Combining insights from ethnographic fieldwork conducted at the Medical Research Council (MRC) Laboratories in Farafenni from 2005 to 2009, open-ended interviews with project nurses, and eight focus group discussions conducted with participating mothers in October 2007, we consider the social impact of the LCP research method in the context of several years of research activity. We found that while participants associated the LCP with the clinical care it provided, they also viewed the collaboration between nurses and VHWs as adding additional benefits. Organized around the operational functions of the trial, the small-scale collaborations provided the platform from which to build local capacity. While the ethical guidelines emphasize considerations that should be added to the experimental effort in southern countries (for example, developing informed consent processes, developing community engagement strategies, or providing therapeutic access to participants after the trial concludes) , these findings suggest that shifting attention from complementing ethics protocols to everyday research work—embedding ethics throughout scientific activity—may provide a stronger foundation for reinforcing the relationship between scientific rigor and social value.

title: Limited impact of a multicenter intervention to improve the quality and efficiency of pneumonia care
abstract: STUDY OBJECTIVES: To assess the impact of a multifactorial intervention to improve the quality, efficiency, and patient understanding of care for community-acquired pneumonia. DESIGN: Time series cohort study. SETTING: Four academic health centers in the New York City metropolitan area. PATIENTS OR PARTICIPANTS: All consecutive adults hospitalized for pneumonia during a 5-month period before (n = 1,013) and after (n = 1,081) implementation of an inpatient quality improvement (QI) initiative. INTERVENTIONS: A multidisciplinary team of opinion leaders developed evidence-based and critical pathway treatment guidelines, conducted educational sessions with physicians, distributed pocket reminder cards, promoted standardized orders, and developed bilingual patient education materials. MEASUREMENTS AND RESULTS: The average age was 71.4 years, with 44.1% of cases at low risk, 36.8% at moderate risk, and 19.2% at high risk. The pre- and post-intervention groups were well matched for age, gender, race, nursing home, pneumonia severity, initial presentation, and most major comorbidities. The intervention increased the use of guideline-recommended antimicrobial therapy from 78.1% to 83.4% (p = 0.003). There was also a borderline decrease in the proportion of patients discharged before becoming clinically stable, from 27.0 to 23.5% (p = 0.06). However, there were no improvements in the other objective indicators, including time to first dose of antibiotics, proportion receiving antibiotics within 8 hours, timely switch to oral antibiotics, timely discharge, length of stay, or the results of patient education. CONCLUSIONS: This real-world QI program was able to modestly improve some quality indicators, but did not affect resource use or patient knowledge of their disease. Changing medical and organizational behavior in academic health centers will require the development and implementation of more intensive and system-oriented strategies.

title: Local clinical guidelines: description and evaluation of a participatory method for their development and implementation
abstract: BACKGROUND: National guidelines are rarely followed with immediate change in clinical behavior. We present our experience of an active educational method for local development and implementation of a guideline. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effectiveness of a participatory method for the development of local clinical guidelines. METHODS: A district trial of the effect of guideline development incorporating the active participation of intended recipients in subsequent relevant prescription. It was carried out in the Wirral Family Health Services Authority district (the Wirral Peninsula) and comprises 69 general practices covering a population of 345,763. An exemplary guideline on 'hypertension in the elderly' was developed using the method described. The main drug recommended was bendrofluazide 2.5 mg once daily. Differences in prescribed daily doses (PDD) of bendrofluazide 2.5 mg tablets per quarter per 1000 prescription units (age-weighted population) between the intervention district and England as a whole were measured. RESULTS: The comparison of the data from the intervention district with the data from England shows a mean difference of 122.49 PDD before and 206.34 PDD after the production of the guide, this change is statistically highly significant (Mann-Whitney two tails P < 0.0001"; 95% CI = 36.51-104.77 Pooled regression analysis shows no significant difference (0.89) in slope gradients before guideline production (P = 0.35, 95% CI = -3.97-5.76), but the difference in slope gradients after (12.95) is highly statistically significant (P < 0.0001;" 95% CI = 8,17-17,73).The data suggest that the change in clinical behavior persisted for at least two years.CONCLUSION:Involvement of targeted general practitioners and local specialists in guideline development using an active educational method such as described was followed by a favorable change in clinical behavior that persisted for a l least two years.

title: Local Learning Collaborations for Quality Improvement in Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD): From Four Regional Practice-Based Research Networks (PBRNs)
abstract: BACKGROUND: Four practice-based research networks (PBRNs) participated in a project to increase the dissemination of evidence-based treatment guidelines for chronic kidney disease (CKD). A multicomponent organizational intervention involved regionally proximate primary care practices in a series of facilitated meetings, termed local learning collaborations (LLCs). METHODS: The 2-wave strategy began with 8 practices in each PBRN receiving practice facilitation and subsequently joining an LLC. A mixed-methods sequential design addressed the behavior, content, and fidelity of the intervention";" clinicians from 2 PBRNs participated in interviews and PBRN coordinators reflected on implementation challenges. RESULTS: LLCs were formed in 3 PBRNs, with 121 monthly meetings held in 20 LLCs. Just over half of the participants were physicians. Qualitative data suggest that clinicians increased the priority of CKD care, improved their knowledge and skills, felt satisfied with the project, and attempted to improve care. Implementation challenges were encountered and concerns about sustainability were raised. CONCLUSION: While PBRNs can successfully leverage resources to disseminate treatment guidelines, and LLCs are well accepted by clinical staff, LLC formation was not feasible for 1 PBRN, with others struggling to meet regularly and have data of performance available despite logistical support.

title: Long-term efficacy in prescribing two multifaceted educational interventions: results of two large-scale cluster randomized trials.
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Information on the benefits and risks of medications is a key element that affects physicians' prescription decisions. Outreach visits that promote independent information have been shown to be moderately effective in changing prescribing behaviors. OBJECTIVES: To test the short-term and long-term effectiveness of pharmacist-led small group meeting prescribing by general practitioners. METHODS: Two open-label cluster randomized controlled trials (RCTs) were conducted in a large-scale NHS setting. Evidence-based material prepared ad hoc was used considering a therapeutic area approach--TEA, with informative materials on osteoporosis or prostatic hyperplasia--and a single drug-oriented approach--SIDRO, with informative materials on me-too drugs from 2 different classes: barnidipine or prulifloxacin. In each study, the 115 Primary Care Groups in an area of northern Italy (2.2 million inhabitants, 1737 general practitioners) were randomly assigned to small group educational meetings, in which available evidence was provided along with data. drug use and clinical scenarios. The main outcomes were changes in the six-month prescription of targeted drugs. Longer-term outcomes (24 and 48 months) were also evaluated. RESULTS: In the TEA trial, one of the four main outcomes showed a reduction (alfuzosin prescription compared to tamsulosin and terazosin in benign prostatic hyperplasia: prescription rate -8.5%, p = 0.03). Another primary outcome (risedronate prescription) showed a reduction at 24 and 48 months (-7.6%, p = 0.02" and -9.8%, p = 0.03), but not at six months (-5.1%, p = In the SIDRO trial, both primary outcomes showed a statistically significant reduction (barnidipine prescription -9.8%, p = 0.02; prulifloxacin prescription -11.1%, p = 0.04), which persisted or increased over time INTERPRETATION: These two cluster RCTs showed the large-scale feasibility of a complex educational program in an NHS setting and its potentially relevant long-term impact on prescribing habits, in particular when focusing on a single drug National health systems should invest in independent drug information programs TRIAL REGISTRATION: Controlled-Trials.com ISRCTN05866587.

title: Long-term effects of an occupational health guideline on outcomes related to employee body weight, cardiovascular disease risk factors, and quality of life: results of a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This study aims to assess the effectiveness of a draft occupational health guideline, aimed at preventing weight gain, on outcomes related to employee body weight, cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors, and quality of life. METHODS: In a cluster-randomized controlled trial involving 16 occupational physicians (OPs) and 523 employees, guideline-based care was compared with usual OP care between 2009 and 2011 in the Netherlands. Guideline-based care consisted of (i) providing advice to employers on how to assess and intervene in the obesogenic work environment, (ii) conducting five face-to-face behavior change counseling sessions with employees to improve their lifestyles , and (iii) evaluating the result and maintaining sections i and ii. Data were collected at baseline and at 6, 12, and 18 month follow-up. To assess the effects of the intervention, multilevel analyzes were performed. RESULTS: No significant differences were found between the intervention and control groups in waist circumference [beta 1.2 cm, 95% confidence interval (95% CI) -0.6-2.9], body weight (beta 0.3 kg, 95% CI -1.0-1.6 ), body mass index (beta 0.1 kg/m (2), 95% CI -0.3-0.5), pressure systolic blood pressure (beta 1.7 mmHG, 95% CI -2.4-5.8), diastolic blood pressure (beta 0.3 mmHG, 95% CI -1.0-0.6), cholesterol (beta 0 mmol /l, 95% CI -0.2-0.2), or indicators of quality of life after 18 months of follow-up. Stratified analyzes showed an increase in waist circumference between men (beta 2.5 cm, 95% CI 0.5 to 4.5) and obese intervention participants (beta 2.7 cm, CI 95%: 0.6 to 4.7) compared to control participants. CONCLUSION: The draft occupational health guideline was not more effective than usual care. Therefore, implementation of the guideline in its current form cannot be recommended.

title: Long-term effects of asthma education for physicians on patient satisfaction and use of health services
abstract: This randomized clinical trial evaluated the long-term impact of an interactive seminar for physicians based on the principles of self-regulation of physician behavior, children's use of health services for asthma, and parents' views on asthma. physician performance. Seventy-four general practice pediatricians and 637 of their asthma patients aged 1 to 12 years were randomized to treatment or control. Children and parents were unaware of physician involvement. Data were collected at baseline and at follow-up through self-administered surveys (paediatricians), telephone interviews (parents), and medical records. The seminar focused on the development of communication and teaching skills and the use of therapeutic medical regimens for asthma as outlined in the National Asthma Prevention and Education Program guidelines. Approximately 2 years after the intervention, physicians in the treatment group were more likely than control physicians to: use protocols to deliver asthma education (odds ratio [OR] 4.9, p=0.2), write for patients how to adjust medications when symptoms change (OR 5.7, p=0.05), and provide more guidelines to modify therapy (OR 3.8, p=0.06). Parents rated physicians in the treatment group higher than control physicians on five specific positive communication behaviors. Children seen by physicians in the treatment group had fewer hospitalizations (p = 0.03), and those with higher levels of emergency department (ED) use at baseline had fewer subsequent ED visits (p = 0, 03). No differences were seen in the number of office visits. No significant differences were found between treatment and control group physicians in the amount of time spent with patients during office visits (26 versus 29 min) or in the number of patients treated with anti-inflammatory medications. We conclude that interactive asthma seminars for pediatricians had significant long-term benefits for asthma care.

title: Long-term reduction in adverse drug events: an evidence-based improvement model
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To develop and test an evidence-based model to reduce medication errors and harm in hospitalized children. METHODS: Prospective interrupted time series study evaluating the effectiveness of a multifaceted, staged intervention over 4 years in a major urban pediatric referral hospital. The guidelines for safe pediatric prescribing were implemented using an evidence-based model. Key components included early physician involvement and improved multidisciplinary communication, consensus building, interactive education, and timely data feedback through the use of iterative Plan-Do-Study-Act cycles. The impact on medication error and harm (adverse drug events, [ADEs]) was measured using standard definitions and a multi-method approach. Prospective data from voluntary reports from nursing, medical, and pharmacist staff and intensive chart review were combined.
