All data were reviewed by a multidisciplinary panel, including causality assessments for ADEs. RESULTS: A total of 1,011 patients with 6,651 medication orders were reviewed over 3 time periods. Total ADEs decreased by >50% in the first year and this was maintained at 4 years. The greatest improvements occurred in potential ADEs, which decreased from 12.26 per 100 patients at baseline to 4.60 per 100 patients at 4 years (p < 0.05). Total medication errors decreased from 4.51 per 100 orders at baseline to 2.78 per 100 orders at 4 years (p < 0.05). Prescription errors were reduced by 65%, from 4.07 per 100 orders at baseline to 2.05 orders at 4 years (p < 0.05). CONCLUSIONS: An evidence-based, multifaceted model for the safe implementation of prescribing guidelines, involving multidisciplinary clinicians, was effective in reducing medication errors and harms in hospitalized children, resulting in sustained long-term improvement.

title: Looking for gallbladder disease in patient's iris
abstract: In alternative health care, iridology is used as an aid to diagnosis. The gallbladder disease diagnosis was used to study its inter-exercise validity and consistency. The presence of an inflamed gallbladder containing gallstones is said to be easily recognized by certain signs on the lower lateral part of the iris of the right eye. Stereo color slides of the right eye were made. Stereocolor slides of the right eye of 39 patients with this disease and 39 control subjects of the same sex and age were made. Slides were presented in random order to five leading iridologists without additional information. The prevalence of the disease was estimated at 56%. The median validity was 51% with a sensitivity of 54% and a specificity of 52%. These results were close to the validity of chance (iota = 0.03). None of the iridologists achieved high validity. The median consistency between performers was 60%. This was only slightly higher than random consistency (kappa = 0.18). This study showed that iridology is not a useful diagnostic aid.

title: Low-value care: an intractable global problem with no quick fix
Magnetic resonance imaging of the head and spine: effective for the clinician or the patient?
abstract: OBJECTIVES To test how MRI results influence clinicians' diagnoses and treatment plans for patients with cranial and spinal problems and to assess changes in the quality of life of these patients. DESIGN Survey of patients undergoing cranial and spinal MRI with questionnaires on diagnoses and anticipated management plans before and after imaging and quality of life questionnaires at the time of imaging and again four months later. SCOPE Spectroscopy and regional magnetic resonance unit. SUBJECTS 100 consecutive patients referred for cranial imaging in early 1989"; 100 similar patients referred for spinal imaging. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Changes in physicians' primary diagnoses after MRI and their confidence in these diagnoses; changes in plans anticipated management; evaluation of the contribution to the future management of the patient;" Changes in the quality of life of patients. RESULTS Magnetic resonance imaging altered physicians' primary diagnoses in 35 of 169 (21%) cases. Physicians became more confident about their main diagnoses in 90 of 167 (54%). There was a change in management plan in 113 of 182 (62%). Physicians considered MRI to have made an important contribution to management in 119 of 162 (73%) patients. In general, the patients' quality of life remained unchanged at the four-month evaluation. CONCLUSIONS Magnetic resonance imaging of patients with cranial and spinal problems influences physicians' diagnoses and management plans, but the quality of life of these patients remains unchanged.

title: Efficacy of sertraline maintenance phase for chronic depression A randomized controlled trial
abstract: Context.Âª The chronic form of major depression is associated with a high rate of prevalence and disability, but no controlled research has examined the impact of long-term treatment on the course and burden of the disease. Goal. To determine whether sertraline hydrochloride maintenance therapy can effectively prevent recurrence of depression in the high-risk group of people experiencing chronic major depression or major depression with a history of dysthymic disorder ('double depression'). Design. A 76-week, randomized, double-blind, parallel-group study conducted between September 1993 and November 1996. Setting. Outpatient psychiatric clinics at 10 academic medical centers and 2 clinical research centers. Intervention. Maintenance treatment with sertraline hydrochloride (n=77) in flexible doses up to 200 mg or placebo (n=84). patients. A total of 161 outpatients with chronic major depression or dual depression who responded to sertraline in a 12-week, double-blind, acute-phase treatment trial and continued to have a satisfactory therapeutic response during a 4-month follow-up. phase. Primary Outcome Measure.Â¡Âª Time to recurrence of major depression. Results. Sertraline provided significantly greater prophylaxis against recurrence than placebo (5 [6%] of 77 in the sertraline group vs. 19 [23%] of 84 in the placebo group"; P = 0.002 for log-rank distribution time to recurrence).Clinically significant depressive symptoms resurfaced in 20 (26%) of 77 patients treated with sertraline vs. 42 (50%) of 84 patients who received placebo (p=0.001).Cox proportional hazards model , patients who received placebo were 4.07 times more likely (95% CI, 1.51-10.95; P = .005) to experience a recurrence of depression, after adjusting for study site, type of depression and randomization strata.CONCLUSIONS: Sertraline maintenance therapy is well tolerated and has significant efficacy in preventing the recurrence or recurrence of depression in patients with chronic depression.

title: Making Comparative Performance Information More Understandable: An Experimental Assessment of the Impact of Formats on Consumer Understanding
abstract: Study Objectives Our objective was to investigate how different presentation formats influence the understanding and use of comparative performance information (CPI) among consumers. Methods A between-subjects and within-subjects experimental design with manipulations of CPI display formats. We enrolled both consumers with lower socioeconomic status (SES)/cognitive abilities and consumers with higher socioeconomic status (SES)/cognitive abilities, recruited through an online access panel. Respondents were given a fictitious CPI and completed questions about the interpretation and use of the information. Across subjects, we tested (1) showing an overall performance score (yes/no)"; (2) showing a small number of quality indicators (5 vs. 9);" and (3) display different types of evaluative symbols (star ratings, colored dots, and word vs. number icons, and bar graphs). Within subjects, we tested the effect of a small number of health care providers (5 vs. 20). Data were analyzed using descriptive analysis, analysis of variance, and paired-samples t-tests. Results A total of 902 (43%) respondents participated. The display of an overall performance score and the use of colored dots and word icons especially enhanced consumer understanding. Importantly, respondents who received colored dots more often correctly selected the top three health care providers (84.3%), compared to word icons (76.6% correct), star ratings (70 .6% correct), numbers (62.0%) and bars (54.2%). by viewing the performance scores of 20 vendors. Additionally, a small number of health care providers seemed to help consumers, for example, when given 20 providers, 69.5% correctly selected the top three, compared to 80.2% with five providers. Discussion Particular display formats improved consumer understanding of CPI, most importantly the use of overall performance scores, colored word and dot icons, and a reduced number of providers displayed. Public reporting efforts should use these formats to maximize impact on consumers.

title: Making Electronic Health Records Meaningful
Making Research a Treatment Requirement: Why We Should Sometimes Let Doctors Push Patients to Participate in Research
abstract: Where a patient can be offered one of multiple established treatments, physicians should be able to offer the treatment only if the patient agrees to participate in research to determine which of the treatments is most effective. Making treatment conditional on participation in research will help researchers complete much-needed studies.

title: Making the Invisible Visible: A Qualitative Study of Radiologists' Values, Attitudes, and Norms Regarding Radiation Safety
abstract: Some safety deficiencies have emerged in inspections by the Swedish Radiation Safety Authority of Swedish radiology departments, which carry out 5.4 million radiological examinations and 100,000 nuclear scans per year. To ensure safety in the health care system and create a strong radiation protection environment for patients (and employees), there must be a strong culture of safety. To understand the behavior, decisions, and actions of an organization, it is important to study its cultural values. The objectives of this study were to discuss how values, attitudes, and norms affect radiologists' decisions and how they influence the implementation of various radiation protection measures. To investigate this, in-depth individual interviews and focus group interviews were conducted in a sample of various radiology departments in hospitals in Sweden. The results show that the central value was derived from the patient's perspective with the focus on the knowledge that he or she has come to the health system for a particular reason: discovering a disease or, in the best of cases, declaring himself healthy. . The majority attitudes were based on experiences associated with aspects that the radiologist could not influence. This often refers to increased pressure on radiology investigations from clinics in the various operating units. Under the concept of standards, the radiologists in the study requested that the development of regulations and guidelines be connected to issues of justification for various radiological consultations.

title: Policies versus practices against malaria, a reality check from Kinshasa, the capital of the Democratic Republic of the Congo
abstract: BACKGROUND: The World Health Organization (WHO) and the National Malaria Control Program (NMCP) of the Congo recommend artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) after a confirmed parasitological diagnosis. However, the commitment and competence of all stakeholders (patients, medical professionals, governments and funders) is required to achieve effective case management and ensure the "shelf-life" of recommended medicines. The health-seeking behavior of the patients and the practices of the health professionals for the management of malaria were evaluated. METHODS: This was an observational study embedded in a two-stage cluster random survey conducted at a health center (HC) in each of 12 selected health zones in the city of Kinshasa. All patients with a clinical diagnosis of malaria were eligible. Their health-seeking behavior was recorded in a specific questionnaire, as well as the practices of health professionals. The latter did not know that their practices would be evaluated. RESULTS: 624 patients were evaluated, of which 136 (21.8%) were under five years of age. Three hundred and thirty-five (55%) had taken medication prior to the current consultation (self-medication with some product or visiting another CS), of which 47 (14%) were taking some antimalarial, and 56 (9%) were presumptively treated . Among them, 53.6% received monotherapy with quinine, artesunate, phytomedicines, sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine, or amodiaquine. On the other hand, when clinicians were informed of laboratory results, monotherapy was prescribed in 39.9% of confirmed malaria cases. Only 285 patients (45.7%) were managed according to WHO and NMCP guidelines, of whom 120 (19.2%) were prescribed an ACT after a positive blood smear and 165 (26 .4%) did not receive antimalarials after a negative result. CONCLUSION: This study shows the discrepancy between malaria policies and the reality in the field in Kinshasa, regarding the health-seeking behavior of patients and the practices of health professionals. Consequently, poor policy enforcement can contribute to the genesis and spread of antimalarial drug resistance and also have a negative impact on disease burden.

title: Competence network in malignant lymphoma
abstract: The Malignant Lymphomas Competence Network is one of 3 oncology networks that have been funded by the German Federal Ministry of Education and Research since 1999. The activities of the network are based on the work of German lymphoma research groups, which have led to significant progress in the diagnosis and therapy of malignant lymphoma in recent years. Based on this infrastructure, the network aims to establish professional quality management for the diagnosis and treatment of malignant lymphomas. The key aspects of the activity include: 1st the establishment of an IT-based information and communication platform, 2nd the creation of IT-based networks of study groups and collaborating centers for pathology and radiotherapy, 3rd research epidemiology and economics of health care, 4th research on improvements and new therapeutic approaches, 5th evidence-based medicine. More information is presented at http://www.lymphome.de.

title: Management for Physicians: An Annotated Bibliography of Recent Literature
abstract: As THE HEALTH CARE delivery system in the United States has become increasingly organized and bureaucratized, physicians often find themselves forced into managerial roles. The exact nature of the physician's responsibilities can range from the line management tasks of running an emergency room, subspecialty section, or clinical department to the more consultative activities of serving on hospital committees for quality assurance. facilities design, long-range planning, personnel, or finances. Regardless of the tasks and responsibilities assigned to them, clinicians rarely have the appropriate training or skills in the various management disciplines to be as effective as they want to be. However, as concerns about the cost and quality of health care force hospitals and other health care institutions to make difficult decisions, it will become increasingly important for physicians to become better managers and understand the opportunities and limitations of better management.

title: Management of acute coronary syndromes at hospital discharge: do targeted educational interventions improve the quality of practice?
abstract: Evidence-based guidelines exist for the management of patients with acute coronary syndromes (ACS), but adherence is suboptimal. The Acute Coronary Syndrome Discharge Management project used a quality improvement approach, with specific intervention strategies to optimize: prescription of guideline-recommended medications; education on lifestyle modifications, including cardiac rehabilitation (CR); and communication between hospital staff, patients and general practitioners. Hospitals across Australia participated in a quality improvement cycle of audit, feedback, intervention and re-audit. Interventions included educational meetings, academic details and point-of-care reminders, and feedback of baseline audit results. Outcome measures included prescription of guideline-recommended medications, referral to CR, and management plan documentation and communication. At baseline, 49 hospitals recruited 1545 patients, and after intervention, 45 hospitals remained active in the study. project and recruited 1,589 patients. Three thousand and thirty-four hospital employees attended group education or academic sessions. After the intervention, there was a significant increase in the prescription of the four guideline-recommended medications (69% vs. 57%; p < 0.0001); short-acting nitrates (68% vs 56%; p<.0001); and documented referral to RC (68% vs. 57%; p<0.0001). There were significant increases in documented discharge medication counseling, smoking cessation counseling, and communication of management plans. Specific educational interventions used as part of a quality improvement cycle may improve adherence to evidence-based guidelines for the management of patients with ACS.

title: Management of Alzheimer's disease
abstract: The management of Alzheimer's disease is based on pharmacological and non-pharmacological treatments. Specific pharmacological treatment includes acetylcholinesterase inhibitors and memantine. They show moderate efficacy over placebo for general condition, cognitive disturbances, need for attention, and behavioral problems, but do not prevent further deterioration. These treatments remain underused. The efficacy of psychotropic drugs (antidepressants, neuroleptics, and antipsychotic agents) in treating behavioral problems is not well documented. Non-pharmacological activities and interventions have not been sufficiently scientifically evaluated. These are interventions against the consequences of the disease (loss of autonomy, malnutrition) and help for family caregivers of patients. Among these activities, the best evaluated and most interesting are: educational programs for caregivers, occupational therapy at home and interventions at home by nurses specially trained as case managers.

title: Exhaled nitric oxide-based management of asthma in addition to guideline-based treatment for inner-city adolescents and young adults: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Preliminary evidence is equivocal about the role of exhaled nitric oxide (NO) in the clinical management of asthma. Our aim was to assess whether measurement of exhaled NO, as a biomarker of airway inflammation, could increase the efficacy of asthma treatment, when used as an adjunct to clinical care according to the Asthma Guidelines for Adolescents and Young Adults. From the center of the city".;" Background Preliminary evidence is equivocal about the role of exhaled nitric oxide (NO) in the clinical management of asthma. Our objective was to assess whether the measurement of exhaled NO, as a biomarker of airway inflammation, could increase the efficacy of asthma treatment, when used as an adjunct to clinical care according to the 2010 Asthma Guidelines for Adolescents and Young Adults. city center.

title: Management of heart failure in primary care (Heart Failure IMPROVEMENT Program): an international survey
abstract: Background Heart failure is a prevalent condition that is usually treated in primary care. The aim of this study was to assess how primary care physicians think heart failure should be managed, how they implement their knowledge, and whether there are differences in practice between countries.";" Background Heart failure is a prevalent condition that is usually treated in primary care. The aim of this study was to assess how primary care physicians think heart failure should be managed, how they implement their knowledge, and whether there are differences in practice between countries.

title: Management of arterial hypertension in clinical practice: perceptible qualitative differences in the approaches used by physicians
abstract: The authors recruited a group of physicians from among investigators who participated in the Antihypertensive and Lipid-Lowering Treatment to Prevent Heart Attacks (ALLHAT) trial with a higher (more successful) or lower (less successful) proportion of trial patients who reached blood pressure (BP). ) control objectives. The authors used qualitative focus group methods to identify similarities and differences in practice behaviors. Successful and less successful physicians had similarities in knowledge and practice behaviors regarding knowledge of treatment guidelines, approaches to diagnosis, use of pharmacological management, and the opinion that systolic BP guidelines should consider age of the patient. However, there were perceptible differences between the two groups of doctors in their views on doctor-patient relationships: doctors in the less successful group were more paternalistic toward their patients, while doctors in the more successful group were more likely to use a patient-centered clinical approach. approach to BP awareness and management.

title: Management of obesity in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus in primary care
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Obesity and overweight is the most powerful risk factor that represents 80-90% of patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM2). The obesity epidemic is driving the diabetes epidemic to alarming levels and primary care is becoming an important arena for obesity management in T2DM in India. However, many primary care providers feel ill-equipped or inadequately supported to address obesity in patients with diabetes. This article reviews the latest and strongest evidence-based strategies that can help clinicians in managing obesity in patients with T2DM in primary care. MATERIAL AND METHODS: A systematic literature search was performed in MEDLINE using the search terms Obesity, Obesity in T2DM, weight loss, and Primary Care. We also searched the websites of the American Diabetes Association, the National Institute for Health, the National Institute of Health and Excellence (NICE), the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN), and the World Health Organization. Most of the studies in this area have an observational design with few randomized controlled trials (RCTs). Articles and studies including meta-analyses or RCTs were preferred over other types. RESULTS AND CONCLUSION: Effective weight control treatment in patients with DM2 can be implemented in the primary care setting. Evidence-based individualized lifestyle and pharmacological measures supported by behavioral intervention and counseling with appropriate and informed surgical referrals have the potential to improve weight management success in primary care.

title: Management of obstructive sleep apnea in adults: a clinical practice guideline from the American College of Physicians.
abstract: Description: The American College of Physicians (ACP) developed this guideline to present the evidence and provide clinical recommendations on the management of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in adults. Methods: This guideline is based on literature published from 1966 to September 2010 that was identified using MEDLINE, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, and the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews. A supplemental MEDLINE search identified additional articles up to October 2012. Searches were limited to publications in English. Clinical outcomes assessed for this guideline included cardiovascular disease (such as heart failure, hypertension, stroke, and myocardial infarction), type 2 diabetes, death, sleep study measures (such as apnea-hypopnea index), measures of cardiovascular status (such as blood pressure), measures of diabetes status (such as hemoglobin A1c levels), and quality of life. This guideline rates the evidence and recommendations using the ACP clinical practice guideline rating system. Recommendation 1: ACP recommends that all overweight and obese patients diagnosed with OSA should be encouraged to lose weight. (Grade: Strong recommendation"; low-quality evidence) Recommendation 2: ACP recommends continuous positive airway pressure therapy as initial therapy for patients diagnosed with OSA. (Grade: Strong recommendation; moderate-quality evidence) Recommendation 3: ACP recommends mandibular advancement devices as an alternative therapy to continuous positive airway pressure therapy for patients diagnosed with OSA who prefer mandibular advancement devices or for those with adverse effects associated with continuous positive airway pressure therapy. (Grade: weak recommendation; low-quality evidence)

title: Management of occupational therapy services for people with cognitive impairment (state). The American Occupational Therapy Association, Inc.
abstract: In summary, occupational therapy professionals play a critical role in helping people with cognitive impairments establish or maintain meaningful and productive lives within their social and cultural environment. Occupational therapy professionals effectively address a wide range of cognitive difficulties in clients with a variety of ages and diagnoses. The intervention may be directed at the individual with cognitive impairments or those who care for or interact with them (eg, family members, significant others, employers, school personnel, other health care workers). Treatment includes changing the person's skills or behaviors or adapting the task and/or environment to maintain function, facilitate caregiving, reduce safety risks, and maximize independence.

title: Management of persistent pain in the elderly patient: a clinical review
abstract: IMPORTANCE: Persistent pain is highly prevalent, costly, and frequently disabling in old age. OBJECTIVE: To describe barriers to the management of persistent pain among older adults, to summarize current management approaches, including pharmacological and non-pharmacological modalities; present rehabilitation approaches; and highlight aspects of the doctor-patient relationship that can help improve treatment outcomes. This review is relevant to clinicians seeking an age-appropriate approach to providing pain care to older adults EVIDENCE ACQUISITION: Search of MEDLINE and the Cochrane Database from January 1990 to May 2014, using the terms search older adults, seniors, 65+, elderly, and elderly along with noncancer pain, chronic pain, persistent pain, pain management, intractable pain, and refractory pain to identify peer-reviewed systematic reviews, meta-analyses, Cochrane reviews, consensus statements and English-language guidelines relevant to the management of persistent pain in older adults. RESULTS: Of the 92 identified studies, 35 evaluated macologic interventions, while 57 examined nonpharmacologic modalities; "the majority (n = 50) focused on in older adults with osteoarthritis.This evidence base supports a stepwise approach with paracetamol as a treatment of first line. If treatment goals are not achieved, it is recommended to try a topical nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, tramadol, or both. Oral nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are not recommended for long-term use. Careful monitoring for toxicity and efficacy is essential, as advancing age increases the risk of adverse effects. A multimodal approach is strongly recommended, emphasizing a combination of pharmacological and non-pharmacological treatments to include physical and occupational rehabilitation, as well as cognitive behavioral and movement-based interventions. Ideally, an integrated pain management approach is achieved by cultivating a strong therapeutic alliance between the older patient and the physician. CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Treatment planning for persistent pain in old age requires a clear understanding of the patient's treatment goals and expectations, comorbidities, and cognitive and functional status, as well as coordination of community resources and family support. when available. A combination of pharmacological, non-pharmacological, and rehabilitative approaches, in addition to a strong therapeutic alliance between patient and physician, is essential to setting, adjusting, and achieving realistic therapeutic goals.

title: Management of severe hypertension in France in 1999 and 2000: intermediate results of a health insurance intervention program.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: As part of its long-term public health program to improve the clinical management of hypertension (HTN), the French health funds conducted two nationwide surveys of members who were recently exempted from doing copays for severe hypertension. The objective was to measure the difference between the clinical management observed and the reference care, defined by the guidelines of the ANAES (National Agency for Accreditation and Evaluation in Health) of 1997, at the beginning (May 1999) and during the program (November 1999) to detect any change in clinical management between the two study periods, the time period corresponding to the intervention period. METHODS: The patient samples used in the two studies included members between the ages of 20 and 80 living in France or one of its overseas territories who were recently exempted from copayments (ETM) for severe hypertension (these patients are reimbursed 100% for all care related to the disorder). The evaluation was based on retrospective data provided by the treating physicians. The isolated indicators to compare the two study periods were blood pressure control, suggested lifestyle changes, and prescribed medications. RESULTS: The first survey was conducted between May and November 1999 and enrolled 10,665 patients (corresponding to a weighted patient population of 50,383), while the second surveyed 2,649 patients in November 2000. The study population in 1999 was, on average, younger than the study population in November 2000: 63.1 years +/- 0.2 vs. 65.4 years +/- 0.4. Almost two out of every three patients had at least one other major cardiovascular risk factor in addition to hypertension (smoking, diabetes mellitus or dyslipidemia): 63.9% in 1999 and 64.4% in 2000. Almost one patient out of seven had associated coronary disease: 14.1% in 1999 and 15.3% in 2000 and more than one in ten had associated cerebrovascular disease: 12.7% in 1999 and 12.2% in 2000. There were more diabetic patients in the 1999 group than in 2000: 27.5% +/- 1.0 vs. 23.9% +/- 1.6. The proportion of patients who had poorly controlled blood pressure (systolic > 140 mmHg or > 160 mmHg in subjects aged 60 to 80 years with isolated systolic hypertension, or diastolic > 90 mmHg) did not change: 46.8% +/- 1.1 in 1999 and 45.7% +/- 1.9 in 2000. If the recommendations of the guide for diabetics are applied (blood pressure < 130/85). 85.4% of diabetics were poorly controlled in 1999 and 86.6% in 2000. Likewise, in hypertensive patients with kidney failure (guideline recommendations: < 125/75 mmHg), 94.5% were poorly controlled in 1999 and 96.3% in 2000. Recommended Lifestyle changes (reduced salt intake, weight loss, decreased alcohol intake, increased physical activity) were not well followed in either studies: In 1999, fewer than one in four patients fully implemented the desired changes (23.7%), compared to only 24.5% in 2000. Physicians prescribed therapeutic agents specifically indicated considering associated diseases in the 68.0% of patients in 1999 and 67.6% in 2000. Prescriptions contained a potentially contraindicated drug in 27.3% of cases in 1999 and 28.0% in 2000. CONCLUSION: A comparison of the results of the two surveys carried out in 1999 and 2000 on the management of cap Patients with severe hypertension failed to demonstrate any significant difference in blood pressure control or treatment modalities. While they do not question the value of health fund interventions, these findings illustrate how difficult it is to change clinical practice in a short period of time, especially in a disorder that involves a number of different elements including, but not limited to, the individual patient behavior. To significantly improve clinical management, it will probably be necessary to continue the dialogue between the medical advisers of the health care funds (médecins conseils) and the doctors and to renew the campaigns aimed at helping patients to be more responsible.

title: Management of severe sepsis in patients admitted to Asian intensive care units: a prospective cohort study.
abstract: OBJECTIVES To assess the compliance of Asian intensive care units and hospitals with the resuscitation and management packages of the Surviving Sepsis Campaign. Secondary objectives were to assess the impact of compliance on mortality and the organizational characteristics of hospitals that were associated with increased compliance. DESIGN Prospective cohort study. SCENARIO 150 intensive care units in 16 Asian countries. PARTICIPANTS 1285 adult patients with severe sepsis admitted to these intensive care units in July 2009. The organizational characteristics of the participating centers, the baseline characteristics of the patients, the achievement of the objectives within the resuscitation and management packages, and the results data. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE Compliance with the resuscitation (six hours) and management (24 hours) packages of the Surviving Sepsis Campaign. RESULTS Hospital mortality was 44.5% (572/1285). Compliance rates for the resuscitation and management packs were 7.6% (98/1285) and 3.5% (45/1285), respectively. In logistic regression analysis, adherence to the following package goals independently predicted decreased mortality: blood cultures (achieved in 803/1285"; 62.5%, 95% confidence interval: 59.8% to 65.1%), broad-spectrum antibiotics (achieved in 821/1285; 63.9%, 61.3% to 66.5%), and central venous pressure (achieved in 345/870;" 39.7% , 36.4% to 42.9%). High-income countries, university hospitals, intensive care units with an accredited fellowship program, and surgical intensive care units were more likely to be compliant with the resuscitation package. CONCLUSIONS Although mortality from severe sepsis is high, compliance with resuscitation and management packages is generally poor in much of Asia. Because the centers included in this study may not be fully representative, the reported performance rates may overestimate the true degree of adherence to recommended care and should be interpreted with caution. Achievement of blood culture, antibiotic, and central venous pressure goals were independently associated with better survival.

title: Management of stable ischemic heart disease: summary of a clinical practice guideline from the American College of Physicians/American College of Cardiology Foundation/American Heart Association/American Association for Thoracic Surgery/Preventive Cardiovascular Nurses Association/Society of Thoracic Surgeons
abstract: Description: The American College of Physicians (ACP) developed this guideline with the American College of Cardiology Foundation (ACCF), the American Heart Association (AHA), the American Association for Thoracic Surgery, the Preventive Cardiovascular Nurses Association, and the Society of Thoracic Surgeons to present the available evidence on the management of known or suspected stable ischemic heart disease. Methods: Literature on this topic published before November 2011 was identified using MEDLINE, Embase, Cochrane CENTRAL, PsychINFO, AMED, and SCOPUS. Searches were limited to human studies published in English. This guideline rates the evidence and recommendations based on a translation from the ACCF/AHA rating system to the ACP clinical practice guideline rating system. Recommendations: The guideline includes 48 specific recommendations that address the following topics: patient education, proven risk factor management (dyslipidemia, hypertension, diabetes, physical activity, body weight, and smoking), non-beneficial risk factor reduction strategies, proven, medical therapy to prevent myocardial infarction and death and to relieve symptoms, alternative therapy, revascularization to improve survival and symptoms, and patient follow-up.

title: Management of agitation associated with schizophrenia and bipolar disorder in emergency situations
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Patient agitation represents a significant challenge in the emergency department (ED), an environment in which medical personnel work under pressure to treat a wide range of medical emergencies. The potential for escalation into aggressive behavior, putting patients, staff, and others at risk, makes it imperative to address agitated behavior quickly and efficiently. Time constraints and limited access to specialized psychiatric support have in the past led to the "monitor and sedate" strategy, which was believed to represent the optimal approach";" however, it is increasingly recognized that more patient-centered approaches result in better outcomes. The aim of this review is to raise awareness of best practice for the management of agitation in the emergency department and to consider the role of new pharmacological interventions in this setting. DISCUSSION: The Best Practices in Assessment and Treatment of Agitation (BETA) guidelines address the complete management of agitation, including triage, diagnosis, interpersonal calming skills, and medication options. Since its publication in 2012, there have been new advances in pharmacological approaches to treating agitation, including new agents and new modes of administration, increasing the options available to both patients and clinicians. Newer modes of administration that may be helpful in rapidly controlling agitation include inhaled, buccal/sublingual, and intranasal formulations. To date, the only formulation administered non-intramuscularly with a specific indication for agitation associated with bipolarity or schizophrenia is inhaled loxapine. Non-invasive formulations, while requiring the cooperation of patients, have the potential to improve the overall patient experience, thus enhancing future cooperation between patients and healthcare providers. CONCLUSION: Management of agitation in the ED should encompass a patient-centered approach, incorporating nonpharmacologic approaches if feasible. When pharmacological intervention is necessary, a cooperative approach using non-invasive medications should be employed when possible.

title: Pain management in high-risk patients within a patient-centered medical home
abstract: Chronic pain remains a major health problem despite remarkable advances in diagnosis, pharmacotherapy, and invasive and non-invasive interventions. The prevalence of chronic pain in the United States is staggering and continues to grow, and the personal and societal costs are not insignificant. The etiology of pain is complex, and people with chronic pain tend to have significant medical and psychiatric comorbidities, including depression, anxiety, and, in some cases, substance use disorders. There is great concern regarding the increasing rate of misuse/abuse of prescription opioids, both for non-medical use and in patients with pain receiving chronic opioid therapy. While there is an ongoing debate about the "true" incidence of opioid abuse in the pain population, clearly, patients with both pain and substance use disorder are particularly challenging. Most patients with chronic pain, including those with co-occurring substance use disorders, are treated in the primary care setting. Primary care physicians have little time, resources, and training to effectively assess, treat, and monitor these complicated cases. A number of evidence-based and expert consensus-based treatment guidelines on opioid therapy and risk mitigation have been developed but have been underused in both specialist and primary care clinics. This article will discuss the use of new technologies and delivery systems for risk stratification, intervention, and follow-up of pain patients receiving opioids.

title: Management of panic attacks in emergency patients
abstract: Patients experiencing panic attacks often seek help at emergency departments. However, panic symptoms can be difficult to distinguish from some common medical emergencies. Additionally, many emergency physicians may not be equipped to effectively treat panic attacks and related psychiatric conditions, such as panic disorder and agoraphobia. Early misdiagnosis and inadequate management of panic attacks can have devastating long-term clinical and financial consequences. The purpose of this document is to provide information designed to increase the comfort and effectiveness of emergency physicians and allied professionals in treating panic attacks. The authors provide guidelines on the differential diagnosis, present strategies for the management of acute symptoms of panic and anxiety, and make recommendations for brief post-panic clinical intervention.

title: Manage perceived conflicts of interest while ensuring continued medical technology innovation
abstract: Were it not for the ongoing collaboration between vascular surgeons and the medical technology industry, many of these advanced treatments used daily in interventional vascular surgery would not exist. The flip side of this coin is that these vital relationships create multiple roles for surgeons and must be managed appropriately. The dynamic process of innovation, coupled with factors such as product delivery technique refinement, education, testing and clinical trials, and product support, necessitate close and ongoing collaboration between surgeons and the surgery industry. the devices. This unique relationship sometimes leads to perceived conflicts of interest for clinicians, in part because the conflicting pressures of multiple and overlapping roles as clinician/caregiver/researcher/innovator/client are significant. To address this issue, the Association for Advanced Medical Technology (AdvaMed), the nation's largest medical technology association representing medical device and diagnostic companies, developed a Code of Ethics to guide medical technology companies in their interactions with health professionals. First introduced in 1993, the AdvaMed Code strongly encourages both industry and physicians to commit to openness and high ethical standards in the conduct of their business interactions. The AdvaMed Code addresses many of the types of interactions that can occur between companies and healthcare professionals, including training, consulting arrangements, provision of demonstration and evaluation units, and charitable donations. By following the Code, companies send a strong message that treatment decisions should always be based on the best interest of the patient.

title: Management of urinary incontinence in stroke rehabilitation: a review.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Post-stroke urinary incontinence is a widespread problem for patients and their families that influences future well-being and care. There are many therapeutic interventions available, however their effectiveness is not fully understood. For rehabilitation practice, the current question is how urinary incontinence (UI) can best be managed so that patients' daily lives are not compromised. METHOD: The search for clinical trials was carried out in PubMed, CINAHL and the Cochrane Library, restricted to articles in German and English published between 1989 and April 2005. Medical, nursing and physiotherapeutic interventions for the treatment of UI after stroke. RESULTS: Clinical trials were divided into process-oriented trials and those looking at individual interventions. The process trials can be divided into three different groups with an overall success rate of 82-95%, 50-56% and 23-36% respectively. Behavioral methods (caregiver-induced, patient-active, and other interventions) and medical interventions are available. The most successful group studies include staff education and the application of interventions based on an assessment procedure and guide. No clinical trial on individual interventions achieved an outcome like the process-oriented studies. CONCLUSION: For the treatment of urinary incontinence, a multimodal approach is necessary: special education of nurses, applying and acting in a problem-solving process, for example in the Rehabilitation Cycle and providing care based on an evaluation procedure and guidelines. . The development of a guideline for the management of urinary incontinence after stroke may be recommended. More research is needed on the efficacy of individual interventions.

title: Commercialization of an investigational drug service
abstract: The customer survey was a useful tool in marketing the IDS. It provided guidelines for making decisions about the best use of limited human and material resources. Analysis of the survey results provided new priorities and directions for the IDS. These results were then used in conjunction with the pharmacy's operational and financial data to focus on the areas of greatest importance to customers and the pharmacy. Physicians should not be reluctant to seek compassionate use treatments because of the administrative program responsibilities that accompany such programs. All patients should have the opportunity to benefit from alternative therapies that are under investigation. For the quality of patient care to be maintained or even improved when studies are conducted, nurses must be well trained. The marketing survey served its purpose of identifying service gaps and allowing us to improve our services.

title: Massachusetts General Practitioner Organization quality incentive program yields encouraging results
abstract: Physicians are increasingly becoming salaried employees of hospitals or large medical groups. However, few published reports have evaluated provider-driven quality incentive programs for salaried physicians. In 2006, the Massachusetts General Practitioner Organization began a quality incentive program for its salaried physicians. Eligible physicians received performance targets for three quality measures every six months. Incentive payments could be as high as 2 percent of a doctor's annual income. Over thirteen six-month periods, the program used 130 different quality measures. Although improvements in quality of care and cost reductions were difficult to estimate, anecdotal evidence points to multiple successes. For example, the program helped physicians meet many federal criteria for meaningful use of health information technology and produced $15.5 million in incentive payments. The program also facilitated the adoption of an electronic health record, improved hand hygiene compliance, increased efficiency in radiology and the cancer center, and decreased use of the emergency department. The program showed that even small incentives tied to carefully structured metrics, priority setting, and clear communication can help change the behavior of salaried physicians in ways that improve the quality and safety of health care and ease the administrative burden felt by physicians. the doctors.

title: MASTERPLAN: study of the role of nursing professionals in a multifactorial intervention to reduce cardiovascular risk in patients with chronic kidney disease
abstract: Moderate to severe chronic kidney disease (CKD) is associated with increased cardiovascular risk. Nephrologists are usually primarily responsible for the care of CKD patients. However, in many cases, treatment goals, as formulated in the guidelines, are not met. The addition of a nurse practitioner could improve the quality of care. The Multifactorial Approach and Superior Treatment Efficacy in Renalpatients with the Aid of Nurse Practitioners (MASTERPLAN) study is a multicenter randomized controlled trial, which aims to investigate whether a multifactorial approach in patients with moderate to severe CKD (stages 3 and 4) to achieve the Treatment The use of a polypharmacy strategy and lifestyle treatment, with or without the addition of a nurse practitioner, will reduce cardiovascular risk and delay the deterioration of renal function. Patients (n=793) were randomly assigned to nursing care or medical care. In the nursing care arm of the study, nurse practitioners use flow charts to address risk factors that require lifestyle modifications and/or medications. They have been trained to coach patients using motivational interviewing with the goal of improving patient self-management. At baseline, both treatment groups show equal distributions with respect to key study variables. Furthermore, in only 1 patient all risk factors were within the limits defined in several guidelines, which underlines the relevance of our initiative.

title: Maternal dietary intake and physical activity habits during the postpartum period: associations with medical advice in a sample of Australian new mothers.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Numerous health benefits are associated with achieving optimal dietary and physical activity behaviors during and after pregnancy. Understanding the predictors of these behaviors is an important public health consideration, yet little is known about the associations between medical advice and diet and physical activity behaviors in postpartum women. The objectives of this study were to compare the frequency of dietary and physical activity advice provided by physicians during and after pregnancy and to assess whether this advice is associated with postpartum diet and physical activity behaviors. METHODS: New mothers (n = 448) enrolled in the Melbourne InFANT Extend trial completed the Cancer Council of Australia Food Frequency Questionnaire when they were three to four months postpartum, which assessed usual fruit and vegetable intake (servings /day). Total physical activity time, time spent walking, and time in moderate and vigorous activity during the previous week (min/week) were assessed using the Active Australia survey. Advice received during and after pregnancy was assessed using separate survey items, which asked whether a health professional had discussed eating a healthy diet and being physically active. Linear and logistic regression evaluated associations of advice with dietary intake and physical activity. RESULTS: Overall, 8.6% of the women met the combined fruit and vegetable intake guidelines. In general, the mean total time of physical activity was 350.9 +/- 281.1 min/week. The time spent walking (251.97 +/- 196.78 min/week) was greater than the time spent in moderate (36.68 +/- 88.58 min/week) or vigorous (61.74 +/- 88.58 min/week) activity. /- 109.96 min/week) and 63.2% of the women fulfilled the physical activity recommendations. Most of the women reported receiving advice on healthy eating (87.1%) and physical activity (82.8%) during pregnancy. Fewer women reported receiving advice on healthy eating (47.5%) and physical activity (51.9%) at three months postpartum. No significant association was found between provision of dietary and/or physical activity advice and maternal dietary intake or physical activity levels. CONCLUSIONS: Less healthy diet and physical activity advice was received after pregnancy than during pregnancy, but no association between advice receipt and behavior was observed. More intensive approaches than provision of advice may be required to promote healthy diet and physical activity behaviors in new mothers. TRIALS REGISTRY: Australia and New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry (ACTRN12611000386932 04/13/2011).

title: McMaster PLUS: A Cluster Randomized Clinical Trial of an Intervention to Accelerate the Clinical Use of Evidence-Based Information from Digital Libraries
abstract: Background: Physicians have difficulty keeping up with new medical research evidence. Methods: We developed the McMaster Premium LiteratUre Service (PLUS), an Internet-based addition to an existing digital library, which delivered quality and relevant qualified medical literature to clinicians, tailored to their clinical disciplines. We evaluated PLUS in a cluster-randomized trial of 203 participating physicians in Northern Ontario, comparing a full-service version (which included new article alerts and a cumulative alert database) with a self-service version (which included a guide to passive for evidence-based literature). Service utilization was the primary endpoint of the trial. Results: Mean library logins increased by 0.77 logins/month/user (95% CI: 0.43, 1.11) in the full-service group compared to the self-service group. . The proportion of full-service participants who used the service during each month of the study period showed a sustained increase during the intervention period, with a relative increase of 57% (95% CI: 12, 123) compared to the group self service. There were no differences in these proportions during the reference period, and after crossover from the self-service to full-service group, use of the self-service group became indistinguishable from the full-service group (relative difference 4.4 (95% CI -23.7 , 43.0).In addition, during the intervention and crossover periods, measures of self-reported utility did not show a difference between the 2 groups.Conclusion: An online literature service rated for quality and relevance increased the use of information based on in evidence: information from a digital library by practicing physicians.

title: Measures to assess practice change in physicians
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is a growing number of randomized trials and systematic reviews examining the efficacy of interventions designed to bring about change in clinical practice. Findings from this research are being used to guide strategies to increase the acceptance of evidence in clinical practice. Knowledge of the outcomes measured by these trials is vital not only to the interpretation and application of the work done to date, but also to inform future research in this expanding area of effort and to aid in the collation of results in systematic reviews and meta-analysis. . METHODS: The objective of this review was to identify the methods used to measure the change in clinical practices of health professionals after an intervention aimed at increasing the acceptance of evidence in practice. All published trials included in a recent comprehensive Health Technology Assessment of interventions to implement clinical practice guidelines and change clinical practice (n = 228) formed the sample for this study. Using a standardized data extraction form, one reviewer (SH) extracted relevant information from the methods or results sections of the trials. RESULTS: Measures of a change in the behavior of health professionals were the most common, with 88.8% of trials using them as outcome measures. Measures that assessed change at the patient level, either actual measures of change or surrogate measures of change, were used in 28.8% and 36.7% of the studies (respectively). The knowledge and attitudes of health professionals were evaluated in 22.8% of the studies, and changes at the organizational level were evaluated in 17.6%. CONCLUSION: Most trials of interventions aimed at changing clinical practice measured the effect of the intervention at the practitioner level, that is, did the practitioner change what they did, or did they change their knowledge and/or attitude toward that practice? Less than a third of the trials measured, with or without changes in practice, resulted in a change in the patient's health status end point.

title: Measurement and monitoring of success in compression of morbidity
Implementation Persistence Measurement: QUERI Series
abstract: As more quality improvement programs are implemented to achieve performance gains, the need to assess their lasting effects becomes increasingly apparent. However, such long-term follow-up evaluations are rare in health care implementation science, largely relegated to the "need for more research" section of most projects. This article explores the variety of conceptualizations of implementation sustainability, as well as the organizational and behavioral factors that influence the maintenance of gains. It highlights the finer points of design considerations and draws on our own experiences with sustainability measurement, framed within the rich theoretical and empirical contributions of others. In addition, recommendations are made for the design of sustainability analysis. This article is one in a series of articles documenting the implementation science frameworks and approaches developed by the US Department of Veterans Affairs' Quality Improvement Research Initiative (QUERI).

title: Measuring the effectiveness of a collaboration for quality improvement in pediatric asthma care: does implementation of the chronic care model improve care processes and outcomes?
abstract: Objective.—To examine whether a collaboration to improve pediatric asthma care positively influenced the processes and outcomes of that care. Methods. Medical record summaries and patient/parent interviews were used to make pre- and post-intervention comparisons of patients at 9 sites participating in the evaluation of a Breakthrough Series (BTS) collaboration in asthma care with patients at 4 sites paired control. . Setting.—Thirteen primary care clinics. Patients.—Three hundred and eighty-five asthmatic children who received care at an intervention clinic and 126 who received care at a control clinic (response rate = 76%). Intervention.—Three 2-day educational sessions for quality improvement teams from participating sites followed by 3 “action” periods over the course of a year. Results. The overall process of asthma care was significantly improved in the intervention group but was unchanged in the control group (+13% vs. 0% change in process score"; P < 0.0001). Patients in the intervention group were more likely than patients in the control group to control their peak flows (70% vs. 43%; P < .0001) and to have a written action plan (41% vs. 22% better general health-related quality of life (scale score 80 vs 77; P = 0.05) and asthma-specific quality of life related to treatment problems (scale score 89 vs 85 ; P < 0.05).Conclusions.â€”The intervention improved some important aspects of care processes that have previously been associated with better outcomes.Patients who received care at intervention clinics also reported better quality of life general and specific for asthma.

title: Measuring the Effectiveness of Mentoring as a Knowledge Translation Intervention to Implement Empirical Evidence: A Systematic Review
abstract: BACKGROUND: Mentoring as a knowledge translation (KT) intervention uses social influence among health professionals to increase the use of evidence in clinical practice. OBJECTIVE: To determine the effectiveness of mentoring as an AT intervention designed to increase the use of evidence by health professionals in clinical practice. METHODS: A systematic review was performed using electronic databases (ie, MEDLINE, CINAHL), gray literature, and handsearching. Eligible studies evaluated mentoring of healthcare professionals responsible for patient care to improve acceptance of evidence in practice. Mentoring is defined as (a) a mentor with more experience than the mentee"; (b) individualized support based on the needs of the mentee"; and (c) involved in an interpersonal relationship as indicated by mutual benefit, involvement, and commitment. Two review authors independently screened citations for eligibility, extracted data and assessed study quality. Data were analyzed descriptively. RESULTS: Of 10,669 citations from 1988 to 2012, 10 studies were eligible. Mentoring as a KT intervention was evaluated in Canada, the USA and Australia. Exposure to tutoring compared with no tutoring improved some behavioral outcomes (one study). Compared with controls or other multifaceted interventions, multifaceted interventions with mentoring improved practitioner knowledge (four of five studies), beliefs (four of six studies), and impact on organizational outcomes (three of four studies). There were mixed findings about changes in practitioner behaviors and the impact on physician and patient outcomes: some outcomes improved, while others showed no difference. LINKING EVIDENCE TO ACTION: Only one study evaluated the effectiveness of tutoring alone as a KT intervention and showed improvement in some behavioral outcomes. The other nine studies evaluating the effectiveness of mentoring as part of a multifaceted intervention showed mixed results, making it difficult to determine the additional effect of mentoring. More research is needed to identify effective tutoring as a KT intervention.

title: Measuring the effects of reminders for outpatient influenza vaccines at the point of clinical opportunity
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the influence of computerized influenza vaccination reminders on the behavior of individual physicians at each clinical opportunity. DESIGN: The authors conducted a prospective study of physicians' influenza vaccination behavior over four years. About half of the physicians in an internal medicine clinic used a computer-based patient record system (CPR users) that generated computer-based reminders. The other clinicians used traditional paper records (PR users). MEASUREMENTS: Each non-acute visit of a patient eligible for an influenza vaccine was considered an opportunity for intervention. Patients who had contraindications to vaccination were excluded. Guideline compliance was defined as documentation that a physician ordered the vaccine, counseled the patient about the vaccine, offered the vaccine to a patient who declined, or verified that the patient had received the vaccine elsewhere. The authors calculated the proportion of times each clinician documented the action in the CPR and PR user groups. RESULTS: The CPR and RP user groups had different baseline compliance rates (40.1 and 27.9 percent, respectively"; "P < 0.05). Both rates were stable over a two-year baseline period (P = 0.34 and P = 0.47, respectively). Compliance rates in the CPR user group increased 78 percent from baseline (P < 0.001), while rates for the RP user group did not change significantly (P = 0.18). CONCLUSIONS: Physicians who used reminder CPR had higher rates of documenting adherence to influenza vaccination guidelines than those who used a paper record. Measurements of individual clinical behavior at the point of each clinical opportunity can provide an accurate assessment of interventions that are designed to improve adherence to guidelines.

title: Medical Admission Order Sets to Improve Deep Vein Thrombosis Prophylaxis Rates and Other Outcomes
abstract: Preliminary results were presented as a poster at the annual meeting of the American Medical Informatics Association, Washington, DC, in October 2005. Upon completion of the study, CO and KD became officers of the Open Source Order Sets (OSOS) , a company that has created a collaborative joint order for Canadian hospitals. OSOS was not involved in the current study. This study did not receive specific funding. JF is supported by a Clinical Scientist Award from the Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR). We thank Barbara Stanek for her invaluable help with the collection of health record data.

title: Medical care of type 2 diabetes mellitus in light of international and national recommendations: a retrospective analysis
abstract: STUDY QUESTION: Type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM2) is a chronic disease with a great economic impact. In 2009, the Swiss Society for Endocrinology and Diabetes (SSED) published recommendations for the treatment of DM2. In Switzerland, few data are currently available on metabolic control and medical adherence to treatment guidelines. Our aim was to investigate clinical care in T2Dm in the year after the publication of the SSED recommendations. METHODS: We retrospectively studied the records of all DM2 patients admitted to our general internal medicine clinic during 2009. Metabolic control was judged from glycated hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) levels. Antidiabetic therapy was discussed and the frequencies of target organ damage screening were investigated. A group with newly diagnosed T2D was analyzed separately from patients with known T2D at admission. RESULTS: In patients with known Dm2, the mean (+/- standard deviation) HbA1c level was 7.66% +/- 1.73%. Only 44% of patients had target HbA1c levels of 8.5%, the proportion of those treated with insulin increased from 49% on admission to 76% on discharge. Only half of the patients received a lifestyle intervention in the year before admission or during their hospital stay. Screening for diabetic retinopathy and nephropathy was performed in approximately one-third and two-thirds of patients, respectively. CONCLUSIONS: In the majority of unselected DM2 patients admitted to our hospital, metabolic control was suboptimal. Implementation of treatment recommendations by both general practitioners and hospitals needs to be improved.

title: Medical technology and communication: a video-based process study on the use of decision aids in primary care consultations
abstract: BACKGROUND: Much of the research on decision making in health care has focused on consultation outcomes. Less is known about the process by which doctors and patients make a treatment decision. This study aimed to quantitatively describe the behavior displayed by physicians and patients during primary care consultations when three types of decision aids were used to promote treatment decision-making in a randomized controlled trial. METHODS: A video-based study set up in an efficacy trial comparing the use of paper-based guidelines (control) with two forms of computer-based decision aids (implicit and explicit versions of DARTS II). The treatment decision referred to anticoagulation with warfarin to reduce the risk of stroke in older patients with atrial fibrillation. 29 consultations were recorded on video. A ten-minute "slice" of the consultation was sampled for detailed content analysis using existing interaction analysis protocols for verbal behavior and ethological techniques for nonverbal behavior. RESULTS: The median consultation times (quartiles) differed significantly according to the technology used. The paper guidelines took 21 (19-26) minutes to work compared to 31 (16-41) minutes for the implicit tool and 44 (39-55) minutes for the explicit tool. decision point, GPs dominated the conversation, accounting for 64% (58-66%) of all statements and this trend was similar across all three arms of the trial.They did this at twice the rate compared to patients and higher rates in consultations involving computerized decision aids. GPs' language was very technically focused and only 7% of their conversation was socio-emotional in content;" this was half of the socioemotional content displayed by the patients (15%). However, frequent head nodding and a close reflection in the direction of gaze suggested that both parties were active participants in the conversation. these queries. However, even in practices designed to promote shared decision-making, GPs were verbally dominant and worked primarily as providers of information to patients. In addition, computer-based decision aids significantly lengthened consultations, particularly in later phases. These data suggest that decision aids may not lead to greater 'participation' in treatment decision-making and that, in their current form, they may take too long to be negotiated for use in primary care. routine.

title: Medical diagnosis through semiotics: giving meaning to the sign
abstract: Physicians are committed to incorporating quantitative methods for clinical decision making into their practices. A knowledge of semiotics, the doctrine of signs, can complement this project. A sign represents something. We communicate indirectly through signs, and by interpreting what the signs mean, we make sense of our world and diagnose and understand our patients. Thus, through association and inference, we transform flowers into love, Othello into jealousy, and staring eyes into thyrotoxicosis. Characteristically in diagnosis, beginning with a shaky inference, we test and otherwise ask questions that are likely to produce signs that support (or discredit) our hypothesis. In a literary sense, we join the author in clarifying and rewriting the text”; creative interpretation is the key. The diagnosis is concluded through the narration, by the meaning that is revealed by telling the patient's story. as long as we respect the principles and warnings of the interpretation of signs. The sign is both the key to the unknown and the main imitator. The sign and its meaning are generally not the same; the meaning has to be inferred. Because interpretations are made subjectively, they are circumscribed by the experience and bias of the clinician. Furthermore, the contexts in which the sign appears sign shape the meaning of the sign and can completely change it.

title: Medical ethics in a revolutionary era
Medical research and Alzheimer's disease: a study of the dangers of conducting research on the incompetent patient
abstract: Following a review of the legal issues relating to the importance of capacity and consent in the context of clinical research involving groups of patients, some of whom may be incompetent, the question of how those involved in this area resolve problems. Responses from 101 Local Research Ethics Committees, 13 pharmaceutical companies, and 10 researchers working with patients with Alzheimer's disease indicate considerable variation in approaches to legal and ethical issues, as well as a degree of conflict regarding the assessment of patients' ability to consent. The conclusion is that the recent proposals of the Legal Commission in this area need further consideration and elaboration in several respects.

title: Medical Research: The Role and Responsibilities of Physicians
abstract: The UK General Medical Council has decided to join the already large number of organisations, national and international, that issue guidelines on the conduct of research. This could be related to the fact that the UK, through the GMC, takes research misconduct more seriously than most countries, except that the GMC is developing separate guidelines in that area, in association with the Royal College of Physicians. Therefore, the purpose of another set of guidelines, even if they are professionally binding on physicians, is unclear. The draft guidelines are available for comment until June 21 and are reproduced below.

title: Medical treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia: physician and patient preferences and satisfaction
abstract: Practice guidelines recognize the importance of patient preferences in determining the appropriate treatment for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Recent literature suggests that patient and physician perspectives and satisfaction with BPH treatment management may differ";" this may have an impact on clinical outcomes and patient compliance. This review assesses patients' and clinicians' preferred treatment options for managing BPH and patient satisfaction with therapy. A Medline-based systematic review using the terms "benign prostatic hyperplasia" + "patient preference/perception/satisfaction" or "physician/urologist preference/perception" was performed. Patients prefer therapies that affect long-term disease progression to those that provide short-term symptom improvement, which is in contrast to their physicians' beliefs. The prescribing behavior of urologists and primary care physicians can be very varied. Studies of patient satisfaction with specific treatments generally show a high level of overall satisfaction, but comparisons between studies are limited due to heterogeneity in study design. The evidence to date suggests that the opinions and beliefs of patients and those of their physician may not always agree. Better doctor-patient communication will help determine the best treatment option for patients with BPH and can ensure greater adherence and treatment success.

title: Medication reconciliation during care transitions as a patient safety strategy
abstract: Medication reconciliation identifies and resolves unintentional discrepancies between patients' medication lists across transitions in care. The purpose of this review is to summarize the evidence about the effectiveness of medication reconciliation interventions in hospital. Searches covered MEDLINE up to November 2012 and EMBASE and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials up to July 2012. Eligible studies assessed the effects of hospital medication reconciliation on unintentional discrepancies with non-trivial risks of harm to patients. or emergency department visits 30 days after discharge and readmission. Two reviewers assessed study eligibility, abstracted data, and assessed study quality. Eighteen studies evaluating 20 interventions met the selection criteria. Pharmacists performed medication reconciliation in 17 of the 20 interventions. Most of the unintentional discrepancies identified were of no clinical importance. Medication reconciliation alone is not likely to reduce hospital utilization after discharge, but may do so when combined with interventions aimed at improving transitions of care.

title: Medication review and reconciliation with pharmacist-GP cooperation and patient benefit: a systematic review
abstract: This article systematically reviews the literature on the impact of collaboration between pharmacists and general practitioners and describes its effect on the health of patients. A systematic literature search yielded 1041 articles. After the first review of the title and abstract, 152 articles remained. After full text review, 83 articles were included. All included articles are presented according to the following variables: (i) reference"; (ii) study design and setting; (iii) patient inclusion criteria; (iv) description of the intervention; (v) if a patient interview was conducted to include patients' experiences with their medication-taking behavior; (vi) outcome; (vii) whether health professionals received additional training; and (viii) whether health professionals received additional training. financial reimbursement. Many different interventions are described where pharmacists and general practitioners work together to improve patients' health. Only nine studies reported harsh outcomes, such as hospital (re)admissions;" however, these studies had different results, not all of which were statistically significant. Randomized controlled trials should be able to describe concrete results, but large groups of patients will be needed to conduct such studies. Patient involvement is important for long-term success.

title: Medicine and human rights: reflections on the fiftieth anniversary of the doctors' trial
abstract: 1996 marks the fiftieth anniversary of the beginning of the Nazi doctors' trial at Nuremberg, a trial that has been variously designated the "Doctors' Trial" and the "Medical Case." In addition to documenting the atrocities committed by doctors and scientists during World War II, the trial's most significant contribution is known as the "Nuremberg Code," a judicial codification of 10 prerequisites for the moral and legal use of human beings in experiments. . Anniversaries give us an opportunity to reflect on the past, but they also allow us to renew our efforts to plan for the future. This article briefly describes the historical evolution of the Nuremberg Code, discusses its current relevance and applicability through the use of a case study example, and proposes future steps to be taken by the international community.

title: Meeting Expectations: The Solihull Approach Parenting Group Pilot Evaluation
abstract: We have developed a new parent group based on the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence guidelines for parent groups for behavior disorders and the Solihull Approach, a multi-agency approach to improving parent-child relationships and child management. of behavior. Our goals were to create a parent group that is theoretically coherent, proven effective, time efficient, for universal to complex problems, for parents of children from birth to 18 years old, accessible to parents with literacy difficulties, capable of being led by community professionals such as health visitors and school nurses, and supported by a cost-effective and hassle-free staff training model. This article describes the development of the Solihull Approach Breeding Group and the results of its first large-scale pilot evaluation. The results show an improvement in the child's behavior and reductions in parental anxiety.

title: Merge U.S. payer, pharmaceutical industry, and regulatory perspectives to improve approaches to heterogeneity of treatment effect in research and practice
abstract: Effective pursuit of the science and management of treatment effect heterogeneity (HTE) relies on mutual understanding of perspectives and collaboration among the various stakeholders in health care. In this article, we compare, contrast, and strive to find areas of alignment between the perspectives of three stakeholders: regulators, the biopharmaceutical and device industry, and US taxpayers. First, we discuss how HTE evidence is generated and how it could be improved. For pharmaceuticals, much of the initial research is conducted by the pharmaceutical industry, guided by basic science but also constrained by potential markets, regulatory approval requirements, trial size considerations, and payer expectations. as to evidence of value. Once a drug is marketed, further evidence can be generated by combining trial data, conducting meta-analyses, and analyzing real-world results through observational research designs";" we explore how these efforts can benefit from cooperation between these stakeholders. Second, we discuss the equally important utilization of HTE evidence for clinicians and patients to access and benefit from the learnings from this research. Research findings need to be translated into actionable information and guidelines that can be incorporated into daily practice. Doing so requires interaction and collaboration between all involved, based on facilitated communication, as well as further evaluation research. We provide examples of various cross-sector initiatives that are underway in this area. Finally, we explore some economic aspects of HTE research as part of the drug development, commercialization and treatment process. Understanding the economic incentives present is critical to aligning those incentives to improve the availability and utilization of HTE evidence. Clear understandings among regulators, pharmaceutical companies, and payers about high-value targets, methods for efficiently generating and communicating information, and value propositions can lead to "win-win" scenarios for patients, individual payers, the health care system as a whole, and the future. of drug development in the production of new drugs.

title: Menopause and exercise
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Accumulating data suggests that regular physical exercise reduces mortality and prolongs functional life in men and women. This review seeks to describe the current state of the medical literature on this topic. METHODS: A narrative review of current medical literature including randomized clinical trials and clinical guidelines addressing the health benefits of physical fitness and regular exercise in postmenopausal and middle-aged women. RESULTS: The reduction and prevention of obesity and its related comorbidities (hypertension, glucose intolerance, dyslipidemia, and heart disease) are one of the main benefits of exercise. However, long-term physical exercise is also associated with reduced rates of cancer, dementia, and cognitive decline, adverse mood and anxiety symptoms, and reduced osteoporosis, osteopenia, falls, and fractures. Beneficial physical activity includes exercise that will promote cardiovascular fitness (aerobic), muscular strength (endurance), flexibility (stretching), and balance (many of the above and additional activities such as yoga). CONCLUSIONS: Since it is unequivocally beneficial, inexpensive, and of minimal risk, maintaining a healthy exercise regimen should be a goal for every participant to improve lifelong well-being.
