Clinicians should use a number of behavioral strategies to support the fitness goals of their participants.

title: Mental Health Link: the development and formative evaluation of a complex intervention to improve shared care for patients with long-term mental illness
abstract: AIMS AND OBJECTIVES: This study aims to develop an intervention and related conceptual framework for developing shared care for patients with long-term mental illness, and to provide a case study of the development of a complex intervention in primary care. METHODS: A pragmatic iterative design involved a literature review and focus groups followed by a formative evaluation that included reflection, questionnaires, and interviews. General practices and associated community mental health teams in South East London participated. Participants included community mental health workers, psychiatrists, nurses, general practitioners, managers, and local experts interested in primary mental health care. RESULTS: The shared care model includes the core components of improved communication along with the development of a registry and database with review and retrieval systems. Local needs assessment, auditing, training and guidance are complementary components. The intervention, Mental Health Link, is a facilitated quality improvement program that aims to accelerate service development by bringing teams together to agree on a shared care model appropriate to local needs, skills and interests, and supporting practice development. systems CONCLUSIONS: A shared care model must take into account the interdependencies of the components, as well as the relationship with the context. The heterogeneity of primary and community care needs to be reflected in the development of complex interventions designed to improve shared care. It is possible to develop a complex generalizable intervention that is sensitive to local circumstances.

title: Families with mental illness. When children are insecure?
abstract: This article examines the impact of parental mental illness on children's behavior and development. Early identification and intervention are crucial";" too often the child is neglected, especially if the parent is not outright abusive. Parenting aids and supports can be crucial for parents with mental illness to prevent relapse and promote the child's mental health. General practitioners have a crucial role in this process.

title: Meta-analysis: the effect of dietary advice for weight loss
abstract: Background: Diet and lifestyle modification efforts are the primary treatments for people who are obese or overweight. The effect of dietary advice on long-term weight change is unclear. Objective: To perform a meta-analysis of the effect of dietary advice compared to usual care on body mass index (BMI) over time in adults. Data sources: First studies (1980 to 1997) of a previously published systematic review"; MEDLINE and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials from 1997 to July 2006. Study selection: English-language randomized controlled trials (≥16 weeks in duration) in overweight adults reporting the effect of dietary advice on weight. The authors included only weight loss studies with a dietary component. Data extraction: Full data extraction was performed by individual reviewers;" at least 1 additional reviewer reviewed the data. Data Synthesis: Random-effects model meta-analyses of 46 dietary advice trials revealed a maximum net treatment effect of 1.9 (95% CI, 2.3 to 1.5) BMI units (approximately 6%). at 12 months. Meta-analysis of changes in weight over time (slopes) and meta-regression suggest a change of approximately 0.1 BMI units per month from 3 to 12 months of active programs and a recovery of approximately 0.02 to 0 .03 BMI units per month during the following maintenance phases. Different analyzes suggested that calorie recommendations, frequency of support meetings, inclusion of exercise, and diabetes may be independent predictors of weight change. Limitations: Interventions, study samples, and weight changes were heterogeneous. Overall, the studies were of moderate to poor methodological quality. They had high rates of missing data and were unable to explain these losses. Meta-analytic techniques could not fully explain these limitations. Conclusions: Compared with usual care, dietary advice interventions result in modest weight loss that decreases over time. In future studies, emphasis should be placed on minimizing losses to follow-up and determining which factors result in more effective weight loss.

title: Methadone substitution: a scientific review in the context of outpatient therapy in Germany
abstract: The German Betaubungsmittelverschreibungsverordnung BtmVV (narcotics prescription regulation), 5 part 2, July 01, 2001, commissioned the German Medical Association to establish guidelines on methadone maintenance therapy in accordance with the medical-scientific state of the art. A joint commission of the German Medical Association and the National Association of Compulsory Health Insurance Physicians developed guidelines for substitution therapy for opioid dependence that were adopted by the board of the German Medical Association in March 2002 and published in Deutsche Arzteblatt on May 24. 2002. The present study is a systematic review of the scientific literature on treatment success in general, as well as on particular aspects of methadone substitution therapy considered by the guidelines of the German Medical Association. The literature is current as of January 2004. The oldest randomized controlled trials and the most recent quasi-experimental studies provide evidence that methadone maintenance therapy is an effective strategy for reducing illicit drug use, improving the health status of drug users, decrease criminal behavior and to promote the rehabilitation of people dependent on opiates. The evaluation of international studies clearly shows that the criteria for access to substitution therapy beyond the diagnosis of opioid dependence, for example, the presence of a life-threatening comorbidity, is not a prerequisite for substitution in other countries and, therefore, it is not discussed in the international community. literature. The evidence from the study shows that the German Medical Association guidelines for substitution therapy of opioid dependence reflect the best available evidence from scientific studies and apply it to conditions in the German healthcare system.

title: Methodology and reporting of smartphone and mobile health app studies for schizophrenia
abstract: The increasing prevalence of mobile devices among patients of all demographic groups has the potential to transform the way we diagnose, monitor, treat and study mental illness. As new tools and technologies emerge, clinicians and researchers are faced with an ever-increasing range of options both for clinical assessment, through digital capture of essential behavioral elements of a condition, and for intervention, through formal treatments, training and other assistive technologies. Means of communication with the patient. And yet, as with any new set of tools for evaluating or treating a medical condition, establishing and adhering to reporting guidelines—that is, what works and under what conditions—is an essential component of the process. of translational research. Here, using the recently published World Health Organization mHealth Assessment, Reporting, and Evaluation Guidelines for Evaluating Mobile Health Apps, we review the methodological strengths and weaknesses of existing studies on smartphones and wearables for schizophrenia. While mounting evidence supports the feasibility of using mobile tools in severe mental illness, most studies to date have not adequately reported accessibility, interoperability, costs, scalability, replicability, data security, usability testing or compliance with national guidelines or regulatory statutes. Future research efforts that address these specific gaps in the literature will help advance our understanding and realize the clinical potential of these new tools of psychiatry.

title: Methods for treating cognitive deficits in schizophrenia
abstract: Studies from the molecular to the clinical level suggest that cognitive dysfunction is central in the characterization of schizophrenia. Consequently, increased efforts have been made to search for effective treatments of these broad and debilitating cognitive deficits. Three general strategies for treating cognitive dysfunction in schizophrenia have emerged in the literature. Second-generation (atypical) antipsychotic medications have received much attention, but their procognitive effects tend to be modest. Augmentation strategies, driven by basic science or translational research, have often shown promise in small uncontrolled trials";" however, few agents have fared well in rigorously designed trials. Behavioral interventions have shown positive effects that generalize to other symptom domains and persist after intervention, but tend to be expensive and labor intensive. Thus, while there have been some exciting advances in the treatment of cognitive dysfunction, advances to date are modest, and the search for treatment methods continues.

title: Microcomputer generated reminders. Improving Primary Care Physician Compliance with Mammography Screening Guidelines
abstract: Recent studies have documented that physician compliance with recommended periodic health exams is improved by physician reminders. However, these reminders are often expensive to maintain and modify. This study investigates the influence of a microcomputer tickler system on the ordering of mammograms. All women (N = 1262) aged 40 years or older who visited an outpatient clinic during a 6-month period were randomly assigned to one of two groups. For the experimental group, the date of the last mammogram ordered and recorded in the clinical database was printed on the encounter form generated for each patient visit. Information on prior mammograms was not printed for patients in the control group. Women in the experimental group were more likely to request a mammogram during the study period (19% vs. 12%, p = 0.001) and, as a result, were more likely to meet mammography guidelines at the end of the study ( 27% vs. 21%, p = 0.011). Microcomputerized data storage and retrieval systems can help increase physicians' attention to preventive health screening recommendations.

title: Microcomputer generated reminders. Improve primary care physician compliance with mammography screening guidelines.
abstract: study was conducted to investigate the influence of microcomputer-generated "reminders" that prompt physicians to schedule periodic mammographic examinations for patients. The main reasons cited by doctors for not performing health screening tests such as mammography included forgetfulness, lack of time, inconvenience, and patient discomfort or rejection. Failure by the doctor to recommend mammography is often due to carelessness on the part of the doctor at the time of the patient's visit. This study demonstrates that a microcomputerized reminder system can be used to increase physician compliance with preventive health screening recommendations. An experimental system resulted in a 50 percent increase in mammogram ordering for a group of women over 40 who participated in the study.

title: Minimal risk, firm administrative judgments and informed consent
Minimizing Errors of Omission: Behavioral Heparin Reinforcement to Prevent Venous Embolism: The BEHAVE Study
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To improve patient safety by increasing heparin thromboprophylaxis for patients in the medical-surgical intensive care unit using a multi-method approach to evidence-based guideline development and implementation. Design. Prospective longitudinal observational study. PLACE: Medical-surgical intensive care unit. PARTICIPANTS: Multidisciplinary physicians caring for critically ill patients in a 15-bed closed medical-surgical intensive care unit. INTERVENTIONS: Phase 1 was an initial 3-month period during which we documented anticoagulation and mechanical thromboprophylaxis. Phase 2 was a 1-year period in which we implemented a thromboprophylaxis guideline using a) interactive multidisciplinary educational services; b) verbal reminders for the intensive care unit team; c) daily computerized record of thromboprophylaxis by nurses; d) weekly graphical feedback to individual intensivists on adherence to guidelines;" and e) publicly displayed graphical feedback on group performance. Phase 3 was a 3-month follow-up period 10 months later, during which we documented thromboprophylaxis Computerized diary recording of thromboprophylaxis by the nurse continued during this period.MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN OUTCOMES: Mortality rates in the intensive care unit and in the hospital were similar in all phases, although patients in the phase 2 had higher Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Assessment II scores than patients in phases 1 and 3. The proportion (median % [interquartile range]) of patient-days in the heparin thromboprophylaxis intensive care unit in the phases 1, 2, and 3 was 60.0 (0, 100), 90.9 (50, 100), and 100.0 (60, 100), respectively (p = 0.01).The proportion (median % [range int erquartile]) of days during which heparin thromboprophylaxis was mistakenly omitted in phases 1, 2, and 3 was 20 (0, 53.8), 0 (0, 6.3), and 0 (0, 0), respectively (p<.001). CONCLUSIONS: After the development and implementation of an evidence-based thromboprophylaxis guideline, we found significantly more patients receiving heparin thromboprophylaxis. Adherence to the guideline was maintained 1 year later. More research is needed on what are the most effective strategies for implementing patient safety initiatives in the intensive care unit.

title: Incorrect prescribing of controlled substances: an evaluation of a professional development program
abstract: BACKGROUND: The abuse of controlled prescription drugs (CPD) has reached epidemic proportions in the United States. Most physicians who attend a 3-day continuing medical education (CME) professional development program (PDP) lack training in identifying risks and managing patients who misuse CPDs. To address this issue, the authors conducted an evaluation of a PDP that trains clinicians on appropriate prescribing, identification of substance abuse, use of screening tests, brief intervention and referral for treatment (SBIRT), and implementation of motivational interviewing (MI). METHODS: The authors conducted a program evaluation to assess the efficacy and impact of the PDP on physicians' prescribing knowledge and behavior. RESULTS: Participants (N = 174) were typically middle-aged (mean age 53 years), male (89%), and physicians (82%) and other health professionals (18%). Many physicians practice alone in primary care settings (46%). Course evaluations were completed by n = 155 (89%) participants who rated the course and presenters highly (mean 4.8/5 respectively). Physicians' knowledge scores at pre- and post-assessments increased significantly: pretest (M = 58.7, SD = 13.12) and posttest (M = 78.28, SD = 9.83) (t( 173) = 20.06, P </= 0.0001, 95% confidence interval, CI: [-21.51, -17.65]). Almost half of the participants, n = 83/174 (48%), completed the follow-up survey and 93% agreed/strongly agreed (A/SA) that they made changes in professional practice. Of practicing participants with an active Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) registration (n = 57), the majority agreed/strongly agreed that they implemented changes to align their practices with current guidelines (89% ), used CPD more appropriately (87%), implemented changes in office prescribing policies (81%), identified and referred more substance abuse patients to treatment (80%), shared new information/course experience with 25 other health professionals (93%) and felt that the course had a positive impact on their behaviors personally and professionally (90% and 96%, respectively). CONCLUSIONS: This is the first known study evaluating a PDP in this population. Results demonstrated participant satisfaction and improvement in prescribers' knowledge and self-reported prescribing behaviors. However, more studies are needed to assess the actual changes in clinical practice, the direct impact on patient outcomes, and relapse rates.

title: Mitigation of prenatal Zika virus infection in the Americas
abstract: Background: Due to the risk of Zika virus infection in the Americas and the links between infection and microcephaly, other serious neurological conditions, and stillbirth, health ministries in the region have advised women to delay pregnancy . However, the effectiveness of this policy in reducing prenatal Zika virus infection has yet to be quantified. Objective: To assess the effectiveness of pregnancy delay policies on the incidence and prevalence of prenatal Zika virus infection. Design: Model of vector-borne Zika virus transmission adjusted to 2015-2016 epidemiological data on Zika virus infection in Colombia. Setting: Colombia, August 2015 to July 2017. Patients: Population of Colombia, stratified by sex, age and pregnancy status. Intervention: Recommendations to delay pregnancy by 3, 6, 9, 12 or 24 months, at different levels of adherence. Measurements: Weekly and cumulative incidence of prenatal infections and cases of microcephaly. Results: With 50% compliance with the recommendations to delay pregnancy from 9 to 24 months, the cumulative incidence of antenatal Zika virus infections is likely to decrease by 17% to 44%, while it is likely to increase recommendations to delay pregnancy for 6 months or less antenatal infections by 2% to 7%. This paradoxical exacerbation of prenatal Zika virus exposure is due to an elevated risk of pregnancies shifting toward the peak of the outbreak. Limitation: Sexual transmission was not explicitly considered in the model due to limited data, but was implicitly included in the overall transmission rate, which was calibrated to observed incidence. Conclusion: Pregnancy delays can have a substantial effect in reducing cases of microcephaly, but they risk exacerbating the Zika virus outbreak if the duration is not sufficient. Careful consideration should be given to the duration of the delay, the adherence of the population, and the timing of the start of the intervention. Primary Funding Source: National Institutes of Health.

title: Mobile Diabetes Intervention Study: Trial of a Personalized Treatment/Behavioral Communication Intervention for Blood Glucose Control
abstract: BACKGROUND: National data finds glycemic control within target (A1c o = 7.5%) at baseline (n = 260) enrolled in study groups based on PCP randomization. All study patients receive blood glucose (BG) meters and a one-year supply of testing materials. Patients in three treatment groups select one of two mobile phone models, receive a one-year service plan and unlimited mobile data, sign up for the individual web-based patient portal, and receive treatment phone software of the study according to study allocation. Patients in the control group receive their usual care from their PCP. The primary outcome is the mean change in A1c over a 12-month intervention period. CONCLUSION: Traditional disease management methods have failed to achieve adequate control of blood glucose and other conditions important to people with diabetes. Tools to improve communication between patients and PCPs can improve patient outcomes and satisfy patients and physicians. This RCT is ongoing.

title: Mobile web application for self-management of low back pain: randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Nonspecific low back pain (NLBP) is the diagnosis for people with back pain that does not have an underlying medical cause (eg, tumor, infection, fracture, herniated disc, spinal stenosis) . The American College of Physicians (ACP) and the American Pain Society (APS) recommend multidisciplinary treatments for NLBP lasting longer than 4 weeks. This approach, however, is impractical for many clinicians to implement, and relatively few providers offer NLBP treatment that meets the joint ACP-APS guidelines. OBJECTIVE: This study evaluated the efficacy of a mobile web intervention called "FitBack" in helping users implement personalized strategies to manage and prevent occurrences of NLBP. METHODS: A total of 597 adults were recruited, screened, consented, and assessed online at baseline, 2 months (T2), and 4 months (T3). After initial assessments, participants were randomized into three groups: FitBack intervention, alternative care group that received 8 emails urging participants to link to six Internet resources for NLBP, and control group. The FitBack group also received weekly email reminders for 8 weeks, in addition to emails to take assessments. The control group was only contacted for evaluation. RESULTS: FitBack program users showed greater improvement compared to the control group in every comparison of critical physical, behavioral, and workplace outcome measures at 4-month follow-up. Additionally, users of the FitBack program performed better than the alternative care group on current back pain, behavior, and workplace outcomes at 4-month follow-up. For example, subjects in the control group were 1.7 times more likely to report current back pain than subjects in the FitBack group; subjects in the alternative care group were 1.6 times more likely to report current back pain at 4-month follow-up. Additionally, users of the FitBack program showed greater improvement compared to control and alternative care groups at 4-month follow-up in patient activation, Theory of Planned Behavior constructs, and attitudes toward pain. CONCLUSIONS: This research demonstrated that a theory-based independent mobile web intervention that tailors content to user preferences and interests can be an effective tool in self-management of low back pain. When viewed from the RE-AIM perspective (i.e., reach, efficacy/effectiveness, adoption, implementation fidelity, and maintenance), this study supports the notion that there is considerable value in this type of intervention as a potentially cost-effective tool. that can ers of the people. The results are promising considering that the FitBack intervention was not supported by professional caregivers or integrated within a health promotion campaign, which could have provided additional support to participants. Still, more research is needed on how self-guided mobile web interventions will be used over time and to understand the factors associated with continued user engagement. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Clinicaltrials.gov NCT01950091;" http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01950091 (Archived by WebCite at http://www.webcitation.org/6TwZucX77).

title: Modeling of Gaze Patterns in Doctor-Patient Interaction with Delay Sequential Analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to examine whether delay sequential analysis could be used to describe gaze orientation between physicians and patients in the medical encounter. This topic is particularly important as new technologies are implemented in multi-user healthcare environments where trust is critical and non-verbal cues are essential to building trust. This method of analysis could lead to design guidelines for more effective technologies and evaluations of interventions. BACKGROUND: Nonverbal communication patterns are important aspects of doctor-patient interactions and can affect patient outcomes. METHOD: The gaze behaviors of physicians and patients in 110 videotaped medical encounters were analyzed using the delay sequential method to identify meaningful behavioral sequences. Sequential analysis of delays included both event-based delay and time-based delay. RESULTS: The results of the event-based delay analysis showed that the patient's gaze followed the physician's gaze, while the physician's gaze did not follow the patient's gaze. Time-based sequential analysis showed that patient responses generally occurred within 2 s after the clinician's initial behavior. CONCLUSION: Our data suggest that the physician's gaze significantly affects the medical encounter, but that the reverse is not true. APPLICATION: The findings of this research have implications for the design of clinical work systems and the modeling of interactions. Similar research methods could be used to identify different patterns of behavior in clinical settings (physical layout, technology, etc.) to facilitate and evaluate clinical work system designs.

title: Referral facilitators with interpersonal counseling or pharmacological treatment in primary care patients with depression: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite the fact that depressive disorders are very common, there has been little research to guide primary care physicians on the choice of treatment for patients with mild to moderate depression. OBJECTIVES: To assess the efficacy of interpersonal counseling compared to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) in primary care attendants with major depression and to identify moderators of treatment outcome. METHOD: A nine center randomized controlled trial (DEPICS, Australian New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry Number: ACTRN12608000479303). The primary outcome was remission of the depressive episode (defined as a Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression score </=7 at 2 months). Daily functioning was assessed using the Social and Occupational Adjustment Scale. Logistic regression models were used to identify moderators of treatment outcome. RESULTS: The percentage of patients achieving remission at 2 months was significantly higher in the interpersonal counseling group compared to the SSRI group (58.7% vs. 45.1%, P = 0.021). Five moderators of treatment outcome were found: depression severity, functional impairment, anxious comorbidity, prior depressive episodes, and smoking. CONCLUSIONS: We identified some patient characteristics that predict a differential outcome with pharmacological and psychological interventions. If our results are confirmed in future studies, these characteristics will help clinicians define criteria for first-line treatment of depression targeting patient characteristics.

title: Modifying management of dyspepsia in primary care: an educational outreach cluster randomized controlled trial compared with passive guideline dissemination
abstract: BACKGROUND: Quality improvement initiatives in health services are based on the effective introduction of clinical practice guidelines. However, even well-crafted guidelines have little effect unless they are supported by dissemination and implementation strategies. OBJECTIVE: To test the efficacy of "educational outreach" as a strategy to facilitate the acceptance of dyspepsia management guidelines in primary care. STUDY DESIGN: A pragmatic, cluster-randomized, controlled trial of guideline introduction comparing educational outreach with postal guideline dissemination alone. SETTING: One hundred and fourteen general practices (233 general practitioners) in the Salford and Trafford Health Authority catchment area in North West England. METHOD: All practices received guidelines by mail in July 1997. Practices in the intervention group began receiving educational outreach three months later. This consisted of practice-based seminars with hospital specialists in which guideline recommendations were evaluated and implementation plans formulated. The seminars were followed by "booster" visits after another 12 weeks. Outcome measures were: (a) appropriateness of referral for "; and (b) open access upper gastrointestinal endoscopy findings; (c) costs of GP prescriptions for acid-suppressing medications , and (d) the use of laboratory serological tests for Helicobacter pylori.Data were collected for seven months before and/or after the intervention and analyzed by intention to treat.RESULTS: (a) The proportion of appropriate referrals was higher in the intervention group in the six months post-intervention-intervention period (practice medians: control = 50.0%, intervention = 63.9%, P < 0.05);(b) the proportion of important findings on endoscopy was not significantly altered; (c) there was a greater increase in total expenditure on acid-suppressing drugs in the intervention compared to the control group (+8% vs. +2%, P = 0.005);" and (d) the median testing rate per practice for H pylori in the post-intervention period was significantly higher in the intervention group (four versus 0, P < 0.001). CONCLUSION: This study suggests that educational outreach may be more effective than passive outreach in changing clinical behavior. It also demonstrates that unpredictable and unforeseen results can arise.

title: Modify angiotensin receptor blocker prescribing behavior by selectively rescinding administrative prior authorization requirements for losartan.
abstract: OBJECTIVES To assess whether rescission of the prior authorization (PA) requirement (pre-approval) for losartan in a health maintenance organization (HMO) could reduce the prescription of more expensive angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs). METHODS HMO physicians were notified that losartan would no longer require PA, and appropriate changes were made to the electronic prescribing software. The monthly distribution by medication of the number of ARB prescriptions filled to new patients was calculated before and after the policy change from data captured from electronic records. The proportion of patients (percentage and 95% confidence interval) treated with losartan who met the criteria for treatment with AIIRAs (hypertension or heart failure in patients who have developed adverse effects in response to angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or macroproteinuria) during the first month after PA requirement was rescinded. RESULTS The total number of PA requests for ARBs dropped by 48.6%, from 961 in December 2008, the month before the policy change, to 494 the following January, rising again to 651 during January 2010. Prescription incidence changed from 121 to 255 patients treated per month (114% increase) for losartan, from 15 to 16 (6.7% increase) for candesartan, and from 89 to 71 (20.2% decrease) for valsartan . The duration of effect of the decrease in ARB requests for the most expensive drugs was approximately 1 year. Only 23.3% (95% confidence interval 18.1–28.4) of patients who received losartan met the criteria for receiving ARBs. CONCLUSIONS Rescission of the PC requirement for this drug alone was an effective strategy of limited duration for reducing the prescription of relatively expensive drugs

title: Modular ICT-based patient empowerment framework for diabetes self-management: design insights and validation results
abstract: INTRODUCTION: It is estimated that more than 382 million people suffer from diabetes worldwide, most of whom are between 40 and 59 years old. ICTs can play a key role in better diabetes control and patient empowerment. Patient empowerment engages patients more in their own healthcare process and disease management becomes an integral part of their daily lives. Self-management opens the possibility for patients to contribute to their own medical care and have greater control of their disease. OBJECTIVES: The aim of our study was to explore the impact of an ICT-based patient empowerment framework on diabetes self-management. METHODS: A modular patient empowerment framework that encourages diabetes self-management was designed and implemented. The framework incorporates expert knowledge in the form of clinical guidelines and supports patients in specifying personalized activities that are based on medical recommendations and personal goals, and in collecting observations from daily life. The usability and usefulness of the proposed framework were evaluated in a pilot study with the participation of 60 patients and 12 health professionals. RESULTS: The study revealed that a patient empowerment approach based on self-management ICT tools is useful and accepted by both patients and physicians. For those patients who were already disciplined in managing their disease, the pilot solution served as a facilitator for data recording. Otherwise, it served as an incentive for better adherence to disease management principles. ICT tools prompted many patients to be more physically active and to make adjustments in their eating habits. However, this impact proved to be closely related to the sociocultural background of the subjects. The study also showed that even in patient-centered self-management interventions, clinicians still have a key role to play. However, the acceptance of such interventions by health professionals depends not only on the level of impact on their patients' disease management, but also on the level of impact on their workflow. CONCLUSIONS: It is clear that a patient empowerment approach based on self-management ICT tools is useful and accepted by patients and physicians. In addition, there are clear indications that ICT frameworks such as the one presented in this paper support patients in behavioral changes and better disease management. Finally, it was perceived that self-care solutions should be built around the goal of not only educating and guiding patients in self-care of the disease, but also helping them explore the decision space and providing information and explanations about the impact of their own values in the decision.

title: Molecular sources of residual cardiovascular risk, clinical signs and innovative solutions: relationship with subclinical disease, undertreatment and poor adherence: implications of new evidence on the optimization of cardiovascular outcomes in patients
abstract: Residual risk, the continuing appreciable risk of major cardiovascular events (MCVE) in statin-treated patients who have achieved evidence-based lipid goals, remains a concern among cardiologists. Factors contributing to this ongoing risk are atherogenic non-low-density lipoprotein (LDL) particles and atherogenic processes unrelated to LDL cholesterol, including other risk factors, inherent properties of statins, and patient characteristics. that is, genetics and behavior. In addition, providers, health systems, the community, public policies and the environment play a role. Major statin studies suggest an average 28% reduction in LDL cholesterol and a 31% reduction in relative risk, leaving a residual risk of about 69%. Incomplete risk reductions and failure to ameliorate the conditions that create risk can result in continued progression of atherosclerosis, with new and recurrent lesions at original and distant culprit sites, remodeling, arrhythmias, rehospitalizations, invasive procedures, and terminal disability. As a result, the identification of additional agents to reduce residual risk, particularly given in conjunction with statins, has been an ongoing search. The current model of atherosclerosis involves many steps during which the disease can progress regardless of guideline-defined elevations in LDL cholesterol. Differences in genetic response to statin therapy, differences in the ability of the endothelium to regenerate and repair itself, and differences in susceptibility to nonlipid risk factors such as smoking, hypertension, and molecular changes associated with obesity and diabetes can create a residual risk. A large number of inflammatory and metabolic processes can also provide potential therapeutic targets to reduce residual risk. Classically, epidemiologic and other evidence suggested that raising high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol would be cardioprotective. When LDL cholesterol is aggressively lowered to targets, low HDL cholesterol levels are still inversely related to MCVE. Efflux capacity, or the ability to relocate cholesterol away from macrophages, is thought to be an important anti-atherogenic mechanism responsible for the reduction of MCVE mediated in part by healthy HDL. HDL cholesterol is a complex molecule with antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antithrombotic, antiplatelet and vasodilator properties, among which is the protection of LDL against oxidation. HDL-associated paraoxonase-1 has an important effect on endothelial function. Additionally, HDL promotes endothelial repair and progenitor cell health, and supports nitric oxide production. HDL from patients with cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and autoimmune disease may fail to protect or even become proinflammatory or prooxidant. Mendelian randomization and other clinical studies in which raising HDL cholesterol has not been beneficial suggest that high plasma levels do not necessarily reduce cardiovascular risk. These data, together with extensive preclinical information on the functional heterogeneity of HDL, challenge the "HDL hypothesis", ie, raising HDL cholesterol per se will lower VEVM. After the equivocal AIM-HIGH (Atherothrombosis Intervention in Metabolic Syndrome With Low HDL/High Triglycerides: Impact on Global Health Outcomes) study and the withdrawal of two important cholesteryl ester transfer protein compounds, one for off-target adverse effects and the other due to lack of efficacy, continues the development of two other agents, that is, anacetrapib and evacetrapib, both of which substantially reduce LDL cholesterol. The negative but controversial HPS2-THRIVE (Heart Protection Study 2-HDL Treatment to Reduce Incidence of Vascular Events) trial casts further doubt on the HDL cholesterol hypothesis. The growing impression that HDL functionality, rather than abundance, is clinically important is supported by experimental evidence highlighting the conditional pleiotropic actions of HDL. Non-HDL cholesterol reflects the cholesterol in all atherogenic particles containing apolipoprotein B and has surpassed LDL cholesterol as a lipid marker of cardiovascular risk and future mortality. In addition to including a measure of residual risk, the advantages of using non-HDL cholesterol as the primary lipid target are now compelling. Reinterpretation of data from the Treating to New Targets study suggests that better control of smoking, body weight, hypertension, and diabetes will help reduce residual risk. Although much improved, control of risk factors other than LDL cholesterol currently remains inadequate due to poor adherence to guidelines and poor patient adherence. More efficient and increased use of proven simple therapies, such as aspirin, beta-blockers, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, and angiotensin II receptor blockers, combined with statin therapy, may be more fruitful in improving results than the use of other complex therapies. Comprehensive, intensive, multi-mechanistic, global and national programs that use primordial, primary and secondary prevention are necessary to reduce the total level of cardiovascular risk.

title: Monitoring and management of metabolic effects of antipsychotics: a cluster randomized trial of an intervention combining evidence-based quality improvement and external facilitation
abstract: Background Treatment of psychotic disorders consists mainly of second-generation antipsychotics, which are associated with metabolic side effects such as overweight/obesity, diabetes, and dyslipidemia. Evidence-based clinical practice guidelines recommend timely evaluation and management of these conditions; however, research studies show deficits and delays in metabolic control and management of these patients. This protocol article describes the Â®Monitoring and Management for Metabolic Side Effects of Antipsychotics,Â¯ project, which is testing an approach to implement recommendations for these practices. Methods/Design This project employs a cluster randomized clinical trial design to test the efficacy of an evidence-based facilitation and quality improvement intervention. Eligible study sites were VA medical centers with 300 patients started on one new antipsychotic prescription within a six-month period. A total of 12 sites, matched in pairs based on scores on an organizational practice survey, were then randomly assigned in pairs to intervention or control conditions. Study participants include VA employees involved in metabolic monitoring and management of patients treated with antipsychotics at participating sites. The intervention involves researchers partnering with clinical stakeholders to facilitate the adaptation of local implementation strategies to address barriers to the control and management of metabolic side effects. The intervention includes a Design Phase (initial site visit and subsequent development of a local implementation plan); Implementation Phase (guided by an experienced external facilitator)" and a Sustainability Phase. The evaluation includes components of interpretive, implementation-focused, progress-focused, and developmental formative evaluation, as well as summative evaluation. The evaluation methods include surveys, qualitative data collection from participating provider, and quantitative data analysis of data from all patients prescribed a new antipsychotic drug at a study site who are required to monitor or manage metabolic side effects during phases of the study. study Changes in recommended monitoring rates and management actions at intervention and control sites will be compared using time series analysis Discussion Improve control of metabolic side effects of antipsychotics as well as promote timely management based on evidence when these effects arise, will lead to better patient safety and long-term results. This article discusses the key strengths and challenges of the study.

title: More informative summaries of articles describing clinical practice guidelines
abstract: Recommendations are proposed for the elaboration of more informative summaries of articles that describe clinical practice guidelines. The information on the development and content of the guidelines should be summarized with the following structure. Purpose: A succinct statement of the purpose of the guideline, including the target health issue, the target patients and providers, and the primary reason for developing recommendations on this issue. for this population. Options: main practice options that were considered when formulating the guideline. Outcomes: Significant health and economic outcomes identified as potential consequences of practice choices. Evidence: methods used to collect, select and synthesize evidence, and the date of the most recent evidence obtained. Values: People and methods used to assign values (relative importance) to the possible outcomes of alternative practice options. Benefits, harms and costs: the type and magnitude of the main benefits, harms and costs that are expected as a result of the implementation of the guide. Recommendations: A short and specific list of key recommendations. Validation: the results of any external review, comparison with guidelines developed by other groups, or clinical evidence of guideline use. Sponsors: Key individuals or groups who developed, funded, or endorsed the guide. Abstracts adhering to these recommendations could improve readers' ability to assess the applicability, relevance, and validity of the guidelines for specific providers, patients, and settings. More informative abstracts could also promote the use of more explicit methods of guideline development, more consistent reporting of guideline documents, and more appropriate use of guidelines by clinicians.

title: Mother-to-child transmission of HIV-1 infection during exclusive breastfeeding in the first 6 months of life: an interventional cohort study.
abstract: Background Exclusive breastfeeding, although better than other forms of infant feeding and associated with better infant survival, is rare. We evaluated the risks of HIV-1 transmission and survival associated with exclusive breastfeeding and other types of infant feeding.";" Background Exclusive breastfeeding, although better than other forms of infant feeding and associated with better infant survival, is rare. We evaluated the risks of HIV-1 transmission and survival associated with exclusive breastfeeding and other types of infant feeding.

title: Motivation is a crucial factor for adherence to a healthy lifestyle among people with coronary heart disease after percutaneous coronary intervention
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To test the Chronic Illness Adherence Theory with respect to treatment adherence among patients with coronary heart disease after percutaneous coronary intervention. BACKGROUND: Greater understanding of the concept of adherence is needed for the development of nursing interventions and nursing guidelines for patients with coronary heart disease. DESIGN. Cross-sectional, multicenter study. METHODS: This study was conducted from February to December 2013 with 416 patients with coronary artery disease 4 months after undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention. A self-administered questionnaire was used to assess their adherence to treatment. The data was analyzed using structural equation modeling. RESULTS: The theory explained 45% of adherence to a healthy lifestyle and 7% of adherence to medication. Structural equation modeling confirmed that motivation and care outcomes had the strongest association with adherence to a healthy lifestyle. Responsibility was associated with medication adherence. Support from relatives, support from nurses and doctors, and motivation, cooperation, fear of complications, and a sense of normalcy were associated with adherence. CONCLUSION: Patients who are motivated to perform self-care and consider outcomes of care important were more likely to adhere to a healthy lifestyle. Responsible patients were more likely to adhere to their medication. It is important to consider these elements as part of secondary prevention strategies among patients with coronary artery disease after percutaneous coronary intervention.

title: Motivational enhancement therapy with and without cognitive behavioral therapy to treat type 1 diabetes
abstract: Background: Although psychological problems can interfere with diabetes care, the effectiveness of psychological treatments in improving diabetes outcomes is uncertain. Objective: To determine whether motivational enhancement therapy with or without cognitive behavioral therapy improves glycemic control in type 1 diabetes compared to usual care. Design: Randomized controlled trial. Setting: 8 diabetes centers in London and Manchester, UK. Patients: 344 adults with type 1 diabetes for more than 2 years, with hemoglobin A1c levels of 8.2% to 15%, and without complications or serious comorbid disease. Intervention: nurse-provided motivational enhancement therapy (4 sessions over 2 months), motivational enhancement therapy plus cognitive behavioral therapy (12 sessions over 6 months), or usual care. Measurements: 12-month change in hemoglobin A1c levels (primary outcome), hypoglycemic events, depression, quality of life, fear of hypoglycemia, diabetes self-management activities, and body mass index x (secondary outcomes). Results: In an analysis that included all randomized patients, the 12-month change in hemoglobin A1c levels compared to usual care was 0.46% (95% CI, 0.81% to 0 .11%) in the motivational enhancement therapy plus cognitive behavioral therapy group and 0.19% (CI, 0.53% to 0.16%) in the motivational enhancement therapy alone group. There was no evidence of treatment effects on secondary outcomes. Limitations: Of 1659 patients screened, only 507 were eligible and 344 participated. Data on the primary outcome were not available for 11.3% of participants. The study design did not allow us to distinguish the additive effect of cognitive behavioral therapy plus motivational enhancement therapy from the effect of greater intensity and duration of the combined intervention compared to motivational enhancement therapy alone. Conclusion: Motivational enhancement therapy and cognitive behavioral therapy provided by nurses is feasible for adults with poorly controlled type 1 diabetes. Combination therapy results in a modest 12-month improvement in hemoglobin A1c levels compared with usual care, but motivation-enhancing therapy alone does not.

title: Motivational Interviewing: Helping People Change, 3rd Edition
abstract: This bestselling work for professionals and students is the authoritative introduction to Motivational Interviewing (MI), the powerful approach to facilitating change. More than an update, the third edition has been completely restructured around the new four-process MI model (engage, focus, recall, and plan). MI creators William R. Miller and Stephen Rollnick demonstrate what processes look like in practice, describe a wide range of applications, and review the growing evidence base. Infused with respect and compassion for clients, the book begins with a comprehensive description of MI's spirit and method. Sections for each of the four processes provide a step-by-step guide to establishing a strong working relationship, developing a clear focus and direction, evoking and strengthening the client's motivation for change, and formulating a concrete plan of action. Basic communication skills used in IM are explained";" vignettes and interview examples vividly illustrate the do's and don'ts of successful implementation in various contexts. Ways to develop competency in IM, integrate it with other practices, and assess intervention fidelity are discussed. Key points at the end of each chapter highlight the book's usefulness for teaching and professional development. The companion website (www.guilford.com/p/miller2) provides other helpful resources, including reflection questions, annotated case material, an expanded bibliography, and a glossary of terms. Reflecting major advances in the understanding and teaching of MS, this book is essential reading for professionals in the mental health and health care disciplines, including addiction specialists, clinical psychologists, psychiatrists, social workers , family therapists, counselors, nurses, doctors, and health educators. Graduate students in these fields will find it to be an accessible and uniquely informative course text. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2016 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: Motivational Interviewing: Is It All Our Clients Need?
abstract: Motivational Interviewing (MI) and its offshoots, such as Drinker Control and Motivational Enhancement Therapy, have become enormously popular in addiction treatment and scientific circles over the past decade. This article first addresses the reasons for this popularity and suggests that it is due to the presumed cost-effectiveness, the relevance of interventions in populations that do not seek treatment, and the essential nature of addictions as motivational disorders. The article then goes on to examine the evidence for the effectiveness of MI in treatment-seeking and non-treatment-seeking samples, taking into account published systematic reviews and, in particular, the findings of Project MATCH. The relevance of possible outcomes of the UK alcohol treatment trial is also considered. The article also discusses the switching mechanisms that can explain the way MI works. It ends with a list of conclusions related to the efficacy of MI, the potential treatment roles it may play, the client groups for which it may be especially appropriate, and what further research is needed. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2016 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: Mouthwash in oral mucositis in the context of allogeneic stem cell transplantation: a qualitative study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Oral mucositis is a common side effect of allogeneic stem cell transplantation and can lead to increased morbidity, mortality, and higher costs. It also has an impact on the quality of life of patients. In the stem cell transplant ward of a Swiss university hospital, patients are instructed according to current mouthwash guidelines and the condition of their mouth is assessed daily. RESEARCH QUESTION: How do patients experience oral mucositis and what factors influence their behavior to mouthwash regularly? METHOD: In this qualitative part of a concurrent nested mixed methods investigation, 14 patients were interviewed using an interview guide. The data was analyzed using content analysis methods. RESULTS: The results showed that oral mucositis cannot be viewed separately from disease, isolation, and care. Mucositis was only a heavy burden for patients with a severe occurrence. For patients with lesser-grade occurrences, other symptoms were more important. The research identified motivating and debilitating factors for regular mouthwashing, which is one of the most important preventive procedures. CONCLUSIONS: This study highlights how important it is to see oral mucositis in the transplant context and that knowledge about the motivating and hindering factors can help nurses in the care of patients. Improving patient self-control is a key aspect.

title: Much cheaper, almost as good: decreasingly profitable medical innovation
abstract: Under conditions of limited resources, cost-saving innovations can improve overall results, even when they are slightly less effective than available options, by allowing for a more efficient reallocation of resources. The authors systematically reviewed all MEDLINE-cited cost-utility analyzes written in English between 2002 and 2007 to identify and describe cost- and quality-lowering medical innovations that might offer "decreasingly" favorable cost-effective trade-offs, defined as savings in minus $100,000 per quality-adjusted life year lost. Of 2128 cost-effectiveness ratios from 887 publications, only 9 comparisons (0.4% of the total) described 8 innovations that were considered to be decreasingly profitable. Examples included percutaneous coronary intervention (rather than coronary artery bypass grafting) for multivessel coronary disease, repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rather than electroconvulsive therapy) for drug-resistant major depression, watchful waiting for inguinal hernias and the sterilization and reuse of the hemodialyzer. Per patient, these innovations generated savings of $122 to nearly $12,000 but losses of 0.001 to 0.021 quality-adjusted life years (approximately 8 hours to 1 week). These findings demonstrate the rarity of declining profitable innovations in the medical literature.

title: Multidimensional analyzes to assess relationships between clinicians' treatment options and patient characteristics: the example of COPD
abstract: BACKGROUND: In some situations, practice guidelines do not provide robust evidence-based guidance regarding COPD treatment options, especially when large trials have failed to identify subgroups of particularly good or poor responders to available medications. METHODS: This cross-sectional observational study explored the performance of four types of multidimensional analyzes to assess associations between clinical characteristics of COPD patients and pharmacological and non-pharmacological treatments prescribed by lung specialists in a real-life setting. RESULTS: In total, 2494 patients were recruited by 515 respiratory physicians. Multiple correspondence analysis and hierarchical clustering identified 6 clinical subtypes and 6 treatment subgroups. Strong bidirectional associations were found between clinical subtypes and treatment subgroups in multivariate logistic regression. However, although the overall frequency of prescriptions varied from one clinical subtype to another for all types of pharmacological treatments, the clinical subtypes were not associated with specific prescription profiles. When canonical redundancy analysis was used, the proportion of variation in drug treatments explained by clinical characteristics remained modest: 6.23%. This proportion was higher (14.29%) for the non-pharmacological components of care. CONCLUSION: This study shows that, although pharmacological treatments for COPD are quantitatively very well related to the clinical characteristics of patients, there is no particular patient profile that can be qualitatively associated with prescriptions. This underlines the uncertainties perceived by clinicians in differentiating the respective effects of available pharmacological treatments. The methodology applied here is helpful in identifying areas of uncertainty that require further investigation and/or clarification of the guidance.

title: Multidisciplinary treatment of pediatric obesity: evaluation and nutritional management
abstract: Methods of evaluation and treatment of pediatric obesity are rapidly evolving. Thought to be caused by an imbalance in caloric intake and expenditure, obesity requires a comprehensive evaluation of patient, family, environmental, genetic, and cultural characteristics so that clinicians can design successful interventions. Quantitative nutritional assessment of caloric intake is difficult and time consuming and should be used only in isolated settings, such as in the research setting, or if initial management approaches have been unsuccessful. Alternatively, providers should identify dietary patterns or behaviors that have been linked to obesity and are promising targets for change. Clinicians should tailor interventions based on the patient's and family's motivation and readiness to change. Current guidelines recommend gradual increases in treatment plans, and multidisciplinary treatment teams are recommended for patients who require intense intervention. Providers involved at a multidisciplinary level should incorporate their area of expertise into that of the team to develop a comprehensive management plan. This article reviews current recommendations for the evaluation and treatment of pediatric obesity with a focus on nutritional assessment as part of a multidisciplinary team.

title: Multifactorial influences and biases on the safety and quality of medication administration in the acute medical/surgical setting
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES: Although numerous factors influence medication administration, our understanding of the interaction of these factors on medication quality and safety is limited. The aim of this study was to explore multifactorial influences on medication quality and safety in the context of a single verification policy for medication administration in intensive care. APPROACH: An exploratory/descriptive study using non-participant observation and follow-up interview was used to identify factors influencing medication quality and safety in medication administration episodes (n=30). Observations focused on nurses' interactions with patients during medication administration and the characteristics of the environment in which they occurred. Confirmation of the observed data occurred at the end of the observation period during short semi-structured interviews with the participating nurses. FINDINGS: Findings showed that nurses developed therapeutic relationships with patients in terms of assessing patients before administering medications and educating patients about drugs during medication administration. Nurses experienced more frequent distractions when medications were stored and prepared in a community medication room according to the room layout. Nurses deviated from best practice guidelines during medication administration. IMPLICATIONS: Nurses' skills and preparation to develop therapeutic relationships with patients increased the quality and safety of medications, thereby protecting patients from potential adverse events. Deviations from best drug administration practices had the potential to decrease drug safety. System factors, such as room layout that determines drug storage areas, can be easily addressed to minimize potential error. CONCLUSIONS: The nurses showed behaviors that increased the quality and safety of medication administration";" however, violations of practice standards were noted. These findings will inform future intervention studies to improve drug quality and safety.

title: Multifactorial intervention with nursing professionals does not change cardiovascular outcomes in patients with chronic kidney disease
abstract: Strict implementation of multi-target guidelines reduces vascular risk in diabetic patients. It is not known if this also applies to patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD). To assess this, the MASTERPLAN study randomly assigned 788 patients with CKD (estimated GFR 20 to 70 mL/min) to receive additional intensive skilled nursing support (the intervention group) or renal care (the control group). The primary endpoint was a composite of myocardial infarction, stroke, or cardiovascular death. During a mean follow-up of 4.62 years, modest but significant decreases in blood pressure, LDL cholesterol, anemia, proteinuria were found along with increased use of active vitamin D or analogs, aspirin, and statins in the intervention group. compared to controls. No differences were found in smoking cessation rate, weight loss, sodium excretion, physical activity, or glycemic control. Intensive control did not reduce the rate of the composite endpoint (21.3/1000 person-years in the intervention group compared to 23.8/1000 person-years in controls (hazard ratio 0.90)). No differences were found in the secondary outcomes of vascular interventions, all-cause mortality, or end-stage kidney disease. Therefore, the addition of intensive support by nurse practitioners in patients with CKD improved some levels of risk factors, but did not significantly reduce the rate of primary or secondary endpoints.

title: Multi-level support for physical activity and healthy eating.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This article reports on a study evaluating the relationship between social and community-level supports and physical activity and dietary behaviors among a low-income Latino population with multiple chronic conditions. BACKGROUND: With consistently lower physical activity than whites and documented nutritional deficiencies, Latinos in the United States of America represent a disproportionate share of the population with chronic disease. This pattern of health disparities is seen in every country, where there is a struggle to improve the health status of Aboriginal, immigrant, and low-income communities. Socioecological theories of healthy behavior highlight the importance of considering social and community support for healthy behavior and provide a useful framework for considering ways to improve physical activity and nutrition for immigrant and Aboriginal groups. METHOD: We present here data from an initial assessment of 200 patients from a health clinic in the United States of America serving a low-income, primarily Latino population. Participants were enrolled in Resources for Health, a randomized controlled trial to promote multilevel support for chronic disease self-management. Measures included self-reported physical activity, dietary behavior, and multilevel support for chronic disease management, as well as demographic data. Baseline data reported here were collected between February 2002 and September 2003. RESULTS: Use of multilevel supports (eg, family, individual, and health care provider) was statistically significantly associated with adherence to physical activity patterns and better eating habits. Being female and having multiple chronic diseases were also associated with better dietary behavior. These variables explained 20% of the variance in dietary behavior. CONCLUSION: The results support a socioecological approach to promoting healthy behavior in this low-income, primarily Latino sample with multiple chronic conditions. Addressing multiple levels of support for healthy behavior is important in interventions to improve physical activity and diet, and nurses may be particularly well placed to address these issues for low-income Aboriginal, immigrant, and chronically ill patients.

title: Multiple antipsychotic medication prescription patterns
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess current prescribing practices regarding the concomitant use of antipsychotic medications and to summarize the reasons why clinicians may prescribe >1 scheduled agent. METHODS: Pharmacy identified patients at William R Sharpe Jr Hospital who are currently receiving antipsychotic therapy. All patients receiving >/= 2 concomitantly scheduled antipsychotic agents were included in the study. Data related to demographics, current drug combinations used, history of tried therapeutic regimens, and prescriber rationale were prospectively evaluated over a 60-day period beginning December 13, 2000, and ending February 10, 2001. Prescriber rationale for using >1 antipsychotic concurrently and other drug treatment regimens that had been tested were compared with documented medical records and published therapeutic guidelines for schizophrenia. RESULTS: During a 60-day surveillance period, 206 patients received scheduled antipsychotic medications, and 85 (41%) received at least 2 agents. Respondents to a questionnaire for prescribers (59%) indicated that the most common justification for combination therapy was augmentation";" the least likely reason was cross-titration. Survey responses also indicated a belief that there was questionable therapeutic benefit in more than half of patients treated with multiple antipsychotic combinations. Additionally, chart documentation showed that most of these patients did not receive an adequate trial of monotherapy with other atypical or typical agents, or clozapine prior to the combination antipsychotic regimen. Fifty-one percent of medical records did not document justification for concomitant therapy. CONCLUSIONS: Due to a lack of published data, the practice of using multiple antipsychotic agents is considered a gray area that requires a higher level of awareness by the prescriber when evaluating effectiveness and safety. Documentation of the rationale, adverse effects, and response to the treatment regimen is essential to providing optimal patient care.

title: Multi-screen electronic alerts to increase venous thromboembolism prophylaxis
abstract: Venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis in high-risk patients is frequently underutilized. Previously, we designed a one-screen computer alert program that identified hospitalized patients at high risk for VTE who were not receiving prophylaxis and advised their physicians to prescribe prophylaxis. Although this strategy reduced the incidence of symptomatic VTE at 90 days by 41%, most electronic alerts were ignored. We have now developed a serial three screen alert software designed to educate clinicians who initially refused to order prophylaxis after a single screen alert. Of a total cohort of 880, physicians responsible for 425 patients received a single electronic alert, while 455 who declined prophylaxis after the first screen received the second and third screens of the new three-screen alert. Our enhanced three-screen serial alert program generated VTE prophylaxis orders for 58.4% of the 455 patients whose physicians initially refused to order prophylaxis after the one-screen alert. There was no significant difference in the rates of symptomatic VTE at 90 days between the two cohorts (2.8% for the single test vs. 2.2% for the triple test, p = 0.55). We conclude that our three-screen computer alert program can markedly increase prophylaxis among clinicians who decline an initial single-screen alert.

title: Should diabetes be a deadly disease in Africa? Study of treatment costs
abstract: OBJECTIVE To estimate the costs of diagnosing and treating diabetes in Tanzania. DESIGN Estimated costs from reported and recorded experience of patients with new-onset diabetes in 1989-1990 and of diabetic patients seen for the first time in 1981-2. SETTING Muhimbili Medical Center, Dar es Salaam. SUBJECTS 464 patients (315 men and 149 women). 262 patients diagnosed between September 1, 1989 and August 31, 1990 (group 1) and 202 between June 1, 1981 and August 31, 1982 (group 2). RESULTS The average annual direct cost of diabetes care in 1989-1990 was $287 for a patient who required insulin and $103 for a patient who did not. Insulin purchases accounted for 68.2% ($156) of the average annual outpatient costs for patients requiring insulin. For patients who did not require insulin, the cost of oral hypoglycemic agents and treatment of chronic complications and infections represented 42.5% ($29.3) and 48.8% ($33.7) of the costs, respectively. The cost of diabetic outpatient care for all of Tanzania was estimated at $2.7 million, of which *75,128 (32.2%) was for insulin. Physician and nurse costs accounted for 0.2% of the total cost of outpatient care. Direct annual hospital care costs were estimated at $1.25 million. About 0.2% of the Tanzanian population aged 15 and over used the equivalent of 8% of total government health spending, which was $47,4088,382. CONCLUSION Diabetes places a heavy strain on the limited resources of developing countries. If African diabetes patients have to pay for their treatment, most will not be able to and will die.

title: National Survey of Alcohol Screening and Brief Intervention Practices in US Level I Trauma Centers.
abstract: BACKGROUND: In 2007, the American College of Surgeons (ACS) Committee on Trauma implemented a requirement that Level I trauma centers must have a mechanism to identify patients who have a drinking problem and the ability to provide an intervention for patients with positive outcomes. Although the historic alcohol screening and brief intervention (SBI) mandate is anticipated to affect trauma practice across the country, a review of the literature revealed no studies that have consistently documented the pre-ACS requirement of SBI practice. . STUDY DESIGN: Trauma programs at all US level I trauma centers were contacted and asked to complete a survey on the ACS prerequisite trauma center SBI practice. RESULTS: One hundred forty-eight of 204 (73%) Level I trauma centers responded to the survey. More than 70% of responding facilities routinely used laboratory tests (eg, blood alcohol concentration) to screen patients for alcohol, and 39% routinely used a standardized screening question or screening instrument. Screen-positive patients received a formal alcohol consultation or had an informal discussion about alcohol with staff members approximately 25% of the time. CONCLUSIONS: The investigation noted marked variability among Level I centers in the percentage of patients screened and in the nature and extent of intervention delivery in screen-positive patients. Following the ACS Committee on Trauma requirement, future research could systematically implement and evaluate training in the delivery of evidence-based alcohol interventions and training in building trauma center organizational capacity for sustained delivery. of SBI.

title: Naturopathic treatment for ear pain in children
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Otitis media is one of the most frequent diseases of early infancy and childhood and one of the most frequent reasons for children to visit the doctor. In the last 2 decades, there has been a substantial increase in the diagnosis of otitis media worldwide. In the United States, 93% of all children have had at least one episode of acute otitis media (AOM) before the age of 7 years. Ear pain is the hallmark of AOM. Most affected children complain of ear pain or exhibit behavior that parents interpret as indicating ear pain. Treating ear pain early in the course of AOM decreases both parental anxiety and child discomfort and speeds the healing process. The objective of this study was to determine the efficacy and tolerability of naturopathic versus traditional treatment for the management of otalgia commonly associated with AOM in children. METHODS: The study was designed as a double-blind trial in a community outpatient clinic. A total of 171 children who were between 5 and 18 years old and had otalgia and clinical findings associated with middle ear infection were studied. The children were randomly assigned to receive treatment with naturopathic herbal extract (NHED) ear drops or anesthetic ear drops, with or without amoxicillin. At enrollment, children were assigned by computer numbered randomization to receive NHED (contains: allium sativum, verbascum thapsus, calendula flowers, hypericum perfoliatum, lavender, and vitamin E in olive oil) 5 drops 3 times daily, alone (group A) or together with a topical anesthetic (amethocaine and phenazone in glycerin) 5 drops 3 times a day (group B), or oral amoxicillin 80 mg/kg/d (maximum 500 mg/dose) divided into 3 doses with NHED 5 drops 3 times daily (group C) or topical anesthetic 5 drops 3 times daily (group D). A double-blind design was used and all ear drops were placed in identical bottles. Treatment was initiated by the nurse in all cases. A single physician (MS) evaluated and treated all patients included in the study and recorded all data. The presence or absence of ear pain was assessed over 3 days with a visual analog scale. Ear pain was assessed using a specially designed observational instrument based on previous reports. One side of the instrument consisted of a linear numbered scale, from 1 (no pain) to 10 (worst possible pain), and a corresponding color scale, ranging from blue to dark red. The reverse contained a scale of 5 facial expressions, ranging from a wide smile (no pain) to a sad, tearful face (worst possible pain), and a corresponding color scale, ranging from blue to dark red. RESULTS: There were no significant differences between the groups regarding the age or sex of the patients, the degree of fever, the main symptoms, the associated symptoms and the severity or laterality of the acute otitis media. Each group had a statistically significant improvement in ear pain within 3 days. Patients who received ear drops alone had a better response than patients who received ear drops together with amoxicillin. The results were better in the NHED group than in the controls. However, the findings indicated that the pain was mostly (80%) self-limited and could simply be explained by time elapsed. Guidelines from the American Academy of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery recommend topical medications as the first line of treatment for ear pain in the absence of systemic infection or serious underlying disease. Since we found no evidence that systemic antibiotics alone improved treatment outcome, if antibiotics do not change the natural course of otitis media, then the primary goal of treatment, as in the present study, should be pain relief. by ear Alternative medications, naturopathic herbal extracts, may offer many new possibilities in the treatment of ear pain associated with AOM. Primary care physicians should be aware that at least 10% of their patients may have tried one or more forms of complementary/alternative medicine before coming to the practice. As widely reported in the medical literature, these herbs, these herbal extracts have the potential to meet all the requirements of appropriate medication that could be routinely used in the pediatric patient, namely in vitro bacteriostatic and bactericidal activity against common pathogens, immunostimulation ability, antioxidant activity and anti-inflammatory effects. They are also well absorbed with good penetration into the tissue surrounding the tympanic membrane. They have been found to enhance local immune activity. Finally, herbal extracts are well tolerated (because of their long elimination time), easy to administer, and less expensive than the newer antibiotics. There are no documented side effects. Based on our findings that the group with the most significant treatment effects (NHED with topical anesthesia) explained only 7.3% of the total pain reduction, we propose that sometimes the general practitioner or pediatrician needs to give the human body the opportunity to repair itself. However, if the doctor believes that some treatment is indicated, especially if the parents are anxious, then a local treatment such as the one used in our study may be adequate. CONCLUSIONS: This study suggests that in cases of ear pain caused by AOM in children where active treatment is needed, in addition to a simple 2-3 day waiting period, an herbal extract solution may be beneficial. Concomitant antibiotic treatment does not appear to contribute.

title: Needs and opportunities in rehabilitation. AIDS and the environment
Negative pressure wound management after partial diabetic foot amputation: a multicentre randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Diabetic foot wounds, particularly those secondary to amputations, are very complex and difficult to treat. We investigated whether negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) improves the proportion and rate of wound healing after partial foot amputation in patients with diabetes.";" Background Diabetic foot wounds, particularly those secondary to amputations, are very complex and difficult to treat. We investigated whether negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) improves the proportion and rate of wound healing after partial foot amputation in patients with diabetes.

title: Neonatal decision-making at the end of life: physicians' attitudes and relationship to self-reported practices in 10 European countries.
abstract: Context The ethical issues surrounding end-of-life decision-making for infants with a poor prognosis are controversial. Little empirical evidence is available on the attitudes and values that underlie such decisions in different countries and cultures. Objective To explore the variability of attitudes of neonatal physicians across 10 European countries and the relationship between such attitudes and self-reported practice of end-of-life decisions. Design and Environment Survey carried out during 1996-1997 in 10 European countries (France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Spain, Sweden, the United Kingdom, Estonia, Hungary and Lithuania). Participants A total of 1,391 physicians (response rate, 89%) regularly employed in 142 neonatal intensive care units (NICUs). Main outcome measures Scores on an attitude scale, which measured opinions about the absolute value of life (score of 0) versus the value of quality of life (score of 10)";" self-report of ever setting limits on intensive neonatal interventions in cases of poor neurological prognosis. Results Physicians most likely to agree with statements consistent with preserving life at any cost were from Hungary (mean attitude scores, 5.2 [95% confidence interval {CI}, 4.9-5.5]), Estonia (4.9 [95% CI, 4.3-5.5]), Lithuania (5.5 [95% CI, 4.8-6.1]), and Italy (5.7 [95% CI, 5.3-6.0 ]), while physicians more in agreement that quality of life should be taken into account were from the United Kingdom (attitudinal scores, 7.4 [95% CI, 7.1-7.7 ]), the Netherlands (7.3 [95% CI, 7.1-7.5]), and Sweden (6.8 [95% CI, 6.4-7.3]) . Other factors associated with having a view in favor of quality of life were being female, not having had children, being Protestant or not having a religious background, considering religion not important, and working in a NICU with a high number of very low . -Newborns with birth weight. Physicians with scores reflecting a more quality-of-life view were more likely to report that their practice had set limits on intensive interventions in cases of poor neurological prognosis, with an adjusted odds ratio of 1.5 (95% CI %, 1.3-1.7) per unit change in attitude score. Conclusions In our study, the likelihood that physicians report setting limits to intensive neonatal interventions in cases of poor neurological prognosis is related to their attitudes.
