After adjusting for potential confounders, country remained the most important predictor of physician attitudes and practices.

title: Neurobehavioral morbidity associated with sleep-disordered breathing in children: a comprehensive review.
abstract: STUDY OBJECTIVES: To comprehensively review the research on the association between childhood sleep-disordered breathing (SDB) and neurobehavioral functioning. DESIGN: Qualitative and quantitative review of the literature. SCENARIO: N/A. PATIENTS OR PARTICIPANTS: N/A. INTERVENTIONS: N/A. MEASUREMENTS AND RESULTS: Findings from 61 studies on the relationship between childhood SDB and neurobehavioral functioning were critically appraised and synthesized. There is strong evidence that childhood SDBs are associated with deficits in behavior and emotion regulation, school performance, sustained attention, selective attention, and alertness. There is also evidence that SDB has minimal association with a child's typical mood, expressive language skills, visual perception, and working memory. Findings have been insufficient to draw conclusions about intelligence, memory, and some aspects of executive functioning. The mechanisms by which RRT might cause neurobehavioral morbidity are being explored, but clinical symptoms, such as chronic snoring, remain the best predictors of morbidity. Short-term studies of RRT treatment outcomes are encouraging, but long-term results are unknown. Failure to treat SDB appears to leave children at risk for long-term neurobehavioral deficits. CONCLUSIONS: Childhood RRT is associated with neurobehavioral morbidity. By applying commonly used guidelines for causal inference, even in the absence of a much-needed randomized clinical trial, there is strong evidence of association, consistent findings, and specificity of effect. There is suggestive evidence that this association fits the expected temporal pattern and that SDB is a biologically plausible cause of neurobehavioral deficits. Clinicians should be alert for the coexistence of RSD symptoms and concerns about the child's academic progress, attention, arousal, or regulation of behavior or emotions.

title: Neurotropic viruses and cerebral palsy: population-based case-control study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To investigate the association between cerebral palsy and direct evidence of perinatal exposure to neurotropic viruses. DESIGN Population-based case-control study. SETTING Adelaide Women's and Children's Hospital Research Laboratory. PARTICIPANTS AND MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Newborn screening cards from 443 white cerebral palsy patients and 883 white controls were analyzed for enterovirus and herpesvirus viral nucleic acids by polymerase chain reaction. Group A herpesviruses included herpes simplex viruses 1 and 2 (HSV-1 and HSV-2), Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), cytomegalovirus (CMV), and human herpesvirus 8 (HHV). -8) and group B herpesviruses included varicella zoster virus (VZV) and human herpesviruses 6 and 7 (HHV-6 and HHV-7). RESULTS The prevalence of viral nucleic acids in the control population was high: 39.8% of the controls were positive, and the prevalence was higher in preterm infants. Detection of herpes group B viral nucleic acids increased the risk of developing cerebral palsy (odds ratio 1.68, 95% confidence interval 1.09 to 2.59). CONCLUSIONS Perinatal exposure to neurotropic viruses is associated with preterm birth and cerebral palsy.

title: Never so old? Age should not be a barrier to enrollment in cancer clinical trials
abstract: Across Europe and the US, more than 60% of the total incidence of cancer occurs in the elderly population (> or = 65 years), a group of patients that requires special consideration when making treatment decisions due to to a number of factors. Despite this, elderly patients are generally underrepresented in clinical trials, so study data should be interpreted with caution because results in younger cancer patients may not always be extrapolated to the typical elderly cancer patient. . Reports suggest that elderly cancer patients represent about 22% of patients enrolled in phase II clinical trials. Barriers to accrual of elderly patients for clinical trials include lack of appropriate trials, high burden of comorbidity, restrictions imposed by the study, and clinician attitudes. There is a belief that elderly patients may be unable to tolerate various cancer therapies, which may result in this patient population being excluded from prospective trials. However, clinical data show that age alone is not a sufficient reason to discontinue treatment. The lack of clinical trial data and the associated lack of evidence-based guidelines for elderly patients means that clinicians have little to guide them, with the result that patients may not receive optimal therapy. Since clinical trials are the primary method for evaluating the efficacy and safety of adjuvant and palliative cancer therapies, trials specifically targeting elderly cancer patients are required to adequately assess the risks and benefits of treatment in this vulnerable population. This review aims to assess the clinical reality and age mismatch of clinical trials to assess the implications for older cancer patients and to identify how this situation can be addressed. Possible reasons for the disparity and resulting clinical consequences are also considered.

title: New challenges in family interventions for schizophrenia
abstract: This review first describes the rationale and research base supporting the development of family interventions for schizophrenia. The fundamental principles that guide effective family interventions for schizophrenia are then presented, along with the key components (engagement, assessment, education, communication skills training, and problem-solving) shared by most family programs in schizophrenia. Meta-analyses demonstrating the efficacy of family interventions in reducing relapse and rehospitalization in schizophrenia are then discussed, along with issues related to the minimum duration of effective treatment, the differential benefits of single and multiple family modalities, and the mixed evidence. for the maintenance of the effects of treatment after termination. The benefits of participating in family-organized non-professional education and support programs are then described. Finally, three issues that deserve further study are outlined.

title: New developments in psychotherapy for schizophrenic psychoses
abstract: There is already sufficient evidence of the efficacy of psychotherapeutic interventions, particularly cognitive behavioral therapy, for symptom reduction and relapse prevention. Evidence-based treatment guidelines recommend this approach for routine care. A growing number of randomized clinical trials and research on active elements of treatment characterize this field. This article presents clinical and research implications. Treatment strategies to reduce positive and negative symptoms, which represent an innovative field of research, are presented and discussed in terms of efficacy, treatment principles, and potential future developments.

title: New drugs in anesthesia: can we afford them?
abstract: The most important challenge facing physicians today is the dilemma of providing high-quality care in a fiscally responsible manner. The cost can no longer be ignored. Pharmacoeconomics is a fundamental component of medical education. Economic issues must be an integral part of drug development and clinical trials. Although anesthesiologists are concerned that the use of less expensive medications may compromise patient outcome and satisfaction, there is little evidence to support such concerns. This is a fertile area for intense future research. Pharmacoeconomics is dynamic. Drug cost is not static, patterns of drug use change rapidly, and clinical practice is in a state of constant flux. The answer to cost containment is not simply to cut back, cap, delist, or simply hope for the best, but to manage and modify the practice as they adapt to changing needs. Educational programs, guidelines, departmental policies, system changes, and financial incentives can be implemented to ensure consistent and long-lasting adherence to the principles of pharmacoeconomics and value-based care. Some suggest that national societies should create guidelines for cost-effective practice. Others favor physician autonomy in drug selection. Changing physician behavior is difficult. This change will occur gradually and will be the subject of many emotionally charged philosophical debates. There will be a great reluctance to deny patients pharmacologically superior drugs based solely on cost, especially since drugs represent such a small portion of total costs. We must be careful to ensure that we do not become stingy and foolish. Drug acquisition costs are just one element in a large and complex equation. Focusing on the cost of purchasing medicines can be dangerous, even naive, if we are prey to knowing the cost of everything but the value of nothing.

title: New format for BMJ research papers in print
abstract: It has been almost 10 years since we began abstracting original research articles for readers of the BMJ print journal. Now we're going one step further, taking advantage of both the web and print. The full open access version of this original article by Hollingshurst and colleagues is published online (doi:10.1136/bmj.a2656), along with our first BMJ research video and podcast. Here are two abridged versions: a BMJ PicoÃ¢â‚¬â€, a new evidence summary prepared by the authorsâ€¢â‚¬â€ and a Short Cuts article written by the BMJ. Which version would you read and use? Which would you prefer if you were the author? Tell us your views, as readers and researchers, by posting quick responses to this article. Sandra Hollinghurst,1 Debbie Sharp,1 Kathleen Ballard,3 Jane Barnett,2 Angela Beattie,1 Maggie Evans,1 George Lewith,2 Karen Middleton,2 Frances Oxford,3 Fran Webley,2 Paul Little2 Study Question What is the difference in cost? effectiveness between long and short courses in the Alexander technique, massage and exercise prescription of a general practitioner for patients with persistent back pain? Answer An exercise prescription and six lessons in the Alexander Technique alone had more than an 85% chance of being cost-effective at values greater than £20,000 per quality-adjusted life year (QALY), but the Alexander Ã¢â‚¬ ¦

title: New insights into common variable immunodeficiency
abstract: Common variable immunodeficiency (CVI) is a heterogeneous immunodeficiency syndrome characterized by hypogammaglobulinemia, recurrent bacterial infections, and various immunological abnormalities. In addition to recurrent infections, patients with this syndrome also have a higher incidence of autoimmune diseases and malignancies. Because the spectrum of associated diseases is broad, patients with CVD are cared for by several specialist doctors. This review discusses the pathogenesis, clinical manifestations, diagnosis, and treatment of CVI.

title: Newly diagnosed idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura in childhood: an observational study.
abstract: Background Diagnosis and treatment of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) have been based primarily on expert opinion and practice guidelines rather than evidence. We have used a registry to prospectively examine the presenting characteristics and diagnostic assessment and management practices used for children with ITP worldwide.";" Background Diagnosis and treatment of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) have been based primarily on expert opinion and practice guidelines rather than evidence. We have used a registry to prospectively survey the presenting characteristics and diagnostic evaluation and management practices used for children with ITP worldwide.

title: NHMRC Guidelines for ASD and PTSD Clinical Practice
abstract: Dear Editor, I recently described the case of a diving instructor who suffered from acute stress disorder (ASD), a type of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), after the death of one of her students. The treatment described was a combination of exposure-based eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR) exercises and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). As it happens, in August, the Australian Center for Post-Traumatic Mental Health released the Australian Clinical Practice Guidelines for ASD and PTSD. These have been endorsed by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC). The treatment described in the diver injury case is consistent with these guidelines. NHMRC guidelines suggest that immediately after a traumatic event (eg, diver death or serious injury), psychological first aid is the most helpful response. This includes providing information about traumatic stress reactions, encouraging self-care, and using available social support. It is recommended that the physician monitor the patient, noting improvement, plateau, or deterioration, and be ready to offer assistance or appropriate referral if necessary. The guidelines recommend the use of trauma-focused psychological therapy as a first-line intervention for ASD and PTSD. EMDR, including in vivo exposure, and CBT are considered the most effective treatments. If medication is required, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor antidepressants are considered the best option. For the benefit and convenience of patients and clinicians, the NHMRC guidelines and a comprehensive set of ASD and PTSD information guides are available online as pdf file downloads at http://www.acpmh.unimelb.edu .au. An update in the Medical Journal of Australia provides information on traumatic stress for clinicians, including screening questions that can be used to identify patients suffering from ASD and PTSD. This article is available online at: http://www.mja.com.au/public/issues/187_02_160707/for10467_fm.html. Short articles and summary sheets specifically for divers on the topics of traumatic stress reactions, death, and panic are available at http://psychodiver.com.

title: NHS 1948-88: less ideology, more humanity
SNS profile. Enter the men of the Audit Committee. Richard Smith Interview
NICE Guide on prevention of STIs and teenage pregnancies
abstract: NICE has published new public health intervention guidance to stop the growing number of sexually transmitted infections, including HIV, and to prevent conception in those under 18 years of age. This article describes the roles of nurses in implementation.

title: No impact of active dissemination of the Ottawa Ankle Rules: further evidence of the need for local implementation of practice guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: Local implementation strategies are often required to promote consistent adherence to clinical guidelines, but are time consuming and costly. The authors tested an educational intervention designed to increase use of the Ottawa Ankle Rules, a widely publicized set of clinical guidelines that had previously been shown to reduce the use of radiographs for the diagnosis of acute ankle injuries. METHODS: The study consisted of a quasi-experimental comparative analysis, before and after. Trained experts delivered 1-hour educational sessions and provided resource materials on the Ottawa Ankle Rules to healthcare professionals from 63 Ontario hospitals. Participants were asked to rate the intervention. The authors then compared, for the periods before and after the educational sessions, the use of ankle radiography for adults with acute ankle injury in 10 hospitals that received the educational intervention and did not report (n = 5) or some ( n = 5) previous use. standards and in 5 control hospitals, which declined the educational intervention because they were already implementing the standards. RESULTS: Although participants gave very positive ratings of the Ottawa Ankle Rules and the educational sessions, there was no reduction in ankle radiography use for the 10 hospitals that received the educational sessions (73% before and 78% after). intervention, p = 0.11). In contrast, the use of radiography decreased significantly, from 75% to 65%, in the 5 control hospitals (p = 0.022). INTERPRETATION: Even when a dissemination strategy is well received and involves a widely accepted clinical guideline, the impact on behavior in clinical practice may be small. In addition to wide dissemination, an active local implementation strategy is needed to encourage clinicians to adopt clinical guidelines.

title: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease and fibrosis in youth taking psychotropic medications: literature review, case reports, and management.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) has become a global epidemic due to the increased prevalence of obesity. Despite the implications for young people with severe mental disorders, little has been published in the psychiatric literature on this increasingly common medical comorbidity. The objectives of this article are: 1) to provide an overview of the epidemiology and pathophysiology of NAFLD, including progression to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)"; 2) to describe two clinical cases that illustrate the difficulties encountered in management; " and 3) review screening recommendations, differential diagnosis, and follow-up and intervention approaches. METHODS: A review of the literature, including guidelines and recommendations, was conducted with case presentations that included case-control liver histology biopsy photographs. RESULTS: NAFLD in childhood and adolescence, as a precursor to NASH, progresses to fibrosis in a small percentage of young people, leading to risk of early-onset cirrhosis and the need for transplantation. The cases presented raise concerns that youth with serious mental health disorders, who are already at increased risk of obesity and its sequelae, may be at increased risk of progression to NASH, possibly due to higher rates of weight gain in addition to state of overweight or obesity, and to changes in the hepatic metabolism of psychotropic drugs that favor fat deposition. CONCLUSIONS: Patients with rapid weight gain in the overweight or obese categories, or who develop elevated liver transaminase levels that persist for 3 to 6 months, should be evaluated or referred for screening by their psychotropic provider physicians. for early detection, diagnosis, and co-management by a pediatric gastroenterologist, to decrease the risk of progression to NASH, which is reversible if early and sufficient lifestyle change results in significant weight loss. There is an urgent need for controlled research on the relationships between weight gain, psychotropic medications, ultrasound and biopsy results, and rates of progression to NAFLD and NASH in youth taking psychotropic medications that induce weight gain. .

title: Noninvasive Imaging Predicts Failure Loading of the Spine with Simulated Osteolytic Defects
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical management of lytic spinal tumors is currently based on geometric measurements of the defect. However, the mechanical behavior of a structure depends on both its material and its geometric properties. Quantitative computed tomography and dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry were investigated as noninvasive tools to measure the material and geometric properties of vertebrae with a simulated lytic defect. From these measurements, yield loads were predicted using composite beam theory. METHODS: Thirty-four fresh-frozen cadaveric spines were segmented into functional spinal units of three vertebral bodies with two intervertebral discs at the thoracic and lumbar levels. Equally sized lytic defects were created in one of three locations: the anterior, lateral, or posterior region of the vertebra. Each column unit was scanned using dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry and computed tomography, and axial and flexural stiffnesses were calculated from the image data. Each specimen was driven to failure under combined compression and forward bending, and the axial load and bending moment at yield were recorded. RESULTS: Although relative defect size was nearly constant, the measured yield loads had a large scatter, suggesting that defect size alone was a poor predictor of failure. However, the image-derived structural stiffness measures correlated moderately well with the measured yield loads. Furthermore, using composite bundle theory with computed tomography-derived quantitative stiffnesses, vertebral yield loads were predicted one-to-one (concordance, r(c) = 0.74). CONCLUSIONS: Although current clinical guidelines for predicting fracture risk are based on geometric measurements of the defect, we have shown that relative defect size alone does not explain variation in vertebral yield loads. However, composite beam theory analysis with quantitative computed tomography-derived stiffness measures can be used to prospectively predict yield loads of vertebrae with lytic defects. CLINICAL RELEVANCE: Image-predicted vertebral yield loads and analytical models that approximate the loads applied to the spine during activities of daily living can be used to calculate a fracture risk factor that clinicians can use to plan treatment or appropriate intervention.

title: Non-surgical management of blunt splenic injury
Nonpharmacologic Therapies for Acute and Chronic Low Back Pain: An Evidence Review for an American Pain Society/American College of Physicians Clinical Practice Guideline
abstract: BACKGROUND: Many non-pharmacological therapies are available for the treatment of low back pain. PURPOSE: To assess the benefits and harms of acupuncture, back schools, psychological therapies, exercise therapy, functional restoration, interdisciplinary therapy, massage, physical therapies (interferential therapy, low-level therapy). laser therapy, lumbar supports, shortwave diathermy, superficial heat, traction, transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation, and ultrasonography), spinal manipulation, and yoga for acute or chronic low back pain (with or without leg pain). DATA SOURCES: Studies in English were identified by searching MEDLINE (up to November 2006) and the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews (2006, Issue 4). These electronic searches were supplemented by handsearching reference lists and additional citations suggested by experts. STUDY SELECTION: Systematic reviews and randomized trials of one or more of the above therapies for acute or chronic low back pain (with or without leg pain) reporting outcomes of pain, specific back function, general health status, work disability or patient satisfaction. DATA EXTRACTION: We extracted information on study design, population characteristics, interventions, outcomes, and adverse events. To rate methodological quality, we used the Oxman criteria for systematic reviews and the Cochrane Back Review Group criteria for individual trials. DATA SYNTHESIS: We found good evidence that cognitive behavioral therapy, exercise, spinal manipulation, and interdisciplinary rehabilitation are all moderately effective for chronic or subacute low back pain (>4 weeks' duration). Benefits over placebo, sham therapy, or no treatment averaged 10 to 20 points on a 100-point visual analog pain scale, 2 to 4 points on the Roland-Morris Disability Questionnaire, or a standardized mean difference of 0.5 to 0.8. We found fair evidence that acupuncture, massage, yoga (Viniyoga), and functional restoration are also effective for chronic low back pain. For acute low back pain (<4 weeks duration), the only non-pharmacological therapies with evidence of efficacy are superficial heat (good evidence of moderate benefit) and spinal manipulation (fair evidence of small to moderate benefit). Although serious damage appeared to be rare, damage data was poorly reported. No trials have addressed the optimal sequencing of therapies, and methods for tailoring therapy to individual patients are still in early stages of development. Evidence is insufficient to assess the efficacy of sciatica therapies. LIMITATIONS: Our main source of data was systematic reviews. We included trials in languages other than English only if they were included in systematic reviews in English. CONCLUSIONS: Therapies with good evidence of moderate efficacy for chronic or subacute low back pain are cognitive behavioral therapy, exercise, spinal manipulation, and interdisciplinary rehabilitation. . For acute low back pain, the only therapy with good evidence of efficacy is superficial heat.

title: Non-pharmacological management of hypertension: results of interviews with 100 general practitioners.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To describe the type and level of non-pharmacological management offered by general practitioners for essential arterial hypertension. DESIGN: An open-ended, interviewer-administered survey using a standard case of a 60-year-old man with essential hypertension. Seventy interviews were conducted face-to-face and 30 by telephone. SETTING: Auckland General Practice. SUBJECTS: A random sample of 100 Auckland general practitioners. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Aspects of patient medical records, physical examination, laboratory tests, and treatments relevant to non-pharmacological management. RESULTS: There was a response rate of 84%. Most general practitioners reported that they offer non-pharmacological management at the first consultation before prescribing medications. However, few offered detailed programs. Most general practitioners suggested dietary therapy, restriction of alcohol consumption, and exercise. Restriction of sodium intake and behavioral therapy were less popular non-pharmacological interventions. The median number of patient visits to a general practitioner before medications were prescribed was five, which is in accordance with guidelines. The median number of days from the first visit to the prescription of pharmacological treatment was 42 (range 2-341). The clinical advice provided by most participants was consistent with current hypertension management guidelines, but the range of advice provided was wide. CONCLUSIONS: The results suggest that general practitioners are aware of non-pharmacological interventions for the management of hypertension. They report routine use of nonpharmacologic therapies for blood pressure reduction and other health benefits early in the clinical process before considering pharmacologic therapy. These non-pharmacological therapies are not delivered with well-defined and detailed programs.

title: Unresponsive celiac disease
Nordic Myeloma Study Group, the first 15 years: scientific collaboration and improving patient care
abstract: The achievements of the Nordic Myeloma Study Group (NMSG) during its first 15 years are briefly reviewed, along with a discussion of the principles guiding the group's clinical trials and the issues that need to be addressed in the coming years. So far, the group has conducted 12 clinical trials, involving more than 2,500 patients, ranging from smaller phase II trials to large randomized phase III trials. At the time of writing, two randomized trials (comparing two doses of intravenous pamidronate and melphalan-prednisone (MP) versus MP-thalidomide in elderly patients) are ongoing. The group has striven for a simple organization with much responsibility delegated to regional coordinators (Denmark 3, Norway 5, Sweden 5). With regard to trial design, the group has considered it important that studies are based on sound scientific questions, are user-friendly for participants, population-based, investigator-initiated, include quality-of-life assessment, and health resources as endpoints, and can be used as the basis for various spin-off science projects. Like other clinical trial groups, the NMSG faces a number of challenges in the coming years. The financial situation of trials initiated by independent investigators is far from satisfactory, especially with regard to the resource-intensive implementation of stricter good clinical practice rules and ethics committee requirements. The NMSG has also found it increasingly difficult to recruit patients for recent trials, in part due to problems related to participating physicians (lack of support, laborious paperwork, insufficient credit for participation). Solutions to these problems must be found if industry-independent clinical trial groups are to survive.

title: Norepinephrine plus dobutamine versus epinephrine alone for the treatment of septic shock: a randomized trial.
abstract: Background International guidelines for the management of septic shock recommend that dopamine or norepinephrine are preferable to epinephrine. However, no large comparative trial has yet been performed. Our objective was to compare the efficacy and safety of norepinephrine plus dobutamine (whenever necessary) with that of epinephrine alone in septic shock.";" Background International guidelines for the management of septic shock recommend that dopamine or norepinephrine are preferable to epinephrine. However, no large comparative trial has yet been performed. The objective was to compare the efficacy and safety of norepinephrine plus dobutamine (whenever necessary) with that of epinephrine alone in septic shock.

title: Normal ranges of heart rate and respiratory rate in children from birth to 18 years: a systematic review of observational studies.
abstract: Background Although heart rate and respiratory rate in children are routinely measured in acute settings, current reference ranges are not evidence-based. Our goal was to derive new percentile plots for these vital signs and to compare these percentiles to existing international ranges.";" Background Although heart rate and respiratory rate in children are routinely measured in acute settings, current reference ranges are not evidence-based. Our goal was to derive new percentile plots for these vital signs and to compare these percentiles with existing international ranges.

title: Pushing guideline-concordant antibiotic prescribing: a randomized clinical trial
abstract: IMPORTANCE: "Nudges" that influence decision making through subtle cognitive mechanisms have been shown to be highly effective in a wide range of applications, but there have been few experiments to improve clinical practice. OBJECTIVE: To investigate the use of a behavioral 'nudge' based on the principle of public engagement to encourage the judicious use of antibiotics for acute respiratory infections (ARIs). DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: Randomized clinical trial in 5 primary care outpatient clinics. A total of 954 adults had ARI visits during the study time period: 449 patients were treated by physicians randomly assigned to the published commitment letter (335 in the reference period, 114 in the intervention period)";" 505 patients were treated by clinicians randomized to standard practice control (384 baseline, 121 intervention). INTERVENTIONS: The intervention consisted of displaying poster-size commitment letters in examination rooms for 12 weeks. These letters, with photos and physician signatures, declared their commitment to prevent the inappropriate prescribing of antibiotics for ARIs. MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES: Antibiotic prescription rates for AKI diagnoses with inappropriate antibiotics in the baseline and intervention periods, adjusted for patient age, sex, and insurance status. RESULTS: Baseline rates were 43.5% and 42.8% for control and poster, respectively. During the intervention period, inappropriate prescribing rates increased to 52.7% for controls, but decreased to 33.7% in the published commitment letter condition. Controlling for baseline prescribing rates, we found that the published commitment letter resulted in a 19.7 absolute percentage reduction in the rate of prescribing inappropriate antibiotics relative to control (P = 0.02). There was no evidence of diagnostic coding switching, and appropriate antibiotic prescription rates did not decline over time. CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Displaying poster-sized engagement letters in exam rooms decreased inappropriate antibiotic prescribing for ARIs. The effect of this simple, low-cost intervention is comparable in magnitude to more expensive and intensive quality improvement efforts. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Clinicaltrials.gov identifier: NCT01767064.

title: Driving prescription decisions by partitioning the order set: results of a vignette-based study.
abstract: Background Electronic health records (EHRs) are being rapidly adopted by healthcare professionals. Within EHRs, seemingly innocuous menu layout configurations can influence vendor decisions for better or worse. Objective The purpose of this study was to examine whether the grouping of menu items systematically affects prescribing practices among primary care providers. Participants We surveyed 166 primary care providers in a network of research practices in the Chicago metropolitan area, of whom 84 responded (51% response rate). Respondents and non-respondents were similar on all observable dimensions, except that respondents were more likely to work in an academic setting. Design The questionnaire consisted of seven clinical vignettes. Each vignette described typical signs and symptoms of acute respiratory infections, and providers chose treatments from a menu of options. For each vignette, vendors were randomly assigned to one of two menu partitions. For inappropriate antibiotic vignettes, the treatment menu listed over-the-counter (OTC) medications individually while grouping prescriptions, or showing the reverse partitioning. For antibiotic-appropriate vignettes, the treatment menu listed narrow-spectrum antibiotics individually while grouping broad-spectrum antibiotics, or showed the reverse partitioning. Main measures The main outcome was provider choice of treatment. For inappropriate antibiotic vignettes, we categorized responses as either prescription drugs or over-the-counter-only options. For the appropriate vignettes for antibiotics, we classified the responses as either broad or narrow spectrum antibiotics. Key results Across all vignettes, there was an 11.5 percentage point reduction in the choice of aggressive treatment options (eg, broad-spectrum antibiotics) when aggressive options were pooled compared with when those same options were listed individually (95% CI 2.9 to 20.1%"; "p?=?.008). Conclusions Provider choice of treatment appears to be influenced by menu option grouping, suggesting that the design of EHR order sets is not an arbitrary exercise. Careful crafting of EHR order sets can serve as an important opportunity to improve patient care without limiting physicians' ability to prescribe what they believe is best for their patients.

title: Pushing prudence? The effect of reminders on antibiotic prescriptions.
abstract: Antibiotic resistance is a large and growing global health threat with significant consequences. The judicious use of antibiotics is vital to slow the spread of resistance. In this study I use a randomized controlled trial to test the effect on antibiotic use of reminders for primary care patients. The intervention was implemented in 31 clinics during the flu season in Stockholm. Two-level randomization was used, with randomization at the clinic level as well as at the individual patient level. With reminders, antibiotic use was reduced by 12.6 percent relative to control clinics. The effect is at the clinical level, suggesting that doctors or doctor-patient interactions, not individual patients, are affected. The results of a follow-up experiment further suggest that an effect on doctor-patient interactions is the main driver of the main results. Behavioral interventions targeting these interactions have the potential to reduce antibiotic use. However, more research is needed as control and adherence may also play a role.

title: Nurse-led home self-help treatment for patients in primary care with chronic fatigue syndrome: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the efficacy of pragmatic rehabilitation at home, a program of gradual increase in activity designed collaboratively by the patient and therapist, and supportive listening, a non-directive advice-based approach, for patients in primary care with chronic fatigue/myalgic syndrome. encephalomyelitis or encephalitis (CFS/ME). DESIGN Single-blind, randomized, controlled trial. SETTING 186 general practices in the North West of England between February 2005 and May 2007. PARTICIPANTS 296 patients aged 18 years or older with ME/CFS (median disease duration seven years) diagnosed according to the Oxford criteria. INTERVENTIONS Participants were randomized to pragmatic rehabilitation, supportive listening, or general medical treatment as usual. Both therapies were delivered at home in 10 sessions over 18 weeks by one of three adult specialist nurse practitioners who had received four months of training, including supervised practice, in each of the interventions. GP treatment, as usual, had no restrictions, except that patients were not to be referred for systematic psychological therapies during the treatment period. Main outcome measures The primary clinical outcomes were fatigue and physical functioning at the end of treatment (20 weeks) and 70 weeks from enrollment compared to usual treatment with general practitioners. Lower fatigue scores and higher physical functioning scores indicate better outcomes. RESULTS A total of 257 (87%) of the 296 patients who entered the trial were evaluated at 70 weeks, the primary outcome point. Analysis was by intention to treat, with robust treatment effects estimated after adjustment for missing data using probability weights. Immediately after treatment (at 20 weeks), patients allocated to pragmatic rehabilitation (n=95) had significantly improved fatigue (effect estimate -1.18, 95% confidence interval -2.18 to -0 .18"; P=0.021), but not physical functioning (-0.18, 95% CI -5.88 to +5.52; P=0.950) compared with patients assigned to treatment as usual (n One year after the end of treatment (70 weeks), there were no statistically significant differences in fatigue or functional physical activity between patients assigned to pragmatic rehabilitation and those in treatment as usual (-1.00, CI of 95%: -2.10 to +0.11, P = 0.076 and +2.57, 95% CI 3.90 to +9.03, P = 0.435). n=101) had poorer physical functioning than those assigned to treatment as usual (-7.54, 95% CI -12.76 to -2.33, P=0.005) and no difference in fatigue. 70 weeks, patients allocated to supportive listening did not differ significantly from those allocated to treatment as usual on any of the primary outcomes. CONCLUSIONS For ME/CFS patients in primary care, pragmatic rehabilitation provided by trained nurse practitioners improves short-term fatigue compared with unrestricted usual GP treatment, but the effect is small and not statistically significant at one year. of follow up. Supportive listening by trained nurse practitioners is not an effective treatment for ME/CFS. Trial registration International standard randomized controlled trial number IRCTN74156610.

title: Nurse practitioners improve quality of care in chronic kidney disease: two-year results of a randomized study.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is associated with increased cardiovascular risk. Here we assess whether strict implementation of multi-target guidelines with the help of nurse practitioners (NPs) improves management in patients with CKD. METHODS: MASTER PLAN is a randomized controlled clinical trial, conducted in nine Dutch hospitals. Patients with CKD (estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) 20-70 mL/min) were randomized to receive PN support (intervention group (IG)) or medical care (control group (CG)). The patients were followed for a median of five years. The data presented is an interim analysis on the control of risk factors at two years of follow-up. RESULTS: We included 788 patients (532 F, 256 F), (393 CG, 395 IG), mean age (+/-SD) 59 (+/-13) years, eGFR 38 (+/-15) mL/min/ 1.73m(2), blood pressure (BP) 138 (+/-21)/80 (+/-11) mmHg. At two years, 698 patients (352 IG, 346 CG) could be analyzed. The IG compared to the CG had lower systolic BP (133 vs 135 mmHg; p= 0.04) and diastolic BP (77 vs 80 mmHg; p=0.007), LDL cholesterol (2.30 vs 2.45 mmol(-l );” p= 0.03) and increased use of ACE inhibitors, statins, aspirin, and vitamin D. The intervention had no effect on smoking cessation, body weight, physical activity, or sodium excretion . CONCLUSION: In both groups, the management of risk factors improved. However, changes in BP control, lipid management, and medication use were more pronounced in the IG than in the CG. Lifestyle interventions were not effective. Coaching by NPs thus benefits the daily care of CKD patients. Whether these changes translate into improvement in clinical endpoints remains to be established.

title: Nurse-led motivational interviewing to change the lifestyle of patients with type 2 diabetes (MILD project): protocol for a group randomized controlled trial on the implementation of lifestyle recommendations
abstract: BACKGROUND: Diabetes in many patients is treated in general practice";" health care providers aim to promote healthy behaviors, such as a healthy diet, adequate physical activity, and smoking cessation. These measures can decrease insulin resistance, improve glycemic control, lipid abnormalities, and hypertension. They can also prevent cardiovascular disease and diabetes complications. However, practitioners do not optimally adhere to guidelines for lifestyle advice. Motivational interviewing to change the lifestyle of patients with type 2 diabetes aims to improve diabetes care in accordance with national guidelines for lifestyle counseling. Primary care nurses will receive training in motivational interviewing integrated into structured care in general practice. The purpose of this article is to describe the design and methods of a study evaluating the effects of nurse education on patient outcomes. METHODS/DESIGN: A cluster randomized controlled trial involving 70 general practices (35 practices in the intervention arm and 35 in the control arm) from March 2007. A total of 700 patients with type 2 diabetes will be recruited. 2. Patients in the intervention arm will receive care from the primary care nurse, who will be trained in an implementation strategy with motivational interviewing as a core component. Other components of this strategy will be the adaptation of the diabetes protocol to local circumstances, the introduction of a social map to support lifestyle, and educational and support tools to maintain motivational interviewing. The control arm will be encouraged to maintain usual care. The measures of effect will be the process of care, metabolic parameters (glycosylated hemoglobin, blood pressure and lipids), lifestyle (diet, physical activity, smoking and alcohol), health-related quality of life and willingness of patients to change of behavior Measurements will be made at baseline and after 14 months. DISCUSSION: The application of motivational interviewing for patients with diabetes in primary care has been studied, but to our knowledge, no other study has yet evaluated the implementation and sustainability of motivating and engaging patients in daily diabetes care in general practice. If this intervention proves to be effective and cost-effective, large-scale implementation of this nurse-oriented intervention will be considered and anticipated. TESTING RECORD: Current Controlled Testing ISRCTN68707773.

title: Nurse-led telephone outreach to improve lipids in people with diabetes
abstract: BACKGROUND: Prospective randomized trials of case management interventions with resource utilization analyzes are needed. OBJECTIVES: To determine if algorithm-based telephone nursing care improves lipid control in patients with diabetes. DESIGN: Prospective, randomized, controlled trial. PARTICIPANTS: Adults with diabetes at a federally funded community health center were randomly assigned to intervention (n = 381) or usual care (n = 381) groups. INTERVENTIONS: Nurses independently initiated and titrated lipid therapy and promoted behavior change through motivational interviewing and self-management techniques. Other parameters of diabetes care were addressed based on time constraints. MAIN MEASURES: The primary outcome was the proportion of patients with low-density lipoprotein (LDL) less than 100 mg/dl. Secondary outcomes included the number of hospital admissions, total hospital charges per patient, and the proportion of patients who met other guidelines for lipids, blood glucose, and blood pressure. KEY RESULTS: The percentage of patients with LDL < 100 mg/dL increased from 52.0% to 58.5% in the intervention group and decreased from 55.6% to 46.7% in the control group (p < 0.01). The average cost per patient to the health system was lower for the intervention group ($6,600 vs $9,033, P = 0.03). Intervention patients tended to have fewer hospital admissions (p = 0.06). The intervention did not affect the results of blood glucose and blood pressure. CONCLUSIONS: Nurses can improve lipid control in patients with diabetes in a primarily indigent population through telephonic care using moderately complex algorithms, but a more targeted approach is warranted. Phone-based outreach may decrease resource utilization, but more study is needed.

title: Nurses' evaluations on the use of CPOT at 12 months post-implementation in the intensive care unit
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical practice guidelines strongly recommend routine pain assessment for all intensive care unit (ICU) patients. As many ICU patients are unable to self-report, the Intensive Care Pain Monitoring Tool (CPOT) is one of two suggested behavioral pain scales for clinical use. Still, no study has described evaluations of its use in daily ICU practice. OBJECTIVE: To describe the nurses' evaluation of the feasibility, clinical relevance and satisfaction with the use of CPOT 12 months after its implementation in the ICU. METHOD: A descriptive design was used. It was carried out in the medical-surgical ICU of a university-affiliated setting in Greenfield Park (Quebec, Canada). ICU nurses, all trained to use the CPOT, completed a self-administered assessment questionnaire that included four sections (ie, feasibility, clinical relevance, satisfaction, and sociodemographic information). The questionnaires were completed anonymously. RESULTS: A total of 38 ICU nurses returned their completed questionnaire (63% participation rate). Regarding its feasibility, the majority rated the CPOT as quick to use, simple to understand and easy to complete (92-100%). Based on clinical relevance, about 70% of ICU nurses recognized that CPOT had influenced their practice, but lower results (<50%) were found for effective communication of pain assessment findings with physicians and other health professionals. More than 80% of ICU nurses were satisfied with its daily use. CONCLUSION: The use of CPOT was considered feasible and relevant in daily practice according to the nurses' evaluations, but it did not allow effective communication with other members of the ICU care team. RELEVANCE TO CLINICAL PRACTICE: Training should be offered to all members of the ICU care team, and other implementation strategies should also be explored to ensure optimal adoption of a pain assessment approach that impacts their decision-making process. decision-making for pain management.

title: pay nurses
Representations of nurses about the care of patients with intellectual disabilities and perceived needs to guarantee quality care
abstract: AIMS AND OBJECTIVES: To explore the representations of nurses about the care of people with intellectual disabilities, the intervention strategies they currently use and identify the needs to guarantee quality care. BACKGROUND: Nurses work in many settings and with diverse clients. Certain clienteles have needs that require specific approaches, such as people who have an intellectual disability. The care offered to these patients can be influenced by the representations that the nurses who care for them have. Design. Descriptive qualitative study. METHODS: Semi-structured interviews using thematic analysis were conducted with 18 nurses working in hospital and community settings. RESULTS: Nurses are concerned about their ability to recognize the specific nature and complex needs associated with patients' intellectual disabilities, promoting quality care by managing behavioral and communication challenges, as well as coping with the perception of lack of time and organization within the work environment. . Current strategies involve trying to promote continuity of care. Participants also identified their learning needs, which are relational and informational in nature. CONCLUSIONS: Nurses are often aware of wanting to provide quality care to patients who have an intellectual disability, while acknowledging that there are many contextual and practical elements that require improvement to ensure the safety of these patients. RELEVANCE TO CLINICAL PRACTICE: Nurses need to be educated to accommodate the findings emerging from current research showing that people with intellectual disabilities want to be part of their local communities and encourage these people to do so. This can be facilitated by adopting specific care guidelines, protocols and programs. More research is needed to develop a better understanding of the expectations of these patients and their caregivers, focusing on self-advocacy and health promotion techniques, with the aim of improving standards of personalized practice and reducing inequalities in health education for these patients.

title: Nursing strategies to address aspects of self-care related to medication adherence and symptom recognition in patients with heart failure: an in-depth look
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Despite a growing body of knowledge about self-management in patients with heart failure, the need for effective interventions remains. We sought to deepen our understanding of the interventions that heart failure nurses use in clinical practice to improve patient adherence to medication and symptom monitoring. METHODS: A qualitative study with targeted content analysis was conducted, using data from a selected sample of Dutch-speaking heart failure nurses who completed two-vignette booklets on medication adherence and symptom recognition. RESULTS: Nurses regularly assess and reassess patients before deciding on an intervention. They assess basic/factual information and barriers in a patient's behavior, and try to find room for improvement in a patient's behavior. Interventions used by heart failure nurses to improve medication adherence and symptom control were grouped under the themes of increasing knowledge, increasing motivation, and providing practical tools to patients. Nurses also described the use of technology-based tools, increased social support, alternative communication, partnership approaches, and care coordination to improve medication adherence and symptom control. CONCLUSION: Despite a strong focus on educational strategies, nurses also reported other strategies to increase patient adherence. Nurses use various strategies to improve patient adherence that are not incorporated in the guidelines. These interventions should be evaluated for future applications in improving the management of heart failure.

title: Nursing research in the United States: the protection of human subjects
abstract: In the United States, the protection of the rights of human subjects in experimentation has evolved on three levels: professional, public, and private. At the professional level, codes, guidelines, and the Patient Bill of Rights address the issues of protecting the dignity, privacy, and autonomy of people who serve as research subjects. At the public level, regulations promulgated by the Food and Drug Administration and the Department of Health and Human Services have become the standard for protecting human beings. At the private level, United States common law regulates the conduct of individual investigators by requiring them to act in a manner consistent with generally accepted standards of care. As professionals, nurses must actively participate in the formation of public policy regarding the conduct of research and strive to formulate a research agenda that ensures that the ethics of nursing research is above question.

title: Standard nursing practice protocol: depression in elderly patients. Faculty NICHE
abstract: Depression is a highly prevalent but underrecognized and undertreated mental health problem in institutionalized, medically ill, and community-dwelling older adults. Untreated depression is associated with serious negative consequences for the elderly patient. Nurses in various practice settings can reduce the negative effects of depression through early recognition, intervention, and referral of patients with depression. This article presents an overview of depression in older age with an emphasis on age-related assessment considerations, clinical decision making, and nursing intervention strategies for older adults with depression. A standard practice protocol for use by nurses in a variety of practice settings is also presented.

title: Nursing students' beliefs about smoking, their own smoking behaviors and the use of professional intervention for the treatment of smoking
abstract: As the largest group of healthcare professionals, nurses are in a unique position to influence their patients who smoke. They also have more contact with patients than any other provider. The purpose of this survey study was to describe nursing students' beliefs about smoking, their smoking behaviors, and the use of evidence-based smoking treatment interventions. Of 200 undergraduate nursing students surveyed, only 6% were smokers. The most inaccurate perception about smoking cessation treatment was that counseling of less than 3 minutes had no effect on improving smoking cessation rate. Eight percent of surveyed smokers reported that they provide anti-smoking treatment to all patients who smoke compared to 26% of non-smokers. Smoking-related morbidity and mortality justify the consistent use of clinical practice guidelines by nursing students and nurse practitioners.

title: Nurture More Important Than Nature in Childhood Obesity: Study
abstract: A study that compared the weight of biological and adopted children with that of their parents found that lifestyles, rather than genes, are primarily responsible for children's overweight.1 The researchers, from the Center for Economic Performance in the London School of Economics and Political Science, concluded that policies to influence parental lifestyles could help combat overweight in children. For the study, the researchers collected data from 13 years Ã¢â‚¬Â¦

title: Nutrition and Policy

Evaluation and treatment of obesity: recommendations of the Expert Committee. The Bureau of Maternal and Child Health, the Health Resources and Services Administration, and the Department of Health and Human Services
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The development of recommendations for physicians, nurse practitioners, and nutritionists to guide the evaluation and treatment of overweight children and adolescents. METHODS: The Bureau of Maternal and Child Health, Health Resources and Services Administration, Department of Health and Human Services convened a committee of experts on pediatric obesity to develop recommendations. RESULTS: The Committee recommended that children with a body mass index (BMI) greater than or equal to the 85th percentile with complications of obesity or with a BMI greater than or equal to the 95th percentile, with or without complications, be evaluated and possibly treatment. . Physicians should be aware of the signs of rare exogenous causes of obesity, including genetic syndromes, endocrine diseases, and psychological disorders. They should detect complications of obesity, such as hypertension, dyslipidemia, orthopedic disorders, sleep disorders, gallbladder disease, and insulin resistance. Conditions that indicate consultation with a pediatric obesity specialist include pseudotumor cerebri, obesity-related sleep disorders, orthopedic problems, massive obesity, and obesity in children younger than 2 years. Recommendations for treatment evaluation included an assessment of the patient's and family's readiness to participate in a weight management program and a focused assessment of diet and physical activity habits. The primary goal of obesity therapy should be healthy eating and activity. The use of weight maintenance versus weight loss to achieve weight goals depends on each patient's age, baseline BMI percentile, and the presence of medical complications. The Committee recommended treatment that begins early, involves the family, and gradually institutes permanent changes. Parenting skills are the foundation for a successful intervention that implements targeted, gradual increases in activity and targeted reductions in high-fat, high-calorie foods. Continued support for families after the initial weight management program will help families maintain their new behaviors. CONCLUSIONS: These recommendations provide practical guidance for pediatric clinicians evaluating and treating overweight children.

title: Observational Study of Telephone Consultations by Stroke Experts Supporting Administration of Tissue Plasminogen Activator in the Community
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Barriers to the use of intravenous (IV) tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) in ischemic stroke include the limited treatment experience of community physicians. Models of acute stroke care have been designed to address these limitations by providing community support. These include telephone or televideo support, with or without subsequent transport to tertiary care centres. The authors describe the frequency, characteristics, and effect of community telephone consultations to a 24/7 stroke "hotline" staffed by stroke physicians at an academic stroke center. strokes using that model. METHODS: Twelve intervention hospitals participating in the INcreasing Stroke Treatment through Interventional Behavior Change Tactics (INSTINCT) trial were provided with a single access number ("hotline") for expert consultation on tPA use. The experts consisted of physicians trained in stroke at an academic medical center. The use of the hotline was not mandatory in the study protocol, nor was patient transfer required. Consultants were asked to record all treatment questions in a web-based log. All patients discussed through the hotline and/or treated with tPA at an INSTINCT hospital underwent multi-level chart review by trained nurse coordinators. Cases were linked to recorded hotline calls, based on time of treatment and hospital of initial treatment. Medical judges evaluated the adequacy of tPA treatment, the presence of deviation from standard guidelines, and treatment complications (intracranial hemorrhage [ICH], systemic hemorrhage, or death). RESULTS: Over 27 months, there were a total of 204 calls to the hotline regarding 116 patients. 91% of calls were made between 8 am and midnight, and 77% of questions explored eligibility issues for IV tPA, particularly for minor strokes or stroke improvement (26%). A total of 243 patients were treated with IV tPA at the 12 intervention hospitals, 54 of whom followed telephone consultations. Seventy-six percent of hotline patients recommended for tPA actually received tPA, while 2% of those not recommended for tPA received the drug. There were no differences in protocol deviations (27.8% hotline group vs 23.8% no hotline group), incidence of symptomatic ICH (5.6% vs 7.3%) or hospital mortality (5.6% vs. 13.2%). No medicolegal issues have been reported for any case in the study. CONCLUSIONS: Providing tPA decision support through telephone consultation to community physicians is feasible and safe. Consultants may play a more prominent role in determining tPA ineligibility than in acceptance. Future work should include a real-time survey of medical providers to determine the potential qualitative benefits of a stroke hotline.

title: Oncologists' Perspectives on Care for Rare Cancers: A National Survey
abstract: PURPOSE: In response to the challenges and difficulties posed by rare cancers, multi-stakeholder initiatives dedicated to improving rare cancer care were launched, and several recommendations were made by professional societies. However, these primarily reflect the views of advocates and supporters, and may not represent the views of the "average" clinician or researcher. In this study, we sought to investigate perceived difficulties regarding rare cancer care and potential solutions supported by oncologists. MATERIALS AND METHODS: A representative sample of 420 oncologists recruited from 13 cancer centers participated in a nationwide survey. RESULTS: Oncologists faced several difficulties in treating patients with rare cancers, including lack of clinical practice guidelines (65.7%) and personal experience (65.2%), lack of approved treatment options (39, 8%) and refund issues (44.5%). . They generally supported recent recommendations from multi-stakeholder initiatives as well as professional societies for the development of clear clinical practice guidelines (66.0%), flexible reimbursement guidelines (52.9%), and a national registry of rare cancer (47.4%). However, there was only moderate support for referrals to high-volume centers (35.5%) and encouragement of unapproved treatments (21.0%). CONCLUSION: Insights into the general attitudes of oncologists gained through our national survey of representative samples would be useful in developing clinical practice and public health policy in rare cancer treatment and research.

title: Implementation of the 5A brief smoking cessation model by health professionals in oncology: patient perceptions
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Health care providers (HCPs) can play an important role in promoting smoking cessation and relapse prevention. Public Health Service guidelines recommend the "5A" brief intervention model. The aim of the current study was to examine cancer patients' perceptions of the implementation of the 5A model by their oncology HCPs. METHODS: This study included 81 thoracic and 87 head and neck cancer patients at a large NCI-designated comprehensive cancer center. Patients completed questionnaires to assess perceptions of the implementation of the 5A's brief intervention model by their oncology professionals. RESULTS: The results indicate a partial implementation of the 5A model. However, most patients reported that their providers had asked them about smoking and advised them to quit";" only half reported that their interest in quitting had been assessed, and few reported smoking cessation assistance or follow-up. Delivery of the 5As was higher among patients who sought smoking cessation advice from their HCP. CONCLUSION: The current findings suggest the need to increase adherence to 5As in the oncology setting. PRACTICAL IMPLICATIONS: Efforts to increase the provision of smoking cessation treatments by health professionals may improve the quit rate among cancer patients and ultimately translate into better long-term cancer treatment outcomes. term.

title: One size? Mixed Methods Evaluation of the Impact of 100% Single Room Accommodation on Staff and Patient Experience, Safety, and Costs
abstract: Background and objectives There is little strong evidence regarding the impact of single room accommodation on the quality and safety of healthcare. We explored the impact of all single rooms on staff and patient experience, safety outcomes, and costs. Methods Mixed methods before/after 'move-in' comparison within four case study rooms nested in a single acute hospital with 100% single rooms; quasi-experimental before-and-after study with two control hospitals;" analysis of capital and operating costs associated with individual rooms. Results Two-thirds of patients expressed a preference for single rooms with comfort and control that outweigh any disadvantage (feeling of isolation) felt by some. Patients appreciated the privacy, confidentiality, and flexibility of individual visitor rooms. Staff perceived improvements (patient comfort and confidentiality), but single rooms were worse in terms of visibility, vigilance, teamwork, monitoring, and patient safety. Staff walking distances increased significantly after the move. A temporary increase in falls and medication errors in a ward is likely to be associated with the need to adjust work patterns rather than with individual rooms per se. We found no evidence that single rooms reduced infection rates. A one-room hospital may cost 5% more to build with higher maintenance and cleaning costs, but the difference is marginal over time. Conclusions Staff needed to significantly adapt their work practices and did not feel ready for new ways of working with potentially significant implications for the long-term nature of teamwork. Staff preference remained for a combination of single rooms and bays. Patients preferred single rooms.

title: One-year outcomes of surgical versus nonsurgical treatments for discogenic back pain: a community-based prospective cohort study.
abstract: BACKGROUND CONTEXT: The clinical entity "discogenic back pain" remains controversial at fundamental levels, including its pathophysiology, diagnostic criteria, and optimal treatment. This is true despite the availability of four randomized trials comparing the efficacy of surgical and non-surgical treatments. One trial showed benefits for lumbar fusion compared to unstructured non-surgical care, and three others showed more or less similar results for lumbar surgery and structured rehabilitation. PURPOSE: To compare the outcomes of community-based surgical and nonsurgical treatments for patients with chronic back pain attributed to degeneration at one or two lumbar disc levels. DESIGN: Prospective observational cohort study. PATIENT SAMPLE: Patients presenting with axial back pain to academic and private practice orthopedic surgeons and neurosurgeons in a large metropolitan area. OUTCOME MEASURES: Roland-Morris back disability score (main outcome), current rating of overall pain severity on a numerical scale, back and leg pain bother measures, the Physical Function Scale of Questionnaire 36 short form version 2, pain medication use, employment status, emergency department visits, hospitalizations, and additional surgery. METHODS: Patients who received spinal surgery within 6 months of enrollment were designated as the "surgical treatment" group and the remainder as "nonsurgical treatment." Outcomes were evaluated at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months after enrollment. RESULTS: We enrolled 495 patients with discogenic back pain who presented for initial surgical consultation at the offices of 16 surgeons. Eighty-six patients (17%) underwent surgery within 6 months of enrollment. Surgery consisted of instrumented fusion (79%), disc replacement (12%), laminectomy or discectomy (9%). Surgical patients reported more severe pain and physical disability at baseline and were more likely to have had prior surgery. Adjusting for baseline differences between groups, surgery showed a limited benefit over non-surgical treatment of 5.4 points on the Modified Roland Disability Questionnaire (23 points) (main outcome) 1 year after enrollment. Using a composite definition of success that incorporates a 30% improvement in Roland score, a 30% improvement in pain, no use of opioid analgesics, and work (if applicable), the 1-year success rate was 33 % for surgery and 15% for non-surgical. treatment. The reoperation rate was 11% in the surgical group";" the surgery rate after treatment appointment in the non-surgical group was 6% at 12 months after enrollment. CONCLUSIONS: The surgical group showed greater improvement at 1 year compared with the nonsurgical group, although the composite success rate for both treatment groups was fair. The results should be interpreted with caution because the results are short term and treatment was not randomised. Only 5% of non-surgical patients received cognitive behavioral therapy. The non-surgical treatment received by the patients was variable and the majority did not comply with the main guidelines.

title: Continuous supply of individual physician performance data improves practice behavior
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical practice guidelines summarize the evidence from science and attempt to translate those findings into clinical practice. Widespread and consistent adoption of these guidelines in providers' daily practice has been slow. METHODS: Using compliance with postoperative nausea and vomiting prophylaxis (PONV) guidelines as our metric, we compared the effects of continuing medical education (CME) alone (I), CME with a single snapshot of provider compliance (II). and ongoing provider reporting. compliance data without further CME (III). We retrospectively analyzed guideline compliance for 23,279 anesthetics at the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center. Compliance was defined as a patient with 1 risk factor for PONV receiving at least 1 antiemetic, 2 risk factors receiving at least 2 antiemetics, and 3 risk factors receiving at least 3 antiemetics. Drugs in the same class were counted as single antiemetic administration. Anesthetic techniques based on propofol were counted as receiving 1 antiemetic. Patients with 0 risk factors for PONV were not included. We estimated compliance rates for each of the 4 study time periods by adjusting for multiple observations from the same physician. Individual performance feedback was provided once at 6 months after intervention I coinciding with a PONV update presentation (start of intervention II) and quarterly during intervention III. RESULTS: Compliance rates were not significantly influenced by CME (intervention I) compared to baseline behavior (54.5% vs. 54.4%, P = 0.9140). There was a significant improvement over the time period when CME was matched to performance data (Intervention II) compared to Intervention I (59.2% vs. 54.4%, P = .0002) . There was a further significant improvement when data were presented alone (intervention III) compared to intervention II (65.1% vs 59.2%, p < 0.0001). For patients with 3 risk factors, we observed a significant improvement in compliance rates during intervention III (P = 0.0002). In the post hoc analysis of overtreatment, the percentage differences between baseline and time period III decreased as the number of risk factors increased. CONCLUSIONS: We observed the greatest improvement in adherence to guidelines with continuous feedback on personal performance. Provider feedback can be an effective tool for changing clinical practice, but it can have unintended consequences.

title: Online interventions for social marketing health behavior change campaigns: a meta-analysis of psychological architectures and adherence factors.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Researchers and practitioners have developed numerous online interventions that encourage people to reduce their alcohol consumption, increase their exercise, and better manage their weight. Motivations for developing eHealth interventions may be driven by reach, interactivity, cost-effectiveness, and Internet studies showing that online interventions work. However, when designing online interventions suitable for public campaigns, few evidence-based guidelines exist, taxonomies are difficult to apply, many studies lack impact data, and previous meta-analyses are not applicable to large-scale public campaigns targeting the voluntary behavior change. OBJECTIVES: This meta-analysis evaluated online intervention design features to inform the development of online campaigns, such as those employed by social marketers, that seek to encourage voluntary health behavior change. Another objective was to increase understanding of the relationships between intervention adherence, study adherence, and behavioral outcomes. METHODS: Based on systematic review methods, a combination of 84 query terms in 5 bibliographic databases with additional gray literature searches was used. This resulted in 1,271 abstracts and articles; 31 met the inclusion criteria. In total, 29 articles describing 30 interventions were included in the main meta-analysis, and the additional 2 studies qualified for compliance analysis. Using a random effects model, the first analysis estimated the overall effect size, including groupings by control conditions and time factors. The second analysis evaluated the impacts of psychological design features that were coded with taxonomies from evidence-based behavioral medicine, persuasive technology, and other fields of behavioral influence. The systems were integrated into a coding framework model called the Communication-Based Influence Component Model. Finally, the third analysis evaluated the relationships between intervention adherence and behavioral outcomes. RESULTS: The overall impact of online interventions across all studies was small but statistically significant (standardized). mean difference effect size d=0.19, 95% confidence interval [CI]=0.11-0.28, p<0.001, number of interventions k=30). The greatest impact with a moderate level of efficacy was exerted by online interventions compared to waiting lists and placebos (d = 0.28, 95% CI = 0.17-0.39, p < 0.001, k = 18), followed by the comparison with those with less technology. online interventions (d=0.16, 95% CI=0.00-0.32, p=0.04, k=8); no significant difference was found compared to sophisticated print interventions (d=-0.11, 95% CI=-0.34 to 0.12, p=0.35, k=4), although online interventions offer a small effect with the advantage of lower costs and greater reach. Time turned out to be a critical factor, with shorter interventions generally achieving higher impacts and better adherence. By design, most interventions were based on the transtheoretical approach and were goal-oriented, deploying numerous influencing components aimed at showing users the consequences of their behavior, helping them achieve goals, and providing normative pressure. Inconclusive results suggest a relationship between the number of influencing components and the effectiveness of the intervention. Despite a conflicting correlation, evidence suggests that study adherence, intervention adherence, and behavioral outcomes are correlated. CONCLUSIONS: These findings demonstrate that online interventions have the ability to influence voluntary behaviors, such as those often targeted by social marketing campaigns. Given the high reach and low cost of online technologies, the stage can be set for increased public health campaigns that combine interpersonal online systems with mass media reach. Such a combination of approaches could help people achieve personal goals that, at the individual level, help citizens improve the quality of their lives and, at the state level, contribute to healthier societies.

title: Operations Research as Implementation Science: Definitions, Challenges, and Research Priorities
abstract: Background Operations research (OR) is the discipline of using models, either quantitative or qualitative, to aid decision-making on complex implementation problems. Operating room methods have been used in health care since the 1950s in a variety of areas, such as emergency medicine and the interface between acute and community care"; hospital performance; visit scheduling and management patients' home visits; scheduling patient appointments"; and many other complex implementation issues of an operational or logistical nature. Discussion To date, there has been limited debate about the role of operations research in implementation science. I detail three such roles for OR, all based on early systems thinking: structuring implementation problems, prospective evaluation of improvement interventions, and strategic reconfiguration. Case studies from mental health, emergency medicine, and stroke care are used to illustrate each role. I then describe the challenges for applied OR within implementation science at the organizational, interventional, and disciplinary levels. Two key challenges include the difficulty faced in achieving a position of mutual understanding between implementation scientists and research users and a marked lack of evaluation of OR interventions. To address these challenges, I propose a research agenda to assess applied OR through the lens of implementation science, freeing OR from the specialized research and consulting environment, and co-designing models with service users. . Abstract Operations research is a mature discipline that has developed an important volume of methodology to improve health services. OR offers implementation scientists the opportunity to think more about the system up front before committing resources or taking risks. OR has three functions within implementation science: the structuring of an implementation problem, the prospective evaluation of implementation problems, and a tool for the strategic reconfiguration of health services. Challenges facing OR as an implementation science include limited evidence and impact evaluation, limited engagement of service users, lack of managerial awareness, effective communication between research users and OR modelers, and availability of care data. medical. To advance the science, a focus on three key areas is needed: evaluation of OR interventions, incorporation of OR knowledge into health services, and education of OR modelers on the goals and benefits of user engagement. from service.

title: Physician opinion survey on ethical issues in medical research
abstract: total of 3622 doctors registered with the Indian Medical Association were contacted by mail and asked to answer a semi-structured questionnaire related to different aspects of medical ethics, with a special emphasis on informed consent. Six hundred and twenty-nine physicians (17.4%) responded to the questionnaire"; 86% of the respondents reported having no formal training in medical ethics"; 49% of the subjects who undertook the research obtained only oral consent. Most respondents noted the relevance of ethics in different medical situations, although in certain areas, such as community health and animal research, ethical issues were considered less important. Patients' inability to follow up regularly and illiteracy were considered to be the main limitations to obtaining consent. Opinion about the amount of information to be imported to research participants as part of informed consent differed from standard guidelines. Physicians who reported taking an orientation course in medical ethics and those with prior research experience were more aware of ethical issues. Most professionals wanted the inclusion of ethics in the medical curriculum.

title: Opportunistic electronic reminders. Improving the performance of preventive care in general practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Preventive care is an important role for general practitioners, but opportunities for prevention are often missed. METHOD: We provided an automated electronic record preventive care reminder system for 12 preventive care activities for a 10-physician practice. All patients who attended were randomized by the terminal digit of their registration number. RESULTS: Control uptake of opportunistic prevention was low";" from 1.5% (vaccination against tetanus) to 27% (vaccination against influenza).
