Reminders increased this by significant but small amounts for four of 12 activities (tetanus and pneumococcal vaccination and allergy and weight log), negligible increases for four (mumps, measles and rubella vaccination, smoking and cervical smear and blood pressure), and a negligible decrease in influenza immunization and screening for diabetes and hyperlipidemia. DISCUSSION: Opportunistic electronic reminders have the potential to increase preventive care in general practice.

title: Optimal Matching of Patients' Preferences for Information, Decision Making, and Interpersonal Behavior: Evidence, Models, and Interventions
abstract: OBJECTIVE: An exhaustive review of the theoretical and empirical work that addresses the strategy of matching preferences in doctor-patient communication was carried out. METHODS: Medline, PsychINFO, InFoTrac One File Plus, Sociological Abstracts, and Dissertation Abstracts were searched up to 2004. The following keywords were used: patient-received and preferred information; patient-preferred, up-to-date treatment decision making; doctor-patient beliefs in shared decision making; compatibility, suitability or concordance between doctor and patient; reciprocal relationship or mutuality; affiliation, control, physician-patient relationship;" match/fit between patient and physician in affiliation, control, or relationship. RESULTS: Findings revealed varying degrees of support for the positive effects of matching preferred levels of information, decision control and consultative interpersonal behavior of patients.CONCLUSIONS:The findings justify not only the continuation but also the expansion of research efforts in this area that would incorporate the recommended changes in research design and implementation.IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE AND EDUCATION RESEARCH: Screening strategies and matching interventions that, if evidence continues to be supportive, could routinely optimize physician-patient encounters toward more positive outcomes are discussed. Methodological guidelines are suggested that may improve future matching studies. doctor-patient interaction preferences. Physicians should consider adopting patient-matched assessment and intervention strategies in addition to the recent unique concentrations on patient-centered, shared decision-making approaches.

title: Optimal patterns of care in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
abstract: There is an intimate relationship between the physiological processes of breathing and swallowing at all levels of neuromotor control and peripheral function in healthy adults. Little is known about potential alterations in these patterns in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), however the impact of impaired swallowing and aspiration on health outcomes in COPD patients may be significant. COPD is a common comorbidity in patients with head and neck cancer and neurological disorders seen by swallowing clinicians, and deserves consideration during swallowing management. This article summarizes reports of alterations in nutritional status, airway protective mechanisms, and swallow efficiency that potentially contribute to or exacerbate chronic and debilitating lung disease. Care guidelines are given for the modification of eating and swallowing behavior to optimize the health status of patients with COPD. The need for controlled clinical trials to validate the impact of these care guidelines on clinical outcomes is explained.

title: Optimization of antiretroviral therapy (ART) for maternal and child health (MCH): rationale and design of the MCH-ART study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Implementation of prevention of mother-to-child transmission of HIV faces significant challenges globally, particularly in the context of universal lifelong antiretroviral therapy (ART) for all HIV-infected pregnant women. METHODS: We describe the rationale and methods of the Maternal and Child Health-Antiretroviral Therapy (MCH-ART) study, an implementation science project examining strategies for providing HIV care and treatment to HIV-infected women who initiate ART during pregnancy. pregnancy and their HIV-exposed infants. RESULTS: MCH-ART is comprised of 3 interrelated study designs in the prenatal and postnatal periods. Phase 1 is a cross-sectional evaluation of consecutive HIV-infected pregnant women seeking antenatal care; Phase 2 is an observational cohort of all women from Phase 1 who are eligible to start ART following local guidelines; and phase 3 is a randomized trial of strategies to provide ART to breastfeeding women from phase 2 through the postpartum period. During each phase, a set of study measurement visits are conducted separately from ANC and ART services;" a maximum of 9 visits are made from the start of ANC to 12 months postpartum. In parallel, in-depth interviews are used to examine issues of ART adherence and retention qualitatively, and the costs and cost-effectiveness of care models are examined Separate substudies examine health outcomes in HIV-uninfected women and their HIV-naïve infants, and the role of the adherence club model for long-term adherence and retention DISCUSSION: Combining observational and experimental components, the MCH-ART study presents a novel approach to understanding and optimizing ART delivery for MCH.

title: Optimizing management of hypertension in clinical practice
abstract: There is a clear relationship between high blood pressure (BP) and various manifestations of cardiovascular disease. Despite the availability of numerous treatment regimens, hypertension remains inadequately controlled and only a small proportion of patients reach target BP levels. Many factors, both patient and physician related, contribute to this poor level of hypertension control. The main determinants include the implementation of inappropriate treatment regimens that do not allow patients to reach the goal and poor patient compliance. For example, it is widely recognized that most patients require two or more antihypertensive drugs to achieve target BP";" however, clinicians may be reluctant to employ such treatment strategies. The aim of this review is to explore the factors that contribute to poor rates of hypertension control and how to overcome them, including the rationale for selecting combination therapy, with particular reference to combinations of angiotensin II receptor blockers.

title: Optimizing Hypertension Management with Combination Therapy: Considerations for the Nurse Practitioner
abstract: Hypertension is a major contributor to the risk of cardiovascular disease and death, but success in achieving blood pressure (BP) control has been limited. Most patients will require 2 or more medications to control their blood pressure. Nurse practitioners play a vital role in treating patients with hypertension and can help overcome barriers to achieving BP goals. Measures to improve therapeutic adherence include educating the patient and simplifying the medication regimen. The use of single-pill combination therapy, which reduces pill burden, may help improve medication persistence and adherence. Rational combination therapy combines drugs with complementary mechanisms of action, such as a calcium channel blocker (CCB) and a renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) inhibitor";" it is often more effective than monotherapy and allows the use of lower doses of the individual components, generally resulting in better tolerability. Current guidelines support the first-line use of combination therapy in many patients. Starting treatment with an RAAS inhibitor-based combination can lower BP and cardiovascular risk and may be more effective for some patients than traditional combinations, such as a beta-blocker with a diuretic. Adverse events associated with any medication may compromise its therapeutic usefulness. Peripheral edema is a common and dose-dependent adverse event seen with dihydropyridine CCBs, which can cause significant patient distress, reduce adherence to therapy, and result in dose reduction or even reversal. interruption of therapy. In most cases, CCB-induced peripheral edema can be successfully controlled and discontinuation of CCB therapy is not necessary. Management strategies include non-pharmacological and pharmacological measures. Several clinical trials have shown a lower incidence of peripheral edema in patients receiving combination therapy with a CCB and an RAAS blocker compared to CCB monotherapy.

title: Oral contraceptives and smoking, current considerations: recommendations from a consensus panel.
abstract: In a closed meeting, members of the consensus panel reviewed the scientific panel's presentations and developed a set of recommendations. They described the clinical imperatives related to the identification and education of patients who smoke, the physician's role in smoking cessation, and the prescription of oral contraceptives for patients who smoke. They also outlined future research goals. Key suggestions include the following: All patients should be asked about their smoking status at each visit, and all smokers should be encouraged and helped to quit. The decision to prescribe an oral contraceptive requires a detailed personal and family history of thrombotic disease. Lipid profile measurement, along with exercise and dietary intervention, should be considered for smokers >35 years of age who use or request oral contraceptives. Patients older than 35 years who are heavy smokers (>15 cigarettes/day) should be denied the use of oral contraceptives. Preliminary data suggest that an oral contraceptive with the very low dose of 20 micrograms ethinyl estradiol may be safer for oral contraceptive users who smoke, including those over 35 years of age who smoke an occasional cigarette, but these laboratory findings require clinical corroboration." " PIP: This article summarizes the activities of a conference in Montreal, Canada, entitled "Oral Contraceptives and Smoking: Current Considerations." Consensus panel members evaluated the scientific panel's presentations and developed a set of recommendations. Clinical imperatives related to the identification and education of smoking patients, the inverted role of the question mark for physicians in smoking cessation, and the prescription of oral contraceptives for smoking patients were elaborated. The following recommendations were made: 1) encourage patients who smoke to quit"; 2) counsel patients about the benefits of oral contraceptives; in addition, counsel patients about the risks of concomitant smoking and the use of oral contraceptives"; and 3) prescribe 20 mcg of ethinyl estradiol for women who smoke. In light of the remaining unanswered questions, the panel outlined several future research goals.

title: Oral quinolones in hospitalized patients: an evaluation of a computerized decision support intervention.
abstract: Goal. To determine if a computerized decision support system could increase the proportion of orders for oral quinolone antibiotics for hospitalized patients. Design. Prospective analysis of interrupted time series. Around. Teaching hospital in the southeastern United States. Subjects. Inpatient orders for quinolones placed from February 1, 2001 to January 31, 2003. Intervention. On February 5, 2002, a web-based intervention was implemented as part of an existing order entry system at a university hospital. Based on an automated query of active medications and dietary requests, some users requesting intravenous quinolones were suggested to consider choosing an oral formulation. Main outcome measure. The proportion of inpatient quinolone orders placed for oral formulations before and after intervention deployment. Results. There were a total of 15,194 orders for quinolones during the study period, of which 8,962 (59%) were for oral forms. Orders for oral quinolones increased from 4,202 (56%) before the intervention to 4,760 (62%) after, with no change in total orders. In time series analysis, there was an overall increase of 5.6% (95% CI: 2.8–8.4%";" P < 0.001) in weekly orders of oral quinolones due to the intervention, with the greatest effect in non-intensive care medical units. Conclusions. A web-based intervention was able to increase orders for oral quinolones in hospitalized patients. This is one of the first studies to demonstrate a significant effect of a computerized intervention on the dosing route within an antibiotic class. This model could be applied to other antibiotics or other drug classes with good oral bioavailability.

title: Oral triptans (serotonin 5-HT1B/1D agonists) in the treatment of acute migraine: a meta-analysis of 53 trials.
abstract: Background Triptans, selective serotonin 5-HT1B/1D agonists, are highly effective drugs for acute migraine with a well-developed scientific basis. Seven different triptans will soon be clinically available, making evidence-based selection guidelines necessary. The triptan trials have similar designs, which facilitates meta-analysis; this will provide a basis for the use of triptans in clinical practice. Background Triptans, selective serotonin 5-HT1B/1D agonists, are highly effective drugs for acute migraine with a well-developed scientific basis. . Seven different triptans will soon be clinically available, making evidence-based selection guidelines necessary. The triptan trials have similar designs, which facilitates meta-analysis;" this will provide a basis for the use of triptans in clinical practice.

title: Orbital/periorbital plexiform neurofibromas in children with neurofibromatosis type 1: multidisciplinary recommendations for care
abstract: TOPIC: Children and adults with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), a common autosomal dominant condition, manifest a variety of ophthalmologic conditions. Plexiform neurofibromas (NPs) involving the eyelid, orbit, periorbital, and facial structures (orbital-periorbital plexiform neurofibroma [OPPN]) can cause significant visual loss in children. Equally important, OPPNs can cause a significant alteration in physical appearance secondary to proptosis, ptosis, and facial disfigurement, leading to social embarrassment and decreased self-esteem. CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE: Although NF1 is a relatively common disease requiring routine eye examinations, there are no formal recommendations for the clinical care of children with OPPN. Although medical and surgical interventions have been reported, there are no agreed criteria for when OPPNs require therapy and which treatment produces the best outcome. METHODS: Because management decisions are directed by a multidisciplinary team of specialists (oculofacial plastics, pediatric ophthalmology, neuro-ophthalmology, medical genetics, and neuro-oncology), the absence of a uniform outcome measure representing visual or cosmetic sequelae complicates treatment design. evidence. based studies and feasible clinical trials. RESULTS: In September 2013, a multidisciplinary task force, comprised of pediatric physicians from tertiary care centers with experience caring for children with OPPN, was convened to address the lack of clinical care guidelines for children with OPPN. CONCLUSIONS: This consensus statement provides recommendations for ophthalmologic management, describes treatment indications and upcoming biologic therapy, and discusses the challenges of conducting clinical trials in this complicated condition.

title: Organization of surveillance in GI practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Several reports documented inefficient use of available resources, as well as suboptimal compliance with surveillance recommendations. Although evidence suggests that organizational issues can influence the quality of care provided, surveillance protocols are generally based on unorganized approaches. METHODS: We conducted a literature search (publication date: 01/2000-06/2016) in PubMed and the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects, and Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials to obtain guidelines or consensus statements for practice surveys, patient information reports, or provider attitudes and behaviors, for intervention studies to improve guideline adherence. Related articles were also analyzed. Based on the clinical relevance and burden on endoscopy services, this review focused on surveillance for Barrett's oesophagus, IBD, and post-polypectomy surveillance for colonic adenomas. RESULTS: Existing guidelines generally acknowledge the structure and process requirements that influence the delivery of surveillance interventions, while less attention has been paid to transitions and interfaces in the process of care. Available evidence from practice surveys suggests the need to design organizational strategies aimed at enabling patients to attend and providers to provide timely and appropriate care. However, well-designed studies evaluating the effectiveness of specific interventions in this setting are lacking. Indirect evidence from screening settings would suggest that implementation of automated standardized retrieval systems, use of clinical records, removal of financial barriers, could improve appropriateness of use and adherence to recommendations. CONCLUSIONS: The lack of solid evidence on the usefulness and methodology of surveillance may help explain the observed variability in provider and patient attitudes and adherence to recommended surveillance.

title: Organizational theory for the dissemination and implementation of research
abstract: Background Even under optimal internal organizational conditions, implementation can be undermined by changes in organizations' external environments, such as fluctuations in funding, adjustments in hiring practices, new technology, new legislation, changes in guidance and practice recommendations clinical or other environmental changes. . Internal organizational conditions are increasingly reflected in implementation frameworks, but nuanced explanations of how organizations' external environments influence implementation success are lacking in implementation research. Organizational theories offer implementation researchers a wealth of extant, highly relevant, and as yet largely untapped explanations of the complex interplay between organizations and their environment. In this article, we demonstrate the usefulness of organizational theories for implementation research. Discussion We applied four well-known organizational theories (institutional theory, transaction cost economics, contingency theories, and resource dependency theory) to published descriptions of efforts to implement SafeCare, an evidence-based practice to prevent abuse and neglect. childish. Transaction cost economics theory explained how the frequent and uncertain processes for contracting SafeCare may have created inefficiencies and thus compromised implementation among private child welfare organizations. Institutional theory explained how child welfare systems may have been motivated to implement SafeCare because doing so aligned with the expectations of key stakeholders within the professional communities of child welfare systems. Contingency theories explained how efforts such as collaborative interagency teams promoted SafeCare implementation by facilitating adaptation to the internal and external contexts of child welfare agencies. Resource Dependency Theory (RDT) explained how interagency relationships, supported by contracts, memorandums of understanding, and negotiations, facilitated SafeCare implementation by balancing autonomy and dependency on funding agencies and SafeCare developers. . Summary In addition to the retrospective application of organizational theories demonstrated above, we advocate the proactive use of organizational theories to design implementation research. For example, implementation strategies should be selected to minimize transaction costs, promote and maintain consistency between the organizations' dynamic internal and external contexts over time, while addressing the organizations' financial and financial needs. preserve their autonomy. We describe the implications of applying organizational theory in implementation research for implementation strategies, evaluation of implementation efforts, measurement, research design, theory, and practice. We also offer guidance to implementation researchers in applying organizational theory.

title: Education for the prevention of osteoporosis: behavioral theories and calcium intake
abstract: Osteoporosis is a global health problem. The prevention of osteoporosis and subsequent fractures has become a goal of many health professionals, especially dietetic professionals. However, few prevention models have proven effective. The goal of this project was to determine whether a theory-based osteoporosis prevention education program would have a significant impact on calcium intake. This project used a convenience sample of 42 women who participated in an 8-week educational intervention, similar to a community class. The program included practical activities to increase self-efficacy and was based on the Health Belief Model and Theory of Reasoned Action (TRA). The main outcome measures were calcium intake and the TRA and Health Belief Model constructs. Significant changes in health belief model and TRA constructs after intervention included higher perceived susceptibility to osteoporosis (p < 0.001), perceived benefits of increasing calcium intake (p < 0.001), and higher self-efficacy related to calcium intake (p < 0.001). /=.003). Statistically significant regression equations were found for all calcium-related preintervention intentions. Post-intervention calcium intake increased significantly to 821+/-372 mg/day (p < 0.0001). The results of this project can be used as guidelines for dieticians to develop osteoporosis prevention programs for their clientele.

title: Outcomes and costs of primary care surveillance and intervention for overweight or obese children: the LEAP 2 randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine whether screening for childhood obesity by surveillance followed by structured secondary prevention in primary care improved outcomes in overweight or mildly obese children. DESIGN Randomized controlled trial nested within a baseline cross-sectional survey of body mass index (BMI). Randomisation and outcome measurement, but not participants, were blinded to group assignment. SETTING 45 family practices (66 general practitioners) in Melbourne, Australia. PARTICIPANTS 3,958 children who visited their general practitioner between May 2005 and July 2006 were surveyed for their BMI. Of these, 258 children aged 5 years 0 months to 10 years who were overweight or obese according to the International Obesity Taskforce criteria were randomized to intervention (n=139) or control (n=119) groups. Children who were severely obese (UK BMI z-score > or = 3.0) were excluded. INTERVENTION Four standard consultations over 12 weeks targeting change in nutrition, physical activity, and sedentary behavior, supported by specifically designed family materials. Main outcome measures The primary measure was BMI at 6 and 12 months after randomisation. Secondary measures were 7-day accelerometry mean activity count/min, 4-day food frequency abbreviated diary nutrition score, and infant health-related quality of life. Differences were adjusted for socioeconomic status, age, sex, and baseline BMI. RESULTS Of 781 eligible children, 258 (33%) entered the trial; attrition was 3.1% at 6 months and 6.2% at 12 months. The adjusted mean differences (intervention - control) at 6 and 12 months were, for BMI, -0.12 (95% CI -0.40 to 0.15, P=0.4) and -0.11 (-0.45 to 0.22, P=0.5); for physical activity in counts/min, 24 (-4 to 52, P=0.09) and 11 (-26 to 49, P=0.6);" and for nutrition score, 0.2 ( -0.03 to 0.4, P=0.1) and 0.1 (-0.1 to 0.4, P=0.2). There was no evidence of harm to the child. The costs to the health were significantly higher in the intervention arm.CONCLUSIONSScreening in primary care followed by brief counseling did not improve BMI, physical activity, or nutrition in overweight or mildly obese children aged 5 to 10 years, and would be very costly if implemented universally.These findings are at odds with national policies in countries such as the US, UK, and Australia.ISRCTN TEST REGISTRATION 52511065 (www.isrctn.org).

title: Outcomes of population-based language promotion for young slow-talkers at ages 2 and 3 years: a Let's Learn Language cluster-randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the benefits of a low-intensity parent-toddler language promotion program delivered to young children identified as slow to speak at screening in universal services. DESIGN Cluster randomized trial nested in a population-based survey. SETTING Three local government areas in Melbourne, Australia. PARTICIPANTS Parents who attended controls of healthy 12-month-olds over a six-month period completed a baseline questionnaire. At 18 months, children at or below the 20th percentile on an expressive vocabulary checklist entered the trial. INTERVENTION Maternal and child health centers (groups) were randomized to either intervention (modified 'You make a difference' program for six weekly sessions) or control ('usual care') arms. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was expressive language (Preschool Language Scale-4) at ages 2 and 3; secondary outcomes were receptive language at 2 and 3 years, Vocabulary Checklist raw score at 2 and 3 years, Expressive Vocabulary Test at 3 years, and Child Behavior Checklist/1.5-5 raw score at 2 years. and 3 years RESULTS 1,217 parents completed the baseline survey, 1,138 (93.5%) completed the 18-month checklist, when 301 (26.4%) children had vocabulary scores at or below the 20th percentile and were randomized (158 intervention, 143 control). 115 (73%) intervention parents attended at least one session (mean 4.5 sessions), with most reporting high satisfaction with the program. Intermediate outcomes at 2 years of age were similar in Similarly, at age 3 years, the adjusted mean differences (intervention-control) were -2.4 (95% confidence interval -6.2 to 1.4, P = 0.21) for expressive language; -0.3 (-4.2 to 3.7, P = 0.90) for receptive language; 4.1 (-2.3 to 10.6; P=0.21) for a list control list; -0.5 (-4.4 to 3.4, P=0.80) for the expressive vocabulary test; -0.1 (-1.6 to 1.4, P=0.86) for externalizing behavior problems; and -0.1 (-1.3 to 1.2;" P = 0.92) for internalizing behavior problems. CONCLUSION This community-based program for slow-talking young children was feasible and acceptable, but little evidence was found that it improved language or behaviour, either immediately or at age 3 years TRIAL REGISTRATION Current controlled trials ISRCTN20953675.

title: Overdiagnosis and overtreatment as a quality problem: insights from healthcare improvement research
Overweight and obesity in pregnancy: the evidence-practice gap in staff knowledge, attitudes, and practices
abstract: BACKGROUND: State (Queensland) clinical guidelines reflecting current best practice are recently available for the management of pregnancy-related obesity. However, dissemination of the guidelines alone does not change practice. OBJECTIVE: To systematically assess the gap between evidence and practice in the multidisciplinary management of overweight and obesity in pregnancy to inform an intervention that facilitates the translation of obesity guidelines into practice in a tertiary maternity service. MATERIALS AND METHODS: An online survey, available over a three-week period (May-June 2011), was distributed to obstetrics, midwifery, and allied health personnel. Outcomes of interest included a 15-point guideline adherence score, knowledge of guideline content, advice provided, knowledge of obesity- and pregnancy-related complications, prior training, and referral patterns. RESULTS: Eighty-four staff members completed the surveys (57% response rate). A general disagreement with the guideline was observed. The majority (88.1%) referred to overweight/obesity (p/ob) as an important/very important general obstetric problem, most correctly identified the associated complications. However, only 32.1% were aware of the existing guidelines, and only half correctly identified the BMI categories for ow/ob. Compliance with referral recommendations ranged";" 20% of staff felt that referral was 'not their job'. CONCLUSIONS: Staff are aware of the negative outcomes associated with maternal discharge/obstetrics, although few fully comply with referral guidelines or provide advice according to recommendations. These findings will be sorted through the implementation of scientific methodological frameworks, and effective behavior change interventions will be built to facilitate the translation of this important guideline into practice.

title: Oxygen therapy in hospitalized patients: the impact of local guidelines
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To study the influence of local guidelines on the behavior of medical and nursing staff to optimize the use of oxygen in hospitalized patients. METHODS: The study was conducted in a district university hospital. The guidelines produced suggested indications, monitoring, use of arterial blood gases (ABG), and advice on when to stop oxygen therapy. The guidelines were implemented both verbally and in writing to all medical and nursing staff before and after an audit studying oxygen use by patients in medical and surgical wards. RESULTS: Ninety patients were included in the pre-intervention audit and 59 in the post-intervention study. Oxygen prescription did not change with the 30% (27/90) vs. 32% (19/59). Nurses administered oxygen better 95% (18/19) vs 70% (19/27) (P = 0.043) and monitored more frequently using oximetry 91% (54/59) vs 69% (62/90) (P = 0.001) after the guidelines. Patients with airway disease had their ABG checked more frequently 87% (14/16) vs. 65% (15/23) on admission and after initiation of oxygen inhalation 68% (11/16) vs. 34% (8/23). CONCLUSION: Verbal and written guidelines did not influence oxygen prescription, but improved the practice of close follow-up of patients with airway disease. The nurses improved their performance both in the administration of oxygen according to the prescribed dose and in the follow-up with oximetry.

title: Postoperative pain management practices of pediatric nurses in non-critical care hospital settings: a narrative review
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To investigate the postoperative pain management practices of pediatric nurses with the goal of identifying factors associated with insufficiently managed pediatric postoperative pain. DESIGN: Search and systematic review. DATA SOURCES: PsychInfo, CINAHL, PubMed, EMBASE, and handsearching. METHODS OF REVIEW: We included peer-reviewed English-language quantitative, qualitative, or mixed methods research articles published between 1990 and 2012 that explored pediatric postoperative pain management practices of registered nurses. Articles with a primary focus on pain management practices of nurses in neonatal or pediatric intensive care units, recovery room, and/or focused on children with cognitive impairment were excluded. Search terms used were: "postoperative pain"; nurses*; paediatrics; pediatrics; children; pain assessment; non-pharmacist*; analgesic*. Titles and abstracts were used for initial selection. Two investigators extracted data and assessed rigor of each RESULTS: Of the initial 248 citations, 27 studies were included Most studies were descriptive and examined relationships between personal factors and nurses' pain management practices Observational data from four articles added information provided in self-report studies Two articles used vignette experimental designs Data were categorized into four themes: pain assessment, pharmacological practices, non-pharmacological practices, and factors affecting practices Despite improvements in the administration of analgesics in the last 20 years, the practices continue to be suboptimal. of children appears to influence nurses' assessment of pain more than validated measures. A significant proportion of children had no pain scores recorded in the first 24 hours postoperatively. Children receive more analgesia when it is requested 24 hours a day compared to when it is required. However, the prescription of analgesia 24 hours a day did not guarantee administration. Nurses reported using several non-pharmacological strategies routinely, but some are not evidence-based. CONCLUSIONS: The results of this review indicate that nurses' assessment and management of pain in children is not consistent with published guidelines. Results from studies exploring nurse-child related factors are inconclusive. Research should examine the impact of organizational factors on nurses' pain care practices. Intervention studies are needed to determine the most effective strategies to support and improve nurses' care of children's pain.

title: Pain descriptors for critically ill patients unable to self-report
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To examine the descriptors used by nurses in two Canadian intensive care units to document the presence of pain in critically ill patients who are unable to self-report. BACKGROUND: Systematic documentation of pain assessment is essential for communication and continuity of pain management, allowing for better pain control, maximizing recovery, and reducing physical and psychological sequelae. METHOD: Retrospective, mixed method, with observational design in two level III intensive care units of a quaternary academic center in Toronto, Canada. During 2008-2009, data were abstracted through chart review guided by a reference compendium of potential behavioral descriptors compiled from existing behavioral pain assessment tools. RESULTS: A total of 679 narrative descriptions were extracted. Behavioral (232, 34%), physiological (93, 14%), and descriptors indicating that the patient was pain-free (117, 17%) were used to describe the presence or absence of pain. Narratives also described analgesia administered without pain assessment descriptors (117, 17%) and assessment and administration of analgesics before a known painful procedure (30, 4%). Emerging themes included life-threatening treatment interference, decision-making uncertainty, and a continuum of wakefulness. CONCLUSION: Inconsistent or ambiguous documentation was problematic in this sample. This may reflect confusing behaviors and concomitant security priorities. Developing a lexicon of pain assessment descriptors for critically ill patients who cannot self-report for use in combination with valid and reliable measures may improve documentation that facilitates appropriate analgesic management. Unit protocols or guidelines that prioritize an analgesia test before the administration of sedatives can reduce uncertainty in decision making when patients exhibit ambiguous behaviors such as agitation or restlessness.

title: Ankle pain
Parallel Pathways to Improve Heart Failure Outcomes: The Evidence Matters
abstract: Gaps and disparities in the delivery of HF education by nurses and performance in achieving self-care behaviors by patients with advanced HF may be factors in clinical decompensation and unplanned health care consumption . Is nurse-led education delivered effectively before hospital discharge? Nursing leaders need to understand the strength of the nurses' knowledge base around self-care principles and significant barriers to best practice. Nurses may not feel comfortable teaching patients about dry weight, meal planning, heart failure medications, or progressive activity and exercise steps. Additionally, clinical nurses may not have the time to provide detailed patient education prior to discharge. Equally important, research is needed to understand the factors that improve patients' adherence to heart failure self-management behaviors, because adherence to evidence-based national heart failure guideline recommendations improves clinical outcomes. Thus, nurses and patients are on parallel paths related to laying the groundwork for better adherence to self-management in advanced heart failure. Through research, we found that nurses were not adequately prepared as heart failure educators and that patients did not believe they could control heart failure. In 2 educational intervention studies that aimed to help patients understand that they could control fluid management and follow a strict daily fluid limit, patients had better clinical outcomes. Therefore, misperceptions about heart failure can be overcome with interventions that go beyond communicating "what" self-care behaviors are recommended. The research results reflect that evidence matters! Systems and processes are needed to support nurses' awareness, comfort, and frequency of providing predischarge self-management education, to increase the accuracy of patients' beliefs about managing heart failure, and to improve patient care. patients' willingness to adhere to guideline-recommended heart failure guidelines. - Care behaviors. This article describes the development of the parallel paths of nursing and patient research programs and explores the translation of findings into practice and the development of translational clinical research.

title: Parental presence during invasive procedures and resuscitation: evaluation of a change in clinical practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: The presence of parents during invasive procedures and/or resuscitation is a relatively underdeveloped and controversial practice. Much of the concern stems from apprehension in the medical community. OBJECTIVES: To assess whether the implementation of formal practice guidelines and corresponding interprofessional education would improve physicians' sense of preparedness and comfort in providing parents with options during their child's procedures. METHODS: Multiphase pre-post survey of (1) physician perceptions and (2) practice from the perspective of physicians and parents undergoing the same procedure. Data were collected over 4 years from a cardiovascular and critical care program at a US children's hospital. and 274 parents participated in the practice surveys. After the intervention, clinicians reported that parents were present during the more invasive procedures and reported higher levels of comfort with the practice of providing parents with options during resuscitation events. Comfort levels were higher in clinicians who had practiced skills in a simulated learning environment. During both phases, few clinicians reported that the presence of parents affected their technical performance (4%), therapeutic decision-making (5%), or ability to teach (9%). During the later phase, physicians reported more active parental behaviors during the procedures. Parents who reported receiving information to help them prepare for their child's procedures reported higher levels of procedural understanding and emotional support. CONCLUSIONS: The implementation of practice guidelines and interprofessional education had a positive impact on physicians' perceptions and practices by providing parents with options and support during invasive procedures and/or resuscitation of their children.

title: Parental intervention in Sure Start services for children at risk of developing conduct disorder: a pragmatic randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the effectiveness of a parenting program as a preventive intervention with parents of preschool children considered at risk of developing a behavioral disorder. DESIGN Pragmatic randomized controlled trial using a block design with allocation by area. SETTING Eleven Sure Start areas in North and Mid Wales. PARTICIPANTS 153 parents from socially disadvantaged areas, with children aged 36 to 59 months at risk for conduct disorder defined by scores above the clinical cutoff on the Eyberg Child Behavior Inventory. Participants were randomized in a 2:1 ratio, 104 to the intervention and 49 to remain on the waiting list (control). Twenty (13%) were lost to follow up six months later, 18 from the intervention group. INTERVENTION The Webster-Stratton Incredible Years core parenting program, a 12-week group intervention. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Children's problem behavior and parenting skills assessed by parent self-reports and by direct observation at home. Parental competence, parental self-reported stress and depression. Standardized and well-validated instruments were used at all times. RESULTS At follow-up, most measures of parenting and child behavior problems showed significant improvement in the intervention group. Intention-to-treat analysis for the primary outcome measure, the Eyberg Child Behavior Inventory, showed a mean between-group difference of 4.4 points (95% confidence interval 2.0 to 6.9, P <0.001) on the problem scale with an effect size of 0.63, and a mean difference of 25.1 (14.9 to 35.2, P<0.001) on the intensity scale with an effect size of 0.89. CONCLUSION This community-based study showed the effectiveness of an evidence-based parenting intervention delivered with fidelity by regular Sure Start staff. It has influenced policy within Wales and provides lessons for England where, to date, Sure Start programs have not been effective. TEST RECORD ISRCTN46984318.

title: Parenting program for parents of children at risk of developing a behavioral disorder: cost-effectiveness analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVE To investigate the profitability of a program for parents. DESIGN An incremental cost-effectiveness analysis coupled with a pragmatic randomized controlled trial of the effectiveness of a group parenting program delivered through Sure Start in the community. SETTING Sure Start areas in North and Mid Wales. PARTICIPANTS Parents of 116 children aged 36 to 59 months (87% of the clinical sample) at risk of developing behavioral disorders defined by score above the clinical cutoff on the Eyberg Child Behavior Inventory). The children were identified by health visitors and recruited by the research team. INTERVENTION Webster-Stratton Incredible Years Basic Parenting Program or a six-month waiting list check. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE Incremental cost per unit of improvement in intensity score of the Eyberg Child Behavior Inventory. RESULTS The point estimate of incremental cost-effectiveness with snatch was £73 (€109, $142) per one point improvement in intensity score (95% confidence interval £42 to £140) . It would cost 5,486 (€8,190, $10,666) to bring the child with the highest intensity score below the clinical cut-off point and 1,344 (€2,006, $2,618) to bring the average child in the intervention group to the non-clinical limits on the score. intensity (below 127). For a maximum ratio of £100 (€149, $194) per point increase in intensity score, there is an 83.9% chance that the intervention will be cost-effective. The average cost per child attending the parent group was £1,934 (€2,887, $3,760) for eight children and £1,289 (€1,924, $2,506) for 12 children, including start-up costs and training materials. the group leaders. When we categorized the sample into relatively mild, moderate, and severe behavioral groups based on intensity scores at baseline, the intervention seemed most cost-effective in those at highest risk of developing conduct disorder. CONCLUSION This parenting program improves infant behavior as measured by the Eyberg Infant Behavior Inventory Intensity Score at relatively low cost and was cost-effective compared to the waiting list control. This rearing program involves modest costs and demonstrates a strong clinical effect, suggesting that it would represent good value for money for public spending.

title: Parkinson's disease
Participant- and study-related characteristics predicting treatment completion and study retention in an adolescent smoking cessation trial.
abstract: Purpose: To determine what factors predict completion and retention of smoking cessation treatment among adolescents. Methods: A multicenter, randomized, controlled trial compared the efficacy of motivational interviewing with brief structured advice to quit smoking and reduce tobacco use in adolescents (n = 355) aged 14 to 18 years (55% female, 45% Black, 12% Hispanic). Treatment spanned 12 weeks, with follow-up evaluations at 24 weeks. Completion of treatment was defined as the completion of all five counseling sessions. Study retention was defined as completing the 24-week evaluation. Participant and study variables served as predictors of treatment completion and retention. Results: Overall, 79% of participants completed all five counseling sessions and the same percentage completed the 24-week evaluation. Black race, stage prior to reduction contemplation, and shorter time period between initial assessment and first counseling session were significantly associated with treatment completion. For every 7.5 days of delay in starting treatment after the initial visit, there was a 50% decrease in the odds of completing all five treatment sessions. Retention at 24 weeks was predicted by black race, younger age, higher maternal education, expectations of graduating from college, and structured brief counseling intervention. Conclusions: High rates of treatment completion and study retention can be achieved in a multi-session behavioral intervention for smoking cessation in adolescents. The findings suggest that treatment should start soon after the intake session to maximize treatment completion. Improved efforts to retain older adolescents and youth with lower academic goals and lower family income will be important in future studies. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2017 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: Participation in biomedical research: the consent process as seen by children, adolescents, young adults, and physicians
abstract: We examine the ability of children, adolescents, and young adults to agree and consent to participate in biomedical research, and what clinician-researchers believe is important for patients in these age groups to know about such participation. The sample included 44 male and female subjects, aged between 7 and 20 years, who were hospitalized for treatment of pediatric cancer or obesity. Participants completed a structured interview that assessed knowledge of research participation using the elements outlined in the federal guidelines for informed consent. Study subjects were more knowledgeable about those elements of consent that assessed specific information (eg, freedom to ask questions, time elements involved, and benefits of participation). They were less knowledgeable about elements of informed consent that evaluated abstract information (eg, scientific versus therapeutic purpose of the study and alternative treatments). Chronological age was not related to knowledge of the elements of informed consent. The strategies that the study subjects used to reason about participating in the research seemed to parallel their reasoning about other physical phenomena.

title: Participation of children in clinical trials: UK, European and international legal perspectives on consent
abstract: The Declaration of Helsinki was, until recently, the main international code on the conduct of clinical trials in humans. The Council of Europe Convention on Human Rights and Biomedicine (1997) and the ICH Good Clinical Practice guidelines (1996) represent a significant step towards further harmonization of standards in conducting medical experiments on human beings. But despite emerging areas of consensus, significant areas of lack of clarity and divergence remain. Clinicians involved in pediatric research in the UK are concerned about a lack of certainty in the law, particularly about the application of consent rules to emergency research. This paper examines UK, European and international standards on children's participation in medical research and compares the circumstances in which consent rules can be waived under each regulatory regime.

title: Participatory Action Research in Antimicrobial Stewardship: A Novel Approach to Improve Antimicrobial Prescription in Hospitals and Long-Term Care Facilities
abstract: It is a challenge to change the antimicrobial prescribing behavior of physicians. Although antimicrobial prescribing is determined by contextual (eg, lack of guidelines), cultural (eg, peer practice), and behavioral (eg, perceived autonomy in decision making), most antimicrobial stewardship programs do not take these factors into account in their approach. This may lead to suboptimal efficacy of the intervention. We present a new approach in antimicrobial stewardship program development that addresses the relevant determinants of antimicrobial prescription: participatory action research (PAR). PAR is a collaborative process that aims to bring about change in social situations by producing practical knowledge that is useful in local practice. It requires substantial engagement of relevant stakeholders to address the determinants of the studied behavior and facilitate empowerment. PAR is suitable for complex problems in multidisciplinary settings as it is tailored to local needs, providing a tailored approach to improve local practice. We describe how PAR can be applied to antimicrobial stewardship and describe the PAR design of two ongoing multicenter antimicrobial stewardship projects, in the acute care setting and the long-term care setting, respectively.

title: Passive Smoking Exposure and COPD Risk Among Adults in China: Guangzhou Biobank Cohort Study
abstract: Background Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is one of the main causes of mortality in China, where the population is also exposed to high levels of passive smoking, although there is little information on the effects of such exposure on COPD. We examined the relationship between passive smoking and COPD and respiratory symptoms in an adult Chinese population.";" Background Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is one of the main causes of mortality in China, where the population is also exposed to high levels of passive smoking, although there is little information on the effects of such exposure on COPD. We examined the relationship between passive smoking and COPD and respiratory symptoms in an adult Chinese population.

title: Pathology of poverty: the need for quality improvement efforts to address the social determinants of health
Patient adherence to family physician recommendations for breast cancer screening: a landmark cohort study.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Breast cancer is the most prevalent malignancy among women in Israel, and routine screening for early detection is recommended. In 1997, a health management organization primary care center in rural Israel established a 1-year program in which family doctors were encouraged to remind their patients to undergo cancer screening from mom This study assesses the impact of physician intervention on patient compliance. METHODS: Family physicians from two practices were asked to discuss the importance of early breast cancer detection with all eligible patients who visited the clinic for any reason and to help them schedule a screening appointment. The files of the patients who received the recommendation were sealed accordingly. At the end of the program, the doctors' records were audited and the potential candidates for breast cancer screening were divided into two groups: those who had received the intervention (n = 251) and those who had not (n = 187). ; " The results were also compared with those of a third group of patients who had attended an examination on their own initiative (n = 100) before the study (i.e., did not require intervention). A random sample of half of the patients also completed an ad hoc questionnaire covering sociodemographic variables and the impact of the physicians' intervention on their behavior.RESULTS:Patients in the intervention group showed a significantly greater change in behavior regarding breast cancer screening than controls (32% versus 13%, P = 0.001).This change was particularly apparent in the group of women aged 50 to 74 years who were recommended to undergo mammography (according to the guidelines).CONCLUSION: Although this is a study In just two practices, the results suggest that primary care physicians can significantly alter their patients' behavior regarding screening. regular loves. The use of a special reminder can also help the individual clinician to ensure that each patient has received the proper instructions.

title: Patient Advocacy and Advance Care Planning in the Acute Hospital Setting
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The objective of this study was to explain the role of patient advocacy in the advance care planning (ACP-ing) process. Nurses rate the prolongation of the dying process with inappropriate measures as their most troubling ethical issue and the protection of patients' rights as a major concern (Johnston et al 2002). Paradoxically, ethical codes assume that nurses have the autonomy to advocate for patients' health care choices. Advance directives (ADs) designed to improve end-of-life care are poorly accepted, and acute care hospitals are often unprepared for the few that receive them. The Respect for Patient Choices Program (RPCP) enhances AD utilization by providing a supportive framework for ACP-ing and primarily equipping nurses as RPC consultants. Helping patients in this process requires attributes consistent with patient advocacy stemming from the most basic principle of nursing, caring for others. DESIGN: Likert scale survey administered before and six months after the intervention to pilot and control groups, with matching focus groups. SETTING: Selected wards in a public acute care hospital in South Australia. SUBJECTS: Nurses from the pilot palliative, respiratory, renal and colorectal care wards and from the haemo-oncology, coronary care, cardiology and neurology/geriatric control wards. INTERVENTION: The RPCP during the 2004-2005 South Australian pilot of the (RPCP). MAIN RESULTS: The organizational support of ACP-ing gave nurses the autonomy to be patient advocates regarding end-of-life care, reconciling clinical practice with its code of ethics and alleviating distress over prolonging life. inappropriate death process. RESULTS: Statistically significant survey results in the post-intervention group showed that nurses experienced: encouragement to ensure patients were able to make informed decisions about their end-of-life treatment (84%); the ability to fulfill these wishes in practice (73%) ; and job satisfaction in providing adequate end-of-life care (67%);" compared to about half (42-55%) of respondents in the pre-intervention and control groups. Focus group participants shared that they used to be difficult to advocate for patients, but now they could act legitimately and felt ethically comfortable regarding end-of-life care.CONCLUSION: Findings suggested that patient advocacy, fostered by the supportive CPR environment, effects the ACP-ing process It is recommended that the RPCP be recognized and developed as an integral part of promoting end-of-life quality assurance and associated job satisfaction.

title: Patient and physician reminders to promote colorectal cancer screening: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Screening reduces colorectal cancer mortality, but effective screening tests remain underused. Systematic reminders for patients and doctors could increase detection rates. Methods We conducted a randomized controlled trial of patient and physician reminders at 11 ambulatory health care centers. Participants included 21,860 patients aged 50 to 80 years who had missed colorectal cancer screening and 110 primary care physicians. Patients were randomly assigned to receive mailings containing an educational brochure, a fecal occult blood test kit, and instructions for direct scheduling of a flexible sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy. Physicians were randomly assigned to receive electronic reminders during office visits for patients due for screening. The primary outcome was receiving fecal occult blood tests, flexible sigmoidoscopy, or colonoscopy for 15 months, and the secondary outcome was detection of colorectal adenomas. Results Detection rates were higher for patients who received mailings compared to those who did not (44.0% vs. 38.1%"; P < 0.001). The effect increased with age: +3.7% for ages 50 to 59 years, +7.3% for ages 60 to 69 years, and +10.1% for ages 70 to 80 years (P = 0.01 for trend). between patients of physicians who received electronic reminders and the control group (41.9% vs. 40.2%; P = .001).47 However, electronic reminders tended to increase detection rates among patients with 3 or more primary care visits (59.5% vs. 52.7%; P = .07) Adenoma detection tended to increase with mailings to patients (5.7% vs. 5.2%, p = 0.10) and medical reminders (6.0% vs. 4.9%, p = 0.09).Conclusions Reminders sent by mail to patients are an effective tool to promote detection cancer r colorectal, and electronic reminders to physicians may increase screening among adults who have more frequent primary care visits.

title: Patient education about cough: effect on consultation behavior of general medicine patients
abstract: The aim of this general practice study was to examine how the consultation behavior of cough patients was affected when the tasks and responsibilities of patients, nurses, and general practitioners were reorganized. In four 'average' one-person general practices, the effects on patient consultation behavior of a rational cough practice policy and the provision of systematic cough patient education were compared with patient behavior in four general practices. paired controls. Behavioral changes were measured in 548 patients who consulted for cough at least twice, in two successive autumn-winter periods. Significantly more patients in the experimental practice changed their behavior to follow the practice guidelines than patients in the control practices (56% versus 30%, P less than 0.001). The proportion of patients who continued to consult in the approved manner was higher among patients who received the intervention (66% versus 29%, P less than 0.001). This was equally true for patients who had experienced fewer than four cough episodes or more than four episodes. The more often the patients received the education, the more effective it was. All patients who consulted their GP for cough during the first autumn-winter period completed a cough diary during the second period. From this, it appeared that the intervention did not cause patients to delay consultation when they had a cough lasting more than three weeks or one with 'severe' symptoms. It would seem that a rational practice policy and the provision of patient education can encourage patients to modify their consulting behaviour. This could result in a reduction in health care costs.

title: Patient education for colon cancer screening: a randomized trial of a video mailed before a physical examination
abstract: BACKGROUND: Colorectal cancer screening is underutilized and primary care physicians are challenged to provide patient education within the constraints of busy practices. OBJECTIVE: To test the effect of an educational video, mailed to patients' homes before a physical examination, on the performance of colorectal cancer screening, particularly sigmoidoscopy. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. SETTING: 5 primary care practices in central Massachusetts. PARTICIPANTS: 938 patients aged 50 to 74 years who were scheduled for an upcoming physical examination, had no personal history of colorectal cancer, and were eligible for lower endoscopy screening according to current guidelines. INTERVENTION: Participants were randomly assigned to receive usual care (n = 488) or a video about colorectal cancer, the importance of early detection, and screening options (n = 450). MEASUREMENTS: Baseline and 6-month follow-up telephone assessments were performed. A dependent variable classified screening from baseline as 1) sigmoidoscopy with or without other tests, 2) another test or combination of tests, or 3) no test. RESULTS: Overall detection rates were the same in the intervention and control groups (55%). In the regression model, intervention participants were nonsignificantly more likely to complete sigmoidoscopy alone or in combination with another test (odds ratio, 1.22 [95% CI, 0.88 to 1.70]) . Intervention dose (watch at least half of the video) was significantly associated with receiving a sigmoidoscopy with or without another test (odds ratio, 2.81 [CI, 1.85 to 4.26]). Recruitment records showed that at least 23% of people presenting for regular health assessments were currently undergoing a lower endoscopy procedure and were therefore ineligible. LIMITATIONS: The primary care sample studied consisted primarily of white, middle-class people who had high screening rates at baseline. The results may not be generalizable to other populations. The trial was conducted during a period of increased health insurance coverage for lower endoscopy procedures and public media attention to colon cancer screening. CONCLUSIONS: A mailed video had no effect on the overall colorectal cancer screening rate and only modestly improved sigmoidoscopy screening rates among patients in primary care practices.

title: Patient engagement programs for the recognition and initial treatment of depression in primary care
abstract: Importance Encouraging primary care patients to address depression symptoms and care with clinicians might improve outcomes, but may also result in unnecessary treatment. Objective To determine whether a depression engagement video (DEV) or personalized interactive multimedia computer program (IMCP) improves initial depression care compared with a control without increasing unnecessary prescribing of antidepressants. Design, Setting, and Participants Randomized clinical trial comparing SVD, PPMI, and control among 925 adult patients treated by 135 primary care physicians (603 patients with depression and 322 patients without depression, defined by the C9 [PHQ-9] score of the Patient Health) conducted from June 2010 through March 2012 at 7 primary care clinical sites in California. DEV interventions targeting gender and income, an IMCP tailored to individual patient characteristics, and a sleep hygiene video (control). Main outcomes and measures Among depressed patients, superiority assessment of the composite measure of patient-reported antidepressant drug recommendation, mental health referral, or both (primary outcome)"; depression at 12-week follow-up, as measured by the PHQ -8 (secondary outcome).Among nondepressed patients, noninferiority assessment of physician- and patient-reported antidepressant drug recommendation (primary outcomes) with a noninferiority margin of 3.5%. adjusted for groups.Results Of the 925 eligible patients, 867 were included in the analysis (depressed, 559; nondepressed, 308).Among depressed patients, the rates of achieving the primary outcome were 17.5% for SVD, 26% for PPMI and 16.3% for control (DEV vs. control, 1.1 [95% CI, ?6.7 to 8.9], P = .79; PPMI vs. control, 9.9 [95% CI, 1.6 to 18.2], p = 0.02).There was no effect on score PHQ-8 measurement of depression at 12-week follow-up: DEV vs. control, 0.2 (95% CI, 1.2 to 0.8), PPMI vs. control, 0.9 (95% CI, ?0.1 to 1.9). Among nondepressed patients, physician-reported antidepressant prescription in the DEV and PPMI groups was noninferior to control (mean percentage point difference [PPD]: DEV vs control, 2.2 [90% CI, 8, 0 to 3.49], P = ? 0.0499 for noninferiority, PPMI vs control, 3.3 [90% CI, 9.1 to 2.4], P = 0.02 for noninferiority); patient-reported antidepressant recommendation did not achieve noninferiority (mean PPD: SED vs. control, ≥ 0.9 [90% CI, ≥ 4.9 to 6.7], P = ≥ 0.23 for noninferiority ;" PPMI vs control, ≥ 0.3 [90% CI], ?5.1 to 5.7], P?=?.16 for non-inferiority). Conclusions and relevance A personalized PPMI increased physicians' recommendations for antidepressant medications , a mental health referral, or both among depressed patients, but had no effect on mental health at 12 The possibility that IMCP and DEV increased patient-reported medical recommendations for a drug could not be excluded antidepressant among nondepressed patients.

title: Patients' perceptions of risky drinking: knowledge of low-risk daily and weekly guidelines and standard drink sizes
abstract: BACKGROUND: Effective intervention for hazardous drinking requires clinicians and patients to be aware of low-risk daily and weekly guidelines and what constitutes a 'standard drink'. The authors hypothesized that most patients lack this knowledge and that education is required. METHODS: After primary care visits, patients completed anonymous exit questionnaires that included the 3 questions of the Alcohol Use Disorder Identification Consumption Test (AUDIT-C): "How many drinks (containing alcohol) can you take safely in one day?" and questions about the size, in ounces, of a standard drink of wine, beer, and liquor. Descriptive analyzes were performed in Stata. RESULTS: Of 1,331 respondents (60% women, mean age: 49.6, SD = 17.5), 21% tested positive on the AUDIT-C for hazardous use. Just 10% of those accurately estimated low-risk daily limits, with exactly 9% at the weekly limits, and half of the estimated low-risk limits at or below the guidelines. Fewer than half who marked "Yes" to "Do you know what a 'standard drink' is?" provided accurate answers for beer, wine, or liquor. Patients with a positive test were twice as likely to say they knew what a standard drink is, but only a third gave precise estimates. When asked about plans for the next month regarding changing drinking behavior, 23% with a positive AUDIT-C indicated that they were at least considering a change. CONCLUSIONS: Most patients in primary care are unaware of the specific National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA) guidelines for low-risk alcohol use. Exploring patients' perceptions of low-risk patterns and current drinking behavior may reveal discrepancies worth discussing. For at-risk drinkers, most of whom are unaware of low-risk daily and weekly guidelines or standard drink sizes, education can be vital to intervene. The findings suggest the need for detailed and explicit social marketing and communication about exactly what low-risk drinking entails.

title: Patient Safety Research: An Overview of the Global Evidence
abstract: Background Unsafe medical care can cause considerable morbidity and mortality worldwide, despite imprecise estimates of the magnitude of the problem. To better understand the scope and nature of the problem of unsafe care, the WHO World Alliance for Patient Safety commissioned a review of the world literature on patient safety research. Methods Major patient safety issues were identified through a consultative and investigative process and classified under the framework of structure, process, and outcomes of unsafe care. Leading experts reviewed the current evidence and identified important knowledge gaps related to issues in developing, transition and developed countries. The report was reviewed by internal and external experts and made improvements based on feedback. Findings Twenty-three major patient safety issues were examined. Much of the evidence for unsafe care outcomes comes from developed countries, where prevalence studies show that between 3% and 16% of hospitalized patients are harmed by medical care. Data from transition and developing countries also suggest substantial harm from health care. However, considerable gaps in knowledge about the structural and process factors underlying unsafe care globally make it difficult to identify solutions, especially in resource-poor settings. Interpretation The harm caused by medical care appears to represent a substantial burden on the world's population. However, much of the evidence base comes from developed countries. Understanding the scope of, and solutions to, unsafe care for the rest of the world is a critical component of providing safe and effective care to all of the world's citizens.

title: Patient Safety: The Physician's Perspective
abstract: Medical errors can be defined as the failure of a planned action to be completed as planned or the use of an incorrect plan to achieve a goal. Beyond their economic cost and their cost in human lives, errors cause loss of trust in the health system by patients and a decrease in the satisfaction of both patients and health professionals. There are many evidence-based safety-oriented behaviors and interventions that are easily implemented, such as ultrasound-guided central venous catheter insertion, prevention of catheter-related bloodstream infections, and more. In vascular access, the development of patient safety research has raised a variety of issues that require study to provide the optimal approach to patient safety. Patients are the primary contributors to their own safety, and as such, clinicians must develop a new approach to involving them in the decision-making cycle at every step of their treatment. There are many opportunities along this path for the patient to engage in safety behaviors and for the access team to ensure such behaviors using simple strategies. The advent of the access center, based on multidisciplinary teamwork, has increased the potential to improve patient safety by preventing errors in planning and performing access surgery, avoiding delays in treating access malfunctions. access and improving communication between team members. However, a significant research effort is still needed to implement an intervention based on evidence-based data and focused on patient safety.

title: Card prompts carried by the patient versus computer generated prompts to remind private practice physicians to perform health maintenance measures.
abstract: Background: We compared the efficacy of a computer-generated instruction sheet placed at the front of patient charts with a patient-carried instruction card in reminding clinicians to perform selected elements of health maintenance. Methods: A single-blind prospective randomized study was conducted in private practice offices in rural eastern North Carolina, involving 28 family physicians and nine general internists. Twenty-two physicians were randomly assigned to the computer prompt group and 22 to the card prompt group. Four physicians in the computer group did not complete the study due to problems with the computer software, and three physicians did not complete the study because their limited staff were unable to enter patient data into the computer. Before the intervention, the medical records of 20 patients (10 men and 10 women) of each doctor were audited to determine the performance of influenza vaccinations, fecal occult blood, Pap tests, breast exams performed by the doctors and mammograms One year after the intervention was instituted, record audits were again performed for the above five items on 20 different patient records for each physician. Results: There was a 7% increase in influenza vaccine yield in the card group (17% vs. 24%) compared to a 6% increase in the computer group (20% vs. 26%). ). There was a 5% decrease in stool yield for occult blood in the card group (28% vs. 23%) compared to a 1% increase in the computer group (30% vs. 31%). There was an 11% decrease in Pap smear performance in the card group (26% vs. 15%) compared to a 3% increase in the computer group (23% vs. 26%) . There was a 2% decrease in physician performance of breast exams in the card group (35% vs. 33%) compared to a 3% increase in the computer group (30% vs. 33% ). Finally, there was a 3% increase in mammography throughput in the card group (22% vs. 25%) compared to an 11% increase in the computer group (15% vs. 26%). Conclusions: Our data show a greater increase in the performance of health maintenance items in the computer-assisted group. Yield of stool for occult blood, Pap smears, physician-performed breast exams, and mammograms increased more in the computer-guided group than in the card group. However, there was no statistically significant difference after intervention for any of the health maintenance items audited for either the computer group or the card group. In general, health maintenance measures were performed only in a minority of suitable patients. (Arch Intern Med. 1994";"154:1957-1960)

title: Patients with gout adhere to curative treatment if adequately informed: a proof-of-concept observational study
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Many physicians believe that gout patients are unwilling to receive urate-lowering therapy (ULT) and blame them for poor treatment adherence. OBJECTIVE: To test the effectiveness of a complex gout intervention that incorporates key elements of current guidelines, including comprehensive patient information, delivered in an optimal setting (specialized hospital clinic). METHOD: Observational study of patients reporting ongoing gout attacks recruited from primary care lists. A total of 106 participants (94 men, 12 women"; mean age 61 years) were enrolled in the study. Patients received a predominantly nurse-led intervention that included education, individualized lifestyle counseling, and appropriate ULT. The predefined goal was to achieve serum uric acid (SUA)</=360 mumol/L after 1 year in at least 70% of participants.RESULTS: Of 106 participants at baseline, 16% had tophi;mean (SD) baseline SUA was 456 (98) micromol/L All participants agreed to co-aspiration to confirm gout and all wanted to receive ULT At 12 months, 92% of 106 participants had achieved therapeutic goal (SUA</=360 micromole);" 85% had SUA <300 micromol/l. Allopurinol was the most widely used ULT, requiring a mean dose of 400 mg daily to reach target. Improvements in Short Form-36 (significant for pain) were seen after 1 year. CONCLUSION: A predominantly nurse-led intervention that includes education, lifestyle advice, and ULT can successfully achieve the recommended treatment goal in more than 9 out of 10 patients. The full explanation and discussion of the nature of gout and its treatment options and the individualization of management probably explain this success.

title: Pearls, dangers and pitfalls in the evaluation and treatment of attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder in adolescents
abstract: PURPOSE OF REVIEW: To provide clinicians with an up-to-date overview of key considerations related to the clinical evaluation and treatment of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in adolescents. RECENT FINDINGS: The recently revised Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-5 of the American Psychiatric Association included significant changes regarding the diagnostic criteria for ADHD in adolescents. The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) also recently revised its Clinical Practice Guidelines for ADHD";" while the previous guidelines focused on children ages 6 to 12, the new guidelines extend to ages 17. Understanding these revised diagnostic criteria and clinical guidelines is essential for pediatricians and others who care for adolescents. In addition to providing an updated review of the clinical approach to the assessment and treatment of ADHD in adolescents, recent findings related to common comorbidities, psychosocial risks, and long-term outcomes are briefly described. ABSTRACT: The diagnosis and treatment of adolescents with ADHD presents unique challenges and obstacles. Clinicians should be careful and deliberate in their evaluation of an adolescent with new-onset symptoms suggestive of ADHD, taking into account other conditions that might mimic ADHD and screening for common comorbid conditions. When it comes to treating adolescents, the AAP recommends medication as a first-line intervention, noting that stimulants have a much broader evidence base and effect size than non-stimulants. Although clinicians now have a multitude of drug formulations to choose from, they must also be vigilant about the potential for misuse and diversion of stimulants.

title: Pediatric Nurse Practitioner Managing Childhood Anxiety in a Rural Primary Care Clinic with the Evidence-Based COPE Program
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Anxiety is the most common mental health disorder in children. Many communities have a shortage of mental health providers, and most children with anxiety do not receive the evidence-based treatment they need. The purpose of this pilot study was to assess the feasibility and effects of a brief, seven-session cognitive-behavioral skill-building intervention, Creating Opportunities for Personal Empowerment (COPE), that was administered to anxious children by a pediatric nurse in a primary care center. around. METHODS: A pre-experimental, single-group, pre-test and post-test design was used. RESULTS: Children who participated had a significant decrease in anxiety symptoms (13.88 points, SD = 17.96, 95% confidence interval [CI] = -1.13-28.89), as well as a increased knowledge of cognitive-behavioral coping skills (M = 11.38, CI = 5.99-8.26, p = .00) and better functioning (at school and at home). Feedback from parents and children was positive. DISCUSSION: COPE is a promising evidence-based intervention for anxious children with feasible delivery by pediatric nurses in primary care.

title: Peer support for patients with type 2 diabetes: cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To test the effectiveness of peer support for patients with type 2 diabetes. DESIGN Randomized control by clusters. SET 20 General Practices in the East of the Republic of Ireland. PARTICIPANTS 395 patients (192 in the intervention group, 203 in the control group) and 29 support partners with type 2 diabetes. INTERVENTION All practices introduced a standardized system of diabetes care. The peer support intervention was developed over a two-year period and contained four elements: the recruitment and training of support peers, nine support peer-led group meetings in the participant's own general practice, and a retention plan. for fellow supporters. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES HbA(1c)"; cholesterol concentration; systolic blood pressure;" and well-being score. RESULTS There was no difference between intervention and control patients at baseline. All practices and 85% (337) of patients were followed up. At two years of follow-up, there was no significant difference in HbA(1c) (mean difference -0.08%, 95% confidence interval -0.35% to 0.18%), systolic blood pressure (-3 .9 mm Hg, -8.9 to 1.1 mm Hg), total cholesterol concentration (-0.03 mmol/L, -0.28 to 0.22 mmol/L), or wellness scores (-0, 7, -2.3 to 0.8). While there was a trend toward a decrease in the proportion of patients with poorly controlled risk factors during follow-up, particularly for systolic blood pressure (52% (87/166) >130 mm Hg at intervention vs. 61% (103 /169) > 130 mm Hg in the control), these changes were not significant. Process evaluation indicated that, overall, the intervention was delivered as planned, although 18% (35) of patients in the intervention group never attended any group meetings. CONCLUSIONS A peer-based group support intervention is feasible in general practice settings, but the intervention was not effective when targeted to all patients with type 2 diabetes. they do not support the widespread adoption of peer support. Trial Registration Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN42541690.

title: Perceptions and performance of function and physical activity in assisted living communities
