abstract: OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this study was to describe residents' self-efficacy and outcome expectations regarding function and physical activity (PA); measure functional performance and time in PA; assess the fit between the resident and the environment; and to assess the knowledge, beliefs, and care behaviors of nursing assistants (NAs) in 4 different assisted living (AL) communities. DESIGN: This was a descriptive study using baseline data from an intervention study in course, Testing the Impact of Care Focused on Function Intervention, Res-Care-AL. SETTING: Four assisted living communities in Maryland. PARTICIPANTS: A total of 171 residents and 96 ANs gave their consent, approved eligibility, and were included in this study. MEASUREMENTS: Descriptive data from NA and residents were obtained. Resident data also included self-efficacy and outcome expectations associated with functional tasks and exercise, social support for exercise, and subjective and objective information about functions. and physical activity. NA data included self-efficacy and outcome expectations, knowledge, and function-focused care performance. RESULTS: The residents were mostly female, white, and widowed; needed some help with activities of daily living; and participated in very little physical activity based on subjective and objective reports. NAs were predominantly female and black, had more than a decade of nursing experience, high confidence but limited knowledge of function-focused care, and performed this care in 76% of observed care interactions. There were no site-specific differences between NAs regarding role-focused care beliefs, knowledge, or performance. There were site-specific differences in residents regarding self-efficacy for functional capacity; functional presentation; social supports for expert exercise"; and family, person-environment adjustment, and physical activity based on subjective surveys. No differences were observed based on actigraphy. CONCLUSION: Residents of AL communities participate in very limited amounts of physical activity and staff at these sites could benefit from continued education on how to increase physical activity among residents and help them meet current guidelines for physical activity to optimize overall health.

title: Performance of the TREAT decision support system in an environment with a low prevalence of resistant pathogens.
abstract: Objectives To evaluate a decision support system (TREAT) for the guidance of empiric antimicrobial therapy in a setting with a low prevalence of resistant pathogens. Methods A retrospective TREAT trial was conducted at the University of Copenhagen, Hvidovre Hospital. The patient cohort included adults with systemic inflammation and suspected community-acquired bacterial infection. TREAT-recommended empiric antimicrobial therapy was compared with empiric antimicrobial therapy prescribed by the first treating clinician. Results Of 171 patients recruited, 161 (65 with microbiologically documented infections) met the TREAT inclusion criteria. The coverage achieved by TREAT was significantly greater than that of clinical practice (86% versus 66%, P = 0.007). There was no significant difference in the cost of future resistance between TREAT-selected and physician-selected treatments. Direct costs for antimicrobials were higher in TREAT when patients without antimicrobial treatment were included, while there were no significant differences in other cases. The cost of side effects was significantly lower with TREAT. Conclusions The results of the study suggest that TREAT may improve the adequacy of antimicrobial therapy and reduce the cost of side effects in regions with a low prevalence of resistant pathogens, however, at the expense of increased use of antibiotics.

title: Perioperative Care Map Improves Compliance with Best Practices for the Morbidly Obese
abstract: BACKGROUND: Morbid obesity can complicate perioperative management. Best practice guidelines have been published but are generally followed only in bariatric patients. Little is known about clinicians' awareness of and adherence to these clinical recommendations for non-bariatric operations. Our study evaluated whether an educational intervention could improve medical screening and adherence to established best practices for all surgically treated morbidly obese patients. METHODS: In 2013, a care map outlining best practices for morbidly obese patients was distributed to all surgeons and anesthesiologists at 4 university hospitals. Pre- and post-intervention surveys were sent to participants in 2012 and 2015 to assess changes in clinical practice. A post-intervention record audit determined physician compliance with distributed guidelines. RESULTS: In the study, 567 physicians completed the survey in 2012 and 375 physicians completed the survey in 2015. Post-intervention, statistically significant improvements were seen in the percentage of surgeons and anesthesiologists combined who reported changing their management of morbidly obese patients surgically treated to meet best practice preoperatively (89% vs. 59%), intraoperatively (71% vs. 54%), postoperatively (80% vs. 57%), and overall (88% vs. to 72%). Results were similar when surgeons and anesthesiologists were analyzed separately. An audit of 170 case files from the 4 hospitals found that 167 (98%) cases met best practice. CONCLUSION: After the distribution of the map of care, the percentage of doctors who reported having changed their management to adapt to best practices improved significantly. These findings highlight the beneficial impact that this educational intervention can have on medical behavior. Continued research is needed to assess the influence of this intervention on clinical outcomes.

title: Perioperative Î²-blockers in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery: a meta-analysis.
abstract: Background The American College of Cardiology and American Heart Association (ACC/AHA) guidelines on perioperative evaluation recommend perioperative? blockers for non-cardiac surgery, although the results of some clinical trials do not seem to support this recommendation. Our aim was to critically review the evidence to assess the use of perioperative? blockers in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery.";" Background The American College of Cardiology and American Heart Association (ACC/AHA) guidelines on perioperative evaluation recommend perioperative? blockers for non-cardiac surgery, although the results of some clinical trials do not seem to support this recommendation. Our aim was to critically review the evidence to assess the use of perioperative? blockers in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery.

title: Person-Centered Primary Care Strategies for the Assessment and Intervention of Aggressive Behaviors in Dementia
abstract: With an increase in the number of people affected by dementia, it is imperative that health care providers are well versed in the most effective ways to manage neuropsychiatric symptoms, such as aggression. Aggression can be particularly difficult to manage because it creates a risk of harm for formal and informal caregivers, and medical intervention options are complex and situation-dependent. Although multiple guidelines for the management of aggression in dementia are available in the literature, their scope is broad and suggested treatments often vary, making decision-making difficult for busy clinicians. Using a composite case as a model, the current article provides guidelines that guide outpatient providers through the steps necessary to provide effective treatment for aggression in people with dementia. Shifting the current focal point of care for patients with aggressive dementia to a more person-centered approach will have a positive impact on patient care. [Journal of Gerontological Nursing, 43(2), 9-17.].

title: Pharmaceutical care in chronic kidney disease: experience at the University Hospital of Grenoble from 2006 to 2010
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical pharmacists (CPs) specifically manage monitoring of laboratory tests, tailor drug dosage according to guidelines, and assess for cardiovascular risk factors and decline in renal function. The objective of this study was to evaluate the impact of clinical pharmacy services in nephrology outpatient consultations. METHOD: Clinical history and current treatment were obtained from each patient. Each intervention was classified according to the Act-IP document of the French Society of Clinical Pharmacy. This tool contains identifications and guidelines for the prevention and resolution of drug-related problems (PRM). RESULTS: From January 2008 to April 2009, 42 patients attended by the PC in at least 2 visits were included in the study. We observed 350 pharmaceutical consultations and 263 interventions. Pharmaceutical interventions in question: untreated indication (30%), underdosing (25.9%) and overdose (18.3%). The PC interventions consisted of: adapting the dose (42.2%) and adding treatments (31.9%). The main drugs involved referred to the cardiovascular (33.1%), digestive-metabolic (28.6%) and hematopoietic (21.6%) systems. CONCLUSION: The inclusion of a PC in the management of patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) is necessary for the identification and prevention of PRM. In addition to the medical improvement of CKD patients, the CP participates in the development of prescription recommendations and therapeutic education programs for patients. In addition, redefining the roles and practices of members of a clinical team has been shown to be effective in optimizing care for CKD patients. In addition, the patient's admission to dialysis is postponed, which translates into a reduction in health care insurance costs.

title: Pharmacoeconomic consequences of measuring and modifying hospital drug use
abstract: Patterns of drug use affect the provision of medical care in hospitals in various ways. Adverse drug reactions (ADRs) precipitate around 5% of admissions and impair the care of around 20% of hospitalized patients, while inadequate pharmacological treatment impairs outcomes and prolongs hospital stay. On the contrary, the appropriate application of medications can promote recovery and increase the quality of care. Well-documented examples include the prevention of deep vein thrombosis and postoperative wound infections. Consequently, optimizing drug use represents an important quality assurance issue in addition to determining the cost-effectiveness of health care delivery. Drug utilization review (DUR) requires all elements of the quality assurance process. In practice, therapeutically meaningful and cost-effective exercises can only be mounted if the link between patterns of drug use and clinical outcomes is known. These measurement processes currently limit the speed of quality assurance. There are several ways to measure drug use in hospitals. These range from readily available and relatively inexpensive quantitative methods to methods that require the availability of expert personnel. There is a sequence of methods involving increasing costs and increasing demands on resources that produce ever greater detail of the information obtained. This sequence begins with pharmacy purchases, followed by pharmacy shipments to particular clinical areas, prescription or treatment sheet survey, chart review, and finally reports from trained investigators working in the clinical area. The simplest methods can provide useful information and an efficient basis for choosing and planning definitive studies. Once a category of drug use is appropriately selected for intervention, drug use can be changed through planned intervention with improved clinical outcomes and reduced economic costs in many cases. Intervention strategies to modify drug use can be classified into re-educational, persuasive, facilitative and power strategies. Other models for implementing behavior change have been considered, including the impact of trained researchers and the use of online electronic prescriptions with interactive software with appropriate guidelines. The challenge is to achieve sustained change when interventions are implemented. Quality assurance of cost-effective medicine use is possible with modest resources if results-oriented activities are prioritized.

title: Pharmacological treatment of insomnia disorder: an evidence report for an American College of Physicians clinical practice guideline
abstract: Background: Pharmacological interventions are often prescribed for insomnia disorder. Purpose: To assess the benefits, harms, and comparative effectiveness of pharmacological treatments for adults with insomnia disorder. Data sources: Various electronic databases (2004Â¨C September 2015), reference lists, and US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) documents. Study selection: 35 randomized controlled trials of at least 4 weeks duration that evaluated pharmacotherapies available in the United States and reported global or sleep outcomes; 11 long-term observational studies reporting harm information; FDA review data for nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics and orexin receptor antagonists and product labels for all agents. Data extraction: data extraction by a single investigator confirmed by a second reviewer; risk of bias assessment by two investigators; consensus determination of the strength of the evidence. Data synthesis: eszopiclone, zolpidem, and suvorexant better short-term sleep and global outcomes compared with placebo, although absolute effect sizes were small (low- to moderate-strength evidence) The evidence for benzodiazepine hypnotics, agonists of melatonin and antidepressants, and for most pharmacological interventions in older adults, was insufficient or underpowered. Evidence was also insufficient to compare efficacy within or between pharmacotherapy classes or versus behavioral therapy. The evidence of harm reported in the trials was judged to be insufficient or of low strength; observational studies suggested that the use of hypnotics for insomnia was associated with an increased risk of dementia, fractures, and serious injuries. FDA documents reported that most drug therapies had risks of cognitive and behavioral changes. , including difficulty driving and other side effects, recommending dose reduction in women and older adults. Limitations: Most trials were small and short-term and included people who met strict criteria. Often minimal important differences in outcomes were not stated or reported. Data were sparse for many treatments. Conclusion: Eszopiclone, zolpidem, and suvorexant may improve short-term sleep and global outcomes in adults with insomnia disorder, but the comparative effectiveness and long-term efficacy of the treatments are unknown. Pharmacotherapies for insomnia. it can cause cognitive and behavioral changes and may be associated with rare but serious harm. Primary Funding Source: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality. (Prospero: CRD42014009908)

title: Pharmacological treatment of low bone density or osteoporosis to prevent fractures: a clinical practice guideline from the American College of Physicians
abstract: Description: The American College of Physicians (ACP) developed this guideline to present the available evidence on various drug treatments to prevent fractures in men and women with low bone density or osteoporosis. Methods: Published literature on this topic was identified using MEDLINE (1966 to December 2006), ACP Journal Club database, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (no date limit), Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews (no date limits), UK National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence Websites (no date limits), and the UK Health Technology Assessment Program (January 1998 to December 2006). Searches were limited to publications in English and human studies. Keywords for the search included terms for osteoporosis, osteopenia, low bone density, and medications listed in the key questions. This guideline rates the evidence and recommendations according to the ACP clinical practice guideline rating system. Recommendation 1: ACP recommends that clinicians offer drug treatment to men and women who have known osteoporosis and those who have experienced fragility fractures (Grade: "Strong recommendation"; high-quality evidence). Recommendation 2: ACP recommends that clinicians consider drug therapy. pharmacological treatment for men and women who are at risk of developing osteoporosis (Grade: Weak recommendation; moderate-quality evidence) Recommendation 3: ACP recommends that clinicians choose between pharmacological treatment options for osteoporosis in men and women based on an assessment of risks and benefits in individual patients (Grade: Strong recommendation; moderate-quality evidence.) Recommendation 4: ACP recommends further research to evaluate the treatment of osteoporosis in men and women.

title: Pharmacological treatment of neuropsychiatric disorders
abstract: Emotional and cognitive symptoms, such as depression, mania, mood and affect lability, psychosis, altered arousal, anxiety and irritability, and aggression often occur in neurological disorders. These neuropsychiatric syndromes significantly impair functioning and rehabilitation efforts. Brain-damaged patients are especially sensitive to the side effects of medications. When appropriate guidelines are followed, psychopharmacological intervention relieves these symptoms, improves rehabilitation, and prevents deterioration of arousal and cognition.

title: Pharmacological treatment of bipolar disorder in children and adolescents
abstract: It is increasingly recognized that bipolar disorder often first presents in adolescence. Preadolescents with volatile behavior and severe mood swings also comprise a large group of patients whose difficulties may fall within the bipolar spectrum. However, the preponderance of scientific effort and clinical trials for this condition has focused on adults. This review summarizes the complexity of bipolar disorder and the diagnosis of the illness among young people. It proceeds to review the principles of pharmacotherapy, evaluates current treatment options, and highlights areas where evidence-based guidance is lacking. Recent developments have expanded the range of possible treatments for bipolar disorder. However, differences in the phenomenology, course, and sequelae of bipolar disorder among youth call for greater attention to the benefits and drawbacks of therapy for those affected by early-onset bipolar disorder. By summarizing current research and opinion on diagnostic issues and treatment approaches, this review aims to provide an update on a clinically important but controversial topic.

title: Pharmacotherapy of social anxiety disorder at the turn of the millennium
abstract: During the last 21 years since the birth of SP in the diagnostic nomenclature, there have been significant advances in knowledge about effective pharmacological and psychotherapeutic treatments. SSRIs have emerged as the first-line pharmacological treatment, although good evidence shows the efficacy of benzodiazepines"; MAOIs;" and anticonvulsant agents, such as gabapentin and pregabalin. There is also emerging evidence for the efficacy of the newer antidepressant venlafaxine and also optimism about the potential usefulness of nefazodone and possibly bupropion. However, there are many areas that require more research. There has been much excitement over the publication of the RUPP Anxiety Study, which demonstrates the efficacy of fluvoxamine in socially phobic youth. Since SP begins in childhood and adolescence, more data are needed to support the use of pharmacotherapy in this age group because early intervention may prevent the sequelae of chronic SP. There needs to be more research into what is required for people with social phobia to have a good response to pharmacotherapy to go into full remission. Additional research is needed regarding the evaluation of the comparative efficacy of different drug classes and to develop an improved ability to predict treatment response for a particular type of treatment. In addition, more research on treatment resistance is needed. In most anxiety disorders that have been studied, the combination of CBT with psychopharmacological treatment has shown little advantage over either treatment alone. These findings may be due to methodological problems. Research is needed on how to sequence treatments to maximize the benefits of combining the two types of effective treatments. Finally, many clinicians are seeing an emerging trend of people who have had untreated SP their entire lives now presenting for treatment in their "golden years." Currently established treatments need to be further evaluated in this geriatric population.

title: Pharmacy Asthma Care Program (PACP) improves outcomes for patients in the community.
abstract: Background: Despite national disease management plans, optimal management of asthma remains a challenge in Australia. Community pharmacists are in an ideal position to implement new strategies that aim to ensure that asthma care meets current best practice standards. The impact of the Pharmaceutical Asthma Care Program (PACP) on asthma control was assessed using a multisite randomized intervention repeated measures study design versus control. Methods: Fifty Australian pharmacies were randomized into two groups: intervention pharmacies implemented PACP (a continuous cycle of assessment, goal setting, monitoring and review) to 191 patients for 6 months, while control pharmacies provided their usual care. to 205 control patients. Both groups administered questionnaires and performed spirometric tests at baseline and 6 months later. The main outcome measure was asthma control status/severity. Results: 186 of 205 control patients (91%) and 165 of 191 intervention patients (86%) completed the study. The intervention resulted in better asthma control: patients who received the intervention were 2.7 times more likely to improve from 'severe' to 'not severe' than control patients (OR 2.68, 95% CI : 1.64 to 4.37"; p<0.001). The intervention also resulted in better adherence to preventive medication (OR 1.89, 95% CI 1.08 to 3.30; p?= ?0.03), decrease in mean daily dose of reliever medication (difference -149.11 µg, 95% CI -283.87 to -14.36, p?=?0.03), a change in medication profile from reliever alone to a combination of prevention, reliever with or without long-acting ß-agonist (OR 3.80, 95% CI 1.40 to 10.32; p?=?0.01) and improved scores on risk of non-compliance (difference -0.44, 95% CI -0.69 to -0.18, P = 0.04), quality of life (difference -0.23, 95% CI -0.46 to 0 .00, p = 0.05), asthma knowledge (difference 1.18, 95% CI 0.73 to 1.63, p<0.01), and perceived control of cue asthma questionnaires (difference -1.39, 95% CI -2.44 to -0.35; p<0.01). There were no significant changes in spirometric measurements in either group. Conclusions: A pharmacist-managed asthma care program based on national guidelines improves asthma control. The sustainability and implementation of the program within the health system remains to be investigated.

title: Physical activity under prescription (PAP) from the perspective of the general practitioner - a qualitative study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Prescription physical activity (PAP) is a successful intervention to increase physical activity among patients with a sedentary lifestyle. The method appears to be used sparingly by general practitioners (GPs) and there is limited information on GP attitudes towards counseling using PAP as a tool. The aim of the study was to explore and understand the meaning of prescribing physical activity from the perspective of the general practitioner. METHODS: Three focus group interviews were conducted with a purposive sample of 15 Swedish general practitioners in southern Sweden. Participants were invited to talk about their experience using PAP. The interviews were transcribed verbatim, analyzed by qualitative content analysis. RESULTS: The analysis resulted in four categories: Tradition hinders attitude change, Shared responsibility is necessary, The PAP has a low status and is viewed with mistrust, and Lack of clear procedures and guidelines. Traditionally, GPs talk to patients about the importance of a higher level of physical activity, but do not prescribe physical activity as a treatment. Physician education focuses on the use of pharmaceuticals. Responsibility for the level of physical activity of patients is shared with other health professionals, the patient and society. GPs express reservations about prescribing physical activity. A heavy workload is a source of frustration. PAP is viewed with mistrust and considered a task of lesser value and status. Using a prescription to emphasize an increased level is considered redundant, and doctors believe it should be administered by someone else in the health care system. Skepticism was also expressed about the result of the method. CONCLUSIONS: There is uncertainty about the use of PAP as a treatment since clinicians lack education in non-pharmaceutical methods. GPs do not consider the written referral as a priority task and rather refer other professionals in the health system to prescribe PAP. GPs pointed out the need to create routines and arrangements for the method to gain credibility and become a daily practice among GPs.

title: Smoking Medical Advice for Teens: Who Gets the Advice and Who Benefits Most?
abstract: PURPOSE: The Clinical Practice Guidelines instruct physicians to ask their patients about smoking and to discourage tobacco use. Physicians are especially urged to care for racial minorities and adolescents because of the increased susceptibility of these groups to smoking. Research on race and medical advice against smoking has produced conflicting results. The purpose of this study is to clarify the relationships between physician communication about tobacco, race, and smoking among adolescents. METHODS: This retrospective cross-sectional study explored (1) racial differences in rates of receiving physician communication and (2) whether the relationship between physician communication and smoking among adolescents was moderated by race. Multiple measures of smoking status (eg, intentions to quit, attempts to quit, quitters, relapse status) were used. We used a large sample (N = 5,154), predominantly African American (82.9%) of 11th graders. RESULTS: Regular smokers were more likely to be screened for smoking. African-Americans were discouraged from smoking more often than Caucasians. Among African Americans, non-smokers were more likely to be screened and counseled";" among Caucasians, regulars were more likely to be tested and counseled. Overall, physician intervention was associated with greater benefits for African American youth, including fewer intentions to smoke, more likely to quit, and fewer relapses. CONCLUSIONS: Physician communication about smoking may hold particular promise for African-American adolescents, reducing health disparities due to racial differences in smoking-related mortality and morbidity. Physicians should be encouraged to screen and counsel all youth about tobacco, regardless of race or smoking status.

title: Physician and patient predictors of evidence-based prescribing in heart failure: a multilevel study.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Treatment of patients with heart failure (HF) must take into account the changing and complex individual clinical characteristics. The guidelines recommend the use of renin angiotensin system inhibitors (RAAS-I) at target doses. But physicians appear to be insufficiently following this recommendation, while little is known about predictors of physician and patient adherence. METHODS: To examine the consistency of primary care physicians' (PC) self-perceived knowledge and competencies about RAAS-I with their respective prescribing behavior related to patient-associated barriers. Cross-sectional follow-up study after a randomized trial of educational medical intervention with an observation period of seven months. PC physicians (n = 37) and patients with systolic HF (n = 168) from practices in Baden-Württemberg. Measures were knowledge (blueprint-based multiple choice test), self-perceived competencies (global confidence in therapy and RAAS-I frequency of use questionnaire), and patient variables (age, gender, NYHA performance status , blood pressure, potassium level, kidney function). The prescription was obtained from the trial documentation. The target variable was >/=50% of the recommended dose of RAAS-I investigated using two-level logistic regression models. RESULTS: The patients (69% male, mean age 68.8 years) presented symptomatic and objectified left ventricle (NYHA II vs. III/IV: 51% vs. 49% and mean LVEF 33.3%) and renal (GFR/ =50%). of the improvement in the prescription of RAAS-I were the age of the patient (OR 0.95, CI 0.92-0.99, p = 0.01), the global self-confidence of the doctor at follow-up (OR 1.09 , CI 1.02-1.05, p = 0.01) and NYHA class (II vs. III/IV) (OR 0.63, CI 0.38-1.05, p = 0.08). CONCLUSIONS: A change in physician confidence as a predictor of RAAS-I dose escalation is a new finding that might reflect an improved physician intervention effect. ' and that it could encourage novel strategies to improve safe evidence-based prescribing, which should include knowledge, attitude and skills guidance.

title: Willingness of physicians and patients to pay for electronic management of cardiovascular diseases
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is an important target for electronic decision support. We examined the potential sustainability of an electronic CVD management program using a discrete choice experiment (DCE). Our goal was to estimate physician and patient willingness-to-pay (WTP) for current and improved programs. METHODS: Focus groups, expert input, and literature searches decided on the attributes to be assessed for physician-patient ECDs, which were conducted using a web-based program. Hierarchical Bayesian analysis estimated preference coefficients for each respondent, and latent class analysis segmented each sample. Simulations were used to estimate the WTP for each of the attributes individually and for an improved vascular management system. RESULTS: 144 participants (70 physicians, 74 patients) completed the DCE. In general, speed of access to up-to-date records and monthly payments for a nurse coordinator were the main determinants of physician choice. Two distinctly different segments of physicians were identified: one highly sensitive to the monthly subscription fee and the speed of updating the tracker with new patient data, and the other highly sensitive to the monthly cost of the nurse coordinator and government billing incentives. Patient choices were most significantly influenced by annual subscription cost. Physician-estimated willingness-to-pay was slightly above the estimated threshold for sustainability, while patient-estimated willingness-to-pay was below. CONCLUSION: Current willingness to pay for electronic cardiovascular disease management should encourage innovation to provide economies of scale in program development, delivery, and maintenance to meet sustainability thresholds.

title: Physicians' attitudes toward the spread of optical spectroscopy devices for cervical cancer monitoring: an industry-academic collaborative study.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Optical spectroscopy has been studied for biological plausibility, technical efficacy, clinical effectiveness, patient satisfaction, and cost effectiveness. OBJECTIVE: We seek to identify the attitudes or practices of health providers that could act as barriers or for the diffusion of this new technology. METHODS: Through an academic-industry partnership, we conducted a series of focus groups to examine medical barriers to optical diagnosis. The study was carried out in 2 stages. First, a pilot group of 10 physicians (8 OB-GYNs and 2 family physicians) from 8 regions of the United States were randomly selected and each physician was interviewed individually. Clinicians were presented with the results of a large trial (N = 980) that tested the accuracy of a spectroscopy-based device in detecting cervical neoplasia. They were also shown a prototype of the device and given a period of time to ask questions and receive answers about the device. They were also asked to provide feedback on a questionnaire that was later revised and presented to 3 larger focus groups (n=13, 15, and 17 for a total N=45). The largest focus groups were conducted during national scientific meetings with 20 obstetrician-gynecologists and 25 primary care physicians (family physicians and internists). RESULTS: When asked about the potential for diffusion of new cervical cancer screening technology, all study groups tended to rely on the established clinical guidelines of their respective professional societies regarding screening and diagnosis of cervical cancer. cervical cancer. Additionally, study participants agreed that real-time spectroscopy would be viewed positively by their patients. Participants were positive about the potential of the new technology as an adjunct to colposcopy, agreeing that improved accuracy would result in reduced healthcare costs (due to fewer biopsies and fewer visits). Although all participants saw the potential of real-time diagnostics, many barriers were perceived. These barriers included schedule and workflow changes, liability, documentation, ease of use, length of training, device cost, and third-party reimbursement. CONCLUSIONS: There are barriers to the diffusion of optical technologies in medical practice. These will need to be addressed before cervical screening and diagnostic programs can take advantage of spectroscopy-based tools for cancer control.

title: Physician behavior in the care of pediatric chronic diseases: association with health outcomes and adherence to treatment
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Physician behavior is an important but understudied influence on children's and parents' adherence to medical treatment. METHOD: To address this need, research was reviewed in the following topic areas: children's and adolescents' perceptions of physicians' behavior in managing pediatric chronic diseases, parents' perceptions of physicians' behavior in managing pediatric chronic diseases; Physician adherence to pediatric chronic disease management guidelines; chronic disease management; communication of information by physicians on the treatment of pediatric chronic diseases; the relationship of medical behavior with adherence to treatment;" and interventions to improve the management of pediatric chronic diseases by physicians. RESULTS: The findings highlight the discrepancies between the needs of parents and adolescents and the behavior of the physician, as well as inconsistencies in physician behavior, including adherence to practice guidelines, that may limit children's adherence to medical treatment.However, the results of interventions designed to improve the medical management of pediatric asthma have been CONCLUSIONS: Future research should be guided by a comprehensive model of physician behavior in chronic disease management that considers contextual determinants (eg, culture and socioeconomic status), identifies clinically relevant targets for intervention, and documents impact on outcomes. should be developed and evaluated Use approaches to chronic disease management that engage clinicians in active communication, support, and decision-making with children with chronic disease and their parents.

title: Medical intervention and patient risk perception among smokers with acute respiratory disease in the emergency department
abstract: BACKGROUND: Acute respiratory illnesses account for more than 12 million visits to emergency departments in the United States each year. Between a quarter and a half of these patients are smokers. We examined the frequency of physician intervention to quit smoking among patients with acute respiratory illness in the emergency department, and examined the influence of physician intervention on patients' perceived risk of smoking and motivation to quit. . METHODS: This study was conducted in the emergency department of a large downtown hospital. Adult smokers (n = 63) presenting with symptoms of acute respiratory illness were surveyed by exit interview while in the emergency department. The frequency and extent of medical interventions for smoking cessation were examined using the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research guidelines as a model. We also assessed patients' perceptions of smoking risk, the presence of other smokers in the home, and patients' motivation to quit. RESULTS: Emergency department physicians provided an incomplete and inconsistent intervention for smoking. Although most patients reported being asked if they smoked, only half of the smokers were advised to quit. Only 9% were offered help to quit smoking. Risk perception was generally low, however, most smokers were willing to receive on-site smoking cessation counseling while in the emergency department. CONCLUSIONS: The small sample size in this study requires that the results be interpreted with caution. However, the findings of this study suggest that the emergency department setting may provide a unique "teachable moment" in which to initiate smoking cessation counseling for this high-risk population.

title: Participation of the physician in the management of obesity as a primary medical condition
abstract: As the obesity epidemic grows, the number of patients with serious comorbidities related to excess body weight is increasing. Obesity must be recognized and treated as a primary medical condition that is progressive, chronic, and relapsing. Effective treatment of obesity has been shown to reduce cardiovascular risk factors and comorbid conditions. Physician involvement is necessary for medical evaluation, management, counseling, and coordination of multidisciplinary obesity treatment. Obese patients who receive weight control and counseling from physicians are much more likely to undertake weight control programs than those who do not. Obesity treatment guidelines and materials are available from various health organizations. A comprehensive weight management program should include dietary adjustments, increased physical activity, and behavior modification. Nutritional modifications should take into account the energy content, composition, and suitability of the diet for the individual patient. The physical activity component should be safe and practical, including aerobic activity, strength training, and increased daily lifestyle activities. Several behavioral strategies allow the patient to make lifestyle changes that will promote weight loss and weight control. Adjunctive therapies may serve to support lifestyle modifications in cases of severe or resistant obesity. Multidisciplinary care models vary depending on whether they are designed for an individual medical practice or as part of the health care services of a larger facility. Lifestyle changes for healthy weight management should be permanently incorporated into a patient's daily lifestyle to reduce obesity and associated health risks. Such intervention is necessary if the growing obesity epidemic is to be slowed and reversed.

title: Medical management of hypercholesterolemia. A randomized trial of continuing medical education
abstract: To determine the effect of continuing medical education (CME) on adherence to the recommendations of the National Cholesterol Education Program Expert Panel on high serum cholesterol levels in adults, we randomly assigned physicians primary care in 174 clinics to 3 groups, 2 who underwent standard treatment or intensive CME and a control group. The standard CME group was offered a free 3-hour seminar on elevated serum cholesterol levels; the intensive CME group was also offered follow-up seminars and free office supplies. After 18 months, we audited 13,099 medical records from the 140 practices that remained in the study. There were no significant differences (P > 0.15) in detection of high serum cholesterol or adherence to guidelines between groups receiving continuing medical education (51% detection; 33% compliance) and the control group (57% detection;" 37% compliance). In the prespecified subgroup of patients with hypercholesterolemia, there was a trend toward modest benefit from education interventions continuous medical: compliance was 21% in the control group, 23% in the standard CME group, and 27% in the intensive CME group (p=0.07 overall).These results emphasize the need for best ways to change the behavior of practicing physicians and the importance of studying the implementation of preventive health recommendations.

title: Physician reimbursement for salary or fee for service: effect on medical practice behavior in a prospective randomized study.
abstract: We used a resident continuity clinic to prospectively compare the impact of salary versus fee-for-service reimbursement on medical practice behavior. This model allowed for the randomization of physicians into salary and fee-for-service groups and the separation of the effects of reimbursement from patient behavior. Physicians reimbursed for fee-for-service scheduled more visits per patient than salaried physicians (3.69 visits vs. 2.83 visits, P less than 0.01) and saw their patients more often (2.70 visits vs. 2.21 visits, P less than 0.05) during the 9-month study. Almost all of this difference was due to fee-for-service physicians taking better care of patients than salaried physicians (1.42 visits and 0.99 visits per enrolled patient, respectively, P less than 0.01). Evaluation of visits according to the American Academy of Pediatrics guidelines indicated that fee-for-service physicians saw more well-child care patients than salaried physicians because they missed fewer recommended visits and scheduled visits in excess of those recommendations. Fee-for-service physicians also provided better continuity of care than salaried physicians by attending a higher percentage of all visits made by their patients (86.6% of visits vs. 78.3% of visits, P less than 0.05) and by promoting fewer emergencies. visits per enrolled patient (0.12 visits vs. 0.22 visits, P less than 0.01). Physicians' interest in private practice, as determined by their career plans, was significantly correlated with the total number of patients enrolled (r = 0.48, P less than 0.05) and the total number of clinical patients served. for each resident during the study (r = 0.40). , P less than .05).(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)

title: Physician response to computer reminders.
abstract: A computerized medical record system was designed to detect and remind the responsible physician of clinical events that might require corrective action. These reminders significantly increased the physician's response rate (in terms of test orders and treatment changes) to the events in question. Adding citations from relevant medical literature to reminders did not significantly change physician response rate compared to reminders alone, nor did it encourage physicians to read any of the cited articles stored in a readily available reprint "library" immediately.

title: Physician responses to a community-wide trial promoting judicious use of antibiotics
abstract: PURPOSE: In an environment of multiple campaigns promoting the judicious use of antibiotics in children, it is important to identify effective strategies. We assessed clinician responses to a community-level intervention regarding antibiotic prescribing, related practices, and perceived efficacy. METHODS: This study was a mixed qualitative and quantitative evaluation of a community-wide randomized controlled educational intervention in 16 Massachusetts communities. Physicians in the intervention communities received locally endorsed guidelines, group educational sessions, and bi-weekly newsletters. Parents received materials simultaneously at doctors' offices and by mail. After the intervention, we conducted a mailed medical survey and individual interviews to assess the impact of the intervention. We compared survey responses for intervention and control physicians, and analyzed interview transcripts to provide insights on selected topics. RESULTS: Among respondents (n = 168), 91% of intervention physicians and 4% of control physicians reported receiving intervention materials. The doctors received information from many other sources. More intervention than control physicians reported a decrease in antibiotic prescribing between 2000 and 2003 (75% vs. 58%, P = .03), but there were no differences between groups in knowledge, attitudes, or behaviors. favor judicious use of antibiotics. Both groups were concerned about antibiotic resistance and reported room to reduce their own prescribing. Physicians interviewed suggested frequent repetition of messages, brief written materials on specific topics for themselves and patients, and promotion in the media as the most effective strategies to reduce prescribing. CONCLUSIONS: Across multiple communities, an intervention in physician offices to promote judicious antibiotic prescribing reached its target audience, but physician self-reported attitudes and practices were similar in intervention and control communities. Campaigns that repeat short and consistent reminders to multiple stakeholder groups may be more effective in ensuring judicious use of antibiotics.

title: Medical screenings for multiple behavioral health risk factors
abstract: BACKGROUND: Screening rates in primary care for unique behavioral health risk factors are well documented. However, such risk factors cluster in individuals and populations. This article examines the number and types of behavioral risk factors reported by US adults who reported being screened for at their last routine health checkup. METHODS: The sample consisted of 16,818 adults from the 1998 National Health Interview Survey who reported having had a routine checkup in the past year. Respondents completed questions about four behavioral risk factors (physical inactivity, overweight, smoking, risky alcohol use) and the provider's detection of behaviors related to these risk factors. RESULTS: Half of the sample (52.0%) reported having two or more of the four risk factors, and more than half (59.4%) were screened for two or more risk behaviors at their last control. routine, although 28.6% reported having been screened for none of them. Respondents who reported at least one risk factor were rated at an average of 57.7% of their own risk factors. Women, adults with lower income and education levels, and those older than 65 years reported being screened for fewer risk factors. CONCLUSIONS: Although risk factor screening and intervention guidelines generally focus on single behavioral risk factors, most primary care patients present with more than one and are evaluated. Behavioral risk factor screening tools and interventions need to be expanded to cover multiple risks. In addition, efforts are needed to reduce the substantial missed opportunities for screening and to eliminate demographic disparities in screening practices and accuracy.

title: Physician, heal yourself: health maintenance behaviors among physicians
abstract: The objective of this article is to assess the need for health maintenance intervention programs aimed at physicians and patients. We compared the adherence to health maintenance behavior of physicians (as patients) with a population of control patients. An online survey was sent to the Texas Tech University Health Science Center (TTUHSC) School of Medicine's faculties of basic clinical and non-clinical sciences and non-TTUHSC physicians from the TTUHSC Medical Society. local county. The survey included questions about basic demographics and recent participation in regular health maintenance strategies, including annual checkup, flu vaccination, colonoscopy, Pap test, and mammography. Logistic regressions were performed to determine whether being a physician had a significant association with the likelihood of engaging in the health maintenance behavior outcomes listed above. This article shows that physicians are less likely than the general population to adhere to specific health maintenance guidelines: namely, annual checkups, colonoscopies, and mammograms. Pap test rates did not differ between physicians and a control population, but physicians were more likely to receive an influenza vaccine.

title: Medical-Industry Relations. Part 1: Individual Physicians
abstract: This is part 1 of a two-part document on ethics and medical-industry relations. Part 1 offers advice to individual physicians";" Part 2 gives recommendations to medical education providers and medical professional societies. Physicians and industry have a shared interest in advancing medical knowledge. However, the primary ethic of the physician is to promote the best interests of the patient, while the primary ethic of the industry is to promote profitability. While physician-industry partnerships can result in impressive medical advances, they also create opportunities for bias and can lead to unfavorable public perceptions. Many doctors and doctors in training believe that they are immune to commercial influence. However, recent studies show that accepting gifts and hospitality from the industry, including drug samples, can compromise judgment of medical information and subsequent decisions about patient care. It is up to the doctor to judge whether a gift is acceptable. A very general guideline is that it is ethical to accept modest gifts that promote medical practice. It is clearly unethical to accept gifts or services that require the physician to reciprocate. Conflicts of interest may arise from other financial ties between physicians and industry, whether with outside companies or their own businesses. Such ties include fees for speaking or writing about a company's product, payment for participating in clinical research, and referrals to medical resources. All of these relationships have the potential to influence a physician's attitudes and practices. This document explores the ethical dilemmas involved and offers guidelines for ethical business relationships.

title: Physicians and the Pharmaceutical Industry (update 2001)
Physicians' health habits are associated with lifestyle counseling for hypertensive patients
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Seventh Report of the Joint National Committee on Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment of High Blood Pressure (JNC VII) recommended lifestyle interventions, with or without pharmacological treatment, for all patients with high blood pressure. The objective of this study is to determine the association of the personal habits of physicians with their attitudes and behaviors regarding the lifestyle modification guidelines of the JNC VII. METHODS: One thousand primary care physicians completed DocStyles 2010, a voluntary web-based survey designed to provide information on physician attitudes and behaviors regarding various health issues. RESULTS: The average age of the respondents was 45.3 years, and 68% were male. Regarding the behavior of the doctor, 4.0% smoked at least once a week, 38.6% ate >/=5 cups of fruits and/or vegetables >/=5 days/week and 27.4 % exercised >/=5 days/week. When asked about the specific types of advice offered to their hypertensive patients, physicians reported advising their patients to eat a healthy diet (92.2%), or reduce salt intake (96.1%), or who reached or maintained a healthy weight (94.8%). o limit alcohol consumption (75.4%), o be physically active (94.4%). Overall, 66.5% made all 5 lifestyle modification recommendations. Nonsmoking physicians were more likely to recommend each lifestyle intervention to their hypertensive patients. Those who exercised at least 1 day a week were more likely to recommend limiting alcohol consumption. CONCLUSIONS: The probability of recommending the 5 JNC VII interventions was higher for physicians who did not smoke and who exercised at least 1 day per week.

title: Response of physicians to victims of domestic violence: towards a model of care
abstract: Although current domestic violence guidelines, such as those published by the AMA in 1992, attempt to relieve clinicians of the "full burden of intervention," they continue to ask them to play an important role in identification, intervention, and follow-up. in case of partner abuse. In this article, we define a limited domestic violence role for physicians that promotes the AMA-recommended direction and complements exemplary programs. We propose to simplify and limit clinicians' tasks to "Asking patients about abuse," providing validation messages, acknowledging that abuse is wrong and confirming the patient's worth, documenting signs, symptoms, and disclosures that occur, and refer victims to specialists in domestic violence (AVDR). Drawing on the literature and our own experience, we show how focusing the physician's role on these four tasks is consistent with exemplary programs and expands on ideas put forth by experts to address domestic violence in health care settings, reduces barriers to medical interventions with the victims; offers a realistic approach for clinicians while reducing unrealistic educational demands;" and complements managed care trends in contemporary health care.

title: Physicians' Understanding of Consent Requirements for Phase I Clinical Trials in Cognitively Impaired or Highly Vulnerable Populations
abstract: We investigated clinicians' attitudes about admitting patients who are unable to give informed consent or who belong to a vulnerable population into clinical trials. A survey instrument asked a national sample of practicing physicians whether ten hypothetical patients could be enrolled in phase I clinical trials. The impact of demographic variables on the number of scenarios considered completely or somewhat acceptable was analyzed using Student's t-tests or analysis of variance (ANOVA), as appropriate. All significant variables (p<0.01) were entered into a multiple logistic regression model. Eighty-four percent of respondents indicated that at least one case scenario was acceptable. Most of those conducting clinical trials (62%), who had training in clinical research ethics (78%), and who serve on institutional review boards (IRBs) (83%) approved at least one case scenario. Doctors approved the entry of some patients who cannot give informed consent or who belong to a vulnerable population in clinical trials. The most effective education on guidelines involving clinical research should be available to practicing physicians, residents, and medical students. It must also be ensured that physicians conducting clinical trials or serving on IRBs have the necessary knowledge of the ethics of clinical research.

title: Determine the diagnosis in breast cancer
Reminders at the point of service for the prescription of cardiovascular medications.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To provide clinicians with evidence-based recommendations for point-of-service care, using an automated system, and to assess their effectiveness in promoting prescriptions for the prevention of cardiovascular events. STUDY DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. METHODS: Patients at risk of cardiovascular events who might benefit from angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl coenzyme A reductase inhibitors (statins) were identified from electronic data at a managed care and were randomized into 2 groups. Physicians attending outpatients in the intervention group were faxed a sheet containing the relevant patient data, including a recommendation to prescribe the indicated medication. In the control group, the technical sheet did not include the recommendation. The prescriptions dispensed were compared between the groups. RESULTS: More than 4000 visits were observed for each type of medication. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin II receptor blockers were given at 7.1% of visits in the intervention group vs. 5.7% in the control group (P=0.048) after of the first doctor-patient encounter. No significant difference was seen for statins (intervention, 8.1% vs. control, 7.7%). Data from all doctor-patient encounters and both medications were combined in a logistic regression analysis. The odds ratio was 1.19 for a prescription filled in the intervention group and 1.54 for 2 or more visits versus 1 visit. CONCLUSIONS: An automated system that provides relevant data and personalized recommendations for point-of-service care modestly increased prescription dispensing rates. Addressing patient-provider encounters to change provider behavior is challenging";" however, even small effects can produce clinically important results over time.

title: Electronic Prompts at the Point of Care: An Effective Means to Increase Compliance, Demonstrate Quality, and Improve Outcomes
abstract: BACKGROUND: Incentives based on quality indicators, such as the basic measures of the Surgical Care Improvement Project (SCIP 1), encourage the implementation of evidence-based guidelines consistently in clinical practice. Information systems with electronic notices at the point of care (POCEP) can facilitate the adoption of processes and benchmark performance. We evaluated the effectiveness of POCEPs on rates of antibiotic administration within 60 minutes of surgical incision and the effect on outcome in a prospective observational trial. METHODS: Compliance with SCIP 1 and the corresponding outcome variable (surgical site infection [SSI]) were prospectively examined during 2 consecutive 6-month periods before (A) and after (B) implementation of POCEP in a hospital system. regional health. The secondary analysis extended the observation to two 12-month periods (A' and B'). A 2-year sustainability phase (C and D) followed. RESULTS: The 19,744 procedures included 9,127 and 10,617 procedures before (A) and after (B) POCEP implementation, respectively. POCEPs increased compliance with SCIP indicators in Period B by 31% (95% CI, 30.0%-32.2%) from 62% to 92% (P 95% with lower mean SSI rates for all periods compared to pre-POCEP SSI rates (0.8%, 0.7%, and 0.5% vs. 1.1%";" P 30% and were associated with reduced risk absolute 0.4% in incidence of SSI POCEPs may be useful in modulating provider behavior and demonstrating intraoperative quality and value.

title: Population-based interventions to reduce sexually transmitted infections, including HIV infection
abstract: BACKGROUND: Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) are common in developing countries. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that in 1999 there were 340 million new cases of syphilis, gonorrhea, chlamydial infection and trichomoniasis. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection is also common in developing countries. UNAIDS estimates that more than 95% of the 40 million people infected with HIV in December 1999 live in developing countries (UNAIDS 2003). The STI and HIV epidemics are interdependent. Similar behaviors, such as frequent unprotected sex with different partners, place people at high risk of both infections, and there is clear evidence that conventional STIs increase the likelihood of HIV transmission. Several studies have shown a strong association between ulcerative and non-ulcerative STIs and HIV infection (Cameron 1989, Laga 1993). There is also biological evidence that the presence of an STI increases the spread of HIV and that treatment of STIs reduces the spread of HIV (Cohen 1997, Robinson 1997). Therefore, STI control may have the potential to contribute substantially to HIV prevention. OBJECTIVES: To determine the impact of population-based STI interventions on the prevalence of HIV infection, the prevalence of STIs, and the quality of STI management. SEARCH STRATEGY: The following electronic databases were searched for relevant randomized trials or reviews: 1) MEDLINE for the years 1966 to 2003 using the search terms 'sexually transmitted diseases' and 'human immunodeficiency virus infection'. 2) The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Effectiveness Reviews Abstracts Database and the Cochrane Clinical Trials Register, in the most recent edition of The Cochrane Library 3) The specialized register of trials maintained by the Cochrane Group of Infectious Diseases.4) EMBASE Relevant conference proceedings were searched and lists of all review articles and primary studies were scanned. Finally, authors of included trials and other experts in the field were contacted as appropriate. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized controlled trials in which the randomisation unit is a community or a treatment centre. Studies in which individuals were randomized were excluded. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two reviewers independently applied the inclusion criteria to potential studies and any disagreement was resolved by discussion. Trial reports were checked for completeness. The methodological quality of each trial was assessed by the same two reviewers, with details of the method of randomisation, blinding, use of intention-to-treat analysis, and number of patients lost to follow-up recorded, using the standard guidelines of the Cochrane Infectious Diseases. Group. MAIN RESULTS: Five trials were included. Frequency of HIV infection: In Rakai, after 3 rounds of STI treatment for all community members, the incident HIV infection rate ratio was 0.97 (95% CI 0.81 to 1 .16), indicating that the intervention had no effect. In Mwanza, the incidence of HIV infection in the intervention groups (enhanced syndromic management of STIs in primary care clinics) was 1.2% compared to 1.9% in the control groups (OR = 0 .58, 95% CI: 0.42-0.70), corresponding to a 38% (95% CI: 15% to 55%) reduction in HIV incidence in the intervention group. In the most recent trial by Kamali et al, the ratio of rates of behavioral intervention and STI management compared to HIV incidence control was 1.00 (0.63-1.58, p = 0, 98). These are consistent with the Rakai data showing no effect of the intervention. STI prevalence: In both Mwanza and Rakai, there was no significant reduction in reported gonorrhea, chlamydia, urethritis, or STI symptoms among the intervention communities. The prevalence ratio for syphilis between intervention and control groups in Rakai was 0.8 (95% CI 0.71 to 0.89), for trichmoniasis 0.59 (0.38 to 0.91) and bacterial vaginosis 0.87 (0.74 to 1.02). In Mwanza, the prevalence of serologically diagnosed syphilis in the intervention community was 5% compared to 7% in the control community at the end of the trial (adjusted r7% in the control community at the end of the trial (adjusted relative risk 0.71 (95% CI: 0.54-0.93). In Kamali et al, there was a significant decrease in cases of gonorrhea and active syphilis. The rate ratio for gonorrhea was 0.29 (0. 12-0.71, p=0.016), active syphilis was 0.53 (0.33-0.84, p=0.016).There was a trend to significance with the intervention on condom use with last partner casual"; the rate ratio was 1.27 (1.02-1.56, p = 0.036). Quality of treatment: In Lima, after training pharmacy assistants in the syndromic management of STIs, recognized that symptoms were due to an STI in 65% of standardized simulated patients (SSPs) visiting the intervention and 60% of SSPs visiting pharmacies control (p = 0.35). physician in most cases (83% intervention and 78% control, p=0.61). Of the SSPs that offered medication, only 1.4% of those who visited the intervention pharmacies and only 0.7% of those who visited the control pharmacies (p=0.57) were offered a regimen. recommended. Similarly, in only 15% and 16% of visits to the SSP, respectively, any recommended drug was offered. However, education and counseling were more likely to be provided to SSPs visiting intervention pharmacies (40% vs. 27%, p = 0.01). No SSP was given partner cards or condoms. In Hlabisa, following intervention targeting primary care clinic nurses (strengthened STI syndrome monitoring and provision of STI syndrome packs containing recommended medicines, condoms, membership cards and patient information booklets) , SSPs were more likely to receive recommended medications at intervention clinics (83% vs. 12%, p<0.005) and were more likely to have case management correctly [with the correct medications, partner cards, and condoms] (88% vs. 50%, p<0.005). There were no significant differences in the proportions of adequate counseling (68% vs. 46%, p=0.06), good staff attitude (84% vs. 58%, p=0.07), and private consultation (92% vs. 86%, p=0.4). There was no strong evidence of any impact on treatment seeking behaviour, service utilization or sexual behavior in any of the four trials. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: There is limited evidence from randomized controlled trials for STI control as an effective HIV prevention strategy. Improving STI treatment services has been shown to reduce HIV incidence in a setting characterized by an emerging HIV epidemic (low and slowly rising prevalence), where STI treatment services are poor, and where STIs have a high prevalence. There is no evidence of substantial benefit from treatment for all members of the community. The addition of the Kamali trial to the existing evidence supports the Rakai trial data of no effect. However, there are other compelling reasons why STI treatment services should be strengthened, and the available evidence suggests that when an intervention is accepted, it can substantially improve the quality of services provided. The Kamali trial shows an increase in condom use, a marker of improved risk behaviors. Further community-based randomized controlled trials testing a variety of alternative STI control strategies in a variety of different settings are needed. Such trials should aim to measure a variety of factors including care-seeking behavior and quality of treatment, as well as HIV, STI, and other biological endpoints.

title: Population-based interventions to reduce sexually transmitted infections, including HIV infection
abstract: BACKGROUND: Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) are common in developing countries. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that in 1995 there were 333 million new cases of syphilis, gonorrhea, chlamydial infection and trichomoniasis. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection is also common in developing countries. UNAIDS estimates that more than 90% of the 33 million people infected with HIV in December 1999 live in developing countries (UNAIDS 1999). The STI and HIV epidemics are interdependent. Similar behaviors, such as frequent unprotected sex with different partners, place people at high risk of both infections, and there is clear evidence that conventional STIs increase the likelihood of HIV transmission. Several studies have shown a strong association between ulcerative and non-ulcerative STIs and HIV infection (Cameron 1989, Laga 1993) and there is biological evidence that the presence of an STI increases the spread of HIV and that treatment of STIs reduces the spread of HIV (Cohen 1997, Robinson 1997). Therefore, STI control may have the potential to contribute substantially to HIV prevention. OBJECTIVES: To determine the impact of population-based STI interventions on the prevalence of HIV infection, the prevalence of STIs, and the quality of STI management. SEARCH STRATEGY: The following electronic databases were searched for relevant randomized trials or reviews: 1) MEDLINE from 1966 to present with the search terms sexually transmitted diseases and human immunodeficiency virus infection 2 ) The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Efficacy Reviews Abstract Database and the Cochrane Clinical Trials Register in the most recent issue of the Cochrane Library 3) The specialized register of trials maintained by the Cochrane Infectious Diseases Group . 4) EMBASE Relevant conference proceedings were searched and the reference lists of all review articles and primary studies were checked. Finally, authors of included trials and other experts in the field were contacted as appropriate. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized controlled trials in which the randomisation unit is a community or a treatment centre. Studies in which individuals were randomized were excluded. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two reviewers independently applied the inclusion criteria to potential studies and any disagreement was resolved by discussion. Trial reports were checked for completeness. The same two reviewers assessed the methodological quality of each trial and recorded details of the method of randomisation, blinding, use of intention-to-treat analysis, and number of patients lost to follow-up using the Cochrane Review Group's standard guidelines. Infectious diseases. MAIN RESULTS: Four trials were included. Frequency of HIV infection: In Rakai, after 3 rounds of STI treatment in all community members, the rate ratio of incident HIV infection was 0.97 (95% CI 0.81 to 1 .16), indicating that the intervention had no effect. In Mwanza, the incidence of HIV infection in the intervention groups (enhanced syndromic management of STIs in primary care clinics) was 1.2% compared to 1.9% in the control groups (OR = 0 .58, 95% CI: 0.42-0.70), corresponding to a 38% (95% CI: 15% to 55%) reduction in HIV incidence in the intervention group. STI prevalence: In both Mwanza and Rakai, there was no significant reduction in reported gonorrhea, chlamydia, urethritis, or STI symptoms among the intervention communities. The prevalence ratio for syphilis between intervention and control groups in Rakai was 0.8 (95% CI 0.71 to 0.89), for trichmoniasis 0.59 (0.38 to 0.91) and bacterial vaginosis 0.87 (0.74 to 1.02). In Mwanza, the prevalence of serologically diagnosed syphilis in the intervention community was 5% compared to 7% in the control community at the end of the trial (adjusted relative risk 0.71 (95% CI: 0.54- 0.93) Treatment quality: in Lima , after training pharmacy assistants in the syndromic management of STIs, it was recognized that the symptoms were due to an STI in 65% of simulated standardized patients (SSP) who visited the intervention and in 60% of the SSPs who visited the control pharmacies (p=0.35) referral to a doctor in most cases (83% intervention and 78% control, p=0.61) Of the SSPs who offered medications, only 1.4% who visited intervention pharmacies and only 0.7% of those who visited control pharmacies (p=0.57) were offered a recommended regimen. , in only 15% and 16% of SSP visits, respectively, was any recommended medication offered. , education and counseling were more likely to be provided to SSPs who visited intervention pharmacies (40% vs. 27%, p = 0.01) .No Y SPs received partner cards or condoms. In Hlabisa, following intervention targeting primary care clinic nurses (strengthened STI syndrome monitoring and provision of STI syndrome packs containing recommended medicines, condoms, membership cards and patient information booklets) , SSPs were more likely to receive recommended medications at intervention clinics (83% vs. 12%, p < 0.005) and were more likely to have case management correctly [with the correct medications, partner cards, and condoms] (88% vs. 50%, p < 0.005). There were no significant differences in the proportions of adequate counseling (68% vs. 46%, p=0.06), good staff attitude (84% vs. 58%, p=0.07), and private consultation (92% vs. 86%, p=0.4). There was no strong evidence of any impact on treatment seeking behaviour, service utilization or sexual behavior in any of the four trials. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: There is limited evidence from randomized controlled trials for STI control as an effective HIV prevention strategy. Improving STI treatment services has been shown to reduce HIV incidence in a setting characterized by an emerging HIV epidemic (low and slowly rising prevalence), where STI treatment services are poor, and where STIs have a high prevalence. There is no evidence of substantial benefit from treatment for all members of the community. However, there are other compelling reasons why STI treatment services should be strengthened, and available evidence suggests that when an intervention is accepted, it can substantially improve the quality of services provided. Further community-based randomized controlled trials testing a variety of alternative STI control strategies in a variety of different settings are needed. Such trials should aim to measure a variety of factors including care-seeking behavior and quality of treatment, as well as HIV, STI, and other biological endpoints.

title: Population-level intervention strategies and examples for the prevention of obesity in children
abstract: Since obesity affects an estimated 12.5 million young Americans, population-level interventions are indicated to help support healthy behaviors. The purpose of this review is to provide a summary of population-level intervention strategies and examples of specific interventions that illustrate ways to help prevent and control obesity in children by improving nutrition and physical activity behaviors. Information is summarized within the settings where children live, learn, and play (early care and education, school, community, health care, home). Intervention strategies are activities or changes intended to promote healthy behaviors in children. They were identified from (a) systematic reviews"; (b) recommendations, guidelines or standards based on evidence and consensus of experts from non-governmental or federal agencies"; and finally (c) peer-reviewed synthesis reviews. The intervention examples illustrate how at least one of the strategies was used in a particular setting. To identify examples of interventions, we considered (a) peer-reviewed literature, as well as (b) additional sources with research-proven and practice-based initiatives. Researchers and practitioners can use this review to set priorities and promote integration across settings and to find research- and practice-proven intervention examples that can be replicated in their communities for childhood obesity prevention.

title: Positron emission tomography in gynecological cancer
abstract: Most positron emission tomography (PET) imaging studies in gynecologic cancer are performed with (18)F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG). Contributes valuable information in primary staging of untreated advanced cervical cancer, post-treatment surveillance with unexplained tumor marker (such as squamous cell carcinoma antigen [SCC-Ag]) elevated or suspected of recurrence, and restaging of potentially curable recurrent cervical cancer. Its value in early-stage resectable cervical cancer is questionable. In ovarian cancer, FDG-PET provides benefits for those with stable or rising abnormal serum CA 125 (>35 U/mL), localized recurrence defined by computed tomography and/or magnetic resonance imaging (CT-MRI) feasible for procedures local destructive (such as surgery, radiation therapy, or radiofrequency ablation); and clinical suspicion of recurrent or persistent cancer for which CT-guided biopsy cannot be performed. The role of FDG-PET in endometrial cancer is relatively less well defined due to a lack of data in the literature. In our prospective study, FDG-PET together with MRI-CT may facilitate optimal management of endometrial cancer in well-selected cases. Clinical impact was positive in 29 (48.3%) of 60 scans, 22.2% for primary staging, 73.1% for post-therapy surveillance, and 57.1% post-therapy rescue, respectively. Few studies have been reported on the management of vulvar cancer using FDG-PET. More data is needed. Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is quite unique in biological behavior and clinical management. Our preliminary results suggest that FDG-PET is potentially useful in selected gestational trophoblastic neoplasia by providing accurate metastatic mapping of tumor extent in advance, monitoring response, and locating viable tumors after chemotherapy. Evaluation of a diagnostic tool, such as PET, is usually done by comparing diagnostic performance (sensitivity, specificity, etc.), using a more sophisticated receiver operating curve method, or modified treatment ratio . Evaluation of PET for clinical benefit is specific to the individual tumor and an attractive new end point.

title: Postpartum depression and child development
Postphlebitic syndrome after leg fractures.
Potential of trans fat policies to reduce socioeconomic inequalities in coronary heart disease mortality in England: a cost-effectiveness modeling study.
abstract: OBJECTIVES To determine the health and equity benefits and cost-effectiveness of policies to reduce or eliminate trans-fatty acids from processed foods, compared to consumption maintained at the most recent levels in England. DESIGN Epidemiological modeling study. SETTING Data from the National Diet and Nutrition Survey, Low-Income Diet and Nutrition Survey, Office for National Statistics, and health economic data from other published studies PARTICIPANTS 25-year-old adults, stratified by fifths for socioeconomic circumstance. INTERVENTIONS Total ban on trans fatty acids in processed foods"; enhanced labeling of trans fatty acids; ban on trans fatty acids in restaurants and takeaways. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Coronary heart disease deaths prevented or postponed; years of life gained; years of life quality-adjusted life earned . Policy costs to government and industry;" policy savings from reductions in direct medical care, informal care, and lost productivity. FINDINGS A complete ban on trans-fatty acids in processed foods could prevent or postpone about 7,200 deaths (2.6%) from coronary heart disease between 2015 and 2020 and reduce inequality in mortality from coronary heart disease by about 3,000 deaths (15% ). Policies to improve labeling or simply remove trans fatty acids from restaurants/fast food could save between 1,800 (0.7%) and 3,500 (1.3%) deaths from coronary heart disease and reduce disparities between 600 (3% ) and 1,500 (7%) fatalities, making them half as effective at best. A full ban would have the largest net cost savings of around £265m ($361m, $415m) excluding reformulation costs, or £64m if substantial reformulation costs are incurred outside the regular cycle. CONCLUSIONS A regulatory policy to remove trans fatty acids from processed foods in England would be the most effective and equitable policy option. Intermediate policies would also be beneficial. However, simply continuing to rely on industry to voluntarily reformulate products could have negative health and economic outcomes.

title: Practical clinical trials in psychopharmacology: a systematic review
abstract: Practical clinical trials (PCTs) are randomized experiments under typical practice conditions with the aim of testing the benefits and risks of therapeutic interventions in "real life". Influential PCTs have been performed in cardiology, oncology, and internal medicine. Psychotropic medications are widely and increasingly used in medical practice. This review examines recent progress in conducting PCT in psychopharmacology. We searched the MEDLINE, Scopus, and ClinicalTrials.gov databases from January 2000 to October 2014 for PCT peer-reviewed publications with at least 100 subjects per treatment group. Most PCTs in psychiatry evaluated mental health services or psychosocial interventions rather than specific pharmacotherapies. Of 157 PCTs in psychiatry, 30 (19%) were in psychopharmacology, with a median of 2 publications per year and no increase during the observation period.
