The sample size ranged from 200 to 18,154";" only 11 studies randomized 500 patients or more. Psychopharmacology PCTs were just as likely to be funded by industry as by public agencies. There were 10 PCTs of antidepressants, for a total of 4206 patients (compared with at least 46 PCTs of antihypertensive medications, for a total of 208,014 patients). Some psychopharmacology PCTs used suicidal behavior, treatment discontinuation, or mortality as the primary outcome and produced efficacy and safety data that have influenced both practice guidelines and regulatory decisions. Practical clinical trials can be an important source of information for clinicians, patients, regulators, and policymakers, but have been relatively underutilized in psychopharmacology. Electronic medical records and integrated practice research networks offer promising platforms for more efficient PCT delivery.

title: Practical Implementation of the Coronary Revascularization Cardiac Team
Practice Changes Associated with the Department of Veterans Affairs Family Care Collaborative
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) offers rehabilitation to moderately to severely injured veterans through four regional Polytrauma Rehabilitation Centers (PRCs). To standardize and improve the care provided to family members of these veterans, health services researchers partnered with program leaders and rehabilitation specialists to implement a collaboration to improve the quality of family care. OBJECTIVE: To describe changes in practice associated with the Family Care Collaborative intervention. DESIGN: Cross-site mixed methods evaluation. PARTICIPANTS: Members of the interdisciplinary rehabilitation team (n = 226) who work at the four participating sites. INTERVENTIONS: The collaboration developed and implemented in a 6-month pilot a web-based tool to standardize and promote family-centered care. RESULTS: Survey of Family Care Providers, Satisfaction with Family Care, and Perceived Competence in Working with Families"; Changes in Site-Specific Practices; Provider and Facilitator Perceptions of Collaborative Work"; and a validated measure to predict the probability of success of the selected intervention. MAIN RESULTS: Family-centered practices and satisfaction improved at sites with lower baseline scores (P < 0.05) and were equivalent across sites after the pilot. Providers initiated specific family-centered practices that often started at one site and spread to others through collaboration. Sites standardized family education and collaboration. Providers believed that collaboration produced a "culture shift" from patient-centered to family-centered care and viewed program leadership and involvement of health services researchers as crucial to success. Scores on the measure for predicting successful implementation of the intervention beyond the pilot were promising. CONCLUSIONS: Collaborations that bring together clinicians, program leaders, and researchers can be helpful in fostering complex change involving interdisciplinary teams.

title: Practice Development: Bridging the Gap Between Research and Practice by Appointing a Research Leader
abstract: Research suggests that while most clinicians support the importance of evidence-based practice, without the right culture of support and encouragement, it can be difficult to achieve. This document presents an outline of a method to improve evidence-based practice. It reports on the evaluation of a new type of occupational therapy position, a clinical practice-based research leader, and suggests that the position has the potential to bridge the gap between research and practice. Based on clinician feedback, research results, and impact on practice, the results offer insight into the role of the research leader in contributing to and improving the use of evidence-based practice. It is hoped that these findings may be of benefit to other areas that are considering the strategies and support needed to improve and invest in evidence-based practice.

title: Practice Doesn't Always Make Perfect: A Qualitative Study Explaining Why a Trial of an Educational Toolkit Didn't Improve Quality of Care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Diabetes is a chronic disease commonly managed by family physicians, the most prevalent complication being cardiovascular disease (CVD). Clinical practice guidelines have been developed to support physicians in the care of diabetic patients. We conducted a pragmatic cluster randomized controlled trial (RCT) of a set of printed educational tools aimed at improving cardiovascular disease management in diabetes in primary care, and found no effect and indeed the possibility of some harm. . We conducted a qualitative evaluation to study the guideline implementation strategy used in this trial and to understand its effects. This paper focuses only on the qualitative findings, as the quantitative results of the RCT have already been reported elsewhere. METHODS AND FINDINGS: All family practices in the province of Ontario were randomly assigned to receive the educational toolkit by mail in either summer 2009 (intervention arm) or spring 2010 (control arm). . A subset of 80 GPs (representing approximately 10% of practices randomized and approached, with records of 1592 randomly selected patients with diabetes at high risk of CVD) then participated in a chart audit and related reflective feedback exercise. with their own practice compared to the guideline recommendations. They were asked to complete two forms (one pre-audit and one post-audit) to understand their knowledge of the pre-trial guidelines, their expectations regarding their individual pre-audit performance, and their reflections on the audit results. In addition, individual interviews were conducted with thirteen other family doctors. Verbatim data from interview transcripts and written comments from pre- and post-audit forms were subjected to qualitative descriptive analysis to identify common themes and patterns. The analysis revealed four main themes: impressions of the toolkit, awareness was not the problem, 'it's not me, it's my patients', and graph auditing as a more effective intervention than the toolkit. Participants saw neither the content of the toolkit nor its dissemination strategy as effective, indicating that they perceived themselves as aware of pre-trial guidelines. However, their accounts also indicated that they may be struggling to prioritize CVD management amid competing demands for their attention. Upon receiving the chart audit results, many participants expressed surprise that they had not performed better. They reported that the results of the audit would be an important motivator for behavior change. CONCLUSIONS: The qualitative findings described in this paper offer important insights into why the intervention was not effective. They also demonstrate that physicians have unperceived needs in relation to CVD management and that the medical record audit served to identify deficiencies in their practice of which they had not previously been aware. The findings also indicate that new methods of intervention development and implementation should be explored. This is important given the high prevalence of diabetes worldwide";" Proper management of CVD is essential to address the morbidity and mortality associated with the disease.

title: Practical Feedback Interventions: 15 Tips to Optimize Effectiveness
abstract: Electronic practice data is increasingly being used to provide feedback to encourage practice improvement. However, the evidence suggests that, despite decades of experience, the effects of such interventions vary widely and do not improve over time. Guidance on how to provide more effective feedback exists, but it is distributed across a wide range of disciplines and theoretical perspectives. Through interviews with experts, systematic reviews, etc. and experience in providing, evaluating, and receiving practice feedback, 15 suggestions were identified that are believed to be associated with effective feedback interventions. These suggestions are intended to provide practical guidance to quality improvement professionals, information technology developers, educators, administrators, and practitioners who receive these types of interventions. Designing interventions with these suggestions in mind should enhance their effect, and studying the mechanisms underlying these suggestions will advance a stagnant literature.

title: Practice guidelines developed by specialized societies: the need for a critical evaluation
abstract: Background There is growing concern about the quality, reliability and independence of practice guidelines. Because there is no information available on the methodological quality of the guidelines developed by specialized societies, we conducted a survey of those published in peer-reviewed journals.";" Background There is growing concern about the quality, reliability and independence of practice guidelines. Because there is no information available on the methodological quality of the guidelines developed by specialized societies, we conducted a survey of those published in peer-reviewed journals.

title: Intentions of practicing nurses to use clinical guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence indicates that although nurses are increasingly using clinical guidelines to ensure higher quality care, there is wide variation in compliance. The usefulness of the Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) has not been previously investigated to explain this variation in community nursing. OBJECTIVE: This article reports on a study whose primary objective was to examine the usefulness of TPB in explaining variations in practice nurses' intentions to offer smoking cessation advice according to coronary heart disease guidelines. METHODS: A cross-sectional survey was conducted through a postal questionnaire. A 52-item questionnaire was administered to 48 practicing nurses in England. The questionnaire was designed to assess components of the TPB and included measures of intentions to offer smoking cessation advice, self-reported past behavior, attitudes, subjective norms, perceived behavioral controls (PBC), behavioral beliefs and evaluations, normative beliefs, and motivation. to comply with and control beliefs and evaluations. RESULTS: The TPB explained up to 40% of the variation in intentions to offer advice to stop smoking. Attitudes and PBCs were the most important predictors of intention. Among other elements of the TPB, indirect attitudes and indirect PBCs made significant positive contributions to explain variation in intention. DISCUSSION: Future trials of interventions to increase adherence to clinical guidelines by practicing nurses could attempt to address the elements identified in this study as important factors. Further studies are required to examine the usefulness of the TPB in predicting the behavior of practicing nurses.

title: Practical parameters for the non-pharmacological treatment of chronic insomnia. A report from the American Academy of Sleep Medicine. Practice Standards Committee of the American Academy of Sleep Medicine
abstract: Insomnia is the most common sleep complaint reported to physicians. Treatment has traditionally consisted of medication. Behavioral approaches have been available for decades, but lack of physician knowledge and training, difficulty in obtaining reimbursement, and doubts about efficacy have limited their use. These practice parameters review the current evidence regarding a variety of nonpharmacologic treatments for insomnia. Using a companion article providing a background review, the available literature was reviewed. Evidence was graded according to previously reported criteria from the American Academy of Sleep Medicine with references to the American Psychological Association criteria. Treatments considered include: stimulus control, progressive muscle relaxation, paradoxical intention, biofeedback, sleep restriction, multicomponent cognitive behavioral therapy, sleep hygiene education, imagery training, and cognitive therapy. Improved experimental design has significantly advanced the process of evaluating nonpharmacologic treatments for insomnia using the guidelines outlined by the American Psychological Association (APA). Recommendations for individual therapies using the American Academy of Sleep Medicine recommendation levels for each are: "stimulus control (standard)"; progressive muscle relaxation, paradoxical intention, and biofeedback (guidelines); sleep restriction and behavioral therapy multicomponent cognitive (options);" Sleep hygiene education, imagery training, and cognitive therapy did not have sufficient evidence to recommend them as sole therapy. The optimal duration of treatment, who should perform the treatments, long-term outcomes and safety issues, and the effect of treatment on quality of life are questions that need future research.

title: Practice-level effects of interventions to improve asthma care in primary care settings: the Pediatric Asthma Care Patient Outcomes Research Team.
abstract: Goal. To assess the practice-level effects of (1) a peer medical leader intervention and (2) peer leader in combination with the introduction of asthma education nurses to facilitate improved care. And, to compare the findings with previously reported patient-level outcomes from those enrolled in the trial. study environment. We included data on children aged 5 to 17 years with asthma in 40 primary care practices, affiliated with managed care plans enrolled in the Pediatric Asthma Care Patient Outcomes Research Team (PORT) randomized trial. Study design. Primary care practices were randomly assigned to one of two care improvement arms or to usual care. Automated claims data was analyzed over 12-month periods using a repeated cross-sectional design. The primary outcome was evidence of at least one dispensed controller medication among patients with persistent asthma. Secondary outcomes included controller use among all identified asthmatics, evidence of chronic controller use, and oral steroid use. Health service utilization outcomes included the number of outpatient visits and hospital events. Main findings. The proportion of children with persistent asthma prescribed controllers increased in all study arms. No effect of the interventions was detected on the proportion receiving controllers (peer leader intervention effect 0.01, 95 percent confidence interval [CI] -0.07, 0.08"; intervention effect of planned care -0.03, 95 percent CI: -0.09, 0.02) A statistical trend was observed towards a greater number of bursts of oral corticosteroids administered in the intervention practices Significant adjusted increases were observed in outpatient visits from 0.08 to 0.10 visits per child per year in the first year of intervention, but a statistical trend in these results only persisted in the second year of follow-up.No differences in hospital events were detected. This analysis showed a slight increase in asthma outpatient visits as a result of interventions to improve asthma care, using automated data.The absence of a detectable impact on medication use practice-level cough differs from the positive effect of the intervention observed in patient self-reported data of trial participants. Automated data analysis on non-enrollees aggregates insights into the practice-level impact of care improvement strategies. The benefits of practice-level interventions may accrue disproportionately for the subgroup of trial participants. The effect of such interventions may be less evident at the level of practices or health plans.

title: Preclinical research in Rett syndrome: laying the groundwork for translational success
abstract: As of September 2011, the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS), the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD), the International Rett Syndrome Foundation (IRSF), and the Research Trust of the Rett Syndrome (RSRT) convened a workshop that involved a broad cross-section of basic scientists, clinicians, and representatives from the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the pharmaceutical industry and private foundations to assess the state of the art in animal studies of Rett syndrome (RTT). The goal of the workshop was to identify crucial knowledge gaps and to suggest scientific priorities and best practices for the use of animal models in the preclinical evaluation of potential new RTT therapies. This review summarizes the results of the workshop and the extensive follow-up discussions among participants, and includes: (1) a comprehensive summary of the physiological and behavioral phenotypes of RTT mouse models to date, and the areas in which require further phenotypic analyzes to improve the utility of these models for translational studies"; (2) discussion of the impact of genetic differences between mouse models and methodological differences between laboratories, on the expression and analysis, respectively, of phenotypic traits;" and (3) definitions of standards that the RTT research community can implement for rigorous preclinical study design and transparent reporting to ensure that decisions to initiate expensive clinical trials are based on reliable preclinical data.

title: Precommitting to choose wisely about low-value services: a randomized stepped wedge cluster test.
abstract: Background Little is known about how to discourage physicians from ordering low-value services. Our goal was to test whether clinicians who committed in the future (ie, previously committed) to following Choosing Wisely recommendations with decision support could decrease potentially low-value orders. METHODS: We conducted a 12-month, cluster-randomized, stepped-wedge trial among 45 primary care physicians and advanced practice providers at six adult primary care clinics of a US community group practice, imaging for sore throats. uncomplicated head and unnecessary antibiotics for acute sinusitis. Pre-engaged physicians received 1 to 6 months of point-of-care pre-engagement reminders, as well as patient education brochures and weekly emails with resources to support communication about low-value services. The primary outcome was the difference between the control and intervention period percentages of visits with potentially low value orders. Secondary outcomes were the differences between the percentages of visits with potential alternative orders between the control and intervention periods, and the differences between the percentages of visits with potentially low-value orders between the control period and the subsequent follow-up period. to the 3-month intervention. Results The intervention was not associated with a change in the percentage of visits with potentially low value orders overall, for headaches or acute sinusitis, but was associated with an overall increase of 1.7% in alternate orders (p=0 .01). For low back pain, the intervention was associated with a 1.2% decrease in the percentage of visits with potentially low value orders (p=0.001) and a 1.9% increase in the percentage of visits with alternate orders (p=0.001). p=0.007). No changes were maintained at follow-up. Conclusion Physicians' prior commitment to following the Choosing Wisely recommendations was associated with a small non-sustained decrease in potentially low-value orders for only one of the three specific conditions and may have increased alternative orders.

title: Predicting adherence to medical guidelines: an assessment of motivators and perceived barriers
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although clinical practice guidelines are widely accepted as "best practice," provider compliance remains low. OBJECTIVES: To examine the relationship between providers' behavioral intentions and their adherence to practice guidelines; assess the impact of perceived barriers that most inhibited compliance; and to examine the ability of factors in the Physician Guideline Compliance Model to predict intent to comply and adherence to implemented guidelines at specific practice sites. METHODS: Survey research methods were used to assess the effects of antecedents (attitudes, subjective norms, past behavior, and perceived behavioral control) on providers' intentions to meet and adhere to clinical practice guidelines. Supplier survey I was conducted at the time of guideline introduction and survey II 4 months after implementation. RESULTS: Behavioral history and behavioral intention scores reflected favorable responses toward use of the guidelines. Median self-reported compliance behavior was 65%, while compliance assessed by chart review was 54%. Approximately 68% of the variation in physician behavioral intentions was due to variables included in the Physician Guideline Compliance Model. A significant negative correlation was found between perceived barriers and self-reported behavior, but not between perceived barriers and behavior assessed by chart review. CONCLUSIONS: Some variables, particularly perceived barriers to guideline implementation, predicted a provider's practice intentions and self-reported behavior. Future guideline intervention efforts should identify and reduce these barriers to guideline compliance prior to implementation.

title: Type 2 diabetes risk prediction in England and Wales: prospective derivation and QDScore validation.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To develop and validate a new diabetes risk algorithm (the QDScore) to estimate the 10-year risk of developing type 2 diabetes diagnosed over a 10-year period in an ethnically and socioeconomically diverse population. DESIGN Prospective open-label cohort study using routinely collected data from 355 general practices in England and Wales to develop the score and from 176 separate practices to validate the score. PARTICIPANTS 2,540,753 patients aged 25-79 years in the referral cohort, who contributed 16,436,135 person-years of observation and of whom 78,081 had incident diagnosis of type 2 diabetes"; 1,232,832 patients (7,643,037 person-years -person) in the validation cohort, with 37,535 incident cases of type 2 diabetes. OUTCOME MEASURES A Cox proportional hazards model was used to estimate the effects of risk factors in the derivation cohort and derive an equation of ethnicity, age, gender, body mass index, smoking, family history of diabetes, Townsend deprivation score, treated hypertension, underlying disease were self-assigned in the final model. cardiovascular disease and the current use of corticosteroids;" the outcome of interest was incident diabetes recorded in general practice registers. Calibration and discrimination measures were calculated in the validation cohort. RESULTS There was a four- to five-fold variation in the risk of type 2 diabetes among different ethnic groups. Compared with the white control group, the adjusted hazard ratio was 4.07 (95% confidence interval 3.24 to 5.11) for Bangladeshi women, 4.53 (3.67 to 5.59) for Bangladeshi men, 2.15 (1.84 to 2.52) for Pakistani women, and 2.54 (2.20 to 2.93) for Pakistani men. Pakistani and Bangladeshi men had significantly higher risk rates than Indian men. Black African men and Chinese women were at increased risk compared to the corresponding white reference group. In the validation data set, the model explained 51.53% (95% confidence interval, 50.90 to 52.16) of the variation in women and 48.16% (47.52 to 48, 80) in men. The risk score showed good discrimination, with a D statistic of 2.11 (95% confidence interval 2.08 to 2.14) in women and 1.97 (1.95 to 2.00) in men. The model was well calibrated. CONCLUSIONS The QDScore is the first risk prediction algorithm that estimates 10-year diabetes risk based on a prospective cohort study and includes both social deprivation and ethnicity. The algorithm does not need laboratory tests and can be used in clinical settings and also by the public through a simple web calculator (www.qdscore.org).

title: Hip fracture prediction in older women: a prospective study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the relative importance of osteoporosis of the os calcis, consciousness, and mobility on the risk of posterior hip fracture in elderly women. DESIGN Prospective study of older women in residential care for two years. SETTING 21 private or 38 local authority nursing homes and 4 geriatric hospitals in Doncaster and Hull. SUBJECTS 1414 Outpatient women over 69 years of age, in private or municipal residential care or in geriatric care. Those who had undergone bilateral hip surgery were excluded. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Broadband ultrasonic attenuation (BUA) index, Clifton assessment procedures for the test of old age (for knowledge), and mobility on a six-point scale, and hip fracture in the subsequent two-year period . RESULTS 73 women fractured their hips during the two years. Their mean age was not significantly different from that of women who did not sustain a fracture (85.3 (SD 5.6) vs. 83.9 (6.3)"; p = 0.07), but their BUA index mean (40.3 (19.3) vs. 50.9 (22.2) ) db/MH2), and knowledge score (median 19 (interquartile range 10.5-27.0) v 24 (17- 30)) were significantly lower (both p less than 0.001), these variables had independent associations with hip fracture Women with fractures scored significantly lower on the psychomotor component of the knowledge test (4.5 (1 -8) vs. 7 (2-10), p less than 0.0025 and were significantly more mobile (1(1-3) vs. 3 (1-6), p less than 0.02). according to high, medium and low scores for the BUA index and knowledge tests revealed a high-risk group (118 women) with low BUA index and knowledge score, whose incidence of fracture was 12.8%;" in the group C With the lowest risk (136 women) with a high BUA index and knowledge score, the incidence of fracture was only 1.5% (relative risk 8.4 (95% confidence interval -2.0 to 35.5) . Further analysis showed that those at highest risk were also the most mobile, but that the least mobile women with good knowledge had a low incidence of fractures, regardless of the BUA index (1.2%, high index, vs. 0). .9%, low rate). CONCLUSIONS Elderly women at highest risk for hip fractures were those with a low BUA index, low knowledge test score, and high mobility. Improving bone strength and consciousness in older women may reduce the incidence of hip fracture.

title: Predictors of Colorectal Cancer Screening for Patients Enrolled in a Managed Care Health Plan
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite growing recognition of the importance of colorectal cancer (CRC) screening in reducing cancer mortality, national screening rates are low, indicating a critical need to understand the barriers and remedies for the underuse of CRC detection tests. METHODS: Using results from independent cross-sectional telephone surveys of patients aged ≥50 years conducted before (2000"; n = 498) and after (2003; n = 482) a quality improvement intervention for CRC detection within from a large managed care health plan, trends and predictors of CRC detection with fecal occult blood testing (FOBT) and/or endoscopy (flexible sigmoidoscopy/colonoscopy) were examined from the patient's perspective. RESULTS: In 2000, patient-reported detection rates within guidelines were 38% for any test, 23% for endoscopy, and 22% for FOBT In 2003, detection rates increased to 50% for any test, 39% for endoscopy and 24% for FOBT Discussing CRC with a physician significantly increased the odds of being screened (FOBT: odds ratio [OR], 2.09 [95% confidence interval (95% CI), 1.47 -2.96], endoscopy: OR, 2.33 [95% CI, 1, 67-3.26]; and any test: OR, 2.86 [95% CI, 2.06-3.96]), and reporting barriers for CRC generally reduced the odds of being screened (FOBT: OR, 0 .76 [95% CI, 0.60-0.95]; endoscopy: OR, 0.74 [95% CI, 0.60-0.92]" and any test: OR, 0.66 [CI 95%, 0.54-0.80]. CONCLUSIONS: Although screening rates increased over the 3-year period, evidence of continued underuse of CRC screening was found. CRC were the influence of provider and patient barriers related to CRC detection in general, pointing to the need for multilevel interventions directed at both the provider and the patient.

title: Predictors of fatigue 30 days after completion of adjuvant anthracycline plus taxane chemotherapy for breast cancer
abstract: PURPOSES/OBJECTIVES: To identify predictors of fatigue 30 days after completion of adjuvant chemotherapy for breast cancer and whether differences are observed between a behavioral sleep intervention and a healthy eating attention control group in predicting fatigue. DESIGN: Descriptive, exploratory, secondary analysis of a randomized clinical trial. SETTING: Oncology outpatients in a Midwestern US city SAMPLE: 96 women, ages 29-83 years, 72% married, 95% white, diagnosed with stage I-IIIA breast cancer, receiving chemotherapy adjuvant with anthracyclines and taxanes. METHODS: Participants were randomly assigned to a behavioral sleep intervention group or an attention control group. Participants completed data collection before and during the peak and rebound days of the initial chemotherapy treatment cycle and after the last treatment. MAIN RESEARCH VARIABLES: Fatigue, circadian rhythms of activity, objective and subjective sleep-wake, and objective and subjective activity-rest. FINDINGS: Predictors of fatigue were less total sleep time before treatment, greater fatigue before treatment and at peak, and less energy upon awakening on recovery days. In the control group, the predictors of increased fatigue were greater fatigue before treatment, higher body mass index, greater number of positive lymph nodes, and less daytime dysfunction. For the intervention group, lower maximal activity at the initial treatment peak differentially predicted fatigue. CONCLUSIONS: The results suggest that participants in the sleep intervention group who maintained activity balanced with sleep at the peak of initial treatment benefited more from the intervention. IMPLICATIONS FOR NURSING: Nurses should assess fatigue before initial chemotherapy treatment and at regular intervals, further assess sleep deprivation in patients reporting fatigue of 4 or more (on a scale of 0 to 10), and use guidelines based on on the evidence to select appropriate interventions.

title: Predictors of Provider Recommendation for HPV Vaccine Among Young Adult Men and Women: Findings from a Cross-Sectional Survey
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although physician recommendation is one of the strongest predictors of human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination, it is unclear for whom physicians recommend the vaccine. To help guide intervention efforts, this study investigated predictors of participant-reported medical recommendation for HPV vaccination among young adults in the US. METHODS: Women and men (N=223) ages 18 to The 26-year-old was recruited online through Craigslist, a popular classifieds website. The ads ran in the 25 largest US cities from September 2013 through March 2014. Participants completed a survey that assessed demographic and sociopolitical characteristics, sexual history, HPV vaccination history, and whether had ever received a recommendation for the HPV vaccine from a doctor or health care provider. supplier. RESULTS: 53% reported having received an HPV vaccine recommendation and 45% had received >/= 1 dose of HPV vaccine. Participants who received a recommendation were more than 35 times more likely to receive >/= 1 dose of HPV vaccine compared to participants without a recommendation. Bivariate and multivariate correlates of provider recommendation were identified. Results from the multivariable model indicated that younger white (age 18 to 21), female, with health insurance (ie, employer-sponsored or some other type, such as military-sponsored) participants were more likely to to report that they received a recommendation for the HPV vaccine. CONCLUSIONS: The results suggest that clinician-recommended practices for HPV vaccination vary by patient characteristics. The findings underscore the key role of the health care provider in promoting HPV vaccination and have important implications for future HPV vaccination interventions with young adults.

title: Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis Protocols (PRISMA-P) 2015: Construction and Explanation
abstract: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses protocols allow planning and documentation of review methods, guard against arbitrary decision-making during the conduct of the review, allow readers to assess the presence of selective reporting versus completed reviews, and, when made publicly available, reduce duplication of effort and potentially speed up collaboration. Evidence is accumulating documenting selective reporting and excessive duplication of reviews on the same or similar topics, and many calls have been made in support of the documentation and public availability of review protocols. Several efforts have emerged in recent years to correct these problems, including the development of an international registry for prospective reviews (PROSPERO) and the launch of the first open access journal dedicated to the exclusive publication of systematic review products, including protocols. (BioMed Central Systematic Reviews). Continuing these efforts and based on the PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses) guidelines, an international group of experts has created a guide to improve the transparency, accuracy, completeness, and frequency of documented systematic reviews and meta-analyses. protocols--PRISMA-P (for protocols) 2015. The PRISMA-P checklist contains 17 items that are considered essential and minimum components of a systematic review or meta-analysis protocol. This PRISMA-P 2015 explanation and elaboration document provides readers with a comprehensive understanding and evidence on the need for each element, as well as a model example of an existing published protocol. This document should be read in conjunction with the PRISMA-P 2015 statement. Authors and evaluators of systematic reviews are strongly encouraged to use PRISMA-P when writing and evaluating review protocols.

title: Prescribing habits of general practitioners in choosing an empiric antibiotic regimen for lower respiratory tract infections in adults in Sicily
abstract: The survey was carried out, between September 1995 and May 1996, in order to describe the prescriptive behavior among Sicilian general practitioners (GP) in choosing an empirical antibiotic regimen for LRTI in adult patients and to start an educational process that involves the same doctors in the decisions. with respect to your prescriptions and in compliance with local guidelines. Each physician completed a questionnaire for each therapeutic intervention that ended with the prescription of an antibiotic. The questionnaire also inquired about the characteristics of the patient, diseases to be treated and medication prescription. Physicians were asked to give their opinion on the assessment of the severity of the infectious disease before choosing antibiotic treatment, in order to assess the prescribing behavior of physicians in relation to the patient's symptoms. Of all the Sicilian general practitioners contacted, 76 physicians from 25 Sicilian cities, with a patient population of 96,630, agreed to participate. The doctors used 49 different molecules and six different combinations of two antibiotics. The most used antibacterial agents were cephalosporins (55.0%). Penicillins (11.7%), fluoroquinolones (11.4%), macrolides (10.1%), and combinations of penicillins with beta-lactamase inhibitors (7.9%), together, accounted for 41.1 % of the rest of antibiotic prescriptions. The choice of the route of administration was significantly influenced by the age of the patients, by the symptoms and signs of the disease, and by the presence of concurrent diseases rather than by bacteria suspected of causing the disease. The quite marked variation in the pattern of prescription of antibiotics for LRTI among Sicilian doctors reflects the lack of availability or knowledge of local or national guidelines on the management of these diseases.

title: Prescription data as a tool in pharmacotherapeutic audit (I). General considerations
abstract: This article looks at how prescribing data that is available from pharmacies can be used as a tool to support the improvement of prescribing behaviour. For optimal use of prescription data in pharmacotherapeutic audit, the specific purpose of the audit meeting should be clear. Then, the appropriate measures (quality of drug choice, volume, cost) should be selected for presentation and discussion of the prescription. For various objectives of audit meetings, suggestions for appropriate measures are given. For each stage of behavior change, the article describes why and how prescription data can provide a useful contribution. Finally, recommendations are given on the prerequisites for the optimal use of prescription data. The important factors are that the prescribing data must sufficiently cover the physicians' patient population, information on the extent of repeat prescribing is needed, and prescribing drugs with multiple indications may cause difficulties with graph interpretation. With this information in mind, prescribing feedback can be tailored to the needs of the audit teams and oriented to the intended intervention.

title: Non-occupational post-exposure HIV prophylaxis prescribing by emergency physicians: an analysis of prescription accuracy and adherence.
abstract: We performed a retrospective analysis of data from a prospective nPEP (non-occupational post-exposure prophylaxis) registry based on patients who consulted in an academic emergency department located in Brussels, Belgium. We review here 1,357 cases consulted from January 2011 to December 2013. The aim of the study is to determine whether emergency physicians prescribe nPEP according to national guidance with the support of IDS (infectious disease specialists). As this intervention has a high cost, we wanted to verify the correct allocation of treatment to high-risk patients. In addition, we wanted to determine whether adherence to nPEP when prescribed by an emergency physician differed from reports in the literature. Finally, we wanted to describe the population that consults for nPEP in our center. Emergency physicians prescribed nPEP more frequently in high-risk exposures (98.6%) compared to intermediate-risk exposures (53.2%)";" properly allocate resources from a public health perspective. The appropriateness of the prescription when assessed according to the Belgian nPEP guidelines was 98.8%. Compliance with nPEP prescribed by emergency physicians was 60% in our study. Compliance was highest in MSM (Men who have sex with men), while sexual assault victims showed the lowest compliance. Taken together, this study suggests that emergency physicians can safely and appropriately prescribe nPEP when supported by comprehensive guidance. Recognizing intrinsic differences within heterogeneous populations consulting for nPEP may improve adherence to this high-cost public health intervention.

title: Prescription Omega-3s: An Overview for Nurse Practitioners
abstract: Nurse practitioners (NPs) often take a multidisciplinary approach when treating and educating patients. Collaboration with a registered dietitian is not uncommon when treating patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia (triglycerides [TG] >/= 500 mg/dL). Patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia should be treated and managed to normalize TG levels (TG level <150 mg/dL). Treatment for severe hypertriglyceridemia is usually threefold, including lifestyle changes, diet modification, and drug therapy. Therapeutic lifestyle changes are usually the first step in lowering TG levels. Registered dietitians promote a heart-healthy diet rich in fruits and vegetables. Evidence has been mounting to support the use of eicosapentaenoic acid and docosahexaenoic acid to lower TG. When lifestyle and dietary changes do not effectively reduce TG, NPs will recommend drug therapy as the next step. A viable drug option includes prescription omega-3 fatty acid ethyl esters (P-OM3). Each 4 g/d dose of P-OM3 provides 465 mg of eicosapentaenoic acid and 375 mg of docosahexaenoic acid. Clinical trials show that P-OM3 can lower TG by 45% safely and effectively in patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia. Nurses play an important role in the management of severe hypertriglyceridemia and in educating patients about lifestyle and dietary changes that can have a major impact on patients' health.

title: Treatment of Pressure Ulcers: Clinical Guidelines
abstract: Clinical guidelines, like any intervention, can and should be systematically evaluated. Evaluation is essential as an intervention that appears to improve care may not in practice. Furthermore, the guidelines are based on behavioral change by professionals and failure to do so may undermine potential health benefits. The key areas considered here are the evaluation of the guidelines themselves and the evaluation of their impact on care.

title: Prevalence of a healthy lifestyle among people with cardiovascular disease in high-, middle-, and low-income countries The Prospective Urban Rural Epidemiology (PURE) Study
abstract: Importance Little is known about the adoption of healthy lifestyle behaviors among people with coronary heart disease (CHD) or stroke in communities in a variety of countries around the world. Objective To examine the prevalence of avoiding or quitting smoking, eating a healthy diet and engaging in regular physical activity by people with coronary heart disease or stroke. Design, Setting, and Participants Prospective Urban Rural Epidemiology (PURE) was a large prospective cohort study using an epidemiological survey of 153,996 adults, aged 35 to 70 years, from 628 urban and rural communities in 3 high-income countries (HIC ). ), 7 upper-middle-income countries (UMICs), 3 lower-middle-income countries (LMICs), and 4 low-income countries (LICs), who enrolled between January 2003 and December 2009. Main outcome measures Smoking (current , previous, never), exercise level (low, <600 equivalent metabolic tasks [MET]-min/wk"; moderate, 600-3000 MET-min/wk; high, >3000 MET-min/wk), and diet (classified by the Food Frequency Questionnaire and defined using the Alternative Healthy Eating Index) Results Among 7,519 individuals with self-reported CHD (past event: median, 5.0 [interquartile range {IQR}, 2.0-10.0] years ago) or stroke (past event: median, 4.0 [IQR, 2.0-8.0] years ago), 18.5% (95% CI, 17.6-19.4%) were still smoking; only 35 .1% (95% CI, 29.6%) %-41.0% engaged in a high level of physical activity related to work or leisure, and 39.0% (95% CI, 30.0% -48.7%) had a healthy diet; 14.3 % (95% CI, 11.7%-17.3%) did not engage in any of the 3 healthy lifestyle behaviors, and 4.3% (95% CI, 3.1%-5.8%) had 3. Overall, 52.5% (95% CI, 50.7%-54.3%) quit smoking (by income country classification: 74.9% [95% CI, 71.1% -78.6%] in ICH; 56.5% [95% CI, 53.4%-58.6%] in MICU; 42.6% [95% CI, 39.6%-45.6%] in LMIC and 38.1% [95% CI, 33.1%-43.2%] in LIC). Physical activity levels increased with increasing country income, but this trend was not statistically significant. The lower prevalence of eating healthy diets was recorded in LIC (25.8%; 95% CI, 13.0%-44.8%) compared to LMIC (43.2%; 95% CI, 30.0% -57.4%), UMIC (45.1%, 95% CI, 30.9%-60.1%), and HIC (43.4%, 95% CI, 21.0%-68.7% ).Conclusion and relevance In a sample of CHD or stroke patients from countries with different income levels, the prevalence of healthy lifestyle behaviors was low, with even lower levels in poorer countries.

title: Prevalence of Chlamydia trachomatis infection in women undergoing cervical smear
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the prevalence of sexually transmitted diseases in patients with normal and abnormal cervical smears. DESIGN A prospective study of asymptomatic women with normal cervical smears attending their general practitioner and newly referred patients with abnormal smears attending a colposcopy clinic. SETTING An urban general practice and hospital-based colposcopy clinic (list size 5500) in North West Glasgow. SUBJECTS 197 asymptomatic women who attended their general practitioner for cervical smear tests and 101 randomly selected patients who attended the colposcopy clinic for investigation of abnormal smears. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Presence of various sexually transmitted infections determined by culture and serological tests. RESULTS Of the 101 women with cytologic abnormalities, six had current culture-proven chlamydial infection and none had gonococcal infection";" Of the 197 women with normal smears, 24 (12%) had a chlamydial infection and two had gonorrhea. Serologic studies for Chlamydia trachomatis-specific antibody also indicated that a large proportion of patients had been exposed to this agent in both groups. There was no significant difference between the groups in the prevalence of any of the sexually transmitted diseases studied. CONCLUSION A high prevalence of chlamydial infection is present in women in North West Glasgow, irrespective of their cervical cytological status.

title: Prevalence of Nonpolypoid Colorectal Neoplasms (Flat and Depressed) in Asymptomatic and Symptomatic Adults
abstract: Context Colorectal cancer is the second leading cause of cancer death in the United States. Prevention has focused on the detection and elimination of polypoid neoplasms. Data on the importance of non-polypoid colorectal neoplasms (NP-CRN) are limited. Objectives To determine the prevalence of NP-CRN in a hospital population of veterans and to characterize its association with colorectal cancer. Design, Setting, and Patients Cross-sectional study at a California VA hospital with 1,819 patients undergoing elective colonoscopy from July 2003 to June 2004. Main outcome measures Endoscopic appearance, location, size, histology, and depth of invasion of neoplasms. Results The overall prevalence of NRC-NP was 9.35% (95% confidence interval [95% CI], 8.05%-10.78%"; n = 170). The prevalence of NRC-NP in the subpopulations for screening, surveillance, and symptoms was 5.84% (95% CI, 4.13%-8.00%; n = 36), 15.44% (95% CI, 12.76%-18, 44%; n = 101) and 6.01% (95% CI, 4.17%-8.34%; n = 33), respectively.The overall prevalence of NP-CRN with infiltrating carcinoma in situ or submucosal was 0.82% (95% CI, 0.46%-1.36%; n = 15); in the screening population, the prevalence was 0.32% (95% CI, 0.04%- 1.17%; n = 2).Overall, NP-CRNs were more likely to contain carcinoma (odds ratio, 9.78; 95% CI, 3.93-24.4) than polypoid lesions, regardless Size-adjusted positive association of NP-CRNs with invasive carcinoma in situ or submucosal was also observed in subpopulations for screening (odds ratio, 2.01; 95% CI, 0.27-15.3) and surveillance (odds ratio, 63.7; 95% CI , 9.41-431). The depressed type had the highest risk (33%). Nonpolypoid colorectal neoplasms containing carcinoma were smaller in diameter compared with polypoids (mean [SD] diameter, 15.9 [10.2] mm vs. 19.2 [9.6] mm, respectively). Procedure times did not change appreciably compared to historical controls. Conclusion In this group of veteran patients, NP-CRNs were relatively common lesions diagnosed during routine colonoscopy and had a greater association with carcinoma compared with polypoid neoplasms, regardless of size.

title: Prevalence of war-related mental health conditions and association with displacement status in post-war Jaffna district, Sri Lanka.
abstract: Context Nearly 2.7 million people around the world are internally displaced (seeking refuge in safe areas of their own country) annually by armed conflict. Although the psychological impact of war has been well documented, less is known about the mental health symptoms of forced displacement among IDPs. Objectives To estimate the prevalence of the most common war-related mental health conditions, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms, anxiety and depression, and to assess the association between displacement status and these conditions in the district of Post-war Jaffna, Sri Lanka. Design, setting, and participants Between July and September 2009, a multi-stage cross-sectional cluster survey was conducted among 1,517 households in the Jaffna district, including 2 IDP camps. The response rate was 92% (1448 respondents, 1409 eligible respondents). Two percent of participants (n=80) were currently displaced, 29.5% (n=539) had recently resettled, and 68.5% (n=790) were long-term residents. Bivariate analyzes followed by multivariate logistic regression models were performed to determine the association between displacement status and mental health. Main outcome measures PTSD, anxiety, and depression symptom criteria measured by the Harvard Trauma Questionnaire and the Hopkins Symptom Checklist¨C25. Results Overall prevalences of PTSD, anxiety, and depression symptoms were 7.0% (95% confidence interval [CI], 5.1%-9.7%), 32.6% (95% CI, %, 28.5%-36.9%) and 22.2% (95% CI, 18.2%-26.5%), respectively. Currently displaced participants were more likely to report PTSD symptoms (odds ratio [OR], 2.71"; 95% CI, 1.28-5.73), anxiety (OR, 2.91; 95% CI , 1.89-4.48) and depression (OR, 4.55; 95% CI, 2.47-8.39) compared with long-term residents.Recently resettled residents were more likely to report symptoms of PTSD (OR, 1.96; 95% CI, 1.11-3.47) compared with long-term residents.However, commuting was no longer associated with mental health symptoms after controlling for exposure Conclusion Among residents of the Jaffna district of Sri Lanka, the prevalence of symptoms of war-related mental health conditions was substantially and significantly associated with displacement status and exposure to underlying trauma.

title: Prevention and management of the lack of professionalism in the faculties of medical schools
abstract: Professionalism is a required competency for medical students, residents, practicing physicians, and academic professors. Faculty members must adhere to codes of conduct or risk discipline. The authors describe problems of lack of professionalism that culminate in reports of faculty misconduct or grievances in academic medicine and describe strategies for early intervention and prevention. The authors, vice and associate deans and executive director of the office of faculty affairs at a large US medical school, have handled many complaints of unprofessional conduct over the past decade. They present case examples based on behaviors such as disrespect, inappropriate language and behavior, lack of cooperation with members of the health care team, and sexual harassment/discrimination. They discuss factors that complicate the evaluation of these behaviors, including varying definitions of respect, different cultural norms, and false accusations. The authors make recommendations for prevention and intervention, including early identification, performance management, sexual harassment education, and referrals to professional coaches, anger management classes, and teacher assistance programs.

title: Caries prevention in young children from Bangladeshi immigrant families in New York: perspectives from mothers and pediatricians.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Childhood caries is common in South Asian immigrant families. Few children visit the dentist at 12 months, as current guidelines recommend. The pediatric visit has important potential to link children to preventive care. The aim of this study was to understand the barriers and facilitators to caries prevention in young children from Bangladeshi immigrant families in New York. Qualitative data were collected as a preliminary step in the development of an oral health counseling intervention for South Asian children. BASIC DESIGN: Qualitative interviews on infant feeding and oral health prevention were conducted with mothers from Bangladesh. Qualitative interviews were conducted with pediatricians about their experiences in providing care. Data were analyzed using standard qualitative approaches. SETTING: Pediatric practices serving low-income Bangladeshi immigrants in New York City. PARTICIPANTS: 26 mothers of children 6-24 months receiving services in five pediatric settings and 15 pediatricians providing care in these settings. RESULTS: Both mothers and their pediatricians described unsafe feeding practices, communication problems, and noncompliance. The oral health of young children was a low priority for some mothers. Most, however, were concerned about childhood caries but lacked the skills or resources to reduce caries risk. CONCLUSIONS: The results support our plan to develop an empowerment-based counseling intervention to address caries risk in children. Pediatric dentists should be aware of the barriers to caries prevention in this group.

title: Preventing child abuse and neglect with a nurse home visiting program: the limiting effects of domestic violence
abstract: Context Home visits to families with young children have been promoted as an effective way to prevent child maltreatment, but few studies have examined the conditions under which such programs meet this goal. Objective To investigate whether the presence of domestic violence limits the effects of nurse home visiting interventions in reducing substantiated reports of child abuse and neglect. Design Fifteen-year follow-up study of a randomized trial. Setting Semi-rural community in upstate New York. Participants Of 400 socially disadvantaged pregnant women with no previous live births consecutively enrolled between April 1978 and September 1980, 324 mothers and their infants participated in the follow-up study. Interventions Families were randomized to receive routine perinatal care (control group; n = 184 participated in follow-up), routine care plus nursing home visits during pregnancy only (n = 100), or routine care plus home visits by nurses during pregnancy and up to the child's second birthday (n = 116). Main outcome measures Number of substantiated reports over the entire 15-year period involving the study child as the subject regardless of the identity of the perpetrator or involving the mother as the perpetrator regardless of the identity of the child extracted from state records and analyzed by treatment group and level of domestic violence in the home as measured by the Conflict Tactics Scale. Results Families receiving home visits during pregnancy and childhood had significantly fewer reports of child maltreatment involving the mother as the perpetrator (P = 0.01) or the study child as the subject (P = 0.04) than those families who did not receive home visits. The number of reports of abuse from mothers who received home visits during pregnancy did not differ from the control group. For mothers who received visits up to the child's second birthday, the treatment effect decreased as the level of domestic violence increased. Of women who reported 28 or fewer incidents of domestic violence (79% of the sample), mothers who visited the home had significantly fewer reports of child maltreatment over the 15-year period than mothers who did not receive the longer intervention term (P = 0.01). However, this intervention did not significantly reduce child maltreatment among mothers who reported more than 28 incidents of domestic violence (21% of the sample). Conclusions The presence of domestic violence may limit the effectiveness of interventions to reduce the incidence of child abuse and neglect.

title: Prevention of coronary heart disease and stroke with aggressive statin therapy in older adults using a team management model
abstract: PURPOSES: The purposes of this review were to highlight the results of recent clinical trials on the safety and efficacy of statin therapy in adults aged 65 years and older and to examine how nurse practitioners (NPs) and physician assistants (PAs) work together with physicians as a team, they can better serve the needs of this fastest growing subset of the US population that is at high risk for cardiovascular events, including stroke. DATA SOURCES: This report was compiled by reviewing the scientific literature on the safety and efficacy of statin therapy, including effects on cardiovascular, coronary, and stroke endpoints, with particular reference to the results of clinical trials in older patients. CONCLUSIONS: Recent guidelines emphasize that age alone is not a reason to discontinue statin therapy in older adults. However, despite the evidence highlighted in this review showing that older patients can safely achieve substantial benefit from statin therapy, studies have consistently shown an inverse relationship between age and treatment propensity. Older patients often have multiple risk factors and many chronic comorbid conditions that appear to complicate and hinder treatment in many busy clinical practices. Broader guidelines for the use of statin therapy in older patients, incorporating recommendations for treatment goals and developing a framework for the use of statins in stroke prevention, would assist care providers in managing this high-risk population. Finally, both NPs and PAs are well educated and well placed to manage patients with stable chronic cardiovascular disease (CVD). IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: Implementing a multidisciplinary team approach to identify people at risk and provide them with education, counseling, and effective statin therapy will help reduce the increased risk of CVD-associated morbidity and mortality in older adults.

title: Prevention of depression in adolescents at risk: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Context Adolescent children of depressed parents are at a markedly increased risk of developing depressive disorders. Although some smaller targeted prevention trials have found that depression risk can be reduced, these results have yet to be replicated and extended to large-scale at-risk populations in different settings. Objective To determine the effects of a group cognitive behavioral (CB) prevention program compared to usual care in preventing the onset of depression. Design, Setting, and Participants A multicenter randomized controlled trial conducted in 4 US cities that enrolled 316 adolescent children (ages 13 to 17 years) of parents with current or prior depressive disorders from August 2003 to February 2006. Adolescents had a history of depression, elevated but underdiagnosed current depressive symptoms, or both. Assessments were performed at baseline, after the 8-week intervention, and after the 6-month continuation phase. Intervention Adolescents were randomly assigned to the CB prevention program consisting of 8 weekly 90-minute group sessions followed by 6 monthly follow-up sessions or assigned to receive usual care only. Main outcome measure Rate and hazard ratio (HR) of a probable or definite depressive episode (ie depressive symptom rating score of 4) for at least 2 weeks as diagnosed by clinical interviewers. Results Through the post-continuation follow-up session, the rate and HR of incident depressive episodes were lower for those in the CB prevention program than for those in usual care (21.4% vs. 32.7%"; HR, 0.63; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.40-0.98). Adolescents in the CB prevention program also showed significantly greater improvement in self-reported depressive symptoms than those in usual care (ratio, ?1.1; z = ?2.2; P = .03).Parents' current depression in moderate intervention effects at baseline (HR, 5.98; 95% CI %, 2.29-15.58; P = .001) Among adolescents whose parents were not depressed at baseline, the CB prevention program was more effective in preventing the onset of depression than usual care (11, 7% vs 40.5%; HR, 0.24; 95% CI, 0.11-0.50), while for adolescents with a currently parent depressed, the CB prevention program was no more effective than usual care in preventing incidents of depression (31.2% vs 24.3%; HR, 1.43; 95% CI, 0.76-2.67). Conclusion The CB prevention program had a significant preventive effect during the 9-month follow-up period based on both clinical and clinical diagnoses. self-reported depressive symptoms, but this effect was not apparent for adolescents with a currently depressed parent.

title: Prevention of Falls in Older Adults Living in the Community: US Preventive Services Task Force Recommendation Statement.
abstract: DESCRIPTION: Update to the 1996 US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) Statement of Recommendations on Counseling to Prevent Home and Recreational Injuries, Including Falls. METHODS: The USPSTF reviewed new evidence on the effectiveness and harms of primary care-relevant interventions to prevent falls in community-dwelling older adults. Interventions were grouped into 5 main categories: multifactorial clinical assessment (with or without direct intervention), clinical management (with or without screening), clinical education or behavioral counseling, home risk modification, and exercise or physical therapy. RECOMMENDATIONS: The USPSTF recommends exercise or physical therapy and vitamin D supplementation to prevent falls in adults 65 years of age or older who live in the community and who are at increased risk of falls. (Grade B Recommendation) The USPSTF does not recommend automatically performing a thorough multifactorial risk assessment in conjunction with comprehensive management of identified risks to prevent falls in community-dwelling adults aged 65 years and older because the probability of benefit is small. In determining whether this service is appropriate in individual cases, patients and physicians should consider the balance of benefits and harms based on the circumstances of prior falls, comorbid medical conditions, and patient values. (Recommendation grade C).

title: Recommended Preventive Care (PCA)/Recommended Operative Care (OCA): Caries Categorization by Treatment Option
abstract: Currently, clinicians, epidemiologists, and clinical research workers use a variety of systems and classifications to subdivide carious lesions into different grades. These systems are based on the depth of the lesion and/or the presence/absence of macroscopic cavitation. In order to improve the meaning and comparability of such systems in light of increased knowledge about the disease process, lesion behavior, and caries treatment options, the authors propose a new categorization system that difference between injuries that normally require surgical intervention and those that do not. In the future, it is proposed that, in addition to existing conventional criteria, diagnostic systems should also allow results to be expressed in terms of 1) lesions for which appropriate non-invasive preventive care is recommended (PCA lesions) and 2) lesions for which surgical intervention is required. Care is advised (OCA lesions). Locally acceptable subdivisions may need to be developed and agreed upon for specific applications. The adoption of this nomenclature and additional focus in the future should help communication between the different groups involved in caries diagnosis and research. It can facilitate the dissemination of research results, as well as help "push" researchers working on caries diagnostic methods to focus on techniques that will aid in the accurate assessment of lesion activity and behavior. Such an approach should also increase our understanding of treatment decision making and promote the development of clinical guidelines. The possibility of keeping existing criteria in parallel, for local and other purposes, would preserve comparability with previously collected data.

title: Preventive evidence in practice (PEP) study: implementation of guidelines to prevent primary vascular disease in the general practice protocol for a cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: There are significant gaps in the implementation and uptake of evidence-based guideline recommendations for cardiovascular disease (CVD) and diabetes in Australian general practice. This study protocol describes the methodology for a cluster randomized trial to assess the effectiveness of a model that aims to improve the implementation of these guidelines in Australian general practice developed by a collaboration between researchers, non-governmental organizations and the profession. METHODS: We hypothesize that the intervention will alter the behavior of physicians and patients, resulting in improvements in recording of lifestyle and physiological risk factors (by 20%) and greater adherence to guidelines. guideline recommendations for: managing CVD and diabetes risk factors (by 20%). %)"; and lifestyle and physiological risk factors of patients at risk (by 5%). Thirty-two general practices will be randomized in a 1:1 allocation to receive the intervention or continue with usual care, after stratification by state. The intervention will be delivered through: education in small groups; auditing of patient records to determine preventive care;" and internship facilitation visits adapted to the needs of the internship. Outcome data will be extracted from electronic medical records and patient questionnaires, and qualitative assessment from interviews with providers and patients. DISCUSSION: We plan to disseminate the study findings widely and directly inform implementation strategies by governments, professional bodies, and non-governmental organizations, including partner organizations.

title: Preventive interventions for postpartum psychosis
abstract: BACKGROUND: Postpartum psychosis is a life-threatening condition worldwide, affecting one to two in 1000 new mothers. It has an abrupt onset within a month of delivery. Affected new mothers rapidly develop frank psychosis, cognitive impairment, and disorganized behaviors. Factors that increase the risk of postnatal psychosis include first-time mothers who are single, women who are older or have a psychiatric history, and a family history of affective psychosis, antenatal depression, and autoimmune thyroid dysfunction. The risk of a future postnatal recurrence is 25% to 57%. Preventive interventions for postpartum psychosis aim to identify women with risk factors, early recognition of impending psychosis through screening, and preventive drug therapy. Mood stabilizers, antipsychotic drugs, and hormone therapy may be beneficial in preventing postnatal psychotic episodes in women at risk. OBJECTIVES: To investigate the best available evidence for interventions to prevent postnatal psychosis. SEARCH METHODS: We searched the Cochrane Schizophrenia Group Trials Register and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL) in October 2012 using the Cochrane Schizophrenia Group search strategy. . SELECTION CRITERIA: All relevant randomized controlled trials for the prevention of postnatal psychosis. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two reviewers inspected all citations to ensure reliable selection. If relevant trials were included, we planned to assess the methodological quality of identified trials using the criteria recommended in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions. Two reviewers would have independently extracted data. For homogeneous dichotomous data, we planned to calculate relative risk (RR), 95% confidence interval (CI), and number needed to treat for benefit/harm (NNTB/NNTH) by intention to treat. MAIN RESULTS: There are no studies included in this review. The electronic search produced three relevant references, including two old planned trials that appear never to have started, and one from which a study was excluded because it was a case series report. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: This is not an empty review, it is a review full of unanswered questions. Despite the growing interest in women's mental health, the literature in the area of postpartum psychosis is still very limited. It appears that physicians have no choice but to continue their current practices guided solely by varied clinical judgment. Women at risk for postpartum psychosis and their families are justified in being disappointed in the medical/research fraternity. A post hoc search of PubMed (not specific to methodology) identified mainly case series. Policymakers have no trial-based evidence on which to base their guidelines. Certainly, preventive interventions for postnatal psychosis are difficult to justify with confidence without well-designed, well-conducted, and well-reported randomized studies. Available literature suggests that such studies are possible and research funders may wish to make this work a priority.

title: Adherence of Primary Care Physicians to Chronic Musculoskeletal Pain Management Guidelines: Study Results of the Effectiveness of a Collaborative Pain Approach
abstract: OBJECTIVE: We evaluated guideline-concordant care provided by the primary care physician as documented in patients' medical records, predictors of documented guideline-concordant care, and its association with pain-related functioning. The patients were participants in a randomized trial of collaborative care for chronic musculoskeletal pain. The intervention included patient and primary care physician education, symptom monitoring, and feedback to physicians by the intervention team. METHODS: To assess concordance with the evidence-based treatment guidelines on which our intervention was based, we developed an 8-item chart review tool, the Pain Process Checklist (PPC). We then reviewed the electronic medical records of 365 veteran patients treated by 42 primary care physicians over 12 months. Intervention status, demographic and clinical variables were tested as predictors of PPC scores using generalized estimating equations (GEE). GEE was also used to test whether PPC scores predicted treatment response (>/= 30% decrease in Roland-Morris Disability Questionnaire score). RESULTS: Rates of documented guideline-concordant care varied widely across PPC items, from 94% of patients with addressed pain to 17% of opioid patients who addressed side effects. Intervention status was not related to item scores, and PPC-7 totals did not differ significantly between intervention and treatment-as-usual patients (61.2%, standard error [SE] = 3.3% vs. 55.2%, SE = 2.6%, P = 0.15). In a multivariate model, higher PPC-7 scores were associated with receiving an opioid prescription (odds ratio [OR] = 1.07, P = 0.007) and lower PPC-7 scores with patient age ( 10-year difference OR = 0.97, P = 0.004). Finally, intervention patients who received quantitative assessments of pain and depression were less likely to respond to treatment (assessed vs. not assessed: 18% vs. 33%, P = 0.008 and 13% vs. 28%, P = 0.001 , respectively). CONCLUSIONS: As measured by review of medical records, additional training and physician feedback did not increase the provision of documented guideline-consistent pain care, and guideline adherence by primary care physicians did not. improved clinical outcomes for patients with chronic musculoskeletal pain.

title: Experiences of primary care physicians prescribing HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis at a specialized community health center in Boston: lessons from early adopters
abstract: INTRODUCTION: An estimated 1.2 million Americans have indications to use antiretroviral pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) to prevent HIV acquisition. For many of these people at risk, the best opportunity to learn about and receive PrEP will be during routine visits to their primary care general practitioners. However, few general practitioners have prescribed PrEP, mainly due to practical concerns about PrEP delivery in primary care settings. The experiences of specialist primary care physicians who have prescribed PrEP may inform the feasibility of PrEP provision by general practitioners. METHODS: During January to February 2015, 35 primary care physicians at a community health center in Boston specializing in the care of sexual and gender minorities completed anonymous surveys about their experiences and practices with PrEP provision. The responses were analyzed with descriptive statistics. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION: Thirty-two physicians (response rate=91%) completed the surveys. Nearly all physicians (97%) had prescribed PrEP (median 20 patients, interquartile range 11-33). Most physicians reported testing and counseling practices for risk reduction consistent with US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention guidelines for PrEP. Physicians indicated that patients using PrEP experienced drug toxicities infrequently and generally reported high adherence. However, some clinicians' practices differed from guideline recommendations, and some clinicians observed patients with higher-risk behaviors. Most clinicians (79%) rated PrEP provision as easy to achieve, and 97% felt likely to prescribe PrEP in the future. CONCLUSIONS: In an experienced primary care clinic specializing in HIV prevention, clinicians perceived provision of PrEP to large numbers of patients to be safe, feasible, and potentially effective. Efforts to engage primary care general practitioners in PrEP provision could facilitate scaling up this effective intervention.

title: Primary care consultation practice guidelines: the effectiveness of computerized versus paper-based versions. A cluster randomized controlled trial among newly qualified primary care physicians.
abstract: Objective: To compare the effects of the computerized and paper versions of the guidelines on the consulting practices of newly qualified physicians. Methods: Two-arm cluster randomized controlled trial. Physicians were randomly assigned to receive computerized or textbook-based versions of the same guidelines over a 4-week study period. Physician adherence to guideline recommendations for laboratory, radiological, physical, and other examinations, procedures, nonpharmacological and pharmacological treatments, physical therapy, and referrals was measured by review of case notes. Results: A total of 139 newly qualified physicians working in 96 primary health care centers in Finland participated in the study. Data from 4,633 patient encounters were abstracted, of which 3,484 were suitable for further analysis. Physician adherence to guidelines was high (over 80% for laboratory use, radiology, physical exams, and referrals). There were no significant differences in physician consultation practices for any of the outcomes measured between the computerized and textbook groups. Conclusion: The guidelines are a useful source of information for newly qualified physicians working in primary care. However, the method of presentation of the guidelines (electronic or paper) has no effect on the use of the guidelines or their impact on decisions. When choosing the guideline presentation method, other factors should be considered, such as information search time, ease of use during consultation, updateability, production costs, and clinician preferences.

title: Response of primary care physicians to the dissemination of practice guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: Much effort has been put into producing clinical practice guidelines, but relatively few studies address dissemination issues. Unless guidelines are used, little is gained. This study assesses the effect of three methods of disseminating asthma guidelines on physician behavior and attitudes toward educational strategies. METHODS: Asthma guidelines were mailed to 60 physicians at three Area Health Education Centers in Arkansas. Outreach efforts on one site included a brief summary, phone calls from "retail" physicians, and a continuing medical education conference. The second site used computer strategies and the third site used a multimedia approach with fax messages, posters, videotapes, audiotapes, and a continuing medical education conference. A fourth site with 22 participants served as a comparison. Data were collected through mailed questionnaires, reviews of outpatient medical records, and interviews with physicians. Changes between baseline and post-test assessments after a 4-month intervention for medication use were calculated, and use of peak flow monitoring was compared with the control group (general linear model). Regression analyzes were used to identify medical and practice factors associated with particular educational techniques. RESULTS: Each site improved in medication use or peak flow monitoring, but none improved in all areas. The continuous reminder multimedia approach was well accepted, but there was little support for the computer strategies. CONCLUSIONS: Further efforts to disseminate clinical guidelines should include a variety of formats with an emphasis on short, concise summaries and frequent reminders. Social influence appears to play a role and will be a fruitful area for future research.

title: Use of lumbar spine imaging by primary care physicians: effects of guidelines and practice pattern feedback
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To reduce variability in the use of procedures by primary care physicians to image the lumbar spine. DESIGN: Controlled intervention using clinical practice guideline and practice pattern feedback. STUDY SAMPLE: Sixty-seven internists and 28 family physicians in a large group model HMO. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN OUTCOMES: Physicians in the intervention group received the clinical practice guideline for low back pain, followed after 4 months by three bimonthly feedback reports on their current rates of use of lumbar spine radiography and computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging. MRI of the lumbar spine. . Physicians in the control group received neither the guide nor the feedback reports. Automated radiology utilization data were used to compare changes in utilization rates and variability in utilization rates for clinicians in the intervention and control groups over the course of the study period. Neither regimen alone nor regimen plus feedback was associated with a significant decrease in rates of use or variability in rates of use of the study lumbar spine imaging procedures. CONCLUSIONS: Clinical practice guidelines and practice pattern feedback fail to achieve their goals when characteristics of the practice environment and patient expectations and behavior are not identified and addressed.

title: Primary care provider attitudes are associated with smoking cessation counseling and referral
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Most primary care providers (PCPs) support the importance of quitting smoking, but counseling rates are low. We assessed the consistency of PCP attitudes toward smoking cessation counseling and corresponding cessation behaviors. DESIGN: This was a post-intervention analysis of a population-based sample from a cluster randomized controlled trial to improve adherence to smoking cessation guidelines. SETTING: A total of 18 VA sites in the southwestern and western United States participated. PARTICIPANTS: A total of 280 PCPs completed a survey 12 months after implementation of a quality improvement (QI) program for smoking cessation. Their patients also completed 12 (n = 1080) and 18 month (n = 924) follow-up surveys. INTERVENTION: The quality improvement intervention included setting local priorities, developing, implementing, and monitoring the quality improvement plan. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: PCPs at intervention sites were more likely to advise patients on how to quit smoking (P = 0.04) but not to refer. PCP attitude toward smoking cessation counseling was strongly associated with informed counseling (P < 0.001) and with referral (P = 0.01).
