Other associations with counseling were the perceived barrier "patients are not interested in quitting" (P = 0.01) and fewer years in practice (P = 0.03)";" other associations with referral were specialty consultation (P < 0.0001) and the perceived barrier "inconvenient referral" (P = 0.001) (negative association). PCP attitudes were associated with higher rates of counseling, referral, and program attendance. CONCLUSIONS: PCPs, regardless of intervention participation, had attitudes consistent with their reported smoking cessation behaviors, and more favorable attitudes were associated with higher rates of patient-reported smoking cessation behavior. The findings suggest that PCPs who support cessation counseling and referral may provide more treatment recommendations and have higher rates of smoking cessation.

title: Smoking cessation interventions provided by primary care providers and smoking cessation among participants in the National Lung Screening Trial.
abstract: SIGNIFICANCE: The National Lung Screening Trial (NLST) found a reduction in lung cancer mortality among participants screened with low-dose computed tomography compared with chest radiography. In February 2015, Medicare announced its decision to cover annual pulmonary screening for patients with a significant history of smoking. These guidelines promote smoking cessation therapy as an adjunct to screening, but the frequency and effectiveness of clinician-provided smoking cessation interventions after lung screening is unknown. OBJECTIVE: To determine the association between the reported clinician-provided 5 A's (ask, counsel, assess, assist [discuss smoking cessation or recommend smoking cessation medications or recommend counselling] and arrange follow-up) after lung screening and changes in smoking behavior. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: A matched case-control study (cases were quitters and controls were continuing smokers) of 3336 NLST participants who were current smokers at enrollment examined rates and patterns of participants' 5A administration after lung screening and reported smoking cessation behaviors. . MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES: Prevalence of physician-provided 5As and associated smoking cessation after pulmonary screening. RESULTS: Delivery of the 5A 1 year after screening was as follows: ask, 77.2%; advise, 75.6%; evaluate, 63.4%; help, 56.4%; and organizing follow-up, 10.4%. and assess was not significantly associated with smoking cessation in multivariate models that were adjusted for sociodemographic characteristics, medical history, screening results, nicotine dependence, and motivation to quit. 95% CI, 1.21-1.63), and organizing was associated with a 46% increased odds of quitting (odds ratio, 1.46; 95% CI, 1.19-1.79) . CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Attending and arranging follow-up by primary care providers for smokers participating in the NLST were associated with increased smoking cessation; "less intensive interventions (ask, counsel, and assess) did not were.However, rates of attendance and organization of follow-up were relatively low.Our findings confirm the need and benefit of clinicians taking more active interventional measures to help screened patients quit of smoking.

title: Responsiveness of Primary Care Providers to Health Risk Behaviors Reported by Adolescent Patients
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the responsiveness of physicians to health risk behaviors reported by adolescent patients during a comprehensive clinical preventive services visit. DESIGN: Nonprobabilistic sample of adolescent patients scheduled for a routine physical examination. SETTING: Seven clinical centers in the Chicago, Ill. area. PARTICIPANTS: Fifteen primary care providers and 95 adolescent patients between the ages of 11 and 18. INTERVENTION: Providers delivered comprehensive clinical preventive services to adolescent patients using the Guidelines for Adolescent Preventive Services model. This model includes screening, counseling, a physical exam, and immunizations. Prior to the visit, adolescent patients completed a screening questionnaire that included a 52-item health risk behavior profile. The answers to the selection questionnaire were discussed during the visit. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Each provider's responsiveness to reported health risk behaviors was determined by comparing the adolescent patient's responses on the screening questionnaire with those reported during a debriefing interview with the adolescent about whether specific topics were discussed . Responsiveness to highly sensitive behaviors was determined by comparing the screening questionnaire and medical history. RESULTS: On average, each adolescent patient reported 10 risk behaviors, of which 7 were discussed. Severity of reported risk behavior, number of reported biological health problems, and gender of the adolescent patient were significant predictors of provider responsiveness. The number of reported health risk behaviors, length of visit, professional role and gender of the provider, whether the adolescent was a new patient, and the age of the adolescent patient were not related to responsiveness. CONCLUSIONS: Providers addressed most reported health risk behaviors during a single visit, but responsiveness decreased when 3 or more biological health problems or relatively serious problems were reported. Steps can be taken to increase the responsiveness of providers.

title: Primary care, generalism, public good: déjà vu? Again!
Primary care-based multifaceted interdisciplinary medical educational intervention for patients with systolic heart failure: lessons learned from a cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Chronic (systolic) heart failure (CHF) is a common and disabling condition. Adherence to evidence-based guidelines in primary care has been shown to improve health outcomes. The aim was to explore the impact of a multidisciplinary educational intervention for general practitioners (GPs) (Train the Trainers = TTT) on patient and performance outcomes. METHODS: This paper presents the key findings of the trial and discusses the lessons learned during the implementation of the TTT trial. Primary care practices were randomized to the TTT intervention or control group. Thirty-seven GPs (18 TTT, 19 control) were randomized and 168 patients diagnosed with proven congestive heart failure (91 TTT, 77 control) were enrolled. GPs in the intervention group attended four meetings that addressed clinical practice guidelines and pharmacotherapy feedback. The primary outcome was patient self-reported quality of life at seven months, using the SF-36 physical functioning scale. Secondary outcomes included other SF-36 scales, the Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire (KCCQ), total mortality, hospital admissions for heart failure, prescription, depressive disorders (PHQ-9), behavior change (European Self-Care Behavior Scale of heart failure), patient-perceived quality of care (EUROPEP), and improvement of heart failure using NT-proBNP levels. Because recruitment targets were not achieved, an exploratory analysis was performed. RESULTS: There was high initial achievement in both groups for many outcomes. At seven months, there was no significant mean difference between groups for the primary outcome measure (-3.3, 95% CI -9.7 to 3.1, p = 0.30). The only difference in secondary outcomes was related to the prescription of aldosterone antagonists by physicians in the intervention group, with significant differences between groups at follow-up (42% vs. 24%, adjusted OR = 4.0 , 95% CI 1.2-13";" p = 0.02). CONCLUSION: The intervention did not change the primary outcome or most of the secondary outcomes. Recruitment targets were not achieved and insufficient recruitment of practices and patients coupled with selection bias of participating physicians preclude definitive conclusions, but the CI indicates a lack of intervention effectiveness in this sample. We describe the lessons learned from conducting the trial for future planning and conducting confirmatory trials in primary care. TEST REGISTRATION: ISRCTN08601529.

title: Interventions for smoking in primary care
abstract: The primary care setting is an important place to promote smoking cessation. Randomized clinical trials (RCTs) testing the effect of brief smoking interventions and comprehensive programs delivered in a primary care setting present excellent evidence that such interventions significantly increase patients' smoking cessation rates and that, as the dose of the intervention increases, the effect increases. Unfortunately, despite widespread dissemination of preventive service guidelines and positive physician attitudes toward such services, the current level of physician smoking cessation intervention in real-world settings is not high, which makes this an important research and public health issue. Interventions to increase the rate of implementation of provider-delivered brief tobacco dependence interventions can be broadly grouped into: provider education; clinical systems and procedures (eg, patient screening and follow-up);" and organizational policy (eg, reimbursement, coverage, performance measures). Given the significant effect that primary care-based interventions can have on the smoking cessation, it is important to investigate methods to increase its delivery rate and effect Examples of research to motivate intervention questions include: what are the best incentives or combination of incentives for clinicians? to remind providers to intervene? How can each of these be best implemented in different types of settings and systems? How can a matched model of stepped care and patient treatment be used? Studying factors such as reimbursement policies and covered benefits does not lend itself well to strictly controlled randomized trials. necessitates the use of quasi-experimental designs and the application of qualitative strategies. These designs represent a different challenge for the research community.

title: Primary Coronary Intervention (PCI) within the myocardial infarction network system in a German city (Essen)
abstract: In a German city (Essen, 490,000 inhabitants), a new network system for patients with ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) was established in 2004. This included the so-called integrated care model (model IV) with the participation of insurance companies. In a cooperative structure between invasive and non-invasive hospitals, general practitioners and cardiologists, as well as emergency systems, all STEMI patients could be treated by primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) as soon as possible according to current guidelines . Patient characteristics (age, sex, comorbidity, medication) were comparable to other trials and registries. The primary success rate was high (96.4%). Acute hospital outcomes demonstrated low mortality (7.6%). The delay time periods were comparable to other records. The symptom-balloon time was 239 min, medical contact-balloon 95 min, door-balloon 60 min, and puncture-balloon 18 min (median values). The STEMI network system in Essen demonstrates the possibility of modern therapy in patients with myocardial infarction (primary PCI) in a cooperative modality between all participants in the health care system.

title: Primary prevention of type 2 diabetes mellitus and cardiovascular diseases through a cognitive behavioral program aimed at lifestyle changes in people at risk: Design of a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: The number of people with cardiovascular disease (CVD) and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) is growing rapidly. To a large extent, this increase is due to lifestyle risk factors such as being overweight, reduced physical activity and an unhealthy diet. Changing these risk factors has the potential to postpone or prevent the development of T2DM and CVD. It is hypothesized that a cognitive behavioral program (CBP), focused in particular on motivation and self-control in people at high risk of CVD and/or T2DM, will improve their lifestyle behavior and, as a result, reduce their risk. . of developing DM2 and CVD. METHODS: 12,000 inhabitants, aged 30 to 50 years living in various municipalities in the semi-rural region of West-Friesland, will receive an invitation from their general practitioner (n = 13) to measure their own waist circumference with a tape measure. Persons with abdominal obesity (male waist >/= 102 cm, female waist > or= 88 cm) will be invited to participate in the second step of screening that includes blood pressure, a blood sample, and anthropometric measurements. DM2 and CVD risk scores will be calculated according to the ARIC and SCORE formulas, respectively. People with a score indicating a high risk of developing DM2 and/or CVD will be randomly assigned to the intervention group (n = 300) or the control group (n = 300). Participants in the intervention group will follow a PFC aimed at modifying their eating behavior, physical activity and smoking behavior. The counseling methods to be used are motivational interviewing (MI) and problem-solving treatment (PST), which focus in particular on participants' intrinsic motivation to change and self-management of problems. CBP will be provided by nurse practitioners trained in the participant's general practice, and will consist of a maximum of six 30-minute individual sessions, followed by 3-month booster sessions over the phone. Control group participants will receive brochures containing health guidelines on physical activity and diet, and how to quit smoking. The primary outcome measures will be changes in T2DM and CVD risk scores. Secondary outcome measures will be changes in lifestyle behavior and cost-effectiveness and cost-utility ratios. All relevant direct and indirect costs will be measured and followed up for 24 months. DISCUSSION: Changing behaviors is difficult, it requires time, considerable effort and motivation. The combination of the two counseling methods MI and PST, followed by booster sessions, can result in sustained behavior change. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN59358434.

title: Hand Hygiene Compliance Preparation in Clinical Settings
abstract: Introduction: Effective hand hygiene is the most important procedure to prevent hospital-acquired infections. Traditional information/education based interventions have shown only modest benefits in adherence. This study set out to investigate whether grooming through olfactory and visual cues influences hand hygiene compliance. Method: Randomized controlled trial conducted in a surgical intensive care unit (ICU) at a teaching hospital in Miami, Florida. Primary outcome data included observations: a mix of health professionals and service users admitted to the SICU was observed by 2 trained observers and independently verified for their hand hygiene compliance. Interventions included either an olfactory priming (clean, citrus smell) or a visual priming (male or female eyes). The primary outcome measure was hand hygiene compliance (HHC) measured by the visitor using the hand sanitizer dispenser. Results: At the 5% level, there was significant evidence that a clean citrus odor significantly improves HHC (46.9% vs. 15.0%, p = 0.0001). Compared to the control group, a significant improvement in HHC was observed when an image of "male eyes" was placed on the hand gel dispenser (33.3% vs. 15.0%, p < 0.038). No significant improvement in HHC was seen when an image of female eyes was placed on the same hand gel dispenser (10.0% vs. 15.0%, p = 0.626). Conclusions: This is one of the first studies to show that priming can influence HHC in a clinical setting. The findings suggest that preparedness interventions could be used to change other behaviors relevant to public health. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2016 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: Printed educational materials: effects on professional practice and health care outcomes
abstract: BACKGROUND: Printed educational materials (PEMs) are widely used passive dissemination strategies to improve knowledge, awareness, attitudes, skills, professional practice, and patient outcomes. They are traditionally presented in print formats, such as monographs, publication in peer-reviewed journals, and clinical guidelines, and seem to be the most frequently adopted method of disseminating information. OBJECTIVES: To determine the effectiveness of MEPs in improving process outcomes (including health professional behavior) and patient outcomes. Explore whether the effect of PEM characteristics (eg, source, content, format, mode of delivery, time/frequency, complexity of target behavior change) can influence process outcomes (including behavior of health professionals and patient outcomes). SEARCH STRATEGY: The following electronic databases were searched up to July 2006: (a) COPD Group Specialized Register (including the database of studies awaiting assessment (see 'Specialized Register' in 'Group Details'). ')"; (b) The Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL) and Efficacy Review Abstracts Database"; (c) MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL, and CAB Health. An updated MEDLINE search was performed on March 2007. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs), controlled clinical trials (CCTs), controlled before-after studies (CBAs), and interrupted time series (ITS) analyzes that evaluated the impact of educational materials were included. printed in the practice of health professionals and/or patient outcomes There was no language restriction Any objective measure of professional performance (e.g., number of tests requested, prescrip tions for a particular drug) or patient health outcomes (eg. g., blood pressure, number of caesarean sections) that we re-included. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Four reviewers independently performed data extraction using a modified version of the EPOC data collection checklist. Any disagreement was resolved by discussion between the reviewers and referees. Statistical analysis was based on consideration of dichotomous process outcomes, continuous process outcomes, dichotomous patient outcome measures, and continuous patient outcome measures. The results of all comparisons were presented using a standard method of presentation where possible. The median effect size for each type of outcome and the median of these effect sizes across studies were reported separately for each study. MAIN RESULTS: Twenty-three studies were included for this review. The evidence in this review showed that MEPs appear to have small beneficial effects in professional practice. RCTs comparing MEPs with no intervention found a median absolute risk difference: +4.3% in categorical process outcomes (eg, X-ray requests, prescribing, and smoking cessation activities) (range -8 .0% to +9.6%, 6 studies), and a +13.6% relative risk difference in continuous process outcomes (eg, medication change, X-ray requests per practice) (range - 5.0% to +26.6%, 4 studies). These findings are similar to those reported for the ITS studies, although significantly larger effect sizes were observed (relative risk difference ranges from 0.07% to 31%). In contrast, the median effect size was -4.3% for categorical patient outcome measures (eg, screening, return to work, smoking cessation) (range -0.4% to - 4.6%, 3 studies)). Two studies reported deteriorations in continuous patient outcome data (eg, depression score, smoking cessation attempts) of -10.0% and -20.5%. A study comparing PEMs with educational workshops found minimal differences. Two studies comparing PEMs and educational outreach had no statistically significant differences between groups. It was not possible to explore potential effect modifiers across studies. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: The results of this review suggest that, compared to no intervention, PEMs when used alone may have a beneficial effect on process outcomes, but not on patient outcomes. Despite this wide range of reported effects for PEMs, the clinical significance of the observed effect sizes is unknown. There is not enough information on how to optimize educational materials. The effectiveness of educational materials compared to other interventions is uncertain.

title: Printed educational messages fail to increase the use of thiazides as first-line medication for hypertension in primary care: a cluster randomized controlled trial [ISRCTN72772651
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence on the effectiveness of print educational messages in helping to increase evidence-based clinical practice is conflicting. Nonetheless, these messages are flooding doctors' offices, in an attempt to promote treatments that can reduce costs and improve patient outcomes. This study evaluated the ability of print educational messages to promote the choice of thiazides as first-line treatment for people newly diagnosed with hypertension, a practice supported by good evidence and included in guidelines, and which could reduce costs for the health care system. . METHODS: The study uses a pragmatic cluster randomized controlled trial (randomized by medical practice group). SCENARIO: The scenario involves all general practitioners/family practitioners in Ontario. Messages advising the use of thiazides as first-line treatment of hypertension were mailed to each physician along with a widely read professional bulletin. Physicians were randomly assigned to receive different versions of printed educational messages: an "insert" (two-page evidence-based article) and/or one of two different versions of an "outsert" (brief, directive message stapled to the outside of the newsletter). ). One outsert was developed with no explicit theory and one with developed messages targeting planned behavior theory factors or none at all (newsletter only, no mention of thiazides). Percentage of patients older than 65 years and newly diagnosed with hypertension who were prescribed a thiazide as the only initial prescription drug. The intervention effect was estimated using a logistic regression model estimated using generalized estimating equation methods to account for patient grouping within medical practices. RESULTS: Four thousand five hundred four physicians (with 23,508 patients) were randomized, providing 97% power to detect a 5% absolute increase in thiazide prescribing. No effect of the intervention was detected. Thiazides were prescribed to 27.6% of patients who consulted control physicians, 27.4% to insertion physicians, 26.8% to outpatient physicians, and 28.3% of patients who consulted insertion + external physicians, p = 0.54. CONCLUSIONS: The study failed conclusively to demonstrate any impact of print educational messages on increased prescription of thiazide diuretics for first-line treatment of hypertension. TEST REGISTRATION: ISRCTN72772651.

title: Private company and public good: ethical issues in the financing of clinical research
abstract: Health care centers, universities, and the researchers and physicians who work in them are encouraged to obtain research funding by developing business relationships. There are positive, practical and morally relevant arguments in support of this initiative, but the measure also raises ethical issues related to potential conflicts of interest. These include conflicts between an institution's or a researcher's responsibilities to each other, to research subjects, and to the public, and competing financial interests. This article examines the evolution of research funding and the ethical difficulties that may arise in the current administrative context. Provides suggestions for guideline development by institutions that support investigators in their efforts to improve clinical care through crucial external funding and implementation of research.

title: Pro re nata drugs for inpatient psychiatric patients: time to act
abstract: Medication pro re nata (PRN"; 'as needed') is an archetypal mainstay for managing the symptoms and behaviors of acute psychiatric inpatients. Mental health and psychiatric nursing practices have circumnavigated the development of a standard Medical-Ethical Uniform for PRN Psychotropic Medication Administration This document examines the evidence for PRN psychotropic medication administration and, in the context of evidence-based best practices, current mental health policy, and professional ethics, proposes a standardized Australian PRN administration protocol PRN medications are divided into five simple steps, namely (i) medical prescription, (ii) nursing assessment of the patient's indications for an intervention, (iii) nursing consideration of the therapeutic options; (iv) obtaining informed consent from the patient;" and (v) documentation of the results of the PRN administration. The literature associated with each step is reviewed, along with national and international professional ethics, guidelines, and patient rights documents related to the care of mental health patients. Recommendations for best practice of care are discussed for each step. There is a gap in published evidence supporting the use of PRN medications in hospitalized psychiatric patients. However, there is published evidence that PRN medications are associated with increased risks of morbidity, inappropriate use, may result in higher-than-recommended doses or polypharmacy, and complicate evaluation of the efficacy of regularly scheduled medications. Alternative non-pharmacological treatment options to PRN medication are effective and associated with fewer side effects. There are no explicit national standards, operational criteria, or quality assurance for the use of PRN medications in inpatient psychiatric units. Contemporary PRN practices are largely unregulated and driven essentially by anecdotal evidence, leaving clinicians and the service open to claims of little liability and (intentional and unintentional) misuse of psychotropic medications. The development of best practice guidelines for the use of PRN administration is essential.

title: Proactive care of childhood asthma: randomized controlled trial based on general practice.
abstract: Objectives To assess the feasibility and effectiveness of a proactive system of care for asthma in children based on general practice. Design Randomized controlled trial with cluster sampling for general practice. Establishment General practice in the northern region of the Australian Capital Territory. Participants 174 children with moderate to severe asthma who attended 24 general practitioners. Structured Asthma Care Intervention System (the 3+ visit plan), reminding participating families to see their GP. Main outcome measures Process measures: GP asthma consultation rates, written asthma plans, completion of 3+ visit plan; clinical measures: rates of asthma emergency department visits, days absent from school, symptom-free days, symptoms in the past year, activity limitation in the past year, and asthma medication use in the past year ; spirometric measures of lung function before and after cold air challenge. Results Children in the intervention group had significantly more asthma-related visits (odds ratio for three or more asthma-related visits). consultations 3.8 (95% confidence interval 1.9 to 7.6; P = 0.0001), written asthma plans (2.2 (1.2 to 4.1); P = 0.01 ) and plans for more than 3 visits completed (24.2 (5.7 to 103.2); P = 0.0001) than control children and a mean reduction in measurements of forced expiratory volume in one second after cold air challenge 2.6% (1.7 to 3.5); P = 0.0001) less than control children. The national written asthma action plan was for 5 (3 to 41) children. Children in the intervention group had lower rates of asthma emergency department attendance (odds ratio 0.4 (0.2 to 1.04); P = 0.06) and less speech-limiting wheezing (0.2 ( 0.1 to 0.4; P = 0.0001) than control children and were more likely to use a spacer (2.8 (1.6 to 4.7); P = 0.0001). no differences occurred in the number of days absent from school or symptom-free days scores.Proactive care with active recall for children with moderate to severe asthma is feasible in general practice and appears to be beneficial.

title: Problems with guideline implementation: a randomized controlled trial of consensus management of dyspepsia
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the feasibility and benefit of developing consensus guidelines for the management of dyspepsia between general practitioners (GPs) and specialists and to assess their introduction into prescribing, use of research, and referrals by GPs. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial of the effect of consensus guidelines agreed between physicians and specialists on physician behavior. SETTING: Southampton and South West Hampshire Health District, UK. SUBJECTS: 179 physicians working in 45 practices in the Southampton district of 254 eligible physicians, 107 in the control group and 78 in the study group. MAIN MEASURES: Referral and investigation rates and prescription costs for dyspepsia in the six months before and after guideline introduction. RESULTS: Consensus guidelines were produced relatively easily. After its introduction, referral rates for upper gastrointestinal symptoms fell significantly in both the study and control groups, but there were no significant changes in either group in the use of endoscopy or radiology, either in terms of referral rates, patient selection, or research findings. No difference was seen between the control and study groups in the number of items prescribed, but prescription costs increased by 25% (from £2,634 to £3,215 per GP) in the study group, almost at its entirely due to a higher prescription rate for ulcer-healing agents. CONCLUSION: The development of district guidelines for the management of dyspepsia by consensus between GPs and specialists was feasible. However, their uptake and adoption was variable, and their measured effects on some aspects of clinical behavior were relatively weak and not necessarily associated with reduced costs or better quality of care.

title: Proceedings of the 9th Annual Conference on the Science of Diffusion and Implementation
Proceedings of the 3rd Biennial Conference of the Society for Implementation Research Collaboration (SIRC) 2015: advancing efficient methodologies through community partnerships and teamwork
Proceedings of the 8th Annual Conference on the Science of Dissemination and Implementation
Process and result in the National Health Service
Process evaluation of an occupational health guideline aimed at preventing weight gain among employees
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the process of an occupational health guide aimed at preventing weight gain. METHODS: Quantitative data on seven process elements were evaluated and linked to effects on employees' waist circumference and body weight at 6 months. RESULTS: Occupational physicians (n = 7) implemented the guideline in part with respect to the environmental level, but performed well at the individual level. Behavior change counseling was done "to some extent." Employees (n = 274) showed high reach (86%), satisfaction (7.1), and attendance rates (4.4 of 5 sessions). Significant effects on waist circumference (-1.5 cm to -2.1 cm) and body weight (-0.9 kg to -1.4 kg) were found among employees with higher rates of attendance and satisfaction . CONCLUSIONS: Workplace health promotion through occupational health guidance is feasible, but the environmental component and behavior change counseling need revision before practical application.

title: Process evaluation of complex interventions: guidance from the Medical Research Council
abstract: Process evaluation is an essential part of the design and testing of complex interventions. New MRC guidance provides a framework for conducting and reporting process evaluation studies Attempts to tackle problems such as smoking and obesity increasingly use complex interventions. These are commonly defined as interventions comprising multiple interacting components, although additional dimensions of complexity include the difficulty of their implementation and the number of organizational levels they target.1 Randomized controlled trials are considered the gold standard for establishing the effectiveness of interventions, when randomization is feasible. However, effect sizes do not provide policymakers with information about how an intervention might be replicated in their specific context, or whether trial results will be replicated. Previous MRC guidance for evaluating complex interventions focused on randomized trials, with no mention of process evaluation.2 The updated guidance recognized the value of process evaluation within trials, stating that it "can be used to assess the fidelity and quality of implementation, clarify causal mechanisms, and identify contextual factors associated with variation in outcomes 3 However, did not provide guidance for conducting process evaluation #### Summary points In 2010, a workshop funded by the MRC Population Health Sciences Research Network discussed the need for guidance on process evaluation.4 There was consensus that investigators, funders and Ã¢â‚¬Â¦

title: Procrastination, deadlines and performance: self-control by previous commitment
abstract: Procrastination is all too familiar to most people. People delay writing their research (we heard that!), repeatedly state they'll start their diets tomorrow, or put off doing odd jobs around the house until next week. However, people sometimes also try to control their procrastination by setting deadlines. In this article we ask three questions: (a) Are people willing to set significant (ie, expensive) deadlines for themselves to overcome procrastination? (b) Are self-imposed deadlines effective in improving task performance? (c) When deadlines are self-imposed, do people set them optimally, to maximize performance? A set of studies examined these issues experimentally and showed that the answer is "yes" to the first two questions and "no" to the third. People have self-control issues, recognize them, and try to control them by setting costly deadlines. These deadlines help people control procrastination, but they are not as effective as some externally imposed deadlines in improving task performance.

title: Professional and lay social support for hysterectomy patients
abstract: This article describes a study of social support for women undergoing hysterectomy and shows how the original research plans had to be modified when the first interviews revealed the women's need for and desire for basic information from the researcher. The modified design allowed for comparisons between a group of women who received information as part of the research interview and a second group who did not receive such help. Post-hysterectomy follow-up at 3 months showed significant differences between the 2 groups, with the 'information group' being less hostile but more critical of their hospital treatment. The study also confirms previous findings by the same author of generally high levels of satisfaction, health, and return to activity after hysterectomy. With regard to social support, it is suggested that full-time homemakers are especially in need of support from nurses due to their relative isolation from other sources of support and information. However, all the interviewees would have liked more information and support from health professionals. Despite the acknowledged limitations of the study, some guidelines are offered for nurses seeking to increase levels of lay and professional support for their patients.

title: Professional interventions for general practitioners in the management of musculoskeletal conditions
abstract: BACKGROUND: Musculoskeletal conditions require particular management skills. Identifying interventions that are effective in equipping general practitioners (GPs) with the necessary skills could translate into better health outcomes for patients and lower healthcare and social costs. OBJECTIVES: To determine the effectiveness of professional interventions for GPs that aim to improve the management of musculoskeletal conditions in primary care. SEARCH METHODS: We searched the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), 2010, Issue 2"; MEDLINE, Ovid (1950 - October 2013); EMBASE, Ovid (1980 - October 2013); CINAHL, EbscoHost ( 1980 - November 2013) ), and the COPD specialist register. We performed cited reference searches using ISI Web of Knowledge and Google Scholar, and manually searched selected issues of Arthritis and Rheumatism and Primary Care-Clinics in Office Practice. The last search was conducted in November 2013. SELECTION CRITERIA: We included randomized controlled trials (RCTs), nonrandomized controlled trials (NRCTs), controlled before-and-after studies (CBAs), and interrupted time series (ITS) studies of professional interventions for GPs, which were conducted in a community setting, with the aim of improving management (including diagnosis and treatment) of musculoskeletal conditions and reporting e of any objective measure of GP performance, financial or patient outcomes. Length, duration, intensity and complexity compared to active or inactive controls. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two reviewers independently abstracted all data. We calculated the risk difference (RD) and risk ratio (RR) of adherence to desired practice for dichotomous outcomes, and the mean difference (MD) and standardized mean difference (SMD) for continuous outcomes. We investigated whether the direction of specific behavior change affects the effectiveness of interventions. MAIN RESULTS: Thirty studies met the inclusion criteria. Of 11 studies on osteoporosis, meta-analysis of five studies (high-certainty evidence) showed that a combination of a GP alert system about a patient's increased risk of osteoporosis and a patient-directed intervention (including patient education and a reminder to see their GP) improves GP behavior regarding diagnostic bone mineral density (BMD) testing and prescription of osteoporosis medications (RR 4.44; ( 95% confidence interval (CI) 3.54 to 5.55, 3 studies, 3386 participants)) for BMD and RR 1.71 (95% CI 1.50 to 1.94, 5 studies, 4223 participants) for medication for osteoporosis. Meta-analysis of two studies showed that GP alert alone probably also improves GP behavior consistent with osteoporosis guidelines (RR 4.75 [95% CI 3.62 to 6.24; 3047 participants]) for BMD and RR 1.52 (95% CI 1.26 to 1.84, 3047 participants) for osteoporosis medication) and that adding the patient-directed component is unlikely to result in a higher effect (RR 0.94 (95% CI 0.81 to 1.09; 2995 participants)) for BMD and RR 0.93 (95% CI 0.79 to 1.10; "2995 participants) for osteoporosis medication.Of the 10 studies on low back pain, seven showed that guideline dissemination and educational opportunities for GPs may lead to little or no improvement in consistent GP behaviour. with guidelines.Two studies showed that the combination of guidelines and GP feedback wax on the total number of investigations requested may have an effect on the behavior of the GP and result in a slight reduction in the number of tests, while one of these studies showed that the combination of the guidelines and the GP r Reminders attached to radiology reports may result in a small but sustained reduction in the number of investigation requests. Of the four studies on osteoarthritis, one study showed that the use of influential physicians in education may result in improvement in GP behavior consistent with guidelines. Another study showed slight improvements in patient outcomes (pain control) after training GPs on pain management. Of three studies on shoulder pain, one study reported that there may be little or no improvement in patient outcomes (functional ability) after education of GPs about shoulder pain. and injection training. Of two studies on other musculoskeletal conditions, one study on pain management showed that there may be worse patient outcomes (pain control) after GP training on the use of validated assessment scales. The remaining 12 studies across all musculoskeletal conditions showed little or no improvement in GP behavior and patient outcomes. The direction of the target behavior (ie, increasing or decreasing a behavior) does not appear to affect the efficacy of an intervention. Most of the studies did not investigate the potential adverse effects of the interventions and only three studies included a cost-effectiveness analysis. Overall, there were important methodological limitations in the body of evidence, with only a third of studies reporting adequate allocation concealment. and blinded outcome assessments. While our confidence in the combined effect estimate of interventions to improve diagnostic testing and medication prescription in osteoporosis is high, our confidence in the effect estimates reported in the remaining studies is low. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: There is good quality evidence that a GP alert system with or without targeted patient education on osteoporosis improves guideline-consistent GP behaviour, resulting in better diagnostic rates. and treatment. combined with guideline dissemination may lead to small improvements in guideline-consistent GP behavior with regard to low-back pain, while GP education on osteoarthritis pain and the use of influential physicians in education may lead to modest improvement in patient outcomes and guideline-consistent behavior, respectively. However, more studies are needed to determine the effectiveness of such interventions in improving GP behavior and patient outcomes.

title: Prognostic Research Strategy (PROGRESS) 1: A Framework for Researching Clinical Outcomes
abstract: Understanding and improving the prognosis of a disease or health condition is a priority in research and clinical practice. In this article, the authors present a framework of four interrelated themes in prognostic research, describe the importance of the first of these themes (understanding future outcomes in relation to current diagnostic and treatment practices), and introduce recommendations for the field of prognosis. prognostic research. In clinical medicine, the term prognosis refers to the risk of future health outcomes in people with a given disease or health condition. Prognostic research is thus the investigation of relationships between future outcomes (endpoints) among people with a given baseline health state (baseline) to improve health (see Supplementary Figure at bmj.com). The study of prognosis has never been more important, as more people worldwide are living with one or more diseases or unhealthy conditions than at any time before.1 For this reason, governments around the world are increasing their interest in health care outcomes today. for people with disease.2 Similarly, research funders and investigators are increasingly focused on translating new interventions and technologies from the laboratory into clinical practice and then into health care policy to establish and implement new standards of care. high-quality care and improve patient outcomes. Therefore, the results of prognostic research should be an integral part of clinical decision making, health care policy, and the discovery and evaluation of new approaches to patient management. However, there is a worrying gap between the potential and actual impact of prognostic research on health. Too often, prognostic research studies fall far short of the high standards required in other fields, such as therapeutic trials and genetic epidemiology. In the PROGnosis RESearch Strategy (PROGRESS) series (www.progress-partnership.org), we propose a framework of four distinct but interrelated prognosis research topics:

title: Promising developments in neuropsychological approaches to screening for preclinical Alzheimer's disease: a selective review.
abstract: Recently published guidelines suggest that the most opportune time to treat people with Alzheimer's disease is during the preclinical phase of the disease. This is a phase in which individuals are defined as clinically normal but show evidence of amyloidosis, neurodegeneration, and subtle cognitive/behavioral impairment. While our standard cognitive tests are useful for detecting cognitive decline in the stage of mild cognitive impairment, they were not designed to detect the subtle cognitive variations associated with this stage of biomarkers of preclinical Alzheimer's disease. However, neuropsychologists are attempting to meet this challenge by designing new cognitive measures and questionnaires derived from translational efforts in neuroimaging, cognitive neuroscience, and clinical/experimental neuropsychology. This review is a selective overview of several novel and potentially promising approaches that are being explored to detect early cognitive evidence of preclinical Alzheimer's disease in presymptomatic individuals.

title: Promoting evidence-based psychosocial care for cancer patients
abstract: With numerous studies showing that psychosocial care reduces distress and improves quality of life, clinicians have an obligation to treat cancer patients in a manner consistent with this evidence. Although the rationale is simple, there are major challenges to achieving the goal of translating research into clinical practice. One challenge has been the nature of the evidence, with many studies of psychosocial interventions characterized by poor methodological quality, an absence of eligibility criteria specifying increased distress, and minimal consideration of the potential for dissemination. A second challenge has been making practitioners aware of the relevant evidence. Dissemination efforts, such as the issuance of clinical practice guidelines and evidence-based recommendations and the distribution of intervention materials via the Internet, appear to be more effective than passive efforts in providing useful information to clinicians. Perhaps the most challenging aspect has been persuading practitioners to change the way they practice. An approach currently under development would allow clinicians and health care organizations to make self-assessments of the quality of their psychosocial care based on review of medical records. Comments showing that the quality of care is not optimal are likely to motivate change, especially if the quality indicators assessed are considered important and reliable and point to specific actions that can be taken. The use of evidence to promote changes in clinical practice represents one of the main ways in which the field of psycho-oncology can fully realize its potential to positively affect the lives of people with cancer.

title: Promotion of hand hygiene compliance
abstract: BACKGROUND: The German "Clean Hands Campaign" (an adaptation of the WHO program "Clean Care is Safer Care") to promote hand hygiene among hospital staff at the Hannover Medical School (MHH, Medizinische Hochschule Hannover) , known as Aktion Saubere Hande (ASH), met with initial success. However, by 2013, rates of adherence to hygienic hand disinfection in the hospital's ten intensive care units (ICUs) and two hematopoietic stem cell transplant units (HSCTUs) had returned to baseline levels ( physicians: 48%;" nurses: 56%). The PSYGIENE cluster randomized controlled trial was conducted to investigate whether interventions tailored in ways suggested by research in behavioral psychology could lead to more sustainable improvements than ASH METHODS: The "Health Action Process Approach" (HAPA) adherence model specifies the key psychological determinants of adherence.These determinants were assessed among MHH ICU and STU health workers by questionnaire (rates of response: physicians: 71%"; nurses: 63%) and through interviews with ward physicians and responsible nursing managers (100%). In 2013, 29 personalized behavior change techniques were implemented in educational training sessions and feedback discussions in the six rooms that made up the intervention arm of the trial, while ASH training sessions were provided in the control arm. trial results) were determined by non-participant observation of hygienic hand disinfection, according to the World Health Organization gold standard. RESULTS: The two groups did not differ in their baseline compliance rates in 2013 (intervention: 54%, control: 55%, p = 0.581). Personalized interventions led to higher adherence in each of the two years of follow-up (2014: 64%, p<0.001; "2015: 70%, p=0.001), while adherence in the control arm increased at 68% in 2014 (p<0.001), but dropped again to 64% in 2015 (p=0.007).The increases in compliance between 2013 and 2015 and the rate of compliance in 2015 were greater in the intervention arm (p< 0.005).This was mainly due to the behavior of the nurses, as the corresponding parameters for the doctors did not differ significantly between the two study arms in the stratified analysis.CONCLUSION: Personalized interventions based on the principles of behavioral psychology led to to more sustainable increases in adherence to hand hygiene guidelines than ASH training sessions.This was true among nurses and thus also for hospital ward staff in their c set (i.e. nurses and doctors combined). Further studies are needed to identify more target group-specific interventions that may improve adherence among clinicians.

title: Promoting recovery in schizophrenic patients: discrepancy between usual practice and evidence. The SIEP-DIRECT Project
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The objective of this paper is to present the main discrepancies, evidenced by the SIEP-DIRECT'S Project, between the evidence-based NICE guidelines for schizophrenia and the usual practices of Italian mental health services to promote the recovery of patients. . with schizophrenia. METHODS: Based on the main NICE recommendations on promoting recovery, 41 indicators were developed. These were experienced in 19 participating Italian Mental Health Departments (MHD) or Psychiatric Services through self-assessment of the activities carried out to promote patient recovery with the aim of assessing the level of compliance with the recommendations. The data required by most of the indicators were obtained from the psychiatric information system or from the Directorate of the MHD. In addition, a specific investigation was carried out on medical records and on representative samples of patients. In addition, for 14 indicators, an evaluation by "multidisciplinary" or "specialized" focus groups was requested, which then assigned a score according to a defined "ad hoc" scale. RESULTS: According to the data obtained, although mental health services seem to care about the physical state of their patients, they do not routinely examine main parameters such as blood pressure, blood glucose, etc., and collaboration with general practitioners is usually complex or not. practiced uniformly. Most psychiatrists and psychologists have basic communication skills but not enough cognitive-behavioral treatment skills";" such treatments, and any other form of structured individual psychotherapy, are rarely carried out and seem to have become marginal activities within the Services. Family psychoeducational interventions are also underused. The Services are very active in the care of patients with multi-problematic schizophrenia, who constitute a large percentage (almost a quarter, on average) of the patients in their care. These patients are offered specific and integrated treatment plans with the involvement of other health services and social agents operating in the territory. The strategies adopted by the services for pharmacological treatment in the prevention of relapses and for patients with frequent crises or with treatment-resistant schizophrenia are all in line with the NICE recommendations. Finally, the Services promote vocational training and supported employment activities, but their results are often unsatisfactory. CONCLUSIONS: The results of the study show a picture of Italian mental health services with light but also dark areas regarding recovery promotion activities. The Services seem to guarantee appropriate pharmacological treatments based on evidence, integrated care and good management of multi-problematic patients. They have difficulty, however, with regard to monitoring the physical health of patients, psychotherapeutic activities, including for families, and promoting supported employment. In addition, they still show problems regarding the structuring and formalization of care processes. To improve this situation, they should make greater use of professional guidelines, protocols and written procedures.

title: Promotion of screening mammography in urban settings: a randomized controlled trial of computerized reminders as a component of a program to facilitate mammography
abstract: In a one-year randomized controlled trial, we evaluated the effectiveness of a computerized mammogram reminder system as a component of a program to increase the use of screening mammography at three health care organizations serving inner-city women in Detroit. , Michigan (two health department sites, one HMO site, and two private hospital sites). Four thousand four hundred one women over the age of 40 who had visited a study site in the previous year were randomly assigned to one of two treatment groups. The limited intervention (LI) included education on breast cancer control by physician and staff, facilitated mammography appointment scheduling procedures, and eliminated the patient's out-of-pocket cost for mammography (in three of five sites). The full intervention (FI) included all the components of the limited intervention plus an additional set of 'cues to action'. These included a mammography reminder form inserted into the medical record of women due for mammography, intended to increase referral for mammography appointments, and reminders for patients intended to increase mammography completion among the women mentioned. During the one-year intervention period, 2725 randomized women visited a study site. 6-month mammography appointment rates among women with FI range from 38% to 65%, with the FI rate exceeding the LI rate at each site with differences of 13% (95% CI, 6 to 20) to 29% (21 to 38). The annual mammogram completion rate among women with FI ranges from 43% to 64% and exceeds the LI rate at each site by 12% (5 to 19) to 25% (16 to 34). After adjustment for age, the mammography intervention effect sizes among the five sites were not significantly different. The average increase in FI compared to LI was 18%. The computerized reminder system is effective in increasing the use of mammography at each of the study institutions, with the main effect being physician referral for mammography.

title: Promotion of self-care through adherence in patients with heart failure discharged from rural hospitals: a study protocol
abstract: UNLABELED: Background Heart failure is one of the most prevalent chronic conditions in adults, leading to prolonged morbidity, repeated hospitalizations, and placing an enormous financial burden on the health care system. Heart failure patients discharged from rural hospitals, or primarily critical access hospitals, have higher rates of readmission and 30-day mortality compared with patients discharged from urban hospitals. Self-care improves health outcomes for heart failure patients and reduces readmissions, but adherence to self-care guidelines is low. We propose a home-based post-acute care service managed by advanced practice nurses to enhance patient activation and lead to improved self-care adherence in heart failure patients discharged from rural hospitals. Objective This article describes the study design and the research methods used to implement and evaluate the intervention. Method Our intervention is a 12-week patient activation (Patient AcTivated Care at Home [PATCH]) to improve adherence to self-care. Patients were randomized into two parallel groups (12-week PATCH intervention + usual care versus usual care only) to assess the efficacy of this intervention. Outcomes were measured at baseline, 3 and 6 months. Discussion This study aimed to examine the efficacy of an activation-enhancing intervention led by advanced practice nurses and based on rural theory on adherence to self-management in patients with heart failure residing in rural areas. Our expectation is to facilitate adherence to self-care behaviors of patients with heart failure after discharge from rural hospitals and reduce complications and hospital readmissions, which will result in a reduction in the economic burden. CLINICAL TRIAL REGISTRATION INFORMATION: ClinicalTrials.gov";" https://register.clinicaltrials.gov/NCT01964053.

title: Promoting the use of colorectal cancer screening tests
abstract: BACKGROUND: Colorectal cancer (CRC) screening is underused despite evidence that screening reduces mortality. OBJECTIVE: To assess the effect of an intervention directed at physicians and their patients on CRC detection rates. DESIGN: A randomized clinical trial of community physicians and their patients. PARTICIPANTS: Ninety-four community primary care physicians randomly assigned to an intervention consisting of academic details and direct mailings to patients or a control group. Patients aged 50 to 79 years in the intervention group received a letter from their doctor, a brochure on CRC screening, and a pack of fecal occult blood test (FOBT) cards. MEASUREMENTS: After 1 year, we measure receipt of the following: (1) FOBT in the last 2 years, (2) flexible sigmoidoscopy (SIG) or colonoscopy (COL) in the previous 5 years, and (3) any CRC detection . We report the percent change from baseline in both groups. RESULTS: 9652 patients were enrolled over 2 years and 3732 patients over 5 years. There was no increase in any CRC screening that occurred in the intervention group for patients enrolled for 2 years (increase of 12.7% vs. 12.5%, p = 0.51). Similar results were seen for any CRC screening among patients enrolled over 5 years (increase of 9.7% vs. 8.6%, p=0.45). The only outcome where the intervention had an effect was on the rates of patients with detection GIS (increase of 7.4% vs 4.4%, p < 0.01). CONCLUSION: With the exception of an increase in SIG rates in the intervention group, the intervention had no effect on CRC detection rates. Future interventions should evaluate innovative approaches to increase CRC detection rates.

title: Promotion and prescription of hormone therapy after report of harm by the Women's Health Initiative
abstract: Context Little is known about how the pharmaceutical industry responds to evidence of harm associated with its products, such as the July 2002 publication of the WomenÂ¡Â¯s Health Initiative Estrogen Plus Progestin Trial (WHI E+P) report showing that the standard-dose of Prempro produced significant harm and no net benefit. Objective To examine the pharmaceutical industry's response to the WHI E+P results by analyzing hormone therapy promotion expenditures before and after July 2002. Design and setting Nationally representative and prospectively collected longitudinal data (January 2001 to December 2003) on the prescription and promotion of hormonal therapies were obtained from IMS Health and Consumer Media Reports. Main outcome measures Trends in quarterly prescriptions for hormone therapy and expenditures in 5 modes of drug promotion: samples, office details, hospital promotion, magazine ads, and direct-to-consumer advertising. Results Prior to the WHI E+P report, prescription rates and promotional spending for hormone therapy were stable. In the quarter prior to the WHI E+P report (April-June 2002), 22.4 million hormone therapy prescriptions were dispensed and $71 million was spent on promotion (in annual terms, $350 per year per US physician). Within 9 months of the report's release (Q1 2003), there was a 32% decline in hormone therapy prescriptions, and a tipping point was reached for promotional spending (37% decline compared to E+P before WHI). levels). Spending decreased for all promotional activities and most hormone therapies. Overall, the largest declines were for displays (36% decline from the first quarter of 2003) and direct-to-consumer advertising (100% decline). The largest decreases in promotion occurred for the standard dose of Prempro (61% decrease from Q1 2003), the agent implicated in the WHI E+P report. More recently, promotional efforts have increased, particularly for Prempro at lower doses, a resurgence associated with a modest increase in prescriptions for this new agent. Conclusions Based on its widespread use, hormone therapy was among the most promoted medications prior to the WHI E+P report. After reporting evidence of harm from this trial, there was a substantial decline in promotional spending for hormone therapy, particularly for agents most directly involved in the trial. Interrelated with the impact of the trial results themselves and subsequent media coverage, reduced promotion may have contributed to a substantial decline in hormone therapy prescriptions.

title: Adequate antibiotic treatment. From penicillin to pharmacogenomics
abstract: Antibiotics have always been considered one of the wonderful discoveries of the 20th century. Flaming's use of penicillin ushered in the golden age of antibiotics and it is now hard to imagine practicing medicine without antibiotics. Life-threatening infections such as meningitis, endocarditis, bacteremic pneumonia sepsis would again prove fatal. Also aggressive chemotherapy and transplant procedures would be impossible. Another true wonder has been the rise in antibiotic resistance soon after the clinical use of penicillin in hospitals and communities. Several studies have shown an over-prescription of antibiotics for community patients and hospitalized patients and, in some hospitals, up to 50% of antibiotic use is inappropriate: the benefits of antibiotic treatment come with the risk of development of antibiotic resistance. In hospitals, infections caused by antibiotic-resistant bacteria are associated with higher mortality, morbidity, and prolonged hospital stay compared to infections caused by antibiotic-sensitive bacteria. A variety of strategies have been proposed to reduce the cost and improve the quality of medication use. Evidence-based education, guidelines, and recommendations are considered essential elements of any program designed to influence prescribing behavior and can provide a knowledge base that will improve and increase acceptance of management strategies. Evidence-based recommendations, an approach to clinical practice that helps make decisions based on clinical experience and intimate knowledge of individual patient situations, beliefs, and priorities, improve antimicrobial stewardship, including selection, appropriate dosage, route, and duration of antimicrobials. therapy can maximize clinical cure or prevention of infection while limiting unintended consequences such as emergence of resistance, adverse drug events, and cost. These evidence-based guidelines are not a substitute for clinical judgment, and clinical discretion is always required in their application. Genome studies have identified hundreds of genetic polymorphisms important determinants of therapy efficacy, and several trials have demonstrated the successful use of pharmacogenomic testing to reduce the incidence of hypersensitivity reactions in patients. Knowing the phenotype of a patient prior to therapy, optimal doses and types of drugs can be prescribed to achieve better patient management.

title: Prophylaxis of infection after appendectomy: a review of current surgical practice.
abstract: 280 questionnaires were sent to junior surgical staff throughout England asking about the use of systemic antibiotic prophylaxis, topical antibacterial agents and surgical drainage in appendectomy. 175 (63%) responses were received from 81 of the 87 hospitals included in the survey. Prophylactic systemic antibiotics were used by 78 surgeons (46%) when operating on a normal appendix, but by 168 (99%) when the organ was perforated. Most surgeons started antibiotics preoperatively, but proportionately fewer did so when the appendix was gangrenous or perforated. Patients with severe contamination tended to receive longer courses of antibiotics, although the duration of administration varied considerably. Metronidazole was included in more than 95% of all prophylactic regimens and was often combined with other drugs when the appendix was gangrenous and perforated. Topical antibacterial agents were applied to the wound routinely by only 45 surgeons (26%), although 106 (61%) used them sometimes. Povidone-iodine was the most used agent. Only 98 surgeons (56%) ever drained appendectomy wounds, while 135 (77%) sometimes drained the peritoneal cavity. Evidence suggests that current methods of administering systemic antibiotic prophylaxis should continue, but that topical agents and surgical drainage may be unnecessary when surgeons are confident in the efficacy of the systemic treatment used.

title: Surgical wound sepsis prophylaxis
Proposal of guidelines for the participation of people with dementia as research subjects
Proposal for revision of the Declaration of Helsinki
Comparative prospective study of computer programs used for warfarin management.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To compare the efficacy of three computerized systems currently used to assist in outpatient warfarin management with the usual dosing method used by experienced medical personnel. METHODS: A randomized pilot study of three systems with an independent randomized follow-up study of two of these was conducted in 186 patients receiving long-term therapy or who had recently started warfarin therapy and had been discharged from the hospital. RESULTS: All three computerized systems appeared to provide satisfactory control compared to the traditional dosing method. For patients who received more intensive treatment with an assigned target range of 3.0-4.5, computerized dosing schedules achieved significantly better control";" medical staff undertreated these patients nearly 50% of the time. CONCLUSION: Computer-based programs can help warfarin outpatient anticoagulant management during early and long-term treatment. For most patients, the control achieved is as good as that achieved by the usual method of dosing by experienced clinicians, although the latter tend to be overly conservative when dosing patients within the intense target range of 3 .0 to 4.5 International Normalized Ratio (INR) . Computers were much more successful at this higher range.

title: Prospective study of quality of life before and after coronary revascularization surgery
abstract: OBJECTIVES To measure changes in patients' perceptions of how different health conditions affect their lives and to determine the ability of preoperative variables to predict outcome after coronary artery bypass grafting. DESIGN Prospective study with completion of questionnaires before myocardial revascularization and three months, one year and five years later. SCOPE Regional cardiothoracic center. PATIENTS 100 male patients, all under 60 years of age at the time of the operation, who were patients of two cardiothoracic surgeons. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Patients' assessment of their health status in terms of functional ability and aspects of distress, based on the Nottingham Health Profile and outcome of the operation in terms of changes in symptoms, work life and daily activities determined by self-completed study questionnaires before the operation and three and six months later. RESULTS Intermediate results at one year are reported. The differences between the Nottingham Health Profile scores preoperatively and three months postoperatively were significantly different (p less than 0.01), indicating appreciable improvement in general health status, and at one year compare favorably. with those of a normal male population. Analysis of the responses to the study questionnaire showed that 65 of 89 patients (73%) were working one year after the operation and another seven (8%) maintained that they were able to work but could not find employment. The proportion of patients complaining of chest pain was reduced from 90% (88/98) before grafting to 19% (17/89) one year after myocardial revascularization, when 91% (81/89) of patients patients maintained that their condition was good. either completely better or definitely improved. Significant positive factors affecting return to work and home activities were preoperative work, short wait for operation, absence of breathlessness, and low physical mobility score on the Nottingham Health Profile (all p less than 0.001). CONCLUSIONS Improvements were evident in general health status, symptoms, and activity at three months and one year after coronary artery bypass graft surgery. Interventions that likely influenced outcomes included reducing waiting times for surgery"; rehabilitation initiatives;" and more attention to the quality of information provided to patients, their families, and the community.

title: Prospective trial of real-time electronic surveillance to accelerate early care for severe sepsis.
abstract: Purpose of Study An automated real-time electronic health record retrieval and caregiver notification system was developed and tested for its utility in improving sepsis care. We hypothesize that the algorithm will increase the speed and timeliness of blood lactate and blood culture sampling, chest radiography, and antibiotic provision. Methods A consecutively enrolled prospective before-and-after study examined an algorithm that automatically identified adult patients who met 2 or more systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) criteria and 2 or more blood pressure measurements less than or equal to 90 mm Hg during your stay in the emergency department (ED). In phase 1, the system collected information but did not alert caregivers. In phase 2, caregivers were notified via alphanumeric paging and text entry in the electronic medical record of patients' possible illness and provided with specific recommendations. Results The patients (33,460) were evaluated for 6 months; 398 patients activated the system, including 184 (46%) properly identified as severely septic. The algorithm had a positive predictive value of 54% and a negative predictive value of 99% in detecting severe infection with acute organ dysfunction. The median time for patients to accumulate SIRS and blood pressure criteria was 152 minutes (range interquartile [IQR] 71 to 284 minutes), underscoring the dynamic nature of critical illness diagnosis in the emergency setting and the need for screening algorithms to repeatedly screen patients during their evaluation. 2 interventions with greater frequency, chest x-ray before admission (odds ratio 3.2, 95% confidence interval 1.1 to 9.5) and extraction of blood cultures (odds ratio 2.9, 95% confidence interval 1.1 to 9.5). 7.7) Only blood culture tests performed significantly faster in the presence of decision support (mean culture time before intercalating). vention 86 minutes, IQR 31, 296 minutes; mean culture time after intervention 81 minutes, IQR 37, 245 minutes; p = 0.032 according to the Cox proportional hazards model). The predominant deficiency of the strategy was not detecting severely septic cases before caregivers. Sepsis increased the frequency and timing of some emergency department interventions for severe sepsis. Future efforts should identify patient characteristics present earlier in the ED evaluation than SIRS and hypotension.

title: Protection of the rights of human subjects
abstract: There is a significant problem with the volume of human subjects research being conducted by researchers who do not adhere to the Belmont Report guidelines for the protection of human subjects. There are numerous reasons for noncompliance, which can create dilemmas in resolving this issue. However, it is important that healthcare organizations, regardless of their size, take a proactive stance to address this issue. This article has briefly described the nature, scope and underlying dilemmas of this problem and has suggested a strategy to solve the problem at the organizational level. As patient advocates by virtue of their professional licenses, nurses in any role can and should take the lead in protecting the rights of human subjects.

title: Protection of Children Participating in Research Studies
Protection of human subjects"; informed consent;" proposed rule
Protocol for a pragmatic cluster randomized controlled trial to reduce irrational antibiotic prescribing in children with upper respiratory tract infections in rural China.
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The irrational use of antibiotics is a serious problem within China and internationally. In 2012, the Chinese Ministry of Health issued a regulation for antibiotic prescriptions limiting them to <20% of all outpatient prescriptions, but no operational details regarding policy implementation have been issued. This study aims to test the effectiveness of a multidimensional intervention designed to reduce antibiotic use among children (2 to 14 years of age) with acute upper respiratory tract infections in rural primary care settings in China, by changing physician prescribing behaviors and parent education. /caregivers. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: This is a pragmatic, parallel-group, controlled, cluster-randomized, superiority trial with blinded outcome assessment and data analysis, and unblinded treatment. From two counties in Guangxi province, 12 municipal hospitals will be randomized to the intervention arm and 13 to the control arm. In the control arm, the management of antibiotic prescriptions will continue with usual care through clinical consultations. In the intervention arm, a provider- and patient/caregiver-focused intervention will be integrated into routine primary care practice. Provider intervention includes operational guidelines, systematic training, peer review of antibiotic prescribing, and health education for patient caregivers. We will also provide educational print materials and educational videos to patient caregivers. The primary outcome is the proportion of all prescriptions written by providers for upper respiratory tract infections in children aged 2-14 years that include at least one antibiotic. ETHICS AND DISSEMINATION: The trial has received ethical approval from the Ethics Committee of the Guangxi Provincial Center for Disease Control and Prevention, China. The results will be disseminated through workshops, policy briefs, peer-reviewed publications, local and international conferences. TEST REGISTRATION NUMBER: ISRCTN14340536";" Pre-results.

title: Protocol for a systematic review of evaluation research for adults who have participated in the mutual support program 'SMART recovery'
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Self-Management and Recovery Training (SMART Recovery) offers an alternative to prevailing 12-step approaches to mutual aid (eg, Alcoholics Anonymous). Although the principles (eg, self-efficacy) and therapeutic approaches (eg, motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy) of SMART Recovery are evidence-based, more clarity is needed regarding direct evidence of its efficacy as mutual aid package Relative to methodologically rigorous reviews supporting the effectiveness of 12-step approaches, reviews of SMART Recovery to date have been descriptive. We aim to address this gap by providing a comprehensive overview of the evidence for SMART Recovery in adults with alcohol, substance or behavioral addiction problems, including a comment on outcomes assessed, potential mediators, feasibility (including economic outcomes ) and a critical evaluation. of the methods used. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: Methods are informed by the Cochrane Guidelines for Systematic Reviews and the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses statement. 6 peer-reviewed electronic databases and 4 gray literature databases have been identified. Preliminary SMART Recovery literature searches were performed (liberal inclusion criteria, not restricted to randomized controlled trials [RCTs], excluding qualitative-only designs). Eligible 'assessment' articles will be assessed against standardized criteria and will be reviewed by an independent assessor. Searches will be re-run just prior to final analyzes and additional studies retrieved for inclusion. A narrative synthesis of the findings will be reported, structured around the type and content of the intervention, the characteristics of the population, and the results. Wherever possible, 'summary of findings' tables will be generated for each comparison. When data become available, we will calculate a risk ratio and its 95% CI (dichotomous outcomes) or effect size using Cohen's formula (continuous outcomes) for the primary outcome of each trial. ETHICS AND DISSEMINATION: Ethical issues are not foreseen. The findings will be widely disseminated to clinicians and researchers through journal publications and conference presentations. PROSPERO REGISTRATION NUMBER: CRD42015025574.

title: Protocol for a systematic review of telephone psychosocial interventions on relapse prevention, adherence to psychiatric medication, and health risk behaviors in adults with a psychotic disorder
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The mental and physical health of people with a psychotic illness is usually poor. When adhered to, medication can reduce relapse. However, despite adherence, relapse remains common and functional outcomes often remain compromised. Compliance is also often low. Morbidity and mortality related to cardiovascular disease are also high, along with several important modifiable health risk behaviors. Therefore, access to psychosocial interventions is important, but currently limited. Wiretaps represent a promising solution, although more clarity is needed. Accordingly, we aim to provide an overview and critical review of the current state of the evidence for telephone-delivered psychosocial interventions targeting key health priorities in adults with a psychotic disorder, including (1) relapse, (2) adherence to psychiatric medication and/or (3) modifiable cardiovascular health risk behaviors. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: Our methods are based on published guidelines. The review is recorded and any modifications to the protocol will be tracked. Ten peer-reviewed electronic databases and four gray literature databases have been identified. Preliminary literature searches on telephone psychosocial interventions targeting relapse, medication adherence, and/or health risk behaviors in adults with a psychotic disorder were conducted. Articles classified as 'evaluation' will be evaluated according to standardized criteria and controlled by an independent evaluator. Searches will be re-run just prior to final analyzes and additional studies retrieved for inclusion. A narrative synthesis will be reported, structured around the type and content of the intervention, the characteristics of the population and the results. Wherever possible, 'summary of findings' tables will be generated for each comparison. For the primary outcome of each trial, where data are available, we will calculate a risk ratio and its 95% CI (dichotomous outcomes) or effect size using Cohen's formula (continuous outcomes). ETHICS AND DISSEMINATION: Ethical issues are not foreseen. The findings will be widely disseminated to clinicians and researchers through journal publications and conference presentations. TEST REGISTRATION NUMBER: PROSPERO CRD42015025402.

title: Protocol processing system (ProtoVIEW) to support residents in the emergency room.
