abstract: This article describes the design, implementation, and evaluation of a prototype protocol processing system (ProtoVIEW). ProtoVIEW provides protocol information for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. The developed system described here is used as a research tool to investigate the impact of automated protocols on physicians' medical decision making. A first evaluation indicates that the residents like using the system and that the use of the system leads to a more uniform work strategy.

title: Provider attitudes toward oral pre-exposure prophylaxis for HIV prevention among high-risk men who have sex with men in Lima, Peru
abstract: Oral pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) was the first biomedical intervention to demonstrate efficacy in preventing HIV infection among men who have sex with men (MSM). Health care providers' attitudes toward PrEP will be critical in translating this finding into effective public health implementation programs. In a convenience sample of 186 health care providers in Peru, we assessed knowledge, barriers, and attitudes to prescribing and monitoring HIV PrEP for high-risk MSM and transgender women, the populations with the highest incidence of HIV in this environment. A total of 57.5% reported knowing about PrEP, and knowledge was independently associated with caring for more than 50 MSM (OR: 3.67, p<0.002). Lack of local guidelines, concerns about increasing high-risk behaviors, antiretroviral drug resistance, and limited availability of antiretrovirals for people living with HIV were the most common barriers to prescribing PrEP. Of all physicians, 44.6% indicated that they would probably prescribe oral PrEP now";" more likely to prescribe if PrEP was supported by local guidelines (70.3%, p<0.001), if more trials supported its effectiveness (68.5%, p<0.001), and if intermittent use was shown to it was effective (62.2%, p<0.001). =0.019). Physicians were more likely to prescribe PrEP now if they care for more than 50 MSM (OR: 6.62, p=0.010). Infectious disease specialists were less likely to prescribe PrEP (OR: 0.10, p=0.003) than non-specialists. Successful large-scale PrEP implementation in Peru will require focused educational campaigns to raise awareness and address concerns among healthcare providers.

title: Provider Details: An Intervention to Reduce Prescription Opioid Deaths in Utah
abstract: BACKGROUND: Utah undertook a multipronged effort to reverse an epidemic of deaths among patients taking prescription opioids. This article describes the provider detailing part of the effort. METHODS: Presentations highlighting six recommended prescribing practices were developed and presented to health care workers. Participants were encouraged to use the state prescription database and to complete a series of surveys to assess confidence and behavior changes at 0, 1, and 6 months after presentation. Continuing medical education credits encouraged participation. FINDINGS: Drug-related overdose deaths in Utah fell 14.0% in 2008 compared to 2007 after program implementation. A total of 581 physicians and numerous non-physician health workers were reached during 46 presentations. Follow-up surveys on the degree of adoption of changes in practice were completed by 366 participants at 0 months, 82 participants at 1 month, and 29 participants at 6 months. The combined results of the three assessments showed that between 60% and 80% of responding providers reported that they no longer prescribe long-acting opioids for acute or sedative pain; 50% reported using the Utah Controlled Substances Database during patient care and using lower starting doses and slower escalations;" and 30-50% reported obtaining EKGs and sleep studies on patients using patient education tools and implementing Utah prescribing guidelines.CONCLUSIONS: Provider details were associated with a decrease in Utah prescription opioid mortality rate and improvements in provider self-reported prescribing behaviors. Other concurrent interventions may have contributed to the decrease in mortality rates.The effect of this intervention was limited by short-term funding.

title: Provider education to promote implementation of clinical practice guidelines
abstract: STUDY OBJECTIVES: Although the interest and promulgation of clinical practice guidelines have increased significantly in the last 2 decades, there is concern about their actual implementation. This article focuses on a strategy to encourage implementation of the guideline at the clinical level: clinical education. The objectives of the article are to review educational strategies, consider them within the context of complementary strategies carried out at the organizational and clinical level, and outline the challenges and recommendations for the continuing education of physicians. METHODS: Experience and data from relevant randomized clinical trials are reviewed within an educational setting. COMMENTS: Implementation of clinical practice guidelines requires a variety of skills, including assessment, proper delineation of a treatment and monitoring plan, patient follow-up, and patient counseling and education skills. Continuing education strategies should reflect the content and teaching methods that best suit the learning objectives. Current practice pressures place limits on the resources, particularly physician time, that are available for continuing education. Organizational resources must be committed to building the complementary support systems needed to improve clinical practice. In addition to clinicians, education should be directed at non-physician clinicians, office staff, and administrators who are also responsible for guideline implementation. CONCLUSIONS: To meet the challenges of building physician motivation, balancing competing demands, and treating patients with complex medical conditions, all within time constraints, clinical leaders must design educational activities that are supported by leadership. , reflect compelling evidence, use multiple teaching strategies and techniques. and engage students in skill development and problem solving.

title: Provision of social norms feedback to high prescribers of antibiotics in general practice: a pragmatic national randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Unnecessary prescription of antibiotics contributes to antimicrobial resistance. In this trial, our aim was to reduce unnecessary antibiotic prescriptions by general practitioners (GPs) in England. Methods In this randomized, 2?Ã—?2 factorial trial, publicly available databases were used to identify GP practices whose antibiotic prescribing rate was in the top 20% for their NHS local area team. of Health (NHS). Eligible practices were randomized (1:1) into two groups using a computer-generated allocation sequence, stratified by NHS local area team. The participants, but not the investigators, were blinded to group assignment. On 29 September 2014, all GPs in the feedback intervention group were sent a letter from the chief medical officer for England and a leaflet on antibiotics to use with patients. The letter said the practice was prescribing antibiotics at a higher rate than 80% of the practices in its NHS Local Area Team. Physicians in the control group received no communication. The sample was re-randomized into two groups, and in December 2014, GP practices were either sent patient-focused information promoting reduced antibiotic use or received no communication at all. The primary outcome measure was the rate of antibiotics dispensed per 1000 weighted population, controlling for previous prescriptions. Analysis was by intention to treat. This trial is registered in the ISRCTN registry, number ISRCTN32349954, and has been completed. Findings Between September 8 and 26, 2014, we recruited and assigned 1,581 general practitioner practices to feedback intervention (n=791) or control (n=790) groups. Letters were sent to 3227 physicians in the intervention group. Between October 2014 and March 2015, the rate of dispensed antibiotic items per 1,000 population was 126 98 (95% CI 125 68–128 27) in the feedback intervention group and 131 25 (130 33″) “132 16) in the control group, a difference of 4 27 (3 3%"; incidence rate ratio [IRR] 0 967 [95% CI 0 957–0 977 ]; p<0 0001), which represents an estimated 73?406 fewer items of antibiotics dispensed.In December 2014, GP practices were reassigned to patient-centered intervention groups (n=777 ) or control (n=804) did not significantly affect the primary outcome between December 2014 and March 2015 (antibiotic items dispensed per 1000 population: 135 00 [95% CI 133 77–136 22 ] in the patient-centered intervention group and 133 98 [133 06–134 90] in the control group, IRR for difference between groups 1 01, 95% CI 1 00–1 02 ; p=0 105) messenger of high per fil can substantially reduce antibiotic prescribing at low cost and on a national scale;" this result makes it worth adding to antimicrobial stewardship programs.

title: Provision of recorded conversations with neonatologists to mothers of infants in intensive care: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine whether providing mothers of infants in neonatal intensive care units with audiotapes of their conversations with a neonatologist improves recall of information and psychological well-being. DESIGN Randomized, single-blind trial. SETTING Neonatal intensive care unit, North Queensland, Australia. PARTICIPANTS 200 mothers of babies in a neonatal intensive care unit. INTERVENTIONS Mothers provided (n=102) or non-reported (n=98) audiotapes of their conversations with a neonatologist. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Recall of information, attitudes and use of the tape, satisfaction with conversations, postpartum depression, anxiety, general health and parenting stress, at 10 days and at 4 and 12 months. RESULTS Ninety-one percent (n=93) of the mothers in the tape group listened to the tape (once at day 10, twice at four months, and three times at 12 months"; range 1-10). At 10 days and at four months, Mothers in the tape group recalled significantly more information about diagnosis, treatment, and outcome than mothers in the control group At four months, mothers in the tape group had a 75 % more likely to remember all treatment information than mothers in the control group (59% vs 34%, relative risk 1.75, 95% confidence interval 1.27 to 2.4). mothers, all in the control group, could not recall their conversations.No statistically significant differences were found between the groups in satisfaction with the conversations (10 days), postpartum depression and anxiety scores (10 days, four and 12 months). ) and parenting stress (12 months). providing mothers of babies in neonatal intensive care units with audiotapes of conversations with a neonatologist improved their recall of information (up to four months). The recorded conversations did not affect the mothers' well-being or satisfaction with the neonatologist. TRIAL REGISTRATION Australian Clinical Trials Registry 12606000478516.

title: Psychiatric experimentation: the lessons of history
Psychoeducation: improving outcomes in bipolar disorder
abstract: BACKGROUND: A relevant paradigm shift in the treatment of bipolar disorder began a few years ago";" Crucial findings on the usefulness of psychological interventions clearly support a shift from an exclusively pharmacological therapeutic approach to a combined but hierarchical model in which pharmacotherapy plays a central role, but psychological interventions can help bridge the gap between theoretical efficacy and "real world" effectiveness. . We hereby review the efficacy of various complementary psychotherapies in the maintenance treatment of bipolar patients. METHODS: A systematic review of the literature on the subject was carried out, using the MEDLINE and CURRENT CONTENTS databases. Keywords "Bipolar", "Psychotherapy", "Psychoeducation", "Cognitive-behavioral" and "Relapse prevention" were entered. RESULTS: Psychological treatments specifically designed for relapse prevention in bipolar affective disorder are useful tools in conjunction with mood stabilizers. Most of the recently published psychotherapy studies report positive results in maintenance as an adjunctive treatment and efficacy in the treatment of depressive episodes. Interestingly, several groups around the world reported similar positive results and came to very similar conclusions";" Nearly all of the interventions tested contain important psychoeducational elements that include both improving adherence and early identification of prodromal signs, emphasizing the importance of lifestyle regularity, and exploring health beliefs and awareness of patients' disease. CONCLUSIONS: The usefulness of psychotherapy to improve adherence to treatment and clinical outcome of bipolar patients is today unquestionable, and future treatment guidelines should promote its regular use among clinicians. As physicians, it is our primary duty to offer the best treatment available to our patients, and this includes both evidence-based psychoeducation programs and newer pharmacological agents.

title: Psychological and behavioral interventions for the management of insomnia disorder: an evidence report for an American College of Physicians clinical practice guideline
abstract: BACKGROUND: Psychological and behavioral interventions are commonly used for insomnia disorder. PURPOSE: To assess the benefits and harms of psychological and behavioral interventions for insomnia disorder in adults. DATA SOURCES: Ovid MEDLINE, Embase, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, and PsycINFO through September 2015, supplemented by handsearching. STUDY SELECTION: Randomized controlled trials of psychological or behavioral interventions that were published in English and included adults with insomnia disorder lasting 4 weeks or longer. DATA EXTRACTION: data extraction by a single investigator confirmed by a second reviewer"; double investigator assessment of risk of bias;" consensus determination of the strength of the evidence. DATA SYNTHESIS: Sixty trials at low to moderate risk of bias compared psychological and behavioral interventions with inactive controls or other psychological and behavioral interventions. Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) improved global outcomes and most sleep outcomes after treatment, often compared with information or wait-list controls (moderate strength of evidence). The use of CBT-I improved several sleep outcomes in older adults (low- to moderate-strength evidence). Multicomponent behavioral therapy improved several sleep outcomes in older adults (low-to-moderate strength of evidence). Stimulus control improved 1 or 2 sleep outcomes (low-robust evidence). Evidence from other comparisons and from harms was insufficient to allow conclusions. LIMITATIONS: A wide variety of comparisons limited the ability to pool data. The trials did not always report overall results and rarely performed a sender or responder analysis. Comparisons were often information or waiting list groups, and publication bias was possible. CONCLUSION: The use of CBT-I improves most outcomes compared to inactive controls. Multicomponent behavioral therapy and stimulus control may improve some sleep outcomes. Evidence on other outcomes, comparisons, and long-term efficacy was limited.

title: Psychological treatments for posttraumatic stress disorder: recommendations for the clinician based on a review of the literature
abstract: This article reviews the available research data supporting the use of psychotherapy in the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The authors highlight how this evidence could inform clinical options in the treatment of PTSD, as well as demonstrate how assumptions based on gaps in the available literature can be misleading. The authors first review findings related to a number of interventions that are commonly used in the treatment of trauma victims or patients with PTSD: critical incident stress reporting, psychoeducation, exposure therapy, eye movement desensitization reprocessing, stress inoculation, trauma management therapy, cognitive therapy, psychodynamic psychotherapy, and hypnotherapy. They also discuss a number of treatment strategies that have recently been studied in PTSD, including imagery rehearsal, memory structure intervention, interpersonal psychotherapy, and dialectical behavior therapy. PTSD is associated with significant symptomatic morbidity, although desired outcomes in clinical practice are generally more related to reduced social, interpersonal, and occupational impairment. The most methodologically sound studies, which have typically examined cognitive or behavioral treatments, indicate that psychotherapy helps alleviate symptom severity";" however, there is no consistent information about whether these interventions are useful in improving other domains of impairment and associated disability, although these issues are often the greatest concern for patients. The available evidence also does not indicate when and for whom various psychotherapeutic interventions should be provided, or whether different treatment modalities can and should be combined or offered sequentially, as is often done in specialized treatment programmes. Clinicians should keep these issues in mind when reviewing the current (and future) clinical research literature. Unfortunately, the current evidence base on psychotherapy for PTSD provides only limited guidance regarding clinical options in the management of PTSD. Therefore, the authors provide some literature-based clinical guidelines for clinicians treating patients with PTSD.

title: Psychometric Analysis of the Three-Factor Feeding Questionnaire-R18V2 in Adolescent and Young Adult Central Nervous System Tumor Survivors
abstract: PURPOSE: Adolescent and young adult (AYA) central nervous system (CNS) tumor survivors are an understudied population at risk of developing adverse health outcomes, including obesity. Long-term follow-up guidelines recommend monitoring people at risk of obesity, which motivates the need for an eating behavior questionnaire. An abbreviated online version of the Three-Factor Dietary Questionnaire (TFEQ-R18v2) has been developed, but its applicability to this population is not yet known. This study investigated the factorial structure and reliability of the instrument in this population. METHODS: AYA-aged CNS tumor survivors (n = 114) aged 15 to 39 years completed the online TFEQ-R18V2 questionnaire. Confirmatory factor analysis was used to examine the fit of the three-factor structure (uncontrollable eating, cognitive restraint, and emotional eating [EE]) and reliability (internal consistency of the TFEQ-R18v2). Associations between the three factors and body mass index (BMI) were evaluated using linear regression. RESULTS: The theorized three-factor structure was supported in our population (RMSEA = 0.056 and CFI = 0.98) and demonstrated good reliability (alpha of 0.81-0.93). EE (beta = 0.07, 95% CI: 0.02-0.13) was positively associated with BMI, while the other two subscale scores were not. CONCLUSION: The TFEQ-R18v2 instrument shows promise for research and clinical use among CNS tumor survivors of AYA age. The instrument may be a useful tool for researchers to develop personalized weight management strategies. It can also be a valuable tool for clinicians to monitor survivors who are at risk for obesity and to facilitate referral. Our results also suggest that EE in this population should be further investigated as a potential target for intervention.

title: psychopharmacology in pregnancy
abstract: Physicians face challenging situations when working with women who are pregnant and have coexisting mental illness. A benefit-risk assessment is helpful in identifying potential care interventions. Psychopharmaceutical intervention is a consideration when non-pharmacological interventions are ineffective or inappropriate. Informed consent should be obtained based on the known and unknown risks to the mother and fetus. The literature and case reports are conflicting and inconclusive about the risks of medications used for psychiatric conditions. This article reviews the literature and provides clinical guidelines for antipsychotic medications, antidepressant medications, mood stabilizing medications, and antianxiety medications.

title: Psychosocial aspects in cardiac rehabilitation: from theory to practice. Position paper of the Cardiac Rehabilitation Section of the European Association for Cardiovascular Prevention and Rehabilitation of the European Society of Cardiology
abstract: large body of empirical research shows that psychosocial risk factors (PSRFs) such as low socioeconomic status, social isolation, stress, type D personality, depression, and anxiety increase the risk of incident coronary heart disease (CHD). and also contribute to poorer health-related quality of life (HRQoL) and prognosis in patients with established coronary heart disease. PSRFs may also act as barriers to lifestyle changes and treatment adherence and may moderate the effects of cardiac rehabilitation (CR). Furthermore, there appears to be a bidirectional interaction between PSRFs and the cardiovascular system. Stress, anxiety, and depression affect the cardiovascular system through immunological, neuroendocrine, and behavioral pathways. In turn, coronary heart disease and its associated treatments can cause distress in patients, including anxiety and depression. In clinical practice, PSRFs can be assessed with single-item screening questions, standardized questionnaires, or structured clinical interviews. Psychotherapy and medication may be considered to alleviate any PSRF-related symptoms and improve HRQoL, but the evidence for a definite beneficial effect on cardiac endpoints is inconclusive. A multimodal behavioral intervention that integrates counseling for PSRF and coping with the disease should be included within comprehensive CR. Patients with clinically significant symptoms of distress should be referred for psychological counseling or interventions focused on psychology and/or psychopharmacological treatment. To conclude, the success of CR may critically depend on the interdependence of the body and mind and this interaction should be reflected through the assessment and management of PSRF in accordance with sound scientific evidence, by trained personnel and integrated within the core CR team.

title: Pulmonary edema precipitated by nifedipine
Putting Evidence into Practice: Evidence-Based Interventions for Sleep-Wake Disorders
abstract: Symptom management is a vital aspect of cancer nursing practice. The Cancer Nursing Society has identified outcomes sensitive to nursing intervention, known as nursing sensitive patient outcomes. This article presents information on sleep-wake disorders that occur in cancer patients and makes recommendations for evidence-based interventions to improve patients' sleep. Sleep-wake disorders occur in 30% to 75% of people with cancer and have a negative impact on other symptoms and quality of life. Despite the frequency and severity of sleep-wake disorders, limited research has tested interventions to improve sleep-wake outcomes. Although no intervention currently receives the highest recommendations for implementation in practice, several nonpharmacological interventions show initial positive findings in promoting high-quality sleep and daytime functioning. Oncology nurses can detect sleep and wake disorders and suggest personalized interventions. Four categories of promising interventions are cognitive behavioral therapy, complementary therapies, psychoeducation and information, and exercise. Clinicians can use the Putting Evidence into Practice (PEP) card and the PEP resources at www.ons.org/outcomes to improve sleep and wake outcomes.

title: Put prevention into practice
abstract: In primary health care settings, disease prevention services are provided at lower rates than recommended. In addition, professionals tend to overestimate the speed at which they perform them. There are essentially two steps in providing evidence-based preventive services: (1) knowing what the evidence is for various screening and intervention maneuvers, and (2) integrating preventive services into daily practice. The first is a scientific process and is carried out in Canada by the Canadian Task Force on the Periodic Health Examination. However, after a decade of experience with evidence-based guidelines, we now know that guidelines are not enough. Integrating clinical prevention into busy practices is a political and logistical process. This truth is best captured by the joke: "An ounce of prevention requires a pound of change from the office system." Several studies have shown that continuing medical education (CME) courses and workshops for physicians are not sufficient to ensure that clinical preventive services are incorporated into practice. According to Lomas, traditional CME educational approaches need to be complemented with paradigm strategies such as the social influence model, the diffusion of innovation model, and the adult learning model. Battista, in "From science to practice", points out the complexity of the communication process required for the diffusion of innovation in practice. Walsh's preventive clinical care systems model better captures the interactive factors that mediate between practitioners' intentions and their actions when it comes to providing preventive clinical services. This paper reports a practical example of how to help GPs develop a "prevention office support system" that minimizes barriers, focuses energy, and integrates clinical prevention into office routines. The key components are (i) a practice coordinator for prevention, (ii) clear descriptions of clinical roles related to prevention for all those who deal with patients, (iii) an information management system that strengthens prevention , and (iv) a feedback system and problem-solving strategy.

title: Qualitative Data Collection and Analysis Methods: The INSTINCT Trial
abstract: Patient care practices often lag behind current scientific evidence and professional guidelines. The failure of such knowledge translation (KT) efforts may reflect inadequate assessment and management of the specific barriers faced by both clinicians and patients at the point of treatment level. Effective KT in this setting can benefit from the use of qualitative methods to identify and overcome these barriers. Qualitative methodology allows for an in-depth exploration of the barriers involved in adopting practice change and has been used infrequently in emergency medicine research. The authors describe the methodology for qualitative analysis within the INcreasing Stroke Treatment through INteractive Behavior Change Tactics (INSTINCT) trial. This includes processes for valid data collection and reliable analysis of textual data from focus groups and interview transcripts. INSTINCT is a 24-hospital, randomized, controlled study designed to evaluate a system-based barrier assessment and interactive educational intervention to increase the appropriate use of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) in ischemic stroke. Intervention hospitals undergo a baseline barrier assessment using both qualitative and quantitative techniques (surveys). Researchers obtain data on local barriers to tPA use, as well as information on local attitudes, knowledge, and beliefs regarding the treatment of acute stroke. Target groups at each site include emergency physicians, emergency nurses, neurologists, radiologists, and hospital administrators. Transcript analysis using NVivo7 with a predefined barrier taxonomy is described. This will provide qualitative information on the use of thrombolytics and the importance of site-specific barrier types. Qualitative findings subsequently direct the shape of professional education efforts and system interventions at treatment sites.

title: Qualitative Research Within Trials: Developing a Standard Operating Procedure for a Clinical Trials Unit
abstract: BACKGROUND: Qualitative research methods are increasingly used in clinical trials to address broader research questions than can be addressed by quantitative methods alone. These methods allow health professionals, service users and other interested parties to contribute their views and experiences to the evaluation of treatments, interventions or health care policies and to influence the design of trials. Qualitative data often provides information that is more capable of reshaping policy or influencing design. METHODS: Health services researchers, including investigators, clinicians and qualitative researchers, worked collaboratively to develop a comprehensive portfolio of standard operating procedures (SOPs) for the West Wales Rigorous Trials Organization in Health (WWORTH) , a clinical trials unit (CTU) at Swansea University, which recently achieved registration with the UK Clinical Research Collaboration (UKCRC). Although UKCRC requires a total of 25 SOPs from registered CTUs, WWORTH chose to add an additional Qualitative Methods SOP (QM-SOP). RESULTS: Qualitative methods SOP (QM-SOP) define good practice in the design and implementation of qualitative components of trials, while allowing flexibility of approach and method. Its basic principles are that: qualitative researchers must contribute from the beginning of trials with qualitative potential"; the qualitative component must have clear objectives"; and the main publication of the study must report on the qualitative component. CONCLUSIONS: We recommend that CTUs consider developing a QM-SOP to improve quantitative testing by aggregating qualitative data and analysis. We believe that this enhances the value of quantitative assays and contributes to the future development of multi-method assays.

title: Evaluation of quality in surgical care services: proposal of a scoring system in terms of structure and process
abstract: Objective Construct a score capable of reflecting and classifying the surgical departments according to a definition of "quality" in terms of structure and process. Methods Collaborative design of a quality score within the framework of the French clinical research project NosoQual. Feasibility and observational study in 46 surgical services visited between November 2002 and March 2003 according to standardized procedures. A literature review followed by expert consultation, a field test, analysis, and a final reconsideration leading to the definition of a consensus score. Results 138 variables made up the score. They were classified into seven dimensions, each of which represents a different aspect of the quality of care in surgery. According to the threshold and the weight attributed to each variable, the scores for each department were calculated. The average level of achievement of the scores varied from 42% to 71% of the theoretical maximum. The variability of the scores related to the seven dimensions was greater and more significant than that expressed by the global score (coefficient of variation=0.1). Conclusion This analytical work contributed to the design of a quality index for surgery. However, the progress of the score must continue to take into account all the obstacles that were observed and meet the high requirements of the real problem of patient safety.

title: Quality improvement and changes in the results of diabetic patients in an academic practice of primary nursing care
abstract: PURPOSE: To examine a set of system interventions in the management of patients with diabetes and the outcomes of their care. DATA SOURCES: Pre- and post-intervention data collected from electronic medical records. CONCLUSIONS: The sample size was smaller than expected, which contributed to the lack of statistical significance from preintervention to postintervention in patient outcome measures. Systems-level variables that were under the direct control of clinic staff (eg, pneumococcal vaccine administered) showed great improvement. In the pre-intervention period, the percentage of "yes" responses to system-level variables ranged from 8 to 24 and jumped from 16 to 95 after the intervention. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: This project unequivocally demonstrated that systems-level changes result in better care being delivered to patients";" however, these had minimal impact on patient outcome variables. Promoting change in patient behavior is difficult, which may have contributed to the lack of prominence in this area, whereas variables under the direct control of clinic staff were more easily changed.

title: Improving the quality of medical records in a university hospital
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The objective of this study was to evaluate the quality of RM collection in some Operative Units of the "Azienda Ospedaliera Universitaria--II Universita di Napoli" (AOU-SUN)-Italy, before and after an intervention to improve quality, highlighting the potential differences in the behavior of different specialists (doctors vs. surgeons). METHODS: Two random samples of 660 RM were reviewed. A four-step program was developed: (1) first evaluation of the RM”; (2) implementation of the quality of the MR, sending a letter with the purpose of the study, the results obtained in the first step of that room, the guidelines to correctly complete the MR; (3) follow-up step four months later;" (4) comparison of data before and after distribution of guidelines using indicators of completeness of all MR sections, writing clarity, and signature presence and clarity. RESULTS: The main concerns were related to the signature of the doctor on duty (present in 2.0% and legible in only 15.4%), the presence of the discharge letter (18.0%) and the clarity of the days of stay hospital (32.0%).) After the intervention, the improvement in the quality of the compilation was modest and was considered mainly in medical rather than surgical wards. DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSIONS: The improvement was not satisfactory since from the medical and legal point of view the indicators should reach 100% clarity and completeness Further study is being carried out to improve the participation of health professionals, so that such requirements are perceived as a common goal, and no co mere bureaucratic initiatives.

title: Quality of hospital care for children in Kazakhstan, the Republic of Moldova, and Russia: a systematic observational evaluation.
abstract: Background Significant concerns have been raised about the quality of basic hospital care for children in developing countries, but no formal assessment applying international standards has been conducted in the Commonwealth of Independent States.";" Background Significant concerns have been raised about the quality of basic hospital care for children in developing countries, but no formal assessment applying international standards has been carried out in the Commonwealth of Independent States.

title: Quality of pharmaceutical advertisements in medical journals: a systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND: Magazine advertising is one of the main sources of drug information for physicians. Despite the availability of drug promotion regulations and controls around the world, drug information provided in journal advertising has been criticized in several studies for being of poor quality. However, no attempt has been made to systematically summarize this body of research. This systematic review was designed to assess all studies that examined the quality of pharmaceutical advertisements for prescription products in medical and pharmaceutical journals. METHODS AND FINDINGS: Studies were identified by searching electronic databases, web library, search engine, and citation review (1950 - February 2006). Only articles published in English and examining the quality of information included in pharmaceutical advertisements for prescription products in medical or pharmacy journals were included. For each eligible article, an investigator independently extracted data on study methodology and results. The data was then reviewed by a second investigator. Any disagreement was resolved by consensus. Data were analyzed descriptively. The final analysis included 24 articles. The studies reviewed ads from 26 countries. The number of journals surveyed in each study ranged from four to 24 journals. Various outcome measures were examined, including references and claims provided in advertisements, availability of product information, compliance with codes or guidelines, and presentation of risk results. Most studies used a convenience sampling method. In general, the commercial name, the generic name and the indications were provided. Journal articles were commonly cited to support pharmaceutical claims. Fewer than 67% of the claims were supported by a systematic review, meta-analysis, or randomized control trial. Studies that evaluated misleading claims had at least one ad with a misleading claim. Two studies found that less than 28% of claims were unequivocal clinical statements. Most ads with quantitative information provided risk outcomes as relative risk reduction. The studies were conducted in only 26 countries and thus the generalizability of the results is limited. CONCLUSIONS: The evidence from this review indicates that low-quality magazine advertising is a global problem. Given that the information provided in magazine advertising has the potential to change the prescribing behavior of physicians, continued efforts to increase drug promotion education are crucial. The results of our review suggest the need for a proactive and effective global regulatory system to ensure that the information provided in medical journal advertising supports the quality use of medicines.

title: Quantitative comparison of research in cognitive behavioral therapy and music therapy: a methodological review of best practices to guide future research for adult psychiatric patients
abstract: Although the music therapy profession is relatively young and small, it can treat a variety of clinical populations and has established a diverse research base. However, although the profession originated working with people diagnosed with mental illness, there is a considerable lack of quantitative research on the effects of music therapy with this population. Music therapy clinicians and researchers have reported this lack of evidence and the difficulty of conducting psychosocial research on their interventions (Choi, 1997"; Silverman, 2003a). While published studies have provided suggestions for future research, no study has provided detailed proposals for the methodology and design of a meticulous randomized controlled investigation of high quality psychiatric music therapy How do other psychotherapies achieve their databases and could the field of music therapy borrow from their rigorous "best methodological practices" to strengthen its Therefore, as the National Institutes of Mental Health states that the treatment of choice for evidence-based psychotherapy is cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), aspects of the literature basis of this psychotherapy were analyzed. The purpose of this literature review was (a) to analyze and id to identify the components of high-quality quantitative CBT research for adult psychiatric consumers, (b) to analyze and identify the variables and other elements of existing quantitative psychiatric music therapy research for adult consumers, and (c) to compare the two data sets to identify the best methodological designs and variables for future quantitative music therapy research with the mental health population. Included is a table that reviews randomized, carefully controlled studies involving the use of CBT for people with serious mental illness to determine the main components of high-quality experimental research designs and the implementation of quantitative clinical research. The table also shows the same components analyzed for existing quantitative psychiatric music therapy research with adult consumers, thus highlighting potential areas and elements for future research. A second table shows a series of possible dependent measures and their sources to be evaluated in future music therapy studies. A third table providing suggestions for future research is derived from a synthesis of the tables and is included to guide researchers and encourage advancement and expansion of the current literature base. The body of the paper is a discussion of the results of the literature analysis derived from the tables, meta-analyses, and literature reviews. It is hoped that this report will lead to the addition of future high-quality quantitative research to the psychiatric music therapy literature base and thereby provide evidence-based services to as many people with mental illness as possible.

title: In search of quality care and patient safety: the case of Singapore
abstract: Quality of care in Singapore has seen a paradigm shift from a traditional focus on structural approaches to a broader multidimensional concept that includes monitoring of clinical indicators and medical errors. Strong political commitment and institutional capacities have been important factors in making the transition. What is still missing, however, is a culture of rigorous program evaluation, public participation, and patient empowerment. Despite these imperfections, Singapore has made considerable progress and its experience can be a lesson to other small developing countries in the common quest for quality care and patient safety.

title: Quetiapine augmentation for depression: dosing pattern in routine practice
abstract: This study investigated quetiapine augmentation (QA) dosing patterns for major depressive disorder (MDD) in routine practice. Between January 1, 2009, and May 31, 2013, patients with a diagnosis of MDD who were receiving quality control along with an ongoing antidepressant were enrolled in this study. Electronic medical records and clinical data for a total of 977 patients up to one year were reviewed. Almost half of the patients maintained the QA treatment for more than 3 months. The median QC duration was approximately 6 months and the median starting and maintenance doses were 23.6 and 40.7 mg/day, respectively (range = 12.5-400 mg/day). The most frequently observed adverse events were drowsiness, followed by dry mouth and lethargy. Our results indicate that actual QC doses for MDD in routine practice should be lower than doses used in placebo-controlled clinical trials and those recommended by a regulatory agency. Well-controlled and adequately powered prospective studies are needed to better understand the exact role of low QC doses in the treatment of MDD, particularly in routine practice.

title: Randomized controlled trial of a complex primary care nurse intervention to increase ambulation in patients aged 60-74 years: PACE-Lift (Pedometer Accelerometer Consultation Evaluation - Lift) trial protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physical activity is essential for the physical and mental health of older people and for maintaining independence. The guidelines recommend at least 150 minutes per week of physical activity of at least moderate intensity, with activity on most days. The most common physical activity of the elderly is walking, light intensity if walking, moderate intensity if speeding. Less than 20% of people aged 65 to 74 in the UK report having met the guidelines, even though the majority can. Effective behavior change techniques include strategies such as goal setting, self-monitoring, developing self-efficacy, and relapse prevention. Physical activity consultations in primary care allow personalized advice. Pedometers measure step count and accelerometers measure the intensity of physical activity. This protocol describes an innovative intervention to increase walking in the elderly, incorporating pedometer and accelerometer feedback within a primary care nursing physical activity consultation, using behavior change techniques. METHODS/DESIGN: DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial with intervention and control arms (usual care) plus qualitative and process evaluations. PARTICIPANTS: 300 people aged 60-74 registered in 3 general practices within the Oxfordshire and Berkshire West Primary Care Trusts, able to walk outdoors and without restriction to increase their physical activity. INTERVENTION: 3-month pedometer and accelerometer-based intervention supported by practice nurse physical activity consultations. Four queries based on behavior change techniques, physical activity diary, average daily pedometer steps, and accelerometer feedback on intensity of physical activity. Individual physical activity plans will be developed based on increased walking and other existing physical activities. RESULTS: Change in average daily steps (primary outcome) and average weekly time spent in physical activity of at least moderate intensity (secondary outcome) at 3 and 12 months, assessed by accelerometry. Other outcomes include quality of life, mood, exercise self-efficacy, and injury. Qualitative assessments will explore reasons for non-participation in the trial, acceptability of the intervention to patients and nurses, and factors that enhance or act as barriers to older people increasing their physical activity levels. DISCUSSION: The PACE-Lift trial will determine the feasibility and efficacy of an intervention to increase physical activity among older primary care patients. Steps taken to minimize bias and anticipated challenges will be discussed. Word count 341. TEST REGISTRATION NUMBER: ISRCTN42122561.

title: Randomized controlled trial of Alexander Technique, Exercise and Massage (ATEAM) lessons for chronic and recurrent back pain.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the effectiveness of lessons in the Alexander technique, massage therapy, and a doctor's advice to exercise (exercise prescription) together with behavioral advice provided by a nurse for patients with chronic or recurrent back pain. DESIGN Randomized factorial trial. SETTING 64 General Practices in England. PARTICIPANTS 579 patients with chronic or recurrent low back pain; 144 were randomized to normal care, 147 to massage, 144 to six Alexander Technique lessons, and 144 to 24 Alexander Technique lessons; half of each of these groups were randomized to exercise prescription. INTERVENTIONS Normal care (control), six massage sessions, six or 24 Alexander Technique lessons, and exercise prescription by a physician with behavioral counseling provided by a nurse. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Roland Morris Disability Score (number of activities affected by pain) and number of days in pain. RESULTS Exercise and Alexander Technique lessons, but not massage, remained effective at 1 year (compared to control Roland Disability Score 8.1: massage -0.58, 95% confidence interval : -1.94 to 0.77, six lessons -1.40, -2.77 to -0.03, 24 lessons -3.4, -4.76 to -2.03, and exercise -1.29, -2.25 to -0.34). Exercise after six lessons achieved 72% of the effect of 24 lessons alone (Roland disability score -2.98 and -4.14, respectively). The number of days with back pain in the last four weeks was lower after the lessons (compared to the control median of 21 days: 24 lessons -18, six lessons -10, massage -7) and the quality of life significantly improved. No significant damage was reported. CONCLUSIONS Individual lessons in the Alexander Technique from registered teachers have long-term benefits for patients with chronic back pain. Six lessons followed by exercise prescription was almost as effective as 24 lessons. TEST REGISTRATION National Research Registry N0028108728.

title: Randomized controlled trial of Alexander Technique, Exercise and Massage (ATEAM) lessons for chronic and recurrent back pain: economic evaluation
abstract: OBJECTIVE An economic evaluation of therapeutic massage, exercise, and lessons in the Alexander Technique for treating persistent back pain. DESIGN Cost-consequence study and cost-effectiveness analysis at 12-month follow-up of a factorial randomized controlled trial. PARTICIPANTS 579 patients with chronic or recurrent low back pain recruited in primary care. INTERVENTIONS Normal care (control), massage and six or 24 lessons in the Alexander technique. Half of each group were randomized to an exercise prescription from a doctor plus behavioral counseling from a nurse. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Costs to the NHS and to participants. Cost comparison with Roland-Morris disability score (number of activities affected by pain), days in pain, and quality-adjusted life years (QALYs). Comparison of NHS costs with QALY gain, using incremental cost-effectiveness ratios and cost-effectiveness acceptability curves. RESULTS Intervention costs ranged from £30 per exercise prescription to £596 for 24 Alexander Technique lessons plus exercise. The cost of health services ranged from £50 for 24 Alexander Technique lessons to £124 per exercise. Incremental cost-effectiveness analysis of the individual therapies showed that exercise offered the best value (£61 per disability score point, £9 per additional pain-free day, £2847 per QALY gained). For two-stage therapy, six lessons in the Alexander technique combined with exercise was the best value (64 additional pounds per disability score point, 43 pounds per additional pain-free day, 5332 pounds per QALY gained). CONCLUSIONS An exercise prescription and six Alexander Technique lessons alone had more than an 85% chance of being profitable at values greater than £20,000 per QALY, but the Alexander Technique performed better than exercise across the full range of results. . A combination of six Alexander Technique lessons followed by exercise was the most effective and cost-effective option.

title: Randomized controlled trial of integrated care to reduce disability from chronic low back pain at work and in private life
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the effectiveness of an integrated care programme, combining patient-directed and workplace-directed intervention, for patients with chronic low back pain. DESIGN Population-based randomized controlled trial. SCOPE Primary care (10 physiotherapy consultations, an occupational health service, an occupational therapy consultation) and secondary care (five hospitals). PARTICIPANTS 134 adults aged 18 to 65 years registered ill for at least 12 weeks due to low back pain. INTERVENTION Patients were randomized to usual care (n=68) or integrated care (n=66). Integrated care consisted of a workplace intervention based on participatory ergonomics, with the participation of a supervisor, and a program of graded activities based on cognitive-behavioral principles. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was the duration of time away from work (incapacity for work) due to low-back pain until full and sustainable return to work. Secondary outcome measures were pain intensity and functional status. RESULTS The median duration to sustainable return to work was 88 days in the integrated care group compared with 208 days in the usual care group (P = 0.003). Integrated care was effective on return to work (hazard ratio 1.9, 95% confidence interval 1.2 to 2.8, P = 0.004). After 12 months, patients in the integrated care group improved significantly more in functional status compared with patients in the usual care group (P = 0.01). Pain improvement between groups did not differ significantly. CONCLUSION The integrated care program substantially reduced disability due to chronic low back pain in private and work life. Trial Registration Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN28478651.

title: Randomized controlled trial of strategies adapted to implement guidelines for the treatment of patients with depression in general practice.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Various methods are available to implement changes in the clinical behavior of general practitioners (GPs). Although passive dissemination of information is generally ineffective, other methods can be variably effective. Few studies have investigated the impact of personalized methods. OBJECTIVE: To determine whether tailored methods for overcoming barriers to change using psychological theories are more effective than dissemination alone in implementing depression guidelines among GPs. STUDY DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. SETTING: Sixty general practices in England"; 30 GPs in the control group, 34 in the intervention group. METHOD: Clinicians identified patients with depression before and after implementation of the guidelines (control group n = 192 at the first data collection, n = 181 at the second, intervention group n = 210 at the first data collection and n = 197 at the second) The main outcome measures were: record of adherence to recommendations guideline in medical records; proportion of patients with a Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) score of less than 11 at 16 weeks after diagnosis RESULTS: Compared with the control group, in the GP group receiving a personalized implementation, there were increases in the proportions of patients assessed for suicide risk In the intervention group, the proportion of patients with BDI scores increased d e less than 11 to 16 weeks. CONCLUSION: It is possible to identify the obstacles to implementation and design strategies to address them. The findings indicate a new research approach to understand and develop implementation methods.

title: Randomized controlled trial to change the hospital management of unstable angina
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To examine the benefits of a guideline-based educational program to improve the management of unstable angina pectoris (UAP) in hospitalized patients. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. SETTING: 37 public hospitals in New South Wales. PATIENTS: 1,872 patients admitted with a diagnosis of UAP between February 1 and June 30, 1996 (initial survey), and 1,368 patients with the same diagnosis admitted between July 1 and December 31, 1998 (follow-up survey). ). INTERVENTION: Educational sessions led by local opinion leaders, featuring guidelines on the management of UAP from the National Council for Health and Medical Research and commentary on local practice using baseline survey data. Sessions were held between March and June 1998. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Use of evidence-based practice, identified by review of medical records. RESULTS: Beta-blocker use increased in intervention and control hospitals, although the increase was significant only in the former. The use of calcium channel blockers decreased significantly in both intervention and control hospitals. However, the change in medication use between baseline and follow-up did not differ significantly between intervention and control hospitals. CONCLUSIONS: Despite some appropriate changes in medication use for UAP management between 1996 and 1998, there was no evidence that a guideline-based educational program was beneficial in changing management. This reaffirms the difficulty of changing physician behavior through practice guidelines. Alternative methods to encourage evidence-based practice should be considered.

title: Randomized trial of an integrated educational strategy to reduce investigation rates in young women with dysfunctional uterine bleeding
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To assess the effectiveness of an integrated educational strategy in changing physician behavior and reducing the number of hysteroscopies or dilations and curettage in women aged 40 years and younger with dysfunctional uterine bleeding (DUB). DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial with six months follow-up. SETTING: Public university hospital gynecology units with 12,000-13,000 relevant procedures per year. PARTICIPANTS: Six public gynecology units composed of 62 gynecologists or interns randomly assigned to intervention group - three, or control group - 3. Intervention An educational strategy that included the dissemination of evidence-based guidelines through an interactive workshop based on in problems facilitated by a thought leader and a laminated algorithm and guidelines. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: The number of hysteroscopies and/or dilations and curettage performed for DUB in women aged 40 years and younger, change in physician behavior, and perceived booking rates of the procedure. RESULTS: At six months, there was no significant effect on the number of hysteroscopies and/or dilations and curettage performed, but there was an increase in evidence-based behavior. CONCLUSIONS: Although the evidence-based educational strategy for adequate screening of young women with DUB resulted in a change in physician behavior when applied to theoretical cases, it did not result in a reduction in hysteroscopy/D&C rates at six months.

title: Randomized clinical trial of a personalized electronic alert requiring a yes response compared to a control group receiving a commercial passive CPOE alert: NSAIDs: warfarin co-prescribed as a test case.
abstract: Background Studies that have looked at the effectiveness of computerized decision support systems in preventing drug interactions have reported modest results due to low provider response to automated alerts. Objective To assess, within an inpatient computerized physician order entry (CPOE) system, the incremental effectiveness of an alert requiring a provider response, intended as a stronger intervention to prevent concurrent orders for warfarin and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. (NSAID). Design Randomized clinical trial of 1,963 physicians assigned to an intervention group receiving a personalized electronic alert requiring a yes response or a control group receiving a commercially available passive alert as part of CPOE. The duration of the study was from August 2, 2006 to December 15, 2007. Adherence to the Alert measurements was compared between the study groups. Results The proportion of desired request responses (i.e., not requesting the alert-triggering drug again after firing) was lower in the intervention group (114/464 (25%) personalized alerts issued) than in the intervention group. control (154/560 (28%) ) activation of passive alerts). The adjusted OR for inappropriate request was 1.22 (95% CI 0.69 to 2.16). Conclusion A personalized CPOE alert requiring a provider response had no effect in reducing the concomitant prescription of NSAIDs and warfarin beyond the commercially available passive alert received by the control group. The new CPOE alerts cannot be assumed to be effective in improving prescribing and need evaluation.

title: Randomized controlled clinical trial of the efficacy of cognitive-behavioral therapy compared to usual treatment for persistent insomnia in cancer patients
abstract: PURPOSE: Persistent insomnia is a common complaint in cancer survivors, but is rarely successfully addressed. Adaptation of a validated and cost-effective intervention to cancer care may offer a viable solution. The aim of this study was to investigate the clinical effectiveness of protocol-based cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for insomnia, administered by oncology nurses. PATIENTS AND METHODS: Randomized, controlled, pragmatic, two-center trial of CBT versus treatment as usual (TAU) in 150 patients (103 women"; mean age, 61 years) who had completed active therapy for breast, prostate, colorectal, or gynecologic cancer.The study followed the CONSORT guidelines.The primary outcomes were sleep diary measures at baseline, after treatment, and at 6-month follow-up.Actigraphic sleep, health-related quality of life (QOL), psychopathology and fatigue were secondary measures. CBT comprised five small group sessions over consecutive weeks, following a manual protocol. TAU represented normal clinical practice;" appropriate control for a clinical efficacy study. RESULTS: CBT was associated with mean reductions in 55-minute wakefulness per night compared with no change in TAU. These results were maintained 6 months after treatment. Standardized relative effect sizes were large for complaints of difficulty initiating sleep, waking during the night, and for sleep efficiency (percentage of time in bed spent asleep). CBT was associated with moderate to large effect sizes for five of seven quality of life outcomes, including a significant reduction in daytime fatigue. There was no significant interaction effect between any of these outcomes and baseline demographic, clinical, or sleep characteristics. CONCLUSION: CBT for insomnia may be clinically effective and feasible to apply in real practice.

title: Randomized controlled trial of an informatics strategy to increase the preventive care of the general practitioner
abstract: BACKGROUND: Previous interventions targeting primary care physicians with the aim of increasing preventive care delivery have shown limited effectiveness. The primary objective of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of a computerized continuing medical education program in increasing rates of three screening behaviors (cholesterol, blood pressure, and cervical screening) and identifying three risk behaviors (smoking, alcohol use, of benzodiazepines) in general practice. METHODS: Nineteen general practitioners were randomly assigned to intervention or control conditions. Those who received the intervention received a computerized feedback system. The intervention was performed using a touch screen computer located in the surgery waiting area. The preventive behaviors of interest were the patient's smoking, alcohol use, use of benzodiazepines, and screening of blood pressure, cholesterol, and the cervix through the Pap smear. Differences in performance by group on each of the outcomes were measured at baseline and at 3-month follow-up. Logistic regression analyzes with generalized estimating equations were performed as the main analyses. RESULTS: At 3-month follow-up, statistically significant differences were evident in the following outcome measures: precise classification of benzodiazepine users (z = 2.8540, P < 0.05); precise classification of non-benzodiazepine users (z = 2.7339, P < 0.05); precise classification of dangerous or harmful alcohol drinkers (z = 2.3079, P < 0.02); blood pressure screening (z = 3.4136, P < 0.001); and cholesterol screening (z = 6.6313, P < 0.001). CONCLUSION: A computerized performance-specific feedback system was effective in increasing some preventive care in general practice.

title: Randomized controlled trial of a computer-adapted multiple health behavior intervention in general practice: 12-month follow-up results.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Effective strategies to address noncommunicable disease risk factors are required to reduce rising health care costs. This trial tested the effectiveness over one year of a minimal intervention targeting multiple health behaviors (diet, physical activity, alcohol, and smoking) in a general practice setting, by providing personalized and computer-adapted feedback. METHODS: Patients who had attended a general practice in the previous 6 months were recruited from 21 general practitioners in Brisbane, Australia. Baseline data were collected through self-reports of adherence to ten health behaviors and summarized on a health score of 0 to 10. This randomized controlled trial used a 2x2 factorial design, with one arm randomizing subjects to intervention or control group. The other arm was feedback at baseline (single contact) or further evaluation with feedback at 3 months (double contact). Thus, 4 study groups were created, to which the participants were blindly randomized: A. Intervention with single contact"; B. Intervention with dual contact; C. Control with single contact and D. Control with dual contact. All participants were tested again at 12 months. RESULTS: Of the 4676 randomized participants, 3065 completed questionnaires at 12 months. Both the single and double contact groups improved their 10-item health scores (+0.31 and +0.49 respectively ) relative to the results of the control group (+0.02; p<0.01).Improvements were observed in compliance with the guidelines for fish intake, the type of milk consumed, the intake of fruits and vegetables and the alcohol intake in the single and double contact intervention groups (p<0.01).Both intervention groups showed greater improvement than controls for health behaviors, in addition to red meat intake, smoking, physical activity ca and body weight Interestingly, there was an improvement in reported non-smoking rates in both intervention and control. l groups (3% single contact;" 4.5% dual contact). CONCLUSIONS: Small but significant long-term changes in health behaviors can be achieved with a low-intensity intervention, which may reduce health care costs if is implemented on a large scale Further research is needed to better understand the mechanism by which maintenance of behavior change may be achieved EVIDENCE REGISTRY: Australian and New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry: ACTRN12611001213932.

title: Randomized controlled trial of education and feedback for the implementation of guidelines for acute low back pain
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The effect of clinical guidelines on resource utilization for complex conditions with substantial barriers to physician behavior change has not been well studied. We report the impact of a multifaceted guideline implementation intervention on radiological and specialty service utilization by primary care physicians for the care of acute low back pain. DESIGN: Groups of physicians were randomized to receive guideline education and individual feedback, supporting patient education materials, both or neither. The impact on guideline compliance and resource utilization was assessed over the 12-month period before and after implementation. PARTICIPANTS: Fourteen physician groups with 120 primary care physicians and associate physicians from 2-group model HMO practices. INTERVENTIONS: Implementation of the guide used an education/audit/feedback model with local opinion leaders. The patient education component included written and videotaped materials on low back pain care. MAIN RESULTS: Physician intervention was associated with an absolute increase in guideline-consistent behavior of 5.4% in the intervention group versus a 2.7% decrease in the control group (p = 0.04 ). The patient education intervention did not produce significant changes in behavior consistent with guidelines, but was poorly adopted. Patient characteristics, including duration of pain, prior history of low back pain, and number of visits during the illness episode, were strong predictors of service utilization and guideline-consistent behavior. CONCLUSIONS: Implementation of an acute low back pain care guideline supported by education and feedback for primary care physicians was associated with an increase in guideline-consistent behavior. Patient education materials did not improve the effectiveness of the guideline. Implementation barriers could limit the usefulness of this approach in usual care settings.

title: Randomized controlled trial of self-monitoring-supported practice nurses managing cardiovascular risk in primary care.
abstract: UNLABELED: BACKGROUND: Treatment goals for cardiovascular risk management are generally not achieved. Specialist practice nurses are increasingly facilitating the work of general practitioners and self-monitoring devices have been developed as an aid to advice. The aim of this study was to compare standard treatment supported by self-management with standard treatment without self-management, both performed by practicing nurses, on cardiovascular risk and separate risk factors. METHODS: Men aged 50 to 75 years and women aged 55 to 75 years with no history of cardiovascular disease or diabetes, but with a 10-year SCORE risk of cardiovascular mortality >/= 5% and at least one treatable risk factor (smoking , high blood pressure, lack of physical activity or overweight), were randomized into two groups. The control group received standard treatment according to the guidelines, the intervention group additionally received proactive advice and self-monitoring (pedometer, scale and/or blood pressure device). After one year, the effect of treatment was analyzed in 179 participants. RESULTS: The SCORE risk assessment decreased 1.6% (95% CI 1.0-2.2) for the control group and 1.8% (1.2-2.4) for the intervention group, the difference between groups was 0.2% (-0.6-1.1). Most risk factors tended to improve in both groups. The number of visits was greater and the visits lasted longer in the intervention group (4.9 (SD2.2) vs. 2.6 (SD1.5) visits p<0.001 and 27 (P25 -P75:20-33 ) vs. 23 (P25 -P75:19-30) minutes/visit p= .048). CONCLUSIONS: In both groups cardiovascular risk decreased significantly after one year of treatment by practice nurses. No additional effect of basing proactive advice on self-monitoring was found, despite the investment of additional time. TRIAL REGISTRATION: trialregister.nl NTR2188.

title: Randomized controlled trial to assess the efficacy of a primary health care liaison worker in promoting shared care for opioid users
abstract: BACKGROUND: Recent national guidelines emphasize the requirement that all general practitioners care for drug users within a shared care scheme and suggest that a primary health care liaison worker (PHCLW) can facilitate these arrangements. We conducted a cluster-randomized, randomized controlled trial to determine the efficacy of a PHCLW in promoting shared care. METHODS: Primary health care teams at Stockport Health Authority, North West England, were randomly assigned to either an intervention arm, offered the services of a PHCLW, or a control arm, who was offered the standard support of the community drug team (CDT). The proportion of CDT clients with a history of regular opioid misuse who were in shared care 12 months after randomization was compared between study arms. RESULTS: Eighteen (24.0 percent) of the 75 CDT clients in the intervention arm but none of the 80 CDT clients in the control arm were in shared care at 12 months (chi2 = 9.37, df = 1, p < 0.01"; "95 percent confidence interval 8.6-39.4 percent). CONCLUSION: A PHCLW can significantly increase the number of CDT clients in shared care arrangements.

title: Randomized controlled trial: effect of nutritional counseling in general practice
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To investigate the effectiveness of a 15-minute unstructured educational intervention conducted by general practitioners (GPs) on daily diet modifications among healthy adults. DESIGN: Two-arm randomized trial with a duration of 12 months. SETTING: Italian general practitioner wards. Subjects A total of 3,186 men and women aged 18 to 65 years recruited from the medical ward by their GPs. INTERVENTIONS: An educational intervention and booklet on the basics of a healthy diet based on the Italian Guidelines for Correct Nutrition, 1998. The primary goal of the study was to achieve fruit and vegetable intake > 5 servings per day. Control visit every 6 months. Main outcome measures Weight, blood pressure, and 40-item food frequency questionnaire. RESULTS: The intervention group showed a slightly reduced net intake of meat and a slightly higher net intake of fruits and vegetables, fish products, and olive oil. Body mass index (BMI) changed only in the treatment arm [-0.41, 95% confidence interval (95% CI) -0.11 to -0.53]. The net change at 1 year in the intervention arm was +1.31 (CI 0.90-4.39) for fruit and vegetables, and -0.22 (-0.11 to -0.69) for meat ( servings per week). We also calculate a "healthy diet score" that reflects adherence to recommended dietary habits. In the intervention group, the mean score at enrollment was significantly lower than the mean score at the end of follow-up (raw score change = 0.29" CI 0.19-0.48). No difference was observed in the control group (raw score change = -0.04; CI -0.22-0.02). The score difference from baseline to final visit, comparing the intervention group versus the control group, was statistically significant (P < 0.001) (MANOVA adjusted for sex, BMI, education, and time). CONCLUSIONS: A brief educational intervention by clinicians can induce multiple dietary changes that can lower BMI and potentially reduce chronic disease risk in generally healthy adults.

title: Randomized study of online immunization reminders in adult primary care
abstract: Online immunization reminders were implemented in an adult medicine environment where all immunization history, vaccine ordering, and charts were required online. Physicians were randomly assigned to one of two arms in a crossover design. Each arm was shown online recommendations for vaccines indicated by nationally accepted guidelines during either the first or second part of the study period. The main objective of the study was to evaluate the impact of reminders on the correct decisions related to the prescription of vaccines. Online reminders had the following impact on physician behavior: 1) Physicians used the app nearly 3 times more when shown reminders. 2) Physicians in the recall group were 27% less likely to order a vaccine than the recall group (p value 0.0005). 3) Compliance with guidelines was significantly improved for tetanus and hepatitis B in several analyses. No such effects were found for pneumococcal, measles, or influenza vaccines.

title: Randomized trial of a clinical decision support system: impact on the management of children with fever without apparent source.
abstract: Objective: to evaluate compliance with a clinical decision support system (CDSS) for the diagnostic management of children with fever without an apparent source and to study the effects of the application of the CDSS on the length of stay in the emergency department (ED). and the number of laboratory tests. Design: The CDSS was used by ED nursing staff to record children with fever. The CDSS identified children who met the inclusion criteria (1-36 months and fever with no apparent source (FWS)) and provided patient-specific diagnostic management advice. Children at high risk of serious bacterial infection were randomly assigned to the "intervention" group (n _x0001_ 74) or the "control" group (n _x0001_ 90). In the intervention group, the CDSS provided advice to immediately order laboratory tests, and in the control group, the ER physician first evaluated the children and then decided to order laboratory tests. Results: Compliance with the registry of febrile children was 50% (683/1,399). Adherence to the advice to request laboratory tests was 82% (61/74). Children in the intervention group had a median (25th to 75th percentile) emergency department stay of 138 (104 to 181) minutes. The mean length of stay in the emergency department in the control group was 123 (83-179) minutes. Laboratory tests were ordered significantly more frequently in the intervention group (82%) than in the control group (44%, p 0.001, test _x0001_2). Conclusion: Implementation of a CDSS for the diagnostic management of young children with unexplained fever was successful in terms of compliance and adherence to CDSS recommendations, but had unexpected effects on patient outcome in terms of length of stay. in the emergency department and number of laboratory tests. The use of the current CDSS was discontinued.

title: Randomized trial of predictive control model to improve anemia management
abstract: Background and objectives: Variable hemoglobin (Hb) response to erythropoiesis-stimulating agents may result in adverse outcomes. The usefulness of the predictive control model for drug dosing has been previously demonstrated. Design, Setting, Participants, and Measurements: This was a double-blind, randomized, controlled trial to test model predictive control for erythropoietin dosing in ESRD patients. The trial included 60 hemodialysis patients who were randomized into a treatment arm (30 subjects) that received erythropoietin doses based on computer recommendations or a control arm (30 subjects) that received erythropoietin doses based on computer recommendations. standard control of anemia. protocol (control). Subjects were followed for 8 months and Hb ratios measured within target 11 to 12 g/dl and outside 9 to 13 g/dl. The variability of the Hb level was measured by the absolute difference between the Hb achieved and the target Hb of 11.5 g/dl, as well as the area under the Hb curve. Results: Predictive control of the model resulted in 15 observations >13 or <9 g/dl (outliers), a mean absolute difference between Hb achieved and 11.5 g/dl of 0.98 ± 0.08 g/dl. dl, and an area under the Hb curve of 2.86 ± 1.46. The control group algorithm yielded 30 Hb outliers (P = 0.051), yielded a mean absolute difference between Hb achieved and 11.5 g/dL of 1.18 ± 0.18 g/dL (P < 0.001 difference in variance) and an area under the Hb Curve of 3.38 ± 2.69 (P = 0.025 difference in variance). Conclusions: The predictive control model of erythropoietin administration improves anemia management.

title: Randomized trial of problem-based versus didactic seminars to disseminate evidence-based guidelines on asthma management to primary care physicians
abstract: INTRODUCTION: This randomized controlled trial (RCT) investigated the effectiveness and satisfaction with small group problem-based learning (PBL) versus an educational lecture approach for disseminating guidelines in asthma control for common confounders in asthma. comparative educational interventions. METHODS: Sites were selected as conference or PBL using simple randomization. All participants were exposed to similar educational resources to ensure equivalence of treatment. Instruments included standardized program/host evaluation forms and a validated case-based questionnaire with a visual analog scale that measures the confidence level of responses. The latter occurred immediately before and after the intervention and 3 months later. The statistician was blinded to the intervention groups. RESULTS: Overall, 52 family physicians agreed to participate, 23 in the PBL sessions (mean 4.6 per group) and 29 in the didactic conference sessions (mean 7.25). There was no significant difference between the groups regarding the knowledge acquired in each application of the test. Participants rated the speaker/facilitator equally highly for having established a positive learning environment. PBL participants rated the perceived educational value of the program higher than conference participants (4.36 vs. 3.93";" p = 0.04). Both groups experienced a significant increase in asthma-related knowledge after the intervention. Attrition rates for the 3-month post-test were 14% for PBL participants vs. 32% for conference-based participants. DISCUSSION: PBL was as effective in knowledge acquisition and retention as conference-based continuing medical education (CME) programs. Further study is warranted to investigate whether the assessment of higher educational value or increased response rate to delayed testing is replicable in other RCTs addressing common confounders and whether these factors influence future participation of CME, changes in physician clinical behavior, or patient health outcomes.

title: Randomized trial to improve prescription safety in elderly outpatients.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To determine whether a computerized tool that alerted pharmacists when patients aged 65 years and older were recently prescribed potentially inappropriate medications was effective in decreasing the proportion of patients who were dispensed these medications. DESIGN: Prospective, randomized trial. SETTING: US Health Maintenance Organization PARTICIPANTS: All 59,680 health plan members age 65 and older were randomly assigned to intervention (n=29,840) or usual care (n=29,840).
