Pharmacists received alerts about all patients randomized to the intervention who were recently prescribed a specific medication. INTERVENTION: Prescription and age information was linked to alert pharmacists when a patient age 65 or older was recently prescribed one of 11 medications that are potentially inappropriate for the elderly. MEASUREMENTS: Physicians and pharmacists collaborated to develop the list of specific medications, indications for use of medications for which an intervention should be performed, intervention guidelines and scripts, and to implement the intervention. RESULTS: During the 1-year study, 543 (1.8%) patients in the intervention group aged 65 years or older received new prescriptions for specific medications, compared with 644 (2.2%) patients in the usual care group ( p = 0.002). For indications of drug use requiring intervention, amitriptyline (p < 0.001) and diazepam (p = 0.02) dispensations were reduced. CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrated the effectiveness of a computerized pharmacy alert system plus collaboration among health professionals to decrease the dispensing of potentially inappropriate medications in elderly patients. Combining the data available from information systems with the knowledge and skills of physicians and pharmacists can improve prescription safety in patients aged 65 and over.

title: Randomized Controlled Trial of the Efficacy of Simulation Education: A 24-Month Follow-up Study in a Clinical Setting
abstract: BACKGROUND: Currently, critical care nurses' knowledge and skills to adhere to evidence-based guidelines to avoid complications associated with intubation and mechanical ventilation are limited. We hypothesized that a single simulation educational session would lead to a higher lasting skill level among critical care nurses. MATERIAL AND METHODS: A randomized controlled trial was conducted in a mixed 22-bed adult medical-surgical intensive care unit in Finland during the period February 2012 to March 2014. Thirty of 40 critical care nurses initially randomized participated. at a 24-month follow-up. -up study. Behavior and cognitive development were assessed through a validated ventilation beam observation program and questionnaire at baseline measurement and repeated 3 times during simulation and in real-life clinical settings. RESULTS: After simulation education, the average skills score increased from 46.8% to 58.8% of the total score in the final measurement after the intervention (Ptime < 0.001, Ptime x group = 0.040 and Pgroup = 0 ,eleven). Mean knowledge scores within groups did not change significantly. The mean between-group difference in skill scores was significant only at the 6-month measurement (P = 0.006). CONCLUSIONS: Critical care nurses' abilities to adhere to evidence-based guidelines improved in both groups over time, but improvements between study groups were significantly different only at 6 months and were no longer evident after 6 months. 2 years after a single simulation education.

title: Rapid change in prescribing behavior in hospitals participating in guideline monitoring: stroke after publication of results from the Clopidogrel Treatment of Atherothrombosis in High-Risk Patients (MATCH) clinical trial
abstract: BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE: Physicians' prescribing patterns are slowly changing despite published randomized trials and consensus guidelines. We measured the effect of the Clopidogrel Management of Atherothrombosis in High-Risk Patients (MATCH) trial on discharge prescribing patterns for patients with stroke and those with transient ischemic attack in the Get With The Guidelines (GWTG)-Stroke program. METHODS: We analyzed the antithrombotic drug prescription patterns at discharge of patients admitted with ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack in hospitals participating in GWTG-Stroke between October 2002 and January 2006. Clinical information was analyzed by quarter in relation to the publication of the MATCH study. The frequency of prescription of aspirin+clopidogrel at discharge after the MATCH publication was compared with the pre-MATCH period after adjusting for patient and hospital characteristics and grouping by hospital. RESULTS: A total of 107,872 patients at 632 sites were eligible to receive antithrombotic therapy at discharge. The use of aspirin + clopidogrel therapy decreased from 22.4% to 15.4% of patients after the publication of MATCH (adjusted OR 0.62, 95% CI 0.56 to 0.70, P <0.0001). Quarterly analysis revealed a rapid and sustained decline in the use of aspirin + clopidogrel therapy during the remainder of the study period. CONCLUSIONS: A rapid and sustained reduction in the frequency of aspirin + clopidogrel use in ischemic stroke and transient ischemic attack was observed after publication of the MATCH trial in the absence of MATCH-specific GWTG-Stroke initiatives and before an update. of the American Heart Association guideline.

title: Rational prescribing in primary care (RaPP): economic evaluation of an intervention to improve professional practice.
abstract: Background Interventions designed to bridge the gap between research findings and clinical practice can be effective, but also costly. Economic evaluations are necessary to judge whether such interventions are worth the effort. We have evaluated the economic effects of a tailored intervention to support the implementation of guidelines for the use of antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering medications. The tailored intervention was evaluated in a randomized trial and was shown to significantly increase the use of thiazides for patients started on antihypertensive medications, but had little or no impact on other outcomes. The increased use of thiazides was not expected to have an impact on health outcomes. Methods and findings We performed cost-minimization and cost-effectiveness analyzes on data from a randomized trial involving 146 general practices from two geographical areas in Norway. Each practice was randomly assigned to either the personalized intervention (70 practices"; 257 physicians) or the control group (69 practices"; 244 physicians). Only patients starting antihypertensive medication were included in the analyses. A multifaceted intervention was designed to address the identified barriers to change. Key components were an educational outreach visit with audit and feedback, and computerized reminders. The pharmacists made the visits. A cost minimization framework was adopted, where intervention costs were compared with reduced treatment costs (mainly due to increased use of thiazides rather than more expensive drugs). The cost-effectiveness of the intervention was estimated as the cost per additional patient starting thiazides. The net annual cost (cost minimization) in our study population was US$53,395, which corresponds to US$763 per practice. The cost per additional patient started with thiazides (cost-effectiveness) was US$454. Net annual savings in a national program were modeled at $761,998, or $540 per practice after 2 years. In this scenario, savings outweighed costs in all but two of the sensitivity analyzes we performed, and the return was estimated at $183. Conclusions We found a significant change in the prescription of antihypertensive drugs towards the use of thiazides in our trial. One of the main reasons for promoting the use of thiazides is their lower price compared to other drugs. The cost of the intervention was more than double the savings within the time frame of our study. However, we anticipate modest savings over a 2-year period.

title: Rationale and design of the evaluation study of the effect of cardiovascular drugs provided as evidence-based generic samples (SAMPLES) of low cost
abstract: BACKGROUND: Highly effective generic cardiovascular drugs are frequently underused, leading to higher overall drug costs and cost-related noncompliance. OBJECTIVE: We attempted to evaluate an intervention to encourage the appropriate use of generic cardiovascular drugs without creating administrative or financial barriers that might impede the use of essential drugs. TRIAL DESIGN: The SAMPLES (Study Assessing the Effect of Cardiovascular Medications Provided as Low-cost, Evidence-based Generic Samples) trial is a clustered randomized controlled trial of the effect of providing physicians with free generic samples of hydrochlorothiazide for hypertensive patients and simvastatin for patients with hyperlipidemia. We will randomly select 660 primary care physicians in Pennsylvania, grouped by medical practice, to receive free samples for both conditions or no samples. We will use data on filled prescriptions obtained from a state-sponsored prescription drug assistance program to conduct an intent-to-treat assessment of the impact of the intervention on physician prescribing behavior (proportion of prescriptions that are generic) and the patient adherence. Secondary outcomes will include physician adherence to established guidelines and overall prescription drug costs. CONCLUSION: This trial will define the potential role of an innovative approach to stimulate clinically appropriate and cost-effective prescribing. We will determine whether free generic samples can reduce overall drug costs as well as patient out-of-pocket costs without sacrificing efficacy and whether this approach results in better adherence to essential cardiovascular medications. This intervention may also improve adherence to practice guidelines and improve the quality of care received. If effective, this strategy could be widely used by private insurers or government payers with the goal of stimulating higher-quality, more cost-effective care.

title: Reasons and consequences of low adherence to standard precautions by the nursing team
abstract: Standard precautions (SP) are recommendations to prevent infections and protect health workers during the provision of care, however, there is still low adherence to these recommendations. Objective To analyze the reasons and consequences of low adherence to standard precautions by nursing staff. Method integrative review of the literature, search in seven databases, from 2005 to 2014. Results 30 articles were selected for analysis. The reasons for low adherence evidenced are related to poor lifelong learning practices, risk behaviors of workers, inadequate provision of equipment and protective equipment and inadequate working conditions. The consequences are accidents and occupational diseases. There are few intervention studies, which are limited to guiding professionals. Conclusions The low adherence to standard precautions is linked to individual aspects of workers, employers and educational institutions. The intervention strategies carried out have been shown to be inefficient by focusing solely on the worker.

title: Visit intervals for oral health in primary care patients
abstract: BACKGROUND: The frequency with which patients should attend a dental checkup and the potential oral health effects of altering the checkup intervals between checkups have been the subject of ongoing international debate for nearly 3 decades. Although recommendations regarding optimal visit intervals vary between countries and dental health systems, general dentists have traditionally advocated dental check-ups every 6 months in many developed countries. OBJECTIVES: To determine the benefits and harms of different fixed revision intervals (for example, 6 months versus 12 months) for the following different types of dental revision: a) clinical examination only"; b) clinical examination plus scale and polish; c ) clinical examination plus preventative advice d) clinical examination plus preventative advice plus scale and polish To determine the relative benefits and harms between any of these different types of dental check-up at the same fixed check-up interval To compare the benefits and harms of the review intervals based on clinicians' assessment of patients' disease risk with fixed review intervals To compare the benefits and harms of no review interval/patient-driven care (which may be symptomatic) with fixed review intervals We searched the Coch Group Trials Register. Rane Oral Health, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), MEDLINE and EMBASE. Reference lists of relevant articles were reviewed and authors of some articles were contacted to identify additional trials and obtain additional information. Date of most recent searches: 5 March 2007. SELECTION CRITERIA: Trials were selected if they met the following criteria: design: random allocation of participants; participants: all children and adults receiving dental check-ups in primary care settings, regardless of their level of risk for oral disease; interventions: review intervals for the following different types of dental check-ups: a) clinical examination only; b) clinical examination plus peeling and polishing; c) clinical examination plus preventive advice; d) clinical examination plus scaling and polishing plus preventive advice; e) absence of patient-driven review/assistance interval (which may be symptomatic); f) review intervals based on physician risk; outcomes: clinical status outcomes for dental caries (including but not limited to mean DMFT/DMFT scores, DMFT/DMFS, caries increment, filled teeth (including replacement restorations), early carious lesions arrested or reversed); periodontal disease (including, but not limited to, plaque, calculus, gingivitis, periodontitis, change in probing depth, attachment level);" oral mucosa (presence or absence of mucosal lesions, potentially malignant lesions, cancerous lesions, size and stage of lesions at diagnosis) Data collection and analysis: Two reviewers independently extracted, in duplicate, information on methods, participants, interventions, outcome measures, and results. considered necessary and where possible, for additional details on study design and data clarification An assessment of the quality of the included trial was carried out Cochrane Collaboration statistics guidelines were followed MAIN RESULTS: Only one study (with 188 participants) was included in this review and assessed as being at high risk of bias.This study provided or limited data on dental caries outcomes (increase in CPM/DMFS) and economic cost outcomes (reported time taken to provide examinations and treatment). AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: There is insufficient evidence from randomized controlled trials (RCTs) to draw any conclusions regarding the possible benefits and harms of altering the visiting interval between dental check-ups. There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the practice of encouraging patients to attend dental check-ups every 6 months. It is important that high quality RCTs are conducted for the outcomes listed in this review in order to address the objectives of this review.

title: Visit intervals for oral health in primary care patients
abstract: BACKGROUND: The frequency with which patients should attend a dental checkup and the potential oral health effects of altering the checkup intervals between checkups have been the subject of ongoing international debate for nearly 3 decades. Although recommendations regarding optimal visit intervals vary between countries and dental health systems, general dentists have traditionally advocated dental check-ups every 6 months in many developed countries. OBJECTIVES: To determine the benefits and harms of different fixed revision intervals (for example, 6 months versus 12 months) for the following different types of dental revision: a) clinical examination only"; b) clinical examination plus scale and polish; c ) clinical examination plus preventative advice d) clinical examination plus preventative advice plus scale and polish To determine the relative benefits and harms between any of these different types of dental check-up at the same fixed check-up interval To compare the benefits and harms of the review intervals based on clinicians' assessment of patients' disease risk with fixed review intervals To compare the benefits and harms of no review interval/patient-driven care (which may be symptomatic) with fixed review intervals We searched the Coch Group Trials Register. Rane Oral Health, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), MEDLINE and EMBASE. Reference lists of relevant articles were reviewed and authors of some articles were contacted to identify additional trials and obtain additional information. Date of most recent searches: 9 April 2003. SELECTION CRITERIA: Trials were selected if they met the following criteria: design: random allocation of participants; participants: all children and adults receiving dental check-ups in primary care settings, regardless of their level of risk for oral disease; Interventions: review intervals for the following different types of dental check-ups: a) clinical examination only; b) clinical examination plus peeling and polishing; c) clinical examination plus preventive advice; d) clinical examination plus scaling and polishing plus preventive advice; e) absence of patient-driven review/assistance interval (which may be symptomatic); f) review intervals based on physician risk; outcomes: clinical status outcomes for dental caries (including but not limited to mean DMFT/DMFT scores, DMFT/DMFS, caries increment, filled teeth (including replacement restorations), early carious lesions arrested or reversed); periodontal disease (including, but not limited to, plaque, calculus, gingivitis, periodontitis, change in probing depth, attachment level);" oral mucosa (presence or absence of mucosal lesions, potentially malignant lesions, cancerous lesions, size and stage of lesions at diagnosis) DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two authors independently extracted, in duplicate, information on methods, participants, interventions, outcome measures, and results. where considered necessary and where possible, for further details on study design and data.clarification.A quality assessment of the included trial was carried out.The Cochrane Oral Health Group's statistical guideline Group) Ideal lines were followed MAIN RESULTS: Only one study (with 188 participants) was included in this review and assessed as high risk of s I am. This study provided limited data on dental caries outcomes (increased CPM/DMFS) and economic cost outcomes (reported time taken to provide examinations and treatment). AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: There is insufficient evidence from randomized controlled trials (RCTs) to draw any conclusions regarding the possible benefits and harms of altering the visiting interval between dental check-ups. There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the practice of encouraging patients to attend dental check-ups every 6 months. It is important that high quality RCTs are conducted for the outcomes listed in this review in order to address the objectives of this review.

title: Recent Trends in Violence-Related Behaviors Among High School Students in the United States
abstract: Context Violence-related behaviors, such as fighting and carrying weapons, are associated with serious physical and psychosocial consequences for adolescents. Objective To measure trends in nonfatal violent behaviors among adolescents in the United States between 1991 and 1997. Design, setting, and participants Nationally representative data from the 1991, 1993, 1995, and 1997 Youth Risk Behavior Surveys were analyzed to describe the percentage of students in grades 9-12 who engaged in behavior related to violence. The overall response rates for each of these years were 68%, 70%, 60%, and 69%, respectively. To assess the statistical significance of time trends for these variables, logistic regression analyzes were performed that controlled for gender, grade, and race/ethnicity and simultaneously tested for linear and higher-order effects. Main outcome measures Self-reported carrying of weapons, physical fights, fight-related injuries, feeling unsafe, and property damaged or stolen. Results Between 1991 and 1997, the percentage of students in a physical fight decreased 14%, from 42.5% (95% confidence interval [CI], 40.1%-44.9%) to 36.6% (95 % CI, 34.6%-38.6%)"; the percentage of students injured in a physical fight decreased 20%, from 4.4% (95% CI, 3.6%-5.2%) to 3.5% (95% CI, 2.9%-4.1%); and the percentage of students who carried a weapon decreased by 30%, from 26.1% (95% CI, 23.8%-28 .4%) to 18.3% (95% CI, 16.5%-20.1%). Between 1993 and 1997, the percentage of students who carried a weapon decreased from 25% to 7.9% (95% CI, 6.6%-9.2%) to 5.9% (95% CI, 5.1%-6.7%); the percentage of students in a physical fight on school property decreased 9%, from 16.2% (95% CI, 15.0%-17.4%) to 14.8% (95% CI, 13.5%-16.1%);" and the percentage of students carrying a weapon on school property decreased by 28%, from 11.8% (95% CI, 10.4%-13.2%) to 8.5% (95% CI, 7.0 %-10.0%). All of these changes represent significant linear decreases. Conclusions The declines in fighting and gun ownership among US adolescents between 1991 and 1997 are encouraging and consistent with declines in homicide, nonfatal victimization, and school delinquency rates. Further research should explore why behaviors related to interpersonal violence are declining and what types of interventions are most effective.

title: Recommendations for the treatment of depression in older community adults
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To present recommendations for community treatment of depression in old age to public health and aging networks. METHODS: An expert panel of mental health and public health researchers and community professionals on aging was convened in April 2006 to formulate consensus-based recommendations. In making recommendations, the panelists considered the feasibility and appropriateness of community-based provision, as well as the strength of the evidence on the effectiveness of the program from a systematic literature review of articles published up to 2005. RESULTS : The expert panel strongly recommended depression care management-based interventions delivered at home or in primary care clinics. The panel recommended individual cognitive behavioral therapy. Interventions not recommended as primary treatments for depression in old age included education and skills training, comprehensive geriatric health assessment programmes, exercise, and physical rehabilitation/occupational therapy. There was insufficient evidence to make recommendations for several intervention categories, including group psychotherapy and psychotherapies other than cognitive behavioral therapy. CONCLUSIONS: This interdisciplinary panel of experts determined that recommended interventions need to be disseminated across public health and aging networks, while acknowledging the challenges and obstacles involved. Interventions that were not recommended or had insufficient evidence often did not treat depression primarily and/or did not include a clinically depressed sample when trying to establish efficacy. These interventions may provide other benefits but should not be assumed to treat depression effectively on their own. The panelists also identified the primary prevention of depression as a highly understudied area. These findings should help individual clinicians, as well as public health decision makers, in the delivery of population-based mental health services in various community settings.

title: Recommendation service for patients with chronic diseases in the home environment of multi-model sensors
abstract: With advanced technologies available, there are potential applications and services built around monitoring the activities of daily living (ADLs) of older people in nursing homes. Most of the elderly people in these facilities suffer from different chronic diseases such as dementia. Existing technologies focus primarily on medication-free interventions and ADL monitoring to address loss of autonomy or well-being. The monitoring and management of ADLs related to cognitive behaviors for intervention without medication are very effective in improving the conditions of patients with dementia. However, the cognitive functions of patients can be improved if appropriate drug recommendations are given at a given time. Previously, we developed the secure wireless sensor network embedded cloud computing for ubiquitous life care (SC(3)). CS(3) services were limited to monitoring the ADLs of older people with Alzheimer's disease and providing non-medication recommendations to the patient. In this article, we propose a system called the Smart Clinical Decision Support System (CDSS) as an integral part of the SC(3) platform. Using Smart CDSS, patients have access to medication recommendations from expert physicians. Physicians are provided with an interface to create clinical knowledge for medication recommendations and to observe the patient's condition. The clinical knowledge created by clinicians as the Smart CDSS knowledge base produces medication recommendations for the caregiver based on each patient's symptoms.

title: Recruiting hospitalized patients for research: how do participants differ from eligible non-participants?
abstract: BACKGROUND: Randomized controlled trials provide strong evidence for guidelines and interventions. However, much of the eligible population refuses to be studied. OBJECTIVE: To identify differences between participants and eligible non-participants in (1) perceived stress, (2) self-efficacy, (3) recovery expectations, (4) discussion of advance directives, and (5) understanding of a standard prescription label (health literacy) . DESIGN: Quasi-experimental prospective cohort study in 5 acute care hospitals. METHODS: We approached 295 hospitalized patients as they were being recruited for a behavioral intervention and asked them to answer 5 screening questions. We compared respondents' responses to their acceptance of the behavioral intervention and to Medicare claims and enrollment data. We used multivariate logistic regression to compare consent rates based on responses to screening questions. SETTING/PATIENTS: Medicare fee-for-service hospital patients. RESULTS: Patients were less likely to consent to behavioral intervention when they reported feeling unable to control important things in their lives (odds ratio [OR]: 0.35, 95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.14 -0.92), had low expectations of recovery (OR: 0.17, 95% CI: 0.06-0.45), or were confused by a question (OR: 0.11, 95% CI: 0, 05-0.24). In contrast, people who answered the medication question incorrectly were more likely to consent to the behavioral intervention (OR: 3.82, 95% CI: 1.12-13.03). There were no significant differences in consent for patients who reported feeling overwhelmed or reported discussing advance care planning with family members or physicians. CONCLUSIONS: Hospitalized eligible nonparticipants differed on constructs related to perceived stress, expectation of recovery, and health literacy. Recognizing such characteristics may inform strategies to improve hospital intervention recruitment and representation in clinical trials.

title: Recruitment and retention of elderly patients in clinical trials: problems and strategies
abstract: Doctors and researchers alike are shifting their focus to older patients to find the most effective treatments for a variety of psychiatric conditions. Clinical trials with elderly patients are necessary because they consume the largest number of prescription drugs. There are special challenges and considerations in designing and conducting clinical trials. The authors review the various phases of such research, including recruiting appropriate patients and retaining enrollees, and make suggestions, using examples from completed research studies, that illustrate the methods that have been most successful.

title: Recurrence after surgical treatment of hidradenitis suppurativa
abstract: Six to 89 months after surgery, 82 patients who had been treated by radical surgery (118 excisions) for intractable hidradenitis suppurativa were reviewed. Local recurrence rates varied widely by disease site, being low after axillary (3%) and perianal (0%) surgery and high after inguinoperineal (37%) and submammary (50%) excision. Recurrence is the result of improper excision or unusually wide distribution of the apocrine glands, but physical factors such as obesity, local pressure, and skin maceration have played a role in some patients. Recurrence due to inappropriate surgery tended to be the most problematic. At follow-up, 75 (91%) of the patients were satisfied with the results of their operation. A quarter of the patients developed disease in a new anatomic site after the operation. Radical surgery provides good symptomatic control for severe hidradenitis suppurativa of the axillary, inguinoperineal, and perianal regions, but is less satisfactory for submammary disease.

title: Redesign of the 'architecture of choice' of hospital prescription charts: a mixed methods study incorporating in situ simulation tests.
abstract: Objectives To incorporate behavioral insights into the user-centered design of an inpatient prescription chart (Imperial Drug Chart Evaluation and Adoption Study, IDEAS chart) and to determine whether changes in the content and design of prescription charts could influence prescription behavior and reduce prescription errors. Design A mixed methods approach was adopted in the project development phase; in situ simulation was used to assess the efficacy of the newly developed IDEAS prescription chart. Setting A London university hospital. Interventions/Methods A multimodal approach comprising ( 1) an exploratory phase consisting of chart reviews, focus groups, and user input gathering (2) iterative design of the IDEAS prescription chart, and finally (3) testing of the final chart with prescribers using in-situ simulation. observed substantial variation between existing inpatient prescription charts used in 15 different hospitals in the UK Review of 40 completed prescription charts from one hospital demonstrated a number of common prescription errors, including illegibility and difficulty in identifying prescribers Insights from focus groups and direct observations were translated into the design of the IDEAS chart. On-site simulation tests revealed significant improvements in prescribing at t The IDEAS table was compared to the prescribing table currently in use at the study hospital. Medication orders on the IDEAS chart were significantly more likely to include correct dose entries (164/164 vs. 166/174; p=0.0046), as well as the prescriber's printed name (163/164 vs. 0/ 174; p<0.0001) and contact number (137/164 vs. 55/174; p<0.0001). The indication of anti-infectives (28/28 vs 17/29; p<0.0001) and the duration (26/28 vs 15/29"; p<0.0001) were more likely to be completed with the IDEAS table. Conclusions a simulated context, the IDEAS chart Prescribing chart significantly reduced a number of common prescribing errors, including dosing errors and illegibility Positive behavior change was observed without prior education or support, suggesting that some common errors in prescription writing are potentially rectifiable simply through changes to the content and layout of the prescription boxes.This is an open access article distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial (CC BY-NC 4.0) license, which permits to others to distribute, remix, adapt, build on this work for non-commercial purposes, and license its derivative works under different terms, provided that the original work is properly cited and the non-commercial use. See: http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/

title: Reducing the risk of cardiovascular disease in patients with diabetes: a message from the National Diabetes Education Program
abstract: PURPOSE: To provide nurse practitioners (NPs) with a review of current practice guidelines that help clinicians reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with diabetes and its major macrovascular complications. DATA SOURCES: This document presents data from major evidence-based studies and clinical trials that define the scope of the problem, the rationale for risk reduction, and a patient-centered plan of action for NPs to effectively manage risk factors. cardiovascular risk in people with diabetes. CONCLUSIONS: NPs are active partners in the National Diabetes Education Program and play a key role in efforts to effectively manage cardiovascular risk factors in people with diabetes and improve their awareness of the link between diabetes and heart disease and stroke. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: The action plan to reduce cardiovascular risk in people with diabetes will help NPs implement the most effective management strategies for medical nutrition therapy, physical activity, and drug therapy necessary for focused proactive management in the patient of hyperglycemia, hypertension and lipids. abnormalities.

title: Reducing the amount of blood transfused: a systematic review of behavioral interventions to change clinicians' transfusion practices
abstract: BACKGROUND: Transfusion services have used various techniques to reduce the use of blood products. Given the potential adverse effects of transfusions and the resources consumed in implementing strategies to reduce transfusions, there is a need to understand their effectiveness. Therefore, we conducted a systematic review of the literature to examine the effectiveness of behavioral interventions to reduce the use of blood products. METHODS: We identified all relevant articles by using electronic searches of MEDLINE and EMBASE, as well as manual searches of review articles and personal files. Electronic searches included articles published between January 1966 and May 2003. Searches included the terms blood transfusion, plasma exchange, guidelines, education, practice patterns, and professional practice. The outcomes of interest were the number of units transfused and the proportion of patients receiving transfusions. RESULTS: Nineteen studies examining the effectiveness of single (guidelines, prospective audits, retrospective audits, and reminders) or multifaceted interventions to reduce red blood cell, platelet, plasma, cryoprecipitate, and albumin transfusions met the inclusion criteria. Eighteen studies demonstrated a relative reduction in the number of units administered (range, 9%-77%) or the proportion of patients receiving transfusions (range, 17%-79%). The reported reductions were qualitatively similar for the different blood products studied. No single intervention or combination of interventions appeared more effective in reducing utilization. CONCLUSIONS: Behavioral interventions, including simple interventions, appear to be effective in changing clinicians' transfusion practices and reducing blood utilization. Properly designed clinical trials are still needed to determine the relative effectiveness of different interventions in changing practices.

title: Reduce the risk of alcohol use disorders in women
abstract: Nurses and other doctors help women examine their lifestyles and consider changes to promote optimal health. When the question is about alcohol consumption, what should be recommended? While a moderate intake can be beneficial for cardiovascular and bone health, drinking more than the recommended amount increases the risk of harmful effects. This column examines moderate drinking guidelines for women, reviews the assessment process, and demonstrates an example of a brief intervention. A screening, brief intervention, and referral for treatment program (called SBIRT by the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration) should be part of the standard screening for every woman. Ongoing assessment of alcohol use can help better target behaviors for early intervention.

title: Reducing therapeutic injection overuse through patient-prescriber interaction group discussions in Kinondoni district, Dar es Salaam, Tanzania
abstract: Inappropriate prescribing of injections has been reported in developing and developed countries. Previous studies in Tanzania showed that more than 70% of patients attending outpatient clinics in private clinics received at least one injection per visit, higher than the WHO recommended target of 10%. This is concerning considering the likelihood of adverse effects from the possible use of unsafe syringes to transmit HIV, hepatitis B and C, polio, and the additional economic impact on the patient and the health care system. This study aimed to investigate the impact of behavioral change interaction group discussion on injection prescribing practices at ten selected public clinics in Kinondoni district, Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. Records of patient injection prescriptions covering the three-month period prior to the study were obtained from 5 randomly selected control facilities and 5 randomly selected intervention facilities. In each health facility, mothers and prescribers were given IGDs for one month, followed by a survey 3 months after the IGD to determine the impact of the IGDs. Chi-square statistical calculations were performed to compare data on the percentage of prescriptions with an injection prescribed and those conforming to national standard treatment guidelines (STGs) between baseline and 3-month follow-up. The results showed no significant difference between the percentage of prescriptions with an injection prescribed at baseline and 3-month follow-up at public clinics (P>0.05, Chi2 test). STG-compliant prescribed injections were low at baseline and did not improve significantly 3 months later (P>0.05, Chi2 test). Comprehensive studies and awareness of compliance with STG by prescribers are recommended.

title: Reduced rates of ventilator-associated pneumonia through a staff education program
abstract: Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) is the most common nosocomial infection in mechanically ventilated patients and results in increases in mortality, prolonged hospitalization, and costs. Preventive measures for VAP are well documented and evidence-based, but remain poorly implemented in most intensive care units. We conducted a pre- and post-intervention observational study to assess whether an educational program focused on preventive practices for VAP could reduce incidence. Six hundred and seventy-seven adult patients, mechanically ventilated for >48 h, were included in the study population. An evidence-based guideline for preventive practices at the bedside was developed and disseminated to intensive care unit staff. The incidence rates of NAR were compared before and after the implementation of the educational program. VAP infection rates were reduced by 51%, from a mean of 13.2+/-1.2 in the pre-intervention period to 6.5+/-1.5/1000 device days in the post-intervention period (mean difference 6.7"; 95% CI: 2.9-10.4, p=0.02). A multidisciplinary educational program targeting intensive care unit staff can successfully reduce VAP incidence rates. More studies will be needed to assess the impact on broader outcome measures, such as costs or mortality.

title: Reduction of clinical abnormalities of the lower extremities in patients with non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus. A randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the effect of patient, health professional, and systems intervention on the prevalence of lower extremity amputation risk factors in patients with non-insulin dependent diabetes. DESIGN: Blinded, randomized, controlled trial. SETTING: Academic practice of general medicine. PARTICIPANTS: Of the 395 patients with non-insulin dependent diabetes who underwent the initial patient evaluation, 352 completed the study. INTERVENTION: The 12-month intervention was multifaceted. Patients received foot care education and signed a behavioral contract for desired foot self-care, which was reinforced by telephone and postal reminders. Healthcare providers were provided with practical guidelines and informative flowcharts on foot-related risk factors for amputation in diabetic patients. In addition, folders for intervention patients had special identifiers that prompted health care providers to: 1) request that patients remove their shoes, 2) perform foot exams, and 3) provide foot care education. feet. RESULTS: Patients who received the intervention were less likely than control patients to have serious foot injuries (baseline prevalence, 2.9%; odds ratio, 0.41 [95% CI, 0.16 to 1 .00]; P = 0.05) and other dermatological abnormalities. In addition, they were more likely to report appropriate foot self-care behaviors, to have foot exams during office visits (68% vs. 28%; P < .001), and to receive foot care education by part of health care providers (42% vs. 18%; P < .001). Physicians assigned to intervention patients were more likely than physicians assigned to control patients to examine patients' feet for ulcers, pulses, and abnormal dermatological conditions and to refer patients to the podiatry clinic (10 .6% compared to 5.0%). %;" p = 0.04). CONCLUSIONS: An intervention designed to reduce risk factors for lower extremity amputations positively affected patient foot self-care behavior as well as foot care provided by caregivers. healthcare providers and reduced the prevalence of clinical lower extremity disease in patients with diabetes.

title: Referral for advice on fertility preservation in women with cancer
abstract: STUDY QUESTION: What changes can be detected in fertility preservation counseling (FP) (FPC) over time and what are the determinants associated with the referral of patients with newly diagnosed female cancer, from 0 to 39 years of age, to a specialist in reproductive medicine for FPC? ? SUMMARY ANSWER: Although the absolute number of patients receiving FPC increased over time, only 9.8% of all potential patients (0-39 years of age) were referred in 2011, and disparities were found in referral relative to to the age of the patients, the diagnosis of cancer and the health care provider. -related factors. WHAT IS ALREADY KNOWN: Referral rates for FPC prior to initiation of gonadotoxic cancer treatment are low. Determinants associated with low referral and referral disparities have been identified in previous studies, although there are only sparse data on referral practices and determinants for FPC referral in settings with FP(C) reimbursement. STUDY DESIGN, SIZE, DURATION: We conducted a retrospective observational and questionnaire study in a Dutch university hospital. Data were collected on all cancer patients receiving FP counseling at this center (2001-2013), as well as all newly diagnosed female cancer patients aged 0-39 years in the region (2009-2011). PARTICIPANTS/MATERIALS, SETTING, METHODS: Data were retrieved from medical records (FPC patients), cancer incidences reported by the Dutch Cancer Registry (to calculate referral rates), and referral professionals (to identify referral rates). reasons for current bypass behavior). MAIN RESULTS AND THE ROLE OF CHANCE: In 2011, a total of 9.8% of patients were referred for PFC. Patients aged 20 to 29 years or diagnosed with breast cancer or lymphoma were more frequently referred compared with patients younger than 20 years or diagnosed with other malignancies. The absolute number of patients receiving FPC increased over time. Health care provider-related determinants for low referral were not initiating a discussion about fertility-related issues, not knowing where to refer a patient for FPC, and not collaborating with patient associations. LIMITATIONS, GROUNDS FOR CAUTION: Actual referral rates may differ slightly from our estimate, as there may be patients who did not wish to receive FPC. Occasionally, patients may have been referred directly to other regions or may have received ovarian transposition without FPC. By excluding skin cancer patients, we will have underestimated the group of women eligible for FPC, as this group also includes melanoma patients who might have received gonadotoxic therapy. WIDER IMPLICATIONS OF THE FINDINGS: The low referral rates and referral disparities reported in the current study indicate that opportunities exist to improve referral practices. Future research should focus on the implementation and evaluation of interventions to improve referral practices, such as patient information materials in oncology departments, discussion messages, or methods to increase physician and patient knowledge of FP techniques and guidelines. . STUDY FUNDING/COMPETING INTERESTS: This work was supported by Radboud University Medical Center and Radboud Institute of Health Sciences. The authors have declared no conflict of interest regarding this work. TEST REGISTRATION NUMBER: Not applicable.

title: Regeneration of peripheral nerves after injury
Regulating and legislating security: the case of candor
Regulatory Models for Human Embryo Cloning: The Free Market, Professional Guidelines, and Government Restrictions
abstract: Both experimental and therapeutic uses of new reproductive technologies have been governed not by the medical ideology of the best interests of patients and their children, but by the market ideology of profit maximization under the guise of "reproductive freedom." The government in our constitutional and democratic society has the authority and obligation to make and enforce reasonable regulations to manage the new reproductive market in order to protect the interests of the public, intended parents and their intended children. The "cloning" debate provides a useful opportunity to compare and contrast competing free-market regulatory models, professional guidelines, and government restrictions.

title: Rehabilitation of antisocial personalities: treatment through self-governance strategies
abstract: It is widely assumed that offenders with antisocial personality disorder (ASPD) reject psychotherapeutic intervention. Some commentators therefore argue that people with the disorder are better handled in the criminal justice system, where, following the introduction of indeterminate sentences, commitment to psychological treatment is coercively linked to the achievement of parole. By comparison, the National Institute for Clinical Excellence guidelines on the management and treatment of ASPD recommend that those seeking treatment should be considered for admission to specialized psychiatric hospitals. The reason is that prison interventions are under-resourced and treatment of ASPD is not a priority. The rationale is that ASPD offenders can be rehabilitated, if motivated. One problem, however, is that little is known about why ASPD offenders seek treatment or what effect subsequent treatment has on their self-understanding. The aim of this paper is to address these unresolved issues. It is based on the findings of the Economic and Social Research Council (ESRC)-funded qualitative study examining the experiences of convicted male offenders admitted to a specialized personality disorder ward within the security state. media and the doctors who treat them. The data is analyzed with reference to Michel Foucault's work on governance and strategy in power relations. Two arguments are advanced: First, ASPD offenders are motivated by coercive legal pressures to implement a variety of Foucauldian-type strategies to give the false impression of progress in treatment. Second, and related, treatment does not result in changes in self-understanding in the resistant client with ASPD. This presupposes that, at least with respect to this group, Foucault was wrong in asserting that resistance behaviors simply mask the efficacy of treatment norms over time. However, the work concludes that specialized treatment in the hospital setting can produce changes in the self-understanding of the resistive offender, but not if the completion of the treatment results, as usual, in his re-entry into prison.

title: Rehabilitation of children and adolescents
abstract: In recent years, a significant increase in most chronic physical and mental illnesses among children and adolescents has been reported. Therefore, the medical rehabilitation of children and adolescents plays an important role. Therefore, early diagnosis and multimodal intervention in childhood and adolescence are necessary to prevent a chronic course of the disease. Patient education programs have been shown to be effective in the treatment of chronic diseases. Those programs are primarily intended to improve compliance behavior and disease management. Consecutively, health status and quality of life should be improved. Due to the implementation of guidelines and evaluation studies, the quality of rehabilitation programs has improved during the last 15 years. However, future research should develop flexible rehabilitation programs in particular (duration of rehabilitation, rehabilitation near or far from the place of residence, rehabilitation chain with inpatient, partially outpatient and outpatient programmes), the efficacy of which needs to be tested.

title: Relapse of anxiety and fear successfully treated: theoretical issues and recommendations for clinical practice
abstract: Despite the existence of effective interventions for anxiety disorders, the relapse, or return of fear, presents a significant problem for patients and clinicians in the long term. This article draws on the experimental and clinical behavioral literature, reviewing the mechanisms by which the return of fear can occur. The purpose of the article was to generate a list of treatment recommendations for clinicians with the goal of reducing relapse in successfully treated anxiety disorders. The clinical and experimental literature on the mechanisms of renewal, reincorporation, spontaneous recovery and reacquisition is reviewed. These are linked to the clinical and experimental literature on the return of fear in successfully treated anxiety. A list of recommendations is presented to help reduce the likelihood of relapse in successfully treated anxiety. This list includes methods for use in the behavioral (exposure) treatment of anxiety disorders that aim to improve clinical outcomes. Despite the significant problem of relapse in successfully treated anxiety, there are methods available to reduce the likelihood of relapse through the return of fear. Physicians involved in the treatment of anxiety disorders should be aware of these methods to ensure an optimal outcome for the patient.

title: Relationship of the integrity of health research reports with the approval of reporting guidelines by journals: a systematic review
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess whether the integrity of health research reports is related to the approval of reporting guidelines by journals. DESIGN Systematic review. DATA SOURCES Reporting guidelines from a published systematic review and the EQUATOR network (October 2011). Studies assessing the completeness of reporting using an included reporting guideline (referred to as "assessments") (1990 to October 2011"; annex searches January 2012) from searches of Medline, Embase, and the Cochrane or Scopus Methodological Register, depending on the report guideline name STUDY SELECTION English reporting guidelines were included that provided explicit guidance for reporting, described the process of developing the guidance, and indicated the use of a consensus development process The CONSORT statement was excluded as assessments of adherence to CONSORT had been previously reviewed English or French assessments of included reporting guidelines were eligible if they assessed the completeness of study reporting as primary intention and those included studies allowed for the comparisons of interest (i.e. after versus before backup). or magazine and/or endorsement versus no endorsement). DATA EXTRACTION Potentially eligible evaluations of incl. The guidelines studied were initially reviewed by title and abstract and later as full-text reports. If eligibility was unclear, authors of assessments were contacted; Journal websites were consulted for supporting information where necessary. Reporting guidelines were analyzed for completeness of reporting in relation to approval per item and, where consistent with the authors' analysis, a summed mean score. RESULTS 101 reporting guidelines were included. Of 15,249 records retrieved from the evaluation search, 26 evaluations were identified that assessed reporting completeness in relation to approval of nine reporting guidelines. Of these, 13 assessments evaluating seven reporting guidelines (BMJ economic checklist, CONSORT for damage, PRISMA, QUOROM, STARD, STRICTA and STROBE) could be analyzed. The reporting guide items were evaluated by few evaluations. CONCLUSIONS The reporting integrity of only nine of the 101 health research reporting guidelines (excluding CONSORT) has been assessed in relation to journal endorsement. Elements of seven reporting guidelines were quantitatively analyzed, with few evaluations each. There is insufficient evidence to determine the relationship between journal support for reporting guidelines and the integrity of published health research reports. Journal editors and researchers should consider prospectively designed, controlled, collaborative studies to provide stronger evidence. SYSTEMATIC REVIEW REGISTRY Not registered; no known registry currently accepts protocols for systematic reviews of methodology.

title: Reminiscence therapy for dementia
abstract: BACKGROUND: Reminiscence therapy (RT) has been defined as the vocal or silent recollection of events in a person's life, either alone or with another person or group of people. It usually involves group meetings, at least once a week, in which participants are encouraged to talk about past events, often with the help of photos, music, objects and videos from the past. There is often little consistent application of psychological therapies in dementia services. Several of these 'therapies' were enthusiastically received by health professionals in unstimulating care settings. They were expected to work miracles and their 'failure' to do this has led to their widespread disuse. A systematic review of the available evidence is important to identify the effectiveness of different therapies. Subsequently, guidelines for their use can be made on a solid evidence base. OBJECTIVES: RT involves groups of older people who talk about past events, assisted by aids such as videos, images and files, as a means of communication and reflection on their life experiences. The aim of the review is to assess the effects of RT for dementia. SEARCH STRATEGY: We searched the Cochrane Controlled Trials Register, MEDLINE, PSYCHLIT, EMBASE, OMNI, BIDS, Dissertation Abstracts International, SIGLE, and reference lists of relevant articles up to 1998, contacting specialists in the field. We also searched relevant internet sites and handsearched Aging and Mental Health, the Gerontologist, Journal of Gerontology, Current Opinion in Psychiatry, Current Research in Britain: Social Sciences, British Psychological Society conference proceedings and the Reminiscence database. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized controlled trials and quasi-randomized trials of RT for dementia in the elderly. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two reviewers independently extracted data and assessed trial quality. MAIN RESULTS: Two trials were included in the review, but only one trial with 15 participants had extractable data. The results were not statistically significant for either cognition or behavior. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: No firm conclusions could be drawn regarding the effectiveness of RT for dementia. The review highlighted the urgent need for more systematic research in the area.

title: Remission, residual symptoms and lack of response in the usual treatment of major depression in directed clinical practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although published guidelines recommend continuation of treatment for depression until complete remission of symptoms and restoration of functioning, little is known about the frequency with which remission is achieved in routine practice and the precipitants of depression. termination of treatment when the result of treatment has not been optimal. METHOD: A naturalistic study design examined 1859 patients who received treatment for DSM-III-R major depression between 1995 and 1997 in the national provider network of a managed behavioral health organization (MBHO). Physician ratings of symptoms and deterioration were used to group patients into complete remission, partial remission, and no response. Claims data was used to characterize treatment and identify comorbid medical conditions. RESULTS: Based on physician ratings, approximately 27% to 39% of patients achieved a complete remission. Medical and substance use comorbidity and hospital admission were more frequent in those with partial response to treatment. Only half of the treatment-naive patients received a trial of medication during their treatment. Patient choice was the most common reason for treatment termination, although nearly 40% of clinicians agreed with patients' decisions even when symptoms had not improved. CONCLUSION: Although complete remission rates were comparable to those in clinical trials of antidepressants, the results suggest that clinicians may not recommend continuation and maintenance treatment according to best practice guidelines and that failed treatment often does not include antidepressant medication.

title: foot replantation
PHLS Communicable Disease Surveillance Center Report
abstract: An outbreak of Legionnaires' disease was reported among tourists returning from Yugoslavia between August and September; there were more outbreaks of gastrointestinal illnesses associated with shellfish; influenza received much publicity after it was suggested that an epidemic could occur during the coming winter; and two tropical diseases made headlines, leishmaniasis and cercarial dermatitis.

title: Report of the NIH Panel to Define Principles of Therapy for HIV Infection*
abstract: Recent advances in research have provided a substantially improved understanding of the biology of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection and the pathogenesis of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). With the advent of sensitive tools to monitor HIV replication in infected people, the risk of disease progression and death can be accurately assessed and the efficacy of anti-HIV therapies can be directly determined. Furthermore, when used appropriately, newly available combinations of potent antiviral therapies can achieve prolonged suppression of detectable levels of HIV replication and circumvent the inherent tendency of HIV to generate drug-resistant viral variants. However, as antiretroviral therapy for HIV infection has become increasingly effective, it has also become increasingly complex. Familiarity with recent research advances is necessary to ensure that the new therapies available are used in ways that most effectively improve the health and prolong the lives of people infected with HIV. To enable clinicians and people living with HIV to better utilize the rapidly accumulating new information on the pathogenesis and treatment of HIV disease, the Office of AIDS Research at the National Institutes of Health sponsored the Panel of NIH to define the principles of therapy of HIV infection. This Panel was asked to define the essential scientific principles that should be used to guide the most effective use of antiretroviral therapies and viral load testing in clinical practice. Based on a detailed consideration of the most current data, the Panel outlined eleven principles that address issues of critical importance to the treatment of HIV infection. These principles provide the scientific basis for the specific treatment recommendations made by the Clinical Practice Panel for the Treatment of HIV Infection sponsored by the Department of Health and Human Services and the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation. Reports from both dashboards are provided in this post. Together, they summarize the new data and provide both the scientific basis and specific guidelines for the treatment of people with HIV infection. This information will be of interest to health care providers, people living with HIV, HIV/AIDS educators, public health educators, public health authorities, and all organizations that fund people's health care. HIV infected.

title: Reproductive rights and the health care system: a plea for rational health policy
abstract: Recently, there have been many challenges to women's reproductive rights and freedoms: "court-ordered caesarean sections," criminal cases against women for prenatal child abuse, and attempts to limit the practice of midwifery, home birth, and the operation of childbirth. alternative. In these cases, medicine has been complicit or proactive in attempts to control the behavior or health care options of pregnant women. We discuss the role of medicine as an agent of social control, the medical reconstruction of problems of a and the need for a more coherent policy framework to guide medical practices." PIP: Reproductive issues are highly controversial. Women's legal right to abortion continues to be challenged, women's rights face rights of the fetus and there is concern about adolescent pregnancy, the appropriate use of reproductive technology and the use of drugs and alcohol during pregnancy.However, little attention has been paid to the role of medicine as an agent of social control and arbiter of reproductive behavior, medical reconstruction and intervention in problems that are essentially of a social nature, or of equity and social justice in the a reproductive health care. The authors discuss these latter issues in light of historical and more recent attempts to control the behavior of pregnant women. In the absence of current reproductive health policy, the medical profession makes arbitrary decisions in individual cases that may or may not reflect the wishes of the patient or the community. A more coherent policy framework and regulatory mechanisms are needed to guide medical practice. The authors discuss the problem in context, the key questions, social discrimination in reproductive health care, choice of what services to provide, coercion and choice, and reproductive health policy as a solution.

title: Requiring physicians to respond to computerized reminders improves their compliance with preventive care protocols.
abstract: Objective: To improve compliance with computer-generated reminders for fecal occult blood tests (FOBTs), mammograms, and cervical Pap tests. Design: six-month prospective, randomized, controlled trial. Setting: Academic practice of primary care general internal medicine. Subjects: Thirty-one professors of general internal medicine, 145 residents, and 5407 patients with scheduled visits who were eligible for any of the three cancer screening protocols. Intervention: Primary care teams of internal medicine residents and faculty received routine computerized reminders (control) or the same reminders who were asked to circle one of four responses: 1) "done/order today" , 2) " "not applicable to this patient", 3) "refused patient", or 4) "next visit". p=0.002) and separately with reminders for FOBT (61% vs. 49%, p=0, 0007) and mammography (54% vs. 47%, p=0.036) but not for cervical Pap smears (21% vs. 18%, p=0.2) Intervention residents responded significantly more often than control residents to all recalls together and separately to FOBT and mammography recalls, but not to Pap smears There was no significant difference between intervention and control faculty, but the compliance rate of the control teacher was significantly higher than the rate of control residents for all reminders together and separately for FOBT, but not for mammography or Pap smear. The effect of the intervention was greater in patients ≥70 years, with significant results for all tests, together and separately, for residents but not for teachers. Intervention clinicians felt that reminders were inapplicable 21% of the time (due to inadequate data in patients' electronic medical records) and stated that their patients refused 10% of the time. CONCLUSIONS: Asking physicians to respond to computer-generated reminders improved their compliance with preventive care protocols, especially for elderly patients for whom control physician compliance was lowest. However, 100% compliance with cancer screening reminders will be unattainable due to incomplete data and patient refusal.

title: Research based on archived information and samples. Recommendations of the Royal College of Physicians Committee on Ethical Issues in Medicine
abstract: In 1996, the College published Guidelines on the Practice of Ethics Committees in Medical Research Involving Human Subjects (3rd Edition), which includes a section on non-intrusive research. The recommendations published here are intended to clarify the issues surrounding this category of research as it relates to consent for the use of archived data and samples.

title: Research in the field of psychiatry.
Research in Practice: Collaboration for Applied Healthcare Research and Leadership (CLAHRC) for Nottinghamshire, Derbyshire, Lincolnshire (NDL)
abstract: Background To address the problem of translating evidence-based research into routine health care practice, the Nottinghamshire, Derbyshire and Lincolnshire Applied Health Care and Research Leadership Collaboration (CLAHRC-NDL) was funded by the National Institute for Health Research as one of nine CLAHRCs in England. This document describes the underlying theory and its application that the CLAHRC-NDL has adopted, as a case example that could be generalized to practice outside of the CLAHRC, compared to alternative implementation models. Discussion Conventional approaches to health research often generate evidence in isolation from the setting in which it is intended to be used. The premise of the CLAHRC-NDL model is that barriers to implementation can be overcome if knowledge is co-produced by academic and clinical services staff, taking into account the organizational context in which it will be applied. This approach is based on organizational learning theory, recognizing that change is a social and political phenomenon. The evidence is produced in real time, taking fully into account the environment in which it will be deployed. To support this process, senior health service staff are seconded to CLAHRC as Â¡Â®diffusion fellowsÂ¡Â¯ (DF) to actively bridge the gap between research and practice by being a full member of both the team of research as well as its area of clinical research. practice. To facilitate innovation and embed change in the local health community, existing communities of practice are enhanced and new ones are fostered around specific topics. Our approach has been adopted by 16 clinical research studies in the areas of mental health, children and youth, primary care, and stroke rehabilitation. Summary The CLAHRC-NDL implementation model applies organizational learning theory by addressing social and situational barriers and facilitators to implementation and adopting a co-production philosophy. Two key mechanisms for innovation translation have been used: FD, to actively bridge the gap between research and practice, and communities of practice, to underpin and sustain improvements in healthcare. The model shows promising results in putting research into practice, which may be transferable to other health care contexts.

title: Research opportunities in the area of early childhood: from birth to 5 years
abstract: The American Occupational Therapy Association (AOTA) Evidence-Based Practice Project has developed a table that summarizes early childhood research opportunities. The table provides an overview of the state of current available evidence on interventions within the occupational therapy scope of practice and is based on the AOTA Evidence-Based Practice Guideline Series systematic reviews. Researchers, students, and clinicians can use this information to develop groundbreaking research that answers important questions within the field of occupational therapy.

title: Research Priorities for Public Health Nursing
abstract: The Research Committee of the Association of Community Health Nursing Educators (ACHNE) initiated a review of the ACHNE Research Priorities for Public Health Nursing Practice in 2006, following those developed in 1992 and 2000. The The committee (a) reviewed public health nursing research abstracts (n = 485) from 7 selected nursing journals to assess progress in addressing the 2000 Priorities"; (b) identified the research methods used, the health problems and health behaviors addressed, and the demographics of the study populations in the abstracts"; and (c) reviewed the research priorities of major federal funding agencies and journal publishers. Overall, progress towards meeting the above priorities was modest, with a limited range of methods, topics, and examples described. The 2009 ACHNE Research Priorities for Public Health Nursing include: (1) Population-Centered Outcomes and (2) Public Health Nursing Workforce. Multi-site studies, clinical trials, community-based participatory research, development and/or analysis of existing large data sets, and development of valid and reliable methods are needed to address these priorities. Collaboration among educators, researchers, and practitioners is crucial to developing the scientific evidence base for population-based nursing practice.

title: Investigation of Effective Approaches to Cleaning in Hospitals: REACH Study Protocol, a Multi-Site Staggered Randomized Trial
abstract: Background The Research into Effective Approaches to Cleaning in Hospitals (REACH) study will generate evidence on the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a new cleaning initiative that aims to improve environmental cleanliness in hospitals. The initiative is an environmental cleaning package, with five interdependent, evidence-based components (training, technique, product, audit, and communication) implemented with environmental services personnel to improve hospital cleaning practices. Methods/Design The REACH study will use a stepped randomized controlled design to test the study intervention, an environmental cleaning package, in 11 Australian hospitals. All hospitals in the trial will receive the intervention and act as their own control, and an analysis of change within each hospital will be performed based on data collected in the control and intervention periods. Each site will be randomly assigned to one of 11 intervention times with staggered start dates in 2016 and an intervention period of between 20 and 50 weeks. All sites complete the trial at the same time in 2017. The inclusion criteria allow for a purposive sample of public and private hospitals that have higher-risk patient populations for healthcare-associated infections (HAIs). The primary outcome (objective one) is the monthly number of Staphylococcus aureus bacteraemias (SAB), Clostridium difficile infections (CDI), and vancomycin-resistant enterococcal infections (VRE), per 10,000 bed days. Secondary outcomes for objective one include thoroughness of hospital cleaning assessed using fluorescent tracer technology, bioburden of frequently touched surfaces after cleaning, and changes in staff knowledge and attitudes about cleaning. environmental cleanup. A business case analysis will determine the second key result (goal two): the incremental cost-benefit ratio of implementing the cleanup package. The study uses the Promoting Action on Implementation of Research in Health Services (iPARIHS) integrated framework to support the tailored implementation of the environmental cleanup package at each hospital. Discussion Evidence from the REACH trial will contribute to future policy and practice guidance on hospital environmental cleaning. It will be used by healthcare leaders and clinicians to inform decision making and implementation of best practice infection prevention strategies to reduce HAIs in hospitals.

title: Respond flexibly, but not incredulously, to drug addiction
Responding to patient-initiated mood: guidelines for practice
abstract: In recent decades, more and more evidence has shown the beneficial effects of humor. The use of caregiver-initiated humor as an intervention in healthcare settings has both physiological and emotional benefits. However, little has been written about another very important aspect of humor, patient-initiated humor. When patients use humor to relieve their feelings of stress, uncertainty, or shame, they are trying to communicate with their caregiver. This use of humor by patients is not to "play down" the situation, but rather a way to reduce their feelings of dehumanization. Humor is an interactive process of sharing and an important aspect of communication. Patients will watch the caregiver for an answer. An open and accepting response indicates understanding";" a negative or no response, however, can serve to isolate the patient. The guidelines discussed in this article for recognizing, interpreting, and responding to patient-initiated humor will help home care and palliative care nurses foster more open patient-caregiver communication and create a supportive, humanistic atmosphere for patient care. patient care.

title: Responding to youth health risks in primary care: a cluster randomized trial of clinician training in screening and motivational interviewing.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the effectiveness of a complex intervention that implements best practice guidelines that recommend clinicians assess and counsel youth on multiple psychosocial risk factors, clinicians' screening for health risks, and behavior of risk of patients, compared with a didactic seminar on the health of young people. . DESIGN: Pragmatic cluster randomized trial in which voluntary general practices were stratified by ZIP code advantage or disadvantage score and billing type (national private, free health, community health center), then randomized into intervention arms or comparison using a computer-generated random sequence. Three months after the intervention, patients were recruited from all practices after consultation for a computer-assisted telephone interview and followed up at three and 12 months later. The investigators who recruited, consented, and interviewed the patients and the patients themselves were blinded to allocation status; doctors don't. SETTING: General practice in metropolitan and rural Victoria, Australia. PARTICIPANTS: General practices with at least one interested clinician (GP or nurse practitioner) and their patients aged 14-24 years. INTERVENTION: This complex intervention was designed using evidence-based practices in learning and changing clinical behavior and general practice systems, and included best practice approaches to encourage change in adolescent risk behaviors. The intervention involved training of clinicians. (nine hours) in screening for health risks, use of a screening tool, and motivational interviewing; training of all practice staff (receptionists and doctors) to engage youth; providing feedback to clinicians on patient risk data; and two practice visits to support new screening and referral resources. Comparison physicians received a didac tic educational seminar (three hours) on youth engagement and health risk screening. OUTCOME MEASURES: Primary outcomes were patient report of (1) physician detection of at least one of six health risk behaviors (tobacco, alcohol, and illicit drug use, risks of sexually transmitted infections , STIs, unplanned pregnancy and road risks); and (2) change in one or more of the six health risk behaviors at three months or 12 months. Secondary outcomes were likelihood of future visits, trust in physician after exit interview, physician detection of emotional distress and relationship fear and abuse, and emotional distress at three and 12 months. Patient acceptability of the screening tool was also described for the intervention arm. Analyzes were adjusted for practice location and billing type, patients' gender, age, and recruitment method, and prior health risks, where applicable. An intention-to-treat analysis approach was used, including multilevel multiple imputation for missing outcome data. RESULTS: 42 practices were randomly assigned to the intervention or comparison arms. Two intervention practices withdrew their post assignments, prior to training, leaving 19 intervention practices (53 physicians, 377 patients) and 21 comparison practices (79 physicians, 524 patients). 69% of patients in the intervention (260) and comparison (360) arms completed the 12-month follow-up. Intervention physicians discussed more health risks per patient (59.7%) than comparison physicians (52.7%) and thus were more likely to detect a higher proportion of youth with at least one of all six health risk behaviors (38.4% vs. 26.7%, risk difference [RD] 11.6%, confidence interval [CI] 2.93% to 20.3%, odds ratio adjusted [OR] 1.7, CI 1.1 to 2.5). Patients reported less illicit drug use (RD -6.0, CI -11 to -1.2, OR 0.52, CI 0.28 to 0.96) and less risk of STIs (RD -5.4, CI -11 to 0.2, OR 0.66, CI 0.46 to 0.96) ) at three months in the intervention relative to the comparison arm, and for unintended pregnancy at 12 months (RD -4.4, CI -8.7 to -0.1;" OR 0.40, CI 0.20 to 0.80). No differences were detected between arms in other health risks.There were no differences in secondary outcomes apart from increased detection of abuse (OR 13.8, CI 1.71 to 111), no reports of harmful events, and youth in the intervention had a high acceptance of the screening tool CONCLUSIONS: A The complex intervention, compared to a simple educational seminar for practices, improved the detection of health risk behaviors in young people The impact on health outcomes did not was conclusive The technology that allows a more efficient detection of health risks and systematic approach can allow providers to target counseling to those most at risk. Additional trials require more power to confirm health benefits. TEST REGISTRATION: ISRCTN.com ISRCTN16059206.

title: Response to intervention: Principles and strategies for effective practice.
abstract: Meeting a key need, this is the first comprehensive guide to implementing a school-wide response to intervention (RTI) program. The book is designed to help practitioners understand and respond to No Child Left Behind and the new special education eligibility guidelines outlined in IDEIA 2004. It presents the theoretical and empirical underpinnings of the approach and a clear 10-step model to follow. conduct RTI procedures. with students experiencing learning difficulties. Special features include reproducible planning and implementation worksheets and more than two dozen master slides for use in RTI training sessions, bound flat for easy photocopying. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2016 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: Educator Responsibility
Results of a collaborative effort of physicians and respiratory therapists to improve long-term metered-dose inhaler technique in a pediatric asthma clinic
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite advances in therapy, asthma continues to be the chronic condition most responsible for school absenteeism and pediatric hospitalizations. This is especially true for inner city children. We operate a downtown Pediatric Asthma Compliance and Technique (PACT) clinic where physicians and respiratory therapists collaborate to improve metered-dose inhaler (MDI) technique and outcomes among children with asthma.
