OBJECTIVE: To determine the efficacy of our strategy to improve MDI technique and asthma outcomes. METHODS: Children referred to the PACT clinic underwent a standardized evaluation based on the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI) Expert Panel Guidelines. Physicians demonstrated and reinforced the correct MDI technique at each visit. Using a standardized format, we prospectively collected, at the patient's first visit (T1) and most recent visit (T2), demographic data, MDI technique scores ("MDI steps performed correctly"; scale of 0-8), functional pulmonary, and asthma severity (NHLBI rating scale: 1 = mild intermittent to 4 = severe persistent). Statistical analyzes were performed using parametric and nonparametric tests. RESULTS: Of the 60 patients who attended the PACT clinic between 1999 and 2002, 15 were excluded from the study due to incomplete data recording.The mean duration from T1 to T2 was 11.8 +/- 9.5 months.At T1 and T2, respectively, the mean MDI technique scores were 53% and 81%, mean overall asthma severity scores were 2.6 and 2.3, and mean overall lung function severity scores were 2.4 and 2.1. the MDI technique significantly improved between T I and T2 (p < 0.001). Black patients had the greatest improvement in the MDI technique (p < 0.001), but lung function test results, overall asthma severity, and lung function severity did not improve significantly. White patients significantly improved both their MDI technique (p = 0.004) and their overall asthma severity scores (p = 0.005). CONCLUSION: In our PACT clinic, asthmatic children showed sustained improvement in the MDI technique, with some of the patients improving in lung function and overall asthma severity score.

title: Outcomes That Matter: Structured vs. Unstructured Self-Monitoring of Blood Glucose in Type 2 Diabetes
abstract: Self-monitoring of blood glucose (SMBG) is one component of diabetes management. SMBG presents information on current glycemic status and provides the ability to get immediate feedback on the impact of behavioral and pharmacological interventions on glucose levels. However, SMBG is useful only when the glucose information is properly understood, the data is accurately interpreted, and the results drive appropriate therapeutic actions. The International Diabetes Federation (IDF) recently published guidelines for the use of SMBG in people with diabetes not treated with insulin, recommending that SMBG be used only when patients and/or their physicians have the ability and willingness to incorporate SMBG management and therapy adjustment into your diabetes care plan. If SMBG is used, the IDF also recommends that structured SMBG be performed using defined regimens to meet individual needs. Structured SMBG can be performed as daily glucose profiles that are representative of daily glucose variations. Measurement of pre-meal/post-meal blood glucose (bG) levels on consecutive or alternate days ("paired testing") also provides powerful glucose information for daily diabetes management. This article reviews recent studies that have appropriately used structured SMBG as an integral component of comprehensive diabetes management and discusses how their findings support IDF recommendations. Our goal is to help clinicians make more informed decisions about the value and usefulness of SMBG in diabetes management.

title: Rethinking Pragmatic Randomized Controlled Trials: Introducing the "Cohort Multiple Randomized Controlled Trial" Design
abstract: Pragmatic trials are important to inform routine clinical practice, but current designs have shortcomings. Clare Relton and colleagues describe the new design of 'multiple cohort randomized controlled trials', which could help address problems associated with existing approaches. "gold standard" for establishing how well an intervention works. However, trials purporting to determine the efficacy of a treatment using a double-blind, placebo-controlled design (ie explanatory trials) are sometimes criticized. For example, although explanatory trial design results in strong internal validity, we may rely on the results of a given trial, such trials may have limited external validity: we can â„¢Do not trust that we can apply the results to the usual clinical practice. Pragmatic trials, 1 2 which aim to inform healthcare decision-making in practice, have been offered as a solution because they retain the rigor of randomization (thereby eliminating selection bias) but retain the characteristics of practice normal clinic. The implementation and interpretation of both pragmatic and explanatory randomized controlled trials are associated with significant problems. This article describes a trial design that helps address these issues: the "cohort multiple randomized controlled trial" approach. Existing clinical trial designs may be deficient in four areas: recruitment; ethics; patient preferences; and treatment comparisons. ### Recruitment Most randomized controlled trials have difficulty recruiting sufficient numbers of patients. For example, one investigation found that less than a third of 114 publicly funded multicentre trials in the UK recruited their original target number of patients within the originally specified time.3 Failure to target recruitment may have implications for power and generalizability of trial results. In addition, many clinical trials exclude hard-to-reach groups and ethnic minorities,4 leading to disparities between the "in-need" (reference) population and the trial population.5 6 Ã¢â'¬ ¦

title: Review of legal instruments and codes on medical experimentation with children
abstract: Medical research involving children has been the subject of ongoing debate. The reason for the controversy is clear. As with adult research, a balance must be struck between two goals: promoting children's health through advances in scientific knowledge and protecting child research subjects from exploitation and harm. However, due to their age and relative immaturity, children cannot protect their own interests as well as adult subjects. However, as they move into adulthood, increasing care must be taken to involve children in decisions that affect them, even to the point of allowing them to make decisions that may have serious and long-term consequences.

title: Review of the Declaration of Helsinki: a new beginning
Revisiting the history of Cold War research ethics
abstract: President Clinton's charge to the Advisory Committee on Human Radiation Experiments included identifying ethical and legal standards for evaluating government-sponsored radiation experiments conducted during the Cold War. In this paper, we review the traditional account of the history of American research ethics and then highlight and explain the importance of a number of the Committee's historical findings in relation to this account. These findings include both the national defense establishment's struggles with legal and insurance issues related to human experimentation, as well as the medical profession's perspective on human experimentation in the years following the Nuremberg Medical Trials. We conclude that the Committee's work enriches the traditional view of the history of research ethics and opens new and important areas of study.

title: RHEUMATIC AND ARTHRITIS: REVIEW OF THE ENGLISH AND AMERICAN LITERATURE OF RECENT YEARS: (ELEVENTH REVIEW OF RHEUMATIC): Part II
Rheumatism and Arthritis: A Review of the American and English Literature of Recent Years: (Sixteenth Review of Rheumatism)
abstract: SINCE 1935, fifteen issues of Rheumatism Reviews have been published periodically in ANNALS OF INTERNAL MEDICINE under the auspices of the American Rheumatism Association. This sixteenth issue contains a review of selected articles from the American and English literature dealing with the fundamental and clinical aspects of connective tissue diseases for 1961 and 1962. The American Rheumatism Association (ARA) with the assistance of the editors of ANNALS OF INTERNAL MEDICINE will continue to publish—at approximately two-year intervals—an analysis of significant contributions in this field with an emphasis on topics of interest to physicians. The American Rheumatism Association, in cooperation with the National Library of Medicine, is preparing a periodic bibliography of rheumatic diseases on computer tape. Using this literature retrieval method, "Current Arthritis and Rheumatism Bibliographic Lists" will be prepared and made available to all those interested in connective tissue diseases. A committee of the American Rheumatism Association will prepare Future Reviews of Rheumatism to provide a unique comprehensive analysis of fundamental and clinical issues in the field of rheumatology. These will be published in the journal Arthritis and Rheumatism.

title: RHEUMATIC AND ARTHRITIS:: REVIEW OF THE ENGLISH AND AMERICAN LITERATURE OF RECENT YEARS: (THIRTEENTH REVIEW OF THE RHEUMATIC)
abstract: CONTENTS PART I General incidence of rheumatic diseases 2 Classification of diseases of the joints and related structures 5 Diseases mainly related to trauma 5 Arthritis due to specific infectious agents 8 Rheumatic fever 19 Sydenham's chorea 29 Rheumatoid arthritis 30 Rheumatoid (ankylosing) spondylitis 81 Osteoarthritis (Degenerative Joint Disease) 88 PART II Back Pain and Sciatica 95 Gout and Gouty Arthritis 119 The Uric Acid Problem 144 "Collagen Diseases" 149 Psoriatic Arthritis 162 Reiter's Syndrome 163 Neurotrophic Arthropathy: Charcot's Joints 165 Rheumatic Purpura of Schönlein-Henoch) 166 Haemophilic arthritis 167 Allergic Arthritis 168 Pharmacological Arthritis and Arthralgia 168 Alkaptonuria, Ochronosis and Ochronic Arthritis

title: Richard Cabot: Medical Reformer During the Progressive Era (1890-1920)
abstract: Richard Cabot's (1868-1939) decision to leave full-time medical work in 1920 to teach social ethics illustrates some of the tensions inherent in the transformation of 20th-century medicine from clinical practice to biomedical science. Cabot, then one of America's best-known physicians, practiced medicine in an era when science redefined medical thought and practice. Although a champion of medical science, Cabot's main concerns were clinical and humanistic. He emphasized the importance of ambulatory medicine, advocated group practice, founded hospital social work, did clinical epidemiological research, pushed for preventive medicine, created the Clinico-Pathology Conference, and wrote extensively on medical ethics. In 1912, despite Cabot's great talents, David Edsall, a general practitioner with a broader basic scientific training, was given a senior professorship at Harvard Medical School. However, Cabot's efforts to define the role of the physician, as well as the health system, in human well-being presaged current attempts in medicine to emphasize the social context of the patient.

title: Ridding the world of hydroxyquinolines
Riding the Knowledge Translation Roundabout: Lessons Learned from the Canadian Institutes of Health Research Summer Institute in Knowledge Translation
abstract: Background Funding the education and training of the next generation of health researchers is a key mandate of the Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR) knowledge translation (KT) portfolio. The KT field grows day by day";" therefore, the training and development of a new generation of CT researchers is essential. Methods Using curriculum documents, participant assessments, and self-reflection, this document describes a unique Summer Institute organized by CIHR in Cornwall, Ontario, Canada. We describe the key aspects of a successful training initiative that could inform organizations and agencies around the world that are interested in or have a mandate for KT. Results This paper offers potential funders, faculty, and students an insight into the purpose, process, and outcomes of such training initiatives. Conclusion National and international KT organizations, research institutions, and funding agencies are encouraged to consider replicating the training model employed here, as investment in KT staff will further advance the field within and beyond local borders. . 'To the individual who dedicates his life to science, nothing can bring greater happiness than when the results immediately find a practical application. There are not two sciences. There is science and the application of science, and these two are linked like fruit to a tree.' Â¨C Louis Pasteur, 1871 (from a presentation by Ian Graham, 2008 CIHR Knowledge Translation Summer Institute)

title: Risk communication in clinical trials: a cognitive experiment and a survey
abstract: BACKGROUND: A Royal Statistical Society task force recently recommended that "greater use of numerical, rather than verbal, risk descriptions should be made" in early human clinical trials. This echoed the views of many physicians and psychologists on risk communication. As the clinical trial industry rapidly expands around the world, it is important to understand risk communication in Asian countries. METHODS: We conducted a cognitive experiment on participation in a hypothetical pain-relieving drug clinical trial and survey in cancer and arthritis patients in Singapore. In part 1 of the experiment, patients received information about the risk of side effects in one of three formats (frequency, percentage, and verbal descriptor) and in one of two sequences (least to most severe and most to least severe), and were asked about their willingness to participate. In part 2, patients received risk information in all three formats, in the same sequence, and were asked again about their willingness to participate. A survey on preference for risk presentation methods and use of verbal descriptors followed immediately. RESULTS: Willingness to participate and the probability of changing their decision were not affected by risk presentation methods. Most patients indicated a preference for the frequency format, but patients with primary education or no formal education were indifferent. Although patients used the verbal descriptors 'very common', 'common' and 'very rare' in a manner similar to the European Commission Guidelines, their use of the descriptors 'uncommon' and 'rare' was substantially different from that of the European Union. CONCLUSION: In this sample of Asian patients with cancer and arthritis, the risk presentation format had no impact on willingness to participate in a clinical trial. However, there is a clear preference for the frequency format. The use of verbal descriptors by lay people was substantially different from that in the EU.

title: Risk factors for methotrexate-induced lung injury in patients with rheumatoid arthritis: a multicenter case-control study.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Toxicity limits the use of methotrexate. OBJECTIVE: To identify risk factors for methotrexate-induced lung injury in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. DESIGN: Case-control study. SETTING: One private and five academic rheumatology practices. PARTICIPANTS: Methotrexate recipients with rheumatoid arthritis with and without lung injury. MEASUREMENTS: Potential risk factors examined were sociodemographic and lifestyle characteristics, medical history, clinical and ancillary characteristics, and treatment of rheumatoid arthritis prior to methotrexate therapy, and characteristics of methotrexate therapy. Cases of lung injury were defined according to the modified Searles and McKendry criteria. RESULTS: Ninety-four percent of study participants were white and 67% were female. Case-patients (n = 29) were older than controls (n = 82) (61.5 vs. 54.5 years). The strongest predictors of lung injury, after adjustment for other variables, were older age (odds ratio [OR], 5.1 [95% CI, 1.2 to 21.1]), diabetes (OR, 35, 6 [CI, 1.3 to infinity]), rheumatoid disease, pleuropulmonary involvement (OR, 7.1 [CI, 1.1 to 45.4]), prior use of disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (OR, 5.6 [CI, 1.2 to 27.0]) and hypoalbuminemia (OR, 19.5 [CI, 3.5 to 109.7]). Prior use of disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs and hypoalbuminemia had very large attributable risks. CONCLUSION: Knowledge of the risk factors that predispose rheumatoid arthritis patients to the lung toxic effects of methotrexate may provide a rationale for monitoring high-risk patients and may facilitate their management.

title: Risk of hospitalized heart failure among new users of saxagliptin, sitagliptin, and other antihyperglycemic drugs
abstract: Background: Recent post-marketing trials have produced conflicting results on the risk of hospital heart failure (hHF) associated with dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors, creating uncertainty about the safety of these antihyperglycemic agents. Objective: To examine the associations of hHF with saxagliptin and sitagliptin. Design: Retrospective, population-based cohort study of new users. Setting: 18 health insurance and health system data partners in the US Food and Drug Administration Mini-Sentinel program Patients: Patients 18 years of age and older with type 2 diabetes who initiated saxagliptin therapy , sitagliptin, pioglitazone, second-generation sulfonylureas, or long-acting insulin products from 2006 to 2013. Measurements: Hospitalized HF, identified by International Classification of Diseases, Ninth Revision, Clinical Modification Codes 402.x1, 404.x1, 404. x3 and 428.xx logged as primary high diagnostic. Results: 78,553 saxagliptin users and 298,124 sitagliptin users contributed an average of 7 to 9 months of follow-up data to 1 or more pairwise comparisons. The risk of hHF was not greater with DPP-4 inhibitors than with the other study drugs. Hazard ratios from stratified disease risk score (DRS) analyzes ¨C were 0.83 (95% CI, 0.70 to 0.99) for saxagliptin versus sitagliptin, 0.63 ( CI, 0.47 to 0.85) for saxagliptin versus pioglitazone, 0.69 (CI, 0.54 to 0.87) for saxagliptin versus sulfonylureas, and 0.61 (CI, 0.50 to 0.73) for saxagliptin versus insulin. DRS-stratified hazard ratios were 0.74 (CI, 0.64 to 0.85) for sitagliptin versus pioglitazone, 0.86 (CI, 0.77 to 0.95) for sitagliptin versus sulfonylureas, and 0.71 (CI, 0.64 to 0.78) for sitagliptin versus insulin. The results of the 1:1 propensity score paired analyzes were similar. Results were also similar in subgroups of patients with and without prior cardiovascular disease and in a subgroup defined by the 2 highest deciles of DRS. Limitation: Residual confounding and short follow-up. Conclusion: In this large cohort study, no increased risk of hHF was observed in users of saxagliptin or sitagliptin compared to other selected antihyperglycemic agents. Primary Funding Source: US Food and Drug Administration.

title: Risk prevalence and cancer screening by general practitioners
abstract: BACKGROUND: This study presents the prevalence of cancer risk and detection rates of patients attending general practitioners. Conditions addressed include smoking, skin cancer, Pap tests, clinical breast exams, and mammography. METHODS: A cross-sectional study of 7,160 patients aged 18 to 75 years presenting to 230 general practitioners in a metropolitan and rural region of Queensland, Australia, was used. The prevalence of risk was evaluated from the self-report of risk behaviors of the patients and the screening prior to the consultation. Details of preventive care provided at the consultation were based on physicians' self-report at the end of the consultation. RESULTS: Twenty-seven percent of the men and 23% of the women smoked, with the rates being higher in the younger age groups. Based on national guidelines, recommended prior screening for men and women had not been received as follows: Screening for skin cancer: 66% of men, 70% of women; cervical cancer screening: 27%; clinical breast exam: 45%; " mammography: 75%. Therefore, these patients were categorized as "at risk", and the rates of detection of these patients in the consultation were as follows: smokers: 34%"; skin cancer: 5%; cervical cancer: 16%; mammography: 4%; clinical breast exam: 8%. CONCLUSIONS: A significant number of patients presenting to general practitioners were at risk of developing cancer, according to national guidelines. Of these, only a small proportion of all All groups had a preventive intervention by their GP at the practice identified in this study.While physicians generally consider their role in prevention important, these results raise questions for future cancer prevention policies and training of primary care physicians. Headboard.

title: Role and interactions of the cardiologist in a regional institutional project of primary prevention
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence is available to support policies for a population-wide approach to changing the distribution of risk factors; on the other hand, it is difficult to establish lasting primary prevention projects, as well as to bring together the right experts. METHODS: In 1999, the Piedmont Region Administration launched a multi-year intervention with the aim of reducing risk factors and increasing protective factors for oncological and cardiovascular diseases in the general population, especially in disadvantaged groups. Cardiologists They played a key role in supporting the evidence-based guideline project, preparing literature reviews, and disseminating coronary risk maps. A core group of trainers was formed in each Local Health Service to promote a lifestyle counseling system, with the central referent of the activity of the general practitioner. -A media campaign has been launched using health advertisements in newspapers, television, public transport, bulletin boards. on the following topics: nutrition, hypertension, tobacco, physical activity, stress;" stores, food markets, trains and plazas intervened. In addition, a revision of the bulletin has been published since January 2000, to produce basic models, more effective interventions and recommendations for its implementation.RESULTS: A new care for primary prevention and counseling arguments, as well as the need for continuous training to promote preventive actions were shown to general practitioners.A system was established to identify the best channels, forms of communication and the most effective messages for healthy lifestyles A model for monitoring changes in risk factors and protective behaviors in the population, describing social differences, was established to better plan and evaluate interventions CONCLUSIONS: After more than half a century of successful public health science, there is e an urgent need for Public Administrations to orient their health policies towards the determinants of health and create the best conditions for citizens to improve their lifestyle.

title: Role of "external facilitation" in the implementation of research results: a qualitative evaluation of experiences of facilitation in the Veterans Health Administration
abstract: Background Facilitation has been identified in the literature as a potentially key component of successful implementation. However, it has been neither well defined nor well studied. Important questions remain about the operational definition of facilitation and about the relationship of facilitation to other interventions, especially other change agent roles when used in multi-faceted implementation projects. Researchers who are part of the Quality Improvement Research Initiative (QUERI) are actively exploring various approaches and processes, including facilitation, to enable the implementation of best practices in the California Health Administration's health care system. Veterans, the largest integrated health care system in the United States. . This paper describes a systematic retrospective evaluation of implementation-related facilitation experiences within QUERI, a quality improvement program developed by the US Department of Veterans Affairs. Methods A post-hoc evaluation was conducted through of a series of semi-structured interviews to examine the concept of facilitation in several QUERI implementation studies across multiple sites. The interview process is based on a technique developed in the field of education, which systematically enhances experiential learning by stimulating recall and reflection on complex past activities. An iterative content analysis approach was used for data analysis relative to a set of concept-based interview questions. Findings The findings suggest that facilitation, within an implementation study initiated by a central change agency, is a deliberate and valued process of interactive problem solving and support that occurs in the context of a recognized need for improvement and an interpersonal relationship. support. Facilitation was mainly described as a distinct role with a number of potentially crucial behaviors and activities. The data further suggests that external facilitators are likely to use or integrate other implementation interventions, while performing this support and problem-solving role. Preliminary conclusions This evaluation provides evidence suggesting that facilitation could be considered a distinct implementation intervention, just as audit and feedback, educational outreach or similar methods are considered discrete interventions. As such, facilitation needs to be well defined and explicitly evaluated for its perceived usefulness within multi-intervention implementation projects. In addition, researchers should better define the specific contribution of facilitation to implementation success in different types of projects, different types of sites, and with evidence and innovations of different levels of strength and complexity.

title: Royal Australian New Zealand College of Psychiatrists clinical practice guidelines for the treatment of schizophrenia and related disorders
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Royal Australian New Zealand College of Psychiatrists is coordinating the development of clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) in psychiatry, funded by the National Mental Health Strategy (Australia) and the New Zealand Health Financing Authority. This article presents the CPGs on schizophrenia and related disorders. Over the past decade, schizophrenia has become more treatable than ever. A new generation of pharmacological treatments, a revival of psychological and psychosocial interventions, and a first generation of reforms within the specialized mental health system have combined to create a climate of realistic, evidence-based optimism. Progressive neuroscientific advances offer the great possibility of more definitive biological treatments in the near future. However, this improved potential for better outcomes and quality of life for people with schizophrenia has not translated into reality in Australia. The efficacy-effectiveness gap is wider for schizophrenia than for any other serious medical disorder. Therapeutic nihilism, under-resourced services and stalled service reform process, low morale within specialist mental health services, lack of comprehensive recovery and life support programmes, and a climate of persistent stigma and consequent lack of of concern for people. with schizophrenia are the causes that contribute to this failure in effective treatment. Therefore, these guidelines address only one element in the effort to reduce the impact of schizophrenia. They distill the current evidence base and make recommendations based on the best available knowledge. METHOD: A comprehensive literature review (1990-2003), including all Cochrane reviews of schizophrenia and all relevant meta-analyses, was performed, and several recent international clinical practice guidelines were consulted. A series of drafts were refined by the expert committee and improved through a binational consultation process. TREATMENT RECOMMENDATIONS: This guideline provides evidence-based recommendations for the management of schizophrenia by type of treatment and by stage of illness. The essential features of the guidelines are: (i) Early detection and comprehensive treatment of first-episode cases is a priority, as it can minimize the psychosocial and possibly biological impact of the disease and improve outcome. An optimistic attitude on the part of health professionals is an essential ingredient from the beginning and in all phases of the disease. (ii) A comprehensive and sustained intervention must be ensured during the first 3 to 5 years after diagnosis, since the course of the disease is strongly influenced by what happens in this 'critical period'. Patients should not have to 'try chronicity' before gaining consistent access and retention in specialist mental health services. (iii) Antipsychotic medication is the cornerstone of treatment. These medications have improved in quality and tolerability, but must be used cautiously and more specifically than in the past. The treatment of choice for most patients is now the newer antipsychotic medications due to their superior tolerability and, in particular, reduced risk of tardive dyskinesia. This is particularly true for the first-episode patient where, due to superior tolerability, newer agents are the first-, second-, and third-line choice. However, these new agents are associated with potentially serious side effects in the medium and long term, so patients should be carefully monitored. Conventional low-dose antipsychotic medications may still have a role in a small proportion of patients, where there has been a complete remission and good tolerability";" however, the indications are progressively reduced. These principles are now accepted in most developed countries. (vi) Clozapine should be used early in the course, as soon as treatment resistance to at least two antipsychotics has been demonstrated. This usually means incomplete remission of positive symptomatology, but clozapine may also be considered when there are pervasive negative symptoms or significant or persistent suicidal risk. (v) Comprehensive psychosocial interventions should be routinely available to all patients and their families, and provided by appropriately trained mental health professionals with time to devote to the task. This includes family interventions, cognitive behavioral therapy, vocational rehabilitation, and other forms of therapy, especially for comorbid conditions, such as substance abuse, depression, and anxiety. (vi) The social and cultural environment of people with schizophrenia is an essential setting for intervention. Adequate housing, financial security, access to meaningful social roles, and the availability of social support are essential components of recovery and quality of life. (vii) Interventions should be carefully tailored to the phase and stage of the disease, and to gender and cultural background. (viii) The genuine participation of consumers and family members in the development and provision of the service must be standard. (ix) The maintenance of good physical health and the prevention and early treatment of serious medical illnesses have been seriously neglected in the treatment of schizophrenia and result in premature death and widespread morbidity. The quality of medical care for people with schizophrenia should be equivalent to the general standard of the community. (x) General practitioners (GPs) should always be closely involved in the care of people with schizophrenia. However, this must be truly shared care, and exclusive care by a GP with minimal or no specialist involvement, while very common, is not considered an acceptable standard of care. Optimal treatment of schizophrenia requires a multidisciplinary team approach with a consultant psychiatrist centrally involved.

title: Royal College calls for a central research ethics committee
Royal College of Physicians Intercollegiate Stroke Working Party Evidence-Based Guidelines for Secondary Prevention of Stroke Through Nutritional or Dietary Modifications
abstract: BACKGROUND: Each year 15 million people worldwide and 110,000 people in England have a stroke. Having a stroke increases the risk of having another. There are a number of additional known risk factors that can be modified by diet. The present study aimed to systematically review key nutrients and diets and their role in secondary prevention, as well as provide evidence-based guidelines for their use in clinical practice. The work was carried out as part of the process to develop the fourth edition of the Royal College of Physicians (RCP) National Clinical Guidelines (NCG) for Stroke. METHODS: The research team generated questions, in consultation with the Virtual Stroke Group, an online professional interest group, and the RCP Intercollegiate Stroke Working Party Guidelines Development Group. Nine questions covering various individual nutrient and diet combinations were defined and searched up to October 31, 2011 using five electronic databases (Embase, Medline, Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Cochrane Library and Web of Science). We assessed the quality and risk of bias of all included studies using the van Tulder criteria for randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and the Quality of Meta-analysis Reporting (QUORUM) criteria for systematic reviews. RESULTS: 4287 abstracts were identified, 79 articles were reviewed, and 29 systematic reviews and RCTs were included to provide evidence for the secondary prevention components of the guidelines. For each question, statements of evidence, recommendations, and practical considerations were developed. CONCLUSIONS: This systematic review process has resulted in the development of evidence-based guidelines for use in clinical practice and has identified areas for future research.

title: Saccadic eye movement metrics reflect fatigue in surgical residents
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Little is known about the effects of surgical resident fatigue on patient safety. We monitored the fatigue levels of surgical residents during the day of their call using (1) eye movement metrics, (2) objective measures of laparoscopic surgical performance, and (3) subjective reports based on standardized questionnaires. BACKGROUND: Previous attempts to investigate the effects of fatigue on surgical performance suffered from methodological limitations, including inconsistent definitions and lack of objective measures of fatigue, and nonstandardized measures of surgical performance. Recent research has shown that fatigue can affect saccadic (rapid ballistic) eye movement characteristics in non-surgical settings. Here we ask whether duty time-induced fatigue (~24 hours) might affect saccadic metrics in surgical residents. Because saccadic velocity is not under voluntary control, a saccadic velocity-based fatigue index has the potential to provide an accurate and unbiased measure of a resident's level of fatigue. METHODS: We measured the eye movements of members of the general surgery resident team at St. Joseph Hospital and Medical Center (Phoenix, AZ) (6 men and 6 women), using a head-mounted video eye tracker ( configuration similar to a surgical device). lighthouse), while performing 3 tasks: 2 simulated laparoscopic surgery tasks (pin transfer and precision cutting) and a guided saccadic task, before and after their call day. Residents rated their perceived level of fatigue every 3 hours during their 24-hour shift, using a standardized scale. RESULTS: Service time decreased saccadic velocity and increased subjective fatigue, but did not affect laparoscopic performance. These results support the hypothesis that saccadic indices reflect gradual changes in fatigue. They also indicate that fatigue due to long service time does not necessarily result in medical error, highlighting the complicated relationship between continuity of care, patient safety, and fatigued providers. CONCLUSIONS: Our data show, for the first time, that saccadic velocity is a reliable indicator of subjective fatigue in health professionals during prolonged duty time. These findings have potential impacts for the development of neuroergonomic tools to detect fatigue among healthcare professionals and for the specifications of future guidelines regarding residents' working hours.

title: Security risks associated with the lack of integration and interface of hospital health information technologies: a qualitative study of electronic hospital prescribing systems in England
abstract: Background Substantial sums of money are being invested worldwide in health information technology. However, realizing benefits and mitigating security risks largely depends on the effective integration of information within systems and/or the interface to enable the exchange of information between systems. As part of a research program in English, we explored the social and technical challenges related to integration and interface experienced by early hospitals to adopt hospital-wide, stand-alone multi-module integrated electronic prescribing systems (ePrescribing). Methods We collected longitudinal qualitative data from six hospitals, which we conceptualized as case studies. We conducted 173 interviews with users, implementers, and software vendors (up to three different times), 24 system usage observations and strategy meetings, 17 documents related to implementation plans, and 2 full-day expert roundtables. Data was analyzed thematically initially within cases and then across cases, drawing on insights surrounding information infrastructures. Results We found that integration and interconnection issues hampered the effective transfer of information in both stand-alone and multi-modular systems, resulting in patient safety threats arising from unavailability of timely information and duplicate data entry. Interface issues were immediately apparent on some standalone systems where users were dealing with multiple logins, and this did not abate over time. Multimodular systems appeared at first glance to obviate such problems. However, with these systems, there was a perceived lack of data consistency between modules, leading to challenges in presenting a complete overview of the patient record, possibly due to the fragmented implementation of modules with different functionalities. Although it was possible to access data from some primary care systems, we found poor two-way data transfer between hospitals and primary care that required workarounds, which in turn created the opportunity for new errors associated with information transfer. duplicate and manual. Extending ePrescribing to include modules with other clinically important information needed to support care remained an aspiration at most sites, although some advanced multi-module systems had begun to implement this functionality. However, multi-module systems were found to be difficult to interface with external systems. Conclusions The decision to pursue a strategy of purchasing stand-alone systems and then interconnecting them, or purchasing hospital-wide multi-module systems, is critical for hospitals to realize the vision of a fully integrated digital record, and this must be based on a clear appreciation of the relative trade-offs between these options. While multi-modular systems offered somewhat better usability, stand-alone systems provided greater flexibility and opportunities for innovation, particularly in relation to interoperability with external systems and in relation to adaptability to the needs of different user groups.

title: Salivary cortisol response after a medical interview: the impact of physician communication behavior, depressive affect, and alexithymia.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To explore whether, and possibly how, a medical interview may affect adrenocortical activity in patients with musculoskeletal pain with and without alexithymia. METHODS: Patients (N = 54) recruited from a fibromyalgia patient organization completed the Toronto Alexithymia Scale (TAS-20) and subgroups with low and high scores, respectively, were selected to participate. Seven physicians made consultations trying to vary their communication according to the given guidelines. All consultations were video recorded and analyzed by the Roter Interaction Analysis System (RIAS) to assess the actual content of the consultations. RESULTS: An increase in depressed affect from before to after the interview was associated with relatively high cortisol levels 24 hours after the interview, but only in patients with alexithymia. Physician psychosocial questions were associated with increased depressive affect immediately after the interview, but not with cortisol responses at any time. CONCLUSION: In patients with impaired affect regulation, increased depressed affect after a medical interview may be associated with delayed effects on adrenocortical activity, possibly mediated by rumination. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: Providers should be sensitive to potential affect regulation deficits in their patients.

title: Salt, hypertension and cardiovascular risk
abstract: For more than a century, salt and blood pressure have been linked. Prospective randomized clinical trials and meta-analyses provided evidence that a reduction in daily salt intake of 100 mmol will reduce systolic blood pressure by 3-5 mm Hg, while diastolic blood pressure can be reduced by 1 mm Hg. The effect of salt restriction depends largely on individual sensitivity to salt. Whether a reduction in salt intake will ultimately result in a decrease in cardiovascular morbidity and mortality remains to be determined in future studies.

title: Do I scan for satisfaction or dig for dismay? Comparison of the results of a postal survey with those of a focus group study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite growing support for mixed methods approaches, we still have little systematic understanding of the consequences of combining surveys and focus groups. Although the methodological aspects of questionnaire surveys have been extensively researched, the characteristics of the focus group methodology are little studied. We suggest and discuss whether the focus group setting, compared to questionnaire surveys, encourages participants to exaggerate views in a negative direction. DISCUSSION: Based on an example from our own research, where we conducted a survey as a follow-up to a focus group study, and with reference to theoretical approaches and empirical evidence from the literature on respondent behavior and small group dynamics, We discuss the possibility that a discrepancy in the findings between the focus groups and the questionnaire reflects characteristics of the two different research methods. Unlike the survey, the focus group study indicated that physicians were generally negative about clinical guidelines. We were not convinced that this difference in results is due to methodological flaws in any of the studies, and instead discuss how this difference may have been the result of a general methodological phenomenon. ABSTRACT: Based on studies of how survey questionnaires influence responses, it seems reasonable to say that surveys are more likely to find exaggerated positive opinions. On the contrary, there are some indications in the literature that focus groups can give rise to complaints and overly negative attitudes, but this remains an open question. We suggest that while problematic issues tend to be underreported in questionnaire surveys, they may be exaggerated in focus groups. We argue the importance of increasing our understanding of focus group methodology, for example by reporting interesting discrepancies in mixed methods studies. In addition, more experimental research on focus groups needs to be done to advance the methodology and test our hypothesis.

title: School-based mental health intervention for children affected by political violence in Indonesia
abstract: Context Little is known about the efficacy of mental health interventions for children exposed to armed conflict in low- and middle-income settings. Children's mental health problems are difficult to address in situations of constant poverty and political instability. Objective To assess the effectiveness of a school intervention designed for conflict-exposed children, implemented in a low-income setting. Design, Setting, and Participants A cluster-randomized trial involving 495 children (81.4% inclusion rate) who had a mean (SD) age of 9.9 (1.3) years and attended selected schools at randomized in communities affected by political violence in Poso, Indonesia, and were assessed for exposure (=1 events), post-traumatic stress disorder, and anxiety symptoms compared to a wait-list control group. Unblinded evaluation was carried out before, 1 week after, and 6 months after treatment between March and December 2006. Intervention Fifteen sessions, over 5 weeks, of a manual-based group intervention at school, including learning activities trauma processing, cooperative play and creative activities. -expressive elements, implemented by locally trained paraprofessionals. Main outcome measures We assessed psychiatric symptoms using the Childhood Posttraumatic Stress Scale, the Depression Self-Rating Scale, the 5-item version of the Self-Report for Anxiety-Related Disorders, and the Childhood Hope Scale, and assessed impairment of function as treatment outcomes using standardized symptom checklists and locally developed rating scales. Results Correcting for grouping of participants within schools, we found a significantly greater improvement in PTSD symptoms (mean change difference, 2.78"; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.02 to 4.53) and hope was maintained (mean change difference, -2.21; 95% CI, -3.52 to -0.91) in the treatment group than in the waiting list group Changes in traumatic idioms (stress-related physical symptoms) (mean change difference, 0.50; 95% CI, -0.12 to 1.11), depressive symptoms (mean change difference, 0.70; 95%, -0.08 to 1.49), anxiety (mean change difference, 0.12; 95% CI, -0.31 to 0.56), and functioning (mean change difference, 0.52; 95% CI, -0.43 to 1.46) were not different between treatment and waiting list groups.ConclusionsIn this study of children in communities affected by violence, an intervention in the school network It reduced post-traumatic stress symptoms and helped maintain hope, but did not reduce traumatic stress-related symptoms, depressive symptoms, anxiety symptoms, or functional impairment.

title: Screening and brief intervention for obesity in primary care: a two-arm parallel randomized trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Obesity is a common cause of noncommunicable diseases. The guidelines recommend that clinicians evaluate and offer brief advice to encourage weight loss through referral to behavioral weight loss programs. However, doctors rarely intervene and no trials have been conducted on the subject. We did this trial to establish whether brief physician intervention is acceptable and effective in reducing body weight in obese patients. METHODS: In this two-arm parallel randomized trial, obesity was examined in patients who consulted 137 primary care physicians in England. Individuals could enroll if they were at least 18 years old, had a body mass index of at least 30 kg/m2 (or at least 25 kg/m2 if Asian), and had a high percentage of body fat. At the end of the consultation, the clinician randomly assigned the participants (1:1) to one of two 30-s interventions. Randomisation was via pre-prepared randomisation cards, labeled with a code representing allocation, which were placed in sealed opaque envelopes and given to clinicians to open at the time of allocation. treatment. In the active intervention, the physician offered referral to a weight control group (12 sessions of 1 hour each, once a week), and if the referral was accepted, the physician ensured that the patient made an appointment and offer follow-up. In the control intervention, the physician advised the patient that their health would benefit from weight loss. The primary outcome was weight change at 12 months in the intention-to-treat population, which was assessed blind to treatment allocation. We also assess patients who are asked about their feelings about talking about their weight when they have visited their GP for other reasons. Given the nature of the intervention, we did not anticipate any adverse events in the usual sense, therefore safety outcomes were not assessed. This trial is registered in the ISRCTN Registry, number ISRCTN26563137. FINDINGS: Between June 4, 2013, and December 23, 2014, we evaluated 8,403 patients, of whom 2,728 (32%) were obese. Of these obese patients, 2256 (83%) agreed to participate and 1882 were eligible, enrolled and included in the intention-to-treat analysis, with 940 people in the support group and 942 people in the counseling group. 722 (77%) people allocated to the supportive intervention agreed to attend the weight control group and 379 (40%) of these people attended, compared to 82 (9%) participants allocated to the counseling intervention. Across the study population, the mean weight change at 12 months was 2.43 kg with the supportive intervention and 1.04 kg with the counseling intervention, giving an adjusted difference of 1.43 kg. (95% CI: 0.89 to 1.97). Patient reactions to brief interventions by general practitioners did not differ significantly between study groups in terms of appropriateness (adjusted odds ratio 0.89, 95% CI 0.75-1.07, p=0.21 ) or usefulness (1.05, 0.89-1.26, p=0.54)";" overall, four (<1%) patients thought their intervention was inappropriate and useless and 1530 (81%) patients thought it was appropriate and useful. INTERPRETATION: A very brief, behaviorally informed, opportunistic clinician-provided intervention is acceptable to patients and an effective way to reduce population mean weight. FUNDING: The UK National Prevention Research Initiative.

title: Screening and Intervention for Comorbid Substance Disorders, PTSD, Depression, and Suicide: A Trauma Center Survey
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Little research has examined screening and intervention procedures for comorbid substance use and mental disorders in trauma centers in the United States, even though these disorders are endemic among traumatic injury survivors. In 2006, the American College of Surgeons (ACS) mandated that Level I and Level II trauma centers assess for alcohol use problems and that Level I centers provide brief intervention for those who give positive. The ACS is expected to recommend best practice policy guidelines for screening for substance use problems and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). This study examined screening and intervention procedures for the full spectrum of comorbid mental and substance use disorders in US trauma centers. METHODS: Respondents at all Level I and Level I trauma centers were asked II (N = 518) in the United States to complete a survey describing screening and intervention procedures for alcohol and drug use problems, suicidality, depression, and PTSD. RESULTS: There were 391 (75%) respondents. More than 80% of trauma centers routinely screen for alcohol and drug use problems. Routine screening and intervention for suicidality, depression, and PTSD were markedly less frequent";" in fact, only 7% of centers reported routine screening for PTSD. Consistent with ACS policy, Level I facilities were significantly more likely than Level II facilities to provide alcohol intervention. CONCLUSIONS: Alcohol screening and intervention occurred frequently in US trauma centers and appeared to respond to ACS mandates. In the future, efforts to orchestrate clinical research and policy could improve screening and intervention procedures for highly prevalent comorbid mental disorders.

title: Screening and interventions for overweight in children and adolescents: statement of recommendations
abstract: The US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) is an independent panel of non-federal experts in prevention and primary care that systematically reviews evidence of effectiveness and develops recommendations for clinical preventive services. This recommendation addresses the evidence for the accuracy of screening children and adolescents using BMI, the effectiveness of behavioral and pharmacological interventions in improving health outcomes in these children, and the potential harms of routine screening and intervention. Using the USPSTF methodology, an analytical framework with key questions to guide the systematic review was developed, which serves as the basis for this recommendation. The number of overweight children and adolescents has more than doubled in the last 25 years. Childhood and adolescent overweight is associated with increased health risks. The USPSTF found insufficient evidence for the effectiveness of behavioral counseling or other preventive interventions with overweight children and adolescents that can be delivered in primary care settings. Currently available studies are limited by factors such as small sample sizes, poor generalizability, and variable follow-up. Based on this critical gap in the evidence of effectiveness, the USPSTF concludes that the evidence is insufficient to recommend for or against routine screening for overweight in children and adolescents as a means of preventing adverse health outcomes (recommendation "I"). There are several gaps in the research evidence on screening and interventions for overweight children and adolescents in the primary care setting. Research is needed to provide well-defined and effective approaches for medical and psychological screening in children, as well as effective clinical approaches for the prevention and treatment of overweight in children that can be implemented by primary care physicians.

title: Suicide risk screening and treatment relevant to primary care: a systematic review for the US Preventive Services Task Force.
abstract: Background: In 2009, suicide accounted for 36,897 deaths in the United States. Purpose: To review the accuracy of screening instruments and the efficacy and safety of suicide risk screening and treatment in populations and settings relevant to primary care. Data sources: citations from MEDLINE, PsycINFO, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, and CINAHL (2002 to 17 July 2012)"; gray literature; and a surveillance search of MEDLINE for additional screening trials (July to December 2012). 2012).Study selection: English-language studies of fair or good quality that evaluated the accuracy of screening instruments in primary care or similar populations and trials of interventions for suicide prevention in primary care or mental health settings Extraction data: one investigator extracted data, a second checked abstraction. Two investigators rated study quality. Data synthesis: evidence was insufficient to determine benefit of screening in primary care populations;" very limited testing identified no serious harm. Minimal evidence suggested that screening tools may identify some adults at increased risk of suicide in primary care, but accuracy was lower in studies of older adults. Minimal evidence limited to high-risk populations suggested poor performance of screening instruments in adolescents. Evidence from the trial showed that psychotherapy reduced suicide attempts in high-risk adults, but not in adolescents. Most trials were underpowered to detect effects on deaths. Limitation: Evidence for treatment was derived from high-risk populations rather than screening populations. Evidence relevant to adolescents, older adults, and racial/ethnic minorities was limited. Conclusion: Feasible primary care screening tools could help identify some adults at increased risk for suicide, but have limited ability to detect suicide risk in adolescents. Psychotherapy may reduce suicide attempts in some high-risk adults, but effective interventions for high-risk adolescents remain unproven. Primary Funding Source: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality.

title: Colorectal cancer detection by a single sigmoidoscopy: a feasibility study in Turin
abstract: Objectives: To assess the impact on compliance of three invitation methods, as well as the acceptability and efficacy of two bowel preparation regimens, for endoscopic screening in the general population. Methods: 1170 subjects (men and women aged 55 to 59 years, on the lists of a sample of general practitioners (GPs) in Turin), were randomly assigned to one of three invitation groups (A: personal letter, signed by GP , by appointment"; B: same as for A + letter of support for the study by a recognized scientist; C: letter signed by the study coordinator, NS) and two preparation regimens (i: one enema, self-administered at home two hours before the test; ii: two enemas, given the night before and two hours before the test) A reminder was sent by post to those who did not attend A sample of those who did not attend were contacted by a trained nurse they did not respond for a telephone interview.Written consent was obtained from all subjects who underwent testing.Results: "A total of 278 subjects attended for sigmoidoscope screening. A GP invitation produced the highest response rate (compliance: A = 29.3%; B = 24.9%; "C = 26.8%). A single enema was as effective as two enemas in achieving satisfactory preparation for the test: the proportion of subjects invited to repeat the test was 8.1% in the single-enema group and 9.6% in the two-enema group. this screening procedure tends to be low.An enema, self-administered two hours before sigmoidoscopy, can ensure satisfactory bowel preparation.

title: Frontline colorectal cancer screening
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The objective of this study was to assess the knowledge, beliefs, and practices of primary care physicians regarding colorectal cancer screening. METHODS: We surveyed 77 primary care providers at six clinics in central Massachusetts to assess various factors related to colorectal cancer screening. RESULTS: Most agreed with the guidelines for fecal occult blood testing (97%) and sigmoidoscopy (87%), which were commonly reported as routine practice. Although the majority (86%) recommended colonoscopy as a screening test for colorectal cancer, it was infrequently reported as routine practice. In addition, 36% considered barium enema as a colorectal cancer screening option and it was rarely reported as routine practice. Despite a lack of evidence supporting effectiveness, office-based digital rectal exams and faecal occult blood testing were commonly reported as routine practice. However, these were generally reported in combination with a guideline-supported trial option. Although only 10% reported that home/fecal occult blood testing was frequently refused, 60% reported that sigmoidoscopy was. Frequently cited patient barriers to compliance with sigmoidoscopy include fear that the procedure will hurt and patients assuming that symptoms occur if there is a problem. Perceptions of health systems barriers to sigmoidoscopy were less strong. CONCLUSIONS: Most providers recommended colorectal cancer screening supported by guidelines. However, patient refusal of sigmoidoscopy was common. Results indicate that multiple levels of intervention, including patient and provider education and systems strategies, may help increase prevalence.

title: Screening for dementia in primary care: an evidence summary for the US Preventive Services Task Force.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Dementia is a large and growing problem, but it often goes undiagnosed in its early stages. Earlier detection and treatment could reduce the burden of suffering from this syndrome. PURPOSE: To review the evidence for the benefits and harms of earlier detection and treatment of dementia. DATA SOURCES: MEDLINE, PsycINFO, EMBASE, The Cochrane Library, experts, and review bibliographies. STUDY SELECTION: The authors developed eight key questions that represent a logical chain between screening and better health outcomes, along with eligibility criteria for admissible evidence for each question. Admissible evidence was obtained by searching data sources. DATA EXTRACTION: Two reviewers abstracted relevant information using standardized extraction forms and graded the article for quality according to US Preventive Services Task Force criteria. Brief screening tools can detect some people with dementia early (positive predictive value < or = 50%). Six to 12 months of treatment with cholinesterase inhibitors modestly slows the decline in clinical global and cognitive change scores in some patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease. Function is minimally affected and less than 20% of patients stop taking cholinesterase inhibitors due to side effects. Only limited evidence indicates that any other pharmacological or non-pharmacological intervention slows deterioration in people with early dementia. Although intensive multi-component caregiver interventions may delay nursing home placement for people who have caregivers, the relevance of this finding for people who do not yet have caregivers is uncertain. Other potential benefits and harms of screening have not been studied. CONCLUSIONS: Screening tests can detect undiagnosed dementia. In people with mild to moderate clinically detected Alzheimer's disease, cholinesterase inhibitors are somewhat effective in slowing cognitive decline. The effect of cholinesterase inhibitors or other treatments in people with screen-detected dementia is uncertain.

title: Screening for depression in adult patients in primary care settings: a systematic review of the evidence.
abstract: Background: In primary care settings, estimates of the prevalence of major depressive disorder range from 5% to 13% in all adults, with lower estimates in those older than 55 years (6% to 9%). In 2002, the US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommended screening adults for depression in clinical practices that have systems in place to ensure accurate diagnosis, effective treatment, and treatment. a tracing. Purpose: To conduct an updated systematic review directed for the US Preventive Services Task Force on the benefits and harms of assessing depression in adult patients in a primary care setting, the benefits of treating depression in Older adults and the harms of treating depression with antidepressant medications. Data sources: MEDLINE, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects, PsycINFO (1998 to 2007), expert suggestions, and bibliographies of recent systematic reviews. Selection of studies: randomized clinical trials or controlled clinical trials of fair to good quality"; systematic reviews; meta-analyses;" and large observational studies of serious adverse events and early discontinuation due to adverse effects. All studies were published in English. Data extraction: Two researchers abstracted, critically appraised, and synthesized 33 articles that met the inclusion criteria. Data Synthesis: Nine trials of fair or good quality suggest that primary care depression screening and staff-assisted care management programmes, such as case management or the involvement of mental health specialists, may increase the response and remission of depression. The benefit was not evident in screening programs without staff assistance in depression care. Seven regulatory reviews or meta-analyses and 3 large cohort studies indicate no increased risk of completed suicide deaths with antidepressant treatment. The risk of suicidal behavior was increased in young adults (18 to 29 years of age) who received antidepressants, particularly those who received paroxetine, but was reduced in older adults. Limitation: Examination of harms was limited to serious adverse events and mainly used existing systematic reviews. Additional studies published between 2007 and 2008 extend this review. Conclusion: Depression screening programs without substantial supports for staff-assisted depression care are unlikely to improve depression outcomes. Close monitoring of all adult patients starting antidepressant treatment, particularly those under 30 years of age, is important both for safety and to ensure optimal treatment.

title: Hypertension screening
abstract: Purpose: To review the evidence on four questions about screening for hypertension in asymptomatic adults: Is hypertension a significant health problem? Is it detectable at an early, presymptomatic stage? Is treatment available and effective? Do the benefits of screening outweigh the costs and risks? Data identification and selection: We did a computer search of the MEDLARS database to identify community trials of drug therapy for mild hypertension";" other relevant citations are included where appropriate. Data synthesis: We address preliminary questions in our analysis through narrative review and argumentation. Estimates of therapeutic efficacy are based on previously published meta-analyses. The cost-effectiveness of screening was addressed using formal mathematical models of the effect of screening in various US populations. Results of the analysis: Hypertension is clearly a major health problem. It can be detected early and effective treatment is available. Screening for hypertension in asymptomatic adults has benefits that outweigh the risks and costs involved. Based on our estimates, screening is more cost-effective for older adults compared to younger adults and for men compared to women and is highly sensitive to the cost of therapy for mild hypertension. Conclusions: We recommend hypertension screening for all adults. We also discuss the frequency and setting of detection activities. When low-cost therapy is used, the cost-effectiveness of hypertension screening compares favorably with other cardiovascular interventions.

title: Screening for postpartum depression in primary care: cost-effectiveness analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the cost-effectiveness of routine screening for postpartum depression in primary care. DESIGN Cost-effectiveness analysis with a decision model of alternative depression screening methods, including standardized postpartum depression and generic depression instruments. Screening instrument performance was derived from a systematic review and bivariate meta-analysis across a variety of instrument cutoff points";" estimates of other relevant parameters were derived from relevant literature sources and databases. A decision tree considered the entire treatment pathway from possible onset of postpartum depression to identification, treatment, and possible relapse. SCOPE Primary care. PARTICIPANTS Hypothetical population of women who were assessed for postpartum depression either through routine care alone or supplemented by the use of formal screening methods six weeks after delivery, as recommended in recent guidelines. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Costs expressed in 2006-7 prices and impact on health outcomes expressed in terms of quality-adjusted life years (QALYs). The time horizon of the analysis was one year. RESULTS Routine administration of postnatal or general depression questionnaires did not appear to be cost-effective compared with routine care alone. The Edinburgh Postpartum Depression Scale (at a cut-off point of 16) had an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) of £41,103 (€45,398, $67,130) per QALY compared with routine care alone . The ICER for all other strategies ranged from £49,928 to £272,463 per QALY compared to routine care alone, while the probability that no formal identification strategy would be cost-effective was 88% (59%) with a break-even threshold of £20,000 (£30,000) per QALY. Although sensitivity analysis indicated that the cost of managing misidentified depression (false-positive outcome) was an important factor in the model, formal identification approaches did not appear to be cost-effective on any plausible estimate of this cost. CONCLUSIONS Formal methods of screening for postpartum depression do not appear to represent good value for money for the NHS. The main determinant of cost-effectiveness appears to be the potential additional cost of managing women incorrectly diagnosed as depressed. Currently, formal screening methods for postpartum depression do not meet the National Screening Committee's criteria for adoption of a screening strategy as part of national health policy.

title: Screening for speech and language delays in preschool children: a systematic review of evidence for the US Preventive Services Task Force.
abstract: BACKGROUND: PEDIATRICS (ISSN Numbers: Printed, 0031-4005";" Online, 1098-4275). Published in the public domain by the American Academy of Pediatrics. Speech and language development is a useful indicator of a child's overall development and cognitive ability and is related to school success. Identifying children at risk for developmental delay or related problems can lead to intervention services and family support at an early age, when the chances for improvement are best. However, optimal methods for screening for speech and language delays have not been identified, and screening is inconsistently practiced in primary care. PURPOSE: We attempted to assess the strengths and limits of the evidence on the effectiveness of screening tests and interventions for speech and language delay in preschool children to determine the balance between benefits and adverse effects of screening. Routine screening in primary care for pattern development in preschool children. the United States Preventive Services Task Force. The target population includes all children up to 5 years of age without previously known conditions associated with speech and language delays, such as hearing and neurological impairments. METHODS: Studies were identified from Medline, PsycINFO, and CINAHL databases (1966 to November 19, 2004), systematic reviews, reference lists, and experts. The evidence review included only articles published in English that are available through libraries. Only randomized controlled trials were considered to examine the effectiveness of the interventions. Outcome measures were considered if they were obtained at any time or age after screening and/or intervention, provided that the baseline assessment occurred while the child had or = 2 screenings in 1 population, and comparisons of a single detection technique in different populations are lacking. Fourteen good and fair quality randomized controlled trials of interventions reported significantly better speech and language outcomes compared to control groups. Improvement in several domains, including articulation, phonology, expressive language, receptive language, lexical acquisition, and syntax, was demonstrated among children of all age groups studied and in multiple therapeutic settings. Improvement in other functional outcomes such as socialization skills, self-esteem, and improved play themes were demonstrated in some, but not all, of the 4 studies that measured them. In general, intervention studies were small and heterogeneous, may be subject to plateau effects, and reported short-term outcomes based on various instruments and measures. As a result, long-term outcomes are unknown, interventions cannot be directly compared, and generalisability is questionable. CONCLUSIONS: Studies do not support the use of risk factors to guide screening. Several aspects of screening have not been adequately studied to determine optimal methods, including which instrument to use, the age at which screening should be performed, and what interval is most useful. Intervention trials demonstrate improvement in some outcome measures, but conclusions and generalisability are limited. There are no data available that address other key issues, including the effectiveness of screening in primary care settings, the role of enhanced surveillance by primary care physicians before referral for diagnostic evaluation, the long-term benefits timing of interventions and adverse effects of screening. and interventions.

title: Surgeons Screening for HIV Infection: A Cost-Effectiveness Analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVE. To determine the cost-effectiveness of a policy to screen surgeons for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection in preventing HIV transmission to patients undergoing invasive procedures. DESIGN: Cost-effectiveness analysis. RESULTS: A single national screening program would identify approximately 137 HIV-infected surgeons (range, 28 to 423 surgeons) and prevent approximately 4.3 infections (range, 1.9 to 21.3 infections) in patients treated by infected surgeons. and 0.9 infections (range, 1.9 to 21.3 infections) in patients treated by infected surgeons and 0.9 infections (range, 0 to 12.9 infections) in sexual partners of infected surgeons at a direct cost of $8 .1 million and an induced cost of approximately $44 million. It would result in costs of $458,000 per year of life saved (range, $147,000 to $687,000 per year of life saved), while an annual screening program would cost approximately $1.1 million per year of life saved (range, $338 000 to $1,886,000 per year). year of life saved). If the prevalence of HIV infection in surgeons is estimated to be three times our base case estimate (an increase from 0.1% to 0.3%), annual screening would cost approximately $741,000 per year of life saved. If the probability of seroconversion after a patient is exposed to a contaminated instrument increases to 5.0% from our base case estimate of 0.29%, an annual screening program would still cost more than $228,000 per year of life saved . CONCLUSION: Screening for HIV in surgeons to prevent HIV transmission to patients undergoing invasive procedures requires costs per year of life saved that substantially exceed those of most accepted healthcare interventions. Surveillance studies of patients treated by HIV-infected surgeons should be continued to confirm that transmission of HIV to patients undergoing invasive procedures is rare.

title: Screening, isolation and decolonization strategies for the control of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus in intensive care units: cost-effectiveness evaluation
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the cost-effectiveness of detection, isolation, and decolonization strategies in the control of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) in intensive care units. DESIGN Economic evaluation based on a dynamic transmission model. SETTING England and Wales. Population Theoretical population of patients in an intensive care unit. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Infections, deaths, costs, quality-adjusted life years (QALYs), incremental cost-effectiveness ratios for alternative strategies, and net monetary benefits. RESULTS All decolonization strategies improved health outcomes and reduced costs. Although universal decolonization (regardless of MRSA status) was the most cost-effective in the short term, strategies using screening to detect MRSA carriers may be preferred due to reduced risk of selection for resistance. Among such targeted strategies, universal admission and weekly polymerase chain reaction screening along with nasal mupirocin decolonization was the most cost-effective. This finding was robust to the size of intensive care units, the prevalence of MRSA at admission, the proportion of patients classified as high risk, and the precise value of willingness to pay for health benefits. All strategies using isolation but not decolonization improved health outcomes but increased costs. Where MRSA prevalence at intensive care unit admission was 5% and willingness to pay per QALY gained was between £20,000 (£23,000;"$32,000) and £30,000, the best such strategy was isolate only patients at high risk of carrying MRSA (either preventively or after identification on admission and weekly screening for MRSA using chromogenic agar) Universal admission and weekly screening using MRSA detection are unlikely to Based on polymerase chain reaction in conjunction with isolation are cost effective unless prevalence is high (10% of patients colonized with MRSA at admission).CONCLUSIONS MRSA control strategies using decolonization are likely to save costs in an intensive care unit setting as long as resistance does not exist, and the combination of universal screening by polymerase chain reaction with decolonization is likely to n represents good value for money if undirected decolonization is considered unacceptable. In intensive care units where decolonization is not implemented, the evidence is insufficient to support universal screening for MRSA outside of high-prevalence settings.

title: Secondary prevention after mild stroke and TIA - usual care and development of a support program
abstract: BACKGROUND: There are effective methods of secondary prevention after stroke or TIA, but adherence to recommended evidence-based treatments is often poor. The study aimed to determine the quality of secondary prevention in usual care and to develop a step-by-step modeled support program. METHODS: Two consecutive cohorts of patients with minor acute stroke or TIAs undergoing routine outpatient care versus a secondary prevention program were compared. Risk factor control and medication adherence were assessed at 6-month follow-ups (6M-FU). Usual care consisted of detailed information on vascular risk factor goals provided at discharge and regular outpatient care by primary care physicians. The step-by-step modeling support program also used up to four outpatient appointments. A combination of educational and behavioral strategies were used. RESULTS: 168 patients from the observational cohort who expressed their willingness to participate in a prevention program (mean age 64.7 years, blood pressure (BP) at admission: 155/84 mmHg) and 173 patients who participated in the support program (mean age 67.6 years, BP: 161/84 mmHg) were evaluated at 6 months. The proportions of patients with AP according to the guidelines were 50% in usual care and 77% in the support program (p<0.01). LDL <100 mg/dl was measured in 62% vs 71% (p = 0.12). The proportions of patients who quit smoking were 50% vs. 79% (p<0.01). 72% vs. 89% of patients with atrial fibrillation received oral anticoagulation (p = 0.09). CONCLUSIONS: Control of risk factors remains unsatisfactory in routine care. Secondary prevention goals were more frequently met within the supported cohort. Effects on (cerebro-)vascular recurrence rates will be evaluated in a multicentre randomized trial.

title: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and routine specialty care with and without cognitive behavioral therapy in adolescents with major depression: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine whether a combination of a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) together with clinical care is more effective in the short term than an SSRI and clinical care alone in adolescents with moderate to severe major depression. . DESIGN Pragmatic randomized controlled superiority trial. SCENARIO 6 outpatient clinics in Manchester and Cambridge. PARTICIPANTS 208 adolescents, aged 11 to 17 years, with moderate to severe major depression or probable major depression who had not responded to a brief initial intervention. Adolescents with suicidal tendencies, depressive psychosis or conduct disorder were included. INTERVENTIONS 103 adolescents received an SSRI and routine care";" 105 received an SSRI, routine care, and CBT. The trial lasted 12 weeks, followed by a 16-week maintenance phase. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Change in Health of the Nation Child and Adolescent Outcome Scales score (primary outcome) from baseline with 12 weeks as the primary endpoint and 28 weeks as the follow-up endpoint.
