Secondary measures were change in Mood and Feelings Questionnaire scores, Childhood Depression Rating Scale-Revised, Children's Global Assessment Scale, and Clinical Global Impression Improvement Scale. RESULTS At 12 weeks, the treatment effect for the primary outcome was -0.64 (95% confidence interval -2.54 to 1.26, P = 0.50). In a longitudinal analysis, there were no differences in treatment effectiveness for primary (average treatment effect 0.001, -1.52 to 1.52, P = 0.99) or secondary outcomes. On average, there was a decrease in suicidal thoughts and self-harm. There was no evidence of a protective effect of cognitive behavioral therapy on suicidal thinking or action. At 28 weeks, 57% had improved a lot or a lot and 20% were still not improved. CONCLUSIONS For adolescents with moderate to severe major depression, there is no evidence that the combination of CBT plus an SSRI in the presence of routine clinical care contributes to better outcome at 28 weeks compared with provision of routine clinical care. plus one SSRI alone. TRIAL REGISTRATION Current Controlled Trials ISRCNT 83809224.

title: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors in childhood depression: systematic review of published versus unpublished data.
abstract: Background Questions about the safety of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) in the treatment of depression in children prompted us to compare and contrast published and unpublished data on the risks and benefits of these medications.";" Background Questions about the safety of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) in the treatment of depression in children prompted us to compare and contrast published and unpublished data on the risks and benefits of these drugs.

title: Conditional self-formulated plans to change health behavior among health care consumers and health professionals.
abstract: This is a protocol for a Cochrane review (intervention). The objectives are as follows: Our main objective is to assess the effects of self-formulated conditional plans in changing health-related behaviors of health consumers and health professionals. Our secondary objective is to explore whether the effects of self-formulated conditional plans are modified by: (i) the form of the plan (for example, implementation intention, action plan, coping plan)"; (ii) fidelity to plan development (not does the individual participate in its development as planned?); and, (iii) complexity of the target behavior (for example, number of actions required; "regularity of behavior).

title: Self-help books for depression: how can professionals and patients make the right choice?
abstract: BACKGROUND: Depression is a common and important public health problem most often treated by GPs. A self-help approach is popular with patients, but little is known about its effectiveness. OBJECTIVE: Our main objective was to review and update the evidence on the clinical effectiveness of bibliotherapy in the treatment of depression. Our secondary objective was to identify which of these self-help materials are generally available to purchase and to examine the specific evidence in these publications. METHOD: Medline, CINAHL, EMBASE, PsycINFO, CCTR, PsiTri, and the National Research Register searched for randomized trials evaluating self-help books for depression that included participants older than 16 years with a diagnosis or symptoms of depression. Clinical symptoms, quality of life, costs or acceptability to users were the required outcome measures. Two investigators independently retrieved articles and extracted data. A meta-analysis with a random effects model was performed using the mean score and standard deviation of the Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression at the end of the trial. RESULTS: Eleven randomized controlled trials were identified. None met the CONSORT guidelines and all were small, with the largest trial having 40 patients per group. Nine of these evaluated two current publications, Managing Anxiety and Depression (UK) and Feeling Good (US). A meta-analysis of 6 trials evaluating Feeling Good found a large effect of treatment compared to delayed treatment (standardized mean difference = -1.36";" 95% confidence interval [CI] = -1.76 to - 0.96). Five self-help books available and commonly purchased by members of the public were identified, in addition to the two books that had been assessed in the trials. CONCLUSION: There are several self-help books for the treatment of depression readily available. For most, there is little direct evidence of its effectiveness. There is weak evidence to suggest that bibliotherapy, based on a cognitive behavioral therapy approach, is helpful for some people when given additional guidance. More work is required in primary care to investigate the cost-effectiveness of self-help and the most suitable format and presentation of materials.

title: COPD Self-Care Programs: Moving Forward
abstract: Self-care is increasingly important in the treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). However, there is confusion about what processes are involved, how the value of self-management should be determined, and about research priorities. For more information and agreement on the program content, outcomes, and future directions of COPD self-management, a group of interested researchers and clinicians, all of whom had previously published on this topic and previously collaborated on other projects, called a workshop. This article summarizes their initial findings. Self-management programs aim at structural behavior change to maintain the effects of treatment after the programs have been completed. Programs should include techniques aimed at behavior change, be individually tailored, take into account the patient's perspective, and may vary with the course of the disease and the patient's comorbidities. The evaluation must include process variables. This report is a step towards greater compliance in the field of self-management. To improve clarity regarding effectiveness, future studies should clearly describe their intervention, be appropriately designed and powered, and include outcomes that focus more on the acquisition and practice of new skills. In this way, more evidence and a better understanding of self-management programs will be obtained, and it will be possible to formulate more specific guidelines on self-management.

title: Self-reported use of personal protective equipment among Chinese intensive care physicians during the 2009 H1N1 influenza pandemic.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Critically ill patients with 2009 H1N1 influenza are often treated in intensive care units (ICUs), posing a significant risk of nosocomial transmission to intensive care physicians and other patients. Despite a large body of literature and guidelines recommending infection control practices, numerous barriers have been identified in ICUs, leading to poor compliance with the use of personal protective equipment (PPE). The use of PPE among critical care physicians has not been extensively evaluated, especially during the influenza pandemic. This study examined self-reported knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors and barriers to adherence to PPE use among ICU healthcare workers (HCWs) during the influenza pandemic. METHODOLOGY/MAIN RESULTS: A survey instrument consisting of 36 questions was developed and mailed to all HCWs in 21 ICUs in 17 provinces of China. A total of 733 physicians, nurses, and other professionals were surveyed, and 650 (88.7%) were included in the analysis. 56% of respondents reported receiving a pandemic influenza training program prior to caring for H1N1 patients, while 77% reported having adequate knowledge of patient and personal protection. Only 18% of respondents were able to correctly identify all PPE components, and 55% reported high compliance (>80%) with PPE use during patient care. On multivariate analysis, 2009 H1N1 influenza vaccination, positive attitudes toward PPE use, organizational factors such as availability of PPE in the ICU, and patient information on influenza precautions, as well as reprimand for Noncompliance by supervisors was associated with high compliance, while negative attitudes toward PPE use and violation of PPE use were independent predictors of low compliance. CONCLUSION/IMPORTANCE: Knowledge of and self-reported adherence to recommended use of PPE among Chinese critical care physicians is suboptimal. Perceived barriers must be addressed to close the significant gap between perception and knowledge or behavior.

title: Self-reported versus actual test requesting behavior among primary care physicians.
abstract: To determine the accuracy of physician self-reports, 38 physicians in a university-based health maintenance organization (HMO) practice were surveyed about their thyroid function test (TFT) patterns one year after distribution. of an educational intervention (the intervention). The mean absolute difference between self-reported and actual test request rates was 12%";" the difference was greater than 20% for only 3 of 33 physicians who ordered TFT for at least five patients during the study period. A strong association was found between self-reported change and true mean change in post-intervention TFT order rates (p less than 0.0001). The results suggest that clinicians, at least in certain settings, can accurately estimate their usage patterns and the effect of practice guidelines.

title: Self-reported violations during medication administration in two pediatric hospitals
abstract: Content Violations of security protocols are pathways to adverse outcomes that have been poorly addressed by existing security efforts. This study reports on self-reported violations by nurses in the medication administration process. Objective To assess the extent of violations in the medication administration process among nurses. Design, Setting, and Participants Participants were 199 nurses from two independent US tertiary care urban academic pediatric hospitals working in a pediatric intensive care unit (PICU), surgical unit (Med/Surg) unit. In a cross-sectional survey, nurses were asked about violations in routine or emergency situations in three steps of the medication administration process. Main outcome measure Self-reported violations of three medication administration protocols were scored using a seven-point scale of 0 to 6 from 'not at all' to 'a great deal'. Results Analysis of variance identified that rape reports were highest for emergency situations, rather than routine operations, highest by nurses from the HOT unit, followed by PICU nurses, and then nurses from the Med/Surg unit. , and higher during patient identification verification, followed by comparing a medication to a medication administration record and then documenting an administration. There was also a significant three-way interaction between rape situation, process step, and unit. Conclusions Protocol violations occur throughout the drug administration process and their prevalence varies depending on the hospital unit, the step of the process and the violation situation. More research is required to determine whether these violations improve or worsen safety, and for those that do worsen safety, how to redesign the management system to reduce the need to violate protocol to perform job tasks.

title: Self-study from printed and web-based guidance materials. A randomized controlled trial among medical residents
abstract: BACKGROUND: Online medical education is increasing, but its effectiveness compared to existing self-study methods is unknown. OBJECTIVE: To compare the knowledge, learning efficiency, and student satisfaction produced by self-study of print and World Wide Web-based guidelines for care after acute myocardial infarction. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. SETTING: 12 family medicine and internal medicine residency programs at four universities. PARTICIPANTS: 162 residents. INTERVENTIONS: In supervised sessions, participants were randomly assigned to study from print materials or from SAGE (Accelerating Self-Study with Graphic Evidence), a web-based tutoring system. Both methods used identical self-assessment questions and answers and guidance text, but SAGE featured hyperlinks to specific guidance passages and graphical evidence animations. MEASURES: Scores on multiple-choice knowledge tests, score gain per unit of study time, and scores on a student satisfaction scale. RESULTS: Post-immediate test scores on a 20-point scale were similar in the SAGE and control groups (median score, 15.0 vs. 14.5"; P>0.2), but SAGE spent less time studying (median, 27.0 vs. 38.5 minutes; P<0.001) and thus had higher learning efficiency (mean score gain, 8.6 vs. 6.7 points per hour, P = 0.04) On a scale of 5 to 20, SAGE users were more satisfied with learning (mean score, 17.0 vs. 15.0, P < 0.001) After 4 to 6 months, knowledge had decreased to the same extent in the SAGE and control groups (mean score, 12.0 vs. 11.0; P = .12).CONCLUSIONS: Online tutorials can produce greater efficiency and satisfaction in learning than printed materials, but self-study exposure may be insufficient for content retention. long-term insights. More research is needed to identify instructional characteristics that motivate higher ultimate learning and retention.

title: Sertraline as monotherapy in the treatment of psychotic and non-psychotic depression
abstract: BACKGROUND: Previous studies suggest that selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are effective when used alone in the treatment of unipolar depression with psychotic features. The purpose of the present study was to examine the response to sertraline in patients with and without psychotic features using standard criteria such as recovery and remission. METHOD: An 8-week open-label trial of sertraline was conducted in hospitalized depressed patients. Twenty-five subjects had DSM-IV major depressive disorder with psychotic features, and 25 had DSM-IV major depressive disorder without psychotic features. After a 1-week open-label washout, all subjects were rated using the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HAM-D) and the Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS) at baseline. The HAM-D was given weekly and the BPRS was given again only at the end of the 8-week trial. Drug dosage was started at 50 mg/day, increased to 100 mg/day after 1 week, and then increased to 200 mg/day if subjects had not remitted. RESULTS: Depressed patients without psychosis responded significantly better than depressed patients with psychosis using the criteria of remission (HAM-D score - 7"; p = 0.001), response (HAM-D score - 50% of baseline score; p = 0.011), referral to electroconvulsive therapy (HAM-D score >/= 15, p = 0.011), or change in HAM-D scores (p = 0.016).Baseline HAM-D score and psychosis strongly predicted independent of response, while baseline BPRS scores did not, regardless of whether psychotic status was entered in the analyses.CONCLUSION: Psychotic depression responds worse than depression without psychosis to sertraline alone.Psychosis was a predictor of response independent of degree of depression and general psychopathology Limitations due to an open-label design are discussed, as well as differences between this study and others using SSRIs for psychotic depression. AC.

title: Services for Children with Developmental Coordination Disorders: An Assessment Against Best Practice Principles
abstract: PURPOSE: The National Health Service Scotland published a best practice framework to help occupational and physiotherapists deliver effective services to children with developmental coordination disorders (DCD)";" however, adherence is variable. To highlight areas of development, this study compared the care pathway within a pediatric DCD service with the Scottish NHS framework. METHODS: A UK-based association of researchers and clinicians conducted a qualitative study with 37 participants (N = 13 interview participants, N = 24 workshop participants). In-depth interviews and/or workshops were used to map the DCD service against the NHS framework. The identified gaps were aligned with four key stages of the care process. Qualitative analysis software was used to analyze the data. RESULTS: Basic principles to guide future development were identified for each phase of the journey. These core principles related to the NHS framework and focused on issues such as family involvement, defining clear pathways and improving children's participation. Participants identified potential strategies to improve service, such as developing community-based interventions and providing information. CONCLUSION: Challenges when providing services for children with DCD include confusing service pathways and poor partnership working. Therefore, it is important for clinicians to use collaborative work strategies that support children's participation. IMPLICATIONS FOR REHABILITATION: There are numerous challenges related to the implementation of best practice principles in the provision of therapy services for children with developmental coordination disorder (DCD). It is important that AHPs seek ways to involve parents and educational professionals at all stages of the care process to ensure optimal service delivery for the child. Addressing participation is an important aspect and community-based strategies can be particularly beneficial, both as a preventive activity and as an intervention approach.

title: Sex in the MD's office
abstract: KIE: A case study explores the dilemma of a physician faced with a serious breach of professional standards by a colleague. Dr. Jones, a psychiatrist, learns from a patient that she is having a voluntary sexual relationship with her internist, who has threatened to harm her if she takes action against him. Though distraught and suicidal, the woman insists on protecting the internist, and Jones must decide on her own what course to take. Shapiro, a psychiatrist, points out in his commentary that Jones's actions depend on those of his patient, to whom he has confidentiality obligations. You also have moral and fraternal obligations towards your colleague which may involve contacting a committee of disabled doctors. Morrow, a sociologist, argues that Jones is morally and legally bound to intervene to protect patients and the integrity of the medical profession. This intervention should probably take the form of notifying an agency that investigates problem doctors.

title: Sex, stroke, and inflammation: the potential for estrogen-mediated immunoprotection in stroke.
abstract: Stroke is the third leading cause of death and the leading cause of disability in the developed world. Experimental and clinical data indicate that stroke is a sexually dimorphic disease, with males demonstrating greater intrinsic sensitivity to ischemic damage for most of their lives. The neuroprotective role of estrogen in the female brain is well established, however estrogen exposure can also be detrimental, especially in older women. The mechanisms for this remain unclear. Our current understanding is based on studies examining estrogen in relation to neuronal injury, however cerebral ischemia also induces a robust sterile inflammatory response involving local and systemic immune cells. Despite the potent anti-inflammatory effects of estrogen, few studies have investigated the contribution of estrogen to sex differences in the inflammatory response to stroke. This review examines the potential role of estrogen-mediated immunoprotection in ischemic injury. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2017 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: Sexual activity and counseling in the first month after acute myocardial infarction among young adults in the United States and Spain: a prospective observational study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Guidelines from the cardiovascular societies of the United States and Europe recommend that clinicians advise patients about resuming sexual activity after acute myocardial infarction (AMI), but little is known about patient experience. with counseling about sexual activity after an AMI. METHODS AND RESULTS: The prospective longitudinal study Variation in Recovery: Role of Gender on Outcomes of Young AMIpatients (VIRGO), conducted in 127 hospitals in the United States and Spain, was designed, in part, to assess gender differences in sexual intercourse initial. Activity, function, and patient experience with medical advice about sexual activity after AMI. This study used baseline and 1-month data collected from the 2:1 sample of women (N=2,349) and men (N=1,152) aged 18 to 55 years with AMI. The median age was 48 years. Among those who reported discussing sexual activity with a physician in the month after AMI (12% women, 19% men), 68% had restrictions placed on them: limiting sexual intercourse (35%), assuming a role more passive (26%), and/or keeping the heart rate down (23%). In risk-adjusted analyses, factors associated with not discussing sexual activity with a physician included female gender (relative risk, 1.07"; 95% confidence interval, 1.03-1.11), age ( relative risk, 1.05 per 10 years; 95% confidence interval, 1.02-1.08), and sexual inactivity at baseline (relative risk, 1.11; 95% confidence interval, 1.08). 08-1.15). ;" 1.36, 95% confidence interval, 1.11-1.66). CONCLUSIONS: Very few patients reported counseling for sexual activity after AMI. Those that did were commonly placed with restrictions that were not supported by evidence or guidelines. CLINICAL TRIAL REGISTRATION URL: http://www.clinicaltrials.gov. Unique identifier: NCT00597922.

title: Sexual Health Curricula in US Medical Schools: Current Educational Goals
abstract: PURPOSE: The authors identify the explicit and implicit goals that shape decisions about what medical schools teach about human sexuality. METHODS: The authors reviewed relevant journal articles, medical licensing exams, and professional organization publications to identify learning objectives for human sexuality in undergraduate medical curricula. RESULTS: There is consensus on many of the attitudinal goals and some of the skills that medical students should acquire in sexual health. There is less consensus about the information related to sexuality that medical students should master. The few common informational targets focus narrowly on the diagnosis of sexual dysfunction and disease. CONCLUSION: Model sexual health curriculum, licensing exams, and professional organization guidelines focus primarily on the pathological aspects of sexuality. Medical students should master the foundational information on healthy sexual function and become familiar with the roles of professionals in various therapeutic disciplines in addressing sexual concerns and improving patients' sexual functioning and well-being. Instruction should also address ways to incorporate this important topic into time-limited interactions with patients.

title: Sexually Transmitted Diseases Among Users of Erectile Dysfunction Medications: Analysis of Claims Data
abstract: Background Pharmacological treatments for erectile dysfunction (ED) have gained great popularity among middle-aged and older men in recent years. The increase in sexual activity among users of these treatments raises concerns about sexually transmitted diseases (STDs). Objective To examine the association between STDs and medications for erectile dysfunction. Design Longitudinal analysis of users and non-users of drugs for erectile dysfunction. of 1,410,806 male employees over 40 years of age with private insurance from 44 large companies. <0.005). Adjusting for these baseline rates, ED drug users had higher rates of STDs in the year after first ED drug use compared with nonusers in the same period (OR 2.06, p < 0.05). Among ED drug users, STD rates were higher in the year after first ED drug use compared with the year before (327 vs. 289 per 100,000 people per year, p <0.05). to increases in STDs. Conclusions Compared with non-users, erectile dysfunction drug users have higher rates of STDs both before the start of treatment and one year later. At a minimum, this relationship suggests that men using erectile dysfunction medications may benefit from earlier discussions of safer sex practices and tighter control of STDs. It is also possible that the availability of ED medications could increase STD rates.

title: Shared decision making does not influence physicians against clinical practice guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although shared decision making (SDM) and adherence to clinical practice guidelines (CPG) are important, some believe they are incompatible. This study explored the mutual influence between physicians' intention to participate in SDM and their intention to follow CPGs. METHODS: Embedded in a cluster randomized trial to assess the impact of training physicians in SDM on the use of antibiotics to treat acute respiratory tract infections, this study assessed physicians' intentions to both participate in SDM and follow CPGs. . A self-administered questionnaire based on the theory of planned behavior evaluated both behavioral intentions and their respective determinants (attitude, subjective norm, and perceived behavioral control) at entry and at the end of the study. We use path analysis to explore relationships between intents. We performed statistical analyzes using the maximum likelihood method and the variance-covariance matrix. The goodness-of-fit indices included the chi-square statistic, the comparative fit index, and the mean square error of approximation. RESULTS: We analyzed 244 responses at entry and 236 at exit. In the control group, at admission we observed that the doctors' intention to perform SDM (r = 0, t = 0.03) did not affect their intention to follow CPG; however, their intention to follow CPG (r = -0.31 t = -2.82) negatively influenced their intention to participate in SDM. On leaving, neither behavioral intention influenced the other. In the experimental group, on entry neither behavioral intention influenced the other; at exit, the intention to perform SDM still did not influence the intention to use CPG, although the intention to follow CPG (r = -0.15 t = -2.02) slightly negatively influenced the intention to perform SDM, but this was not clinically significant. CONCLUSION: Physicians' intention to participate in SDM does not affect their intention to adopt CPG even after SDM training. Physicians' intention to adopt CPGs did not have a clinically significant influence on intention to participate in SDM. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov NCT01116076.

title: Short Course of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy May Reduce Health Anxiety, Researchers Say
abstract: A short course of cognitive behavioral therapy taught by nurses with minimal training would be an effective and relatively inexpensive way to reduce health anxiety in general medical clinics, the researchers say. Health anxiety or hypochondriasis places a substantial burden on health services because it leads to multiple consultations and investigations. Cognitive behavioral therapy is known to be an effective treatment for other anxiety disorders, but there is a shortage of specialist therapists and long waiting lists for treatment. The Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Health Anxiety in Medical Patients (CHAMP) study randomized 445 people with abnormal health anxiety attending gastroenterology, neurology, and respiratory medicine clinics in Ã¢â' ¬Â¦

title: Should future interventional neuroradiologists be screened for mutations that impair radiation-induced DNA repair?
abstract: In our current medical practice, more and more specialists have access to radiology technical platforms to perform image-guided procedures. Although knowledge of current guidelines and radiation protection devices is a prerequisite for the use of radiation, preventive measures are often followed more or less strictly, leading to chronic daily exposure to significant doses of radiation. and large exposures accumulated throughout life. Aortic intervention, electrophysiology and neurointervention in particular can result in large doses for operators. Interventionists might try to rationalize their dismissal of exposure risks with various excuses: they don't know where they left their badges (although, guiltily, they would readily admit that it is good practice to always wear them), the estimated short duration of the procedure, muscle strain and spasms caused by heaviness of lead aprons, decreased dexterity with lead gloves, or discomfort when wearing lead goggles. But their dismissive attitude is probably due to an inherent inability to feel threatened by something they cannot see or feel, a commitment to the patient at all costs, and a culture of bravado that reinforces their behavior.

title: Should recommendations on initiation of inhaled corticosteroid therapy for mild asthma be based on symptom frequency: a post-hoc efficacy analysis of the START study?
abstract: Background Low dose inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) are very effective in reducing asthma exacerbations and mortality. Conventionally, ICS treatment is recommended for patients with symptoms more than 2 days per week, but this criterion has little evidence. Our aim was to assess the validity of the previous symptom-based cutoff for starting ICS by establishing whether there was a differential response to budesonide versus placebo for severe asthma exacerbations, lung function, and asthma symptom control. asthma in subgroups identified by baseline frequency of asthma symptoms." ;" Background Low dose inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) are very effective in reducing asthma exacerbations and mortality. Conventionally, ICS treatment is recommended for patients with symptoms more than 2 days per week, but this criterion has little evidence. Our aim was to assess the validity of the previous symptom-based cutoff point for starting ICS by establishing whether there was a differential response to budesonide versus placebo for severe asthma exacerbations, lung function, and asthma symptom control. in subgroups identified by baseline frequency of asthma symptoms.

title: Should women participate in breast cancer clinical trials? Problems and some solutions
abstract: PURPOSE: The purpose of this review is to consider the issues for women related to participation in clinical trials evaluating the management of breast cancer and to provide some recommendations for future initiatives to address the identified areas of concern. METHODS: The National Breast Cancer Center of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) organized an international workshop to address the question "Clinical trials in breast cancer: should women participate?" We also reviewed the literature on informed participation in clinical trials that was identified in a broad search that spanned Medline, PsycLIT, and HealthPlan from 1986 to 1996. FINDINGS AND CONCLUSION: When women are asked to participate in a clinical trial, they are faced with a series of questions and dilemmas. These include issues related to the conduct and ethical considerations of the trial; the effect of participation or non-participation in treatment; the functions of the physician as a clinician and as a researcher; the informed consent process; the time of the request to participate; and the benefits and costs of participation. A series of steps are identified that could help women decide whether to participate in clinical trials. These include providing community information about clinical trials; the establishment of independent intermediaries and registries for clinical trials; review of consumer information and protocols and participation in trials; review of the role of ethics committees; collection of data on the proportion of women currently recruited for clinical trials, their reasons for participating or refusing, and their views on the recruitment and participation process; models for best practice recruit women for clinical trials and encourage continued participation in trials; Evidence-based communication skills training for clinicians to teach skills to properly inform women about clinical trial participation; and essay sponsorship and promotion by an independent agency.

title: Importance of chronic fatigue syndrome in rehabilitation medicine: status and prospects
abstract: It appears that from a clinical point of view chronic exhaustion or fatigue is an important factor in rehabilitation. It is, however, primarily a phenomenon that can be described as a function according to the International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (JCF), caused by chronic diseases or chronic excessive stress. The clinical and sociomedical classification of chronic fatigue or burnout with respect to rehabilitation was discussed in the framework of a Workshop at the 12th Rehabilitation Sciences Colloquium, 2003 from the points of view of psychiatric rehabilitation, methodology, sociology and practical rehabilitation, and conclusions for future research were drawn. drawn. The definition of chronic fatigue is based primarily on the feeling of chronic tiredness, but also on phenomena of disturbed concentration, physical discomfort, headache, and "drive" and mood disorders. A psychiatric diagnosis related to symptoms of chronic fatigue is neurasthenia, which is arrived at according to precisely defined criteria. Depressive disorder is one of the most important differential diagnoses in this field. Examinations carried out by general practitioners revealed that about 90% of the patients who had been diagnosed with psycho-vegetative disorders fully agreed with the diagnosis of neurasthenia. Neurasthenia resulted more frequently in periods of incapacity for work than in somatization disorders and other psychosomatic diagnoses. Based on the "IRES" scale, "vital exhaustion", singular or even severe changes, become evident in about 50% to 90% of patients undergoing rehabilitation, depending on their individual range of indications. As expected, most of the pathological findings correspond to patients undergoing psychosomatic rehabilitation, since in these cases they overlap with symptoms of psychosomatic illnesses. However, it is notable that even in somatically oriented orthopedic rehabilitation symptoms of fatigue are observed in up to 50% of patients. Preliminary studies have shown that these symptoms can definitely improve within the framework of rehabilitation, although pathological signs remain abundant on follow-up examinations. Markedly severe degrees of "vital exhaustion" and "vocational exhaustion" are also observed in rheumatologic patients undergoing somatic rehabilitation. This is consistent with the clinical history details reported by many male and female patients. Therefore, it seems necessary to adapt the rehabilitation intervention to both the psychovegetative and behavioral medical aspects of this symptom. The scientific classification of the entire field of chronic fatigue with respect to rehabilitation requires the classification of the relevant functions within the framework of the ICF. For this, it would be necessary, on the one hand, to carry out patient consultations within cross-sectional studies and, on the other, a systematic consensus process among experts for the assignment to the relevant functions. This is the basis for the development of appropriate assessment tools for use in prospective studies to systematically assess the impact on roles and especially their effects on activities and participation.

title: Simplifying care: when is the burden of treatment too much for patients living in poverty?
Simulation education as a single intervention does not improve hand hygiene practices: a randomized controlled follow-up study.
abstract: BACKGROUND: To assess how critical nurses' knowledge of and adherence to current hand hygiene (HH) guidelines differ between intervention and control groups randomized before and after simulation education in both a simulation and simulation setting. in clinical practice during a 2-year follow-up. period. We hypothesized that the intervention group's knowledge of and adherence to current HH guidelines might be increased compared to a control group after simulation education. METHODS: A prospective, parallel, randomized, controlled trial with repeated measures was conducted in a 22-bed mixed adult medical-surgical intensive care unit in Oulu, Finland. Thirty of the 40 randomized intensive care nurses initially participated in the baseline measurements";" of these, 17 completed all study procedures. Participants' HH compliance was observed only in high-risk contact situations before and after endotracheal suctioning events using a direct, nonparticipatory observation method. Participants' knowledge of HH was assessed at the end of each observation session. RESULTS: Overall adherence to HH increased from a baseline of 40.8% to 50.8% at the final post-intervention measurement at 24 months (p = 0.002). However, the linear mixed model did not identify any significant group (P = 0.77) or time group interactions (P = 0.17) between the study groups after 2 years of simulation education. Furthermore, simulation education had no impact on participants' HH knowledge. CONCLUSIONS: After a single simulation education session, critical care nurses' knowledge and adherence to current HH guidelines remained below target behavioral rates.

title: Sleep disturbance in adults with cancer: a systematic review of the evidence for best practices in assessment and management for clinical practice.
abstract: Sleep disturbance is common in cancer with detrimental effects on health outcomes. Sleep problems are rarely identified or addressed in oncology practice. The purpose of this review was to identify the evidence base for the evaluation and treatment of cancer-related sleep disorders (insomnia and insomnia syndrome) for oncology practice. The health literature search included gray literature data sources and empirical databases from June 2004 to June 2012. Evidence was reviewed by a Canadian panel of sleep experts, comprised of nurses, psychologists, primary care physicians physicians, oncologists, sleep physicians, investigators, and guideline methodologists to develop clinical practice recommendations for pan-Canadian use reported in a separate document. Three clinical practice guidelines and 12 randomized controlled trials were identified as the main source of evidence. Additional guidelines and systematic reviews were also reviewed for evidence-based recommendations on the assessment and management of insomnia, not necessarily cancer. The need to routinely screen for sleep disorders has been identified and randomized controlled trial (RCT) evidence suggests benefits for cognitive behavioral therapy to improve sleep quality in cancer. Sleep disturbance is a prevalent problem in cancer that needs further recognition in clinical practice and future research.

title: Smoking among patients with emergency chest pain: motivation to quit smoking, risk perception and medical intervention
abstract: The feasibility of the emergency department (ED) setting for anti-smoking interventions was examined among 159 adult patients presenting with chest pain (38% were smokers). Subjects had been admitted to a 24-h observation unit (OU) to rule out myocardial infarction. We examined the frequency and extent of medical interventions for tobacco dependence using the AHCPR guidelines as a model. We also assessed patients' perceptions of smoking risk and motivation to quit. Results indicate that emergency physicians provided an incomplete and inconsistent intervention. Although most patients were asked if they smoked, only half were advised to quit and few were offered help to quit. The perceived risk of smoking was low among nearly half of all smokers. However, more than three quarters were willing to receive smoking cessation advice while in the emergency department. The emergency department may be an opportune place to initiate smoking cessation counseling for certain high-risk populations.

title: Smoking cessation activities by general practitioners and practice nurses
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To assess the behavior, attitudes and knowledge reported by general practitioners and nurses in relation to smoking cessation. DESIGN AND SETTING: Two postal surveys of national random samples of 303 general practitioners (survey 1) and 459 nurse practitioners (survey 2) covering England and Wales"; effective response rates were 75% and 96%, respectively. RESULTS : Survey 1 found that 96% of GPs agreed that intervening against smoking was part of their role and nearly all (99%) said they recorded smoking status when patients checked in; 57% reported that routinely updated their smoking status records, 50% said they advised smokers to quit during most or all consultations, and 76% said they advised smokers to quit if they were unable to quit A large majority (83%) said they recommend or prescribe nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) Although most GPs (86%) thought NRTs were effective, only a minority Most thought it was worth the cost (47%) or that it should be prescribed by the National Health Service (NHS) (32%). There was little evidence that prior training to stop smoking was associated with more activity, meter More positive attitudes, or greater knowledge. Survey 2 found that nearly all nurse practitioners (99%) agreed that tobacco intervention was part of their role, and 95% said they advise patients to quit smoking at least occasionally; 71% said they advise smokers to quit at most or all visits. A majority (74%) said they recommend NRT to their patients. As with GPs, most nurse practitioners thought nicotine replacement was effective (79%), but fewer (42%) thought the cost was justified, with only around half (53%) ) thought it should be available on NHS prescription. Nurses who said they had been trained to stop smoking participated in more activities related to smoking cessation, had more positive attitudes and were more informed. CONCLUSION: GPs and practice nurses accepted that intervening with smoking was an important part of their role, with a large majority reporting that they intervened with at least some smokers. This represents a promising baseline from which to proceed in terms of implementation of the new smok guidelines for smoking cessation, but it is hoped that improvements can be made in terms of the frequency of updating records and interventions, and the acceptance of the cost-effectiveness of NRT as an intervention to preserve the lifetime.

title: Smoking cessation counseling beliefs and behaviors of outpatient oncology providers
abstract: PURPOSE: Many cancer patients continue to smoke after diagnosis, increasing the risk of treatment complications, reduced treatment efficacy, secondary cancers, and reduced survival. Outpatient oncology providers may not be using the "teachable moment" of cancer diagnosis to provide smoking cessation assistance. PROVIDERS AND METHODS: Physicians and midlevel providers (n = 74) providing outpatient oncology services completed an online survey of behaviors, beliefs, and perceived barriers to smoking cessation counseling. The outpatient medical records of 120 patients with breast, lung, head and neck, colon, prostate, and acute leukemia cancer were reviewed to assess current practices for documentation of smoking cessation intervention and assessment. RESULTS: Providers reported commonly assessing smoking in new patients (82.4% often or always), but rates decreased at subsequent visits for both current smokers and recent quitters. Rates of counseling patients to quit smoking were also high (86.5% frequently or always), but less than 30% of providers reported providing interventions to patients who smoke frequently or always (eg, smoking cessation). , nicotine replacement therapy or other medications, self-help materials, and/or referrals). Only 30% of providers reported that they frequently or always followed up with patients to assess progress in quitting smoking. Few providers (18.1%) reported high levels of confidence in their ability to counsel smoking patients. Patients' lack of motivation was identified as the most important barrier to smoking cessation. CONCLUSIONS: Although beliefs about providing smoking cessation services to patients who smoke were generally positive, few providers reported that they commonly provide interventions beyond cessation counseling. Additional training and clinical interventions may improve adherence to smoking cessation practice guidelines in the oncology outpatient setting.

title: Smoking cessation counseling with pregnant and postpartum women: a survey of community health center providers
abstract: OBJECTIVES: This study evaluated provider performance of smoking cessation counseling steps with low-income pregnant and postpartum women receiving care at community health centers. METHODS: WIC (Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children) staff, obstetrician physicians, and pediatric physicians at 6 community health centers were asked to complete surveys. Intervention practices (performance), knowledge and attitudes, and organizational facilitators were measured. Factors associated with performance were explored with analysis of variance and regression analysis. RESULTS: Performance scores differed significantly by clinic type and provider. Providers from obstetric clinics had the highest scores and those from pediatric clinics had the lowest scores. Nurse practitioners and nutritionists scored higher than other providers. The type of clinic, greater knowledge related to smoking, older age, and the perception of quitting smoking as a priority were independently related to better counseling performance. CONCLUSIONS: Mean performance scores showed room for improvement in all groups. Low scores for performance of steps beyond assessment and counseling indicate a need to emphasize the steps of assisting and following national guidelines. Providers' own commitment to helping mothers quit smoking was important.

title: Quit smoking from office to bed. An evidence-based practical approach
abstract: Cigarette smoking continues to be a national health care crisis and is responsible for unacceptable levels of suffering, illness and death. Barriers to effective intervention, such as training, time, and reimbursement, are formidable, although the situation is improving as behavioral approaches and appropriate medications become more clearly defined. The application of these practical points is an acquired skill that takes time. Incorporating these suggestions into daily practice ensures that your smoking patients have the best opportunity to quit smoking and the highest level of care.

title: Smoking cessation in family medicine: effects of a training program at an area health education center
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES: Many physicians have not received adequate training in smoking cessation. We examined the effects of a tobacco education program on clinicians' behaviour, attitudes, knowledge, and comfort related to smoking cessation. METHODS: In a prospective cohort study, family medicine residents and faculty completed a pretest, followed by an educational intervention that included presentations on smoking cessation resources, motivational interviewing, and the neurobiology of addiction and pharmacotherapy. After 3 months, participants completed a post-intervention survey. The results were analyzed using chi-square tests to examine the effects of training. RESULTS: Thirty-three residents and faculty completed the pre-training survey and 25 completed the post-training survey. After training, participants were more familiar and comfortable with the Public Health Service Clinical Practice Guidelines (P < 0.0001). No significant differences were found in performance of the 5 A's (Ask, Advise, Assess, Help, and Organize) or other behaviors, including providing assistance with counseling, quit plans, resources, or pharmacotherapy. There was no improvement in knowledge of specific intervention plans or in attitudes related to identifying and counseling smokers. CONCLUSION: A multidisciplinary tobacco training program increases physician familiarity and comfort with practice guidelines and may contribute to improved care activities that promote a healthy lifestyle. Future research should explore other interventions that have the potential to change practice patterns on a larger scale. Future studies should also assess the effect of training programs on patient-oriented outcomes.

title: Smoking cessation: a central role for clinicians
abstract: Physicians are in a unique position to advise smokers to quit because of the ability to integrate the various aspects of nicotine dependence. This review provides an overview of intervention with smokers presenting in a primary care setting. Strategies used for counseling to quit smoking differed depending on the patient's willingness to quit. For smokers who do not intend to quit, clinicians should inform and sensitize patients about tobacco use and cessation, especially by personalizing the benefits of smoking cessation and challenging smokers' beliefs. For dissonant smokers, clinicians should use motivational strategies, such as discussing barriers to quitting and their solutions. For smokers ready to quit, physician should show strong support, help set quit date, prescribe pharmaceutical therapies for nicotine dependence such as replacement therapy and/or bupropion, with instructions for use and suggest behavioral strategies to prevent relapse.

title: Smoking: can we really make a difference?
abstract: The enormous health benefits of quitting smoking are now well established. Physicians play a vital role in motivating smokers and initiating quit attempts. The mainstay of the NHS smoking cessation strategy should be the routine provision of a brief opportunistic intervention in primary care, supported by referral to a specialist smoking cessation service. There is an urgent need to substantially increase the number of smokers referred by general practitioners, other members of the primary care team and those working in acute care hospitals, to specialized smoking cessation services and better channels of communication between the various agencies. The use of pharmacotherapy (nicotine replacement therapy or bupropion) in combination with behavioral support achieves higher quit rates than either component alone and is the most effective way to help smokers quit. Smokers who quit often relapse and will therefore need repeated help.

title: Social status and mortality
Social Preferences for the Return of Incidental Findings from Clinical Genomic Sequencing: A Discrete Choice Experiment
abstract: BACKGROUND: A major challenge with the application of next-generation sequencing technology is the possibility of uncovering incidental genomic findings. The dearth of evidence on the personal utility of incidental findings has hampered clinical guidelines. Our goal was to estimate the personal utility of complex information derived from incidental genomic findings. METHODS: We used a discrete-choice experiment to assess participants' self-utility for the following attributes: disease penetrance, disease treatability, disease severity, carrier status, and cost. The study participants were drawn from the Canadian public. We analyze the data with a mixed logit model. RESULTS: In total, 1200 participants completed our questionnaire (available in English and French). Participants valued receiving information about high penetrance disorders but expressed disutility about receiving information about low penetrance disorders. Median willingness to pay was $445 (95% confidence interval [CI] $322 to $567) to receive incidental findings in a scenario where clinicians returned information on high-penetrance medically treatable disorders, but only 66% of participants (95% CI 63%-71%) indicated that they would choose to receive information in that scenario. On average, participants placed significant value ($725, 95% CI: $600-$850) on having a choice about what type of findings they would receive, including receiving information about high-penetrance treatable disorders or receiving information on high penetrance. disorders with or without available treatment. The predicted acceptance of that scenario was 76% (95% CI: 72%-79%). INTERPRETATION: Most participants valued receiving incidental findings, but personal utility depended on the type of finding, and not all participants wanted to receive incidental findings, regardless of potential health implications. These results indicate that to maximize benefit, participant-level preferences should inform the decision about whether to return incidental findings.

title: Society for Adolescent Medicine Position Paper on Adolescent Reproductive Health Care
abstract: PIP: This article is a revision of a 1983 position paper from the Society for Adolescent Medicine with the inclusion of the most recent medical advances in research on adolescent sexuality; that is, contraceptive adherence, behavior change promotion, ethnicity and pregnancy relationships, and male gender. reproductive health The themes for the 1990s will be morbidity and mortality from sexually transmitted diseases The identified themes are sexual activity and adolescent pregnancy, attention to pregnant adolescents, sexually transmitted diseases, HIV infection, adolescent males, sexual abuse in adolescents, youth and lesbians, interventions, reproductive health care for adolescents with disabilities and chronic diseases, and training of primary care physicians. The HIV/AIDS epidemic has focused attention on the reproductive behavior of men. Sexual activity varies by racial/ethnic group. Interventions for delayed sexual initiation should be examined, although condom use has increased among 17-19 year olds from 21% to 58% in metropolitan areas. However, condom use is lowest among the group of men most at risk for STDs: those who have ever used drugs, those who have ever had sex with a prostitute, and those who had 5 or more partners per year. Male beliefs about contraception have been infrequently examined. There are misconceptions about heterosexual transmission of HIV. Better screening is needed for STD detection. Fathers are more involved in prenatal care and postnatal intervention programs. 7% of children have been the object of involuntary sexual relations between the ages of 18 and 21. ;" that is, 12.7% white women, 9% black women, 1.9% white men, and 6.1% black men. Risk factors for white women were living apart from parents by age 16, poverty, physical and emotional limitations, parental alcohol, tobacco, and drug use Sexual assault was associated with hitchhiking and alcohol and drug use in 1 cited study Clinicians should be sensitive to this issue and probe for information The sexual needs of people who are unsure of their orientation or who are gay or lesbian are gradually being recognized Among 12th graders 1% of men and 1% of women saw themselves themselves as mostly or completely gay or lesbian, and 10% were unsure Psychological and medical problems found Interventions needed are STD and reproductive information , multiple approaches in a variety of settings nos, teen clinics and outreach.

title: Socioeconomic factors, health behaviors, and mortality: results of a nationally representative prospective study of American adults.
abstract: Context.Âª A prominent hypothesis regarding social inequalities in mortality is that the elevated risk among the socioeconomically disadvantaged is largely due to the higher prevalence of health risk behaviors among those with lower levels of education and income. Lower. Objective.Â¡Âª To investigate the extent to which 4 behavioral risk factors (smoking, alcohol use, sedentary lifestyle, and relative body weight) explain the observed association between socioeconomic characteristics and all-cause mortality. Design. Longitudinal survey study investigating the impact of education, income, and health behaviors on the risk of dying in the next 7.5 years. Participants. A nationally representative sample of 3,617 adult women and men participating in the Americans' Changing Lives survey. Main outcome measure. All-cause mortality verified through the National Death Index and death certificate reviews. Results. Educational differences in mortality are fully explained by the strong association between education and income. Controlling for age, sex, race, urbanity, and education, the mortality hazard ratio was 3.22 (95% confidence interval [CI], 2.01-5.16) for those in the lower income and 2.34 (95% CI, 1.49 -3.67) for those in the middle income group. When health risk behaviors were considered, the risk of dying was still significantly elevated for the lowest income group (hazard ratio, 2.77"; 95% CI, 1.74-4.42 ) and the middle-income group (hazard rate ratio, 2.14; 95% CI, 1.38-3.25).Â¡Âª Although reducing the prevalence of health risk behaviors in populations of low income is an important public health goal, socioeconomic differences in mortality are due to a broader range of factors and thus would persist even with better health behaviors among those harmed.

title: Sources of variation and bias in diagnostic accuracy studies
abstract: Background: Diagnostic accuracy studies are subject to different sources of bias and variation than studies evaluating the effectiveness of an intervention. Little is known about the effects of these sources of bias and variation. Purpose: To summarize the evidence on the factors that can generate bias or variation in the results of diagnostic accuracy studies. Data sources: MEDLINE, EMBASE, and BIOSIS, and the methodological databases of the Center for Reviews and Dissemination and the Cochrane Collaboration. Expert methodologists in diagnostic tests were contacted. Study selection: Studies that investigated the effects of bias and variation in measures of test performance were eligible for inclusion, which was assessed by one reviewer and checked by a second reviewer. Discrepancies were resolved by discussion. Data Extraction: Data extraction was performed by one reviewer and checked by a second reviewer. Data Synthesis: The best-documented effects of bias and variation were found for demographics, disease prevalence and severity, partial verification bias, clinical review bias, and observer and instrument variation. For other sources, such as biased participant selection, missing or inappropriate reference standard, differential verification bias, and review bias, the amount of evidence was limited. Evidence was lacking for other features, including recruitment bias, treatment paradox, arbitrary choice of threshold value, and dropouts. Conclusions: many problems in the design and performance of diagnostic accuracy studies can generate bias or variations";" however, empirical evidence on the size and effect of these problems is limited.

title: Detect malignant melanoma
Stability of attitudes toward ethical issues raised by the return of incidental genomics research findings in children: a follow-up study.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: We explored the stability of parental attitudes to the ethical questions raised by the return of genomic research results. METHODS: A 19-item questionnaire was mailed to participants in a large genome research consortium 18 months after a baseline survey. We describe the stability of parents' attitudes toward (a) sharing genomic research results, (b) children's support of genomic research, (c) researchers' responsibilities, and (d) responsibilities to the community. extended family. We also explore your experience in receiving results. RESULTS: Of 170 original participants, 154 (91%) responded. Most participants expressed positive rights to receive incidental genomic research findings (85%), even when enhancement therapy was unknown (85%). Only 3% considered it acceptable to delegate the decision to return the results to an independent committee. Researchers, either with a parent (42%) or a doctor (17%), were held responsible for passing on research results to children when they reach adulthood. The majority of participants (74%) indicated that the results should be shared with the potentially affected extended family. These results are very similar to those of the reference survey. All participants who received genomic results would do so again and reported actions similar to their expressed attitudes. CONCLUSIONS: Parents' opinions regarding genomic research remain stable over time. Guidelines on return of results should incorporate these findings.

title: Staged diabetes management: computerization of a disease state management program
abstract: Recently, the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and other similar studies have shown that near normalization of blood glucose in diabetes will reduce complications by up to 75%, but translation of these results into practice it has been difficult. In an attempt to help provide the best possible control for patients with diabetes, we have produced an attempt to help provide the best possible control for patients with diabetes, we have produced a new disease state monitoring system for diabetes , called "Diabetes management by stages". (SDM), deployed it at more than 100 sites worldwide, and developed software to simplify its use. SDM, designed to change the way we treat patients with diabetes, is based on five principles: (1) community participation in establishing guidelines for care; (2) goal negotiation with patients; (3) appropriate timeframes for therapeutic success; (4) use of flow charts for medical decisions;" and (5) program evaluation. SDM is designed to be modified by a community to meet its needs and resources. It encourages primary care physicians to provide better health care diabetes using a team approach and refer patients with diabetes to specialists when appropriate Has a comprehensive set of materials for communities, individual healthcare providers and patients SDM has been tested for changes in structure, process and results A meta-analysis of seven clinical trials with more than 500 patients showed a time-weighted average drop in hemoglobin A1c of 1.7 points (equivalent to a drop in mean blood glucose of approximately 3.5 mM or 60 mg/dL) Preliminary pharmacoeconomic analysis demonstrates lifetime cost savings of more than $27,000 per patient A computer program has been developed for the e Microsoft Windows environment containing a client-server database, based on DiabCare, for the data file structure.

title: Standard operating procedure changed the behavior of prehospital intensive care anesthesiologists: a quality control study
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The ability of standard operating procedures to improve prehospital critical care by changing prehospital physician behavior is uncertain. We present data from a prospective quality control study of the effect on behavior of prehospital intensive care anesthesiologists of implementing a standard operating procedure for prehospital controlled ventilation. MATERIALS AND METHODS: Anesthesiologists from eight prehospital intensive care teams in the central region of Denmark prospectively recorded prehospital advanced airway management data according to the Utstein-style template. We collected pre-intervention data from February 1, 2011 through January 31, 2012, implemented standard operating procedure on February 1, 2012, and collected post-intervention data from February 1, 2012 through January 31, 2012. October 2012. We included transported patients of all ages requiring controlled ventilation treated with prehospital endotracheal intubation or supraglottic airway device insertion. The objective was to assess whether the development and implementation of a standard operating procedure for controlled ventilation during transport could change the behavior of prehospital critical care anesthesiologists and thus increase the use of automated ventilators in these patients. RESULTS: Implementation of a standard operating procedure increased the overall prevalence of automated ventilator use in transported patients requiring controlled ventilation from 0.40 (0.34-0.47) to 0.74 (0.69-0.80). ) with a prevalence ratio of 1.85 (1.57-2.19) (p = 0.00). The prevalence of automatic ventilator use in transported traumatic brain injury patients requiring controlled ventilation increased from 0.44 (0.26-0.62) to 0.85 (0.62-0.97) with a prevalence ratio 1.94 (1.26-3.0) (p = 0.0039). The prevalence of automatic ventilator use in patients transported after return of spontaneous circulation after prehospital cardiac arrest increased from 0.39 (0.26-0.48) to 0.69 (0.58-0.78) with a prevalence ratio of 1.79 (1.36-2.35) (p = 0.00). CONCLUSION: We have shown that the implementation of a standard operating procedure for prehospital controlled ventilation can significantly change the behavior of prehospital intensive care anesthesiologists.

title: Statement of Standards for Reporting Implementation Studies (Stari)
abstract: Implementation studies are often poorly reported and indexed, reducing their potential to inform initiatives to improve health care services. The Standards for Reporting Implementation Studies (STARI) initiative aimed to develop guidelines for transparent and accurate reporting of implementation studies. Informed by the findings of a systematic review and an e-Delphi consensus-building exercise, an international working group of implementation science experts discussed and agreed on the StaRI checklist comprising 27 items. It prompts researchers to describe both the implementation strategy (techniques used to promote the implementation of an underutilized evidence-based intervention) and the effectiveness of the intervention that was being implemented. An accompanying Explanation and Elaboration document (published in BMJ Open, doi: 10.1136/bmjopen-2016-013318) details each of the elements, explains the rationale, and provides examples of good reporting practice. The adoption of StaRI will improve the reporting of implementation studies, which could facilitate the translation of research into practice and improve the health of individuals and populations.

title: State of the science: beta-blockers and reduction of perioperative cardiac events
abstract: This article assesses the current literature on the use of perioperative beta-blockade to reduce cardiac events in the hope that it may provide guidance to clinicians or demonstrate gaps in medical knowledge, thereby revealing suitable areas for future study. The current practice standard for the use of perioperative beta-blockers in preoperative patients is outlined in the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines. Results differ on the risk and benefit of perioperative beta-blocker use to reduce cardiac events. More research is needed to support the ACC/AHA recommendations. It is essential that the decision to use beta-blockade is made on a case-by-case basis with appropriate risk stratification as part of the criteria.

title: Meet Minimum Standards: Implement Antibiotic Stewardship in Intensive Care
abstract: BACKGROUND: In Australia, antimicrobial stewardship programs are a mandatory component of hospital accreditation. Good antimicrobial prescribing documentation aids communication and can improve prescribing practice in settings with multiple decision makers. OBJECTIVE: This study aims to develop and implement an intervention to improve antimicrobial prescribing practice in a 24-bed intensive care unit at a tertiary referral hospital for adults. METHODS: We conducted a prospective collaborative study of quality improvement before and after four phases (observation, reflection, implementation, evaluation). Baseline audits and surveys of antimicrobial prescribing practices identified barriers to and facilitators of good prescribing practices. A tailored intervention was then implemented for 6 weeks and included a yellow sticker on the medication record, quarterly educational sessions, and empirical intensive care unit-specific antimicrobial prescribing guidelines. After implementation, effects were monitored by serial antimicrobial prescription audits for 1 year. Primary outcomes were clear documentation of start date, planned end date or review date, and indication of an antibiotic. All of these were considered the "minimum standards" for an antimicrobial prescription in the drug registry. RESULTS: Documentation of the minimum standards specifically addressed by the label (start date (72% to 90%, P < 0.001), end date (16% to 63%, P < 0.001), documented antimicrobial indication in the medication table (58% to 83%, P < 0.01). Overall, compliance with the three minimum standards (start date, end date, and indication) improved from 41/306 (13%) to 306/492 (63%) (P < .001). One year after implementation, the yellow tag had been integrated into daily practice. CONCLUSION: A systematic approach to quality improvement combined with the implementation of a tailored multifaceted intervention can improve antimicrobial prescribing practices.

title: stimulant drugs
abstract: Stimulants are a key element in the treatment of ADHD. Carefully designed stimulant trials have found substantial improvement in core ADHD behaviors in 65-75% of ADHD subjects. Most standard stimulants are rapidly absorbed, with their behavioral effects appearing within 30 minutes, peaking in one to three hours, and wearing off within five hours. Doses at school are often necessary, despite the risk of teasing from peers and the additional requirements of adult supervision. The mechanism by which stimulants act to reduce hyperactivity is not fully understood, but they do improve impulsivity and activity levels. Several controlled evaluations carried out over periods of time greater than one year show a clear persistence of the effects of the medication over time. A carefully crafted program of methylphenidate treatment is more effective in reducing symptoms of hyperactivity than an intensive program of behavioral and cognitive intervention. The combination of stimulants with psychosocial interventions in ADHD offers few advantages over medication alone. It is difficult to propose unquestionable guidelines for practice that would be appropriate everywhere. It is imperative that physicians who prescribe stimulants supervise the use of the drug appropriately, ensuring that the child's family, peers, or those administering the medication at school do not abuse it. Polypharmacy should only be started by a specialized service and the combination of methylphenidate and clonidine should be used with caution. Aside from ADHD, stimulants are useful in narcolepsy, resistant depression, and partial attention-hyperactivity syndromes. Significant gaps in knowledge remain";" the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and pharmacogenetics of the stimulant effects need further study. The details of the stimulant administration regimens appear to have an important effect on the response achieved. More research is needed, preferably in realistic practical settings, comparing different forms of combination with psychological interventions, investigating effects in out-of-core groups of children of school age with typical ADHD: preschool children, adults, those with partial syndromes (such as inattention) and those with comorbid disorders.

title: strangle the future
Strategies for rehabilitation professionals to put evidence-based knowledge into practice: a systematic review
abstract: RATIONALE: Rehabilitation clinicians need to stay current on best practices, especially since adhering to clinical guidelines can significantly improve patient outcomes. However, little is known about the benefits of knowledge translation interventions for these professionals. OBJECTIVES: To examine the effectiveness of single- and multi-component knowledge translation interventions in improving the practical knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors of rehabilitation clinicians. METHODS: Systematic review of 7 databases conducted to identify studies evaluating specific knowledge translation interventions for occupational therapists and physical therapists. RESULTS: 12 studies met the eligibility criteria. For physical therapists, participation in a multi-component active knowledge translation intervention resulted in better evidence-based knowledge and practice behaviors compared to passive dissemination strategies. These achievements did not translate into changes in physicians' attitudes toward best practice. For occupational therapists, no studies have examined the use of multi-component interventions";" studies of single interventions suggest limited evidence of effectiveness for all outcomes measured. CONCLUSION: While this review suggests the use of multicomponent active knowledge translation interventions to improve physical therapists' knowledge and practice behaviors, further research is needed to understand the impact of these strategies on occupational therapists. Serious research gaps remain regarding which knowledge translation strategies have a positive impact on patient outcomes.

title: Strengthening general practice
Strengthening of the Report on Observational Studies in Epidemiology (STROBE): Explanation and Elaboration
abstract: Much of medical research is observational. Reporting of observational studies is often of poor quality. Poor reporting makes it difficult to assess the strengths and weaknesses of a study and to generalize its results. Taking into account empirical evidence and theoretical considerations, a group of methodologists, researchers, and editors developed the Strengthening Observational Study Reporting in Epidemiology (STROBE) recommendations to improve the quality of observational study reporting. The STROBE Statement consists of a checklist of 22 items, which relate to the title, abstract, introduction, methods, results, and discussion sections of the articles. Eighteen elements are common to cohort studies, case-control studies, and cross-sectional studies, and four are specific to each of the three study designs. The STROBE Statement provides guidance to authors on how to improve observational study reporting and facilitates critical appraisal and interpretation of studies by reviewers, journal editors, and readers. This explanatory and elaboration document is intended to improve the use, understanding and dissemination of the STROBE Statement. The meaning and rationale for each checklist item is presented. For each item, one or more published examples are provided and, where possible, references to relevant empirical studies and methodological literature. Examples of useful flow charts are also included. The STROBE Statement, this document, and the associated website (http://www.strobe-statement.org/) should be useful resources for improving observational research reporting.

title: Stress as a cardiovascular risk factor
abstract: Stress is the body's reaction to a stressor with various negative consequences for health, including the development of arteriosclerosis. Stress can cause myocardial ischemia, rhythm disturbances, platelet stimulation, increased blood viscosity due to hemoconcentration, as well as endothelial dysfunction and coronary vasoconstriction in the presence of atherosclerosis of the coronary arteries. Psychosocial risk factors can also lead to the development and clinical consequences of arteriosclerosis. The five most important psychosocial risk factors are: depression, anxiety, personality factors, social isolation and chronic life stress. Various components are responsible for the fact that life events or certain psychosocial factors can lead to a stress reaction. Psychosocial risk factors have direct pathophysiological effects but also influence lifestyle and behavior Several intervention programs for stress management have been shown to be effective. Psychosocial intervention in conjunction with cardiac rehabilitation programs has been shown to reduce cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.

title: Stress echocardiography in heart failure
abstract: Echocardiography has the ability to noninvasively explore hemodynamic variables during pharmacological or exercise stress testing in patients with heart failure. In this review, we detail some important potential applications of stress echocardiography in patients with heart failure. In patients with coronary artery disease and chronic LV dysfunction, dobutamine stress echocardiography is able to distinguish between viable and fibrotic tissue to make appropriate clinical decisions. The stress test, in combination with echocardiographic monitoring, is a method to obtain accurate information in the evaluation of functional capacity and prognosis. Functional mitral regurgitation is a common finding in patients with dilated and ischemic cardiomyopathy, and stress echocardiography in the form of exercise or pharmacological protocols can be useful in evaluating the behavior of mitral regurgitation. It is of clinical utility to search for the presence of contractile reserve in non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy as well as to screen for or monitor the presence of latent myocardial dysfunction in patients who have been exposed to cardiotoxic agents. Furthermore, in patients with suspected diastolic heart failure and normal systolic function, stress echocardiography could demonstrate the existence of such dysfunction and determine that it is sufficient to limit exercise tolerance. Finally, in aortic stenosis, dobutamine echocardiography can distinguish severe from non-severe stenosis in patients with low transvalvular gradients and depressed left ventricular function.

title: Structured follow-up by general practitioners after deliberate self-poisoning: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: General practitioners (GPs) play an important role in the follow-up of patients after deliberate self-poisoning (DSP). The objective was to examine whether structured follow-up by GPs increased content, adherence and satisfaction with treatment after discharge from the emergency department. METHODS: This was a multicenter randomized trial with blinded allocation. Five emergency services and general practices in the area of influence participated. 202 patients discharged from emergency departments after DSP were assigned. The intervention consisted of a structured follow-up by the general practitioner for a period of 6 months with a minimum of five consultations, accompanied by a written guide for general practitioners with suggestions to motivate patients to follow the treatment, assess personal problems and suicidal ideation and availability in the event of a suicidal crisis. Outcome measures were data extracted from the Register for the Control and Payment of Reimbursement to Health Service Providers (KUHR) and through questionnaires mailed to patients and GPs. After 3 and 6 months, the frequency and content of GP contact and adherence to GP consultations and treatment in general were recorded. Satisfaction with the general treatment received and with the GP was measured using the EUROPEP scale. RESULTS: Patients in the intervention group received significantly more consultations than the control group (mean 6.7 vs. 4.5 (p = 0.004)). The intervention group was significantly more satisfied with the time their GP spent listening to their personal problems (93.1% vs 59.4% (p=0.002)) and with the fact that the GP included in medical decisions (87.5% vs. 54.8% (p = 0.009)).
