The intervention group was significantly more satisfied with the treatment in general than the control group (79% vs. 51% (p = 0.026)). CONCLUSIONS: Structured and improved GP guidelines and follow-up after DSP patient discharge increased the number of consultations and satisfaction with aftercare in general practice. Consistent with previous research, there is still a need for intervention studies. TRIAL REGISTRY: ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT01342809. Registered on April 18, 2011.

title: Structured smoking cessation training for health professionals in cardiology wards: a prospective study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Cigarette smoking is a major cardiovascular risk factor, and smoking cessation is imperative for patients hospitalized with a cardiovascular event. This study aimed to evaluate a systems-based approach to help hospitalized smokers quit and identify implementation barriers. DESIGN: Prospective intervention study followed by qualitative analysis of staff interviews. METHODS: The prospective intervention study evaluated the effects of implementing standard operating procedures (SOPs) for the provision of counseling and pharmacotherapy to smokers admitted to cardiology wards on the frequency of counseling. In addition, a qualitative analysis of staff interviews was conducted to examine the determinants of physician and nurse behavior";" this sought to understand the barriers in terms of motivation, ability and/or opportunity. RESULTS: A total of 150 smoker patients were included in the study (75 before and 75 after SOP implementation). Before the implementation of the SOPs, the proportion of patients who reported receiving smoking cessation advice from doctors and nurses was 6.7% and 1.3%, respectively. After SOP implementation, these proportions increased to 38.7% (p < 0.001) and 2.7% (p = 0.56), respectively. Qualitative analysis revealed that lack of motivation, for example role incongruity, appeared to be a major barrier. CONCLUSIONS: The introduction of a set of standard operating procedures for smoking cessation counseling was effective with physicians but not with nurses. The analysis of barriers to implementation highlighted lack of motivation rather than capacity or opportunity as an important factor that should be addressed.

title: Study confirms value of STD treatment in curbing HIV transmission
abstract: PIP: An intervention was carried out in the Mwanza region of Tanzania to determine whether improved treatment at health centers and rural clinics of sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) other than HIV/AIDS could reduce the incidence of new HIV/AIDS infections. The hiv. Physician assistants and nurses at six rural health centers were trained in syndromic management of STDs, and health center staff were encouraged to counsel their patients, offer them condoms, and request referrals from sexual partners for treatment. The centers received the least expensive effective drugs for the treatment of the main STD syndromes. Health workers trained as supervisors visited each center every 8 weeks to check drug supplies and patient records, provide refresher training, and ensure adherence to syndromic management guidelines. In addition, a cohort of 1,000 adults in the communities served by the six health centers were interviewed and tested for HIV at the start of the study and 2 years after the intervention was introduced. The number of new cases of HIV infection that occurred in the cohort was then compared with those that occurred in another selected cohort of communities served by health centers where improved STD treatment had not been provided. 11,632 STD cases were treated at the centers during the 2-year study period. The intervention was found to reduce the number of new HIV infections that occurred during the study period by 42%. That reduction was in both sexes and in all age groups, but was especially evident among women aged 15 to 24 years. The survey results indicate that the reductions in HIV incidence were the result of better STD treatment rather than changes in sexual behavior. Preliminary calculations indicate a cost of approximately US$300 per HIV infection averted.

title: Study of a novel curriculum on electronic communication in family medicine residencies
abstract: Electronic communication between doctors and patients is common, but it can carry risks for users, both patients and doctors. Little is known about electronic communication between physicians and patients, and even less about electronic communication during residency. We studied knowledge and practices before and after a controlled trial of a novel curriculum teaching email communication with patients using residents and faculty at 16 family medicine residencies in the United States. Both teaching staff and residents showed a lack of knowledge about confidentiality and encryption, unfamiliarity with published guidelines for doctor-patient email, and noncompliance with documentation requirements before the curriculum was presented. Post-testing revealed greater improvement in knowledge and appropriate behaviors related to doctor-patient email in the intervention group compared to control sites (mean intervention increase of 13 points [t = -4.065 , P < 0.01], mean increase in control is 5 points [t=-2.015, p<0.05]). Greater uncertainty about comfort with patient email among intervention residents is an interesting finding that could be due to increased awareness of issues but limited time spent absorbing the topic. Suggestions for delivering the curriculum are provided.

title: Study protocol for a randomized controlled trial: the feasibility and impact of absolute cardiovascular risk assessment in Australian general practice.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although absolute cardiovascular risk assessment (CVAR) has been recommended for use in Australian general practice for a number of years, there is continuing uncertainty about its implementation and impact. Our previous work has developed a multifaceted implementation model. This study aims to investigate both the feasibility of using this model and the impact of CVAR assessment and management on general practice clinical processes and patient care. STUDY DESIGN: This cluster randomized controlled trial will be conducted in general practices in Sydney, involving general practitioners (GPs), other practice staff, and patients aged 45 to 69 years without existing cardiovascular disease. METHODS: A total of 32 practices (40 physicians) and 1,320 patients will be recruited. Randomization will be carried out at the practice level. The intervention group of GPs will be trained to use a CVAR implementation model, while the control group of GPs will continue with usual care. Study outcomes include clinical processes, patient risk, use of lifestyle interventions, and prescription of antihypertensive and lipid-lowering medications. Data will be collected and analyzed using mixed methods. Study results before and after the intervention will be compared, and the 2 groups will also be compared after adjusting for baseline difference and grouping factors. DISCUSSION: This trial will be the first study in Australian general practice and one of the few international studies to assess the impact of implementing CVAR assessment and management. The results of this study will help improve primary prevention of cardiovascular disease and inform guidelines for clinical practice and the implementation of other health initiatives.

title: Studying deimplementation in health: an analysis of funded research grants
abstract: Background The study of the lack of implementation, defined in this document as the reduction or cessation of the use of a health service or practice provided to patients by health care professionals and systems, has gained strength in recent years. years. Eliminating ineffective, unproven, harmful, overused, inappropriate, and/or low-value health services and practices is important to mitigate patient harm, improve care processes, and reduce health care costs. A better understanding of the state of the science is needed to guide future goals and funding initiatives. To this end, we characterized deimplementation research grants funded by the United States (US) National Institutes of Health (NIH) and the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ). Methods We used systematic methods to search for, identify, and describe deimplementation research grants funded at the 27 NIH Institutes and Centers (ICs) and AHRQ from fiscal year 2000 through 2017. Eleven key terms and three funding opportunity announcements were used to search for research grants in the NIH Query, View and Report (QVR) system. Two coders identified eligible grants based on inclusion/exclusion criteria. A codebook was developed, pilot tested and reviewed before the final sample full grant applications were coded. Results A total of 1,277 grants were identified through the QVR";" system. 542 remained after removing duplicates. After the multi-step eligibility screening and review process, 20 grant applications were coded. Many grants were funded by NIH (n?=?15), with fewer funded by AHRQ, and most were funded between fiscal years 2015 and 2016 (n?=?11). Grant proposals focused on the elimination of a variety of health practices and services (eg, drugs, therapies, screening tests) in various health areas (eg, cancer, cardiovascular disease) and settings. provision (eg, hospitals, nursing homes, schools). The grants proposed to use a variety of study designs and research methods (eg, experimental, observational, mixed methods) to achieve the objectives of the study. Conclusions Based on systematic review of the portfolio of NIH and AHRQ-funded research grants over the past 17 years, relatively few have focused on studying the lack of implementation of ineffective, unproven, harmful, overused health programs. , inappropriate and/or of low value. services and practices provided to patients by health professionals and systems. Strategies to raise the profile and grow the field of deimplementation research are discussed.

title: Success after treatment of periprosthetic joint infection: a Delphi-based international multidisciplinary consensus
abstract: BACKGROUND: The lack of agreement regarding what constitutes successful treatment for periprosthetic joint infections (PJIs) makes it difficult to compare different management strategies used in clinical practice and in research studies. QUESTIONS/PURPOSES: The goals of this study were to create a consensus definition for success after PJI treatment and to provide a universal, multidimensional framework for informing PJI treatment studies. METHODS: A basic two-round Delphi method was used to arrive at a consensus definition. We invited 159 international experts (orthopedic surgeons, infectious disease specialists, and clinical researchers) from 17 countries to participate; 59 participated in the first round and 42 participated in the second round. The final definition consisted of all statements that achieved strong agreement. (80% or more of participants considering a relevant criterion to define success) RESULTS: The consensus definition of a successfully treated PJI is: (1) eradication of infection, characterized by a healed wound without fistula, drainage, or pain , and no recurrent infection caused by the same strain of the organism; (2) no subsequent surgical intervention for infection after replantation surgery;" and (3) no PJI-related mortality (from causes such as sepsis, necrotizing fasciitis). The Delphi panel agreed to define mid-term outcomes as reported 5 or more years after definitive PJI surgery, and long-term outcomes as reported 10 or more years after surgery Although no consensus was reached on the definition of short-term outcomes, 71% of participants agreed that 2 years after definitive PJI surgery is acceptable to define PJI.CONCLUSIONS: This multidimensional definition of success after PJI treatment can be used to report and compare treatment outcomes for this catastrophic complication LEVEL OF EVIDENCE: Level V, Therapeutic Study See Guidelines to Authors for a full description of levels of evidence.

title: Successful implementation of a guideline through peer comparisons, education, and positive feedback from clinicians
abstract: The objective of this study was to determine if peer comparisons, an educational intervention, and positive feedback from clinicians would decrease the ordering of knee X-ray studies. We prospectively studied the ordering of knee X-ray studies for patients presenting with knee injuries before and after an educational program to encourage the use of the Ottawa decision rule for knee radiography. Physicians were able to privately compare their individual baseline X-ray utilization data with that of their colleagues. Although acceptance of the rule was voluntary, both oral and written feedback encouraged consideration of the rule in clinical decision making. The percentage of patients with knee injuries who received X-ray studies, as well as the percentage of abnormal results (PAR, defined as the percentage of X-ray studies showing a fracture or effusion), were calculated before and after the meeting. educational. The results of the study showed that the percentage of patients with knee injuries who received X-ray studies decreased by 23%. Furthermore, PAR increased 58.4% between the two study periods. In conclusion, the physician's behavior can be positively modified by reinforcement. Peer comparisons, education, and positive feedback from physicians reduced physician testing even without the mandatory use of a protocol. PAR is a useful outcome measure for tracking physician utilization.

title: Successful implementation of a sedation and neonatal pain protocol in 2 NICUs
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the implementation of a sedation and neonatal pain protocol in 2 ICUs. METHODS: The intervention began with an assessment of local practice, problems, and staff satisfaction. We then developed and implemented the Vienna Protocol for Neonatal Pain and Sedation. The protocol included well-defined strategies for nonpharmacologic and pharmacologic interventions based on periodic assessment of a translated version of the Neonatal Pain Agitation and Sedation Scale and titration of sedative and analgesic therapy according to target scores. Health care staff were trained in the assessment using a video-based tutorial and bedside teaching. In addition, we conduct re-evaluation, training and random quality checks. The frequency and quality of assessments, drug therapy, duration of mechanical ventilation, and outcome were compared between baseline (12 months before implementation) and 12 months after implementation. RESULTS: Cumulative median (interquartile range) opioid dose (initial dose of 1.4 [0.5-5.9] mg/kg versus intervention group dose of 2.7 [0.4-57] mg /kg morphine equivalents"; P = 0.002), pharmacological interventions per episode of continuous sedation/analgesia (4 [2-10] vs 6 [2-13]; P = 0.005), and overall staff satisfaction (physicians : 31% vs. 89%; p < 0.001; nurses: 17% vs. 55%;" p < 0.001) increased after implementation. Time on mechanical ventilation, length of ICU stay, and adverse outcomes were similar before and after implementation. CONCLUSIONS: Implementation of a neonatal pain and sedation protocol in 2 ICUs resulted in an increase in opioid prescription, pharmacological interventions, and staff satisfaction without affecting time on mechanical ventilation, length of stay in intensive care and adverse outcomes.

title: Successful reduction of catheter-associated urinary tract infections: focus on nurse-led catheter removal.
abstract: Background Despite using sterile technique for catheter insertion, closed drainage systems, and structured daily care plans, catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CUTs) occur regularly in acute care hospitals. We believe that a significant reduction in CAUTI rates can only be achieved by reducing the use of urinary catheters. Methods We used a hospital-wide multidisciplinary program intervention study to reduce the use of urinary catheters and CAUTIs in all patient care units at a 300-bed community teaching hospital in Connecticut. Our primary focus was the implementation of a nurse-led urinary catheter removal protocol. This protocol was linked to the physician's order of catheter insertion. Three additional items included physician documentation of catheter insertion criteria, a device-specific charting module added to electronic physician progress notes, and biweekly unit-specific feedback on catheter use rates and rates of discharge. CAUTI in a multidisciplinary forum. Results We achieved a hospital-wide 50% reduction in catheter use and a 70% reduction in CAUTI over a 36-month period, although there was wide unit-to-unit variation in catheter reduction efforts, which they range from 4% (maternity) to 74%. % (telemetry). Conclusion Urinary catheter use, and ultimately CAUTI rates, can be effectively reduced by diligent application of relatively few evidence-based interventions. Aggressive implementation of the nurse-led catheter removal protocol was associated with lower rates of catheter use and reduced infection rates.

title: Suicidal tendency: procedure in emergency cases
abstract: Emergency physicians (EP), paramedics and emergency personnel play an increasingly important role in the emergency medical and psychological treatment of patients after suicide attempts, as well as in crisis intervention of people with acute suicidal tendencies. . This article aims to give an overview of the prevalence rates, the methods of suicide or attempted suicide, and the problems faced by EPs in the treatment of these patients. In addition, concepts are presented that allow an adequate evaluation of the risk of suicidality and the options of primary intervention in crisis. Paramedics and critical care physicians are increasingly dealing with this complex process with social, personal and medical aspects. To treat people in suicidal crisis and/or after a suicide attempt and to provide safe and optimal care for this often heterogeneous patient group, clear guidelines are a prerequisite. The first assessment of the acute danger of suicide is of particular importance because of the resulting consequences and demonstrates a clear approach to dealing with suicidal people. In addition, the legal principles are presented.

title: Evaluation of suicide and violence in psychiatry
abstract: Psychiatrists are increasingly expected to predict and prevent suicidal and violent/homicidal impulses in their clients. This article reviews the literature and current research in these areas. While the debate continues as to whether clinicians can successfully predict violence or suicidal behavior in their patients, the preponderance of studies weighs that predicting suicide and violence in the individual may not be possible at present given current knowledge. . To compensate for prognostic limitations, conservative physicians deliberately predict suicide or violence to help ensure the safety of their patients and the larger communities in which they reside. In addition, clinicians must conduct thorough evaluations and make sound clinical decisions that are in line with perceived risks. Preventive measures for violence remain complex, but clinicians can maximize the effects of treatment by following specific intervention guidelines. At a minimum, documentation of violence should focus on the rationale for why treatment interventions were or were not implemented. The chart does not require extensive annotations, but should include a reasonable assessment of risk and the delineation of a prudent course of action.

title: Summary of Practice Parameters for the Evaluation and Treatment of Children and Adolescents with Suicidal Behavior
abstract: These guidelines review what is known about the epidemiology, causes, management, and prevention of suicide and suicide attempts in youth. Detailed guidelines on the evaluation and emergency management of children and adolescents exhibiting suicidal behavior are provided. The guidelines also present suggestions on how the doctor can interact with the community. Crisis hotlines, method restriction, educational programs, and screening/case detection strategies for suicide prevention are discussed, and the clinician is advised on media advice. Intervention in the community after suicide, minimization of contagion or mimicry of suicide, and training of primary care physicians and other gatekeepers to recognize and refer the potentially suicidal child and adolescent are discussed.

title: Supporting clinical practice at the bedside using wireless technology.
abstract: Objectives: Despite studies showing improvements in both standards of care and outcomes with judicious application of clinical practice guidelines (CPGs), their clinical use remains low. This randomized controlled trial examined the use of a wirelessly networked mobile computer (MC) by physicians at the bedside with access to an emergency department information system, decision support tools (DST), and other management options. software. Methods: Each of the 10 volunteer ER physicians was randomized using a matched-pair design to work five shifts in a standard manner (access to a desktop computer [DC]) and five shifts with a CM on a wireless network. Work pattern problems and use of electronic CPG/DST were compared using end-of-shift satisfaction questionnaires and review of a CPG/DST database. Repeated measures analysis of variance was used to examine differences between shifts. Results: A total of 100 eight-hour shifts" were evaluated; 99% compliance with post-shift questionnaires was achieved. Using a seven-point Likert scale (MC values first), MCs were rated as as fast (5.04 vs. 4.54; p = 0.13) and convenient (5.08 vs. 4.14; p = 0.07) as DC In general, physicians rated CMs as less efficient (3.18 vs. 4.30; p = 0.02), but recommended more frequent use of DSTs (4.10 vs. 3.47; p = 0.03) without affecting doctor-patient communication (2.78 vs. 2.96, p = 0.51) During the study period, physicians' use of an intranet web application (eCPG) was more frequent during shifts assigned to the CM compared to the CD (eCPG uses/turn, 3.6 vs. 2.0;" p = 0.033). Conclusions: MC technology enabled clinicians to access information at the bedside and increased the use of CPG/DST tools. According to the doctors, the patients seemed to accept the use of information technology to help in decision-making. The development of improved computing technology may address the main limitation of MC portability.

title: Support for initiation of insulin in type 2 diabetes in primary care: results from the Stepping Up pragmatic cluster randomized controlled clinical trial.
abstract: Objective: To compare the efficacy of a new model of care ("Stepping Up") with usual primary care in normalizing insulin initiation for type 2 diabetes, leading to improved levels of glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c). Design of a cluster randomized controlled trial. Setting Primary care practice in Victoria, Australia, with a practice nurse and at least one consenting eligible patient (HbA1c Ã¢â€°Â¥7.5% with maximum oral therapy). Participants 266 patients with type 2 diabetes and 74 practices (mean cluster size 4 (range 1-8) patients), followed up for 12 months. Intervention The Stepping Up model of care intervention involved theory-based change in practice systems and reorientation of the roles of health professionals in the primary care diabetes team Core components were an enhanced role for the nurse of practice in directing insulin initiation and mentoring by a registered nurse with diabetes educator credentials. Main Outcome Measures The primary endpoint was change in HbA1c. Secondary endpoints included the proportion of participants who transitioned to insulin, the proportion who reached target HbA1c, and a change in depressive symptoms (patient health questionnaire, PHQ-9), diabetes-specific distress (problem areas on the diabetes scale, PAID) and generic health. (assessment of the quality of life instrument, AQoL-8D). Results: HbA1c improved in both arms, with a clinically significant difference between arms (mean difference -0.6%, 95% confidence interval -0.9% to -0.3%). favoring the intervention. At 12 months, in the intervention practices, 105/151 (70%) of the participants had started insulin, compared to 25/115 (22%) in the control practices (odds ratio 8.3, interval 95% confidence 4.5 to 15.4, P<0.001). The HbA1c goal (Ã¢â€°Â¤7% (53 mmol/mol)) was achieved by 54 (36%) intervention participants and 22 (19%) control participants (odds ratio 2.2, 1 .2 to 4.3, P=0.02). Depressive symptoms did not worsen at 12 months (PHQ-9: -1.1 (3.5) v -0.1 (2.9), P=0.05). A statistically significant difference was found between arms in mean change in mental health (mental component summary AQoL: 0.04 (SD 0.16) v -0.002 (0.13), mean difference 0.04 (95% confidence interval 0.002 to 0.08), P=0.04), in favor of the intervention, but there was no significant difference in physical health (physical component summary AQoL: 0.03 (0.15) v 0, 02 (0.13)) nor diabetes-specific distress (5.6 (15.5) v -2.4 (15.4)). No events of severe hypoglycemia were reported. Conclusions: The Stepping Up model of care was associated with higher rates of insulin initiation in primary care and improvements in glycosylated hemoglobin without worsening emotional well-being. Trial Registry: Australian New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry ACTRN12612001028897.

title: Supporting mid-level health workers in Malawi: lessons learned during the implementation of the PALM PLUS package
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Government of Malawi is committed to the broad implementation of antiretroviral treatment in Malawi in the public health sector";" however, one of the main challenges has been the shortage of trained health workers. The Practical Approach to Lung Health Plus HIV/AIDS in Malawi (PALM PLUS) package is an innovative guideline and training intervention that supports mid-tier primary care health care workers to deliver frontline integrated primary care. The purpose of this document is to describe the lessons learned in the implementation of the PALM PLUS package. METHODS: An algorithm- and symptom-based guideline-based clinical tool was adapted to the Malawian context. A complementary training program was developed based on educational outreach principles and a cascade training approach was used for the implementation of the PALM PLUS package in 30 health centers, targeting clinical officers, physician assistants, and nurses. Lessons learned were identified during program implementation through engagement with collaborating partners and program participants and review of program evaluation results. RESULTS: Key lessons learned for the successful implementation of the PALM PLUS package include the importance of building networks for peer support, ensuring adequate training capacity, linking to continuing professional development accreditation, and providing modest budgets for on-site training. service. The main limiting factors for implementation were staff turnover and the desire for financial allocations for training. CONCLUSIONS: The PALM PLUS approach is a potential model for supporting mid-level health workers to provide frontline integrated primary care in low- and middle-income countries, and may be useful for future task-shift initiatives.

title: Surgical decision making and behavior. Explanations of social psychology and research perspectives.
abstract: Social psychology is the discipline that investigates thought processes, emotions, and behaviors in the interpersonal context. There are three broad thematic domains: understanding oneself and other people, interpersonal relationships, and group influence. The most important method is the experiment. The value of the social psychological perspective is illustrated with respect to the following surgical research questions: How do surgeons arrive at their decisions? How do surgeons confirm their decisions? Why are decision aids (computer support, guidelines) so poorly accepted? How should patients be informed? What group processes play a role in the operating room? What are the determinants of patient outcomes? Social psychology can extend surgical research in three ways: a better understanding of everyday phenomena in clinical and surgical settings, methodologically refined and more robust patient-oriented study designs, and new perspectives to improve patient outcomes.

title: Surgical treatments for men with benign prostatic enlargement: cost-effectiveness study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine which surgical treatment for lower urinary tract symptoms suggestive of benign prostate enlargement is cost-effective. DESIGN Care pathways describing credible treatment strategies were decided by consensus. The cost-utility analysis used Markov models and Monte Carlo simulation. DATA SOURCES Clinical effectiveness data come from a systematic review and an individual level dataset. The utility values come from previous economic evaluations. Costs were calculated from the National Health Service (NHS) and commercial sources. METHODS The Markov model included parameters with associated measures of uncertainty that described the health states between which individuals could move in three-month intervals over 10 years. Successive annual cohorts of 25,000 men were entered into the model, and the likelihood of treatment strategies being cost-effective was evaluated using Monte Carlo simulation with 10,000 iterations. RESULTS A treatment strategy of initial diathermic vaporisation of the prostate followed by endoscopic holmium laser enucleation of the prostate in case of subsequent failure or relapse had an 85% chance of being cost effective at a willingness to pay value of £20,000 (21 euros). ,595, $28,686)/quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) gained. Other strategies with diathermy vaporization as initial treatment were generally cheaper and more effective than the current standard of transurethral resection repeated once if necessary. The use of potassium titanyl phosphate laser vaporization incurred higher costs and was less effective than transurethral resection, and strategies involving minimally invasive initial treatment with microwave thermotherapy were not cost-effective. Findings did not change in wide range sensitivity analyses. CONCLUSION The result of this economic model should be interpreted with caution due to the limitations of the data used. The finding that initial vaporization followed by holmium laser enucleation for failure or relapse might be advantageous for both men with lower urinary tract symptoms and health care providers requires confirmation in a good-quality prospective clinical trial before any changes in current practice. Laser vaporization of potassium titanyl phosphate is unlikely to be cost-effective in our model, which argues against its unrestricted use until more evidence of effectiveness and cost reduction is obtained.

title: Surrogate decision making for research subjects with severe cognitive impairment: the ongoing debate
abstract: As research on Alzheimer's disease and other dementing disorders becomes more complex, risky, invasive, and commonplace, the need to discuss the ethics of involving people with dementia in research, specifically higher-than-risk research, intensifies. minimal and with no expected direct benefit to the subject. (It is beyond the scope of this document to consider ethical issues related to the research participation of children with cognitive impairments or children or adults with intermittent and/or reversible cognitive or psychiatric impairments. For such discussions, see the references in the notes 1–6.) Reviewing such studies stretches our traditional analysis tools to their limits. Simply balancing and prioritizing the basic ethical principles of respect for persons, beneficence, and fairness that serve us well in reviewing the vast majority of studies is inadequate when reviewing research with such ethical complexities as studies with marked risks and no risk. expectation of direct benefit to subjects. unable to consent or withdraw. Moving to the level of theory, placing these principles within the commonly applied frameworks of consequentialism, deontology, or virtue ethics does not bring us any closer to reducing the tensions such research creates between defending individual autonomy and promoting the need for society. to learn to treat and cure. these devastating diseases. What is needed is the introduction of more contemporary moral analyses. Specifically, we need to become more inclusive of the diversity of values perspectives of our broader citizenry. In more theoretical terms, we should elevate a community perspective and a feminist ethical emphasis on relationships and context to a more central role as we hurry to keep pace, ethically, with this rapidly expanding area of medical research.

title: Survivorship care plans and adherence to lifestyle recommendations among breast cancer survivors
abstract: PURPOSE: The effectiveness of survivor care plans has not been widely tested. We evaluated whether a single brief lifestyle consultation as part of a larger survivorship care plan was effective in changing diet and lifestyle patterns. METHODS: A diverse sample of women with stage 0-III breast cancer was randomly assigned to control or intervention groups within 6 weeks of completion of adjuvant treatment. Both groups received the National Cancer Institute publication, "Facing Forward: Life after Cancer Treatment." The intervention group also met with a nurse (1h) and a nutritionist (1h) to receive personalized lifestyle recommendations based on national guidelines. Diet, lifestyle, and perceived health were assessed at baseline, 3, and 6 months. Linear regression analyzes evaluated intervention effects adjusted for covariates. RESULTS: A total of 126 women completed the study (60 control/66 intervention, 61 Hispanic/65 non-Hispanic). At 3 months, the intervention group reported greater knowledge of a healthy diet (P = 0.047), the importance of physical activity (P = 0.03), and the appropriate use of dietary supplements (P = 0.006) and reported a lower frequency of alcohol consumption (P = 0.006). = 0.03) than controls. At 6 months, only greater knowledge about healthy eating persisted (p = 0.01). The intervention was more effective among non-Hispanics than among Hispanics in improving attitudes toward healthy eating (P = 0.03) and frequency of physical activity (P = 0.006). CONCLUSIONS: The intervention changed lifestyle behaviors and knowledge in the short term, but the benefits did not persist. IMPLICATIONS FOR CANCER SURVIVORS: Culturally competent long-term behavioral interventions should be tested beyond the survivorship care plan to facilitate long-term behavior change among breast cancer survivors.

title: Kwashiorkor-like syndrome after partial gastrectomy
Systematic review: an evaluation of the leading commercial weight loss programs in the United States.
abstract: Background: Each year, millions of Americans enroll in commercial and self-help weight loss programs. Health care providers and their obese patients know little about these programs due to the absence of systematic reviews. Purpose: To describe the components, costs, and effectiveness of the major commercial and organized self-help weight loss programs in the United States that provide structured counseling in person or online. Data sources: review of company websites, telephone conversation with company representatives, and search of the MEDLINE database. Study Selection: Randomized trials of at least 12 weeks' duration that enrolled adults only and evaluated interventions as generally provided to the public, or case series that met these criteria, indicated the number enrolled, and included an evaluation of follow-up lasting 1 year or more. Data Extraction: Data on study design, attrition, weight loss, duration of follow-up, and maintenance of weight loss were extracted. Data Synthesis: We found studies from eDiets.com, Health Management Resources, Take Off Pounds Sensible, OPTIFAST, and Weight Watchers. Of 3 randomized controlled trials of Weight Watchers, the largest reported a 3.2% loss of baseline weight at 2 years. A randomized trial and multiple case series of medically supervised very-low-calorie diet programs found that patients who completed treatment lost approximately 15% to 25% of their initial weight. These programs were associated with high costs, high dropout rates, and a high probability of regaining 50% or more of lost weight in 1 to 2 years. Commercial interventions available on the Internet and organized self-help programs produced minimal weight loss. Limitations: As many studies did not control for high attrition rates, the reported results are probably best case. Conclusions: With the exception of 1 Weight Watchers trial, the evidence to support the use of major commercial and self-help weight loss programs is suboptimal. Controlled trials are needed to assess the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of these interventions.

title: Systematic review: elective induction of labor versus expectant management of pregnancy
abstract: BACKGROUND: Rates of induction of labor and elective induction of labor are increasing. Whether elective induction of labor improves outcomes or simply leads to increased complications and healthcare costs is commonly debated in the literature. PURPOSE: To compare the benefits and harms of elective induction of labor and expectant management of pregnancy. 2009), Web of Science, CINAHL, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (up to March 2009), bibliographies of included studies, and previous systematic reviews. STUDY SELECTION: Experimental and observational studies of elective induction of labor reported in English. DATA EXTRACTION: Two authors summarized study design, patient characteristics, quality criteria, and outcomes, including cesarean delivery and maternal and neonatal morbidity. Overall, expectant management of pregnancy was associated with a higher odds ratio (OR) for cesarean delivery than elective labor induction (OR, 1.22 [95% CI, 1.07 to 1, 39]; absolute risk difference, 1.9 percentage points [CI, 0.2 to 3.7 percentage points]) in 9 RCTs. Women at or greater than 41 completed weeks' gestation who were managed expectantly had an increased risk of cesarean delivery (OR, 1.21 [CI, 1.01 to 1.46]), but this difference was not statistically significant. in women less than 41 completed weeks' gestation (OR, 1.73 [CI, 0.67 to 4.5]). Women who were managed expectantly were more likely to have meconium-stained amniotic fluid than those who were induced electively (OR, 2.04 [CI, 1.34 to 3.09]). LIMITATIONS: There were no recent RCTs of elective induction of labor at less than 41 weeks' gestation. The 2 studies conducted at less than 41 weeks' gestation were of poor quality and were not generalizable to current practice. CONCLUSION: RCTs suggest that elective induction of labor at 41 weeks' gestation and beyond is associated with a decreased risk of cesarean delivery and meconium-stained amniotic fluid. There are concerns about the translation of these findings into actual practice; therefore, future studies should examine elective induction of labor in settings where most obstetric care is provided.

title: Systematic review: the long-term effects of false-positive mammograms.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although abnormal screening mammograms negatively affect women's psychological well-being during the time immediately following screening, their long-term effects are poorly understood. PURPOSE: To characterize the long-term effects of false-positive screening mammography on behavior and well-being in women aged 40 years and older. DATA SOURCES: English-language studies from MEDLINE, Web of Science, EMBASE, CINAHL, PsycINFO, and ERIC databases up to August 2006. STUDY SELECTION: Studies were identified that examined the effects of false-positive screening mammography results routine screening on women's behavior, well-being, or beliefs. DATA EXTRACTION: Two investigators independently coded study characteristics, quality, and effect size. DATA SYNTHESIS: 23 eligible studies (n = 313,967) were identified. A random-effects meta-analysis showed that US women who received false-positive screening mammography results were more likely to return for routine screening than those who received normal results (hazard ratio, 1.07 [CI 95%, 1.02 to 1.12]). The effect was not statistically significant among European women (hazard ratio, 0.97 [CI, 0.93 to 1.01]), and Canadian women were less likely to return for routine screening due to false-positive results. (hazard ratio, 0.63 [CI, 0.50 to 1.01]). 0.80]). Women who received false-positive results performed breast self-exams more frequently and had higher, but not apparently pathologically elevated, levels of distress and anxiety, and thought more about breast cancer than those with normal results. LIMITATIONS: Correlational study designs, a small number of studies, lack of clinical validation for many measures, and possible heterogeneity. CONCLUSIONS: Some women with false-positive mammography results may have differences in whether they return for mammography, frequency of breast self-exams, and anxiety levels compared to women with normal results. Future research should examine how false-positive mammography results affect other outcomes, such as trust and use of health care.

title: Systematic review: the value of periodic health assessment
abstract: Background: Periodic health assessment (PHE) has been a fundamental part of medical practice for decades despite a lack of consensus about its value. Purpose: To synthesize the evidence on the benefits and harms of PHE. Data sources: Electronic searches of such databases as MEDLINE and the Cochrane Library, review of reference lists, and journal handsearching up to September 2006. Study Selection: Studies (English only) evaluating the provision of preventive services , clinical outcomes, and costs among patients receiving PHE versus those receiving usual care. Data extraction: study design and settings, descriptions of the PHE, and clinical outcomes associated with the PHE. Data Synthesis: The best available evidence evaluating the benefits or harms of PHE consisted of 21 studies published between 1973 and 2004. PHE had a consistently beneficial association with patients receiving gynecological exams and Pap smears, cholesterol screening, and fecal occult blood tests. tinkling PHE also had a beneficial effect on patient 'concern' in 1 randomized controlled trial, but had mixed effects on other clinical outcomes and costs. Limitations: PHE descriptions and outcomes were heterogeneous. Some trials were conducted before the US Preventive Services Task Force guidelines were released, limiting their applicability to modern practice. Conclusions: The evidence suggests that PHE improves the provision of some recommended preventive services and may reduce patient concern. Although additional research is needed to clarify the long-term benefits, harms, and costs of receiving PHE, the evidence of benefit in this study warrants implementation of PHE in clinical practice."

title: Systematic reviews are needed that examine the implementation of the research in practice and the impact on population health.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To examine the focus of the research translation phase (T1-T4) of systematic reviews published in the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews (CDSR) and the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects (DARE). Briefly, T1 includes reviews of basic science experiments; T2 includes reviews of human trials leading to guideline development; T3 includes reviews examining how to translate the guidelines into policy and practice; and T4 includes reviews that describe the impact of changing health practices on population outcomes. STUDY DESIGN AND SETTING: A cross-sectional audit of randomly selected reviews of CDSR (n = 500) and DARE (n = 500) was conducted. The translation phase of review research, overall and by subgroups of communicable diseases, noncommunicable diseases, and injuries, was coded by two researchers. RESULTS: A total of 898 reviews examined a communicable, noncommunicable, or injury-related condition. Of these, 98% of reviews within CDSR focused on T2 and the remaining 2% focused on T3. In DARE, 88% focused on T2, 8.7% focused on T1, 2.5% focused on T3, and 1.3% focused on T4. Almost all reviews that examined communicable (CDSR 100%, DARE 93%), noncommunicable (CDSR 98%, DARE 87%), and lesions (CDSR 95%, DARE 88%) also focused on T2. CONCLUSION: Few reviews exist to guide practitioners and policymakers in implementing evidence-based treatments or programs.

title: Network of competence in systemic inflammatory rheumatic diseases
abstract: The foundation of the network of competences in rheumatology, financed by the "Bundesministerium fur Bildung und Forschung" (BMBF) since 1999, managed to create a unique research structure in Germany: doctors and scientists from six university centers for rheumatology (Berlin, Dusseldorf, Erlangen, Freiburg, Hannover und Lubeck/Bad Bramstedt) work closely with scientists conducting basic research at the Deutsches Rheuma-Forschungszentrum (DRFZ), with rheumatology hospitals, rehabilitation clinics and rheumatologists. Together they search for the causes of systemic inflammatory rheumatic diseases and try to improve therapies at a national level and with an interdisciplinary approach. The main objective of this collaboration is to transfer new scientific knowledge more quickly to improve the methods of diagnosis and treatment of patients.

title: Systems of Care for ST-segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction: An American Heart Association Mission Statement: Lifeline
abstract: BACKGROUND: National guidelines require participation in systems to rapidly diagnose and treat ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). In order to characterize currently deployed STEMI reperfusion systems and identify practices common to system organization, the American Heart Association surveyed existing systems in the United States. METHODS AND RESULTS: A STEMI system was defined as an integrated group of separate entities focused on reperfusion therapy for STEMI within a geographic region that included at least 1 hospital performing percutaneous coronary intervention and at least 1 emergency medical services agency. . Systems meeting this definition were invited to participate in a 42-question survey based on expert panel opinion and knowledge of existing systems. Data was collected through the American Heart Association Mission: Lifeline website. Between April 2008 and January 2010, 381 unique systems involving 899 percutaneous coronary intervention hospitals in 47 states responded to the survey, of which 255 systems (67%) involved urban regions. The predominant funding sources for STEMI systems were percutaneous coronary intervention hospitals (n = 320, 84%) and/or cardiology practices (n = 88, 23%). Predominant system characteristics identified by the survey included: acceptance of STEMI patients into the percutaneous coronary intervention hospital regardless of bed availability (N = 346, 97%); activation of the cath lab with a single phone call (N = 335, 92%); emergency department physician lab activation without cardiology consultation (N = 318, 87%); participation in data recording (N = 311, 84%);" and prehospital activation of the laboratory by notification to the emergency room without notification to cardiology (N = 297, 78%). The most common barriers to the implementation of the system were the hospital ( n = 139, 37%) and the proficiency of the cardiology group (n = 81, 21%) and emergency medical services, transportation, and finance (n = 99, 26%). CONCLUSIONS: This survey broadly describes the organizational characteristics collaborative efforts of hospitals and emergency medical services to provide timely reperfusion in the U.S. These findings serve as a benchmark for existing systems and should help guide health care teams in the process of reperfusion. organization of care for patients with STEMI.

title: Personalized information increases patient-doctor discussion about colon cancer risk and testing: the Cancer Risk Intake System trial
abstract: To assess whether receiving personalized impressions generated by the Cancer Risk Intake System (CRIS), a touchscreen computer program that collects patient data and generates impressions for patients and physicians, results in resulted in more conversations between patients and providers about colorectal cancer (CRC). risk and screening than the receipt of non-adapted information. Physician-randomized, cluster-randomized trial with data collected through pre-visit CRIS and a 2-week follow-up telephone survey among 623 patients. Patients ages 25-75 with upcoming primary care visits and eligible for, but currently do not meet CRC screening guidelines. Patient-reported discussions with providers about CRC risk and testing. Personalized recipients were more likely to report doctor-patient discussions about personal and family risk, stool tests, and colonoscopy (all p < 0.05). Personalized recipients were more likely to report discussions of: chances of getting cancer (+10%)"; family history (+15%); stool analysis (+9%);" and colonoscopy (+ 8%) (all p < 0.05). CRIS is a promising strategy for facilitating discussions about testing in primary care settings.

title: Personalized skills training for professionals to improve assessment of prognostic factors for persistent and disabling back pain: four quasi-experimental single-subject studies.
abstract: The well-known gap between guidelines and behavior in clinical practice calls for effective behavior change interventions. An example showing this gap is the insufficient assessment by physical therapists of psychosocial prognostic factors in back pain (ie yellow flags). The present study aimed to evaluate an educational model by conducting a personalized skills training intervention for caregivers and studying changes over time in physiotherapists' assessment of prognostic factors in telephone consultations. A single-subject quasi-experimental design was used for 36 weeks, with repeated measurements during baseline, intervention, and post-intervention phases. Four primary health care physical therapists audio-recorded a total of 63 patient consultations. The personalized intervention included individual goal setting, skills training, and performance feedback. The primary outcome was the number of prognostic factors evaluated (0-10). Changes were observed in all four participants. The number of prognostic factors evaluated increased from 0 to 2 at baseline to 6 to 10 after the intervention. Time spent assessing psychosocial factors increased and time spent discussing biomedical pain symptoms decreased. Biopsychosocial knowledge and attitudes toward back pain were consistent with guidelines at enrollment and did not change markedly during the intervention. Self-efficacy for the evaluation of cognitive and emotional prognostic factors increased during the phases of the study. The results suggest that a personalized skills training intervention using behavior change techniques, such as individual goal setting, skills training, and performance feedback, is effective in producing changes in specific clinical behaviors in physical therapists.

title: Targeted intervention programs: creating a personalized practice model to improve the treatment of allergic rhinitis in a managed care population
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To develop an intervention program to improve health outcomes among patients with allergic rhinitis in a managed care setting. STUDY DESIGN: The Lovelace Health Systems Episodes of Care (EOC) team selected allergic rhinitis for an intervention program because it was identified as one of the top 10 reasons for visits to primary care clinics. The intervention program was based on a multidisciplinary team process designed to create a personalized patient and provider education program to address inconsistency or deficiencies in the treatment of allergic rhinitis. PATIENTS AND METHODS: The EOC team investigated the literature and current practices and then identified inconsistencies in patterns of diagnosis and treatment. Based on this research, the team developed guidelines and a provider education program. Intervention strategies were structured around decision points in a treatment protocol. More than 500 patients were monitored during allergy season using written and telephone surveys, symptom diaries, and encounter data. Measurable outcomes were established for provider and patient behavior. Patient outcomes were derived from a preventive behavior index and administrative data reporting the use of 5 medication classes. RESULTS: Approximately 50% of providers modified their practice patterns as a result of the intervention program. Patient outcomes showed a decrease in the use of rescue medications, particularly antibiotics, and an increase in preventive measures in the treatment group compared to the control group. CONCLUSION: The EOC model resulted in positive changes in provider and patient behavior. The multidisciplinary approach resulted in extensive supplier participation.

title: Targeting cognitive deficits in schizophrenia: a review of the development of a new class of medications from the perspective of community mental health researchers.
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Schizophrenia is a chronic disorder associated with positive and negative symptoms and extensive deficits in neurocognitive function. Neurocognitive deficits are considered the core pathophysiological symptoms of the disease. Neurocognitive deficits are also closely associated with functional outcome. Currently, cognitive deficits remain one of the most important unmet therapeutic needs in schizophrenia. AREAS COVERED: Neuroscientific discoveries in the last few decades have enriched our understanding of the neurobiological mechanism underlying cognitive deficits in schizophrenia. This research has identified new molecular mechanisms and processes as promising drug targets. However, despite extensive efforts to develop a new class of cognition-enhancing drugs for the treatment of schizophrenia over the past 5 years, no new pharmacological agents have received the required regulatory approvals by the Food and Drug Administration. Efficacy and safety results from selective phase II clinical trials are reviewed. EXPERT OPINION: Critically examines the evolving concept of neurocognition and current guidelines for the design and methodology of clinical trials of cognition-enhancing drugs for the treatment of people with schizophrenia. Future directions in the development of cognition-enhancing medications for the treatment of schizophrenia are discussed from the perspective of clinicians and researchers in community mental health settings.

title: Working group VI: Self-monitoring of blood pressure
abstract: BACKGROUND: Self-monitoring of blood pressure by patients at home or in other nonclinical settings has become increasingly common in recent years. This phenomenon has been fueled in part by the increased availability of automated sphygmomanometers, which are now affordable and easy for patients to use. BENEFITS OF SELF-MONITORING: Self-monitoring of blood pressure can be an important adjunct to the control of hypertension. The technique allows patients to be more involved in their care. Self-measured blood pressure values are more likely to be representative of average daily blood pressure than a clinical measurement and may be better related to hypertensive end-organ involvement and cardiovascular morbidity than clinical blood pressure. Finally, self-monitoring of blood pressure has the potential to reduce the costs of care related to hypertension. LIMITATIONS OF SELF-MONITORING: There are several issues that prevent the more widespread use of self-monitoring of blood pressure in clinical practice. First, devices marketed for patient use have advanced technically during the 1990s, but many have not undergone rigorous clinical validation for accuracy and reliability (for example, in terms of the Association for Advances in Medical Instrumentation and the British Society of Hypertension). It is recommended that blood pressure measurement devices used by patients at home undergo the same validation processes as those applied to ambulatory records. Second, although the upper limits of normal for self-monitored blood pressure in a general population can be defined statistically (it is approximately 135/85 mmHg), it is not yet possible to determine normal self-monitored blood pressure because these values must be linked to endpoints. or classical clinical cardiovascular outcomes. Third, the relationships between self-monitored, clinical, and ambulatory blood pressures are well defined for some populations, but their behaviors by age, sex, ethnicity, and treatment status require further study. Fourth, several different programs for self-monitoring of blood pressure by patients have been used in clinical practice and research. It will be necessary to determine the optimal time and number of records required when patients self-monitor their blood pressure. Fifth, self-monitoring of blood pressure in clinical trials of antihypertensive therapies is feasible, but has generally not been included in their design, either by investigators or pharmaceutical sponsors. Sixth, there have been data suggesting that self-monitoring of blood pressure reduces the overall costs associated with hypertension care on a yearly basis. However, since most of the work on the economic impact of blood pressure self-monitoring has been done in managed care settings in the US, it is not known whether this reduction in health care costs would be applicable to other types of practice settings. Worldwide. CONCLUSIONS: Blood pressure self-monitoring is currently useful as an adjunctive measure for the treatment of hypertensive patients and could provide benefit in clinical trials of antihypertensive therapy. However, available data on blood pressure self-monitoring are inadequate as a basis for clinicians to make primary diagnostic or therapeutic decisions and should not override blood pressure obtained by clinical measurement or ambulatory monitoring.

title: Teaching Appropriate Interactions with Pharmaceutical Company Representatives: The Impact of an Innovative Workshop on Student Attitudes
abstract: BACKGROUND: Pharmaceutical company representatives (PCRs) influence the prescribing habits and professional behavior of physicians. However, the skills to interact with PCR are not taught in the traditional medical school curriculum. We examined whether an innovative mandatory workshop for third-year medical students had immediate effects on knowledge and attitudes regarding interactions with RCPs. METHODS: Surveys conducted before and after the workshop intervention solicited opinions (five-point Likert scale) from third-year students (n = 75) on the degree of bias in CRP reporting, the influence of CRP on prescribing habits, the acceptability of specific gifts, and the educational value of PCR information for both practicing physicians and students. Two faculty members and a PCR led the workshop, which highlighted typical physician-PCR interactions, the use of samples and gifts, the validity and legal limits of PCR information, and associated ethical issues. Role plays with CRP demonstrated appropriate and inappropriate strategies for interacting with CRP. RESULTS: The majority of third-year students (56%, 42/75) had experienced more than three face-to-face conversations with a PCR about a medication since they started medical school. Five percent (4/75) stated that they had no previous personal experience with PCR. Most of the students (57.3%, 43/75) were unaware of the available guidelines regarding PCR interactions. Twenty-eight percent of students (21/75) thought that none of the activities/gifts mentioned (access to lunch, free stethoscope, textbooks, educational CD-ROMS, sporting events) should be restricted, while 24.0 % (8/75) thought that students should be restricted from sporting events only. The perceived educational value of CRP information for both practicing physicians and students increased after the workshop intervention from 17.7% to 43.2% (chi-squared, p=0.0001) and from 22.1% to % to 40.5% (p = 0.0007), respectively. The students' perception of the degree of bias in the PCR information decreased from 84.1% to 72.9% (p = 0.065), but the degree of perceived influence on prescription increased (44.2% to 62.1% % (p = 0.02)). CONCLUSIONS: Students have exposure to CRP early in their medical training. A single workshop intervention may influence students' attitudes toward interactions with RCPs. Students were more likely to recognize the educational value of PCR interactions and their impact on prescribing after the workshop intervention.

title: Teach hospital medical staff to wash their hands
abstract: Objective Increase the frequency of handwashing by medical personnel. Design A prospective study of handwashing before and after patient contact. Setting A pediatric intensive care unit in a tertiary care hospital. Participants 61 medical staff from the intensive care unit and visiting medical staff. Interventions A five-phase behavior modification program: (i) discreet observation for four weeks to obtain a "baseline handwashing rate"; (ii) open observation for five weeks (preceded by written counselling); (iii) open observation continued for four weeks with feedback on performance; (iv) all observations and feedback were suspended for seven weeks;" and (v) discrete observation for five weeks to obtain a residual rate. Results 939 patient contacts were observed. Baseline rates of handwashing before and after patient contact were 12.4% and 10.6%, respectively. During open observation, the respective rates increased and plateaued at 32.7% and 33.3%, but increased further (to 68.3% and 64.8%) during the performance feedback period. Residual handwashing rates, observed discreetly seven weeks after cessation of performance feedback, were 54.6% before and 54.9% after patient contact. Conclusions Performance feedback is moderately effective in training hospital medical staff in handwashing.

title: Unraveling the "Tangled Web" of Policy Dialogue Influence: Lessons from a Case Study of Health Reform Options Dialogues for Canada
abstract: Background The literature on knowledge sharing suggests that policy dialogues are intended to enhance the short-, medium-, and long-term capacities of individuals, organizations, and health systems to use evidence to inform policymaking. Key characteristics of effective dialogues have been suggested, but the links between these characteristics and the realization of enhanced capacities for evidence-based policymaking among dialogue attendees and subsequent influence on policymaking activities are not understood. good. Methods We conducted a qualitative case study of a series of four policy dialogues that were convened in Canada among national, provincial, and regional stakeholders on issues related to health care financing and financing in 2011. Data sources they included videos of the participants' perspectives captured during or immediately after each. event and follow-up key informant interviews among dialogue participants conducted 4 years later, in 2015. Three conceptual frameworks related to (i) dialogues on policies and capacities for the use of evidence, (ii) factors that shape the formulation throughout the policy cycle and (iii) the factors that shaped the implementation of the evidence guided the thematic analysis. We then synthesized the findings across the three frameworks. Results The results suggest that the potential benefits of the policy dialogues described in the literature were developed among the participants in these dialogues. Informants explained how the characteristics of the dialogue influenced their abilities to use evidence, ideas, interests, and institutions during the agenda-setting and policy-making stages, and how implementation was affected by the characteristics of the options. policy, people, organizations and the external environment. and processes. Conclusions We present a conceptual framework that broadens our understanding of the potential influence of policy dialogues on the content and mechanisms of policy development and illustrates the pathways of influence at various stages of the policy cycle from agenda setting to formulation. and implementation. The framework highlights important factors to consider in designing and evaluating policy dialogues and in supporting post-dialogue knowledge-sharing efforts.

title: Educational Teleconference Details: Diabetes Education for Primary Care Physicians
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Formal didactic continuing medical education (CME) is relatively ineffective in changing medical behavior. Diabetes mellitus is an increasingly prevalent disease and interventions are required to improve adherence to clinical practice guidelines (CPG). METHODS: A stratified, cluster-randomized, controlled trial design was used to assess the effects of a detailed teleconference educational CME (TED) on glycemic control (hemoglobin [Hb] A1c) and GP adherence to guidelines. diabetes nationals. TED used sequential, small group, and case-based education using CPGs delivered by a diabetes specialist. Medical record audit data were compared from baseline to the end of a 12-month post-intervention period for the control and intervention groups. Satisfaction with the intervention was assessed. RESULTS: Sixty-one physicians provided 660 medical records. The intervention did not affect mean Hb A1c levels but did significantly (p = 0.04) alter the distribution of patients by glycemic control category, with fewer in the intervention group with inadequate control (15.8% versus 23.9% ). More patients took insulin (alone or with oral agents) in the intervention group (21.2% vs 12.0%, p = 0.03) and more patients took oral agents alone in the control group (89.0 % vs. 82.9%, p = 0.005). More patients in the intervention group had documentation of body mass index (7.8% vs. 1.9%, p < 0.02), eye exam (12.1% vs. 5.1%, p = 0.02) and treatment plan (43.5% vs. 23.6%, p = 0.01) and used a flowchart (14.6% vs. 7.7%, p < 0.03 ). Although there was general satisfaction with the teleconference format, specialist educators found the format more challenging than GPs. DISCUSSION: CME delivered via teleconference was feasible, well attended, well received by participants, and improved some key diabetes management practices and outcomes.

title: Telehealth for patients at high risk of cardiovascular disease: a pragmatic randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE Ã‚Â To assess whether non-clinical staff can effectively manage people at high risk for cardiovascular disease using digital health technologies. DESIGN Ã‚Â Randomized, multicentre, pragmatic controlled trial. SETTING Ã‚Â 42 general practices in three areas of England. PARTICIPANTS Ã‚Â Between December 3, 2012, and July 23, 2013, we recruited 641 adults aged 40 to 74 years with a 10-year cardiovascular disease risk of 20% or greater, no prior cardiovascular event, at least one modifiable risk factor (systolic blood pressure Ã¢â€°Â¥140 mm Hg, body mass index Ã¢â€°Â¥30, current smoker), and access to telephone, internet, and email. Participants were individually assigned to intervention (n=325) or control (n=316) groups using automatic randomization stratified by site, minimized by practice, and baseline risk score. INTERVENTIONS Ã‚Â The intervention was the Healthlines service (along with usual care), comprising regular phone calls from trained lay health advisors following scripts generated by interactive software. Counselors facilitated self-management by helping participants use online resources to reduce risk factors and sought to optimize medication use, improve treatment adherence, and encourage healthier lifestyles. The control group comprised only usual care. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Ã‚Â The primary outcome was the proportion of participants who responded to treatment, defined as maintaining or reducing their cardiovascular risk after 12 months. Results were collected at six and 12 months after randomisation and analyzed blinded. The participants were not masked. RESULTS: 50% (148/295) of participants in the intervention group responded to treatment compared to 43% (124/291) in the control group (adjusted odds ratio 1.3, 95% confidence interval). % 1.0 to 1.9"; number needed to treat = 13); a difference possibly due to chance (P = 0.08). The intervention was associated with reductions in blood pressure (difference in mean systolic -2, 7 mm Hg (95% confidence interval -4.7 to -0.6 mm Hg), mean diastolic -2.8 (-4.0 to -1.6 mm Hg);" weight -1.0 kg (-1.8 to -0.3 kg) and body mass index -0.4 (-0.6 to -0.1) but not cholesterol -0.1 (-0.2 to 0.0), smoking (adjusted odds ratio 0.4, 0.2 to 1.0) or global cardiovascular risk as a continuous measure (-0.4, -1.2 to 0.3). The intervention was associated with improvements in diet, physical activity, medication adherence, and satisfaction with access to care, treatment received, and coordination of care. A related serious adverse event occurred when a participant was admitted to hospital with low blood pressure. CONCLUSIONS Ã‚Â This evidence-based telehealth approach was associated with small clinical benefits for a minority of people at high cardiovascular risk, and there was no overall improvement in average risk. However, the Healthlines service was associated with improvements in some risk behaviors and in perceptions of support and access to care. Trials Register Current controlled trials ISRCTN 27508731.

title: Call center management to improve cancer detection among low-income women
abstract: Background Minority and low-income women receive fewer cancer screening tests than other women. Objective To assess the effect of a telephone support intervention in increasing breast, cervical, and colorectal cancer screening rates among low-income and minority women. Design Randomized controlled trial conducted between November 2001 and April 2004. Setting 11 migrant and community health centers in New York City. Patients 1,413 women who had been late for cancer screening. Intervention Over 18 months, women assigned to the intervention group received an average of 4 calls from preventive care managers and the control group received usual care. Follow-up data was available for 99% of women, and 91% of the intervention group received at least 1 call. women who received a mammogram increased from 0.58 to 0.68 with the intervention and decreased from 0.60 to 0.58 with usual care"; the proportion who received a Pap smear increased from 0, 71 to 0.78 with intervention and did not change with usual care"; and the proportion undergoing colorectal screening increased from 0.39 to 0.63 with the intervention and from 0.39 to 0.50 with usual care. The difference in change in detection rates between groups was 0.12 for mammography (95% CI, 0.06 to 0.19), 0.07 for Pap smear (CI, 0.01 to 0.12) and 0.13 for colorectal screening (CI, 0.07 to 0.19). The proportion of women who were up to date on 3 tests increased from 0.21 to 0.43 with the intervention. Limitations Participants were from 1 city and had access to a regular source of care. Medical records may not have recorded all cancer screening tests. Conclusions Telephone support can improve cancer screening rates among women visiting community and migrant health centers. The intervention appears to be suitable for health plans, large medical groups, and other organizations seeking to increase cancer detection rates and address disparities in care.

title: Telephone Screening, Disclosure, and Care Management for Depressed Workers and Impact on Work Productivity and Clinical Outcomes: A Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: Context Although guideline-consistent treatment of depression is clearly effective, treatment often falls short of evidence-based recommendations. Organized depression care programs significantly improve the quality of treatment, but employer purchasers have been slow to adopt these programs due to a lack of evidence of cost-effectiveness from their perspective. Objective To assess the effects of a depression treatment program on workplace outcomes, a concern for employers. Design, Setting, and Participants A randomized controlled trial involving 604 employees covered by a managed behavioral health plan were identified in a two-stage screening process with significant depression. Patients' treatment allocation was concealed, and assessment of depression severity and work performance at 6 and 12 months was blinded. Employees with lifetime bipolar disorder, substance use disorder, recent specialty mental health care, or suicidality were excluded. Intervention A telephone outreach and care management program encouraged workers to enter outpatient treatment (psychotherapy and/or antidepressant medication), monitored continuity of treatment quality, and attempted to improve treatment by giving recommendations to providers. Participants reluctant to start treatment were offered structured telephone cognitive behavioral psychotherapy. Main outcome measures Severity of depression (Rapid Inventory of Depressive Symptomatology, QIDS) and job performance (World Health Organization Health and Productivity Questionnaire [HPQ], a validated self-report instrument that assesses job retention, time lost at work, job performance and critical workplace incidents). Results Combining data from the 6-month and 12-month evaluations, the intervention group had significantly lower self-report QIDS scores (odds ratio of recovery, 1.4"; 95% confidence interval, 1.1-2, 0; P = .009), retention (odds ratio, 1.7; 95% confidence interval, 1.1-3.3; P = .02), and significantly more hours worked between intervention (ß=2 .0; P=0.02;" equivalent to an annualized effect of 2 weeks of work) than the usual care groups who were employed. Conclusions A systematic program to identify depression and promote effective treatment significantly improves not only clinical outcomes but also workplace outcomes. The financial value of the latter to employers in terms of costs of hiring, training, and recovered wages suggests that many employers would experience a positive return on investment from outreach and improved treatment of depressed workers.

title: Collaborative care delivered over the phone to treat post-CABG depression
abstract: Context Depressive symptoms commonly follow coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery and are associated with less positive clinical outcomes. Objective To test the effectiveness of collaborative care delivered by telephone for post-CABG depression compared to usual medical care. Design, Setting, and Participants Single-blind efficacy trial at 7 university and community hospitals in or near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Participants were 302 post-CABG patients with depression (150, intervention; 152, usual care) and a randomly selected comparison group of 151 post-CABG patients without depression recruited between March 2004 and September 2007 and observed as patients. until June 2008. Intervention Eight months of collaborative telephone care provided by nurses working with patients' primary care physicians and supervised by a psychiatrist and a primary care physician from this study Main outcome measures Quality of life related to mental health (HRQL) as measured by the short form -36 Mental Component Summary (SF-36 MCS) at 8-month follow-up, secondary outcome measures included assessment of mood symptoms (Health Rating Scale) Hamilton for depression [HRS-D]), physical HRQoL (SF-36 PCS) and functional status (Duke Activity Status Index [DASI]), and reing hospital inmates Results Intervention patients reported greater improvements in mental HRQoL (all P = 0.02) (SF-36 MCS: ?, 3.2 points; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.5-6.0), physical functioning (DASI: ?, 4.6 points; 95% CI, 1.9-7.3), and mood symptoms (HRS-D: ?, 3.1 points; 95% CI, 1.3-4.9); and were more likely to report a 50% or greater decrease in HRS-D score from baseline (50.0% vs. 29.6%; number needed to treat, 4.9 [95% CI, 3, 2-10.4]) than usual care patients (P < 0.001). 001). Depressed men were more likely to benefit from the intervention (SF-36 MCS: ?, 5.7 points; 95% CI, 2.2-9.2; P = .001). However, the mean HRQoL and physical functioning of intervention patients did not match that of the comparison group without depression. Conclusion Compared with usual care, collaborative care delivered by telephone for the treatment of depression after CABG resulted in improvement in HRQoL, physical functioning, and mood symptoms at 8-month follow-up.

title: Telepractice in the assessment and treatment of people with autism spectrum disorders: a systematic review
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Studies related to the use of telepractice in the provision of services to people with autism spectrum disorders (ASD) were reviewed with the intention of informing practice and identifying areas for future research. METHODS: Systematic searches of electronic databases, reference lists, and journals identified eight studies that met predetermined inclusion criteria. These studies were analyzed and summarized in terms of: (a) participant characteristics, (b) technology used, (c) services provided through telepractice, (d) research methodology, and (e) study results. RESULTS: Telepractice was used by university researchers, behavior analysts, psychiatrists, and psychologists to assist caregivers and educators in providing services to 46 participants with ASD. Services provided included behavioral and diagnostic evaluations, educational consulting, guidance and supervision of behavioral interventions, and coaching/training in the implementation of a comprehensive early intervention program. CONCLUSIONS: The results suggest that telepractice is a promising service delivery approach in treating people with ASD that warrants further investigation. Guidelines for practitioners and potential directions for future research are discussed.

title: Test Ordering Guidelines May Disrupt Ordering Patterns in an Academic Emergency Department
abstract: To determine the impact of an educational program designed to modify test-seeking behavior in an academic Emergency Department (ED), an observational before-and-after study was conducted at a university-based tertiary referral center and Medicine residency site. Emergency (EM). Test request standards were developed by EM, RN, and NP teachers based on group consensus and published data. The standards were issued to all ED staff beginning in February 1996 and were included in the evidence-based medicine orientation and educational program for all residents and medical students prior to beginning their rotation. No restrictions were placed on the request for actual evidence. The number of laboratory tests (total and individual) ordered per 100 patients decreased significantly after the educational program began for: total test, CBC and liver function test (LFT). Furthermore, the decreases during individual months for these tests were statistically significant.
