Prothrombin time and blood culture tests did not show significant decreases in the frequency of requesting tests. The frequency of requesting chemistry tests showed statistically significant increases. Overall, approximately $50,000 was saved by decreasing the testing order. Test requesting behavior can be modified and maintained by an educational program and can have significant economic effects.

title: Testimony of LeRoy Walters
Evidence of the efficacy of an innovative information package on professional-reported behavior and beliefs: the UK Low Back Pain Management (COMPLEMENT) trial [ISRCTN77245761]
abstract: BACKGROUND: Low back pain (LBP) is a common and costly problem. Initiatives designed to help physicians and patients make decisions about appropriate medical care for low back pain include evidence-based printed clinical guidelines. The three professional groups of chiropractic, osteopathy and musculoskeletal physiotherapy in the UK share common ground with their approaches to managing low back pain and are among the recipients of the low back pain guidelines. Still, many seem unaware that such guidelines exist. Furthermore, the behavior of at least some of these professionals differs from that recommended in these guidelines. Few randomized controlled trials evaluating print information as an intervention to change practitioner behavior have used a no-intervention control. All of these trials used a cluster design and most have methodological flaws. None specifically focus on physician behavior toward patients with low back pain. Studies that have investigated other strategies to change physician behavior with patients with low back pain have produced conflicting results. Although numerous LBP guidelines have been developed around the world, there is a paucity of data on whether their dissemination actually changes clinician behaviour. Mainly due to its low unit cost, sending printed information to a large number of professionals is an attractive dissemination and implementation strategy. The effect size of such a strategy, at the level of an individual practitioner, is likely to be small. However, if a large number of professionals are targeted, this strategy could achieve significant changes at the population level. METHODS: The primary objective of this prospective, pragmatic, randomized, controlled trial is to test the short-term (six months post-intervention) effectiveness of a directly published information package on reported clinical behavior (primary outcome), attitudes, and UK beliefs. chiropractors, osteopaths and musculoskeletal physical therapists. We attempted to randomly assign a pooled sample of 1,800 practitioners who consented to receive the information pack (intervention arm) or no information above that obtained during normal practice (control arm). We collected questionnaire data at baseline and six months after the intervention. The primary outcome analysis will assess between-arm differences in the proportions of responses to questions about recommendations on activity, work, and bed rest, which fall within categories previously defined by a consensus exercise. experts as "consistent with the guideline" and "in accordance with the guideline". -inconsistent'.

title: Test implementation of clinical guidelines
Texas Children's Medication Algorithm Project: Update from the Texas Consensus Conference Panel on Medication Treatment of Childhood Major Depressive Disorder
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To review and update consensus guidelines for medication treatment algorithms for childhood major depressive disorder based on new scientific evidence and expert clinical consensus when evidence is lacking. METHOD: A consensus conference was held on January 13-14, 2005, including academic physicians and researchers, practicing physicians, administrators, consumers, and families. The focus was to review, update, and incorporate the most current data to inform and recommend specific pharmacological approaches and clinical guidance for the treatment of major depressive disorder in children and adolescents. RESULTS: Consensus medication algorithms for major depression (with and without psychosis) and comorbid attention deficit disorders were updated. These revised algorithms also incorporated approaches to address issues of suicidality, aggression, and irritability. Stages 1, 2, and 3 of the algorithm consist of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor and serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor medications whose use is supported by acute controlled clinical trials and clinical experience. Recent studies support that selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, in addition to fluoxetine, are still recommended as first-line interventions. The need for additional evaluations, precautions, and monitoring, as well as continuation and maintenance treatment, is emphasized. CONCLUSIONS: Evidence and expert clinical consensus support the use of selected antidepressants in the treatment of depression in youth. Use of recommended antidepressant medications requires adequate control of suicidality and potential adverse effects and consideration of other evidence-based treatment alternatives, such as cognitive behavioral therapies.

title: The 2013 ACC/AHA guideline on blood cholesterol management to reduce the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease in adults: the good, the bad, and the uncertain: a comparison with the 2011 ESC/EAS guidelines for the management of dyslipidemias
abstract: Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is the most important public health problem of our time, both in Europe and in the rest of the world, and represents the largest expenditure in most health budgets. Achieving consistency in clinical care, incorporating new evidence, and synthesizing it into practical recommendations for clinicians is the task of various guideline committees around the world. Therefore, any change to a set of guidelines can have far-reaching consequences, particularly if they appear to be at odds with existing guidelines. This article reviews the recent 2013 American College of Cardiology (ACC)/American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines on monitoring blood cholesterol to reduce the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease in adults. Compared to the 2011 ESC/EAS lipid modification guidelines, the 2013 ACC/AHA guidelines differ markedly. Specifically, (i) the scope is limited to randomized trials only, excluding a significant set of data and essentially promoting a "statin-only approach"; (ii) the abolition of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol targets ( LDL-C) in favor of specific statin regimens that produce a 30-50% reduction in LDL-C, we believe will confuse many clinicians and miss the opportunity for medication adherence and patient participation in self-monitoring; ( iii) the absence of target LDL-C levels in very high-risk patients with high absolute risk or residual risk factors will discourage clinicians from considering adding lipid-altering therapies and individualizing patient care; (iv ) a reduction in the threshold for treatment in primary prevention will result in more patients being prescribed statin therapy, which is potentially good in young patients at high risk for life, but will result in a large number of older patients being offered therapy;" and (v) the mixed group risk calculator used to assess CVD risk in guidelines for primary prevention has not been fully evaluated. This article discusses the potential implications of adopting the ACC/AHA guidelines on patient care in Europe and beyond and concludes with the view that the 2011 ESC/EAS guidelines appear to be the most comprehensive, pragmatic and appropriate option for European countries.

title: the aggressive child
abstract: The acute evaluation and management of the aggressive or violent child or adolescent is challenging for clinicians. Early recognition of signs of impending violence and a clear understanding of the progression of violent behavior are essential to ensure the safety of patients and staff. Managing violent and aggressive patients through behavioral interventions tailored to the stage of violence or aggression is essential to reduce the likelihood that the child or adolescent will attack staff or harm himself or others. The indications and risks of chemical and physical restraints and hospital standards and guidelines that govern the use of practices and experience regarding the prevalence, presentation and differential diagnosis of psychotic disorders in minors. The clinician must quickly unravel which elements of the clinical presentation indicate true psychotic thought processes versus elements that represent poorly understood developmentally appropriate phenomena, symptoms of nonpsychotic illnesses, or precursors to an underlying primary medical illness. A thorough evaluation is required before proper treatment can begin.

title: The AHCPR Heart Failure Guidelines: Comparison of a Family Medicine and Internal Medicine Practice with the Guidelines and an Educational Behavior Modification Intervention
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The objectives of this study were to apply the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research (AHCPR) guideline for heart failure to the measurement of quality of care in the outpatient setting, compare the results of two large practices and design an educational program. intervention for the two practices under study. METHODS: A retrospective chart review was performed on a random sample of 50 heart failure patients selected from each of two outpatient clinics: the general internal medicine clinic and the family medicine clinic at a large academic medical center. Five medical review criteria were developed from the AHCPR guideline for heart failure to compare the two practices with each other and with the guidelines. An educational intervention was developed to modify the physician's behavior regarding compliance with the guidelines. RESULTS: Evaluation of left ventricular function occurred in 79% of all cases. Of eligible patients, 68% were treated with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE-I). Of the patients treated with enalapril and captopril, 30% and 12%, respectively, received the target dose defined in the AHCPR guidelines. Of the patients ineligible for ACE-I treatment, none were treated with hydralazine and nitrates. When the ejection fraction was less than or equal to 40%, 81% of eligible patients were treated with ACE inhibitors, while 59% were treated with ACE inhibitors when the ejection fraction was greater than 40%. Calcium channel blockers were used in the treatment of 42% of patients. A statistical difference (p = 0.05) was found between the two practices for documentation of left ventricular function, the use of ACE-I for patients with ejection fraction less than or equal to 40% and the use of ventricular blockers. Calcium Channels and Beta Blockers CONCLUSIONS: In the practices studied, there is underuse of documentation of left ventricular function, ACE-Is in eligible patients, target dose of ACE-Is, and the use of hydralazine and nitrates for ineligible patients. A higher proportion of patients are treated with ACE-I when the ejection fraction is less than or equal to 40%. There may be inappropriate use of calcium channel blockers in some patients. There is an unexplained clinical variation between the two practices studied.

title: The Altruistic Medical Researcher: Gone and Forgotten?
abstract: With increasing economic, political, and bureaucratic involvement in research, little attention is paid to the idealistic and benevolent intentions of the medical researcher. Benevolence is a mainstay of ethical research involving human subjects, and altruism is a form of benevolence that is difficult to quantify. It is interest in the welfare of others without personal gain. This article examines the scope of altruism in medical research from philosophical, psychological, and practical points of view. With the advent of experimental trials in humans in the first half of the century, the fame and recognition of physicians greatly impeded altruistic motivation. From a philosophical perspective, altruism is at best an optional moral principle. It is not evident in the ethical guidelines. In the scientific process, altruism can only exist in well-designed and ethical research. Selfishness, scientific misconduct, and conflicts of interest undermine it”; but altruism is also a potential solution to these problems. Research does not have a global orientation and is unfairly distributed. In an evolutionary model, altruism cannot thrive due to its lack of rewards and feedback, particularly in the economic climate of current science. Anonymity is decreasing, selfishness is increasing. Research has become an industry, and virtuous ideals are a romantic notion. If we use altruism as an indicator, then its rarity and fragility indicate the sick state of the research.

title: American Society for Clinical Psychopharmacology Survey of Psychopharmacologists' Practice Patterns for the Treatment of Mood Disorders
abstract: BACKGROUND: Optimal successive treatment decisions are not well established after an initial lack of response to medication in major depressive disorder or bipolar disorder. While practice guidelines offer expert consensus-based treatment recommendations, little is known about "real world" pharmacological decision-making by practicing psychopharmacologists. MATERIALS AND METHODS: We surveyed national members of the American Society for Clinical Psychopharmacology (ASCP) via the Internet to study preferred pharmacotherapy strategies and factors influencing medication choice for patients with mood disorders. RESULTS: Surveys were returned by 154/752 ASCP members (21%). After lack of response to a serotonin reuptake inhibitor in major depressive disorder, participants similarly favored switching within or between antidepressant classes. After a partial response, adjuvant bupropion was the preferred intervention, followed by switching antidepressant classes. The increase in atypical antipsychotics was only a fourth-line consideration, although moderate or marked efficacy was perceived in most cases with olanzapine, aripiprazole, and quetiapine. Respondents favored avoiding antidepressants in bipolar I patients with mixed/cyclical features or prior mania/hypomania associated with antidepressants. In rapid cyclers, they recommended stopping antidepressants and preferred the use of atypical antipsychotics and lamotrigine. CONCLUSIONS: Participating psychopharmacologists treating adults with mood disorders report prescribing medications that largely reflect the evidence base with only a few notable exceptions, in consideration of the characteristics of definable clinical subpopulations.

title: The anticipated clinical and economic effects of 90-90-90 in South Africa
abstract: Background The UNAIDS '90-90-90' global treatment target aims to achieve 73% virological suppression among HIV-infected people worldwide by 2020. Objective Using a microsimulation model of HIV detection, disease and treatment HIV, we estimate the clinical and economic value of achieving this ambitious goal in South Africa. Design We modeled: the Current Pace strategy, simulating existing scale-up efforts and gradual increases in overall virologic suppression from 24% to 36% over 5 years";" and the UNAIDS Target strategy, simulating a 73% suppression in 5 years. Data sources Published estimates and South African survey data report HIV transmission rates (0.16–9.03/100 PY), HIV-specific age-stratified fertility rates (1.0–9, 1/100 PY) and costs (ART: $11–100 PY) 31/month, routine care: $20-157/month). Target population South African population infected with HIV, including incident infections over the next ten years Perspective Modified social perspective, excluding time and productivity costs Time horizon Five and ten years Interventions Aggressive HIV case finding, efficient linkage to care, rapid scale-up of treatment and adherence/retention interventions towards UNAIDS target strategy Outcome measures HIV transmissions, deaths, years of life saved (YLS), maternal orphans, costs (2014USD) and cost-effectiveness Base case analysis compared to baseline current rate over (5 y) In 10 years, the UNAIDS Target strategy would prevent (873,000) 2,051,000 HIV transmissions, (1,174,000) 2,478,000 deaths and (726,000) 1,689,000 maternal orphans, while saving (3,002,000) 13,340,000 years of life. The additional budget required for the UNAIDS Target Strategy would be ($7,965) $15,979 billion, resulting in an Incremental Cost Effectiveness Ratio (ICER) of ($2,720/YLS) $1,260/YLS, (<50%) <20% of South Africa per capita GDP. Sensitivity analysis results Results generally varied <20% from the base case results when we varied key input parameters within plausible ranges. Limitations Several pathways can lead to an overall suppression of 73% which was examined in the sensitivity analysis. Conclusions Achieving the “90-90-90” HIV suppression target would be costly but remarkably effective and cost-effective in South Africa. Global health policymakers should mobilize political and financial support to make the 90-90-90 aspiration a reality.

title: The application of an occupational health guideline reduces sedentary lifestyle and increases fruit intake at work: results of an RCT
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the effectiveness of a draft occupational health practice guideline aimed at preventing weight gain on physical activity, sedentary behavior, and dietary behavior of employees and on outcomes related to body weight. METHODS: A randomized controlled trial comparing guideline-based care with usual care was conducted among 16 occupational physicians and 523 employees in the Netherlands between 2009 and 2011. Occupational physicians in the intervention group followed the draft guideline providing advice to employers on how to assess and intervene in the obesogenic work environment and conducting five face-to-face behavior change counseling sessions with employees to improve their lifestyle. Employee data was collected through questionnaires and physical measurements at baseline and at 6-month follow-up. Linear and logistic regression analyzes were performed to determine effects. RESULTS: The intervention showed significant effects on sedentary behavior at work (beta -28 min/day, 95% CI -2 to -54) and on fruit intake (beta 2.1 pieces/week"; 95% CI 0.6 to 3.6) No significant intervention effects were found for physical activity, sedentary behavior in leisure time or on weekends, snack intake, and body weight outcomes. : Guideline-based care resulted in more favorable sedentary behavior at work and higher fruit consumption, but did not improve employees' physical activity, snack intake, or body weight-related outcomes. trial registry ISRCTN/73545254 and NTR/1190.

title: The assessment of attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder in rural primary care: portability of the American Academy of Pediatrics guidelines to the "real world".
abstract: Goal. To examine the implementation of a protocol for the evaluation of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in rural pediatric practices. The protocol was designed to provide an efficient means for pediatricians to learn and use the ADHD guidelines put forth by the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP). Methods. Primary care staff (doctors, nurses, etc.) from 2 rural pediatric clinics were trained in the use of the ADHD screening protocol. Medical records of 101 patients 1 to 2 years prior to protocol introduction and 86 patients 2 to 3 years thereafter were reviewed for compliance with AAP guidelines. Additionally, 34% of staff-rated scales were re-rated to verify rating accuracy. Results. Prior to the availability of the AAP guidelines and the implementation of the assessment protocol, none of the primary care sites consistently collected the comprehensive information now recommended for an ADHD assessment. Parent and/or teacher rating scales were collected for only 0% to 21% of assessments across all sites. When provided with brief training and support materials, medical records showed a significant improvement in determining clinically necessary ADHD information, with parent-teacher rating scales present from 88% to 100% of the time. Staff demonstrated the ability to rate rating scales with a high degree of accuracy. The integrity of protocol collection and management was maintained 2 to 3 years after training. Conclusions. An efficient system for conducting ADHD assessments according to AAP guidelines can be initiated and maintained with integrity in rural pediatric clinics. Additional research is needed to determine if this system improves diagnostic decision making and patient outcomes. Pediatrics 2005";115:e120-e126. URL: www.pediatrics.org/cgi/doi/10.1542/peds.2004-1521;" attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, assessment, guidelines, pediatric

title: The behavioral economics of health and healthcare
abstract: People often make health care decisions that aren't in their best interest, from not signing up for the health insurance they're entitled to to engaging in extremely harmful behavior. Traditional economic theory provides a limited set of tools for improving behavior because it assumes that people make decisions rationally, have the mental capacity to handle large amounts of information and choice, and have endemic tastes and are not open to manipulation. By merging economics with psychology, behavioral economics recognizes that people often do not act rationally in the economic sense. Thus, it offers a potentially richer set of tools than traditional economic theory for understanding and influencing behaviors. However, it has only recently been applied to health care. This article provides an overview of behavioral economics, reviews some of its contributions, and shows how it can be used in health care to improve people's decisions and health.

title: The Behavior Change Wheel: A New Method for Characterizing and Designing Behavior Change Interventions
abstract: Background Improving the design and implementation of evidence-based practice depends on the success of behavior change interventions. This requires an appropriate method to characterize the interventions and link them to an analysis of the target behaviour. A plethora of behavior change intervention frameworks exist, but it is unclear how well they serve this purpose. This paper evaluates these frameworks and develops and evaluates a new framework intended to overcome their limitations. Methods A systematic search of electronic databases and consultations with experts in behavior change were used to identify frameworks for behavior change interventions. These were assessed according to three criteria: completeness, consistency, and a clear link to a general pattern of behaviour. A new framework was developed to meet these criteria. We examined the reliability with which it could be applied in two behavior change domains: tobacco control and obesity. Results Nineteen frameworks covering nine intervention functions and seven policy categories that could enable those interventions were identified. None of the frameworks reviewed covered the full range of intervention roles or policies, and only a minority met the criteria for consistency or linkage to a behavioral pattern. At the core of a proposed new framework is a 'behavioral system' involving three essential conditions: ability, opportunity and motivation (what we call the 'COM-B system'). This forms the center of a 'behaviour change wheel' (BCW) around which are located the nine intervention functions intended to address deficits in one or more of these conditions";" Around this are seven categories of policies that could allow such interventions to occur. The BCW was reliably used to characterize interventions within the 2010 Department of Health England tobacco control strategy and the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence guidance for reducing obesity. Conclusions Interventions and policies to change behavior can be usefully characterized by a BCW comprising: a 'behaviour system' at the core, surrounded by intervention functions and then by policy categories. Research is needed to establish to what extent BCW can lead to more efficient design of effective interventions.

title: The Black report on socioeconomic inequalities in health 10 years later
The Bold Promise Project: A System Change in Primary Care to Support Cardiovascular Risk Screening
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To develop a series of changes in the primary care system to facilitate cardiovascular risk screening of all eligible patients identified in accordance with the current New Zealand Cardiovascular Guidelines (NZGG), and provide the ability to measure and track clinical management of high-risk patients. METHODS: Several system changes were developed within primary care practice management software to identify the cohort of patients eligible for cardiovascular risk screening, to calculate cardiovascular disease risk (CVR), and to extract the data for cardiovascular risk screening. report on screening results and clinical management indicators in high-risk patients. patients Following a baseline audit, system changes were tested for 12 months in three general practices with a combined enrolled patient population of 30,963. RESULTS: A total of 6570 eligible patients were identified for NZGG";" 20.1% of these were Maori and 19.7% were Pacific people (mostly of Samoan, Tongan, Niuean or Cook Island origin). Over 12 months, screening rates for cardiovascular risk assessment increased from 4.7% to 53.5% for the cohort. Of the 3,516 patients examined, 482 (13.7%) had established cardiovascular disease. Another 230 (6.5%) had diabetes without CVD and 646 (18.4%) had a 5-year CVD risk of > or = 15%. Management data were available on 232 (48.1%) of those with CVD, 74%, 65%, and 79% taking aspirin, statins, and blood pressure-lowering medications, respectively. 55% exceeded the low-density lipoprotein (LDL) target of 2.5 mmol/L, 62% had a systolic blood pressure (BP) above the target of 130 mmHg, 18% continued to smoke, and only 9% met all the clinical objectives recommended in the guideline. Of 646 with a 5-year CVD risk > or = 15%, management data was available for 347 (53.7%). Only 34% were prescribed aspirin, 40% were prescribed statins, and 57% were prescribed blood pressure-lowering medications. Forty percent of this group had systolic BP >140 mmHg, 36% had LDL >3.5 mmol/L, and only 7% of patients met all guideline clinical targets. CONCLUSIONS: Changes in the system comprising this intervention have dramatically increased cardiovascular risk assessment rates in a primary care setting and will facilitate appropriate targeting of intensive cardiovascular prevention measures to close the observed treatment gap.

title: The challenge of preventive cardiology

The challenge of transferring an implementation strategy from academia to the field: a process evaluation of local quality improvement collaborations in Dutch primary care using standardization process theory
abstract: BACKGROUND, PURPOSE, AND OBJECTIVES: A quality improvement strategy consisting of comparative feedback and peer review embedded in locally available quality improvement collaborations was shown to be effective in changing the test-ordering behavior of general practitioners. However, implementation of this strategy was problematic. Our goal was the large-scale implementation of a tailored strategy covering both test ordering and prescription performance. Since we were unable to achieve a large-scale implementation, the objective of this study was to describe and analyze the challenges of the transfer process. METHODS: In a qualitative study, 19 regional health officers, pharmacists, laboratory specialists, and general practitioners were interviewed within 6 months of the transfer period. The interviews were audio recorded, transcribed and coded independently by two of the authors. The codes were matched with the dimensions of the normalization process theory. RESULTS: The general idea of the strategy was widely supported, but generating the feedback was more complex than expected and the need for external support after the transfer of the strategy remained high because the participants did not take responsibility for the work and distribution of the resources that arrived. with that. CONCLUSION: Evidence of effectiveness, a national infrastructure for these collaborations, and a general positive attitude were not sufficient for standardization. Thinking about managing large databases, task responsibility, and resource allocation should start as early as possible when planning complex quality improvement strategies. Simply exploring the barriers and facilitators experienced in a previous trial is not enough. Although multifaceted implementation strategies to change professional behavior are attractive, their inherent complexity is also a stumbling block for large-scale implementation.

title: The clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of low-intensity psychological interventions for secondary prevention of relapse after depression: a systematic review.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Depression is the most common mental disorder in community settings and a leading cause of disability worldwide. The goal of treatment is to achieve remission or at least adequate control of depressive symptoms; however, even after successful treatment, the risk of relapse after remission is significant. Although the effectiveness of low-intensity interventions has been extensively evaluated for treating the primary symptoms of psychological distress, there has been substantially less research examining the use of these interventions as a relapse prevention strategy. OBJECTIVE: To systematically review the clinical and the cost-effectiveness of low-intensity psychological or psychosocial interventions to prevent relapse or recurrence in people with depression As the broader definition of 'low-intensity' psychological intervention is somewhat contested, the review was conducted in two parts: A , a systematic review of all evaluations of 'low intensity' interventions by paraprofessionals, peer supporters, or psychological well-being professionals as defined by the Improving Access to Psychological Therapies program; and B, a scoping review of relevant evaluations of interventions involving qualified mental health professionals (eg, psychiatrists, clinical psychologists, cognitive behavioral therapists) involving <6 contact hours per patient. DATA SOURCES: Exhaustive bibliographic searches were carried out; Electronic databases were searched from inception to September 2010 (including MEDLINE, MEDLINE In-Process & Other Non-Indexed Citations, PsycINFO, EMBASE, The Cochrane Library), using internet resources to identify treatment guidelines of depression and bibliographies of Relevant reviews, guidelines and included studies were scrutinised. REVIEW METHODS: Two reviewers independently screened titles and abstracts; data were independently extracted by one reviewer using a standardized data extraction form and checked by another reviewer. Discrepancies were resolved by consensus, with the participation of a third reviewer when necessary. Inclusion criteria were population - adults or adolescents who had received treatment for depression; intervention - part A, low-intensity interventions, specifically any unsupported psychological/psychosocial intervention or any supported intervention that does not involve highly qualified mental health professionals, and, part B, interventions performed by qualified mental health professionals that involve < 6 contact hours per patient; comparator: any, including no treatment, placebo, psychological or pharmacological interventions; outcomes: relapse or recurrence, other outcomes (eg social function, quality of life) recorded where reported; and study design: for clinical efficacy, randomized, quasi-randomized, and nonrandomized studies with concurrent control patients. For cost-effectiveness, full economic evaluations comparing two or more treatment options and considering both costs and consequences. No study met the inclusion criteria for Part A main. RESULTS: For the clinical effectiveness review, 17 studies (14 completed, 3 ongoing), reported in 27 publications, met the Part B inclusion criteria. These studies were clinically and methodologically diverse and reported different degrees of efficacy for the interventions evaluated. One randomized controlled trial (RCT), evaluating a collaborative care type programme, was potentially relevant to part A; this study reported no difference between people who received the intervention and those who received usual care in relapse of depression over 12 months. For the cost-effectiveness review, two studies met the criteria for part B. One of these was an economic evaluation of the earlier RCT, which was potentially relevant to part A. This evaluation found that the intervention may be a cost-effective use of resources compared to usual care; however, it was unclear how valid these estimates were for the NHS. LIMITATIONS: Although any definition of 'brief' is likely to be somewhat arbitrary, an inclusion threshold of 6 contact hours per patient was used to select brief high-intensity intervention studies. Most of the excluded studies evaluated clearly resource-intensive interventions, although studies were occasionally excluded on the basis of having just over 6 contact hours per patient. CONCLUSIONS: There is inadequate evidence to determine the clinical effectiveness or cost-effectiveness of low-intensity interventions for the prevention of relapse or recurrence of depression. A scoping review of high-intensity brief therapies indicates that some approaches have shown promise in some studies, but the findings have not been consistent. Many uncertainties remain and more primary research is required. The scope of such research should be carefully considered; it is important to assess the broader patient pathway taking into account the heterogeneous groups of patients of interest. Future RCTs conducted in a UK primary care setting should include adult participants in remission or recovery from depression, and assess the quality of the intervention and consistency of delivery between practitioners where appropriate. The occurrence of relapse or recurrence should be measured using established methods, and functional outcomes and symptoms should be measured;" data on quality of life using a generic instrument, such as the European Quality of Life-5 Dimensions (EQ-5D), should be collected FUNDING: Health Technology Assessment Program of the National Institute for Health Research.

title: The clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of screening for anal squamous intraepithelial lesions in HIV-positive homosexual and bisexual men.
abstract: Context Homosexual and bisexual men infected with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) are at increased risk for human papillomavirus-associated anal neoplasia and anal squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). Objective To estimate the clinical benefits and cost-effectiveness of screening for anal squamous intraepithelial lesions (ASIL) and anal SCC in HIV-positive gay and bisexual men. Design Cost-effectiveness analysis conducted from a societal perspective using reference case recommendations from the Panel on cost-effectiveness in health and medicine. A state transition Markov model was developed to estimate lifetime costs, life expectancy, and quality-adjusted life expectancy for non-screening versus various screening strategies for ASIL and anal SCC using Pap smears ( Pap) anal at different intervals. Values of incidence, progression and regression of anal neoplasia"; effectiveness of screening and treatment; natural history of HIV; quality of life related to health"; and costs were obtained from the literature. Setting and participants Hypothetical cohort of HIV-positive gay and bisexual men living in the United States. Main outcome measures Life expectancy, quality-adjusted life expectancy, quality-adjusted life years saved, lifetime costs, and incremental cost-effectiveness. Results Screening for ASIL increased quality-adjusted life expectancy at all stages of HIV disease. Screening with anal Pap tests every 2 years, beginning in the early stages of HIV disease (CD4 cell count >0.50 ¡Ã 109/L), resulted in a 2.7-month increase in life expectancy of quality-adjusted life for an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio of $13,000 per quality-adjusted life year saved. Annual screening with anal Pap smears provided an additional benefit at an incremental cost of $16,600 per quality-adjusted life year saved. If screening was not started until later in the course of HIV disease (CD4 cell count <0.50¡Ã109/L), then yearly Pap smear was preferred due to increased amount of disease prevalent anal (cost-effectiveness ratio of less than $25,000 per quality-adjusted life year saved compared with no screening). Screening every 6 months provided a small additional benefit over annual screening. The results were most sensitive to the rate of progression from ASIL to anal SCC and the effectiveness of treatment of precancerous lesions. Conclusions Screening for ASIL and anal SCC in HIV-positive gay and bisexual men with anal Pap smears offers quality-adjusted life expectancy benefits at a cost comparable to other accepted preventive clinical interventions.

title: The clinician-researcher: inevitable but manageable tension
abstract: The "difference position" holds that clinical research and therapeutic medical practice are sufficiently different activities to require different rules and ethical principles. Instead, the "similarity position" holds that clinical investigators should be bound by the same fundamental principles that govern therapeutic medicine, specifically, the duty to provide the optimal therapeutic benefit to each patient or subject. Some advocates of the similarity position defend it because of the overlap between the role of the treating physician and the role of the investigator in a research trial. This overlap is greatest when the same physician occupies both roles with respect to a particular patient-subject. We address the ethical tensions inherent in such role conflict and argue that the tensions are real but manageable. The difference position provides a solid ethical framework within which to manage these tensions, while the similarity position is unsatisfactory because it seeks to deny the existence of the tensions.

title: The CLUES study: a cluster randomized clinical trial to evaluate the implementation of cardiovascular guidelines in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Appropriate care for people with cardiovascular risk factors can reduce morbidity and mortality. One strategy to improve the care of these patients involves the implementation of evidence-based guidelines. To date, little research has been published on the impact of these implementation strategies in our setting. Goals. To evaluate the effectiveness of a multifaceted personalized intervention in the implementation of three guidelines related to cardiovascular risk (hypertension, type 2 diabetes and dyslipidemia) in primary care in the Basque Health Service compared to the usual implementation. METHODS/DESIGN: Two-year cluster randomized clinical trial in primary care in two districts of the Basque Health Service. All primary care units are randomized. The data of all diabetic, hypertensive and susceptible to coronary risk screening will be analyzed. Interventions. The control group will receive the standard implementation. The experimental group will receive a multifaceted personalized implementation strategy, including a specific web page and workshops for family doctors and nurses. Evaluation criteria. Primary endpoints: annual request for glycosylated hemoglobin, basic laboratory tests for hypertension, cardiovascular risk screening (women between 45-74 and men between 40-74 years). Secondary variables: other process indicators and clinical guidelines. ANALYSIS: The data will be extracted from the centralized computerized clinical history. The ANALYSIS will be carried out at the primary care unit level weighted by cluster size. DISCUSSION: The main contribution of our study is that it aims to identify an effective strategy for the implementation of cardiovascular guidelines in primary care in our environment. TESTING RECORD: Current Controlled Testing, ISRCTN88876909.

title: The Colorado Asthma Toolkit Program: A High Plains Research Network Practice Training Intervention
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Asthma is often underdiagnosed and undertreated in primary care. The Colorado Asthma Toolkit Program was initiated to establish a method for improving asthma care by providing primary care practices with guidance, training, and support for (1) evidence-based diagnosis and treatment of asthma, and (2) patient education and activation for effective care. self-management of your illness. METHODS: A collaborative program involving 2 academic medical institutions and the High Plains Research Network, a primary care practice-based research network in eastern Colorado, was initiated. Focus groups were conducted with rural Colorado patients and health care physicians to assess the need and determine the most effective intervention strategies. Two interrelated training programs, or "tool kits," were subsequently developed, one for each of the healthcare physicians and patients. Physicians received 3 training sessions conducted by 2 nurse practitioners that included training in guideline-based methods for the assessment and treatment of asthma, training to assist practices in implementing these methods, and training in communication techniques for promote self-control of asthma. A spirometer was also delivered to the practices and they were trained in its use and interpretation. Patient self-management toolkits were provided to clinicians, who were trained to use the materials to educate patients and increase treatment adherence. Evaluations were based on practice interviews 1 to 3 months after training. RESULTS: Training occurred in 57 of 58 primary care offices in rural and semi-rural areas of eastern Colorado. Practices reported changes in their asthma management behaviors: (1) 40.4% of practices increased their use of inhaled corticosteroids, and the median percentage of patients taking inhaled corticosteroids increased from 25% to 50%"; (2) 53.2% of practices increased their use of asthma action plans, with the median percentage of patients with action plans increasing from 0% to 20%;" and (3) 78.7% of practices started or increased their use of spirometry, resulting in an increase in median use from 0% to 30%. CONCLUSION: The Colorado Asthma Toolkit Program successfully delivered asthma care training to most rural health care practices in the area. Acceptance by practices was attributed to flexible office training and provision of spirometry. The significant changes observed in asthma management practices are likely to reduce hospitalizations and emergency department visits.

title: The Community Physicians Network (CPN): an academic-community partnership to eliminate health care disparities
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Disparities in health care are maintained by three main factors: 1) patient factors that include multiple risk factors and comorbidities"; 2) health professional factors that include inconsistent application of practice guidelines due to a limited database of clinical trials of effective therapies in African Americans and other underrepresented minorities, and 3) barriers in the health care delivery system that result in poor access to care The Community Physician Network ( CPN) at Morehouse School of Medicine was established to address health care disparities by focusing on provider-specific strategies OBJECTIVES: To: 1) use disease-specific registries to identify treatment gaps and facilitate care improvement processes quality among CPN practices; 2) develop specific educational messages practice-specific and guideline-based to promote quality of care; 3) engage and train NPC clinicians to participate in clinical protocols approved by the NIH, other governments, and industry; and 4) develop a data repository of all CPN-sponsored clinical trials that include significant numbers of African Americans and other underrepresented minorities. METHODS: Disease-specific outpatient registries will have the following characteristics: 1) data structures and data elements will use standard database codes and a data dictionary; 2) HIPAA compliant data transfer and extraction tool; 3) reference chart review to establish practice patterns and provide practice-specific feedback; 4) annual update of the registry; 5) registration and data repository maintained on the secure servers of the Morehouse School of Medicine; 6) registry publications will include only aggregated data, without identification of contributing practices; 7) An electronic medical record platform will be promoted as the ultimate data management tool for NPC practices. Additionally, up to three continuing medical education (CME) programs each year will feature national speakers and promote evidence-based practice guidelines. RESULTS: Eighty-five primary care and subspecialty practices are actively enrolled in CPN with a total of 385,000 annual outpatient visits. The composition of the insurance status is: HMO/PPO (45%); Medicare only (19%); Medicare HMO (11%); Medicare plus (8%); Medicaid (6%);" Uninsured (11%). CONCLUSIONS: The Community Physician Network will address specific gaps in health care for African American and other minority patients by promoting quality care among its members and facilitating participation in approved clinics trial protocols The unique partnership of the academic community is consistent with the NIH roadmap goal of eliminating health care disparities.

title: Compensation for patients injured in clinical trials
abstract: The issue of 'no-fault' compensation for patients suffering adverse effects as a result of their participation in clinical trials is discussed in light of the guidelines issued by the Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry (ABPI) and our recent experiences in the review. of protocols. presented to the local surgical research ethics subcommittee. We have found a variety of qualifications applied by pharmaceutical companies that are not in the spirit of the guidelines, let alone in the interests of the patient, and suggest a means by which patients can be assured of fair treatment in the event that ' no fault injury.

title: The Context of Antibiotic Overuse
The cost-effectiveness and population outcomes of expanded HIV screening and antiretroviral treatment in the United States
abstract: Background Although recent guidelines call for the expansion of routine HIV screening, resources for antiretroviral treatment (ART) are limited and all eligible people are not currently being treated. Objective To assess the effects on the HIV epidemic in the US to reduce risk behavior. Design Dynamic mathematical model of HIV transmission and disease progression, and cost-effectiveness analysis. in the US Time horizon 20 years and life (costs and QALYs). Society perspective. Interventions Expanded HIV screening and counselling, ART treatment, or both. Outcomes New HIV infections, reduced costs and quality-adjusted life years (QALYs), and incremental cost-effectiveness Rationale. Outcomes Base-case analysis One-time HIV screening in low-risk individuals along with annual HIV screening high risk in high risk people. Individuals could prevent 6.7% of the projected 1.23 million new infections and cost $22,382/QALY gained, assuming a 20% reduction in post-screening sexual activity. Expanding ART use to 75% of eligible people prevents 10.3% of infections and costs $20,300/QALY earned. A combined strategy prevents 17.3% of infections and costs $21,580/QALY gained. Sensitivity analysis of results With no reduction in sexual activity, expanded screening prevents 3.7% of infections. Early initiation of ART when CD4>350 cells/mL prevents 20Â¨C28% of infections. Additional efforts to cut high-risk behavior in half could reduce infections by 65%. Limitations Simplified model of disease progression and treatment";" exclusion from acute HIV screening. Conclusions Simultaneous expansion of HIV screening and treatment offers the greatest health benefit and is cost-effective. However, even a substantial expansion of HIV testing and treatment programs is not enough to markedly reduce the US HIV epidemic without significant reductions in risk behavior. ) and the United States Department of Veterans Affairs.

title: The costs, clinical benefits, and cost-effectiveness of cervical cancer screening in HIV-infected women.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Women with HIV infection are at higher risk of cervical squamous intraepithelial lesions than women without HIV infection, and the optimal regimen for cervical cancer screening in these women is uncertain. Objective: To assess the net health consequences, costs, and costs. Efficacy of various screening strategies for cervical neoplasia and cancer in HIV-infected women. Values of incidence, progression and regression of cervical neoplasia"; effectiveness of detection and treatment; progression of HIV disease; mortality due to HIV infection and cancer; quality of life;" and costs were obtained from the literature. Setting: Simulated clinical practice in the United States. Patients: HIV-infected women representative of the US population. Smears obtained 6 months apart (recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention), semi-annual Pap smears, annual colposcopy, and semi-annual colposcopy were considered. Measures: quality-adjusted life years (QALYs), lifetime costs, and incremental cost. effectiveness. Results: Annual Pap smear resulted in a gain of 2.1 months in quality-adjusted life expectancy for an incremental cost of $12,800 per QALY saved. Annual Pap smear testing after two negative smears obtained 6 months apart provided an additional 0.04 QALYs at a cost of $14,800 per QALY saved. The biannual Pap smear test provided an additional 0.17 QALYs at a cost of $27,600 per QALY saved. Annual colposcopy cost more but provided no additional benefit compared to biannual Pap smear, and biannual colposcopy exceeded $375,000 per QALY saved. The results were more sensitive to the rate of progression of the neoplasm to invasive cancer. Conclusions: In HIV-infected women, screening for cervical cancer with annual Pap smears after two negative smears obtained 6 months apart offers quality-adjusted life expectancy benefits at a cost comparable to that of other screening tests. preventive clinical interventions.

title: The current situation of research and health ethics in Sudan
abstract: In the early 20th century, health research in Sudan developed mainly as a function of the British colonial administration. The ethical issues of the medical profession in the Sudan are governed by the Sudan Medical Council. To address these issues, the Sudanese Medical Council issued Medico-Legal and Ethical Guidelines in 1967. This important document has focused primarily on ethical issues arising in clinical medicine. Throughout the history of health research in Sudan it is very difficult to find any reference to research ethics. However, there have been some attempts to articulate ethics in health research. In 1979, Sudan witnessed the establishment of the first ethics review committee, which was established at the initiative of a group of doctors and scientists from the national health research laboratory. This committee did not obtain political or institutional recognition. Therefore, it was not developed and came to an end shortly after its creation. However, in 2000, FMOH established an ethical review committee (ERC). The functions of this committee were to review the health research proposals to be carried out in the country for ethical reasons, regardless of the financing agents. Unfortunately, the committee spent all of its work reviewing only externally sponsored health research and research conducted by expatriate researchers or international organizations.

title: Demonstration of a theory-based approach to the design of localized patient safety interventions.
abstract: Background There is evidence of unsafe care in health systems worldwide. Interventions to implement recommended practice often have modest and variable effects. Ideally, selecting and adapting interventions according to local contexts should enhance effects. However, the means by which this can happen are rarely systematic, based on theory, or made transparent. This work aimed to demonstrate the applicability, feasibility, and acceptability of a Theoretical Domains Framework Implementation (TDFI) approach to co-design patient safety interventions. Methods We worked with three hospitals to support the implementation of evidence-based guidance to reduce the risk of feeding through misplaced nasogastric feeding tubes. Our tiered process, informed by the TDF and key principles of the implementation literature, involved: "engaging stakeholders"; identifying target behaviors; identifying local factors (barriers and levers) that affect behavior change using a questionnaire based on TDF, work with stakeholders to bring about targeted local changes strategies to address key barriers and support to stakeholders to implement strategies Exit interviews and audit data collection were conducted to assess the feasibility and acceptability of this approach Results After audit and discussion, the implementation teams of each trust identified the process of verifying the placement of nasogastric tubes before feeding as the key behavior for the objective The results of the questionnaire indicated differences in the key barriers between the or organizations. The focus groups generated innovative, generalizable, and adaptable strategies to overcome barriers, such as awareness events, screen savers, equipment modifications, and interactive learning resources. rces. Exit interviews identified issues related to the benefits, challenges, and sustainability of this approach. Time trend audit data was collected for 301 patients over an 18-month period for a Trust, suggesting clinically significant improvement in pH use and practice documentation post-intervention. Conclusions The TDF is a feasible and acceptable framework to guide the implementation of patient safety interventions. The stepped TDFI approach engages health professionals and facilitates contextualization in identifying the target behavior, eliciting local barriers, and selecting strategies to address those barriers. This approach may be useful for implementation teams and policymakers, although our promising findings confirm the need for more rigorous evaluation; a balanced block assessment is currently underway.

title: The design and evaluation of a graphic display for laboratory data.
abstract: Purpose Advances in health care information technology have provided opportunities to present data in new and more effective ways. In this study, we designed a lab display that presents small, data-dense graphs called sparklines, which have recently been touted as effective representations of medical data but have not been well studied. The effect of this new screen on clinicians' interpretation of the data was investigated. Design Twelve physicians spoke aloud while evaluating laboratory data from four patients in a pediatric intensive care unit with the graphical display and a conventional tabletop display. Measurements Verbalizations were coded based on abnormal values and trends identified for each laboratory variable. The correspondence of the interpretations of the variables in each screen was evaluated and the patterns between the participants were investigated. The evaluation time was also analyzed. Results Physicians completed assessments significantly faster with the graphic display (3.6 min vs. 4.4 min, p=0.042). When compared between screens, 37% of interpretations did not match. The charts were most useful when the visual cues in the charts did not provide trend information, while slightly abnormal values were easier to identify with the charts. Conclusions The data presentation format may affect the way clinicians interpret laboratory data. Graphic displays have several advantages over numeric displays, but they are not always optimal. The characteristics of the user, the task and the data must be taken into account when designing information screens.

title: The development of an intervention to promote adherence to national guidelines for suspected viral encephalitis
abstract: BACKGROUND: Central nervous system infections can have devastating clinical outcomes if not diagnosed and treated early. There is a documented gap between recommended and actual practice and a limited understanding of its causes. We identify and explore the reasons for this gap, focusing on the points in the patient's journey most amenable to change and developing a personalized intervention strategy to improve diagnosis and treatment. METHODS: Using semi-structured interviews with theoretical information, we explored the barriers and facilitators to diagnosing and managing patients with suspected encephalitis, specifically performing lumbar punctures and initiating antiviral therapy within 6 h. We intentionally take samples from hospitals and hospital staff in the UK. We audio recorded and transcribed all interviews prior to frame analysis. We map the barriers and facilitators identified in the patient's journey. We combine clinician-targeted behavior change techniques with leading barriers and facilitators and integrate them into an intervention package. RESULTS: We interviewed 43 staff members at six hospitals. Clinical staff expressed uncertainty about when and how to perform lumbar punctures, highlighting the practical difficulties of performing lumbar punctures in busy clinical settings. Once the need for treatment was triggered, clinicians generally felt able to take appropriate therapeutic action, albeit within organizational and resource constraints. Combined behavior change techniques focused largely on treatment history. These included decision support for rapid recognition, highlighting the consequences of missed diagnoses for clinicians and patients, and practical support for lumbar punctures. We then designed an evidence-based package comprising "core" interventions and, to allow for local flexibility, "optional" interventions. CONCLUSIONS: We identified several points in the patient journey where the practice could improve, the most critical being around clinical suspicion and initial investigation. Interventions targeting professional beliefs and behaviors while optimizing their clinical environment are among the most promising approaches for improving the care of suspected encephalitis. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Randomized trial registered in Controlled Trials ISRCTN06886935.

title: The development of an intervention to promote compliance with national guidelines for suspected viral encephalitis.
abstract: Background Central nervous system infections can have devastating clinical outcomes if not diagnosed and treated early. There is a documented gap between recommended and actual practice and a limited understanding of its causes. We identify and explore the reasons for this gap, focusing on the points in the patient's journey most amenable to change and developing a personalized intervention strategy to improve diagnosis and treatment. Methods Using semi-structured interviews with theoretical information, we explore the barriers and facilitators to diagnosing and managing patients with suspected encephalitis, specifically performing lumbar punctures and initiating antiviral therapy within 6 h. We intentionally take samples from hospitals and hospital staff in the UK. We audio recorded and transcribed all interviews prior to frame analysis. We map the barriers and facilitators identified in the patient's journey. We combine clinician-targeted behavior change techniques with leading barriers and facilitators and integrate them into an intervention package. Results We interviewed 43 staff members from six hospitals. Clinical staff expressed uncertainty about when and how to perform lumbar punctures, highlighting the practical difficulties of performing lumbar punctures in busy clinical settings. Once the need for treatment was triggered, clinicians generally felt able to take appropriate therapeutic action, albeit within organizational and resource constraints. Combined behavior change techniques focused largely on treatment history. These included decision support for rapid recognition, highlighting the consequences of missed diagnoses for clinicians and patients, and practical support for lumbar punctures. We then designed an evidence-based package comprising "core" interventions and, to allow for local flexibility, "optional" interventions. Conclusions We identified several points in the patient journey where the practice could improve, the most critical being around clinical suspicion and initial investigation. Interventions targeting professional beliefs and behaviors while optimizing their clinical environment are among the most promising approaches for improving the care of suspected encephalitis.

title: The development of evidence-based psychotherapy for use in alcoholism. A review
abstract: The past decades have seen tremendous progress in the development and validation of evidence-based approaches to psychotherapy for alcoholism. While early behavioral and psychoanalytic techniques were the original foundation of psychotherapy in this field, evidence-based approaches are now based on the principles of motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy. Different techniques have been developed to modify the preceding and persistent conditions that favor problem behavior, for example, coping/social skills training and the community reinforcement approach. According to the results of the MATCH project, one of the largest treatment trials, "cognitive behavioral intervention" combines motivational enhancement therapy, the 12-step approach and cognitive behavioral therapy, with the aim of providing a new and even more effective. for alcohol dependent patients. However, these very promising developments are fraught with enormous problems, in that few of the new evidence-based treatment approaches are accepted as standard treatment in Germany, in addition to the fact that only a fraction of all alcohol dependent people in the country they find their way. in the care system, for various reasons. Early diagnosis and facilitating access to the various treatment options available could be a future task for general practitioners and also for business/industry medical schemes.

title: The dirty dozen: 12 sources of bias in forensic neuropsychology with ways to mitigate.
abstract: The increasing role of a forensic neuropsychologist in civil litigation has led to a higher level of expectations for this expert, in areas such as clinical and judicial knowledge, objectivity, and usefulness of the work product. The onus is on forensic neuropsychologists to ensure that these expectations are met. Recognizing that bias is inherent in clinical and forensic work, it is imperative that in high-risk situations, such as forensic neuropsychological evaluation, the assessor be proactively mindful in recognizing and minimizing the effects of these biases. This article highlights 12 of many common biases that the prudent forensic neuropsychologist should always be aware of, during the evaluation, as well as the provision of deposition or testimony at trial. Role, cognitive, and practical biases are defined and illustrated with examples. Specific suggestions are drawn from both the empirical literature and forensic experience on how to recognize and mitigate these biases. The information contained in this article is intended to provide sound and practical strategies that may be useful to practitioners of forensic neuropsychology. Lawyers will also find the content helpful when working with such experts, including during deposition preparation and cross-examination. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2017 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: The economy-wide impact of pandemic influenza in the UK: a computable general equilibrium modeling experiment
abstract: OBJECTIVES To estimate the potential economic impact of pandemic influenza, associated behavioral responses, school closures and vaccination in the UK. DESIGN A computable general equilibrium model of the UK economy was specified for various combinations of pandemic influenza mortality and morbidity, vaccine efficacy, school closures, and prophylactic absenteeism using published data. ADJUSTMENT 2004 UK economy (most up-to-date available with adequate economic data). MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The economic impact of various scenarios with different pandemic severity, vaccination, school closures, and prophylactic absenteeism specified in terms of gross domestic product, output of different economic sectors, and equivalent variation. RESULTS Costs related to disease alone ranged from 0.5% to 1.0% of gross domestic product (£8.4bn to £16.8bn) for low-mortality scenarios, 3.3% and 4.3% ( £55.5bn to £72.3bn) for high-mortality scenarios, and larger still for an extreme pandemic. School closures increase the economic impact, particularly for mild pandemics. If there is widespread behavior change and large-scale prophylactic sick leave, the economic impact would be markedly increased with little health benefit. Vaccination with a pre-pandemic vaccine could save 0.13% to 2.3% of gross domestic product (£2.2bn to £38.6bn)"; a single dose of a combination vaccine could save 0 .3% to 4.3% (from 5 billion to 72 pounds sterling). 3 billion);" and two doses of a compatible vaccine could limit the overall economic impact to about 1% of gross domestic product for all disease scenarios. CONCLUSION Balancing school closures with "business as usual" and obtaining sufficient supplies of effective vaccines are more important factors in determining the economic impact of an influenza pandemic than the disease itself. Prophylactic absence from work in response to fear of infection can greatly increase the economic impact.

title: The EDUCATE study: an example of continuing education for the implementation of clinical practice guidelines
abstract: Cancer care is evolving from a single-physician care delivery system based on tradition and anecdotal experience to a science-driven, collaborative, multidisciplinary paradigm. Evidence-based practice facilitates optimal quality of care for cancer patients and is effected for medical and nursing professionals through the implementation of clinical practice guidelines. Clinical education based on the principles of adult learning is a method of implementing clinical practice guidelines in clinical practice. However, research shows that conventional static education methods do little to change behavior";" Instead, effective education incorporates interactive formats, provides feedback, and includes reminder and reinforcement strategies. The EDUCATE (Educating Clinicians for Efficacy of Treatment Guidelines) study provides a model for the implementation of clinical practice guidelines using educational methods. A faculty of nurse educators, along with practice champions, conducted an intensive educational intervention comprised of multiple teaching/learning activities over a 12-month period in community oncology practices in the United States. In addition to an overview of clinical practice guidelines and educational methods that can be used for clinical practice guideline implementation, obstacles faced and lessons learned through the EDUCATE Study are presented, along with recommendations for implementation in the practice environment.

title: The effect of a computerized reminder system in the prevention of postoperative venous thromboembolism
abstract: Study objective To measure the effect of an altered process of care, directed by a computerized reminder system, on rates of symptomatic postoperative venous thromboembolism. Design comparisons of pre- and post-intervention measures. Setting A university-affiliated community hospital in Utah. Patients Two thousand and seventy-seven consecutive patients who underwent major operations in four surgical divisions between January 1, 1997 and October 31, 1997 (before the procedure), and 2093 consecutive patients who underwent the same procedures between January 1, 1998 and October 31, 1998 (postintervention). Intervention A program to prevent venous thromboembolism developed from the American College of Chest Physicians guidelines and a modified workflow driven by a computerized reminder system. Measurements Rates of objectively confirmed symptomatic deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), and death attributable to venous thromboembolism occurring within 90 days of the date of surgery. Results Pre- and post-intervention cohorts did not differ with respect to age, disease severity, number of risk factors for venous thromboembolism, or individual risk factors for venous thromboembolism. The overall prophylaxis rate increased from 89.9% before implementation of the computerized reminder system to 95.0% after implementation (p < 0.0001). The combined 90-day rate of symptomatic DVT, PE, and death attributable to PE remained the same (preintervention, 1.0%"; postintervention, 1.2%; odds ratio, 1.21;" 95% confidence interval, 0.67 to 2.20). Forty of 46 venous thromboembolic complications (87%) occurred despite the application of the measures recommended by the American College of Chest Physicians to prevent venous thromboembolism. Conclusions Computerized reminder systems combined with altered care procedures increase the rate of venous thromboembolism prophylaxis without decreasing the rate of symptomatic venous thromboembolism when the initial prophylaxis rate is high. There is a population of surgical patients who are resistant to the prophylactic measures against venous thromboembolism recommended by the American College of Chest Physicians. New strategies are needed to address prophylaxis-resistant venous thromboembolism.

title: The effect of a mobile clinical decision support system on the diagnosis of obesity and overweight in primary and acute care encounters.
abstract: The purpose of the study was to compare the proportion of obesity-related diagnoses in clinical encounters (N = 1874) documented by nurses using a personal digital assistant-based record with and without obesity decision support features. Experimental group encounters in the randomized controlled trial had significantly more (P = 0.000) obesity-related diagnoses (11.3%) than control group encounters (1%) and a significantly lower false negative rate (24 .5% vs. 66.5%, p = 0.000). The study findings provide evidence that integrating a decision support function that automatically calculates an obesity-related diagnosis increases diagnoses and decreases missed diagnoses and suggests that such systems have the potential to improve the quality of obesity-related care. with obesity. OVERWEIGHT AND OBESITY are challenging public health problems and the target of public health prevention goals in the United States.1 Overweight and obesity have been underrecognized conditions, leading many obese patients to not receive appropriate interventions.2,3 Prevention and control of obesity and overweight encompasses a set of complex and dynamic processes,4 and the integration of relevant evidence into practice is needed to improve obesity management.5,6 The guidelines of clinical practice can serve as a tool to provide evidence-based practice";" however, few studies have been conducted with nurses, and methodological issues limit the generalizability of their results.7 Although advanced practice nurses have the potential to play a critical role in the prevention and treatment of obesity and overweight, there is little empirical evidence on their adherence to, and therefore, research is needed to explore effective strategies to support implementation of the guidelines.8 The purpose of this study was to compare the proportion of obesity-related diagnoses (obesity and overweight) in clinical encounters documented through a clinical decision based on a personal digital assistant. support system compared to a personal digital assistant-based clinical record without obesity decision support features.

title: The Effect of a Patient-Centered Care Package Intervention on Pressure Ulcer Incidence (INTACT): A Cluster-Randomized Trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Hospital-acquired pressure ulcers are a serious patient safety concern, associated with poor patient outcomes and high healthcare costs. They are also seen as an indicator of the quality of nursing care. OBJECTIVE: To assess the effectiveness of a pressure ulcer prevention care package in preventing hospital-acquired pressure ulcers among patients at risk. DESIGN: Pragmatic cluster randomized trial. SETTING: Eight tertiary referral hospitals with >200 beds each in three Australian states. PARTICIPANTS: 1600 patients (200/hospital) were recruited. Patients were eligible if they were: >/= 18 years of age; risk of pressure ulcer due to limited mobility; they were expected to stay in the hospital >/= 48 hours and could read English. METHODS: Hospitals (groups) were stratified into two groups by recent pressure ulcer rates and randomly assigned within strata to a package of care for pressure ulcer prevention or standard care. The care package was theoretically and empirically based on patient participation and clinical practice guidelines. It had multiple components, with three messages for patients. participation in pressure ulcer prevention care: keep moving, take care of your skin and eat a healthy diet. Patient training aids included a DVD, brochure, and poster. Nurses in intervention hospitals were trained to collaborate with patients in their pressure ulcer prevention care. The statistician, recruiters, and outcome assessors were blinded to group assignment, and the interventionists were blinded to the study hypotheses, tested in both group and patient. speed The primary outcome, the incidence of hospital-acquired pressure ulcers, which was applied at both the group and individual participant levels, was measured by daily skin inspection. RESULTS: Four groups were randomized to each group and 799 patients per group were analyzed. The intraclass correlation coefficient was 0.035. After adjusting for clustering and prespecified covariates (age, pressure ulcer present at baseline, body mass index, reason for admission, residence, and number of comorbidities at admission), the hazard ratio for new pressure ulcers was developed. (package of care for pressure ulcer prevention relative to standard care) was 0.58 (95% CI 0.25, 1.33, p = 0.198). No adverse events or harms were reported. CONCLUSIONS: Although the pressure ulcer prevention care package was associated with a large reduction in the risk of pressure ulceration, there was a high degree of uncertainty surrounding this estimate and the difference was not statistically significant. Possible explanations for this Non-significant findings include that the pressure ulcer prevention care package was effective but the sample size was too small to detect.

title: The effect of adding Pap smear information to a mammography reminder system in an HMO: results from a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Although reminders can promote cancer screening in primary care, little is known about the potential interaction between multiple reminders. Methods We conducted a randomized controlled trial to compare the effect of Pap smears combined with mammogram recalls and mammogram recalls alone among 2,471 women aged 40 years and older enrolled in a health maintenance organization serving a predominantly eligible population. Medicaid. The reminders included both a letter mailed to the woman and a medical record notice. Results Intervention allocation was not associated with differences in rates of visits to family medicine or internal medicine or mammograms during the study year. Compared with women assigned to mammography recall treatment alone, those assigned to the combined mammography recall and Pap smear intervention were more likely to visit a gynecologist (34% vs. 29%, adjusted odds ratio = 1.33, 95% confidence interval 1.08). “1.63) and completing a Pap smear (30% compared with 23%, adjusted odds ratio = 1.39, 95% confidence interval 1.07–1.89). Conclusions Within the study setting, the addition of Pap smears to mammography reminders has a procedure-specific effect, increasing gynecology visits and Pap smear use without increasing or decreasing other primary care or mammography visits. We found no evidence of reinforcement or competition between these reminders.

title: The effect of computerized reminders on the prescribing behavior of general practitioners: a cluster randomized trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: It is difficult to monitor drug prescribing behavior in general practice, despite the development and distribution of guidelines. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effect on medication prescription behavior of the implementation of prescription guidelines through a computerized reactive reminder system (CRS). DESIGN: Cluster randomized controlled trial with incomplete block design in the south of the Netherlands: 25 GPs (7 GP practices) received reminders about prescriptions for antibiotics and asthma/COPD, 28 GPs (7 GP consultations) received reminders about cholesterol prescriptions. Prescription guidelines were integrated into the computerized GP information system. MEASUREMENTS: Both performance indicators and prescription volumes were calculated as the main outcome measures. Along with the individual volume measure, total scores were constructed on the volume measures by drug group (antibiotics, asthma/COPD, and cholesterol). RESULTS: The variation among general practitioners was found to be larger and more biased than expected. No differences were found between groups for the indicators and volumes related to the recommendations that advocate certain medications. Although there was a trend towards clinically relevant outcomes for prescription volumes that were supposed to decrease, the difference in total score between groups was not significant. For antibiotic prescriptions that were supposed to decrease, the total score for the intervention group was 28.2 (95% CI: 20.8-44.5) prescriptions per 1,000 patients per GP, while for the control group it was 39.7 (95% CI: 29.7-64.1). group (p 0.2). For asthma/COPD prescriptions that were supposed to decrease, the total score for the intervention group was 1.1 (95% CI: 0.6-2.6) prescriptions per 1,000 patients per GP, while which was 2.2 (95% CI: 1.4-4.3) for the control group (p 0.1). In three specific recommendations (on quinolones for cystitis, corticosteroids for COPD and antibiotics for acute sore throat) significant differences were found. CONCLUSIONS: This study was found to be underpowered due to high inter-physician variation in prescribing behavior. However, computerized reminders sometimes have a favorable effect in restricting certain drugs that are not or are no longer indicated in general practice.
