title: The effect of the educational intervention on the registration of medical diagnoses among residents
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Studies indicate that the use of interventions that include education can improve medical record documentation and reduce incomplete files. Since physicians play a crucial role in documenting medical records, the researchers intend to examine the effect of the educational intervention on physicians' performance and knowledge of the principles of medical diagnostic recording among residents of the Hormozgan University of Medical Sciences (HUMS). METHODS: This quasi-experimental study was conducted in 2010 on 40 specialty residents (from the specialties of internal medicine, obstetrics and gynecology, pediatrics, anesthesiology, and surgery) at Hormozgan University of Medical Sciences. During a workshop, guidelines were given for recording diagnostic information related to the given specialty. Before and after the intervention, five medical records were selected from each resident to assess the physician's performance in documenting medical records. Through a questionnaire, the knowledge of the doctors before and after the intervention was investigated. The data was analyzed through the one-way ANOVA test. RESULTS: The change in doctors' knowledge before and after education was not statistically significant (p = 0.15). The behavior of the residents did not have statistically significant changes during the three phases of the study. CONCLUSION: The diversity of related factors that contribute to the quality of the documentation forces the portfolio of strategies to improve the clinical history. Employing a combination of best practice efforts, including educating clinicians from the beginning of the internship and applying a specific strategy focus on problem areas and existing gaps, can improve clinicians' behavior on documentation of medical records.

title: The effect of external feedback in the management of hospitalized Medicare patients with congestive heart failure
abstract: The purpose of this study was to compare the effect of 2 feedback strategies on compliance with congestive heart failure (CHF) guidelines. Thirty-two hospitals in 4 states were randomized to receive either a written feedback intervention (low-intensity intervention [LII]) or an intervention that includes feedback, a physician liaison, and quality improvement tools (high-intensity intervention [HII]). ]). CHF quality indicators were evaluated and quality managers were interviewed at baseline and remeasurement. No significant changes in quality indicators were found as a result of any of the interventions. Seventy-eight percent of quality managers indicated that implementation of the hospital project had not started until shortly before the remeasurement. HII quality managers perceived the CHF project as significantly more successful compared to LII quality managers (63% versus 13%, P < .01). Assessing the effects of external feedback on practice behavior requires sufficient time for organizational and individual clinical change to occur. Medical liaisons can play a role in facilitating this change.

title: The effect of mobile phone text message reminders on Kenyan health workers' adherence to malaria treatment guidelines: a cluster-randomized trial.
abstract: Background Malaria case management practices of healthcare workers often differ from national guidelines. We evaluated whether text message reminders sent to health workers' mobile phones could improve and maintain their adherence to treatment guidelines for outpatient pediatric malaria in Kenya. Methods From March 6, 2009, to May 31, 2010, we conducted a cluster-randomized controlled trial at 107 rural health facilities in 11 coastal and western districts of Kenya. Using a computer-generated sequence, health facilities were randomly assigned to the intervention group, in which all health workers received text messages on their personal mobile phones about malaria case management for 6 months, or to the control group, in which health workers did not receive any text messages. The health workers were not blinded to the intervention, although the patients did not know whether they were in an intervention or control center. The primary outcome was correct management with artemether-lumefantrine, defined as a dichotomous composite indicator of treatment, dispensing, and counseling tasks according to Kenyan national guidelines. The primary analysis was by intention to treat. The trial is registered with Current Controlled Trials, ISRCTN72328636. Findings 119 health workers received the intervention. Case management practices were assessed for 2,269 children in need of treatment (1,157 in the intervention group and 1,112 in the control group). The intention-to-treat analysis showed that the correct handling of artemether-lumefantrine improved by 23 7 percentage points (95% CI 7 6–40 0"; p=0 004) immediately after the intervention and at 24 5 percentage points -points (8 1-41 0;" p=0 003) 6 months later. Interpretation In resource-limited settings, malaria control programs should consider the use of text messaging to improve the case management practices of health workers.

title: The effect of orthodontic referral guidelines: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To develop and evaluate the effectiveness of referral guidelines for the referral of orthodontic patients to consultant orthodontists and specialists. DESIGN: Single center randomized controlled trial with random assignment of referral guidelines for orthodontic treatment to general dentists. SETTING: Hospital orthodontic departments and specialist orthodontic clinics in Manchester and Stockport. SUBJECTS: General dentists and patients referred for orthodontic treatment. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: Appropriateness of referral, defined as whether the patient was accepted for orthodontic treatment. RESULTS: Referral guidelines did not reduce the number of inappropriate referrals. CONCLUSIONS: Referral guidelines for orthodontic referrals did not influence the behavior of general dentists. More research is needed on the optimal methods of dissemination and implementation of referral guidelines for use in the general dental service.

title: The effect of record-based performance feedback via short text messages and traditional postal letters on parenteral steroid prescription by general practitioners: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background It is conjectured that providing feedback on physicians' prescribing behavior improves the quality of drug prescriptions. However, the effectiveness of feedback provision and the mode of feedback delivery are not well understood. The aim of this study was to assess and compare the effect of traditional text messages (TPL) and short text messages (STM) on the parenteral steroid (PS) prescription behavior of general practitioners. Methods In a single-blind randomized controlled trial, 906 general practitioners (GPs) who had at least 10 monthly prescriptions were randomly recruited into two intervention and one control study arms with 1:1 allocation, stratified by percentage of prescriptions. The intervention consisted of the provision of 3 feedback messages containing prescription rates in TPL and STM (in the first two arms) versus the control arm (CG) with an interval of 3 months between these messages. We calculated the Defined Daily Dose (DDD) of PS for each GP, each month, and compared between the 3 arms, before and after the interventions. The primary expected outcome was to reduce participants' prescription of parenteral steroids. The study was conducted at the Kerman Social Security Organization in Iran. Results A total of 906 GPs were selected for the trial, but only 721 of them (TPL = 191, STM = 228, CG = 302) were recruited for the first feedback. The average age of the GPs was 44 years and 59% of them were men. The DDDs of parenteral steroids prescribed at baseline were similar (TPL = 121.62, STM = 127.49, CG = 115.68, P > 0.5). At the end of the study, the DDDs in the TPL and STM arms were similar (TPL = 104.38, STM = 101.90, P > 0.9), but the DDDs in each intervention arm were statistically significantly lower than in each intervention arm. CG (CG = 156.17, P < 0.0001). ). Being in the TPL and STM arms resulted in a 36.1 and 41.7 unit decrease in DDD, respectively, compared to the control arm (P < 0.02 and P < 0.005) after the one year duration of the study. Conclusion Feedback from TPLs and STMs on prescribing performance effectively reduced PS prescribing by GPs. STM, being a cheap and fast tool, is potentially powerful and efficient for drug prescription rationalization.

title: The effect of the Vermont Diabetes Information System on emergency room and inpatient use: results of a randomized trial.
abstract: Objective To describe the effect of the Vermont Diabetes Information System (VDIS) on hospital and emergency department use. Data Source Database of downloads throughout the state. Study design Randomized controlled trial of a decision support system for 7412 adults with diabetes and their 64 primary care providers. Data Collection/Data Extraction Charges and dates of hospital admissions and emergency department care in Vermont over an average of 32 months of observation. Data from New York hospitals were not available. Results Patients randomized to VDIS were admitted to the hospital less frequently than control subjects (0.17 admissions vs. 0.20"; P = 0.01) and had lower hospital charges ($3,113 vs. $3,480; P = 0.019). utilization (0.27 visits vs. 0.36; P < 0.0001) and charges ($304 vs. $414; P < 0.0001).The intervention was particularly effective in men and in older subjects. Apart from data limitations that tended to reduce the apparent effect of the system, this randomized controlled trial showed that VDIS reduces hospitalization and emergency department utilization and expense.

title: The efficacy and cost-effectiveness of dark chocolate consumption as preventive therapy in people at high risk of cardiovascular disease: best-case analysis using a Markov model.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To model the long-term effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of daily dark chocolate consumption in a population with metabolic syndrome at high risk for cardiovascular disease. DESIGN Best case analysis using a Markov model. SETTING Australian Study of Diabetes, Obesity and Lifestyle. PARTICIPANTS 2013 hypertensive people who met criteria for metabolic syndrome, with no history of cardiovascular disease and who did not receive antihypertensive treatment. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Treatment effects associated with dark chocolate consumption derived from published meta-analyses were used to determine the absolute number of cardiovascular events with and without treatment. Costs associated with cardiovascular events and treatments were applied to determine the potential amount of funding required for dark chocolate therapy to be considered cost-effective. RESULTS Daily consumption of dark chocolate (polyphenol content equivalent to 100 g of dark chocolate) can reduce cardiovascular events by 85 (95% confidence interval 60 to 105) per 10,000 population treated for 10 years. $A40 (£25"; Ã¢â€šÂ¬31;" $42) could be profitably spent per person per year on prevention strategies using dark chocolate. These results assume 100% compliance and represent the best case scenario. CONCLUSIONS The hypotensive and hypocholesterolemic effects of dark chocolate consumption are beneficial in the prevention of cardiovascular events in a population with metabolic syndrome. The daily consumption of dark chocolate could be an effective cardiovascular preventive strategy in this population.

title: The effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of psychological treatments delivered by lay counselors for harmful and dependent drinking and moderate to severe depression in primary care in India: PREMIUM study protocol for randomized controlled trials
abstract: BACKGROUND: The leading mental health causes of the global burden of disease are depression in women and alcohol use disorders in men. A major obstacle to the implementation of evidence-based psychological treatments in primary care in developing countries is the lack of availability of qualified human resources. The aim of these trials is to assess the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of two psychological treatments developed for the treatment of depression and alcohol use disorders in primary care in India. METHODS/DESIGN: This study protocol is for parallel group randomized controlled trials (Healthy Activity Program for Moderate to Severe Depression, Counseling for Harmful and Dependent Drinking Alcohol Problems) in eight primary health centers in Goa, India. . Adult primary care attendees will be screened with the Patient Health Questionnaire for depression and, in men only, the Alcohol Use Disorder Screening Test for problem drinking. Attendees who test positive will be invited to participate; men who test positive for both disorders will be invited to participate in the Alcohol Problem Counseling trial. Those who consent will be allocated in a 1:1 ratio to receive the respective psychological treatment plus enhanced usual care or enhanced usual care only using a computer-generated allocation sequence stratified by primary health center and, for depression, by sex. treatments will be administered by lay counsellors, for a maximum period of three months Primary outcomes are severity of disorder and remission rates at three months after enrollment and, for the alcohol counseling trial, Alcohol use and the impact of alcohol use on daily life Secondary outcomes include disorder severity and remission rates at 12 months, disability scores, suicidal behavior and economic impact, and cost-effectiveness at three and 12 months. months. 500 participants with depression and 400 participants with harmful use of alcohol will be recruited. Primary analyzes will be by intention to treat. DISCUSSION: These trials may offer a new approach to the treatment of moderate to severe depression and problem drinking in primary care that is potentially scalable as it relies on the provision of a single group of lay counsellors. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Both trials are registered with the International Society for Clinical Trials Registration (Healthy Activity Program registration number ISRCTN95149997; Counseling for Problems with Alcohol registration number ISRCTN76465238).

title: The Efficacy of a Published Information Package on the Beliefs and Behavior of Musculoskeletal Professionals: The UK Musculoskeletal Chiropractors, Osteopaths and Physiotherapists Low Back Pain Management (COMPLEMENT) Randomized Trial
abstract: STUDY DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. OBJECTIVE: To investigate the effect of a printed information pack on low-back pain (LBP)-related beliefs and reported behavior of musculoskeletal professionals (chiropractors, osteopaths and musculoskeletal physiotherapists) across the UK. SUMMARY OF BACKGROUND DATA: A substantial proportion of musculoskeletal clinicians in the UK do not follow current LBP guideline recommendations. METHODS: In total, 1758 physicians were randomly assigned to either of the 2 study arms. One arm was sent a printed information packet containing the guideline recommendations for the management of low back pain (n = 876) and the other received no intervention (n = 882). The primary outcome measure consisted of 3 'quality indicators' (activity, work and bed rest) related to a vignette of a patient with low back pain, in which responses were dichotomized into 'inconsistent with guidelines' or 'consistent with the guidelines. The secondary outcome was practitioners' low back pain-related beliefs, as measured by the Healthcare Providers' Pain and Impairment Relationship Scale. Outcomes were measured at baseline and at 6 months. RESULTS: Follow-up at 6 months was 89%. Changes in behavior reported on quality indicators were as follows: activity, odds ratio (OR) 1.29 (95% confidence interval, 1.03-1.61), and number needed to treat (NNT) , 19 (15-28)"; work, OR 1.35 (1.07-1.70) and NNT 19 (14-29) and bed rest, OR 1.31 (0.97-1.76) and NNT 47 (33-103) -Consistent behavior in at least 1 of the 3 quality indicators was 10 (9-14). information (P = 0.002), but only to a small degree (mean difference, 0.884 scale points; 95% confidence interval, 0.319-1.448). CONCLUSION: Printed educational material may change low-back pain-related beliefs and reported behaviors of musculoskeletal professionals toward practice that is more in line with guideline recommendations.

title: Efficacy of an intervention to increase the delivery of preventive care by community health clinicians: a study protocol from a nonrandomized, multiple-base trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The leading behavioral risks for the most common causes of mortality and morbidity in developed countries are smoking, poor nutrition, hazardous alcohol use, and physical inactivity. Evidence, guidelines and policies support the provision of routine health care to prevent these risks within primary care settings. Despite the potential offered by community health services for the provision of such preventive care, the limited evidence available suggests that it is provided at suboptimal levels. This study aims to assess the effectiveness of a multi-strategic practice change intervention to increase the provision of routine physician preventive care in a community health service network. METHODS/DESIGN: A multi-site study will be conducted involving all 56 community health facilities in a single health district in New South Wales, Australia. Facilities will be assigned to one of three administratively defined groups. A 12-month practice change intervention will be implemented at all facilities in each cluster to facilitate physician risk assessment of eligible clients, and provision of brief physician counseling and referral to those identified as "at risk". The intervention will be implemented in a non-random sequence in the three groups of facilities. Repeated cross-sectional measures of preventive care medical provision for four individual risks (smoking, poor nutrition, hazardous alcohol use, and physical inactivity) will be performed continuously for the three groups of facilities for 54 months through telephone interviews. Interviews will be conducted with randomly selected clients who have visited a community health facility in the past two weeks. Data collection will start 12 months before the implementation of the intervention in the first group and will continue for six months after the end of the intervention in the last group. As a secondary source of data, pre- and post-intervention telephone interviews will be conducted with randomly selected samples of physicians from each group of facilities to assess informed provision of preventive care and acceptability of the intervention and implementation of practice change. DISCUSSION: The study will provide novel evidence regarding the ability to increase the provision of routine preventive physician care through a network of community health centers. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australian Clinical Trials Registry ACTRN12611001284954 UNIVERSAL TRIAL NUMBER (UTN): U1111-1126-3465.

title: The Efficacy of Computer Reminders in Improving Point-of-Care Test Quality Assessment in General Practice: A Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: Background Computer reminders are increasingly being applied in an effort to improve quality and patient safety. However, research is still needed to establish the effectiveness of different types of reminders in various settings. This study aimed to assess the efficacy of computerized reminders in improving adherence to a quality assessment scheme for point-of-care testing in general practice. Method The study was conducted as a randomized controlled crossover trial among general practices in the Capital Region of Denmark. The intervention consisted of sending computerized reminders (ComRem) to the practices that did not adhere to the recommendations of the hemoglobin and glucose split test guideline. Practices were randomized into two groups. During the first follow-up period, one of the groups received the ComRem intervention together with the general implementation activities (GIA), while the other group received only the GIA. For the second follow-up period, the intervention was switched between the two groups. Results were measured as adherence to the split test procedure. Results A total of 142 practices were randomized to the early intervention group and 144 practices to the late intervention group (the control group at the first follow-up period). In the first intervention period, the mean number of split tests performed in the RemCom group increased from 1.22 to 3.76 (out of eight possible tests), while the mean number of split tests increased from 1.11 to 2.35 in the GIA target group only. (p = 0.0059). After crossover, a similar effect of reminders was observed. Furthermore, the evolution of the outcome measures over time showed a strong effect of computer reminders beyond the intervention periods. Conclusion There was a significant effect of computerized reminders on adherence to the quality assessment scheme for point-of-care tests. Therefore, computerized reminders appear to be useful in supporting the implementation of relatively simple procedures for quality and safety.

title: The effectiveness of computerized clinical guidelines in the care process: a systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical practice guidelines have been developed with the aim of improving the quality of care. The implementation of computerized clinical guidelines (CCG) has been supported by the development of computerized clinical decision support systems. This systematic review assesses the impact of CCG on the process of care compared to non-computerized clinical guidelines. METHODS: The specific characteristics of GCC were studied through an extensive search of the scientific literature, consulting electronic databases: Pubmed/Medline, Embase and Cochrane Controlled Trials Register. Multivariate logistic regression was performed to assess the association of GCC characteristics with a positive effect on the care process. RESULTS: Forty-five articles were selected. Logistic modeling showed that Automatic Provision of Electronic Recommendations as Part of Clinical Workflow (Odds Ratio [OR]= 17.5"; 95% Confidence Interval [CI]: 1.6-193.7) and Year of publication (OR = 6.7; "95% CI: 1.3-34.3) were statistically significant predictors. CONCLUSIONS: From the research carried out, we can conclude that after the implementation of the CCG, significant improvements are shown in the care process. Our findings also suggest to physicians, managers, and other health care decision makers which features of CCG could improve the structure of the computerized system.

title: The effectiveness of interventions to improve laboratory request patterns among primary care physicians: a systematic review.
abstract: Background Laboratory tests are an integral part of daily primary care practice, with approximately 30% of patient encounters resulting in a request. However, research suggests that a large proportion of requests is not in the best interest of patient care and is avoidable. The objective of this systematic review was to conduct a comprehensive search of the literature for studies evaluating the effectiveness of interventions to improve the use of laboratory tests by primary care physicians. Methods A search of PubMed, Cochrane Library, Embase and Scopus (from inception to 09/02/14) was performed. The following study designs were considered: systematic reviews, randomized controlled trials (RCTs), controlled clinical trials (CCTs), controlled before-after studies (CBAs), and interrupted time series analyzes (ITS). Study quality was assessed using a modified version of the Effective Practice and Organization of Care (EPOC) checklist. The population of interest was primary care physicians. Interventions were considered if they aimed to improve laboratory testing in primary care. The outcome of interest was a volume of laboratory tests. Results In total, 6,166 titles and abstracts were reviewed, followed by 87 full texts. Of these, 11 papers were eligible for inclusion in the systematic review. This included four RCTs, six CBAs, and one ITS study. The types of interventions examined included education, feedback, cues, education with feedback, feedback with cues, and changing order forms. The quality of the included studies varied: seven studies were judged to be at low risk of bias, three at unclear risk of bias, and one at high risk of bias. All but one study found significant reductions in the volume of evidence after the intervention, with effect sizes ranging from 1.2% to 60%. Due to heterogeneity, a meta-analysis was not performed. Conclusions Interventions such as educational strategies, feedback and changing test request forms can improve the efficient use of laboratory tests in primary care";" however, the level of evidence is quite low and the quality is poor. The reproducibility of findings from different laboratories is also difficult to determine from the literature. Some standardization of both interventions and outcome measures is required to allow formal meta-analysis.

title: The efficacy of SPARX, a computerized self-help intervention for adolescents seeking help for depression: a randomized controlled noninferiority trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess whether a new computerized cognitive behavioral therapy intervention (SPARX, Thinking Smart, Positive, Active, Realistic, Factor X) could reduce depressive symptoms in help-seeking adolescents as much or more than treatment as usual. DESIGN Multicenter randomized controlled non-inferiority trial. SCENARIO 24 primary health care sites in New Zealand (youth clinics, general practices and school counseling services). PARTICIPANTS 187 adolescents aged 12 to 19 years seeking help for depressive symptoms, not at increased risk of self-harm, and deemed in need of treatment by their primary care physicians: 94 were assigned to SPARX and 93 to treatment as usual. INTERVENTIONS Computerized cognitive behavioral therapy (SPARX) comprising seven modules administered over a period of between four and seven weeks, versus treatment as usual comprising primarily personal counseling provided by trained counselors and clinical psychologists. RESULTS The primary outcome was change in score on the Childhood Depression Rating Scale-Revised. Secondary outcomes included response and remission on the Childhood Depression Rating Scale-Revised, change scores on the Reynolds Adolescent Depression Rating Scale 2nd Edition, Mood and Feelings Questionnaire, Kazdin Hopelessness for Children, Spence Childhood Anxiety Scale, Pediatric Quality of Life Satisfaction and Enjoyment Questionnaire, and Overall Satisfaction with Treatment ratings. RESULTS 94 participants were assigned to SPARX (mean age 15.6 years, 62.8% women) and 93 to treatment as usual (mean age 15.6 years, 68.8% women). 170 adolescents (91%, SPARX n=85, treatment as usual n=85) were evaluated post-intervention and 168 (90%, SPARX n=83, treatment as usual n=85) were evaluated at 3-month follow-up. Per-protocol analyzes (n = 143) showed that SPARX was non-inferior to treatment as usual. Post-intervention, there was a mean reduction of 10.32 in SPARX and 7.59 in treatment as usual in raw scores on the Childhood Depression Rating Scale-Revised (between-group difference 2.73, 95% confidence interval : -0.31 to 5.77"; P = 0.079) Remission rates were significantly higher in the SPARX arm (n = 31, 43.7%) than in the treatment-as-usual arm (n = 19, 26.4%) (difference 17.3%, 95% confidence interval 1.6% to 31.8%; P = 0.030) and response rates did not differ significantly between the SPARX arm (66.2%, n = 47) and the usual treatment arm (58.3%, n = 42) (difference 7.9%, -7.9% to 24%; P = 0.332).All secondary measures supported non-inferiority. Intention-to-treat analyzes confirmed these findings.The improvements were maintained at follow-up.The frequency of adverse events classified as "possibly" or "probably" related to the intervention did not differed between groups (SPARX n = 11"; usual treatment n = 11). CONCLUSIONS SPARX is a potential alternative to usual care for adolescents presenting with depressive symptoms in primary care settings and could be used to address some of the unmet demand for treatment. TRIAL REGISTRATION Australian and New Zealand Clinical Trials ACTRN12609000249257.

title: The effectiveness of workplace interventions to increase physical activity and decrease sedentary behavior in adults: protocol for a systematic review.
abstract: BACKGROUND: A physically active lifestyle plays a preventive role in the development of various chronic diseases and mental health conditions. Unfortunately, few adults achieve the minimum amount of physical activity and spend a lot of time sitting. The development of specific interventions to increase active life among adults is an important public health effort. A plausible context for reaching adults is the workplace. This systematic review aims to review the effectiveness of workplace interventions to increase physical activity and decrease sedentary behavior in the workplace. METHODS: A professional advisory group will work in collaboration with the research team to inform the systematic review and knowledge mobilization. Fifteen electronic databases will be searched to identify studies examining the effectiveness of workplace interventions on physical activity and sedentary behaviour. All experimental designs and observational studies (non-experimental intervention studies) that meet the study criteria will be included. Studies examining generally healthy, employed adult participants will be included in the review. Interventions will focus on increasing physical activity and/or decreasing sedentary behavior from the individual to the normative level. The primary outcome variables will be reported or observed physical activity and/or sedentary behavior in the workplace. Secondary outcomes will include variables ranging from return on investment to quality of life. Study quality will be assessed for risk of bias following the protocol identified in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions and supplemented by guidelines developed by the Cochrane Practice and Organization of Effective Care group, using RevMan. The quality of the evidence will be assessed using the recommendation classification, evaluation, development and evaluation approach. Where appropriate, meta-analyses, forest plots, and crop plots will be used to assess the direction, size, and consistency of intervention effect across studies using similar intervention strategies. Follow-up knowledge mobilization activities and products will be developed to support the use of this knowledge in practice. DISCUSSION: This protocol document describes a systematic review evaluating the effectiveness of various types of workplace interventions to increase physical activity and decrease sedentary behavior at work. Collaboration with an advisory group of potential knowledge users throughout the process postulates a greater use and scope of the information obtained from this systematic review by knowledge users. SYSTEMATIC REVIEW RECORD: PROSPERO CRD42015019398.

title: The effects of a postgraduate course on the opioid prescribing patterns of general practitioners
abstract: BACKGROUND: The aim of this study is to assess whether a single cancer palliative care workshop, which included medication prescription information, had an effect on general practitioners' opioid prescribing patterns in daily practice. METHOD: Opioid prescription figures for 68 general practitioners who had participated in the workshop were aggregated from the Regional Fund for Diseases computer system. Prescription figures for one year before and one year after the workshop were compared, and a control group of non-participants was included. RESULTS: This study showed limited effectiveness of a cancer palliative care workshop on morphine prescription figures for general practitioners in daily practice. This limited effect did not match the results of a pre- and post-workshop questionnaire that assessed the attitudes of the practitioners themselves. CONCLUSION: A single workshop cannot effect substantial changes in prescription behaviors. Possibilities for more reinforcements are discussed.

title: The effects of a theory-based training program on nurses' self-efficacy and behavior for smoking cessation counseling
abstract: BACKGROUND: Cigarette smoking continues to put Americans at risk of serious health consequences and premature death. Nurses play an important role in disseminating smoking cessation interventions to patients in the hospital. However, nurses are not prepared for smoking cessation advice. METHOD: A quasi-experimental design was used. Fifteen nurses participated in the "5 A's" Clinical Practice Guideline brief intervention training program, completing a survey over three time periods. RESULTS: There were several statistically significant changes in the dependent variables of self-efficacy and behavior for advice to stop smoking. CONCLUSION: The results of this study support further research and theoretical training for nurses.

title: The effects of lowering LDL cholesterol with statin therapy in people at low risk of vascular disease: meta-analysis of individual data from 27 randomized trials.
abstract: BackgroundStatins lower LDL cholesterol and prevent vascular events, but their net effects in people at low risk of vascular events remain uncertain.";" Background Statins lower LDL cholesterol and prevent vascular events, but their net effects in people at low risk of vascular events remain uncertain.

title: The effects of maternal depression, anxiety, and perceived stress during pregnancy on preterm birth: a systematic review.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Experiencing psychological distress such as depression, anxiety, or perceived stress during pregnancy may increase the risk of adverse birth outcomes, including preterm birth. Clarifying the association between exposure and outcome may improve understanding of risk factors for prematurity and guide future clinical and research practices. OBJECTIVE: The objectives of the present review were to outline the evidence on the risk of preterm birth associated with antenatal depression, anxiety, and stress. METHODS: Four electronic database searches were conducted to identify published quantitative, population-based, multicenter cohort studies and randomized controlled trial studies focusing on the association between antenatal depression, anxiety and stress, and preterm birth. in English between 1980 and 2013 FINDINGS: Of 1469 electronically retrieved articles, 39 peer-reviewed studies met the final selection criteria and were included in this review following the PRISMA and MOOSE review guidelines. Information was extracted on the characteristics of the study";" depression, anxiety, and perceived stress were examined as separate and combined exposures. There is strong evidence that antenatal distress during pregnancy increases the likelihood of preterm birth. CONCLUSION: Complex pathways of significant interactions between depression, anxiety and stress, risk factors, and preterm birth were indicated both directly and indirectly. The effects of pregnancy distress were associated with spontaneous but not medically indicated preterm birth. Health professionals who provide perinatal care to women, such as obstetricians, midwives, nurses, and mental health specialists, should provide appropriate support to women experiencing psychological distress to improve outcomes for both mothers and children. for babies.

title: The Effects of Pay-for-Performance Programs on Health, Health Care Use, and Care Processes
abstract: Background: The benefits of pay-for-performance (P4P) programs are uncertain. Purpose: To update and expand on a previous review examining the effects of P4P programs directed at the physician, group, manager, or institutional level on the process of care. and patient outcomes in outpatient and inpatient settings. Data sources: PubMed from June 2007 to October 2016"; MEDLINE, PsycINFO, CINAHL, Business Economics and Theory, Business Source Elite, Scopus, Faculty of 1000 and Gartner Research from June 2007 to February 2016. Selection of studies: Trials and observational studies in inpatient and outpatient settings reporting process of care, health, or utilization outcomes Data extraction: Two investigators extracted data, assessed study quality, and rated the strength of the evidence. Data Synthesis: Among 69 studies, 58 were conducted in outpatient settings, 52 reported process-of-care outcomes, and 38 reported patient outcomes. Low-strength evidence suggested that P4P programs in outpatient settings may improve pro- short-term (2 to 3 years) care cessation outcomes, while data on longer-term effects were limited. The positive studies were done in the UK, where incentives were higher than in the US. The greatest improvements were seen in areas where initial performance was poor. There was no consistent effect of P4P on intermediate health outcomes (low strength evidence) and insufficient evidence to characterize any effect on patient health outcomes. In the hospital setting, there was low-strength evidence that P4P had little or no effect on patient health outcomes and a positive effect in reducing hospital readmissions. Limitation: Few methodologically rigorous studies; heterogeneous population and characteristics of the program and incentive objectives. Conclusion: Pay-for-performance programs may be associated with better care processes in outpatient settings, but consistently positive associations with better health outcomes have not been shown in any setting.

title: The Effects of Price Information on Physicians' Test Ordering Behavior: Ordering Diagnostic Tests.
abstract: This research evaluated the effects of providing clinicians with information about diagnostic test prices on their subsequent test-ordering behavior. The study population consisted of 36 second- and third-year residents and 23 clinical professors at three family medicine centers affiliated with the Department of Family Medicine, Wayne State University School of Medicine, Detroit, Michigan. Study participants were asked to review four case studies, each describing a patient with ambiguous symptoms, and to indicate on an attached test request form which tests they would order for each patient. Subjects were randomly assigned to a group that received test order forms on which diagnostic test prices were printed (price information group) or a group that received test order forms with no prices indicated (price information group). control). The results of the study show that for each of the four cases, the average number of diagnostic tests ordered was significantly lower in the price information group than in the control group. Our findings also show an average reduction in the cumulative cost of tests ordered per patient of 31.1 percent related to providing price information. The feasibility of regularly providing physicians with price information is discussed and reviewed in light of other approaches that have been developed to modify physician behavior when ordering diagnostic tests.

title: The effectiveness of an automated feedback system for general practitioners
abstract: OBJECTIVE: An automated feedback system was developed that produces feedback on general practitioners (GPs) non-adherence to accepted practice guidelines for ordering diagnostic tests. Before implementing the automated feedback system in daily practice, we evaluated the potential effect of the system on the test-ordering behavior of GPs. DESIGN: We used a randomized controlled trial with a balanced block design. SETTING: Five times six participating groups of GPs in a computer lab setting. INTERVENTION: GPs reviewed a random sample of 30 application forms that they completed earlier that year. If deemed necessary, they may make changes to the requested tests. The system then displayed critical comments about their non-compliance with the guidelines, as evident from the (updated) application forms. SUBJECTS: Twenty-four randomly selected physicians participated. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: The number of diagnostic tests ordered (17% with 95% confidence interval [CI]: 12-22%) and the fraction of tests ordered that were not in accordance with practice guidelines (39% with 95% CI: 28-51%) decreased due to feedback from the automated feedback system. Physicians accepted 362 (50%) of the 729 reminders. IMPLICATIONS: Although our experiment cannot predict the actual effect size of the automated feedback system in daily practice, the observed effect can be viewed as the maximum achievable.

title: The efficacy of computerized reminders in external quality assessment for point-of-care testing in Danish general practice: rationale and methodology for two randomized trials.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Point-of-care tests (POCT) are increasingly used in general practice to assist general practitioners (GPs) in the management of patients with disease. However, low adherence to quality guidelines in terms of split testing procedures has been observed among GPs in parts of the Capital Region of Denmark. Computerized reminders embedded in GPs' electronic medical records (RemComs) may facilitate improved quality control behaviour, but more research is needed to identify which types of reminders work and when. The general objective of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of ComRem in improving compliance with quality guidelines by general practitioners. This article describes the rationale and study methods that constitute this research project. METHODS/DESIGN: The study is carried out as two randomized controlled trials (RCTs) among general practices in two districts of the Capital Region of Denmark. These districts contain a total of 739 GPs in 567 practices with a total of 1.1 million patients assigned to practice rosters. In the first RCT (RCT A), ComRem is compared with reminder postcards. In the second RCT (RCT B), ComRem is compared with usual activities (without reminders) in a crossover approach. In both studies, outcomes are measured by the number of split tests received by the laboratory. CONCLUSIONS: This study will contribute to the knowledge about the efficacy of ComRem in primary care. Since the study does not explore the perceptions and experiences of GPs regarding ComRem, we will later carry out a qualitative survey focused on these aspects. TEST RECORDS: Study A: ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT01152151 Study B: ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT01152177.

title: The efficacy of visual cues to improve hand hygiene compliance
abstract: BACKGROUND: Guidelines governing the hand hygiene (HH) behavior of healthcare workers (HCWs) are well established. Despite the known dangers of healthcare-associated infections for both healthcare workers and patients, hand hygiene compliance (HHC) rates remain appallingly low . To evaluate a potential solution to this ongoing challenge, we used a simulated patient encounter in an actual hospital room to test the efficacy of individual HH triggers. METHODS: One hundred fifty HCWs (75 physicians and 75 nurses) participated in this study and were randomly assigned to one of five equal-sized groups. Each participant performed a standardized patient-focused physical examination and was expected to maintain HH before and after the examination. Using two rooms in a medical-surgical unit at a tertiary care university hospital, various signals were employed and the impact on HHC was recorded before and after the examination. In the control group, the hand sanitizer dispenser was in its usual location (Baseline). In one group, the dispenser was relocated to "Line-of-Sight" upon entering the room"; in another, flashing lights were placed on the dispenser in its usual location (Baseline & Flicker); and in a third group, the dispenser was relocated to line-of-sight and flashing lights (Line-of-Sight & Flicker) were placed. In the last group, a large warning sign (Warning Sign) was placed on the door, informing the health care provider that the room was under electronic surveillance and that failure to perform HHC would trigger an alarm Data were analyzed using a generalized linear model to perform repeated measures logistic regression, P<0.05 was considered statistically significant.RESULTS:In the control group (baseline), the HHC rates before and after the examination were 36.7% and 33.3%, respectively.All interventions improved preintervention HHC compared to baseline (line of sight = 53.3%, baseline and flicker = 60%, line of sight and flicker = 66%, warning signal = 93.3%), but only Sight & Flicker line of sight and Warning Sign produced a statistically significant increase in pre-examination HHC (P = 0.022 and P < 0.001, respectively). Only the warning signal produced a statistically significant increase in HHC after examination (P < 0.001). CONCLUSIONS: Visual cues can improve HHC, but their efficacy varies. A warning signal reporting a surveillance system with subsequent reports of noncompliance resulted in the most significant improvement at HHC. The use of a standardized patient in an actual hospital room was a useful tool to assess the impact of various interventions designed to improve HHC and patient safety.

title: The use of ward opinion leaders for continuing education in the hospital.
abstract: Opinion leaders (OLs) are members within a social group with significant social influence over others. Urinary catheter care guidance was introduced in three groups (A, B, and C) of two randomized wards. Two OLs per ward were identified by nurses from groups A and B, using a sociomemetic method. For education, in-service lectures were used for 30% of nurses and OL tutorials for all nurses in group A; OL tutorials at B, lectures at C, and ward nurses were in turn responsible for educating newcomers of student nurses. Before and After the educational program, the frequency of practicing the guideline was evaluated by surveying 30% of the randomly selected nurses and by direct observation of incorrect practices. A student questionnaire on the guide was also conducted. For the three measurement methods, the best results were in group A followed by B and C;" and the differences for the three groups were significant (p<.05). This indicates that continuing education in the hospital can be carried out effectively by enlisting the OLs in the room.

title: The growing pandemics of obesity and sedentary lifestyle. A call to action for doctors
abstract: Obesity and a sedentary lifestyle are growing national and global epidemics that warrant increased attention from physicians and other health professionals. These intricately linked conditions are responsible for an enormous burden of chronic disease, impaired physical function and quality of life, at least 300,000 premature deaths, and at least $90 billion in direct health care costs annually in the United States alone. Physicians are on the front lines, but these conditions receive minimal attention during a typical office visit. Clinicians are often overwhelmed by these challenges, citing the absence of clear guidelines and practical tools, minimal training in behavior modification strategies, and lack of time as reasons not to address them. This report provides a "call to action" with step-by-step guidance specifically targeting the critical role of physicians and other health professionals in curbing these dangerous epidemics. Requiring only a few minutes of a clinician's time to implement, this action plan will facilitate more effective intervention related to obesity and inactivity and should have a favorable impact on public health.

title: The Esperance Primary Suicide Prevention Project
abstract: BACKGROUND: Suicide has been a major community concern in Esperance, a geographically isolated port on the south coast of Western Australia. OBJECTIVES: To assess the effect of three evidence-based initiatives for the primary prevention of suicide: (i) providing "suicide awareness" sessions for health, education, and social service staff members"; (ii) limiting the sale of pain relievers over-the-counter drugs (aspirin and acetaminophen) to packages containing less than the minimum lethal dose;" and (iii) implement Commonwealth media guidelines on media reporting of suicides. METHODS: Changes in knowledge, awareness, attitudes, comfort, and use were assessed before and after each intervention, using standardized and pro forma instruments derived from previous work, such as the Suicide Prevention Training Manual. Juvenile and Suicide Intervention Belief Scale. Percentage changes in the number of retail outlets selling over-the-counter pain relievers in amounts less than life-threatening (less than 8 g of acetaminophen or aspirin) were also measured. Media representatives were interviewed for their perceptions of the Commonwealth Suicide Reporting Guidelines, and were encouraged to consult the project team before reporting on suicide-related issues. RESULTS: The baseline survey illustrated that mental health staff and general practitioners were more aware of suicide issues, suicide risk factors, and professional and ethical responses than staff from other services, and were more willing to raise the issue with a person at risk. . Thirty-three subjects participated in the suicide awareness training, of whom 21 (66%) answered questionnaires. There were significant increases in awareness of suicide-related issues and risk factors, as well as reported levels of knowledge of professional and ethical responses and levels of comfort, competence, and confidence in helping a person at risk. Only three media representatives were aware of the Commonwealth Department of Health Guidelines for reporting suicides and only one believed the guidelines influenced their reporting. Local newspapers subsequently contacted investigators to verify that their reporting complied with the guidelines. On access to painkillers, one in seven retailers agreed to implement the strategy (pending agreement from other retailers), another stated increased awareness of the danger of painkillers, and three said they would try to control excessive quantities sold to An individual. CONCLUSIONS: Local initiatives can improve the awareness and knowledge of staff in suicide risk assessment, as well as the local media. These should be complemented by Commonwealth or state level initiatives to bring about changes in state media or OTC painkiller sales.

title: The ethical evaluation of innovative therapies: living donor liver transplantation
abstract: Liver transplantation is the treatment of choice for many forms of liver disease. Unfortunately, the scarcity of cadaveric donor livers limits the availability of this technique. To improve liver transplant availability, surgeons have developed the ability to remove a portion of the liver from a living donor and transplant it into a recipient. Some living donor liver transplants have been performed around the world. Our purpose was to review the ethics of living-donor liver transplants and to propose guidelines for the procedure prior to its introduction in the United States. We use a "research ethics consultation" process that involves a collaboration between clinical investigators and clinical ethicists. We concluded that it was ethically appropriate to perform a living-donor liver transplant in a small series of patients on a trial basis, and published our ethical guidelines in a medical journal before the procedure was introduced. We recommend this prospective and public approach to the introduction of other innovative therapies in medicine and surgery.

title: The ethics of medicine: an annotated bibliography of recent literature
The European Psychiatric Association (EPA) guideline on the treatment and prevention of suicide
abstract: UNLABELED: Suicide is a major public health problem in the WHO European Region, causing more than 150,000 deaths a year. Suicidal crisis: Acute intervention must begin immediately to keep the patient alive. DIAGNOSIS: An underlying psychiatric disorder is present in up to 90% of people who commit suicide. Comorbidity with depression, anxiety, substance abuse, and personality disorders is high. For successful prevention of suicidality, proper diagnostic procedures and appropriate treatment for the underlying disorder are essential. TREATMENT: Existing evidence supports the efficacy of pharmacological treatment and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) in the prevention of suicidal behaviour. Some other psychological treatments show promise, but the evidence supporting them is currently insufficient. Studies show that antidepressant treatment decreases the risk of suicide among depressed patients. However, the risk of suicidal behavior in depressed patients treated with antidepressants exists during the first 10-14 days of treatment, which requires careful monitoring. Short-term complementary medication with anxiolytics and hypnotics is recommended in case of anxiety and insomnia. TREATMENT of children and adolescents with antidepressants should only be carried out under the supervision of a specialist. Long-term treatment with lithium has been shown to be effective in preventing both suicide and attempted suicide in patients with unipolar and bipolar depression. Clozapine TREATMENT is effective in reducing suicidal behavior in patients with schizophrenia. Other atypical antipsychotics show promise, but more evidence is needed. TREATMENT Team: Multidisciplinary treatment teams that include psychiatrist and other professionals such as psychologist, social worker and occupational therapist are always preferable, as the integration of pharmacological, psychological and social rehabilitation is recommended, especially for patients with chronic suicidal tendencies. Family: The suicidal person regardless of age should always be motivated to involve the family in treatment. Social support: Treatment and psychosocial support are recommended, as most suicidal patients have problems with relationships, work, school, and lack functioning social networks. SAFETY: A safe home, public and hospital environment, without access to suicide means, is a necessary strategy in suicide prevention. Each treatment option, medication prescription, and patient discharge from the hospital must be carefully weighed against the risks involved. Staff training: General practitioner (GP) training is effective in suicide prevention. It improves the treatment of depression and anxiety, the quality of care provided and attitudes towards suicide. Continuing education that includes discussions of ethical and legal issues is necessary for psychiatrists and other mental health professionals.

title: The evaluation of a personalized intervention to improve the management of suspected viral encephalitis: protocol for a cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background Viral encephalitis is a devastating condition for which late treatment is associated with increased morbidity and mortality. Clinical audits indicate substantial room for improvement in detection and treatment. Ideally, improvement strategies should be tailored according to identified needs and barriers to change. The aim of the study is to assess the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a personalized intervention to improve secondary care management of suspected encephalitis. Methods/Design The study is a two-arm cluster randomized controlled trial with assignment by graduate deanship. Participants from 24 hospitals nested within 12 postgraduate deanships in the United Kingdom (UK) were identified. We develop a multifaceted intervention package that includes core and flexible components with integrated behavior change techniques selected based on identified needs and barriers to change. The primary outcome will be a composite of the proportion of patients with suspected encephalitis who receive a timely and appropriate diagnostic lumbar puncture within 12 hours of hospital admission and treatment with acyclovir within 6 hours. We will collect outcome data pre-intervention and up to 12 months post-intervention from patient records. Statistical analysis at the cluster level will be blind to allocation. An economic evaluation will estimate the cost-effectiveness of the intervention from the perspective of the health service.

title: The evolution of current medical and popular attitudes towards ultraviolet light exposure: part 3
abstract: In the 1930s, attitudes toward ultraviolet (UV) light exposure began to change significantly within the medical profession. UV radiation has been promoted as healthy since the turn of the century, and particularly after the discovery of its role in vitamin D metabolism. Increasingly, however, attention would be focused on the risks of light exposure UV from sunlamps and sunbathing. During this time, the American Medical Association established guidelines for the approval of UV lamps and the appropriate therapeutic uses of phototherapy. The landmark experiments by Findlay and others, in which malignant skin tumors were induced in rodents after exposure to ultraviolet lamps or sunlight, would lead to widespread recognition of the carcinogenicity of ultraviolet radiation. The role of sunlight in the etiology of skin cancer was increasingly mentioned in popular magazine articles in the 1940s and 1950s. There was also a rapid growth in the sunscreen industry, although product efficacy remained unknown. very variable. In the 1950s, interest developed in the use of 8-methoxypsoralen ("the tanning pill") and dihydroxyacetone ("suntan lotion in a bottle"). Despite the known risks of UV exposure and attempts by doctors and other health professionals to educate the public and modify behavior, tanning has remained stubbornly popular. Today, excessive exposure to ultraviolet light is recognized as the leading cause of approximately 1.3 million cases of skin cancer in the United States each year.

title: The Evolution of Informed Consent in American Medicine
The expert consensus guideline series. Optimization of the pharmacological treatment of psychotic disorders. Introduction: methods, comment and summary
abstract: OBJECTIVES: An increasing number of atypical antipsychotics are available for clinicians to choose from in the treatment of psychotic disorders. However, a number of important questions related to drug selection, dosage and dose equivalence, and the management of inadequate response, adherence problems, and relapse have not been adequately addressed by clinical trials. To aid in clinical decision making, a consensus survey of expert opinion on the pharmacological treatment of psychotic disorders was conducted to address questions that have not been definitively answered in the research literature. METHOD: Based on a literature review, a written survey with 60 questions and 994 options was developed. Approximately half of the options were rated using a modified version of the 9-point RAND scale for rating appropriateness of medical decisions. For the other options, the experts were asked to write the answers (for example, average dose) or to check a box to indicate their preferred answer. The survey was sent to 50 national experts in the pharmacological treatment of psychotic disorders, of whom 47 (94%) completed it. When analyzing responses to items rated on the 9-point scale, consensus on each option was defined as a nonrandom distribution of scores using the chi-square "goodness-of-fit" test. We assigned a categorical rating (first line/preferred option, second line/alternative option, third line/generally inappropriate) to each option based on the 95% confidence interval around the mean rating. Guidance tables indicating preferred treatment strategies for key clinical situations were then developed. RESULTS: The expert panel reached a consensus on 88% of the options rated on the 9-point scale. Experts overwhelmingly approve of atypical antipsychotics for the treatment of psychotic disorders. Risperidone was the first choice for first-episode and multiple-episode patients, while the other newer atypicals were classified as first-line or high as second-line, depending on the clinical situation. Clozapine and an atypical long-acting injectable (when available) were other high second-line options for patients with multiple episodes. The expert's dosing recommendations closely matched the drug labels, and his estimates of dose equivalence between antipsychotics followed a linear pattern. Experts considered 3 to 6 weeks an adequate antipsychotic trial, but would wait slightly longer (4 to 10 weeks) before making a major change in treatment regimen if there is a partial response. The experts recommended trying to improve response by increasing the dose of atypical and depot antipsychotics before switching to a different agent";" there was less agreement on increasing the dose of conventional antipsychotics before the switch, probably due to concerns about side effects at higher doses. If a decision is made to switch due to inadequate response, risperidone was the expert's first choice to switch, regardless of which drug was initially tried. Although there was some disparity in expert recommendations regarding how many agents to try before switching to clozapine, expert responses suggest that switching to clozapine should be clozapine was also the antipsychotic of choice for patients with suicidal behaviour. When changing oral antipsychotics, experts considered cross-titration to be the preferred strategy. When switching to an injectable antipsychotic, the experts stressed the importance of continuing the oral antipsychotic until therapeutic levels of the injectable agent are achieved. The experts considered psychosocial interventions as the first choice strategy for patients who were partially compliant, while pharmacological interventions were the first choice for patients with clear evidence of non-compliance. However, because it can be difficult to distinguish between partially compliant and noncompliant patients, the editors recommended combining psychosocial and pharmacological interventions to improve adherence whenever possible. When patients relapse due to adherence problems or if there is any question about adherence, experts recommend the use of a long-acting injectable antipsychotic and would select an injectable atypical when this option becomes available. Experts would also consider the use of an injectable atypical antipsychotic (when available) in many clinical situations that do not involve compliance issues. The experts highlighted the importance of monitoring health problems, especially obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular problems, HIV risk behaviors, medical complications of substance abuse, heavy smoking and its effects, hypertension and amenorrhea , in patients receiving treatment with antipsychotics. Although many patients are prescribed adjuvant therapies, multiple antipsychotics, and combinations of different drug classes (eg, antipsychotics plus mood stabilizers or antidepressants) in an effort to improve response, experts gave little support to either of these strategies, with the exception of antidepressants for patients with dysphoria/depression, antidepressants or ECT for patients with suicidal behavior, and mood stabilizers for patients with aggression/violence. When asked about indicators of remission and recovery, experts considered acute improvement in psychotic symptoms to be the most important indicator of remission, while they considered more sustained improvement in multiple outcome domains (eg, functioning occupational/educational, peer relations, independent living) important in assessing recovery. CONCLUSIONS: The experts reached a high level of consensus on many of the key treatment questions in the survey. Within the limits of expert opinion and with the expectation that future research data will take precedence, these guidelines provide guidance for addressing common clinical dilemmas that arise in the pharmacological treatment of psychotic disorders. They can be used to inform clinicians and educate patients about the relative merits of a variety of interventions. Clinicians should keep in mind that no guideline can address the complexities involved in caring for each individual patient and that sound clinical judgment based on clinical experience should be used when applying these recommendations.

title: The expert consensus guideline series. Behavioral Emergency Treatment 2005
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Due to the inherent dangers and barriers to research in emergency settings, little data is available to guide clinicians on how best to manage behavioral emergencies. Key constructs, like agitation, are poorly defined. This lack of empirical data prompted us to conduct an expert opinion survey, the results of which were published in the 2001 Expert Consensus Guidelines on the Treatment of Behavioral Emergencies. Several second-generation (atypical) antipsychotics (SGAs) are now available. in new formulations to treat behavioral emergencies (eg, intramuscular [im]olanzapine and ziprasidone"; olanzapine and risperidone fast-dissolving tablets). Critical questions face the field. SGAs are significantly different from FGAs and from each other and have not been studied in unselected patients as FGAs have been Can SGAs be thought of as a class Do all antipsychotics have similar effects against agitation under different conditions and, if equally effective, what limits might their safety profiles?Should antipsychotics be used more specifically to treat psychotic conditions, while Benzodiazepines (BNZ) alone are used non-specifically? Few data are available on combinations of SGA and BNZ, and the findings on the traditional combination of haloperidol plus a BNZ may not be relevant to combinations with SGA. The culture is also evolving with more emphasis on patient involvement in treatment decisions. An international consensus has developed that calming rather than sedation is the appropriate endpoint of behavioral emergency interventions. We conducted a new expert opinion survey to update the recommendations from the previous survey. METHOD: A written survey of 61 questions (1020 options) was mailed to 50 experts in the field, 48 (96%) of whom completed it. The survey sought to define the level of agitation at which emergency interventions are appropriate, the scope of assessment based on urgency and the ability of patients to cooperate, guiding principles for selecting interventions, and appropriate physical and medication strategies in different levels of diagnostic confidence for a variety of tentative diagnoses and complicated conditions. A modified version of the RAND Corporation 9-point scale for rating appropriateness of medical decisions was used to rate most options. Consensus was defined as a non-random distribution of scores using the chi-square 'goodness of fit' test. We assigned a categorical ranking (first line/preferred, second line/alternative, third line/generally inappropriate) to each option based on the 95% confidence interval around the mean. The ratings were used to develop guidelines for preferred strategies in key clinical situations. This study received financial support from multiple sponsors, and the panel was blinded to sponsorship to reduce potential bias. Drug ratings were based on responses from only those respondents with direct experience with each drug. In reporting practice patterns, the panel was asked to respond based on actual data rather than estimates. RESULTS: The expert panel reached a consensus on 78% of the options rated on the 9-point scale. The responses suggest that clinicians can make tentative diagnoses with some confidence and that pharmacologic and nonpharmacologic interventions are differentially selected based on diagnosis and other salient demographic and medical characteristics. BNZs are recommended when no data is available, when there is no specific treatment (eg, personality disorder), or when they may have specific benefits (eg, intoxication). No SGA emerges as a nonspecific replacement for haloperidol"; instead, different SGAs are preferred in various circumstances based on current evidence. To the extent that haloperidol is recommended, it is almost always combined with a BNZ; haloperidol is only preferred alone in oral risperidone alone or in combination with a BNZ receives strong support in a variety of situations Oral olanzapine was rated very similarly to risperidone, with slightly higher ratings than risperidone in situations where studied (eg, schizophrenia, mania) and slightly lower ratings where not studied or safety may be a concern, there was less support for combining oral olanzapine with BNZ For oral treatment of schizophrenia-related agitation or mania, olanzapine alone, risperidone alone or in combination with a BNZ, and halo peridol plus a BNZ are first-line, with strong support also for combinations r divalproex with the antipsychotic for suspected mania. Oral ziprasidone and quetiapine generally received similar second-line ratings in most situations. If a parenteral agent is needed, im olanzapine alone received slightly more support than im ziprasidone alone; however, there was more support for im ziprasidone alone or in combination with a BNZ than for im olanzapine plus a BNZ, probably reflecting safety concerns. For example, for a provisional diagnosis of schizophrenia, the first-line parenteral options are im olanzapine or ziprasidone alone or im haloperidol or ziprasidone combined with a BNZ None of the newer parenteral formulations received as much support as the traditional agents (im BNZ, im haloperidol ) when no data is available or the diagnosis implies medical comorbidity or intoxication. When initial intervention with risperidone, ziprasidone, or haloperidol is unsuccessful, the panel recommended adding a BZD to the antipsychotic. However, when initial treatment with olanzapine or quetiapine is unsuccessful, increasing Perphenazine was consistently ranked as second line and droperidol and chlorpromazine as rec. He got third line ratings at all times. CONCLUSIONS: Within the limits of expert opinion and with the expectation that future research data will take precedence, these guidelines suggest that SGAs are now preferred for agitation in the setting of primary psychiatric illnesses, but that BNZs are preferred in other situations.

title: The Fit Family Challenge: A Pilot Primary Care Intervention for Childhood Obesity
abstract: BACKGROUND: Childhood obesity has increased dramatically for several decades, and the American Academy of Pediatrics has recommended primary care practices as ideal sites for identification, education, and implementation of therapeutic interventions. The aim of this study was to describe the implementation and outcomes of the Fit Family Challenge (FFC), a primary care-based intervention for childhood obesity. METHODS: A single-intervention pilot project training primary care practices in childhood obesity guidelines and implementation of a family-centered behavior modification curriculum. A total of 29 Colorado pediatric and family practice community practices participated. Participants included 290 patients, aged 6 to 12 years, with a body mass index (BMI) above the 85th percentile. The main outcome measure included the feasibility of implementing a childhood obesity program in primary care; secondary outcomes were changes in BMI percentile, BMI z-scores, blood pressure, and changes in lifestyle factors related to childhood obesity. RESULTS: Implementation of FFC is feasible, statistically significant changes were observed for declines in BMI percentile and BMI z-scores for participants who completed 9 to 15 months of follow-up; "lifestyle factors related to Childhood obesity in known Spanish-speaking families and food insecurity were associated with shorter follow-up time (p < 0.01).CONCLUSIONS: A primary care-based childhood obesity intervention can result in significant clinical and lifestyle changes.

title: The future of British psychiatric hospitals
The Gestational Diabetes Management System (GooDMomS): Development, Feasibility, and Lessons Learned from a Web-Based, Patient-Informed Pregnancy and Postpartum Lifestyle Intervention
abstract: BACKGROUND: Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) contributes to the epidemic of diabetes and obesity in mothers and their children. The primary objective of this pilot study was to: 1) refine the GDM Management System (GooDMomS), a web-based behavioral pregnancy and postpartum intervention, and 2) assess the feasibility of the intervention. METHODS: In phase 1, ten semi-structured interviews were conducted with women experiencing current or recent GDM mellitus to collect pilot data on the interface and content of the web-based intervention and to solicit women's recommendations for improvements to improve the GoodMomS intervention site. Interviews were audio-recorded, transcribed, and independently reviewed for major themes using Atlas.ti v7.0. In phase 2, a single-arm feasibility study was conducted and 23 participants were enrolled in the GoodMomS program. Participants received web lessons, self-monitoring of weight and glucose, automated feedback, and access to a message board for peer support. The primary outcome was viability, including recruitment, retention, and acceptability. Secondary outcomes included the proportion of women whose gestational weight gain (GWG) was within the Institute of Medicine (IOM) guidelines and who were able to return to their prepregnancy weight after delivery. RESULTS: Feedback from the semi-structured interviews focused on: 1) the usability of the self-monitoring diary and online tracking system, 2) access to a secure and reliable social network for peer support, and 3) the ability to antenatal physicians to access the online diary for clinical management. Overall, 21 (91%) completed the pregnancy phase. 15/21 (71%) of the participants were within the Institute of Medicine (IOM) guidelines for GWG. Sixteen (70%) completed the postpartum phase. 7/16 (43%) and 9/16 (56%) of the participants returned to their pre-pregnancy weight at 6 and 30 weeks postpartum, respectively. CONCLUSIONS: This study documents the feasibility of the GoodDMomS program. The results may have implications for web technology in perinatal care and inform the current care paradigm for women with GDM. The findings support further research with recruitment of a larger sample of participants and comparison of results with intervention and standard care. TRIAL REGISTRATION: The study was registered with ClinicalTrials.gov on May 15, 2012 under protocol no. NCT01600534.

title: The impact of a body weight and physical activity (BeWEL) intervention initiated through a national colorectal cancer screening program: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the impact of a diet and physical activity intervention (BeWEL) on weight change in people with a body mass index >25 weight (kg)/height (m)(2) at increased risk of colorectal cancer and other obesity-related comorbidities. DESIGN Multicentre, parallel group, randomized controlled trial. SETTING Four health boards of the Scottish National Health Service. PARTICIPANTS 329 overweight or obese adults (aged 50 to 74 years) who had undergone a colonoscopy after a positive fecal occult blood test, as part of the national bowel screening program, and had a diagnosis of adenoma confirmed by histopathology. 163 were randomized to intervention and 166 to control. INTERVENTION Participants were randomly assigned to a control group (weight loss booklet only) or a 12-month intervention group (three face-to-face visits with a lifestyle counselor plus monthly 15-minute phone calls). A goal of 7% body weight loss was set, and participants received a personalized energy prescription (2,508 kJ (600 kcal) below what is needed to maintain weight) and body weight scales. Motivational interviewing techniques explored self-reported confidence, ambivalence, and weight-related personal values. Behavioral strategies included goal setting, identification of implementation intentions, self-monitoring of body weight, and counselor feedback on reported diet, physical activity, and weight change. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was weight change over 12 months. Secondary outcomes included changes in waist circumference, blood pressure, fasting cardiovascular biomarkers, and variables of glucose metabolism, physical activity, diet, and alcohol consumption. RESULTS At 12 months, data on the primary outcome were available for 148 (91%) participants in the intervention group and 157 (95%) in the control group. Mean weight loss was 3.50 kg (SD 4.91) (95% confidence interval 2.70 to 4.30) in the intervention group compared with 0.78 kg (SD 3.77 ) (0.19 to 1.38) in the control group. The group difference was 2.69 kg (95% confidence interval 1.70 to 3.67). Between-group differences were significant for waist circumference, body mass index, blood pressure, blood glucose level, diet, and physical activity. No reported adverse events were considered to be related to trial participation. CONCLUSIONS Significant weight loss can be achieved by a diet and physical activity intervention initiated within a national colorectal cancer screening program, which offers considerable potential for disease risk reduction in older adults. TRIAL REGISTRATION Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN53033856.

title: The impact of a nurse-led care program on physical and psychosocial events and parameters in heart failure patients with preserved ejection fraction: a randomized clinical trial in primary care in Russia
abstract: BACKGROUND: Disease management programs (DMPs) improve the quality of care for patients with heart failure (HF). However, only a limited number of trials have studied the efficacy of such programs for patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFPEF). OBJECTIVE: To estimate the impact of a nurse-led, structured patient education program and plan of care in general practice on outcome parameters and events in patients with PFEFI. METHODS: Single-blind randomized clinical trial with a six-month intervention and an additional 12-month follow-up. In the control group, patients (n = 41) were managed according to Russian national guidelines. Patients in the intervention group (n = 44) received education on individual lifestyle changes and cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factor modifications, home physical training, and weekly nursing consultations in addition to usual care . RESULTS: Six months after inclusion, patients in the intervention group had significant improvements in body mass index, waist circumference, six-minute walk test distance, total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein , left ventricular end-diastolic volume index, quality of life, and level. of anxiety After 18 months, there were 11 deaths (25%) or hospitalizations in the intervention group and 12 (29%) in the control group (P = 0.134). Cardiovascular mortality and readmission rate were not significantly reduced after six months of follow-up: hazard ratio was 0.47 (95% CI: 0.17-1.28"; P = 0.197). at 18 months, it was 0.85 (0.42-1.73;" p = 0.658).
