CONCLUSION: This primary care-based PMD for HFpEF patients improved patients' emotional status and quality of life, positively influenced body weight, functional capacity, and lipid profile, and attenuated cardiac remodeling.

title: The impact of cost screens on the primary care physician's ordering of laboratory tests.
abstract: BACKGROUND Physicians are under increased pressure to help control rising health care costs, yet they lack information about the cost implications of patient care decisions. OBJECTIVE To assess the impact of real-time display of laboratory costs on primary care physician ordering of common laboratory tests in the outpatient setting. DESIGN Interrupted time series analysis with a parallel control group. PARTICIPANTS Two hundred and fifteen primary care physicians (153 intervention and 62 control) who used a common electronic health record between April 2010 and November 2011. The setting was an alliance of five multispecialty group practices in Massachusetts. INTERVENTION The average Medicare reimbursement rate for 27 laboratory tests was displayed in an electronic health record at the time of order, including 21 lower cost tests (<$40.00) and six higher cost tests (>$40.00). ). MAIN MEASURES We compared the change in the slope of the monthly rate of laboratory orders between intervention and control physicians for 12 months before the intervention and 6 months after the intervention. We surveyed all intervention and control physicians at 6 months post-intervention to assess cost attitudes and cost visualizations. KEY FINDINGS Across 27 laboratory tests, intervention clinicians demonstrated a significant decrease in request rates compared to control clinicians for five (19%) tests. This included a significant relative decrease in order rates for four of 21 (19%) lower-cost lab tests and one of six (17%) higher-cost lab tests. The majority (81%) of physicians reported that the intervention improved their knowledge of the relative costs of laboratory tests. CONCLUSIONS Real-time display of cost information in an electronic health record can lead to a modest reduction in laboratory test ordering and is welcome. Our study demonstrates that electronic health records can serve as a tool to promote cost transparency and reduce the use of laboratory tests.

title: The impact of disseminating evidence-based guidelines for the assessment and treatment of major depression in a managed behavioral health care organization
abstract: This study assesses whether a managed behavioral health care organization can influence adherence to practice guidelines for the treatment of major depression in a randomized guideline dissemination trial. The guidelines were distributed to mental health clinicians (N = 443) under one of three conditions: (1) a general mailing of the guidelines to clinicians, (2) a mailing in which the guidelines were addressed to a patient starting treating with the doctor, and (3) not sending guidelines. The results showed no effect of guideline dissemination as measured by patient and physician self-report and through episode characteristics derived from claims data, despite sentinel effects. The results also showed high rates of adherence to physician-reported guidelines that were not detected in the claims data, indicating significant undertreatment of depression. The results suggest that mental health systems should seek other outreach strategies to improve compliance with standards of care and raise the performance of independent physicians.

title: The impact of guidelines, standards and economic restrictions on clinical decision-making processes
abstract: The guidelines aim to improve clinical decision making. Unlike textbooks and reviews that seek to improve medical knowledge, guidelines seek to influence medical behavior. Scientific models of clinical decision making, such as theory of action and empirical data on the effects of guidelines, suggest that guidelines will not always achieve their goals, but may even lead to a deterioration in the quality of care medical. Therefore, there is a need for controlled clinical trials to investigate whether clinicians exposed to the guidelines achieve better patient outcomes than clinicians unaware of the guidelines. Guidelines should only be considered evidence-based if their positive effects have been empirically demonstrated.

title: The Impact of Computerized Physician Order Entry Antimicrobial Stewardship Program Led by Infectious Disease Specialists on Linezolid Use
The impact of medication adherence on lung health outcomes in cystic fibrosis
abstract: PURPOSE OF REVIEW: As new medicines continue to appear on the market to improve the health of people with cystic fibrosis (CF), it is increasingly important to address patient adherence. Currently, adherence to pulmonary medications is about 50% for people with CF. There has been recent research showing that poor adherence is linked to poorer health outcomes. This review summarizes recent research on the impact of adherence on lung health and highlights future areas of research and clinical practice to address this growing need. RECENT FINDINGS: Recent research has indicated that nonadherence is associated with increased hospitalizations and pulmonary exacerbations, lower baseline lung function, and longer length of stay. However, most research has been conducted using pharmacy refill records as an objective measure of adherence. Electronic medication monitoring provides more detailed information about usage patterns, which can directly inform clinical care. Furthermore, there have been few published clinical trials evaluating behavioral interventions to promote adherence. ABSTRACT: Given recent research linking adherence to lung health outcomes, there is a growing need to measure and assess adherence in clinical care. As new CF drugs are approved, methods for monitoring adherence also need to be developed and approved. Clinicians should continue to assess barriers to adherence so that interventions can be individually tailored to the needs of the patient.

title: The impact of telemetry-assisted monitoring in people with type 2 diabetes: study protocol for a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The prevalence of diabetes is increasing and current methods of treatment are unsustainable. Effective approaches are required to support self-management. The objective of this randomized controlled trial is to establish whether telemetric-supported monitoring of glycemic control and blood pressure results in reductions in glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c";" the primary outcome of a measure of long-term glycemic control) and the secondary outcomes of blood pressure. and weight among people with poorly controlled diabetes compared with a control group receiving usual care. METHODS/DESIGN: Design: multicenter, randomized controlled trial with integrated qualitative study. Setting: Primary care in the Lothian, Kent, Glasgow and Borders regions of the UK. Participants: people with type 2 diabetes and confirmed HbA1c >7.5% (58 mmol/mol). Intervention/comparison: Randomisation to intervention or control groups will be performed by the Edinburgh Clinical Trials Unit. Participants in the intervention group will be shown how to use blood glucose and blood pressure monitors and scales that use Bluetooth wireless technology to transmit readings via modem to a remote server. These participants will be asked to provide at least two weekly morning and evening blood glucose measurements and weekly weight and blood pressure measurements. Practice nurses will review measurements at least weekly and communicate with patients to adjust therapy according to guidelines and reinforce lifestyle advice. Participants in the control group will receive usual care. All participants will receive an individual education session. Follow-up: Measurements will be made at practices 9 months after randomization by research nurses blinded to allocation. The primary outcome measure is HbA1c and the secondary outcome measure is daytime systolic and diastolic blood pressure, weight, and cost per quality-adjusted life year. Analysis: Intention-to-treat analyzes will be performed. The sample size of 320 participants allows for 20% dropout and has 80% power at 5% significance to detect a 0.5% (6 mmol/mol) absolute drop in HbA1c in the intervention. The qualitative study will explore the experiences of patients and professionals using the intervention. TEST REGISTRATION: Test registration number ISRCTN71674628.

title: The importance of cardiovascular risk control in the treatment of hypertension: the role of ACE inhibitors and ARBs
The importance of doctor-patient communication in the care of somatizing patients
abstract: The term "somatization" refers to the manifestation of multiple somatic complaints not explained by organic changes. According to the literature, 15-25 percent of all medical visits are related to somatization. Because medical training does not place sufficient emphasis on evaluating the possible psychological antecedents of certain somatic symptoms, clinicians may feel powerless and make unwarranted diagnostic and therapeutic efforts. Patients may also feel helpless and frustrated, their anxiety and the intensity of their complaints may increase. Since stress is an important factor in the somatization process, reducing stress and improving coping are key elements of treatment guidelines for chronic diseases. Evidence-based interventions range from brief counseling and medication to cognitive and behavioral psychotherapy. Reattribution, a brief (10-30 minute) structured intervention that can be implemented in primary or secondary care, can in certain cases result in a significant decrease in somatic symptoms and anxiety.

title: The Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease Care Improvement Study: CAROL Improves Processes of Care and Quality of Life for COPD Patients in Primary Care: Study Protocol for a Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Swiss Ministry of Health launched a national quality program 'QualiCCare' in 2011 to improve medical care for COPD patients. The aim of this study is to determine if participation in the COPD quality initiative ('QualiCCare') improves adherence to processes and shows the impact on the care of patients with COPD and on the impact of COPD on the a person's life. METHODS: CAROL is a cluster randomized controlled trial with randomization at the general practitioner (GP) level. Thirty GPs will be randomly assigned to an intervention or control group of equal size. Each GP will address consecutively and regardless of the reason for the current consultation, patients aged 45 years or older, with a smoking history of >/= ten pack-years (PY). Patients with confirmed COPD (by spirometric evaluation) will be included in the study. GPs in the intervention group will receive 'QualiCCare' education, which addresses knowledge, decision-making and behavioral aspects, as well as the provision of care according to COPD quality indicators and key elements based on the evidence. In the control group, no educational intervention will be applied and COPD patients will be treated as usual. The study period is one year. The primary outcome measure is an aggregate score of relevant clinical processes that define elements in the care of patients with COPD: smoking cessation counseling, influenza vaccination, motivation for physical activity, appropriate pharmacotherapy, patient education, and collaborative care. . Given a power of 90% and an alpha level of significance of 5%, 15 GPs recruiting eight patients each in both arms of the study will be required. With an assumed dropout rate of 20%, it will be necessary to include 288 patients. DISCUSSION: It is important to develop and implement interventions that add value to COPD care considering quality and efficiency. Care pathways that modify clinicians' knowledge and behavior have the potential to improve care by transferring knowledge to clinical practice. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov: NCT01921556.

title: The influence of a physician-patient intervention program on dietary intake
abstract: BACKGROUND: Efficient dietary interventions are needed for patients with hypertension in clinical settings. OBJECTIVE: To assess the separate and combined influence of a medical intervention (MD-I) and a patient intervention (PT-I) on the dietary intake of patients with hypertension. DESIGN: A nested 2x2 design randomized controlled trial conducted over 18 months. PARTICIPANTS: A total of 32 physicians and 574 outpatients with hypertension. INTERVENTION: MD-I included training modules addressing the Seventh Report of the Joint National Committee on Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment of high blood pressure management and lifestyle modification guidelines. PT-I included lifestyle counseling to adopt the Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) eating pattern, reduce sodium intake, control weight, increase exercise, and moderate alcohol intake. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Dietary intakes were measured using the Block Food Frequency Questionnaire. Concordance with the DASH dietary pattern was estimated using a DASH score. STATISTICAL ANALYSIS: The main effects of MD-I and PT-I, and their interaction, were evaluated by analysis of covariance. RESULTS: After 6 months of intervention, MD-I participants significantly increased intake of potassium, fruit, juice, and carbohydrates; decreased fat intake; and improved overall diet quality as measured by the Healthy Eating Index. The PT-I intervention resulted in an increase in intake of carbohydrates, protein, fiber, calcium, potassium, fruits and fruit juices, vegetables, dairy products, and the Healthy Eating Index score, and a decrease in intake of fat, saturated fat, cholesterol, sodium, sweets and fats/oils/sweets. Furthermore, PT-I improved the overall DASH concordance score. Change in DASH score was significantly associated with changes in blood pressure and weight at 6 months. At 18 months, most changes reverted to baseline levels, including DASH score. CONCLUSIONS: Both MD-I and PT-I improved eating patterns at 6 months with some sustained effects at 18 months. Although all observed dietary changes were consistent with the DASH nutrient targets or food group guidelines, only the PT-I intervention was effective in improving the overall DASH concordance score. This finding affirms the role of medical nutrition therapy in long-term intensive interventions for hypertension risk reduction and weight control and underscores the need to develop maintenance strategies. Additionally, this study emphasizes the importance of collaboration between physicians, registered dietitians and other dietary professionals, and lay health advisors as they help patients make healthy behavior changes.

title: The influence of patient characteristics on the adequacy of surgical treatment for patients with breast cancer. Women's Oncology Project
abstract: BACKGROUND: Within the framework of a multi-year educational intervention sponsored by the Ministry of Health and regional health authorities, patterns of care provided to patients with breast cancer in Italian general hospitals were monitored to identify areas of practice whose quality needed improvement. DESIGN: Information on diagnostic and therapeutic procedures in 63 general hospitals in eight Italian regions performed on 1724 consecutive patients with breast cancer was collected retrospectively from medical records. The quality of care was assessed using a diagnostic and therapeutic score based on the observed degree of compliance with previously established courses of action. RESULTS: The mean value of the global diagnosis and staging score was 60%. About a third of surgeries (38%) were inappropriate: a quarter (24%) of patients with stage I-II disease underwent unnecessary radical surgery (ie, Halsted mastectomy) and limited surgery in patients with small tumors (ie, < or = 2 cm) was underutilized. Chronological age influenced physician behavior: older patients were more likely to have less intensive diagnostic workup and less appropriate surgical treatment (with more frequent performance of an unnecessary radical operation and less frequent use of surgical intervention). limited), regardless of their general condition. Health condition. The presence of one or more coexisting diseases was associated with a lack of axillary cleaning and less use of conservative surgery, regardless of age. CONCLUSION: In agreement with others, this study confirms the existence of a clinically important effect of patient age on diagnostic and therapeutic behavior and the use of unnecessarily radical surgical procedures. The document analyzes the implications of these findings for the next stage of the educational project, in which practical guidelines will be developed and implemented to improve the quality of care for breast cancer patients.

title: The intellectual structure and substance of the field of knowledge utilization: a longitudinal analysis of cocitation of authors, 1945 to 2004
abstract: Background It has been argued that science and society are in the midst of a far-reaching renegotiation of the social contract between science and society, with society becoming a much more active partner in knowledge creation. On the one hand, new forms of knowledge production are emerging and, on the other, both science and society are experiencing a rapid acceleration of new forms of knowledge utilization. At the same time, since World War II, the science behind the field of knowledge utilization has grown exponentially. There are few in-depth reviews of this field, and no comprehensive analysis has used bibliometric methods. Methods Using bibliometric analysis, specifically first author co-citation analysis, our group performed a domain analysis of the field of knowledge utilization, tracing its historical development between 1945 and 2004. Our purposes were to map the historical development of knowledge utilization as a field, and identify the changing intellectual structure of its scientific domains. We analyzed more than 5,000 articles using citation data extracted from Web of Science?. Search terms were combinations of knowledge, research, evidence, guidelines, ideas, science, innovation, technology, information theory and use, utilization, and acceptance. Results We provide an overview of the intellectual structure and how it changed over six decades. The field did not become large enough to be represented by a co-citation map until the mid-1960s. Our findings demonstrate vigorous growth from the mid-1960s to 2004, as well as the emergence of specialized domains reflecting different groups of intellectual activity and thought. Until the mid-1980s, the main domains focused on the diffusion of innovation, technology transfer and knowledge utilization. Starting slowly in the mid-1980s and then growing rapidly, a fourth scientific domain emerged, evidence-based medicine. The field is dominated in every decade by one individual, Everett Rogers, and by one paradigm, the diffusion of innovation. Conclusion We conclude that the received view that the social science disciplines are in a state where no accepted set of principles or theories guide research (ie, they are pre-paradigmatic) could not be supported for this field. Second, we document the emergence of a new domain within the field of knowledge utilization, evidence-based medicine. Third, we conclude that Everett Rogers was the dominant figure in the field and, until the rise of evidence-based medicine, his portrayal of the mainstream model was the dominant paradigm in the field.

title: The Irritable Bowel Syndrome Outcomes Study (IBSOS): rationale and design of a randomized, placebo-controlled trial with 12-month follow-up of self-administered versus physician-administered CBT for moderate to severe irritable bowel syndrome
abstract: Irritable bowel syndrome is a common, often disabling gastrointestinal disorder, the full range of symptoms of which do not have satisfactory medical or dietary treatment. One of the few empirically validated treatments includes a specific psychological therapy called cognitive behavioral therapy which, if available, is typically delivered over several months by trained professionals in tertiary care settings. There is an urgent need to develop more efficient versions of CBT that require minimal professional assistance but maintain the efficacy profile of clinical CBT. The Irritable Bowel Syndrome Outcome Study (IBSOS) is a multicenter, randomized, placebo-controlled trial to assess whether a self-administered version of CBT is at least as effective as standard CBT and more effective than an attention control in reducing symptoms. Central GI of IBS and its burden (eg, distress, impaired quality of life, etc.) in moderately to severely affected IBS patients. Additional objectives are to assess, at quarterly intervals, the durability of treatment response over a 12-month period; identify clinically useful patient characteristics associated with outcome as a way of understanding the subgroups of participants for whom CBT is most beneficial; identify theory-based mechanisms of change (active ingredients) that explain how and why CBT works;" and assess the economic costs and benefits of CBT. Between August 2010, when IBSOS began recruiting subjects, and February 2012 , IBSOS randomized 171 of 480 patients.The findings have the potential to improve the health of IBS patients, reduce their social and economic costs, conserve scarce healthcare resources, and inform evidence-based practice guidelines.

title: The Italian Diabetes and Exercise Study 2 (IDES-2): a long-term behavioral intervention for the adoption and maintenance of a physically active lifestyle
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physical activity (PA)/exercise has become an integral part of the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). However, current guidelines are difficult to implement in this population due to a number of barriers, most notably the lack of acceptable, feasible, and validated behavioral intervention strategies. The present manuscript reports the rationale, study design and methods, and design considerations of the Italian Diabetes and Exercise Study (IDES)-2, a randomized controlled trial testing the efficacy of a behavior change strategy to increase total daily physical activity and reduce sedentary time (SED-time) in patients with DM2. METHODS/DESIGN: Starting January 7, 2014, IDES_2 began enrolling 300 patients with known T2DM of at least 1 year's duration in three tertiary referral outpatient diabetes clinics in Rome. Additional requirements are age 40 to 80 years, body mass index 27 to 40 kg/m2, sedentary lifestyle and physical inactivity for at least 6 months, ability to walk 1.6 km unassisted, and eligibility after a cardiovascular evaluation. Patients are randomized by center and within each center, by age and type of diabetes treatment to the intervention or control group. Patients in the intervention group (INT) (n = 150) receive theoretical and practical exercise counseling consisting of aggregate behavior change techniques (one individual theoretical counseling session plus eight individual theoretical and practical exercise counseling sessions two times a week) once a year for 3 years. Patients in the control group (CON) (n = 150), receive standard care, including general practitioner recommendations for daily physical activity. The primary outcomes are total daily BP and SED time, objectively measured using an accelerometer. Secondary outcomes include physical fitness, modifiable cardiovascular risk factors, musculoskeletal disorders, well-being/depression, and health-related quality of life. DISCUSSION: The behavioral intervention strategy tested in the IDES_2 is based on strong theoretical foundations and uses various behavior change techniques, two factors that have been found to improve the effectiveness of behavioral intervention. In addition, physicians and exercise specialists have been specifically trained to advise/prescribe and supervise PA/exercise, respectively, in subjects suffering from metabolic disorders. Finally, the large sample size, the long duration of the study and the objective measurement of PA allow statistically significant and scientifically sound conclusions to be drawn about the viability and efficacy of this intervention in patients with DM2. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov"; NCT01600937;" October 10, 2012.

title: The sickness of knowledge
The lack, need, and opportunities for decision-making and informational tools to educate primary care physicians and women about breast cancer chemoprevention
abstract: This perspective on Vogel et al. (beginning on page 696 of this journal issue) examines the prescribing patterns of tamoxifen and raloxifene and why these agents are underused for breast cancer prevention despite their efficacy in definitive trials, approval of the Food and Drug Administration and the Guidelines Committee of the American Society of Clinical Oncology. endorsement for this purpose. The complexity of weighing the positives and negatives of medications and estimating net benefit is discussed, as well as the need for informational resources such as interactive Internet-based tools to enable better individualized decisions about chemoprevention options.

title: The legal personality of local research ethics committees

The LIFESTYLE study: costs and effects of a structured lifestyle program in overweight and obese subfertile women to reduce the need for fertility treatment and improve reproductive outcome. A randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: In the Netherlands, 30% of subfertile women are overweight or obese, and there is currently no agreement on fertility care for them. Data from observational and small intervention studies suggest that weight reduction will increase the chance of conception, decrease pregnancy complications, and improve perinatal outcome, but this has not been confirmed in randomized controlled trials. This study will assess the cost and effects of a six-month structured lifestyle program aiming at weight reduction followed by conventional fertility care (intervention group) compared to conventional fertility care alone (intervention group). control) in overweight and obese subfertile women. We hypothesize that the intervention will decrease the need for fertility treatment, reduce overweight-related pregnancy complications, and improve perinatal outcome. METHODS/DESIGN: Multicenter randomized controlled trial in subfertile women (age 18-39 years) with a body mass index between 29 and 40 kg/m2. Exclusion criteria are azoospermia, use of donor sperm, severe endometriosis, premature ovarian failure, pre-existing endocrinopathies or hypertensive disorders. achieved through a combination of diet, increased physical activity, and behavior modification. At six months, in case conception has not been achieved, these patients will start fertility treatment according to the Dutch fertility guidelines. In the control group, treatment will be started according to the Dutch fertility guidelines, regardless of the patient's weight. OUTCOME MEASURES AND ANALYSIS: The primary outcome measure is a single healthy fetus delivered after at least 37 weeks' gestation following vaginal delivery. Secondary outcome parameters, including pregnancy outcome and complications, percentage of women needing fertility treatment, clinical and ongoing pregnancy rates, body weight, quality of life, and costs. Data will be analyzed according to the intention-to-treat principle and a cost-benefit analysis will be performed to compare costs and health effects in the intervention and control group. DISCUSSION: The trial will provide evidence of the costs and effects of a lifestyle intervention aimed at weight reduction in overweight and obese subfertile women and offer guidance to clinicians in treating these patients. TEST REGISTRATION: Dutch Test Registration NTR1530.

title: Management of "psychogenic" orofacial pain
The management of patients with nicotine dependence: the role of general practitioners
abstract: The guardian needs a management of the disease of his patients who smoke. The questionnaires will help define the diagnosis and the degree of nicotine dependence, as well as the fingerprint of the patient's smoking history. The ICD-10 code and the Fagerstrom nicotine dependence test are used. There is no indicated therapy without the optimal motivation of the patient. Prochaska and DiClemente's transtheoretical model is widely accepted to separate the stage of motivation into precontemplation, contemplation, preparation, and action. Many other factors, such as previous experiences, catastrophic scenarios, self-efficacy, and therapeutic modality selection, are important to obtain the best result. 90% of a gatekeeper's job is minimal intervention. This means individually tailored arguments to change the patient's motivation to quit. The concept is defined in the rules of the five Rs with relevance, risks, rewards, obstacles and repetition. Following these criteria, the gatekeeper achieves a positive change in their motivation of up to 60% with a single minimal intervention. Smoking cessation guidelines around the world are very similar, showing an A-level rating for a synergy of behavioral therapy and nicotine replacement medication, bupropion, or varenicline. The selection of any other regimen is less efficient or anecdotal and leads to a greater loss of life expectancy for the smoker. The gatekeeper has the infrastructure, knowledge, and trust of his patient to act as a steward of the disease. A successful therapy is possible for six months with about seven consultations, the success rate is expected to be even higher than the values in drug studies. Smokers should be informed by health organizations to avoid autotherapy and seek help from specialists. The goalkeeper is an ideal candidate.

title: The MAURO study: baseline characteristics and compliance with the objectives of the guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Multiple Intervention and Audit in Renal Diseases to Optimize Care (MAURO) study was a cluster randomized controlled trial in 22 renal clinics that aimed to assess the efficacy of a multimodal quality improvement intervention in increasing adherence to recommendations for guidelines for the prevention of chronic kidney diseases. disease progression (CKD) and cardiovascular (CV) complications. The trial aimed to test whether this multimodal intervention improved adherence to recommended targets for a range of surrogate indicators relevant to blood pressure (BP) control, sodium intake, proteinuria, dyslipidemia, anemia, and calcium phosphate abnormalities. The trial also tested whether the same intervention slowed CKD progression and prevented CV complications in CKD patients. METHOD: Twenty-two renal clinics were randomized into 2 arms: an intervention arm applying a multi-method quality improvement intervention and a control arm providing standard care. Surrogate indicators were measured to assess blood pressure (BP) control, sodium intake, proteinuria, dyslipidemia, anemia, and calcium-phosphate abnormalities. RESULTS: Despite the fact that the vast majority of patients enrolled in this study (95%) were being treated with antihypertensive medications, baseline BP goals (specific for proteinuria level and diabetes) were met only in the 45% of non-proteinuric patients and in only 14% and 18% of proteinuric and diabetic patients, respectively. The use of diuretics in hypertensive patients was less than necessary, and about 80% of the patients presented a salt excretion >100 mmol/24 hours. Total cholesterol and low-density lipoprotein levels were off target in more than 40% of patients, but only about 60% of these were taking statins. The vast majority of CKD patients were obese or overweight. The proportion of smokers was relatively small (13%) and 37% of patients had quit smoking, indicating that patients are aware of the health risks of smoking. CONCLUSIONS: In our cohort, the management of modifiable risk factors for CKD and CV disease progression could be substantially improved.

title: The McMaster Curriculum: A Critique
The medical office of the 21st century (MOXXI): effectiveness of computerized support for decision-making in reducing inappropriate prescription in primary care.
abstract: Background: Drug-related adverse events are common in the elderly, and inappropriate prescribing is a preventable risk factor. Our goal was to determine whether inappropriate prescribing could be reduced when primary care physicians had computerized access to information on all prescriptions dispensed and automatic alerts of potential prescribing problems. Methods: We randomly assigned 107 primary care physicians with at least 100 patients aged 66 years or older (total 12,560) to a group that received computerized decision support (CDS) or a control group. CDS group physicians had access to information on current and past prescriptions through a dedicated computer link to the provincial senior drug insurance program. When the CDS software identified any of the 159 clinically relevant prescription problems, the physician received an alert that identified the nature of the problem, the possible consequences, and the alternative therapy. The rate of initiation and discontinuation of potentially inappropriate prescriptions was evaluated over a 13-month period. Results: In the 2 months prior to the study, 31.8% of patients in the CDS group and 33.3% of those in the control group had at least 1 potentially inappropriate prescription. During the study, the number of potentially inappropriate new prescriptions per 1,000 visits was significantly lower (18%) in the CDS group than in the control group (relative rate [RR] 0.82, 95% confidence interval [CI] 0.69-0.98), but differences between groups in the rate of discontinuation of potentially inappropriate prescriptions were significant only for therapeutic duplication by the study doctor and another doctor (RR 1.66, 95% CI : 0.99 to 2.79) and drug interactions caused by prescriptions written by the doctor. study physician (RR 2.15, 95% CI 0.98-4.70). Interpretation: Computerized access to comprehensive medication profiles and alerts on potential prescribing problems reduces the initiation rate of potentially inappropriate prescriptions, but has a more selective effect on discontinuation of such prescriptions.

title: The moderating effect of adherence-promoting interventions with clients on evidence-based practices for children and adolescents with mental health problems.
abstract: Poor adherence of children and adolescents to evidence-based psychosocial interventions remains a critical impediment to treatment efficacy. To maintain client adherence, researchers and clinicians have employed a number of adherence promotion strategies, from phone calls and letters to provide transportation and childcare costs to motivation-enhancing therapies. However, the influence of adherence promoters on intervention outcomes was not reported. This study examined the moderating effect of adherence promotion strategies in a survey and meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials of cognitive behavioral treatments, interpersonal therapy, and psychoeducation for children and adolescents with mental health problems (k = 33). The results indicated the type and intensity of effect sizes of the moderated study of adherence promoters according to client characteristics (age, gender, diagnosis). Preliminary findings suggest that men had higher effect sizes when more intensive adherence promotion efforts were employed. Adherence promotion efforts were associated with lower effect sizes for youth who were diagnosed with externalizing disorders. The results of this study suggest directions for future research to clarify clinical guidelines for maximizing retention in evidence-based psychotherapy.

title: The myADHDportal.com Improvement Program: An Innovative Quality Improvement Intervention to Improve the Quality of ADHD Care Among Community Pediatricians
abstract: Although the American Academy of Pediatrics has developed and disseminated clear evidence-based guidelines for ADHD care, community pediatricians often have difficulty implementing these guidelines. New strategies are needed to improve the quality of care that children with ADHD receive and to improve pediatricians' use of the AAP consensus guidelines. An evidence-based quality improvement intervention has been developed that effectively improves the quality of ADHD care provided by community pediatricians. To facilitate widespread dissemination of this intervention model, the entire intervention has been modified for online delivery. The intervention is called the myADHDportal.com Improvement Program. The full functionality of this online intervention is described, including the collection of online ADHD rating scales from parents and teachers and online communication between parents, teachers, and clinicians. In addition, the web portal integrates several innovative quality improvement features, including an online wizard to map the flow of ADHD patients, an online report card to monitor quality of care, and an online wizard to guide practices through the Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycle process. The combination of clinical utility and quality improvement tools facilitates the delivery of quality ADHD care and reduces many of the barriers to implementing AAP-recommended practice behaviors. The initial results with this intervention model are reviewed and the dissemination objectives are described.

title: The trial of Nazi doctors and the international ban on medical participation in torture
The need for research designed to support decisions in the provision of mental health services.
abstract: Seligman MEP (1995) argued that traditional approaches to mental health services research fail to provide useful information to consumers and professionals, particularly in an environment increasingly dominated by managed care. The authors recommend 4 guidelines for designing a research program so that the results can support the decisions of the main stakeholders (clients-families, professionals, service managers and policy makers): (a) The research must be specific and programmatic and encompass a strategy of complementary studies of efficacy, effectiveness and cost-effectiveness"; (b) the study design and the selection of measures must be sensitive to describe who, and in what context, is best served by what intervention; ( c) the design should inform interested parties about the type and amount of effort that is required to achieve a performance criterion;" and (d) the strategy should inform researchers how the information should be formatted to better support the decisions of key stakeholders.

title: The NIH report of their review of the Baby Fae case
The Nuremberg Code and medical research
abstract: It addresses the tensions between religious discourse and bioethics. Accessibility issues and meaning";" Address different concepts and moral language.

title: The Nuremberg Code and the Nuremberg Trials. a reassessment
abstract: The Nuremberg Code includes 10 principles to guide medical researchers in experiments with human beings. These principles, particularly the first principle on "voluntary consent", were based primarily on legal concepts because the medical codes of ethics in existence at the time of the Nazi atrocities did not address consent and other safeguards for human subjects. The American judges who presided over the proceedings did not intend the Code to apply only to the case before them, to be a response to the atrocities committed by Nazi doctors, or not to apply to the investigation being carried out. usually in medical institutions. . Instead, a careful reading of the sentence suggests that they wrote the Code for the practice of human experimentation whenever it takes place.

title: The potential of asthma adherence management to improve asthma guidelines
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Expert panel report 3 guidelines recommend that clinicians use adherence management strategies; however, the evidence for these interventions is weak. unnecessary morbidity. This review examines the components of an organized compliance management program that has been successful in uncontrolled trials in promoting compliance and reducing morbidity and cost. DATA SOURCES: A literature review was conducted in the following areas of asthma management: guidelines, cost, morbidity, compliance, monitoring, and communication skills. STUDY SELECTION: Studies that examined the outcomes of psychoeducational, behavioral, monitoring, and communication interventions. RESULTS: Studies using individual interventions by themselves were moderately effective in promoting adherence. Two uncontrolled studies of children with severe asthma, treated in inpatient and outpatient rehabilitation settings, used 4 intervention strategies to achieve a marked reduction in morbidity and cost. These strategies included: (1) objective adherence monitoring; (2) identification of the cause(s) of noncompliance; (3) delivery of "cause-specific" strategies; and (4) use of motivational interviewing communication skills to improve strategy delivery. CONCLUSION: Nonadherence remains a significant problem. Clinicians need an organized approach proven to improve adherence and reduce morbidity and cost Evaluation of effective methods in a controlled manner is warranted to increase the evidence of adherence management for future asthma guidelines.

title: The power of clinical trials and guidelines, and the challenge of conflicts of interest
The practice of ethics committees.
abstract: KIE: A short news note welcomes the publication in September 1984 of a useful report, Guidelines on the Practice of Ethics Committees in Medical Research, by the Royal College of Physicians of London. An important recommendation in the Guidelines is that committees should be notified of adverse or unforeseen circumstances arising from a study and should receive abstracts or reprints of publications. If it emerges that clinical research has been conducted without reference to ethical review concerns, the committee must convey the facts to the institution it serves.

title: The problem with the '5 whys'
abstract: The 'The Problem With...' series covers controversial topics related to efforts to improve the quality of health care, including widely advocated but deceptively difficult improvement strategies and pervasive problems that seem to resist solution.

title: The problem of survey research.
abstract: The problem of survey research argues against survey research as the primary source of reliable information. George Beam argues that all survey research instruments, all question types, including surveys, face-to-face interviews, and focus groups, produce unreliable and potentially inaccurate results. Because those who rely on survey research only see the answers to the questions, it is impossible for them, or anyone else, to evaluate the results. They cannot know if the answers correspond to the real behaviors of the respondents (objective phenomena) or to their true beliefs and opinions (subjective phenomena). Reliable information can only be acquired through observation, experimentation, multiple data sources, formal model building and testing, document analysis, and comparison. In fifteen chapters divided into six parts: The Pervasiveness of Survey Research, The Problem, Questioning Instruments, Question Environments, Askers, and Appropriate Research Designs and Methods, The Survey Research Problem demonstrates how the instruments of questioning, the environments in which the questions and answers take place. and the survey researchers themselves distort the results and thus make the answers unreliable. The last two chapters and appendices examine observation, other data collection methods, and research designs that can produce accurate or correct information, and show how reliance on survey research can and should be overcome. (PsycINFO Database Registry (c) 2016 APA, All Rights Reserved)

title: The Prussian regulation of 1900: first ethical standards for human experimentation in Germany
The QICKD study protocol: a cluster randomized trial to compare quality improvement interventions to reduce systolic BP in chronic kidney disease (CKD) in primary care
abstract: Background Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is a relatively new but common long-term condition, affecting 5-10% of the population. Effective management of CKD, with an emphasis on tight blood pressure (BP) control, reduces cardiovascular risk and delays CKD progression. There is currently an unprecedented increase in referrals to specialist renal services, often located in tertiary centres, inconvenience for patients and a waste of resources. National and international CKD guidelines include quality objectives for primary care. However, there have been no rigorous evaluations of strategies to implement these guidelines. This study aims to test whether quality improvement interventions improve primary care management of elevated blood pressure in CKD, reduce cardiovascular risk, and slow the progression of kidney disease Design Cluster Randomized Controlled Trial (CRT) Methods This three-arm CRT compares two well-established quality improvement interventions with usual practice. The two interventions comprise: provision of clinical practice guidelines with indications and audit-based education. The study population will be all people with CKD from general practices in eight locations in England. Randomization will be carried out at the level of general practices. The intended sample (three arms of 25 practices) powers the study to detect a difference of 3 mmHg in systolic BP between the different quality improvement interventions. An additional ten practices per arm will receive a questionnaire to measure any change in confidence in managing CKD. Follow-up will take place for two years. Results will be measured using routinely collected anonymous data extracted from the practice's computer systems. The primary outcome measure will be reduction in systolic BP in patients with chronic kidney disease and hypertension at two years. Secondary outcomes will include biomedical outcomes and quality markers, including physician confidence in CKD management. A small group of practices (n = 4) will participate in an in-depth evaluation of the process. We will use time series data to examine the natural history of CKD in the community. Finally, we will carry out an economic evaluation based on a comparison of the profitability of each intervention.

title: The quality of diabetes care for Gullah families in South Carolina
abstract: Empirical evidence from the Diabetes Control and Complication Trial (DCCT) suggests that maintaining normal glycemic control can prevent both microvascular and macrovascular disease in people diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) (DCCT, 1993). Adults with T2DM are also more likely to have hypertension (73% [HTN]), and patients with both are 2 to 4 times more likely to develop diabetic complications compared to the general population (CDC, 2005). The purpose of this descriptive study was to 1) describe the quality of diabetes care received by Gullah families who participated in the "Project Sugar" research study;" and 2) comparing Gullah's quality of care to the national sample on the Center for Disease Control (CDC) Diabetes Report Card using the two indicators of blood pressure and HbA1c. This was a secondary analysis of a main study comparing selected data from the CDC Diabetes Report Card, the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES III), and the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) . Sociodemographic and clinical data were obtained from 1,057 research participants (N = 1,057). Overall, compared to the national sample in the CDC Report Card, HbA1c greater than 9.5% mg/dL was higher among the Gullah (30.2% vs. 18%), and blood pressure greater than 140/90 mmHg was lower (29% vs 34%) among the participants. Nearly half of the Gullahs (45.9%) reported neurovascular complications, including foot pain, claudication, and kidney complications from kidney infection and dialysis (7.3%). Gullah study participants are at risk for diabetes-related complications. The results suggest a quality gap in diabetes care and also suggest health disparities in outcome measures. Optimal care that is consistent with clinical guidelines could have a significant impact in reducing complications and health disparities.

title: The rational patient and beyond: implications for treatment adherence in people with psychiatric disabilities.
abstract: Objective: Many people with psychiatric disabilities do not benefit from evidence-based practices because they often do not seek or fully adhere to them. One way psychologists have made sense of this health and rehabilitation decision process and subsequent behaviors (of which adherence might be seen as one) is by proposing a "rational patient"; that is, that decisions are deliberately made by weighing the perceived costs and benefits of intervention options. Research in social psychology, however, suggests limitations to a rational patient theory that impact health decision-making models. Design: The research literature was reviewed for studies of rational patient models and alternative theories with empirical support. It focused especially on models specifically related to decisions about rehabilitation strategies for psychiatric disability. Results: Notions of the rational patient evolved from various psychological models, including the health belief model, the motivation theory of protection and planned behavior theory. A variety of practical strategies evolved to promote rational decision making. However, research also suggests limiting ions to rational health deliberations. (1) Rather than being carefully and consciously considered, many health decisions are implicit and may occur outside of awareness. (2) Decisions are not always planned; often it is the immediate demands of a context rather than a prior balance of costs and benefits that have the greatest effect. (3) Cold cognitions often do not dictate the process; Emotional factors play an important role in health decisions. Each of these limitations suggests additional practice strategies that facilitate a person's health decisions. Conclusion: the old rational decision-making models must be supplanted by multi-process models that explain supradeliberative factors in decisions and health behaviors (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: The regulation of gene therapy research in competent adult patients, today and tomorrow: implications of the EU Directive 2001/20/EC
The results of the main clinical trials: critical evaluation, circulation of information and media coverage
abstract: The roundtable chose to focus its discussion on trials that, in terms of their importance, are likely to change medical practices and behavior. Such trials may be pre-marketing or post-marketing studies. For trial findings to result in a change in practice, they must be credible and meet basic methodological criteria. However, it is appropriate to complete that binary assessment by using an appropriate assessment checklist for each category of users, i.e. Regulatory Agency, prescribing physicians and patients, who are sometimes directly informed by the media. Communication. Roundtable members proposed the 'Giens 2003 checklist'. It consists of an interpretive semi-quantitative assessment checklist based on simple messages relevant to practice. Critical evaluation is a necessary step prior to the dissemination of the results to the different parties involved (health professionals, patients, patient associations, the media and the general public) and to the process of informing said parties in understandable but precise terms. . The practical implementation of the results, with a change in behavior and/or the issuance of guidelines, are later stages in which some lag is inevitable. The evaluation of implementation programs, together with an accurate analysis of the obstacles to changing medical practice, should, in the future, improve and accelerate the implementation of important results to optimize patient management.

title: The right material for early intervention in psychosis: time, attitude, place, intensity, treatment and cost
abstract: This article shares information about an exciting new approach in psychiatry. For the past 12 years, the authors have worked with young people experiencing their first episode of psychosis. It is clear that intervention in the early stages of psychotic illness allows clinicians to make a significant difference in the lives of young people and their families. This article summarizes current intervention strategies, which are considered best practice guidelines for early treatment.

title: The rise of private hospital care
The role of the clinical pharmacist in lipid control in dyslipidemic patients in northern Jordan
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this study is to investigate the effectiveness of introducing clinical pharmacy services in achieving target lipid profile in patients with dyslipidemia in northern Jordan. The study was carried out in a primary care center in northern Jordan. METHODS: One hundred fifty-two patients with dyslipidemia were randomized into intervention and control groups and followed up for a period of 6 months. Patients in the intervention group received intensive follow-up by a clinical pharmacist who worked closely with physicians to monitor lipid profiles in accordance with the third edition of the National Education Program Adult Treatment Panel recommendations. On Cholesterol, patients in the control group received standard medical care. Main outcome measure Percentage of patients at their target low-density lipoprotein cholesterol in the intervention group compared to the percentage of patients at their target low-density lipoprotein cholesterol in the control group at the end of the study. RESULTS: One hundred twenty-five patients completed the duration of the study. After 6 months, 94.5% of patients in the intervention group and 71.2% of patients in the control group reached their target low-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels (P value < 0.001, test of Pearson Chi-Square) compared to 24.7% and 28.8% respectively at baseline. Most pharmacists' recommendations (90.4%) were followed by physicians, and overall use of lipid-lowering agents increased to 91.8% in intervention group patients and 86.5% in intervention group patients. control compared to 69.9 and 78.8% respectively at baseline. CONCLUSION: The implementation of clinical pharmacy services in Jordan has improved the lipid profiles of dyslipidemic patients.

title: The role of GPs in increasing colorectal cancer screening compliance: a randomized controlled trial (Italy)
abstract: Objectives To assess the effect of provider (GPs versus hospital) on compliance with return of faecal occult blood testing. To analyze the characteristics of the general practitioner associated with high compliance among their beneficiaries. Methods A questionnaire on screening attitudes was mailed to 1192 physicians working in 13 districts of the Lazio region. We asked GPs to participate in a randomized trial, sampled 130 GPs, and approximately 1/10 of GP beneficiaries aged 50 to 75 years (n = 3657) were invited to be evaluated at the GP's office and 1/10 (3675) at the nearest gastroenterology center. Results 58.5% of physicians completed the questionnaire and 22.7% agreed to participate in the trial. Compliance in the GP arm was 50%, in the hospital arm 16% (RR 3.4"; 95% CI: 3.13-3.70). There was high variability in compliance obtained by GPs with more than 25 patients seen/day and those who incorrectly recommended colorectal cancer screening had lower compliance (OR 0.74, 95% CI: 0.57-0.95 and OR 0. 76, 95% CI: 0.59-0.97, respectively) Conclusions The participation of general practitioners in colorectal cancer screening can be very effective in improving compliance, but the effectiveness depends on their willingness to participate.

title: The role of nurses/social workers in the use of a multidimensional guide for the diagnosis of anxiety and challenging behavior in people with intellectual disabilities
abstract: AIMS AND OBJECTIVES: This study seeks to (1) investigate the impact of the implementation of the 'Diagnostic Guide for Anxiety and Challenging Behaviors in Clients with Intellectual Disability' on the knowledge and self-efficacy of nurses/social workers";" and (2) evaluate the role of nurses/social workers in the diagnostic process when applying the guideline. BACKGROUND: Nurses/social workers have extensive contact with clients with intellectual disabilities. Despite this key position, the contribution of nurses/social workers to the diagnosis of mental health problems and challenging behaviors is quite limited. The authors developed the multidimensional 'Diagnostic Guide for Anxiety and Challenging Behaviours'. In this article, the implementation of this guideline on the knowledge and self-efficacy of nurses/social workers is evaluated, as well as the role of nurses/social workers in the diagnostic process. DESIGN: This study employed a comparative multiple-case study design. METHODS: Qualitative and quantitative research methods. RESULTS: Working with the 'Diagnostic Guideline for Anxiety and Challenging Behaviors' led to a statistically significant increase in knowledge and self-efficacy among nurses/social workers in the experimental condition, compared to nurses/social workers in the experimental condition. control condition. Nurses/social workers and psychologists appreciated the more active contribution of nurses/social workers in the diagnostic process. CONCLUSIONS: Working with the guideline increased the knowledge and self-efficacy of the nurses/social workers and led to a more active participation of the nurses/social workers in the diagnostic process. RELEVANCE TO CLINICAL PRACTICE: After following a training program, nurses/social workers can effectively contribute to the diagnostic process in patients with anxiety and related challenging behaviors.

title: The role of relationship-based developmental supportive neonatal intensive care in strengthening outcomes for preterm infants
abstract: This article details the conceptual framework, clinical application, and efficacy of a relationship-based developmental support approach to neonatal intensive care called NIDCAP (Newborn Individualized Developmental Care and Assessment Program). Results of the approach with respect to child health and development, reduction of hospital costs, and family adjustment are reported. The approach is guided by a neurodevelopmental framework for understanding preterm infants and relies on the abilities of professionals to collaborate with each other and with families in support of infants' developmental, emotional, and medical well-being. The primary vehicle for clinical implementation is detailed behavioral observation with subsequent recommendations for individualized care based on the infant's current functioning and apparent developmental goals. A number of essential components of developmental care are described, including strategies for coordinated discharge planning and linkage to community services. The voices of individual clinicians highlight the process of moving from protocol-based care to relationship-based care.

title: The role of stimulants in the treatment of preschool children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder
abstract: Symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) can have an early onset, before the age of 6. Despite the significant number of preschool children who may be diagnosed with ADHD, there are limited controlled data available on pharmacological interventions that are increasingly being used in this population. A 1990 review showed that 34% of pediatricians and 15% of family physicians had prescribed psychostimulant medications for preschool children with ADHD, and pharmacoepidemiological studies indicate increasing use of stimulants in preschool children during childhood. 1990s. Unfortunately, only six controlled trials, with a total enrollment of less than 200 children, have been conducted using these drugs in preschool children. While these small studies provide some evidence of benefit from the use of methylphenidate in preschool children with ADHD, more data is critically needed. Practice parameters developed by the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry and the American Academy of Pediatrics provide some guidance on the diagnosis and treatment of young children with ADHD, but are based primarily on research in elementary school-aged children. The ongoing PATS (Preschool ADHD Treatment Study), funded by the National Institute of Mental Health, will provide important clinical guidance for diagnostic considerations and intervention strategies for children with ADHD ages 3 to 5 years. Pending publication of PATS data, clinicians must rely on developmental assessment skills, available standardized scoring instruments, multi-informant reporting of the child, and knowledge of the risks and benefits of treatments. pharmacological and behavioral drugs available, to be able to treat preschool children. children with ADHD effectively.

title: The role of surveillance in the management of small renal masses
abstract: Incidentally detected small renal masses (SRM) have increased significantly in recent years due to the widespread use of enhanced cross-sectional imaging. A significant number of incident SRMs are diagnosed in elderly patients who are more likely to undergo imaging for other medical problems. Historically, the natural history of SRMs has been poorly understood because most masses are surgically removed soon after diagnosis. Several SRM surveillance reports have been published in recent years. When followed conservatively with serial imaging, SRMs have variable growth rates averaging 0.28 cm/year, according to a recent meta-analysis. Larger series with longer follow-up are needed, but a significant number of small tumors appear to be indolent with a slow growth rate and a limited tendency to progress. The standard treatment to improve SRMs is surgery. Up to a third of tumors <4 cm surgically removed are histologically benign. The results of current surgical treatment of histologically confirmed renal cell carcinomas <4 cm are excellent, but this has not led to a decrease in mortality. Based on these considerations and the data available on the natural history of SRM, it seems reasonable to consider that we may be overtreating these lesions. This is especially true for elderly or unfit patients who have a reduced life expectancy. In these selected patients and in those who refuse active treatment, it seems reasonable to propose an initial period of active surveillance for incidental MRE, with late intervention for those tumors that are going to grow rapidly during follow-up. Percutaneous needle biopsies of renal tumors can be performed safely with the use of modern techniques and have the potential to characterize SRM in histological diagnosis, allowing a better selection of the conservative or active treatment that best suits each individual. individual patient.

title: The role of theory in research to develop and evaluate the implementation of patient safety practices
abstract: Theories provide a way to understand and predict the effects of patient safety practices (PSPs), interventions intended to prevent or mitigate health care harms or the risks of such harms. However, most published evaluations make little or no explicit reference to theory, making efforts to generalize findings from one context to another difficult. Theories from a wide range of disciplines are potentially relevant to PSP research. The theory can be used in research to explain clinical and organizational behavior, to guide the development and selection of PSPs, and to evaluate their implementation and mechanisms of action. A key recommendation from an expert consensus process is that researchers should describe the theoretical basis for the chosen intervention components or provide an explicit logic model of "why this PSP should work." a cumulative understanding of the nature of change.

title: The roles of the social worker and the nurse in case management: applying the Three Rs
abstract: There are different skill sets that nurse case managers and social workers need to have a good patient outcome. The problem is that there is a gap in the relationship between social workers and nurses, and this gap is based on factors that can and should be addressed. This gap can be minimized with conscious effort, addressing the issue, and a willingness to maximize the energy expended in professional relationships to improve patient outcomes. Equally important is the professional experience of each practitioner. The intervention is based on the Three R's: Reciprocity, Responsibility and Respect.

title: The SPHERE study. Secondary heart disease prevention in general practice: protocol of a randomized controlled trial of personalized practice and patient care plans with parallel qualitative, economic, and policy analyses. [ISRCTN24081411
abstract: BACKGROUND: The objective of the SPHERE study is to design, implement, and evaluate personalized practice and personal care plans to improve process of care and objective clinical outcomes for patients with coronary heart disease (CHD) established in general practice in two systems. different health conditions on the island of Ireland. Coronary heart disease is a common cause of death and a major cause of morbidity in Ireland. Secondary prevention has been advocated as a key strategy to reduce CHD mortality levels and general practice has been highlighted as an ideal setting for secondary prevention initiatives. Current indications suggest that there is considerable room for improvement in the provision of secondary prevention for patients with established heart disease on the island of Ireland. The review literature recommends structured programs with ongoing support and follow-up of patients; the provision of training, tailored to the needs of the practice of access to evidence of the effectiveness of secondary prevention; structured recovery programs that also take into account the needs of the individual practice; and patient-centered consultations accompanied by attention to disease management guidelines. METHODS: SPHERE is a cluster randomized controlled trial, with practice-level randomization to intervention and control groups, recruiting 960 patients from 48 practices in three study centers (Belfast, Dublin, and Galway). The primary outcomes are blood pressure, total cholesterol, physical and mental health status (SF-12), and hospital readmissions. The intervention is carried out for two years and data is collected at baseline, one year and two years of follow-up. The data is obtained from medical records, consultations with doctors and postal questionnaires from patients. The SPHERE intervention involves the implementation of a structured and systematic program of care for patients with CHD attending general practice. It is a multifaceted intervention that has been developed to respond to barriers and solutions to optimal secondary prevention identified in preliminary qualitative research with clinicians and patients. General practitioners and practice nurses attend training sessions to facilitate behavior change and medication prescription guidelines for secondary prevention of CHD. Patients are invited to attend regular quarterly consultations for two years, during which goals and targets for secondary prevention are established and reviewed. The analysis will be reinforced by economic, regulatory and qualitative components.

title: The standard of care: a case report and ethical analysis
abstract: Physicians increasingly allow their perceived legal responsibilities to override their clinical judgment. Misunderstandings surrounding the term "standard of care" have fostered fears of liability and led to the practice of defensive medicine. Physicians may view the standard of care as a technical or legal obligation, but an optimal standard would be one based on detailed knowledge of the patient's medical history and personal condition. It would include the physician's clinical judgment that integrates specific technical and legal information with clinical experience in patient care. Occasionally, such judgment may conflict with the rulings of a court, which considers technical and legal information without the benefit of clinical judgment. Physicians must be prepared to be advocates for their patients, especially when legal procedures are flawed or harmful. Systematic review and review processes, such as those used by ethics consultants, can help resolve concerns about the standard of care.

title: The state of office-based interventions for tobacco use among youth
abstract: Tobacco use is a serious pediatric health problem as dependence begins during childhood or adolescence in most tobacco users. Primary care settings provide tremendous opportunities to provide tobacco dependence treatment to young tobacco users. Although evidence-based practice guidelines for the treatment of nicotine dependence in youth are not yet available, professional organizations and current clinical practice guidance for adults provide recommendations based on expert opinion. This article reports on the current tobacco use treatment practices of pediatric and family medicine physicians, discusses the similarities and differences between adolescent and adult tobacco use, summarizes research efforts to date and current cutting-edge research that , ultimately, can help inform and guide clinicians, and presents existing recommendations on the treatment of tobacco use in youth. Finally, recommendations are made for the primary care physician, professional organizations, and health care systems and policies. Pediatricians and other physicians can and should play an important role in treating youth tobacco use.

title: The Study Team for Asthma Research in Early Life (STELAR) 'Asthma e-lab' Consortium: Team Science Bringing Together Data, Methods, and Investigators
abstract: We created the Asthma e-Lab, a secure web-based research environment to support the consistent recording, description and sharing of data, computational/statistical methods and emerging findings across all five UK birth cohorts. The e-Lab serves as the data repository for our unified data set and provides the computational resources and scientific social network to support collaborative research. All activities are transparent and emerging findings are shared through the e-Lab, linked to explanations of analytical methods, allowing knowledge transfer. eLab facilitates iterative interdisciplinary dialogue between clinicians, statisticians, computer scientists, mathematicians, geneticists, and basic scientists, capturing the collective thinking behind interpretations of findings.

title: The systematic influence of messages framed in gains and losses on the interest and use of different types of health behaviors
abstract: Systematically framing health messages in terms of gains or losses influences the behaviors people adopt. Rothman and Salovey proposed that the relative influence of framed messages on gains and losses depends on people's perception of the risk or uncertainty associated with adopting the recommended behavior. Specifically, loss-framed messages are more effective when they promote disease screening behaviors (detection), but gains-framed messages are more effective when they promote health-affirming behaviors (prevention). Two experiments provide a direct test of this conceptual framework. In Experiment 1, participants' willingness to act after reading about a new illness was a function of how the information was framed and the type of behavior promoted. Experiment 2 replicated and extended these findings with a real health problem: gum disease. Profit-framed brochures increased interest in a plaque-fighting mouthwash, while loss-framed brochures increased interest in a revealing plaque-detecting mouthwash. Research on message framing provides theoretically based guidance for the development of effective health messages.

title: The time is now: education and service organization
The tools of an evidence-based culture: implementation of clinical practice guidelines in an Israeli HMO
abstract: PURPOSE: Although clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) are implemented under the assumption that they will improve the quality, efficiency, and consistency of medical care, they generally have limited effect in changing physician behavior. The purpose of this study was to design and implement an effective program to formulate, promulgate, and implement CPGs to foster the development of an evidence-based culture in an Israeli HMO. METHOD: The authors implemented a four-stage program of step-by-step collaborative efforts with academic institutions comprised of developing quantitative tools to assess prescribing patterns, updating CPGs, gathering information from physicians through focus groups and quantitative surveys, and conducting a randomized controlled trial of a two-stage, multifaceted intervention. The test case of this study was the development, dissemination and implementation of a CPG for the treatment of acute uncomplicated cystitis in adult women. Interventions in the form of a conference dissertation and personalized feedback letter were implemented, both individually and in combination, to improve physicians' rates of prescribing the first-line drug, nitrofurantoin, and, in the absence of nitrofurantoin, adherence. to the recommended duration of three days of treatment with ofloxacin. RESULTS: The data generation tools and capabilities designed and built in Phase I of the project were integral components of all subsequent phases of the program. Personalized feedback alone was sufficient to improve guideline adherence rate by 19.4% (95% CI = 16.7, 22.1). CONCLUSIONS: This study provides a template for introducing the experimentation component essential to cultivating an evidence-based culture. This process, made up of collaborative efforts between academic institutions and a managed care organization, can be beneficial to other health care systems.

title: The US Training Institute for Health Research Dissemination and Implementation
abstract: Background The science of dissemination and implementation (D&I) is advancing the knowledge base on how to better integrate evidence-based interventions within clinical and community settings and how to reframe the nature or delivery of interventions. the research itself to make it more relevant and actionable in those settings. settings. While the field is growing, there are only a few training programs for D&I research; this is an important avenue to help build the capacity of the field. To enhance the United States' capacity for D&I research, the National Institutes of Health and the Veterans Health Administration collaborated to develop a five-day training institute for postdoctoral-level applicants aspiring to advance this science .MethodsWe describe the background, objectives, structure, curriculum, application process, trainee evaluation, and future plans for the Training in Dissemination and Implementation of Health Research (TIDIRH). Results The TIDIRH used a five-day residential immersion to maximize opportunities for trainees and faculty to interact. The training-of-trainers-like approach was intended to equip participants with materials that they could easily take back to their home institutions to increase the interest and increased investment in D&I. The TIDIRH curriculum included u n Balance of structured studies, large group discussions and interactive small group sessions. Thirty-five of the 266 applicants for the first annual training institute were accepted from a variety of disciplines, including psychology (12 trainees); medicine (6 interns); epidemiology (5 interns); health behavior/health education (4 interns); and 1 trainee in education and human development, health policy and management, health services research, public health studies, public policy and social work, with a maximum of two people from any institution. The institute was rated very helpful by attendees and six months after the institute, a follow-up survey (97% response rate) revealed that 72% had initiated a new D&I research grant proposal; 28% had received funding, and 77% had used TIDIRH skills to influence peers from different disciplines on D&I research through building local research networks, organizing formal presentations and symposiums, teaching and leading interdisciplinary teams to conduct D&I research. apprentice evaluation at the end of the week's training and six-month follow-up, and plans are to continue and possibly expand TIDIRH in the coming years. Strengths are seen as the residential format, the quality of the faculty and their flexibility in adjusting content to meet learners' needs, and the highlighting of concrete examples of D&I by the local host institution, which rotates lessons annually. learned and plans for the future TIDIR Trainings are summarized H.

title: The UPBEAT program for depression and coronary heart disease: using the UK Medical Research Council framework to design a complex nurse-led intervention for use in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Depression is common in coronary heart disease (CHD) and increases the incidence of coronary symptoms and death in patients with CHD. Viable interventions are needed for use in primary care to improve mood and cardiac outcomes. The UPBEAT-UK research program has been funded by the NHS's National Institute for Health Research (NIHR) to explore the relationship between coronary heart disease and depression and to develop a new intervention for use in primary care. METHODS: Using the Medical Research Council (MRC) guidelines for developing and evaluating complex interventions, we conducted a systematic review and qualitative research to develop a primary care nurse-led intervention to improve mood and cardiac outcomes in patients with CHD and depression. An iterative review of the literature was used to synthesize our empirical work and identify evidence and theory to inform the intervention. RESULTS: We developed a personalized care intervention led by primary care nurses that uses elements of case management to promote self-management. After the biopsychosocial assessment, a personalized care plan is drawn up. Nurses trained in behavior change techniques help patients address issues important to them. The identification and use of existing resources is promoted. The nurse's time is preserved through telephone follow-up. CONCLUSIONS: The application of the MRC framework for complex interventions has allowed us to develop an evidence-based intervention informed by patient and physician preferences and established theory. The feasibility and acceptability of this intervention is now being further tested in an exploratory trial.

title: The use of computerized reminders of birthday wishes in the management of diabetes.
