abstract: BACKGROUND: Although mailed reminders have been used for prevention among general populations, few studies have evaluated their efficacy among chronically ill populations. OBJECTIVE: We evaluated the effectiveness of mailed reminders in improving diabetes control. The reminder included a letter from the person's primary care physician (PCP), a self-care manual, a preventive care checklist, and specific recommendations regarding receiving routine checkups and screenings. METHODS: Of 195 PCPs practicing with a large group, 111 agreed to have their adult patients with diabetes randomized to receive the reminder (n=1641) or usual care (n=1668). Using data from automated databases, we fit generalized estimating equations to assess the effect of receipt of reminders on fasting lipid profile and glycosylated hemoglobin tests, receipt of dilated retinal examination, and frequency of visits during 6 and 12 months after randomization, and levels of glycosylated hemoglobin and cholesterol. in the year following randomization. RESULTS: Recipients of reminders and usual care did not differ in sociodemographic, clinical, or pretest characteristics. Within 6 months of randomization, reminder recipients were more likely to receive a retinal exam (odds ratio [OR], 1.29"; 95% confidence interval [95% CI], 1. 12 to 1.49) and a visit for diabetes (OR, 1.28; 95% CI, 1.12 to 1.47).In the 12 months after randomization, reminder recipients were more likely to receive a glycosylated hemoglobin test (OR, 1.21; 95% CI, 1.03 to 1.43), retinal exam (OR, 1.23; 95% CI, 1.07 to 1.41), and visit for diabetes (OR, 1.25; 95% CI, 1.09 to 1.29).At 1 year of follow-up, reminder recipients also tended to have a glycated hemoglobin test that did not reflect poor control (<9, 5%). CONCLUSIONS: We found small but significant improvements in the management of patients with diabetes who receive an email reminder.

title: The use of laboratory intervention to stop the flow of fresh frozen plasma
abstract: The hospital blood bank tested four laboratory intervention methods in an effort to modify the use of fresh frozen plasma (FFP). Over a one-year period, a utilization audit with feedback to physicians was initiated serially, a recurring educational program was introduced for internal staff outlining guidelines for FFP use, a form was introduced requiring justification of FFP orders and a policy requiring pathologist approval was established. of FFP in patients with normal or absent coagulation studies. Overall, when comparing the period after all forms of intervention (February 1986 to October 1986) with the baseline period before any form of intervention (July 1984 to March 1985), FFP use decreased by 52% vs. a 17% increase in red blood cell usage. It was concluded that blood bankers can drastically alter the use of this product using established methods to modify the ordering behavior of physicians.

title: The use of simulation to train teamwork skills in health care: how far can it go?
abstract: High-fidelity simulation has become a popular technique for training teamwork skills in high-risk industries such as aviation, healthcare, and nuclear power production. Simulation is a powerful training tool because it allows the trainer to systematically control the practice schedule, the presentation of feedback, and the introduction (or removal) of environmental distractions within a safe and controlled learning environment. Unfortunately, many within the training community have begun to use the terms simulation and high-fidelity simulation almost synonymously. This is unfortunate because doing so places too much emphasis on educational technology to the detriment of more substantive issues such as training goals, content and design. It also perpetuates various myths: either simulation fidelity is one-dimensional, or higher levels of simulation fidelity lead to higher training efficacy. The authors propose a simulation fidelity typology and provide examples of how different kinds of simulation have been used successfully to train teamwork skills in high-risk industries. Guidelines are also provided to maximize the usefulness of simulation for training teamwork skills in health care.

title: The use of nicotine inhaler to quit smoking
abstract: PURPOSE: To sensitize nursing professionals (NP) about the nicotine inhaler by providing clinical and practical information on the use of the nicotine inhaler as a treatment option for smoking cessation. DATA SOURCES: This included review and data-driven articles in the medical literature, the clinical practice guideline on tobacco use and dependence, and Medline and Cinahl search engines. The criteria for the search keywords were "nicotine inhaler" and "nicotine replacement therapy". The initial search was conducted in December 2004. CONCLUSIONS: The nicotine inhaler has been proven to be safe and effective in the treatment of smoking cessation. Clinical trials show that nicotine inhaler is useful alone or as an adjunct to other drug therapies. Current national guidelines recommend that the nicotine inhaler be used in smoking cessation therapy. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: The nicotine inhaler is appropriate for many different smokers, including certain types of cardiac patients. NPs may include the nicotine inhaler in a group of nicotine replacement therapies to ensure that smokers are successful in quitting.

title: Utilization of appropriate osteoporosis medications improves after a multifaceted educational intervention: the Canadian Circle of Quality (CQC) project
abstract: BACKGROUND: Osteoporosis is a serious but treatable condition. However, adequate utilization of disease therapy remains suboptimal. Therefore, the aim of the study was to change clinicians' therapy delivery behavior in accordance with the Osteoporosis Canada 2002 guidelines. METHODS: The Project was a two-year cohort study consisting of five phases of the Circle of (QC) that included: 1) Training and baseline data collection, 2) First educational intervention and first follow-up data collection 3) First strategy implementation session, 4) Final educational intervention and follow-up data collection and 5) Implementation session of the final strategy. A total of 340 family doctors formed 34 CCs and participated in the study. Clinicians reviewed a total of 8,376, 7,354, and 3,673 randomly selected patient records at baseline, Follow-up #1, and Final Follow-up, respectively. The patients were divided into three groups";" high-risk, low-risk, and low-risk groups without fracture. The generalized estimating equations technique was used to model change over time in whether clinicians RESULTS: The odds of adequate therapy were 1.29 (95% CI: 1.13, 1.46) and 1 .41 (95% CI: 1.20, 1.66) in the high-risk group. 1.15 (95% CI: 0.97, 1.36) and 1.16 (95% CI: 0.93, 1.44) in the low-risk group, and 1.20 (95% CI: 1 .01, 1.43) and 1.23 (95% CI: 0.97, 1.55) in the low-risk group without fractures at follow-up #1 and final follow-up, respectively. CONCLUSION: The quality control methodology was successful in increasing the appropriate use of osteoporosis medications by clinicians in accordance with Osteoporosis Canada guidelines.

title: The value of the 'gentle reminder' on safe medical behavior
abstract: Background Based on the knowledge and methods of cognitive psychology and behavioral economics, we introduced the 'Soft Reminder'. This procedure requires public planning of safety standards and an agreement by all team members to help each other adhere to this plan. Methods Team members agree to gently remind their co-workers whenever they deviate from the safety rule. For the study, we looked at glove use during IV insertion and blood draw. Results and discussion During the 2 years of observation, the safe behavior increased, if the safe behavior before the implementation of the "gentle reminder" was 55% in a room"; it increased after 2 months above 80%; 2 months later, it was 83% and 90%;" and finally stabilized at 90%. A similar pattern was documented in all districts. This is a recommended way to overcome unsafe behavior.

title: Theory and practice in the management of depressive disorders
abstract: Scientific, professional, and governmental bodies have intensified efforts in recent years to formulate guidelines for the treatment of depression with the goal that medical practice meets these standards and thus improve patient care. 'Evidence-based medicine' requires that medical practice explicitly refer to the best available scientific knowledge. Empirical data on the epidemiology of care suggests that there are important differences between guidelines and usual practice. The lack of detection of mental disorders ranges between 45 and 90%. Only 1 in 10 of those who suffer from depression receive adequate treatment. Treatment is insufficient because prescribed doses are usually too low, because up to 50% of treatments are terminated prematurely, and because patient noncompliance interferes with proper application of treatment. Psychological treatment is provided only in 60% of the cases that need it and is mostly non-specific, that is, listening or giving advice. Furthermore, there are large regional variations in prescribing patterns showing that treatment is influenced by many non-medical factors. Empirical studies show that giving information to clinicians or even measures to improve recognition alone are not enough to make changes in treatment behavior. Only if steps are taken to improve treatment interventions directly, at least for the most severe cases, could a better disease outcome be shown. If one wants to understand the therapist's noncompliance with treatment guidelines, one must first understand the medical decision-making process. Theory of action provides a model that brings together theoretical and experiential knowledge, goal setting, medical and emotional assessment, and operational procedures. Based on this theory, future guidelines should specify the setting for which they claim to be valid, should be empirically tested for feasibility and effects on patient outcome, and should pay due attention to nonmedical factors that have a role. major impact. about medical practice.

title: Therapeutic improvement: category of nursing intervention for patients with a diagnosis of Preparation for the Management of Therapeutic Regimen
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To present a new category of nursing intervention called therapeutic improvement. BACKGROUND: Fewer than half of Americans follow their doctor's recommendations about diet and exercise, even when they are crucial to their health or recovery. It is imperative that nurses consider new ways to promote healthy behaviors. Therapeutic enhancement aims to provide such a novel approach. Traditional intervention techniques focused on education, contracts, social support, and more frequent interaction with physicians appear to be ineffective when used alone. Successful strategies have been multidisciplinary";" and have included professional nursing interventions that help patients understand their disease and disease process and help them develop disease management and self-management skills. Therapeutic enhancement incorporates stages of change theory, health engagement theory, motivational interviewing techniques, and instrumentation designed specifically for process evaluation of health-promoting interventions. METHOD: This is a critical review of approaches that, to date, have not been synthesized in a single published article. CONCLUSIONS: Based on the commonly used Stages of Change model, therapeutic enhancement is useful for patients who are in the action stage of change. Using therapeutic enhancement, as well as therapeutic strategies identified in stages of change theory, such as contingency management, helping relationships, counterconditioning, stimulus control, and motivational interviewing techniques, nurses can Significantly increase the chances that patients will move from action to the maintenance stage of change. for a specific health behavior. RELEVANCE TO CLINICAL PRACTICE: Using the nursing intervention category, therapeutic enhancement can increase caregivers' success in helping patients maintain healthy behaviors.

title: Therapy and supportive care of alcoholics: guidelines for professionals
abstract: BACKGROUND/OBJECTIVES: Alcoholism is a widespread disorder in our societies. However, only a small percentage of alcoholics appear in specific psychotherapeutic treatment programs. The vast majority are cared for by general practitioners or experts from other medical specialties where they are treated intensively for their alcohol-induced comorbidities. But the reason for these comorbidities, alcoholism itself, is rarely treated. This article provides guidance for specialists and non-specialists on how to correctly treat these patients in nonspecific treatment programs and how to increase motivation to remain abstinent. In addition, the concept can be quickly and easily integrated into the daily routine of any therapeutic team. METHODS: The literature on therapeutic methods of brief interventions, motivational interviewing and pharmacological relapse prevention was reviewed in PubMed during the years 1991-2005. RESULTS/CONCLUSION: The disease burden of alcoholism and alcohol abuse as primary disorders is very apparent but often underestimated even by therapists from various medical disciplines. Systematic studies of the brief intervention method, motivational interviewing, and also pharmacological treatment with acamprosate have shown that these are powerful methods that are easily used to increase the duration of abstinence and the motivation of patients to participate in additional specific treatment. .

title: Thoughtless EHR Design Drives Overuse, But Intentional Design Can Drive Better Patient Care
Three-dimensional and four-dimensional ultrasound in obstetric practice: does it help?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this article was to review the published literature on 3-dimensional ultrasound (3DUS) and 4-dimensional ultrasound (4DUS) in obstetrics and to determine whether 3DUS adds diagnostic information to what is currently provided by 2-dimensional ultrasound (2DUS). ) and, if so, in which areas. METHODS: A PubMed search was performed for articles reporting the use of 3DUS or 4DUS in obstetrics. 706 articles were identified, and among them, 525 were actually related to the topic of this review. Articles describing technical developments, clinical studies, reviews, editorials, and studies on fetal behavior or the maternal-fetal bond were reviewed. RESULTS: Three-dimensional ultrasound provides additional diagnostic information for the diagnosis of facial abnormalities, especially facial clefts. There is also evidence that 3DUS provides additional diagnostic information in neural tube defects and skeletal malformations. Large studies comparing 2DUS and 3DUS for the diagnosis of congenital anomalies have provided inconclusive results. Preliminary evidence suggests that ultrasonographic tomography may decrease the examination time of obstetric ultrasound examination, with minimal impact on visualization rates of anatomical structures. CONCLUSIONS: Three-dimensional ultrasound provides additional diagnostic information for the diagnosis of facial abnormalities, evaluation of neural tube defects, and skeletal malformations. Additional research is needed to determine the clinical role of 3DUS and 4DUS for the diagnosis of congenital heart disease and central nervous system abnormalities. Future studies should determine whether the information contained in the volume dataset, alone, is sufficient to assess fetal biometric measurements and diagnose congenital anomalies.

title: through the carpal tunnel
Thyroid disease in pregnancy
Tics in the pediatric population: pragmatic management
abstract: BACKGROUND: Primary tic disorders, particularly Tourette's syndrome, are very common movement disorders in childhood. However, the management of these patients still poses great therapeutic challenges to medical professionals. METHODS: Based on a synthesis of available guidelines published in Europe, Canada, and the United States, along with more recent therapeutic developments, the authors provide pragmatic guidance to help clinicians decide when and how to treat patients with primary tic disorders. . RESULTS: After a systematic evaluation of tics and common neuropsychiatric comorbidities (mainly attention deficit hyperactivity disorder [ADHD] and obsessive-compulsive disorder [OCD]), the first step in treatment is a comprehensive psychoeducation of patients and families that addresses the protein phenomenology of tics and associated behaviors, coping mechanisms, prognosis, and treatment options. When a more active intervention beyond vigilant monitoring is indicated, hierarchical evaluation of treatment goals (ie, tics versus comorbid behavioral symptoms) is crucial. Behavioral treatments for tics are restricted to older children and are not readily available in all settings, mainly due to a shortage of well-trained therapists. Pharmacological treatments, such as antipsychotics for tics, stimulants and atomoxetine for ADHD, and alpha2A agonists for children with tics plus ADHD, represent widely available and effective treatment options, but safety should be monitored. Polypharmacologic and combined behavioral/pharmacologic approaches, as well as neuromodulation strategies, remain under-investigated in this patient population. CONCLUSIONS: The treatment of children with tics and Tourette syndrome is multifaceted. Multidisciplinary teams with expertise in neurology, psychiatry, psychology, and pediatrics can be helpful in addressing the complex needs of these children.

title: Training in Brief Smoking Interventions for Chiropractic, Acupuncture, and Massage Practitioners: Protocol for the CAM Scoping Study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Tobacco use remains the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the US Effective smoking cessation aids are widely available but underused. Brief interventions (BI) for smoking cessation increase quit rates. However, BI training has focused on conventional medical providers, neglecting other health professionals with regular contact with tobacco users. The 2007 National Health Interview Survey found that approximately 20% of provider-based complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) users are tobacco users. Therefore, CAM professionals potentially represent a large untapped community resource for promoting tobacco cessation and the use of cessation aids. Existing BI training is not well suited to the backgrounds and practice patterns of CAM clinicians, because it assumes a conventional biomedical foundation of knowledge and philosophical approaches to health, healing, and the doctor-patient relationship. There is a pressing need to develop and test the effectiveness of BI training that is based on the Public Health Service (PHS) Guidelines for tobacco dependence treatment and that is relevant and appropriate for CAM professionals. METHODS/DESIGN: The CAM Reach (CAMR) intervention is a smoking cessation training and office system intervention designed specifically for chiropractors, acupuncturists, and massage therapists. The CAMR study uses a single-group, one-way crossover design to examine the impact of the CAMR intervention on smoking-related practice behaviors of CAM practitioners. Primary outcomes included CAM professionals' self-reported tobacco use screening behavior and BI. Secondary outcomes include tobacco users' readiness to quit, quit attempts, use of guideline-based treatments and quit rates, and also non-tobacco users' actions to help another person. to stop smoking. DISCUSSION: CAM practitioners provide care to a significant number of tobacco users. His practice patterns and philosophical approaches to health and healing are well suited to providing BI. The CAMR study is examining the impact of the CAMR intervention on practitioners' tobacco-related practice behaviors, CAM patient behaviors, and documenting important factors for conducting practice-based research in CAM practices. from the real world.

title: Smoking cessation in primary care: maximizing intervention strategies
abstract: The most effective preventive intervention a physician can provide to patients who smoke against heart disease, cancer, cerebrovascular disease, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is an empathic, personalized smoking cessation intervention program with long-term support and follow-up. The objective of the intervention must be the total abandonment of the smoking habit. The reduction does not provide direct health benefits to the individual smoker. Interventions are readily available but underutilized, in part due to a lack of medical training and organizational support. This article summarizes current guidelines for smoking cessation interventions as a framework from which to start. The guidelines incorporate the transtheoretical model of patient behavior change and the "Five A's": Ask, Advise, Assess, Help, and Organize. Pharmacotherapeutic tools are considered, including nicotine replacement therapies (nicotine gum, patches, nasal sprays, inhalers, and new therapies) and non-nicotine therapies (bupropion, clonidine, nortriptyline, and other antidepressants and anxiolytics). Adherence validation methods, new approaches to tobacco treatment, and addictions that appear in the recent research literature are reviewed. Beyond this framework, specific categories of tobacco users (including smokeless tobacco users), cultural and ethnic minorities, adolescent snuff and bidi users, women, Medicaid recipients, and multi-form users of tobacco require special consideration. With this framework and modifications that may be necessary for specific categories of patients, practicing physicians can incorporate a successful smoking cessation intervention program into daily practice with quit rates approaching 20%.

title: Quit smoking in the dental office
abstract: Evidence-based smoking cessation guidelines, when used by clinicians, are effective in reducing tobacco use and leading patients to quit smoking successfully. Dentists have been encouraged to provide smoking cessation instruction and intervention in the dental office. The dental provider is in a unique position to relate oral findings to the patient and provide tobacco-using patients with advice to stop smoking. In addition, dentists can assess patients' self-addiction and level of readiness to quit tobacco use. With this information, dentists can help patients to stop using tobacco by providing them with the appropriate pharmacotherapeutic support and thus improve their oral and general health.

title: Smoking cessation training for complementary and alternative medicine practitioners: results of a practice-based trial
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Brief behavioral intervention (BI) is a well-established good practice for smoking cessation among conventional health professionals. Complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) practitioners treat a significant number of tobacco users, but do not receive systematic training in BI. The CAM Reach study developed and evaluated a BI smoking cessation/intervention training program of practice system tailored specifically for CAM professionals and evaluated in real-world CAM practices. STUDY DESIGN: Single arm intervention. Data were collected in 2010-2014 and analyzed in 2015. SETTING/PARTICIPANTS: Private practices of 30 chiropractors, 27 acupuncturists, 42 massage therapists (N=99), in the Tucson, Arizona metropolitan area. INTERVENTION: 8-hour BI Smoking Cessation Continuing Education Workshop, In-Office BI Skills Practice/Assessment, and System Intervention. Training tailored to CAM's practice setting addressed smoking cessation best practices from the US Public Health Service Guidelines. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Seventeen items (assessing practitioner behavior, motivation, and self-efficacy with smoking cessation) comprising three factors, Activity to Quit, Motivation to Quit, and Comfort to Quit without CAM, were assessed at baseline and 3, 6, 9, and 12 months after training by professional self-report. Research staff visited practices at approximately the same intervals to directly observe changes in clinical practice systems. RESULTS: At 3 months, there were significant increases in practitioners' cessation activities, motivation, and confidence in helping patients quit, and comfort with providing information and referrals for smoking-based cessation aids. in guides (p<0.0001). Physicians significantly increased rates of discussing smoking cessation medications with patients (AOR=3.76, 95% CI=1.84, 7.68) and routine questions about tobacco use in practice clinical (AOR=2.62, 95% CI=1.11, 6.20). Increases occurred in all three types of practitioners and were maintained at 12 months, despite heterogeneity in professional training, practice patterns/organization, and practice business models. CONCLUSIONS: Results suggest that CAM practitioners are willing and able to offer BIs, and are an important but overlooked channel for promoting tobacco cessation and the use of evidence-based cessation aids.

title: Guidelines for the treatment of smoking
abstract: Tobacco dependence causes one in six deaths in the Czech Republic and is associated with diseases of the whole body. Tobacco dependence treatment should be a standard part of clinical care for the time available, ranging from a brief intervention at each clinical contact with patients to intensive treatment. Includes psycho-socio-behavioral support and pharmacotherapy. It should apply to all professions of clinical medicine, as recommended by the WHO, mainly doctors, nurses, pharmacists and dentists, and should be covered by health care systems. Economically, it is one of the most profitable interventions in medicine. In our population over 15 years of age, about 30% smoke (about 2.2 million people), the F17 diagnosis is related to approximately 1.75 million people (about 80% of smokers).

title: Smoking Intervention Practices of Licensed Psychologists
abstract: Tobacco dependence is a serious public health problem. The US Department of Health and Human Services has issued a best practice guideline to encourage all health care providers to intervene with tobacco dependent individuals they encounter. Psychologists may be ideal for implementing brief tobacco use interventions because of their expertise in behavior change strategies and interpersonal counseling skills. This study sought to investigate current tobacco use assessment and intervention practices and perceptions of responsibility for tobacco use intervention among a regional sample of licensed practicing psychologists. The results suggest that most psychologists fall short of the ideal best practices recommended in the practice guideline, and many are unaware of the availability of the guidelines. Furthermore, the psychologists in this study perceived smoking intervention to be a greater responsibility of physicians and other health professionals than of psychologists and other mental health professionals.

title: Smoking in people with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder: epidemiology and pharmacological approaches to smoking cessation.
abstract: The coexistence of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and nicotine dependence is common. People with ADHD are more likely to start smoking and become dependent on nicotine than their counterparts without ADHD, and recent evidence suggests that they may have a harder time quitting. Little is known about how to best approach the treatment of these comorbidities to optimize clinical outcome. Clinicians treating people with ADHD or nicotine dependence need to be aware of their common coexistence and the need to address both in treatment. This review of ADHD and nicotine dependence provides an overview of the relevant epidemiology, bidirectional interactions, and implications for adjunctive pharmacological and psychosocial treatment. Incorporating the current evidence base and their clinical experience, the authors propose a stepwise approach to the treatment of patients with comorbid ADHD and nicotine dependence. Given the potential for ADHD symptoms to interfere with successful quitting, the first priority is to stabilize ADHD. The first-line pharmacological approach should be a long-acting psychostimulant. Following stabilization of ADHD, motivational techniques should be used to encourage readiness to attempt smoking cessation. In the context of behavioral smoking cessation interventions sensitive to the patient's needs and developmental stage, a pharmacological intervention aimed at smoking cessation can be initiated. The authors recommend varenicline as a first-line agent, given the superior effect size among available drug treatments. ADHD symptoms, as well as nicotine withdrawal and craving symptoms, should be closely monitored during the quit attempt, and adjustments in therapy should be considered if warranted. The authors conclude that while current treatments may be potentially effective for comorbid ADHD and nicotine dependence, more research is needed to explore the complex associations between these disorders and prospectively study combination treatments.

title: Tobacco and nicotine education and training for students and health professionals: a systematic review
abstract: Introduction: The objective of this systematic review was to investigate what characteristics of education and training prepare and support health professionals (HCPs) in providing competent and effective care to clients who use tobacco and nicotine. Methods: A search of eight bibliographic databases of peer-reviewed publications in English from January 2006 to March 2015. Studies were included if they met the a priori inclusion criteria, which consisted of: 1) quantitative study design and 2) focus on tobacco and nicotine education or training for HCP students and professionals. Two reviewers independently screened all studies for inclusion. Data from included studies were extracted for study characteristics and key outcomes and then critically appraised for methodological quality. Results: 59 studies were included for the narrative synthesis. Two categories emerged: 1) curriculum characteristics (n=10), and 2) education and training interventions (n=49). The included curricular studies identified the following themes: content, intensity, evaluation of competencies and barriers. Study findings on education and training interventions were grouped by education level (pre-licensing, post-licensing, and faculty training), teaching modality, health discipline, and outcomes. HCP and client associates. Conclusion: This comprehensive review suggests that there is a lack of consistency in the characteristics of tobacco and nicotine education and training in HCP. This document provides a valuable categorization of the most frequently used academic curriculum components and discusses interventions in relation to HCP and client outcomes. Gaps in the literature are highlighted and the need to standardize competencies and assessment of tobacco and nicotine training is discussed. Future research is needed to investigate the most effective approaches to training. Test record: PROSPERO - protocol number: CRD42015019219 Available at http://www.crd.york.ac.uk/PROSPERO/display_record.asp?ID=CRD42015019219. IMPLICATIONS: This systematic review summarizes existing tobacco-related curriculum components (content, intensity, competency assessment, barriers) and training interventions for health professionals worldwide and demonstrates that they are associated with positive outcomes for health professionals (knowledge, attitudes, behaviors). , skills) and client outcomes (smoking cessation attempts and smoking abstinence).

title: Tools to implement an evidence-based approach in public health practice
abstract: Rising disease rates, limited funding, and a growing scientific basis for intervention call for the use of proven strategies to improve population health. Public health professionals must be prepared to implement an evidence-based approach in their work to meet health objectives and maintain the necessary resources. We investigate easily accessible and time-efficient tools to implement an evidence-based public health (EBPH) approach to improve population health. Several tools have been developed to meet the needs of EBPH, including free online resources in the following topic areas: Training and Planning Tools, US Health Surveillance, Policy Tracking and Surveillance, Systematic Reviews, and Guidelines based on evidence, economic evaluation and gray literature. The key elements of EBPH are to involve the community in evaluation and decision making; use data and information systems systematically; make decisions based on the best available peer-reviewed evidence (both quantitative and qualitative); apply program planning frameworks (often based on behavioral health theory); conduct a robust evaluation;" and disseminate what has been learned.

title: Topical intranasal corticosteroids in children aged 4 to 11 years with persistent bilateral otitis media with effusion in primary care: a randomized double-blind placebo-controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the clinical effectiveness of topical intranasal corticosteroids in children with bilateral otitis media with effusion. DESIGN Randomized double-blind placebo-controlled trial. SCENARIO 76 Practices from the Medical Research Council General Practice Research Framework across the UK, between 2004 and 2007. PARTICIPANTS 217 children aged 4 to 11 years who had had at least one recorded episode of otitis media or an ear problem related in the previous 12 months, and with bilateral otitis media with effusion confirmed by a research nurse by otoscopy plus microtympanometry (B/B or B/C2, modified Jerger types). INTERVENTION Mometasone furoate 50 micrograms or placebo spray administered once daily in each nostril for three months. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Proportions of children cured of bilateral otitis media with effusion assessed with tympanometry (type C1 or A) at 1 month (primary endpoint), 3 months, and 9 months"; adverse events; 3-month daily symptoms. Outcomes 41% (39/96) in the topical steroid group and 45% (44/98) in the placebo group were healed in one or both ears within one month (difference in favor of placebo 4.3% (95% confidence interval : -9.3% to 18.1%) Poisson regression was performed with adjustment for four prespecified covariates (clinical severity, P=0.003; atopy, P=0.67; age, P=0.92; season, P=0.71).The adjusted relative risk at month was 0.97 (95% confidence interval: 0.74 to 1.26).At three months, 58% of the topical steroid group and the 52% of the placebo group were cured (relative risk: 1.23, 0.84 to 1.80) Daily symptoms did not differ between the two groups, and no significant harm was reported CONCLUSIONS Unlikely that topical steroids are an effective treatment for otitis media with effusion in general practice. High rates of natural resolution occurred between 1 and 3 months. TRIAL REGISTRATION Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN38988331; National Research Registry NO575123823;" MREC 03/11/073.

title: Tough-talking magazine editor faces accusations of leniency
Towards Criteria for Pragmatic Measurement in Implementation Research and Practice: A Stakeholder-Driven Approach Using Concept Maps
abstract: Background Advancing implementation research and practice requires valid and reliable measures of the determinants, mechanisms, processes, strategies, and outcomes of implementation. However, researchers and implementation stakeholders are unlikely to use measures if they are not also pragmatic. The purpose of this study was to establish a stakeholder-driven conceptualization of the domains that comprise the pragmatic measure construct. It was based on a systematic review of the literature and semi-structured interviews with stakeholders that generated 47 criteria for pragmatic measures, and aimed to further refine that set of criteria by identifying conceptually distinct categories of the pragmatic measure construct and providing quantitative ratings of the criteria. . Â¯s clarity and importance. Methods Twenty-four stakeholders with implementation practice experience completed a concept mapping activity in which they organized the initial list of 47 criteria into conceptually distinct categories and rated their clarity and importance. Multidimensional scaling, hierarchical cluster analysis, and descriptive statistics were used to analyze the data. Results The 47 criteria were significantly grouped into four distinct categories: (1) acceptable, (2) compatible, (3) easy, and (4) useful. Average clarity and importance ratings will be presented at the category level and individual criteria. Conclusions This study advances the field of implementation science and practice by providing clear and conceptually distinct domains of the pragmatic measure construct. The next steps will include a Delphi process to develop a consensus on the most important criteria and the development of quantifiable pragmatic scoring criteria that can be used to assess the measures.

title: Towards Evidence-Based Medical Statistics. 1: The P-Value Fallacy
abstract: There is a major problem in the interpretation of modern medical research data: Biological understanding and prior research play little formal role in interpreting quantitative results. This phenomenon manifests itself in the discussion sections of research articles and can ultimately affect the reliability of the conclusions. The standard statistical approach has created this situation by promoting the illusion that conclusions with certain â€œerror ratesâ€ can be produced, regardless of information external to the experiment. This statistical approach, whose key components are P-values and hypothesis testing, is widely perceived as a mathematically consistent approach to inference. There is little appreciation in the medical community that the methodology is an amalgamation of incompatible elements, the usefulness of which for scientific inference has been the subject of intense debate among statisticians for nearly 70 years. This article introduces some of the key elements of that debate and traces the appeal and adverse impact of this methodology back to the P-value fallacy, the misconception that a single number can capture both the long-term results of an experiment and the probative significance of a single result. This argument is made as a prelude to the suggestion that another measure of evidence should be used: the Bayesian factor, which correctly separates long-term behavioral problems from the strength of the evidence and allows integration of prior knowledge with existing knowledge. statistical findings.

title: Towards a common terminology: a simplified framework of interventions to promote and integrate evidence into health practices, systems and policies
abstract: Background There is a wide range of diverse and inconsistent terminology in the field of knowledge translation. This limits the performance of evidence synthesis, impedes communication and collaboration, and undermines knowledge translation of research findings in diverse settings. Improving consistency of terminology could help address these challenges. In 2012, we convened an international working group to explore the idea of developing a common terminology and general framework for knowledge translation interventions. Findings Methods included identifying and summarizing existing frameworks, mapping a subset of those frameworks, and convening a multidisciplinary group to begin working toward consensus. The group considered four possible approaches to creating a simplified framework: merge existing taxonomies, create a framework of intervention mechanisms rather than intervention strategies, use a consensus process to expand on one of the existing models/frameworks used by the group, or develop a new consensus frame of reference. Conclusions The working group chose to draft a new simplified consensus framework of interventions to promote and integrate evidence into health practices, systems and policies. The framework will include four key components: strategies and techniques (active ingredients), how they work (causal mechanisms), how they are delivered (delivery mode), and what they intend to change (intended goals). The draft framework needs to be further developed through feedback and consultation with the research community and tested for usefulness through application and evaluation.

title: Toxic hepatitis during treatment with ketoconazole
Tracheotomy and weaning
abstract: No hypothesis related to respiratory care in the intensive care unit has been more difficult to study objectively than the common belief that tracheostomy hastens weaning from ventilatory support. Tracheostomy might facilitate weaning by reducing dead space and lowering airway resistance, improving secretion clearance, reducing the need for sedation, and decreasing the risk of aspiration. The available evidence indicates that dead space and airway resistance are reduced, although it is less certain that the magnitude of these reductions explains the clinical observation of faster weaning after tracheostomy. Most of the data on this topic comes from laboratory experiments and short-term physiological studies in clinically stable patients, and the available evidence from clinical trials with weaning as the primary endpoint is sparse. A large multicenter trial showed no advantage to early tracheostomy, but showed how difficult it is to get clinicians to manage their patients with regimens that go against their long-held views. The most recent clinical trial found that percutaneous dilatational tracheostomy performed within the first 2 days in patients projected to need >14 days of ventilatory support greatly reduced ventilator and intensive care unit days, and decreased both the incidence of pneumonia as overall mortality, compared with tracheostomy performed after day 14. Conducting such trials is difficult due to investigator and physician bias, inability to predict which patients will actually require prolonged mechanical ventilation, and several other factors. discussed in this article. Tracheostomy probably helps relieve some patients from ventilatory support, but this may be due to its effect on clinical behavior as well as any physiological impact.

title: Tracing the foundations of a conceptual framework for a patient safety ontology
abstract: Background In the work of the World Alliance for Patient Safety on research methods and measures and on the definition of key concepts for an International Classification of Patient Safety (ICPS), it became clear that there was a need to try to understand how the meaning of patient safety and the The concepts relate to existing safety and quality frameworks commonly used in health care. Objectives To develop the concept of patient safety and how it relates to the safety and quality frameworks commonly used in health care and to trace the evolution of the ICPS framework as the basis for the electronic capture of the component elements of patient safety. Conclusion The ICPS conceptual framework for patient safety has its origins in existing frameworks and an international consultation process. Although its 10 classes and their semantic relationships can be used as a reference model for different disciplines, it must remain dynamic in the ever-changing world of healthcare. By expanding ICPS by examining data from all available sources and ensuring rigorous adherence to the latest principles in informatics, a deeper interdisciplinary approach will be progressively developed to address the complex and refractory problem of reducing care-associated harms. medical.

title: Training for general practitioners in prescribing opioids for chronic pain based on practice guidelines: a randomized pilot and feasibility trial
abstract: UNLABELED: This study is a pilot and feasibility study comparing 2 training experiences to improve appropriate prescription of opioids for chronic pain. Both training conditions included education regarding opioid guidelines. After education, 1 condition included training aimed at improving psychological flexibility and the other included training in practical knowledge and skills related to pain management. Eighty-one general practitioners (GPs) participated in the study, each of whom was randomly assigned to one of the training conditions. It was easy to recruit GPs for training. Overall, GPs demonstrated increased knowledge of prescribing opioids for chronic pain and decreased prescribing-related concerns after training. However, no changes were seen in reported prescribing practices or secondary measures of well-being. There were also no significant differences between the training conditions, except for a greater increase in the intention to use the prescription guidelines in the psychological flexibility condition. The feasibility and acceptability of the training methods were generally rated as high. The psychological flexibility condition scored higher than the comparison condition in terms of interest and satisfaction. Finally, psychological flexibility processes before and after training were significantly correlated with measures of GP well-being, providing partial support for the relevance of these processes as a focus in GP training. PERSPECTIVE: A training intervention for GPs that included education on opioid guidelines for chronic pain and psychological flexibility training increased prescribing knowledge and reduced worries, but did not change prescribing behavior or well-being. The training was very acceptable to the GPs but may have been too short to produce any other effects.

title: Training in internal fracture fixation
Training physicians to provide high-value, cost-conscious care
abstract: Importance Rising health care spending is testing the sustainability of the health care system. Physicians must be prepared to provide high-value, cost-conscious care. Objective To understand the circumstances in which cost-conscious, high-value care delivery is learned, with the aim of informing the development of effective educational interventions. Data sources PubMed, EMBASE, ERIC, and Cochrane databases were searched from inception to September 5, 2015, to identify students and cost-related topics. Study selection Studies were included on the basis of relevance to topic, implementation of the intervention, evaluation of the intervention, educational components of the intervention, and appropriate target group. There were no restrictions on the study design. Data extraction and synthesis Data extraction was guided by a merged and modified version of a Best Evidence in Medical Education abstraction form and a Cochrane data coding sheet. Articles were reviewed using the realist review method, a narrative review technique that focuses on understanding the underlying mechanisms in interventions. Recurring patterns in the data were identified through thematic analyses. The resulting themes were discussed within the research team until a consensus was reached. Main results and measures The main results were factors that promote education to provide high-value and cost-conscious care. Findings The initial search identified 2650 articles; 79 met the inclusion criteria, of which 14 were randomized clinical trials. Most studies were conducted in North America (78.5%) using a pre-post intervention design (58.2%; at least 1619 participants); they focused on practicing physicians (36.7%; at least 3448 participants), resident physicians (6.3%; n=?516), and medical students (15.2%; n=?275). Among the 14 randomized clinical trial participants, 12 addressed knowledge transmission, 7 reflective practices, and 1 supportive environment; 10 (71%) concluded that the intervention was effective. The data analysis suggested that 3 factors help successful learning: (1) effective transmission of knowledge, related, for example, to general health economics and prices of health services, to scientific evidence regarding the guidelines and the benefits and harms of medical care, and patient preferences and personal values (67 articles); (2) facilitating reflective practice, such as providing feedback or asking reflective questions regarding decisions related to laboratory ordering or prescription to give learners insight into their past and current behavior (56 items);" and (3) creating a supportive environment in which the organization of the health care system, the presence of role models of providing high-value, cost-conscious care, and a culture of high-value, cost-conscious care of costs reinforce the desire for training objectives (27 articles).Conclusions and relevanceResearch on educating physicians to provide high-value, cost-conscious care suggests that learning by practicing physicians, resident physicians, and medical students is promoted by combining the transmission of specific knowledge, reflective practice and a supportive environment.These factors should t taken into account when developing educational interventions.

title: Training physicians to provide cost-conscious, high-value care: a systematic review
abstract: SIGNIFICANCE: Rising health care spending is testing the sustainability of the health care system. Physicians must be prepared to provide high-value, cost-conscious care. OBJECTIVE: To understand the circumstances in which cost-conscious, high-value care delivery is learned, with the goal of informing the development of effective educational interventions. DATA SOURCES: PubMed, EMBASE, ERIC, and Cochrane databases were searched from inception to September 5, 2015, to identify students and cost-related topics. STUDY SELECTION: Studies were included on the basis of relevance to topic, implementation of the intervention, evaluation of the intervention, educational components of the intervention, and appropriate target group. There were no restrictions on the study design. DATA EXTRACTION AND SYNTHESIS: Data extraction was guided by a merged and modified version of a Best Evidence in Medical Education abstraction form and a Cochrane data coding sheet. Articles were reviewed using the realist review method, a narrative review technique that focuses on understanding the underlying mechanisms in interventions. Recurring patterns in the data were identified through thematic analyses. The resulting themes were discussed within the research team until a consensus was reached. MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES: The main results were factors that promote education to provide high-value, cost-conscious care. FINDINGS: The initial search identified 2650 articles; 79 met the inclusion criteria, of which 14 were randomized clinical trials. minus 1619 participants); they focused on practicing physicians (36.7%; at least 3,448 participants), resident physicians (6.3%; n = 516), and medical students (15.2%; n = 275). Among the 14 randomized clinical trials, 12 addressed knowledge transmission, 7 reflective practice, and 1 supportive environment; 10 (71%) concluded that the intervention was effective. The analysis of the data suggested that 3 factors help successful learning: (1) the effective transmission of knowledge, related, for example, to the general economics of health and the prices of health services, to the scientific evidence regarding to guidelines and the benefits and harms of medical care, and to patient preferences and personal values (67 articles); (2) facilitating reflective practice, such as providing feedback or asking reflective questions about decisions related to laboratory orders or prescriptions to give students insight into their past and current behavior (56 items);" and (3) creating a supportive environment in which the organization of the health care system, the presence of role models of providing high-value, cost-conscious care, and a culture of high-value, cost-conscious care reinforce desire training objectives (27 articles) CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Research on educating physicians to provide high-value, cost-conscious care suggests that learning by practicing physicians, resident physicians, and medical students Medicine is promoted by combining the transmission of specific knowledge, reflective practice and a supportive environment.These factors must be taken into account c hen educational interventions are developed.

title: Training professionals to provide opportunistic counseling on multiple behavior changes in primary care: a cluster randomized trial
abstract: OBJECTIVES To assess the effect of training primary care health professionals in behavioral change counseling on the proportion of patients reporting changes in four risk behaviors (smoking, alcohol use, exercise and healthy eating). DESIGN Cluster randomized trial with general practice as the unit of randomization. SETTING General practice in Wales. PARTICIPANTS 53 general practitioners and practice nurses from 27 general practices (one each minus one practice) recruited 1827 patients who tested positive for at least one risk behavior. INTERVENTION Behavior change counseling was developed from motivational interviewing to enable clinicians to improve patients' motivation to change health-related behaviour. Physicians were trained through a blended learning program called Talking Lifestyles. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Proportion of patients reporting beneficial changes in at least one of four risk behaviors at three months. RESULTS A total of 1308 patients from 13 interventions and 1496 from 14 control practices were approached: 76% and 72% respectively agreed to participate, with 831 (84%) and 996 (92%) respectively screened eligible for an intervention. There was no effect on the primary outcome (beneficial change in behaviour) at three months (362 (44%) vs 404 (41%), odds ratio 1.12 (95% CI 0.90 to 1, 39)) or on biochemical or biometric measurements at 12 months. months. More patients who had seen trained physicians recalled the health behavior consultation discussion (724/795 (91%) vs. 531/966 (55%), odds ratio 12.44 (5.85 to 26, 46)) and intended to switch (599/831 (72%) vs. 491/996 (49%), odds ratio 2.88 (2.05 to 4.05)). More intervention practice patients reported attempting to change (328 (39%) vs. 317 (32%), odds ratio 1.40 (1.15 to 1.70)), sustained behavior change at three months (288 (35%) vs. 280 (28%, odds ratio 1.36 (1.11 to 1.65)), reporting slightly greater improvements in healthy eating at three and 12 months, in addition to an improvement in activity at 12 months Training cost £1597 per practice DISCUSSION Training primary care clinicians in behavior change counseling using a short blended learning program did not increase beneficial behavior changes reported by patients at three months nor did biometric and biochemical measures improve at 12 months, but it did increase patients' recall of having discussed behavior change with their clinicians, intentions to change, attempts to change, and perceptions of having discussed behavior change with their clinicians. made a lasting change to the three months. Lasting behavior change and improvements in biometric measures are unlikely after a single routine consultation with a clinician trained in behavior change counseling without further intervention. TEST RECORD ISRCTN 22495456.

title: Transforming Assertive Community Treatment into an Integrated Care System: The Role of Nursing and Primary Care Associations
abstract: Despite the high rate of co-occurring medical conditions experienced by people receiving Assertive Community Treatment (ACT), this comprehensive service model is still viewed primarily as a mental health intervention. Without compromising fidelity to the model, ACT can serve as an ideal platform from which to deliver primary and behavioral health care to those with complex service needs. Using a case example, this article considers the transformation of the ACT mental health care model into an integrated health care delivery system through the establishment of nursing and primary care partnerships. Specifically, by explicitly expanding and redefining the role of the ACT nurse, well-developed care models such as guided care can provide additional guidance and training to ACT nurses who are uniquely trained and oriented to serve as leader and coordinator. of health integration. efforts

title: transfusion medicine
abstract: The evolution of transfusion medicine into a clinically oriented discipline that emphasizes patient care has been accompanied by challenges that must be addressed as specialists look to the future. Emerging issues affecting the safety of blood and the blood supply, such as pathogen inactivation and more stringent questions about donor selection, are creating new pressures on the availability of an affordable blood supply. Imminent alternatives for anemia management, such as oxygen carriers, hold great promise but, if available, will require close monitoring. With current estimates of HIV or hepatitis C virus (HCV) transmission approaching one in 2,000,000 transfused units, keeping bacterial contamination of platelet products (one in 2000) and transfusion errors to a minimum , with an estimate of one in 800. Mortality rate ˆ000, assume great urgency. Finally, the serious difficulties in the safety and availability of blood for poor developing countries require innovative strategies and the commitment of resources.

title: Translating clinical research into clinical practice: impact of using prediction rules to make decisions
abstract: Clinical prediction rules, sometimes called clinical decision rules, have proliferated in recent years. However, very few have undergone formal impact analysis, the standard of evidence for assessing their impact on patient care. Without an impact analysis, clinicians cannot know whether the use of a prediction rule will be beneficial or harmful. This document reviews the standards of evidence for developing and evaluating prediction rules; important differences between prediction rules and decision rules; how to assess the potential clinical impact of a prediction rule before translating it into a decision rule; critical methodological issues for a successful impact analysis, including defining outcome measures and estimating sample size; the importance of close collaboration between clinical investigators and practicing physicians before, during, and after impact analysis;" and the need to measure both efficacy and effectiveness when analyzing the clinical impact of a decision rule. These considerations they should inform the future development, evaluation, and use of any clinical prediction or decision rules.

title: Translating Evidence-Based Fall Prevention into Clinical Practice in Nursing Facilities: Results and Lessons from a Quality Improvement Collaboration
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To describe changes in the care process before and after an evidence-based fall reduction quality improvement collaboration in nursing facilities. DESIGN: Natural experiment with nonparticipating facilities serving as controls. SETTING: Community nursing homes. PARTICIPANTS: Thirty-six participating and 353 nonparticipating nursing facilities in North Carolina. INTERVENTION: Two in-person learning sessions, monthly teleconferences, and an email discussion list for 9 months. The package of changes emphasized screening, labeling, and risk factor reduction. MEASUREMENTS: Compliance was measured by center self-report and graph abstraction (n = 832) before and after the intervention. Fall rates measured with the Minimum Data Set (MDS) were compared with those of non-participating facilities as an exploratory outcome. RESULTS: Self-reported compliance with screening, labeling, and risk factor reduction approached 100%. Plot abstraction revealed only modest improvements in screening (51% to 68%, P < .05), risk factor reduction (4% to 7%, P = .30), and medication evaluation (2% at 6%, P = .34). There was a significant increase in vitamin D prescriptions (40% to 48%, P = 0.03) and a decrease in sedative-hypnotics (19% to 12%, P = 0.04), but no change in the use of benzodiazepines, neuroleptics or calcium. No significant changes were observed in the proportions of people who fall or in the rates of falls according to the abstraction of the graph (28.6% to 37.5%, P = 0.17), MDS (18.2% to 15 .4%, P = 0.56) or self-report (6.1-5.6 falls/1,000 bed days, P = 0.31). CONCLUSION: Multiple risk factor reduction tasks are implemented infrequently, whereas screening tasks appear to be more easily modified in a real-world setting. Substantial differences between self-reported practice and medical record documentation require that additional data sources be used to assess processes of change in care resulting from quality improvement programs. Interventions need to be developed to enhance interdisciplinary collaboration.

title: Translating guidelines into practice: findings from a multidisciplinary preventive cardiology program in the west of Ireland
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The objective of this observational and descriptive study is to evaluate the impact of an intensive evidence-based preventive cardiology program on medical and lifestyle risk factors in patients at high risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD). METHODS: Patients at increased risk of CVD and their family members/partners were invited to attend a 16-week program consisting of professional multidisciplinary lifestyle intervention with appropriate risk factors and therapeutic management in a community setting. . Smoking, dietary habits, physical activity levels, waist circumference and body mass index, and medical risk factors were measured at baseline, at the end of the program, and at 1-year follow-up. RESULTS: Adherence to the program was high, with 375 (87.2%) participants and 181 (84.6%) couples completing the program, with 1-year data obtained from 235 (93.6%) patients and 107 ( 90.7%) couples. There were statistically significant improvements in both lifestyle (body mass index, waist circumference, physical activity, Mediterranean diet score, consumption of fish, fruits and vegetables, smoking cessation rates), psychosocial (scales of anxiety and depression and quality of life indices) and medical risk factors (blood pressure, lipids and glycemic goals) between the beginning and the end of the program, and these improvements were maintained at the 1-year follow-up. CONCLUSIONS: These findings demonstrate how a holistic model of CVD prevention can improve cardiovascular risk factors through healthier lifestyles and optimal medical management.

title: Translation of alcohol screening and brief intervention guidelines to pediatric trauma centers
abstract: BACKGROUND: As part of the American College of Surgeons' verification to be a Level 1 trauma center, centers must have the ability to identify trauma patients with at-risk alcohol use and provide intervention. Despite supporting scientific evidence and national policy statements that encourage alcohol screening, brief intervention, and referral for treatment (SBIRT), barriers still exist that prevent the integration of SBIRT into clinical care. The study objectives of this multisite translational research study were to identify best practices for integrating SBIRT services into routine care for pediatric trauma patients, measure changes in practice with the adoption and implementation of an SBIRT policy, and define the barriers and opportunities for the adoption and implementation of SBIRT Services in pediatric trauma centers. METHODS: This translational research study was conducted at seven US pediatric trauma centers over a 3-year period. Changes in SBIRT practice were measured through self-report and medical record review at three different phases of the study, namely the adoption, implementation, and maintenance phases. RESULTS: Based on medical record review, at baseline, 11% of eligible patients were screened and received a brief intervention (if needed) at all sites. After completing SBIRT technical assistance activities, the seven participating trauma centers effectively developed, adopted, and implemented SBIRT policies for injured adolescent inpatients. Additionally, across all sites, 73% of eligible patients received SBIRT services after the implementation and maintenance phases. Opportunities and barriers to successful integration were identified. CONCLUSION: This model can serve as a method for translating SBIRT services into practice within pediatric trauma centers.

title: Translation of adequacy criteria to practice guidelines: application of decision table techniques to the RAND criteria for coronary artery bypass grafting.
abstract: The process of creating clinical practice guidelines from the evidence collected has not been well defined. We have developed a technique for translating a comprehensive set of eligibility criteria into a usable set of practical guides. The criteria are derived from a formal consensus process conducted by RAND and relate to the indications for coronary artery bypass grafting in acute myocardial infarction. The clinical indications defined by the expert panel are entered as conditions in a decision table. For each combination of relevant clinical findings, the recommended action is defined by the mean Rand panel rating. The fully constructed table is then compacted using conventional decision table techniques and sorted to facilitate knowledge analysis. Ultimately, 8 narrative statements are derived from 51 rules. Augmented decision tables allow detailed data to be viewed in the summary table and accessed as needed.

title: Translation of obesity practice guidelines: interprofessional perspectives regarding the impact of intervention at the level of the public health nursing system
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The purpose of the study was to investigate the perceptions of administrators and clinicians regarding a public health-facilitated collaboration supporting the translation into practice of the Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement (ICSI) Adult Obesity Guideline. ). DESIGN AND SAMPLE: This qualitative study was conducted with 10 healthcare organizations participating in a voluntary interprofessional collaboration for obesity management. A purposive sample of 39 participants included two to three physicians and one administrator from each organization. The analysis of the interview focused on how the intervention affected the participants and their practices. RESULTS: Four themes described participants' experiences of translating the obesity guideline: (1) a shift from helplessness to positive motivation, (2) heightened awareness coupled with better responsiveness, (3) ownership personal and use of creativity, and (4) a sense of the importance of greater interprofessional collaboration. CONCLUSIONS: Research from interprofessional perspectives illuminates the feelings and perceptions of clinical participants and administrators regarding the translation of obesity practice guidelines. These themes suggest that positive motivation, capacity enhancement, personal creative ownership, and interprofessional collaboration can lead to successful implementation of evidence-based obesity guidance. Further research is needed to assess these findings in relation to translation of the ICSI obesity guideline and other guidelines into practice in various clinical settings.

title: Translation of obesity practice guidelines: measurement and evaluation
abstract: OBJECTIVE(S): A public health nurse (PHN) in the Midwestern United States (USA) led a system-level collaborative intervention to translate the Clinical Systems Improvement Institute's Adult Obesity Guideline (ICSI) to interprofessional practice. This study (1) evaluated the extent of guideline translation in organizations and (2) evaluated the Omaha System as a method for translating system-level interventions and measuring outcomes. DESIGN AND SAMPLE: This retrospective mixed-methods study was conducted with a purposive sample of one administrator (n = 10) and two to three physicians (n = 29) from each organization (n = 10). MEASURES: Omaha System Problem Rating Scale for Knowledge, Behavior, and Status (KBS) Outcomes. KBS ratings compiled from semi-structured interviews and Omaha System documentation were analyzed using standard descriptive and inferential statistics and triangulated findings with participant citations. RESULTS: KBS ratings and participant citations revealed the effectiveness of the intervention in creating sustained system-level change. Self-reported and observed KBS ratings demonstrated improvement across all organizations. There was moderate to substantial agreement regarding achievement of benchmarks within organizations. On average, self-reported improvement exceeded observer improvement. CONCLUSIONS: System-level PHN practice facilitator interventions successfully translated clinical obesity guidelines into interprofessional use in health care organizations. The Omaha System Problem Rating Scale for Outcomes reliably measured system-level outcomes.

title: Trends to Statistical Significance Trap: Likelihood that Nearly Significant P-Value Will Become More Significant with Additional Data
abstract: When faced with a P value that has failed to meet some specific threshold (usually P<0.05), authors of scientific articles may hint at a "trend toward statistical significance" or otherwise suggest that failure to achieve statistical significance was due to insufficient data. This paper presents a quantitative analysis to show that such descriptions give a misleading impression and undermine the principle of accurate information. P-values that fail to reach the conventional significance level of PÃ¢â€°Â¤0.05 are regularly reported as moving in that direction. Phrases like Ã¢â‚¬Å"nearly/approaching statistical significance" or, more tellingly, a "trend toward statistical significance" continue to find their way into journal articles with high impact factors.1 In In this article, we examine the mathematical basis for this assumption and assess the extent to which a nearly significant P value can predict movement toward a future significant P value by adding additional data. We also explored the probability that the additional data would lead to a significant result and, finally, how confident one could be that a repeated experiment would independently yield statistically significant results. The clearest context in which to consider the correct interpretation of a p value is within a randomized trial. Fisher described how the "simple precaution of randomization will suffice to ensure the validity of the test of significance." Treatment effect may explain any observed difference in outcome between groups. The AP value tells us the extent to which chance alone can explain the observed difference and acts as a "snapshot" measure of the strength of the evidence at the end of the trial. As evidence accumulates, conclusions become more firmly grounded. The AP value could easily be imagined as follows Ã¢â‚¬Â¦

title: Treatment of alcohol problems: making ends meet
Treatment of depression within the HIV "medical home": a guided algorithm for antidepressant management by HIV specialist clinicians
abstract: People living with HIV/AIDS (PLWHA) experience a higher prevalence of depression compared to the general population, negatively affecting antiretroviral treatment (ART) adherence and HIV-related outcomes leading to morbidity and the mortality. However, depression in this population often goes undiagnosed and untreated. The current project sought to design an evidence-based approach to integrating depression care into HIV clinics. The chosen model, measurement-based care (MBC), is based on existing guidelines and the largest randomized trial of depression treatment. MBC was adapted to the clinical realities of HIV care for use in a randomized controlled trial of the effectiveness of depression management in three academic HIV clinics. Tailoring takes into account drug interactions critical to the continued efficacy of ART and can be performed by a multidisciplinary team of non-mental health providers. A treatment algorithm was developed that enables clinically supervised non-physician depression care managers (DCMs) to track and monitor antidepressant tolerability and response to treatment, while supporting clinicians. Non-psychiatric prescribers with the choice and dosage of antidepressants. Quality of care is ensured through weekly supervision of DCMs by psychiatrists. Key areas of flexibility that have been important in implementation have included flexibility in the timing of assessments, accommodating divergences between algorithm recommendations and provider decisions, and accommodating delays in implementation of treatment plans. This adaptation of the MBC model to HIV care has taken into account the critical interactions between antidepressants and antiretrovirals and has facilitated the provision of quality antidepressant treatment within the HIV medical home.

title: Treating obesity with a novel handheld device, software, and Internet technology in primary care: the SMART motivational essay.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the short-term motivational effect of a technology-based weight reduction program for obese adults. METHODS: One hundred eleven middle-aged (45.5+/-10.8 years) obese (37.0+/-5.8 kg/m(2)) adults (62% women) were randomly assigned to a usual or experimental care (SMART: self-monitoring and resting metabolic rate technology). The usual care group received a standard nutritional program according to national guidelines. All participants received a comprehensive weight management program consisting of motivational interviewing (MI) sessions and automated behavioral email newsletters. Body weight, blood pressure, and psychobehavioral constructs were assessed over 12 weeks. RESULTS: Completion analysis (n = 80) indicated significant improvement in body weight (-3.9%), systolic blood pressure (-4 mmHg), and all motivational constructs after the 12-week study (p < or = 0.05). However, there were no significant differences between the groups at any time period. CONCLUSION: Based on these data, a comprehensive 12-week weight loss program consisting of MI and automated behavioral email newsletters with or without SMART is effective in treating obese adults. PRACTICE IMPLICATIONS: Although both treatment programs were equally effective, clinicians should consider a treatment program that meets the patient's needs. This study was registered with ClinicalTrials.gov NCT00750022.

title: Treatment and prophylaxis of recurrent urinary tract infections
abstract: Recurrent urinary tract infections are typical diseases of sexually active young women. Only older women show significant rates of underlying diseases, mostly urological. In addition to behavioral changes, long-term antimicrobial therapy remains the mainstay of both prophylaxis and therapy. This report provides information on the etiology of recurrent urinary tract infections. Strategies for prevention are illustrated. The actual meanings of organic remedies and antibiotics are discussed, respectively";" ineffective therapies are identified. In addition, a perspective is offered on promising new therapies, that is, vaccines that have already been tested in clinical trials.

title: Treatment of anxiety disorders in primary care practice: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Anxiety disorders are prevalent in primary care. Psychological treatment is effective but time consuming and there are waiting lists for secondary care. Therefore, interest has grown in developing treatment guidelines that are feasible in primary care. OBJECTIVE: To compare the efficacy and feasibility of guided self-help, the Dutch College of General Practitioners Guidelines on Anxiety Disorders, and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). STUDY DESIGN: Randomized controlled study of 12 weeks duration with follow-up at 3 and 9 months for primary care patients with panic disorder and/or generalized anxiety disorder. SETTING: The first two forms of treatment were performed by 46 physicians who were randomly assigned to one or the other form. CBT was performed by cognitive behavioral therapists in a psychiatric outpatient clinic. METHOD: Participants (n = 154) were randomly assigned to one of three forms of treatment. The main outcome measure used was the state subscale of the Spielberger Anxiety Inventory. RESULTS: All three forms of treatment gave significant improvement between pre-test and post-test, and this improvement remained stable between post-test and follow-ups. The results obtained with the three forms of treatment did not differ significantly over time. The feasibility of the Anxiety Disorders Guidelines was low compared to that of guided self-help. CONCLUSION: Our results indicate that primary care patients with prevalent anxiety disorders for whom referral is not considered necessary by the GP can be adequately managed by the GP. Referral to the psychiatric outpatient clinic does not give better results. Guided self-help is easier for the GP to carry out than less structured treatment such as that set out in the Anxiety Disorders Guidelines.

title: Treatment of childhood memories: theory and practice
abstract: With the growing interest of cognitive behavioral therapy in early developmental psychopathology such as personality disorders, there is a greater need for therapeutic methods to more directly treat pathogenic schemas. Exploring and reinterpreting memories of early childhood experiences that are assumed to have contributed to pathogenesis is increasingly seen as a promising way to modify core schemas. Experiential methods seem to be the most effective. This article analyzes two main forms of these methods: (i) imagery with rewriting and (ii) role play, both of children's interactions with key figures. For both, the protocols are provided as guidelines for clinicians and to encourage standardization so that this new field can be opened up for experimental research. Theoretical views on why these methods might be so effective in treating chronic problems that originate in childhood are discussed.

title: Treatment of common 'life event' traumas
abstract: BACKGROUND: General practitioners are confronted daily with patients who have experienced distressing 'life events'. Helping patients through this process can present a significant challenge. OBJECTIVE: This article points to the reactive symptomatology that can be overtly present or hidden in a stressful event and its subsequent reactions, establishes the goal of restoring a person's functioning and their own resources, and provides guidelines on what counseling can do for a patient. DISCUSSION: People trying to cope with a distressing 'life event' or the aftermath of trauma can be helped effectively by early, short-term counselling. Although this task may not be to the liking of the busy GP, many accessible interventions can restore a person's coping capacity and avert the prospect of ongoing and deeper pathology. Many symptoms do not fit the diagnostic categories generally associated with stress disorders. Some may display social engagement issues and social phobia";" others may describe low self-esteem, states of distress, relationship dissatisfaction, and maladjustment in key behavioral areas.
