The task is to help the person gain a different perspective on the distressing event, their own abilities, and the supportive influences around them.

title: Treatment of myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome: a systematic review for a National Institutes of Health pathways to prevention workshop.
abstract: Background: Myalgic encephalomyelitis (ME)/chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) is a debilitating multisystem condition that affects more than 1 million adults in the United States. Purpose: To determine the benefits and harms of treatments for adults with ME/CFS and to identify future research needs. Data sources: MEDLINE, PsycINFO, and Cochrane databases (January 1988 to September 2014)"; clinical trial registries; reference lists and manufacturer information. Study selection: English-language randomized trials of efficacy and adverse effects of ME/CFS treatments Data extraction: Data on participants, study design, analysis, follow-up, and outcomes were extracted and confirmed Study quality was dually rated using of prespecified criteria, discrepancies resolved by consensus Data synthesis: Among 35 treatment trials that enrolled participants primarily By meeting the 1994 Oxford and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention CFS case definitions , the immune modulator rintatolimod improved some measures of exercise performance compared with placebo in 2 trials (low-solid evidence ez). Trials of galantamine, hydrocortisone, IgG, valganciclovir, isoprinosine, fluoxetine, and several complementary medications were inconclusive (insufficient evidence). Graded and stepped exercise therapy compared with no treatment, relaxation, or support improved fatigue, function, global improvement, and work impairment in some trials;" counseling therapies also improved quality of life (evidence of strength low to moderate) Harm was rarely reported in the studies (insufficient evidence) Limitation: trials were heterogeneous and limited by size, number, duration, applicability, and methodological quality Conclusion: trials of rintatolimod, counseling therapies, and graded exercise therapy suggest a benefit for some patients who meet CFS case definitions, while evidence for other treatments and harms is insufficient More definitive studies comparing participants are needed that meet different case definitions, including MS, and that provide subgroup analyzes for the fill research gaps.

title: Treatment of seasonal affective disorder
abstract: Seasonal affective disorder (SAD), winter type, is characterized by regular annual onset of major depressive episodes during the fall or winter, followed by spontaneous remission and sometimes manic or hypomanic episodes during the spring and summer. SAD is clinically important, affecting approximately 2-5% of the general population in temperate climates. Since the first description of the syndrome, investigators have attempted to elucidate the pathophysiologic antecedents of SAD. Bright light therapy has been proposed as the treatment of choice for this disorder. However, numerous studies have also investigated appropriate psychopharmacological treatments for SAD. This report aims to provide an overview of the clinical management and current therapeutic options for SAD.

title: Treatment Services for Children with ADHD: A National Perspective
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To summarize knowledge about treatment services for children and adolescents with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), trends in services from 1989 to 1996, types of services provided, mix of services, and barriers to treatment. the attention METHOD: A review of the literature and analysis of 2 national surveys of medical practices are presented. RESULTS: There have been major changes in stimulant prescriptions since 1989, and prescriptions now comprise three-quarters of all doctor visits for children with ADHD. Between 1989 and 1996, related services, such as health counseling, for children with ADHD increased 10-fold and diagnostic services increased 3-fold. However, the provision of psychotherapy fell from 40% of pediatric visits to only 25% in the same period of time. Follow-up care also dropped from over 90% of visits to just 75%. Family doctors were more likely than pediatricians or psychiatrists to prescribe stimulants and less likely to use diagnostic services, provide mental health advice, or recommend follow-up care. About 50% of children with identified ADHD who are seen in real-world practice settings receive care that corresponds to the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry guidelines. Physicians reported significant barriers to providing services for these children, including a lack of pediatric specialists, insurance barriers, and long waiting lists. CONCLUSIONS: Trends in treatment services and clinician variations in service delivery point to important gaps between the research base and clinical practice. Clinical variations may reflect differences in training, inequality in the availability of specialists and location of services, and changes in health care incentives.

title: Trends in the social control of medical and psychiatric research
Activation of anti-smoking advice by doctors: mode of action of an intervention that stimulates advice to quit smoking by doctors
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the mode of action of an intervention (GP desktop resource, GDR) that increased the frequency of general practitioner (GP) advice to quit smoking. METHODS: Analyzes were performed to differentiate between three hypotheses about the mode of action of RDA. That the RDA acts: (1) by altering the attitudes of physicians, (2) independently of attitudes by prompting physicians to intervene with smokers, or (3) by altering the relationship between attitudes and behavior. RESULTS: The GDR was an independent predictor of the number of patients advised to quit smoking (beta = .345, p < .001). Concern about the doctor-patient relationship was the only attitudinal variable that independently predicted giving advice, in this case negatively (beta = -.465, p < .001). Possession of the GDR did not alter physicians' opinion about whether intervening with smokers harmed the physician-patient relationship, but it weakened the relationship between this attitude item and the number of patients advised to stop smoking (beta = . 595, p < .001). for interaction). CONCLUSION: This study is the first to show that concern about the doctor-patient relationship was an independent predictor of giving advice, whereas in other studies it has simply been flagged as something that GPs express concern about. A simple device designed to trigger action by clinicians appeared to work by mitigating the negative effect of an attitudinal barrier to action. It would be interesting to explore this phenomenon more generally in relation to health promotion activities by health professionals. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: Recommendations that GPs engage in health promotion activities with their patients should take into account that GPs' concerns about damaging the doctor-patient relationship may deter them from performing such interventions. The GDR appears to be effective in prompting GPs to advise their smoking patients to stop smoking and its widespread distribution to GPs should be considered.

title: Tumor boards: optimizing the structure and improving the efficiency of the multidisciplinary management of cancer patients worldwide
abstract: Currently, multidisciplinary tumor management boards are held around the world for the management of cancer patients. Studies evaluating its influence on decision-making and patient outcome are limited";" however, single center studies reported significant changes in diagnosis and treatment plans. A survey of Arab countries showed widespread use of and reliance on tumor boards for decision-making. A recent multi-institutional survey of Veterans Affairs (VA) hospitals in the United States found a limited association between the presence of tumor boards and care and outcomes. The Cancer Care Outcomes Surveillance and Research Consortium analyzed the association between tumor panel characteristics and measures of quality of care. Results of overall survival among patients of these physicians participating in tumor boards are ongoing, but preliminary results are described in this article along with a recent survey of international ASCO members on the presence, use, and the influence of tumor joints. Tumor boards enable the implementation of clinical practice guidelines and can help capture cases for clinical trials. Efforts to improve the preparation, structure, and conduct of tumor boards, research methods to monitor their performance, teamwork, and outcomes are also described in this article. The concept of mini-tumor plaques and more efficient methods for MDM in resource-limited countries are also discussed. In suboptimal settings, such as small community hospitals, rural areas, and areas with limited resources, the limits in diagnosis and management can be overcome, or at least improved, with tumor boards, especially with the use of videoconferencing facilities. Studies from the UK demonstrated that special multidisciplinary team (MDT) training led to better team dynamics and communication, improved patient satisfaction and improved clinical outcome. This article also reviews the weight of benefits against the time and effort spent on improving efficiency, patient care, and better time management in the United States and in the international cancer community.

title: Turning Knowledge into Action at the Point of Care: The Collective Experience of Nurses Facilitating the Implementation of Evidence-Based Practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Facilitation is seen as a way to enable clinicians to implement evidence in practice by solving problems and providing support. Practice development is a well-established movement in the UK incorporating the use of facilitators, but in Canada, the role is more obtuse. Little research has looked at the facilitation process described by people with experience of guideline implementation in North America. OBJECTIVE: To describe the tacit knowledge about facilitation embedded in the experiences of nurses implementing the evidence in practice. METHODS: Twenty nurses from across Canada were intentionally selected to attend an interactive knowledge translation symposium to examine what worked and what didn't in implementing evidence in practice. This study is a further in-depth analysis of the data collected at the symposium that focuses on facilitation as an intervention to improve evidence capture. The critical incident technique was used to obtain examples to examine nurses' facilitation experiences. Participants shared their experiences with each other and completed the initial data analysis and coding collaboratively. Data were analyzed thematically using the constant comparison qualitative inductive approach. RESULTS: A number of factors emerged at various levels associated with the successes and failures of participants' efforts to facilitate evidence-based practice. Successful implementation was related to: (a) focus on a priority issue, (b) relevant evidence, (c) development of strategic alliances, (d) use of multiple strategies to effect change, and (e) characteristics and approach of the facilitator. Negative factors that influenced the process were: (a) poor commitment or ownership, (b) resource shortfall, (c) conflict, (d) contextual issues, and (e) lack of evaluation and sustainability. CONCLUSIONS: Factors at the individual, environmental, organizational and cultural levels influence the facilitation of evidence-based practice in real situations at the point of care. With a greater understanding of the factors that contribute to successful or unsuccessful facilitation, future research should focus on examining facilitation interventions designed to address barriers and improve facilitators of evidence capture.

title: Two cheers or three for treatment guidelines? Pushing prescribers in the right directions
Type 2 diabetes mellitus in youth
abstract: In the United States, the incidence of type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) in children and adolescents has increased at an alarming rate. Early recognition and intervention can delay the onset of type 2 DM and prevent long-term complications. School nurses have an essential role in implementing the American Diabetes Association (ADA) recommended screening guidelines to identify youth at high risk for type 2 DM and in implementing student health programs that target positively on the importance of physical activity and healthy eating habits. The purpose of this article is to present an overview of the epidemiology, pathophysiology, complications, diagnosis and treatment, as well as the recommended guidelines for screening for type 2 DM in children. The information provided will increase awareness, promote screening, and empower the school nurse to more effectively promote healthy lifestyle education.

title: Undergraduate medical education: current status and future needs
Understanding and preventing criminal recidivism among adults with psychotic disorders
abstract: The high prevalence of adults with psychotic disorders in the criminal justice system has received much attention recently, but our understanding of this problem is marked by divergent opinions. Mental health professionals point to deinstitutionalization and our fragmented mental health system as major causes. Criminologists downplay the role of mental illness and hold that people with and without mental illness are arrested for the same reasons. Meanwhile, practice guidelines offer little guidance to clinicians on how to tackle the problem. Drawing on contemporary crime prevention principles, as well as current knowledge of psychotic disorders and their treatment, this article presents a conceptual framework for understanding and preventing criminal recidivism. The framework highlights the importance of individual and service system risk variables and emphasizes the central role of treatment nonadherence as a mediator between modifiable risk variables and recidivism. Building on the conceptual framework described in this article, three intervention elements necessary to prevent recidivism among adults with psychotic disorders are presented: competent care, access to services, and legal influence. Research is needed to further define and test these intervention elements as a basis for future service delivery efforts.

title: Understanding and promoting smoking cessation: overview and guidelines for medical intervention
abstract: This chapter describes the requirements for successful smoking cessation and for effective treatments. Presents practical guidelines for physicians and allied health care providers with specific recommendations on how to motivate and assist patients to quit smoking "on their own" and how to select more intensive supportive treatment if necessary. Helpful guides, references, and resources are suggested, with recommendations on the optimal use of nicotine gum.

title: Understanding the diagnosis and management of dementia and guideline implementation in general practice: a qualitative study using the domains theoretical framework
abstract: BACKGROUND: Dementia is a growing problem causing a substantial burden on patients, their families and society. General practitioners (GPs) play an important role in the diagnosis and management of dementia"; however, there are gaps between current and recommended practice. The aim of this study was to explore the reported practice of physicians in diagnosing and management of dementia and describe, terms, proposed explanations for practice that was and was not consistent with evidence-based guidelines.METHODS: Semi-structured interviews were conducted with GPs in Victoria, Australia.The domain-theoretical framework ( TDF) guided the data collection and analysis. The interviews explored the factors that hinder and enable the achievement of 13 recommended behaviors. The data was analyzed through thematic and content analysis. This document presents a detailed description of the factors that influence two behaviors, assessing comorbid depression using a validated tool and performing a cognitive assessment f normal. using a validated scale. RESULTS: A total of 30 clinicians were interviewed. Most clinicians reported that they did not assess comorbid depression using a validated tool according to recommended guidance. Barriers included the belief that depression can be adequately assessed using general clinical indicators and that validated tools provide little additional information ('Beliefs about Consequences' theoretical domain); discomfort in using validated tools ('Excitement'), possibly due to limited training and confidence ('Skills'; 'Beliefs about skills'); limited awareness of the need for and forgetting to carry out an evaluation for depression ('Knowledge'; 'Memory, attention and decision processes'). Most reported practicing in a manner consistent with the recommendation to perform a formal cognitive assessment using a validated scale. The key factors that enabled this were awareness of the need for cognitive assessment ("Knowledge"); possess the necessary skills and confidence ('Skills'; 'Ability Beliefs');" and have adequate time and resources ('Context and Environmental Resources'). CONCLUSIONS: This is the first study to our knowledge that uses a theoretical approach to investigate the barriers and facilitators to guideline-recommended diagnosis and management of dementia in general practice Has identified key factors that are likely to explain the adoption of the guidelines by GPs The results have informed the design of an intervention aimed at supporting practice change according to dementia guidelines, which is currently being evaluated in a cluster randomized trial.

title: Understanding how physician evaluation produces its effects: a realistic review protocol
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Doctors in the UK are now required to take part in revalidation to maintain their license to practise. The appraisal is a fundamental component of the revalidation. However, objective evidence that screening changes physician behavior and directly results in better patient care is limited. In particular, it is unclear how the evaluation process is supposed to change physician behavior and improve clinical performance. The aim of this research is to understand how and why the assessment of physicians is supposed to produce its effect. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: The realist review is a theory-based, interpretive approach to evidence synthesis. It applies the realist logic of research to produce an explanatory analysis of an intervention, that is, what works, for whom, under what circumstances, in what respects. Using a realist review approach, an initial program evaluation theory will be developed by consulting with key stakeholders in physician evaluation in expert panels (ethical approval not required) and searching the literature to identify relevant existing theories. The search strategy will have a series of phases including a combination of: (1) searching electronic databases, eg, EMBASE, MEDLINE, the Cochrane Library, ASSIA, (2) searching for 'cited by' articles, ( 3) citation search, (4) contact with authors, and (5) gray literature search. The search for evidence will be iteratively expanded and refocused as the review proceeds. Studies will be included based on their ability to provide data to test the theory of the program. Data extraction will be carried out, for example, by taking notes and annotations at different stages of revision, in accordance with the realist approach. The evidence will be synthesized using realist logic to question the final program theory on the impact of evaluation on the performance of physicians. The results of the synthesis will be written according to the RAMESES guidelines and will be disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and presentations. TEST REGISTRATION NUMBER: The protocol is registered with PROSPERO 2014:CRD42014007092.

title: Understanding the implementation processes of clinical pathways and clinical practice guidelines in pediatric settings: a study protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: Canada is among the most prosperous nations in the world, but the health and well-being outcomes of Canadian children are shockingly poor. There is some evidence to suggest that these poor health outcomes are due in part to clinical practice variation, which may stem from failure to apply the best available research evidence in clinical practice, also known as knowledge translation ( KT). Surprisingly, clinical practice variation, even for common acute pediatric conditions, is widespread. Clinical practice variation results in unnecessary medical treatments, increased suffering, and higher health care costs. This study focuses on improving health outcomes for common pediatric acute health problems by evaluating strategies that improve KT and reduce clinical practice variation. DESIGN/METHODS: Using a multiple case study design, qualitative and quantitative data will be collected from four emergency departments in Western Canada. Data sources will include: pre- and post-implementation focus group data from multidisciplinary health professionals"; individual interviews with local champions, KT intervention providers, and unit/site leaders/managers; survey data from Alberta Context Tool (ACT);" and aggregated patient outcome data. Qualitative and quantitative data will be systematically triangulated and matrices will be constructed to make comparisons between cases. Explanations on the success or lack of success of clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) and acceptance of clinical pathways (CPs) will be constructed based on cross-case comparisons. IMPORTANCE: This study will generate new insights into the potential mechanisms and causal factors that shape implementation. Future studies will track the impact of CPG/CP implementation on children's health outcome and health care costs.

title: Understanding noncompliance with colorectal cancer screening: a case-control study, nested in a randomized trial
abstract: Background The main limit to the effectiveness of colorectal cancer screening is often poor compliance. We studied reasons for noncompliance and determinants of compliance with fecal occult blood tests in Lazio, Italy. Methods This is a case-control study nested within a trial that tested the effect of test type and provider on adherence to colorectal cancer screening. Non-compliant trial subjects were classified as cases and compliant subjects were classified as controls. We sampled 600 cases and 600 controls matched by their general practitioner, half were invited for screening at the hospital and the other half directly at their general practitioner's office. Cases and controls answered questions about: distance from the test provider, logistical problems, colorectal cancer risk perception, confidence in screening efficacy, fear of results, presence of colorectal cancer in the family, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Results About 31% of cases never received the letter offering free screening, and 17% of the sampled population had already been screened. The first reported reason for noncompliance was "lack of time" (30%)";" the main determinant of adherence was distance from the test provider: odds ratio >30 minutes vs. <15 minutes 0.3 (95% CI = 0.2-0.7). The odds ratio for lack of time was 0.16 (95% CI 0.1-0.26). The effect was stronger if the provider was the hospital (0.03 95% CI = 0.01 to 0.1) rather than the general practitioner (0.3 95% CI = 0.2 to 0.6) . Twenty-two percent of the controls were accompanied by someone to the test. Conclusion To increase compliance, screening programs should involve testing providers that are geographically close to the target population.

title: Understanding acceptance of mobile technology by clinicians: insights from two telephone interviews in Finland
abstract: This paper sets out to investigate the perceptions and use of physicians regarding a new mobile medical information system in a pilot test in the health sector in Finland. Two sets of data were collected in June and October 2003 through telephone interviews. The doctors interviewed had positive perceptions of the mobile system and began to use it frequently in their work. They showed few negative experiences using Nokia Communicator. They favored the use of mobile technology as a way to improve the dissemination of medical knowledge. The main contents of the system, the Evidence-Based Medical Guidelines and the Pharmaca Fennica (the pharmacopoeia), were crucial to using the system. Some differences in physician behavior over time were also found. Implications for system improvement are discussed.

title: Understanding the practice: factors influencing the management of mild traumatic brain injury in the emergency department: a qualitative study using the Theoretical Domains Framework
abstract: BACKGROUND: Mild head trauma is a common cause of presentation in the emergency department. Despite the availability of clinical practice guidelines in this area, there is variation in practice. One of the goals of the Neurotrauma Evidence Translation program is to develop and evaluate a targeted, theory- and evidence-based intervention to improve the management of mild traumatic brain injury in Australian emergency departments. This study is the first step in the intervention development process and uses the Theoretical Domains Framework to explore perceived factors influencing the adoption of four key evidence-based recommended practices for the management of MTI. METHODS: Semi-structured interviews were conducted with emergency personnel in the Australian state of Victoria. The interview guide was developed using the Theoretical Domains Framework to explore current practice and identify factors that are perceived to influence practice. Two researchers coded the interview transcripts using thematic content analysis. RESULTS: A total of 42 participants (9 Directors, 20 physicians, and 13 nurses) were interviewed over a seven-month period. Results suggested that (i) prospective assessment of posttraumatic amnesia was influenced by: "knowledge"; beliefs about consequences; environmental context and resources; skills; social/professional role and identity; and beliefs about abilities; (ii) the Use of criteria developed by guidelines or decision rules to inform the appropriate use of a CT scan was influenced by: knowledge; beliefs about consequences; environmental context and resources; memory, attention, and decision processes; beliefs about abilities ; social influences; skills and behavior regulation ; (iii) providing verbal and written information to the patient about discharge was influenced by: beliefs about consequences; context and environmental resources; memory, attention and decision processes; role and social identity/ professional; and knowledge; (iv) the practice of providing brief information, the follow-up Routine treatment at discharge was influenced by: environmental context and resources; role and social/professional identity; knowledge. edge; beliefs about consequences"; and motivation and goals. CONCLUSIONS: Using the Theoretical Domains Framework, factors believed to influence the management of mild traumatic brain injury in the emergency department were identified. These factors present theoretically based goals. for future intervention.

title: Understanding the Neurobiology, Assessment, and Treatment of Substances of Abuse and Dependence: A Guide for the Critical Care Nurse
abstract: What do I do as an intensive care nurse? Nurses, by virtue of being trained in health promotion and also because they interact with patients, families and communities, have first-hand opportunities to play an active role in primary prevention practice. To prevent the first occurrence of substance abuse, assess community needs, assess facility needs, and identify potential risk. Identify the magnitude of the problem. Intervene early with youth and at-risk populations. Refer patients and their families to mental health specialists. Provide education to patients, families, communities. To reduce occurrences of substance abuse, the practice of secondary prevention requires prompt action in the earliest moments of recognizing a problem and directing patients to early intervention and rehabilitation. Assessment of your patients, brief education, and prompt referral constitute early intervention. To slow the progression of the disease, practice tertiary prevention by providing education, counseling, and support to those affected to achieve and maintain sobriety through medication adherence and counseling and group rehabilitation work. The goal of intervention in the lives of substance users is to stop drug use, prevent relapse, and maintain recovery. After years of research, NIDA has identified 13 fundamental principles for effective drug abuse treatment. 1. Addiction is a complex but treatable disease that affects brain function and behavior. 2. No single treatment is appropriate for everyone. 3. Treatment must be readily available. 4. Effective treatment addresses multiple needs of the individual, not just their drug abuse. 5. It is essential to remain in treatment for an adequate period of time. 6. Counseling (individual and/or group) and other behavioral therapies are the most widely used forms of drug abuse treatment. 7. Medications are an important element of treatment for many patients, especially when combined with counseling and other behavioral therapies. 8. A person's treatment and service plan must be continually evaluated and modified as necessary to ensure that it meets his or her changing needs. 9. Many people addicted to drugs also have other mental disorders that need treatment. 10. Medically assisted detoxification in the early stage of addiction treatment alone does little to change long-term drug abuse. 11. Treatment does not need to be voluntary to be effective. 12. Drug use during treatment must be continuously monitored, because failures occur during treatment. 13. Treatment programs should screen patients for HIV/AIDS, hepatitis B and C, tuberculosis, and other infectious diseases, as well as provide specific risk reduction counseling to help patients modify or change treatment regimens. behaviors that put them at risk of contracting or spreading infectious diseases. To truly impact this disease, there is a need to improve identification of risk factors and early identification and early intervention with children and adolescents. The future of neuroscience lies in objective brain scans and genetic testing. More objective measures of addiction and dependence using brain scans and genetic testing may emerge from these approaches. These measures would potentially allow the development of vaccines for specific drugs of abuse and dependence, as well as increasingly selective and effective pharmacological approaches to treatment and a new consensus on the standard of care for substance dependence.

title: Understanding the performance of community health volunteers involved in delivering health programs in underserved areas: a realistic synthesis
abstract: Background Recruitment of community health volunteers (CHVs) to support the delivery of health programs is an established approach in underserved areas and particularly where health inequalities exist due to a shortage of trained human resources. However, there is a paucity of evidence on what works to improve the performance of CHVs. This review aimed to synthesize the existing literature to explain why, how, and under what circumstances intervention approaches to improve VHC performance are most likely to be successful. Methods We perform a realistic synthesis. We identified candidate theories related to our review questions, which then guided the selection, evaluation, and analysis of primary studies. Publications of interest dating from 2008 to 2012 were identified through a systematic search of the PubMed and IDEAS databases. All study designs that examined various aspects of HCV performance in the context of formal organizational settings were considered eligible, and studies that did not provide an explanation of HCV performance in either the findings or the discussion part were excluded. discussion. The data was organized according to its reference to the context, interventions, outcomes and mechanisms to identify the interaction between them. Data synthesis allowed us to determine explanatory patterns within or between studies. Results We identified broad intervention approaches within the 23 articles included in the review: positioning of the CHV within the community, establishment of clear roles, provision of ongoing and skills-based training, incentives, supervision and logistical support for distribution and implementation of chores. The findings provided information on which mechanisms (self-esteem, sense of duty, self-efficacy, sense of being treated fairly) to target when implementing such approaches, and which contextual factors (stable cultural, political and social context and support and intervention closely linked to local health services) create the most favorable conditions for these mechanisms to occur, ultimately contributing to a better performance of the CHV. Four main explanatory patterns around these mechanisms emerged as fundamental to better performance. Conclusions The patterns identified, combined with the assumptions of designers and other stakeholders about how such interventions are expected to work, can be tested through empirical studies to provide useful information for use by program implementers, policymakers, and donors. . and the community

title: Unemployment and mortality in Denmark, 1970-80
abstract: Relative mortality in the period 1970-80 was studied among Danish men and women who were unemployed and employed on the day of the 1970 census. The study population consisted of the total working population in the age range 20-64 years on 9 November 1970, that is, about 2 million employed and 22,000 unemployed. Relative mortality was analyzed using a multiplicative hazard regression model (as a natural extension of the standardized mortality ratio) and a multiplicative regression model with extra-Poisson variance. A significantly higher mortality rate (40-50%) was found among the unemployed after adjusting for occupation, housing category, geographic region, and marital status. Analysis of the five leading causes of death showed an increase in mortality from all causes, but especially from suicide or accidents. In areas where the local unemployment rate was comparatively high, the relative mortality among the unemployed was lower. The increased mortality among the unemployed was interpreted as a consequence of health-related selection as well as increased susceptibility associated with the psychosocial stress of unemployment.

title: Unequal protection of patients' rights: the gap between the university and health ethics committees
abstract: Despite the recommendations of the Cartwright Report, ethical review by health ethics committees has continued in New Zealand without health professionals having to recognize their dual role as health professionals investigating their own patients. On the other hand, universities explicitly identify doctor/researcher-patient relationships as potentially generating role conflict problems. This stems from the recognition within the university sector itself that professor/researcher-student relationships are plagued by such conflicts. Although it is noted that similar unequal relationships exist between health researchers and their patients, patients/subjects do not receive the levels of protection afforded to students/subjects. In this article we argue that the difference between universities and health research is the result of the failure of the Standard Operating Code for Ethics Committees to explicitly recognize the vulnerability of the patient and the conflict of interest in the dual roles of doctor/researcher. Of the health. We end the article by recommending that the Ministry of Health consider rewriting the Standard Operating Code of Ethics Committees, in particular the rewriting of article 26 of the Standard Operating Code of Ethics Committees. We also identify the value of comparative ethical review and suggest the trilateral relationship of the Health Research Council of New Zealand with the NHMRC (National Health and Medical Research Council) of Australia and the CIHR (Canadian Institute of Health Research) of Australia. Canada as a useful starting point for such a process.

title: Unhealthy consumption patterns and receipt of preventive medical services by older adults
abstract: BACKGROUND: Use of preventive services among older adults is suboptimal. Unhealthy alcohol use may be a risk factor for not receiving these services. OBJECTIVES: To determine the relationship between unhealthy alcohol use and receipt of recommended preventive services among older Medicare beneficiaries, applying the framework of current alcohol use guidelines. DESIGN/METHODS: The data source is the 2003 nationally representative Survey of Current Medicare Beneficiaries. The sample included community-living fee-for-service Medicare beneficiaries age 65 and older (N = 10,523). Based on self-reported alcohol use, respondents were classified as nondrinkers, guideline drinkers, exceeding monthly but not daily limits, or heavy episodic drinkers. Using survey and claims data, influenza vaccination, pneumonia vaccination, glaucoma screening, and receipt of mammograms were determined. Bivariate and logistic regression analyzes were performed. RESULTS: Overall, 70.3% received influenza vaccination and 49% received glaucoma screening during the year, 66.8% received pneumonia vaccination, and 56.2% of women received a mammogram for 2 years. In logistic regression, heavy episodic alcohol consumption was associated with a lower probability of receiving the service compared to consumption within the guidelines: influenza vaccination (OR 0.75, CI 0.59-0.96) , glaucoma screening (OR 0.74, CI 0.58-0.95) and vaccination against pneumonia (OR 0.75, CI 0.59-0.96). Non-drinkers, compared with those who reported drinking within guidelines, were less likely to receive a mammogram (OR 0.83, CI 0.69-1.00). CONCLUSIONS: Heavy episodic alcohol use is associated with a lower likelihood of receiving various preventive services. Practitioners should be encouraged to screen all older people for alcohol use and, in addition to appropriate intervention, consider older people who report episodes of heavy drinking to be at increased risk of not receiving preventive services.

title: Unintended effects of a near-alert stop-computerized medical order entry to prevent a drug interaction: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background The effectiveness of computerized physician order entry (CPOE) systems has been modest, largely because physicians frequently override electronic alerts. Methods To assess the efficacy of a near "snap stop" CPOE prescription alert aimed at reducing concomitant orders for warfarin and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, a randomized clinical trial was conducted at 2 academic medical centers in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. A total of 1,981 physicians were assigned to either an intervention group that received a near-sudden-stop alert or a control group that received standard practice. The duration of the study was from August 9, 2006 to February 13, 2007. Results The proportion of desired responses (i.e., not reordering the drug that activates the alert within 10 minutes after activation) was 57, 2% (111 of 194 hard stop alerts) in the intervention group and 13.5% (20 of 148) in the control group (adjusted odds ratio, 0.12; 95% confidence interval, 0.045-0 ,33). However, the study was terminated early due to 4 unintended consequences identified among patients in the intervention group: a delay of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole treatment in 2 patients and a delay of warfarin treatment in another 2 patients. electronic hard stop as part of an inpatient CPOE system appeared to be extremely effective in changing prescription. Intervention precipitated clinically important treatment delays in 4 patients who required immediate pharmacological treatment These results illustrate the importance of formal evaluation and monitoring of unintended consequences of the program matic interventions aimed at improving prescribing habits.

title: Update on interventions focused on clusters of symptoms: what has been tried and what have we learned?
abstract: PURPOSE OF REVIEW: Although clusters of symptoms are recognized by clinicians and researchers, attention has focused on relieving a single symptom. This review summarizes the recent literature on interventions that focus on alleviating clusters of symptoms in cancer patients. RECENT FINDINGS: Twelve intervention studies that met the inclusion criteria were published in 2011-2012. The time frame was extended to 2009-2012 and 24 studies met the criteria: 18 in early stage and 6 in patients with advanced stage cancer. Various cognitive behavioral therapy, complementary therapy, and exercise interventions have shown positive results in relieving a variety of symptom clusters in various cancer types. Most psychoeducational interventions that used traditional formats or those combined with automated medical alerts demonstrated effectiveness in reducing a variety of clusters. The groups that included fatigue and anxiety or depression were reduced by exercise in early-stage patients and by methylphenidate in late-stage patients. Current NIH-funded studies R01 verified trends in the types of interventions being tested. SUMMARY: Few interventions have been tested and found to be effective in relieving specific symptom clusters in patients with early and advanced cancer. Future research should further our understanding of the mechanisms that initiate concurrent symptoms. Mechanism-targeted interventions need to be identified and tested in homogeneous samples with specific symptom clusters. Interventions need to be replicated before guidelines can be established.

title: Update on pediatric hyperlipidemia
abstract: PURPOSE OF REVIEW: The purpose of this study is to review the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHBLI) guidelines on the detection and management of hyperlipidemia in children and discuss concerns of critics regarding universal screening. RECENT FINDINGS: Data derived from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey have shown favorable trends in serum lipid levels among children and adolescents aged 6 to 19 years between 1988-1994 and 2007-2010. Mean total cholesterol (TC) decreased from 165 to 160 mg/dl, and the prevalence of elevated TC decreased from 11.3 to 8.1%. However, between 2007 and 2010, about 20% of children ages 9 to 11 had low high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) or high non-HDL cholesterol. This warrants further evaluation according to NHBLI guidelines. ABSTRACT: The NHBLI guidelines present clinicians with a balanced perspective for the detection and management of hyperlipidemia in children. These guidelines provide a schematic approach to help primary care physicians make treatment decisions. The hope is that this will lead to decreased health care system spending and better overall health through early identification and intervention.

title: American medical researchers, the Nuremberg Doctors' Trial, and the Nuremberg Code. A review of the findings of the Advisory Committee on Human Radiation Experiments
abstract: The Advisory Committee on Human Radiation Experiments (ACHRE), established to review allegations of abuse of human subjects in federally sponsored radiation research, was charged with identifying appropriate standards for evaluating the ethics of human radiation experiments. the Cold War. A central question for ACHRE was to determine what role, if any, the Nuremberg Code played in the standards and practices of American medical researchers. Based on evidence from the ACHRE Oral History of Ethics Project and extensive archival research, we conclude that the Code, at the time it was enacted, had little effect on leading medical researchers involved in research involving human subjects. Although some clinical investigators raised questions about conducting research with human subjects, the medical profession did not address the issue until the 1960s.

title: Use and effect of health information exchange: a systematic review
abstract: Background: Health information exchanges (HIEs) are on the rise in the United States and are incentivized by government policy. Purpose: To systematically review and appraise the evidence for the use and effect of HIE in clinical care. Data sources: Selected databases from January 1, 2003 to May 31, 2014. Study selection: Hypothesis tests or quantitative studies in English of various types of data sharing between non-affiliated organizations for use in care clinic that addressed health outcomes, efficiency, utilization, costs, satisfaction, HIE use, sustainability, and attitudes or barriers. Data Extraction: Data extraction was performed in duplicate. Data Synthesis: Low-quality evidence from 12 hypothesis-testing studies supports an effect of HIE use in reducing use or costs in the emergency department. Direct evidence that providers used HIEs was reported in 21 studies involving 13 different HIE organizations, 6 of which were located in New York, and generally showed use in less than 10% of patient encounters. Results from 17 sustainability studies suggest that approximately a quarter of existing HIE organizations are considered financially stable. Findings from 38 studies on attitudes and barriers showed that providers, patients, and other stakeholders view HIE as valuable, but barriers include technical and workflow issues, cost, and privacy concerns. Limitation: publication bias, possible selective reporting of results, and paucity of reporting on context and implementation processes. Conclusion: Use of health information exchange likely reduces emergency department use and costs in some cases. Effects on other outcomes are unknown. All stakeholders say they value HIE, but there are many barriers to acceptance and sustainability. A small portion of operational HIEs have been evaluated and more research is needed to identify and understand success factors.

title: Use and avoidance of seclusion and restraint: Consensus statement of the American Association of Emergency Psychiatry Project Seclusion and Restraint Beta Task Force.
abstract: Issues related to reducing and/or eliminating episodes of seclusion and restraint for patients with behavior problems in crisis clinics, emergency departments, inpatient psychiatric units, and specialized psychiatric emergency services continue to be an area of concern and debate. among mental health physicians. An important underlying principle of the BETA (Best Practices in Assessment and Treatment of Agitation) Project is non-coercive de-escalation as the intervention of choice in the management of acute agitation and threatening behavior. In this article, the authors discuss various aspects of seclusion and restraint, including review of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services guidelines governing its use in behavioral health settings, the negative consequences of this intervention for patients, and staff, and a review of quality improvement and risk management strategies that have been effective in decreasing its use in various treatment settings. An algorithm designed to help the clinician determine when isolation or restraint is most appropriate is presented. The authors conclude that specialized psychiatric emergency services and emergency departments, due to their treatment of primarily acute patients, may not be able to completely eliminate the use of seclusion and restraint events, but these programs can adopt strategies to reduce their utilization rate. interventions.

title: Use and Care of Animals in Research and Teaching: MMA Policy Statement
Use of a clinical decision support tool to improve adherence to guidelines for the treatment of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus: skin and soft tissue infections.
abstract: Skin and soft tissue infections (SSTIs) with abscess are commonly seen in the emergency department (ED) setting. Given the increasing prevalence of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus-aureus (MRSA)-related abscesses, appropriate evidence-based decisions are essential to ensure treatment success. Provider adherence to clinical guidelines for the treatment of SSTIs with suspected MRSA remains inconsistent in terms of prescriptive practice related to antibiotic selection, wound culture, and patient discharge recommendations regarding the use of infection control techniques. . Evidence indicates that the use of clinical decision support (CDS) tools is valuable in improving provider awareness and adherence to clinical guidelines. This study was conducted to examine whether developing a CDS tool to guide order entry for treatment of MRSA-related SSTIs and integrating it into the electronic medical record program would improve providers' compliance with the Consensus Guidelines of North Carolina for the management of suspected cases in the community. MRSA acquired in skin and soft tissues.

title: Using a computer to detect and respond to clinical events: Its effect on clinical behavior.
abstract: computer was used to prospectively detect and suggest responses to simple medication-related events as reflected in a computerized record in a prospective, randomized study from a diabetes clinic with primary care responsibility. There were two categories of events/suggestions: when the last observation of a test required for drug monitoring was too old, the computer suggested a repeat; and when an abnormality with therapeutic implications was detected, the computer suggested a specific change in therapy. Physicians responded to 36% of events in the first category with computer-assisted reminders and 11% without (p < 0.0001);" they responded to 28% of events in the second category with computer-assisted and 13% without her (P < 0.026).For the most clinically significant of these second-category events, the difference was even greater: 47% with and 4% without computer assistance (P < 0.0004).I think computer detection and response ( in the form of reminders) to simple clinical events will change the behavior of the doctor.

title: The use of a computerized guideline for glucose regulation in the intensive care unit improved both adherence to the guideline and glucose regulation.
abstract: Objective: To measure the impact of a computerized guide for glucose regulation in an ICU. Design: A randomized controlled trial with an off-on-off design. Methods: We implemented a glucose regulation guide in an intensive care unit on paper during the first study period. During the second period, the guide was applied randomly in paper or electronic format. In the third period, the guide was available only on paper. Measurements and results: We analyzed data from 484 patients. During the intervention period, the control group included 54 patients and the computerized intervention group included 66 patients. The two guideline-related outcomes consisted of adherence to: (a) glucose measurement time recommendations and (b) insulin dose recommendations. We measured clinical impact as the proportion of time that glucose levels fell within the target range. In the first study period (on paper), 29.0% of the samples were taken at the optimal time; during the second period, this increased to 35.5% for paper protocols and 40.2% for computerized protocols. Late (suboptimal) sampling occurred for 66% of glucose measurements in the first study period, for 42% of paper-based and 28% of computer-based protocol samples in the second period, and for 50.0% of the samples in the third study period. In the first study period, compliance with insulin dosing guidelines was 56.3%;" in the second period it was 64.2% for paper protocols and 77.3% for computerized protocols, and decreased to 42.4% in period 3. For the second study period, the time a patient's glucose values were within the target range improved for both the control (52.9%) and the computerized groups (54 .2%) compared to the first study period (44.3%) and the third period (42.3%).Conclusion: Implementation of a computerized version of a guideline significantly improved the timeliness of measurements and glucose level regulation for critically ill patients compared to implementing a printed version of the guideline.

title: Use of a decision aid that includes information on overscreening to support informed choice about breast cancer screening: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Screening mammography may reduce mortality from breast cancer. However, most women are unaware that inconsequential diseases can also be detected by screening tests, leading to overdiagnosis and overtreatment. Our aim was to investigate whether including information about breast cancer overscreening in a decision aid would help women in their 50s make an informed decision about breast screening. Methods We conducted a community-based parallel-group randomized controlled trial in New South Wales, Australia, using a randomized cohort of women aged 48 to 50 years. Recruitment for the study was done by phone"; women were eligible if they had not had a mammogram in the past 2 years and had no significant personal or family history of breast cancer. Using a computer program, we randomly assigned 879 participants to an intervention decision aid (comprising evidence-based quantitative and explanatory information on overscreening, reduction in breast cancer mortality, and false positives) or a control decision aid (comprising information on reduction in breast cancer mortality and false positives) allocation The primary outcome was informed choice (defined as adequate knowledge and consistency between attitudes and screening intentions), which we assessed by interview telephone about 3 weeks after randomisation.The primary outcome was analyzed in all women who completed n follow-up relevant interview questions fully This trial is registered with the Australian New Zealand Clinical Tria ls Register, number ACTRN12613001035718. Results Between January 2014 and July 2014, 440 women were assigned to the intervention group and 439 to the control group. 21 women in the intervention group and 20 controls were lost to follow-up; another ten women assigned to the intervention and 11 controls did not answer all questions about attitudes. Therefore, 409 women in the intervention group and 408 controls were analyzed for the primary outcome. 99 (24%) of 409 women in the intervention group made an informed decision compared to 63 (15%) of 408 in the control group (difference 9%, 95% CI 3-14; p=0 0017) . Compared with controls, more women in the intervention group reached the adequate general knowledge threshold (122/419 [29%] vs 71/419 [17%]; difference 12%, 95% CI 6–18; p<0 0001), fewer women expressed positive attitudes toward screening (282/409 [69%] vs. 340/408 [83%]; 14%, 9–20; p<0 0001), and fewer women had intention to undergo screening (308/419 [74%] vs. 363/419 [87%]; 13%, 8–19;" p<0 0001). When conceptual knowledge alone was considered, 203 ( 50%) of 409 women in the intervention group made an informed decision compared to 79 (19%) of 408 in the control group (p<0 0001) Interpretation Information on breast cancer overdetection provided within a decision aid increased the number of women who made an informed decision about breast screening Being better informed could mean women are less likely to choose screening.

title: Use of a fall prevention practice guideline for community-dwelling older people at risk of falls: a feasibility study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Falls among older people occur frequently and are a common cause of physical and psychological morbidity and health care utilization. The problem can be attributed to a complex interplay between environmental, behavioral, and health-related factors. To ensure a consistent, evidence-based approach, a practical guideline for fall prevention in community-dwelling older people at risk of falls was developed. OBJECTIVE: To test the feasibility of integrating a fall prevention practice guideline into the daily practice of 4 primary health care disciplines, i.e. general practitioners, nurses, occupational therapists and physical therapists. METHODS: This was a descriptive study conducted by 10 local health networks located in Flanders. The subjects involved in the study were 99 primary care workers and 1142 elderly patients (65 years or older) who lived in the community and who could get up from a chair and move around independently. For 6 months, primary care workers implemented our 3-part fall prevention guideline (case finding, in-depth multifactorial assessment, and interventions). After the 6-month test phase, participating primary care workers were asked to complete a semi-structured questionnaire to assess the feasibility of using the guideline in daily practice. RESULTS: The mean time used to carry out the guideline was 32.0+/-14.0 min. The health workers of the 4 disciplines considered that the search for cases was their responsibility. The picture was different for risk factor assessment and interventions. Although 87.5% considered fall prevention to be an important topic, health workers from different disciplines could not agree on how to integrate the prevention guide into daily practice. The perceived barriers to implementing the guideline were lack of time (57.3%), low motivation of the target population (53.3%), and insufficient cooperation among health workers (37.3%). CONCLUSION: A guide can be used to initiate the integration of prevention strategies in daily practice. Case search is feasible for all disciplines. Multifactorial assessments and interventions require specific task assignments, multidisciplinary cooperation, and clear communication.

title: Use of action plans to increase provision of smoking cessation care by general practitioners: role of specificity and plan enactment
abstract: Background Strategies are needed to help general practitioners (GPs) promote smoking cessation as recommended by guidelines. This study examines whether the quality of action planning among GPs improves their delivery of smoking cessation care. Methods The efficacy of a 1-hour training program was examined in a cluster randomized controlled trial involving 49 GPs. GPs who followed the training (intervention group";" n?=?25) formulated action plans related to i) asking about smoking, ii) giving advice to quit smoking and iii) organizing follow-up of smokers motivated to quit smoking. Doctors also formulated a coping plan to meet smokers who are not motivated to quit. The quality of these plans (plan specificity) was rated and, 6 weeks after training, GPs reported on the performance of these plans (plan implementation). Multilevel regression analyzes were used to examine the effects of plan specificity and plan implementation on patient-reported smoking cessation activities of GPs in the intervention group (n = 1632 patients) compared with the control group (n = 1769 patients). Results Compared to the control group, GPs who formulated a highly specific action plan during the training asked their patients about smoking more often after the training than before the training (OR 2.11, CI 95%: 1.51 to 2.95). GPs were more likely to have asked patients about smoking after training compared to before training when they had enacted a highly specific formulated action plan (OR 3.08, 95% CI 2, 04 to 4.64). The effects of GP plan specificity and plan enactment on asking the patient about smoking were more prominent among GPs who, at baseline, intended to provide smoking cessation care. Conclusions A very specific action plan formulated by a GP about when, how and who will ask patients about smoking had a positive effect on GPs asking patients questions about smoking, especially when these professionals also reported enacting this plan. This effect was most prominent among GPs who intended to provide smoking cessation care before the intervention. Training in designing personalized coping plans is recommended to further augment GP advice to quit smoking and organize follow-up support to quit smoking.

title: Using an Internet portal to improve community-based pediatric ADHD care: a cluster randomized trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the effectiveness of a quality improvement program in improving pediatricians' adherence to existing evidence-based practice guidelines for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). METHODS: Forty-nine community pediatricians in 8 practices participated in a cluster randomized trial. Practices were matched based on the number of pediatricians and the proportions of patients receiving Medicaid. Medical records of a random sample of ADHD patients from each of the participating pediatricians were reviewed at baseline and at 6 months. All practices participated in 4 training sessions, which included educational conferences and office flow modification workshops. Clinics were then given access to an ADHD Internet portal that allowed parents, teachers, and pediatricians to enter information (eg, rating scales) about patients, after which the information was scored, interpreted and formatted in a report style that was useful for the assessment and treatment of patients with ADHD. Physicians evaluated their practice behaviors quarterly and addressed areas of poor performance. RESULTS: Pediatricians in the intervention group, compared with those in the control group, demonstrated significantly higher rates of many ADHD care practices recommended by the American Academy of Pediatrics, including collecting parent ratings (d of Cohen = 0.69) and the teacher (d = 0.68). scales for the assessment of children with ADHD, use of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fourth Edition, criteria (d = 0.85), and use of teacher rating scales to monitor responses to treatment (d = 1 .01). CONCLUSION: A quality improvement intervention that can be widely disseminated through the use of Internet-based information technology significantly improved the quality of ADHD care in pediatric community settings.

title: Use of antibiotics. Septicemia
Use of evidence in WHO recommendations
abstract: Background WHO guidelines, dating from 1951, emphasize the role of expert opinion in developing recommendations. However, the organization's guidelines, approved in 2003, emphasize the use of systematic reviews for evidence of effects, processes that allow the explicit incorporation of other types of information (including values), and evidence-based implementation and dissemination strategies. We examine the use of evidence, particularly evidence of effects, in recommendations developed by WHO departments.";" Background WHO guidelines, dating from 1951, emphasize the role of expert opinion in developing recommendations. However, the organization's guidelines, approved in 2003, emphasize the use of systematic reviews for evidence of effects, processes that allow the explicit incorporation of other types of information (including values), and evidence-based implementation and dissemination strategies. We examine the use of evidence, particularly effects evidence, in recommendations developed by WHO departments.

title: Warfarin use at discharge among patients with acute ischemic stroke and nonvalvular atrial fibrillation in China.
abstract: BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE: Guidelines recommend oral anticoagulation for ischemic stroke patients with atrial fibrillation, and previous studies have shown underuse of anticoagulation for these patients in China. We try to explore the reasons and underlying factors that currently affect the use of warfarin in China. METHODS: From June 2012 to January 2013, 19,604 patients with acute ischemic stroke were admitted to 219 urban hospitals that voluntarily participate in the China National Stroke Registry II. Multivariate logistic regression models using the generalized estimating equation method were used to identify patient/hospital factors independently associated with warfarin use at discharge. RESULTS: Among 952 patients with acute ischemic stroke with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation, 19.4% were discharged on warfarin. The risk of bleeding (52.8%) and patient refusal (31.9%) were the main reasons for not prescribing anticoagulation. Larger/teaching hospitals were more likely to prescribe warfarin. Older patients, heavy drinkers, patients with a higher National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale score at admission were less likely to receive warfarin, while patients with a history of heart failure and a normalized ratio between 2.0 and 3.0 during hospitalization were significantly associated with warfarin use at discharge CONCLUSIONS: The rate of warfarin use remains low among patients with ischemic stroke and known nonvalvular atrial fibrillation in China. Hospital size and academic status along with patient age, heart failure, heavy alcohol use, hospital international normalized ratio, and admission stroke severity were independently associated with warfarin use to high. There is much room for improvement for secondary stroke prevention in patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation in China.

title: User satisfaction and frustration with a portable pen-based asthma guideline delivery system
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the satisfaction and frustration of physicians with the use of a portable computer system that implements a guide for the treatment of childhood asthma exacerbations. SETTING: Nine pediatric primary care practices. DESIGN: Survey component of a prospective randomized before-after trial. INTERVENTION: Newton MessagePad equipped with custom software (called "AsthMonitor") that aids in the documentation of clinical findings and provides guideline-based recommendations. RESULTS: Overall, 3 users gave very positive overall ratings, while 6 users were neutral. Most used the documentation features at the same time as care. Except for the recommendations to administer oxygen (which were not supported by evidence), users found the recommendations appropriate and appreciated the reminders. Seven of 9 participants believed that it took them longer to document with AsthMonitor. CONCLUSIONS: Handheld computers are acceptable to some office professionals for providing guideline-based advice within the context of the clinical encounter.

title: Using "Nudge" Principles for Order Set Design: A Before and After Evaluation of an Electronic Prescribing Template in Critical Care
abstract: Objective Computerized order sets have the potential to reduce clinical variation and improve patient safety, but the effect is variable. We sought to assess the impact of changes in the design of an established order on the delivery of chlorhexidine and hydroxyethyl starch (HES) mouthwash to patients in the intensive care unit. Methods The study was carried out at the University Hospitals of Bristol NHS Foundation Trust, UK. Our intensive care unit uses a clinical information system (CIS). All medications and fluids are prescribed with the CIS and the medication and fluid charts are stored in a database. Chlorhexidine mouthrinse was added as a default prescription to the prescription template in January 2010. HES was removed from the prescription template in April 2009. Both interventions were available for manual prescription throughout the study period. We performed a database review of all eligible patients for each intervention before and after changes to option settings within the prescription system. Results: 2231 ventilated patients were identified as suitable for treatment with chlorhexidine, 591 before the intervention and 1640 after. 55.3% were prescribed chlorhexidine before the change and 90.4% after (p<0.001). 6199 patients were considered at the HES intervention, 2177 before the intervention and 4022 after. The mean volume of HES infused per patient decreased from 630 mL to 20 mL after the switch (p<0.001) and the percentage of patients receiving HES decreased from 54.1% to 3.1% (p<0.001). These results held up well over time. Conclusions The presentation of options within an electronic prescription system influenced the delivery of evidence-based interventions in a predictable manner and the effect was well sustained. This approach has the potential to improve the effectiveness of computerized order sets.

title: Using a Taxonomy of Behavior Change Techniques to Identify Active Ingredients in Trials of Implementation Interventions for Diabetes Care
abstract: BACKGROUND: The methodological guidelines for the intervention report emphasize the detailed description of the content of the intervention. Despite this, systematic reviews of implementation quality improvement (QI) interventions continue to be limited by a lack of clarity and detail regarding the content of the intervention being evaluated. Our aim was to apply the newly developed Taxonomy of Behavior Change Techniques version 1 (BCTTv1) to trials of implementation interventions to control diabetes to assess the ability and utility of this taxonomy to characterize active ingredients. METHODS: Three psychologists independently coded a random sample of 23 trials of health system, provider, and/or patient-focused implementation interventions from a systematic review that included 142 such studies. Intervention content was coded using BCTTv1, which describes 93 behavior change techniques (BCTs) grouped into 16 categories. We supplement the generic coding instructions within BCTTv1 with decision rules and examples from this literature. RESULTS: Less than a quarter of the putative BCTs were identified within BCTTv1. For implementation interventions targeting providers, the most commonly identified BCTs included the following: adding objects to the environment, cues/cues, instruction on how to perform the behavior, credible source, goal setting (outcome), feedback on the outcome of the behavior and social. support (practical). For implementation interventions that are also directed at patients, the most frequently identified BCTs included the following: cues/cues, instruction on how to perform the behavior, information on health consequences, restructuring of the social environment, addition of objects environment, social support (practical), and goal setting (behavior). The BCTTv1 mapped well to implementing interventions directly targeting clinicians and patients and could also be used to examine the impact of system-level interventions on clinician and patient behavior. CONCLUSIONS: The BCTTv1 can be used to characterize active ingredients in implementation intervention trials and provides content specificity beyond that given by broader intervention labels. Identifying BCTs may provide a more useful means of accumulating insights into the content used in trials of implementation interventions, which may help better inform replication efforts. Furthermore, prospective use of a taxonomy of behavior change techniques to develop and inform intervention content would further help build a cumulative science of effective implementation interventions.

title: Using a Planned Behavior Theory Framework to Explore '5 Critical Moments' Hand Hygiene Beliefs Among Australian Hospital Nurses
abstract: BACKGROUND: Improving hand hygiene among healthcare workers (HCWs) is the single most effective intervention to reduce healthcare-associated infections in hospitals. Understanding the cognitive determinants of hand hygiene decisions for HCWs with increased patient contact (nurses) is essential to improve compliance. The objective of this study was to explore the beliefs of hospital nurses associated with performing hand hygiene guided by the 5 critical moments of the World Health Organization (WHO). Using the Planned Behavior Theory belief-base framework, we examine the attitudinal, normative, and control beliefs that underpin nurses' decisions to perform hand hygiene according to recently implemented national guidelines. METHODS: Thematic content analysis of qualitative data from focus group discussions with hospital registered nurses from 5 wards in 3 hospitals in Queensland, Australia. RESULTS: important advantages (protection of the patient and oneself), disadvantages (time, damage to the hand), referents (support: patients, colleagues"; "lack of support: some doctors), barriers (being too busy, situations of emergency) and facilitators (accessibility of sinks/products, training, reminders). There was some ambiguity regarding the relative importance of handwashing after contact with the patient environment. CONCLUSIONS: The belief base of planned behavior theory provided a useful framework to systematically explore the beliefs underlying nurses' hand hygiene decisions according to the 5 critical moments, allowing comparisons with previous belief studies. . A commitment to improve nurses' hand hygiene practice in the 5 Moments should focus on individual strategies to combat distraction from other tasks, peer-based initiatives to foster a sense of shared responsibility, and management-driven solutions to address problems. of staff and resources. Hand hygiene after touching a patient's environment remains the most neglected compliance opportunity.

title: Using Appreciative Inquiry to promote evidence-based practice in nursing: the glass is more than half full
abstract: It is now understood that the successful implementation of evidence-based practice (EBP) requires an approach in the context of the care setting. While constraints and barriers are the focus of many reports, this paper proposes a new approach to "making EBP happen". Appreciative Inquiry (AI), both a social research method and an organizational development or change intervention, is a novel means of generating enthusiasm and support for EBP in nursing. Readers will be introduced to the theoretical underpinnings and assumptions as well as the "4-D Model" of AI. It is proposed that the advanced practice nurse (APN) is in a key position to introduce and support this intervention in health organizations to promote the successful implementation of EBP.

title: Use of computerized clinical decision support for the detection of latent tuberculosis infections.
abstract: Background The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) have published guidelines recommending screening for high-risk groups for latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI). The aim of this study was to determine the impact of computerized clinical decision support and web-based guided documentation on LTBI detection rates. Design Prospective, non-randomized intervention study. Setting and participants Participants were 8,463 patients seen at two community public health center outpatient primary care clinics in late 2002 and early 2003. Intervention CDC LTBI guidelines were codified into a decision support system computerized clinics that provided an alert recommending further LTBI risk assessment if certain guideline criteria were met (born in a high-risk TB country and age <40). A web-based guided documentation tool was provided to facilitate proper compliance with the LTBI screening guideline and to promote accurate documentation and assessment. Baseline data was collected for 15 weeks and study phase data was collected for 12 weeks. Main outcome measures Adequate detection of LTBI according to CDC guidelines based on chart review. Results Among the 4135 patients who were registered during the post-intervention phase, 73% had at least one risk factor defined by the CDC and 610 met the alert criteria (born in a country with high risk of TB and minors 40 years) for the potential detection of LTBI. Adherence to the LTBI screening regimen improved significantly from 8.9% at baseline to 25.2% during the study phase (183% increase, p < 0.001). Conclusions This study demonstrated that computerized clinical decision support using alerts and guided web-based documentation increased screening of high-risk patients for LTBI. This type of technology could lead to improved screening for LTBI in the United States and also promises better care for other chronic and preventative conditions.

title: Using Implementation Intentions to Teach Practitioners: Changing Practice Behaviors Through Continuing Education
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This study evaluated the effectiveness of implementation intentions in increasing the use of a practice behavior among mental health professionals who attended a one-day continuing education class. METHODS: Seventy-eight professionals were randomly assigned to one of two classes of psychiatric advance directives. One class incorporated instruction in implementation intentions (N=40) and the other class did not (N=38). Implementation intent training involved participants describing the best time and place to use a physician-guided procedure to help consumers complete a psychiatric advance directive. Use of the physician-guided procedure was the dependent variable in this study. The use of the procedure in practice was evaluated three months after the class through an electronic self-report survey. RESULTS: There were no statistically significant differences between the two class conditions in participant characteristics or pre- or post-class knowledge and intentions to use the procedure. Fifty-four participants (69%) responded to the three-month follow-up survey, indicating that they had used the professionally guided procedure. Results from the follow-up survey showed that, overall, those who attended the class that incorporated implementation intentions used the practitioner-led procedure much more often than those in the other class (80% vs. 58%). The effect of implementation intentions on practitioner-guided procedure utilization was evident among practitioners whose post-class intentions were high but lower than the median for the overall sample (chi(2)=7.1, df=1, p<.01). Implementation rates among professionals with the highest post-class intentions were equivalent in the two class conditions. CONCLUSIONS: Incorporating implementation intentions into continuing education classes may increase the use of the practices taught in these classes among well-motivated professionals.

title: Using Implementation Intentions to Teach Practitioners: Changing Practice Behaviors through Continuing Education.
abstract: Objective: This study evaluated the effectiveness of implementation intentions in increasing the use of a practice behavior among mental health professionals who attended a one-day continuing education class. Methods: Seventy-eight professionals were randomly assigned to one of two classes on psychiatric advance directives. One class incorporated instruction in implementation intentions (N=40) and the other class did not (N=38). Implementation intent training involved participants describing the best time and place to use a physician-guided procedure to help consumers complete a psychiatric advance directive. Use of the physician-guided procedure was the dependent variable in this study. The use of the procedure in practice was evaluated three months after the class through an electronic self-report survey.
