Results: There were no statistically significant differences between the two class conditions in participant characteristics or pre- or post-class knowledge and intentions to use the procedure. Fifty-four participants (69%) responded to the three-month follow-up survey, indicating that they had used the professionally guided procedure. Results from the follow-up survey showed that, overall, those who attended the class that incorporated implementation intentions used the practitioner-led procedure much more often than those in the other class (80% vs. 58%). The effect of implementation intentions on practitioner-guided procedure utilization was evident among practitioners whose post-class intentions were high but lower than the median for the overall sample (? 2 = 7.1, df = 1, p < 0.01). Implementation rates among professionals with the highest post-class intentions were equivalent in the two class conditions. Conclusions: Incorporating implementation intentions into continuing education classes may increase the use of the practices taught in these classes among well-motivated professionals. (Psychiatric Services 59:747-752, 2008)

title: Using paper-based chart-based clinical reminders to improve adherence to lipid management guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND, PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVES: The aim of this study was to apply a paper-based clinical reminder to improve adherence to lipid guidelines. METHODS: Coronary heart disease (CHD) patients without lipid-lowering therapy (LLT) were recruited and medical records were reviewed. Eligible subjects were randomized";" a clinical reminder indicating the current standards and local insurance policy was stamped on the paper chart in the study group, but not in the control. The primary outcome was LLT re-enrollment at the 6-month follow-up period, and the secondary endpoint was the LLT composite outcome or lipid profile control. RESULTS: Ninety-two patients were assigned to the study group and 102 to the control group. The primary outcome showed no difference at the end of 6 months (OR: 1.70, P=0.248, 95% CI: 0.69-4.19). The secondary end point was significantly higher in the reminder group (OR: 2.81, P = 0.001, 95% CI: 1.57-5.04). CONCLUSION: A clinical reminder based on paper cards that provides updated clinical recommendations could modify the behavior of the physician and improve attention to lipid levels. However, its effect cannot be transformed into an increase in LLT or a decrease in low-density lipoprotein level due to local policy restriction.

title: Use of Pathology-Specific Laboratory Profiles in Clinical Pathology to Reduce Request for Inappropriate Testing – Two Audit Cycles Completed
abstract: BACKGROUND: Systematic reviews have shown that although well prepared, Consensus Guidelines have failed to change clinical practice. In the Castelnovo ne Monti health district (Reggio Emilia, Italy), it became necessary for GPs and clinical pathologists to work together to jointly define laboratory profiles. METHODS: Observational study with two retrospective audit cycles on test request forms, in a primary care setting. The goals of the study were to develop pathology-specific laboratory profiles and increase the number of provisional diagnoses on laboratory test request forms. A Multidisciplinary Multiprofessional Interhospital Task Force developed pathology-specific laboratory profiles for more effective test ordering. After 8 training sessions using a combined strategy with multifaceted interventions, all 23 general practitioners (GPs) in the test district (Castelnovo ne Monti) tested the "profiles"; the 21 doctors in Puianello district were the control group. , all physicians in both districts participated in the trial All laboratory tests for both health care districts are performed at the laboratory located in the trial district Baseline and 1-year audit performed in both districts on physician request forms RESULTS: Seven specific pathologies Outpatient laboratory profiles were developed In the year after the first audit cycle: 1) the number of tests requested in the test district was clearly lower than in the previous year above, with a decrease of about 5% (p < 0.001); 2) the provisional diagnosis on the application forms was 52.8 % in the test district and 42% in the control district (P < 0.001); 3) the decrease in the number of tests in each application form was much more marked in the t district rial (8.73 vs. 10.77; p < 0.001). CONCLUSIONS: The first audit cycle showed a significant decrease in the number of tests ordered in the test district alone. The combined strategy used in this study improved prescription compliance for most of the physicians involved. The presence of the clinical pathologist is considered an added value.

title: Use of second-generation antidepressants to treat depressive disorders: an American College of Physicians clinical practice guideline
abstract: Description: The American College of Physicians developed this guideline to present the available evidence on the pharmacological management of the acute, continuation, and maintenance phases of major depressive disorder, dysthymia, subsyndromal depression, and accompanying symptoms such as anxiety, insomnia, or depression. autonomic symptoms, using second-generation antidepressants. Methods: Published literature on this topic was identified using MEDLINE, EMBASE, PsychLit, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, and International Pharmaceutical Abstracts from 1980 to April 2007. limited to English. -linguistic studies in adults over 19 years of age Search keywords included terms for depressive disorders and 12 specific second-generation antidepressantsbupropion, citalopram, duloxetine, escitalopram, fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, mirtazapine, nefazodone, paroxetine, sertraline, trazodone, and venlafaxine and their specific trade names.This guideline rates t The evidence and recommendations using the American College of Physicians clinical practice guideline rating system. Recommendation 1: The American College of Physicians recommends that when clinicians choose a drug therapy to treat patients with acute major depression, they select second-generation antidepressants based on adverse effect profiles, cost, and patient preference (Grade: strong recommendation; moderate- quality evidence). Recommendation 2: The American College of Physicians recommends that clinicians assess the patient's status, therapeutic response, and adverse effects of antidepressant therapy on a regular basis, beginning within 1 to 2 weeks of initiation of therapy (Grade: Strong recommendation ; moderate-quality evidence). Recommendation 3: The American College of Physicians recommends that clinicians modify treatment if the patient does not have an adequate response to pharmacotherapy within 6 to 8 weeks after initiation of therapy for major depressive disorder (Grade: Strong recommendation; moderate-quality evidence). Recommendation 4: The American College of Physicians recommends that clinicians continue treatment for 4 to 9 months after a satisfactory response in patients with a first episode of major depressive disorder. For people who have had 2 or more episodes of depression, an even longer duration of therapy may be beneficial (Grade: Strong recommendation; moderate-quality evidence).

title: Using Shared Goal Setting to Improve Access and Equity: A Mixed Methods Study of the Good Goals Intervention in Child Occupational Therapy
abstract: Background Access and equity in child therapy services can be improved by directing clinicians' use of resources toward specific goals that are important to patients. A practice change intervention (entitled Â¡Â®Good GoalsÂ¡Â¯) was designed to achieve this. This study investigated the uptake, adoption, and possible effects of that intervention in occupational therapy services for children. Methods Mixed methods case studies were conducted (n = 3 services, including 46 therapists and 558 children). The intervention was delivered over 25 weeks through face-to-face training, teamwork notebooks and Â¡Â®tools for changeÂ¡Â¯. Data were collected before, during, and after the intervention on a variety of factors through interviews, a focus group, case note analysis, routine data, document analysis, and investigator observations. Results Factors related to recruitment and adoptions were: mode of implementation of the intervention, competing demands on therapists' time, and service manager leadership. Service managers and therapists reported that the intervention: helped therapists establish shared rationale for clinical decisions; increased clarity in service delivery and improved interactions with families and schools. Over the study period, the therapists' behaviors changed: identify goals, odds ratio 2.4 (95% CI 1.5 to 3.8); agreement goals, 3.5 (2.4 to 5.1);" assessing progress, 2.0 (1.1 to 3.5). ChildrenÂ¡Â¯s LoT decreased over two months [95% CI ?8 to +4?months ] across services The cost per trained therapist ranged from 1,003 to 1,277, depending on the size of the service and the salary bands of the therapists Conclusions Good Goals is a promising quality improvement intervention that can be applied and adopted in the practice and may have benefits.Further research is required to assess its: (i) impact on patient outcomes, effectiveness, cost-effectiveness, and (ii) transferability to other clinical settings.

title: Use of standardized patients to measure the professional performance of physicians
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the nature of inaccuracies likely to occur when using standardized patients (SP) to measure physician behavior and to assess the potential impact of these inaccuracies on estimates of physician performance. DESIGN: Secondary analysis of a randomized controlled trial. PLACE: Family doctor offices. STUDY PARTICIPANTS: Eighteen people, each representing one of two patient scenarios, made a total of 179 visits to 92 family physicians participating in a separate randomized controlled trial to assess the impact of an educational workshop on implementation of preventive guidelines. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Accuracy of SPs' representation of assigned scenarios and accuracy of their coding of physician performance, determined on the basis of audiotapes of visits and correlated with indicators of physicians' preventive practices. RESULTS: Accuracy of patient scenario representation was 84.8% for male SPs and 93.5% for female SPs. Inaccuracies in representation had no impact on physician performance scores. The accuracy of medical performance coding was 90.5% for female SPs (kappa = 0.66) and 90.1% for male SPs (kappa = 0.68). Coding inaccuracies occurred most frequently for assessment of alcohol consumption and advice against smoking. CONCLUSION: PS can provide valid information on the professional performance of physicians. However, the standardization of their activities should not be taken for granted. It may be more difficult to obtain standardized coding for counseling activities, an aspect of physician visits for which SPs are particularly well suited.

title: Using the Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF) to understand adherence to multiple evidence-based indicators in primary care: a qualitative study
abstract: Background There are recognized gaps between evidence and practice in general practice, an environment that poses particular implementation challenges. We previously discussed guideline recommendations to derive a set of "high-impact" indicators based on criteria that include the potential for significant patient benefit, scope for improved practice, and measurability using routinely collected data. routine. Here, we explored health professionals' perceived determinants of adherence to these indicators, examining the extent to which the determinants were indicator-specific or potentially generalizable across indicators. Methods We interviewed 60 general practitioners, nurse practitioners and practice managers in West Yorkshire, UK, about adherence to four indicators: "avoiding risky prescriptions"; treatment targets in type 2 diabetes; blood pressure targets in treated hypertension; and anticoagulation in atrial fibrillation. The interview questions were based on the Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF). Data were analyzed using frame analysis. Results Professional role and identity and environmental context and resources ranked high across all indicators, while the importance of other domains, for example, beliefs about consequences, social influences, and knowledge, varied across indicators. . We identify five metathemes that represent broader organizational and contextual factors common to all indicators. Conclusions TDF helped elicit a wide range of reported determinants of adherence to 'high impact' indicators in primary care. It was more difficult to pinpoint which determinants, if targeted by an implementation strategy, would maximize change. The metathemes broadly underscore the need to align the design of interventions targeting general practices with higher level supports and broader contextual considerations. However, our findings suggest that it is feasible to develop interventions to promote the adoption of different evidence-based indicators that share common features while including content-specific adaptations.

title: Using the Turning Research Into Practice (TRIP) Database: How Do Physicians Really Search?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Physicians and patients increasingly access information through Internet searches. This study aimed to examine physicians' current search behavior when using the Turning Research Into Practice (TRIP) database to examine search engine use and ways it could be improved. METHODS: Web log analysis of the TRIP database, a metasearch engine covering 150 health resources, including MEDLINE, The Cochrane Library, and a variety of guidelines, was performed. The term connectors used in the searches were studied and the search behaviors of 9 users were observed when working with the TRIP database. RESULTS: Of 620,735 searches, the majority used a single term and 12% (n = 75,947) used a Boolean operator: 11% (n = 69,006) used "AND" and 0.8% (n = 4941) used "OR". Of the elements of a well-structured clinical question (population, intervention, comparator, and outcome), population was used most often, while fewer searches included intervention. The comparator and the result were rarely used. Participants in the observational study were interested in learning how to formulate better searches. CONCLUSIONS: Web log analysis showed that most searches used a single term and no Boolean operators. The observational study revealed that users were interested in performing efficient searches, but did not always know how to do it. Therefore, better training or better search interfaces are required to help users and enable more effective searching.

title: Using theory to improve low back pain care in primary care for Aboriginal Australians: a mixed-method single-cohort pilot study.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Low back pain (LBP) care is frequently discordant with research evidence. This pilot study evaluated changes in low-back pain care following a theory-based systematic intervention in a rural Australian Aboriginal Health Service. Our goal was to improve three aspects of care: reduce inappropriate radiological imaging referrals for low back pain, increase patient psychosocial assessment, and increase the provision of information on low back pain self-management to patients. METHODS: Three interventions to improve care were developed using a four-step approach. systematic implementation approach. A mixed-methods pre/post cohort design assessed changes in all three behaviors using a clinical audit of low-back pain care over a six-month period before intervention and then after implementation. In-depth interviews elicited the perspectives of the general practitioners involved. (GP). The qualitative analysis was guided by the theoretical framework of the domains. RESULTS: The proportion of patients receiving guideline-inconsistent imaging referrals (GICI) improved from 4.1 GICI per 10 patients to 0.4 (95% CI for rate decrease: 1.6 to 5.6) among GPs involved in intervention Among non-participating GPs (substitute/part-time doctors who started after the intervention) the rate of GICI increased from 1.5 to 4.4 GICI per 10 patients (95% CI for the rate increase: 0.5 to 5.3). There was a modest increase in the number of patients receiving information on self-management of low-back pain from participating clinicians and no substantial change in psychosocial assessments of patients by any of the participants; however, the physicians qualitatively reported that their behaviors had changed. Knowledge and beliefs about consequences were important behavioral domains related to changes. Environmental and resource factors, including protocols for substitute staff and clinical tools integrated into patient management software, were identified as future strategies. CONCLUSIONS: A systematic intervention model resulted in partial improvements in low back pain care. The determinants of practice change among GPs were increased knowledge of clinical guidelines, education provided by someone considered a reliable source of information, and awareness of the negative consequences of inappropriate practices, especially radiological imaging on outcomes. from the patients. problem that arose and will be an important future challenge. The systematic approach used is applicable to other services interested in improving low back pain care.

title: Use of wearable devices and smartphones to track physical activity: initial activation, sustained use, and step counts across sociodemographic characteristics in a national sample.
abstract: Background: Interest in using wearable devices and smartphones to monitor daily health behaviors, such as physical activity, is growing (1, 2). Many large employers are using these technologies in workplace wellness programs (3). The Precision Medicine Initiative has outlined how the data collected by these technologies can be used to better target interventions. However, the characteristics of the people who use these devices are poorly understood. Objective: To describe the rates of initial activity tracker use, sustained use after 6 months, and step counts across different sociodemographic characteristics of a wellness program offered in the United States. Methods and Findings: Data on activity tracker use, average daily step count, and sociodemographic characteristics were obtained between 2014 and 2015 from Humana for members with access to HumanaVitality (now Go365), a wellness program offered in the U.S. Median household income from US Census data was linked by ZIP code. Data were received anonymous and were considered exempt from review by the University of Pennsylvania Institutional Review Board.

title: Validation of the SF-36 health survey questionnaire: a new outcome measure for primary care
abstract: OBJECTIVES To test the acceptability, validity and reliability of the Short Form Health Survey Questionnaire 36 (SF-36) and compare it with the Nottingham Health Profile. DESIGN Postal survey using a questionnaire booklet together with a letter from the general practitioner. Non-responders received two reminders at two-week intervals. The SF-36 questionnaire was retested on a subsample of respondents two weeks after the first mailing. SETTING Two general practices in Sheffield. PATIENTS 1980 patients aged 16 to 74 years randomly selected from the two practice lists. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Scores for each health dimension on the SF-36 questionnaire and the Nottingham Health Profile. Response to questions about recent use of health services and sociodemographic characteristics. RESULTS The response rate of the SF-36 questionnaire was high (83%) and the completion rate of each dimension exceeded 95%. Considerable evidence was found for the reliability of the SF-36 (Cronbach's alpha greater than 0.85, reliability coefficient greater than 0.75 for all dimensions except social functioning) and for construct validity in terms of distinguishing between groups. with expected health differences. The SF-36 was able to detect low levels of poor health in patients who had scored 0 (good health) on the Nottingham Health Profile. CONCLUSIONS The SF-36 is a promising new instrument for measuring health perception in the general population. It is easy to use, acceptable to patients, and meets strict criteria for reliability and validity. Its use in other contexts and with different disease groups requires further investigation.

title: Variations in GP decisions to investigate suspected lung cancer: a factorial experiment using multimedia vignettes
abstract: Introduction Lung cancer survival is low and comparatively poor in the UK. Patients with symptoms suggestive of lung cancer commonly present to primary care, but it is unclear how general practitioners (GPs) distinguish which patients require further investigation. This study examined how clinical and sociodemographic characteristics of patients influence physicians' decisions to initiate lung cancer investigations. Methods A factorial experiment was conducted among a national sample of 227 English GPs using vignettes presented as simulated consultations. An interactive multimedia website simulated the key features of consultations using actors ("patients"). GP participants made online management decisions for six 'patients', whose sociodemographic characteristics varied systematically across three levels of cancer risk. In low-risk vignettes, no investigation was indicated (i.e., ordered chest x-ray, CT scan, or referral to a respiratory consultant)"; in medium-risk vignettes, investigation might be appropriate; in high-risk vignettes, definitely indicated investigation Each 'patient' had two symptoms related to lung cancer: one voluntary and one elicited if GPs asked Variations in the likelihood of investigation were examined using multilevel logistic regression Results GPs decided to investigate the lung cancer in 74% (1000/1348) of vignettes Likelihood of investigation did not increase with cancer risk Investigations were more likely when GPs asked for information about symptoms that "patients" had but did not volunteered (adjusted OR (AOR) = 3.18, 95% CI 2.27 to 4.70 However, GPs they failed to search for this information in 42% (570/1348) of cases. Older 'patients' were less likely to be investigated by GPs than younger (AOR = 0.52, 95% CI 0.39 to 0.7) and black. 'patients' than whites (AOR=0.6 8;" 95% CI 0.48 to 0.95). GPs were no more likely to investigate 'patients' with high-risk cancer symptoms than those at low risk. In addition, they did not investigate all people with the same symptoms equally. Insufficient data collection could be responsible for missed opportunities in diagnosis.

title: Venous thromboembolism risk and prophylaxis in the acute hospital care setting (ENDORSE study): a multinational cross-sectional study
abstract: Background Information on variation in venous thromboembolism (VTE) risk and prophylaxis practices around the world is scarce. The ENDORSE (International Day of Epidemiology for Assessment of Patients at Risk for Venous Thromboembolism in the Acute Hospital Care Setting) study is a multinational cross-sectional survey designed to assess the prevalence of VTE risk in the acute hospital care setting and to determine the proportion of patients at risk receiving effective prophylaxis.";" Background Information on variation in venous thromboembolism (VTE) risk and prophylaxis practices around the world is scarce. The ENDORSE (International Day of Epidemiology for Assessment of Patients at Risk for Venous Thromboembolism in the Acute Hospital Care Setting) study is a multinational cross-sectional survey designed to assess the prevalence of VTE risk in the acute hospital care setting and to determine the proportion of patients at risk receiving effective prophylaxis.

title: Violence and Aggression: Short-Term Management in Mental Health, Health, and Community Settings: Updated Edition.
abstract: This guide has been developed to advise on the short-term management of violence and aggression in community, mental health, and mental health settings in adults, children (ages 12 and under), and youth (ages 13-17). . This guideline updates Violence: the short-term management of disruptive/violent behaviors in psychiatric inpatient settings and emergency departments (NICE clinical guideline 25), which was developed by the National Collaborating Center for Nursing and Supportive Care and published in 2005. Since Since the publication of the 2005 guideline, there have been some important advances in our knowledge about the management of violence and aggression, including the opinions of service users about the use of physical intervention and seclusion, and the effectiveness, acceptability and safety of drugs and their doses. for a quick reassurance. Previous guidance was restricted to people age 16 and older in adult psychiatric settings and emergency departments";" this update has been expanded to include some of the previously excluded populations and settings. All areas of NICE clinical guideline 25 have been updated and this guideline will replace it in its entirety. The guideline recommendations have been developed by a multidisciplinary team of health professionals, people with mental health conditions who have personally experienced the management of violent or aggressive behavior, their caregivers, and guideline methodologists after careful consideration of the best available evidence. The guide is intended to be useful to clinicians and service commissioners in providing and planning high-quality care for the management of violence and aggression, while also emphasizing the importance of these service users' experience of care. services and the experience of their caregivers. (see Appendix 1 for more details on the scope of the guide). Although the evidence base is expanding rapidly, there are a number of important gaps. The guideline makes a number of research recommendations specifically to address gaps in the evidence base. In the meantime, the guideline is expected to help clinicians, service users and carers by identifying the merits of particular treatment approaches where research evidence and clinical experience exist.

title: Violence in general practice: a study of the opinions of general practitioners
abstract: OBJECTIVE To study the scope of abuse and violence directed at general practitioners during the exercise of their professional duties and to categorize the characteristics of such aggression. DESIGN Retrospective survey of the opinions of a large sample of general practitioners using a piloted postal questionnaire. SETTING All medical practices in the West Midlands. SUBJECTS A total of 1093 general practitioners (40.6% of the total sample) who responded to the questionnaire. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE Number of aggressive incidents experienced by general practitioners over a 12-month period and the incidence of various triggers. RESULTS Although the response was low, 40.6%, this study is the largest published database on aggression towards family doctors. In total, 687 (62.9%) of the respondents had experienced abuse or violence in the previous 12 months, with 191 (17.5%) experiencing some form of abuse at least once a month and 11 (1%) they had experienced verbal abuse every month. day. Even assuming that all non-respondents did not experience violence of any kind, patient aggression affects 25.5% of GPs in the West Midlands. For those physicians who had experienced patient aggression, the annual incidence of one event per general practitioner was 2.42. In total, 96 (14%) of these general practitioners thought that aggression was increasing. A total of 1,520 (91.3%) of all incidents consisted of verbal abuse or threats without a direct physical act. Surgery was the most frequent place of aggression, with 942 (56.6%) incidents";" however, 90 (62.5%) of the assault or injury incidents occurred during home visits and 22 (66%) of the injuries were received during night calls. Family members were the aggressors in 668 (37.6%) cases, anxiety was the precipitant in 435 (25.7%) cases, and the long wait in 183 (10.8%). CONCLUSIONS Violence against general practitioners is common and may be increasing. Some of the precipitants of aggression are potentially avoidable and practices must make strenuous efforts to identify such factors and remedy them. Staff training in interpersonal skills and in recognizing anxious or intoxicated patients is essential and should be complemented by consideration of surgical design and repair. Physicians must avoid delays for patients by rearranging reservation policies or the times and duration of surgeries. Victims of aggression must be followed up. A prospective study or centralized record of incidents should be financed.

title: 'We can only do what we have the means to do' General practitioners' views on primary care for older people with complex health problems
abstract: BACKGROUND: Due to demographic change, general practitioners (GPs) are increasingly needed to care for older people with complex health problems. Little is known about physicians' subjective assessments of required changes. Our goal is to explore how general practitioners view their mandates and professional capabilities to provide comprehensive care for older people with complex health problems. Does training or experience in geriatrics influence views? Can barriers be detected for the implementation of changes in the primary care of older people with complex health problems? METHODS: Prior to a controlled intervention study on case management for older patients in the primary care setting (OMAHA II), this qualitative study included 10 general practitioners with varying degrees of geriatric qualification. Semi-structured and audio-recorded interviews were conducted. Full interview transcripts were analyzed starting with open coding based on cases and case descriptions. The emerging thematic structure was enriched with comparative dimensions through repeated case comparisons and developed into a multidimensional typology of viewpoints. RESULTS: Based on the themes emerging from the data and their presentation by the general practitioners interviewed, we were able to identify three different types of views on primary care for older people with complex health problems: 'maneuvering along across the boundaries of competence', 'Herculean task' and 'cooperation and networking'. Viewpoint types differ in role perception, perception of their own professional domain, and action patterns with respect to cooperation. One guy shows a strong correspondence with a geriatrician. Across all groups, there is a shared concern about the availability of sufficient resources to meet the challenges of primary care for older people with complex health problems. CONCLUSIONS: Limited financial resources, lack of cooperative networks, and attitudes appear to be barriers to ensuring better primary care for older people with complex health problems. To overcome these barriers, training in geriatrics is likely to have a positive impact, but must be complemented by regulations related to reimbursement. Above all, general practitioner care for older people with complex health problems needs a conceptual framework that provides guidance on their specific role and contribution and care networks. For example, it is essential that general practice guidelines be more explicit regarding the management of older people with complex health problems.

title: Web-based computer adaptation for practicing nurses to improve adherence to smoking cessation guidelines: a study protocol for a randomized controlled effectiveness trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Dutch practice nurses adhere suboptimally to evidence-based smoking cessation guidelines. Web-based computer adaptation could be effective in improving compliance with the guidelines. Therefore, this paper aims to describe the development of a web-based computer-adapted program and the design of a randomized controlled trial testing its (cost) effectiveness. METHODS: Based theoretically on the I-Change model and self-determination theory, and on the results of a qualitative needs assessment among practicing nurses, a personalized web-based program was developed that includes three modules with personalized advice, a online forum, modules with up-to-date information on smoking cessation, frequently asked questions (FAQs) and project information, and a counseling checklist. The effects of the program are evaluated by comparing an intervention group (access to all modules) with a control group (access to FAQs, project information, and counseling checklist only). Compliance with smoking cessation guidelines and behavioral predictors (ie, intention, knowledge, attitude, self-efficacy, social influence, action, and coping planning) are measured at baseline and at 6 and 12-month follow-up. In addition, the indirect effects of the program on smokers' quit rates and the number of quit attempts are assessed after 6 and 12 months. DISCUSSION: This article describes the development of a web-based adherence support software for practicing nurses and the study design of a randomized controlled trial testing its (cost) effectiveness. This program potentially contributes to improving the quality of smoking cessation care in Dutch general practices. If proven effective, the program could be adapted for use by other health professionals, increasing the public health benefits of better cessation counseling for smokers.

title: Web-based interventions for ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease: a systematic review and future directions.
abstract: Behavioral Intervention Technologies (BIT), the application of psychological and behavioral interventions through the use of technology, provide the opportunity for clinicians to deliver care through a means that overcomes a number of treatment barriers. Web-based interventions are a subset of BITs that are being developed as promising alternatives for treatment delivery and face-to-face follow-up for patients with ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn's disease (CD). A systematic review of the literature resulted in five empirical studies of web-based interventions for UC and CD. Furthermore, an informal search on a popular search engine yielded limited currently available web-based interventions for UC and CD patients. Despite being an ideal population for the development and dissemination of online interventions, UC and CD patients have far fewer treatment options compared to other behavioral health problems. However, given the growing body of research involving web-based interventions for other conditions, researchers and clinicians focusing on the management and treatment of UC and CD have the advantage of being able to use the BIT model, a existing conceptual framework for the development of web-based interventions. interventions for both conditions. The BIT model is presented and applied to the treatment of UC and CD, as well as a technology development program, Purple, and usage guidelines to guide clinical researchers in the future development, evaluation, and dissemination of BIT for UC and CD patients. CD.

title: Weekly Email Reminders Influence Emergency Physician Behavior: A Case Study Using the Joint Commission and Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services Pneumonia Guidelines
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Improving clinicians' compliance with evidence-based guidelines is challenging. The authors wanted to determine whether weekly email reminders to emergency department (ED) staff increase compliance with the Joint Commission and Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) community-acquired pneumonia quality measures. ). METHODS: A nurse administrator reviewed weekly charts for all adult patients admitted to the hospital from the emergency department with a functional diagnosis of pneumonia. Next, an email was sent to all emergency personnel indicating the percentage of patients with antibiotics within 4 hours of arrival. The names of people who administered antibiotics in less than 1 hour were highlighted. This study compared antibiotic time for 11 months before and 11 months after starting this intervention. RESULTS: There were 281 patients in the control cohort, and 37 met the exclusion criteria, leaving 244 for analysis. There were 342 patients in the intervention cohort and 40 met the exclusion criteria, leaving 302 for analysis. Median time from arrival to CXR order decreased significantly from 61 to 47 minutes (p < 0.001). The median time interval from the request for chest radiography to the administration of antibiotics did not change significantly (92 to 88 minutes, p = 0.294). The overall median time from arrival to antibiotic administration decreased significantly from 162 to 146 minutes (p = 0.018). The percentage of patients with antibiotic administration within 4 hours increased from 77.5% to 86.1% (p = 0.009). CONCLUSIONS: Weekly email reminders listing performance of antibiotic stewardship recommendations are associated with increased adherence to a clinical guideline.

title: Weight Care Project: Attitudes and capacity of health professionals to assess body weight status - study protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: Health professionals working in primary care and public health have the opportunity to address issues of body weight status with their patients through face-to-face contact. The objectives of this all-Ireland project are: 1. to assess the current attitudes, practices/behaviours and knowledge of key groups of health professionals about body weight status"; 2. to assess the capacity of professional groups to identify body weight status in both adults and children Health professional groups include: (a) community-associated public health nurses (b) school public health nurses (c) physicians bedside and practice nurses (primary care);" and (d) occupational health nurses (workplace) from both Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. METHODS/DESIGN: This multidisciplinary, all-Ireland project follows a mixed methods approach using both quantitative and qualitative methodologies, and consists of four components:1. Literature review - to explore the role of health professionals in managing obesity through spontaneous intervention in a variety of health promotion settings.2. Telephone interviews and focus groups: to obtain an in-depth view of the opinions of health professionals when evaluating body weight status.3. Survey (primarily online but also paper based) - to determine health professionals' current attitudes, practices/behaviors and knowledge in assessing body weight status.4. Online Assessment Study: An interactive online program will be developed to assess the ability of health professionals to identify body weight status in adults and children. DISCUSSION: This project will assess and report on the attitudes, current practices/behaviours and knowledge of key groups of healthcare professionals in Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland about body weight status and their ability to identify weight status body in both adults and children. The results of this project will generate recommendations for clinical practice in obesity management, which can inform policy guidelines.

title: Weight Maintenance: Challenges, Tools, and Strategies for Primary Care Physicians
abstract: Obesity is recognized as a chronic disease and one of the main health challenges we face today. Weight loss can be achieved through lifestyle, pharmacological and surgical interventions, but weight maintenance remains a lifelong challenge for people with obesity. Guidelines for the management of obesity have highlighted the role of primary care providers (PCPs). This review examines the long-term results of clinical trials to identify effective weight maintenance strategies that PCPs can use. Due to the broad nature of the topic, a structured PubMed search was conducted to identify relevant research articles, peer-reviewed reviews, guidelines, and articles published by regulatory agencies. Trials have shown the benefit of sustained weight loss in the management of obesity and its comorbidities. Maintaining 5-10% weight loss for >/= 1 year is known to improve many comorbidities. Weight maintenance with lifestyle modification, while challenging, is possible but requires long-term support to reinforce diet, physical activity, and behavioral changes. The addition of pharmacotherapy to lifestyle interventions promotes greater and more sustained weight loss. Clinical evidence and recently approved pharmacotherapy have provided PCPs with improved strategies to help their patients maintain weight loss. Further studies are needed to assess the translation of these strategies to clinical practice.

title: Weight Matters: An Approach to Childhood Overweight in General Practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: In Australia, childhood obesity now rivals asthma as the most prevalent chronic childhood health condition. The last 2 decades have shown a rapid increase in the prevalence of childhood overweight and obesity with no signs of this trajectory leveling off. Primary care is increasingly recognized as a forum in which to address this growing public health problem. OBJECTIVE: This article reviews the epidemiology of childhood overweight and obesity in Australia and its associated physical and psychosocial morbidities. Discusses the current evidence base and resources for the definition, research, and management of childhood obesity and describes an approach in the primary care setting. It also reports on a recently developed GP-led intervention to reduce overweight in primary school-age children: the Live, Eat and Play (LEAP) project. DISCUSSION: There are currently clear clinical practice guidelines for the evaluation and management of overweight and obesity in childhood in primary care. The feasibility of these guidelines and the availability of the necessary resources to deliver them is still unclear. The LEAP project proposes an effective intervention carried out by general practitioners to address this vital and complex issue.

title: Well Balanced: 8 Steps to Wellness for Adults with Mental Illness and Diabetes
abstract: Serious mental illness places an enormous burden on clients, their families, and medical and behavioral health care providers. The concurrence of diabetes with mental illness can further compromise daily functioning. Psychiatric nurses can make a significant difference in improving the health and medical outcomes of this client population. A partnership was developed between the University of Rochester School of Nursing and the Western New York Care Coordination Program to test a new nursing model for adults with serious mental illness and diabetes mellitus. The Well Balanced program incorporated health promotion, disease management, nursing care management, and evidence-based practice guidelines into 8 Steps to Wellness for a community-based mental health population. During an intervention period of 16 visits, psychiatric nurses interacted with 74 clients. As a result of the program, clients experienced improvements in their hemoglobin A1C and health risk status and reported a high degree of satisfaction with the Well Balanced program.

title: WellDoc Mobile Diabetes Management Randomized Controlled Trial: Change in Clinical and Behavioral Outcomes and Patient and Physician Satisfaction
abstract: BACKGROUND: Fewer than 63% of people with diabetes meet the professional guideline goal of hemoglobin A1c <7.0%, and only 7% meet combined goals for blood glucose, lipids, and blood pressure. The primary objective of the study was to evaluate the impact on A1c of a cell phone-based diabetes management software system used with web-based data analysis and therapy optimization tools. Secondary objectives examined healthcare provider (HCP) adherence to prescribing guidelines and assessed HCP adoption of the technology. METHODS: Thirty patients with type 2 diabetes were recruited from three community medical practices for a 3-month study and randomized evenly. The intervention group received cell phone-based software designed by endocrinologists and CDEs (WellDoc Communications, Inc., Baltimore, MD). The software provided real-time information on patients' blood glucose levels, displayed patients' medication regimens, incorporated hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia treatment algorithms, and queried additional data needed to assess diabetes control. Patient data captured and transferred to secure servers was analyzed by proprietary statistical algorithms. The system sent computer-generated records (with suggested treatment plans) to HCPs of intervention patients. RESULTS: The mean decrease in A1c for intervention patients was 2.03%, compared to 0.68% (P < 0.02, one-sided) for control patients. Of the intervention patients, the HCP titrated or changed medications in 84% compared to controls (23%, P=0.002). HCPs of intervention patients reported that the system facilitated treatment decisions, provided organized data, and reduced logbook review time. CONCLUSIONS: Adults with type 2 diabetes using the WellDoc software achieved statistically significant improvements in A1c. HCP and patient satisfaction with the system was clinically and statistically significant.

title: What are the attitudes of mental health specialists regarding the recommendations of the guidelines for the treatment of depression in young people?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: We sought to examine potential barriers to the use of evidence-based guidelines for youth depression in a tertiary specialist mental health service, as part of an initiative to implement evidence-based practice within the service. METHODS: This was a qualitative study that took a social constructionist perspective using focus groups. The focus groups, carried out with all the doctors (doctors and health allies), were audio recorded, transcribed and a thematic analysis was carried out. Clinicians were asked about barriers to implementing four key recommendations from the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) guidelines. RESULTS: Barriers existed at (i) the individual clinical level”; (ii) the clinical level regarding the presentation of young people”; and (iii) the level of service. The key barrier at the individual clinician level was a stated belief that the guidelines were not relevant to young people presenting for service, with little evidence to guide practice. Related, the main barrier regarding clinical presentation was the severity and complexity of this presentation, which often makes it difficult to deliver interventions such as cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). At the service level, the lack of integration with primary and secondary level care made sequencing interventions according to guideline recommendations difficult. CONCLUSIONS: There is a clear imperative to develop the evidence base to ensure that effective treatments are researched and disseminated for young people up to 25 years of age with serious and complex disorders that include comorbid conditions, suicide risk, and psychosocial difficulties. Furthermore, this work has highlighted the need for greater investment in models of care that ensure integration between existing primary and secondary care and improved specialized early intervention mental health services for young people.

title: What do general practitioners think and do about prostate cancer screening in Australia?
abstract: BACKGROUND: Men seek advice from their general practitioner (GP) about the merits of prostate cancer screening. This study aimed to examine how GPs' clinical knowledge and experience influenced their position on prostate cancer screening. METHODS: A total of 13 focus groups with 77 general practitioners were established. Focus group discussions were audio recorded and transcribed verbatim. The transcripts were analyzed by two researchers through thematic analysis. RESULTS: GPs were evenly split between those who proactively screen men for prostate cancer and those who do so only at the request of the patient. GPs had limited knowledge of recently published evidence from prostate cancer screening trials. DISCUSSION: Effective methods to increase GPs' knowledge of evidence-based recommendations and potentially changing clinical behavior are required to promote evidence-based decision-making by GPs and their patients.

title: What do patients and families know about problems and failures in care?
abstract: Objective To understand what patients and families know about problems and failures in health care. Design Qualitative, semi-structured and open interviews were carried out with 39 patients and 80 relatives about their experiences of incidents in the third level of health. Nineteen interviews involved more than one respondent, giving a total of 100 interviews. Participants were recruited through advertisements in large-format print media and national tabloids (43%), with the help of the health services where the incidents occurred (28%), through invitations sent by two marketing companies on the Internet (27%) and by consumers. organizations (2%). Setting Interviews were conducted in the homes of respondents or by telephone. One participant emailed her answers to the questionnaire. Results The analysis of the interview data revealed: (1) a considerable knowledge on the part of the patients and relatives about the risks, problems and incidents of the health services"; (2) the understanding of the interviewees about the opportunities of improvement of care"; and (3) the challenges that patients and family members face when trying to negotiate their knowledge and points of view with health service personnel. Conclusion Patients (and their families) need access to structured processes that ensure dialogue with health service personnel about perceived risks, problems, and incidents. Such a dialogue would reveal patients' and family members' questions and knowledge about opportunities for improvement, and minimize the risk of their questions and knowledge being ignored.

title: What do people with mental illness need to quit smoking? Perspectives from Mental Health Consumers and Providers
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Forty-one percent (41%) of people in the US who report recent mental illness also smoke cigarettes. Tobacco use among this population is associated with up to 25 years less life and excess medical comorbidity compared to the general population. Although research shows that anti-smoking interventions can be effective for people with mental illness, they are not commonly used in clinical practice. The current study explored how to tailor evidence-based smoking cessation interventions to address the unique physiological, psychological, and social challenges faced by people with mental illness. METHODS: Ten focus groups were conducted using a semi-structured discussion ";" 5 for adult mental health consumers (n = 62) and 5 with physicians and mental health administrators (n = 22). Content analysis was used to organize the topics into categories. RESULTS: Five thematic categories were found: (1) Barriers to treatment, (2) Resources and infrastructure, (3) Negative influences on smoking behavior, (4) Knowledge deficits, and (5) Treatment needs. CONCLUSIONS: These results are instructive in the development of appropriate smoking cessation services for this population. Specifically, these data have been incorporated into a smoking cessation toolkit for mental health providers and have informed the development of a smoking cessation intervention study.

title: What I would tell the Royal Commission. Our wastelands forsaken
What implementation interventions increase cancer detection rates? a systematic review
abstract: Background Proper screening can reduce mortality and morbidity from colorectal, breast, and cervical cancers. However, effective implementation strategies are warranted if the full benefits of detection are to be realized. As part of a broader agenda to create implementation guidance, we conducted a systematic review to assess interventions designed to increase the detection rate of breast, cervical, and colorectal cancer (CRC). The interventions considered were: client reminders, client incentives, mass media, small media, group education, individual education, reduction of structural barriers, reduction of out-of-pocket costs, provider evaluation and feedback interventions, and incentives. for the provider. . Our primary outcome, completion of screening, was calculated as the overall median post-intervention absolute percentage point (PP) change in completed screening. Methods Our first step was to conduct an iterative scoping review on the research area. This produced three relevant high-quality systematic reviews. Serving as our evidentiary basis, we conducted a formal update. We searched MEDLINE, EMBASE, and PSYCHinfo for randomized controlled trials and cluster randomized controlled trials, published between 2004 and 2010. Results The update produced 66 new eligible studies with 74 comparisons. The new studies varied considerably in quality. Client reminders, small media, and provider audit and feedback appear to be effective interventions to increase uptake of screening for three types of cancer. Personalized education and reduction of structural barriers also appear effective, but their roles with CRC and cervical screening, respectively, are less well established. Further studies are required to assess client incentives, media, group education, reduction of out-of-pocket costs, and provider incentive interventions. Conclusion New evidence generally aligns with the evidence and conclusions of the original systematic reviews. This review served as the evidence base for an implementation guide. Poor reporting, lack of precision and consistency in defining operational elements, and insufficient consideration of context and differences between populations are areas for further investigation.

title: What is the role of the general practitioner in relation to the family caregiver of a demented family member living in the community? A systematic review of the literature
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To identify the attitudes and perspectives of the family doctor towards the caregivers of family members with dementia and to describe the satisfaction of the caregivers. DESIGN: Systematic review. SUBJECTS: The study population consisted of family members with dementia and their general practitioners. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Outcome measures were generic general practitioner tasks and skills to improve home care from the family caregiver's perspective. Caregivers were assessed on satisfaction with the care provided by their general practitioner. RESULTS: The general practitioner is aware of his abilities and limits in all aspects of dementia care and his role vis-à-vis the family caregiver. They also recognized the importance of a proper diagnostic process, but felt uncomfortable disclosing the diagnosis to both the patient and caregiver. They reported being more confident in treatment issues than in diagnostic stages. Caregivers' reports of their GP's attitude in the diagnostic process were rated as helpful to unempathic. General practitioners were found to be highly involved in dementia home care, but carers rated their involvement as insufficient. Caregivers also did not appreciate the general practitioners' lack of appropriate communication skills. The general practitioner considered the lack of time and reward to be a major obstacle in dementia care. CONCLUSION: The key role of general practitioners as care providers and care planners is strengthened by family caregivers' confidence in their abilities. Clear guidelines from early diagnosis to appropriate referrals should improve the general practitioner's ability to support these time- and energy-consuming home care situations. Intervention studies addressing gaps in general practitioners' skills in managing dementia home care could be useful in supporting the family caregiver.

title: What is the value of routinely using patient-reported outcome measures to improve patient outcomes, care processes, and health service outcomes in cancer care? A systematic review of controlled trials
abstract: PURPOSE: The routine use of patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) has been advocated as an effective way to standardize cancer practice. However, the question of whether PROMs can lead to real improvements in the quality of patient care remains a matter of debate. This review examined whether the inclusion of PROM in routine clinical practice is associated with improvements in patient outcomes, processes of care, and health service outcomes during active cancer treatment. METHODS: A systematic review of five electronic databases (Medline, EMBASE, CINAHL [Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature], PsycINFO, and Psychology and Behavioral Sciences Collection [PBSC]) was conducted from database inception to May 2012 to locate nonrandomized controlled trials of patients receiving active anticancer therapy or supportive care, regardless of cancer type. RESULTS: Based on prespecified eligibility criteria, we included 26 articles reporting on 24 single controlled trials. Wide variability was evident in the design and use of the interventions performed, the outcomes assessed, and the cancer-specific setting and modality. Health services outcomes were hardly included as endpoints. Overall, the number of statistically significant findings was limited and intervention effect sizes for PROMs were predominantly small to moderate. CONCLUSION: Routine use of PROM increases the frequency of discussion of patient results during consultations. In some studies, PROM is associated with better symptom control, greater measures of supportive care, and patient satisfaction. Additional effort is required to ensure patient adherence, as well as additional support to clinicians who will respond to patient concerns and issues, with clear system guidelines to guide their responses. More research is required to support the cost-benefit ratio of PROM in terms of patient safety, physician burden, and use of health services.

title: What will we teach undergraduate students?
abstract: Opinions of 600 randomly selected physicians on what should be taught to undergraduates in clinical years were analysed. Respondents gave high priority to general medicine, pediatrics, general surgery, emergency medicine, and gynecology, but low priority to forensic medicine, plastic surgery, radiation therapy, anesthesia, radiology, and rehabilitation medicine. Physicians thought these should be taught to postgraduates. The two main groups of physicians, general practitioners and consultants, gave essentially the same priorities. Undergraduate curricula cannot include all major majors, so the results of this analysis can provide a useful basis for selecting the most suitable subjects. Criteria for including other majors may be the ability and enthusiasm of faculty and well thought out and academically sound teaching programs.

title: What's in a Setting?: Influence of Organizational Culture on Provider Adherence to Smoking Treatment Guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: Organizational culture is an important but underinvestigated feature of the work environment that can affect provider behavior, including adherence to clinical practice guidelines. There is substantial evidence that medical assistance to smokers can produce significant reductions in tobacco use. However, this evidence has not translated well into practice, as only a small proportion of smokers receive recommended treatment during medical visits. PURPOSE: This study examines organizational culture as a contextual feature of primary care clinics and its impact on adherence to evidence-based guidelines for tobacco use treatment. METHODOLOGY: Cross-sectional survey data from 500 primary care providers in 60 community clinics located in New York City were collected. Relationships between provider adherence to "5A" clinical guidelines, as recommended by the US Public Health Service, and both provider and organization covariates were described. We use hierarchical linear models to examine associations between clinical culture and provider treatment patterns. FINDINGS: Providers in clinics with stronger "group/clan," "hierarchical," and "rational" culture types, compared with a "developmental" culture, reported greater adherence to 5A guidelines (p < .05 ). System-level structures and care processes were positively associated (p < 0.01), while the number of ongoing quality initiatives was negatively associated with 5A delivery (p < 0.05). Provider familiarity with guidelines (p < 0.01), confidence with cessation counseling (p < 0.05), and perceived efficacy in helping smokers to quit were associated with a 5A intervention more frequent (p < 0.01). IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: Findings suggest that organizational culture may influence provider adherence to smoking cessation treatment guidelines, even when controlling for other factors known to affect practice patterns. Specifically, cultures that emphasize human resources and performance standards lead to the integration of the 5A guidelines into routine practice. Understanding the role of organizational culture allows managers and healthcare professionals to be strategic in implementing and also maintaining the use of evidence-based guidelines.

title: What's on YOUR Facebook profile? Evaluation of an educational intervention to promote the appropriate use of privacy settings by medical students on social networking sites
abstract: BACKGROUND: The rise of social media has given rise to growing concern about the potential implications of "unprofessional" postings by physicians and medical students on individuals, institutions, and the medical profession. Developing and enforcing relevant and effective guidelines has been difficult, and students and clinicians need to consider how their online activities may be perceived in the context of their professional roles. The purpose of this project was to examine the Internet presence of a Canadian medical school graduating class by scanning students' public profiles on the social networking site Facebook, incorporate this information into an educational activity that addresses professionalism and social networks, and evaluate the impact of this activity on the behavior of students. METHODS: A systematic search of the public Facebook profiles of each class member was conducted and data was collected on the types of publicly viewable material. These were presented as part of an educational session on social media and professionalism. A month later, the Facebook search was repeated. RESULTS: Of 152 students in the class, profiles were found for 121 (79.8%). Most students used appropriately restrictive privacy settings";" however, a significant minority had publicly viewable information, including comments, photos, location, and status as a medical student. Educational innovation was well received with over 90% of students agreeing that this topic was important and well addressed. A follow-up search found that many students had altered their privacy settings so that less information was publicly available. CONCLUSIONS: A small but significant proportion of students share potentially unprofessional content on social media. An interactive educational intervention, including targeted disclosure of how participants view others on social media, resulted in a significant change in student behavior.

title: When is it cost-effective to change the behavior of health professionals?
abstract: Because of how health care systems work, new, important, and cost-effective treatments sometimes fail to become routine care, while well-marketed products of equivocal value achieve widespread adoption. Should policymakers try to influence clinical behavior and correct these inefficiencies? The implementation methods achieve a certain level of behavior change, but they cost money to implement. These factors can be combined with the cost effectiveness of treatments to estimate the overall cost effectiveness of the policy. In general, the profitability of policies is always less attractive than the profitability of treatment. Consequently, trying to improve uptake of underused cost-effective care or reduce overuse of new and expensive treatments may not always make economic sense. In this article, we present a method for calculating the cost-effectiveness of policies and illustrate it with examples from a recent trial, conducted during 1997 and 1998, of educational outreach by community pharmacists to influence prescribing in England.

title: When pharmacotherapeutic recommendations can have the opposite effect on the doctor's decision making
abstract: For a long time, the medical literature has shown that patients do not always receive adequate care, including pharmacotherapeutic treatment. To achieve better patient care, a number of physician-oriented interventions are being implemented internationally in an attempt to implement evidence-based medicine in the routine daily practice of physicians. The pharmacy profession has assumed an active role in the implementation of intervention strategies aimed at promoting evidence-based prescription and improving the quality and safety of medication use. However, the medical literature also supports the idea that valid clinical recommendations do not always have the desired impact on medical behavior. We argue that the well-established theory of psychological reactance could explain, at least partially, the cases in which doctors do not act according to such recommendations. Reactance theory suggests that when a certain action is recommended, a motivational state compels us to react in a way that asserts our freedom of choice. Many times we choose to do the opposite of what the recommendation proposes we do or we simply entrench ourselves in our initial position. The basic concepts of psychological reactance are universal and probably applicable to the provision of recommendations to clinicians. Making recommendations about clinical care, including pharmacotherapy, may carry implicit threats, as it may be perceived as an attempt to restrict freedom of choice, potentially generating reactance and efforts to avoid it. By identifying and accounting for factors likely to promote reactance, clinician-oriented interventions might be more effective.

title: When the branch breaks: rethinking treatment strategies for perinatal depression
abstract: Awareness of depression among OB/GYN physicians has increased with the result that more than 13% of pregnant women in the United States are prescribed antidepressant medications. But the safety and efficacy of these compounds have been exaggerated, while the efficacy of psychotherapy has been overlooked and distorted, and various medical guidelines for the treatment of perinatal depression have been downplayed or ignored. This article addresses common fears and misconceptions surrounding the treatment of depression during pregnancy and after childbirth. The effectiveness of hypnosis-enhanced strategic cognitive behavioral therapy offers excellent results without the risks associated with these medications. The goals for the focused intervention are identified and discussed.

title: When to start dialysis: effect of proposed US guidelines on survival
abstract: Background Recent guidelines from the US National Kidney Foundation's Dialysis Outcomes Quality Initiative recommend earlier initiation of dialysis treatment than has been common practice. Its implementation would have a substantial effect on the daily life of patients and would increase costs. The guidelines are largely based on opinion, because evidence is still lacking.";" Background Recent guidelines from the US National Kidney Foundation's Dialysis Outcomes Quality Initiative recommend earlier initiation of dialysis treatment than has been common practice. Its implementation would have a substantial effect on the daily life of patients and would increase costs. The guidelines are largely based on opinion, because evidence is still lacking.

title: Where will John go? Newfoundland
Who wrote the Declaration of Helsinki?
Why don't clinicians accept the results of pivotal clinical trials in severe sepsis? A Bayesian analysis
abstract: BACKGROUND: Five pivotal clinical trials (Intensive Insulin Therapy"; Recombinant Human Activated Protein C [rhAPC]; Low Tidal Volume; Low-Dose Steroids; Early Goal-Directed Therapy [EGDT]) demonstrated reduced mortality in patients with sepsis and have been recommended for clinical practice by guidelines. However, adoption of these therapies remains low among clinicians. OBJECTIVES: We selected these five trials and asked: Question 1: What is the current probability that the new therapy is not better than the standard of in my patient with severe sepsis Question 2: What is the current probability of reducing the relative risk of death (RRR) of my patient with severe sepsis at clinically meaningful thresholds (RRR >15%; >20 % >25% METHODS: Bayesian methodologies were applied to this study, considering the odds ratio (OR) for question 1 and using RRR for question 2. previous nes (enthusiastic; 'mild, moderate and severe skeptical) based on various effective sample sizes from other relevant clinical trials (unfavorable evidence). Posterior distributions were calculated by combining the prior distributions and data from pivotal trials (favorable evidence). MAIN FINDINGS: Answer 1: Analysis based on slight prior skepticism shows beneficial results with the Intensive Insulin, rhAPC, and Low-Tidal Volume trials, but not with the Low-Dose Steroid and EGDT trials All trial results become unacceptable by analyzes using moderate or severe skeptical background Answer 2: If we aim for an RRR >15%, the moderate skeptical analysis shows that the current probability of reducing death by this clinical threshold is 88% for intensive insulin, 62 to 65% for the low tidal volume, rhAPC, EGDT trials and 17% for the low dose steroid trial. moderate and severe skeptics do not show a clinically significant reduction in the risk of death for all trials. If our goal is an RRR >20% or >25%, all chances of benefit are reduced regardless of the degree of skepticism. CONCLUSIONS: Our clinical threshold analysis offers a new bedside tool to be applied directly to the care of patients with severe sepsis. Our results demonstrate that the strength of the evidence (statistical and clinical) is weak for all trials, particularly for the low-dose steroid and EGDT trials. Replication of the results of each of these five clinical trials in confirmatory studies is critical if we are to provide scientifically sound evidence-based patient care.

title: Why do doctors treat their relatives? Exploring the influence of social psychology
abstract: Physicians often receive requests for treatment, medical advice, or other intervention from relatives. Most doctors comply. Reasons for compliance can be classified according to physicians' attitudes toward the family member, colleagues, themselves, ethical guidelines, and the problem. Compliance can also be influenced by elements of social psychology. Social exchange theory, techniques of persuasion, attribution, conformity, desire for approval, and the principle of affinity can induce intervention. Future research should explore clinicians' attitudes toward relatives, the means by which requests are made, treatment outcomes, changes in the relationship after treatment, cultural or family norms, and changes in beliefs or the behavior of physicians that occur when faced with conflicting requests and guidelines. Knowledge of these influences can help clinicians make objective decisions regarding intervention.

title: Why don't even good doctors wash their hands?
Why are there no guidelines for behavior modification?
abstract: This document reviews the guidelines for behavioral programs published by the National Association for Retarded Children. The review discusses a number of reasons why behavior modification guidelines should not be enunciated, for example, behavior modification procedures appear to be no more or less subject to abuse and need no more or less ethical regulation than intervention procedures derived from any other set of principles and called by other terms. The review recommends alternative methods to protect the rights of clients participating in behavioral programs. Specifically, behavioral doctors, like other therapists, must abide by the codes of ethics of their professions";" Furthermore, the ethics of all intervention programs must be evaluated in terms of a number of critical questions.

title: Why Providers Transfuse Blood Products Outside of Recommended Guidelines Despite Built-In Electronic Best Practice Alerts
abstract: BACKGROUND: Best practice alerts (BPAs) provide clinical decision support (CDS) at the point of care to reduce unnecessary transfusions of blood products, although substantial transfusions continue to fall outside recommended guidelines. OBJECTIVE: To understand why providers request blood transfusions outside of recommended guidelines despite interrupted alerts. DESIGN: Retrospective review. SETTING: Third level hospital. PARTICIPANTS: Inpatient healthcare providers. INTERVENTION: Provider-BPA interaction data were collected from January 2011 to August 2012 from the hospital's electronic medical record. MEASUREMENTS: Provider responses (free text) to BPA indications for blood transfusion were independently reviewed and categorized by 2 licensed clinicians, and agreement was assessed by chi(2) analysis and kappa score. RESULTS: The justification for canceling BPA for blood transfusion was very diverse, with acute bleeding being the most common (> 34%), followed by protocolized behaviors in specialized services (up to 26%), up to "symptomatic" anemia (11%). -12%). Many providers transfused in anticipation of a surgical or procedural intervention (10%-15%) or imminent hospital discharge (2%-5%). Resident physicians represented the majority (55%) of providers interacting with BPAs. CONCLUSION: Providers who interact with BPAs (mainly residents and mid-tier providers) often do not have the bargaining power to change ordering behavior. Protocolized behaviors, which are unlikely to be influenced by BPAs, are among the most cited reasons for transfusing outside the guidelines. Symptomatic anemia is a common, albeit subjective, indication cited for blood transfusion. With a wide range of individually uncommon rationales for transfusion behavior, secondary use of electronic medical record databases and integrated CDS tools are important to efficiently analyze common practice behaviors.

title: Why we still perform arthroscopy in knee osteoarthritis: a multi-method study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Historically, knee arthroscopy has been a common treatment for knee osteoarthritis. However, multiple randomized controlled trials in conjunction with a Cochrane review have led NICE to recommend that arthroscopy not be used in the vast majority of patients with knee osteoarthritis. These recommendations have been replicated internationally. The use of arthroscopy for osteoarthritis of the knee has decreased";" however, it is still prevalent. This study examines factors perceived to influence decision making using a theoretical framework that was developed for behavior change research (Theoretical Domains Framework). This study will allow future work to develop and evaluate an intervention specifically targeting the identified barriers. METHODS: A multimodal approach involving questionnaire research and semi-structured interviews was used with all grades of clinicians providing a knee arthroscopy service at a Level One Trauma Center in the West Midlands, UK. Focus groups with patients were also conducted. Mixed methods analysis was used, with descriptive statistics for quantitative data and thematic content analysis for qualitative data. RESULTS: A total of 26 surgeons responded to the questionnaires, carrying out 6 semi-structured interviews. All surgical grades were represented. Two focus groups of six patients were conducted. The results identified 13 beliefs in 12 domains (some beliefs were represented in all domains). Beliefs that there was pressure from patients to do something, that there were limited other options available, that surgeons wanted to meet patients' expectations, and that there was time pressure in the clinic seemed to be the predominant barriers. CONCLUSIONS: Using the Theoretical Domains Framework, this paper has described the relevant barriers and facilitators to the implementation of the NICE guideline regarding the use of arthroscopy in patients with knee osteoarthritis. The next step in this process is the development of a targeted intervention, and we discuss the barriers that are most likely to disrupt practice if targeted through an intervention, and what such an intervention might look like. Such intervention would require evaluation within the clinical setting.

title: Why don't women ask for information on preconception health? A qualitative study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Preconception care involves health promotion to reduce risk factors that can affect women and couples of childbearing age. Risk factors for adverse reproductive outcomes include recognized genetic disease in the family or the individual, prior congenital disease, miscarriage, prematurity, fetal growth restriction, infertility, chronic maternal disease, lifestyle, and environmental or occupational factors. Effective preconception care involves a variety of preventive, therapeutic, and behavioral interventions. Although there are national preconception care recommendations for the general population in Italy, they are generally promoted informally and only for single risk factors. There is currently a growing interest in offering a global intervention in this field. The aim of this study was to investigate the attitudes and behaviors of Italian women of childbearing age and health professionals regarding preconception health. METHODS: We conducted a qualitative study among women of childbearing age and health professionals between February 2014 and February 2015. Five focus groups were conducted: 2 with non-pregnant women aged 22 to 44 years and 3 with health professionals. Discussion topics included women's questions about preconception health, concerns and barriers regarding preconception care interventions, attitudes and behaviors of women and health professionals towards preconception health. conception, sources of information for women. In the analysis of the focus groups, what was said by the women was prioritized, complemented with information from the focus groups of health professionals. RESULTS: Fourteen women of childbearing age (8 nulliparous and 6 multiparous) and 12 health professionals (3 nurses, 4 midwives, 5 physicians) participated in the focus groups. The results indicate the presence of many barriers and a lack of awareness of preconception health in relation to women, health professionals and policies. Women's knowledge and attitudes toward preconception primary care information are described. The main source of reference information in this field for Italian women seems to be their obstetrician-gynaecologist. CONCLUSIONS: The study indicates that several barriers influence preconception care in Italy.
