In addition, a lack of awareness about preconception health and care emerges among Italian women of childbearing age and health professionals. The findings could contribute to strategies for the implementation of preconception care guidelines.

title: WIC Provider Perspectives on Offering Smoking Cessation Interventions
abstract: PURPOSE: To examine WIC clinic providers' perspectives on the offering of smoking cessation interventions for pregnant women. STUDY DESIGN AND METHODS: Four focus groups comprised of WIC nurses, dieticians, and social workers (N = 25) were conducted at WIC clinics in eastern Iowa. Researchers developed discussion guidelines to determine how WIC providers were currently approaching pregnant women who smoke cigarettes and what barriers they considered to providing effective smoking cessation interventions. Code mapping was used to analyze the focus group discussions. RESULTS: Factors that influenced the ability of WIC staff to provide a smoking cessation intervention to pregnant women included available time, clinic priorities, staff approaches to clients, and staff training. In addition, providers expressed concerns about educational materials for clients, as well as other client issues that prevented smoking cessation. The absence of mechanisms to track clinical outcomes related to smoking cessation was also noted. CLINICAL IMPLICATIONS: WIC providers have time constraints that may require minimal or low-intensity smoking cessation interventions, but were not aware that such approaches are truly effective. WIC providers require more education on the whole topic of smoking cessation in order to be more proactive in their attempts to help pregnant women quit. Training that improves self-efficacy and understanding of the impact of smoking on mothers, infants, and children should be initiated to motivate staff to intervene. Another strategy to motivate WIC staff in this regard could be to follow up on clinic results to help women quit or prevent relapse.

title: Will mothers of sick children help their husbands quit smoking after receiving a brief intervention from nurses? Secondary analysis of a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Secondhand smoke is a serious health hazard to children. Clinical guidelines suggest that nurses advise smoking parents to stop smoking when accompanying their sick children to pediatric settings, but the guidelines did not mention what nurses can do if parents are not with their children. This study examines the effectiveness of a nurse-led, low-intensity health education initiative for nonsmoking mothers in motivating them to take action to help their husbands quit smoking. METHODS: This was a randomized controlled trial and 1483 non-smoking women, living with smoking husbands, were recruited when accompanying their sick children on hospital admission in general pediatric wards/outpatient departments of four hospitals in Hong Kong. The women were randomly assigned to intervention and control groups. The first received a brief health education advice from the nurses, a specially designed health education booklet, a "no smoking" sticker, and a telephone reminder a week later";" the control group received usual care. The primary outcome was women's action in helping their smoking husbands quit smoking at 3-, 6-, and 12-month follow-ups. RESULTS: A higher proportion of women in the intervention than in the control group had taken steps to help their husbands quit smoking. husbands quit smoking at 3 months (76% vs. 65%, p < 0.001), at 6 months (66% vs. 49%, p < 0.001), and at 12 months (52% vs. 40%, P < 0.001) Women who had received the intervention had a better knowledge of the health risks of smoking, a greater intention to take action, perceived their husbands' willingness to quit/reduce smoking, had previously advised their husbands that they quit smoking. had quit smoking, knew their husbands' smoking history, and knew that their husbands had tried to quit before and intended to help them quit at follow-up. CONCLUSIONS: A brief health education intervention delivered by nurses in pediatric settings can be effective in motivating mothers of sick children to take steps to help their husbands quit smoking. recommend adding the following to clinical practice guidelines on the treatment of tobacco dependence and dependence: 'Nurses should offer all non-smoking mothers of a sick child brief advice to encourage their husbands to quit smoking'. TESTING RECORD: Current Controlled Testing ISRCTN72290421.

title: Words matter: increasing implementation of clinical guidelines.
abstract: Objectives: To determine whether writing guideline recommendations in behavior-specific 'plain English' language increases the likelihood that service users (patients) will implement them. Design: Randomized controlled trial in which participants received either the original text of the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (NICE) public guidelines for the treatment of schizophrenia or a behaviorally specified text with the same content. Setting: Networks of mental health service users and voluntary sector organizations within two inner London boroughs. Participants: Eighty-four mental health service users recruited by mail or face-to-face contact at service user meetings. Intervention: The section of the NICE public guidelines for schizophrenia relating to psychological and pharmacological treatments was rewritten to improve behavioral style and specificity by applying evidence-based and psychologically informed principles of good written communication. Outcome measures: Cognitive predictors of behaviour, as specified by evidence-based theory of planned behaviour, constituted the primary outcome as it was not possible to measure actual behavior from guideline implementation. Predictors were behavioral intentions to implement the guidelines, attitudes toward implementation, and perceived behavioral control over implementation. Satisfaction with the guidelines and perceived understanding were also measured. Results: Specified "plain language" cues in behavior led to stronger intentions to implement the cues, more positive attitudes toward them, and greater perceived behavioral control over their use. There was no difference in perceived satisfaction or understanding. Conclusions: Writing guidelines with high behavioral specificity along with the use of "plain language" can be a simple and effective method to increase their implementation. An assessment with a behavioral outcome is now needed.

title: Working to improve hospital hyperglycemia care through statewide collaboration: the Georgia Hospital Association Diabetes Special Interest Group
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To review the efforts of the Georgia Hospital Association Diabetes Special Interest Group (DSIG) to develop and disseminate sample clinical guidelines on the management of hyperglycemia in hospitalized patients. METHODS: Beginning in February 2003, a consortium of physicians and allied health professionals from across the state of Georgia began meeting frequently to develop a plan to improve care for hospitalized patients with hyperglycemia. The immediate goals of the DSIG were the identification and organization of stakeholders, the development of consensus sample clinical guidelines, and the dissemination of information. RESULTS: Since its inception, DSIG has accomplished the following: development of 7 consensus sample clinical guidelines, construction of a website that publishes these clinical guidelines and other useful related information and educational materials, and sponsorship of workshops statewide. Georgia. CONCLUSION: As the importance of glucose monitoring in the hospital setting is increasingly recognized, institutions must find ways to apply the results of clinical trials to "real world" hospital settings. The DSIG is an example of a successful collaboration that could serve as a model for other state hospital organizations that wish to develop programs to improve care for hospitalized patients with hyperglycemia.

title: The World Medical Association adopts declarations, etc., on various matters
Declaration of the World Medical Association of Helsinki. Recommendations that guide clinicians in biomedical research involving human beings
Xenotransplantation: proceed with caution
Yoga for chronic low back pain: a randomized trial.
abstract: Background: Previous studies indicate that yoga may be an effective treatment for chronic or recurrent low back pain. Objective: To compare the effectiveness of yoga and usual care for chronic or recurrent low back pain. Design: Parallel-group randomized controlled trial using computer-generated randomization conducted between April 2007 and March 2010. Results were assessed using a postal questionnaire. (International Standard Randomized Controlled Trial Registration Number: ISRCTN 81079604) Setting: 13 non-UK NHS facilities. Patients: 313 adults with chronic or recurrent low back pain. Intervention: Yoga (n = 156) or usual care (n = 157). All participants received an educational brochure on back pain. The intervention group was offered a 12-class graded-progress yoga program taught by 12 teachers for 3 months. Measurements: Roland'CMorris Disability Questionnaire (RMDQ) scores at 3 (primary outcomes), 6, and 12 (secondary outcomes) months"; pain, pain self-efficacy, and general health measures at 3, 6, and 12 months (secondary outcomes). Results: 93 (60%) patients offered yoga attended at least 3 of the first 6 sessions and at least 3 other sessions. The yoga group had better back function at 3, 6, and 12 months than usual care Adjusted mean RMDQ score was 2.17 points (95% CI, 1.03 to 3.31 points) lower in the yoga group at 3 months, 1 .48 points (CI, 0.33 to 2.62 points) lower at 6 months and 1.57 points (CI, 0.42 to 2.71 points) lower at 12 months.The yoga and mindfulness groups group had similar back pain and general health scores at 3, 6, and 12 months, and the yoga group had higher pain self-efficacy scores at 3 and 6 months, but not at 12 months. of 157 usual care participants and 12 of 156 yoga participants reported adverse events, mostly increased pain. Information: Data were missing for the primary outcome (yoga group, n = 21; usual care group, n = 18) and differential data (more in the yoga group) were missing for secondary outcomes. Conclusion: Offering a 12-week yoga program to adults with chronic or recurrent low back pain produced greater improvements in back function than usual care.

title: Young people receiving orthodontic care are not immune to poor diet and being overweight: A call for dental providers to participate in prevention efforts
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Although obesity is common in the US, disparities exist. Orthodontic samples are assumed to be wealthier than the general population and not in need of assistance in developing or maintaining healthy lifestyles. This document assesses the need for intervention in the orthodontic population by examining the diet and weight status of a sample of orthodontic patients and describes the role of dentists in obesity prevention efforts. METHODS: 552 patients ages 8 to 14 years, 54% female, 51% non-Hispanic white, 26% Hispanic, were recruited from orthodontic practices in Southern California to participate in a randomized controlled trial of health promotion provided by a doctor. Height, weight, demographics, and diet were recorded. Chi-square analyzes were used to test for baseline differences by gender, age, ethnicity, and income. RESULTS: 13% of the sample were overweight and 9% obese. Men had a higher rate of obesity than women. Lower-income youth had a higher rate than higher-income youth. Hispanic youth had a higher rate than non-Hispanic white youth. Non-compliance with national dietary guidelines was common, differing significantly by demographic group. CONCLUSIONS: Within a sample not normally considered to be in need of assistance, nearly 25% were overweight or obese, and the majority did not meet dietary recommendations. While most patients could benefit from the intervention, male, Hispanic, and low-income groups were in greater need of assistance. Dental providers, who frequently see young people and already discuss nutrition in the context of oral health, have an opportunity to contribute to obesity prevention.

title: Systematic Review of the Scope of the Choice Architecture Movement: Toward Understanding When and Why Nudges Work
abstract: In this paper, we provide a comprehensive review of the nudge movement domain by reviewing 422 choice architecture interventions in 156 empirical studies. We report the distribution of studies across countries, years, domains, applicability subdomains, intervention types, and moderators associated with each intervention category to review the current state of the nudge movement. In addition, we highlight certain characteristics of experimental and reporting studies and practices that can make it difficult to accumulate evidence in the field. Specifically, we found that 74% of studies were primarily motivated to assess the effectiveness of interventions in a specific setting, while only 24% of studies focused on exploring moderators or underlying processes. We also noted that only 7% of studies applied power analyses, 2% used guidelines to improve reporting quality, no studies in our database were pre-registered, and the intervention nomenclatures used were not exhaustive, and They often had overlapping categories. Based on our current observations and proposed solutions from other fields, we provide directly applicable recommendations for future research to support the accumulation of evidence on why and when nudges work.
